press Ctrl+slash\n ‌\nKindly‌ ‌refer‌ ‌to‌ ‌both‌ ‌the‌‌ ‌Videos‌ ‌and‌ ‌Lecture‌ ‌Notes‌‌ ‌for‌ ‌exhaustive‌ ‌coverage‌ ‌and‌ ‌making‌ ‌notes.‌ ‌ ‌\nSection‌ ‌‌2.5‌ ‌‌onwards‌‌ ‌Value‌ ‌Additions‌ ‌and‌ ‌Case‌ ‌Studies‌ ‌will‌ ‌be‌ ‌covered‌ ‌in‌ ‌Video‌ ‌ONLY‌ ‌&‌ ‌Lecture‌ ‌NOTES‌‌ ‌will‌ ‌cover‌ ‌the‌ ‌standard‌ ‌portion‌ ‌of‌ ‌syllabus.‌ ‌\n ‌\nSUPPORT‌‌ ‌the‌ ‌channel,‌ ‌by‌ ‌being‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌‌ ‌‌GIFT‌ ‌ECONOMY‌,‌ ‌Check‌ ‌out‌ ‌the‌ ‌link‌ ‌for‌ ‌details:‌ ‌‌https://rzp.io/l/ylaMNVFb‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nTable‌ ‌of‌ ‌Content‌ ‌\n ‌\n1.1‌ ‌Meaning,‌ ‌scope‌ ‌and‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌\n1.2‌ ‌Relationships‌ ‌with‌ ‌other‌ ‌disciplines‌ ‌\n1.3‌ ‌Main‌ ‌branches‌ ‌of‌ ‌Anthropology,‌ ‌their‌ ‌scope‌ ‌and‌ ‌relevance‌ ‌\n1.4‌ ‌(a)‌ ‌Human‌ ‌Evolution‌ ‌and‌ ‌Emergence‌ ‌of‌ ‌Man‌ ‌\n1.4‌ ‌(b)‌ ‌Human‌ ‌Evolution‌ ‌and‌ ‌Emergence‌ ‌of‌ ‌Man‌ ‌\n1.4‌ ‌(c)‌ ‌Synthetic‌ ‌Theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌Evolution;‌ ‌Part-I‌ ‌\n1.4‌ ‌(c)‌ ‌Brief‌ ‌outline‌ ‌of‌ ‌terms‌ ‌and‌ ‌concepts‌ ‌of‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌biology‌ ‌(Dollo’s‌ ‌rule,‌ ‌Cope’s‌ ‌rule,‌ ‌Gause’s‌ ‌rule,‌ ‌parallelism,‌ ‌convergence,‌ ‌\nadaptive‌ ‌radiation,‌ ‌and‌ ‌mosaic‌ ‌evolution)‌ ‌Part-II‌ ‌\n1.5‌ ‌Characteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌Primates;‌ ‌Evolutionary‌ ‌Trend‌ ‌and‌ ‌Primate‌ ‌Taxonomy;-Part‌ ‌I‌ ‌\n1.5‌ ‌Primate‌ ‌Adaptations;‌ ‌(Arboreal‌ ‌and‌ ‌Terrestrial)‌ ‌Primate‌ ‌Taxonomy;-Part‌ ‌II‌ ‌\n1.5‌ ‌Primate‌ ‌Behaviour;‌ ‌Tertiary‌ ‌and‌ ‌Quaternary‌ ‌fossil‌ ‌primates;‌ ‌Living‌ ‌Major‌ ‌Primates;‌ ‌Part-III‌ ‌\n1.5‌ ‌Living‌ ‌Major‌ ‌Primates;‌ ‌Part‌ ‌IV‌ ‌\n1.5‌ ‌Comparative‌ ‌Anatomy‌ ‌of‌ ‌Man‌ ‌and‌ ‌Apes;‌ ‌Skeletal‌ ‌changes‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌erect‌ ‌posture‌ ‌and‌ ‌its‌ ‌implications.-‌ ‌Part‌ ‌V‌ ‌\n1.6‌ ‌Phylogenetic‌ ‌status,‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌and‌ ‌geographical‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌following‌ ‌:‌ ‌\n(a)‌ ‌Plio-pleistocene‌ ‌hominids‌ ‌in‌ ‌South‌ ‌and‌ ‌East‌ ‌Africa—Australopithecines.-‌ ‌Part‌ ‌I‌ ‌\n1.6‌ ‌Phylogenetic‌ ‌status,‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌and‌ ‌geographical‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌following‌ ‌:‌ ‌\n(b)‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌(Paranthropus)-Part‌ ‌II‌ ‌\n ‌\n1.6‌ ‌Phylogenetic‌ ‌status,‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌and‌ ‌geographical‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌following‌ ‌:‌ ‌\n(b)‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌:‌ ‌Europe‌ ‌(Homo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌(heidelbergensis),‌ ‌Asia‌ ‌(Homoerectus‌ ‌javanicus,‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌pekinensis.-‌ ‌Part‌ ‌III‌ ‌\n1.6‌ ‌Phylogenetic‌ ‌status,‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌and‌ ‌geographical‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌following‌ ‌:‌ ‌\n ‌(c)‌ ‌Neanderthal‌ ‌man-‌ ‌La-chapelle-aux-saints‌ ‌(Classical‌ ‌type),‌ ‌Mt.‌ ‌Carmel‌ ‌(Progressive‌ ‌type)‌ ‌\n ‌(d)‌ ‌Rhodesian‌ ‌man‌ ‌\n ‌(e)‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌sapiens—Cromagnon,‌ ‌Grimaldi‌ ‌and‌ ‌Chancelade-Part-IV‌ ‌\n1.8‌ ‌(a)‌ ‌Principles‌ ‌of‌ ‌Prehistoric‌ ‌Archaeology.‌ ‌Chronology‌ ‌:‌ ‌Relative‌ ‌and‌ ‌Absolute‌ ‌Dating‌ ‌methods‌ ‌Part-I‌ ‌\n1.8‌ ‌(b)‌ ‌Cultural‌ ‌Evolution—Broad‌ ‌Outlines‌ ‌of‌ ‌Prehistoric‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌:‌ ‌Paleolithic,‌ ‌Mesolithic,‌ ‌Neolithic,‌ ‌Chalcolithic,‌ ‌Copper-Bronze‌ ‌Age,‌ ‌\nIron‌ ‌Age-‌ ‌Part-II‌ ‌\n1.8‌ ‌(b)‌ ‌Cultural‌ ‌Evolution—Broad‌ ‌Outlines‌ ‌of‌ ‌Prehistoric‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌:‌ ‌Paleolithic,‌ ‌Mesolithic,‌ ‌Neolithic,‌ ‌Chalcolithic,‌ ‌Copper-Bronze‌ ‌Age,‌ ‌\nIron‌ ‌Age-‌ ‌Part-III‌ ‌\n2.1‌ ‌The‌ ‌Nature‌ ‌of‌ ‌Culture‌ ‌:‌ ‌The‌ ‌Concept‌ ‌and‌ ‌Characteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌civilization;‌ ‌Ethnocentrism‌ ‌vis-a-vis‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌Relativism‌ ‌\n2.2‌ ‌The‌ ‌Nature‌ ‌of‌ ‌Society‌ ‌:‌ ‌Concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌Society;‌ ‌Society‌ ‌and‌ ‌Culture;‌ ‌Social‌ ‌Institution;‌ ‌Social‌ ‌groups;-Part-I‌ ‌\n2.2‌ ‌The‌ ‌Nature‌ ‌of‌ ‌Society‌ ‌:‌ ‌Social‌ ‌stratification-Part-II‌ ‌\n2.3‌ ‌Marriage‌ ‌:‌ ‌Definition‌ ‌and‌ ‌universality‌ ‌\n ‌Laws‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌(endogamy,‌ ‌exogamy,‌ ‌hypergamy,‌ ‌hypogamy,‌ ‌incest‌ ‌taboo);‌ ‌\n ‌Type‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌(monogamy,‌ ‌polygamy,‌ ‌polyandry,‌ ‌group‌ ‌marriage).‌ ‌\n ‌Functions‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage;‌ ‌\n ‌Marriage‌ ‌regulations‌ ‌(preferential,‌ ‌prescriptive‌ ‌and‌ ‌proscriptive)‌ ‌\n ‌Marriage‌ ‌payments‌ ‌(bride‌ ‌wealth‌ ‌and‌ ‌dowry)‌ ‌\n2.4‌ ‌Family‌ ‌:‌ ‌Definition‌ ‌and‌ ‌Universality;‌ ‌Family,‌ ‌household‌ ‌and‌ ‌Domestic‌ ‌groups;‌ ‌Functions‌ ‌of‌ ‌family;-Part-I‌ ‌\n2.4‌ ‌Types‌ ‌of‌ ‌family‌ ‌(from‌ ‌the‌ ‌perspectives‌ ‌of‌ ‌structure,‌ ‌blood‌ ‌relation,‌ ‌marriage,‌ ‌residence‌ ‌and‌ ‌succession);‌ ‌Impact‌ ‌of‌ ‌urbanization,‌ ‌\nindustrialization‌ ‌and‌ ‌feminist‌ ‌movements‌ ‌on‌ ‌family-Part-II‌ ‌\n2.5‌ ‌Kinship‌ ‌:‌ ‌Consanguinity‌ ‌and‌ ‌Affinity;‌ ‌Principles‌ ‌and‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌descent‌ ‌(Unilineal,‌ ‌Double,‌ ‌Bilateral‌ ‌Ambilineal);‌ ‌Forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌descent‌ ‌\ngroups‌ ‌(lineage,‌ ‌clan,‌ ‌phratry,‌ ‌moiety‌ ‌and‌ ‌kindred);‌ ‌-Part-I‌ ‌\n2.5‌ ‌Kinship‌ ‌terminology‌ ‌(descriptive‌ ‌and‌ ‌classificatory);‌ ‌Descent,‌ ‌Filiation‌ ‌and‌ ‌Complementary‌ ‌Filiation;Descent‌ ‌and‌ ‌Alliance-Part-II‌ ‌\n2.5‌ ‌Filiation‌ ‌and‌ ‌Complementary‌ ‌Filiation;‌ ‌Descent‌ ‌and‌ ‌Alliance-‌ ‌Part-III‌ ‌\n3.‌ ‌Economic‌ ‌Organization:Meaning,‌ ‌scope‌ ‌and‌ ‌relevance‌ ‌of‌ ‌economic‌ ‌anthropology;‌ ‌Formalist‌ ‌and‌ ‌Substantivist‌ ‌debate;‌ ‌Part-I‌ ‌\n2‌ ‌\n3.Economic‌ ‌Organization:Principles‌ ‌governing‌ ‌production,‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌and‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌(reciprocity,‌ ‌redistribution‌ ‌and‌ ‌market),‌ ‌in‌ ‌\ncommunities,‌ ‌subsisting‌ ‌on‌ ‌hunting‌ ‌and‌ ‌gathering,‌ ‌fishing,‌ ‌swiddening,‌ ‌pastoralism,‌ ‌horticulture,‌ ‌and‌ ‌agriculture;‌ ‌Globalization‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nindigenous‌ ‌economic‌ ‌systems-Part-II‌ ‌\n4.‌ ‌Political‌ ‌Organization:‌ ‌Band,‌ ‌tribe,‌ ‌chiefdom,‌ ‌kingdom‌ ‌and‌ ‌State;-‌ ‌Part-I‌ ‌\n4.Political‌ ‌Organization‌ ‌and‌ ‌Social‌ ‌Control‌ ‌:‌ ‌Band,‌ ‌tribe,‌ ‌chiefdom,‌ ‌kingdom‌ ‌and‌ ‌State;‌ ‌Concepts‌ ‌of‌ ‌power,‌ ‌authority‌ ‌and‌ ‌legitimacy;‌ ‌\nSocial‌ ‌control,‌ ‌law‌ ‌and‌ ‌justice‌ ‌in‌ ‌simple‌ ‌Societies-Part‌ ‌II‌ ‌\n5.Religion:Anthropological‌ ‌approaches‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion‌ ‌(evolutionary,‌ ‌psychological‌ ‌and‌ ‌functional);‌ ‌Monotheism‌ ‌and‌ ‌polytheism;‌ ‌\nSacred‌ ‌and‌ ‌profane;‌ ‌-Part-I‌ ‌\n5.‌ ‌Myths‌ ‌and‌ ‌rituals;Forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion‌ ‌in‌ ‌tribal‌ ‌and‌ ‌peasant‌ ‌Societies‌ ‌(animism,‌ ‌animatism,‌ ‌fetishism,‌ ‌naturism‌ ‌and‌ ‌totemism);‌ ‌Religion,‌ ‌\nmagic‌ ‌and‌ ‌science‌ ‌distinguished;‌ ‌Magico-religious‌ ‌functionaries‌ ‌(priest,‌ ‌shaman,‌ ‌medicine‌ ‌man,‌ ‌sorcerer‌ ‌and‌ ‌witch)-Part-II‌ ‌\n6.‌ ‌Anthropological‌ ‌theories‌ ‌:‌ ‌(a)‌ ‌Classical‌ ‌evolutionism‌ ‌(Tylor,‌ ‌Morgan‌ ‌and‌ ‌Frazer),‌ ‌(f)‌ ‌Neo-evolutionism‌ ‌(Childe,‌ ‌White,‌ ‌Steward,‌ ‌Sahlins‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌Service)-Part-I‌ ‌\n6.‌ ‌Anthropological‌ ‌theories‌ ‌:‌ ‌(b)‌ ‌Historical‌ ‌particularism‌ ‌(Boas)‌ ‌Diffusionism‌ ‌(British,‌ ‌German‌ ‌and‌ ‌American)-Part-II‌ ‌\n6.‌ ‌Anthropological‌ ‌theories:(c)‌ ‌Functionalism‌ ‌(Malinowski);‌ ‌Structural—Functionalism‌ ‌(Radcliffe-Brown),‌ ‌(d)‌ ‌Structuralism‌ ‌(L’evi-Strauss‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌E.‌ ‌Leach)-Part-III‌ ‌\n6.‌ ‌Anthropological‌ ‌theories‌ ‌:‌ ‌(e)‌ ‌Culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌personality‌ ‌(Benedict,‌ ‌Mead,‌ ‌Linton,‌ ‌Kardiner‌ ‌and‌ ‌Cora-du‌ ‌Bois)‌ ‌(g)‌ ‌Cultural‌ ‌materialism‌ ‌\n(Harris)-Part-IV‌ ‌\n6.‌ ‌Anthropological‌ ‌theories:(h)‌ ‌Symbolic‌ ‌and‌ ‌interpretive‌ ‌theories‌ ‌(Turner,‌ ‌Schneider‌ ‌and‌ ‌Geertz),‌ ‌(i)‌ ‌Cognitive‌ ‌theories‌ ‌(Tyler,‌ ‌Conklin),‌ ‌\n(j)‌ ‌Postmodernism‌ ‌in‌ ‌anthropology-Part-V‌ ‌\n7.‌ ‌Culture,‌ ‌Language‌ ‌and‌ ‌Communication‌ ‌:‌ ‌Nature,‌ ‌origin‌ ‌and‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌language;‌ ‌verbal‌ ‌and‌ ‌non-verbal‌ ‌communication;‌ ‌social‌ ‌\ncontext‌ ‌of‌ ‌language‌ ‌use-Part-I‌ ‌\n7.‌ ‌Culture,‌ ‌Language‌ ‌and‌ ‌Communication‌ ‌:‌ ‌Nature,‌ ‌origin‌ ‌and‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌language;‌ ‌verbal‌ ‌and‌ ‌non-verbal‌ ‌communication;‌ ‌social‌ ‌\ncontext‌ ‌of‌ ‌language‌ ‌use-Part-II‌ ‌\n9.1‌ ‌Human‌ ‌Genetics‌ ‌:‌ ‌Methods‌ ‌and‌ ‌Application:‌ ‌Part-I‌ ‌ ‌\na)‌ ‌Methods‌ ‌for‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌principles‌ ‌in‌ ‌man-family‌ ‌study‌ ‌\ni.‌ ‌Pedigree‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌\nii.Twin‌ ‌study‌ ‌\niii.‌ ‌Foster‌ ‌child‌ ‌\n3‌ ‌\n9.1‌ ‌Human‌ ‌Genetics‌ ‌:‌ ‌Methods‌ ‌and‌ ‌Application:‌ ‌-Part-II‌ ‌ ‌\na)‌ ‌Methods‌ ‌for‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌principles‌ ‌in‌ ‌man-family‌ ‌study‌ ‌\niv.‌ ‌Co-twin‌ ‌method‌ ‌\nv.‌ ‌Cytogenetic‌ ‌method‌ ‌\nvi.‌ ‌Chromosomal‌ ‌and‌ ‌karyo-type‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌\nb)‌ ‌Biochemical‌ ‌methods‌ ‌\nc)‌ ‌Immunological‌ ‌methods‌ ‌\nd)‌ ‌D.N.A.‌ ‌technology‌ ‌&‌ ‌Recombinant‌ ‌technologies‌ ‌\n9.2‌ ‌Mendelian‌ ‌genetics‌ ‌in‌ ‌man-family‌ ‌study,‌ ‌single‌ ‌factor,‌ ‌multifactor,‌ ‌lethal,‌ ‌sub-lethal‌ ‌and‌ ‌polygenic‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌in‌ ‌man-Part-I‌ ‌\n9.2‌ ‌Single‌ ‌factor,‌ ‌multifactor,‌ ‌lethal,‌ ‌sub-lethal‌ ‌and‌ ‌polygenic‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌in‌ ‌man‌ ‌Part-II‌ ‌\n9.3‌ ‌Concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌polymorphism‌ ‌and‌ ‌selection,‌ ‌Mendelian‌ ‌population,‌ ‌Hardy-Weinberg‌ ‌law;‌ ‌Part-I‌ ‌\n9.3‌ ‌Causes‌ ‌and‌ ‌changes‌ ‌which‌ ‌bring‌ ‌down‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌–‌ ‌mutation,‌ ‌isolation,‌ ‌migration,‌ ‌Selection,‌ ‌inbreeding‌ ‌&‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌drift‌ ‌Part-II‌ ‌\n9.3‌ ‌Consanguineous‌ ‌and‌ ‌non-consanguineous‌ ‌mating,‌ ‌Genetic‌ ‌load,‌ ‌Genetic‌ ‌effect‌ ‌of‌ ‌consanguineous‌ ‌and‌ ‌cousin‌ ‌mating-‌ ‌Part-III‌ ‌\n9.4‌ ‌Chromosomes‌ ‌and‌ ‌chromosomal‌ ‌aberrations‌ ‌in‌ ‌man‌ ‌methodology-Part‌ ‌I‌ ‌\n(a)‌ ‌Numerical‌ ‌and‌ ‌structural‌ ‌aberrations‌ ‌(disorders).‌ ‌\n(b)‌ ‌Sex‌ ‌chromosomal‌ ‌aberration-‌ ‌Klinefelter‌ ‌(XXY),‌ ‌Turner‌ ‌(XO),‌ ‌Super‌ ‌female‌ ‌(XXX),‌ ‌intersex‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌syndromic‌ ‌disorders.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n4‌ ‌\n ‌\n1.1‌ ‌Meaning,‌ ‌scope‌ ‌and‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌Anthropology:‌   ‌ ‌\n ‌\nMeaning:‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌origin,‌ ‌development‌ ‌and‌ ‌nature‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌human‌ ‌species‌ ‌etymologically‌ ‌the‌ ‌word‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌is‌ ‌derived‌ ‌\nfrom‌ ‌two‌ ‌Greek‌ ‌words‌ ‌‘Anthropos’‌ ‌means‌ ‌‘human’‌ ‌and‌ ‌‘logos’‌ ‌means‌ ‌study‌ ‌or‌ ‌Science.‌ ‌Thus,‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌understood‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nscience‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌beings‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌humanity.‌ ‌\n ‌\nAs‌ ‌a‌ ‌matter‌ ‌of‌ ‌fact‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌comparative‌ ‌and‌ ‌integrated‌ ‌discipline‌ ‌that‌ ‌examines‌ ‌all‌ ‌societies‌ ‌and‌ ‌fields‌ ‌and‌ ‌models‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌simple‌ ‌and‌ ‌\ncomplex.‌ ‌This‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌considered‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌Holistic‌ ‌Science‌ ‌as‌ ‌it‌ ‌also‌ ‌studies‌ ‌the‌ ‌whole‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌condition‌ ‌past‌ ‌present‌ ‌and‌ ‌future‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌Biology‌ ‌\nsociety‌ ‌language‌ ‌and‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\n ‌\nSome‌ ‌popular‌ ‌definitions‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌As‌ ‌given‌ ‌by‌ ‌some‌ ‌renowned‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌\n ‌\nAristotle:‌ ‌‌He‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌Greek‌ ‌philosopher‌ ‌and‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌‘father’‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropology.‌ ‌ ‌\nHe‌ ‌is‌ ‌considered‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌anthropologist‌ ‌who‌ ‌coined,‌ ‌defined‌ ‌and‌ ‌explained‌ ‌the‌ ‌term‌ ‌anthropology.‌ ‌ ‌\nHe‌ ‌defined‌ ‌Anthropology,‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌“gossip”‌ ‌that‌ ‌revolves‌ ‌around‌ ‌man‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌anthropologist‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌gossiper‌ ‌who‌ ‌talks‌ ‌about‌ ‌himself.‌ ‌\nImmanuel‌ ‌Kant-‌ ‌‌He‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌German‌ ‌philosopher,who‌ ‌published‌ ‌a‌ ‌book‌ ‌titled‌ ‌‘Anthropology’‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌18th‌ ‌CE.‌ ‌ ‌\nHe‌ ‌found‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌study‌ ‌which‌ ‌describes‌ ‌and‌ ‌explains‌ ‌the‌ ‌animal’s‌ ‌origin,‌ ‌social‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌development‌ ‌and‌ ‌progress‌ ‌of‌ ‌man.‌ ‌\nAL‌ ‌Kroeber:‌ ‌‌“Anthropology‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌science‌ ‌of‌ ‌man”‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌Scope‌ ‌and‌ ‌Nature:‌ ‌\n ‌The‌ ‌scope‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌is‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌its‌ ‌methods/‌ ‌perspective‌ ‌\n●Holistic‌ ‌and‌ ‌historical‌ ‌perspective‌ ‌in‌ ‌anthropology.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌biological‌ ‌and‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌man‌ ‌(Physical‌ ‌and‌ ‌Cultural‌ ‌Anthropology)‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌works‌ ‌of‌ ‌man‌ ‌through‌ ‌material‌ ‌culture‌ ‌of‌ ‌prehistoric‌ ‌time‌ ‌(Prehistoric‌ ‌Archaeological‌ ‌Anthropology)‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌races‌ ‌,culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌migration‌ ‌(Ethnology)‌ ‌\n○ ‌The‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌material‌ ‌culture,‌ ‌social‌ ‌control,‌ ‌faith‌ ‌and‌ ‌rituals‌ ‌(Economic,Political‌ ‌and‌ ‌Religious‌ ‌Anthropology)‌ ‌\n●Investigative,‌ ‌applied‌ ‌and‌ ‌comparative‌ ‌perspective‌ ‌and‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌communication‌ ‌symbols‌ ‌like‌ ‌language‌ ‌and‌ ‌arts‌ ‌(Linguistic‌ ‌Anthropology)‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌ways‌ ‌of‌ ‌life,‌ ‌society,‌ ‌different‌ ‌culture‌ ‌(‌ ‌Sociocultural‌ ‌Anthropology)‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌health‌ ‌and‌ ‌disease‌ ‌and‌ ‌its‌ ‌social‌ ‌and‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌aspects‌ ‌(Epidemiological‌ ‌Anthropology)‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌environment‌ ‌and‌ ‌adaptations‌ ‌(Ecological‌ ‌Anthropology)‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌healthy‌ ‌diet,‌ ‌social‌ ‌variation‌ ‌(Nutritional‌ ‌Anthropology)‌ ‌\n5‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌personal‌ ‌identification‌ ‌and‌ ‌reconstruction‌ ‌(Forensic‌ ‌Anthropology)‌ ‌\nDevelopment‌ ‌of‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌\n●There‌ ‌was‌ ‌divided‌ ‌opinion‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌scope‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌till‌ ‌the19th‌ ‌century.‌ ‌\n●During‌ ‌the‌ ‌beginning‌ ‌of‌ ‌19th‌ ‌century‌ ‌Encyclopaedia‌ ‌Britannica‌ ‌defined‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌separate‌ ‌discipline,‌ ‌devoted‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌discourse‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nhuman‌ ‌nature‌ ‌\n●Anthropologist‌ ‌Edward‌ ‌Tylor,‌ ‌had‌ ‌restricted‌ ‌the‌ ‌scope‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌people‌ ‌only‌ ‌later‌ ‌Paul‌ ‌Bohannan‌ ‌had‌ ‌\nemphasized‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌scope‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌extends‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌modern‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\n●Scholars‌ ‌like‌ ‌Malinowski,‌ ‌Brown‌ ‌and‌ ‌Boas‌ ‌defined‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌during‌ ‌the‌ ‌beginning‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌20th‌ ‌century‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌man‌ ‌at‌ ‌all‌ ‌levels‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌development.‌ ‌\n●Today,‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌is‌ ‌equally‌ ‌inquisitive‌ ‌about‌ ‌the‌ ‌man‌ ‌in‌ ‌his‌ ‌past,‌ ‌present‌ ‌and‌ ‌future‌ ‌and‌ ‌exists‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌comprehensive,‌ ‌comparative,‌ ‌\nHolistic‌ ‌field‌ ‌of‌ ‌study‌ ‌among‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌social,‌ ‌biological‌ ‌and‌ ‌humanistic‌ ‌sciences.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nExamples‌ ‌\nVicos‌ ‌Project(Peru)‌ ‌\nContemporary‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌application‌ ‌in‌ ‌Peru-‌ ‌Helped‌ ‌Quechua-speaking‌ ‌highland‌ ‌peasants‌ ‌run‌ ‌a‌ ‌plantation.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●In‌ ‌1952,‌ ‌Professor‌ ‌Allan‌ ‌Holmberg‌ ‌arranged‌ ‌for‌ ‌Cornell‌ ‌University‌ ‌to‌ ‌lease‌ ‌the‌ ‌Hacienda‌ ‌Vicos,‌ ‌an‌ ‌agricultural‌ ‌estate‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌central‌ ‌Peruvian‌ ‌\nhighlands‌ ‌on‌ ‌which‌ ‌some‌ ‌1800‌ ‌Quechua-speaking‌ ‌highland‌ ‌peasants‌ ‌resided.‌ ‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌initiated‌ ‌a‌ ‌set‌ ‌of‌ ‌social,‌ ‌economic,‌ ‌and‌ ‌agrarian‌ ‌changes,‌ ‌and‌ ‌nurtured‌ ‌mechanisms‌ ‌for‌ ‌community-based‌ ‌management‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌estate‌ ‌\nby‌ ‌the‌ ‌resident‌ ‌peasants.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Holmberg's‌ ‌twin‌ ‌goals‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌Vicos‌ ‌Project‌ ‌were‌ ‌to‌ ‌bring‌ ‌about‌ ‌community‌ ‌possession‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌land‌ ‌base‌ ‌and‌ ‌to‌ ‌study‌ ‌the‌ ‌process‌ ‌as‌ ‌it‌ ‌\nunfolded,‌ ‌advancing‌ ‌anthropological‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌change.‌ ‌ ‌\n●To‌ ‌describe‌ ‌the‌ ‌process‌ ‌of‌ ‌doing‌ ‌both,‌ ‌he‌ ‌invented‌ ‌the‌ ‌term‌ ‌\"participant‌ ‌intervention.\"‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n1.2‌ ‌Relationships‌ ‌with‌ ‌other‌ ‌disciplines:‌ ‌ ‌\n●Social‌ ‌Sciences,‌ ‌ ‌\n●Behavioural‌ ‌Sciences,‌ ‌ ‌\n●Life‌ ‌Sciences,‌ ‌ ‌\n●Medical‌ ‌Sciences,‌ ‌ ‌\n●Earth‌ ‌Sciences‌ ‌and‌ ‌Humanities.‌ ‌\n ‌\n6‌ ‌\nA.Anthropology‌ ‌relation‌ ‌with‌ ‌Social,‌ ‌Behavioural‌ ‌Science‌ ‌and‌ ‌Humanities‌ ‌ ‌\nDifferent‌ ‌social‌ ‌sciences‌ ‌study‌ ‌the‌ ‌different‌ ‌aspects‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌beings‌ ‌and‌ ‌society‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌ways.‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌science‌ ‌of‌ ‌humans‌ ‌\nAnthropology‌ ‌studies‌ ‌human‌ ‌life‌ ‌at‌ ‌all‌ ‌time,‌ ‌place‌ ‌and‌ ‌types.‌ ‌Hence,‌ ‌historical‌ ‌comparative‌ ‌and‌ ‌interdisciplinary‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌is‌ ‌indispensable‌ ‌for‌ ‌\nAnthropological‌ ‌studies.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌clear‌ ‌that‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌gains‌ ‌significant‌ ‌knowledge‌ ‌from‌ ‌History,‌ ‌Sociology‌ ‌Psychology,‌ ‌Political‌ ‌science,‌ ‌\nEconomy‌ ‌and‌ ‌many‌ ‌other‌ ‌Social‌ ‌Sciences.‌ ‌\n ‌\n1.Anthropology‌ ‌and‌ ‌History‌ ‌\nSimilarities‌ ‌\n●History‌ ‌studies‌ ‌about‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌life‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌past.‌ ‌It‌ ‌resorts‌ ‌to‌ ‌written‌ ‌documents‌ ‌to‌ ‌analyse‌ ‌the‌ ‌past‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌Society.It‌ ‌examines‌ ‌how‌ ‌\nhumans‌ ‌live‌ ‌and‌ ‌how‌ ‌their‌ ‌life‌ ‌is‌ ‌deferred‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌\n●Anthropology‌ ‌also‌ ‌deals‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌life‌ ‌of‌ ‌humans.‌ ‌It‌ ‌examines‌ ‌how‌ ‌they‌ ‌lived,‌ ‌how‌ ‌their‌ ‌life‌ ‌changed‌ ‌over‌ ‌time‌ ‌and‌ ‌how‌ ‌they‌ ‌gave‌ ‌birth‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌different‌ ‌social‌ ‌Institutions‌ ‌like‌ ‌family‌ ‌political‌ ‌systems‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n ‌\nDifferences‌ ‌\nHistory‌ ‌\n\t\n ‌Anthropology‌ ‌\n\n\n ‌History‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌social‌ ‌science‌ ‌\n\t\n ‌Anthropology‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌bio-social‌ ‌science‌ ‌\n\n\n ‌History‌ ‌deals‌ ‌with‌ ‌past‌ ‌\n\t\n ‌It‌ ‌deals‌ ‌with‌ ‌human‌ ‌beings‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌time‌ ‌\n\n\n ‌It‌ ‌examine‌ ‌the‌ ‌cause‌ ‌and‌ ‌effect‌ ‌of‌ ‌event‌ ‌\n\t\n ‌Its‌ ‌exam‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌socio‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌aspect‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌event‌ ‌\n\n\n ‌It‌ ‌uses‌ ‌secondary‌ ‌data‌ ‌\n\t\n ‌It‌ ‌gives‌ ‌importance‌ ‌to‌ ‌primary‌ ‌data‌ ‌\n ‌\n2.Anthropology‌ ‌and‌ ‌Sociology‌ ‌\nSimilarities‌ ‌\n●Sociology‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌science‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌society.‌ ‌studies‌ ‌human‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌in‌ ‌social‌ ‌surroundings.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌clear‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌subject‌ ‌matter‌ ‌of‌ ‌Sociology‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nanthropology‌ ‌is‌ ‌common‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌great‌ ‌extent;‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌highly‌ ‌influenced‌ ‌by‌ ‌each‌ ‌other.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌Great‌ ‌Britain,‌ ‌social‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌was‌ ‌regarded‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌branch‌ ‌of‌ ‌sociology.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●For‌ ‌example:‌ ‌\ni.‌ ‌The‌ ‌views‌ ‌of‌‌ ‌Durkheim‌,‌ ‌a‌ ‌Sociologist,‌ ‌had‌ ‌greatly‌ ‌influenced‌ ‌the‌ ‌doctrine‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌like‌ ‌Malinowski‌ ‌and‌ ‌Radcliffe‌ ‌Brown.‌ ‌\nii.‌ ‌‌Hoebel‌ ‌‌stated‌ ‌that‌ ‌Sociology‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌broad‌ ‌sense,‌ ‌are‌ ‌one‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌\niii.‌ ‌‌A.L.‌ ‌Kroeber‌‌ ‌,‌ ‌an‌ ‌American‌ ‌anthropologist‌ ‌considered‌ ‌them‌ ‌as‌ ‌twin‌ ‌sisters.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nDifferences‌ ‌\n7‌ ‌\nSociology‌ ‌\n\t\n ‌Anthropology‌ ‌\n\n\n ‌Studies‌ ‌mostly‌ ‌through‌ ‌secondary‌ ‌data‌ ‌\n\t\nStudies‌ ‌culture‌ ‌directly‌ ‌with‌ ‌intensive‌ ‌fieldwork‌ ‌over‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nperiod‌ ‌\n\n\n ‌Studies‌ ‌are‌ ‌quantitative‌ ‌\n\t\n ‌Studies‌ ‌are‌ ‌largely‌ ‌qualitative‌ ‌\n\n\n ‌It‌ ‌only‌ ‌examine‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌aspect‌ ‌\n\t\n ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌more‌ ‌elastic,‌ ‌as‌ ‌it‌ ‌studies‌ ‌both‌ ‌social‌ ‌and‌ ‌biological‌ ‌\naspects‌ ‌\n\n\n ‌Sociology=‌ ‌social‌ ‌problems‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌\n\t\n ‌Anthropology=‌ ‌culture+‌ ‌community‌ ‌\n ‌\n3.Anthropology‌ ‌and‌ ‌Psychology‌ ‌\nSimilarities‌ ‌\n●Both‌ ‌are‌ ‌concerned‌ ‌with‌ ‌human‌ ‌behaviour.‌ ‌\n●Psychological‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌examines‌ ‌the‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌between‌ ‌human‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌behaviour.‌ ‌\n●Both‌ ‌try‌ ‌to‌ ‌understand‌ ‌man‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌context‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌behaviour,‌ ‌both‌ ‌are‌ ‌complementary‌ ‌to‌ ‌each‌ ‌other,‌ ‌psychological‌ ‌knowledge‌ ‌helps‌ ‌an‌ ‌\nanthropologist‌ ‌understand‌ ‌the‌ ‌root‌ ‌cause‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌cultures.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Similarly‌ ‌anthropological‌ ‌studies‌ ‌help‌ ‌the‌ ‌psychologist‌ ‌in‌ ‌calculating‌ ‌the‌ ‌influence‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌environment‌ ‌on‌ ‌human‌ ‌behaviour.‌ ‌\n ‌\nDifferences‌ ‌\nPsychology‌ ‌\n\t\n ‌Anthropology‌ ‌\n\n\n ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌concerned‌ ‌with‌ ‌individual‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌\n\t\n ‌It‌ ‌it‌ ‌focuses‌ ‌on‌ ‌group‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌\n\n\n ‌Give‌ ‌importance‌ ‌to‌ ‌clinical‌ ‌experiments.‌ ‌\n\t\n ‌Social‌ ‌anthropologist‌ ‌depend‌ ‌greatly‌ ‌on‌ ‌field‌ ‌work‌ ‌\n\n\nDevote‌ ‌particular‌ ‌attention,‌ ‌to‌ ‌emotion‌ ‌and‌ ‌motivation‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌individual‌ ‌\n\t\nIt‌ ‌study‌ ‌social‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌of‌ ‌individual‌ ‌to‌ ‌analyse‌ ‌\nSocial‌ ‌Organisation‌ ‌\n ‌\n4.Anthropology‌ ‌and‌ ‌Political‌ ‌Science‌ ‌\nSimilarities‌ ‌\n●Social‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌and‌ ‌political‌ ‌science‌ ‌examine‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌life‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌beings.‌ ‌\n●Political‌ ‌science‌ ‌contributes‌ ‌to‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌the‌ ‌facts‌ ‌regarding‌ ‌the‌ ‌organisation‌ ‌and‌ ‌activities‌ ‌of‌ ‌state,‌ ‌while‌ ‌social‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌\ncontributes‌ ‌to‌ ‌political‌ ‌science‌ ‌the‌ ‌knowledge‌ ‌of‌ ‌origin‌ ‌of‌ ‌state‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌stateless‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n ‌\nDifferences‌ ‌\n8‌ ‌\nPolitical‌ ‌science‌ ‌\n\t\n ‌Anthropology‌ ‌\n\n\n ‌It‌ ‌study‌ ‌the‌ ‌institutional‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌government‌ ‌in‌ ‌state‌ ‌\nsystem‌ ‌alone‌ ‌\n\t\n ‌It‌ ‌study‌ ‌the‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌government‌ ‌in‌ ‌state‌ ‌and‌ ‌stateless‌ ‌\nsociety‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌\n\n\n ‌It‌ ‌deals‌ ‌with‌ ‌political‌ ‌life‌ ‌of‌ ‌society‌ ‌\n\t\n ‌It‌ ‌deals‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌total‌ ‌social‌ ‌life‌ ‌\n ‌\n5.Anthropology‌ ‌and‌ ‌Economy‌ ‌\nSimilarities‌ ‌\n● ‌‌Both‌ ‌the‌ ‌subjects‌ ‌considered‌ ‌humans‌ ‌as‌ ‌social‌ ‌beings.‌ ‌\n● ‌The‌ ‌economic‌ ‌life‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual‌ ‌is‌ ‌examined‌ ‌in‌ ‌both‌ ‌the‌ ‌subjects.‌ ‌\n● ‌Any‌ ‌change‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌economic‌ ‌system‌ ‌in‌ ‌turn‌ ‌causes‌ ‌changes‌ ‌in‌ ‌other‌ ‌aspects‌ ‌of‌ ‌society‌ ‌and‌ ‌culture.Hence‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌requires‌ ‌an‌ ‌\ninsight‌ ‌into‌ ‌the‌ ‌economic‌ ‌system‌ ‌as‌ ‌well.‌ ‌\n ‌\nDifferences‌ ‌\nEconomy‌ ‌\n\t\n ‌Anthropology‌ ‌\n\n\nIt‌ ‌only‌ ‌deals‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌economic‌ ‌life‌ ‌of‌ ‌people.‌ ‌\n\t\nIt‌ ‌is‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌whole‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌life‌ ‌\n\n\nGive‌ ‌importance‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌economic‌ ‌life‌ ‌of‌ ‌modern‌ ‌\nComplex‌ ‌society‌ ‌\n\t\nAnthropologist‌ ‌are‌ ‌interested‌ ‌in‌ ‌simple‌ ‌economic‌ ‌and‌ ‌its‌ ‌\nevolutionary‌ ‌linked‌ ‌with‌ ‌modern‌ ‌economy‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nB.‌ ‌‌Anthropology‌ ‌relation‌ ‌with‌ ‌Life‌ ‌Science‌ ‌\n ‌‌Similarities‌ ‌\n●Anthropology‌ ‌is‌ ‌closely‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌several‌ ‌life‌ ‌sciences.‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌example‌ ‌\n●Zoology‌-‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌with‌ ‌other‌ ‌animals‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌overall‌ ‌places‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌species‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌process‌ ‌of‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌\n●Biology‌-‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌from‌ ‌pre‌ ‌human‌ ‌forms‌ ‌\n●Anatomy‌ ‌and‌ ‌Physiology‌-‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌concerned‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌structure‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌body,‌ ‌the‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌of‌ ‌various‌ ‌part‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌operation‌ ‌and‌ ‌function‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌these‌ ‌different‌ ‌parts.‌ ‌\n●Genetics‌-‌ ‌it‌ ‌concerns‌ ‌variations‌ ‌in‌ ‌today's‌ ‌world.‌ ‌\n●Anthropology‌ ‌studies‌ ‌the‌ ‌physical‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌man‌ ‌principle‌ ‌of‌ ‌biology‌ ‌and‌ ‌utilise‌ ‌the‌ ‌findings‌ ‌of‌ ‌anatomy‌ ‌physiology‌ ‌Zoology‌ ‌\nplanetology‌ ‌and‌ ‌so‌ ‌on.‌ ‌\n9‌ ‌\n●Paul‌ ‌Broca‌ ‌(1871),‌ ‌the‌ ‌famous‌ ‌biologist‌ ‌defined‌ ‌physical‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌science‌ ‌whose‌ ‌objective‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌humanity‌ ‌considered‌ ‌\nas‌ ‌a‌ ‌four‌ ‌in‌ ‌its‌ ‌part‌ ‌and‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌rest‌ ‌of‌ ‌nature.‌ ‌\n ‌\nDifferences‌ ‌\nLife‌ ‌science‌ ‌\n\t\n ‌Anthropology‌ ‌\n\n\nBiology‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌that‌ ‌elaborated‌ ‌an‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌length‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌breadth‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌Skull‌ ‌\n\t\nIt‌ ‌is‌ ‌more‌ ‌elaborative.‌ ‌physical‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌exam‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nskull‌ ‌in‌ ‌detail‌ ‌\n\n\n ‌Biology‌ ‌is‌ ‌entire‌ ‌living‌ ‌beings‌ ‌\n\t\n ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌concerned‌ ‌with‌ ‌certain‌ ‌aspect‌ ‌of‌ ‌general‌ ‌biology‌ ‌\n\n\n ‌It‌ ‌moves‌ ‌beyond‌ ‌human‌ ‌being‌ ‌\n\t\n ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌restricted‌ ‌to‌ ‌Human‌ ‌being‌ ‌\n ‌\nC.‌ ‌‌Anthropology‌ ‌and‌ ‌Medical‌ ‌Science‌ ‌\n ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌knowledge‌ ‌about‌ ‌the‌ ‌various‌ ‌concepts‌ ‌of‌ ‌disease‌ ‌and‌ ‌healing‌ ‌in‌ ‌various‌ ‌communities‌ ‌is‌ ‌very‌ ‌essential‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌medical‌ ‌practitioner.‌ ‌\nAnthropological‌ ‌studies‌ ‌provide‌ ‌such‌ ‌information‌ ‌to‌ ‌us.‌ ‌\n●With‌ ‌regard‌ ‌to‌ ‌direct‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌between‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌and‌ ‌health,‌ ‌it‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌specifically‌ ‌noted‌ ‌that‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌\nhas‌ ‌exercised‌ ‌a‌ ‌remarkable‌ ‌influence‌ ‌upon‌ ‌the‌ ‌field‌ ‌of‌ ‌psychiatry‌ ‌and‌ ‌psychosomatics‌ ‌and‌ ‌many‌ ‌other‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌diseases.‌ ‌\n●Physical‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌significantly‌ ‌contributes‌ ‌in‌ ‌investigating‌ ‌the‌ ‌nature‌ ‌and‌ ‌extent‌ ‌of‌ ‌various‌ ‌diseases.‌ ‌E.g.‌ ‌whether‌ ‌the‌ ‌concerned‌ ‌\ndisease‌ ‌is‌ ‌hereditary‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌running‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌family‌ ‌trait‌ ‌or‌ ‌non‌ ‌hereditary.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Not‌ ‌only‌ ‌this‌ ‌but‌ ‌also‌ ‌the‌ ‌growth‌ ‌studies‌ ‌relating‌ ‌to‌ ‌their‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌growth‌ ‌Trend‌ ‌abnormality‌ ‌and‌ ‌environmental‌ ‌effects‌ ‌are‌ ‌also‌ ‌assessed‌ ‌by‌ ‌\nphysical‌ ‌anthropologists.‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌example‌ ‌:‌‌ ‌Cross-cultural‌ ‌knowledge‌ ‌is‌ ‌important‌ ‌especially‌ ‌during‌ ‌disaster‌ ‌pandemic.‌ ‌\nCulture‌ ‌produces‌ ‌likelihood‌ ‌of‌ ‌disease.‌ ‌The‌ ‌very‌ ‌recent‌ ‌example‌ ‌of‌ ‌Coronavirus‌ ‌origin‌ ‌in‌ ‌Wuhan‌ ‌‘wet‌ ‌market’.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nD.‌ ‌‌Anthropology‌ ‌and‌ ‌Environmental‌ ‌Science‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Being‌ ‌equipped‌ ‌with‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌means‌ ‌in‌ ‌coping‌ ‌with‌ ‌nature‌ ‌human‌ ‌beings‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌able‌ ‌to‌ ‌adjust‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌variety‌ ‌of‌ ‌environments‌ ‌including‌ ‌\npolar‌ ‌region‌ ‌man‌ ‌could‌ ‌alter‌ ‌the‌ ‌environment‌ ‌condition‌ ‌by‌ ‌mid‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌making‌ ‌it‌ ‌favourable‌ ‌to‌ ‌serve‌ ‌his‌ ‌needs.‌ ‌E.g.‌ ‌In‌ ‌the‌ ‌earth‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nwater‌ ‌he‌ ‌can‌ ‌dig‌ ‌a‌ ‌well‌ ‌and‌ ‌you‌ ‌can‌ ‌domesticate‌ ‌animals‌ ‌and‌ ‌plants‌ ‌as‌ ‌food.‌ ‌\n● ‌However,‌ ‌men‌ ‌have‌ ‌to‌ ‌depend‌ ‌partly‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌physical‌ ‌environment‌ ‌and‌ ‌natural‌ ‌resources‌ ‌as‌ ‌we‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌make‌ ‌it‌ ‌absolutely‌ ‌free‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌\ninfluence‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌environment.‌ ‌That‌ ‌is‌ ‌why‌ ‌culture‌ ‌has‌ ‌taken‌ ‌shape‌ ‌in‌ ‌accordance‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌environment.‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌example‌,‌ ‌The‌ ‌Mesopotamian‌ ‌and‌ ‌Harappan‌ ‌civilisation‌ ‌were‌ ‌located‌ ‌near‌ ‌the‌ ‌the‌ ‌river‌ ‌sources‌ ‌and‌ ‌not‌ ‌in‌ ‌desert‌ ‌and‌ ‌polar‌ ‌region‌ ‌\n ‌\n10‌ ‌\n ‌\nE.‌‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌and‌ ‌Earth‌ ‌Science‌ ‌\n ‌ ‌\n●Anthropology‌ ‌is‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌earth‌ ‌science‌ ‌i.e.‌ ‌geography,‌ ‌pedology‌ ‌and‌ ‌geology.‌ ‌ ‌\n● ‌Both‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌and‌ ‌geography‌ ‌study‌ ‌man‌ ‌and‌ ‌environment‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌\n● ‌Geography‌ ‌studies‌ ‌environment‌ ‌and‌ ‌its‌ ‌impact‌ ‌of‌ ‌man‌ ‌social‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌economic‌ ‌political‌ ‌and‌ ‌biological‌ ‌aspect‌ ‌\n● ‌Pedology‌ ‌the‌ ‌science‌ ‌of‌ ‌soil‌ ‌is‌ ‌another‌ ‌potential‌ ‌field‌ ‌with‌ ‌which‌ ‌Archaeological‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌is‌ ‌highly‌ ‌related‌ ‌\n● ‌Anthropologists‌ ‌analyse‌ ‌the‌ ‌soil‌ ‌and‌ ‌understand‌ ‌the‌ ‌manner‌ ‌of‌ ‌formation‌ ‌of‌ ‌deposits‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌environment‌ ‌at‌ ‌that‌ ‌time.‌ ‌\n● ‌Archaeological‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌revisit‌ ‌the‌ ‌man's‌ ‌past‌ ‌from‌ ‌material‌ ‌remains.‌ ‌These‌ ‌interpretations‌ ‌are‌ ‌done‌ ‌by‌ ‌using‌ ‌tools‌ ‌,‌ ‌method‌ ‌theory‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌principle‌ ‌of‌ ‌Earth‌ ‌sciences.For‌ ‌example,‌ ‌Grecco‌ ‌Roman‌ ‌lifestyles‌ ‌revealed‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌recent‌ ‌discovery‌ ‌of‌ ‌ancient‌ ‌STREET‌ ‌FOOD‌ ‌SHOP‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nPompeii(Napoli)-Italy‌ ‌by‌ ‌Archaeological‌ ‌anthropologists.‌ ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌Addition‌ ‌\nSituate‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌in‌ ‌Social‌ ‌Science‌ ‌\n ‌\n#For‌ ‌diagram‌ ‌visit‌ ‌youtube‌ ‌video‌ ‌\nIt‌ ‌is‌ ‌difficult‌ ‌to‌ ‌identify‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌with‌ ‌social‌ ‌science‌ ‌alone,‌ ‌it‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌identified‌ ‌as‌ ‌Natural‌ ‌science‌ ‌either.‌ ‌Thus,‌ ‌it‌ ‌fits‌ ‌somewhere‌ ‌between‌ ‌two‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌more‌ ‌of‌ ‌free‌ ‌science‌ ‌with‌ ‌interactions‌ ‌cutting‌ ‌across‌ ‌the‌ ‌old‌ ‌divisions‌ ‌and‌ ‌developing‌ ‌a‌ ‌Holistic‌ ‌science‌ ‌of‌ ‌humans.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n1.3‌ ‌Main‌ ‌branches‌ ‌of‌ ‌Anthropology,‌ ‌their‌ ‌scope‌ ‌and‌ ‌relevance:‌ ‌\n(a)‌ ‌Social-Cultural‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌\n(b)‌ ‌Biological‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌\n(c)‌ ‌Archaeological‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌\n(d)‌ ‌Linguistic‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n11‌ ‌\n(a)‌ ‌Social-cultural‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌\nDefinition:‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌branch‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌that‌ ‌concerns‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌Social‌ ‌Science‌ ‌Institutions‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌socio-cultural‌ ‌aspects‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌life‌ ‌is‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌\nsocio-cultural‌ ‌anthropology.‌ ‌\n ‌\nThoughts‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropologist:‌ ‌\n●Radcliffe‌ ‌Brown‌‌ ‌defined‌ ‌Social-cultural‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌natural‌ ‌science‌ ‌of‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Charles‌ ‌Winick‌ ‌(American‌ ‌professor‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌and‌ ‌sociology)‌ ‌defines‌ ‌social‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌as‌ ‌‘‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌\nespecially‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌point‌ ‌of‌ ‌view‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌systematic‌ ‌and‌ ‌comparative‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌form‌ ‌and‌ ‌institutions.‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌‌Piddington‌,‌ ‌‘Social‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌studies‌ ‌the‌ ‌culture‌ ‌of‌ ‌contemporary‌ ‌communities.‌ ‌\n●MJ‌ ‌Herskovits‌ ‌in‌ ‌his‌ ‌book‌ ‌‘‌Man‌ ‌and‌ ‌his‌ ‌work‌’‌ ‌(1955)‌ ‌point‌ ‌out‌ ‌that‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌studies‌ ‌the‌ ‌way‌ ‌and‌ ‌has‌ ‌devised‌ ‌to‌ ‌cope‌ ‌with‌ ‌\nnatural‌ ‌settings‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌milieu‌ ‌and‌ ‌how‌ ‌bodies‌ ‌of‌ ‌customers‌ ‌are‌ ‌retained‌ ‌and‌ ‌handed‌ ‌over‌ ‌from‌ ‌one‌ ‌generation‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌next.‌ ‌\n ‌\nAim:‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌main‌ ‌aim‌ ‌of‌ ‌socio-cultural‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌is‌ ‌to‌ ‌understand‌ ‌and‌ ‌appreciate‌ ‌the‌ ‌diversity‌ ‌in‌ ‌human‌ ‌behaviour,‌ ‌and‌ ‌ultimately‌ ‌to‌ ‌develop‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nscience‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌behaviour.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌is‌ ‌obtained‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌comparison‌ ‌of‌ ‌different‌ ‌people‌ ‌throughout‌ ‌the‌ ‌world.‌ ‌\n ‌\nSub‌ ‌Branches:‌ ‌ ‌\n●Familial‌ ‌Anthropology:‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌deals‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌comparative‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌families‌ ‌of‌ ‌different‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌and‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌studies‌ ‌the‌ ‌origin‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family,‌ ‌its‌ ‌forms‌ ‌and‌ ‌functions‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌also‌ ‌studies‌ ‌different‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage,‌ ‌ways‌ ‌of‌ ‌acquiring‌ ‌mates‌ ‌and‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌payments‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌\n●Economic‌ ‌Anthropology:‌ ‌\n○Economic‌ ‌activities‌ ‌play‌ ‌an‌ ‌important‌ ‌role‌ ‌in‌ ‌social‌ ‌organization.‌ ‌\n○Studies‌ ‌the‌ ‌economic‌ ‌organization‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌societies‌ ‌ranging‌ ‌from‌ ‌preliterate‌ ‌food-collecting‌ ‌economy‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌modern‌ ‌industrial‌ ‌\neconomy.‌ ‌\n●Religion‌ ‌Anthropology:‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌deals‌ ‌with‌ ‌beliefs‌ ‌and‌ ‌practices‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌supernatural‌ ‌powers‌ ‌and‌ ‌forces‌ ‌which‌ ‌play‌ ‌an‌ ‌important‌ ‌role‌ ‌in‌ ‌shaping‌ ‌the‌ ‌culture‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌\ngroup.‌ ‌\n●Political‌ ‌Anthropology:‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌political‌ ‌system‌ ‌prevailing‌ ‌in‌ ‌society‌ ‌plays‌ ‌an‌ ‌important‌ ‌role‌ ‌in‌ ‌shaping‌ ‌the‌ ‌ways‌ ‌of‌ ‌life‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌people.‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌deals‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌types‌ ‌and‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌government,‌ ‌state‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌stateless‌ ‌political‌ ‌organizations,‌ ‌regulations‌ ‌including‌ ‌mores‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nnorms‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌customs‌ ‌and‌ ‌laws,‌ ‌nature‌ ‌of‌ ‌sanctions‌ ‌including‌ ‌punishment‌ ‌and‌ ‌rewards,‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n●Ecological‌ ‌Anthropology:‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌environment‌ ‌plays‌ ‌an‌ ‌important‌ ‌role‌ ‌in‌ ‌shaping‌ ‌the‌ ‌culture‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌people.‌ ‌\n12‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌studies‌ ‌the‌ ‌inter-relationship‌ ‌between‌ ‌humans,‌ ‌the‌ ‌environment,‌ ‌and‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\n●Medical‌ ‌Anthropology:‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌deals‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌bio-cultural‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌of‌ ‌humans‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌works‌ ‌in‌ ‌relation‌ ‌to‌ ‌health‌ ‌and‌ ‌disease.‌ ‌\n○Local‌ ‌beliefs‌ ‌regarding‌ ‌health‌ ‌and‌ ‌disease,‌ ‌treatment‌ ‌and‌ ‌preventive‌ ‌measures.‌ ‌\n ‌\nScope:‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌society‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌whole‌ ‌in‌ ‌social‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌provides‌ ‌it‌ ‌but‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌then‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌specific‌ ‌problems‌ ‌as‌ ‌in‌ ‌Sociology.‌ ‌\n●Social‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌has‌ ‌wide‌ ‌scope;‌ ‌it‌ ‌studies‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌Civilization‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌like‌ ‌family‌ ‌kinship,‌ ‌political‌ ‌organisation‌ ‌\nunderstanding‌ ‌of‌ ‌customs,‌ ‌traditional‌ ‌religion‌ ‌belief‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌systematic‌ ‌observation‌ ‌and‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌do‌ ‌comparative‌ ‌analysis.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Comprehensive‌ ‌approach‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌important‌ ‌characteristic;‌ ‌it‌ ‌also‌ ‌studies‌ ‌the‌ ‌origin‌ ‌and‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌organisation.‌ ‌Thus,‌ ‌\nit‌ ‌examines‌ ‌every‌ ‌aspect‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌single‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌every‌ ‌aspect‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌single‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nSome‌ ‌related‌ ‌terms:‌ ‌\n●Ethnocentrism‌ ‌‌:‌ ‌It's‌ ‌the‌ ‌attitude‌ ‌of‌ ‌judging‌ ‌other‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌norm‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌values‌ ‌present‌ ‌in‌ ‌one's‌ ‌own‌ ‌culture,‌ ‌for‌ ‌example‌ ‌\neating‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌hand‌ ‌sitting‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌floor.‌ ‌\n●Cultural‌ ‌relativism‌ ‌:‌‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌idea‌ ‌that‌ ‌its‌ ‌culture‌ ‌must‌ ‌be‌ ‌understood‌ ‌in‌ ‌its‌ ‌own‌ ‌standard.‌ ‌\n●Enculturation:‌ ‌It‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌process‌ ‌by‌ ‌which‌ ‌one‌ ‌learns‌ ‌the‌ ‌way‌ ‌of‌ ‌life‌ ‌and‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌of‌ ‌one's‌ ‌own‌ ‌culture‌ ‌for‌ ‌example‌ ‌children‌ ‌\nlearning‌ ‌from‌ ‌parents‌ ‌about‌ ‌family‌ ‌custom.‌ ‌\n●Acculturation‌:‌ ‌It‌ ‌changes‌ ‌that‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌in‌ ‌one‌ ‌culture‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌continuous‌ ‌contact‌ ‌with‌ ‌another‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌For‌ ‌example:‌ ‌The‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌fast‌ ‌food‌ ‌\ngradually‌ ‌adopted‌ ‌from‌ ‌Britishers.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n(b)‌ ‌Biological‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌\nDefinition:‌ ‌\n●Biological‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌physical‌ ‌anthropology.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌deals‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌biological‌ ‌origin,‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌and‌ ‌variations‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌beings.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌interested‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌comparative‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌past,‌ ‌present‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nfuture‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌life‌ ‌from‌ ‌a‌ ‌biological‌ ‌point‌ ‌of‌ ‌view.‌ ‌\n●Physical‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌oldest‌ ‌branch‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌primarily‌ ‌concerned‌ ‌with‌ ‌human‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌context‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\nBiological‌ ‌science‌ ‌has‌ ‌made‌ ‌a‌ ‌huge‌ ‌contribution‌ ‌to‌ ‌Physical‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌organic‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌and‌ ‌principles‌ ‌of‌ ‌genetics‌ ‌are‌ ‌\nsignificant.‌ ‌\n ‌\nThoughts‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropologist:‌ ‌\n13‌ ‌\n●Paul‌ ‌Broca‌ ‌defines‌ ‌Biological‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌as‌ ‌“the‌ ‌science‌ ‌whose‌ ‌objective‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌humanity‌ ‌considered‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌whole‌ ‌in‌ ‌its‌ ‌parts‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nin‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌rest‌ ‌of‌ ‌nature”.‌ ‌\n ‌\nSub‌ ‌Branches:‌ ‌\n●There‌ ‌are‌ ‌many‌ ‌sub-branches/fields‌ ‌in‌ ‌biological‌ ‌anthropology.‌ ‌They‌ ‌are‌ ‌Primatology,‌ ‌Paleoanthropology,‌ ‌Human‌ ‌Genetics,‌ ‌Forensic‌ ‌\nAnthropology,‌ ‌Serology‌ ‌(ABO‌ ‌Blood‌ ‌Group),‌ ‌Dermatoglyphics,‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n●Primatology:‌ ‌ ‌\n○Study‌ ‌of‌ ‌living‌ ‌and‌ ‌extinct‌ ‌primates‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌humans,‌ ‌apes,‌ ‌monkeys,‌ ‌prosimians.‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌focuses‌ ‌on‌ ‌how‌ ‌the‌ ‌behavior‌ ‌of‌ ‌non-human‌ ‌primates‌ ‌is‌ ‌similar‌ ‌to‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌humans‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌helps‌ ‌to‌ ‌trace‌ ‌the‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌between‌ ‌human‌ ‌non-human‌ ‌primates‌ ‌because‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌remarkable‌ ‌similarities‌ ‌between‌ ‌\nmonkeys,‌ ‌apes,‌ ‌and‌ ‌humans.‌ ‌\n●Paleoanthropology:‌ ‌ ‌\n○Studies‌ ‌the‌ ‌fossil‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌skeletons‌ ‌of‌ ‌different‌ ‌stages‌ ‌and‌ ‌thereby‌ ‌reconstructs‌ ‌the‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌history‌ ‌of‌ ‌humans.‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌studies‌ ‌extinct‌ ‌primate‌ ‌and‌ ‌concerned‌ ‌itself‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌man‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌helps‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌classification‌ ‌and‌ ‌comparison‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌fossils‌ ‌of‌ ‌different‌ ‌stages‌ ‌to‌ ‌determine‌ ‌the‌ ‌link‌ ‌between‌ ‌modern‌ ‌humans‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌\nancestors.‌ ‌\n●Human‌ ‌Genetics:‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌deals‌ ‌with‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌and‌ ‌variation‌ ‌thereby‌ ‌helping‌ ‌in‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌how‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌works.‌ ‌\n●Neontology:‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌studies‌ ‌living‌ ‌primates‌ ‌and‌ ‌examines‌ ‌comparative‌ ‌anatomy,‌ ‌physiology‌ ‌and‌ ‌human‌ ‌variation‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌population‌ ‌genetics.‌ ‌\n●Forensic‌ ‌Anthropology:‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌branch‌ ‌of‌ ‌biological‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌that‌ ‌helps‌ ‌to‌ ‌identify‌ ‌individuals,‌ ‌criminals,‌ ‌victims‌ ‌of‌ ‌misshapes‌ ‌and‌ ‌natural‌ ‌calamities,‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n○From‌ ‌the‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌of‌ ‌DNA,‌ ‌hair‌ ‌with‌ ‌roots,‌ ‌bloodstains,‌ ‌drops‌ ‌of‌ ‌semen,‌ ‌body‌ ‌fluids,‌ ‌skin‌ ‌cells,‌ ‌cells‌ ‌of‌ ‌bone-‌ ‌marrow,‌ ‌fingerprints,‌ ‌\nskeletal‌ ‌remains,‌ ‌etc.,‌ ‌forensic‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌are‌ ‌able‌ ‌to‌ ‌identify‌ ‌such‌ ‌persons.‌ ‌\n○With‌ ‌the‌ ‌help‌ ‌of‌ ‌techniques,‌ ‌it‌ ‌helps‌ ‌one‌ ‌to‌ ‌determine‌ ‌age,‌ ‌sex‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌morphological‌ ‌features‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌victims.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●The‌ ‌studies‌ ‌of‌ ‌physical‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌broadly‌ ‌divided‌ ‌into‌ ‌two:‌ ‌\n○Classical‌ ‌anthropology:‌ ‌It‌ ‌relies‌ ‌on‌ ‌anthropometric‌ ‌measurement‌ ‌computing‌ ‌indices‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌statistics.‌ ‌Also,it‌ ‌focuses‌ ‌heavily‌ ‌on‌ ‌\ndata‌ ‌collection‌ ‌and‌ ‌tabulation.‌ ‌\n○New‌ ‌physical‌ ‌Anthropology:‌ ‌It‌ ‌focuses‌ ‌on‌ ‌comprehending‌ ‌and‌ ‌interpreting‌ ‌data.‌ ‌The‌ ‌term‌ ‌coined‌ ‌by‌ ‌SL‌ ‌washburn‌ ‌in‌ ‌(1951).It‌ ‌\nrefer‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌mechanism‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌‌Scope:‌ ‌ ‌\n●Physical‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌has‌ ‌contributed‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌studies‌ ‌of‌ ‌primatology,‌ ‌primate‌ ‌paleontology,‌ ‌raciology,‌ ‌eugenics‌ ‌forensic‌ ‌science‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌studies‌ ‌human‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌and‌ ‌human‌ ‌variation.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌branch‌ ‌of‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌that‌ ‌considers‌ ‌humans‌ ‌as‌ ‌biological‌ ‌organisms.‌ ‌\n14‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌helps‌ ‌to‌ ‌understand‌ ‌the‌ ‌physical‌ ‌differences‌ ‌and‌ ‌changes‌ ‌among‌ ‌humans.‌ ‌\n●Study‌ ‌of‌ ‌origin‌ ‌and‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌humans‌ ‌and‌ ‌analyses‌ ‌their‌ ‌diversity.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌examines‌ ‌the‌ ‌bio-social‌ ‌adaptation‌ ‌of‌ ‌different‌ ‌human‌ ‌populations‌ ‌living‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌geographical‌ ‌and‌ ‌ecological‌ ‌settings.‌ ‌\n ‌\nContemporary‌ ‌applications‌ ‌of‌ ‌Biological‌ ‌Anthropology:‌ ‌ ‌\n●Paleopathology:‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌disease‌ ‌in‌ ‌antiquity.‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌studies‌ ‌the‌ ‌traces‌ ‌of‌ ‌disease‌ ‌and‌ ‌injury‌ ‌in‌ ‌human‌ ‌skeletal‌ ‌remains.‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌focuses‌ ‌on‌ ‌pathogenic‌ ‌conditions‌ ‌observable‌ ‌in‌ ‌bones‌ ‌or‌ ‌mummified‌ ‌soft‌ ‌tissue.‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌also‌ ‌studies‌ ‌nutritional‌ ‌disorders,‌ ‌variation‌ ‌in‌ ‌stature‌ ‌or‌ ‌the‌ ‌morphology‌ ‌of‌ ‌bones‌ ‌over‌ ‌time.‌ ‌\n●Bio-archaeology:‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌combination‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌osteology‌ ‌and‌ ‌archaeology.‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌studies‌ ‌the‌ ‌human‌ ‌bones‌ ‌associating‌ ‌them‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌location‌ ‌of‌ ‌its‌ ‌recovery‌ ‌in‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌understand‌ ‌the‌ ‌past‌ ‌human‌ ‌populations.‌ ‌\n●Neuro-Anthropology:‌ ‌\n○Study‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌human‌ ‌brain,‌ ‌evolution,‌ ‌and‌ ‌culture‌ ‌as‌ ‌neurological‌ ‌adaptation‌ ‌and‌ ‌environment.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n(c)‌ ‌Archaeological‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌\nDefinition:‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌branch‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌that‌ ‌deals‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌past‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌through‌ ‌remains‌ ‌left‌ ‌by‌ ‌ancient‌ ‌humans‌ ‌in‌ ‌relation‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nenvironment.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌derived‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌broad‌ ‌field‌ ‌of‌ ‌archaeology.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌deals‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌prehistoric‌ ‌period‌ ‌which‌ ‌constitutes‌ ‌over‌ ‌99%‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌history.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌word‌ ‌archaeology‌ ‌is‌ ‌derived‌ ‌from‌ ‌two‌ ‌Greek‌ ‌words‌ ‌‘arkhaios’‌ ‌means‌ ‌ancient‌ ‌and‌ ‌logos‌ ‌means‌ ‌studies.‌ ‌So,‌ ‌archaeological‌ ‌study‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nstudy‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌activity‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌past.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌deals‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌tribal‌ ‌and‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌and‌ ‌non‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌remains‌ ‌left‌ ‌behind‌ ‌by‌ ‌extinct‌ ‌humans‌ ‌by‌ ‌reconstructing‌ ‌their‌ ‌environment,‌ ‌\nculture‌ ‌and‌ ‌socio‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌evolution.‌ ‌\n ‌\nAim‌ ‌\n●To‌ ‌reconstruct‌ ‌the‌ ‌Prehistoric‌ ‌past‌ ‌and‌ ‌early‌ ‌historic‌ ‌settings‌ ‌of‌ ‌humankind.‌ ‌\n ‌\nScope‌ ‌\n●Text‌ ‌free‌ ‌archaeological‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌provided‌ ‌by‌ ‌environmental‌ ‌factors‌ ‌and‌ ‌exposure‌ ‌of‌ ‌sides‌ ‌by‌ ‌natural‌ ‌\nprocesses.‌ ‌\n ‌\n15‌ ‌\n●Sub‌ ‌Branches:‌ ‌\nIt‌ ‌has‌ ‌two‌ ‌sub‌ ‌branches‌ ‌namely:‌ ‌\n○Old‌ ‌World‌ ‌Archaeological‌ ‌Anthropology:‌ ‌Text‌ ‌free‌ ‌archaeological‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌written‌ ‌sources‌ ‌ ‌\n○New‌ ‌World‌ ‌Archaeological‌ ‌Anthropology:‌ ‌It‌ ‌emphasizes‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌revolutionary‌ ‌perspective‌ ‌system‌ ‌approach‌ ‌and‌ ‌loading‌ ‌logical‌ ‌\nreasoning.‌ ‌\n●Recent‌ ‌application:‌ ‌ ‌\n○Applied‌ ‌archeological‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌It‌ ‌includes‌ ‌salvage‌ ‌archaeology,‌ ‌industrial‌ ‌archaeology‌ ‌and‌ ‌museology.‌ ‌\n○Aerial‌ ‌Survey‌ ‌(Remote‌ ‌sensing).‌ ‌\n○Ground‌ ‌Survey.‌ ‌\n○Computer-Aided‌ ‌Mapping.‌ ‌\n○Urban‌ ‌Water‌ ‌Archaeology.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n(d)‌ ‌Linguistic‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌\nDefinition:‌ ‌\n●Linguistic‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌branch‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌that‌ ‌deals‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌language‌ ‌in‌ ‌relation‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌biological‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌\naspects‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌beings.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌examines‌ ‌the‌ ‌structure‌ ‌of‌ ‌language,‌ ‌its‌ ‌uses‌ ‌origin‌ ‌development‌ ‌and‌ ‌classification‌ ‌in‌ ‌relation‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌specific‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\n●Linguistic‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌work‌ ‌may‌ ‌involve‌ ‌developing‌ ‌a‌ ‌way‌ ‌to‌ ‌write‌ ‌a‌ ‌formal‌ ‌and‌ ‌written‌ ‌language.‌ ‌\n●Till‌ ‌the‌ ‌19th‌ ‌century‌ ‌e‌ ‌the‌ ‌focus‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌study‌ ‌was‌ ‌classical‌ ‌language‌ ‌and‌ ‌its‌ ‌branch‌ ‌of‌ ‌knowledge‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌philology.‌ ‌\n●Till‌ ‌1950‌ ‌‘s‌ ‌it‌ ‌dealt‌ ‌with‌ ‌only‌ ‌descriptive‌ ‌studies‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌origin‌ ‌of‌ ‌language‌ ‌classification‌ ‌similarities‌ ‌and‌ ‌was‌ ‌called‌ ‌anthropological‌ ‌\nlinguistics.‌ ‌\n ‌\nScope:‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌mainly‌ ‌belongs‌ ‌to‌ ‌socio-cultural‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌and‌ ‌deals‌ ‌with‌ ‌how‌ ‌language‌ ‌is‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌various‌ ‌aspects‌ ‌of‌ ‌sociocultural‌ ‌anthropology.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌examines‌ ‌the‌ ‌origin‌ ‌of‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌and‌ ‌variation‌ ‌of‌ ‌languages‌ ‌as‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌examines‌ ‌the‌ ‌structure‌ ‌of‌ ‌language,‌ ‌its‌ ‌use,‌ ‌origin,‌ ‌development,‌ ‌and‌ ‌classification‌ ‌in‌ ‌relation‌ ‌to‌ ‌specific‌ ‌cultures.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌studies‌ ‌language‌ ‌as‌ ‌an‌ ‌integral‌ ‌aspect‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌life‌ ‌as‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌primary‌ ‌medium‌ ‌of‌ ‌communication‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌interaction‌ ‌without‌ ‌which‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nmajor‌ ‌social‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌(the‌ ‌family,‌ ‌the‌ ‌law,‌ ‌the‌ ‌polity,‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌economy)‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌function‌ ‌in‌ ‌any‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌helps‌ ‌to‌ ‌document‌ ‌the‌ ‌disappearing‌ ‌languages,‌ ‌particularly‌ ‌tribal‌ ‌languages‌ ‌or‌ ‌languages‌ ‌spoken‌ ‌by‌ ‌only‌ ‌a‌ ‌few‌ ‌numbers‌ ‌of‌ ‌people.‌ ‌\n●Contemporary‌ ‌linguistic‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌is‌ ‌considered‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌both‌ ‌descriptive‌ ‌and‌ ‌analytical‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nSub‌ ‌Branches‌ ‌ ‌\n●Historical‌ ‌or‌ ‌comparative‌ ‌linguistic‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌studies‌ ‌Origin,‌ ‌comparison,‌ ‌and‌ ‌classification‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌dynamic‌ ‌of‌ ‌language‌ ‌overtime‌ ‌in‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌context‌ ‌\n16‌ ‌\n●Structural‌ ‌or‌ ‌Descriptive‌ ‌Linguistic:‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌helps‌ ‌in‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌the‌ ‌construction‌ ‌of‌ ‌language.‌ ‌Deals‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌phonemic,‌ ‌syntactic‌ ‌and‌ ‌structure,‌ ‌grammatical‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nlanguages.‌ ‌\n●Social‌ ‌linguistics‌ ‌or‌ ‌Sociolinguistics:‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌studies‌ ‌the‌ ‌role‌ ‌of‌ ‌language‌ ‌in‌ ‌social‌ ‌behavior‌ ‌in‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌studies‌ ‌how‌ ‌contemporary‌ ‌languages‌ ‌differ‌ ‌from‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌simple‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌studies‌ ‌how‌ ‌people‌ ‌speak‌ ‌differently‌ ‌in‌ ‌social‌ ‌contexts.‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌covers‌ ‌regional‌ ‌dialect,‌ ‌secret‌ ‌language,‌ ‌magical‌ ‌language‌ ‌and‌ ‌folktales.‌ ‌\n●Metalinguistics:‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌studies‌ ‌the‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌and‌ ‌functions‌ ‌of‌ ‌language‌ ‌and‌ ‌how‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌behavior.‌ ‌\n ‌\nThe‌ ‌relevance‌ ‌of‌ ‌Linguistic‌ ‌Anthropology:‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌helps‌ ‌in‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌the‌ ‌continuity‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌insights‌ ‌into‌ ‌the‌ ‌culture‌ ‌of‌ ‌simple‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌also‌ ‌helps‌ ‌to‌ ‌explain‌ ‌the‌ ‌structure‌ ‌of‌ ‌society,‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌status‌ ‌of‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌in‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n●Contemporary‌ ‌linguistic‌ ‌tries‌ ‌to‌ ‌understand‌ ‌the‌ ‌historical‌ ‌linkages‌ ‌and‌ ‌tries‌ ‌to‌ ‌divide‌ ‌script‌ ‌to‌ ‌language‌ ‌without‌ ‌having‌ ‌one‌ ‌it‌ ‌helps‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nestablishing‌ ‌contract‌ ‌with‌ ‌alien‌ ‌and‌ ‌foreign‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌in‌ ‌devising‌ ‌content‌ ‌and‌ ‌curriculum‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌tribal‌ ‌education‌ ‌policies‌ ‌for‌ ‌example‌ ‌\n●Linguistic‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌structural‌ ‌description‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌language‌ ‌might‌ ‌tell‌ ‌us‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌sound‌ ‌p‌ ‌and‌ ‌K‌ ‌are‌ ‌interchangeable‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌word‌ ‌\nwithout‌ ‌causing‌ ‌a‌ ‌difference‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌meaning.‌ ‌\n●American‌ ‌Samoa‌ ‌one‌ ‌could‌ ‌say‌ ‌tutuila‌ ‌or‌ ‌Kukuila‌ ‌the‌ ‌name‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌largest‌ ‌island.‌ ‌\n●Social‌ ‌linguistic‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌address‌ ‌everyone‌ ‌we‌ ‌meet‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌way‌ ‌we‌ ‌say‌ ‌‘Hi’‌ ‌to‌ ‌friends,‌ ‌‘Good‌ ‌Morning’‌ ‌to‌ ‌Doctor‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\nSuch‌ ‌variations‌ ‌are‌ ‌determined‌ ‌by‌ ‌social‌ ‌status.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌Value‌ ‌addition‌ ‌ ‌\nApplied‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌application‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropological‌ ‌data,‌ ‌respective‌ ‌theory‌ ‌and‌ ‌methods‌ ‌to‌ ‌identify,‌ ‌assess‌ ‌and‌ ‌solve‌ ‌social‌ ‌problems.‌ ‌\n●Relevance‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌in‌ ‌contemporary‌ ‌world‌ ‌\n○Archaeological‌ ‌anthropology:‌ ‌\n■Applied‌ ‌archaeologists‌ ‌locate,‌ ‌study‌ ‌and‌ ‌preserve‌ ‌prehistoric‌ ‌and‌ ‌historic‌ ‌sites‌ ‌threatened‌ ‌bi‌ ‌development.‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌is‌ ‌important‌ ‌because‌ ‌we‌ ‌can‌ ‌gain‌ ‌a‌ ‌greater‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌about‌ ‌how‌ ‌humanity‌ ‌has‌ ‌reached‌ ‌its‌ ‌current‌ ‌point.‌ ‌\n○Linguistic‌ ‌anthropologists:‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌finds‌ ‌out‌ ‌how‌ ‌many‌ ‌languages‌ ‌there‌ ‌are,‌ ‌how‌ ‌those‌ ‌languages‌ ‌are‌ ‌distributed‌ ‌across‌ ‌the‌ ‌world‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌contemporary‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nhistorical‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌different‌ ‌areas‌ ‌of‌ ‌language.‌ ‌Scientists‌ ‌try‌ ‌to‌ ‌find‌ ‌a‌ ‌deeper‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌of‌ ‌our‌ ‌past‌ ‌and‌ ‌\npresent.‌ ‌\n■Linguistic‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌frequently‌ ‌works‌ ‌with‌ ‌schools‌ ‌in‌ ‌districts‌ ‌with‌ ‌multiple‌ ‌languages‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌tribals.‌ ‌\n○Biological‌ ‌anthropology:‌ ‌\n17‌ ‌\n■Biological‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌work‌ ‌in‌ ‌public‌ ‌health‌ ‌nutrition,‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌counseling,‌ ‌substance‌ ‌abuse,‌ ‌aging,‌ ‌mental‌ ‌illness,‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nforensic.‌ ‌\n■To‌ ‌understand‌ ‌how‌ ‌organisms‌ ‌that‌ ‌survived‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌harsh‌ ‌climate‌ ‌of‌ ‌arctic‌ ‌using‌ ‌clever‌ ‌behavioral‌ ‌adaptation‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌\nbiological‌ ‌adaptation‌ ‌another‌ ‌example,‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌presence‌ ‌of‌ ‌strange‌ ‌disease‌ ‌in‌ ‌New‌ ‌Guinea,‌ ‌native‌ ‌people‌ ‌led‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌discovery‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌whole‌ ‌new‌ ‌class‌ ‌of‌ ‌infectious‌ ‌organism‌ ‌and‌ ‌also‌ ‌won‌ ‌its‌ ‌Discover‌ ‌Dr‌ ‌Carlton‌ ‌the‌ ‌Nobel‌ ‌Prize(His‌ ‌identification‌ ‌and‌ ‌\ndescription‌ ‌of‌ ‌kuru,‌ ‌the‌ ‌exotic‌ ‌disease‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌remote‌ ‌tribe‌ ‌in‌ ‌New‌ ‌Guinea‌ ‌that‌ ‌was‌ ‌caused‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌family‌ ‌of‌ ‌mysterious‌ ‌agents‌ ‌\ncalled‌ ‌prions)‌ ‌\n●Major‌ ‌area‌ ‌of‌ ‌focus‌ ‌:‌ ‌\n○Education‌ ‌\n○Health‌ ‌care‌ ‌and‌ ‌family‌ ‌planning‌ ‌\n○Community‌ ‌development‌ ‌programme‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌criminology‌ ‌and‌ ‌crime‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌\n○Industrial‌ ‌and‌ ‌Auburn‌ ‌problem‌ ‌solving‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌example:‌ ‌During‌ ‌WW2‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌worked‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌US‌ ‌government‌ ‌to‌ ‌study‌ ‌the‌ ‌Japanese‌ ‌and‌ ‌German‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nAction‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌\n●Sol‌ ‌Tax,‌ ‌an‌ ‌American‌ ‌anthropologist,‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌to‌ ‌use‌ ‌the‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌action‌ ‌anthropology.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌action‌ ‌Anthropologist‌ ‌involves‌ ‌themselves‌ ‌ultimately‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌social‌ ‌problem‌ ‌and‌ ‌perceives‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌context‌ ‌of‌ ‌action‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌\naccept‌ ‌the‌ ‌problem‌ ‌as‌ ‌their‌ ‌own‌ ‌and‌ ‌process‌ ‌through‌ ‌trial‌ ‌and‌ ‌error‌ ‌methods.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Action‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌is‌ ‌wholly‌ ‌clinical‌ ‌or‌ ‌experimental‌ ‌action‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌seldom‌ ‌keep‌ ‌themselves‌ ‌as‌ ‌mere‌ ‌observers;‌ ‌they‌ ‌\nrecognise‌ ‌their‌ ‌own‌ ‌responsibility‌ ‌in‌ ‌solving‌ ‌human‌ ‌problems‌ ‌therefore‌ ‌they‌ ‌stick‌ ‌onto‌ ‌the‌ ‌problem‌ ‌and‌ ‌until‌ ‌the‌ ‌problem‌ ‌is‌ ‌solved.‌ ‌\n●Action‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌may‌ ‌generate‌ ‌new‌ ‌theories‌ ‌and‌ ‌findings‌ ‌acceptable‌ ‌to‌ ‌general‌ ‌anthropology.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nDiagrams‌ ‌\nRefer‌ ‌PPT‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n18‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n1.4‌ ‌(a)‌ ‌Human‌ ‌Evolution‌ ‌and‌ ‌Emergence‌ ‌of‌ ‌Man:‌ ‌\n(a)‌ ‌Biological‌ ‌and‌ ‌Cultural‌ ‌factors‌ ‌in‌ ‌Human‌ ‌Evolution.‌ ‌\n(b)‌ ‌Theories‌ ‌of‌ ‌Organic‌ ‌Evolution‌ ‌(Pre-Darwinian,‌ ‌Darwinian‌ ‌and‌ ‌Post-Darwinian).‌ ‌\n(c)‌ ‌Synthetic‌ ‌theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌evolution;‌ ‌Brief‌ ‌outline‌ ‌of‌ ‌terms‌ ‌and‌ ‌concepts‌ ‌of‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌biology‌ ‌(Doll’s‌ ‌rule,‌ ‌Cope’s‌ ‌rule,‌ ‌Gause’s‌ ‌rule,‌ ‌\nparallelism,‌ ‌convergence,‌ ‌adaptive‌ ‌radiation,‌ ‌and‌ ‌mosaic‌ ‌evolution).‌ ‌\n ‌\na)Biological‌ ‌and‌ ‌Cultural‌ ‌factors‌ ‌in‌ ‌Human‌ ‌Evolution.‌ ‌\n ‌\nBiological‌ ‌Evolution‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌population‌ ‌level‌ ‌process‌ ‌guided‌ ‌in‌ ‌large‌ ‌part‌ ‌by‌ ‌selection‌ ‌and‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌random‌ ‌process‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌small‌ ‌population.‌ ‌\n●Also‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌biological‌ ‌world‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌two‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌selection‌ ‌targeted‌ ‌at‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌and‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌differences‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌genes.‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌selections‌ ‌are‌ ‌called‌ ‌natural‌ ‌selection‌ ‌as‌ ‌described‌ ‌by‌ ‌Charles‌ ‌Darwin‌ ‌in‌ ‌1859‌ ‌and‌ ‌sexual‌ ‌selection‌ ‌also‌ ‌described‌ ‌by‌ ‌\nDarwin.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌the‌ ‌theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌the‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌fitness‌ ‌is‌ ‌central.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌general‌ ‌fitness‌ ‌has‌ ‌two‌ ‌component‌ ‌ ‌\n○Survival‌ ‌component‌ ‌and‌ ‌ ‌\n○Productive‌ ‌component‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌addition‌ ‌to‌ ‌this,‌ ‌a‌ ‌third‌ ‌component‌ ‌of‌ ‌fitness‌ ‌is‌ ‌Nursing‌ ‌or‌ ‌Fostering.‌ ‌\n ‌\nHomo‌ ‌sapiens,‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌modern‌ ‌humans,‌ ‌evolved‌ ‌from‌ ‌their‌ ‌early‌ ‌hominid‌ ‌predecessors‌ ‌between‌ ‌200,000‌ ‌and‌ ‌300,000‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago.‌ ‌It‌ ‌\nincludes‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌aspects‌ ‌of‌ ‌structural‌ ‌and‌ ‌behavioral‌ ‌changes‌ ‌that‌ ‌occurred‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌hominid.‌ ‌Finally‌ ‌leading‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌modern‌ ‌man.‌ ‌\n ‌\nThe‌ ‌biological‌ ‌factors‌ ‌are:‌ ‌\ni)‌ ‌‌Erect‌ ‌posture‌ ‌and‌ ‌Bipedal‌ ‌locomotion‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌most‌ ‌obvious‌ ‌thing‌ ‌about‌ ‌human‌ ‌beings‌ ‌that‌ ‌differentiate‌ ‌them‌ ‌from‌ ‌all‌ ‌other‌ ‌animals‌ ‌is‌ ‌upright‌ ‌posture‌ ‌and‌ ‌bipedal‌ ‌\nlocomotion.Many‌ ‌human‌ ‌morphological‌ ‌traits‌ ‌are‌ ‌directly‌ ‌attributed‌ ‌to‌ ‌these‌ ‌two‌ ‌facts‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌life.‌ ‌\n○Some‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌changes‌ ‌are:‌ ‌\n■Enlarging‌ ‌lower‌ ‌vertebra‌ ‌to‌ ‌observe‌ ‌the‌ ‌force‌ ‌of‌ ‌compression.‌ ‌\n19‌ ‌\n■Backward‌ ‌curving‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌spine‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌lumbar‌ ‌region‌ ‌provides‌ ‌a‌ ‌solid‌ ‌platform‌ ‌to‌ ‌transform‌ ‌the‌ ‌weight‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌body‌ ‌into‌ ‌\npelvis.‌ ‌\n■Increases‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌size‌ ‌and‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌bones‌ ‌in‌ ‌sacrum‌ ‌take‌ ‌up‌ ‌transmission‌ ‌of‌ ‌weight‌ ‌through‌ ‌pelvis‌ ‌and‌ ‌legs.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Pelvic‌ ‌region‌ ‌became‌ ‌a‌ ‌basin‌ ‌shaped‌ ‌to‌ ‌support‌ ‌vertical‌ ‌weight‌ ‌transfer.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Ischium,‌ ‌a‌ ‌pelvic‌ ‌bone,‌ ‌flattens,‌ ‌allowing‌ ‌humans‌ ‌to‌ ‌sit‌ ‌comfortably.‌ ‌\n■Human‌ ‌feet‌ ‌are‌ ‌redesigned‌ ‌into‌ ‌a‌ ‌platform‌ ‌to‌ ‌support‌ ‌the‌ ‌entire‌ ‌body‌ ‌weight‌ ‌Rather‌ ‌than‌ ‌grasping‌ ‌structure‌ ‌to‌ ‌get‌ ‌\nreduced‌ ‌and‌ ‌to‌ ‌develop‌ ‌to‌ ‌support‌ ‌body‌ ‌weight.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n■Image‌ ‌Link‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nii)‌ ‌‌Remodeling‌ ‌face‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌teeth‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌major‌ ‌trend‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌development‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌dramatic‌ ‌increase‌ ‌in‌ ‌brain‌ ‌size‌ ‌since‌ ‌the‌ ‌Australopithecus.‌ ‌\n●Since‌ ‌the‌ ‌size‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌head‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌whole‌ ‌should‌ ‌not‌ ‌keep‌ ‌getting‌ ‌larger‌ ‌beyond‌ ‌the‌ ‌limit‌ ‌allowed‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌process‌ ‌of‌ ‌birth‌ ‌there‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nstrong‌ ‌adoptive‌ ‌pressure‌ ‌to‌ ‌shorten‌ ‌them.‌ ‌\n20‌ ‌\n ‌ ‌\nImage‌ ‌Link‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Short‌ ‌and‌ ‌reduce‌ ‌the‌ ‌size‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌face‌ ‌to‌ ‌make‌ ‌room‌ ‌for‌ ‌cranial‌ ‌expansion‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌course‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌evolution.‌ ‌\n○Specific‌ ‌modification‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌face‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌modern‌ ‌man‌ ‌include:‌ ‌\n■Forehead‌ ‌approaches‌ ‌being‌ ‌vertical‌ ‌\n■Chin‌ ‌became‌ ‌prominent,‌ ‌nose‌ ‌became‌ ‌protruding‌ ‌\n■Face‌ ‌is‌ ‌flat‌ ‌ ‌\n■Nasal‌ ‌cavity‌ ‌and‌ ‌palate‌ ‌shortened‌ ‌and‌ ‌arched.‌ ‌\n■Tongue‌ ‌Thickened‌ ‌and‌ ‌shortened.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\niii)‌ ‌‌Expansion‌ ‌and‌ ‌Development‌ ‌of‌ ‌Brain‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌brain‌ ‌grew‌ ‌larger‌ ‌proportionally.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌most‌ ‌likely‌ ‌reason‌ ‌for‌ ‌an‌ ‌increase‌ ‌in‌ ‌both‌ ‌the‌ ‌size‌ ‌and‌ ‌kinds‌ ‌of‌ ‌connection‌ ‌between‌ ‌brain‌ ‌cells‌ ‌i.e‌ ‌responsible‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nemergence‌ ‌of‌ ‌new‌ ‌kinds‌ ‌of‌ ‌mental‌ ‌operations‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌thinking‌ ‌and‌ ‌using‌ ‌language‌ ‌Corporation‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌fundamental‌ ‌to‌ ‌human‌ ‌\nexistence.‌ ‌\n●Increase‌ ‌in‌ ‌size‌ ‌and‌ ‌complexity‌ ‌of‌ ‌cerebral‌ ‌cortex.‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌expansion‌ ‌of‌ ‌cortex‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌recent‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌brain‌ ‌and‌ ‌primarily‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌thinking‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nlanguage.‌ ‌\n●Foramen‌ ‌magnum‌ ‌is‌ ‌now‌ ‌exactly‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌centre‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌skull‌ ‌base.(Human/ape‌ ‌differences‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌position‌ ‌and‌ ‌orientation‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nforamen‌ ‌magnum‌ ‌reflect‌ ‌differences‌ ‌in‌ ‌habitual‌ ‌body‌ ‌posture‌ ‌and‌ ‌mode‌ ‌of‌ ‌locomotion.)‌ ‌\n21‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nCultural‌ ‌Evolution‌ ‌\n●Cultural‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌customs‌ ‌and‌ ‌languages‌ ‌and‌ ‌involves‌ ‌the‌ ‌transfer‌ ‌of‌ ‌information‌ ‌either‌ ‌within‌ ‌a‌ ‌\ngeneration‌ ‌or‌ ‌across‌ ‌many‌ ‌generations.‌ ‌\n●Result‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌has‌ ‌brought‌ ‌changes‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌human‌ ‌species‌ ‌e.g.‌ ‌Food‌ ‌gathering‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌activity‌ ‌had‌ ‌an‌ ‌effect‌ ‌on‌ ‌\nexpansion‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌frontal‌ ‌lobe‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌brain‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n22‌ ‌\n ‌\nImage‌ ‌Link‌ ‌\n ‌\n●After‌ ‌food‌ ‌gathering‌ ‌the‌ ‌next‌ ‌state‌ ‌was‌ ‌hunting‌ ‌which‌ ‌brought‌ ‌about‌ ‌many‌ ‌direct‌ ‌or‌ ‌indirect‌ ‌effects‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌brain‌ ‌and‌ ‌its‌ ‌activity.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Cultural‌ ‌revolution‌ ‌led‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌tools‌ ‌for‌ ‌various‌ ‌purposes‌ ‌advancement‌ ‌in‌ ‌tool‌ ‌making‌ ‌technology‌ ‌and‌ ‌more‌ ‌importantly‌ ‌\npurpose‌ ‌specific‌ ‌tool‌ ‌had‌ ‌input‌ ‌on‌ ‌human‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌\n●Group‌ ‌habitation‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌favourable‌ ‌environment,‌ ‌group‌ ‌living‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌friendship.‌ ‌\n●Big‌ ‌hunting‌ ‌skill‌ ‌leadership‌ ‌in‌ ‌groups‌ ‌leading‌ ‌to‌ ‌political‌ ‌organisations.It‌ ‌provides‌ ‌an‌ ‌explanation‌ ‌for‌ ‌how‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌societies‌ ‌change‌ ‌\nover‌ ‌time‌ ‌and‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌also‌ ‌covers.‌ ‌\n●It's‌ ‌a‌ ‌process‌ ‌that‌ ‌can‌ ‌lead‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌decrease‌ ‌in‌ ‌complexity‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌that‌ ‌can‌ ‌produce‌ ‌variation‌ ‌or‌ ‌proliferation‌ ‌without‌ ‌any‌ ‌seemingly‌ ‌\nsignificant‌ ‌change‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌complexity.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nComparison‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nBiological‌ ‌Evolution‌ ‌\n\t\nCultural‌ ‌Evolution‌ ‌\n23‌ ‌\nTraits‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌transmitted‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌person‌ ‌only‌ ‌from‌ ‌parents‌ ‌\n\t\nTraits‌ ‌transmitted‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌person‌ ‌by‌ ‌many‌ ‌and‌ ‌related‌ ‌people‌ ‌\n\n\nTransmission‌ ‌can‌ ‌only‌ ‌from‌ ‌one‌ ‌generation‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌next‌ ‌\n\t\nTransmission‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌within‌ ‌or‌ ‌between‌ ‌generation‌ ‌and‌ ‌can‌ ‌\nbe‌ ‌widely‌ ‌separated‌ ‌in‌ ‌time‌ ‌and‌ ‌space‌ ‌\n\n\nOccur‌ ‌at‌ ‌a‌ ‌slow‌ ‌pace‌ ‌\n\t\n ‌Occur‌ ‌at‌ ‌a‌ ‌fast‌ ‌pace‌ ‌\n\n\nTraits‌ ‌acquired‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌lifetime‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌be‌ ‌transmitted‌ ‌by‌ ‌\ngenetic‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌\n\t\nCan‌ ‌be‌ ‌transmitted‌ ‌within‌ ‌lifetime‌ ‌via‌ ‌teaching‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nimitation‌ ‌\n\n\nData‌ ‌transmitted‌ ‌is‌ ‌encoded‌ ‌by‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌material(DNA)‌ ‌\n\t\nData‌ ‌transmitted‌ ‌in‌ ‌any‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌written‌ ‌or‌ ‌spoken‌ ‌language‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌addition‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌Human‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌sequence‌ ‌\n ‌\nHomo‌ ‌‌S‌apiens‌ ‌ ‌\n\t\n(S)tudents‌ ‌\n\n\nHomo‌ ‌‌N‌eanderthalensis‌ ‌\n\t\n(N)umber‌ ‌of‌ ‌\n\n\nHomo‌ ‌‌E‌rectus‌ ‌\n\t\n(E)nough‌ ‌\n\n\nHomo‌ ‌‌H‌abilis‌ ‌\n\t\n(H)as‌ ‌\n\n\nA‌ustralopithecus‌ ‌\n\t\n(A)merica‌ ‌\n\n\nR‌amapithecus‌ ‌\n\t\n(R)emember‌ ‌\n\n\nD‌ryopithecus‌ ‌\n\t\n(D)o‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n24‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n25‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n1.4‌ ‌(b)‌ ‌Human‌ ‌Evolution‌ ‌and‌ ‌Emergence‌ ‌of‌ ‌Man‌ ‌\n ‌\n(a)‌ ‌Biological‌ ‌and‌ ‌Cultural‌ ‌factors‌ ‌in‌ ‌Human‌ ‌Evolution.‌ ‌\n(b)‌ ‌Theories‌ ‌of‌ ‌Organic‌ ‌Evolution‌ ‌(Pre-Darwinian,‌ ‌Darwinian‌ ‌and‌ ‌Post-Darwinian).‌ ‌\n26‌ ‌\n(c)‌ ‌Synthetic‌ ‌theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌evolution;‌ ‌Brief‌ ‌outline‌ ‌of‌ ‌terms‌ ‌and‌ ‌concepts‌ ‌of‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌biology‌ ‌(Doll’s‌ ‌rule,‌ ‌Cope’s‌ ‌rule,‌ ‌Gause’s‌ ‌rule,‌ ‌\nparallelism,‌ ‌convergence,‌ ‌adaptive‌ ‌radiation,‌ ‌and‌ ‌mosaic‌ ‌evolution).‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n(b)‌ ‌Theories‌ ‌of‌ ‌Organic‌ ‌Evolution‌ ‌(Pre-Darwinian,‌ ‌Darwinian‌ ‌and‌ ‌Post-Darwinian)‌ ‌\n ‌\nOrganic‌ ‌evolution:‌‌ ‌The‌ ‌changes‌ ‌that‌ ‌have‌ ‌taken‌ ‌place‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌living‌ ‌things‌ ‌viz‌ ‌plants‌ ‌and‌ ‌animals.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nPre-Darwinism‌ ‌\n ‌\nLamarckism‌ ‌(Theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌of‌ ‌acquired‌ ‌character)‌ ‌\n●“Modification‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌organism‌ ‌acquired‌ ‌is‌ ‌adaptation‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌environment‌ ‌which‌ ‌it‌ ‌made‌ ‌during‌ ‌its‌ ‌lifetime‌ ‌automatically‌ ‌handed‌ ‌down‌ ‌to‌ ‌its‌ ‌\ndescendant‌ ‌and‌ ‌so‌ ‌become‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌hereditary”.‌ ‌\n ‌\nAssumption‌ ‌\n● ‌Organism‌ ‌evolved‌ ‌from‌ ‌simple‌ ‌to‌ ‌complex‌ ‌\n27‌ ‌\n● ‌The‌ ‌changes‌ ‌in‌ ‌environment‌ ‌places‌ ‌demand‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌organism‌ ‌for‌ ‌adjustment.‌ ‌The‌ ‌new‌ ‌organ‌ ‌resulted‌ ‌from‌ ‌that‌ ‌demand.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌The‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌Jean‌ ‌Baptiste‌ ‌Lamarck‌ ‌was‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌principle‌ ‌of:‌ ‌\n● ‌Principle‌ ‌of‌ ‌use‌ ‌and‌ ‌disuse:‌ ‌\n○ ‌For‌ ‌an‌ ‌organism,‌ ‌new‌ ‌structures‌ ‌appeared‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌course‌ ‌of‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌because‌ ‌they‌ ‌were‌ ‌needed.‌ ‌\n○ ‌Structures‌ ‌that‌ ‌were‌ ‌present‌ ‌and‌ ‌were‌ ‌used‌ ‌become‌ ‌better‌ ‌developed‌ ‌and‌ ‌increased‌ ‌in‌ ‌size.‌ ‌\n○ ‌Structures‌ ‌that‌ ‌we‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌use‌ ‌decreased‌ ‌in‌ ‌size‌ ‌and‌ ‌eventually‌ ‌disappeared.‌ ‌\n○E.g.‌ ‌Human‌ ‌appendix‌ ‌and‌ ‌little‌ ‌toes‌ ‌are‌ ‌gradually‌ ‌disappearing‌ ‌\n● ‌Inheritance‌ ‌of‌ ‌acquired‌ ‌trait:‌ ‌\n○Useful‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌acquired‌ ‌by‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌during‌ ‌its‌ ‌lifetime‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌transmitted‌ ‌to‌ ‌its‌ ‌offspring.‌ ‌\n○Acquired‌ ‌traits‌ ‌result‌ ‌in‌ ‌species‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌better‌ ‌adapted‌ ‌to‌ ‌their‌ ‌environment.‌ ‌\n○Example:‌ ‌\n■Giraffe‌ ‌necks‌ ‌become‌ ‌longer‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌result‌ ‌of‌ ‌structure‌ ‌into‌ ‌higher‌ ‌branches;‌ ‌this‌ ‌acquired‌ ‌trait‌ ‌was‌ ‌passed‌ ‌on‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌offspring.‌ ‌\n■Development‌ ‌of‌ ‌web‌ ‌feet‌ ‌in‌ ‌aquatic‌ ‌Birds‌ ‌like‌ ‌ducks.‌ ‌They‌ ‌are‌ ‌considered‌ ‌to‌ ‌have‌ ‌arisen‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌terrestrial‌ ‌and‌ ‌ancestors.‌ ‌\n■Development‌ ‌of‌ ‌speed‌ ‌in‌ ‌dear‌ ‌through‌ ‌continuous‌ ‌effort‌ ‌of‌ ‌running‌ ‌in‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌protect‌ ‌itself‌ ‌from‌ ‌enemies.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n28‌ ‌\nValue‌ ‌addition‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌Significance‌ ‌of‌ ‌Lamarckism:‌ ‌\n●Though,‌ ‌theory‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌rejected‌ ‌on‌ ‌scientific‌ ‌grounds.‌ ‌\n●But‌ ‌still‌ ‌his‌ ‌pioneering‌ ‌work‌ ‌deserves‌ ‌a‌ ‌lot‌ ‌of‌ ‌appreciation‌ ‌because‌ ‌this‌ ‌theory‌ ‌established‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌time‌ ‌that‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌biological‌ ‌fact.‌ ‌\n●Rejecting‌ ‌theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌origin‌ ‌of‌ ‌man‌ ‌in‌ ‌religious‌ ‌terms.‌ ‌\n ‌\nCritical‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌of‌ ‌Lamarck's‌ ‌proposition:‌ ‌\n●August‌ ‌Weisman‌ ‌did‌ ‌not‌ ‌agree‌ ‌with‌ ‌Lamarck's‌ ‌theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌acquired‌ ‌traits.‌ ‌In‌ ‌a‌ ‌series‌ ‌of‌ ‌experiments‌ ‌he‌ ‌removed‌ ‌the‌ ‌tail‌ ‌of‌ ‌mice‌ ‌.‌ ‌The‌ ‌mating‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌the‌ ‌tailless‌ ‌mice‌ ‌offspring‌ ‌produced‌ ‌mice‌ ‌with‌ ‌normal‌ ‌length‌ ‌tails.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌principle‌ ‌of‌ ‌use‌ ‌and‌ ‌disuse‌ ‌is‌ ‌true‌ ‌to‌ ‌certain‌ ‌extent.‌ ‌The‌ ‌organ‌ ‌will‌ ‌develop‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌use‌ ‌and‌ ‌degenerate‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌disuse‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌correct‌ ‌as‌ ‌\nfar‌ ‌as‌ ‌growth‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌organism‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌lifetime‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌is‌ ‌concerned.‌ ‌\n ‌\nDarwin‌ ‌Theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌Evolution‌ ‌ ‌\nHe‌ ‌presented‌ ‌the‌ ‌logical‌ ‌theory‌ ‌regarding‌ ‌the‌ ‌major‌ ‌mechanism‌ ‌of‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌and‌ ‌natural‌ ‌selection‌ ‌\n●‘Theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌evolution’‌ ‌by‌ ‌Natural‌ ‌Selection.‌ ‌\n●‘The‌ ‌origin‌ ‌of‌ ‌species’‌ ‌by‌ ‌Natural‌ ‌Selection‌ ‌\n29‌ ‌\n●‘The‌ ‌preservation‌ ‌of‌ ‌favoured‌ ‌race’‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌struggle‌ ‌for‌ ‌life.‌ ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌addition‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌Propositions‌ ‌\n●Variation‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌characteristic‌ ‌of‌ ‌every‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌animal‌ ‌and‌ ‌plants‌ ‌and‌ ‌that's‌ ‌why‌ ‌organisms‌ ‌may‌ ‌differ‌ ‌in‌ ‌many‌ ‌ways.‌ ‌\n●There‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌natural‌ ‌tendency‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌organism‌ ‌to‌ ‌reproduce‌ ‌more‌ ‌and‌ ‌more‌ ‌but‌ ‌remained‌ ‌stable‌ ‌under‌ ‌natural‌ ‌conditions‌ ‌\n●There‌ ‌would‌ ‌be‌ ‌struggle‌ ‌for‌ ‌existence‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌organism‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌struggle‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌intraspecies‌ ‌inter‌ ‌species‌ ‌or‌ ‌against‌ ‌nature‌ ‌\n●Survival‌ ‌of‌ ‌fittest‌-Core‌ ‌theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌natural‌ ‌selection.‌ ‌ ‌\n○ ‌Survival‌ ‌of‌ ‌only‌ ‌those‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌satisfactory‌ ‌adopted‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌get‌ ‌eliminated‌ ‌\n●Inheritance‌ ‌of‌ ‌variations-‌The‌ ‌operation‌ ‌of‌ ‌natural‌ ‌selection‌ ‌over‌ ‌many‌ ‌generations‌ ‌may‌ ‌produce‌ ‌descendants‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌quite‌ ‌different‌ ‌\nfrom‌ ‌the‌ ‌ancestor,‌ ‌different‌ ‌enough‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌a‌ ‌separate‌ ‌species.‌ ‌\n●Examples:‌ ‌\n○Peacock‌ ‌females‌ ‌pick‌ ‌their‌ ‌mate‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌males‌ ‌tail.The‌ ‌one‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌largest‌ ‌and‌ ‌brightest‌ ‌tail‌ ‌made‌ ‌more‌ ‌of‌ ‌the.‌ ‌Today‌ ‌\npeacock‌ ‌male‌ ‌that‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌have‌ ‌bright‌ ‌feathers‌ ‌are‌ ‌very‌ ‌rare.‌ ‌\n○Galapagos‌ ‌finches‌ ‌all‌ ‌have‌ ‌different‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌beaks.‌ ‌During‌ ‌drought‌ ‌the‌ ‌finches‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌largest‌ ‌beak‌ ‌survived‌ ‌better‌ ‌than‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nsmaller‌ ‌beaks.‌ ‌During‌ ‌rainy‌ ‌Times‌ ‌more‌ ‌small‌ ‌seeds‌ ‌were‌ ‌produced‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌finches‌ ‌with‌ ‌smaller‌ ‌beaks‌ ‌fared‌ ‌better.The‌ ‌finches‌ ‌had‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌adapt‌ ‌to‌ ‌their‌ ‌new‌ ‌environments‌ ‌and‌ ‌food‌ ‌sources.‌ ‌They‌ ‌gradually‌ ‌evolved‌ ‌into‌ ‌different‌ ‌species.‌ ‌\n ‌\nDemerits‌ ‌of‌ ‌Darwinism:‌ ‌ ‌\n●Over‌ ‌emphasis‌ ‌on‌ ‌natural‌ ‌selection,‌ ‌ignoring‌ ‌the‌ ‌role‌ ‌of‌ ‌other‌ ‌factors‌ ‌like‌ ‌mutation,‌ ‌variation,‌ ‌isolation‌ ‌and‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌drift.‌ ‌\n30‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌did‌ ‌not‌ ‌explain‌ ‌the‌ ‌origin‌ ‌and‌ ‌transmission‌ ‌of‌ ‌variations.‌ ‌His‌ ‌Penguin‌ ‌hypothesis‌ ‌proved‌ ‌wrong‌ ‌against‌ ‌knowledge‌ ‌of‌ ‌genetics.‌ ‌\n●His‌ ‌theory‌ ‌did‌ ‌not‌ ‌explain‌ ‌the‌ ‌phenomena‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌degeneracy‌ ‌\n●Over-specialisation‌ ‌by‌ ‌certain‌ ‌organisms‌ ‌was‌ ‌not‌ ‌explained‌ ‌by‌ ‌Darwin.‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌did‌ ‌not‌ ‌explain‌ ‌the‌ ‌cause‌ ‌of‌ ‌variations‌ ‌and‌ ‌did‌ ‌not‌ ‌specify‌ ‌the‌ ‌significance‌ ‌of‌ ‌macro‌ ‌variations.‌ ‌\n ‌\nPost-Darwinian‌ ‌\nDarwin's‌ ‌explanation‌ ‌of‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌by‌ ‌natural‌ ‌selection‌ ‌followed‌ ‌by‌ ‌various‌ ‌theories‌ ‌where‌ ‌other‌ ‌forces‌ ‌of‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌given.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌isolation:‌  ‌ ‌\n○Proposed‌ ‌by‌ ‌‌Wagner‌,‌ ‌which‌ ‌says‌ ‌the‌ ‌two‌ ‌or‌ ‌more‌ ‌population‌ ‌of‌ ‌same‌ ‌species‌ ‌get‌ ‌separated‌ ‌because‌ ‌of‌ ‌some‌ ‌physical‌ ‌or‌ ‌\ngeographical‌ ‌various‌ ‌or‌ ‌they‌ ‌may‌ ‌occupy‌ ‌different‌ ‌areas‌ ‌natural‌ ‌selections‌ ‌thus,‌ ‌occur‌ ‌independently‌ ‌in‌ ‌each‌ ‌segregating‌ ‌population‌ ‌\n●Theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌mutation:‌ ‌\n○Hugo‌ ‌De‌ ‌vries‌ ‌stated‌ ‌that‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌preceded‌ ‌by‌ ‌large,‌ ‌discrete‌ ‌and‌ ‌certain‌ ‌changes‌ ‌or‌ ‌variations‌ ‌called‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌These‌ ‌mutations‌ ‌\nare‌ ‌inheritable‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌progeny.‌ ‌\n○Mutation‌ ‌may‌ ‌occur‌ ‌in‌ ‌any‌ ‌direction,nature‌ ‌selects‌ ‌those‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌suitable‌ ‌for‌ ‌survival‌ ‌and‌ ‌continuity.Other‌ ‌on‌ ‌suitable‌ ‌mutants‌ ‌are‌ ‌\neliminated‌ ‌by‌ ‌nature.‌ ‌\n○Genetics‌ ‌have‌ ‌shown‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌origin‌ ‌of‌ ‌species‌ ‌by‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌is‌ ‌common‌ ‌not‌ ‌only‌ ‌among‌ ‌plants‌ ‌but‌ ‌also‌ ‌among‌ ‌animals.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n● ‌Theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌continuity‌ ‌of‌ ‌germplasm:‌ ‌\n○Weisman‌ ‌proposed‌ ‌that‌ ‌somatoplasm‌ ‌makeup‌ ‌all‌ ‌body‌ ‌organs‌ ‌except‌ ‌reproductive‌ ‌cells‌ ‌and‌ ‌formation‌ ‌of‌ ‌complex‌ ‌organs‌ ‌during‌ ‌\nwhich‌ ‌they‌ ‌lose‌ ‌capacity‌ ‌to‌ ‌reproduce.‌ ‌ ‌\n■A‌ ‌somatic‌ ‌cell‌ ‌is‌ ‌any‌ ‌cell‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌body‌ ‌except‌ ‌sperm‌ ‌and‌ ‌egg‌ ‌cells.‌ ‌\n○Germplasm‌ ‌remains‌ ‌undifferentiated‌ ‌and‌ ‌retains‌ ‌its‌ ‌power‌ ‌to‌ ‌generate‌ ‌new‌ ‌life.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Germ‌ ‌cells‌ ‌are‌ ‌cells‌ ‌that‌ ‌create‌ ‌reproductive‌ ‌cells‌ ‌called‌ ‌gametes.‌ ‌\n○Thus,‌ ‌changes‌ ‌in‌ ‌somatoplasm‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌transmitted‌ ‌but‌ ‌those‌ ‌in‌ ‌germplasm‌ ‌are‌ ‌transmitted‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌next‌ ‌generation.‌ ‌\n31‌ ‌\n■Example:‌‌ ‌Wrestler‌ ‌children‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌inherit‌ ‌muscle‌ ‌from‌ ‌father/‌ ‌mother.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Rediscovery‌ ‌of‌ ‌Mendel’s‌ ‌Law‌ ‌of‌ ‌Heredity‌ ‌\n ‌\nMendel’s‌ ‌principles‌ ‌of‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌\n●Mendel‌ ‌worked‌ ‌on‌ ‌pea‌ ‌plants,‌ ‌but‌ ‌his‌ ‌principles‌ ‌apply‌ ‌to‌ ‌traits‌ ‌in‌ ‌plants‌ ‌and‌ ‌animals‌ ‌–‌ ‌they‌ ‌can‌ ‌explain‌ ‌how‌ ‌we‌ ‌inherit‌ ‌our‌ ‌eye‌ ‌\ncolour,‌ ‌hair‌ ‌colour‌ ‌and‌ ‌even‌ ‌tongue-rolling‌ ‌ability.‌ ‌\n●Fundamental‌ ‌theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌heredity‌ ‌\n○Inheritance‌ ‌involves‌ ‌the‌ ‌passing‌ ‌of‌ ‌discrete‌ ‌units‌ ‌of‌ ‌inheritance,‌ ‌or‌ ‌genes,‌ ‌from‌ ‌parents‌ ‌to‌ ‌offspring.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n32‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Principle‌ ‌of‌ ‌segregation‌ ‌\n○During‌ ‌reproduction,‌ ‌‌the‌ ‌inherited‌ ‌factors‌ ‌‌(now‌ ‌called‌ ‌alleles)‌ ‌that‌ ‌determine‌ ‌traits‌ ‌are‌ ‌separated‌ ‌into‌ ‌reproductive‌ ‌cells‌ ‌by‌ ‌\na‌ ‌process‌ ‌called‌ ‌meiosis‌ ‌and‌ ‌‌randomly‌ ‌reunite‌ ‌during‌ ‌fertilisation.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n33‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Principle‌ ‌of‌ ‌independent‌ ‌assortment‌ ‌\n○Genes‌ ‌located‌ ‌on‌ ‌different‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌will‌ ‌be‌ ‌inherited‌ ‌independently‌ ‌of‌ ‌each‌ ‌other.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○Mendel's‌ ‌work‌ ‌was‌ ‌unappreciated‌ ‌and‌ ‌remained‌ ‌dormant‌ ‌for‌ ‌34‌ ‌years‌ ‌.‌ ‌Even‌ ‌Darwin's‌ ‌theories‌ ‌were‌ ‌viewed‌ ‌with‌ ‌\n○skepticism‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌late‌ ‌1800's‌ ‌because‌ ‌he‌ ‌could‌ ‌not‌ ‌explain‌ ‌the‌ ‌mode‌ ‌of‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌of‌ ‌variation.‌ ‌‌In‌ ‌1900,‌ ‌16‌ ‌years‌ ‌after‌ ‌Mendel‌ ‌died,‌ ‌\nfour‌ ‌scientists‌ ‌rediscovered‌ ‌and‌ ‌acknowledged‌ ‌Mendel's‌ ‌work,‌ ‌giving‌ ‌birth‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌science‌ ‌of‌ ‌genetics.‌ ‌\n○DeVries,‌ ‌Correns‌ ‌and‌ ‌Tschermak‌ ‌independently‌ ‌rediscover‌ ‌Mendel's‌ ‌work.‌ ‌The‌ ‌three‌ ‌Europeans,‌ ‌unknown‌ ‌to‌ ‌each‌ ‌other,‌ ‌were‌ ‌\nworking‌ ‌on‌ ‌different‌ ‌plant‌ ‌hybrids‌ ‌when‌ ‌they‌ ‌each‌ ‌worked‌ ‌out‌ ‌the‌ ‌laws‌ ‌of‌ ‌inheritance.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌factor‌ ‌given‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌offspring‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌parents‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌mix‌ ‌but‌ ‌segregates.‌ ‌\n○If‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌one‌ ‌pair‌ ‌of‌ ‌contrasting‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌is‌ ‌considered‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌process‌ ‌the‌ ‌factor‌ ‌responsible‌ ‌for‌ ‌these‌ ‌are‌ ‌inherited‌ ‌\nindependently.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌Addition:‌ ‌\n34‌ ‌\nDarwinism‌ ‌vs‌ ‌Lamarckism‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n35‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nImage‌ ‌Link‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n36‌ ‌\n1.4‌ ‌(c)‌ ‌Synthetic‌ ‌Theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌Evolution;‌ ‌Part-I‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nSynthetic‌ ‌Theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌Evolution‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Modern‌ ‌Synthetic‌ ‌Theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌Evolution‌ ‌describes‌ ‌the‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌life‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌changes‌ ‌occurring‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌population‌ ‌that‌ ‌leads‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌formation‌ ‌of‌ ‌new‌ ‌species.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌also‌ ‌describes‌ ‌the‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌population‌ ‌or‌ ‌‌mendelian‌ ‌population,‌ ‌gene‌ ‌pool‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌gene‌ ‌frequency‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌need‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌theory‌ ‌arose‌ ‌as‌ ‌Darwinism‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌satisfactorily‌ ‌explain‌ ‌the‌ ‌origin‌ ‌and‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌of‌ ‌variation.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌synthetic‌ ‌theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌describes‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌merging‌ ‌of‌ ‌Darwinian‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌with‌ ‌Mendelian‌ ‌genetics‌ ‌‌resulting‌ ‌into‌ ‌a‌ ‌unified‌ ‌theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nevolution.‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌theory‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Neo-Darwinian‌ ‌theory‌,‌ ‌and‌ ‌was‌ ‌introduced‌ ‌to‌ ‌us‌ ‌by‌ ‌few‌ ‌legendary‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌biologists‌ ‌naming‌ ‌‌T.‌ ‌\nDobzhansky,‌ ‌J.B.S.‌ ‌Haldane,‌ ‌R.A.‌ ‌Fisher,‌ ‌Sewall‌ ‌Wright,‌ ‌G.L.‌ ‌Stebbins,‌ ‌Ernst‌ ‌Mayr‌‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌years‌ ‌1930‌ ‌and‌ ‌1940.‌ ‌\nValue‌ ‌Addition‌ ‌\n37‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nFactors‌ ‌of‌ ‌Modern‌ ‌Synthetic‌ ‌Theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌Evolution‌ ‌\nThere‌ ‌are‌ ‌some‌ ‌factors‌ ‌describing‌ ‌the‌ ‌modern‌ ‌theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌synthetic‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌as‌ ‌explained‌ ‌below:‌ ‌\n(In‌ ‌addition‌ ‌to‌ ‌these,‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌factors‌ ‌include,‌ ‌migration,‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌variability‌ ‌etc.)‌ ‌\n ‌ ‌\n ‌\n1.Recombination‌ ‌or‌ ‌Variation‌ ‌\n○Recombination‌ ‌that‌ ‌is,‌ ‌new‌ ‌genotypes‌ ‌from‌ ‌already‌ ‌existing‌ ‌genesis‌ ‌of‌ ‌several‌ ‌types‌ ‌:‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌production‌ ‌of‌ ‌gene‌ ‌combinations‌ ‌containing‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌indi­vidual‌ ‌two‌ ‌different‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌gene,‌ ‌or‌ ‌the‌ ‌production‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌heterozygous‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌(meiosis);‌ ‌ ‌\n38‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nConnecting‌ ‌Dots:‌ ‌\n ‌\nA‌ ‌gene‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌unit‌ ‌of‌ ‌hereditary‌ ‌information.‌ ‌Except‌ ‌in‌ ‌some‌ ‌viruses,‌ ‌genes‌ ‌are‌ ‌made‌ ‌up‌ ‌of‌ ‌DNA,‌ ‌a‌ ‌complex‌ ‌molecule‌ ‌that‌ ‌codes‌ ‌\ngenetic‌ ‌information‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌transmission‌ ‌of‌ ‌inherited‌ ‌traits.‌ ‌ ‌\nAlleles‌ ‌are‌ ‌also‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌sequences,‌ ‌and‌ ‌they‌ ‌too‌ ‌code‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌transmission‌ ‌of‌ ‌traits.‌ ‌ ‌\nSo,‌ ‌what‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌difference‌ ‌between‌ ‌a‌ ‌gene‌ ‌and‌ ‌an‌ ‌allele?‌ ‌\n ‌\nAn‌ ‌allele‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌variant‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌gene.‌ ‌Explained‌ ‌in‌ ‌greater‌ ‌detail,‌ ‌each‌ ‌gene‌ ‌resides‌ ‌at‌ ‌a‌ ‌specific‌ ‌locus‌ ‌(location‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌chromosome)‌ ‌\nin‌ ‌two‌ ‌copies,‌ ‌one‌ ‌copy‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌gene‌ ‌inherited‌ ‌from‌ ‌each‌ ‌parent.‌ ‌The‌ ‌copies,‌ ‌however,‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌necessarily‌ ‌the‌ ‌same.‌ ‌When‌ ‌the‌ ‌\ncopies‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌gene‌ ‌differ‌ ‌from‌ ‌each‌ ‌other,‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌alleles.‌ ‌A‌ ‌given‌ ‌gene‌ ‌may‌ ‌have‌ ‌multiple‌ ‌different‌ ‌alleles,‌ ‌though‌ ‌only‌ ‌\ntwo‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌are‌ ‌present‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌gene’s‌ ‌locus‌ ‌in‌ ‌any‌ ‌individual.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nImage‌ ‌Link‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌random‌ ‌mixing‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌from‌ ‌two‌ ‌parents‌ ‌during‌ ‌sexual‌ ‌reproduc­tion‌ ‌to‌ ‌produce‌ ‌a‌ ‌new‌ ‌individual;‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌between‌ ‌chromosomal‌ ‌pairs‌ ‌of‌ ‌particular‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌during‌ ‌meiosis,‌ ‌called‌ ‌crossing‌ ‌over,‌ ‌to‌ ‌produce‌ ‌new‌ ‌gene‌ ‌\ncombinations.‌ ‌\nChromosomal‌ ‌mutations‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌deletion,‌ ‌duplication,‌ ‌inversion,‌ ‌translocation‌ ‌and‌ ‌polyploidy‌ ‌also‌ ‌result‌ ‌in‌ ‌variation.‌ ‌\n2.Mutation‌ ‌\n○Alteration‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌chemistry‌ ‌of‌ ‌genes‌ ‌(DNA)‌ ‌is‌ ‌able‌ ‌to‌ ‌change‌ ‌its‌ ‌phenotypic(observable‌ ‌physical‌ ‌properties)‌ ‌effect;‌ ‌this‌ ‌is‌ ‌called‌ ‌point‌ ‌\nmutation‌ ‌or‌ ‌gene‌ ‌mutation.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Mutation‌ ‌can‌ ‌produce‌ ‌drastic‌ ‌changes‌ ‌which‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌deleterious‌ ‌or‌ ‌harmful‌ ‌and‌ ‌lethal‌ ‌or‌ ‌can‌ ‌remain‌ ‌insignificant.‌ ‌\n39‌ ‌\n○There‌ ‌are‌ ‌equal‌ ‌chances‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌gene‌ ‌to‌ ‌mutate‌ ‌back‌ ‌to‌ ‌normal.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Most‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌mutant‌ ‌genes‌ ‌are‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌to‌ ‌normal‌ ‌genes‌ ‌and‌ ‌these‌ ‌are‌ ‌able‌ ‌to‌ ‌express‌ ‌phenotypically‌ ‌only‌ ‌in‌ ‌homozygous‌ ‌\nconditions.‌ ‌Thus,‌ ‌gene‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌tends‌ ‌to‌ ‌produce‌ ‌variations‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌offspring.‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌example:‌ ‌Sickle‌ ‌cell‌ ‌anemia.‌ ‌\n ‌\n‌Image‌ ‌Link‌ ‌\n ‌\n40‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n3.Heredity‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌transmission‌ ‌occurring‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌variations‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌parents‌ ‌to‌ ‌their‌ ‌offsprings‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌primary‌ ‌mechanism‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌evolution.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌organisms‌ ‌which‌ ‌possess‌ ‌hereditary‌ ‌properties‌ ‌are‌ ‌favoured‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌struggle‌ ‌for‌ ‌existence.‌ ‌ ‌\n○By‌ ‌this,‌ ‌the‌ ‌offspring‌ ‌benefit‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌parents.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nImage‌ ‌Link‌ ‌\n ‌\n4.Natural‌ ‌selection‌ ‌\n○Natural‌ ‌selection‌ ‌produces‌ ‌a‌ ‌change‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌genes‌ ‌from‌ ‌one‌ ‌generation‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌favouring‌ ‌the‌ ‌differential‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌reproduction.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌natural‌ ‌selection‌ ‌process‌ ‌creates‌ ‌an‌ ‌adaptive‌ ‌relation‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌environment‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌population‌ ‌through‌ ‌various‌ ‌\ncombinations‌ ‌of‌ ‌genes.‌ ‌\nExample:‌‌ ‌Natural‌ ‌Selection‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌Peppered‌ ‌Moth‌ ‌\n41‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nImage‌ ‌Link‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n5.Isolation‌ ‌\n○Isolation‌ ‌of‌ ‌organisms‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌species‌ ‌into‌ ‌several‌ ‌populations‌ ‌or‌ ‌groups‌ ‌under‌ ‌psychic,‌ ‌physiological‌ ‌or‌ ‌geographical‌ ‌factors‌ ‌is‌ ‌\nsupposed‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌significant‌ ‌factors‌ ‌responsible‌ ‌for‌ ‌evolution.‌ ‌ ‌\n42‌ ‌\n○Geographical‌ ‌barriers‌ ‌include‌ ‌physical‌ ‌barriers‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌rivers,‌ ‌oceans,‌ ‌high‌ ‌mountains‌ ‌which‌ ‌prevent‌ ‌interbreeding‌ ‌between‌ ‌related‌ ‌\norganisms.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Physiologi­cal‌ ‌barriers‌ ‌help‌ ‌in‌ ‌maintaining‌ ‌the‌ ‌individuality‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌species,‌ ‌since‌ ‌the‌ ‌isolations‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌reproductive‌ ‌isolation‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌\nallow‌ ‌the‌ ‌inbreeding‌ ‌amongst‌ ‌the‌ ‌organisms‌ ‌of‌ ‌different‌ ‌spe­cies.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○Example:‌ ‌\n■Scientists‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌Zoological‌ ‌Survey‌ ‌of‌ ‌India‌ ‌have‌ ‌concluded‌ ‌that‌ ‌India‌ ‌is‌ ‌home‌ ‌to‌ ‌both‌ ‌the‌ ‌(sub)‌ ‌species‌ ‌—‌ ‌Himalayan‌ ‌red‌ ‌\npanda‌ ‌(Ailurus‌ ‌fulgens)‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌Chinese‌ ‌red‌ ‌panda‌ ‌(Ailurus‌ ‌styani).‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌Siang‌ ‌river‌ ‌in‌ ‌Arunachal‌ ‌Pradesh‌ ‌splits‌ ‌the‌ ‌red‌ ‌panda‌ ‌into‌ ‌these‌ ‌two‌ ‌phylogenetic‌ ‌species.‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌red‌ ‌panda‌ ‌was‌ ‌considered‌ ‌a‌ ‌monotypic‌ ‌species‌ ‌till‌ ‌2020‌ ‌until‌ ‌the‌ ‌scientists‌ ‌studied‌ ‌its‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌make-up‌ ‌with‌ ‌respect‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌geographical‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌and‌ ‌described‌ ‌the‌ ‌occurrence‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌two‌ ‌species.‌ ‌\n ‌ ‌\nRelated‌ ‌Terminology‌ ‌\n○Gene-flow‌ ‌and‌ ‌Migration:‌ ‌\n■Animals‌ ‌have‌ ‌the‌ ‌tendency‌ ‌to‌ ‌migrate‌ ‌and‌ ‌then‌ ‌they‌ ‌come‌ ‌into‌ ‌contact‌ ‌with‌ ‌another‌ ‌population.‌ ‌ ‌\n43‌ ‌\n■They‌ ‌mate‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌inmates‌ ‌of‌ ‌other‌ ‌populations.‌ ‌Thus,‌ ‌genes‌ ‌of‌ ‌one‌ ‌population‌ ‌are‌ ‌transferred‌ ‌into‌ ‌another‌ ‌population‌ ‌\nwhich‌ ‌is‌ ‌called‌ ‌‌gene‌ ‌flow.‌ ‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌brings‌ ‌about‌ ‌an‌ ‌addition‌ ‌or‌ ‌loss‌ ‌of‌ ‌genes‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌gene‌ ‌pool‌ ‌and‌ ‌change‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌allele‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌population.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○Genetic‌ ‌Drift:‌ ‌\n■ ‌Also‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌drift‌ ‌or‌ ‌‘‌Sewall‌ ‌wright‌ ‌effect‌’‌ ‌or‌ ‌chance.‌ ‌ ‌\n■In‌ ‌this‌ ‌phenomena‌ ‌certain‌ ‌genes‌ ‌without‌ ‌being‌ ‌advantageous‌ ‌Increase‌ ‌in‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌and‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌fixed.‌ ‌This‌ ‌generally‌ ‌\nhappens‌ ‌in‌ ‌small‌ ‌and‌ ‌isolated‌ ‌populations.As‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌large‌ ‌population‌ ‌it‌ ‌will‌ ‌be‌ ‌logical‌ ‌to‌ ‌propose‌ ‌the‌ ‌disappearance‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nmajority‌ ‌of‌ ‌persons.‌ ‌\n■In‌ ‌non-isolated‌ ‌some‌ ‌advantageous‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌and‌ ‌genes‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌introduced‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌population‌ ‌which‌ ‌will‌ ‌hamper‌ ‌spread‌ ‌of‌ ‌\ndisadvantageous‌ ‌alleles.‌ ‌Therefore,‌ ‌the‌ ‌population‌ ‌needs‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌small‌ ‌and‌ ‌isolated.‌ ‌\n44‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n■Example‌‌ ‌:‌ ‌ ‌\n●Retinitis‌ ‌Pigmentosa‌ ‌in‌ ‌Tristan‌ ‌da‌ ‌Cusha‌ ‌island.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Small‌ ‌Island‌ ‌near‌ ‌Saint‌ ‌Helena.‌ ‌A‌ ‌small‌ ‌Garrison‌ ‌was‌ ‌placed‌ ‌at‌ ‌Tristan‌ ‌to‌ ‌watch‌ ‌over‌ ‌Napoleon‌ ‌who‌ ‌was‌ ‌\nexiled‌ ‌in‌ ‌Saint‌ ‌Helena‌ ‌after‌ ‌the‌ ‌death‌ ‌of‌ ‌Napoleon‌ ‌Garrison‌ ‌returned‌ ‌but‌ ‌two‌ ‌related‌ ‌families‌ ‌decided‌ ‌to‌ ‌stay‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌majority‌ ‌of‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌their‌ ‌descendant‌ ‌cause‌ ‌founder‌ ‌effect‌ ‌+inbreeding.‌ ‌\n●Spread‌ ‌of‌ ‌ITD‌ ‌genes‌ ‌in‌ ‌US-‌ ‌Bottleneck‌ ‌effect‌ ‌\n●Drift‌ ‌in‌ ‌Dunker‌ ‌community‌ ‌Pennsylvania,self-isolated‌ ‌by‌ ‌their‌ ‌strict‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌rules‌ ‌for‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌two‌ ‌centuries,‌ ‌it‌ ‌had‌ ‌\nbeen‌ ‌assumed‌ ‌that‌ ‌they‌ ‌were‌ ‌a‌ ‌more‌ ‌or‌ ‌less‌ ‌closed‌ ‌breeding‌ ‌population.---Bottleneck+Inbreeding.‌ ‌\n ‌\n■ ‌Causes‌ ‌of‌ ‌Genetic‌ ‌Drift‌ ‌\n●Natural‌ ‌calamities‌ ‌\n●Migration‌ ‌\n●Inbreeding‌ ‌\n●Individuals‌ ‌may‌ ‌not‌ ‌be‌ ‌leaving‌ ‌a‌ ‌large‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌offspring.‌ ‌\n ‌\nNote:‌ ‌‌The‌ ‌below‌ ‌section‌ ‌also‌ ‌forms‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌Syllabus‌ ‌section‌ ‌9.3‌ ‌\n ‌\n45‌ ‌\nEffect‌ ‌of‌ ‌Drift‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Bottleneck‌ ‌effect‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌population‌ ‌bottleneck‌ ‌or‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌bottleneck‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌sharp‌ ‌reduction‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌size‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌population‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌environmental‌ ‌events‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌\nfamines,‌ ‌earthquakes,‌ ‌floods,‌ ‌fires,‌ ‌disease,‌ ‌and‌ ‌droughts‌ ‌or‌ ‌human‌ ‌activities‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌specicide‌ ‌and‌ ‌human‌ ‌population‌ ‌planning.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○Example‌ ‌glycogen‌ ‌storage‌ ‌related‌ ‌disease‌ ‌in‌ ‌Southeast‌ ‌Asia.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Spread‌ ‌of‌ ‌ITD‌ ‌gene‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌US.‌ ‌\n●Inbreeding‌ ‌\n○Inbreeding‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌mating‌ ‌of‌ ‌organisms‌ ‌closely‌ ‌related‌ ‌by‌ ‌ancestry.‌ ‌It‌ ‌goes‌ ‌against‌ ‌the‌ ‌biological‌ ‌aim‌ ‌of‌ ‌mating,‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌shuffling‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌DNA.‌ ‌\n○Examples‌ ‌‌of‌ ‌specific‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌disorders‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌inbreeding‌ ‌include‌ ‌schizophrenia,‌ ‌limb‌ ‌malformation,‌ ‌blindness,‌ ‌congenital‌ ‌\nheart‌ ‌disease,‌ ‌and‌ ‌neonatal‌ ‌diabetes.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Founder‌ ‌effect‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌population‌ ‌genetics,‌ ‌the‌ ‌founder‌ ‌effect‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌loss‌ ‌of‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌variation‌ ‌that‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌when‌ ‌a‌ ‌new‌ ‌population‌ ‌is‌ ‌established‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌very‌ ‌\nsmall‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌from‌ ‌a‌ ‌larger‌ ‌population.‌ ‌It‌ ‌was‌ ‌first‌ ‌fully‌ ‌outlined‌ ‌by‌ ‌Ernst‌ ‌Mayr‌ ‌in‌ ‌1942,‌ ‌using‌ ‌existing‌ ‌theoretical‌ ‌work‌ ‌\nby‌ ‌those‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌Sewall‌ ‌Wright.‌ ‌ ‌\n46‌ ‌\n ‌\nImage‌ ‌Link‌ ‌\n ‌\n○Example:‌ ‌six‌ ‌finger‌ ‌dwarfism.‌ ‌\n●Bottlenecks‌ ‌occur‌ ‌when‌ ‌a‌ ‌population's‌ ‌size‌ ‌is‌ ‌reduced‌ ‌for‌ ‌at‌ ‌least‌ ‌one‌ ‌generation.‌ ‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌founder‌ ‌effect‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌when‌ ‌a‌ ‌new‌ ‌colony‌ ‌is‌ ‌started‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌few‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌original‌ ‌population.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nRole‌ ‌of‌ ‌Drift‌ ‌in‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌\n●Formation‌ ‌of‌ ‌different‌ ‌gene‌ ‌combinations.‌ ‌May‌ ‌not‌ ‌bring‌ ‌any‌ ‌major‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌change‌ ‌but‌ ‌it‌ ‌can‌ ‌change‌ ‌adaptive‌ ‌characters‌ ‌of‌ ‌population‌ ‌by‌ ‌\ndividing‌ ‌into‌ ‌several‌ ‌subpopulations‌ ‌of‌ ‌differing‌ ‌gene‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌this‌ ‌competition‌ ‌leads‌ ‌to‌ ‌species‌ ‌division‌ ‌and‌ ‌several‌ ‌subgroups‌ ‌try‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nexploit‌ ‌the‌ ‌environment‌ ‌by‌ ‌exploring‌ ‌best‌ ‌means.‌ ‌\n●Success‌ ‌of‌ ‌disadvantages‌ ‌genes-A‌ ‌gene‌ ‌which‌ ‌in‌ ‌large‌ ‌populations‌ ‌had‌ ‌a‌ ‌net‌ ‌disadvantage‌ ‌may‌ ‌prove‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌advantages‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌\ncombinations‌ ‌of‌ ‌genes‌ ‌and‌ ‌thus,‌ ‌get‌ ‌a‌ ‌foothold‌ ‌of‌ ‌population‌ ‌which‌ ‌was‌ ‌earlier‌ ‌denied‌ ‌in‌ ‌large‌ ‌populations‌ ‌but‌ ‌formation‌ ‌of‌ ‌such‌ ‌green‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌\npassed‌ ‌under‌ ‌selection.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌addition:‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌ ‌\n47‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○Genetics‌ ‌frequency:‌ ‌\n■Gene‌ ‌frequency=‌ ‌Number‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌gene‌ ‌under‌ ‌consideration‌ ‌/‌ ‌Total‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌genes‌ ‌present‌ ‌on‌ ‌that‌ ‌locus‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌\npopulation.‌ ‌\n■Suppose‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌100‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌population‌ ‌out‌ ‌of‌ ‌which‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌40‌ ‌homozygous‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌(AA),‌ ‌40‌ ‌heterozygous‌ ‌\n(Aa)‌ ‌and‌ ‌20‌ ‌homozygous‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌(aa).‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌of‌ ‌gene‌ ‌'A'‌ ‌will‌ ‌be‌ ‌(80-40/200)‌ ‌=0.6‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌of‌ ‌gene‌ ‌'a'‌ ‌will‌ ‌be‌ ‌(40+40/200)=0.4‌ ‌\n ‌\n*Introgression:‌ ‌Transfer‌ ‌of‌ ‌genetics‌ ‌information‌ ‌from‌ ‌one‌ ‌species‌ ‌to‌ ‌another‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌result‌ ‌of‌ ‌hybridisation‌ ‌between‌ ‌them‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nrepeated‌ ‌backcrossing.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n48‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n1.4‌ ‌(c)‌ ‌Brief‌ ‌outline‌ ‌of‌ ‌terms‌ ‌and‌ ‌concepts‌ ‌of‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌biology‌ ‌(Dollo’s‌ ‌rule,‌ ‌Cope’s‌ ‌rule,‌ ‌Gause’s‌ ‌rule,‌ ‌parallelism,‌ ‌convergence,‌ ‌\nadaptive‌ ‌radiation,‌ ‌and‌ ‌mosaic‌ ‌evolution)‌ ‌Part-II‌ ‌\n ‌\n49‌ ‌\nDollo’s‌ ‌rule(Doctrine‌ ‌of‌ ‌irreversibility‌ ‌of‌ ‌evolution)‌ ‌\n●Dollo’s‌ ‌law‌,‌ ‌named‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌19th-century‌
