‌paleontologist‌ ‌‌Louis‌ ‌Dollo‌.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌states‌ ‌that‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌always‌ ‌moves‌ ‌forward‌ ‌—‌ ‌that‌ ‌an‌ ‌organism‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌redevelop‌ ‌an‌ ‌organ‌ ‌or‌ ‌attribute‌ ‌discarded‌ ‌by‌ ‌its‌ ‌ancestors.‌ ‌\n○Many‌ ‌times‌ ‌during‌ ‌the‌ ‌long‌ ‌history‌ ‌of‌ ‌life‌ ‌advanced‌ ‌organisms‌ ‌have‌ ‌returned‌ ‌to‌ ‌ancestral‌ ‌habits‌ ‌and‌ ‌mode‌ ‌of‌ ‌life.‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌gives‌ ‌selected‌ ‌value‌ ‌to‌ ‌adaptation‌ ‌similar‌ ‌to‌ ‌those‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌ancestral‌ ‌species,‌ ‌and‌ ‌raised‌ ‌the‌ ‌question‌ ‌whether‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌is‌ ‌\nIrreversible.‌ ‌\n○Study‌ ‌of‌ ‌such‌ ‌cases‌ ‌suggest‌ ‌that‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌commonality‌ ‌of‌ ‌environment‌ ‌and‌ ‌resultant‌ ‌function‌ ‌of‌ ‌adaptation,‌ ‌always‌ ‌a‌ ‌gross‌ ‌similarity‌ ‌\nbetween‌ ‌ancestral‌ ‌and‌ ‌descendant‌ ‌structure‌ ‌is‌ ‌achieved‌ ‌without‌ ‌any‌ ‌genuine‌ ‌reversal‌ ‌at‌ ‌all.‌ ‌\n○Thus,reptiles‌ ‌and‌ ‌mammals‌ ‌have‌ ‌reverted‌ ‌to‌ ‌aquatic‌ ‌mode‌ ‌of‌ ‌life;‌ ‌they‌ ‌have‌ ‌assumed‌ ‌a‌ ‌generally‌ ‌streamlined‌ ‌fish‌ ‌like‌ ‌form‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nlamb‌ ‌have‌ ‌become‌ ‌shortened‌ ‌web‌ ‌and‌ ‌finlike.‌ ‌\n○Yet‌ ‌the‌ ‌skeleton‌ ‌of‌ ‌such‌ ‌flippers‌ ‌is‌ ‌always‌ ‌distinctly‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌class‌ ‌to‌ ‌which‌ ‌animals‌ ‌belong‌ ‌rather‌ ‌than‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌fish‌ ‌fin.‌ ‌The‌ ‌\nevidence‌ ‌indicates‌ ‌that‌ ‌major‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌steps‌ ‌once‌ ‌taken‌ ‌are‌ ‌never‌ ‌reversed.‌ ‌It‌ ‌might‌ ‌even‌ ‌be‌ ‌expected‌ ‌that‌ ‌major‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌\nsteps‌ ‌are‌ ‌composed‌ ‌of‌ ‌many‌ ‌smaller‌ ‌steps‌ ‌each‌ ‌preserved‌ ‌by‌ ‌natural‌ ‌selection.‌ ‌\n○Such‌ ‌a‌ ‌sequence‌ ‌of‌ ‌occurring‌ ‌by‌ ‌chance‌ ‌once‌ ‌shut‌ ‌by‌ ‌chance‌ ‌be‌ ‌exactly‌ ‌reversed‌ ‌would‌ ‌be‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌extraordinary‌ ‌thing‌ ‌if‌ ‌not‌ ‌\nimpossible‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌at‌ ‌least‌ ‌most‌ ‌improbable‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌whole‌ ‌organism.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Example:‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌dentition,‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌series‌ ‌is‌ ‌lost;‌ ‌it‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌reoccur‌ ‌again‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌series‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌form.‌ ‌\n○After‌ ‌the‌ ‌extinction‌ ‌of‌ ‌flying‌ ‌reptiles‌ ‌the‌ ‌combination‌ ‌of‌ ‌wind‌ ‌and‌ ‌reptile‌ ‌did‌ ‌not‌ ‌come‌ ‌together.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌Criticism:‌ ‌\n● ‌Being‌ ‌descriptive‌ ‌generalisation‌ ‌it‌ ‌could‌ ‌not‌ ‌be‌ ‌considered‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌law‌ ‌of‌ ‌nature‌ ‌but‌ ‌only‌ ‌a‌ ‌property‌ ‌of‌ ‌Living‌ ‌Organism.‌ ‌\n ‌\n50‌ ‌\nCope’s‌ ‌rule‌ ‌\n●Edwin‌ ‌Drinker‌ ‌Cope‌ ‌(1870)‌ ‌‌proposed‌ ‌this‌ ‌rule‌ ‌to‌ ‌describe‌ ‌the‌ ‌changes‌ ‌in‌ ‌size‌ ‌of‌ ‌organisms‌ ‌as‌ ‌they‌ ‌evolved.‌ ‌\n●As‌ ‌time‌ ‌progresses,‌ ‌organisms‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌clade‌ ‌increase‌ ‌in‌ ‌size‌ ‌Horses‌ ‌over‌ ‌the‌ ‌Cenozoic‌ ‌are‌ ‌a‌ ‌good‌ ‌example‌ ‌\n●Organisms‌ ‌generally‌ ‌increase‌ ‌in‌ ‌size‌ ‌from‌ ‌their‌ ‌ancestors.‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌is‌ ‌possibly‌ ‌due‌ ‌to:‌ ‌\n○Larger‌ ‌organisms‌ ‌have‌ ‌fewer‌ ‌predators‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌larger‌ ‌size‌ ‌protects‌ ‌against‌ ‌many‌ ‌smaller‌ ‌predators‌ ‌\n○Food‌ ‌utilization‌ ‌is‌ ‌more‌ ‌efficient‌ ‌\n○Thermal‌ ‌inertia‌ ‌increases,‌ ‌constant‌ ‌body‌ ‌temperature‌ ‌\n●Increase‌ ‌in‌ ‌size‌ ‌>>‌ ‌decrease‌ ‌in‌ ‌population‌ ‌>>‌ ‌decrease‌ ‌in‌ ‌biomass‌ ‌>>‌ ‌Leads‌ ‌to‌ ‌extinction‌ ‌>>‌ ‌increases‌ ‌opportunity‌ ‌for‌ ‌others.‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌example:‌ ‌Horses'‌ ‌average‌ ‌body‌ ‌mass‌ ‌increased‌ ‌5-10‌ ‌fold‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌last‌ ‌60‌ ‌million‌ ‌year.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Criticism:‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌only‌ ‌descriptive‌ ‌generalisation‌ ‌and‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌apply‌ ‌to‌ ‌all‌ ‌living‌ ‌organisms‌ ‌hence‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌reject‌ ‌Cope‌ ‌rule‌ ‌as‌ ‌not‌ ‌being‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nlaw‌ ‌of‌ ‌nature.‌ ‌\n ‌\n51‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nGause’s‌ ‌rule‌ ‌\n●Competition‌ ‌may‌ ‌occur‌ ‌between‌ ‌populations‌ ‌within‌ ‌an‌ ‌ecosystem‌ ‌for‌ ‌any‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌available‌ ‌resources‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌food,‌ ‌shelter‌ ‌or‌ ‌sunlight.‌ ‌\n●If‌ ‌two‌ ‌species‌ ‌occur‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌trophic‌ ‌level‌ ‌then‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌likely‌ ‌to‌ ‌compete‌ ‌with‌ ‌each‌ ‌other‌ ‌for‌ ‌food.‌ ‌\n●Adaptive‌ ‌radiation‌ ‌by‌ ‌one‌ ‌or‌ ‌both‌ ‌species‌ ‌may‌ ‌then‌ ‌occur‌ ‌over‌ ‌a‌ ‌period‌ ‌of‌ ‌time‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌result‌ ‌that‌ ‌they‌ ‌come‌ ‌to‌ ‌occupy‌ ‌a‌ ‌separate‌ ‌niche‌ ‌\nwithin‌ ‌the‌ ‌tropical‌ ‌level,‌ ‌Thus,‌ ‌minimising‌ ‌the‌ ‌extent‌ ‌of‌ ‌competition.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nImage‌ ‌Link‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n52‌ ‌\n●Example‌ ‌ ‌\n○Adaptive‌ ‌radiation‌ ‌is‌ ‌seen‌ ‌in‌ ‌finches‌ ‌of‌ ‌Galapagos‌ ‌Island.‌ ‌which‌ ‌have‌ ‌undergone‌ ‌great‌ ‌diversification‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌feeding‌ ‌habit.‌ ‌\n● ‌Criticism:‌ ‌\n○Gause‌ ‌speaks‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌structural‌ ‌adaptation‌ ‌but‌ ‌not‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌physiological,‌ ‌biotic‌ ‌and‌ ‌organic‌ ‌adaptation.‌ ‌\n○Example:‌ ‌Grey‌ ‌squirrels‌ ‌have‌ ‌replaced‌ ‌red‌ ‌squirrels‌ ‌in‌ ‌Britain.‌ ‌The‌ ‌population‌ ‌of‌ ‌red‌ ‌squirrels‌ ‌decreased‌ ‌substantially‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌\ncompetitive‌ ‌exclusion.‌ ‌\n ‌\nConcepts‌ ‌and‌ ‌terminology‌ ‌in‌ ‌Evolutionary‌ ‌Biology:‌ ‌\n●Parallelism‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌common‌ ‌ancestor‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌organisms‌ ‌that‌ ‌\n○ ‌was‌ ‌not‌ ‌very‌ ‌ancient‌ ‌and‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌descendant‌ ‌line‌ ‌for‌ ‌load‌ ‌more‌ ‌or‌ ‌less‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌course.‌ ‌\n○ ‌parallelism‌ ‌implies‌ ‌a‌ ‌similarity‌ ‌in‌ ‌biological‌ ‌makeup‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌ancestral‌ ‌form.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○Example‌ ‌lack‌ ‌of‌ ‌tale‌ ‌in‌ ‌Gibbon‌ ‌great‌ ‌Apes‌ ‌and‌ ‌humans‌ ‌could‌ ‌be‌ ‌as‌ ‌their‌ ‌common‌ ‌ancestors‌ ‌had‌ ‌tails‌ ‌but‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌devoid‌ ‌them‌ ‌in‌ ‌\na‌ ‌parallel‌ ‌fashion‌ ‌in‌ ‌separate‌ ‌Revolutionary‌ ‌lines‌ ‌after‌ ‌they‌ ‌diverged.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Convergence‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌similar‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌or‌ ‌adaptation‌ ‌in‌ ‌animals‌ ‌that‌ ‌differ‌ ‌in‌ ‌direct‌ ‌and‌ ‌ancestry.‌ ‌it‌ ‌usually‌ ‌applies‌ ‌to‌ ‌\none‌ ‌or‌ ‌a‌ ‌few‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌animals‌ ‌then‌ ‌to‌ ‌its‌ ‌entirety.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n53‌ ‌\n○Example‌‌ ‌retinal‌ ‌cells‌ ‌i.e.‌ ‌rod‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌more‌ ‌sensitive‌ ‌to‌ ‌dim‌ ‌light‌ ‌at‌ ‌present‌ ‌in‌ ‌deep‌ ‌sea‌ ‌fish,‌ ‌bat,‌ ‌lizards,‌ ‌and‌ ‌Lemurs.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nParallelism‌ ‌implies‌ ‌of‌ ‌similarity‌ ‌in‌ ‌biological‌ ‌makeup‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌ancestral‌ ‌forms‌ ‌where‌ ‌as‌ ‌conversions‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Adaptive‌ ‌radiation‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌spread‌ ‌and‌ ‌differentiation‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌descendants‌ ‌of‌ ‌one‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌animal‌ ‌of‌ ‌whatever‌ ‌level‌ ‌of‌ ‌classification.‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌way‌ ‌a‌ ‌species‌ ‌evolves‌ ‌into‌ ‌progressively‌ ‌dissimilar‌ ‌organisms.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nImage‌ ‌Link‌ ‌\n ‌\n○Example:‌ ‌ ‌Mammals‌ ‌adopted‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌tertiary‌ ‌era‌ ‌wild‌ ‌dinosaurs‌ ‌did‌ ‌not‌ ‌and‌ ‌hence‌ ‌became‌ ‌extinct.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Mosaic‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌principle‌ ‌states‌ ‌that‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌species‌ ‌tends‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌constant‌ ‌and‌ ‌asymmetrical.‌ ‌I.e.‌ ‌it‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌rapid‌ ‌at‌ ‌once‌ ‌and‌ ‌slow‌ ‌another‌ ‌\ntime‌ ‌sometimes‌ ‌might‌ ‌even‌ ‌stop.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Example:‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌of‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌different‌ ‌elephant‌ ‌species.‌ ‌The‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌elephant‌ ‌underwent‌ ‌rapid‌ ‌early‌ ‌molar‌ ‌modification‌ ‌\nwith‌ ‌little‌ ‌foreshortening‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌forehead.‌ ‌The‌ ‌African‌ ‌elephant‌ ‌underwent‌ ‌parallel‌ ‌changes‌ ‌but‌ ‌at‌ ‌different‌ ‌rates:‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nforeshortening‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌forehead‌ ‌took‌ ‌place‌ ‌in‌ ‌an‌ ‌early‌ ‌stage‌ ‌of‌ ‌development,‌ ‌molar‌ ‌modification‌ ‌occurring‌ ‌later.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n54‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌ ‌\n1.5‌ ‌Characteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌Primates;‌ ‌Evolutionary‌ ‌Trend‌ ‌and‌ ‌Primate‌ ‌Taxonomy;-Part‌ ‌I‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nCharacteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌Primates;‌ ‌ ‌\nWhat‌ ‌are‌ ‌Primates?‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌diverse‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌‌vertebrates‌ ‌represented‌ ‌by‌ ‌animals‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌humans,‌ ‌monkeys,‌ ‌and‌ ‌apes‌ ‌is‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌Primates.‌ ‌They‌ ‌belong‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nMammalia‌ ‌class‌ ‌and‌ ‌form‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌subgroup‌ ‌placental‌ ‌mammals(those‌ ‌carry‌ ‌uterus).‌ ‌\n ‌\nPlacental‌ ‌mammals‌ ‌\n○Unguiculate‌ ‌(possessing‌ ‌nails‌ ‌or‌ ‌claws,‌ ‌as‌ ‌opposed‌ ‌to‌ ‌hooves)‌ ‌\n○Clavicles‌ ‌(collar‌ ‌bones)‌ ‌present‌ ‌\n○Orbits‌ ‌encircled‌ ‌by‌ ‌bone‌ ‌\n○Three‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌teeth,‌ ‌at‌ ‌least‌ ‌at‌ ‌one‌ ‌time‌ ‌of‌ ‌life‌ ‌\n○Brain‌ ‌always‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌posterior‌ ‌lobe‌ ‌and‌ ‌calcarine‌ ‌fissure‌ ‌\n55‌ ‌\n○Innermost‌ ‌digit‌ ‌of‌ ‌at‌ ‌least‌ ‌one‌ ‌pair‌ ‌of‌ ‌extremities‌ ‌opposable‌ ‌\n○Hallux‌ ‌(big‌ ‌toe)‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌flat‌ ‌nail‌ ‌or‌ ‌none‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌well-developed‌ ‌caecum‌ ‌(appendix)‌ ‌\n○Penis‌ ‌pendulous‌ ‌\n○Testes‌ ‌scrotal‌ ‌\n○Two‌ ‌pectoral‌ ‌mammae‌ ‌\n●After‌ ‌careful‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌definition‌ ‌it‌ ‌becomes‌ ‌clear‌ ‌that‌ ‌these‌ ‌are‌ ‌serial‌ ‌listing‌ ‌of‌ ‌characters‌ ‌of‌ ‌Primates‌ ‌and‌ ‌these‌ ‌are‌ ‌mixtures‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌types‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌characters:‌ ‌\n1.‌ ‌‌General‌ ‌Mammalian‌ ‌Characters:‌ ‌ ‌\n●Like‌ ‌three‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌teeth,‌ ‌inceasers,‌ ‌canine‌ ‌and‌ ‌molars,‌ ‌testes‌ ‌in‌ ‌sac‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌are‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌all‌ ‌mammals‌ ‌including‌ ‌primates‌ ‌and‌ ‌are‌ ‌\nequally‌ ‌developed‌ ‌in‌ ‌all‌ ‌primates.‌ ‌\n2.‌ ‌‌Specialized‌ ‌characters‌ ‌of‌ ‌Primates:‌ ‌\n●Like‌ ‌posterior‌ ‌lobe‌ ‌of‌ ‌brain‌ ‌and‌ ‌opposability‌ ‌of‌ ‌thumb‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌are‌ ‌found‌ ‌only‌ ‌in‌ ‌Primates‌ ‌and‌ ‌these‌ ‌are‌ ‌evolved‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌levels‌ ‌i.e.‌ ‌\nsuborder,‌ ‌genera,‌ ‌species‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌All‌ ‌these‌ ‌characters‌ ‌are‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌Man‌ ‌too,‌ ‌hence‌ ‌we‌ ‌include‌ ‌man‌ ‌in‌ ‌order‌ ‌Primate.‌ ‌\n ‌\nHabitat‌ ‌\n●Primary‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌tropical‌ ‌and‌ ‌subtropical‌ ‌region‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌new‌ ‌and‌ ‌old‌ ‌world.‌ ‌\n●Never‌ ‌lived.‌ ‌in‌ ‌Australia‌ ‌and‌ ‌most‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌islands‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Pacific‌ ‌Ocean.‌ ‌\n56‌ ‌\n●Though,‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌that‌ ‌around‌ ‌55-50‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago‌ ‌the‌ ‌earliest‌ ‌primate‌ ‌lived‌ ‌in‌ ‌North‌ ‌America‌ ‌and‌ ‌Europe.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●In‌ ‌present‌ ‌scenario,‌ ‌the‌ ‌living‌ ‌primates‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌categorized‌ ‌into‌ ‌following‌ ‌six‌ ‌natural‌ ‌groups-‌ ‌(Martin,‌ ‌1994)‌ ‌\ni.‌ ‌‌Lemurs‌ ‌of‌ ‌Madagascar‌ ‌\nii.‌ ‌The‌ ‌Lorises‌ ‌and‌ ‌bush‌ ‌babies‌ ‌of‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌and‌ ‌Asia‌ ‌\niii.‌ ‌The‌ ‌Tarsiers‌ ‌of‌ ‌Southeast‌ ‌Asia‌ ‌\niv.‌ ‌The‌ ‌New‌ ‌World‌ ‌Monkeys‌ ‌of‌ ‌Central‌ ‌and‌ ‌South‌ ‌America‌ ‌\nv.‌ ‌The‌ ‌Old‌ ‌World‌ ‌Monkeys‌ ‌of‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌and‌ ‌Asia‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nvi.‌ ‌The‌ ‌apes‌ ‌of‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌and‌ ‌Asia‌ ‌and‌ ‌Humans‌ ‌\n ‌\nCommon‌ ‌traits‌ ‌of‌ ‌primates:‌ ‌\n●Fur‌ ‌(or‌ ‌body‌ ‌hair)‌ ‌\n●Long‌ ‌gestation‌ ‌and‌ ‌live‌ ‌birth‌ ‌\n●Heterodontism(‌ ‌different‌ ‌kind‌ ‌of‌ ‌specialised‌ ‌teeth)‌ ‌\n●Ability‌ ‌to‌ ‌maintain‌ ‌constant‌ ‌body‌ ‌temperature(‌ ‌homeothermy)‌ ‌\n●Increase‌ ‌brain‌ ‌size‌ ‌greater‌ ‌ability‌ ‌for‌ ‌learning‌ ‌and‌ ‌behavioural‌ ‌flexibility.‌ ‌ ‌\n57‌ ‌\n●Dexterous‌ ‌hands‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nCharacteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌Primates:‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nThe‌ ‌following‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌main‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌primates:‌ ‌\n ‌\n58‌ ‌\n●Hand‌ ‌&‌ ‌feet‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌anatomy‌ ‌of‌ ‌Primates‌ ‌enables‌ ‌them‌ ‌to‌ ‌maintain‌ ‌semi-erect‌ ‌and‌ ‌erect‌ ‌postures‌ ‌and‌ ‌locomotor‌ ‌patterns.‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌have‌ ‌pentadactyl‌ ‌hands‌ ‌and‌ ‌feet‌ ‌(a‌ ‌very‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌trait).‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌have‌ ‌flattened‌ ‌nails‌ ‌on‌ ‌each‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌digits‌ ‌except‌ ‌tree‌ ‌shrews.‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌have‌ ‌pseudo-and‌ ‌true-opposability‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌thumb‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌great‌ ‌toe‌ ‌(i.e.,‌ ‌the‌ ‌two‌ ‌function,‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌varying‌ ‌degree,‌ ‌independently‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌other‌ ‌digits.‌ ‌They‌ ‌are‌ ‌widely‌ ‌separated‌ ‌from‌ ‌them);‌ ‌usually‌ ‌they‌ ‌have‌ ‌both‌ ‌these‌ ‌digits,‌ ‌on‌ ‌hands‌ ‌and‌ ‌feet,‌ ‌opposable‌ ‌for‌ ‌\ngrasping‌ ‌purposes.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Body‌ ‌fur‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌possess‌ ‌a‌ ‌relatively‌ ‌low‌ ‌density‌ ‌of‌ ‌body‌ ‌hairs‌ ‌(hair‌ ‌instead‌ ‌of‌ ‌fur).‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌have‌ ‌fewer‌ ‌tactile‌ ‌hairs.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Vision‌ ‌&‌ ‌Smell‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌olfactory‌ ‌area‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌brain‌ ‌is‌ ‌reduced.‌ ‌They‌ ‌thus‌ ‌have‌ ‌an‌ ‌increased‌ ‌dominance‌ ‌of‌ ‌vision‌ ‌over‌ ‌smell,‌ ‌and‌ ‌reduction‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌length‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌the‌ ‌(nose)‌ ‌snout‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌visual‌ ‌area‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌brain‌ ‌is‌ ‌expanded.‌ ‌\n○Their‌ ‌eye‌ ‌sockets‌ ‌are‌ ‌completely‌ ‌encircled‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌bony‌ ‌ridge.‌ ‌Their‌ ‌eyes‌ ‌are‌ ‌more‌ ‌forwardly‌ ‌directed‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌skull‌ ‌(for‌ ‌binocular‌ ‌vision)‌ ‌\nsuggesting‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌stereoscopic‌ ‌vision.‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌show‌ ‌an‌ ‌increased‌ ‌reliance‌ ‌on‌ ‌stereoscopic‌ ‌vision‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌expense‌ ‌of‌ ‌smell‌ ‌(the‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌sensory‌ ‌system‌ ‌in‌ ‌majority‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nmammals).‌ ‌\n○Some‌ ‌primates‌ ‌have‌ ‌developed‌ ‌a‌ ‌three‌ ‌color‌ ‌vision.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Brain‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌possess‌ ‌relatively‌ ‌larger‌ ‌and‌ ‌complex‌ ‌brains.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Reproductive‌ ‌system‌ ‌\n○Most‌ ‌female‌ ‌primates‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌simple‌ ‌unicornuate‌ ‌uterus.‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌are‌ ‌placental‌ ‌mammals‌ ‌with‌ ‌longer‌ ‌gestation‌ ‌periods‌ ‌and‌ ‌generally‌ ‌give‌ ‌birth‌ ‌to‌ ‌only‌ ‌one‌ ‌or‌ ‌two‌ ‌infants‌ ‌at‌ ‌a‌ ‌time.‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌have‌ ‌year‌ ‌round‌ ‌fertility.‌ ‌\n○Their‌ ‌infants‌ ‌have‌ ‌prolonged‌ ‌physical‌ ‌and‌ ‌emotional‌ ‌dependence‌ ‌upon‌ ‌their‌ ‌mothers,‌ ‌i.e.‌ ‌they‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌longer‌ ‌period‌ ‌of‌ ‌infant‌ ‌\ndependency‌ ‌and‌ ‌parenting.‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌have‌ ‌prolonged‌ ‌growth‌ ‌and‌ ‌maturation‌ ‌periods‌ ‌and‌ ‌long‌ ‌life‌ ‌spans.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Teeth‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌display‌ ‌a‌ ‌reduction‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌teeth,‌ ‌i.e.‌ ‌they‌ ‌have‌ ‌an‌ ‌incisor‌ ‌and‌ ‌premolar‌ ‌less‌ ‌in‌ ‌each‌ ‌half‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌upper‌ ‌and‌ ‌lower‌ ‌jaws‌ ‌\nunlike‌ ‌those‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌placental‌ ‌mammals.‌ ‌\n59‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌have‌ ‌retained‌ ‌a‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌clavicle.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Others‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌possess‌ ‌a‌ ‌separate‌ ‌radius‌ ‌and‌ ‌an‌ ‌ulna‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌forearm‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌separate‌ ‌tibia‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌fibula‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌lower‌ ‌leg‌ ‌(excepting‌ ‌tarsier).‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌show‌ ‌reduction‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌length‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌external‌ ‌tail.‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌possess‌ ‌a‌ ‌shortened‌ ‌vertebral‌ ‌column.‌ ‌\n○Some‌ ‌have‌ ‌prehensile‌ ‌tails.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nEvolutionary‌ ‌Trend‌ ‌and‌ ‌Primate‌ ‌Taxonomy;‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nPrimates‌ ‌Constitute:‌ ‌\nClassification‌ ‌of‌ ‌primates‌ ‌is‌ ‌primarily‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌similarities‌ ‌and‌ ‌dissimilarities‌ ‌of‌ ‌external‌ ‌morphology,‌ ‌although‌ ‌phylogenetic‌ ‌classifications‌ ‌have‌ ‌\nalso‌ ‌been‌ ‌done.‌ ‌‌Primates‌ ‌consist‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌suborders:‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n1.Prosimians(Strepsirhini)-‌ ‌lower‌ ‌primates.‌ ‌\n2.Anthropoidea(Haplorhini)-‌ ‌higher‌ ‌primates.‌ ‌\n ‌\nThey‌ ‌live‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌habitats‌ ‌and‌ ‌exhibit‌ ‌diversification‌ ‌in‌ ‌behaviour.‌ ‌They‌ ‌showed‌ ‌different‌ ‌trends‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌dentition,‌ ‌brain,‌ ‌hand,‌ ‌feet‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌This‌ ‌\nRevolutionary‌ ‌trend‌ ‌has‌ ‌led‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌emergence‌ ‌of‌ ‌man‌ ‌from‌ ‌apes.‌ ‌\n ‌\nEvolutionary‌ ‌trends‌ ‌in‌ ‌Primates‌ ‌\nOther‌ ‌than‌ ‌man‌ ‌All‌ ‌apps‌ ‌live‌ ‌on‌ ‌tree‌ ‌branches.‌ ‌They‌ ‌are‌ ‌quadrupled‌ ‌and‌ ‌mainly‌ ‌Herbivores.‌ ‌They‌ ‌did‌ ‌not‌ ‌have‌ ‌culture‌ ‌where‌ ‌as‌ ‌man‌ ‌is‌ ‌biped‌ ‌living‌ ‌\non‌ ‌ground,‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌Omnivores,‌ ‌having‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌ ‌\nAs‌ ‌a‌ ‌result‌ ‌following‌ ‌trends‌ ‌in‌ ‌primates‌ ‌are‌ ‌found:‌ ‌\n ‌\n1.Dentition‌ ‌\n ‌\nThe‌ ‌general‌ ‌trend‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌dentition‌ ‌in‌ ‌Primates‌ ‌are‌ ‌as‌ ‌follow:‌ ‌\n1.Retention‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌fairly‌ ‌simple‌ ‌teeth‌ ‌structure.‌ ‌\n2.Reduction‌ ‌and‌ ‌size‌ ‌of‌ ‌teeth‌ ‌\n60‌ ‌\n3.The‌ ‌lower‌ ‌the‌ ‌teeth‌ ‌is‌ ‌different‌ ‌in‌ ‌various‌ ‌primate‌ ‌group‌ ‌as‌ ‌given‌ ‌below:‌ ‌\n ‌\nProsimians‌ ‌\nTree‌ ‌shrews‌ ‌ ‌\n2133‌ ‌\n ‌+‌ ‌X‌ ‌2‌ ‌=‌ ‌38‌ ‌\n3133‌ ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌Addition‌ ‌\n ‌\nDental‌ ‌Formula:‌ ‌\nExpresses‌ ‌the‌ ‌number‌ ‌and‌ ‌kind‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌teeth‌ ‌possessed‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌mammal.‌ ‌\nIt‌ ‌is‌ ‌written‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌four‌ ‌‘fraction’‌ ‌one‌ ‌for‌ ‌each‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌tooth,‌ ‌with‌ ‌upper‌ ‌and‌ ‌lower‌ ‌jaw.‌ ‌\nTeeth‌ ‌type:‌ ‌\nI‌ ‌-(Incisor)‌ ‌C‌ ‌-(Canine)‌ ‌P‌ ‌-(PreMolar)‌ ‌M‌ ‌-(Molar)‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nLemurs‌ ‌and‌ ‌Lorises‌ ‌ ‌\n2133‌ ‌\n ‌+‌ ‌X‌ ‌2‌ ‌=‌ ‌36‌ ‌\n2133‌ ‌\n ‌\nTrasiers‌ ‌\n2133‌ ‌\n61‌ ‌\n ‌+‌ ‌X‌ ‌2‌ ‌=‌ ‌34‌ ‌\n1133‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nAnthropoidea‌ ‌\n ‌\nNew‌ ‌World‌ ‌Monkey‌ ‌\n2133‌ ‌\n ‌+‌ ‌X‌ ‌2‌ ‌=‌ ‌36‌ ‌\n2133‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nOld‌ ‌World‌ ‌Monkey‌ ‌&‌ ‌Human‌ ‌\n2133‌ ‌\n ‌+‌ ‌X‌ ‌2‌ ‌=‌ ‌32‌ ‌\n2122‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n4.Affected‌ ‌all‌ ‌four‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌teeth‌ ‌\n●Incisors‌ ‌\n○Commonly‌ ‌used‌ ‌for‌ ‌cutting‌ ‌the‌ ‌general‌ ‌trend‌ ‌reduction‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌size‌ ‌of‌ ‌Incisor‌ ‌is‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌increasing‌ ‌trend‌ ‌of‌ ‌eating‌ ‌already‌ ‌\nprocessed‌ ‌food.‌ ‌\n●Canines‌ ‌\n○Size‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌canine‌ ‌is‌ ‌gradually‌ ‌reduced.It‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌tools.‌ ‌Canines‌ ‌role‌ ‌in‌ ‌primate:‌ ‌\n■Tearing‌ ‌and‌ ‌shredding‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌food.‌ ‌\n■Aesthetic‌ ‌display‌ ‌\n●Premolars‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌commonly‌ ‌works‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌grinder‌ ‌and‌ ‌sometimes‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌cutting‌ ‌surface.‌ ‌\n○Apes,‌ ‌monkeys‌ ‌and‌ ‌some‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌earliest‌ ‌hominids‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌‌Australopithecus‌.‌ ‌\n○After‌ ‌the‌ ‌lower‌ ‌first‌ ‌premolar‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌factorial‌ ‌in‌ ‌all‌ ‌other‌ ‌later‌ ‌hominids‌ ‌and‌ ‌modern‌ ‌Sapiens.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌first‌ ‌lower‌ ‌premolar‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌bicuspid‌ ‌tooth.‌ ‌I.e.‌ ‌to‌ ‌cusp‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌biting‌ ‌surface.‌ ‌\n○All‌ ‌the‌ ‌remaining‌ ‌premolar‌ ‌in‌ ‌apes,‌ ‌monkeys‌ ‌and‌ ‌hominids‌ ‌are‌ ‌bicuspid.‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌many‌ ‌fossil‌ ‌hominids.‌ ‌e.g.‌ ‌Australopithecus‌ ‌Africanus‌ ‌premolar‌ ‌have‌ ‌become‌ ‌molar‌ ‌by‌ ‌acquiring‌ ‌extra‌ ‌cusp‌ ‌to‌ ‌deal‌ ‌with‌ ‌\ntough‌ ‌food.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌premolar‌ ‌were‌ ‌four‌ ‌in‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌mammals.‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌has‌ ‌decreased‌ ‌to‌ ‌three‌ ‌in‌ ‌Prosimians‌ ‌and‌ ‌new‌ ‌world‌ ‌monkeys,‌ ‌and‌ ‌two‌ ‌in‌ ‌old‌ ‌world‌ ‌monkeys,‌ ‌Apes‌ ‌and‌ ‌Humans.‌ ‌.‌ ‌\n○Thus,‌ ‌reduction‌ ‌to‌ ‌two‌ ‌in‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌selective‌ ‌advantage‌ ‌because‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌tools.‌ ‌\n●Molars‌ ‌\n○Molar‌ ‌also‌ ‌worked‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌grinder.‌ ‌\n62‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌molar‌ ‌have‌ ‌remained‌ ‌same‌ ‌i.e.‌ ‌three‌ ‌in‌ ‌both‌ ‌upper‌ ‌and‌ ‌lower‌ ‌jaw‌ ‌except‌ ‌Marasmus‌ ‌and‌ ‌Tamarins.‌ ‌ ‌\n○But‌ ‌have‌ ‌changed‌ ‌considerably‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌groups.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌molar‌ ‌teeth‌ ‌of‌ ‌ancestral‌ ‌placental‌ ‌mammals‌ ‌had‌ ‌basically‌ ‌triangular‌ ‌patterns.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌upper‌ ‌molars‌ ‌were‌ ‌simple‌ ‌with‌ ‌only‌ ‌three‌ ‌main‌ ‌cusps.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌lower‌ ‌molar‌ ‌had‌ ‌five‌ ‌to‌ ‌six‌ ‌cusps.‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌is‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌modern‌ ‌tarsiers.‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌other‌ ‌living‌ ‌primates‌ ‌there‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌a‌ ‌trend‌ ‌to‌ ‌add‌ ‌a‌ ‌fourth‌ ‌kasht‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌lower‌ ‌molar.‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌has‌ ‌left‌ ‌only‌ ‌4‌ ‌or‌ ‌5‌ ‌cusp‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌lower‌ ‌molar.‌ ‌\n○Both‌ ‌the‌ ‌upper‌ ‌and‌ ‌lower‌ ‌molars‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌old‌ ‌world‌ ‌monkey‌ ‌have‌ ‌4‌ ‌cusps‌ ‌linked‌ ‌in‌ ‌pairs‌ ‌and‌ ‌forming‌ ‌two‌ ‌ridges.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌apes‌ ‌and‌ ‌men‌ ‌the‌ ‌upper‌ ‌molar‌ ‌have‌ ‌4‌ ‌cusp‌ ‌whereas‌ ‌lower‌ ‌molars‌ ‌have‌ ‌5‌ ‌cusp‌ ‌which‌ ‌forms‌ ‌a‌ ‌modified‌ ‌Y‌ ‌shaped‌ ‌fissure.‌ ‌\n○Evolutionary‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌of‌ ‌reduction‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌teeth‌ ‌of‌ ‌Primates‌ ‌is‌ ‌still‌ ‌continuing.‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌apes‌ ‌and‌ ‌humans‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌possibility‌ ‌of‌ ‌further‌ ‌reduction‌ ‌in‌ ‌dental‌ ‌formula‌ ‌as‌ ‌sometimes‌ ‌3rd‌ ‌molars‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌develop‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nsome‌ ‌individuals.‌ ‌\n ‌\n2.‌ ‌Brain‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Primate‌ ‌brain‌ ‌is‌ ‌characterized‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌general‌ ‌increase‌ ‌in‌ ‌size‌ ‌relative‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌body‌ ‌size.‌ ‌\n●As‌ ‌the‌ ‌size‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌body‌ ‌increases‌ ‌so‌ ‌does‌ ‌the‌ ‌size‌ ‌of‌ ‌various‌ ‌parts‌ ‌including‌ ‌the‌ ‌brain.‌ ‌\n●Areas‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌sense‌ ‌of‌ ‌smell‌ ‌have‌ ‌undergone‌ ‌reduction.‌ ‌\n●Areas‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌vision‌ ‌and‌ ‌sense‌ ‌of‌ ‌touch‌ ‌have‌ ‌become‌ ‌elaborate.‌ ‌\n●Development‌ ‌of‌ ‌tool‌ ‌making‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌human‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌have‌ ‌affected‌ ‌the‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌brain.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌cortical‌ ‌area‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌hand‌ ‌coordination‌ ‌is‌ ‌about‌ ‌three‌ ‌times‌ ‌as‌ ‌extensive‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Apes‌ ‌brain‌ ‌and‌ ‌expansion‌ ‌of‌ ‌areas‌ ‌concerned‌ ‌\nwith‌ ‌language‌ ‌is‌ ‌even‌ ‌greater.‌ ‌ ‌\n●There‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌a‌ ‌gradual‌ ‌increase‌ ‌in‌ ‌size‌ ‌of‌ ‌cerebellum,‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌balance‌ ‌or‌ ‌equilibrium.‌ ‌\n ‌\n3.‌ ‌Hand‌ ‌\n●Greater‌ ‌flexibility‌ ‌In‌ ‌the‌ ‌finger‌ ‌permitting‌ ‌the‌ ‌grasping‌ ‌and‌ ‌manipulating‌ ‌object.‌ ‌\n●Beside‌ ‌locomotion‌ ‌behind‌ ‌has‌ ‌also‌ ‌been‌ ‌used‌ ‌for‌ ‌exploring‌ ‌surrounding‌ ‌among‌ ‌other‌ ‌things.‌ ‌\n ‌\n4.‌ ‌Orthograde‌ ‌Posture‌ ‌\nIt‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌manner‌ ‌of‌ ‌upright‌ ‌walking‌ ‌with‌ ‌independent‌ ‌motion‌ ‌of‌ ‌limbs‌ ‌\n●Spinal‌ ‌cord‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌man‌ ‌the‌ ‌vertebral‌ ‌column‌ ‌shows‌ ‌progressive‌ ‌increase‌ ‌in‌ ‌size.‌ ‌Hence‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌conical‌ ‌in‌ ‌outline‌ ‌which‌ ‌can‌ ‌bear‌ ‌the‌ ‌weight‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌head‌ ‌\nas‌ ‌much‌ ‌efficiently.‌ ‌\n63‌ ‌\n●Pelvic‌ ‌girdle‌ ‌\n ‌\n○Because‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌shape‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌pelvis‌ ‌in‌ ‌men.‌ ‌It‌ ‌can‌ ‌support‌ ‌the‌ ‌internal‌ ‌organ‌ ‌against‌ ‌gravitation.‌ ‌\n●Femur‌ ‌head‌ ‌has‌ ‌a‌ ‌large‌ ‌angle‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌axis‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌shaft‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌femur,‌ ‌which‌ ‌joins‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌pelvis.‌ ‌it‌ ‌makes‌ ‌all‌ ‌round‌ ‌movement‌ ‌of‌ ‌legs.‌ ‌\n ‌\nImage‌ ‌Link‌ ‌\n ‌\n●The‌ ‌hip‌ ‌muscles,‌ ‌Gluteus‌ ‌maximus,‌ ‌Gluteus‌ ‌Medius‌ ‌and‌ ‌Gluteus‌ ‌Minimus‌ ‌Are‌ ‌well‌ ‌developed‌ ‌in‌ ‌men‌ ‌for‌ ‌stabilizing‌ ‌pelvis‌ ‌during‌ ‌walking.‌ ‌\n ‌\n64‌ ‌\nThus,‌ ‌anatomy‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌response‌ ‌to‌ ‌adaptation‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌environment;‌ ‌the‌ ‌change‌ ‌in‌ ‌Anatomy‌ ‌correlates‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌changing‌ ‌environment;‌ ‌this‌ ‌\nCardinal‌ ‌principle‌ ‌is‌ ‌evident‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌case‌ ‌of‌ ‌Primate‌ ‌evolution.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nPrimates‌ ‌Taxonomy:‌ ‌\n ‌\nTraditionally,‌ ‌the‌ ‌order‌ ‌Primates‌ ‌was‌ ‌divided‌ ‌into:‌ ‌\n●Prosimians‌‌ ‌(the‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌primates:‌ ‌lemurs,‌ ‌lorises,‌ ‌and‌ ‌tarsiers)‌ ‌i.e‌ ‌lower‌ ‌primates‌ ‌ ‌\n●Anthropoidea‌ ‌‌(the‌ ‌bigger-brained‌ ‌monkeys‌ ‌and‌ ‌apes,‌ ‌including‌ ‌humans)‌ ‌i.e.‌ ‌higher‌ ‌primates.‌ ‌\n65‌ ‌\n ‌\nIt‌ ‌is‌ ‌now‌ ‌known‌ ‌that‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌“‌prosimians‌,”‌ ‌the‌ ‌tarsier,‌ ‌is‌ ‌actually‌ ‌more‌ ‌closely‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌“anthropoids‌,”‌ ‌so‌ ‌the‌ ‌classification‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nprimates‌ ‌has‌ ‌had‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌revised.‌ ‌ ‌\nThe‌ ‌two‌ ‌suborders‌ ‌recognized‌ ‌today‌ ‌are‌ ‌‌Strepsirrhini‌ ‌(lemurs‌ ‌and‌ ‌lorises)‌ ‌‌and‌ ‌‌Haplorrhini‌ ‌(tarsiers,‌ ‌monkeys,‌ ‌and‌ ‌apes,‌ ‌including‌ ‌\nhumans)‌.‌ ‌\nThe‌ ‌present‌ ‌classification‌ ‌was‌ ‌adopted‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌early‌ ‌1970s‌,‌ ‌when‌ ‌the‌ ‌logic‌ ‌of‌ ‌phylogenetic‌ ‌systematics‌ ‌was‌ ‌beginning‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌appreciated,‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌the‌ ‌taxonomy‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌order‌ ‌Primates‌ ‌was‌ ‌reorganized‌ ‌so‌ ‌as‌ ‌to‌ ‌make‌ ‌taxa‌ ‌equivalent,‌ ‌as‌ ‌far‌ ‌as‌ ‌possible,‌ ‌to‌ ‌clades.‌ ‌In‌ ‌this‌ ‌classification,‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌order‌ ‌is‌ ‌divided‌ ‌into‌ ‌the‌ ‌suborder‌ ‌‌Strepsirrhini‌ ‌‌and‌ ‌‌Haplorrhini,‌‌ ‌and‌ ‌these‌ ‌in‌ ‌turn‌ ‌are‌ ‌divided‌ ‌into‌ ‌infraorders.‌ ‌\nDetailed‌ ‌Taxonomy-‌Image‌ ‌Link‌ ‌\n66‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●This‌ ‌division‌ ‌is‌ ‌mainly‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌brain‌ ‌size‌ ‌of‌ ‌both‌ ‌the‌ ‌orders.‌ ‌\n●Brains‌ ‌sizes‌ ‌of‌ ‌lower‌ ‌primates‌ ‌have‌ ‌similar‌ ‌size‌ ‌to‌ ‌other‌ ‌mammals‌ ‌while‌ ‌higher‌ ‌primates‌ ‌have‌ ‌large‌ ‌brain‌ ‌size‌ ‌relative‌ ‌to‌ ‌body‌ ‌size.‌ ‌\n●Order‌ ‌primate‌ ‌of‌ ‌class‌ ‌Mammalia‌ ‌includes‌ ‌various‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌animals.‌ ‌ ‌\n●At‌ ‌the‌ ‌one‌ ‌end‌ ‌it‌ ‌has‌ ‌prosimian‌ ‌which‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌small‌ ‌as‌ ‌squirrels‌ ‌and‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌hand,‌ ‌has‌ ‌large‌ ‌sized‌ ‌animals‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌Man‌ ‌and‌ ‌Gorilla.‌ ‌\n●At‌ ‌both‌ ‌the‌ ‌ends‌ ‌of‌ ‌primate‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌lot‌ ‌of‌ ‌difference‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌structure,‌ ‌behaviours‌ ‌,‌ ‌and‌ ‌intelligence.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Such‌ ‌a‌ ‌large‌ ‌difference‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌any‌ ‌other‌ ‌order.‌ ‌ ‌\n67‌ ‌\n●But‌ ‌still‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌many‌ ‌similarities‌ ‌keeping‌ ‌all‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌order‌ ‌primates‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌single‌ ‌group‌ ‌seems‌ ‌logical,‌ ‌yet‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌very‌ ‌difficult‌ ‌to‌ ‌\ndefine‌ ‌this‌ ‌order‌ ‌because‌ ‌of‌ ‌many‌ ‌differences.‌ ‌\n ‌\nImage‌ ‌Link‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nCladogram‌ ‌of‌ ‌Primates:‌ ‌ ‌\n68‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n1.5‌ ‌Primate‌ ‌Adaptations;‌ ‌(Arboreal‌ ‌and‌ ‌Terrestrial)‌ ‌Primate‌ ‌Taxonomy;-Part‌ ‌II‌ ‌\n ‌\nPrimate‌ ‌Adaptations;‌ ‌ ‌\n69‌ ‌\nGeneral‌ ‌Adaptation:‌ ‌\nPrimates‌ ‌have‌ ‌diversified‌ ‌in‌ ‌arboreal‌ ‌and‌ ‌terrestrial‌ ‌habitats‌ ‌(trees,‌ ‌bushes‌ ‌and‌ ‌land)‌ ‌and‌ ‌retain‌ ‌many‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌facilitating‌ ‌adaptations‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nthese‌ ‌environments:‌ ‌\n●Retention‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌collar‌ ‌bone‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌pectoral‌ ‌girdle.‌ ‌\n●Shoulder‌ ‌joints‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌high‌ ‌degree‌ ‌of‌ ‌movement‌ ‌in‌ ‌all‌ ‌directions.‌ ‌\n●Possession‌ ‌of‌ ‌five‌ ‌digits‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌fore‌ ‌and‌ ‌hind‌ ‌limbs‌ ‌with‌ ‌opposable‌ ‌thumbs‌ ‌and‌ ‌big‌ ‌toes‌ ‌facilitating‌ ‌them‌ ‌in‌ ‌grasping‌ ‌objects‌ ‌and‌ ‌climbing‌ ‌\ntrees.‌ ‌\n●Presence‌ ‌of‌ ‌nails‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌fingers‌ ‌and‌ ‌toes‌ ‌in‌ ‌most‌ ‌species.‌ ‌\n●Presence‌ ‌of‌ ‌sensitive‌ ‌tactile‌ ‌pads‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌ends‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌digits.‌ ‌\n●Orbits‌ ‌encircled‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌bony‌ ‌rim‌ ‌facilitating‌ ‌rotation‌ ‌of‌ ‌eyeballs‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌socket.‌ ‌\n●Trend‌ ‌towards‌ ‌a‌ ‌reduced‌ ‌snout‌ ‌and‌ ‌flattened‌ ‌face‌ ‌supposedly‌ ‌leading‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌vision‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌expense‌ ‌of‌ ‌olfaction.‌ ‌\n●Complex‌ ‌visual‌ ‌system‌ ‌with‌ ‌stereoscopic‌ ‌vision,‌ ‌high‌ ‌visual‌ ‌acuity‌ ‌and‌ ‌color‌ ‌vision‌ ‌–‌ ‌all‌ ‌contributing‌ ‌to‌ ‌quicker‌ ‌movements‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌trees.‌ ‌\n●Large‌ ‌brain‌ ‌in‌ ‌comparison‌ ‌to‌ ‌body‌ ‌size‌ ‌especially‌ ‌in‌ ‌simians.‌ ‌\n●Differentiation‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌enlarged‌ ‌cerebral‌ ‌cortex.‌ ‌\n●Reduction‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌teeth‌ ‌compared‌ ‌to‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌mammals.‌ ‌\n●Three‌ ‌kinds‌ ‌of‌ ‌teeth.‌ ‌\n●Longer‌ ‌gestation‌ ‌and‌ ‌developmental‌ ‌period;‌ ‌and‌ ‌\n●Trend‌ ‌towards‌ ‌holding‌ ‌the‌ ‌torso‌ ‌upright‌ ‌leading‌ ‌to‌ ‌bipedalism.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nMovement‌ ‌Adaptation:‌ ‌\nDue‌ ‌to‌ ‌to‌ ‌various‌ ‌body‌ ‌sizes‌ ‌specialised‌ ‌skeleton‌ ‌and‌ ‌habits‌ ‌Primates‌ ‌showed‌ ‌various‌ ‌adaptation‌ ‌in‌ ‌movements:‌ ‌\n1.Clinging(‌ ‌Vertical)‌ ‌and‌ ‌Leaping‌ ‌\n70‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌found‌ ‌that‌ ‌in‌ ‌tarsiers,‌ ‌galago‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌When‌ ‌an‌ ‌animal‌ ‌is‌ ‌on‌ ‌rest,‌ ‌clinging‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌branch,‌ ‌keeping‌ ‌its‌ ‌body‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌vertical‌ ‌position.‌ ‌While‌ ‌\nmoving‌ ‌it‌ ‌will‌ ‌lead‌ ‌landing‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌second‌ ‌branch‌ ‌vertically‌ ‌and‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌ground‌ ‌they‌ ‌move‌ ‌by‌ ‌hopping‌ ‌or‌ ‌bipedal.‌ ‌\n ‌\n● ‌Bone‌ ‌is‌ ‌very‌ ‌small‌ ‌in‌ ‌men‌ ‌and‌ ‌is‌ ‌extremely‌ ‌long‌ ‌in‌ ‌tarsiers.‌ ‌Tarsal‌ ‌bones‌ ‌act‌ ‌as‌ ‌an‌ ‌added‌ ‌spring.‌ ‌\n2.Quadrupedalism‌ ‌\n●Means‌ ‌an‌ ‌animal‌ ‌more‌ ‌on‌ ‌or‌ ‌four‌ ‌Limbs‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌body‌ ‌is‌ ‌held‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌ground‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌shown‌ ‌by‌ ‌monkeys‌ ‌and‌ ‌Apes.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●In‌ ‌monkeys‌ ‌they‌ ‌move‌ ‌quadrupedalism‌ ‌on‌ ‌both‌ ‌ground‌ ‌and‌ ‌pre‌ ‌branches‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌best‌ ‌possible‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌following‌ ‌factors.‌ ‌\n○Small‌ ‌to‌ ‌moderate‌ ‌size‌ ‌of‌ ‌body.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌big‌ ‌toe‌ ‌is‌ ‌prehensile‌ ‌and‌ ‌set‌ ‌at‌ ‌a‌ ‌Greater‌ ‌angle‌ ‌than‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌prosimians.‌ ‌\n71‌ ‌\n●Both‌ ‌the‌ ‌thumb‌ ‌and‌ ‌big‌ ‌toe‌ ‌are‌ ‌diverse‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌rest‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌finger.‌ ‌\n●Thus,‌ ‌both‌ ‌the‌ ‌hands‌ ‌and‌ ‌legs‌ ‌of‌ ‌Monkey‌ ‌are‌ ‌prehensile.‌ ‌This‌ ‌makes‌ ‌the‌ ‌monkey‌ ‌very‌ ‌much‌ ‌Agile‌ ‌On‌ ‌tree.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌Apes,‌ ‌they‌ ‌perform‌ ‌quadrupedalism‌ ‌on‌ ‌land,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌types:‌ ‌\n○Palm‌ ‌and‌ ‌fist‌ ‌walking‌-‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌performed‌ ‌by‌ ‌Orangutan‌ ‌on‌ ‌land,‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌whole‌ ‌Palm‌ ‌and‌ ‌fist‌ ‌of‌ ‌hand‌ ‌and‌ ‌legs.‌ ‌\nThey‌ ‌predominantly‌ ‌live‌ ‌on‌ ‌land‌ ‌because‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌body.‌ ‌\n○Knuckle‌ ‌walking-‌‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌commonly‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌Chimpanzee‌ ‌and‌ ‌Gorilla.‌ ‌In‌ ‌this‌ ‌case‌ ‌fingers‌ ‌bend‌ ‌and‌ ‌touch‌ ‌the‌ ‌ground.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nIt‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌attributed‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌following:‌ ‌\n■Fingers‌ ‌are‌ ‌thickly‌ ‌padded.‌ ‌\n■Pelvis‌ ‌is‌ ‌elongated‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌knee‌ ‌is‌ ‌habitually‌ ‌bent.‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌whole‌ ‌foot‌ ‌makes‌ ‌contact‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌surface.‌ ‌ ‌\n3.Brachiation‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌suspensory‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌hands‌ ‌are‌ ‌used‌ ‌as‌ ‌main‌ ‌locomotory‌ ‌organs.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌of‌ ‌following‌ ‌type:‌ ‌\n○Primitive‌ ‌brachiation‌ ‌\n■Here,‌ ‌the‌ ‌animal‌ ‌uses‌ ‌both‌ ‌hands‌ ‌alternatively‌ ‌and‌ ‌turns‌ ‌180‌ ‌Deg‌ ‌While‌ ‌progressing‌ ‌through‌ ‌a‌ ‌branch.‌ ‌\n○True‌ ‌brachiation‌ ‌\n■In‌ ‌this‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌flight‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌air‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌animal‌ ‌jumps‌ ‌from‌ ‌a‌ ‌branch‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌other.‌ ‌\n■In‌ ‌such‌ ‌cases‌ ‌both‌ ‌the‌ ‌hands‌ ‌are‌ ‌used(‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌cheat‌ ‌Locomotory‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌of‌ ‌Apes‌ ‌though‌ ‌All‌ ‌Apes‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌equally‌ ‌\nefficient‌ ‌in‌ ‌brachiation.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nThere‌ ‌are‌ ‌now‌ ‌only‌ ‌about‌ ‌‌20‌ ‌living‌ ‌species‌ ‌of‌ ‌apes‌ ‌and‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌divided‌ ‌into‌ ‌two‌ ‌major‌ ‌groups.‌ ‌These‌ ‌are‌ ‌the:‌ ‌\nLesser‌ ‌Apes,‌ ‌containing‌ ‌the‌ ‌gibbons.‌ ‌Great‌ ‌Apes,‌ ‌containing‌ ‌the‌ ‌orang-utans,‌ ‌gorillas,‌ ‌chimpanzees‌ ‌and‌ ‌humans.‌ ‌\n72‌ ‌\n■Gibbons‌ ‌are‌ ‌most‌ ‌efficient‌ ‌brecciated‌ ‌among‌ ‌all‌ ‌Apes‌ ‌because:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Very‌ ‌small‌ ‌size‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌body‌ ‌\n●Extremely‌ ‌long‌ ‌forelimb‌ ‌in‌ ‌comparison‌ ‌to‌ ‌Hindlimb‌ ‌\n●Shortening‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌posterior‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌body,‌ ‌converts‌ ‌the‌ ‌body‌ ‌into‌ ‌a‌ ‌compact‌ ‌mass,‌ ‌consisting‌ ‌mainly‌ ‌of‌ ‌trunk‌ ‌\nwhich‌ ‌can‌ ‌rotate‌ ‌more‌ ‌easily‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌increased‌ ‌centrifugal‌ ‌force.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌collarbone‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌nature‌ ‌of‌ ‌attachment‌ ‌of‌ ‌head‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌shoulder‌ ‌blade‌ ‌facilitate‌ ‌free‌ ‌rotation‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌arm‌ ‌\nin‌ ‌the‌ ‌overhead‌ ‌position‌ ‌and‌ ‌capable‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌round‌ ‌movement‌ ‌\n○SemiBrachiation‌ ‌\n73‌ ‌\n■When‌ ‌some‌ ‌quadrupeds‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌Spider‌ ‌Monkey‌ ‌and‌ ‌wooly‌ ‌monkey‌ ‌use‌ ‌their‌ ‌prehensile‌ ‌tail‌ ‌in‌ ‌addition‌ ‌to‌ ‌their‌ ‌hands‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌suspend‌ ‌and‌ ‌move‌ ‌forward‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌branches‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌tree‌ ‌\n.‌ ‌\n4.Bipedalism‌ ‌\nIn‌ ‌a‌ ‌man's‌ ‌foot‌ ‌heel‌ ‌the‌ ‌big‌ ‌toe‌ ‌is‌ ‌well‌ ‌developed‌ ‌and‌ ‌not‌ ‌opposable.‌ ‌Also‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌two‌ ‌arches‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌foot‌ ‌helping‌ ‌in‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌of‌ ‌load‌ ‌\nwhile‌ ‌standing.Thus,‌ ‌skeletal‌ ‌change‌ ‌in‌ ‌various‌ ‌primates‌ ‌are‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌terrestrial‌ ‌arboreal‌ ‌adaptation.‌ ‌Consequently,‌ ‌they‌ ‌exploit‌ ‌different‌ ‌\nkinds‌ ‌of‌ ‌habitat‌ ‌which‌ ‌resulted‌ ‌in‌ ‌diversification‌ ‌of‌ ‌primates.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Changes‌ ‌associated‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌bipedalism‌ ‌\n○Changes‌ ‌in‌ ‌spinal‌ ‌cord‌ ‌\n■Spinal‌ ‌cord‌ ‌developed‌ ‌for‌ ‌distinctive‌ ‌curves-‌ ‌cervical,‌ ‌thoracic,‌ ‌lumber‌ ‌and‌ ‌sacral.‌ ‌\n■These‌ ‌curves‌ ‌allow‌ ‌the‌ ‌erectness‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌spine.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Change‌ ‌in‌ ‌Sacrum‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌vertebrates‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Sacral‌ ‌region‌ ‌unite‌ ‌with‌ ‌Ilium‌ ‌of‌ ‌pelvis,‌ ‌the‌ ‌latter‌ ‌in‌ ‌turn‌ ‌to‌ ‌femur.‌ ‌This‌ ‌small‌ ‌distance‌ ‌between‌ ‌\nthese‌ ‌two‌ ‌joints‌ ‌allowed‌ ‌the‌ ‌transfer‌ ‌of‌ ‌load‌ ‌directly‌ ‌to‌ ‌femur.‌ ‌\n○Change‌ ‌in‌ ‌vertebral‌ ‌column‌ ‌\n■From‌ ‌top‌ ‌to‌ ‌bottom‌ ‌the‌ ‌vertebra‌ ‌gradually‌ ‌increases‌ ‌in‌ ‌size‌ ‌this‌ ‌gives‌ ‌the‌ ‌human‌ ‌vertebral‌ ‌column‌ ‌its‌ ‌characteristic‌ ‌\ncone‌ ‌shape‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌more‌ ‌stable‌ ‌in‌ ‌load‌ ‌bearing‌ ‌function.‌ ‌\n○Change‌ ‌in‌ ‌Skull‌ ‌\n■In‌ ‌a‌ ‌quadrilateral‌ ‌animal,‌ ‌the‌ ‌foramen‌ ‌Magnum‌ ‌is‌ ‌situated‌ ‌more‌ ‌dorsally.‌ ‌in‌ ‌human‌ ‌being‌ ‌it‌ ‌has‌ ‌shifted‌ ‌forward‌ ‌and‌ ‌\ndownward‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌centre‌ ‌of‌ ‌Skull.‌ ‌\nValue‌ ‌addition‌ ‌\n74‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nImage‌ ‌Link‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nAdaptive‌ ‌radiation‌ ‌in‌ ‌Primates(PYQ:‌ ‌2015)‌ ‌\n ‌\n●The‌ ‌Rapid‌ ‌increase‌ ‌and‌ ‌spread‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌evolving‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌organisms‌ ‌which‌ ‌diversify‌ ‌and‌ ‌adapt‌ ‌to‌ ‌new‌ ‌niches‌ ‌as‌ ‌adaptive‌ ‌radiation.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌formation‌ ‌of‌ ‌many‌ ‌species‌ ‌following‌ ‌the‌ ‌availability‌ ‌of‌ ‌new‌ ‌environments‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌new‌ ‌adaptation‌ ‌is‌ ‌called‌ ‌adaptive‌ ‌\nradiation.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌primates‌ ‌comprise‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌150‌ ‌living‌ ‌species‌ ‌this‌ ‌fall‌ ‌within‌ ‌two‌ ‌sub‌ ‌orders:‌ ‌Prosimian‌ ‌and‌ ‌Anthropoidae.‌ ‌\n●Though‌ ‌in‌ ‌many‌ ‌ways‌ ‌the‌ ‌premade‌ ‌species‌ ‌showed‌ ‌remarkable‌ ‌similarities‌ ‌that‌ ‌they‌ ‌have‌ ‌adapted‌ ‌in‌ ‌distinct‌ ‌ways‌ ‌both‌ ‌anatomically‌ ‌and‌ ‌\notherwise.‌ ‌ ‌\n● ‌There‌ ‌were‌ ‌about‌ ‌64‌ ‌genera‌ ‌of‌ ‌prosimians‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Eocene.‌ ‌but‌ ‌today‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌only‌ ‌16‌ ‌generals‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌world.‌ ‌\n● ‌The‌ ‌most‌ ‌diverse‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌best‌ ‌known‌ ‌eocene‌ ‌prosimian‌ ‌were‌ ‌the‌ ‌lemurs.‌ ‌\n● ‌Today,‌ ‌Lemur‌ ‌exists‌ ‌only‌ ‌in‌ ‌Madagascar‌ ‌and‌ ‌its‌ ‌adjacent‌ ‌Island‌ ‌off‌ ‌the‌ ‌east‌ ‌coast‌ ‌of‌ ‌Africa.‌ ‌\n● ‌one‌ ‌unusual‌ ‌Lemur‌ ‌called‌ ‌aye-aye‌ ‌who‌ ‌still‌ ‌lives‌ ‌in‌ ‌Madagascar‌ ‌suggests‌ ‌a‌ ‌rodent-like‌ ‌adaptation.‌ ‌\n75‌ ‌\n● ‌Another‌ ‌called‌‌ ‌Indri‌‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌largest‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌lemur‌ ‌in‌ ‌Madagascar.‌ ‌\n● ‌The‌ ‌hindlimbs‌ ‌are‌ ‌larger‌ ‌than‌ ‌the‌ ‌forelimbs.‌ ‌\n● ‌Finally‌ ‌the‌ ‌Megala‌ ‌Dapis‌ ‌weighing‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌300pounds‌ ‌are‌ ‌extremely‌ ‌short‌ ‌Limbs.‌ ‌\n● ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌now‌ ‌extinct;‌ ‌this‌ ‌kind‌ ‌of‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌limos‌ ‌characterized‌ ‌by‌ ‌Rapid‌ ‌diversification‌ ‌and‌ ‌expansion‌ ‌into‌ ‌varied‌ ‌ecological‌ ‌niches‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌\nexample‌ ‌of‌ ‌adaptive‌ ‌radiation‌ ‌in‌ ‌primates.‌ ‌\n ‌\n(Arboreal‌ ‌and‌ ‌Terrestrial)‌ ‌Primate‌ ‌Taxonomy;‌ ‌ ‌\nMost‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌primate‌ ‌species‌ ‌are‌ ‌mostly‌ ‌arboreal‌ ‌and‌ ‌inhabit‌ ‌forest‌ ‌or‌ ‌woodland‌ ‌ecological‌ ‌settings.Certain‌ ‌primate‌ ‌species‌ ‌(such‌ ‌as‌ ‌baboons)‌ ‌have‌ ‌\nadapted‌ ‌to‌ ‌life‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌ground‌ ‌in‌ ‌places‌ ‌where‌ ‌trees‌ ‌are‌ ‌sparsely‌ ‌distributed.‌ ‌The‌ ‌African‌ ‌apes,‌ ‌namely,‌ ‌gorillas,‌ ‌chimpanzees,‌ ‌and‌ ‌bonobos‌ ‌also‌ ‌\ninvest‌ ‌much‌ ‌time‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌ground‌ ‌in‌ ‌forested‌ ‌and‌ ‌wooded‌ ‌ecological‌ ‌settings.‌ ‌But‌ ‌no‌ ‌nonhuman‌ ‌primate‌ ‌is‌ ‌adapted‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌complete‌ ‌terrestrial‌ ‌lifestyle‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌thus‌ ‌they‌ ‌spend‌ ‌some‌ ‌time‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌trees.‌ ‌\n ‌\nCharacteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌Prosimian‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌locomotion‌ ‌in‌ ‌are‌ ‌boreal‌ ‌life,‌ ‌usually‌ ‌two‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌adaptation‌ ‌is‌ ‌found.‌ ‌\n●Tarsius‌ ‌has‌ ‌long‌ ‌legs‌ ‌for‌ ‌holding‌ ‌branches‌ ‌and‌ ‌for‌ ‌jumping‌ ‌from‌ ‌one‌ ‌branch‌ ‌to‌ ‌another‌ ‌and‌ ‌muscles‌ ‌developed‌ ‌in‌ ‌compact.‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌slow‌ ‌quaderplasim,‌ ‌lemurs‌ ‌have‌ ‌short‌ ‌forelimbs‌ ‌and‌ ‌limbs‌ ‌are‌ ‌of‌ ‌same‌ ‌size,‌ ‌mobile‌ ‌pelvis‌ ‌and‌ ‌talus‌ ‌for‌ ‌swinging,‌ ‌tail‌ ‌small‌ ‌or‌ ‌absent.‌ ‌\n●Lack‌ ‌of‌ ‌separate‌ ‌mobility‌ ‌of‌ ‌fingers,‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌of‌ ‌them‌ ‌possible,‌ ‌precision‌ ‌grip‌ ‌impossible,‌ ‌to‌ ‌increase‌ ‌the‌ ‌hold,‌ ‌grip‌ ‌digits‌ ‌of‌ ‌figures‌ ‌with‌ ‌pads‌ ‌\n(feature‌ ‌of‌ ‌Men)‌ ‌\n●Claw‌ ‌in‌ ‌place‌ ‌of‌ ‌nail,‌ ‌usually‌ ‌on‌ ‌second‌ ‌and‌ ‌third‌ ‌finger‌ ‌for‌ ‌cleansing‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌body‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌comparison‌ ‌to‌ ‌anthropoids‌ ‌laterally‌ ‌placed‌ ‌eyes,‌ ‌eyeballs‌ ‌not‌ ‌completely‌ ‌surrounded‌ ‌by‌ ‌bones.‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌better‌ ‌hearing‌ ‌long‌ ‌and‌ ‌mobile‌ ‌ears.‌ ‌\n●Developed‌ ‌olfaction‌ ‌and‌ ‌organs‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌it.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌maxilla‌ ‌incisors‌ ‌are‌ ‌small‌ ‌and‌ ‌canines‌ ‌larger,‌ ‌in‌ ‌many‌ ‌species‌ ‌lower‌ ‌incisors‌ ‌and‌ ‌canines‌ ‌together‌ ‌are‌ ‌efficient‌ ‌in‌ ‌cleaning‌ ‌the‌ ‌body.‌ ‌\nDental‌ ‌formula‌ ‌usually‌ ‌2:1:3:3‌ ‌\n●Foramen‌ ‌Magnum‌ ‌comparatively‌ ‌backward‌ ‌placed‌ ‌\n●Cerebrum‌ ‌small‌ ‌in‌ ‌size‌ ‌and‌ ‌lacking‌ ‌in‌ ‌complexity.‌ ‌\n●Digital‌ ‌formula‌ ‌usually‌ ‌IV>III>V>II>I‌ ‌\n●All‌ ‌animals‌ ‌arboreal‌ ‌usually‌ ‌nocturnal‌ ‌\n●Many‌ ‌characters‌ ‌of‌ ‌lower‌ ‌primates‌ ‌resemble‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌other‌ ‌mammals‌ ‌than‌ ‌higher‌ ‌primates.‌ ‌Specialized‌ ‌characters‌ ‌of‌ ‌primates‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌\nmuch‌ ‌developed‌ ‌in‌ ‌Prosomii,‌ ‌whereas‌ ‌in‌ ‌case‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropoids‌ ‌the‌ ‌situation‌ ‌is‌ ‌just‌ ‌reversed.‌ ‌For‌ ‌example‌ ‌opposability‌ ‌of‌ ‌thumbs‌ ‌is‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌all‌ ‌\nanthropoids‌ ‌whereas‌ ‌in‌ ‌Prosomii‌ ‌such‌ ‌possibility‌ ‌is‌ ‌marginally‌ ‌present.‌ ‌Similarly‌ ‌in‌ ‌prosimii‌ ‌second‌ ‌and‌ ‌third‌ ‌finger‌ ‌digit‌ ‌has‌ ‌claw‌ ‌instead‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nnail.‌ ‌Specialized‌ ‌/‌ ‌evolved‌ ‌characters‌ ‌of‌ ‌primates‌ ‌are‌ ‌seen‌ ‌in‌ ‌men‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌why‌ ‌man‌ ‌is‌ ‌higher‌ ‌primate.‌ ‌Otherwise‌ ‌characters‌ ‌typical‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nProsomii‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌men.‌ ‌That‌ ‌is‌ ‌why‌ ‌men‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌be‌ ‌considered‌ ‌a‌ ‌member‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌suborder.‌ ‌\n●Present‌ ‌day‌ ‌Prosomii‌ ‌are‌ ‌descendants‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌45‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌old‌ ‌large‌ ‌and‌ ‌mixed‌ ‌group,‌ ‌from‌ ‌which‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌of‌ ‌Anthropoids‌ ‌separated‌ ‌\nabout‌ ‌35‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago.‌ ‌\n ‌\n76‌ ‌\nCharacteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌Anthropoid‌ ‌are‌ ‌as‌ ‌follows:‌ ‌\n●Large‌ ‌and‌ ‌comparative‌ ‌round‌ ‌cranium.‌ ‌\n●Reduction‌ ‌in‌ ‌prognathism‌ ‌and‌ ‌size‌ ‌of‌ ‌nasal‌ ‌cavity,‌ ‌Face‌ ‌showing‌ ‌sign‌ ‌of‌ ‌coming‌ ‌right‌ ‌under‌ ‌frontal‌ ‌lobe‌ ‌of‌ ‌brain.‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌front‌ ‌vision‌ ‌eyes‌ ‌are‌ ‌placed‌ ‌nearer‌ ‌to‌ ‌each‌ ‌other.‌ ‌\n●Facial‌ ‌muscles‌ ‌developed.‌ ‌\n●Fingers‌ ‌of‌ ‌foot‌ ‌and‌ ‌hand‌ ‌with‌ ‌nails,‌ ‌third‌ ‌finger‌ ‌longer‌ ‌than‌ ‌the‌ ‌fourth‌ ‌or‌ ‌same‌ ‌as‌ ‌fourth.‌ ‌\n●Pinna‌ ‌small‌ ‌and‌ ‌movable‌ ‌\n●Lachrymal‌ ‌canal‌ ‌opens‌ ‌into‌ ‌orbital‌ ‌cavity‌ ‌\n●Greater‌ ‌capacity‌ ‌for‌ ‌bipedalism‌ ‌\n●Hands‌ ‌prehensile.‌ ‌\n●Many‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌classify‌ ‌anthropoids‌ ‌into‌ ‌two‌ ‌natural‌ ‌groups‌ ‌i.e.‌ ‌Platyrrhini‌ ‌and‌ ‌Catarrhini.‌ ‌Platyrrhini,‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌geographical‌ ‌\ndistribution‌ ‌are‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌New‌ ‌World‌ ‌Monkeys‌ ‌and‌ ‌Catarrhini‌ ‌are‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌Old‌ ‌World‌ ‌Monkeys‌ ‌which‌ ‌include‌ ‌Cercopithecoidea‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nHominoidea.‌ ‌Though‌ ‌both‌ ‌of‌ ‌them‌ ‌have‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Anthropoids‌ ‌but‌ ‌Platyrrhini‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌following‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌\ncan‌ ‌be‌ ‌separated‌ ‌from‌ ‌Catarrhini.‌ ‌\n ‌\nCharacteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌New‌ ‌World‌ ‌Monkey(‌ ‌Platyrrhini)‌ ‌\n●Brain‌ ‌more‌ ‌developed‌ ‌and‌ ‌complex‌ ‌than‌ ‌Prosomii‌ ‌but‌ ‌less‌ ‌than‌ ‌Hominoids.‌ ‌\n●Dental‌ ‌formula‌ ‌2,1,3,3‌ ‌or‌ ‌2,1,3,2‌ ‌\n●Molars‌ ‌and‌ ‌premolars‌ ‌usually‌ ‌squarish‌ ‌\n●Zygomatic-Temporal‌ ‌fossa‌ ‌is‌ ‌bigger‌ ‌\n●Lack‌ ‌of‌ ‌buccal‌ ‌pouch‌ ‌\n●Lack‌ ‌of‌ ‌ischial‌ ‌callosities‌ ‌\n●Thumb‌ ‌not‌ ‌opposable‌ ‌and‌ ‌usually‌ ‌small‌ ‌or‌ ‌absent‌ ‌\n●Long‌ ‌big‌ ‌toe,‌ ‌more‌ ‌strong‌ ‌and‌ ‌distantly‌ ‌placed‌ ‌from‌ ‌fingers‌ ‌\n●Long‌ ‌and‌ ‌prehensile‌ ‌tail‌ ‌\n ‌\nCharacteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌Hominoidea‌ ‌\n●From‌ ‌an‌ ‌anthropological‌ ‌point‌ ‌of‌ ‌view‌ ‌Hominoidea‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌interesting‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌living‌ ‌primate‌ ‌world.‌ ‌Members‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌group‌ ‌are‌ ‌\nconsidered‌ ‌as‌ ‌most‌ ‌intelligent‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌entire‌ ‌animal‌ ‌kingdom.‌ ‌\n●Increase‌ ‌in‌ ‌size‌ ‌but‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌decrease‌ ‌in‌ ‌size‌ ‌of‌ ‌facial‌ ‌bones.‌ ‌\n●Change‌ ‌in‌ ‌dental‌ ‌arch‌ ‌from‌ ‌V‌ ‌shape‌ ‌to‌ ‌U‌ ‌shape.‌ ‌\n●Molars‌ ‌showing‌ ‌signs‌ ‌of‌ ‌increase‌ ‌in‌ ‌size‌ ‌\n●Lower‌ ‌third‌ ‌molar‌ ‌having‌ ‌characteristic‌ ‌Dryopithecus‌ ‌Y-5‌ ‌cusp‌ ‌pattern.‌ ‌\n●Foramen‌ ‌magnum‌ ‌and‌ ‌occipital‌ ‌condyle‌ ‌showing‌ ‌signs‌ ‌of‌ ‌forward‌ ‌movement.‌ ‌\n●Neck‌ ‌and‌ ‌forelimbs‌ ‌are‌ ‌long‌ ‌\n●Broad‌ ‌shoulders‌ ‌and‌ ‌iliac‌ ‌bone.‌ ‌\n77‌ ‌\n●More‌ ‌developed‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌forelimbs.‌ ‌Hind‌ ‌limbs‌ ‌are‌ ‌comparatively‌ ‌less‌ ‌developed.‌ ‌\n●Lack‌ ‌of‌ ‌externally‌ ‌visible‌ ‌tail‌ ‌\n●Besides‌ ‌the‌ ‌characters‌ ‌of‌ ‌Hominoidea‌ ‌listed,‌ ‌higher‌ ‌apes‌ ‌and‌ ‌man‌ ‌have‌ ‌many‌ ‌interesting‌ ‌similarities.‌ ‌Both‌ ‌have‌ ‌similar‌ ‌blood‌ ‌proteins.‌ ‌Both‌ ‌\nlive‌ ‌in‌ ‌small‌ ‌groups‌ ‌and‌ ‌both‌ ‌are‌ ‌prone‌ ‌to‌ ‌diseases‌ ‌like‌ ‌flu‌ ‌and‌ ‌syphilis.‌ ‌So‌ ‌can‌ ‌man‌ ‌be‌ ‌considered‌ ‌similar‌ ‌to‌ ‌apes?‌ ‌No‌ ‌because‌ ‌both‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nthem‌ ‌have‌ ‌significant‌ ‌differences,‌ ‌important‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌are‌ ‌listed‌ ‌here.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌comparison‌ ‌to‌ ‌apes‌ ‌knuckle‌ ‌walking,‌ ‌quadrupedalism‌ ‌and‌ ‌pronograde‌ ‌posture,‌ ‌man‌ ‌is‌ ‌bipedal‌ ‌and‌ ‌orthograde.‌ ‌\n●Hallux‌ ‌/‌ ‌great‌ ‌toe‌ ‌more‌ ‌developed‌ ‌and‌ ‌not‌ ‌opposable‌ ‌\n●Foot‌ ‌with‌ ‌curves‌ ‌to‌ ‌distribute‌ ‌body‌ ‌weight‌ ‌\n●Foramen‌ ‌magnum‌ ‌and‌ ‌occipital‌ ‌condyle‌ ‌placed‌ ‌lower‌ ‌and‌ ‌forward‌ ‌(sign‌ ‌of‌ ‌bipedalism)‌ ‌\n●Stereoscopic‌ ‌vision‌ ‌\n●Well-developed‌ ‌mastoid‌ ‌process.‌ ‌\n●Reduction‌ ‌in‌ ‌length‌ ‌of‌ ‌face‌ ‌and‌ ‌mandible,‌ ‌orthognathous‌ ‌or‌ ‌slight‌ ‌prognathous‌ ‌face.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Lemurs‌ ‌\n○Lemurs‌ ‌and‌ ‌lorises‌ ‌constitute‌ ‌most‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌primates‌ ‌as‌ ‌they‌ ‌have‌ ‌retained‌ ‌several‌ ‌ancestral‌ ‌traits,‌ ‌\n○such‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌more‌ ‌pronounced‌ ‌dependence‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌sense‌ ‌of‌ ‌smell‌ ‌(greater‌ ‌olfactory‌ ‌capabilities).‌ ‌Besides‌ ‌\n○Lemurs‌ ‌and‌ ‌lorises‌ ‌also‌ ‌exhibit‌ ‌a‌ ‌distinctive‌ ‌character‌ ‌termed‌ ‌as‌ ‌“dental‌ ‌comb”.‌ ‌\n○Lemurs‌ ‌are‌ ‌specifically‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌island‌ ‌of‌ ‌Madagascar.‌ ‌They‌ ‌also‌ ‌inhabit‌ ‌nearby‌ ‌islands‌ ‌off‌ ‌the‌ ‌east‌ ‌coast‌ ‌of‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌\n○Lemurs‌ ‌have‌ ‌successfully‌ ‌adapted‌ ‌to‌ ‌occupy‌ ‌numerous‌ ‌open‌ ‌ecological‌ ‌niches‌ ‌in‌ ‌absence‌ ‌of‌ ‌competition‌ ‌from‌ ‌monkeys‌ ‌and‌ ‌apes‌ ‌\nas‌ ‌they‌ ‌made‌ ‌their‌ ‌way‌ ‌to‌ ‌Madagascar.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Lorises‌ ‌\n○Primarily‌ ‌inhabit‌ ‌tropical‌ ‌forest‌ ‌and‌ ‌woodland‌ ‌habitats‌ ‌of‌ ‌Africa,‌ ‌Southeast‌ ‌Asia,‌ ‌India‌ ‌and‌ ‌Sri‌ ‌Lanka.‌ ‌\n○Nycticebus‌ ‌or‌ ‌slow‌ ‌loris‌ ‌resides‌ ‌in‌ ‌jungles‌ ‌of‌ ‌Southeast‌ ‌Asia‌ ‌and‌ ‌some‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌western‌ ‌islands‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Indonesian‌ ‌archipelago‌ ‌\n●Tarsiers‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌are‌ ‌small‌ ‌nocturnal‌ ‌primates‌ ‌and‌ ‌supreme‌ ‌leapers.‌ ‌They‌ ‌relate‌ ‌to‌ ‌one‌ ‌genus,‌ ‌Tarsius,‌ ‌which‌ ‌\n○includes‌ ‌five‌ ‌tarsier‌ ‌species‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌species‌ ‌are‌ ‌restricted‌ ‌to‌ ‌island‌ ‌regime‌ ‌in‌ ‌Southeast‌ ‌Asia‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌\n○Philippine‌ ‌Islands.‌ ‌These‌ ‌primates‌ ‌reside‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌wide‌ ‌array‌ ‌of‌ ‌habitats‌ ‌ranging‌ ‌from‌ ‌tropical‌ ‌forest‌ ‌to‌ ‌\n○backyard‌ ‌gardens‌ ‌and‌ ‌prefer‌ ‌small‌ ‌vertebrates‌ ‌and‌ ‌insects‌ ‌as‌ ‌their‌ ‌prey.‌ ‌Tarsiers‌ ‌are‌ ‌nocturnal‌ ‌\n○insectivores‌ ‌that‌ ‌leap‌ ‌from‌ ‌lower‌ ‌branches‌ ‌and‌ ‌shrubs‌ ‌onto‌ ‌prey‌ ‌(which‌ ‌may‌ ‌include‌ ‌small‌ ‌vertebrates)‌ ‌\n○and‌ ‌the‌ ‌basic‌ ‌tarsier‌ ‌social‌ ‌unit‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌mated‌ ‌pair‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌young‌ ‌offspring.‌ ‌They‌ ‌are‌ ‌characterized‌ ‌by‌ ‌\n○enormous‌ ‌eyes,‌ ‌which‌ ‌dominate‌ ‌much‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌facial‌ ‌region.‌ ‌\n●New‌ ‌World‌ ‌Monkeys‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌New‌ ‌World‌ ‌monkeys‌ ‌or‌ ‌platyrrhines‌ ‌(included‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌superfamily‌ ‌Ceboidea.)‌ ‌constitute‌ ‌tropical‌ ‌arboreal‌ ‌primates‌ ‌residing‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nforest‌ ‌areas‌ ‌of‌ ‌Central‌ ‌and‌ ‌South‌ ‌America‌ ‌and‌ ‌Mexico.‌ ‌\n78‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌are‌ ‌dichotomized‌ ‌into‌ ‌two‌ ‌families:‌ ‌ ‌\n■Callitrichidae‌ ‌(marmosets‌ ‌and‌ ‌tamarins)‌ ‌and‌ ‌ ‌\n■Cebidae‌ ‌(all‌ ‌other‌ ‌New‌ ‌World‌ ‌Monkeys).‌ ‌New‌ ‌World‌ ‌monkeys‌ ‌are‌ ‌diurnal‌ ‌with‌ ‌only‌ ‌one‌ ‌exception‌ ‌(Aotus),‌ ‌and‌ ‌some‌ ‌never‌ ‌\ncome‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌ground.‌ ‌Like‌ ‌Old‌ ‌World‌ ‌monkeys,‌ ‌all‌ ‌except‌ ‌one‌ ‌species‌ ‌(the‌ ‌owl‌ ‌monkey)‌ ‌are‌ ‌diurnal.‌ ‌\n●Marmosets‌ ‌and‌ ‌Tamarins‌ ‌(Callitrichids)‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌smallest‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌New‌ ‌World‌ ‌monkeys.‌ ‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌are‌ ‌arboreal‌ ‌quadrupeds‌ ‌having‌ ‌claws‌ ‌on‌ ‌all‌ ‌their‌ ‌digits.‌ ‌\n○Their‌ ‌diet‌ ‌consists‌ ‌largely‌ ‌of‌ ‌insects,‌ ‌although‌ ‌marmosets‌ ‌eat‌ ‌gums‌ ‌from‌ ‌trees,‌ ‌and‌ ‌tamarins‌ ‌eat‌ ‌fruits.‌ ‌Socially,‌ ‌these‌ ‌small‌ ‌monkeys‌ ‌\nlive‌ ‌in‌ ‌family‌ ‌groups‌ ‌usually‌ ‌composed‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌mated‌ ‌pair,‌ ‌or‌ ‌a‌ ‌female‌ ‌and‌ ‌two‌ ‌adult‌ ‌males,‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌offspring.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Unlike‌ ‌other‌ ‌primates,‌ ‌marmosets‌ ‌and‌ ‌tamarins‌ ‌usually‌ ‌give‌ ‌birth‌ ‌to‌ ‌twins,‌ ‌and‌ ‌they’re‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌few‌ ‌primate‌ ‌species‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌males‌ ‌\nare‌ ‌extensively‌ ‌involved‌ ‌in‌ ‌infant‌ ‌care.‌ ‌\n●Cebidae‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌family‌ ‌Cebidae‌ ‌is‌ ‌composed‌ ‌of‌ ‌eleven‌ ‌primate‌ ‌genera‌ ‌which‌ ‌further‌ ‌encompass‌ ‌a‌ ‌wide‌ ‌range‌ ‌of‌ ‌animals.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Cebidae‌ ‌are‌ ‌larger‌ ‌in‌ ‌size‌ ‌in‌ ‌comparison‌ ‌to‌ ‌Callitrichids.‌ ‌Cebidae‌ ‌are‌ ‌only‌ ‌primates‌ ‌characterized‌ ‌with‌ ‌prehensile‌ ‌tail‌ ‌\n○Most‌ ‌cebid‌ ‌exhibit‌ ‌quadrupedal‌ ‌locomotion;‌ ‌but‌ ‌some‌ ‌(such‌ ‌as‌ ‌muriquis‌ ‌and‌ ‌spider‌ ‌monkeys)‌ ‌are‌ ‌semi-brachiator‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌Cebidae‌ ‌reside‌ ‌in‌ ‌communities‌ ‌(exception:‌ ‌night‌ ‌monkeys).‌ ‌\n●Old‌ ‌world‌ ‌Monkeys‌ ‌\n○Old‌ ‌world‌ ‌Monkeys‌ ‌are‌ ‌placed‌ ‌under‌ ‌superfamily‌ ‌Cercopithecoidea‌ ‌and‌ ‌one‌ ‌taxonomic‌ ‌family‌ ‌\n○Cercopithecidae‌ ‌and‌ ‌this‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌further‌ ‌subdivided‌ ‌into‌ ‌two‌ ‌subfamilies‌ ‌namely,‌ ‌\n■Cercopithecinae‌ ‌(non-leaf‌ ‌eating)‌ ‌and‌ ‌ ‌\n■Colobinae‌ ‌(leaf‌ ‌eating).‌ ‌ ‌\n○Cercopithecines‌ ‌are‌ ‌different‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌colobines‌ ‌because‌ ‌former‌ ‌lack‌ ‌sacculated‌ ‌stomach‌ ‌and‌ ‌possess‌ ‌cheek‌ ‌pouches‌ ‌(for‌ ‌\ntemporary‌ ‌food‌ ‌storage).‌ ‌\n○Leaf‌ ‌eating‌ ‌monkeys‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌Colobus‌ ‌monkey,‌ ‌Proboscis‌ ‌monkey,‌ ‌Snub-nosed‌ ‌monkey,‌ ‌Hanuman‌ ‌Langurs‌ ‌reside‌ ‌in‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌(only‌ ‌\none‌ ‌genus‌ ‌Colobus),‌ ‌India,‌ ‌Indonesia,‌ ‌Malaysia,‌ ‌Java,‌ ‌Sumatra,‌ ‌Borneo‌ ‌and‌ ‌China.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Old‌ ‌World‌ ‌monkeys‌ ‌represent‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌widely‌ ‌distributed‌ ‌living‌ ‌primates‌ ‌except‌ ‌Humans‌ ‌because‌ ‌they‌ ‌inhabit‌ ‌a‌ ‌wide‌ ‌array‌ ‌of‌ ‌\necological‌ ‌domains‌ ‌ranging‌ ‌from‌ ‌tropical‌ ‌jungle‌ ‌habitats‌ ‌to‌ ‌semiarid‌ ‌desert‌ ‌throughout‌ ‌sub-Saharan‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌and‌ ‌southern‌ ‌Asia‌ ‌and‌ ‌\neven‌ ‌to‌ ‌seasonally‌ ‌snow-covered‌ ‌regions‌ ‌in‌ ‌northern‌ ‌Japan.‌ ‌\n○Most‌ ‌Old‌ ‌World‌ ‌monkeys‌ ‌are‌ ‌quadrupedal‌ ‌and‌ ‌primarily‌ ‌arboreal,‌ ‌but‌ ‌certain‌ ‌species‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌baboons,‌ ‌macaques,‌ ‌and‌ ‌langurs‌ ‌\nexhibit‌ ‌terrestrial‌ ‌lifestyle‌ ‌and‌ ‌spend‌ ‌much‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌day‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌ground.‌ ‌\n○Sexual‌ ‌dimorphism‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌typical‌ ‌trait‌ ‌among‌ ‌some‌ ‌terrestrial‌ ‌species‌ ‌and‌ ‌particularly‌ ‌pronounced‌ ‌in‌ ‌baboons.‌ ‌\n○Females‌ ‌of‌ ‌certain‌ ‌species,‌ ‌especially‌ ‌baboons‌ ‌and‌ ‌some‌ ‌macaques,‌ ‌exhibit‌ ‌marked‌ ‌cyclical‌ ‌changes‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌external‌ ‌genitalia.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n79‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌ ‌\n1.5‌ ‌Primate‌ ‌Behaviour;‌ ‌Tertiary‌ ‌and‌ ‌Quaternary‌ ‌fossil‌ ‌primates;‌ ‌Living‌ ‌Major‌ ‌Primates;‌ ‌Part-III‌ ‌\n ‌\nPrimate‌ ‌Behaviour;‌ ‌ ‌\nA‌ ‌large‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌Primates‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌is‌ ‌learned‌ ‌rather‌ ‌than‌ ‌innate.‌ ‌Despite‌ ‌the‌ ‌diversity‌ ‌in‌ ‌behavioural‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌of‌ ‌primates,‌ ‌primatologists‌ ‌like:‌ ‌\n●Jane‌ ‌goodall(‌ ‌chimpanzee)‌ ‌\nIn‌ ‌1960‌ ‌Jane‌ ‌Goodall‌ ‌pioneered‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌chimpanzees‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌wild,‌ ‌showing‌ ‌the‌ ‌world‌ ‌how‌ ‌similar‌ ‌chimpanzee‌ ‌behavior‌ ‌is‌ ‌to‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nhumans,‌ ‌and‌ ‌helping‌ ‌to‌ ‌demonstrate‌ ‌the‌ ‌close‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌two‌ ‌species.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Dolhinow‌ ‌(Indian‌ ‌langur‌ ‌monkey)‌ ‌\nAn‌ ‌experimental‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌mother‌ ‌loss‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌langur‌ ‌monkey.‌ ‌Langur‌ ‌monkeys‌ ‌normally‌ ‌have‌ ‌many‌ ‌important‌ ‌caregivers‌ ‌from‌ ‌birth.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●George‌ ‌Schallar(Mountain‌ ‌Gorilla)‌ ‌\nStudied‌ ‌Mountain‌ ‌Gorilla‌ ‌in‌ ‌African‌ ‌Jungles,‌ ‌gave‌ ‌insights‌ ‌about‌ ‌gorilla‌ ‌and‌ ‌its‌ ‌true‌ ‌nature,‌ ‌which‌ ‌was‌ ‌far‌ ‌gentler,‌ ‌friendlier‌ ‌and‌ ‌more‌ ‌\ncooperative‌ ‌than‌ ‌popular‌ ‌lore‌ ‌suggested.‌ ‌The‌ ‌great‌ ‌apes‌ ‌typically‌ ‌live‌ ‌in‌ ‌bands‌ ‌of‌ ‌five‌ ‌to‌ ‌27‌ ‌members,‌ ‌under‌ ‌the‌ ‌leadership‌ ‌of‌ ‌one‌ ‌mature‌ ‌\nmale‌ ‌gorilla.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n●C.‌ ‌R.‌ ‌Carpenter‌ ‌(Gibbon‌ ‌and‌ ‌Howler‌ ‌Monkey)‌ ‌\nCarpenter’s‌ ‌research‌ ‌of‌ ‌wild‌ ‌primate‌ ‌behavior‌ ‌during‌ ‌the‌ ‌1930s‌ ‌was,‌ ‌and‌ ‌continued‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌early‌ ‌2000s,‌ ‌widely‌ ‌recognized‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nprimatological‌ ‌community‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌scientific‌ ‌primate‌ ‌field‌ ‌studies.‌ ‌He‌ ‌studied‌ ‌behavior‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌relations‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Howling‌ ‌Monkey‌ ‌\n ‌\nIdentified‌ ‌the‌ ‌following‌ ‌Primate‌ ‌Behaviour:‌ ‌\n1.Group‌ ‌Living‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌benefits‌ ‌like‌ ‌defence‌ ‌against‌ ‌predators,‌ ‌enhanced‌ ‌food‌ ‌gathering,‌ ‌intensive‌ ‌social‌ ‌learning,‌ ‌assistance‌ ‌and‌ ‌rearing‌ ‌offspring‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌increased‌ ‌reproductive‌ ‌opportunities.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Example:‌‌ ‌Baboons‌ ‌live‌ ‌within‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌for‌ ‌their‌ ‌entire‌ ‌life‌ ‌whereas‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌unit‌ ‌of‌ ‌chimpanzees‌ ‌is‌ ‌ever-changing.‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌Primates‌ ‌particularly‌ ‌those‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌diurnal‌ ‌group‌ ‌life‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌crucial‌ ‌for‌ ‌survival.‌ ‌\n ‌\n2.Communication‌ ‌\n80‌ ‌\n○Body‌ ‌movement,‌ ‌vocalisation,‌ ‌olfactory‌ ‌signal‌ ‌and‌ ‌facial‌ ‌gases.‌ ‌physical‌ ‌aggression‌ ‌ranges‌ ‌from‌ ‌simple‌ ‌gestures‌ ‌to‌ ‌violence.‌ ‌\n ‌\n3.Dominance‌ ‌and‌ ‌Hierarchy‌ ‌\n○Ranking‌ ‌of‌ ‌remade‌ ‌in‌ ‌social‌ ‌status‌ ‌determined‌ ‌by‌ ‌physical‌ ‌strength,‌ ‌aggression,‌ ‌age‌ ‌and‌ ‌ability‌ ‌to‌ ‌attract‌ ‌each‌ ‌other.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Dominance‌ ‌submission‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌result‌ ‌of‌ ‌dominance‌ ‌hierarchy.‌ ‌\n○Example:‌ ‌‌Chimpanzee‌ ‌if‌ ‌two‌ ‌males‌ ‌go‌ ‌after‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌fruit‌ ‌the‌ ‌subordinate‌ ‌holds‌ ‌back.‌ ‌\n ‌\n4.Dependency‌ ‌and‌ ‌development‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌prolonged‌ ‌dependency‌ ‌of‌ ‌Infant‌ ‌monkeys,‌ ‌apes‌ ‌an‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌advantage‌ ‌by‌ ‌allowing‌ ‌infants‌ ‌more‌ ‌time‌ ‌to‌ ‌observe‌ ‌and‌ ‌learn‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌complex‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌essential‌ ‌to‌ ‌Survival.‌ ‌\n ‌\n5.Training‌ ‌and‌ ‌learning‌ ‌\n○Primates‌ ‌often‌ ‌learn‌ ‌many‌ ‌things‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌groups.‌ ‌\n○Example:‌‌ ‌Method‌ ‌of‌ ‌feeding‌ ‌among‌ ‌chimpanzees,‌ ‌termite‌ ‌fishing‌ ‌using‌ ‌a‌ ‌graph‌ ‌stalk‌ ‌to‌ ‌withdraw‌ ‌termites‌ ‌from‌ ‌termite‌ ‌mound.‌ ‌\n ‌\n6.Sexual‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌varies‌ ‌among‌ ‌Primates.‌ ‌gibbons‌ ‌are‌ ‌monogamous,‌ ‌chimpanzees‌ ‌are‌ ‌Promiscuous.‌ ‌Thus,‌ ‌most‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌primate‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌\nare‌ ‌learned‌ ‌and‌ ‌show‌ ‌a‌ ‌great‌ ‌diversity‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌group‌ ‌and‌ ‌between‌ ‌groups‌ ‌of‌ ‌primates.‌ ‌\n ‌\nTertiary‌ ‌and‌ ‌Quaternary‌ ‌fossil‌ ‌primates;‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Primates‌ ‌have‌ ‌lived‌ ‌during‌ ‌the‌ ‌past‌ ‌65‌ ‌million‌ ‌years,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Cenozoic‌ ‌era,which‌ ‌has‌ ‌seven‌ ‌epochs.‌ ‌\n●During‌ ‌the‌ ‌Cenozoic,‌ ‌most‌ ‌land‌ ‌masses‌ ‌had‌ ‌tropical‌ ‌or‌ ‌subtropical‌ ‌climates.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌mesozoic‌ ‌era‌ ‌had‌ ‌ended‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌massive‌ ‌worldwide‌ ‌extinction‌ ‌of‌ ‌plants‌ ‌and‌ ‌animals,‌ ‌including‌ ‌the‌ ‌dinosaurs.‌ ‌Thereafter,‌ ‌mammals‌ ‌\nreplaced‌ ‌reptiles‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌large‌ ‌land‌ ‌animals.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Trees‌ ‌and‌ ‌flowering‌ ‌plants‌ ‌soon‌ ‌proliferated,‌ ‌supplying‌ ‌arboreal‌ ‌foods‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌primates‌ ‌that‌ ‌eventually‌ ‌evolved‌ ‌to‌ ‌fill‌ ‌the‌ ‌new‌ ‌niches.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nAnthropologists‌ ‌are‌ ‌concerned‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Cenozoic‌ ‌era‌,‌ ‌which‌ ‌includes‌ ‌two‌ ‌periods:‌ ‌ ‌\n●Tertiary‌ ‌and‌ ‌\n●Quaternary.‌ ‌ ‌\nEach‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌periods‌ ‌is‌ ‌subdivided‌ ‌into‌ ‌epochs.‌ ‌ ‌\nThe‌ ‌Tertiary‌ ‌had‌ ‌five‌ ‌epochs:‌ ‌ ‌\n1.Paleocene,‌ ‌ ‌\n2.Eocene,‌ ‌ ‌\n3.Oligocene,‌ ‌ ‌\n4.Miocene,‌ ‌and‌ ‌ ‌\n81‌ ‌\n5.Pliocene.‌ ‌\nThe‌ ‌Quaternary‌ ‌includes‌ ‌just‌ ‌two‌ ‌epochs:‌ ‌ ‌\n1.Pleistocene‌ ‌and‌ ‌ ‌\n2.Holocene‌ ‌\nUnderstanding‌ ‌Geological‌ ‌Time‌ ‌Scale:‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n82‌ ‌\nSignificance‌ ‌of‌ ‌various‌ ‌tertiary‌ ‌epoch:‌ ‌\n●Paleocene‌ ‌epoch:‌‌ ‌Sediments‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌Paleocene‌ ‌epoch‌ ‌(65‌ ‌to‌ ‌54‌ ‌m.y.a.)‌ ‌have‌ ‌yielded‌ ‌fossil‌ ‌remains‌ ‌of‌ ‌diverse‌ ‌small‌ ‌mammals,‌ ‌some‌ ‌\npossibly‌ ‌ancestral‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌primates.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Eocene‌ ‌epoch:‌‌ ‌Prosimian-like‌ ‌fossils‌ ‌abound‌ ‌in‌ ‌strata‌ ‌dating‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌Eocene‌ ‌(54‌ ‌to‌ ‌36‌ ‌m.y.a.).‌ ‌ ‌\n●Oligocene‌ ‌epoch:‌‌ ‌The‌ ‌first‌ ‌anthropoid‌ ‌fossils‌ ‌date‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌mid-‌ ‌to‌ ‌late‌ ‌Eocene‌ ‌and‌ ‌early‌ ‌Oligocene‌ ‌(36‌ ‌to‌ ‌23‌ ‌m.y.a.).‌ ‌ ‌\n●Miocene:‌‌ ‌Hominoids‌ ‌became‌ ‌widespread‌ ‌during‌ ‌the‌ ‌Miocene‌ ‌(23‌ ‌to‌ ‌5‌ ‌m.y.a.),‌ ‌\n●Pliocene:‌‌ ‌Hominids‌ ‌first‌ ‌appeared‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Pliocene‌ ‌(5‌ ‌to‌ ‌2‌ ‌m.y.a.)‌ ‌\n ‌\nSignificance‌ ‌of‌ ‌various‌ ‌Quaternary‌ ‌epoch:‌ ‌\n●Pleistocene‌ ‌epoch:‌‌ ‌Evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌genus‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌during‌ ‌the‌ ‌Pleistocene‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌extinction‌ ‌of‌ ‌large‌ ‌mammals‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌end‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌epoch.‌ ‌\n●Holocene‌ ‌epoch:‌‌ ‌Holocene‌ ‌has‌ ‌witnessed‌ ‌all‌ ‌of‌ ‌humanity's‌ ‌recorded‌ ‌history‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌rise‌ ‌and‌ ‌fall‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌its‌ ‌civilizations.‌ ‌\n ‌\nTransition‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Earliest‌ ‌primate-‌ ‌‌Purgatorius‌,‌ ‌a‌ ‌small‌ ‌mammal‌ ‌that‌ ‌lived‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌diet‌ ‌of‌ ‌fruit‌ ‌and‌ ‌insects,‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌tree‌ ‌dweller,‌ ‌evolved‌ ‌from‌ ‌insectivore‌ ‌stock‌ ‌\nbefore‌ ‌or‌ ‌during‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌cretaceous‌ ‌period.‌ ‌\n ‌\n83‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Altiatlasius‌,‌ ‌which‌ ‌lived‌ ‌some‌ ‌57‌ ‌or‌ ‌56‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago,‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌true‌ ‌primate.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Present-day‌ ‌ecosystems‌ ‌are‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌part‌ ‌populated‌ ‌by‌ ‌animals,‌ ‌plants,‌ ‌and‌ ‌single-celled‌ ‌organisms‌ ‌that‌ ‌survived‌ ‌and‌ ‌redeployed‌ ‌after‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌great‌ ‌extinction‌ ‌event‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌end‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Mesozoic.‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌‌ ‌arboreal‌ ‌theory‌,‌ ‌primates‌ ‌became‌ ‌primates‌ ‌by‌ ‌adapting‌ ‌to‌ ‌arboreal‌ ‌life.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌primate‌ ‌traits‌ ‌and‌ ‌trends‌ ‌as‌ ‌adaptations‌ ‌to‌ ‌life‌ ‌high‌ ‌up‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌trees.‌ ‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌key‌ ‌feature‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌importance‌ ‌of‌ ‌sight‌ ‌over‌ ‌smell.‌ ‌The‌‌ ‌visual‌ ‌predation‌ ‌hypothesis‌‌ ‌suggests‌ ‌that‌ ‌key‌ ‌primate‌ ‌traits‌ ‌developed‌ ‌\nbecause‌ ‌they‌ ‌facilitated‌ ‌the‌ ‌capture‌ ‌of‌ ‌insects.‌ ‌\n●Changes‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌visual‌ ‌apparatus‌ ‌were‌ ‌adaptive‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌trees,‌ ‌where‌ ‌depth‌ ‌perception‌ ‌facilitated‌ ‌leaping.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Grasping‌ ‌hands‌ ‌and‌ ‌feet‌ ‌were‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌crawl‌ ‌along‌ ‌slender‌ ‌branches.‌ ‌\n●Grasping‌ ‌feet‌ ‌anchored‌ ‌the‌ ‌body‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌primate‌ ‌reached‌ ‌for‌ ‌foods‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌ends‌ ‌of‌ ‌branches.‌ ‌ ‌\n84‌ ‌\n●Early‌ ‌primates‌ ‌probably‌ ‌had‌ ‌omnivorous‌ ‌diets‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌foods‌ ‌available‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌trees,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌flowers,‌ ‌fruits,‌ ‌berries,‌ ‌gums,‌ ‌leaves,‌ ‌and‌ ‌\ninsects.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌early‌ ‌Cenozoic‌ ‌era‌ ‌witnessed‌ ‌a‌ ‌proliferation‌ ‌of‌ ‌flowering‌ ‌plants,‌ ‌attracting‌ ‌insects‌ ‌that‌ ‌were‌ ‌to‌ ‌figure‌ ‌prominently‌ ‌in‌ ‌many‌ ‌primate‌ ‌diets‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nTertiary‌ ‌Fossil‌ ‌Primates‌ ‌\n●Amid‌ ‌the‌ ‌rapid‌ ‌diversification‌ ‌of‌ ‌mammals‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌early‌ ‌Tertiary,‌ ‌primates‌ ‌evolved‌ ‌from‌ ‌animals‌ ‌similar‌ ‌to‌ ‌modern‌ ‌squirrels‌ ‌and‌ ‌tree‌ ‌shrews.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Compared‌ ‌with‌ ‌other‌ ‌terrestrial‌ ‌mammals,‌ ‌primates‌ ‌possessed‌ ‌the‌ ‌largest‌ ‌brains‌ ‌relative‌ ‌to‌ ‌their‌ ‌body‌ ‌weight.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌feature—along‌ ‌with‌ ‌limb‌ ‌extremities‌ ‌composed‌ ‌of‌ ‌flat‌ ‌nails‌ ‌rather‌ ‌than‌ ‌hooves‌ ‌or‌ ‌claws,‌ ‌specialized‌ ‌nerve‌ ‌endings‌ ‌called‌ ‌‌Meissner’s‌ ‌\ncorpuscles‌ ‌‌that‌ ‌increased‌ ‌the‌ ‌tactile‌ ‌sensitivity‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌hands‌ ‌and‌ ‌feet,‌ ‌and‌ ‌rounded‌ ‌molars‌ ‌and‌ ‌premolar‌ ‌cusps—allowed‌ ‌primates‌ ‌to‌ ‌adapt‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌and‌ ‌exploit‌ ‌arboreal‌ ‌environments‌ ‌and‌ ‌newly‌ ‌emergent‌ ‌grasslands.‌ ‌\n●Although‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌signs‌ ‌of‌ ‌primate‌ ‌dentition‌ ‌were‌ ‌present‌ ‌as‌ ‌early‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Paleocene‌ ‌Epoch‌,‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌fully‌ ‌recognizable‌ ‌primate‌ ‌forms‌ ‌did‌ ‌not‌ ‌\nemerge‌ ‌until‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Eocene‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Tarsiidae‌‌ ‌(which‌ ‌include‌ ‌modern‌ ‌tarsiers‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌ancestors)‌ ‌appeared‌ ‌in‌ ‌western‌ ‌Europe‌ ‌and‌ ‌North‌ ‌Africa,‌ ‌ ‌\n○the‌ ‌‌Adapidae‌ ‌‌(which‌ ‌include‌ ‌lemurs,‌ ‌lorises,‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌ancestors)‌ ‌arose‌ ‌in‌ ‌North‌ ‌America‌ ‌and‌ ‌Europe,‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Omomyidae‌‌ ‌(which‌ ‌\ninclude‌ ‌the‌ ‌possible‌ ‌ancestors‌ ‌of‌ ‌monkeys‌ ‌and‌ ‌apes)‌ ‌emerged‌ ‌in‌ ‌North‌ ‌America,‌ ‌Europe,‌ ‌Egypt,‌ ‌and‌ ‌Asia‌ ‌during‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Eocene‌ ‌\nEpoch.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌separation‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌more‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌primates‌ ‌(lemurs,‌ ‌lorises,‌ ‌tarsiers,‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌ancestors)‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌more‌ ‌advanced‌ ‌forms‌ ‌(monkeys,‌ ‌apes,‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌humans)‌ ‌is‌ ‌thought‌ ‌to‌ ‌have‌ ‌occurred‌ ‌during‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Oligocene‌ ‌Epoch.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Some‌ ‌primate‌ ‌groups‌ ‌‌abandoned‌ ‌the‌ ‌locomotor‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌of‌ ‌vertical‌ ‌clinging‌ ‌and‌ ‌leaping‌ ‌for‌ ‌quadrupedalism‌ ‌(walking‌ ‌on‌ ‌four‌ ‌limbs)‌ ‌\nduring‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Oligocene‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Other‌ ‌developments‌ ‌include‌ ‌the‌ ‌emergence‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌catarrhines‌ ‌(Old‌ ‌World‌ ‌monkeys,‌ ‌apes,‌ ‌and‌ ‌humans)‌ ‌in‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌platyrrhines‌ ‌\n(New‌ ‌World‌ ‌monkeys)‌ ‌in‌ ‌South‌ ‌America.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌catarrhines‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌only‌ ‌group‌ ‌to‌ ‌possess‌ ‌truly‌ ‌opposable‌ ‌thumbs.‌ ‌(Some‌ ‌lower‌ ‌primates‌ ‌possess‌ ‌nominally‌ ‌opposable‌ ‌thumbs‌ ‌\nbut‌ ‌lack‌ ‌the‌ ‌precision‌ ‌grip‌ ‌of‌ ‌catarrhines.)‌ ‌\n●By‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Miocene‌,‌ ‌‌Sivapithecus—a‌ ‌form‌ ‌considered‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌the‌ ‌direct‌ ‌ancestor‌ ‌of‌ ‌orangutans—appeared‌ ‌in‌ ‌Eurasia,‌ ‌and‌ ‌Dryopithecus—the‌ ‌\ndirect‌ ‌ancestor‌ ‌of‌ ‌gorillas,‌ ‌chimpanzees,‌ ‌and‌ ‌humans—appeared‌ ‌in‌ ‌parts‌ ‌of‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌and‌ ‌Eurasia.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌addition,‌ ‌‌Morotopithecus‌ ‌bishopi,‌‌ ‌a‌ ‌species‌ ‌possessing‌ ‌the‌ ‌earliest‌ ‌traces‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌modern‌ ‌hominoid‌ ‌skeletal‌ ‌features,‌ ‌appeared‌ ‌some‌ ‌20‌ ‌\nmillion‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago‌ ‌near‌ ‌Lake‌ ‌Victoria‌ ‌in‌ ‌Africa.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌late‌ ‌‌Miocene-Pliocen‌e‌ ‌primate‌ ‌fossil‌ ‌record‌ ‌is‌ ‌surprisingly‌ ‌sparse.‌ ‌ ‌\n●No‌ ‌fossils‌ ‌traceable‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌lineages‌ ‌of‌ ‌modern‌ ‌apes‌ ‌are‌ ‌known,‌ ‌and‌ ‌only‌ ‌meagre‌ ‌information‌ ‌exists‌ ‌for‌ ‌monkey‌ ‌families.‌ ‌\n●Nevertheless,‌ ‌this‌ ‌interval‌ ‌is‌ ‌perhaps‌ ‌best‌ ‌known‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌rise‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌human‌ ‌lineage‌ ‌in‌ ‌central‌ ‌and‌ ‌eastern‌ ‌Africa,‌ ‌as‌ ‌evidenced‌ ‌by‌ ‌\nSahelanthropus‌ ‌tchadensis‌‌ ‌from‌ ‌Chad‌ ‌(7‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago),‌‌ ‌Orrorin‌ ‌tugenensis‌‌ ‌from‌ ‌Kenya‌ ‌(6.1–5.8‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago),‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nArdipithecus‌ ‌ramidus‌‌ ‌(4.4‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago)‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Ardipithecus‌ ‌‌has‌ ‌an‌ ‌expanded‌ ‌tarsal‌ ‌region‌ ‌on‌ ‌each‌ ‌foot,‌ ‌and‌ ‌its‌ ‌foramen‌ ‌(the‌ ‌hole‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌skull‌ ‌through‌ ‌which‌ ‌the‌ ‌spinal‌ ‌cord‌ ‌enters)‌ ‌is‌ ‌\nlocated‌ ‌centrally‌ ‌under‌ ‌the‌ ‌skull‌ ‌instead‌ ‌of‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌rear‌ ‌of‌ ‌it.‌ ‌\n85‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌addition,‌ ‌the‌ ‌design‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌pelvis‌ ‌of‌ ‌‌Ardipithecus‌‌ ‌is‌ ‌similar‌ ‌to‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌more‌ ‌advanced‌ ‌hominins.‌ ‌These‌ ‌features‌ ‌are‌ ‌indicative‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nbipedalism,‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌that‌ ‌separate‌ ‌the‌ ‌human‌ ‌lineage‌ ‌from‌ ‌those‌ ‌of‌ ‌apes‌ ‌and‌ ‌chimpanzees.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Other‌ ‌bipedal‌ ‌primates‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Pliocene‌‌ ‌include‌ ‌‌Kenyanthropus‌ ‌platyops‌‌ ‌and‌ ‌various‌ ‌species‌ ‌of‌ ‌‌Australopithecus.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌precise‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌among‌ ‌these‌ ‌forms‌ ‌remain‌ ‌controversial,‌ ‌but‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌clear‌ ‌that‌ ‌they‌ ‌lie‌ ‌close‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌\nbranching‌ ‌event‌ ‌that‌ ‌separates‌ ‌humans‌ ‌from‌ ‌apes.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nQuaternary‌ ‌Fossil‌ ‌Primates‌ ‌\n●Gigantopithecus,‌‌ ‌(Gigantopithecus‌ ‌blacki),‌ ‌genus‌ ‌of‌ ‌large‌ ‌extinct‌ ‌apes‌ ‌represented‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌single‌ ‌species,‌ ‌Gigantopithecus‌ ‌blacki,‌ ‌which‌ ‌lived‌ ‌\nduring‌ ‌the‌‌ ‌Pleistocene‌ ‌Epoch‌‌ ‌(2.6‌ ‌million‌ ‌to‌ ‌11,700‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago)‌ ‌in‌ ‌southern‌ ‌China.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Gigantopithecus‌ ‌is‌ ‌considered‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌a‌ ‌sister‌ ‌genus‌ ‌of‌ ‌Pongo‌ ‌(the‌ ‌genus‌ ‌that‌ ‌contains‌ ‌living‌ ‌orangutans)‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌subfamily‌ ‌Ponginae‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nfamily‌ ‌Hominidae.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n86‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌‌Holocene‌ ‌Epoch‌‌ ‌began‌ ‌12,000‌ ‌to‌ ‌11,500‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌close‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Paleolithic‌ ‌Ice‌ ‌Age‌ ‌and‌ ‌continues‌ ‌through‌ ‌today.‌ ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌Addition‌ ‌\nMiocene‌ ‌Hominoids‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌earliest‌ ‌hominoid‌ ‌fossils‌ ‌date‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌Miocene‌ ‌epoch‌ ‌(23–5‌ ‌m.y.a.),‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌divided‌ ‌into‌ ‌three‌ ‌parts:‌ ‌ ‌\n○Lower,‌ ‌\n○Middle,‌ ‌and‌ ‌ ‌\n○Upper‌ ‌or‌ ‌late.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌early‌ ‌Miocene‌ ‌(23–16‌ ‌m.y.a.)‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌warm‌ ‌and‌ ‌wet‌ ‌period,‌ ‌when‌ ‌forests‌ ‌covered‌ ‌East‌ ‌Africa.‌ ‌\n●Hominoidea‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌superfamily‌ ‌that‌ ‌includes‌ ‌fossil‌ ‌and‌ ‌living‌ ‌apes‌ ‌and‌ ‌humans.‌ ‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌simplicity’s‌ ‌sake,‌ ‌the‌ ‌earliest‌ ‌hominoids‌ ‌are‌ ‌here‌ ‌called‌ ‌proto-apes,‌ ‌or‌ ‌simply‌ ‌apes.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Although‌ ‌some‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌ancestral‌ ‌to‌ ‌living‌ ‌apes,‌ ‌none‌ ‌is‌ ‌identical,‌ ‌or‌ ‌often‌ ‌even‌ ‌very‌ ‌similar,‌ ‌to‌ ‌modern‌ ‌apes.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n87‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌ ‌\n88‌ ‌\n1.5‌ ‌Living‌ ‌Major‌ ‌Primates;‌ ‌Part‌ ‌IV‌ ‌\n89‌ ‌\n ‌\n90‌ ‌\nOverview‌ ‌of‌ ‌Living‌ ‌Primates‌ ‌\n ‌\nPROSIMIANS‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Lemurs‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○Geographical‌ ‌Location:‌ ‌ ‌\n■Lemurs‌ ‌are‌ ‌found‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌island‌ ‌of‌ ‌Madagascar‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌islands‌ ‌off‌ ‌the‌ ‌coast‌ ‌of‌ ‌Africa,they‌ ‌became‌ ‌extinct‌ ‌elsewhere‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nworld.‌ ‌ ‌\n91‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○Characteristics:‌ ‌ ‌\n■Larger‌ ‌lemurs‌ ‌are‌ ‌diurnal‌ ‌and‌ ‌eat‌ ‌vegetable‌ ‌foods:‌ ‌fruit,‌ ‌leaves,‌ ‌buds,‌ ‌and‌ ‌bark.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Smaller‌ ‌lemurs‌ ‌are‌ ‌nocturnal‌ ‌and‌ ‌insectivorous‌ ‌(insect‌ ‌-feeding).‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n92‌ ‌\n●Lorises‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○Geographical‌ ‌Location:‌ ‌ ‌\n■Lorises‌ ‌are‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌tropical‌ ‌forests‌ ‌and‌ ‌woodlands‌ ‌of‌ ‌India,‌ ‌Sri‌ ‌Lanka,‌ ‌southeast‌ ‌Asia,‌ ‌and‌ ‌Africa.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○Characteristics:‌ ‌ ‌\n■Lorises‌ ‌use‌ ‌a‌ ‌climbing‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌quadrupedalism.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Some‌ ‌lorises‌ ‌are‌ ‌insectivorous;‌ ‌others‌ ‌supplement‌ ‌their‌ ‌diet‌ ‌with‌ ‌fruit,‌ ‌leaves,‌ ‌gums,‌ ‌and‌ ‌slugs.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Females‌ ‌frequently‌ ‌form‌ ‌associations‌ ‌for‌ ‌foraging‌ ‌or‌ ‌in‌ ‌sharing‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌sleeping‌ ‌nest.‌ ‌\n ‌\n93‌ ‌\n●Tarsiers‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○Geographical‌ ‌Location:‌ ‌ ‌\n■Tarsiers‌ ‌are‌ ‌primates‌ ‌found‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌islands‌ ‌of‌ ‌southeast‌ ‌Asia.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○Characteristics:‌ ‌\n■Tarsiers‌ ‌are‌ ‌small‌ ‌nocturnal.‌ ‌\n■Tarsiers‌ ‌eat‌ ‌insects‌ ‌and‌ ‌small‌ ‌vertebrates‌ ‌which‌ ‌they‌ ‌catch‌ ‌by‌ ‌leaping‌ ‌from‌ ‌branches.‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌basic‌ ‌social‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌appears‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌a‌ ‌family‌ ‌unit‌ ‌consisting‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌mated‌ ‌pair‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌offspring.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nANTHROPOIDS‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n94‌ ‌\n●Monkey‌ ‌\n○Monkeys‌ ‌represent‌ ‌about‌ ‌70%‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌primates‌ ‌ ‌\n○Monkeys‌ ‌are‌ ‌divided‌ ‌into‌ ‌two‌ ‌large‌ ‌groups‌ ‌separated‌ ‌by‌ ‌geographic‌ ‌area‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌several‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌of‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌history:‌ ‌ ‌\n■New‌ ‌world‌ ‌monkeys‌ ‌(Platyrrhini)‌ ‌ ‌\n■Old‌ ‌world‌ ‌monkeys‌ ‌(Catarhini)‌ ‌\n■\n ‌\n●New‌ ‌World‌ ‌Monkeys‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○Geographical‌ ‌Location:‌ ‌ ‌\n■Almost‌ ‌exclusively‌ ‌arboreal‌ ‌and‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌southern‌ ‌Mexico‌ ‌and‌ ‌central‌ ‌and‌ ‌south‌ ‌America.‌ ‌\n ‌\n○Characteristics:‌ ‌\n95‌ ‌\n■Callitrichidae‌ ‌give‌ ‌birth‌ ‌to‌ ‌twins,‌ ‌have‌ ‌claws,‌ ‌live‌ ‌in‌ ‌families‌ ‌composed‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌mated‌ ‌pair‌ ‌or‌ ‌a‌ ‌female‌ ‌and‌ ‌two‌ ‌adult‌ ‌males,‌ ‌plus‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌offspring.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Males‌ ‌are‌ ‌involved‌ ‌with‌ ‌infant‌ ‌care.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Some‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌cebidae‌ ‌family‌ ‌possess‌ ‌prehensile,‌ ‌and‌ ‌most‌ ‌live‌ ‌in‌ ‌groups‌ ‌of‌ ‌both‌ ‌sexes‌ ‌and‌ ‌ages,‌ ‌or‌ ‌as‌ ‌monogamous‌ ‌pairs‌ ‌\nwith‌ ‌subadults.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Old‌ ‌World‌ ‌Monkeys‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○Geographical‌ ‌Location:‌ ‌ ‌\n■Habitats‌ ‌range‌ ‌from‌ ‌tropical‌ ‌forests‌ ‌to‌ ‌semiarid‌ ‌desert‌ ‌to‌ ‌snow-covered‌ ‌areas‌ ‌in‌ ‌Japan‌ ‌and‌ ‌China.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n○Characteristics:‌ ‌ ‌\n■Most‌ ‌old‌ ‌world‌ ‌monkeys‌ ‌are‌ ‌quadrupedal‌ ‌and‌ ‌arboreal;‌ ‌others‌ ‌have‌ ‌adapted‌ ‌to‌ ‌life‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌ground.‌ ‌ ‌\n■All‌ ‌old‌ ‌world‌ ‌monkeys‌ ‌belong‌ ‌to‌ ‌one‌ ‌family,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Cercopithecidae,‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌divided‌ ‌into‌ ‌subfamilies,‌ ‌the‌ ‌cercopithecines‌ ‌\n(terrestrial‌ ‌and‌ ‌omnivorous)‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌colobines‌ ‌(arboreal‌ ‌and‌ ‌vegetarian).‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n96‌ ‌\nValue‌ ‌Addition‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n97‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Hylobatidae‌ ‌\n●Gibbons‌ ‌and‌ ‌Siamangs‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n98‌ ‌\n○Geographical‌ ‌Location:‌ ‌ ‌\n■Found‌ ‌in‌ ‌tropical‌ ‌southeast‌ ‌Asia.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Characteristics:‌ ‌ ‌\n■Locomotor‌ ‌adaptations‌ ‌for‌ ‌brachiation‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌feeding‌ ‌behavior‌ ‌while‌ ‌hanging‌ ‌from‌ ‌branches.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Diet‌ ‌is‌ ‌largely‌ ‌fruit‌ ‌with‌ ‌supplements‌ ‌of‌ ‌leaves,‌ ‌flowers,‌ ‌and‌ ‌insects.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Basic‌ ‌social‌ ‌unit‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌monogamous‌ ‌pair‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌dependent‌ ‌offspring.‌ ‌\n■Males‌ ‌and‌ ‌females‌ ‌are‌ ‌territorial‌ ‌and‌ ‌delineate‌ ‌their‌ ‌territories‌ ‌with‌ ‌whoops‌ ‌and‌ ‌“songs”.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Pongidae‌ ‌\n●Orangutans‌ ‌(Pongo‌ ‌pygmaeus)‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○Geographical‌ ‌Location:‌ ‌ ‌\n■Found‌ ‌in‌ ‌heavily‌ ‌forested‌ ‌areas‌ ‌of‌ ‌Borneo‌ ‌and‌ ‌Sumatra.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Characteristics:‌ ‌ ‌\n■Slow,‌ ‌cautious‌ ‌climbers‌ ‌and‌ ‌almost‌ ‌completely‌ ‌arboreal.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Large‌ ‌animals‌ ‌(males‌ ‌=‌ ‌200‌ ‌pounds,‌ ‌females‌ ‌=‌ ‌100‌ ‌pounds)‌ ‌with‌ ‌pronounced‌ ‌sexual‌ ‌dimorphism.‌ ‌\n■Solitary‌ ‌ ‌\n■Principally‌ ‌frugivorous‌ ‌(feed-eating).‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Pongidae‌ ‌\n ‌\n99‌ ‌\n●Gorillas‌ ‌(Gorilla‌ ‌gorilla)‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○Geographical‌ ‌Location:‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌largest‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌living‌ ‌primates‌ ‌confined‌ ‌to‌ ‌forested‌ ‌regions‌ ‌of‌ ‌central‌ ‌Africa.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Characteristics:‌ ‌ ‌\n■Exhibit‌ ‌marked‌ ‌sexual‌ ‌dimorphism;‌ ‌ ‌\n■Males‌ ‌can‌ ‌weigh‌ ‌up‌ ‌to‌ ‌400‌ ‌pounds,‌ ‌females‌ ‌200‌ ‌pounds.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Primarily‌ ‌terrestrial,‌ ‌employing‌ ‌a‌ ‌semi-quadrupedal‌ ‌posture‌ ‌called‌ ‌knuckle-walking.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Live‌ ‌in‌ ‌groups‌ ‌that‌ ‌consist‌ ‌of‌ ‌one‌ ‌large‌ ‌silverback‌ ‌male,‌ ‌a‌ ‌few‌ ‌adult‌ ‌females,‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌sub‌ ‌adult‌ ‌offspring.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Pongidae‌ ‌\n ‌\n100‌ ‌\n●Chimpanzees‌ ‌(Pan‌ ‌troglodytes)‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○Geographical‌ ‌Location:‌ ‌ ‌\n■Found‌ ‌in‌ ‌equatorial‌ ‌Africa.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Characteristics:‌ ‌ ‌\n■Anatomically‌ ‌similar‌ ‌to‌ ‌gorillas‌ ‌particularly‌ ‌in‌ ‌limb‌ ‌proportions‌ ‌and‌ ‌upper-body‌ ‌shape.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Locomotion‌ ‌includes‌ ‌knuckle-walking‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌ground‌ ‌and‌ ‌brachiation‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌trees.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Eat‌ ‌a‌ ‌variety‌ ‌of‌ ‌plant‌ ‌and‌ ‌animal‌ ‌foods.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Large‌ ‌communities‌ ‌of‌ ‌as‌ ‌many‌ ‌as‌ ‌50‌ ‌individuals.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Pongidae‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n101‌ ‌\n●Bonobos‌ ‌(Pan‌ ‌paniscus)‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○Geographical‌ ‌Location:‌ ‌ ‌\n■Only‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌an‌ ‌area‌ ‌south‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Zaire‌ ‌river.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Characteristics:‌ ‌ ‌\n■Their‌ ‌population‌ ‌is‌ ‌believed‌ ‌to‌ ‌only‌ ‌number‌ ‌a‌ ‌few‌ ‌thousand‌ ‌individuals.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Exploit‌ ‌many‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌foods‌ ‌as‌ ‌chimps,‌ ‌including‌ ‌occasional‌ ‌small‌ ‌mammals.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Male-female‌ ‌bonds‌ ‌constitute‌ ‌the‌ ‌societal‌ ‌core.‌ ‌\n■Bonobo‌ ‌sexuality‌ ‌includes‌ ‌frequent‌ ‌copulations‌ ‌and‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌throughout‌ ‌the‌ ‌female's‌ ‌estrous‌ ‌cycle.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Hominidae‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Humans‌ ‌(Homo‌ ‌sapiens)‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○The‌ ‌only‌ ‌living‌ ‌species‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌Hominidae.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Characteristics:‌ ‌\n■Primate‌ ‌heritage‌ ‌is‌ ‌evident‌ ‌in‌ ‌anatomy,‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌makeup‌ ‌and‌ ‌aspects‌ ‌of‌ ‌behavior.‌ ‌\n102‌ ‌\n■Human‌ ‌teeth‌ ‌are‌ ‌typical‌ ‌primate‌ ‌teeth.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Dependence‌ ‌on‌ ‌vision‌ ‌for‌ ‌orientation‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌world,‌ ‌ ‌\n■Flexible‌ ‌limbs‌ ‌and‌ ‌grasping‌ ‌hands‌ ‌\n■Omnivorous‌ ‌diet‌ ‌ ‌\n■Cognitive‌ ‌abilities‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌result‌ ‌of‌ ‌dramatic‌ ‌increases‌ ‌in‌ ‌brain‌ ‌size‌ ‌\n■Bipedal‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nDetails‌ ‌of‌ ‌Living‌ ‌Primates:‌ ‌Value‌ ‌Addition‌ ‌\n ‌\n1.‌ ‌\n103‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n2.‌ ‌\n104‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n3.‌ ‌\n105‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n4.‌ ‌\n106‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n5.‌ ‌\n107‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n1.5‌ ‌Comparative‌ ‌Anatomy‌ ‌of‌ ‌Man‌ ‌and‌ ‌Apes;‌ ‌Skeletal‌ ‌changes‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌erect‌ ‌posture‌ ‌and‌ ‌its‌ ‌implications.-‌ ‌Part‌ ‌V‌ ‌\n ‌\n108‌ ‌\nComparative‌ ‌Anatomy‌ ‌of‌ ‌Man‌ ‌and‌ ‌Apes;‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Darwin's‌ ‌declaration‌ ‌regarding‌ ‌the‌ ‌descent‌ ‌of‌ ‌man‌ ‌from‌ ‌non-human‌ ‌ancestors‌ ‌caused‌ ‌a‌ ‌great‌ ‌deal‌ ‌of‌ ‌controversy‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌scientists‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌general‌ ‌public‌ ‌of‌ ‌those‌ ‌times.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌matter‌ ‌of‌ ‌great‌ ‌degradation‌ ‌when‌ ‌any‌ ‌attempt‌ ‌was‌ ‌made‌ ‌to‌ ‌draw‌ ‌any‌ ‌line‌ ‌of‌ ‌relation‌ ‌between‌ ‌Man‌ ‌and‌ ‌Apes.‌ ‌ ‌\n●However,‌ ‌in‌ ‌due‌ ‌course,‌ ‌with‌ ‌newer‌ ‌inventions‌ ‌and‌ ‌discoveries‌ ‌in‌ ‌this‌ ‌area,‌ ‌Darwin’s‌ ‌views‌ ‌were‌ ‌accepted‌ ‌by‌ ‌all‌ ‌and‌ ‌thereby‌ ‌the‌ ‌people‌ ‌\nwere‌ ‌forced‌ ‌to‌ ‌embrace‌ ‌their‌ ‌strange‌ ‌relatives.‌ ‌\n●Apes‌ ‌and‌ ‌Man‌ ‌are‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌family‌ ‌Pongidae,‌ ‌Hylobatidae‌ ‌and‌ ‌Hominidae.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●They‌ ‌belong‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌suborder‌ ‌Anthropoidea‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌order‌ ‌Primates.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌of‌ ‌apes‌ ‌and‌ ‌man‌ ‌will‌ ‌be‌ ‌understood‌ ‌if‌ ‌attempts‌ ‌are‌ ‌made‌ ‌to‌ ‌study‌ ‌the‌ ‌various‌ ‌anatomical‌ ‌features‌ ‌critically.‌ ‌\n ‌\nSkull‌ ‌\n ‌\nMan‌ ‌\n\t\nApes‌ ‌\n\n\n1.The‌ ‌skull‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌man‌ ‌is‌ ‌highly‌ ‌developed‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌frontal‌ ‌region.‌ ‌\n2.The‌ ‌forehead‌ ‌extends‌ ‌almost‌ ‌vertically‌ ‌in‌ ‌upward‌ ‌direction.‌ ‌\n3.The‌ ‌supra-orbital‌ ‌ridge‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌so‌ ‌developed.‌ ‌\n4.No‌ ‌sagittal‌ ‌crest‌ ‌is‌ ‌present‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌skull.‌ ‌\n5.The‌ ‌maxilla‌ ‌and‌ ‌premaxilla‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌fused.‌ ‌\n6.Foramen‌ ‌Magnum‌ ‌is‌ ‌situated‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌center‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌skull.‌ ‌\n7.The‌ ‌head‌ ‌is‌ ‌well‌ ‌balanced‌ ‌hence‌ ‌the‌ ‌face‌ ‌is‌ ‌perfectly‌ ‌vertical.‌ ‌\n ‌\n\t\n1.The‌ ‌forehead‌ ‌is‌ ‌less‌ ‌developed‌ ‌and‌ ‌head‌ ‌slopes‌ ‌backward‌ ‌\n2.The‌ ‌supraorbital‌ ‌is‌ ‌highly‌ ‌developed‌ ‌\n3.Sagittal‌ ‌crest‌ ‌is‌ ‌present‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌skull‌ ‌\n4.Foramen‌ ‌magnum‌ ‌is‌ ‌seen‌ ‌further‌ ‌backward‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌base‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nskull,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌for‌ ‌this‌ ‌reason‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌face‌ ‌of‌ ‌apes‌ ‌hangs‌ ‌\ndownwards.‌ ‌\n ‌\n109‌ ‌\n ‌\n\t\n ‌\n●\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nJaws‌ ‌\n ‌\nMan‌ ‌\n\t\nApes‌ ‌\n\n\n1.The‌ ‌lower‌ ‌jaw‌ ‌in‌ ‌man‌ ‌is‌ ‌small‌ ‌in‌ ‌size‌ ‌in‌ ‌comparison‌ ‌to‌ ‌those‌ ‌of‌ ‌\n\t\n1.Ape's‌ ‌lower‌ ‌jaw‌ ‌is‌ ‌massive‌ ‌\n110‌ ‌\napes‌ ‌\n2.The‌ ‌muscle‌ ‌responsible‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌movement‌ ‌of‌ ‌lower‌ ‌jaw‌ ‌is‌ ‌weak‌ ‌\n3.In‌ ‌man‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌always‌ ‌a‌ ‌well‌ ‌developed‌ ‌chin‌ ‌\n4.Prognathism‌ ‌is‌ ‌absent.‌ ‌\n\t\n2.There‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌trace‌ ‌of‌ ‌chin‌ ‌\n3.Muscles‌ ‌for‌ ‌movement‌ ‌of‌ ‌lower‌ ‌jaw‌ ‌are‌ ‌strong‌ ‌\n4.Facial‌ ‌prognathism‌ ‌is‌ ‌very‌ ‌common‌ ‌among‌ ‌apes.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nTeeth‌ ‌\n ‌\nMan‌ ‌\n\t\nApes‌ ‌\n\n\n1.Smaller‌ ‌in‌ ‌size‌ ‌than‌ ‌those‌ ‌of‌ ‌apes‌ ‌\n2.Canines‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌project‌ ‌forward‌ ‌beyond‌ ‌the‌ ‌level‌ ‌of‌ ‌other‌ ‌teeth‌ ‌\n3.Chewing‌ ‌motion‌ ‌is‌ ‌side‌ ‌to‌ ‌side‌ ‌and‌ ‌also‌ ‌up‌ ‌and‌ ‌down‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌\nrotary‌ ‌motion‌ ‌\n4.Dental‌ ‌arch‌ ‌takes‌ ‌the‌ ‌shape‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌parabola.‌ ‌\n\t\n1.Dental‌ ‌arch‌ ‌is‌ ‌U‌ ‌shaped‌ ‌\n2.Size‌ ‌of‌ ‌teeth‌ ‌are‌ ‌large‌ ‌\n3.Canines‌ ‌projects‌ ‌beyond‌ ‌the‌ ‌level‌ ‌of‌ ‌other‌ ‌teeth,‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌this‌ ‌\nnature‌ ‌canine‌ ‌of‌ ‌apes‌ ‌interlock‌ ‌when‌ ‌jaws‌ ‌are‌ ‌closed‌ ‌\n4.This‌ ‌arrangement‌ ‌prevents‌ ‌the‌ ‌lateral‌ ‌movement‌ ‌in‌ ‌chewing‌ ‌so‌ ‌\nonly‌ ‌up-down‌ ‌chewing‌ ‌motion‌ ‌is‌ ‌present.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nNose‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nMan‌ ‌\n\t\nApes‌ ‌\n\n\n1.Nose‌ ‌is‌ ‌well‌ ‌developed‌ ‌\n2.The‌ ‌root‌ ‌and‌ ‌bridge‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌nose‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌slightly‌ ‌marked‌ ‌elevation‌ ‌\n\t\n1.Nostrils‌ ‌are‌ ‌smaller‌ ‌and‌ ‌generally‌ ‌pointed‌ ‌downwards‌ ‌\n2.The‌ ‌elevation‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌root‌ ‌and‌ ‌bridge‌ ‌is‌ ‌very‌ ‌little‌ ‌or‌ ‌absent‌ ‌\n111‌ ‌\n3.Tip‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌man‌ ‌has‌ ‌a‌ ‌thick‌ ‌bulb‌ ‌\n4.The‌ ‌nasal‌ ‌wings‌ ‌are‌ ‌strongly‌ ‌developed.‌ ‌\n\t\n3.Tip‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌nose‌ ‌is‌ ‌lacking‌ ‌in‌ ‌apes‌ ‌\n4.The‌ ‌cartilaginous‌ ‌portion‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌nose‌ ‌is‌ ‌very‌ ‌wide‌ ‌unlike‌ ‌man‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌little‌ ‌raised‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌surface‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌face.‌ ‌\n ‌\nLips‌ ‌\n ‌\nMan‌ ‌\n\t\nApes‌ ‌\n\n\n1.Integumental‌ ‌upper‌ ‌lip‌ ‌shows‌ ‌a‌ ‌median‌ ‌furrow‌ ‌which‌ ‌starts‌ ‌from‌ ‌\nnasal‌ ‌septum‌ ‌and‌ ‌continues‌ ‌up‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌edge‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌membranous‌ ‌\nlip.‌ ‌ ‌\n2.Median‌ ‌furrow‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌characteristic‌ ‌feature‌ ‌of‌ ‌Man.‌ ‌\n\t\n1.The‌ ‌lips‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌apes‌ ‌are‌ ‌seen‌ ‌starched‌ ‌over‌ ‌their‌ ‌bulging‌ ‌jaws‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌loose‌ ‌and‌ ‌protrusive.‌ ‌\n2.The‌ ‌apse‌ ‌lips‌ ‌are‌ ‌thin‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌red‌ ‌portion‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌lips‌ ‌are‌ ‌rarely‌ ‌\nseen‌ ‌when‌ ‌the‌ ‌mouth‌ ‌is‌ ‌closed.‌ ‌The‌ ‌integumental‌ ‌lip‌ ‌has‌ ‌little‌ ‌\nquantity‌ ‌of‌ ‌fat.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nBrain‌ ‌\n●Brain‌ ‌in‌ ‌man‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌only‌ ‌much‌ ‌larger‌ ‌than‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌apes‌ ‌but‌ ‌also‌ ‌highly‌ ‌developed.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌weight‌ ‌of‌ ‌man’s‌ ‌brain‌ ‌is‌ ‌three‌ ‌times‌ ‌as‌ ‌heavy‌ ‌as‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌gorilla,‌ ‌the‌ ‌largest‌ ‌ape.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌frontal‌ ‌region‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌human‌ ‌brain‌ ‌is‌ ‌especially‌ ‌developed‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌cerebral‌ ‌cortex‌ ‌presents‌ ‌a‌ ‌much‌ ‌more‌ ‌complex‌ ‌development‌ ‌than‌ ‌that‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌the‌ ‌apes.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌brain‌ ‌case‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌man‌ ‌is‌ ‌largest‌ ‌ranging‌ ‌from‌ ‌1300‌ ‌to‌ ‌1450‌ ‌cc.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌average‌ ‌cranial‌ ‌capacity‌ ‌of‌ ‌gorilla‌ ‌is‌ ‌549,‌ ‌chimpanzee‌ ‌400,‌ ‌orangutan‌ ‌416‌ ‌and‌ ‌gibbon‌ ‌98‌ ‌cc‌ ‌respectively.‌ ‌\n112‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nArms‌ ‌\n ‌\nMan‌ ‌\n\t\nApes‌ ‌\n\n\n1.The‌ ‌lower‌ ‌arm‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌movable‌ ‌lever‌ ‌and‌ ‌hence‌ ‌shortened.‌ ‌\n\t\n1.In‌ ‌apes‌ ‌the‌ ‌arms‌ ‌are‌ ‌greatly‌ ‌elongated,‌ ‌an‌ ‌adaptation‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nhabit‌ ‌of‌ ‌hanging‌ ‌and‌ ‌walking‌ ‌in‌ ‌branches.‌ ‌ ‌\n2.In‌ ‌apes‌ ‌upper‌ ‌arms‌ ‌act‌ ‌as‌ ‌movable‌ ‌levers‌ ‌and‌ ‌hence‌ ‌the‌ ‌length‌ ‌\nis‌ ‌short.‌ ‌\n ‌\nLegs‌ ‌\n ‌\nMan‌ ‌\n\t\nApes‌ ‌\n\n\n1.In‌ ‌man‌ ‌femur‌ ‌(Thigh‌ ‌Bone)‌ ‌is‌ ‌long,‌ ‌slender‌ ‌and‌ ‌elongated.‌ ‌\n\t\n1.The‌ ‌femur‌ ‌(Thigh‌ ‌Bone)‌ ‌of‌ ‌ape‌ ‌is‌ ‌short,‌ ‌thick‌ ‌and‌ ‌curved.‌ ‌ ‌\n113‌ ‌\n2.The‌ ‌ridges‌ ‌for‌ ‌muscle‌ ‌development‌ ‌in‌ ‌femur‌ ‌are‌ ‌greatly‌ ‌\ndeveloped‌ ‌in‌ ‌man‌ ‌than‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌apes.‌ ‌The‌ ‌linea‌ ‌aspera,‌ ‌a‌ ‌rough‌ ‌\nridge‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌back‌ ‌side‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌femur‌ ‌is‌ ‌characteristic‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌man.it‌ ‌\nhas‌ ‌resulted‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌great‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌extensor‌ ‌muscle‌ ‌\nwhich‌ ‌play‌ ‌an‌ ‌important‌ ‌part‌ ‌in‌ ‌erect‌ ‌posture‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌bipedal‌ ‌\ngait.‌ ‌\n\t\n2.The‌ ‌ridges‌ ‌for‌ ‌muscle‌ ‌development‌ ‌in‌ ‌femur‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌developed.‌ ‌\n ‌\nFoot‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌foot‌ ‌of‌ ‌man‌ ‌has‌ ‌witnessed‌ ‌a‌ ‌remarkable‌ ‌change‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌its‌ ‌new‌ ‌mode‌ ‌of‌ ‌locomotion.‌ ‌The‌ ‌foot‌ ‌supports‌ ‌the‌ ‌weight‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌body‌ ‌and‌ ‌helps‌ ‌\nin‌ ‌walking‌ ‌and‌ ‌standing‌ ‌erect.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌apes‌ ‌the‌ ‌foot‌ ‌is‌ ‌used‌ ‌both‌ ‌for‌ ‌locomotion‌ ‌and‌ ‌grasping‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌tree‌ ‌branches.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌great‌ ‌toe‌ ‌in‌ ‌man‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌opposable.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌lateral‌ ‌toes‌ ‌are‌ ‌reduced‌ ‌in‌ ‌size‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌fifth‌ ‌one‌ ‌rudimentary.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nLanguage‌ ‌&‌ ‌Speech‌ ‌\n●Man‌ ‌is‌ ‌distinguished‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌apes‌ ‌mainly‌ ‌by‌ ‌his‌ ‌ability‌ ‌of‌ ‌articulating‌ ‌speech.‌ ‌But‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌some‌ ‌scientists‌ ‌who‌ ‌have‌ ‌felt‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nsome‌ ‌sort‌ ‌of‌ ‌language‌ ‌among‌ ‌apes.‌ ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌Addition‌ ‌\n ‌\nApe‌ ‌&‌ ‌Man‌ ‌\n\t\nSimilarities‌ ‌\n\t\nDissimilarities‌ ‌\n\n\n ‌\nChimpanzee‌ ‌&‌ ‌Man‌ ‌\n\t\n●Skull‌ ‌and‌ ‌pigmentation‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌body.‌ ‌\n●Chest‌ ‌portion‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌same.‌ ‌\n\t\n●Canines‌ ‌\n\n\n ‌\nOrangutan‌ ‌&‌ ‌Man‌ ‌\n\t\n●High‌ ‌forehead‌ ‌ ‌\n●Same‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌pair‌ ‌of‌ ‌ribs‌ ‌ ‌\n\t\n●Shortness‌ ‌and‌ ‌degenerate‌ ‌character‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌legs.‌ ‌\n●Adaptation‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌feet‌ ‌for‌ ‌suspension.‌ ‌\n\n\n ‌\nGibbon‌ ‌&‌ ‌Man‌ ‌\n\t\n●Length‌ ‌of‌ ‌leg‌ ‌ ‌\n●Erect‌ ‌gait‌ ‌ ‌\n\t\n●Excessive‌ ‌arm‌ ‌lengths,‌ ‌ ‌\n●General‌ ‌size‌ ‌of‌ ‌pelvis,‌ ‌hands‌ ‌and‌ ‌feet‌ ‌\n●Length‌ ‌of‌ ‌canine‌ ‌teeth‌ ‌\n●Size‌ ‌of‌ ‌brain‌ ‌\n\n\nGorilla‌ ‌&‌ ‌Man‌ ‌\n\t\n●Size‌ ‌of‌ ‌hands,feet‌ ‌,pelvis‌ ‌and‌ ‌size‌ ‌of‌ ‌\n\t\n●Massive‌ ‌jaws‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌gorillas‌ ‌\n114‌ ‌\n\t\nbrain‌ ‌\n\t\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nSkeletal‌ ‌changes‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌erect‌ ‌posture‌ ‌and‌ ‌its‌ ‌implications.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●The‌ ‌history‌ ‌of‌ ‌primate‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌evolved‌ ‌from‌ ‌non‌ ‌human‌ ‌primates.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Gradual‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌from:‌ ‌\n○Terrestrial‌ ‌quadrupedalism‌ ‌(pronograde)‌>>>‌Semi-erect‌ ‌posture‌ ‌(clinograde)‌>>>‌Fully‌ ‌erect‌ ‌posture‌ ‌(orthograde)‌ ‌with‌ ‌bipedal‌ ‌\nlocomotion.‌ ‌\n●Erect‌ ‌posture‌ ‌has‌ ‌consequences‌ ‌on‌ ‌our‌ ‌skeletal‌ ‌system.‌ ‌Anatomical‌ ‌modifications‌ ‌that‌ ‌took‌ ‌place‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌skeletal‌ ‌system‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌assumption‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌erect‌ ‌posture‌ ‌vary‌ ‌in‌ ‌magnitude‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌parts‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌skeleton.‌ ‌\n●Changes‌ ‌are‌ ‌observed‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌more‌ ‌prominent‌ ‌on:‌ ‌\n○Skull,‌ ‌ ‌\n○Vertebral‌ ‌column,‌ ‌ ‌\n○Pelvic‌ ‌girdle,‌ ‌ ‌\n○Femur‌ ‌and‌ ‌ ‌\n○Foot.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Changes‌ ‌in‌ ‌Pelvic‌ ‌Girdle‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌assumption‌ ‌of‌ ‌Erect‌ ‌Posture:-‌ ‌\n○When‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌stands‌ ‌erect,‌ ‌his‌ ‌whole‌ ‌body‌ ‌weight‌ ‌is‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌transmitted‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌hind‌ ‌legs‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌pelvic‌ ‌girdle.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Therefore‌ ‌the‌ ‌pelvis‌ ‌plays‌ ‌a‌ ‌great‌ ‌role‌ ‌in‌ ‌getting‌ ‌an‌ ‌erect‌ ‌posture‌ ‌and‌ ‌naturally‌ ‌has‌ ‌experienced‌ ‌a‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌changes.‌ ‌\n○Some‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌associated‌ ‌changes‌ ‌are:‌ ‌\n ‌\n■When‌ ‌an‌ ‌animal‌ ‌stands‌ ‌up‌ ‌with‌ ‌its‌ ‌spine‌ ‌more‌ ‌or‌ ‌less‌ ‌perpendicular‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌ground,‌ ‌the‌ ‌girdle‌ ‌is‌ ‌now‌ ‌to‌ ‌transmit‌ ‌the‌ ‌weight‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌entire‌ ‌body.‌ ‌As‌ ‌a‌ ‌result‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌new‌ ‌stress‌ ‌the‌ ‌pelvis‌ ‌is‌ ‌now‌ ‌flattened‌ ‌downward‌ ‌and‌ ‌expanded‌ ‌laterally;‌ ‌it‌ ‌becomes‌ ‌lower‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌broader.‌ ‌Its‌ ‌anterior‌ ‌or‌ ‌superior‌ ‌end‌ ‌spreads‌ ‌out,‌ ‌making‌ ‌it‌ ‌funnel‌ ‌shaped‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌small‌ ‌orifice‌ ‌directed‌ ‌downward.‌ ‌\n115‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌was‌ ‌observed‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌human‌ ‌pelvis‌ ‌had‌ ‌experienced‌ ‌a‌ ‌‌mosaic‌ ‌evolution‌.‌ ‌The‌ ‌three‌ ‌bones‌ ‌that‌ ‌make‌ ‌up‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌pelvis-‌ ‌\nischium,‌ ‌ilium‌ ‌and‌ ‌pubis‌‌ ‌did‌ ‌not‌ ‌develop‌ ‌and‌ ‌change‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌rate.‌ ‌\n ‌\n■The‌ ‌ilium‌ ‌experienced‌ ‌change‌ ‌most‌ ‌and‌ ‌ischium‌ ‌the‌ ‌least.‌ ‌The‌ ‌ischium‌ ‌of‌ ‌man‌ ‌is‌ ‌almost‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌as‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌living‌ ‌pongidae.‌ ‌\nThe‌ ‌ilium‌ ‌shortened‌ ‌and‌ ‌broadened‌ ‌and‌ ‌bent‌ ‌back‌ ‌on‌ ‌ischium,‌ ‌and‌ ‌resembled‌ ‌a‌ ‌fan‌ ‌shaped‌ ‌in‌ ‌appearance.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n116‌ ‌\n■Among‌ ‌the‌ ‌primates,‌ ‌the‌ ‌extreme‌ ‌shortness‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌ilium‌ ‌puts‌ ‌man‌ ‌in‌ ‌position‌ ‌of‌ ‌lower‌ ‌pelvis‌ ‌relative‌ ‌to‌ ‌trunk‌ ‌height‌ ‌than‌ ‌\nany‌ ‌other‌ ‌primate.‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌excessive‌ ‌breadth‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌sacral‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌human‌ ‌ilium‌ ‌also‌ ‌helps‌ ‌in‌ ‌transmitting‌ ‌the‌ ‌whole‌ ‌body‌ ‌weight.‌ ‌\n■Proportionately,‌ ‌the‌ ‌human‌ ‌pelvis‌ ‌exhibits‌ ‌a‌ ‌much‌ ‌larger‌ ‌and‌ ‌thicker‌ ‌acetabular‌ ‌region(hip‌ ‌joints)‌ ‌than‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌other‌ ‌primates.‌ ‌\nThis‌ ‌also‌ ‌helps‌ ‌in‌ ‌transmitting‌ ‌and‌ ‌supporting‌ ‌the‌ ‌body‌ ‌weight‌ ‌femur‌ ‌whose‌ ‌head‌ ‌articulates‌ ‌with‌ ‌it.‌ ‌\n ‌\n■The‌ ‌acetabulum‌ ‌lies‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌middle‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌ilium‌ ‌and‌ ‌ischium,‌ ‌unlike‌ ‌those‌ ‌of‌ ‌pongids‌ ‌among‌ ‌whom‌ ‌the‌ ‌acetabulum‌ ‌is‌ ‌located‌ ‌\nwell‌ ‌below.‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌sacrum‌ ‌is‌ ‌shorter‌ ‌and‌ ‌broader‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌inlet‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌pelvis‌ ‌forms‌ ‌a‌ ‌broad‌ ‌bottomless‌ ‌basin‌ ‌which‌ ‌supports‌ ‌pelvic‌ ‌viscera.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Changes‌ ‌in‌ ‌Femur‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌assumption‌ ‌of‌ ‌Erect‌
