‌Posture:-‌ ‌\n ‌\n○In‌ ‌an‌ ‌erect‌ ‌standing‌ ‌animal‌ ‌the‌ ‌entire‌ ‌weight‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌trunk‌ ‌and‌ ‌upper‌ ‌extremity‌ ‌is‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌transmitted‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌pelvis‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌femur‌ ‌which‌ ‌\nin‌ ‌turn‌ ‌supports‌ ‌the‌ ‌same.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Therefore‌ ‌in‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌bear‌ ‌the‌ ‌load‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌weight,‌ ‌the‌ ‌femur‌ ‌has‌ ‌to‌ ‌experience‌ ‌a‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌modifications‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌femur‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nquadrupedal‌ ‌or‌ ‌semi‌ ‌erect‌ ‌postured‌ ‌primates.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌following‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌modifications‌ ‌observed‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌femur‌ ‌of‌ ‌man‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌assumption‌ ‌of‌ ‌erect‌ ‌posture.‌ ‌\n■In‌ ‌contrast‌ ‌to‌ ‌other‌ ‌primates,‌ ‌human‌ ‌legs‌ ‌(lower‌ ‌extremity)‌ ‌are‌ ‌longer‌ ‌than‌ ‌arms,‌ ‌as‌ ‌such‌ ‌the‌ ‌femur‌ ‌is‌ ‌long‌ ‌and‌ ‌stout.‌ ‌To‌ ‌meet‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌pressure‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌body‌ ‌weight.‌ ‌Infect‌ ‌femur‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌longest,‌ ‌largest‌ ‌and‌ ‌strongest‌ ‌single‌ ‌bone‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌human‌ ‌body.‌ ‌\n117‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌condyles‌ ‌(lateral‌ ‌and‌ ‌medial)‌ ‌are‌ ‌comparatively‌ ‌larger‌ ‌than‌ ‌those‌ ‌of‌ ‌other‌ ‌nonhuman‌ ‌primates‌ ‌because‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌fact‌ ‌that‌ ‌\njoints‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌leg‌ ‌need‌ ‌to‌ ‌have‌ ‌large‌ ‌and‌ ‌stout‌ ‌structures‌ ‌for‌ ‌supporting‌ ‌the‌ ‌body‌ ‌weight.‌ ‌\n ‌\n■The‌ ‌ridges‌ ‌for‌ ‌muscle‌ ‌attachments‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌femur‌ ‌are‌ ‌much‌ ‌more‌ ‌sharply‌ ‌defined‌ ‌and‌ ‌differentiated‌ ‌than‌ ‌other‌ ‌non-human‌ ‌\nprimates.‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌femur‌ ‌is‌ ‌angled‌ ‌outward‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌knee‌ ‌rather‌ ‌than‌ ‌standing‌ ‌upright‌ ‌as‌ ‌observed‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌great‌ ‌apes.‌ ‌This‌ ‌carrying‌ ‌\nangle‌ ‌ensures‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌knee‌ ‌is‌ ‌brought‌ ‌well‌ ‌under‌ ‌the‌ ‌body‌ ‌and‌ ‌closer‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌line‌ ‌of‌ ‌action‌ ‌of‌ ‌body‌ ‌weight.‌ ‌\n ‌\n118‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Changes‌ ‌in‌ ‌Foot‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌assumption‌ ‌of‌ ‌Erect‌ ‌Posture:-‌ ‌\n○With‌ ‌the‌ ‌assumption‌ ‌of‌ ‌erect‌ ‌posture‌ ‌and‌ ‌bipedal‌ ‌walk,‌ ‌the‌ ‌hind‌ ‌limb‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌longer‌ ‌a‌ ‌grasping‌ ‌organ‌ ‌but‌ ‌locomotory‌ ‌organ.‌ ‌ ‌\n○As‌ ‌such‌ ‌changes‌ ‌necessary‌ ‌for‌ ‌modifying‌ ‌this‌ ‌grasping‌ ‌foot‌ ‌into‌ ‌an‌ ‌organ‌ ‌capable‌ ‌of‌ ‌supporting‌ ‌the‌ ‌weight‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌body‌ ‌is‌ ‌fairly‌ ‌clear.‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌great‌ ‌toe‌ ‌and‌ ‌its‌ ‌supporting‌ ‌metatarsal‌ ‌bones‌ ‌must‌ ‌be‌ ‌brought‌ ‌into‌ ‌the‌ ‌line‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌long‌ ‌axis‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌foot;‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌divergent‌ ‌toe,‌ ‌\nsticking‌ ‌out‌ ‌like‌ ‌a‌ ‌thumb‌ ‌would‌ ‌be‌ ‌a‌ ‌hindrance‌ ‌to‌ ‌ground‌ ‌walking,‌ ‌since‌ ‌it‌ ‌would‌ ‌be‌ ‌stubbed‌ ‌almost‌ ‌constantly.‌ ‌Therefore,‌ ‌all‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌toes‌ ‌are‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌line.‌ ‌\n ‌\n■The‌ ‌big‌ ‌toe‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌more‌ ‌opposable‌ ‌since‌ ‌the‌ ‌foot‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌whole‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌a‌ ‌grasping‌ ‌organ.‌ ‌Because‌ ‌of‌ ‌this,‌ ‌it‌ ‌also‌ ‌became‌ ‌shorter‌ ‌\nthan‌ ‌the‌ ‌thumb.‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌four‌ ‌lesser‌ ‌toes‌ ‌being‌ ‌no‌ ‌longer‌ ‌used‌ ‌for‌ ‌grasping‌ ‌now‌ ‌underwent‌ ‌a‌ ‌process‌ ‌of‌ ‌shortening‌ ‌and‌ ‌degeneration.‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌great‌ ‌toe‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌separated‌ ‌from‌ ‌other‌ ‌toes‌ ‌and‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌metatarsal‌ ‌are‌ ‌bound‌ ‌together‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌common‌ ‌ligament.‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌weight‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌body‌ ‌is‌ ‌transmitted‌ ‌from‌ ‌heel‌ ‌to‌ ‌great‌ ‌toe‌ ‌during‌ ‌walking.‌ ‌Therefore‌ ‌the‌ ‌foot‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌modified‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌\ndevelopment‌ ‌of‌ ‌transverse‌ ‌and‌ ‌longitudinal‌ ‌arches‌ ‌which‌ ‌help‌ ‌to‌ ‌absorb‌ ‌shocks.‌ ‌\n119‌ ‌\n■Elongation‌ ‌and‌ ‌strengthening‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌calcaneus‌‌ ‌is‌ ‌another‌ ‌modification‌ ‌so‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌weight‌ ‌is‌ ‌easily‌ ‌transmitted.‌ ‌\n ‌\n120‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌talus‌ ‌bone‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌enlarged‌ ‌and‌ ‌wedge‌ ‌shaped‌ ‌to‌ ‌serve‌ ‌the‌ ‌purpose‌ ‌of‌ ‌transmitting‌ ‌the‌ ‌weight‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌great‌ ‌toe‌ ‌while‌ ‌\nwalking.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n121‌ ‌\n1.6‌ ‌Phylogenetic‌ ‌status,‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌and‌ ‌geographical‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌following‌ ‌:‌ ‌\n(a)‌ ‌Plio-pleistocene‌ ‌hominids‌ ‌in‌ ‌South‌ ‌and‌ ‌East‌ ‌Africa—Australopithecines.-‌ ‌Part‌ ‌I‌ ‌\n ‌ ‌\nIntroduction:‌ ‌\n●Australopithecina‌‌ ‌or‌ ‌‌Hominina‌‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌subtribe‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌tribe‌ ‌‌Hominini.‌ ‌\n●Members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌human‌ ‌clade,‌ ‌i.e.‌‌ ‌the‌ ‌Hominini‌ ‌after‌ ‌the‌ ‌split‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌chimpanzees,‌ ‌are‌ ‌now‌ ‌called‌ ‌Hominina.‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌were‌ ‌an‌ ‌adaptive‌ ‌radiation‌ ‌of‌ ‌hominins‌ ‌that‌ ‌lived‌ ‌4.2-2‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago.‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌were‌ ‌an‌ ‌adaptive‌ ‌radiation‌ ‌of‌ ‌hominins‌ ‌that‌ ‌lived‌ ‌4.2-2‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌genus‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌subtribe‌ ‌Australopithecina‌ ‌typically‌ ‌includes‌ ‌the‌ ‌earlier‌ ‌Australopithecus,‌ ‌Paranthropus,Ardipithecus,‌ ‌Orrorin,‌ ‌\nSahelanthropus,‌ ‌and‌ ‌Kenyanthropus.‌ ‌\n○All‌ ‌these‌ ‌related‌ ‌species‌ ‌are‌ ‌now‌ ‌sometimes‌ ‌collectively‌ ‌termed‌‌ ‌australopiths‌ ‌or‌ ‌homininians‌.‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌extinct,‌ ‌close‌ ‌relatives‌ ‌of‌ ‌humans‌ ‌and,‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌extant‌ ‌genus‌ ‌Homo,‌ ‌comprise‌ ‌the‌ ‌human‌ ‌clade.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Antedate‌ ‌or‌ ‌overlap‌ ‌with‌ ‌earliest‌ ‌representatives‌ ‌of‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌and‌ ‌are‌ ‌known‌ ‌collectively‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌Australopithecines.‌ ‌Hence,‌ ‌we‌ ‌should‌ ‌\nunderstand‌ ‌the‌ ‌importance‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌hominid‌ ‌fossil‌ ‌(Australopithecines)‌ ‌in‌ ‌tracing‌ ‌the‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌line‌ ‌of‌ ‌present‌ ‌day‌ ‌human‌ ‌beings.‌ ‌\n ‌\n122‌ ‌\n ‌\n123‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nNote:‌ ‌We‌ ‌don’t‌ ‌know‌ ‌everything‌ ‌about‌ ‌our‌ ‌early‌ ‌ancestors—but‌ ‌we‌ ‌keep‌ ‌learning‌ ‌more!‌ ‌Paleoanthropologists‌ ‌are‌ ‌constantly‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌field,‌ ‌excavating‌ ‌\nnew‌ ‌areas,‌ ‌using‌ ‌groundbreaking‌ ‌technology,‌ ‌and‌ ‌continually‌ ‌filling‌ ‌in‌ ‌some‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌gaps‌ ‌about‌ ‌our‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌evolution.‌ ‌\n ‌\nAbout:‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Australopithecines‌ ‌(group‌ ‌of‌ ‌extinct‌ ‌primates)‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌genus‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌hominids‌ ‌that‌ ‌lived‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Pliocene(5.3-2.6‌ ‌mya)‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nPleistocene(2.6mya‌ ‌-11,700years‌ ‌ago)‌.‌ ‌\n●Most‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌Hominid‌ ‌fossils‌ ‌of‌ ‌Africa.‌ ‌\n○Perhaps‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌famous‌ ‌specimen‌ ‌is‌ ‌“‌Lucy‌,”‌ ‌(Australopithecus‌ ‌afarensis)‌ ‌a‌ ‌remarkably‌ ‌preserved‌ ‌fossilized‌ ‌skeleton‌ ‌from‌ ‌Ethiopia‌ ‌\nthat‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌dated‌ ‌to‌ ‌3.2‌ ‌mya.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Australopithecine‌ ‌fossils‌ ‌were‌ ‌found‌ ‌at‌ ‌different‌ ‌places‌ ‌in‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌and‌ ‌outside‌ ‌Africa.‌ ‌ ‌\n●As‌ ‌characterized‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌fossil‌ ‌evidence,‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌Australopithecus‌ ‌bore‌ ‌a‌ ‌combination‌ ‌of‌ ‌humanlike‌ ‌and‌ ‌apelike‌ ‌traits.‌ ‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌were‌ ‌similar‌ ‌to‌ ‌modern‌ ‌humans‌ ‌in‌ ‌that‌ ‌they‌ ‌were‌ ‌bipedal‌ ‌(that‌ ‌is,‌ ‌they‌ ‌walked‌ ‌on‌ ‌two‌ ‌legs),‌ ‌but,‌ ‌like‌ ‌apes,‌ ‌they‌ ‌had‌ ‌small‌ ‌\nbrains.‌ ‌\n●Australopithecine‌ ‌fossils‌ ‌named‌ ‌five‌ ‌to‌ ‌six‌ ‌genera‌,‌ ‌but‌ ‌now‌ ‌the‌ ‌consensus‌ ‌of‌ ‌scientific‌ ‌opinion‌ ‌recognizes‌ ‌one‌ ‌genus‌ ‌Australopithecus‌ ‌and‌ ‌\ntwo‌ ‌species,namely:‌ ‌\n124‌ ‌\n○Australopithecus‌ ‌(Gracile‌ ‌form)-‌A‌ ‌slenderly‌ ‌built‌ ‌and‌ ‌smaller‌ ‌form.‌ ‌\n○Australopithecus‌ ‌(Robustus‌ ‌form)‌-Larger‌ ‌roughly‌ ‌built,‌ ‌originally‌ ‌called‌ ‌Paranthropus.‌ ‌\nIt‌ ‌is‌ ‌still‌ ‌under‌ ‌discussion‌ ‌whether‌ ‌they‌ ‌should‌ ‌be‌ ‌put‌ ‌in‌ ‌separate‌ ‌genera.‌ ‌Here‌ ‌we‌ ‌treat‌ ‌the‌ ‌gracile‌ ‌forms;‌ ‌the‌ ‌robust‌ ‌forms‌ ‌are‌ ‌described‌ ‌elsewhere‌ ‌\nas‌ ‌Paranthropus.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nUnderstanding‌ ‌Classification‌ ‌ ‌\nClassification‌ ‌of‌ ‌subtribe‌ ‌‌Australopithecina‌‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌Briggs‌ ‌&‌ ‌Crowther‌ ‌2008.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Australopithecus‌ ‌\n○Australopithecus‌ ‌africanus‌ ‌\n○Australopithecus‌ ‌deyiremeda‌ ‌\n○Australopithecus‌ ‌garhi‌ ‌\n○Australopithecus‌ ‌sediba‌ ‌\n○Australopithecus‌ ‌afarensis‌ ‌‌(=Praeanthropus‌ ‌afarensis)‌ ‌\n○Australopithecus‌ ‌anamensis‌‌ ‌(=Praeanthropus‌ ‌anamensis)‌ ‌\n125‌ ‌\n○Australopithecus‌ ‌bahrelghazali‌ ‌(=Praeanthropus‌ ‌bahrelghazali)‌ ‌\n●Paranthropus‌ ‌\n○Paranthropus‌ ‌robustus‌ ‌\n○Paranthropus‌ ‌boisei‌ ‌\n○Paranthropus‌ ‌aethiopicus‌ ‌\n●Ardipithecus‌ ‌\n○Ardipithecus‌ ‌ramidus‌ ‌\n○Ardipithecus‌ ‌kadabba‌ ‌\n●Orrorin‌ ‌\n○Orrorin‌ ‌tugenensis‌ ‌\n●Sahelanthropus‌ ‌\n○Sahelanthropus‌ ‌tchadensis‌ ‌\n●Graecopithecus‌ ‌\n●Graecopithecus‌ ‌freybergi‌ ‌\n●Graecopithecus‌ ‌macedoniensis‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nAustralopithecus‌ ‌(Gracile‌ ‌form)‌ ‌\nGracile‌ ‌australopithecines‌ ‌shared‌ ‌several‌ ‌traits‌ ‌with‌ ‌modern‌ ‌apes‌ ‌and‌ ‌humans.‌ ‌They‌ ‌were‌ ‌widespread‌ ‌throughout‌ ‌Eastern‌ ‌and‌ ‌Northern‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌3.9‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌3‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago.‌ ‌\nIt‌ ‌include:‌ ‌\n1.Australopithecus‌ ‌Anamensis‌ ‌\n2.Australopithecus‌ ‌Afarensis‌ ‌\n3.Australopithecus‌ ‌Africanus‌ ‌\n4.Australopithecus‌ ‌Garhi‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nHuman‌ ‌Family‌ ‌Tree‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n126‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n127‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nAustralopithecus‌ ‌group‌ ‌\n ‌\n128‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nAustralopithecus‌ ‌anamensis‌ ‌\n●Australopithecus‌ ‌anamensis‌ ‌(anem‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌Turkana‌ ‌word‌ ‌for‌ ‌lake)‌ ‌i‌s‌ ‌the‌ ‌earliest‌ ‌and‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌poorly‌ ‌known‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌genus‌ ‌\nAustralopithecus.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌species‌ ‌is‌ ‌largely‌ ‌known‌ ‌from‌ ‌teeth‌ ‌and‌ ‌fragmentary‌ ‌pieces‌ ‌of‌ ‌maxillae‌ ‌and‌ ‌mandibles;‌ ‌very‌ ‌limited‌ ‌postcranial‌ ‌material‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌\nrecovered.‌ ‌\n ‌\nAustralopithecus‌ ‌anamensis‌ ‌\n129‌ ‌\n ‌\nDiscovery‌ ‌Date:‌ ‌‌1995‌ ‌\nWhere‌ ‌Lived:‌ ‌Eastern‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌(Lake‌ ‌Turkana,‌ ‌Kenya‌ ‌and‌ ‌Middle‌ ‌Awash,‌ ‌\nEthiopia)‌ ‌\nWhen‌ ‌Lived:‌ ‌‌About‌ ‌4.2‌ ‌to‌ ‌3.8‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nCharacteristics:‌ ‌\n●Australopithecus‌ ‌anamensis‌ ‌has‌ ‌a‌ ‌combination‌ ‌of‌ ‌traits‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌‌both‌ ‌apes‌ ‌and‌ ‌humans.‌ ‌ ‌\n●A.‌ ‌anamensis‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌habitual‌ ‌biped.‌ ‌However,‌ ‌the‌ ‌humerus‌ ‌and‌ ‌radius‌ ‌of‌ ‌A.‌ ‌anamensis‌ ‌show‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌that‌ ‌suggest‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌also‌ ‌adept‌ ‌\nat‌ ‌moving‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌tree‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌upper‌ ‌end‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌tibia‌ ‌(shin‌ ‌bone)‌ ‌shows‌ ‌an‌ ‌expanded‌ ‌area‌ ‌of‌ ‌bone‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌human-like‌ ‌orientation‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌ankle‌ ‌joint,‌ ‌indicative‌ ‌of‌ ‌regular‌ ‌\nbipedal‌ ‌walking‌ ‌(support‌ ‌of‌ ‌body‌ ‌weight‌ ‌on‌ ‌one‌ ‌leg‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌time).‌ ‌ ‌\n●Long‌ ‌forearms‌ ‌and‌ ‌features‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌wrist‌ ‌bones‌ ‌suggest‌ ‌these‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌probably‌ ‌climbed‌ ‌trees‌ ‌as‌ ‌well.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌cranium‌ ‌combines‌ ‌some‌ ‌more‌ ‌ancestral‌ ‌features‌,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌protruding‌ ‌face‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌long‌ ‌and‌ ‌narrow‌ ‌braincase,‌ ‌with‌ ‌some‌ ‌more‌ ‌derived‌ ‌\nfeatures,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌forwardly‌ ‌projecting‌ ‌cheekbones‌ ‌similar‌ ‌to‌ ‌Paranthropus.‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌had‌ ‌t‌hickly-built,‌ ‌long,‌ ‌narrow‌ ‌jaws‌ ‌with‌ ‌their‌ ‌side‌ ‌rows‌ ‌of‌ ‌teeth‌ ‌arranged‌ ‌in‌ ‌parallel‌ ‌lines.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Their‌ ‌strong‌ ‌jaws‌ ‌combined‌ ‌with‌ ‌heavily‌ ‌enameled‌ ‌teeth‌ ‌suggest‌ ‌‌Au.‌ ‌anamensis‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌may‌ ‌at‌ ‌times‌ ‌have‌ ‌eaten‌ ‌hard,‌ ‌abrasive‌ ‌foods,‌ ‌\nbut‌ ‌they‌ ‌likely‌ ‌were‌ ‌plant-eaters‌ ‌in‌ ‌general,‌ ‌relying‌ ‌on‌ ‌both‌ ‌fruits‌ ‌and‌ ‌tough‌ ‌foods‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌nuts.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n130‌ ‌\nFossil‌ ‌Discovery:‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌1994‌,‌ ‌a‌ ‌research‌ ‌team‌ ‌led‌ ‌by‌ ‌paleoanthropologist‌ ‌‌Meave‌ ‌Leakey‌ ‌found‌ ‌numerous‌ ‌teeth‌ ‌and‌ ‌fragments‌ ‌of‌ ‌bone‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌site‌ ‌of‌ ‌Kanapoi‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nnorthern‌ ‌Kenya.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Leakey‌ ‌and‌ ‌her‌ ‌colleagues‌ ‌determined‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌fossils‌ ‌were‌ ‌those‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌very‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌hominin‌ ‌and‌ ‌they‌ ‌named‌ ‌a‌ ‌new‌ ‌species‌ ‌called‌ ‌\nAustralopithecus‌ ‌anamensis‌ ‌(‘anam’‌ ‌means‌ ‌‘lake’‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Turkana‌ ‌language).‌ ‌ ‌\n○Researchers‌ ‌have‌ ‌since‌ ‌found‌ ‌other‌ ‌Au.‌ ‌anamensis‌ ‌fossils‌ ‌at‌ ‌nearby‌ ‌sites‌ ‌(including‌ ‌Allia‌ ‌Bay),‌ ‌all‌ ‌of‌ ‌which‌ ‌date‌ ‌between‌ ‌about‌ ‌4.2‌ ‌\nmillion‌ ‌and‌ ‌3.9‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌old.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌2019,‌ ‌‌a‌ ‌team‌ ‌led‌ ‌by‌ ‌Yohannes‌ ‌Haile-Selassie‌ ‌announced‌ ‌a‌ ‌nearly‌ ‌complete‌ ‌Au.‌ ‌anamensis‌ ‌cranium‌ ‌from‌ ‌Woranso-Mille,‌ ‌Ethiopia,‌ ‌dated‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌3.8‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago.‌ ‌\n ‌\nPhylogeny:‌ ‌\n●Jaw‌ ‌remains‌ ‌suggest‌ ‌that‌ ‌this‌ ‌species‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌direct‌ ‌ancestor‌ ‌of‌ ‌Australopithecus‌ ‌afarensis,‌ ‌and‌ ‌possibly‌ ‌the‌ ‌direct‌ ‌descendent‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌species‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌Ardipithecus.‌ ‌ ‌\n●However,‌ ‌‌a‌ ‌new‌ ‌cranium‌ ‌announced‌ ‌in‌ ‌2019‌ ‌dated‌ ‌to‌ ‌3.8‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago‌ ‌indicates‌ ‌that‌ ‌this‌ ‌species‌ ‌overlapped‌ ‌in‌ ‌time‌ ‌with‌ ‌\nAustralopithecus‌ ‌afarensis‌ ‌for‌ ‌at‌ ‌least‌ ‌100,000‌ ‌years.‌ ‌\n131‌ ‌\n ‌\n132‌ ‌\n ‌\nPhylogeny‌ ‌of‌ ‌early‌ ‌hominins.‌ ‌Cladogram‌ ‌obtained‌ ‌by‌ ‌Strait‌ ‌and‌ ‌Grine‌ ‌(2004)‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌of‌ ‌“traditional”‌ ‌characters‌ ‌applied‌ ‌to‌ ‌all‌ ‌\ningroup‌ ‌taxa.‌ ‌Last‌ ‌common‌ ‌ancestor‌ ‌of‌ ‌australopiths‌ ‌and‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌indicated‌ ‌by‌ ‌arrow.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nAustralopithecus‌ ‌afarensis‌ ‌\nOverview‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Australopithecus‌ ‌afarensis‌ ‌is‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌longest-lived‌ ‌and‌ ‌best-known‌ ‌early‌ ‌human‌ ‌species‌—paleoanthropologists‌ ‌have‌ ‌uncovered‌ ‌\nremains‌ ‌from‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌300‌ ‌individuals!‌ ‌ ‌\n●Found‌ ‌between‌ ‌3.85‌ ‌and‌ ‌2.95‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago‌ ‌in‌ ‌Eastern‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌(Ethiopia,‌ ‌Kenya,‌ ‌Tanzania),‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌species‌ ‌survived‌ ‌for‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌‌900,000‌ ‌years,‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌over‌ ‌four‌ ‌times‌ ‌as‌ ‌long‌ ‌as‌ ‌our‌ ‌own‌ ‌species‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌around.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌best‌ ‌known‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌sites‌ ‌of:‌ ‌\n●Hadar,‌ ‌Ethiopia‌ ‌(‘Lucy’);‌ ‌ ‌\n133‌ ‌\n●Dikika,‌ ‌Ethiopia‌ ‌(Dikika‌ ‌‘child’‌ ‌skeleton);‌ ‌and‌ ‌ ‌\n●Laetoli‌ ‌(fossils‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌species‌ ‌plus‌ ‌the‌ ‌oldest‌ ‌documented‌ ‌bipedal‌ ‌footprint‌ ‌trails)‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nAustralopithecus‌ ‌afarensis‌ ‌\nNickname:‌ ‌Lucy's‌ ‌species‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nDiscovery‌ ‌Date:‌ ‌‌1974‌ ‌\n134‌ ‌\nWhere‌ ‌Lived:‌ ‌‌Eastern‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌(Ethiopia,‌ ‌Kenya,‌ ‌Tanzania)‌ ‌\nWhen‌ ‌Lived:‌ ‌‌Between‌ ‌about‌ ‌3.85‌ ‌and‌ ‌2.95‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nHeight:‌ ‌Males:‌ ‌‌average‌ ‌4‌ ‌ft‌ ‌11‌ ‌in‌ ‌(151‌ ‌cm);‌ ‌Females:‌ ‌average‌ ‌3‌ ‌ft‌ ‌5‌ ‌in‌ ‌(105‌ ‌cm)‌ ‌\nWeight:‌ ‌Males‌:‌ ‌average‌ ‌92‌ ‌lbs‌ ‌(42‌ ‌kg)‌ ‌;‌ ‌Females:‌ ‌average‌ ‌64‌ ‌lbs‌ ‌(29‌ ‌kg)‌ ‌\n ‌\nCharacteristics‌ ‌\n●Au.‌ ‌afarensis‌ ‌had‌ ‌a‌ ‌‌mixture‌ ‌of‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌features‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌skull,‌ ‌and‌ ‌advanced‌ ‌features‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌body.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌teeth‌ ‌and‌ ‌jaws‌ ‌are‌ ‌very‌ ‌similar‌ ‌to‌ ‌those‌ ‌of‌ ‌older‌ ‌fossil‌ ‌apes.‌ ‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌also‌ ‌had‌ ‌‌small‌ ‌canine‌ ‌teeth‌ ‌like‌ ‌all‌ ‌other‌ ‌early‌ ‌humans,‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌body‌ ‌that‌ ‌stood‌ ‌on‌ ‌two‌ ‌legs‌ ‌and‌ ‌regularly‌ ‌walked‌ ‌upright.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌‌pelvis‌ ‌and‌ ‌leg‌ ‌bones‌ ‌far‌ ‌more‌ ‌closely‌ ‌resemble‌ ‌those‌ ‌of‌ ‌modern‌ ‌man.‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌partial‌ ‌tibia‌ ‌(the‌ ‌larger‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌two‌ ‌lower‌ ‌leg‌ ‌bones)‌ ‌is‌ ‌strong‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌of‌ ‌bipedality,‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌lower‌ ‌humerus‌ ‌(the‌ ‌upper‌ ‌arm‌ ‌bone)‌ ‌is‌ ‌extremely‌ ‌\nhumanlike.‌ ‌\n●Members‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌species‌ ‌had‌ ‌‌apelike‌ ‌face‌ ‌proportions‌‌ ‌(a‌ ‌flat‌ ‌nose,‌ ‌a‌ ‌strongly‌ ‌projecting‌ ‌lower‌ ‌jaw)‌ ‌ ‌\n●Braincase‌ ‌(with‌ ‌a‌ ‌small‌ ‌brain,‌ ‌usually‌ ‌less‌ ‌than‌ ‌500‌ ‌cubic‌ ‌centimeters‌ ‌--‌ ‌about‌ ‌1/3‌ ‌the‌ ‌size‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌modern‌ ‌human‌ ‌brain)‌ ‌\n●Long,‌ ‌strong‌ ‌arms‌ ‌with‌ ‌curved‌ ‌fingers‌ ‌adapted‌ ‌for‌ ‌climbing‌ ‌trees.‌ ‌\n●A.‌ ‌afarensis‌ ‌also‌ ‌demonstrated‌ ‌significant‌ ‌sexual‌ ‌dimorphism;‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n135‌ ‌\n●Their‌ ‌adaptations‌ ‌for‌ ‌living‌ ‌both‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌trees‌ ‌and‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌ground‌ ‌helped‌ ‌them‌ ‌survive‌ ‌for‌ ‌almost‌ ‌a‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌as‌ ‌climate‌ ‌and‌ ‌environments‌ ‌\nchanged.‌ ‌\n●Similar‌ ‌to‌ ‌chimpanzees,‌‌ ‌Au.‌ ‌afarensis‌ ‌children‌ ‌grew‌ ‌rapidly‌ ‌after‌ ‌birth‌ ‌and‌ ‌reached‌ ‌adulthood‌ ‌earlier‌ ‌than‌ ‌modern‌ ‌humans.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌meant‌ ‌Au.‌ ‌afarensis‌ ‌had‌ ‌a‌ ‌shorter‌ ‌period‌ ‌of‌ ‌growing‌ ‌up‌ ‌than‌ ‌modern‌ ‌humans‌ ‌have‌ ‌today,‌ ‌leaving‌ ‌them‌ ‌less‌ ‌time‌ ‌for‌ ‌parental‌ ‌guidance‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌socialization‌ ‌during‌ ‌childhood.‌ ‌\n●Au.‌ ‌afarensis‌ ‌had‌ ‌mainly‌ ‌a‌ ‌‌plant-based‌ ‌diet‌,‌ ‌including‌ ‌leaves,‌ ‌fruit,‌ ‌seeds,‌ ‌roots,‌ ‌nuts,‌ ‌and‌ ‌insects…‌ ‌and‌ ‌probably‌ ‌the‌ ‌occasional‌ ‌small‌ ‌\nvertebrates,‌ ‌like‌ ‌lizards.‌ ‌\n ‌\nFossil‌ ‌Discovery:‌ ‌\n●‘Lucy’‌ ‌was‌ ‌found‌ ‌by‌ ‌‌Donald‌ ‌Johanson‌‌ ‌and‌ ‌‌Tom‌ ‌Gray‌‌ ‌on‌ ‌November‌ ‌24,‌ ‌‌1974,‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌site‌ ‌of‌ ‌Hadar‌ ‌in‌ ‌Ethiopia.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌s‌pecies‌ ‌was‌ ‌formally‌ ‌named‌ ‌in‌ ‌1978‌‌ ‌following‌ ‌a‌ ‌wave‌ ‌of‌ ‌fossil‌ ‌discoveries‌ ‌at‌ ‌Hadar,‌ ‌Ethiopia,‌ ‌and‌ ‌Laetoli,‌ ‌Tanzania.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nPhylogeny:‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌species‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌a‌ ‌direct‌ ‌descendant‌ ‌of‌ ‌Au.‌ ‌anamensis‌ ‌and‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌ancestral‌ ‌to‌ ‌later‌ ‌species‌ ‌of‌ ‌Paranthropus,‌ ‌Australopithecus,‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nHomo.‌ ‌\n136‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nAustralopithecus‌ ‌africanus‌ ‌\nOverview‌ ‌\n●Au.‌ ‌africanus‌ ‌was‌ ‌anatomically‌ ‌‌similar‌ ‌to‌ ‌Au.‌ ‌afarensis‌,‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌combination‌ ‌of‌ ‌human-like‌ ‌and‌ ‌ape-like‌ ‌features.‌ ‌\n ‌\n137‌ ‌\nAustralopithecus‌ ‌africanus‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nDiscovery‌ ‌Date:‌ ‌‌1924‌ ‌\nWhere‌ ‌Lived:‌ ‌‌Southern‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌(South‌ ‌Africa)‌ ‌\nWhen‌ ‌Lived:‌ ‌‌About‌ ‌3.3‌ ‌to‌ ‌2.1‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago‌ ‌\n ‌ ‌\n ‌ ‌\nHeight:‌ ‌Males:‌ ‌‌average‌ ‌4‌ ‌ft‌ ‌6‌ ‌in‌ ‌(138‌ ‌cm);‌ ‌Females:‌ ‌average‌ ‌3‌ ‌ft‌ ‌9‌ ‌in‌ ‌(115‌ ‌cm)‌ ‌\nWeight:‌ ‌Males:‌ ‌‌average‌ ‌90‌ ‌lbs‌ ‌(41‌ ‌kg);‌ ‌Females:‌ ‌average‌ ‌66‌ ‌lb‌ ‌(30‌ ‌kg)‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nCharacteristics‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌‌similar‌ ‌to‌ ‌afarensis‌,‌ ‌but‌ ‌‌body‌ ‌size‌ ‌was‌ ‌slightly‌ ‌greater.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Brain‌ ‌size‌ ‌may‌ ‌also‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌‌slightly‌ ‌larger,‌ ‌ranging‌ ‌between‌ ‌420‌ ‌and‌ ‌500‌ ‌cc.‌ ‌and‌ ‌smaller‌ ‌teeth‌,‌ ‌but‌ ‌it‌ ‌also‌ ‌had‌ ‌‌some‌ ‌ape-like‌ ‌features‌ ‌\nincluding‌ ‌relatively‌ ‌long‌ ‌arms‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌strongly‌ ‌sloping‌ ‌face‌‌ ‌that‌ ‌juts‌ ‌out‌ ‌from‌ ‌underneath‌ ‌the‌ ‌braincase‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌pronounced‌ ‌jaw.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Thus‌ ‌the‌ ‌general‌ ‌endocranial‌ ‌size‌ ‌of‌ ‌‌Australopithecus‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌differ‌ ‌markedly‌ ‌from‌ ‌those‌ ‌of‌ ‌gorilla‌ ‌and‌ ‌chimpanzee.‌ ‌ ‌\n●However‌‌ ‌in‌ ‌relation‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌body‌ ‌size‌ ‌Australopithecus‌ ‌shows‌ ‌larger‌ ‌brain‌ ‌capacity‌ ‌proportion‌ ‌than‌ ‌the‌ ‌apes.‌ ‌\n138‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Like‌ ‌Au.‌ ‌afarensis,‌ ‌the‌ ‌pelvis,‌ ‌femur‌ ‌(upper‌ ‌leg),‌ ‌and‌ ‌foot‌ ‌bones‌ ‌of‌ ‌Au.‌ ‌africanus‌ ‌indicate‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌‌walked‌ ‌bipedally,‌ ‌but‌ ‌its‌ ‌shoulder‌ ‌and‌ ‌hand‌ ‌\nbones‌ ‌indicate‌ ‌they‌ ‌were‌ ‌also‌ ‌adapted‌ ‌for‌ ‌climbing‌ ‌\n●Au.‌ ‌africanus‌ ‌‌ate‌ ‌tough‌ ‌foods‌ ‌but‌ ‌also‌ ‌had‌ ‌a‌ ‌very‌ ‌variable‌ ‌diet‌ ‌including‌ ‌softer‌ ‌fruits‌ ‌and‌ ‌plants.‌ ‌\n●No‌ ‌stone‌ ‌tools‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌sediments‌ ‌as‌ ‌Au.‌ ‌africanus‌ ‌fossils.‌ ‌\n ‌\nFossil‌ ‌discovery‌ ‌\n●‘‌The‌ ‌Taung‌ ‌child‌’‌‌ ‌‌first‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌by‌ ‌‌Raymond‌ ‌Dart‌ ‌‌in‌ ‌‌1924‌ ‌at‌ ‌Taung‌ ‌in‌ ‌South‌ ‌Africa.‌ ‌ ‌\n○An‌ ‌interesting‌ ‌associated‌ ‌find‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌discovery‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌skull‌ ‌from‌ ‌a‌ ‌young‌ ‌A.africanus‌ ‌child.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌skull‌ ‌is‌ ‌thought‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌from‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌approximately‌ ‌three‌ ‌years‌ ‌old‌ ‌who‌ ‌was‌ ‌killed‌ ‌by‌ ‌an‌ ‌eagle‌ ‌or‌ ‌other‌ ‌large‌ ‌predatory‌ ‌bird.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌finding‌ ‌includes‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌mandible,‌ ‌facial‌ ‌skeleton‌ ‌and‌ ‌endocranial‌ ‌parts‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌child.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Dart‌ ‌named‌ ‌the‌ ‌skull‌ ‌as‌ ‌Australopithecus‌ ‌africanus.‌ ‌\n ‌\nPhylogeny‌ ‌\n ‌\n139‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nAustralopithecus‌ ‌garhi‌ ‌\nOverview‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌species‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌well‌ ‌documented;‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌defined‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌one‌ ‌fossil‌ ‌cranium‌ ‌and‌ ‌four‌ ‌other‌ ‌skull‌ ‌fragments,‌ ‌although‌ ‌a‌ ‌partial‌ ‌\nskeleton‌ ‌found‌ ‌nearby,‌ ‌from‌ ‌about‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌layer,‌ ‌is‌ ‌usually‌ ‌included‌ ‌as‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Australopithecus‌ ‌garhi‌ ‌sample.‌ ‌\n ‌\nAustralopithecus‌ ‌garhi‌ ‌\n ‌\n140‌ ‌\n ‌\nDiscovery‌ ‌Date:‌ ‌‌1990‌ ‌\nWhere‌ ‌Lived:‌‌ ‌Eastern‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌(the‌ ‌site‌ ‌of‌ ‌Bouri,‌ ‌Middle‌ ‌Awash,‌ ‌Ethiopia)‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nWhen‌ ‌Lived:‌ ‌‌About‌ ‌2.5‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nCharacteristics‌ ‌\n●Fossils‌ ‌of‌ ‌‌Australopithecus‌ ‌garhi‌ ‌are‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌some‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌oldest‌ ‌known‌ ‌stone‌ ‌tools,‌ ‌along‌ ‌with‌ ‌animal‌ ‌bones‌ ‌that‌ ‌were‌ ‌cut‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nbroken‌ ‌open‌ ‌with‌ ‌stone‌ ‌tools.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌possible,‌ ‌then,‌ ‌that‌ ‌t‌his‌ ‌species‌ ‌was‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌to‌ ‌make‌ ‌the‌ ‌transition‌ ‌to‌ ‌stone‌ ‌toolmaking‌ ‌‌and‌ ‌to‌ ‌eating‌ ‌meat‌ ‌and‌ ‌bone‌ ‌marrow‌ ‌\nfrom‌ ‌large‌ ‌animals.‌ ‌\nFossil‌ ‌discovery‌ ‌\n●First‌ ‌in‌ ‌‌1990‌ ‌‌and‌ ‌then‌ ‌from‌ ‌1996‌ ‌to‌ ‌1998,‌ ‌a‌ ‌research‌ ‌team‌ ‌led‌ ‌by‌ ‌Ethiopian‌ ‌paleoanthropologist‌ ‌‌Berhane‌ ‌Asfaw‌ ‌‌and‌ ‌American‌ ‌\npaleoanthropologist‌ ‌‌Tim‌ ‌White‌ ‌‌found‌ ‌the‌ ‌partial‌ ‌skull‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌site‌ ‌of‌ ‌Bouri,‌ ‌Middle‌ ‌Awash‌ ‌Ethiopia‌ ‌\nPhylogeny‌ ‌\n141‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nGeneral‌ ‌Characteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌Australopithecus‌ ‌(Gracile‌ ‌form)‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Small‌ ‌and‌ ‌gracile‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌body‌ ‌weight.‌ ‌\n●Skull:‌ ‌ ‌\n○Taken‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌whole,‌ ‌the‌ ‌skull‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌combination‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌small‌ ‌brain‌ ‌case‌ ‌and‌ ‌large‌ ‌jaws.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌brain‌ ‌case‌ ‌lacks‌ ‌the‌ ‌high‌ ‌vertical‌ ‌forehead‌ ‌of‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌sapiens‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌high‌ ‌roundedness‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌skull‌ ‌vault.‌ ‌This‌ ‌gives‌ ‌a‌ ‌simian‌ ‌\nappearance.‌ ‌‌But‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌bone‌ ‌feature‌ ‌it‌ ‌contrasts‌ ‌with‌ ‌pongidae‌ ‌and‌ ‌matches‌ ‌with‌ ‌hominidae.‌ ‌\n142‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌supraorbital‌ ‌height‌ ‌index‌ ‌shows‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌relative‌ ‌high‌ ‌exceeds‌ ‌the‌ ‌range‌ ‌of‌ ‌variation‌ ‌in‌ ‌anthropoid‌ ‌ape‌ ‌and‌ ‌actually‌ ‌comes‌ ‌within‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌range‌ ‌of‌ ‌hominid‌ ‌skull.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌occipital‌ ‌torus‌ ‌occupy‌ ‌a‌ ‌low‌ ‌level‌ ‌as‌ ‌in‌ ‌hominid‌ ‌skulls.‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌adult‌ ‌apes‌ ‌this‌ ‌occipital‌ ‌torus‌ ‌forms‌ ‌a‌ ‌crest‌ ‌high‌ ‌up‌ ‌the‌ ‌occipital‌ ‌aspects‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌skull,‌ ‌thus‌ ‌extending‌ ‌considerably‌ ‌the‌ ‌nuchal‌ ‌area‌ ‌\nfor‌ ‌attachment‌ ‌of‌ ‌neck‌ ‌muscles.‌ ‌The‌ ‌nuchal‌ ‌area‌ ‌is‌ ‌restricted‌ ‌as‌ ‌in‌ ‌homo.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌‌occipital‌ ‌condyles‌ ‌are‌ ‌forward‌ ‌in‌ ‌position‌ ‌relative‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌total‌ ‌length‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌skull‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌auditory‌ ‌aperture‌.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌skulls‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌mastoid‌ ‌regions‌ ‌are‌ ‌sufficiently‌ ‌well‌ ‌preserved,‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌well‌ ‌marked‌ ‌pyramidal‌ ‌process‌ ‌typical‌ ‌of‌ ‌hominid‌ ‌form.‌ ‌\n●Jaws‌ ‌&‌ ‌Face‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌‌brow‌ ‌ridges‌ ‌are‌ ‌poorly‌ ‌developed‌ ‌‌compared‌ ‌to‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌apes.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌f‌acial‌ ‌skeleton‌ ‌is‌ ‌however,‌ ‌large‌ ‌in‌ ‌relation‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌brain‌ ‌case.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌jaws‌ ‌are‌ ‌also‌ ‌relatively‌ ‌large‌ ‌but‌ ‌have‌ ‌no‌ ‌simian‌ ‌shelf.‌ ‌\n●Dentition‌ ‌\n○Their‌‌ ‌canine‌ ‌teeth‌ ‌were‌ ‌smaller‌ ‌than‌ ‌those‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌apes,‌‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌cheek‌ ‌teeth‌ ‌were‌ ‌larger‌ ‌than‌ ‌those‌ ‌of‌ ‌modern‌ ‌humans.‌ ‌\n●Pelvis‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌all‌ ‌these‌ ‌characters‌ ‌the‌ ‌pelvic‌ ‌bone‌ ‌of‌‌ ‌Australopithecus‌ ‌contrasts‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌apes‌ ‌and‌ ‌shows‌ ‌a‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌for‌ ‌erect‌ ‌bipedalism.‌ ‌ ‌\n○However‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌pelvis‌ ‌of‌ ‌Australopithecus‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌fully‌ ‌developed‌ ‌like‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌modern‌ ‌man.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Ischial‌ ‌tuberosity(The‌ ‌ischial‌ ‌tuberosity‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌rounded‌ ‌bone‌ ‌that‌ ‌extends‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌ischium‌ ‌—‌ ‌the‌ ‌curved‌ ‌bone‌ ‌that‌ ‌makes‌ ‌up‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nbottom‌ ‌of‌ ‌your‌ ‌pelvis.)‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌as‌ ‌quite‌ ‌closely‌ ‌approximated‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌acetabulum‌ ‌as‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌in‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌sapiens.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌anterior‌ ‌superior‌ ‌spine‌ ‌extends‌ ‌further‌ ‌forward.‌ ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌Addition‌ ‌\n ‌Australopithecus‌ ‌(Gracile‌ ‌form)‌ ‌vs‌ ‌Human‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n143‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌Addition‌ ‌\n ‌\nPlace‌ ‌\n\t\nFossils‌ ‌\n\t\nParts‌ ‌of‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌\n\t\nDiscoverer‌ ‌\n\n\nTaung‌ ‌\n\t\nAustralopithecus‌ ‌africanus‌ ‌ ‌\n\t\nSouth‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌\n\t\nRaymond‌ ‌Dart,‌ ‌1924‌ ‌\n144‌ ‌\nBouri‌ ‌\n\t\nAustralopithecus‌ ‌garhi‌ ‌ ‌\n\t\nEast‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌\n\t\nBerhane‌ ‌Asfaw,Tim‌ ‌White,‌ ‌\n1990‌ ‌\n\n\nHadar‌ ‌\n\t\nAustralopithecus‌ ‌afarensis‌ ‌(Lucy)‌ ‌\n\t\nEast‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌\n\t\nC.‌ ‌Johanson,‌ ‌1974.‌ ‌\n\n\nOmo‌ ‌\n\t\nAustralopithecus‌ ‌africanus‌ ‌\n\t\nEast‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌\n\t\n ‌\n\n\nKanapoi‌ ‌ ‌\n\t\nAustralopithecus‌ ‌anamensis‌ ‌\n\t\nEast‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌\n\t\nMeave‌ ‌Leakey,‌ ‌1994‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nGeographical‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌of‌ ‌‌Australopithecus‌‌ ‌:‌ ‌\n145‌ ‌\n ‌\nImage‌ ‌Link‌ ‌\nValue‌ ‌Addition-‌Image‌ ‌Link‌ ‌\n146‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n147‌ ‌\n ‌ ‌\n1.6‌ ‌Phylogenetic‌ ‌status,‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌and‌ ‌geographical‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌following‌ ‌:‌ ‌\n(b)‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌(Paranthropus)-Part‌ ‌II‌ ‌\n ‌\nAustralopithecus‌ ‌robustus‌ ‌(Originally‌ ‌Paranthropus)‌ ‌ ‌\n●Paranthropus‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌genus‌ ‌of‌ ‌extinct‌ ‌hominin.‌ ‌However,‌ ‌the‌ ‌validity‌ ‌of‌ ‌Paranthropus‌ ‌is‌ ‌contested,‌ ‌and‌ ‌‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌sometimes‌ ‌considered‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌\nsynonymous‌ ‌with‌ ‌Australopithecus.‌ ‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌are‌ ‌also‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌‌ ‌robust‌ ‌australopithecines‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌lived‌ ‌between‌ ‌approximately‌ ‌2.6‌ ‌and‌ ‌0.6‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago‌ ‌(mya)‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌end‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Pliocene‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌Middle‌ ‌Pleistocene.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌genus‌ ‌or‌ ‌group‌ ‌Pranthropus‌ ‌currently‌ ‌include‌ ‌three‌ ‌species:‌ ‌\n1.Paranthropus‌ ‌aethiopicus‌ ‌\n2.Paranthropus‌ ‌boisei‌ ‌\n3.Paranthropus‌ ‌robustus‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌are‌ ‌collectively‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌robustus‌ ‌because‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌extremely‌ ‌large‌ ‌jaw‌ ‌and‌ ‌molar‌ ‌teeth.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌first‌ ‌fossils‌ ‌attributed‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌genus‌ ‌Paranthropus‌ ‌in‌ ‌‌Southern‌ ‌Africa‌‌ ‌were‌ ‌announced‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌1938‌ ‌Nature‌ ‌paper‌ ‌by‌ ‌Robert‌ ‌Broom,The‌ ‌first‌ ‌\nParanthropus‌ ‌Discovery‌ ‌in‌ ‌‌East‌ ‌Africa‌‌ ‌was‌ ‌made‌ ‌by‌ ‌‌Mary‌ ‌Leakey‌ ‌i‌n‌ ‌1959.‌ ‌\n148‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nHuman‌ ‌Family‌ ‌Tree‌ ‌\n149‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n150‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nParanthropus‌ ‌group‌ ‌\n151‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nParanthropus‌ ‌aethiopicus‌ ‌\nOverview‌ ‌\n●Paranthropus‌ ‌aethiopicus‌ ‌is‌ ‌still‌ ‌much‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌mystery‌ ‌to‌ ‌paleoanthropologists‌,‌ ‌as‌ ‌very‌ ‌few‌ ‌remains‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌species‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌found.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌discovery‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌2.5‌ ‌million‌ ‌year‌ ‌old‌ ‌‌’Black‌ ‌Skull‌’‌ ‌in‌ ‌1985‌ ‌helped‌ ‌‌define‌ ‌this‌ ‌species‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌earliest‌ ‌known‌ ‌robust‌ ‌australopithecine.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n152‌ ‌\nParanthropus‌ ‌aethiopicus‌ ‌\n ‌\nWhere‌ ‌Lived:‌ ‌‌Eastern‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌(Turkana‌ ‌basin‌ ‌of‌ ‌northern‌ ‌Kenya,‌ ‌southern‌ ‌\nEthiopia)‌ ‌\nWhen‌ ‌Lived:‌ ‌‌About‌ ‌2.7‌ ‌to‌ ‌2.3‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nCharacteristics:‌ ‌\n●P.‌ ‌aethiopicus‌ ‌has‌ ‌a‌‌ ‌strongly‌ ‌protruding‌ ‌face,‌ ‌large‌ ‌megadont‌ ‌teeth,‌ ‌a‌ ‌powerful‌ ‌jaw‌,‌ ‌ ‌\n●Well-developed‌ ‌sagittal‌ ‌crest‌ ‌on‌ ‌top‌ ‌of‌ ‌skull,‌ ‌indicating‌ ‌huge‌ ‌chewing‌ ‌muscles,‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌strong‌ ‌emphasis‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌muscles‌ ‌that‌ ‌connected‌ ‌\ntoward‌ ‌the‌ ‌back‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌crest‌ ‌and‌ ‌created‌ ‌strong‌ ‌chewing‌ ‌forces‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌front‌ ‌teeth.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌shape‌ ‌and‌ ‌large‌ ‌size‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌teeth‌ ‌indicate‌ ‌a‌ ‌largely‌ ‌vegetarian‌ ‌diet.‌ ‌\n ‌\nFossil‌ ‌Discovery:‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌‌1985‌,‌ ‌when‌ ‌‌Alan‌ ‌Walker‌ ‌and‌ ‌Richard‌ ‌Leakey‌‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌the‌ ‌famous‌ ‌\"Black‌ ‌Skull\"‌ ‌west‌ ‌of‌ ‌Lake‌ ‌Turkana‌ ‌in‌ ‌Kenya‌ ‌\n ‌\nPhylogeny‌ ‌\n●Many‌ ‌features‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌skull‌ ‌are‌ ‌quite‌‌ ‌similar‌ ‌to‌ ‌Australopithecus‌ ‌afarensis,‌ ‌and‌ ‌P.‌ ‌aethiopicus‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌a‌ ‌descendent‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌species.‌ ‌\n153‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌most‌ ‌likely‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌ancestor‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌robust‌ ‌australopithecine‌ ‌species‌ ‌found‌ ‌later‌ ‌in‌ ‌Eastern‌ ‌Africa,‌ ‌Paranthropus‌ ‌boisei.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nParanthropus‌ ‌boisei‌ ‌\nOverview‌ ‌\n●P.‌ ‌boisei‌ ‌is‌ ‌usually‌ ‌thought‌ ‌to‌ ‌‌descend‌ ‌from‌ ‌earlier‌ ‌P.‌ ‌aethiopicu‌s‌ ‌(who‌ ‌inhabited‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌geographic‌ ‌area‌ ‌just‌ ‌a‌ ‌few‌ ‌hundred‌ ‌thousand‌ ‌\nyears‌ ‌before)‌ ‌and‌ ‌lived‌ ‌alongside‌ ‌several‌ ‌other‌ ‌species‌ ‌of‌ ‌early‌ ‌humans‌ ‌during‌ ‌its‌ ‌1.1‌ ‌million‌ ‌year‌ ‌existence.‌ ‌ ‌\n●P.‌ ‌boisei‌ ‌belongs‌ ‌to‌ ‌just‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌many‌ ‌side‌ ‌branches‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌evolution,‌ ‌which‌ ‌most‌ ‌scientists‌ ‌agree‌ ‌includes‌ ‌all‌ ‌\nParanthropus‌ ‌species‌ ‌and‌ ‌‌did‌ ‌not‌ ‌lead‌ ‌to‌ ‌H.‌ ‌sapiens.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nParanthropus‌ ‌boisei‌ ‌\n ‌\n154‌ ‌\n ‌\nDiscovery‌ ‌Date:‌ ‌‌1959‌ ‌\nWhere‌ ‌Lived:‌ ‌‌Eastern‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌(Ethiopia,‌ ‌Kenya,‌ ‌Tanzania,‌ ‌Malawi)‌ ‌\nWhen‌ ‌Lived:‌ ‌‌About‌ ‌2.3‌ ‌to‌ ‌1.2‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nCharacteristics:‌ ‌\n●Like‌ ‌other‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Paranthropus‌ ‌genus,‌ ‌P.‌ ‌boisei‌ ‌is‌ ‌characterized‌ ‌by‌ ‌‌a‌ ‌specialized‌ ‌skull‌ ‌with‌ ‌adaptations‌ ‌for‌ ‌heavy‌ ‌chewing.‌ ‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌‌strong‌ ‌sagittal‌ ‌crest‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌midline‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌top‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌skull‌ ‌anchored‌ ‌the‌ ‌temporalis‌ ‌muscles‌ ‌(large‌ ‌chewing‌ ‌muscles)‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌top‌ ‌and‌ ‌side‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌the‌ ‌braincase‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌lower‌ ‌jaw,‌ ‌and‌ ‌thus‌ ‌moved‌ ‌the‌ ‌massive‌ ‌jaw‌ ‌up‌ ‌and‌ ‌down.‌ ‌The‌ ‌force‌ ‌was‌ ‌focused‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌large‌ ‌cheek‌ ‌teeth‌ ‌(molars‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌premolars).‌ ‌ ‌\n●Flaring‌ ‌cheekbones‌ ‌gave‌ ‌P.‌ ‌boisei‌ ‌a‌ ‌very‌ ‌wide‌ ‌and‌ ‌dish-shaped‌ ‌face‌,‌ ‌creating‌ ‌a‌ ‌larger‌ ‌opening‌ ‌for‌ ‌bigger‌ ‌jaw‌ ‌muscles‌ ‌to‌ ‌pass‌ ‌through‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nsupport‌ ‌massive‌ ‌cheek‌ ‌teeth‌ ‌four‌ ‌times‌ ‌the‌ ‌size‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌modern‌ ‌human’s.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌species‌ ‌had‌ ‌even‌ ‌‌larger‌ ‌cheek‌ ‌teeth‌ ‌than‌ ‌P.‌ ‌robustus‌,‌ ‌a‌ ‌flatter,‌ ‌bigger-brained‌ ‌skull‌ ‌than‌ ‌P.‌ ‌aethiopicus,‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌thickest‌ ‌dental‌ ‌enamel‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌any‌ ‌known‌ ‌early‌ ‌human.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Cranial‌ ‌capacity‌ ‌in‌ ‌this‌ ‌species‌ ‌suggests‌ ‌a‌ ‌slight‌ ‌rise‌ ‌in‌ ‌brain‌ ‌size‌ ‌(about‌ ‌100‌ ‌cc‌ ‌in‌ ‌1‌ ‌million‌ ‌years)‌ ‌independent‌ ‌of‌ ‌brain‌ ‌enlargement‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌\ngenus‌ ‌Homo.‌ ‌\n○Cranial‌ ‌capacity‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌volume‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌interior‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌cranium‌ ‌of‌ ‌vertebrates‌ ‌that‌ ‌possess‌ ‌a‌ ‌cranium‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌brain.‌ ‌\n○Cranial‌ ‌volume‌ ‌is‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌approximate‌ ‌the‌ ‌size‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌brain,‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌suggestive‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌intelligence‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌organism‌ ‌ ‌\n●It's‌ ‌possible‌ ‌that‌ ‌this‌ ‌species‌ ‌only‌ ‌ate‌ ‌hard‌ ‌or‌ ‌tough‌ ‌foods‌ ‌‌during‌ ‌times‌ ‌when‌ ‌its‌ ‌preferred‌ ‌resources‌ ‌were‌ ‌scarce,‌ ‌relying‌ ‌on‌ ‌them‌ ‌as‌ ‌fallback‌ ‌\nfoods.‌ ‌\n155‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌species‌ ‌lived‌ ‌in‌ ‌environments‌ ‌that‌ ‌were‌ ‌dominated‌ ‌by‌ ‌‌grasslands‌ ‌but‌ ‌also‌ ‌included‌ ‌more‌ ‌closed,‌ ‌wet‌ ‌habitats‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌rivers‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌lakes.‌ ‌\n ‌\nFossil‌ ‌Discovery:‌ ‌\n●Paleoanthropologists‌ ‌actually‌ ‌found‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌fossils‌ ‌belonging‌ ‌to‌ ‌P.‌ ‌boisei‌ ‌in‌ ‌‌1955‌,‌ ‌but‌ ‌it‌ ‌wasn’t‌ ‌until‌ ‌‌Mary‌ ‌Leakey’‌s‌ ‌‌1959‌ ‌‌discovery‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\n‘Zinj’‌ ‌skull‌ ‌that‌ ‌scientists‌ ‌knew‌ ‌what‌ ‌they‌ ‌had‌ ‌found‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌new‌ ‌species.‌ ‌ ‌\n●‘Zinj’‌ ‌became‌ ‌the‌ ‌type‌ ‌specimen‌ ‌for‌ ‌P.‌ ‌boisei‌ ‌‌and,‌ ‌soon‌ ‌after,‌ ‌arguably‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌famous‌ ‌early‌ ‌human‌ ‌fossil‌ ‌from‌ ‌Olduvai‌ ‌Gorge‌ ‌in‌ ‌northern‌ ‌\nTanzania.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nPhylogeny‌ ‌\n156‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nParanthropus‌ ‌robustus‌ ‌\nOverview‌ ‌\n●Paranthropus‌ ‌robustus‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌example‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌robust‌ ‌australopithecine‌ ‌\n ‌\nParanthropus‌ ‌robustus‌ ‌\n157‌ ‌\n ‌\nDiscovery‌ ‌Date:‌ ‌‌1938‌ ‌\nWhere‌ ‌Lived:‌ ‌‌Southern‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌(South‌ ‌Africa)‌ ‌\nWhen‌ ‌Lived:‌‌ ‌About‌ ‌1.8‌ ‌to‌ ‌1.2‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago‌ ‌\n ‌\nHeight:‌ ‌‌Males:‌ ‌average‌ ‌3‌ ‌ft‌ ‌9‌ ‌in‌ ‌(1.2‌ ‌m)‌ ‌tall;‌ ‌Females:‌ ‌average‌ ‌just‌ ‌under‌ ‌3‌ ‌ft‌ ‌3‌ ‌in‌ ‌(1‌ ‌\nm)‌ ‌\nWeight:‌‌ ‌Males:‌ ‌average‌ ‌119‌ ‌lbs‌ ‌(54‌ ‌kg);‌ ‌Females:‌ ‌average‌ ‌88‌ ‌lbs‌ ‌(40‌ ‌kg)‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nCharacteristics:‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌had‌ ‌very‌ ‌‌large‌ ‌megadont‌ ‌cheek‌ ‌teeth‌ ‌with‌ ‌thick‌ ‌enamel‌ ‌a‌nd‌ ‌focused‌ ‌their‌ ‌chewing‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌back‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌jaw.‌ ‌\n●Large‌ ‌zygomatic‌ ‌arches‌ ‌(cheek‌ ‌bones)‌ ‌allowed‌ ‌the‌ ‌passage‌ ‌of‌ ‌large‌ ‌chewing‌ ‌muscles‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌jaw‌ ‌and‌ ‌gave‌ ‌P.‌ ‌robustus‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌their‌ ‌\ncharacteristically‌ ‌‌wide,‌ ‌dish-shaped‌ ‌face‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n●A‌‌ ‌large‌ ‌sagittal‌ ‌crest‌ ‌‌provided‌ ‌a‌ ‌large‌ ‌area‌ ‌to‌ ‌anchor‌ ‌these‌ ‌chewing‌ ‌muscles‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌skull.‌ ‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌adaptations‌ ‌provided‌ ‌P.‌ ‌robustus‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌ability‌ ‌of‌ ‌grinding‌ ‌down‌ ‌tough,‌ ‌fibrous‌ ‌foods.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌now‌ ‌known‌ ‌that‌ ‌‌‘robust’‌ ‌refers‌ ‌solely‌ ‌to‌ ‌tooth‌ ‌and‌ ‌face‌ ‌size,‌ ‌not‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌body‌ ‌size‌ ‌of‌ ‌P.‌ ‌robustus.‌ ‌\n●Probably‌ ‌used‌ ‌‌bones‌ ‌as‌ ‌tools‌ ‌to‌ ‌dig‌ ‌in‌ ‌termite‌ ‌mounds.‌ ‌ ‌\n158‌ ‌\n●Biochemical‌ ‌analyses‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌diet‌ ‌of‌ ‌‌P.‌ ‌robustus‌ ‌imply‌ ‌that‌ ‌these‌ ‌hominins‌ ‌were‌ ‌omnivorous‌ ‌89-93‌ ‌and‌ ‌possibly‌ ‌even‌ ‌changed‌ ‌their‌ ‌diets‌ ‌\nseasonally‌ ‌\n ‌\nFossil‌ ‌Discovery:‌ ‌\n●When‌ ‌scientist‌ ‌‌Robert‌ ‌Broom‌‌ ‌bought‌ ‌a‌ ‌fossil‌ ‌jaw‌ ‌fragment‌ ‌and‌ ‌molar‌ ‌in‌ ‌‌1938‌‌ ‌that‌ ‌didn’t‌ ‌look‌ ‌anything‌ ‌like‌ ‌some‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Au.‌ ‌africanus‌ ‌fossils‌ ‌\nhe’d‌ ‌found‌ ‌during‌ ‌his‌ ‌career.‌ ‌\n●After‌ ‌exploring‌‌ ‌Kromdraai,‌ ‌South‌ ‌Afric‌a,‌ ‌the‌ ‌site‌ ‌where‌ ‌the‌ ‌curious‌ ‌fossils‌ ‌came‌ ‌from,‌ ‌Broom‌ ‌collected‌ ‌many‌ ‌more‌ ‌bones‌ ‌and‌ ‌teeth‌ ‌that‌ ‌\ntogether‌ ‌convinced‌ ‌him‌ ‌he‌ ‌had‌ ‌a‌ ‌new‌ ‌species‌ ‌which‌ ‌he‌ ‌named‌ ‌Paranthropus‌ ‌robustus‌ ‌(Paranthropus‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌“beside‌ ‌man”).‌ ‌\n ‌\nPhylogeny‌ ‌\n●From‌ ‌the‌ ‌1940s‌ ‌through‌ ‌1970s,‌ ‌lots‌ ‌of‌ ‌debate‌ ‌whether‌ ‌this‌ ‌species‌ ‌represented‌ ‌the‌ ‌males‌ ‌of‌ ‌Au.‌ ‌africanus.‌ ‌\n●Eventually,‌ ‌‌scientists‌ ‌recognized‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌'robust'‌ ‌forms‌ ‌were‌ ‌different‌ ‌enough‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌own‌ ‌species,‌ ‌originally‌ ‌called‌ ‌Australopithecus‌ ‌\nrobustus.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Later,‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌three‌ ‌robust‌ ‌species‌ ‌(aethiopicus,‌ ‌boisei,‌ ‌and‌ ‌robustus)‌ ‌were‌ ‌recognized‌ ‌as‌ ‌being‌ ‌different‌ ‌enough‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌\naustralopithecines‌ ‌-‌ ‌and‌ ‌similar‌ ‌enough‌ ‌to‌ ‌each‌ ‌other‌ ‌-‌ ‌‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌placed‌ ‌into‌ ‌a‌ ‌separate‌ ‌genus,‌ ‌Paranthropus.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n159‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nGeneral‌ ‌Characteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌Australopithecus‌ ‌robustus‌ ‌(Originally‌ ‌Paranthropus)‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Skull‌ ‌\n○Cranial‌ ‌features‌ ‌where‌ ‌ape‌ ‌like‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌flat‌ ‌forehead‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌prominent‌ ‌brow‌ ‌ridge‌ ‌over‌ ‌the‌ ‌eye.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌face‌ ‌was‌ ‌relatively‌ ‌broad‌ ‌with‌ ‌flaring‌ ‌cheekbones.‌ ‌\n○Spinal‌ ‌cord‌ ‌passed‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌centre‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌skull‌ ‌base,‌ ‌indicating‌ ‌these‌ ‌species‌ ‌walked‌ ‌upright.‌ ‌\n●Body‌ ‌size‌ ‌and‌ ‌shape‌ ‌\n○All‌ ‌three‌ ‌species‌ ‌share‌ ‌similar‌ ‌physical‌ ‌characteristics-‌ ‌relatively‌ ‌small‌ ‌body‌ ‌robust‌ ‌and‌ ‌strongly‌ ‌built‌ ‌Skull‌ ‌including‌ ‌large‌ ‌lower‌ ‌jaw‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌extremely‌ ‌large‌ ‌molar‌ ‌teeth.‌ ‌\n○Paranthropus‌ ‌aethiopicus‌ ‌appeared‌ ‌to‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌much‌ ‌larger‌ ‌than‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌two.‌‌ ‌Paranthropus‌ ‌robustus‌ ‌and‌ ‌Pranthropus‌ ‌Boisei‌ ‌\nprobably‌ ‌only‌ ‌‌slightly‌ ‌larger‌ ‌than‌ ‌Australopithecus‌ ‌africanus..‌ ‌\n○Males‌ ‌are‌ ‌bigger‌ ‌than‌ ‌females.‌ ‌\n●Brain‌ ‌\n○Size‌ ‌was‌ ‌relatively‌ ‌small.‌ ‌\n○Paranthropus‌ ‌aethiopicus-‌ ‌420cc‌ ‌\n○Pranthropus‌ ‌Boisei‌ ‌and‌ ‌Paranthropus‌ ‌robustus-‌ ‌520cc.‌ ‌\n●Jaws‌ ‌and‌ ‌teeth‌ ‌\n○Front‌ ‌teeth‌ ‌(Incisor‌ ‌and‌ ‌canine)‌ ‌were‌ ‌very‌ ‌small‌ ‌compared‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌extremely‌ ‌large‌ ‌molar‌ ‌teeth.‌ ‌\n○Jaws‌ ‌were‌ ‌large‌ ‌and‌ ‌robust.‌ ‌\n●Limb‌ ‌and‌ ‌pelvis‌ ‌\n○Arms‌ ‌were‌ ‌long‌ ‌compared‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌legs.‌ ‌\n○Pelvis‌ ‌was‌ ‌similar‌ ‌to‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌Australopithecus,‌ ‌as‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌built‌ ‌for‌ ‌walking‌ ‌on‌ ‌two‌ ‌legs‌ ‌but‌ ‌without‌ ‌the‌ ‌refinement‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌striding‌ ‌gait‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌humans.‌ ‌\n●There‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌fairly‌ ‌‌high‌ ‌level‌ ‌of‌ ‌sexual‌ ‌dimorphism,‌ ‌at‌ ‌least‌ ‌in‌ ‌P.‌ ‌boisei.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n160‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌Addition-Summary‌ ‌\n ‌\nPlace‌ ‌\n\t\nFossils‌ ‌\n\t\nParts‌ ‌of‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌\n\t\nDiscoverer‌ ‌\n\n\nKromdraai‌ ‌\n\t\nParanthropus‌ ‌robustus‌ ‌ ‌\n\t\nSouth‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌\n\t\nRobert‌ ‌Broom,‌ ‌1938‌ ‌\n\n\nSwartkrans‌ ‌\n\t\nParanthropus‌ ‌crassidens‌ ‌\n\t\nSouth‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌\n\t\nRobert‌ ‌Broom,‌ ‌1947‌ ‌\n\n\nOmo‌ ‌\n\t\nAustralopithecus‌ ‌boisei‌ ‌\n\t\nEast‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌\n\t\nMary‌ ‌Leakey,‌ ‌1959‌ ‌\n\n\nLake‌ ‌Turkana‌ ‌\n\t\nParanthropus‌ ‌aethiopicus‌ ‌\n\t\nEast‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌\n\t\nAlan‌ ‌Walker‌ ‌and‌ ‌Richard‌ ‌\nLeakey,1985‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nGeographical‌ ‌Distribution‌ ‌Australopithecus‌ ‌robustus‌ ‌(Originally‌ ‌Paranthropus)‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n161‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n162‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌Addition‌ ‌\nGracile‌ ‌vs‌ ‌Robustus‌ ‌\n163‌ ‌\n ‌\n164‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nEarly‌ ‌expansions‌ ‌of‌ ‌hominins‌ ‌out‌ ‌of‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nHow‌ ‌are‌ ‌Australopithecines‌ ‌different‌ ‌from‌ ‌Apes?‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌were‌ ‌similar‌ ‌to‌ ‌modern‌ ‌humans‌ ‌in‌ ‌that‌ ‌they‌ ‌were‌ ‌bipedal‌ ‌(that‌ ‌is,‌ ‌they‌ ‌walked‌ ‌on‌ ‌two‌ ‌legs),‌ ‌but,‌ ‌like‌ ‌apes,‌ ‌they‌ ‌had‌ ‌small‌ ‌brains.‌ ‌ ‌\n165‌ ‌\n●Their‌ ‌canine‌ ‌teeth‌ ‌were‌ ‌smaller‌ ‌than‌ ‌those‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌apes,‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌cheek‌ ‌teeth‌ ‌were‌ ‌larger‌ ‌than‌ ‌those‌ ‌of‌ ‌modern‌ ‌humans.‌ ‌\nLink:‌ ‌‌https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xT8Np0gI1dI&t=1s‌ ‌\nCredit:‌ ‌California‌ ‌Academy‌ ‌of‌ ‌Sciences‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n1.6‌ ‌Phylogenetic‌ ‌status,‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌and‌ ‌geographical‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌following‌ ‌:‌ ‌\n(b)‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌:‌ ‌Europe‌ ‌(Homo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌(heidelbergensis),‌ ‌Asia‌ ‌(Homoerectus‌ ‌javanicus,‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌pekinensis.-‌ ‌Part‌ ‌III‌ ‌\nIntroduction‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌genus‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌includes‌ ‌the‌ ‌extant‌ ‌(surviving)‌ ‌species‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌sapiens‌ ‌(us),‌ ‌plus‌ ‌several‌ ‌extinct‌ ‌species‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌considered‌ ‌ancestral‌ ‌or‌ ‌\nmore‌ ‌or‌ ‌less‌ ‌closely‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌us:‌ ‌ ‌\n○Homo‌ ‌habilis,‌ ‌ ‌\n○Homo‌ ‌rudolfensis,‌ ‌ ‌\n○Homo‌ ‌ergaster,‌ ‌ ‌\n166‌ ‌\n○Homo‌ ‌erectus,‌ ‌ ‌\n○Homo‌ ‌antecessor‌ ‌ ‌\n○Homo‌ ‌heidelbergensis,‌ ‌ ‌\n○Homo‌ ‌neanderthalensis,‌ ‌ ‌\n○Homo‌ ‌floresiensis.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Rewinding‌ ‌Basics‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n167‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n168‌ ‌\nBackground‌ ‌\n●Homo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌‌appeared‌ ‌about‌ ‌2‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago‌ ‌and,‌ ‌in‌ ‌several‌ ‌early‌ ‌migrations,‌ ‌spread‌ ‌throughout‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌(where‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌dubbed‌ ‌‌Homo‌ ‌\nergaster‌)‌ ‌and‌ ‌Eurasia.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌was‌ ‌likely‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌human‌ ‌species‌ ‌to‌ ‌live‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌hunter-gatherer‌ ‌society‌ ‌and‌ ‌to‌ ‌control‌ ‌fire.‌ ‌ ‌\n●An‌ ‌adaptive‌ ‌and‌ ‌successful‌ ‌species,‌ ‌‌Homo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌persisted‌ ‌for‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌a‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌and‌ ‌gradually‌ ‌diverged‌ ‌into‌ ‌new‌ ‌species‌ ‌by‌ ‌\naround‌ ‌500,000‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago.‌ ‌\n●Relation‌ ‌with‌ ‌Australopithecus‌ ‌\n○Several‌ ‌species,‌ ‌including‌ ‌‌Australopithecus‌ ‌garhi,‌ ‌Australopithecus‌ ‌sediba,‌ ‌Australopithecus‌ ‌africanus,‌ ‌and‌ ‌Australopithecus‌ ‌\nafarensis,‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌proposed‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌ancestor‌ ‌or‌ ‌sister‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌lineage.‌ ‌\n○These‌ ‌species‌ ‌have‌ ‌morphological‌ ‌features‌ ‌that‌ ‌align‌ ‌them‌ ‌with‌ ‌Homo,‌ ‌‌but‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌consensus‌ ‌as‌ ‌to‌ ‌which‌ ‌gave‌ ‌rise‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nHomo.‌ ‌\n○Especially‌ ‌since‌ ‌the‌ ‌2010s,‌ ‌the‌ ‌delineation‌ ‌of‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌in‌ ‌Australopithecus‌ ‌has‌ ‌become‌ ‌more‌ ‌contentious.‌ ‌‌Traditionally,‌ ‌the‌ ‌advent‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nHomo‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌taken‌ ‌to‌ ‌coincide‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌stone‌ ‌tools‌ ‌(the‌ ‌Oldowan‌ ‌industry),‌ ‌and‌ ‌thus‌ ‌by‌ ‌definition‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌beginning‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌Lower‌ ‌Palaeolithic.‌ ‌ ‌\n○But‌ ‌in‌ ‌2010,‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌was‌ ‌presented‌ ‌that‌ ‌seems‌ ‌to‌ ‌attribute‌ ‌the‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌stone‌ ‌tools‌ ‌to‌ ‌Australopithecus‌ ‌afarensis‌ ‌around‌ ‌3.3‌ ‌million‌ ‌\nyears‌ ‌ago,‌ ‌close‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌before‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌appearance‌ ‌of‌ ‌Homo.‌ ‌\n■ ‌‌A‌ ‌fossil‌ ‌mandible‌ ‌fragment‌ ‌dated‌ ‌to‌ ‌2.8‌ ‌Mya,‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌in‌ ‌2015‌ ‌in‌ ‌Afar,‌ ‌Ethiopia,‌ ‌was‌ ‌described‌ ‌as‌ ‌combining‌ ‌\"primitive‌ ‌\ntraits‌ ‌seen‌ ‌in‌ ‌early‌ ‌Australopithecus‌ ‌with‌ ‌derived‌ ‌morphology‌ ‌observed‌ ‌in‌ ‌later‌ ‌Homo.‌ ‌\n○Some‌ ‌authors‌ ‌would‌ ‌push‌ ‌the‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌close‌ ‌to‌ ‌or‌ ‌even‌ ‌past‌ ‌3‌ ‌Mya.‌ ‌\n○Others‌ ‌have‌ ‌voiced‌ ‌doubt‌ ‌as‌ ‌to‌ ‌whether‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌habilis‌ ‌should‌ ‌be‌ ‌included‌ ‌in‌ ‌Homo,‌ ‌proposing‌ ‌an‌ ‌origin‌ ‌of‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌with‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌\nat‌ ‌roughly‌ ‌1.9‌ ‌Mya‌ ‌instead.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌most‌ ‌salient‌ ‌physiological‌ ‌development‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌earlier‌ ‌australopithecine‌ ‌species‌ ‌and‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌increase‌ ‌in‌ ‌endocranial‌ ‌\nvolume‌ ‌(ECV),‌ ‌from‌ ‌about‌ ‌460‌ ‌cm3‌ ‌(28‌ ‌cu‌ ‌in)‌ ‌in‌ ‌A.‌ ‌garhi‌ ‌to‌ ‌660‌ ‌cm3‌ ‌(40‌ ‌cu‌ ‌in)‌ ‌in‌ ‌H.‌ ‌habilis‌ ‌and‌ ‌further‌ ‌to‌ ‌760‌ ‌cm3‌ ‌(46‌ ‌cu‌ ‌in)‌ ‌in‌ ‌H.‌ ‌\nerectus,‌ ‌1,250‌ ‌cm3‌ ‌(76‌ ‌cu‌ ‌in)‌ ‌in‌ ‌H.‌ ‌heidelbergensis‌ ‌and‌ ‌up‌ ‌to‌ ‌1,760‌ ‌cm3‌ ‌(107‌ ‌cu‌ ‌in)‌ ‌in‌ ‌H.‌ ‌neanderthalensis.‌ ‌ ‌\n○However,‌ ‌a‌ ‌steady‌ ‌rise‌ ‌in‌ ‌cranial‌ ‌capacity‌ ‌is‌ ‌observed‌ ‌already‌ ‌in‌ ‌Australopithecine‌ ‌and‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌terminate‌ ‌after‌ ‌the‌ ‌emergence‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nHomo,‌ ‌so‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌serve‌ ‌as‌ ‌an‌ ‌objective‌ ‌criterion‌ ‌to‌ ‌define‌ ‌the‌ ‌emergence‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌genus.‌ ‌\nHomo‌ ‌habilis‌ ‌\nOverview:‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌species,‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌earliest‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌genus‌ ‌Homo.‌ ‌\n●Its‌ ‌name,‌ ‌which‌ ‌means‌ ‌‘handy‌ ‌man’,‌ ‌was‌ ‌given‌ ‌in‌ ‌1964‌ ‌because‌ ‌this‌ ‌species‌ ‌was‌ ‌thought‌ ‌to‌ ‌represent‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌maker‌ ‌of‌ ‌stone‌ ‌tools.‌ ‌\nCurrently,‌ ‌the‌ ‌oldest‌ ‌stone‌ ‌tools‌ ‌are‌ ‌dated‌ ‌slightly‌ ‌older‌ ‌than‌ ‌the‌ ‌oldest‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌genus‌ ‌Homo.‌ ‌\nNote:‌ ‌Not‌ ‌mentioned‌ ‌directly‌ ‌in‌ ‌syllabus‌ ‌but‌ ‌UPSC‌ ‌PYQ‌ ‌(Homo‌ ‌Habilis‌ ‌(20‌ ‌Marks‌ ‌-‌ ‌2009))‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n169‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nHomo‌ ‌habilis‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nNickname:‌‌ ‌Handy‌ ‌Man‌ ‌\nDiscovery‌ ‌Date:‌‌ ‌1960‌ ‌\nWhere‌ ‌Lived:‌ ‌‌Eastern‌ ‌and‌ ‌Southern‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌\nWhen‌ ‌Lived:‌‌ ‌2.4‌ ‌million‌ ‌to‌ ‌1.4‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n170‌ ‌\nHeight:‌ ‌‌average‌ ‌3‌ ‌ft‌ ‌4‌ ‌in‌ ‌-‌ ‌4‌ ‌ft‌ ‌5‌ ‌in‌ ‌(100‌ ‌-‌ ‌135‌ ‌cm)‌ ‌\nWeight:‌‌ ‌average‌ ‌70‌ ‌lbs‌ ‌(32‌ ‌kg)‌ ‌\n ‌\nCharacteristics‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌‌slightly‌ ‌larger‌ ‌braincase‌ ‌and‌ ‌smaller‌ ‌face‌ ‌and‌ ‌teeth‌ ‌than‌ ‌in‌ ‌Australopithecus‌ ‌or‌ ‌older‌ ‌hominin‌ ‌species.‌ ‌ ‌\n●But‌ ‌it‌ ‌still‌ ‌retains‌ ‌some‌ ‌ape-like‌ ‌features‌,‌ ‌including‌ ‌long‌ ‌arms‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌‌moderately-prognathic‌ ‌face‌.‌ ‌\n●Early‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌had‌ ‌smaller‌ ‌teeth‌ ‌than‌ ‌Australopithecus,‌ ‌but‌ ‌their‌ ‌tooth‌ ‌enamel‌ ‌was‌ ‌still‌ ‌thick‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌jaws‌ ‌were‌ ‌still‌ ‌strong,‌ ‌indicating‌ ‌their‌ ‌\nteeth‌ ‌were‌ ‌still‌ ‌adapted‌ ‌to‌ ‌chewing‌ ‌some‌ ‌hard‌ ‌foods‌ ‌(possibly‌ ‌only‌ ‌seasonally‌ ‌when‌ ‌their‌ ‌preferred‌ ‌foods‌ ‌became‌ ‌less‌ ‌available).‌ ‌\n●Many‌ ‌scientists‌ ‌think‌ ‌early‌ ‌Homo,‌ ‌including‌ ‌H.‌ ‌habilis,‌ ‌made‌ ‌and‌ ‌used‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌stone‌ ‌tools‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌archaeological‌ ‌record—these‌ ‌also‌ ‌\ndate‌ ‌back‌ ‌to‌ ‌about‌ ‌2.6‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago;‌ ‌however,‌ ‌this‌ ‌hypothesis‌ ‌is‌ ‌difficult‌ ‌to‌ ‌test‌ ‌because‌ ‌several‌ ‌other‌ ‌species‌ ‌of‌ ‌early‌ ‌human‌ ‌lived‌ ‌at‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌same‌ ‌time,‌ ‌and‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌geographic‌ ‌area,‌ ‌as‌ ‌where‌ ‌traces‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌earliest‌ ‌tool‌ ‌use‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌found.‌ ‌\n○Placement‌ ‌contradiction‌ ‌\n■Homo‌ ‌habilis‌ ‌emerged‌ ‌about‌ ‌2.1‌ ‌Mya.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Already‌ ‌before‌ ‌2010,‌ ‌there‌ ‌were‌ ‌suggestions‌ ‌that‌ ‌H.‌ ‌habilis‌ ‌should‌ ‌not‌ ‌be‌ ‌placed‌ ‌in‌ ‌genus‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌but‌ ‌rather‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nAustralopithecus.‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌main‌ ‌reason‌ ‌to‌ ‌include‌ ‌H.‌ ‌habilis‌ ‌and‌ ‌Homo,‌ ‌its‌ ‌undisputed‌ ‌tool‌ ‌use,‌ ‌has‌ ‌become‌ ‌obsolete‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌discovery‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nAustralopithecus‌ ‌tool‌ ‌use‌ ‌at‌ ‌least‌ ‌a‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌before‌ ‌H.‌ ‌habilis.‌ ‌\n■Furthermore,‌ ‌H.‌ ‌habilis‌ ‌was‌ ‌long‌ ‌thought‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌the‌ ‌ancestor‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌more‌ ‌gracile‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌ergaster‌ ‌(Homo‌ ‌erectus).‌ ‌ ‌\n■In‌ ‌2007,‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌that‌ ‌H.‌ ‌habilis‌ ‌and‌ ‌H.‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌coexisted‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌considerable‌ ‌time,‌ ‌suggesting‌ ‌that‌ ‌H.‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌\nimmediately‌ ‌derived‌ ‌from‌ ‌H.‌ ‌habilis‌ ‌but‌ ‌instead‌ ‌from‌ ‌a‌ ‌common‌ ‌ancestor.‌ ‌\n■With‌ ‌the‌ ‌publication‌ ‌of‌ ‌Dmanisi‌ ‌skull‌ ‌5‌ ‌in‌ ‌2013,‌ ‌it‌ ‌has‌ ‌become‌ ‌less‌ ‌certain‌ ‌that‌ ‌Asian‌ ‌H.‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌descendant‌ ‌of‌ ‌African‌ ‌H.‌ ‌\nergaster‌ ‌which‌ ‌was‌ ‌in‌ ‌turn‌ ‌derived‌ ‌from‌ ‌H.‌ ‌habilis.‌ ‌Instead,‌ ‌H.‌ ‌ergaster‌ ‌and‌ ‌H.‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌appear‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌variants‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌\nspecies,‌ ‌which‌ ‌may‌ ‌have‌ ‌originated‌ ‌in‌ ‌either‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌or‌ ‌Asia‌ ‌and‌ ‌widely‌ ‌dispersed‌ ‌throughout‌ ‌Eurasia‌ ‌(including‌ ‌Europe,‌ ‌\nIndonesia,‌ ‌China)‌ ‌by‌ ‌0.5‌ ‌Mya.‌ ‌\nFossil‌ ‌Discovery:‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌team‌ ‌led‌ ‌by‌ ‌scientists‌ ‌‌Louis‌ ‌‌and‌ ‌Mary‌ ‌Leakey‌ ‌uncovered‌ ‌the‌ ‌fossilized‌ ‌remains‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌unique‌ ‌early‌ ‌human‌ ‌between‌ ‌‌1960‌ ‌‌and‌ ‌1963‌ ‌at‌ ‌\nOlduvai‌ ‌Gorge‌ ‌in‌ ‌Tanzania.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌type‌ ‌specimen,‌ ‌OH‌ ‌7,‌ ‌was‌ ‌found‌ ‌by‌ ‌‌Jonathan‌ ‌Leakey‌,‌ ‌so‌ ‌was‌ ‌nicknamed‌ ‌\"Jonny's‌ ‌child\".‌ ‌ ‌\n●Because‌ ‌this‌ ‌early‌ ‌human‌ ‌had‌ ‌a‌ ‌combination‌ ‌of‌ ‌features‌ ‌different‌ ‌from‌ ‌those‌ ‌seen‌ ‌in‌ ‌Australopithecus,‌ ‌‌Louis‌ ‌Leakey‌,‌ ‌South‌ ‌African‌ ‌\nscientist‌ ‌‌Philip‌ ‌Tobias,‌ ‌and‌ ‌British‌ ‌scientist‌ ‌John‌ ‌Napier‌ ‌declared‌ ‌these‌ ‌fossils‌ ‌a‌ ‌new‌ ‌species,‌ ‌and‌ ‌called‌ ‌them‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌habilis‌ ‌(meaning‌ ‌\n'handy‌ ‌man'),‌ ‌because‌ ‌they‌ ‌suspected‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌this‌ ‌slightly‌ ‌larger-brained‌ ‌early‌ ‌human‌ ‌that‌ ‌made‌ ‌the‌ ‌thousands‌ ‌of‌ ‌stone‌ ‌tools‌ ‌also‌ ‌found‌ ‌\nat‌ ‌Olduvai‌ ‌Gorge.‌ ‌\n ‌\n171‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nPhylogeny‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌species,‌ ‌along‌ ‌with‌ ‌‌H.‌ ‌rudolfensis‌,‌ ‌is‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌earliest‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌genus‌ ‌Homo.‌ ‌ ‌\n●While‌ ‌scientists‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌think‌ ‌that‌ ‌‌H.‌ ‌habilis‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌ancestor‌ ‌of‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌erectus,‌ ‌recent‌ ‌discoveries‌ ‌in‌ ‌2000‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌relatively‌ ‌late‌ ‌1.44‌ ‌\nmillion-year-old‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌habilis‌ ‌(KNM-ER‌ ‌42703)‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌relatively‌ ‌early‌ ‌1.55‌ ‌million-year-old‌ ‌H.‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌(KNM-ER‌ ‌42700)‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌area‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌northern‌ ‌Kenya‌ ‌(Ileret,‌ ‌Lake‌ ‌Turkana)‌ ‌challenged‌ ‌the‌ ‌conventional‌ ‌view‌ ‌that‌ ‌these‌ ‌species‌ ‌evolved‌ ‌one‌ ‌after‌ ‌the‌ ‌other.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Instead,‌ ‌this‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌-‌ ‌along‌ ‌with‌ ‌other‌ ‌fossils‌ ‌-‌ ‌demonstrate‌ ‌that‌ ‌they‌ ‌co-existed‌ ‌in‌ ‌Eastern‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌for‌ ‌almost‌ ‌half‌ ‌a‌ ‌million‌ ‌years.‌ ‌\n ‌\n172‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n173‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌addition‌ ‌\nTaxonomy‌ ‌vs‌ ‌Phylogeny‌ ‌\n●Taxonomy‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌science/study‌ ‌of‌ ‌classification.‌ ‌\n○Its‌ ‌a‌ ‌description‌ ‌of‌ ‌species‌ ‌and‌ ‌larger‌ ‌groups,‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌naming‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌species‌ ‌and‌ ‌groups.‌ ‌\n●Phylogeny‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌science/study‌ ‌of‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌between‌ ‌organisms.‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌—‌ ‌the‌ ‌lines‌ ‌of‌ ‌shared‌ ‌descent‌ ‌—‌ ‌between‌ ‌these‌ ‌groups.‌ ‌\n ‌\n174‌ ‌\n●To‌ ‌put‌ ‌it‌ ‌simply,‌ ‌Taxonomy‌ ‌is‌ ‌about‌ ‌how‌ ‌we‌ ‌want‌ ‌to‌ ‌classify‌ ‌species‌ ‌(which‌ ‌might‌ ‌include‌ ‌the‌ ‌rules‌ ‌for‌ ‌giving‌ ‌them‌ ‌formal‌ ‌scientific‌ ‌\nnames).‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Phylogeny‌ ‌is‌ ‌about‌ ‌how‌ ‌species‌ ‌are‌ ‌genealogically+evolutionarily‌ ‌related.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nHomo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌\nOverview‌ ‌\n●Homo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌(meaning‌ ‌\"upright‌ ‌man\")‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌‌extinct‌ ‌species‌ ‌of‌ ‌archaic‌ ‌human‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌Pleistocene,‌ ‌with‌ ‌its‌ ‌earliest‌ ‌occurrence‌ ‌about‌ ‌2‌ ‌\nmillion‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago.‌ ‌\n175‌ ‌\n○Its‌ ‌specimens‌ ‌are‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌recognisable‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌genus‌ ‌Homo.‌ ‌ ‌\n●H.‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌human‌ ‌ancestor‌ ‌to‌ ‌spread‌ ‌throughout‌ ‌the‌ ‌Old‌ ‌World,‌ ‌having‌ ‌a‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌in‌ ‌Eurasia‌ ‌extending‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌Iberian‌ ‌\nPeninsula‌ ‌to‌ ‌Java.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Early‌ ‌fossil‌ ‌discoveries‌ ‌from‌ ‌Java‌ ‌‌(beginning‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌1890s)‌ ‌and‌ ‌‌China‌ ‌‌(‘Peking‌ ‌Man’,‌ ‌beginning‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌1920s)‌ ‌comprise‌ ‌the‌ ‌classic‌ ‌examples‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌this‌ ‌species.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n176‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nHomo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nDiscovery‌ ‌Date:‌ ‌‌1891‌ ‌\nWhere‌ ‌Lived:‌ ‌‌Northern,‌ ‌Eastern,‌ ‌and‌ ‌Southern‌ ‌Africa;‌ ‌Western‌ ‌Asia‌ ‌\n(Dmanisi,‌ ‌Republic‌ ‌of‌ ‌Georgia);‌ ‌East‌ ‌Asia‌ ‌(China‌ ‌and‌ ‌Indonesia)‌ ‌\nWhen‌ ‌Lived:‌ ‌‌Between‌ ‌about‌ ‌1.89‌ ‌million‌ ‌and‌ ‌110,000‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nHeight:‌ ‌‌Ranges‌ ‌from‌ ‌4‌ ‌ft‌ ‌9‌ ‌in‌ ‌-‌ ‌6‌ ‌ft‌ ‌1‌ ‌in‌ ‌(145‌ ‌-‌ ‌185‌ ‌cm)‌ ‌\nWeight:‌ ‌‌Ranges‌ ‌from‌ ‌88‌ ‌-‌ ‌150‌ ‌lbs‌ ‌(40‌ ‌-‌ ‌68‌ ‌kg)‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nCharacteristics‌ ‌\n●Early‌ ‌African‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌fossils‌ ‌(sometimes‌ ‌called‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌ergaster)‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌oldest‌ ‌known‌ ‌early‌ ‌humans‌ ‌to‌ ‌have‌ ‌possessed‌ ‌modern‌ ‌\nhuman-like‌ ‌body‌ ‌proportions‌ ‌with‌ ‌relatively‌ ‌elongated‌ ‌legs‌ ‌and‌ ‌shorter‌ ‌arms‌ ‌compared‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌size‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌torso.‌ ‌ ‌\n○These‌ ‌features‌ ‌are‌ ‌considered‌ ‌adaptations‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌life‌ ‌lived‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌ground,‌ ‌indicating‌ ‌the‌ ‌loss‌ ‌of‌ ‌earlier‌ ‌tree-climbing‌ ‌adaptations,‌ ‌with‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌ability‌ ‌to‌ ‌walk‌ ‌and‌ ‌possibly‌ ‌run‌ ‌long‌ ‌distances.‌ ‌ ‌\n177‌ ‌\n●Compared‌ ‌with‌ ‌earlier‌ ‌fossil‌ ‌humans,‌ ‌note‌ ‌the‌ ‌expanded‌ ‌braincase‌ ‌relative‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌size‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌face.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌adult‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌brain‌ ‌size‌ ‌ranged‌ ‌from‌ ‌around‌ ‌750‌ ‌to‌ ‌1250‌ ‌cm3,‌ ‌averaging‌ ‌about‌ ‌930‌ ‌cm3.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌was‌ ‌only‌ ‌around‌ ‌69%‌ ‌the‌ ‌size‌ ‌of‌ ‌modern‌ ‌human‌ ‌brains‌ ‌on‌ ‌average‌ ‌but‌ ‌50%‌ ‌larger‌ ‌than‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌habilis.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Homo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌heads‌ ‌were‌ ‌strikingly‌ ‌different‌ ‌from‌ ‌ours‌ ‌in‌ ‌shape.‌ ‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌had‌ ‌relatively‌ ‌strong‌ ‌muscles‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌back‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌necks.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Their‌ ‌foreheads‌ ‌were‌ ‌shallow,‌ ‌sloping‌ ‌back‌ ‌from‌ ‌very‌ ‌prominent‌ ‌bony‌ ‌brow‌ ‌ridges.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●H.‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌men‌ ‌and‌ ‌women‌ ‌may‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌roughly‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌size‌ ‌as‌ ‌each‌ ‌other‌ ‌(exhibit‌ ‌reduced‌ ‌sexual‌ ‌dimorphism)‌ ‌like‌ ‌modern‌ ‌humans,‌ ‌\nwhich‌ ‌could‌ ‌indicate‌ ‌monogamy‌ ‌in‌ ‌line‌ ‌with‌ ‌general‌ ‌trends‌ ‌exhibited‌ ‌in‌ ‌primates.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌tall‌ ‌bodies‌ ‌and‌ ‌large‌ ‌brains‌ ‌of‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌required‌ ‌a‌ ‌lot‌ ‌of‌ ‌energy‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌regular‌ ‌basis‌ ‌to‌ ‌function.‌ ‌\n○Eating‌ ‌meat‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌protein‌ ‌that‌ ‌could‌ ‌be‌ ‌quickly‌ ‌digested‌ ‌made‌ ‌it‌ ‌possible‌ ‌to‌ ‌absorb‌ ‌nutrients‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌shorter‌ ‌digestive‌ ‌\ntract,‌ ‌making‌ ‌more‌ ‌energy‌ ‌available‌ ‌faster.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌postulated‌ ‌they‌ ‌communicated‌ ‌using‌ ‌some‌ ‌proto-language.‌ ‌\n178‌ ‌\n●H.‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌is‌ ‌credited‌ ‌with‌ ‌inventing‌ ‌the‌ ‌Acheulean‌ ‌stone‌ ‌tool‌ ‌industry,‌ ‌succeeding‌ ‌the‌ ‌Oldowan‌ ‌industry.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nFossil‌ ‌Discovery‌ ‌\n●Eugène‌ ‌Dubois‌,‌ ‌a‌ ‌Dutch‌ ‌surgeon,‌ ‌found‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌individual‌ ‌(Trinil‌ ‌2)‌ ‌in‌ ‌‌Indonesia‌ ‌in‌ ‌1891‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌1894,‌ ‌Dubois‌ ‌named‌ ‌the‌ ‌species‌ ‌Pithecanthropus‌ ‌erectus,‌ ‌or‌ ‌‘erect‌ ‌ape-man.’‌ ‌ ‌\n●At‌ ‌that‌ ‌time,‌ ‌Pithecanthropus‌ ‌(later‌ ‌changed‌ ‌to‌ ‌Homo)‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌and‌ ‌smallest-brained‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌known‌ ‌early‌ ‌human‌ ‌\nspecies;‌ ‌no‌ ‌early‌ ‌human‌ ‌fossils‌ ‌had‌ ‌even‌ ‌been‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌in‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌yet.‌ ‌\n179‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nPhylogeny‌ ‌\n●Some‌ ‌scientists‌ ‌distinguish‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌African‌ ‌(Homo‌ ‌ergaster)‌ ‌and‌ ‌Asian‌ ‌(Homo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌sensu‌ ‌stricto)‌ ‌fossils‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌taxon‌,‌ ‌while‌ ‌others‌ ‌\nlump‌ ‌them‌ ‌together‌ ‌as‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌sensu‌ ‌lato.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌either‌ ‌case,‌ ‌‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌general‌ ‌agreement‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌descended‌ ‌from‌ ‌an‌ ‌earlier‌ ‌species‌ ‌of‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌(e.g.,‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌habilis)‌ ‌and‌ ‌represents‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nwidest‌ ‌dispersals‌ ‌of‌ ‌early‌ ‌humans‌ ‌in‌ ‌our‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌history.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌likely‌ ‌that‌ ‌distinct‌ ‌populations‌ ‌of‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌sensu‌ ‌lato‌ ‌led‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌emergence‌ ‌of‌ ‌later‌ ‌hominin‌ ‌species,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌\nheidelbergensis,‌ ‌and‌ ‌ultimately‌ ‌to‌ ‌our‌ ‌own‌ ‌species,‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌sapiens.‌ ‌\n●At‌ ‌the‌ ‌beginning‌ ‌of‌ ‌its‌ ‌time‌ ‌range,‌ ‌around‌ ‌1.9‌ ‌Mya,‌ ‌H.‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌coexisted‌ ‌in‌ ‌East‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌with‌ ‌several‌ ‌other‌ ‌early‌ ‌human‌ ‌species‌ ‌including‌ ‌\nHomo‌ ‌rudolfensis,‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌habilis,‌ ‌and‌ ‌Paranthropus‌ ‌boisei.‌ ‌Sometimes‌ ‌they‌ ‌were‌ ‌even‌ ‌found‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌fossil‌ ‌sites.‌ ‌At‌ ‌the‌ ‌end‌ ‌of‌ ‌its‌ ‌time‌ ‌\nrange,‌ ‌around‌ ‌143,000‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago,‌ ‌it‌ ‌coexisted‌ ‌with‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌sapiens‌ ‌and‌ ‌possibly‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌floresiensis‌ ‌in‌ ‌Indonesia.‌ ‌\n180‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nGeographical‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌\nHomo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌Distribution‌ ‌\n●Homo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌is‌ ‌now‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌better‌ ‌known‌ ‌of‌ ‌our‌ ‌human‌ ‌relatives‌ ‌with‌ ‌over‌ ‌‌40‌ ‌specimens‌ ‌excavated‌ ‌from‌ ‌Java‌ ‌and‌ ‌many‌ ‌more‌ ‌from‌ ‌\nsites‌ ‌in‌ ‌China.‌ ‌\n●Sangiran‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌island‌ ‌of‌ ‌Java,‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌important‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌site‌ ‌in‌ ‌Indonesia.‌ ‌The‌ ‌remains‌ ‌of‌ ‌over‌ ‌80‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌found‌ ‌\nhere‌ ‌at‌ ‌a‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌localities.‌ ‌The‌ ‌region‌ ‌was‌ ‌first‌ ‌occupied‌ ‌about‌ ‌1.6‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago.‌ ‌\n ‌\n181‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌site‌ ‌of‌ ‌Zhoukoudian,‌ ‌40‌ ‌kilometres‌ ‌south‌ ‌of‌ ‌Beijing‌ ‌in‌ ‌China,‌ ‌has‌ ‌yielded‌ ‌the‌ ‌largest‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌fossils‌ ‌from‌ ‌any‌ ‌one‌ ‌\nlocality‌ ‌(about‌ ‌50‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌are‌ ‌represented‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌remains).‌ ‌About‌ ‌100,000‌ ‌stone‌ ‌tool‌ ‌artefacts‌ ‌were‌ ‌also‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌cave.‌ ‌These‌ ‌were‌ ‌mostly‌ ‌\nquartz‌ ‌and‌ ‌sandstone‌ ‌chopping‌ ‌tools‌ ‌and‌ ‌flakes.‌ ‌It‌ ‌was‌ ‌occupied‌ ‌between‌ ‌200,000‌ ‌and‌ ‌750,000‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago,‌ ‌although‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌suggests‌ ‌that‌ ‌\noccupation‌ ‌was‌ ‌sporadic‌ ‌rather‌ ‌than‌ ‌permanent.‌ ‌Hyenas‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌animals‌ ‌also‌ ‌used‌ ‌the‌ ‌cave‌ ‌site.‌ ‌\n●Initial‌ ‌excavations‌ ‌between‌ ‌1926‌ ‌and‌ ‌1937‌ ‌yielded‌ ‌five‌ ‌skullcaps,‌ ‌various‌ ‌other‌ ‌skull‌ ‌fragments,‌ ‌11‌ ‌jaws‌ ‌and‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌140‌ ‌teeth.‌ ‌Almost‌ ‌all‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌these‌ ‌fossils‌ ‌were‌ ‌lost‌ ‌in‌ ‌1941‌ ‌when‌ ‌the‌ ‌Japanese‌ ‌invaded‌ ‌China‌ ‌during‌ ‌World‌ ‌War‌ ‌II.‌ ‌Fortunately,‌ ‌accurate‌ ‌replicas‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌fossils‌ ‌had‌ ‌\nbeen‌ ‌made.‌ ‌Additional‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌fossils‌ ‌were‌ ‌excavated‌ ‌at‌ ‌Zhoukoudian‌ ‌after‌ ‌World‌ ‌War‌ ‌II‌ ‌and‌ ‌have‌ ‌also‌ ‌been‌ ‌excavated‌ ‌since‌ ‌from‌ ‌\nChinese‌ ‌sites‌ ‌including‌ ‌Hexian,‌ ‌Lantian‌ ‌and‌ ‌Nanjing.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n182‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nHomo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌Relationships‌ ‌with‌ ‌other‌ ‌species‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌growing‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌scientists‌ ‌have‌ ‌redefined‌ ‌the‌ ‌species‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌erectus‌‌ ‌‌so‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌now‌ ‌contains‌ ‌only‌ ‌east‌ ‌Asian‌ ‌fossils.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Many‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌older‌ ‌African‌ ‌fossils‌ ‌formerly‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌have‌ ‌now‌ ‌been‌ ‌placed‌ ‌into‌ ‌a‌ ‌separate‌ ‌species,‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌ergaster‌ ‌and‌ ‌this‌ ‌\nspecies‌ ‌is‌ ‌considered‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌ancestral‌ ‌to‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌erectus.‌ ‌ ‌\n183‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌redefined‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌is‌ ‌now‌ ‌generally‌ ‌believed‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌a‌ ‌side‌ ‌branch‌ ‌on‌ ‌our‌ ‌family‌ ‌tree‌ ‌whereas‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌ergaster‌ ‌is‌ ‌now‌ ‌viewed‌ ‌\nas‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌our‌ ‌direct‌ ‌ancestors.‌ ‌\n●However,‌ ‌some‌ ‌scientists‌ ‌still‌ ‌support‌ ‌the‌ ‌view‌ ‌that‌ ‌all‌ ‌these‌ ‌specimens‌ ‌are‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌and‌ ‌that‌ ‌this‌ ‌species‌ ‌includes‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌that‌ ‌\nvary‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌features‌ ‌and‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌widespread‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌over‌ ‌both‌ ‌time‌ ‌and‌ ‌geographic‌ ‌location.‌ ‌\n●There‌ ‌is‌ ‌even‌ ‌‌debate‌ ‌about‌ ‌whether‌ ‌the‌ ‌two‌ ‌Asian‌ ‌H.erectus‌ ‌populations‌ ‌represent‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌species‌.‌ ‌Prior‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌1950s‌ ‌the‌ ‌fossils‌ ‌from‌ ‌\nJava‌ ‌were‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌Pithecanthropus‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌and‌ ‌those‌ ‌from‌ ‌China‌ ‌were‌ ‌called‌ ‌Sinanthropus‌ ‌pekinensis.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌the‌ ‌1950s‌ ‌they‌ ‌were‌ ‌all‌ ‌placed‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌one‌ ‌species,‌ ‌‌Homo‌ ‌erectus,‌ ‌but‌ ‌some‌ ‌scientists‌ ‌still‌ ‌believe‌ ‌the‌ ‌specimens‌ ‌represent‌ ‌different‌ ‌\nspecies‌ ‌or‌ ‌subspecies‌ ‌and‌ ‌use‌ ‌the‌ ‌name‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌pekinensis‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌Chinese‌ ‌fossils.‌ ‌\n●Even‌ ‌if‌ ‌the‌ ‌populations‌ ‌in‌ ‌Indonesia‌ ‌and‌ ‌China‌ ‌were‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌species,‌ ‌the‌ ‌idea‌ ‌is‌ ‌now‌ ‌being‌ ‌proposed‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌populations‌ ‌were‌ ‌not‌ ‌\nconnected,‌ ‌and‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌Chinese‌ ‌population‌ ‌arrived‌ ‌later‌ ‌than‌ ‌the‌ ‌Indonesian‌ ‌and‌ ‌came‌ ‌from‌ ‌a‌ ‌different‌ ‌source.‌ ‌\n●Initially,‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌believed‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌Asian‌ ‌H.erectus‌ ‌originated‌ ‌with‌ ‌one‌ ‌group‌ ‌that‌ ‌dispersed‌ ‌from‌ ‌a‌ ‌single‌ ‌source‌ ‌in‌ ‌Africa.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nAdditional(for‌ ‌better‌ ‌understanding)‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nHomo‌ ‌sapiens‌ ‌\n ‌\n184‌ ‌\nHomo‌ ‌sapiens‌ ‌\nWhere‌ ‌Lived:‌ ‌‌Evolved‌ ‌in‌ ‌Africa,‌ ‌now‌ ‌worldwide‌ ‌\nWhen‌ ‌Lived:‌ ‌‌About‌ ‌300,000‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago‌ ‌to‌ ‌present‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nEvolutionary‌ ‌Tree‌ ‌Information:‌ ‌\n●Fossils‌ ‌and‌ ‌DNA‌ ‌confirm‌ ‌humans‌ ‌are‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌200‌ ‌species‌ ‌belonging‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌order‌ ‌of‌ ‌Primates.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Within‌ ‌that‌ ‌larger‌ ‌group,‌ ‌‌humans‌ ‌are‌ ‌nested‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌great‌ ‌ape‌ ‌family.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Although‌ ‌we‌ ‌did‌ ‌not‌ ‌evolve‌ ‌from‌ ‌any‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌apes‌ ‌living‌ ‌today,‌ ‌we‌ ‌share‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌with‌ ‌chimpanzees,‌ ‌gorillas,‌ ‌and‌ ‌orangutans‌ ‌(the‌ ‌\ngreat‌ ‌apes),‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌other‌ ‌apes.‌ ‌ ‌\n●We‌ ‌most‌ ‌likely‌ ‌evolved‌ ‌from‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌heidelbergensis,‌ ‌the‌ ‌common‌ ‌ancestor‌ ‌we‌ ‌share‌ ‌with‌ ‌Neanderthals,‌ ‌who‌ ‌are‌ ‌our‌ ‌closest‌ ‌\nextinct‌ ‌relatives.‌ ‌\nHomoerectus‌ ‌vs‌ ‌Homosapien‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Homo‌ ‌neanderthalensis,‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌rhodesiensis,‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌heidelbergensis‌ ‌‌and‌‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌antecessor‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌archaic‌ ‌humans.‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌archaic‌ ‌human‌ ‌group‌ ‌is‌ ‌completely‌ ‌contrasted‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌modern‌ ‌humans‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌anatomic‌ ‌traits.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌‌Homo‌ ‌sapiens‌ ‌sapiens‌ ‌and‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌sapiens‌ ‌idaltu‌ ‌are‌ ‌categorized‌ ‌under‌ ‌modern‌ ‌humans.‌ ‌\n●Recent‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌studies‌ ‌have‌ ‌suggested‌ ‌the‌ ‌modern‌ ‌humans‌ ‌were‌ ‌evolved‌ ‌from‌ ‌at‌ ‌least‌ ‌two‌ ‌ancient‌ ‌human‌ ‌species‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌\nNeanderthals‌‌ ‌and‌‌ ‌Denisovans.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Theoretically,‌ ‌the‌ ‌modern‌ ‌humans‌ ‌have‌ ‌evolved‌ ‌from‌ ‌archaic‌ ‌humans‌ ‌who‌ ‌in‌ ‌turn‌ ‌evolved‌ ‌from‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌erectus.‌ ‌‌This‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌difference‌ ‌\nbetween‌ ‌Homoerectus‌ ‌and‌ ‌Homosapien.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n185‌ ‌\n ‌\n186‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nHomo‌ ‌rudolfensis‌ ‌\nOverview‌ ‌\n●Originally‌ ‌considered‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌H.‌ ‌habili‌s,‌ ‌the‌ ‌ways‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌H.‌ ‌rudolfensis‌ ‌differs‌ ‌is‌ ‌in‌ ‌its‌ ‌larger‌ ‌braincase,‌ ‌longer‌ ‌face,‌ ‌and‌ ‌larger‌ ‌molar‌ ‌and‌ ‌\npremolar‌ ‌teeth.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Due‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌last‌ ‌two‌ ‌features,‌ ‌though,‌ ‌some‌ ‌scientists‌ ‌still‌ ‌wonder‌ ‌whether‌ ‌this‌ ‌species‌ ‌might‌ ‌better‌ ‌be‌ ‌considered‌ ‌an‌ ‌Australopithecus,‌ ‌\nalthough‌ ‌one‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌large‌ ‌brain!‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌was‌ ‌originally‌ ‌named‌ ‌as‌ ‌Pithecanthropus‌ ‌rudolfensis,‌ ‌but‌ ‌the‌ ‌genus‌ ‌name‌ ‌Pithecanthropus‌ ‌was‌ ‌later‌ ‌replaced‌ ‌by‌ ‌Homo.‌ ‌\n ‌\n187‌ ‌\nHomo‌ ‌rudolfensis‌ ‌\n ‌\nDiscovery‌ ‌Date:‌ ‌‌1986‌ ‌\nWhere‌ ‌Lived:‌ ‌‌Eastern‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌(northern‌ ‌Kenya,‌ ‌possibly‌ ‌northern‌ ‌\nTanzania‌ ‌and‌ ‌Malawi)‌ ‌\nWhen‌ ‌Lived:‌‌ ‌About‌ ‌1.9‌ ‌million‌ ‌to‌ ‌1.8‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nCharacteristics‌ ‌\n●Homo‌ ‌rudolfensis‌ ‌had‌ ‌large‌ ‌and‌ ‌wider‌ ‌molars‌ ‌compared‌ ‌to‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌habilis.‌ ‌ ‌\n●While‌ ‌their‌ ‌teeth‌ ‌were‌ ‌only‌ ‌slightly‌ ‌smaller‌ ‌than‌ ‌those‌ ‌seen‌ ‌in‌ ‌robust‌ ‌australopithecines,‌ ‌H.‌ ‌rudolfensis‌ ‌didn’t‌ ‌have‌ ‌the‌ ‌heavily-built‌ ‌jaw‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nstrong‌ ‌jaw‌ ‌muscle‌ ‌attachments‌ ‌seen‌ ‌in‌ ‌robust‌ ‌early‌ ‌humans.‌ ‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌anatomical‌ ‌differences‌ ‌likely‌ ‌indicate‌ ‌different‌ ‌diets‌ ‌between‌ ‌H.‌ ‌rudolfensis‌ ‌and‌ ‌earlier‌ ‌australopith‌ ‌species‌ ‌capable‌ ‌of‌ ‌more‌ ‌powerful‌ ‌\nchewing.‌ ‌\n●Like‌ ‌other‌ ‌early‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌species,‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌rudolfensis‌ ‌may‌ ‌have‌ ‌used‌ ‌stone‌ ‌tools‌ ‌to‌ ‌process‌ ‌their‌ ‌food.‌ ‌ ‌\n●However,‌ ‌because‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌one‌ ‌species‌ ‌of‌ ‌early‌ ‌humans‌ ‌lived‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌time‌ ‌tool‌ ‌manufacture‌ ‌and‌ ‌use‌ ‌originated,‌ ‌it’s‌ ‌hard‌ ‌for‌ ‌scientists‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌\ncertain‌ ‌which‌ ‌species‌ ‌is‌ ‌responsible‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌making‌ ‌and‌ ‌using‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌stone‌ ‌tools.‌ ‌ ‌\n●There‌ ‌are‌ ‌currently‌ ‌no‌ ‌stone‌ ‌tools‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌layers‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌H.‌ ‌rudolfensis‌ ‌fossils,‌ ‌but‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌stone‌ ‌tools‌ ‌existing‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌time‌ ‌\nperiod‌ ‌that‌ ‌H.‌ ‌rudolfensis‌ ‌lived.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n188‌ ‌\nFossil‌ ‌Discovery:‌ ‌\n●Richard‌ ‌Leakey’s‌ ‌‌team‌ ‌uncovered‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌rudolfensis‌ ‌fossils‌ ‌near‌ ‌the‌ ‌shores‌ ‌of‌ ‌‌Lake‌ ‌Rudolf‌‌ ‌(now‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌Lake‌ ‌Turkana)‌ ‌in‌ ‌‌1972‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n189‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nEurope‌ ‌(Homo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌(heidelbergensis)‌ ‌\nOverview‌ ‌\n●Homo‌ ‌heidelbergensis‌ ‌(also‌ ‌‌H.‌ ‌sapiens‌ ‌heidelbergensis)‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌extinct‌ ‌species‌ ‌or‌ ‌subspecies‌ ‌of‌ ‌archaic‌ ‌humans‌ ‌which‌ ‌‌existed‌ ‌during‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nMiddle‌ ‌Pleistocene.‌ ‌ ‌\n190‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌was‌ ‌subsumed‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌subspecies‌ ‌of‌ ‌H.‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌in‌ ‌1950‌ ‌as‌ ‌H.‌ ‌e.‌ ‌heidelbergensis‌,‌ ‌but‌ ‌towards‌ ‌the‌ ‌end‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌century,‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌more‌ ‌widely‌ ‌\nclassified‌ ‌as‌ ‌its‌ ‌own‌ ‌species.‌ ‌ ‌\n●H.‌ ‌heidelbergensis‌ ‌is‌ ‌regarded‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌chronospecies,‌ ‌evolving‌ ‌from‌ ‌an‌ ‌African‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌H.‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌‌(sometimes‌ ‌called‌ ‌H.‌ ‌ergaster).‌ ‌ ‌\n●By‌ ‌convention,‌ ‌‌H.‌ ‌heidelbergensis‌ ‌is‌ ‌placed‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌recent‌ ‌common‌ ‌ancestor‌ ‌between‌ ‌modern‌ ‌humans‌ ‌(H.‌ ‌sapiens‌ ‌or‌ ‌H.‌ ‌s.‌ ‌sapiens)‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌Neanderthals‌ ‌(H.‌ ‌neanderthalensis‌ ‌or‌ ‌H.‌ ‌s.‌ ‌neanderthalensis).‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌debated‌ ‌‌whether‌ ‌or‌ ‌not‌ ‌to‌ ‌constrain‌ ‌H.‌ ‌heidelbergensis‌ ‌to‌ ‌only‌ ‌Europe‌ ‌or‌ ‌to‌ ‌also‌ ‌include‌ ‌African‌ ‌and‌ ‌Asian‌ ‌specimens‌,‌ ‌and‌ ‌this‌ ‌\nis‌ ‌further‌ ‌confounded‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌type‌ ‌specimen‌ ‌(Mauer‌ ‌1)‌ ‌being‌ ‌a‌ ‌jawbone,‌ ‌because‌ ‌jawbones‌ ‌feature‌ ‌few‌ ‌diagnostic‌ ‌traits‌ ‌and‌ ‌are‌ ‌\ngenerally‌ ‌missing‌ ‌among‌ ‌Middle‌ ‌Pleistocene‌ ‌specimens.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Thus,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌debated‌ ‌if‌ ‌some‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌specimens‌ ‌could‌ ‌be‌ ‌split‌ ‌off‌ ‌into‌ ‌their‌ ‌own‌ ‌species‌ ‌or‌ ‌a‌ ‌subspecies‌ ‌of‌ ‌H.‌ ‌erectus.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Because‌ ‌the‌ ‌classification‌ ‌is‌ ‌so‌ ‌disputed,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Middle‌ ‌Pleistocene‌ ‌is‌ ‌often‌ ‌called‌ ‌the‌ ‌\"muddle‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌middle.\"‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n191‌ ‌\nHomo‌ ‌heidelbergensis‌ ‌\n ‌\nDiscovery‌ ‌Date:‌ ‌‌1908‌ ‌\nWhere‌ ‌Lived:‌ ‌‌Europe;‌ ‌possibly‌ ‌Asia‌ ‌(China);‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌(eastern‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nsouthern)‌ ‌\nWhen‌ ‌Lived:‌ ‌‌About‌ ‌700,000‌ ‌to‌ ‌200,000‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nHeight:‌ ‌‌Males:‌ ‌average‌ ‌5‌ ‌ft‌ ‌9‌ ‌in‌ ‌(175‌ ‌cm);‌ ‌Females:‌ ‌average‌ ‌5‌ ‌ft‌ ‌2‌ ‌in‌ ‌(157‌ ‌\ncm)‌ ‌\nWeight:‌ ‌‌Males:‌ ‌average‌ ‌136‌ ‌lbs‌ ‌(62‌ ‌kg);‌ ‌Females:‌ ‌average‌ ‌112‌ ‌lbs‌ ‌(51‌ ‌\nkg)‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nCharacteristics‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌early‌ ‌human‌ ‌species‌ ‌had‌ ‌a‌ ‌‌very‌ ‌large‌ ‌brow‌ ‌ridge,‌‌ ‌and‌ ‌‌a‌ ‌larger‌ ‌braincase‌ ‌and‌ ‌flatter‌ ‌face‌ ‌than‌ ‌older‌ ‌early‌ ‌human‌ ‌species.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌‌bodies‌ ‌of‌ ‌heidelbergensis‌ ‌in‌ ‌Europe‌ ‌tended‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌compact,‌ ‌as‌ ‌would‌ ‌be‌ ‌expected‌ ‌for‌ ‌people‌ ‌living‌ ‌in‌ ‌cold‌ ‌climates.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌early‌ ‌human‌ ‌species‌ ‌to‌ ‌live‌ ‌in‌ ‌colder‌ ‌climates,‌ ‌wide‌ ‌bodies‌ ‌were‌ ‌likely‌ ‌an‌ ‌adaptation‌ ‌to‌ ‌conserving‌ ‌heat.‌ ‌\n192‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌lived‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌time‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌oldest‌ ‌definite‌ ‌control‌ ‌of‌ ‌fire‌ ‌and‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌wooden‌ ‌spears,‌ ‌and‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌early‌ ‌human‌ ‌species‌ ‌to‌ ‌routinely‌ ‌hunt‌ ‌\nlarge‌ ‌animals.‌ ‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌are‌ ‌capable‌ ‌of‌ ‌controlling‌ ‌fire‌ ‌by‌ ‌building‌ ‌hearths,‌ ‌or‌ ‌early‌ ‌fireplaces,‌ ‌by‌ ‌790,000‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌fire-altered‌ ‌tools‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nburnt‌ ‌wood‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌site‌ ‌of‌ ‌‌Gesher‌ ‌Benot‌ ‌Ya-aqov‌ ‌in‌ ‌Israel.‌ ‌Social‌ ‌groups‌ ‌probably‌ ‌often‌ ‌gather‌ ‌around‌ ‌their‌ ‌hearths‌ ‌sharing‌ ‌food,‌ ‌\nstay‌ ‌warm,‌ ‌and‌ ‌ward‌ ‌off‌ ‌predators.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌early‌ ‌human‌ ‌also‌ ‌broke‌ ‌new‌ ‌ground;‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌species‌ ‌to‌ ‌build‌ ‌shelters,‌ ‌creating‌ ‌simple‌ ‌dwellings‌ ‌out‌ ‌of‌ ‌wood‌ ‌and‌ ‌rock.‌ ‌\n○Evidence‌ ‌for‌ ‌this‌ ‌comes‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌site‌ ‌of‌‌ ‌Terra‌ ‌Amata,‌ ‌France‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌postulated‌ ‌that‌ ‌this‌ ‌population‌ ‌was‌ ‌speaking‌ ‌with‌ ‌some‌ ‌early‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌language.‌ ‌\n ‌\nFossil‌ ‌Discovery‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌‌1908‌ ‌near‌ ‌Heidelberg,‌ ‌Germany‌,‌ ‌a‌ ‌workman‌ ‌found‌ ‌the‌ ‌type‌ ‌specimen‌ ‌of‌ ‌H.‌ ‌heidelbergensis‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Rösch‌ ‌sandpit‌ ‌just‌ ‌north‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌village‌ ‌\nof‌‌ ‌Mauer‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Before‌ ‌the‌ ‌naming‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌species,‌ ‌scientists‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to‌ ‌early‌ ‌human‌ ‌fossils‌ ‌showing‌ ‌traits‌ ‌similar‌ ‌to‌ ‌both‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌and‌ ‌modern‌ ‌humans‌ ‌\nas‌ ‌‘archaic’‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌sapiens.‌ ‌\n ‌\nPhylogeny‌ ‌\n193‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nGeographical‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌\n194‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nImportant‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌specimens‌ ‌\n ‌\n1.Sangiran‌ ‌17‌ ‌‌–‌ ‌a‌ ‌1.2‌ ‌million-year-old‌ ‌skull‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌in‌ ‌1969‌ ‌in‌ ‌Sangiran,‌ ‌Indonesia.‌ ‌This‌ ‌adult‌ ‌male‌ ‌skull‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌best‌ ‌preserved‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌\nerectus‌ ‌skull‌ ‌from‌ ‌Java.‌ ‌\n195‌ ‌\n ‌\n2.Zhoukoudian‌ ‌3‌‌ ‌–‌ ‌a‌ ‌skullcap‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌in‌ ‌1929‌ ‌in‌ ‌Zhoukoudian,‌ ‌China.‌ ‌This‌ ‌adolescent’s‌ ‌skullcap‌ ‌was‌ ‌originally‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌fragments.‌ ‌\nWhen‌ ‌the‌ ‌pieces‌ ‌were‌ ‌fitted‌ ‌together,‌ ‌they‌ ‌showed‌ ‌that‌ ‌this‌ ‌young‌ ‌individual‌ ‌had‌ ‌a‌ ‌brain‌ ‌size‌ ‌of‌ ‌915‌ ‌cubic‌ ‌centimetres.‌ ‌\n ‌\n3.‘Java‌ ‌Man’‌ ‌‌or‌ ‌Trinil‌ ‌2‌ ‌–‌ ‌a‌ ‌skullcap‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌in‌ ‌1891‌ ‌by‌ ‌Eugene‌ ‌Dubois‌ ‌in‌ ‌Trinil,‌ ‌Indonesia.‌ ‌This‌ ‌fossil‌ ‌was‌ ‌nicknamed‌ ‌‘Java‌ ‌Man’‌ ‌\nbecause‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌found‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌island‌ ‌of‌ ‌Java.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌‘type‌ ‌specimen’‌ ‌or‌ ‌official‌ ‌representative‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌species.‌ ‌\n ‌\n4.Sangiran‌ ‌2‌ ‌‌–‌ ‌a‌ ‌1‌ ‌million-year-old‌ ‌skullcap‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌in‌ ‌1937‌ ‌in‌ ‌Sangiran,‌ ‌Indonesia.‌ ‌\n ‌\n5.‘Solo‌ ‌Man’‌ ‌or‌ ‌Ngandong‌‌ ‌–‌ ‌a‌ ‌skull‌ ‌cap‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌in‌ ‌1932‌ ‌in‌ ‌Ngandong,‌ ‌Indonesia.‌ ‌Because‌ ‌its‌ ‌exact‌ ‌original‌ ‌location‌ ‌is‌ ‌unknown,‌ ‌\npublished‌ ‌dates‌ ‌have‌ ‌ranged‌ ‌from‌ ‌35,000‌ ‌to‌ ‌500,000‌ ‌years‌ ‌old.‌ ‌‘Solo‌ ‌Man’‌ ‌shares‌ ‌similarities‌ ‌with‌ ‌earlier‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌specimens‌ ‌from‌ ‌\nSangiran‌ ‌and‌ ‌is‌ ‌considered‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌a‌ ‌late‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌erectus.‌ ‌\n ‌\n6.‘Mojokerto’‌ ‌or‌ ‌Perning‌ ‌1‌‌ ‌–‌ ‌a‌ ‌juvenile‌ ‌skull‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌in‌ ‌1936‌ ‌in‌ ‌Mojokerto,‌ ‌Indonesia.‌ ‌Radiometric‌ ‌dates‌ ‌have‌ ‌suggested‌ ‌this‌ ‌child’s‌ ‌\nskull‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌as‌ ‌old‌ ‌as‌ ‌1.8‌ ‌million‌ ‌years,‌ ‌which‌ ‌significantly‌ ‌increases‌ ‌the‌ ‌previous‌ ‌dates‌ ‌for‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌in‌ ‌Asia.‌ ‌However,‌ ‌this‌ ‌date‌ ‌is‌ ‌\ndebated‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌sediment‌ ‌sample‌ ‌taken‌ ‌for‌ ‌dating‌ ‌was‌ ‌taken‌ ‌about‌ ‌60‌ ‌years‌ ‌after‌ ‌the‌ ‌skull‌ ‌was‌ ‌collected‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌two‌ ‌may‌ ‌have‌ ‌come‌ ‌from‌ ‌\ndifferent‌ ‌levels.‌ ‌\n ‌\n7.Zhoukoudian‌ ‌5‌ ‌‌–‌ ‌a‌ ‌partial‌ ‌skull‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌in‌ ‌Zhoukoudian,‌ ‌China.‌ ‌This‌ ‌skull‌ ‌was‌ ‌reconstructed‌ ‌from‌ ‌several‌ ‌pieces‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌1934,‌ ‌1936‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌1966.‌ ‌\n ‌\n8.‘Peking‌ ‌Man’‌‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌in‌ ‌Zhoukoudian,‌ ‌China.‌ ‌The‌ ‌original‌ ‌‘Peking‌ ‌Man’‌ ‌skull‌ ‌was‌ ‌reconstructed‌ ‌using‌ ‌a‌ ‌mixture‌ ‌of‌ ‌male‌ ‌and‌ ‌female‌ ‌\nfossils‌ ‌whereas‌ ‌the‌ ‌modern‌ ‌reconstruction‌ ‌by‌ ‌I.‌ ‌Tattersal‌ ‌and‌ ‌G.‌ ‌Sawyer‌ ‌combines‌ ‌fossil‌ ‌pieces‌ ‌from‌ ‌males‌ ‌only.‌ ‌\n ‌\n9.Sangiran‌ ‌4‌ ‌‌–‌ ‌a‌ ‌1.5‌ ‌million-year-old‌ ‌upper‌ ‌jaw‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌in‌ ‌1939‌ ‌in‌ ‌Sangiran,‌ ‌Indonesia.‌ ‌The‌ ‌canine‌ ‌teeth‌ ‌were‌ ‌larger‌ ‌than‌ ‌those‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nmodern‌ ‌humans.‌ ‌This‌ ‌is‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌oldest‌ ‌specimens‌ ‌from‌ ‌Sangiran.‌ ‌\n ‌\n10.Sangiran‌ ‌1‌ ‌‌–‌ ‌a‌ ‌1.5‌ ‌million-year-old‌ ‌partial‌ ‌lower‌ ‌jaw‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌in‌ ‌1936‌ ‌in‌ ‌Sangiran,‌ ‌Indonesia.‌ ‌This‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌human‌ ‌fossil‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌at‌ ‌\nSangiran.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nAsia‌ ‌(Homoerectus‌ ‌javanicus)‌ ‌\nOverview‌ ‌\n196‌ ‌\n●Java‌ ‌Man‌ ‌(Homo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌erectus,‌ ‌formerly‌ ‌also‌ ‌Anthropopithecus‌ ‌erectus,‌ ‌Pithecanthropus‌ ‌erectus)‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌early‌ ‌human‌ ‌fossil.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nHomoerectus‌ ‌javanicus‌ ‌\n ‌\n197‌ ‌\n ‌\nDiscovery‌ ‌Date:‌ ‌‌1891‌ ‌\nWhere‌ ‌Lived:‌ ‌‌The‌ ‌island‌ ‌of‌ ‌Java‌ ‌(Dutch‌ ‌East‌ ‌Indies,‌ ‌now‌ ‌\npart‌ ‌of‌ ‌Indonesia)‌ ‌\nWhen‌ ‌Lived:‌ ‌‌700,000‌ ‌and‌ ‌1,000,000‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nCharacteristics‌ ‌\n●Java‌ ‌Man‌ ‌was‌ ‌about‌ ‌‌5‌ ‌feet‌ ‌8‌ ‌inches‌ ‌(173‌ ‌cm)‌ ‌tall‌ ‌and‌ ‌his‌ ‌thighbones‌ ‌show‌ ‌that‌ ‌he‌ ‌walked‌ ‌erect‌ ‌like‌ ‌modern‌ ‌humans.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌femur‌ ‌is‌ ‌thicker‌ ‌than‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌modern‌ ‌human,‌ ‌indicating‌ ‌he‌ ‌was‌ ‌engaging‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌lot‌ ‌of‌ ‌running.‌ ‌\n●Brain‌ ‌size‌-‌ ‌800‌ ‌cm3‌ ‌to‌ ‌1200‌ ‌cm3‌ ‌(150%‌ ‌of‌ ‌Habilis,70%‌ ‌of‌ ‌humans).‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌skull‌ ‌was‌ ‌characterized‌ ‌by‌ ‌thick‌ ‌bones‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌retreating‌ ‌forehead.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌large‌ ‌teeth‌ ‌made‌ ‌the‌ ‌jaw‌ ‌large‌ ‌and‌ ‌jutting,‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌lower‌ ‌lips‌ ‌overhanging‌ ‌the‌ ‌lower‌ ‌margin‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌mandible,‌ ‌giving‌ ‌the‌ ‌impression‌ ‌of‌ ‌no‌ ‌\nchin.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌brow‌ ‌ridges‌ ‌were‌ ‌straight‌ ‌and‌ ‌massive.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Judging‌ ‌from‌ ‌anatomical‌ ‌and‌ ‌archeological‌ ‌aspects‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌Java‌ ‌Man's‌ ‌ecological‌ ‌role,‌ ‌‌meat‌ ‌from‌ ‌vertebrates‌ ‌was‌ ‌likely‌ ‌an‌ ‌important‌ ‌part‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌their‌ ‌diet.‌ ‌Java‌ ‌Man,‌ ‌like‌ ‌other‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌erectus,‌ ‌was‌ ‌probably‌ ‌a‌ ‌rare‌ ‌species.‌ ‌\n●There‌ ‌is‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌that‌ ‌J‌ava‌ ‌Man‌ ‌used‌ ‌shell‌ ‌tools‌ ‌to‌ ‌cut‌ ‌meat.‌ ‌\n ‌\nFossil‌ ‌discovery‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌1891,‌ ‌Led‌ ‌by‌ ‌‌Eugène‌ ‌Dubois‌,‌ ‌the‌ ‌excavation‌ ‌team‌ ‌uncovered‌ ‌a‌ ‌tooth,‌ ‌a‌ ‌skullcap,‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌thigh‌ ‌bone‌ ‌at‌ ‌Trinil‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌banks‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Solo‌ ‌\nRiver‌ ‌in‌ ‌East‌ ‌Java.‌ ‌\n ‌\n198‌ ‌\nPhylogeny‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Java‌ ‌specimens‌ ‌along‌ ‌with‌ ‌those‌ ‌from‌ ‌China‌ ‌were‌ ‌renamed‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌1950s‌ ‌by‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌biologist‌ ‌Ernst‌ ‌Mayr.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Thus,‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌became‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌officially‌ ‌named‌ ‌prehistoric‌ ‌species‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌genus‌ ‌Homo.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nGeographical‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌\n199‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nAsia‌ ‌(Homo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌pekinensis)‌ ‌\n ‌\nOverview‌ ‌\n●Peking‌ ‌Man‌ ‌(sometimes‌ ‌called‌ ‌Beijing‌ ‌Man),‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌prominent‌ ‌example‌ ‌of‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌erectus,‌ ‌an‌ ‌extinct‌ ‌species‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌genus‌ ‌to‌ ‌which‌ ‌modern‌ ‌\nhumans‌ ‌also‌ ‌belong.‌ ‌ ‌\n200‌ ‌\n●Before‌ ‌being‌ ‌assigned‌ ‌to‌ ‌H.‌ ‌erectus,‌ ‌they‌ ‌were‌ ‌variously‌ ‌classified‌ ‌as‌ ‌‌Pithecanthropus‌ ‌and‌ ‌Sinanthropus‌ ‌pekinensis‌ ‌and‌ ‌is‌ ‌currently‌ ‌best‌ ‌\nknown‌ ‌as‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌pekinensis.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌Peking‌ ‌Man‌ ‌Site‌ ‌at‌ ‌‌Zhoukoudian‌‌ ‌was‌ ‌listed‌ ‌by‌ ‌‌UNESCO‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌World‌ ‌Heritage‌ ‌Site‌ ‌in‌ ‌1987.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nHomo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌pekinensis.‌ ‌\n ‌\n201‌ ‌\n ‌\nDiscovery‌ ‌Date:‌ ‌‌1921-27‌ ‌\nWhere‌ ‌Lived:‌ ‌‌Zhoukoudian‌ ‌(Choukoutien)‌ ‌near‌ ‌Beijing‌ ‌\n(former‌ ‌Peking),‌ ‌China‌ ‌\nWhen‌ ‌Lived:‌ ‌‌750,000‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago‌  ‌ ‌\n ‌\nCharacteristics‌ ‌\n●Peking‌ ‌man‌ ‌is‌ ‌characterized‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌cranial‌ ‌capacity‌ ‌averaging‌ ‌about‌ ‌1,000‌ ‌cubic‌ ‌cm‌,‌ ‌though‌ ‌some‌ ‌individual‌ ‌skull‌ ‌capacities‌ ‌approached‌ ‌\n1,300‌ ‌cubic‌ ‌cm—nearly‌ ‌the‌ ‌size‌ ‌of‌ ‌modern‌ ‌man’s.‌ ‌\n●Peking‌ ‌man‌ ‌had‌ ‌a‌ ‌skull‌ ‌that‌ ‌was‌ ‌‌flat‌ ‌in‌ ‌profile,‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌small‌ ‌forehead,‌ ‌a‌ ‌keel‌ ‌along‌ ‌the‌ ‌top‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌head‌ ‌for‌ ‌attachment‌ ‌of‌ ‌powerful‌ ‌jaw‌ ‌\nmuscles,‌‌ ‌very‌ ‌thick‌ ‌skull‌ ‌bones,‌ ‌heavy‌ ‌brow‌ ‌ridges,‌ ‌an‌ ‌occipital‌ ‌torus,‌ ‌a‌ ‌large‌ ‌palate,‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌large,‌ ‌chinless‌ ‌jaw.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌teeth‌ ‌are‌ ‌essentially‌ ‌modern,‌‌ ‌though‌ ‌the‌ ‌canines‌ ‌and‌ ‌molars‌ ‌are‌ ‌quite‌ ‌large‌,‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌enamel‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌molars‌ ‌is‌ ‌often‌ ‌wrinkled.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌limb‌ ‌bones‌ ‌are‌ ‌indistinguishable‌ ‌from‌ ‌those‌ ‌of‌ ‌modern‌ ‌humans.‌ ‌\n●Peking‌ ‌man‌ ‌postdates‌ ‌Java‌ ‌man‌ ‌and‌ ‌is‌ ‌considered‌ ‌more‌ ‌advanced‌ ‌in‌ ‌having‌ ‌a‌ ‌larger‌ ‌cranial‌ ‌capacity,‌ ‌a‌ ‌forehead,‌ ‌and‌ ‌non‌ ‌\noverlapping‌ ‌canines.‌ ‌\n ‌\nFossil‌ ‌discovery‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌remains‌ ‌were‌ ‌first‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌in‌ ‌‌1921-1927‌ ‌‌during‌ ‌excavations‌ ‌at‌ ‌‌Zhoukoudian‌ ‌(Choukoutien)‌ ‌near‌ ‌Beijing‌ ‌‌(former‌ ‌Peking),‌ ‌China.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌finds‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌dated‌ ‌from‌ ‌roughly‌‌ ‌250,000-400,000‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Pleistocene.‌ ‌\n ‌\nPhylogeny‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Java‌ ‌specimens‌ ‌along‌ ‌with‌ ‌those‌ ‌from‌ ‌China‌ ‌were‌ ‌renamed‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌1950s‌ ‌by‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌biologist‌ ‌Ernst‌ ‌Mayr.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Thus,‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌became‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌officially‌ ‌named‌ ‌prehistoric‌ ‌species‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌genus‌ ‌Homo.‌ ‌\n ‌\nGeographical‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌\n202‌ ‌\n ‌\n1.6‌ ‌Phylogenetic‌ ‌status,‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌and‌ ‌geographical‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌following‌ ‌:‌ ‌\n ‌(c)‌ ‌Neanderthal‌ ‌man-‌ ‌La-chapelle-aux-saints‌ ‌(Classical‌ ‌type),‌ ‌Mt.‌ ‌Carmel‌ ‌(Progressive‌ ‌type)‌ ‌\n ‌(d)‌ ‌Rhodesian‌ ‌man‌ ‌\n ‌(e)‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌sapiens—Cromagnon,‌ ‌Grimaldi‌ ‌and‌ ‌Chancelade-Part-IV‌ ‌\n ‌\n(c)‌ ‌Neanderthal‌ ‌man-‌ ‌La-chapelle-aux-saints‌ ‌(Classical‌ ‌type),‌ ‌Mt.‌ ‌Carmel‌ ‌(Progressive‌ ‌type)‌ ‌\nHomo‌ ‌neanderthalensis‌ ‌\nOverview‌ ‌\n●Neanderthals‌ ‌(the‌ ‌‘th’‌ ‌pronounced‌ ‌as‌ ‌‘t’)‌ ‌are‌ ‌‌our‌ ‌closest‌ ‌extinct‌ ‌human‌ ‌relative.‌ ‌ ‌\n●DNA‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌recovered‌ ‌from‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌a‌ ‌dozen‌ ‌Neanderthal‌ ‌fossils,‌ ‌all‌ ‌from‌ ‌Europe;‌ ‌‌the‌ ‌Neanderthal‌ ‌Genome‌ ‌Project‌ ‌is‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nexciting‌ ‌new‌ ‌areas‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌origins‌ ‌research.‌ ‌\n●Previously,‌ ‌Neanderthals‌ ‌were‌ ‌thought‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌ancestors‌ ‌of‌ ‌sapiens.‌ ‌ ‌\n203‌ ‌\n○But,‌ ‌subsequently,‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌found‌ ‌that‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌an‌ ‌extinct‌ ‌cousin‌ ‌of‌ ‌humans.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Neanderthals‌ ‌appeared‌ ‌in‌ ‌middle‌ ‌palaeolithic‌ ‌whereas‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌appeared‌ ‌in‌ ‌lower‌ ‌palaeolithic‌ ‌and‌ ‌sapiens‌ ‌in‌ ‌upper‌ ‌palaeolithic.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nNeanderthal‌ ‌Ancestors‌ ‌\nHomo‌ ‌habilis‌ ‌→‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌→‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌heidelbergensis‌ ‌→‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌neanderthalensis‌ ‌\n ‌\nNeanderthal‌ ‌facts‌ ‌\n●Species:‌ ‌‌Homo‌ ‌neanderthalensis‌ ‌\n●Lived:‌‌ ‌from‌ ‌about‌ ‌400,000‌ ‌to‌ ‌40,000‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago‌ ‌\n●Where:‌‌ ‌across‌ ‌Europe‌ ‌and‌ ‌southwest‌ ‌and‌ ‌central‌ ‌Asia‌ ‌\n●Appearance:‌‌ ‌large‌ ‌nose,‌ ‌strong‌ ‌double-arched‌ ‌brow‌ ‌ridge,‌ ‌relatively‌ ‌short‌ ‌and‌ ‌stocky‌ ‌bodies‌ ‌\n●Brain‌ ‌size:‌ ‌‌at‌ ‌least‌ ‌1,200cm3‌ ‌to‌ ‌1,750cm3‌ ‌\n●Height:‌ ‌‌about‌ ‌1.50-1.75m‌ ‌\n●Weight:‌‌ ‌about‌ ‌64-82kg‌ ‌\n●Diet:‌‌ ‌meat,‌ ‌plants‌ ‌and‌ ‌fungi,‌ ‌shellfish‌ ‌when‌ ‌available‌ ‌\n●Species‌ ‌named‌ ‌in:‌ ‌‌1864‌ ‌\n●Name‌ ‌meaning:‌‌ ‌'human‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌Neander‌ ‌Valley'‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n204‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n205‌ ‌\n ‌‌Homo‌ ‌neanderthalensis‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nNickname:‌‌ ‌Neanderthal‌ ‌\nDiscovery‌ ‌Date:‌ ‌‌1829‌ ‌\nWhere‌ ‌Lived:‌‌ ‌Europe‌ ‌and‌ ‌southwestern‌ ‌to‌ ‌central‌ ‌Asia‌ ‌\nWhen‌ ‌Lived:‌‌ ‌About‌ ‌400,000‌ ‌-‌ ‌40,000‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nHeight:‌‌ ‌Males:‌ ‌average‌ ‌5‌ ‌ft‌ ‌5‌ ‌in‌ ‌(164‌ ‌cm);‌ ‌Females:‌ ‌average‌ ‌5‌ ‌ft‌ ‌1‌ ‌in‌ ‌(155‌ ‌cm)‌ ‌\nWeight:‌‌ ‌Males:‌ ‌average‌ ‌143‌ ‌lbs‌ ‌(65‌ ‌kg);‌ ‌Females:‌ ‌average‌ ‌119‌ ‌lbs‌ ‌(54‌ ‌kg)‌ ‌\n ‌\nTypes‌ ‌of‌ ‌Neanderthals‌ ‌\n ‌\nHooton‌ ‌‌divided‌ ‌them‌ ‌into‌ ‌‌classical‌ ‌and‌ ‌progressive‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌anatomical‌ ‌features‌ ‌and‌ ‌phylogenetic‌ ‌timeline.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Classical‌ ‌type:‌ ‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌were‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌‌western‌ ‌Europe‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌are‌ ‌thought‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌in‌ ‌existence‌ ‌around‌ ‌‌75000‌ ‌years‌ ‌to‌ ‌40000‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌were‌ ‌‌short,‌ ‌larger‌ ‌cranial‌ ‌bases‌ ‌as‌ ‌compared‌ ‌to‌ ‌modern‌ ‌Europeans,‌ ‌muscular,‌ ‌broad‌ ‌digits‌ ‌of‌ ‌hand‌ ‌and‌ ‌feet,‌ ‌prominent‌ ‌brow‌ ‌\nridges.‌ ‌ ‌\n206‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌had‌‌ ‌large‌ ‌teeth,‌ ‌enlarged‌ ‌pulp‌ ‌cavities,‌‌ ‌shovel-shaped‌ ‌incisors.‌ ‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌had‌ ‌a‌‌ ‌larger‌ ‌cranial‌ ‌capacity‌ ‌as‌ ‌compared‌ ‌to‌ ‌modern‌ ‌Europeans.‌ ‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌possessed‌ ‌unique‌ ‌features‌ ‌of‌ ‌neanderthal‌ ‌i.e.‌ ‌muzzle‌ ‌appearance‌ ‌of‌ ‌face‌ ‌and‌ ‌presence‌ ‌of‌ ‌occipital‌ ‌torus.‌ ‌Progressive‌ ‌types‌ ‌\ndid‌ ‌not‌ ‌possess‌ ‌them.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Overall‌,‌ ‌they‌ ‌had‌ ‌more‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌features.‌ ‌ ‌\n○La‌ ‌Chapelle‌ ‌aux‌ ‌Saint,‌ ‌a‌ ‌typical‌ ‌example‌ ‌of‌ ‌Classical‌ ‌Neanderthals,‌ ‌was‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌in‌ ‌‌1908‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌village‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌name‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nFrance‌ ‌by‌ ‌three‌ ‌priests.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Progressive‌ ‌type:‌ ‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌‌appeared‌ ‌earlier‌ ‌and‌ ‌gave‌ ‌rise‌ ‌to‌ ‌classical‌ ‌types,‌ ‌but‌ ‌lasted‌ ‌beyond‌ ‌them.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Their‌ ‌fossils‌ ‌are‌ ‌found‌ ‌from‌‌ ‌extra-European‌ ‌sites‌ ‌i.e.‌ ‌Asia‌ ‌and‌ ‌Africa.‌ ‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌had‌‌ ‌round,‌ ‌massive‌ ‌heads‌ ‌with‌ ‌less‌ ‌prominent‌ ‌brow‌ ‌ridges.‌ ‌ ‌\n○They‌‌ ‌did‌ ‌not‌ ‌have‌ ‌canine‌ ‌fossa.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Overall,‌ ‌they‌ ‌‌resembled‌ ‌more‌ ‌sapiens.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌mount‌ ‌Carmel‌ ‌type‌‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌typical‌ ‌example,‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌in‌ ‌‌1931‌ ‌in‌ ‌Palestine‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n207‌ ‌\n○Others‌ ‌include‌ ‌the‌ ‌London‌ ‌skull,‌ ‌Swanscombe‌ ‌man,‌ ‌fontechevade‌ ‌skulls‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nCharacteristics‌ ‌\nPhysical‌ ‌\n●Some‌ ‌defining‌ ‌features‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌skulls‌ ‌include‌ ‌the‌ ‌large‌ ‌middle‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌face,‌ ‌angled‌ ‌cheek‌ ‌bones,‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌huge‌ ‌nose‌ ‌for‌ ‌humidifying‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nwarming‌ ‌cold,‌ ‌dry‌ ‌air.‌ ‌ ‌\n208‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n209‌ ‌\n ‌\n210‌ ‌\n●Their‌‌ ‌bodies‌ ‌were‌ ‌shorter‌ ‌and‌ ‌stockier‌ ‌than‌ ‌ours,‌‌ ‌another‌ ‌adaptation‌ ‌to‌ ‌living‌ ‌in‌ ‌cold‌ ‌environments.‌ ‌ ‌\n●But‌ ‌their‌ ‌‌brains‌ ‌were‌ ‌just‌ ‌as‌ ‌large‌ ‌as‌ ‌ours‌ ‌and‌ ‌often‌ ‌larger‌ ‌‌-‌ ‌proportional‌ ‌to‌ ‌their‌ ‌brawnier‌ ‌bodies.‌ ‌\nCultural‌ ‌\n●Neanderthals‌ ‌made‌ ‌and‌ ‌used‌ ‌a‌ ‌‌diverse‌ ‌set‌ ‌of‌ ‌sophisticated‌ ‌tools,‌ ‌controlled‌ ‌fire‌,‌ ‌‌lived‌ ‌in‌ ‌shelters,‌ ‌made‌ ‌and‌ ‌wore‌ ‌clothing,‌ ‌were‌ ‌skilled‌ ‌\nhunters‌ ‌of‌ ‌large‌ ‌animals‌ ‌and‌ ‌also‌ ‌ate‌ ‌plant‌ ‌foods,‌ ‌and‌ ‌occasionally‌ ‌made‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌or‌ ‌ornamental‌ ‌objects.‌ ‌ ‌\n●There‌ ‌is‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌that‌ ‌Neanderthals‌ ‌deliberately‌ ‌buried‌ ‌their‌ ‌dead‌ ‌and‌ ‌occasionally‌ ‌even‌ ‌marked‌ ‌their‌ ‌graves‌ ‌with‌ ‌offerings,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌\nflowers.‌ ‌ ‌\n○No‌ ‌other‌ ‌primates,‌ ‌and‌ ‌no‌ ‌earlier‌ ‌human‌ ‌species,‌ ‌had‌ ‌ever‌ ‌practiced‌ ‌this‌ ‌sophisticated‌ ‌and‌ ‌symbolic‌
