‌behavior.‌ ‌\n● ‌There‌ ‌is‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌that‌ ‌Neanderthals‌ ‌were‌ ‌specialized‌ ‌seasonal‌ ‌hunters,‌ ‌‌eating‌ ‌animals‌ ‌were‌ ‌available‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌time‌ ‌(i.e.‌ ‌reindeer‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌winter‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌red‌ ‌deer‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌summer).‌ ‌ ‌\n○Scientists‌ ‌have‌ ‌clear‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌of‌ ‌Neanderthal‌ ‌hunting‌ ‌from‌ ‌uncovering‌ ‌sharp‌ ‌wooden‌ ‌spears‌ ‌and‌ ‌large‌ ‌numbers‌ ‌of‌ ‌big‌ ‌game‌ ‌animal‌ ‌\nremains‌ ‌were‌ ‌hunted‌ ‌and‌ ‌butchered‌ ‌by‌ ‌Neanderthals.‌ ‌There‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌from‌ ‌Gibraltar‌ ‌that‌ ‌when‌ ‌they‌ ‌lived‌ ‌in‌ ‌coastal‌ ‌areas,‌ ‌\nthey‌ ‌exploited‌ ‌marine‌ ‌resources‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌mollusks,‌ ‌seals,‌ ‌dolphins‌ ‌and‌ ‌fish.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Mousterian‌ ‌stone‌ ‌tool‌ ‌industry‌ ‌of‌ ‌Neanderthals‌ ‌is‌ ‌characterized‌ ‌by‌ ‌sophisticated‌ ‌flake‌ ‌tools‌ ‌that‌ ‌were‌ ‌detached‌ ‌from‌ ‌a‌ ‌prepared‌ ‌stone‌ ‌\ncore.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌technology‌ ‌differs‌ ‌from‌ ‌earlier‌ ‌‘core‌ ‌tool’‌ ‌traditions,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌Acheulean‌ ‌tradition‌ ‌of‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌erectus.‌ ‌\n○Acheulean‌ ‌tools‌ ‌worked‌ ‌from‌ ‌a‌ ‌suitable‌ ‌stone‌ ‌that‌ ‌was‌ ‌chipped‌ ‌down‌ ‌to‌ ‌tool‌ ‌form‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌removal‌ ‌of‌ ‌flakes‌ ‌off‌ ‌the‌ ‌surface.‌ ‌\n●Neanderthals‌ ‌used‌ ‌tools‌ ‌for‌ ‌‌activities‌ ‌like‌ ‌hunting‌ ‌and‌ ‌sewing.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Maximum‌ ‌‌natural‌ ‌lifespan‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌timing‌ ‌of‌ ‌adulthood,‌ ‌menopause,‌ ‌and‌ ‌gestation‌ ‌were‌ ‌most‌ ‌likely‌ ‌very‌ ‌similar‌ ‌to‌ ‌modern‌ ‌humans.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nFossil‌ ‌Discovery:‌ ‌\n●Neanderthal‌ ‌1‌ ‌‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌first‌ ‌specimen‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌recognized‌ ‌as‌ ‌an‌ ‌early‌ ‌human‌ ‌fossil.‌ ‌ ‌\n●When‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌in‌ ‌‌1856‌ ‌in‌ ‌Germany‌,‌ ‌scientists‌ ‌had‌ ‌never‌ ‌seen‌ ‌a‌ ‌specimen‌ ‌like‌ ‌it:‌ ‌‌the‌ ‌oval‌ ‌shaped‌ ‌skull‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌low,‌ ‌receding‌ ‌\nforehead‌ ‌and‌ ‌distinct‌ ‌brow‌ ‌ridges,‌ ‌the‌ ‌thick,‌ ‌strong‌ ‌bones.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌‌1864,‌ ‌it‌ ‌became‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌fossil‌ ‌hominin‌ ‌species‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌named‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Geologist‌ ‌William‌ ‌King‌ ‌suggested‌ ‌the‌ ‌name‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌neanderthalensis‌ ‌(Johanson‌ ‌and‌ ‌Edgar,‌ ‌2006),‌ ‌after‌ ‌these‌ ‌fossils‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nFeldhofer‌ ‌Cave‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Neander‌ ‌Valley‌ ‌in‌ ‌Germany‌ ‌‌(tal—a‌ ‌modern‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌thal—means‌ ‌“valley”‌ ‌in‌ ‌German).‌ ‌ ‌\n●Several‌ ‌years‌ ‌after‌ ‌‌Neanderthal‌ ‌1‌ ‌‌was‌ ‌discovered,‌ ‌scientists‌ ‌realized‌ ‌that‌ ‌prior‌ ‌fossil‌ ‌discoveries—in‌ ‌‌1829‌ ‌at‌ ‌Engis,‌ ‌Belgium,‌ ‌and‌ ‌in‌ ‌1848‌ ‌\nat‌ ‌Forbes‌ ‌Quarry,‌ ‌Gibraltar—were‌ ‌also‌ ‌Neanderthals.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Even‌ ‌though‌ ‌they‌ ‌weren’t‌ ‌recognized‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌time,‌ ‌these‌ ‌two‌ ‌earlier‌ ‌discoveries‌ ‌were‌ ‌actually‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌early‌ ‌human‌ ‌fossils‌ ‌ever‌ ‌found.‌ ‌\n ‌\nPhylogeny‌ ‌\n●Both‌ ‌fossil‌ ‌and‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌indicate‌ ‌that‌ ‌Neanderthals‌ ‌and‌ ‌modern‌ ‌humans‌ ‌(Homo‌ ‌sapiens)‌ ‌evolved‌ ‌from‌ ‌a‌ ‌common‌ ‌ancestor‌ ‌between‌ ‌\n700,000‌ ‌and‌ ‌300,000‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago.‌ ‌ ‌\n211‌ ‌\n●Neanderthals‌ ‌and‌ ‌modern‌ ‌humans‌ ‌belong‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌genus‌ ‌(Homo)‌ ‌and‌ ‌inhabited‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌geographic‌ ‌areas‌ ‌in‌ ‌western‌ ‌Asia‌ ‌for‌ ‌\n30,000–50,000‌ ‌years;‌ ‌ ‌\n○Genetic‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌indicate‌ ‌while‌ ‌they‌ ‌interbred‌ ‌with‌ ‌non-African‌ ‌modern‌ ‌humans,‌ ‌they‌ ‌ultimately‌ ‌became‌ ‌distinct‌ ‌branches‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nhuman‌ ‌family‌ ‌tree‌ ‌(separate‌ ‌species).‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌fact,‌ ‌Neanderthals‌ ‌and‌ ‌modern‌ ‌humans‌ ‌may‌ ‌have‌ ‌had‌ ‌little‌ ‌direct‌ ‌interaction‌ ‌for‌ ‌tens‌ ‌of‌ ‌thousands‌ ‌of‌ ‌years‌ ‌until‌ ‌during‌ ‌one‌ ‌very‌ ‌cold‌ ‌\nperiod‌ ‌when‌ ‌modern‌ ‌humans‌ ‌spread‌ ‌into‌ ‌Europe.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Their‌ ‌presence‌ ‌may‌ ‌have‌ ‌prevented‌ ‌Neanderthals‌ ‌from‌ ‌expanding‌ ‌back‌ ‌into‌ ‌areas‌ ‌they‌ ‌once‌ ‌favored‌ ‌and‌ ‌served‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌catalyst‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nNeanderthal’s‌ ‌impending‌ ‌extinction.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Over‌ ‌just‌ ‌a‌ ‌few‌ ‌thousand‌ ‌years‌ ‌after‌ ‌modern‌ ‌humans‌ ‌moved‌ ‌into‌ ‌Europe,‌ ‌Neanderthal‌ ‌numbers‌ ‌dwindled‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌point‌ ‌of‌ ‌extinction.‌ ‌ ‌\n●All‌ ‌traces‌ ‌of‌ ‌Neanderthals‌ ‌disappeared‌ ‌about‌ ‌40,000‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌most‌ ‌‌recently‌ ‌dated‌ ‌Neanderthal‌ ‌fossils‌ ‌come‌ ‌from‌ ‌small‌ ‌areas‌ ‌of‌ ‌western‌ ‌Europe‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌Near‌ ‌east,‌ ‌which‌ ‌was‌ ‌likely‌ ‌where‌ ‌the‌ ‌last‌ ‌\npopulation‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌early‌ ‌human‌ ‌species‌ ‌existed.‌ ‌\n212‌ ‌\n ‌\n213‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nLa-chapelle-aux-saints‌ ‌(Classical‌ ‌type)‌ ‌\nOverview‌ ‌\n●La‌ ‌Chapelle-aux-Saints‌ ‌1‌ ‌(\"The‌ ‌Old‌ ‌Man\")‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌almost-complete‌ ‌male‌ ‌Neanderthal‌ ‌skeleton‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌in‌ ‌La‌ ‌Chapelle-aux-Saints,‌ ‌‌France‌ ‌\nby‌ ‌A.‌ ‌and‌ ‌J.‌ ‌Bouyssonie,‌ ‌and‌ ‌L.‌ ‌Bardon‌ ‌in‌ ‌1908.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌individual‌ ‌was‌ ‌about‌ ‌40‌ ‌years‌ ‌of‌ ‌age‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌time‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌death.‌ ‌ ‌\n○He‌ ‌was‌ ‌in‌ ‌bad‌ ‌health,‌ ‌having‌ ‌lost‌ ‌most‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌teeth‌ ‌and‌ ‌suffering‌ ‌from‌ ‌resorption‌ ‌of‌ ‌bone‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌mandible‌ ‌and‌ ‌advanced‌ ‌arthritis.‌ ‌\n○Other‌ ‌Neanderthals‌ ‌in‌ ‌his‌ ‌social‌ ‌group‌ ‌may‌ ‌have‌ ‌supported‌ ‌him‌ ‌in‌ ‌his‌ ‌final‌ ‌years.‌ ‌\n○Buried‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌limestone‌ ‌bedrock‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌small‌ ‌cave‌ ‌near‌ ‌La‌ ‌Chapelle-aux-Saints,‌ ‌France,‌ ‌this‌ ‌skeleton‌ ‌includes‌ ‌the‌ ‌skull,‌ ‌jaw,‌ ‌most‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌vertebrae,‌ ‌several‌ ‌ribs,‌ ‌most‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌long‌ ‌bones‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌arms‌ ‌and‌ ‌legs,‌ ‌plus‌ ‌some‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌smaller‌ ‌bones‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌hands‌ ‌and‌ ‌feet.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌well-preserved‌ ‌skull‌ ‌shows‌ ‌the‌ ‌low,‌ ‌receding‌ ‌forehead,‌ ‌protruding‌ ‌midface,‌ ‌and‌ ‌heavy‌ ‌brow‌ ‌ridges‌ ‌typical‌ ‌of‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌\nneanderthalensis.‌ ‌\n214‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nCharacteristics:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Brain‌ ‌&‌ ‌Skull:‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌cranial‌ ‌capacity‌ ‌is‌ ‌about‌ ‌‌1600‌ ‌cc‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌well‌ ‌above‌ ‌the‌ ‌average‌ ‌capacity‌ ‌of‌ ‌modern‌ ‌Englishman.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌skull‌ ‌is‌ ‌heavy-looking‌ ‌and‌ ‌very‌ ‌large.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌bones‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌vault‌ ‌are‌ ‌very‌ ‌thick.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌face‌ ‌is‌ ‌highly‌ ‌developed‌ ‌in‌ ‌comparison‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌cranium.‌ ‌\n215‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌skull‌ ‌is‌ ‌more‌ ‌enlarged‌ ‌behind‌ ‌than‌ ‌in‌ ‌front.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌occipital‌ ‌region‌ ‌is‌ ‌protruding‌ ‌and‌ ‌much‌ ‌depressed.‌ ‌\n●Face‌ ‌&‌ ‌Dentition‌ ‌\n○The‌‌ ‌face‌ ‌is‌ ‌long‌ ‌and‌ ‌projects‌ ‌forwards.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌‌supraorbital‌ ‌regions‌ ‌are‌ ‌of‌ ‌enormous‌ ‌size,‌ ‌and‌ ‌continuous‌ ‌to‌ ‌form‌ ‌a‌ ‌heavy‌ ‌rounded‌ ‌torus‌ ‌(as‌ ‌in‌ ‌chimpanzee,‌ ‌gorilla‌ ‌and‌ ‌also‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nPithecanthropus).‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌orbits‌ ‌are‌ ‌very‌ ‌large.‌ ‌Their‌ ‌transverse‌ ‌diameter‌ ‌is‌ ‌much‌ ‌greater‌ ‌than‌ ‌their‌ ‌height.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌massive‌ ‌molar‌ ‌region‌‌ ‌is‌ ‌inclined‌ ‌forward‌ ‌and‌ ‌it‌ ‌suggests‌ ‌flat‌ ‌cheek.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌maxillary‌ ‌position‌ ‌is‌ ‌seong‌ ‌and‌ ‌massive.‌ ‌It‌ ‌projects‌ ‌forwards‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌muzzle-like‌ ‌appearance.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌root‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌nose‌ ‌is‌ ‌depressed‌ ‌(as‌ ‌in‌ ‌native‌ ‌Australians).‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌nose‌ ‌is‌ ‌broad‌ ‌(Platyrrhine)‌.‌ ‌The‌ ‌nasal‌ ‌aperture‌ ‌is‌ ‌large,‌ ‌wide‌ ‌and‌ ‌pyriform.‌ ‌\n○Though‌ ‌the‌ ‌dentition‌ ‌shows‌ ‌some‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌features,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌definitely‌ ‌human.‌ ‌\n●Lower‌ ‌Jaw:‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌has‌ ‌a‌ ‌‌large‌ ‌and‌ ‌strong‌ ‌jaw.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌‌chin‌ ‌is‌ ‌absent‌ ‌or‌ ‌it‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌called‌ ‌a‌ ‌rudimentary‌ ‌chin.‌ ‌\n●Bones‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Trunk‌ ‌and‌ ‌Limbs:‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌short,‌ ‌strong‌ ‌and‌ ‌stout‌ ‌bones‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌skeleton‌ ‌indicate‌ ‌powerful‌ ‌muscular‌ ‌development.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌vertebral‌ ‌column‌ ‌is‌ ‌short‌ ‌and‌ ‌stout.‌ ‌The‌ ‌ribs‌ ‌are‌ ‌strong‌ ‌indicating‌ ‌large‌ ‌thorax.‌ ‌The‌ ‌clavicles‌ ‌are‌ ‌long,‌ ‌slender‌ ‌and‌ ‌arched‌ ‌(as‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nchimpanzees).‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌forearm‌ ‌is‌ ‌short‌ ‌in‌ ‌relation‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌upper‌ ‌arm.‌ ‌The‌ ‌hand‌ ‌is‌ ‌quite‌ ‌human‌ ‌in‌ ‌character.‌‌ ‌The‌ ‌fingers‌ ‌are‌ ‌comparatively‌ ‌short.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌femur‌ ‌is‌ ‌massive,‌ ‌strong‌ ‌and‌ ‌it‌ ‌has‌ ‌a‌ ‌large‌ ‌head.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌foot‌ ‌exhibits‌ ‌some‌ ‌interesting‌ ‌features.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌stature‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌old‌ ‌man‌ ‌of‌ ‌La‌ ‌Chapelle-aux‌ ‌Saints‌ ‌was‌ ‌5‌ ‌feet‌ ‌1‌ ‌inch.‌ ‌(The‌ ‌stature‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌classic‌ ‌Neanderthals‌ ‌varies‌ ‌between‌ ‌5″1″‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌5’5″).‌ ‌\n ‌\nMt.‌ ‌Carmel‌ ‌(Progressive‌ ‌type)‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Mount‌ ‌Carmel‌ ‌skeletons‌ ‌were‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌from‌ ‌two‌ ‌adjoining‌ ‌caves‌ ‌in‌ ‌‌Palestine‌ ‌in‌ ‌1931-32.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌layers‌ ‌yielded‌ ‌the‌ ‌Levalloiso-Mousterian‌ ‌industry‌ ‌also.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌one‌ ‌case,‌ ‌the‌ ‌skeleton‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌adult‌ ‌female,‌ ‌a‌ ‌mandible‌ ‌and‌ ‌various‌ ‌bones‌ ‌and‌ ‌teeth‌ ‌were‌ ‌found,‌ ‌while‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌produced‌ ‌fragmentary‌ ‌\nremains‌ ‌of‌ ‌about‌ ‌ten‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌besides‌ ‌many‌ ‌isolated‌ ‌fragments.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Mount‌ ‌Carmel‌ ‌men‌ ‌were‌ ‌tall.‌ ‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌had‌ ‌‌massive‌ ‌heads.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌‌occiput‌ ‌was‌ ‌slightly‌ ‌projecting.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌head‌ ‌was‌ ‌medium‌ ‌in‌ ‌height.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌‌ ‌face‌ ‌was‌ ‌of‌ ‌moderate‌ ‌height.‌ ‌ ‌\n216‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌‌chin‌ ‌was‌ ‌almost‌ ‌well‌ ‌developed.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●\n ‌\n(d)‌ ‌Rhodesian‌ ‌man‌ ‌(Homo‌ ‌rhodesiensis)‌ ‌\n ‌\n217‌ ‌\nOverview‌ ‌\n●Rhodesian‌ ‌Man‌ ‌(Homo‌ ‌rhodesiensis)‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌‌hominin‌ ‌fossil‌ ‌‌that‌ ‌was‌ ‌described‌ ‌from‌ ‌a‌ ‌cranium‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌an‌ ‌iron‌ ‌and‌ ‌zinc‌ ‌mine‌ ‌in‌ ‌‌Northern‌ ‌\nRhodesia‌ ‌(now‌ ‌Kabwe,‌ ‌Zambia).‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌geological‌ ‌age‌ ‌is‌ ‌uncertain.‌ ‌ ‌\n●From‌ ‌the‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌point‌ ‌of‌ ‌view‌ ‌it‌ ‌appears‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌the‌ ‌Upper‌ ‌Pleistocene.‌ ‌But‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌not‌ ‌certain.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nCharacteristics‌ ‌\n ‌\n●The‌ ‌s‌kull‌ ‌is‌ ‌very‌ ‌long‌ ‌(208-210‌ ‌mm)‌ ‌and‌ ‌narrow‌ ‌(145-148‌ ‌mm)‌ ‌being‌ ‌dolichocranic.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌height‌ ‌is‌ ‌about‌ ‌131‌ ‌cm.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌‌cranial‌ ‌capacity‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌measured‌ ‌variously‌ ‌from‌ ‌1280‌ ‌to‌ ‌1400‌ ‌cc.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌‌supraorbital‌ ‌ridges‌ ‌are‌ ‌prominent.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌forehead‌ ‌is‌ ‌‌receding.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌maxillary‌ ‌bones‌ ‌lack‌ ‌canine‌ ‌fossa‌ ‌and‌ ‌are‌ ‌very‌ ‌large‌ ‌and‌ ‌flat.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌face‌ ‌gives‌ ‌a‌ ‌muzzle-like‌ ‌appearance.‌ ‌\n●The‌‌ ‌nasal‌ ‌aperture‌ ‌is‌ ‌very‌ ‌large.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌orbits‌ ‌are‌ ‌high‌ ‌and‌ ‌of‌ ‌great‌ ‌size.‌ ‌\n●The‌‌ ‌palate‌ ‌is‌ ‌large‌ ‌\n218‌ ‌\n●The‌‌ ‌teeth‌ ‌are‌ ‌of‌ ‌modern‌ ‌human‌ ‌proportion.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌canine‌ ‌is‌ ‌normal.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌third‌ ‌molars‌ ‌are‌ ‌reduced‌ ‌in‌ ‌size.‌ ‌\n●Unlike‌ ‌sites‌ ‌of‌ ‌comparable‌ ‌age‌ ‌in‌ ‌this‌ ‌region,‌ ‌the‌ ‌tool‌ ‌collection‌ ‌lacks‌ ‌Acheulean‌ ‌hand‌ ‌axes,‌ ‌although‌ ‌some‌ ‌were‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌an‌ ‌excavation‌ ‌280‌ ‌\nkm‌ ‌(170‌ ‌miles)‌ ‌away.‌ ‌\n ‌\nFossil‌ ‌Discovery:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●In‌ ‌1‌921‌‌ ‌‌Mr.‌ ‌Tom‌ ‌Zwiglaar(a‌ ‌swiss‌ ‌miner)‌‌ ‌unearthed‌ ‌some‌ ‌human‌ ‌remains‌ ‌at‌ ‌Broken‌ ‌Hill‌ ‌Mine,‌ ‌‌Rhodesia,‌ ‌in‌ ‌South‌ ‌Africa.‌ ‌\n ‌\nPhylogeny‌ ‌\n●Opinions‌ ‌differ‌ ‌as‌ ‌regards‌ ‌the‌ ‌phylogenetic‌ ‌position‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Rhodesian‌ ‌man.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Some‌ ‌want‌ ‌to‌ ‌call‌ ‌them‌ ‌Neanderthals,‌ ‌while‌ ‌others‌ ‌prefer‌ ‌to‌ ‌put‌ ‌them‌ ‌under‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌erectus.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌most‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌physical‌ ‌features‌ ‌the‌ ‌Rhodesian‌ ‌man‌ ‌resembles‌ ‌the‌ ‌Neanderthal‌ ‌man,‌ ‌and‌ ‌bence‌ ‌by‌ ‌many‌ ‌authorities‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌\nconsidered‌ ‌to‌ ‌form‌ ‌an‌ ‌African‌ ‌variety‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Neanderthals.‌ ‌\n●Rhodesian‌ ‌man‌ ‌bifurcated‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌Neanderthal‌ ‌man‌ ‌and‌ ‌proceeded‌ ‌towards‌ ‌modern‌ ‌man.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Others‌ ‌find‌ ‌close‌ ‌similarities‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌Solo‌ ‌man‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌Rhodesian‌ ‌man.‌ ‌According‌ ‌to‌ ‌them‌ ‌the‌ ‌Rhodesian‌ ‌man‌ ‌has‌ ‌no‌ ‌\nrelationship‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌Neanderthal,‌ ‌but‌ ‌shows‌ ‌resemblances‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌Australian‌ ‌aborigines.‌ ‌\n219‌ ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌addition‌ ‌\nThe‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌phylogeny‌ ‌since‌ ‌1955.‌ ‌\n220‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n(e)‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌Sapiens-Cro‌ ‌Magnon,‌ ‌Grimaldi‌ ‌and‌ ‌Chancelade‌ ‌\n ‌\nCro‌ ‌Magnon‌ ‌\n●Cro-Magnon‌ ‌man,‌ ‌an‌ ‌early‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌sapiens‌ ‌‌(the‌ ‌species‌ ‌to‌ ‌which‌ ‌modern‌ ‌humans‌ ‌belong)‌ ‌that‌ ‌lived‌ ‌about‌ ‌40,000‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago(Upper‌ ‌\nPaleolithic‌ ‌Period)‌ ‌\n221‌ ‌\n●Skeletal‌ ‌remains‌ ‌and‌ ‌associated‌ ‌artifacts‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Aurignacian‌ ‌culture‌ ‌were‌ ‌first‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌‌1868‌ ‌in‌ ‌Les‌ ‌Eyzies,‌ ‌Dordogne,‌ ‌France‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Later‌ ‌discoveries‌ ‌were‌ ‌made‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌caverns‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Dordogne‌ ‌valley,‌ ‌Solutré,‌ ‌and‌ ‌in‌ ‌Spain,‌ ‌Germany,‌ ‌and‌ ‌central‌ ‌Europe.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Cro-Magnon‌ ‌man‌ ‌was‌ ‌anatomically‌ ‌identical‌ ‌to‌ ‌modern‌ ‌humans,‌ ‌‌but‌ ‌‌differed‌ ‌significantly‌ ‌from‌ ‌Neanderthals‌,‌ ‌who‌ ‌disappeared‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌fossil‌ ‌\nabout‌ ‌10,000‌ ‌years‌ ‌after‌ ‌the‌ ‌appearance‌ ‌of‌ ‌Aurignacian‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌upper‌ ‌Paleolithic‌ ‌populations‌ ‌(e.g.‌ ‌the‌ ‌Perigordian‌ ‌culture).‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌abrupt‌ ‌disappearance‌ ‌of‌ ‌Neanderthal‌ ‌populations‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌associated‌ ‌Mousterian‌ ‌technologies,‌ ‌the‌ ‌sudden‌ ‌appearance‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nmodern‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌sapiens‌ ‌(who‌ ‌had‌ ‌arisen‌ ‌earlier‌ ‌in‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌and‌ ‌migrated‌ ‌to‌ ‌Europe)‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌associated‌ ‌upper‌ ‌Paleolithic‌ ‌technologies,‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌the‌ ‌absence‌ ‌of‌ ‌transitional‌ ‌anatomical‌ ‌or‌ ‌technological‌ ‌forms‌ ‌have‌ ‌led‌ ‌many‌ ‌researchers‌ ‌to‌ ‌hypothesize‌ ‌that‌ ‌Neanderthals‌ ‌were‌ ‌\ndriven‌ ‌to‌ ‌extinction‌ ‌through‌ ‌competition‌ ‌with‌ ‌Cro-Magnon‌ ‌or‌ ‌related‌ ‌populations.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Greater‌ ‌linguistic‌ ‌competence‌ ‌and‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌sophistication‌ ‌‌are‌ ‌often‌ ‌suggested‌ ‌as‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌tilting‌ ‌the‌ ‌competitive‌ ‌balance‌ ‌in‌ ‌favor‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nupper‌ ‌Paleolithic‌ ‌groups.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Finely‌ ‌crafted‌ ‌stone‌ ‌and‌ ‌bone‌ ‌tools,‌ ‌shell‌ ‌and‌ ‌ivory‌ ‌jewelry,‌ ‌and‌ ‌polychrome‌ ‌paintings‌ ‌found‌ ‌on‌ ‌cave‌ ‌walls‌ ‌all‌ ‌testify‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌\nadvancement‌ ‌of‌ ‌Cro-Magnon‌ ‌man.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nCharacteristics‌ ‌\n●Cro-Magnons‌ ‌were‌ ‌robustly‌ ‌built‌ ‌and‌ ‌powerful‌ ‌and‌ ‌are‌ ‌presumed‌ ‌to‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌about‌ ‌166‌ ‌to‌ ‌171‌ ‌cm‌ ‌(about‌ ‌5‌ ‌feet‌ ‌5‌ ‌inches‌ ‌to‌ ‌5‌ ‌feet‌ ‌7‌ ‌\ninches)‌ ‌tall.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌body‌ ‌was‌ ‌generally‌ ‌‌heavy‌ ‌and‌ ‌solid,‌ ‌apparently‌ ‌with‌ ‌strong‌ ‌musculature.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌forehead‌ ‌was‌ ‌straight,‌ ‌with‌ ‌slight‌ ‌brow‌ ‌ridges,‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌face‌ ‌short‌ ‌and‌ ‌wide.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Cro-Magnons‌ ‌were‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌first‌ ‌humans‌ ‌(genus‌ ‌Homo)‌ ‌to‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌prominent‌ ‌chin.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌brain‌ ‌capacity‌ ‌was‌ ‌about‌ ‌‌1,600‌ ‌cc‌ ‌(100‌ ‌cubic‌ ‌inches),‌ ‌somewhat‌ ‌larger‌ ‌than‌ ‌the‌ ‌average‌ ‌for‌ ‌modern‌ ‌humans.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌thought‌ ‌that‌ ‌Cro-Magnons‌ ‌were‌ ‌‌probably‌ ‌fairly‌ ‌tall‌ ‌compared‌ ‌with‌ ‌other‌ ‌early‌ ‌human‌ ‌species.‌ ‌\n●Cro-Magnon‌ ‌dwellings‌ ‌are‌ ‌most‌ ‌often‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌‌deep‌ ‌caves‌ ‌and‌ ‌in‌ ‌shallow‌ ‌caves‌ ‌formed‌ ‌by‌ ‌rock‌ ‌overhangs,‌ ‌although‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌huts,‌ ‌either‌ ‌\nlean-tos‌ ‌against‌ ‌rock‌ ‌walls‌ ‌or‌ ‌those‌ ‌built‌ ‌completely‌ ‌from‌ ‌stones,‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌found.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌rock‌ ‌shelters‌ ‌were‌ ‌used‌ ‌year-round;‌ ‌the‌ ‌Cro-Magnons‌ ‌seem‌ ‌to‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌settled‌ ‌people,‌ ‌moving‌ ‌only‌ ‌when‌ ‌necessary‌ ‌to‌ ‌find‌ ‌new‌ ‌\nhunting‌ ‌or‌ ‌because‌ ‌of‌ ‌environmental‌ ‌changes.‌ ‌\n●Like‌ ‌the‌ ‌Neanderthals,‌ ‌‌the‌ ‌Cro-Magnon‌ ‌people‌ ‌buried‌ ‌their‌ ‌dead.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Some‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌examples‌ ‌of‌ ‌art‌ ‌by‌ ‌prehistoric‌ ‌peoples‌ ‌are‌ ‌Cro-Magnon.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌Cro-Magnons‌ ‌carved‌ ‌and‌ ‌sculpted‌ ‌small‌ ‌engravings,‌ ‌reliefs,‌ ‌and‌ ‌statuettes‌ ‌not‌ ‌only‌ ‌of‌ ‌humans‌ ‌but‌ ‌also‌ ‌of‌ ‌animals.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Their‌ ‌human‌ ‌figures‌ ‌generally‌ ‌‌depict‌ ‌large-breasted,‌ ‌wide-hipped,‌ ‌and‌ ‌often‌ ‌obviously‌ ‌pregnant‌ ‌women,‌ ‌from‌ ‌which‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌assumed‌ ‌that‌ ‌these‌ ‌\nfigures‌ ‌had‌ ‌significance‌ ‌in‌ ‌fertility‌ ‌rites.‌ ‌\nPhylogeny‌ ‌\n222‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nWorld’s‌ ‌oldest‌ ‌cave‌ ‌painting,‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌in‌ ‌Indonesia‌ ‌\n■Archaeologists‌ ‌have‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌the‌ ‌world’s‌ ‌oldest‌ ‌known‌ ‌cave‌ ‌art,‌ ‌a‌ ‌life-sized‌ ‌picture‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌wild‌ ‌pig‌ ‌that‌ ‌was‌ ‌painted‌ ‌at‌ ‌least‌ ‌45,500‌ ‌\nyears‌ ‌ago‌ ‌in‌ ‌Indonesia.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n■Significance‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌cave‌ ‌painting:‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌archaeologists‌ ‌note‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌dated‌ ‌painting‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Sulawesi‌ ‌warty‌ ‌pig‌ ‌seems‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌the‌ ‌world’s‌ ‌oldest‌ ‌surviving‌ ‌\n223‌ ‌\nrepresentational‌ ‌image‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌animal.‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌previously‌ ‌oldest‌ ‌dated‌ ‌rock‌ ‌art‌ ‌‘scene’‌ ‌at‌ ‌least‌ ‌43,900‌ ‌years‌ ‌old,‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌depiction‌ ‌of‌ ‌hybrid‌ ‌human-animal‌ ‌\nbeings‌ ‌hunting‌ ‌Sulawesi‌ ‌warty‌ ‌pigs‌ ‌and‌ ‌dwarf‌ ‌bovids.‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌book,‌ ‌“The‌ ‌Archaeology‌ ‌of‌ ‌Sulawesi”,‌ ‌published‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌Australian‌ ‌National‌ ‌University‌ ‌press‌ ‌in‌ ‌2018‌ ‌mentions‌ ‌\nthat‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Sulawesi‌ ‌island‌ ‌contains‌ ‌some‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌oldest‌ ‌directly‌ ‌dated‌ ‌rock‌ ‌art‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌world‌ ‌and‌ ‌also‌ ‌some‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\noldest‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌presence‌ ‌of‌ ‌hominins‌ ‌beyond‌ ‌the‌ ‌southeastern‌ ‌limits‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Ice‌ ‌Age‌ ‌Asian‌ ‌continent.‌ ‌\n ‌\nConclusion‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌difficult‌ ‌to‌ ‌determine‌ ‌how‌ ‌long‌ ‌the‌ ‌Cro-Magnons‌ ‌lasted‌ ‌and‌ ‌what‌ ‌happened‌ ‌to‌ ‌them.‌ ‌Presumably‌ ‌they‌ ‌were‌ ‌gradually‌ ‌absorbed‌ ‌into‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nEuropean‌ ‌populations‌ ‌that‌ ‌came‌ ‌later.‌ ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌Addition‌ ‌\nOutlines‌ ‌the‌ ‌morphological‌ ‌differences‌ ‌between‌ ‌Cro-Magnons‌ ‌and‌ ‌Neanderthals.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Neanderthals‌ ‌had‌ ‌a‌ ‌longer‌ ‌clavicle‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌wider‌ ‌scapula‌ ‌to‌ ‌allow‌ ‌for‌ ‌more‌ ‌muscle‌ ‌attachments.‌ ‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌had‌ ‌significantly‌ ‌larger‌ ‌shoulder‌ ‌and‌ ‌elbow‌ ‌joints‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌notably‌ ‌wider,‌ ‌larger‌ ‌rib‌ ‌cage.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Their‌ ‌hands‌ ‌had‌ ‌much‌ ‌wider‌ ‌phalanges‌ ‌and‌ ‌fingertips.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Their‌ ‌leg‌ ‌bones‌ ‌(femur‌ ‌and‌ ‌tibia)‌ ‌were‌ ‌larger‌ ‌in‌ ‌diameter‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌tibia‌ ‌being‌ ‌shorter‌ ‌than‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌Cro-Magnons.‌ ‌\nTheir‌ ‌ankles‌ ‌were‌ ‌larger‌ ‌to‌ ‌account‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌overall‌ ‌heavier‌ ‌body‌ ‌frame‌ ‌and‌ ‌they‌ ‌had‌ ‌wider‌ ‌feet‌ ‌with‌ ‌strong‌ ‌toes.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nGrimaldi‌ ‌Man‌ ‌\n●Grimaldi‌ ‌man‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌name‌ ‌formerly‌ ‌given‌ ‌to‌ ‌two‌ ‌human‌ ‌skeletons‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Upper‌ ‌Paleolithic‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌in‌ ‌Italy‌ ‌in‌ ‌1901.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌remains‌ ‌are‌ ‌now‌ ‌recognized‌ ‌as‌ ‌representing‌ ‌two‌ ‌individuals,‌ ‌and‌ ‌are‌ ‌dated‌ ‌to‌ ‌ca.‌ ‌26,000‌ ‌to‌ ‌22,000‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago‌ ‌(i.e.‌ ‌c.‌ ‌24000–20000‌ ‌BC).‌ ‌\n ‌\n224‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nDiscovery‌ ‌\n\t\nAt‌ ‌Grotte‌ ‌dei‌ ‌fanciulli‌ ‌cave,‌ ‌near‌ ‌Grimaldi‌ ‌village‌ ‌on‌ ‌Mediteraen‌ ‌coast.‌ ‌\n\n\nSkeleton‌ ‌\n\t\nWomen‌ ‌of‌ ‌30‌ ‌year,‌ ‌Boy‌ ‌of‌ ‌15‌ ‌year‌ ‌stained‌ ‌in‌ ‌red‌ ‌ochre‌ ‌implies‌ ‌intentional‌ ‌burial.‌ ‌\n\n\nPhysical‌ ‌Similarity‌ ‌\n\t\nNegroid‌ ‌type‌ ‌\n\n\nTime‌ ‌&‌ ‌technology‌ ‌\n\t\nUpper‌ ‌Paleolithic,‌ ‌Aurignacian‌ ‌\n\n\nCulture‌ ‌\n\t\nGrave‌ ‌material‌ ‌has‌ ‌tools‌ ‌like‌ ‌double‌ ‌edged‌ ‌flints,‌ ‌knives,‌ ‌graver‌ ‌saw‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n\n\nFeatures‌ ‌\n\t\n●Cranial‌ ‌Capacity:‌ ‌1250-1450CC.‌ ‌\n●Short‌ ‌stature‌ ‌\n●Lower‌ ‌limb‌ ‌much‌ ‌longer‌ ‌than‌ ‌upper‌ ‌limb‌ ‌so‌ ‌less‌ ‌energetic‌ ‌bipedalism.‌ ‌\n●Sexual‌ ‌Dimorphism.‌ ‌\n●Skulls‌ ‌have‌ ‌elliptical‌ ‌contours.‌ ‌\n●Small‌ ‌mastoid‌ ‌process.‌ ‌\n●Long,narrow‌ ‌and‌ ‌high‌ ‌skull,‌ ‌hyper‌ ‌dolichocephalic.‌ ‌\n●Disharmonic‌ ‌face.‌ ‌\n●Feeble‌ ‌supraorbital‌ ‌ridge.‌ ‌\n●Bulbous‌ ‌forehead.‌ ‌\n●Large‌ ‌rectangular‌ ‌orbits.‌ ‌\n●Alveolar‌ ‌prognathism.‌ ‌\n●Strong‌ ‌&‌ ‌broad‌ ‌jaws.‌ ‌\n●Teeth‌ ‌are‌ ‌large‌ ‌in‌ ‌general.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nChancelade‌ ‌Man‌ ‌\n●Chancelade‌ ‌man‌ ‌(the‌ ‌Chancelade‌ ‌cranium)‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌ancient‌ ‌anatomically‌ ‌modern‌ ‌human‌ ‌fossil‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌male‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌Chancelade‌ ‌in‌ ‌France‌ ‌in‌ ‌\n1888.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nDiscovery‌ ‌\n\t\nAt‌ ‌a‌ ‌rock‌ ‌shelter‌ ‌in‌ ‌Chancelade‌ ‌in‌ ‌France‌ ‌in‌ ‌1888.‌ ‌\n\n\nSkeleton‌ ‌\n\t\nOld‌ ‌man‌ ‌with‌ ‌arm‌ ‌folded‌ ‌&‌ ‌knees‌ ‌doubled‌ ‌up‌ ‌against‌ ‌body,‌ ‌stained‌ ‌in‌ ‌red‌ ‌ochre‌ ‌\n225‌ ‌\n\t\nimplies‌ ‌intentional‌ ‌burial.‌ ‌\n\n\nPhysical‌ ‌Similarity‌ ‌\n\t\nEskimos,‌ ‌Magdalanian‌ ‌\n\n\nTime‌ ‌&‌ ‌technology‌ ‌\n\t\nUpper‌ ‌paleolithic,‌ ‌Magdalanian‌ ‌\n\n\nCulture‌ ‌\n\t\nTools‌ ‌of‌ ‌ivory‌ ‌bone,‌ ‌antler‌ ‌blades‌ ‌&‌ ‌harpoons‌ ‌were‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌of‌ ‌cave‌ ‌\npaintings.‌ ‌\n\n\nFeatures‌ ‌\n\t\n●Cranial‌ ‌capacity:‌ ‌1530cc-1710cc‌ ‌\n●Upper‌ ‌Limb‌ ‌comparatively‌ ‌longer‌ ‌than‌ ‌lower‌ ‌limb.‌ ‌\n●Femur‌ ‌bent‌ ‌7‌ ‌linea‌ ‌aspera‌ ‌well‌ ‌marked.‌ ‌\n●Short‌ ‌stature‌ ‌\n●Well‌ ‌developed‌ ‌mastoid‌ ‌process.‌ ‌\n●Dolichocephalic‌ ‌skull‌ ‌with‌ ‌sagittal‌ ‌crest.‌ ‌\n●Wide‌ ‌&‌ ‌Long‌ ‌face.‌ ‌\n●Prominent‌ ‌cheekbones.‌ ‌\n●Supraorbital‌ ‌ridges‌ ‌slightly‌ ‌developed.‌ ‌\n●Vertical‌ ‌forehead.‌ ‌\n●Quadrilateral‌ ‌orbit.‌ ‌\n●Leptorrhine.‌ ‌\n●Lower‌ ‌teeth‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌very‌ ‌large.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n1.8‌ ‌(a)‌ ‌Principles‌ ‌of‌ ‌Prehistoric‌ ‌Archaeology.‌ ‌Chronology‌ ‌:‌ ‌Relative‌ ‌and‌ ‌Absolute‌ ‌Dating‌ ‌methods‌ ‌Part-I‌ ‌\nWhat‌ ‌is‌ ‌Archaeology?‌ ‌\n●Archaeology‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌that‌ ‌lived‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌past.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌subfield‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropology,‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌cultures.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌other‌ ‌subfields‌ ‌are:‌ ‌\n○Cultural‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌that‌ ‌studies‌ ‌living‌ ‌cultures,‌ ‌ ‌\n226‌ ‌\n○Physical‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌that‌ ‌studies‌ ‌human‌ ‌biology‌ ‌and‌ ‌where‌ ‌humans‌ ‌fit‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌living‌ ‌and‌ ‌extinct‌ ‌species‌ ‌of‌ ‌our‌ ‌family‌ ‌tree,‌ ‌and‌ ‌ ‌\n○Linguistics‌ ‌that‌ ‌studies‌ ‌human‌ ‌language.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌subject‌ ‌was‌ ‌originally‌ ‌divided‌ ‌into‌ ‌two‌ ‌major‌ ‌branches‌ ‌namely‌ ‌physical‌ ‌and‌ ‌social-cultural‌ ‌anthropology.‌ ‌Both‌ ‌the‌ ‌branches‌ ‌are‌ ‌again‌ ‌\nsubdivided.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Prehistoric‌ ‌archaeology‌ ‌was‌ ‌considered‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌subfield‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌anthropology.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Archaeology‌ ‌is‌ ‌primarily‌ ‌concerned‌ ‌with‌ ‌reconstructing‌ ‌extinct‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌material‌ ‌remains‌ ‌of‌ ‌past‌ ‌human‌ ‌behavior,‌ ‌or‌ ‌the‌ ‌things‌ ‌\npeople‌ ‌made‌ ‌or‌ ‌used‌ ‌and‌ ‌left‌ ‌behind.‌ ‌These‌ ‌remains‌ ‌are‌ ‌called‌ ‌‌artifacts‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Much‌ ‌of‌ ‌what‌ ‌we‌ ‌see‌ ‌around‌ ‌us‌ ‌–‌ ‌computers,‌ ‌clothing,‌ ‌food,‌ ‌books,‌ ‌and‌ ‌buildings‌ ‌–‌ ‌are‌ ‌artifacts.‌ ‌Even‌ ‌natural‌ ‌objects,‌ ‌like‌ ‌a‌ ‌stick‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nwood‌ ‌or‌ ‌a‌ ‌piece‌ ‌of‌ ‌bone,‌ ‌are‌ ‌artifacts‌ ‌if‌ ‌humans‌ ‌have‌ ‌used‌ ‌them‌ ‌for‌ ‌some‌ ‌purpose.‌ ‌\n●From‌ ‌these‌ ‌artifacts‌ ‌archaeologists‌ ‌build‌ ‌a‌ ‌model‌ ‌of‌ ‌what‌ ‌a‌ ‌culture‌ ‌was‌ ‌like.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Archaeologists‌ ‌look‌ ‌for‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌artifacts‌ ‌they‌ ‌study‌ ‌that‌ ‌give‌ ‌them‌ ‌clues‌ ‌about‌ ‌how‌ ‌the‌ ‌people‌ ‌who‌ ‌made‌ ‌and‌ ‌used‌ ‌them‌ ‌lived.‌ ‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌instance,‌ ‌the‌ ‌way‌ ‌people‌ ‌made‌ ‌pottery‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌southwest‌ ‌changed‌ ‌over‌ ‌time,‌ ‌reflecting‌ ‌their‌ ‌skill,‌ ‌different‌ ‌technologies‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nproduce‌ ‌it,‌ ‌the‌ ‌ways‌ ‌they‌ ‌used‌ ‌designs‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌decorations,‌ ‌and‌ ‌how‌ ‌they‌ ‌used‌ ‌the‌ ‌pottery.‌ ‌\n●There‌ ‌are‌ ‌several‌ ‌different‌ ‌kinds‌ ‌of‌ ‌archaeology:‌ ‌ ‌\n○Prehistoric,‌ ‌ ‌\n○Historic,‌ ‌ ‌\n○Classical,‌ ‌and‌ ‌ ‌\n○Underwater,‌ ‌to‌ ‌name‌ ‌a‌ ‌few.‌ ‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌often‌ ‌overlap.‌ ‌The‌ ‌two‌ ‌main‌ ‌types‌ ‌are‌‌ ‌Prehistoric‌ ‌‌and‌‌ ‌Historic‌ ‌archaeology.‌ ‌ ‌\nHistoric‌ ‌archaeology‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌studies‌ ‌that‌ ‌portion‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌human‌ ‌past‌ ‌that‌ ‌has‌ ‌written‌ ‌records.‌ ‌ ‌\n○While‌ ‌it‌ ‌shares‌ ‌many‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌techniques‌ ‌used‌ ‌in‌ ‌prehistoric‌ ‌archaeology,‌ ‌written‌ ‌records‌ ‌give‌ ‌historic‌ ‌archaeology‌ ‌an‌ ‌advantage‌ ‌in‌ ‌its‌ ‌\nresearch.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Classical‌ ‌archaeology‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌considered‌ ‌a‌ ‌branch‌ ‌of‌ ‌historic‌ ‌archaeology‌ ‌that‌ ‌studies‌ ‌the‌ ‌ancient‌ ‌civilizations‌ ‌of‌ ‌Mesopotamia‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nMediterranean,‌ ‌including‌ ‌Greece‌ ‌and‌ ‌Rome.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Egyptology‌‌ ‌can‌ ‌also‌ ‌be‌ ‌considered‌ ‌a‌ ‌branch‌ ‌of‌ ‌historic‌ ‌archaeology.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌North‌ ‌America,‌ ‌historic‌ ‌archaeologists‌ ‌study‌ ‌colonial‌ ‌sites‌ ‌like‌ ‌Jamestown‌ ‌or‌ ‌Salem,‌ ‌or‌ ‌Civil‌ ‌War‌ ‌sites‌ ‌like‌ ‌the‌ ‌Gettysburg‌ ‌Battlefield.‌ ‌\nPrehistoric‌ ‌archaeology‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌prehistory,‌ ‌or‌ ‌the‌ ‌period‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌history‌ ‌before‌ ‌written‌ ‌records‌ ‌existed.‌ ‌This‌ ‌comprises‌ ‌most‌ ‌of‌ ‌our‌ ‌human‌ ‌\npast.‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌human‌ ‌family‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌traced‌ ‌back‌ ‌at‌ ‌least‌ ‌five‌ ‌million‌ ‌years.‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌first‌ ‌modern‌ ‌humans‌ ‌appeared‌ ‌about‌ ‌fifty‌ ‌thousand‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Humans‌ ‌did‌ ‌not‌ ‌start‌ ‌writing‌ ‌things‌ ‌down‌ ‌until‌ ‌5,200‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago.‌ ‌That‌ ‌leaves‌ ‌many‌ ‌thousands‌ ‌of‌ ‌years‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌experience‌ ‌that‌ ‌was‌ ‌not‌ ‌\nrecorded.‌ ‌\nPrinciple‌ ‌of‌ ‌Prehistoric‌ ‌Archeology‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌also‌ ‌has‌ ‌a‌ ‌distinctive‌ ‌set‌ ‌of‌ ‌procedures‌ ‌for‌ ‌analysing‌ ‌material‌ ‌remains‌ ‌so‌ ‌that‌ ‌archaeologists‌ ‌can‌ ‌reconstruct‌ ‌their‌ ‌ecological‌ ‌settings.‌ ‌\n227‌ ‌\n○Prehistoric‌ ‌archaeology‌ ‌also‌ ‌has‌ ‌divisions.who‌ ‌concentrate‌ ‌on‌ ‌specific‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌and‌ ‌time‌ ‌periods.‌ ‌There‌ ‌are:‌ ‌\n■Paleoindian‌ ‌archaeologists‌ ‌who‌ ‌study‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌populations‌ ‌that‌ ‌migrated‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌Americas.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Mesoamerican‌ ‌archaeologists,‌ ‌ ‌\n■Southwestern‌ ‌archaeologists,‌ ‌ ‌\n■South‌ ‌American‌ ‌archaeologists,‌ ‌and‌ ‌many‌ ‌more,‌ ‌\n●As‌ ‌a‌ ‌scientific‌ ‌discipline‌ ‌prehistoric‌ ‌archaeology‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌recent‌ ‌intellectual‌ ‌development.‌ ‌In‌ ‌fact‌ ‌till‌ ‌1833,‌ ‌there‌ ‌was‌ ‌no‌ ‌term‌ ‌like‌ ‌prehistory.‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌term‌ ‌was‌ ‌used‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌time‌ ‌by‌ ‌Tournel‌ ‌and‌ ‌then‌ ‌in‌ ‌1851,‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌Daniel‌ ‌Wilson‌ ‌who‌ ‌used‌ ‌the‌ ‌word‌ ‌in‌ ‌his‌ ‌book‌ ‌\"The‌ ‌\nArchaeology‌ ‌and‌ ‌Prehistoric‌ ‌Annals‌ ‌of‌ ‌Scotland\"‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n■But‌ ‌within‌ ‌a‌ ‌few‌ ‌decades,‌ ‌especially‌ ‌after‌ ‌the‌ ‌Second‌ ‌World‌ ‌War,‌ ‌the‌ ‌subject‌ ‌has‌ ‌developed‌ ‌tremendously.‌ ‌ ‌\n■As‌ ‌a‌ ‌result‌ ‌several‌ ‌new‌ ‌subfields‌ ‌or‌ ‌approaches‌ ‌have‌ ‌emerged‌ ‌which‌ ‌gave‌ ‌birth‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌concept‌ ‌like:‌ ‌\n●New‌ ‌Archaeology,‌ ‌ ‌\n●Ethnoarchaeology/‌ ‌Ethno-Archaeology,‌ ‌ ‌\n●Social‌ ‌Archaeology,‌ ‌ ‌\n●Environmental‌ ‌Archaeology,‌ ‌ ‌\n●Salvage‌ ‌Archaeology,‌ ‌ ‌\n●Underwater/‌ ‌Marine‌ ‌Archaeology,‌ ‌ ‌\n●Forensic‌ ‌Archaeology,‌ ‌ ‌\n●Cognitive‌ ‌Archaeology,‌ ‌ ‌\n●Action‌ ‌Archaeology‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌ ‌\n○All‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌new‌ ‌areas‌ ‌mainly‌ ‌concentrate‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌reconstruction‌ ‌of‌ ‌total‌ ‌life‌ ‌ways‌ ‌of‌ ‌man's‌ ‌prehistoric‌ ‌past.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nScope‌ ‌of‌ ‌Prehistoric‌ ‌Archaeology‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌has‌ ‌contributed‌ ‌a‌ ‌lot‌ ‌not‌ ‌only‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌antiquities‌ ‌or‌ ‌relics‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌past‌ ‌societies‌ ‌but‌ ‌also‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌modern‌ ‌people‌ ‌or‌ ‌\ncontemporary‌ ‌societies‌ ‌with‌ ‌simple‌ ‌Technology‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌light‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌practise‌ ‌set‌ ‌during‌ ‌Prehistoric‌ ‌time.‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌example:‌‌ ‌Megalithism‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌using‌ ‌Megaliths‌ ‌to‌ ‌create‌ ‌monuments‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌dead‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌phenomena‌ ‌in‌ ‌most‌ ‌parts‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌world.‌ ‌\n●But‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌still‌ ‌practiced‌ ‌by‌ ‌different‌ ‌tribal‌ ‌communities‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌way‌ ‌or‌ ‌in‌ ‌some‌ ‌modified‌ ‌form‌ ‌in‌ ‌North‌ ‌East‌ ‌India,‌ ‌specially‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nNagaland,‌ ‌Manipur‌ ‌and‌ ‌Meghalaya.‌ ‌\n●Megalithism‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌living‌ ‌tradition‌ ‌among‌ ‌these‌ ‌tribal‌ ‌communities.‌ ‌\n ‌\nOld‌ ‌world‌ ‌and‌ ‌New‌ ‌world‌ ‌archeology‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌Europe,‌ ‌archaeology‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌a‌ ‌subfield‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropology,‌ ‌but‌ ‌of‌ ‌history.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌is‌ ‌because‌ ‌most‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Old‌ ‌World‌ ‌had‌ ‌written‌ ‌languages.‌ ‌ ‌\n○But‌ ‌archaeologists‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌New‌ ‌World‌ ‌did‌ ‌not‌ ‌have‌ ‌that‌ ‌resource,‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌exception‌ ‌of‌ ‌Mesoamerican‌ ‌archaeologists‌ ‌studying‌ ‌the‌ ‌Maya‌ ‌\nwhose‌ ‌hieroglyphic‌ ‌language‌ ‌has‌ ‌only‌ ‌recently‌ ‌been‌ ‌deciphered.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Because‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌difference,‌ ‌New‌ ‌World‌ ‌archaeologists‌ ‌have‌ ‌more‌ ‌in‌ ‌common‌ ‌with‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌than‌ ‌they‌ ‌do‌ ‌with‌ ‌historians‌ ‌in‌ ‌many‌ ‌\ncases.‌ ‌ ‌\n228‌ ‌\n●But‌ ‌when‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌various‌ ‌branches‌ ‌are‌ ‌boiled‌ ‌down,‌ ‌they‌ ‌all‌ ‌must‌ ‌rely‌ ‌on‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌archaeological‌ ‌record.‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌means‌ ‌artifacts,‌ ‌the‌ ‌place‌ ‌they‌ ‌were‌ ‌found,‌ ‌and‌ ‌with‌ ‌what‌ ‌they‌ ‌were‌ ‌found.‌ ‌Even‌ ‌in‌ ‌sites‌ ‌for‌ ‌which‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌written‌ ‌records,‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌\ngreat‌ ‌deal‌ ‌of‌ ‌information‌ ‌left‌ ‌out.‌ ‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌example‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌ruins‌ ‌of‌ ‌Pompeii‌ ‌and‌ ‌Herculaneum.‌ ‌We‌ ‌have‌ ‌dramatic‌ ‌accounts‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌Roman‌ ‌historians‌ ‌about‌ ‌what‌ ‌happened‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nthese‌ ‌communities‌ ‌when‌ ‌Vesuvius‌ ‌erupted,‌ ‌but‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌not‌ ‌until‌ ‌archaeologists‌ ‌began‌ ‌to‌ ‌uncover‌ ‌Pompeii‌ ‌and‌ ‌Herculaneum‌ ‌that‌ ‌we‌ ‌really‌ ‌began‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nunderstand‌ ‌this‌ ‌catastrophic‌ ‌event‌ ‌and‌ ‌perhaps‌ ‌more‌ ‌importantly,‌ ‌how‌ ‌Romans‌ ‌lived‌ ‌their‌ ‌everyday‌ ‌lives.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Archaeologists‌ ‌use‌ ‌many‌ ‌kinds‌ ‌of‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌to‌ ‌reconstruct‌ ‌the‌ ‌past.‌ ‌The‌ ‌excavations‌ ‌at‌ ‌Pompeii‌ ‌utilized‌ ‌the‌ ‌classical‌ ‌written‌ ‌accounts,‌ ‌state‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌the‌ ‌art‌ ‌geology‌ ‌to‌ ‌understand‌ ‌the‌ ‌layers‌ ‌of‌ ‌volcanic‌ ‌debris,‌ ‌physical‌ ‌and‌ ‌forensic‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌to‌ ‌study‌ ‌the‌ ‌human‌ ‌remains,‌ ‌and‌ ‌art‌ ‌conservators‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌uncover‌ ‌the‌ ‌beauty‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌Roman‌ ‌city‌ ‌that‌ ‌was‌ ‌frozen‌ ‌in‌ ‌time.‌ ‌\nSo‌ ‌how‌ ‌do‌ ‌archaeologists‌ ‌study‌ ‌the‌ ‌past?‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌record‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌past,‌ ‌or‌ ‌archaeological‌ ‌record,‌ ‌is‌ ‌fragmentary‌ ‌at‌ ‌best.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Most‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌material‌ ‌objects‌ ‌left‌ ‌behind‌ ‌are‌ ‌perishable.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Organic‌ ‌materials‌ ‌like‌ ‌food‌ ‌or‌ ‌clothing‌ ‌decay‌ ‌and‌ ‌disappear.‌ ‌ ‌\n●But‌ ‌some‌ ‌artifacts,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌pottery,‌ ‌stone,‌ ‌and‌ ‌bone‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌as‌ ‌perishable,‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌great‌ ‌deal‌ ‌of‌ ‌information‌ ‌about‌ ‌past‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌\ngleaned‌ ‌from‌ ‌them.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Stone‌ ‌tools‌ ‌can‌ ‌tell‌ ‌archaeologists‌ ‌about‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌food‌ ‌resources‌ ‌utilized‌ ‌–‌ ‌flaked‌ ‌stone‌ ‌projectile‌ ‌points‌ ‌for‌ ‌hunting,‌ ‌ground‌ ‌stone‌ ‌for‌ ‌\ngrinding‌ ‌corn.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Different‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌structures‌ ‌can‌ ‌tell‌ ‌archaeologists‌ ‌about‌ ‌social‌ ‌organization.‌ ‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌pithouse,‌ ‌for‌ ‌instance,‌ ‌indicates‌ ‌a‌ ‌small‌ ‌family‌ ‌unit‌ ‌while‌ ‌a‌ ‌pueblo‌ ‌indicates‌ ‌a‌ ‌much‌ ‌larger‌ ‌and‌ ‌more‌ ‌complex‌ ‌social‌ ‌group.‌ ‌ ‌\n●And‌ ‌an‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌of‌ ‌when‌ ‌certain‌ ‌artifacts‌ ‌appear‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌archaeological‌ ‌record‌ ‌tells‌ ‌archaeologists‌ ‌when‌ ‌a‌ ‌site‌ ‌was‌ ‌occupied.‌ ‌\n●Perhaps‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌important‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌the‌ ‌past‌ ‌is‌ ‌how‌ ‌artifacts‌ ‌are‌ ‌placed‌ ‌in‌ ‌time‌ ‌and‌ ‌space.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌is‌ ‌called‌‌ ‌context.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌geological‌ ‌law‌ ‌of‌ ‌association,‌ ‌which‌ ‌states‌ ‌that‌ ‌objects‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌geological‌ ‌level‌ ‌are‌ ‌contemporary‌ ‌with‌ ‌each‌ ‌\nother.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Also,‌ ‌objects‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌lower‌ ‌layers‌ ‌are‌ ‌older‌ ‌than‌ ‌those‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌above‌ ‌them‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌geological‌ ‌law‌ ‌of‌ ‌superposition.‌ ‌ ‌\n○These‌ ‌laws‌ ‌help‌ ‌the‌ ‌archaeologists‌ ‌to‌ ‌establish‌ ‌artifacts‌ ‌within‌ ‌a‌ ‌framework‌ ‌of‌ ‌time‌ ‌and‌ ‌space.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Context‌ ‌is‌ ‌everything‌ ‌to‌ ‌an‌ ‌archaeologist.‌ ‌Without‌ ‌it‌ ‌artifacts‌ ‌are‌ ‌just‌ ‌objects‌ ‌that‌ ‌provide‌ ‌little‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌general‌ ‌information‌ ‌about‌ ‌their‌ ‌\nfunction‌ ‌or‌ ‌the‌ ‌people‌ ‌who‌ ‌made‌ ‌them.‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌example‌,‌ ‌the‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌ceramic‌ ‌vessel‌ ‌can‌ ‌indicate‌ ‌its‌ ‌function.‌ ‌A‌ ‌jar‌ ‌could‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌used‌ ‌for‌ ‌storage‌ ‌or‌ ‌cooking.‌ ‌Where‌ ‌the‌ ‌jar‌ ‌was‌ ‌\nfound‌ ‌–‌ ‌near‌ ‌a‌ ‌hearth‌ ‌–‌ ‌could‌ ‌further‌ ‌point‌ ‌toward‌ ‌a‌ ‌cooking‌ ‌function.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Some‌ ‌artifacts,‌ ‌like‌ ‌projectile‌ ‌points,‌ ‌stone‌ ‌knives,‌ ‌or‌ ‌ax‌ ‌blades‌ ‌demonstrate‌ ‌their‌ ‌function‌ ‌more‌ ‌clearly,‌ ‌but‌ ‌the‌ ‌function‌ ‌of‌ ‌others‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌\nmuch‌ ‌less‌ ‌clear,‌ ‌at‌ ‌least‌ ‌to‌ ‌modern‌ ‌eyes.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌famous‌ ‌“Dancing‌ ‌girl”‌ ‌figurines‌ ‌from‌ ‌Harappa.‌ ‌Animal‌ ‌effigies‌ ‌made‌ ‌of‌ ‌stone‌ ‌or‌ ‌bone‌ ‌or‌ ‌ceramic‌ ‌are‌ ‌also‌ ‌examples‌ ‌of‌ ‌objects‌ ‌whose‌ ‌\npurpose‌ ‌is‌ ‌unknown.‌ ‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌artifacts‌ ‌are‌ ‌often‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to‌ ‌as‌ ‌ritual,‌ ‌ceremonial,‌ ‌symbolic,‌ ‌or‌ ‌artistic‌ ‌by‌ ‌archaeologists‌ ‌for‌ ‌lack‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌better‌ ‌word.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌ ‌\n229‌ ‌\nRelationship‌ ‌of‌ ‌Prehistoric‌ ‌Archeology‌ ‌with‌ ‌Physical‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌\n●Both‌ ‌physical‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌and‌ ‌prehistoric‌ ‌archaeologists‌ ‌may‌ ‌closely‌ ‌work‌ ‌while‌ ‌studying‌ ‌ancient‌ ‌tools,‌ ‌associated‌ ‌finds‌ ‌including‌ ‌fossil‌ ‌\nremains‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌activities‌ ‌of‌ ‌early‌ ‌man,‌ ‌to‌ ‌learn‌ ‌the‌ ‌earlier‌ ‌behavior‌ ‌of‌ ‌man‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌to‌ ‌reconstruct‌ ‌the‌ ‌prehistoric‌ ‌cultures.‌ ‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌L.G.‌ ‌Freeman‌ ‌\"within‌ ‌the‌ ‌field‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropology,‌ ‌the‌ ‌discipline‌ ‌called‌ ‌palaeoanthropology,‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌which‌ ‌attempts‌ ‌to‌ ‌\ndiscover,‌ ‌describe‌ ‌and‌ ‌interpret‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌physical‌ ‌and‌ ‌behavioral‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌sapiens‌ ‌and‌ ‌his‌ ‌hominid‌ ‌ancestors‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nrelatives\".‌ ‌ ‌\n●Thus‌ ‌it‌ ‌embraces‌ ‌scholars‌ ‌who‌ ‌called‌ ‌themselves‌ ‌as‌ ‌'Physical‌ ‌anthropologists'‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌one‌ ‌hand‌ ‌and‌ ‌'Archaeologists‌ ‌or‌ ‌Prehistorians'‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nother.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nRelationship‌ ‌of‌ ‌Prehistoric‌ ‌Archaeology‌ ‌with‌ ‌Social/cultural‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌\n●One‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌important‌ ‌aims‌ ‌of‌ ‌modern‌ ‌archaeological‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌is‌ ‌to‌ ‌reconstruct‌ ‌the‌ ‌total‌ ‌life‌ ‌ways‌ ‌as‌ ‌far‌ ‌as‌ ‌possible.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Modern‌ ‌prehistorians‌ ‌not‌ ‌only‌ ‌try‌ ‌to‌ ‌reconstruct‌ ‌the‌ ‌daily‌ ‌life‌ ‌and‌ ‌customs‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌prehistoric‌ ‌people,‌ ‌but‌ ‌also‌ ‌try‌ ‌to‌ ‌know‌ ‌the‌ ‌changing‌ ‌\naspects‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌raise‌ ‌questions‌ ‌like‌ ‌how‌ ‌culture‌ ‌changes‌ ‌and‌ ‌why.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌do‌ ‌so,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌found‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌remains‌ ‌that‌ ‌they‌ ‌dug‌ ‌have‌ ‌their‌ ‌closest‌ ‌counterpart‌ ‌among‌ ‌living‌ ‌primitives,‌ ‌rather‌ ‌than‌ ‌among‌ ‌civilized‌ ‌\npeople.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Therefore‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌natural‌ ‌for‌ ‌them‌ ‌to‌ ‌come‌ ‌to‌ ‌Anthropologist‌ ‌and‌ ‌especially‌ ‌social‌ ‌anthropologist‌ ‌who‌ ‌gathered‌ ‌information‌ ‌on‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌\npeople.‌ ‌\n●Like‌ ‌social‌ ‌anthropologists,‌ ‌prehistorians‌ ‌also‌ ‌live‌ ‌among‌ ‌those‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌tribes,‌ ‌observe‌ ‌their‌ ‌tool‌ ‌making‌ ‌technique,‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌aspects‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nlife‌ ‌which‌ ‌throw‌ ‌a‌ ‌flood‌ ‌of‌ ‌light‌ ‌regarding‌ ‌their‌ ‌prehistoric‌ ‌counterparts.‌ ‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌example‌,‌ ‌the‌ ‌dry‌ ‌farming‌ ‌method‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌practiced‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌hills‌ ‌of‌ ‌North‌ ‌east‌ ‌India‌ ‌would‌ ‌illustrate‌ ‌the‌ ‌ancient‌ ‌method‌ ‌of‌ ‌Neolithic‌ ‌\nagriculture.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌circular‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌huts‌ ‌used‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌present‌ ‌day‌ ‌village‌ ‌folk‌ ‌in‌ ‌Bellary‌ ‌district‌ ‌of‌ ‌Karnataka‌ ‌talked‌ ‌well‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌similar‌ ‌ones‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nNeolithic‌ ‌strata‌ ‌at‌ ‌Tekalakotta.‌ ‌\n230‌ ‌\n●Here‌ ‌archaeologists‌ ‌and‌ ‌ethnologists‌ ‌combine‌ ‌together‌ ‌in‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌get‌ ‌insight‌ ‌about‌ ‌the‌ ‌past‌ ‌life‌ ‌ways.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nChronology‌ ‌:‌ ‌Relative‌ ‌and‌ ‌Absolute‌ ‌Dating‌ ‌methods‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nDefinition‌ ‌\n●Chronology‌ ‌is‌ ‌defined‌ ‌as‌ ‌‌the‌ ‌management‌ ‌of‌ ‌past‌ ‌events‌ ‌in‌ ‌time‌ ‌of‌ ‌occurrence.‌ ‌\nChronology‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌emergence‌ ‌of‌ ‌man‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌process‌ ‌of‌ ‌biological‌ ‌and‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌story‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌long‌ ‌span‌ ‌of‌ ‌time.‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌archeologists‌ ‌and‌ ‌prehistorians‌ ‌who‌ ‌deal‌ ‌with‌ ‌that‌ ‌long‌ ‌history‌ ‌of‌ ‌man,‌ ‌time‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌important‌ ‌consideration.‌ ‌\n●Chronology‌ ‌plays‌ ‌a‌ ‌central‌ ‌role‌ ‌in‌ ‌prehistory‌ ‌and‌ ‌helps‌ ‌us‌ ‌to‌ ‌understand‌ ‌about‌ ‌their‌ ‌relative‌ ‌timings‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌changing‌ ‌human‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌\n231‌ ‌\n●Chronology‌ ‌helps‌ ‌in‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌prehistory‌ ‌by‌ ‌developing‌ ‌relative‌ ‌and‌ ‌absolute‌ ‌chronologies‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌pottery‌ ‌techniques‌ ‌and‌ ‌styles.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌helps‌ ‌to‌ ‌identify‌ ‌the‌ ‌likely‌ ‌environmental‌ ‌and‌ ‌life‌ ‌conditions‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌tool‌ ‌technology‌ ‌and‌ ‌tool‌ ‌types‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n●Thus,‌ ‌‌chronology‌ ‌acts‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌back‌ ‌bone‌ ‌for‌ ‌historical‌ ‌events‌ ‌and‌ ‌helps‌ ‌us‌ ‌to‌ ‌narrate‌ ‌and‌ ‌correlate‌ ‌the‌ ‌prehistory‌ ‌events‌ ‌to‌ ‌frame‌ ‌a‌ ‌bigger‌ ‌\npicture‌ ‌and‌ ‌understand‌ ‌our‌ ‌past.‌ ‌\n○Therefore,‌ ‌whenever‌ ‌any‌ ‌kind‌ ‌of‌ ‌prehistoric‌ ‌remains‌ ‌are‌ ‌recovered,‌ ‌a‌ ‌very‌ ‌common‌ ‌question‌ ‌comes‌ ‌into‌ ‌mind‌ ‌is‌ ‌that,‌ ‌How‌ ‌old‌ ‌is‌ ‌it?‌ ‌\nWhether‌ ‌it‌ ‌belongs‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌palaeolithic‌ ‌period‌ ‌of‌ ‌some‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌old‌ ‌or‌ ‌it‌ ‌belongs‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌comparatively‌ ‌recent‌ ‌chalcolithic‌ ‌period‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nonly‌ ‌some‌ ‌thousand‌ ‌years‌ ‌old?‌ ‌\n○To‌ ‌get‌ ‌the‌ ‌answer‌ ‌we‌ ‌have‌ ‌to‌ ‌rely‌ ‌on‌ ‌various‌ ‌dating‌ ‌methods‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌available‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌prehistorians.‌ ‌\n●Any‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌origins‌ ‌of‌ ‌humans‌ ‌must‌ ‌be‌ ‌set‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌chronological‌ ‌context.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Prehistoric‌ ‌archaeologists‌ ‌use‌ ‌several‌ ‌methods‌ ‌to‌ ‌assign‌ ‌ages‌ ‌to‌ ‌events‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌past.‌ ‌\n● ‌Knowledge‌ ‌on‌ ‌various‌ ‌dating‌ ‌methods,‌ ‌therefore,‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌very‌ ‌essential‌ ‌aspect‌ ‌of‌ ‌prehistoric‌ ‌archaeological‌ ‌studies.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nTypes‌ ‌of‌ ‌Dating‌ ‌\nThere‌ ‌are‌ ‌mainly‌ ‌two‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌dating;‌ ‌ ‌\ni)‌ ‌‌Relative‌ ‌Dating‌ ‌\n ‌ii)‌‌ ‌Absolute‌ ‌‌or‌‌ ‌Chronometric‌ ‌Dating.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n1.Relative‌ ‌Dating:‌ ‌ ‌\n○Relative‌ ‌dating‌ ‌fixes‌ ‌a‌ ‌time‌ ‌frame‌ ‌in‌ ‌relation‌ ‌to‌ ‌other‌ ‌strata‌ ‌or‌ ‌material‌ ‌and‌ ‌not‌ ‌in‌ ‌absolute‌ ‌dates‌ ‌in‌ ‌numbers.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌can‌ ‌only‌ ‌define‌ ‌antiquity‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌older‌ ‌or‌ ‌younger‌ ‌than‌ ‌something‌ ‌else‌ ‌and‌ ‌makes‌ ‌it‌ ‌possible‌ ‌to‌ ‌arrange‌ ‌a‌ ‌series‌ ‌of‌ ‌things‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nproper‌ ‌chronological‌ ‌order.‌ ‌ ‌\n232‌ ‌\n○But‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌difficult‌ ‌to‌ ‌know‌ ‌the‌ ‌total‌ ‌time‌ ‌span‌ ‌involved‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌intervals‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌things.‌ ‌\n■Stratigraphy‌ ‌\n■Typology‌ ‌\n■Cross‌ ‌dating‌ ‌\n■Sequence‌ ‌dating‌ ‌\n■Fluorine,‌ ‌uranium‌ ‌and‌ ‌nitrogen‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌\n■Palaeontology‌ ‌\n■Palynology‌ ‌\n■Patination‌ ‌\n ‌\n2.Absolute‌ ‌Dating:‌ ‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌techniques‌ ‌exhibit‌ ‌chronology‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌years.‌ ‌It‌ ‌offers‌ ‌precise‌ ‌and‌ ‌accurate‌ ‌dating.‌ ‌There‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌marginal‌ ‌errors‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌\nalmost‌ ‌negligible.‌ ‌\n○Carbon‌ ‌Dating‌ ‌\n○Potassium-‌ ‌argon‌ ‌Dating‌ ‌\n○Thermoluminescence‌ ‌\n○Dendrochronology‌ ‌\n○Electron‌ ‌Spin‌ ‌Resonance‌ ‌\n○Fission‌ ‌Track‌ ‌Dating‌ ‌\n○Paleomagnetic‌ ‌dating‌ ‌\n○Varve‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌\n○Amino‌ ‌Acid‌ ‌Racemization.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌addition‌ ‌\n233‌ ‌\n ‌\n234‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n235‌ ‌\nRelative‌ ‌Dating:‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Stratigraphy‌ ‌\n○Stratigraphy‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌series‌ ‌of‌ ‌layers‌ ‌that‌ ‌exist‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌horizontal‌ ‌dimension,‌ ‌studied‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌vertical‌ ‌time‌ ‌dimension.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌method‌ ‌is‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌basic‌ ‌geological‌ ‌principle‌ ‌that‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌layers,‌ ‌the‌ ‌earlier‌ ‌deposit‌ ‌lies‌ ‌under‌ ‌later‌ ‌deposit.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Typology‌ ‌\n○An‌ ‌archaeological‌ ‌site‌ ‌mainly‌ ‌consists‌ ‌of‌ ‌artefacts‌ ‌and‌ ‌tools.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌tools‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌site‌ ‌are‌ ‌classified‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌form‌ ‌or‌ ‌shape‌ ‌and‌ ‌accordingly‌ ‌different‌ ‌categories‌ ‌or‌ ‌types‌ ‌are‌ ‌made.‌ ‌\n○These‌ ‌are‌ ‌then‌ ‌arranged‌ ‌from‌ ‌simple‌ ‌to‌ ‌elaborate‌ ‌or‌ ‌from‌ ‌poorly‌ ‌preserved‌ ‌to‌ ‌well‌ ‌preserved‌ ‌or‌ ‌from‌ ‌crude‌ ‌to‌ ‌refine‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Then‌ ‌a‌ ‌relative‌ ‌antiquity‌ ‌is‌ ‌derived‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌presumption‌ ‌that‌ ‌simple,‌ ‌poorly‌ ‌preserved‌ ‌and‌ ‌crude‌ ‌tools‌ ‌are‌ ‌earlier‌ ‌than‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nelaborate,‌ ‌well‌ ‌preserved‌ ‌and‌ ‌refined‌ ‌ones.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Cross‌ ‌dating‌ ‌\n○Cross‌ ‌dating‌ ‌involves‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌comparison‌ ‌of‌ ‌artefacts‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌stratigraphic‌ ‌levels.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌method‌ ‌is‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌fact‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌similar‌ ‌artefacts‌ ‌are‌ ‌approximately‌ ‌contemporary.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌greater‌ ‌the‌ ‌similarity,‌ ‌the‌ ‌closer‌ ‌the‌ ‌ages‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n236‌ ‌\n○Certain‌ ‌artefacts‌ ‌like‌ ‌coins,‌ ‌pottery,‌ ‌arrowheads‌ ‌etc.,‌ ‌which‌ ‌have‌ ‌limited‌ ‌occurrence‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌given‌ ‌culture‌ ‌provide‌ ‌the‌ ‌best‌ ‌sample‌ ‌for‌ ‌\ncross‌ ‌dating.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Sequence‌ ‌dating‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌method‌ ‌is‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌fact‌ ‌that‌ ‌artefacts‌ ‌change‌ ‌in‌ ‌predictable‌ ‌ways‌ ‌through‌ ‌time.‌ ‌Among‌ ‌all‌ ‌other‌ ‌artefacts‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌found‌ ‌that‌ ‌\npottery‌ ‌changes‌ ‌with‌ ‌time‌ ‌frequently‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌sequence‌ ‌of‌ ‌pottery‌ ‌design‌ ‌can‌ ‌thus‌ ‌be‌ ‌worked‌ ‌out.‌ ‌\n○By‌ ‌detecting‌ ‌this‌ ‌trend‌ ‌of‌ ‌change,‌ ‌an‌ ‌archaeologist‌ ‌can‌ ‌trace‌ ‌associated‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌changes‌ ‌and‌ ‌make‌ ‌short‌ ‌term‌ ‌time‌ ‌distinction.‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌method‌ ‌was‌ ‌applied‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌great‌ ‌anthropologist,‌ ‌Kroeber‌ ‌in‌ ‌determining‌ ‌the‌ ‌relative‌ ‌age‌ ‌of‌ ‌some‌ ‌sites‌ ‌in‌ ‌south‌ ‌western‌ ‌United‌ ‌\nStates,‌ ‌Mexico‌ ‌and‌ ‌Peru.‌ ‌\n237‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Fluorine,‌ ‌uranium‌ ‌and‌ ‌nitrogen‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌\n○Prehistoric‌ ‌sites‌ ‌often‌ ‌consist‌ ‌of‌ ‌many‌ ‌bone‌ ‌remains.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌‌basic‌ ‌principle‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌method‌ ‌is‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌longer‌ ‌a‌ ‌bone‌ ‌will‌ ‌be‌ ‌placed‌ ‌in‌ ‌soil,‌ ‌the‌ ‌more‌ ‌fluorine‌ ‌will‌ ‌be‌ ‌caught‌ ‌in‌ ‌and‌ ‌hence‌ ‌can‌ ‌\nsuggest‌ ‌a‌ ‌relative‌ ‌date.‌ ‌\n○All‌ ‌bones‌ ‌whether‌ ‌of‌ ‌animal‌ ‌or‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌‌lying‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌level‌ ‌exhibit‌ ‌similar‌ ‌fluorine‌ ‌percentage‌ ‌in‌ ‌them‌.‌ ‌Therefore,‌ ‌if‌ ‌the‌ ‌quantity‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌fluorine‌ ‌remains‌ ‌same‌ ‌in‌ ‌both‌ ‌kinds‌ ‌of‌ ‌bone,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌sure‌ ‌that‌ ‌they‌ ‌belong‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌age.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌bones‌ ‌acquired‌ ‌from‌ ‌a‌ ‌lower‌ ‌level‌ ‌show‌ ‌more‌ ‌fluorine‌ ‌in‌ ‌them‌ ‌whereas‌ ‌the‌ ‌bone‌ ‌remains‌ ‌coming‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌upper‌ ‌level‌ ‌contains‌ ‌\nless‌ ‌fluorine.‌ ‌Relative‌ ‌ages‌ ‌of‌ ‌different‌ ‌bones‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌site‌ ‌thus‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌established‌ ‌by‌ ‌measuring‌ ‌their‌ ‌fluorine‌ ‌contents.‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌method‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌provide‌ ‌an‌ ‌absolute‌ ‌age‌ ‌because‌ ‌the‌ ‌amount‌ ‌of‌ ‌fluorine‌ ‌differs‌ ‌from‌ ‌soil‌ ‌to‌ ‌soil,‌ ‌which‌ ‌gives‌ ‌a‌ ‌differential‌ ‌\nrate‌ ‌of‌ ‌absorption.‌ ‌\n■Like‌ ‌fluorine,‌ ‌uranium‌ ‌or‌ ‌nitrogen‌ ‌content‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌bones‌ ‌also‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌measured.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Since‌ ‌fluorine‌ ‌and‌ ‌uranium‌ ‌levels‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌bone‌ ‌increase‌ ‌with‌ ‌time,‌ ‌while‌ ‌nitrogen‌ ‌decreases,‌ ‌such‌ ‌measurements‌ ‌help‌ ‌to‌ ‌place‌ ‌\nin‌ ‌sequence‌ ‌the‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌phases‌ ‌with‌ ‌which‌ ‌the‌ ‌different‌ ‌bones‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌associated.‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌fact‌ ‌the‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌of‌ ‌fluorine,‌ ‌uranium‌ ‌or‌ ‌nitrogen‌ ‌is‌ ‌regarded‌ ‌as‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌very‌ ‌important‌ ‌technique‌ ‌for‌ ‌relative‌ ‌dating.‌ ‌\n ‌\n238‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Palaeontology‌ ‌\n○Palaeontology,‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌fossilised‌ ‌remains‌ ‌of‌ ‌bones‌ ‌in‌ ‌archaeological‌ ‌sites‌ ‌also‌ ‌provide‌ ‌relative‌ ‌dates.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌method‌ ‌is‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌fact‌ ‌that‌ ‌some‌ ‌animals‌ ‌migrate‌ ‌or‌ ‌become‌ ‌extinct‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌change‌ ‌of‌ ‌climate.‌ ‌\n○That‌ ‌is,‌ ‌climate‌ ‌has‌ ‌a‌ ‌direct‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌presence‌ ‌or‌ ‌absence‌ ‌of‌ ‌certain‌ ‌animals.‌ ‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌example,‌ ‌‌if‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌forest‌ ‌elephant‌ ‌is‌ ‌found,‌ ‌one‌ ‌can‌ ‌assume‌ ‌a‌ ‌temperate‌ ‌climate,‌ ‌while‌ ‌the‌ ‌presence‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌‌steppe‌ ‌\nelephant‌‌ ‌indicates‌ ‌a‌ ‌steppes‌ ‌or‌ ‌tundra‌ ‌environment‌ ‌of‌ ‌almost‌ ‌glacial‌ ‌conditions.‌ ‌\n ‌\n○Likewise,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌found‌ ‌that‌ ‌in‌ ‌North‌ ‌America‌ ‌the‌ ‌arrival‌ ‌of‌ ‌man‌ ‌caused‌ ‌the‌ ‌extinction‌ ‌of‌ ‌mammals‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌mammoth,‌ ‌horse,‌ ‌camel‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌several‌ ‌species‌ ‌of‌ ‌bison.‌ ‌\n ‌\n239‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Palynology‌ ‌\n○Lennart‌ ‌Von‌ ‌Post,‌ ‌a‌ ‌Swedish‌ ‌Scientis‌t,‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌to‌ ‌develop‌ ‌this‌ ‌palaeobotanical‌ ‌method‌ ‌in‌ ‌1916.‌ ‌\n○By‌ ‌this‌ ‌method‌ ‌a‌ ‌microscopic‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌of‌ ‌pollen‌ ‌extracted‌ ‌from‌ ‌trees‌ ‌is‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌identify‌ ‌various‌ ‌trees‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌pollen‌ ‌diagram‌ ‌is‌ ‌\nprepared.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌pollen‌ ‌diagram‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌relative‌ ‌frequencies‌ ‌of‌ ‌various‌ ‌species‌ ‌are‌ ‌plotted‌ ‌helps‌ ‌in‌ ‌tracing‌ ‌out‌ ‌the‌ ‌changing‌ ‌vegetation‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌\narea.‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌very‌ ‌good‌ ‌example‌ ‌of‌ ‌application‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌pollen‌ ‌method‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌archaeological‌ ‌site‌ ‌at‌ ‌Choukoutien‌ ‌in‌ ‌China.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Patination‌ ‌\n○There‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌precise‌ ‌definition‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌term‌ ‌patination‌ ‌though‌ ‌it‌ ‌‌generally‌ ‌means‌ ‌chemical‌ ‌alteration‌ ‌of‌ ‌rock‌ ‌surfaces‌ ‌exposed‌ ‌to‌ ‌\natmospheric‌ ‌conditions.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌chemical‌ ‌alterations‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌stone‌ ‌are‌ ‌usually‌ ‌brought‌ ‌about‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌action‌ ‌of‌ ‌iron‌ ‌oxides‌ ‌through‌ ‌time.‌ ‌\n240‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌observation‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌amount‌ ‌of‌ ‌patina‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌stone‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌used‌ ‌at‌ ‌sites‌ ‌where‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌long‌ ‌sequence‌ ‌and‌ ‌demonstrates‌ ‌that‌ ‌\nthose‌ ‌tools‌ ‌which‌ ‌lie‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌bottom‌ ‌level‌ ‌may‌ ‌have‌ ‌more‌ ‌patina‌ ‌than‌ ‌those‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌upper‌ ‌levels.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌different‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌tools‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌river‌ ‌gravels,‌ ‌terraces‌ ‌of‌ ‌rivers‌ ‌or‌ ‌lakes‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌differentiated‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌relative‌ ‌amounts‌ ‌of‌ ‌patina‌ ‌on‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌which‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌relative‌ ‌ages‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌assigned‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌artefacts.‌ ‌\n○A.J.H.‌ ‌Goodwin‌ ‌who‌ ‌worked‌ ‌extensively‌ ‌on‌ ‌patination‌ ‌in‌ ‌1960‌ ‌lists‌ ‌many‌ ‌variables‌ ‌involved‌ ‌in‌ ‌patina‌ ‌formation‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌different‌ ‌\ntypes‌ ‌of‌ ‌patination.‌ ‌That‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌used‌ ‌fruitfully‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌tools‌ ‌from‌ ‌stratified‌ ‌deposits.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nAbsolute‌ ‌Dating:‌ ‌\n●Carbon‌ ‌Dating‌ ‌\n○Radiocarbon‌ ‌dating‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌chemical‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌determine‌ ‌the‌ ‌age‌ ‌of‌ ‌organic‌ ‌materials‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌their‌ ‌content‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌radioisotope‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌‌carbon‌ ‌14.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌method‌ ‌was‌ ‌developed‌ ‌by‌ ‌‌Willard‌ ‌F.‌ ‌Libby‌‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌team‌ ‌of‌ ‌scientists‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌University‌ ‌of‌ ‌Chicago.‌ ‌ ‌\n■In‌ ‌1960‌ ‌Libby‌ ‌received‌ ‌the‌ ‌Nobel‌ ‌Prize‌ ‌for‌ ‌his‌ ‌method‌ ‌to‌ ‌use‌ ‌Carbon-14‌ ‌for‌ ‌age‌ ‌determinations‌ ‌in‌ ‌archaeology,‌ ‌geology,‌ ‌\ngeophysics,‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌branches‌ ‌of‌ ‌science.‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌subsequently‌ ‌evolved‌ ‌into‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌powerful‌ ‌method‌ ‌of‌ ‌dating‌ ‌and‌ ‌Holocene‌ ‌artefacts‌ ‌and‌ ‌geologic‌ ‌events‌ ‌up‌ ‌to‌ ‌about‌ ‌50,000‌ ‌\nyears.‌ ‌\n○By‌ ‌radiocarbon‌ ‌method‌ ‌one‌ ‌can‌ ‌date‌ ‌different‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌organic‌ ‌or‌ ‌inorganic‌ ‌materials‌ ‌as‌ ‌long‌ ‌as‌ ‌they‌ ‌consist‌ ‌of‌ ‌carbon.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌method‌ ‌is‌ ‌actually‌ ‌devised‌ ‌to‌ ‌measure‌ ‌the‌ ‌amount‌ ‌of‌ ‌low‌ ‌level‌ ‌radioactivity‌ ‌of‌ ‌carbon‌ ‌remaining‌ ‌in‌ ‌ancient‌ ‌and‌ ‌dead‌ ‌material‌ ‌of‌ ‌\norganic‌ ‌origin.‌ ‌\n241‌ ‌\n○Radiocarbon‌ ‌(14C)‌ ‌dating‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌widely‌ ‌accepted‌ ‌technique‌ ‌for‌ ‌studying‌ ‌the‌ ‌chronological‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌of‌ ‌archaeological‌ ‌\ncomplexes.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Potassium-‌ ‌Argon‌ ‌(K-A40)‌ ‌Dating‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌method‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌a‌ ‌radioactive‌ ‌method.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌earth's‌ ‌crust‌ ‌contains‌ ‌potassium‌ ‌of‌ ‌which‌ ‌isotope‌ ‌K40‌ ‌decays‌ ‌to‌ ‌A40‌ ‌at‌ ‌a‌ ‌known‌ ‌rate.‌ ‌\n242‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌ratio‌ ‌of‌ ‌potassium‌ ‌to‌ ‌Argon‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌measured‌ ‌to‌ ‌ascertain‌ ‌the‌ ‌date‌ ‌of‌ ‌minerals‌ ‌and‌ ‌rocks‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌deposit.‌ ‌\n■This‌ ‌method‌ ‌is‌ ‌able‌ ‌to‌ ‌cover‌ ‌a‌ ‌wide‌ ‌range‌ ‌of‌ ‌time‌ ‌even‌ ‌far‌ ‌greater‌ ‌than‌ ‌the‌ ‌C-14‌ ‌method‌ ‌because‌ ‌the‌ ‌half‌ ‌life‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nradioactive‌ ‌potassium‌ ‌is‌ ‌1330‌ ‌million‌ ‌years.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌method‌ ‌has‌ ‌proved‌ ‌quite‌ ‌useful‌ ‌in‌ ‌dating‌ ‌some‌ ‌hominid‌ ‌fossils‌ ‌as‌ ‌employed‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌site‌ ‌of‌ ‌Olduvai‌ ‌Gorge‌ ‌in‌ ‌east‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌where‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nremains‌ ‌were‌ ‌as‌ ‌old‌ ‌as‌ ‌1.75‌ ‌million‌ ‌years.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌advantage‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌method‌ ‌is‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌works‌ ‌well‌ ‌in‌ ‌case‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌sites‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌500,000‌ ‌years‌ ‌old.‌ ‌ ‌\n■But‌ ‌the‌ ‌disadvantage‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌method‌ ‌is‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌applied‌ ‌to‌ ‌only‌ ‌those‌ ‌rocks‌ ‌and‌ ‌minerals‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌rich‌ ‌in‌ ‌potassium.‌ ‌\nTherefore‌ ‌the‌ ‌method‌ ‌is‌ ‌restricted‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌areas‌ ‌where‌ ‌volcanic‌ ‌rocks‌ ‌rich‌ ‌in‌ ‌potassium‌ ‌are‌ ‌available.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n243‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n244‌ ‌\n●Thermoluminescence(TL)‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌Thermoluminescence‌ ‌(TL)‌ ‌for‌ ‌dating‌ ‌purposes‌ ‌was‌ ‌developed‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌1960s‌ ‌mainly‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌Oxford‌ ‌Research‌ ‌Laboratory‌ ‌for‌ ‌\nArchaeology‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌History‌ ‌of‌ ‌Art‌ ‌by‌ ‌M.‌ ‌Aitken‌ ‌and‌ ‌co-‌ ‌workers.‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌is‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌fact‌ ‌that‌ ‌objects‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌pottery‌ ‌that‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌heated‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌past‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌dated‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌measurement‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌\nThermoluminescence‌ ‌(TL)‌ ‌glow.‌ ‌\n○Thermoluminescence‌ ‌(TL)‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌emitted‌ ‌light‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌pottery‌ ‌which‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌measured.‌ ‌\n■If‌ ‌the‌ ‌ground‌ ‌up‌ ‌pottery‌ ‌is‌ ‌reheated,‌ ‌it‌ ‌emits‌ ‌light.‌ ‌The‌ ‌phenomenon‌ ‌results‌ ‌from‌ ‌radio-active‌ ‌influence‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌metallic‌ ‌\nelements‌ ‌like‌ ‌uranium‌ ‌and‌ ‌potassium‌ ‌present‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌clay‌ ‌and‌ ‌surrounding‌ ‌soils.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌Thermoluminescence‌ ‌(TL)‌ ‌dating‌ ‌methods‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌results‌ ‌obtained‌ ‌could‌ ‌make‌ ‌it‌ ‌possible‌ ‌to‌ ‌provide‌ ‌a‌ ‌new‌ ‌chronological‌ ‌\nframework‌ ‌for‌ ‌archaeological‌ ‌and‌ ‌anthropological‌ ‌knowledge.‌ ‌\n■For‌ ‌example,‌ ‌the‌ ‌new‌ ‌chronology‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌Thermoluminescence‌ ‌(TL)‌ ‌dating‌ ‌enabled‌ ‌in‌ ‌revising‌ ‌some‌ ‌prior‌ ‌assumptions‌ ‌\nabout‌ ‌the‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌lithic‌ ‌industries‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌nature‌ ‌of‌ ‌hominids‌ ‌present‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Near‌ ‌East‌ ‌at‌ ‌various‌ ‌stages‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Middle‌ ‌\nPalaeolithic.‌ ‌\n ‌\nHow‌ ‌it‌ ‌works‌ ‌\n●TL‌ ‌is‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌fact‌ ‌that‌ ‌almost‌ ‌all‌ ‌natural‌ ‌minerals‌ ‌are‌ ‌thermoluminescent.‌ ‌Energy‌ ‌absorbed‌ ‌from‌ ‌ionizing‌ ‌\nradiation‌ ‌frees‌ ‌electrons‌ ‌to‌ ‌move‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌crystal‌ ‌lattice,‌ ‌some‌ ‌of‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌trapped‌ ‌at‌ ‌imperfections‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌\ncrystal‌ ‌lattice.‌ ‌Later,‌ ‌heating‌ ‌releases‌ ‌the‌ ‌trapped‌ ‌electrons,‌ ‌producing‌ ‌light.‌ ‌\n●Measuring‌ ‌the‌ ‌intensity‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌luminescence‌ ‌can‌ ‌determine‌ ‌how‌ ‌much‌ ‌time‌ ‌has‌ ‌passed‌ ‌since‌ ‌the‌ ‌last‌ ‌time‌ ‌the‌ ‌object‌ ‌\nwas‌ ‌heated.‌ ‌The‌ ‌light‌ ‌is‌ ‌proportional‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌amount‌ ‌of‌ ‌radiation‌ ‌absorbed‌ ‌since‌ ‌the‌ ‌material‌ ‌was‌ ‌last‌ ‌heated.‌ ‌Natural‌ ‌\nradioactivity‌ ‌causes‌ ‌latent‌ ‌thermoluminescence‌ ‌to‌ ‌build‌ ‌up‌ ‌so‌ ‌the‌ ‌older‌ ‌an‌ ‌object‌ ‌is,‌ ‌the‌ ‌more‌ ‌light‌ ‌is‌ ‌produced.‌ ‌\nTherefore,‌ ‌thermoluminescence‌ ‌dating‌ ‌is‌ ‌actually‌ ‌determining‌ ‌the‌ ‌last‌ ‌time‌ ‌a‌ ‌crystal‌ ‌was‌ ‌heated‌ ‌and‌ ‌electrons‌ ‌were‌ ‌\nreleased.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nElectron‌ ‌trapping‌ ‌\n245‌ ‌\n ‌\nEnergy‌ ‌absorbed‌ ‌from‌ ‌ionizing‌ ‌radiation‌ ‌frees‌ ‌electrons‌ ‌to‌ ‌move‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌crystal‌ ‌lattice,‌ ‌where‌ ‌some‌ ‌are‌ ‌trapped‌ ‌at‌ ‌\nimperfections.‌ ‌Later‌ ‌heating‌ ‌releases‌ ‌the‌ ‌trapped‌ ‌electrons,‌ ‌producing‌ ‌light‌ ‌whose‌ ‌intensity‌ ‌is‌ ‌proportional‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌amount‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌radiation‌ ‌absorbed.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Dendrochronology‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌age‌ ‌of‌ ‌wooden‌ ‌objects‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌determined‌ ‌by‌ ‌means‌ ‌of‌ ‌Dendrochronology‌ ‌or‌ ‌tree‌ ‌ring‌ ‌analysis.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌determines‌ ‌the‌ ‌calendar‌ ‌years‌ ‌of‌ ‌tree-ring‌ ‌formation‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌felling‌ ‌dates‌ ‌of‌ ‌trees,‌ ‌which‌ ‌helps‌ ‌to‌ ‌determine‌ ‌the‌ ‌age‌ ‌of‌ ‌wooden‌ ‌\nobjects‌ ‌with‌ ‌great‌ ‌precision.‌ ‌\n○Dendrochronology‌ ‌has‌ ‌therefore‌ ‌become‌ ‌well‌ ‌established‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌field‌ ‌of‌ ‌archaeology,‌ ‌art‌ ‌history‌ ‌and‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌heritage.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌method‌ ‌depends‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌fact‌ ‌that‌ ‌trees‌ ‌growing‌ ‌in‌ ‌temperate‌ ‌zones‌ ‌have‌ ‌clearly‌ ‌defined‌ ‌annual‌ ‌rings‌ ‌of‌ ‌growth.‌ ‌As‌ ‌these‌ ‌tree‌ ‌\nrings‌ ‌represent‌ ‌annual‌ ‌growth,‌ ‌merely‌ ‌by‌ ‌counting‌ ‌rings‌ ‌one‌ ‌can‌ ‌count‌ ‌the‌ ‌age‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌tree‌ ‌and‌ ‌hence‌ ‌its‌ ‌association.‌ ‌\n246‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Electron‌ ‌Spin‌ ‌Resonance‌ ‌(ESR)‌ ‌\n247‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌the‌ ‌last‌ ‌20‌ ‌years,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Electron‌ ‌Spin‌ ‌Resonance‌ ‌(ESR)‌ ‌dating‌ ‌method‌ ‌has‌ ‌allowed‌ ‌the‌ ‌establishment‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌chronological‌ ‌time‌ ‌frame‌ ‌\nover‌ ‌most‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌history‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌evolution.‌ ‌\n○Despite‌ ‌many‌ ‌difficulties‌ ‌found‌ ‌for‌ ‌ESR‌ ‌dating‌ ‌of‌ ‌bones‌ ‌and‌ ‌carbonates,‌ ‌tooth‌ ‌enamel‌ ‌dated‌ ‌by‌ ‌Electron‌ ‌Spin‌ ‌Resonance‌ ‌(ESR)‌ ‌has‌ ‌\nbeen‌ ‌proven‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌reliable‌ ‌method‌ ‌in‌ ‌its‌ ‌application‌ ‌to‌ ‌fossil‌ ‌teeth‌ ‌and‌ ‌quartz.‌ ‌\n○Both‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌latter‌ ‌materials‌ ‌have‌ ‌allowed‌ ‌dating‌ ‌of‌ ‌Early‌ ‌and‌ ‌Middle‌ ‌Pleistocene‌ ‌sites‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌datable‌ ‌using‌ ‌other‌ ‌methods.‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌particular,‌ ‌recent‌ ‌discoveries‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌remains‌ ‌in‌ ‌Western‌ ‌Europe‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌proposed‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌sites‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌earliest‌ ‌arrival‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nhumans‌ ‌there,‌ ‌and‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌dated‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌Early‌ ‌Pleistocene‌ ‌by‌ ‌Electron‌ ‌Spin‌ ‌Resonance‌ ‌(ESR)‌ ‌using‌ ‌quartz‌ ‌and‌ ‌tooth‌ ‌enamel.‌ ‌\n○Electron‌ ‌Spin‌ ‌Resonance‌ ‌(ESR)‌ ‌dates‌ ‌ranging‌ ‌between‌ ‌1.7‌ ‌and‌ ‌2.3‌ ‌Ma‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌proposed‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌South‌ ‌African‌ ‌sites‌ ‌Sterkfontein‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌Swartzkrans,‌ ‌indicating‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌whole‌ ‌Quaternary‌ ‌period‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌dated.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n248‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Paleomagnetic‌ ‌Dating‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌important‌ ‌means‌ ‌of‌ ‌cross‌ ‌checking‌ ‌the‌ ‌dates‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌constantly‌ ‌shifting‌ ‌nature‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌earth‌ ‌magnetic‌ ‌field,‌ ‌both‌ ‌in‌ ‌\ndirection‌ ‌and‌ ‌intensity.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌measurement‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌earth's‌ ‌magnetic‌ ‌field‌ ‌in‌ ‌several‌ ‌places‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌world‌ ‌for‌ ‌centuries‌ ‌has‌ ‌shown‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌varies‌ ‌with‌ ‌time.‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌studies‌ ‌have‌ ‌shown‌ ‌that‌ ‌a‌ ‌record‌ ‌of‌ ‌past‌ ‌magnetic‌ ‌field‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌angles‌ ‌of‌ ‌declination‌ ‌and‌ ‌dip‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌trapped‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nbaked‌ ‌clay.‌ ‌\n■When‌ ‌clay‌ ‌is‌ ‌heated‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌certain‌ ‌degree,‌ ‌the‌ ‌magnetic‌ ‌elements‌ ‌of‌ ‌baked‌ ‌clay‌ ‌realign‌ ‌themselves‌ ‌along‌ ‌lines‌ ‌dictated‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nintensity‌ ‌and‌ ‌character‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌magnetic‌ ‌field‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌earth‌ ‌at‌ ‌that‌ ‌time.‌ ‌\n■On‌ ‌cooling‌ ‌the‌ ‌magnetic‌ ‌elements‌ ‌are‌ ‌frozen‌ ‌and‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌recorded‌ ‌as‌ ‌long‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌clay‌ ‌is‌ ‌preserved.‌ ‌This‌ ‌is‌ ‌called‌ ‌remnant‌ ‌\nmagnetism.‌ ‌\n○When‌ ‌records‌ ‌of‌ ‌past‌ ‌angles‌ ‌of‌ ‌declination‌ ‌and‌ ‌dip‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌kept‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌possible‌ ‌to‌ ‌compare‌ ‌the‌ ‌values‌ ‌of‌ ‌historic‌ ‌records‌ ‌and‌ ‌arrive‌ ‌\nat‌ ‌the‌ ‌date‌ ‌of‌ ‌archaeological‌ ‌specimens‌ ‌of‌ ‌fired‌ ‌clay.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌method‌ ‌was‌ ‌used‌ ‌in‌ ‌Great‌ ‌Britain‌ ‌by‌ ‌Aitken‌ ‌in‌ ‌detail.‌ ‌It‌ ‌has‌ ‌also‌ ‌been‌ ‌used‌ ‌in‌ ‌Japan‌ ‌and‌ ‌Arizona.‌ ‌In‌ ‌‌India‌ ‌the‌ ‌method‌ ‌is‌ ‌applied‌ ‌\nin‌ ‌dating‌ ‌Karewa‌ ‌sediments‌ ‌in‌ ‌Kashmir.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌reliability‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌application‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌method‌ ‌depends‌ ‌on‌ ‌certain‌ ‌conditions‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌availability‌ ‌of‌ ‌good‌ ‌records‌ ‌of‌ ‌change‌ ‌of‌ ‌magnetic‌ ‌paths‌ ‌near‌ ‌the‌ ‌prehistoric‌ ‌sites,‌ ‌\n■Occurrence‌ ‌of‌ ‌series‌ ‌of‌ ‌already‌ ‌dated‌ ‌baked‌ ‌clay‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌area‌ ‌against‌ ‌which‌ ‌objects‌ ‌of‌ ‌unknown‌ ‌dates‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌dated.‌ ‌\n●Varve‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌\n○Varve‌ ‌analysis,‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌oldest‌ ‌dating‌ ‌methods‌ ‌which‌ ‌demonstrate‌ ‌seasonal‌ ‌variation‌ ‌and‌ ‌also‌ ‌reflect‌ ‌the‌ ‌climatic‌ ‌conditions‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nancient‌ ‌time.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌word‌ ‌varve‌ ‌in‌ ‌Swedish‌ ‌means‌ ‌annual‌ ‌layers‌ ‌of‌ ‌sediments‌ ‌deposited‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌bottom‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌lakes‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌runoff‌ ‌from‌ ‌melting‌ ‌glacial‌ ‌\nice.‌ ‌ ‌\n249‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌method‌ ‌is‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌relative‌ ‌thickness‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌varves‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌comparison‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌new‌ ‌sections‌ ‌as‌ ‌in‌ ‌tree‌ ‌ring‌ ‌analysis.‌ ‌\nFormation‌ ‌of‌ ‌varves‌ ‌depends‌ ‌on‌ ‌climatic‌ ‌variation.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌summer‌ ‌when‌ ‌ice‌ ‌melts‌ ‌coarse‌ ‌sediment‌ ‌deposits‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌bottom‌ ‌and‌ ‌in‌ ‌winter‌ ‌when‌ ‌the‌ ‌lake‌ ‌is‌ ‌frozen,‌ ‌the‌ ‌finer‌ ‌sediments‌ ‌deposit‌ ‌\nat‌ ‌the‌ ‌top.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌possible‌ ‌to‌ ‌measure‌ ‌the‌ ‌relative‌ ‌thickness‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌varves‌ ‌and‌ ‌obtain‌ ‌a‌ ‌series‌ ‌to‌ ‌which‌ ‌one‌ ‌can‌ ‌compare‌ ‌and‌ ‌correlate‌ ‌new‌ ‌\nsections‌ ‌as‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌discovered.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌application‌ ‌of‌ ‌varve‌ ‌dating‌ ‌is‌ ‌restricted‌ ‌by‌ ‌several‌ ‌factors.‌ ‌ ‌\n■First,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌because‌ ‌varve‌ ‌accumulation‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌only‌ ‌to‌ ‌glacial‌ ‌areas‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌world.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Second,‌ ‌many‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Pleistocene‌ ‌glacial‌ ‌areas‌ ‌have‌ ‌receded‌ ‌nowadays‌ ‌and‌ ‌are‌ ‌affecting‌ ‌the‌ ‌supply‌ ‌of‌ ‌sediments.‌ ‌Therefore‌ ‌\noutside‌ ‌Scandinavia‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌difficult‌ ‌to‌ ‌find‌ ‌a‌ ‌continuous‌ ‌sequence‌ ‌of‌ ‌varves‌ ‌reaching‌ ‌the‌ ‌present.‌ ‌The‌ ‌longest‌ ‌sequence‌ ‌known‌ ‌\ngoes‌ ‌back‌ ‌only‌ ‌17,000‌ ‌years.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Third,‌ ‌the‌ ‌varves‌ ‌may‌ ‌form‌ ‌frequently‌ ‌rather‌ ‌than‌ ‌annually‌ ‌depending‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌melting.‌ ‌\n○However,‌ ‌instead‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌limitations,‌ ‌varve‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌used‌ ‌indirectly‌ ‌for‌ ‌archaeological‌ ‌dating.‌ ‌It‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌used‌ ‌in‌ ‌Baltic‌ ‌area,‌ ‌\nNorth‌ ‌America,‌ ‌South‌ ‌America‌ ‌and‌ ‌Africa.‌ ‌In‌ ‌North‌ ‌America,‌ ‌Ernst‌ ‌Antevs‌ ‌has‌ ‌made‌ ‌several‌ ‌attempts‌ ‌to‌ ‌relate‌ ‌Pleistocene‌ ‌\ngeological‌ ‌formations‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌American‌ ‌Southwest‌ ‌to‌ ‌events‌ ‌that‌ ‌produced‌ ‌varves‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌northern‌ ‌parts‌ ‌of‌ ‌North‌ ‌America.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Fission‌ ‌Track‌ ‌Technique‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌technique‌ ‌dates‌ ‌material‌ ‌ranging‌ ‌from‌ ‌20‌ ‌years‌ ‌to‌ ‌1,000,000,000‌ ‌years‌ ‌before‌ ‌the‌ ‌present.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Fission‌ ‌track‌ ‌dating‌ ‌is‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌analyses‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌damage‌ ‌trails,‌ ‌or‌ ‌tracks,‌ ‌left‌ ‌by‌ ‌fission‌ ‌fragments‌ ‌in‌ ‌certain‌ ‌uranium-bearing‌ ‌minerals‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌glasses.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Amino‌ ‌Acid‌ ‌Racemisation‌ ‌Technique‌ ‌\n○Amino‌ ‌Acid‌ ‌Racemisation,‌ ‌a‌ ‌method‌ ‌of‌ ‌absolute‌ ‌dating‌ ‌applied‌ ‌to‌ ‌human‌ ‌fossils,‌ ‌was‌ ‌developed‌ ‌very‌ ‌recently.‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌is‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌fact‌ ‌that‌ ‌all‌ ‌living‌ ‌organisms‌ ‌have‌ ‌L-amino‌ ‌acid‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌protein‌ ‌and‌ ‌after‌ ‌death,‌ ‌and‌ ‌over‌ ‌a‌ ‌long‌ ‌period‌ ‌of‌ ‌time‌ ‌all‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌L-amino‌ ‌acids‌ ‌except‌ ‌glycine‌ ‌undergo‌ ‌change‌ ‌called‌ ‌racemisation‌ ‌and‌ ‌become‌ ‌non‌ ‌protein‌ ‌D-amino‌ ‌acid.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌proportion‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌D-amino‌ ‌acids‌ ‌increases‌ ‌with‌ ‌time.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Thus‌ ‌the‌ ‌age‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌skeletal‌ ‌materials‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌archaeological‌ ‌sites‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌estimated‌ ‌by‌ ‌determining‌ ‌the‌ ‌amount‌ ‌of‌ ‌change,‌ ‌\nracemisation‌ ‌that‌ ‌has‌ ‌occurred.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Amino‌ ‌Acid‌ ‌Racemisation‌ ‌(AAR)‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌useful‌ ‌comparative‌ ‌dating‌ ‌method‌ ‌with‌ ‌great‌ ‌potential,‌ ‌but‌ ‌it‌ ‌introduces‌ ‌problems‌ ‌of‌ ‌calibration‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌the‌ ‌requirement‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌intimate‌ ‌knowledge‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌palaeoenvironmental‌ ‌conditions‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌bone‌ ‌deposition‌ ‌site.‌ ‌\n250‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌addition‌ ‌\n251‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n252‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n253‌ ‌\n1.8‌ ‌(b)‌ ‌Cultural‌ ‌Evolution—Broad‌ ‌Outlines‌ ‌of‌ ‌Prehistoric‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌:‌ ‌Paleolithic,‌ ‌Mesolithic,‌ ‌Neolithic,‌ ‌Chalcolithic,‌ ‌Copper-Bronze‌ ‌Age,‌ ‌\nIron‌ ‌Age-‌ ‌Part-II‌ ‌\n ‌\nRewinding‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nWhat‌ ‌is‌ ‌Cultural‌ ‌Evolution?‌ ‌\n254‌ ‌\n●Cultural‌ ‌evolution,‌ ‌also‌ ‌called‌ ‌sociocultural‌ ‌evolution,‌ ‌the‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌one‌ ‌or‌ ‌more‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌from‌ ‌simpler‌ ‌to‌ ‌more‌ ‌complex‌ ‌forms.‌ ‌\n●Human‌ ‌culture‌ ‌encompasses‌ ‌ideas,‌ ‌behaviors,‌ ‌and‌ ‌artifacts‌ ‌that‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌learned‌ ‌and‌ ‌transmitted‌ ‌between‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌and‌ ‌can‌ ‌change‌ ‌over‌ ‌\ntime.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌Addition‌ ‌\n ‌\nHow‌ ‌Darwinian‌ ‌is‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌evolution?‌ ‌\n●Cultural‌ ‌Evolution‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌described‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌Darwinian‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌process‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌similar‌ ‌in‌ ‌key‌ ‌respects‌ ‌(but‌ ‌not‌ ‌identical)‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nbiological/genetic‌ ‌evolution.‌ ‌ ‌\n●More‌ ‌specifically,‌ ‌just‌ ‌as‌ ‌Darwin‌ ‌described‌ ‌biological/genetic‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌as‌ ‌comprising‌ ‌three‌ ‌key‌ ‌components––variation,‌ ‌\ncompetition‌ ‌(or‌ ‌selection),‌ ‌and‌ ‌inheritance––cultural‌ ‌change‌ ‌also‌ ‌comprises‌ ‌these‌ ‌same‌ ‌phenomena.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Yet‌ ‌while‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌described‌ ‌as‌ ‌Darwinian‌ ‌in‌ ‌this‌ ‌sense,‌ ‌the‌ ‌details‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌processes‌ ‌(e.g.,‌ ‌how‌ ‌variation‌ ‌is‌ ‌\ngenerated,‌ ‌or‌ ‌how‌ ‌information‌ ‌is‌ ‌transmitted)‌ ‌are‌ ‌likely‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌different‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌case‌ ‌compared‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌details‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nbiological/genetic‌ ‌evolution.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Bearing‌ ‌these‌ ‌differences‌ ‌in‌ ‌mind,‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌researchers‌ ‌have‌ ‌taken‌ ‌many‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌methods,‌ ‌tools,‌ ‌and‌ ‌concepts‌ ‌that‌ ‌\nbiologists‌ ‌have‌ ‌developed‌ ‌to‌ ‌explain‌ ‌biological‌ ‌diversity‌ ‌and‌ ‌complexity‌ ‌and‌ ‌used‌ ‌them‌ ‌to‌ ‌explain‌ ‌similar‌ ‌diversity‌ ‌and‌ ‌complexity‌ ‌\nin‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌systems.‌ ‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌include:‌ ‌\n○Phylogenetic‌ ‌methods‌ ‌to‌ ‌reconstruct‌ ‌“macroevolutionary”‌ ‌historical‌ ‌relations‌ ‌between‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌traits‌ ‌(e.g.,‌ ‌languages‌ ‌or‌ ‌\ntools),‌ ‌ethnographic‌ ‌field‌ ‌studies‌ ‌to‌ ‌document‌ ‌and‌ ‌explain‌ ‌contemporary‌ ‌cross-cultural‌ ‌variation,‌ ‌laboratory‌ ‌experiments‌ ‌to‌ ‌\ndetermine‌ ‌the‌ ‌small-scale‌ ‌details‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌“microevolution”‌ ‌(e.g.,‌ ‌how‌ ‌cognitive‌ ‌biases‌ ‌favor‌ ‌certain‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌over‌ ‌others‌ ‌or‌ ‌\nwhether‌ ‌we‌ ‌preferentially‌ ‌learn‌ ‌from‌ ‌certain‌ ‌people‌ ‌within‌ ‌a‌ ‌group),‌ ‌and‌ ‌mathematical‌ ‌models‌ ‌to‌ ‌explore‌ ‌the‌ ‌long-term‌ ‌and‌ ‌\npopulation-level‌ ‌consequences‌ ‌of‌ ‌those‌ ‌microevolutionary‌ ‌processes.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Given‌ ‌this‌ ‌interdisciplinary‌ ‌breadth,‌ ‌it‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌suggested‌ ‌that‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌theory‌ ‌may‌ ‌serve‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌synthetic‌ ‌framework‌ ‌for‌ ‌\n255‌ ‌\nunifying‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌sciences,‌ ‌just‌ ‌as‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌theory‌ ‌synthesized‌ ‌the‌ ‌biological‌ ‌sciences‌ ‌during‌ ‌the‌ ‌early‌ ‌20th‌ ‌century.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nBackground:‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌the‌ ‌book‌ ‌‌Primitive‌ ‌Culture‌ ‌Lubbock‌ ‌made‌ ‌notable‌ ‌contributions‌ ‌particularly‌ ‌for‌ ‌its‌ ‌inclusion‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌culture‌ ‌starting‌ ‌from‌ ‌palaeolithic‌ ‌to‌ ‌\niron‌ ‌age.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌Europe‌ ‌the‌ ‌studies‌ ‌of‌ ‌prehistoric‌ ‌culture‌ ‌formally‌ ‌began‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌work‌ ‌of‌ ‌‌Boucher-de-Perthes‌ ‌discovery‌ ‌of‌ ‌Chellean‌ ‌and‌ ‌Acheulian‌ ‌\nindustries‌ ‌of‌ ‌Europe.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Edward‌ ‌Lartet‌ ‌‌began‌ ‌a‌ ‌systematic‌ ‌work‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Dordogne‌ ‌region‌ ‌of‌ ‌France‌ ‌in‌ ‌1860.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌the‌ ‌Cro-magnon‌ ‌Man‌ ‌fossil‌ ‌(prehistoric‌ ‌man)‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌materials‌ ‌of‌ ‌Aurignacian‌ ‌culture‌ ‌in‌ ‌Europe.‌ ‌Similar‌ ‌developments‌ ‌also‌ ‌\ntook‌ ‌place‌ ‌in‌ ‌America,‌ ‌South‌ ‌Africa,‌ ‌East‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌and‌ ‌India.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌South‌ ‌East‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌Mr.‌ ‌and‌ ‌Mrs.‌ ‌Leakey‌ ‌were‌ ‌able‌ ‌to‌ ‌trace‌ ‌out‌ ‌the‌ ‌earliest‌ ‌human‌ ‌fossil‌ ‌and‌ ‌his‌ ‌material‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌India,‌ ‌Robert‌ ‌Bruce‌ ‌Foote‌ ‌was‌ ‌responsible‌ ‌for‌ ‌excavating‌ ‌the‌ ‌palaeolithic‌ ‌culture‌ ‌or‌ ‌culture‌ ‌of‌ ‌preliterate‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nUnderstanding‌ ‌Basic‌ ‌Chronology-‌ ‌Value‌ ‌Addition‌ ‌\n256‌ ‌\n257‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nTimeline:‌ ‌\n ‌\n258‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nThe‌ ‌Stone‌ ‌Age‌ ‌\n259‌ ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌Addition‌ ‌\n260‌ ‌\n ‌\nOld‌ ‌World‌ ‌\n●Stone‌ ‌Age‌ ‌\n○Lower‌ ‌Paleolithic‌ ‌\n○Middle‌ ‌Paleolithic‌ ‌\n○Upper‌ ‌Paleolithic‌ ‌Revolution‌ ‌\n○Mesolithic‌ ‌period‌ ‌\n○Neolithic‌ ‌Revolution‌ ‌\n●Bronze‌ ‌Age‌ ‌\n●Iron‌ ‌Age‌ ‌\n ‌\nNew‌ ‌World‌ ‌\n●Lithic‌ ‌\n●Archaic‌ ‌\n●Formative‌ ‌\n ‌\nNew‌ ‌World‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌New‌ ‌World‌ ‌periods‌ ‌began‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌crossing‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Paleo-Indians,‌ ‌Athabaskan,‌ ‌Aleuts‌ ‌and‌ ‌Eskimos‌ ‌along‌ ‌the‌ ‌Bering‌ ‌Land‌ ‌Bridge‌ ‌onto‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌North‌ ‌American‌ ‌continent.‌ ‌\n261‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌‌Paleo-Indians‌ ‌‌were‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌people‌ ‌who‌ ‌entered,‌ ‌and‌ ‌subsequently‌ ‌inhabited,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Americas‌ ‌during‌ ‌the‌ ‌final‌ ‌glacial‌ ‌episodes‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nlate‌ ‌Pleistocene‌ ‌period.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Evidence‌ ‌suggests‌ ‌big-game‌ ‌hunters‌ ‌crossed‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Bering‌ ‌Strait‌ ‌‌from‌ ‌Asia‌ ‌into‌ ‌North‌ ‌America‌ ‌over‌ ‌a‌ ‌land‌ ‌and‌ ‌ice‌ ‌bridge‌ ‌(Beringia),‌ ‌that‌ ‌\nexisted‌ ‌between‌ ‌45,000‌ ‌BCE‌ ‌–‌ ‌12,000‌ ‌BCE,‌ ‌following‌ ‌herds‌ ‌of‌ ‌large‌ ‌herbivores‌ ‌far‌ ‌into‌ ‌Alaska.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●In‌ ‌their‌ ‌book,‌ ‌Method‌ ‌and‌ ‌Theory‌ ‌in‌ ‌American‌ ‌Archaeology,‌ ‌Gordon‌ ‌Willey‌ ‌and‌ ‌Philip‌ ‌Phillips‌ ‌defined‌ ‌five‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌stages‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌Americas,‌ ‌\nincluding‌ ‌the‌ ‌three‌ ‌prehistoric‌ ‌Lithic,‌ ‌Archaic‌ ‌and‌ ‌Formative‌ ‌stages.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌historic‌ ‌stages‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌Classic‌ ‌and‌ ‌Postclassic‌ ‌stages.‌ ‌\n ‌\nLithic‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Lithic‌ ‌period‌ ‌occurred‌ ‌from‌ ‌‌12,000‌ ‌to‌ ‌6,000‌ ‌years‌ ‌before‌ ‌present‌ ‌and‌ ‌included‌ ‌the‌ ‌Clovis,‌ ‌Folsom‌ ‌and‌ ‌Plano‌ ‌cultures.‌ ‌\n●Clovis‌ ‌culture‌ ‌was‌ ‌considered‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌first‌ ‌culture‌ ‌to‌ ‌use‌ ‌projectile‌ ‌points‌ ‌to‌ ‌hunt‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌North‌ ‌American‌ ‌continent‌.‌ ‌Since‌ ‌then,‌ ‌a‌ ‌pre-Clovis‌ ‌\nsite‌ ‌was‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌Manis,‌ ‌Washington‌ ‌that‌ ‌found‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌projectile‌ ‌points‌ ‌to‌ ‌hunt‌ ‌mastodons.‌ ‌\n ‌\nArchai‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Archaic‌ ‌period‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Americas‌ ‌was‌ ‌dated‌ ‌from‌‌ ‌8,000‌ ‌to‌ ‌2,000‌ ‌years‌ ‌before‌ ‌present.‌ ‌\n●People‌ ‌were‌ ‌hunters‌ ‌of‌ ‌small‌ ‌game,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌deer,‌ ‌antelope‌ ‌and‌ ‌rabbits,‌ ‌and‌ ‌gatherers‌ ‌of‌ ‌wild‌ ‌plants,‌ ‌moving‌ ‌seasonally‌ ‌to‌ ‌hunting‌ ‌and‌ ‌\ngathering‌ ‌sites.‌ ‌\n●Late‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Archaic‌ ‌period,‌ ‌about‌ ‌200-500‌ ‌A.D.‌ ‌corn‌ ‌was‌ ‌introduced‌ ‌into‌ ‌the‌ ‌diet‌ ‌and‌ ‌pottery-making‌ ‌became‌ ‌an‌ ‌occupation‌ ‌for‌ ‌storing‌ ‌and‌ ‌\ncaring‌ ‌food.‌ ‌\n ‌\nFormative‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Formative‌ ‌stage‌ ‌followed‌ ‌the‌ ‌Archaic‌ ‌period‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Americas‌ ‌and‌ ‌continued‌ ‌until‌ ‌there‌ ‌was‌ ‌contact‌ ‌by‌ ‌European‌ ‌people.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Some‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌from‌ ‌that‌ ‌period‌ ‌include‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌‌ ‌Ancient‌ ‌Pueblo‌ ‌People,‌ ‌Mississippian‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌Olmec‌ ‌cultures.‌ ‌\n●Cultures‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Formative‌ ‌Stage‌ ‌are‌ ‌‌supposed‌ ‌to‌ ‌possess‌ ‌the‌ ‌technologies‌ ‌of‌ ‌pottery,‌ ‌weaving,‌ ‌and‌ ‌developed‌ ‌food‌ ‌production.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Social‌ ‌organization‌ ‌is‌ ‌supposed‌ ‌to‌ ‌involve‌ ‌permanent‌ ‌towns‌ ‌and‌ ‌villages,‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌ceremonial‌ ‌centers.‌ ‌\n●Ideologically,‌ ‌an‌ ‌early‌ ‌priestly‌ ‌class‌ ‌or‌ ‌theocracy‌ ‌is‌ ‌often‌ ‌present‌ ‌or‌ ‌in‌ ‌development.‌ ‌\n ‌\n262‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nIntroduction-Stone‌ ‌Age‌ ‌\n ‌\n●The‌ ‌Stone‌ ‌Age‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌‌broad‌ ‌prehistoric‌ ‌period‌ ‌during‌ ‌which‌ ‌stone‌ ‌was‌ ‌widely‌ ‌used‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌manufacture‌ ‌of‌ ‌implements‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌sharp‌ ‌edge,‌ ‌a‌ ‌\npoint,‌ ‌or‌ ‌a‌ ‌percussion‌ ‌surface.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌period,‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌time‌ ‌of‌ ‌early‌ ‌hominids‌ ‌to‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌sapiens‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌later‌ ‌Pleistocene‌ ‌era,‌ ‌and‌ ‌largely‌ ‌ended‌ ‌between‌ ‌6000‌ ‌and‌ ‌3000‌ ‌BCE‌ ‌\nwith‌ ‌the‌ ‌advent‌ ‌of‌ ‌metalworking.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Stone‌ ‌Age‌ ‌lifestyle‌ ‌was‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌hunter-gatherers‌ ‌who‌ ‌traveled‌ ‌to‌ ‌hunt‌ ‌game‌ ‌and‌ ‌gather‌ ‌wild‌ ‌plants,‌ ‌with‌ ‌minimal‌ ‌changes‌ ‌in‌ ‌technology.‌ ‌ ‌\n●As‌ ‌the‌ ‌last‌ ‌glacial‌ ‌period‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌current‌ ‌ice‌ ‌age‌ ‌neared‌ ‌its‌ ‌end‌ ‌(about‌ ‌12,500‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago),‌ ‌large‌ ‌animals‌ ‌like‌ ‌the‌ ‌mammoth‌ ‌and‌ ‌bison‌ ‌antiquus‌ ‌\nbecame‌ ‌extinct‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌climate‌ ‌changed.‌ ‌\n●Humans‌ ‌adapted‌ ‌by‌ ‌maximizing‌ ‌the‌ ‌resources‌ ‌in‌ ‌local‌ ‌environments,‌ ‌gathering‌ ‌and‌ ‌eating‌ ‌a‌ ‌wider‌ ‌range‌ ‌of‌ ‌wild‌ ‌plants‌ ‌and‌ ‌hunting‌ ‌or‌ ‌\ncatching‌ ‌smaller‌ ‌game.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Domestication‌ ‌of‌ ‌plants‌ ‌and‌ ‌animals‌ ‌with‌ ‌early‌ ‌stages‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Old‌ ‌World‌ ‌(Afro-Eurasia)‌ ‌Mesolithic‌ ‌and‌ ‌New‌ ‌World‌ ‌(Americas)‌ ‌Archaic‌ ‌\nperiods‌ ‌led‌ ‌to‌ ‌significant‌ ‌changes‌ ‌and‌ ‌reliance‌ ‌on‌ ‌agriculture‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Old‌ ‌World‌ ‌Neolithic‌ ‌and‌ ‌New‌ ‌World‌ ‌Formative‌ ‌stage.‌ ‌The‌ ‌\nagricultural‌ ‌life‌ ‌led‌ ‌to‌ ‌more‌ ‌settled‌ ‌existences‌ ‌and‌ ‌significant‌ ‌technological‌ ‌advancements.‌ ‌\nStone‌ ‌Tools‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌stone‌ ‌tool‌ ‌is,‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌general‌ ‌sense,‌ ‌any‌ ‌tool‌ ‌made‌ ‌either‌ ‌partially‌ ‌or‌ ‌entirely‌ ‌out‌ ‌of‌ ‌stone.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Although‌ ‌stone‌ ‌tool-dependent‌ ‌societies‌ ‌and‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌still‌ ‌exist‌ ‌today,‌ ‌‌most‌ ‌stone‌ ‌tools‌ ‌are‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌prehistoric‌ ‌(particularly‌ ‌Stone‌ ‌\nAge)‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌that‌ ‌have‌ ‌become‌ ‌extinct.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Archaeologists‌ ‌often‌ ‌study‌ ‌such‌ ‌prehistoric‌ ‌societies,‌ ‌and‌ ‌refer‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌stone‌ ‌tools‌ ‌as‌ ‌lithic‌ ‌analysis.‌ ‌\n●Ethnoarchaeology‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌a‌ ‌valuable‌ ‌research‌ ‌field‌ ‌in‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌further‌ ‌the‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌and‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌implications‌ ‌of‌ ‌stone‌ ‌tool‌ ‌use‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nmanufacture.‌ ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌Addition-‌ ‌Evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌Stone‌ ‌tools‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Ecology‌ ‌of‌ ‌man,‌ ‌in‌ ‌contrast‌ ‌to‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌other‌ ‌living‌ ‌beings‌ ‌is‌ ‌heavily‌ ‌influenced‌ ‌by‌ ‌technology‌ ‌and‌ ‌its‌ ‌material‌ ‌products.‌ ‌\n263‌ ‌\n●As‌ ‌‌Beals‌ ‌and‌ ‌Hoijer‌ ‌(1971)‌ ‌rightly‌ ‌point‌ ‌out‌ ‌that‌ ‌technology‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌sum‌ ‌total‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌techniques‌ ‌possessed‌ ‌by‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌society‌;‌ ‌\nthat‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌totality‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌ways‌ ‌of‌ ‌behaving‌ ‌in‌ ‌respect‌ ‌to‌ ‌collecting‌ ‌raw‌ ‌materials‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌environments‌ ‌and‌ ‌processing‌ ‌these‌ ‌to‌ ‌make‌ ‌tools,‌ ‌\ncontainers,‌ ‌foods,‌ ‌clothing,‌ ‌shelters,‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n●Archaeologists‌ ‌classify‌ ‌stone‌ ‌tools‌ ‌into‌ ‌industries‌ ‌(also‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌complexes‌ ‌or‌ ‌technocomplexes‌ ‌that‌ ‌share‌ ‌distinctive‌ ‌technological‌ ‌or‌ ‌\nmorphological‌ ‌characteristics.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌1969‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌2nd‌ ‌edition‌ ‌of‌ ‌‌World‌ ‌Prehistory,‌ ‌Grahame‌ ‌Clark‌ ‌proposed‌ ‌an‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌progression‌ ‌of‌ ‌flint-knapping‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌the‌ ‌\n\"dominant‌ ‌lithic‌ ‌technologies\"‌ ‌occurred‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌fixed‌ ‌sequence‌ ‌from‌ ‌Mode‌ ‌1‌ ‌through‌ ‌Mode‌ ‌5.‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌assigned‌ ‌to‌ ‌them‌ ‌relative‌ ‌dates:‌ ‌‌Modes‌ ‌I‌ ‌and‌ ‌II‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌Lower‌ ‌Palaeolithic‌,‌ ‌‌III‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌Middle‌ ‌Palaeolithic‌,‌ ‌‌IV‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌Advanced‌ ‌‌and‌ ‌V‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌Mesolithic‌ ‌\n○Pre-Mode‌ ‌I-Lomekwian‌ ‌\n○Mode‌ ‌I:‌ ‌‌The‌ ‌Oldowan‌ ‌Industry‌ ‌\n○Mode‌ ‌II:‌ ‌‌The‌ ‌Acheulean‌ ‌Industry‌ ‌\n○Mode‌ ‌III:‌ ‌‌The‌ ‌Mousterian‌ ‌Industry‌ ‌\n○Mode‌ ‌IV:‌ ‌‌The‌ ‌Aurignacian‌ ‌Industry‌ ‌\n○Mode‌ ‌V:‌‌ ‌The‌ ‌Microlithic‌ ‌Industries‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n264‌ ‌\n●Pre-Mode‌ ‌I‌ ‌\n○Kenya-‌ ‌Stone‌ ‌tools‌ ‌found‌ ‌from‌ ‌2011‌ ‌to‌ ‌2014‌ ‌at‌ ‌Lake‌ ‌Turkana‌ ‌in‌ ‌Kenya,‌ ‌are‌ ‌dated‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌‌3.3‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌old,‌ ‌and‌ ‌predate‌ ‌the‌ ‌genus‌ ‌\nHomo‌ ‌by‌ ‌about‌ ‌one‌ ‌million‌ ‌years.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌o‌ldest‌ ‌known‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌fossil‌ ‌is‌ ‌about‌ ‌2.4-2.3‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌old‌ ‌compared‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌3.3‌ ‌million‌ ‌year‌ ‌old‌ ‌stone‌ ‌tools.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌stone‌ ‌tools‌ ‌may‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌made‌ ‌by‌ ‌Australopithecus‌ ‌afarensis‌,‌ ‌the‌ ‌species‌ ‌whose‌ ‌best‌ ‌fossil‌ ‌example‌ ‌is‌ ‌Lucy,‌ ‌which‌ ‌\ninhabited‌ ‌East‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌time‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌date‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌oldest‌ ‌stone‌ ‌tools.‌ ‌\n○Ethiopia-‌ ‌Grooved,‌ ‌cut‌ ‌and‌ ‌fractured‌ ‌animal‌ ‌bone‌ ‌fossils,‌ ‌made‌ ‌by‌ ‌using‌ ‌stone‌ ‌tools,‌ ‌were‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌Dikika,‌ ‌Ethiopia‌ ‌near‌ ‌the‌ ‌remains‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌‌Selam‌,‌ ‌a‌ ‌young‌‌ ‌Australopithecus‌ ‌afarensis‌ ‌girl‌ ‌‌who‌ ‌lived‌ ‌about‌ ‌3.3‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Mode‌ ‌I:‌ ‌The‌ ‌Oldowan‌ ‌Industry‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌earliest‌ ‌stone‌ ‌tools‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌life‌ ‌span‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌genus‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌are‌ ‌Mode‌ ‌I‌ ‌tools,and‌ ‌come‌ ‌from‌ ‌what‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌termed‌ ‌the‌ ‌Oldowan‌ ‌\nIndustry,‌ ‌named‌ ‌after‌ ‌the‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌site‌ ‌(many‌ ‌sites,‌ ‌actually)‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌Olduvai‌ ‌Gorge,‌ ‌Tanzania,‌ ‌where‌ ‌they‌ ‌were‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌in‌ ‌large‌ ‌\nquantities.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Oldowan‌ ‌tools‌ ‌were‌ ‌‌characterised‌ ‌by‌ ‌their‌ ‌simple‌ ‌construction,‌ ‌predominantly‌ ‌using‌ ‌core‌ ‌forms‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Oldowan‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌‌percussion‌ ‌technology‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○Geographical‌ ‌spread:‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌earliest‌ ‌known‌ ‌Oldowan‌ ‌tools‌ ‌yet‌ ‌found‌ ‌date‌ ‌from‌ ‌2.6‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago,‌ ‌during‌ ‌the‌ ‌Lower‌ ‌Palaeolithic‌ ‌period,‌ ‌and‌ ‌have‌ ‌\nbeen‌ ‌uncovered‌ ‌at‌ ‌Gona‌ ‌in‌ ‌Ethiopia.‌ ‌\n■After‌ ‌this‌ ‌date,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Oldowan‌ ‌Industry‌ ‌subsequently‌ ‌spread‌ ‌throughout‌ ‌much‌ ‌of‌ ‌Africa,‌ ‌although‌ ‌archaeologists‌ ‌are‌ ‌‌currently‌ ‌\nunsure‌ ‌which‌ ‌Hominan‌ ‌species‌ ‌first‌ ‌developed‌ ‌them,‌ ‌with‌ ‌some‌ ‌speculating‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌Australopithecus‌ ‌garhi,‌ ‌and‌ ‌others‌ ‌\nbelieving‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌in‌ ‌fact‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌habilis.‌ ‌\n■Homo‌ ‌habilis‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌hominin‌ ‌who‌ ‌used‌ ‌the‌ ‌tools‌ ‌for‌ ‌most‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Oldowan‌ ‌in‌ ‌Africa,‌ ‌but‌ ‌at‌ ‌about‌ ‌1.9-1.8‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago‌ ‌\nHomo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌inherited‌ ‌them.‌ ‌ ‌\n265‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌Industry‌ ‌flourished‌ ‌in‌ ‌southern‌ ‌and‌ ‌eastern‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌between‌ ‌2.6‌ ‌and‌ ‌1.7‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago,‌ ‌but‌ ‌was‌ ‌also‌ ‌spread‌ ‌out‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nAfrica‌ ‌and‌ ‌into‌ ‌Eurasia‌ ‌by‌ ‌travelling‌ ‌bands‌ ‌of‌ ‌H.‌ ‌erectus,‌ ‌who‌ ‌took‌ ‌it‌ ‌as‌ ‌far‌ ‌east‌ ‌as‌ ‌Java‌ ‌by‌ ‌1.8‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago‌ ‌and‌ ‌Northern‌ ‌\nChina‌ ‌by‌ ‌1.6‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Mode‌ ‌II:‌ ‌The‌ ‌Acheulean‌ ‌Industry‌ ‌\n○Eventually,‌ ‌more‌ ‌complex‌ ‌Mode‌ ‌II‌ ‌tools‌ ‌began‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌developed‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌Acheulean‌ ‌Industry,‌ ‌named‌ ‌after‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌site‌ ‌of‌ ‌Saint-Acheul‌ ‌\nin‌ ‌France‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌Acheulean‌ ‌was‌ ‌characterised‌ ‌not‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌core,‌ ‌but‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌biface,‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌notable‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌which‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌hand‌ ‌axe.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌Acheulean‌ ‌first‌ ‌appears‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌archaeological‌ ‌record‌ ‌as‌ ‌early‌ ‌as‌ ‌1.7‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌West‌ ‌Turkana‌ ‌area‌ ‌of‌ ‌Kenya‌ ‌and‌ ‌\ncontemporaneously‌ ‌in‌ ‌southern‌ ‌Africa.‌ ‌\n○Acheulean‌ ‌tools‌ ‌have‌ ‌also‌ ‌been‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Middle‌ ‌East,‌ ‌India,‌ ‌and‌ ‌Java.‌ ‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌were‌ ‌‌common‌ ‌in‌ ‌southern‌ ‌Europe‌ ‌as‌ ‌well,‌ ‌but‌ ‌were‌ ‌replaced‌ ‌there‌ ‌about‌ ‌one‌ ‌lac‌ ‌to‌ ‌70000‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago.‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌beginning‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nNext‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌tradition,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Mousterian.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○At‌ ‌first‌ ‌this‌ ‌flaking‌ ‌was‌ ‌done‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌hammer‌ ‌stone,‌ ‌as‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Oldowan‌ ‌industries.‌ ‌ ‌\n■But‌ ‌eventually‌ ‌acheulean‌ ‌tool‌ ‌makers‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌that‌ ‌they‌ ‌could‌ ‌control‌ ‌the‌ ‌size‌ ‌and‌ ‌shape‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌flake‌ ‌better‌ ‌by‌ ‌using‌ ‌bone‌ ‌\nor‌ ‌a‌ ‌stick‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌hammer.‌ ‌ ‌\n266‌ ‌\n■This‌ ‌method‌ ‌is‌ ‌called‌ ‌the‌ ‌soft‌ ‌hammer‌ ‌technique.‌ ‌In‌ ‌this‌ ‌technique‌ ‌a‌ ‌bone,‌ ‌antler‌ ‌or‌ ‌piece‌ ‌of‌ ‌wood‌ ‌was‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌strike‌ ‌off‌ ‌\nshallow‌ ‌flakes‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌side‌ ‌of‌ ‌core‌ ‌tools.‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌technique‌ ‌is‌ ‌marked‌ ‌by‌ ‌thinner‌ ‌access‌ ‌from‌ ‌which‌ ‌many‌ ‌more‌ ‌flakes‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌removed‌ ‌to‌ ‌create‌ ‌a‌ ‌sharper‌ ‌\nedge.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌increasing‌ ‌sophistication‌ ‌in‌ ‌production‌ ‌of‌ ‌flakes‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Acheulean‌ ‌culture‌ ‌was‌ ‌its‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌specialities.‌ ‌As‌ ‌in‌ ‌Oldowan‌ ‌Industries‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌flakes‌ ‌were‌ ‌only‌ ‌useful‌ ‌by‌ ‌products‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌main‌ ‌tool.‌ ‌\n○Acheulean‌ ‌used‌ ‌bone‌ ‌and‌ ‌Woods‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌for‌ ‌making‌ ‌tools‌ ‌other‌ ‌than‌ ‌stone,‌ ‌bones‌ ‌and‌ ‌woods‌ ‌were‌ ‌also‌ ‌used.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nFlake‌ ‌Industry:‌ ‌\nThe‌ ‌flake‌ ‌industry‌ ‌of‌ ‌Lower‌ ‌Palaeolithic‌ ‌culture‌ ‌has‌ ‌two‌ ‌traditions.‌ ‌They‌ ‌are‌ ‌:‌ ‌ ‌\n1.Clactonian‌ ‌tradition‌ ‌and‌ ‌ ‌\n2.Levalloisian.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n1.The‌ ‌Clactonian‌ ‌tradition‌ ‌:‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌Clactonian‌ ‌flakes‌ ‌are‌ ‌rough‌ ‌and‌ ‌struck‌ ‌out‌ ‌unsystematically‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌prepared‌ ‌core.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌suggested‌ ‌that‌ ‌most‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌flakes‌ ‌are‌ ‌produced‌ ‌by‌ ‌striking‌ ‌the‌ ‌lump‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌edge‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌anvil.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌Clactonian‌ ‌flakes‌ ‌generally‌ ‌exhibited‌ ‌large,‌ ‌massive,‌ ‌unfaceted‌ ‌striking‌ ‌platforms‌ ‌and‌ ‌prominent‌ ‌positive‌ ‌bulbs‌ ‌of‌ ‌\npercussion.‌ ‌\n ‌\n267‌ ‌\n2.Levalloisian‌ ‌tradition:‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌predominantly‌ ‌represented‌ ‌by‌ ‌flake‌ ‌tools‌ ‌which‌ ‌were‌ ‌produced‌ ‌by‌ ‌using‌ ‌the‌ ‌Levalloisian‌ ‌tool‌ ‌making‌ ‌technique.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌requires‌ ‌a‌ ‌careful‌ ‌preparation‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌core.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌core‌ ‌is‌ ‌prepared‌ ‌to‌ ‌look‌ ‌like‌ ‌the‌ ‌back‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌tortoise.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌flakes‌ ‌are‌ ‌detached‌ ‌from‌ ‌these‌ ‌specially‌ ‌prepared‌ ‌cores.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌facetted‌ ‌striking‌ ‌platform‌ ‌makes‌ ‌an‌ ‌angle‌ ‌of‌ ‌900‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌flake‌ ‌surface.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌flake‌ ‌tradition‌ ‌is‌ ‌found‌ ‌well‌ ‌distributed‌ ‌in‌ ‌western‌ ‌Europe,‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌and‌ ‌India‌ ‌(specially‌ ‌in‌ ‌Madrasian‌ ‌industries).‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌Middle‌ ‌Palaeolithic‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌phase‌ ‌is‌ ‌differentiated‌ ‌mainly‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌typological‌ ‌point‌ ‌of‌ ‌view‌ ‌where‌ ‌the‌ ‌core‌ ‌tool‌ ‌\nindustry‌ ‌has‌ ‌totally‌ ‌been‌ ‌transferred‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌flake‌ ‌industry‌ ‌in‌ ‌this‌ ‌level.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Both‌ ‌Levalloisian‌ ‌and‌ ‌Mousterian‌ ‌traditions‌ ‌were‌ ‌developed‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌flake‌ ‌industry‌ ‌involving‌ ‌a‌ ‌higher‌ ‌technology.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌marked‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌large‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌side‌ ‌scrapers,‌ ‌backed‌ ‌knives,‌ ‌points,‌ ‌nosed‌ ‌flakes,‌ ‌bruins,‌ ‌and‌ ‌end‌ ‌scrapers‌ ‌have‌ ‌\nappeared.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌geological‌ ‌age‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌middle‌ ‌Pleistocene‌ ‌and‌ ‌Neanderthal‌ ‌people‌ ‌were‌ ‌definitely‌ ‌responsible‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌\ncreation‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌phase.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n268‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Mode‌ ‌III:‌ ‌The‌ ‌Mousterian‌ ‌Industry‌ ‌\n○Eventually,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Acheulean‌ ‌in‌ ‌Europe‌ ‌was‌ ‌replaced‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌lithic‌ ‌technology‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌Mousterian‌ ‌Industry,‌ ‌which‌ ‌was‌ ‌named‌ ‌after‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌site‌ ‌of‌ ‌Le‌ ‌Moustier‌ ‌in‌ ‌France,‌ ‌where‌ ‌examples‌ ‌were‌ ‌first‌ ‌uncovered‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌1860s.‌ ‌\n○Evolving‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌Acheulean,‌ ‌it‌ ‌adopted‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Levallois‌ ‌technique‌ ‌(A‌ ‌method‌ ‌of‌ ‌creating‌ ‌stone‌ ‌tools‌ ‌by‌ ‌first‌ ‌striking‌ ‌flakes‌ ‌off‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌stone,‌ ‌or‌ ‌core,‌ ‌along‌ ‌the‌ ‌edges‌ ‌to‌ ‌create‌ ‌the‌ ‌prepared‌ ‌core‌ ‌and‌ ‌then‌ ‌striking‌ ‌the‌ ‌prepared‌ ‌core‌ ‌in‌ ‌such‌ ‌a‌ ‌way‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nintended‌ ‌tool‌ ‌is‌ ‌flaked‌ ‌off‌ ‌with‌ ‌all‌ ‌of‌ ‌its‌ ‌edges‌ ‌pre-sharpened.)‌  ‌to‌ ‌produce‌ ‌smaller‌ ‌and‌ ‌sharper‌ ‌knife-like‌ ‌tools‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌\nscrapers.‌ ‌\n269‌ ‌\n■Also‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌\"prepared‌ ‌core‌ ‌technique,\"‌ ‌flakes‌ ‌are‌ ‌struck‌ ‌from‌ ‌working‌ ‌cores‌ ‌and‌ ‌then‌ ‌subsequently‌
