‌retouched.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○The‌ ‌‌Mousterian‌ ‌Industry‌ ‌was‌ ‌developed‌ ‌and‌ ‌used‌ ‌primarily‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌Neanderthals,‌ ‌a‌ ‌native‌ ‌European‌ ‌and‌ ‌Middle‌ ‌Eastern‌ ‌hominin‌ ‌\nspecies,‌ ‌but‌ ‌a‌ ‌broadly‌ ‌similar‌ ‌industry‌ ‌is‌ ‌contemporaneously‌ ‌widespread‌ ‌in‌ ‌Africa.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Mode‌ ‌IV:‌ ‌The‌ ‌Aurignacian‌ ‌Industry‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌widespread‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌long‌ ‌blades‌ ‌(rather‌ ‌than‌ ‌flakes)‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Upper‌ ‌Palaeolithic‌ ‌Mode‌ ‌IV‌ ‌‌industries‌ ‌appeared‌ ‌during‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Upper‌ ‌\nPalaeolithic‌ ‌between‌ ‌50,000‌ ‌and‌ ‌10,000‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago‌,‌ ‌although‌ ‌blades‌ ‌were‌ ‌still‌ ‌produced‌ ‌in‌ ‌small‌ ‌quantities‌ ‌much‌ ‌earlier‌ ‌by‌ ‌\nNeanderthals.‌ ‌\n270‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌Aurignacian‌ ‌culture‌ ‌seems‌ ‌to‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌to‌ ‌rely‌ ‌largely‌ ‌on‌ ‌blades.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○The‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌blades‌ ‌exponentially‌ ‌increases‌ ‌the‌ ‌efficiency‌ ‌of‌ ‌core‌ ‌usage‌ ‌compared‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌Levallois‌ ‌flake‌ ‌technique,‌ ‌which‌ ‌had‌ ‌a‌ ‌similar‌ ‌\nadvantage‌ ‌over‌ ‌Acheulean‌ ‌technology‌ ‌which‌ ‌was‌ ‌worked‌ ‌from‌ ‌cores.‌ ‌\n ‌\nOsteodontokeratic‌ ‌culture‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌last‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Palaeolithic‌ ‌culture‌ ‌gave‌ ‌rise‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌Upper‌ ‌Palaeolithic‌ ‌phase.‌ ‌During‌ ‌this‌ ‌short‌ ‌span‌ ‌of‌ ‌time,‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nprehistoric‌ ‌man‌ ‌made‌ ‌his‌ ‌greatest‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌progress.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌phase‌ ‌of‌ ‌Palaeolithic‌ ‌culture‌ ‌shows‌ ‌diversified‌ ‌and‌ ‌specialized‌ ‌tools‌ ‌made‌ ‌on‌ ‌blades‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌replacement‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌core‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌flake‌ ‌tools‌ ‌of‌ ‌earlier‌ ‌phases.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌notable‌ ‌that,‌ ‌not‌ ‌only‌ ‌flint‌ ‌and‌ ‌similar‌ ‌rocks‌ ‌were‌ ‌used‌ ‌as‌ ‌tools,‌ ‌bone‌ ‌was‌ ‌also‌ ‌taken‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌material‌ ‌for‌ ‌making‌ ‌\ntools.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌culture‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Osteodontokeratic‌ ‌culture‌‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌utilization‌ ‌of‌ ‌bone,‌ ‌teeth‌ ‌and‌ ‌horn‌ ‌at‌ ‌a‌ ‌time.‌ ‌ ‌\n271‌ ‌\n●Early‌ ‌man‌ ‌of‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌types‌ ‌disappeared‌ ‌at‌ ‌this‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌stage‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌man‌ ‌of‌ ‌modern‌ ‌type‌ ‌came‌ ‌into‌ ‌existence.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌stage‌ ‌also‌ ‌shows‌ ‌the‌ ‌beginning‌ ‌and‌ ‌flowering‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Palaeolithic‌ ‌art.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Mode‌ ‌V:‌ ‌The‌ ‌Microlithic‌ ‌Industries‌ ‌\n○Mode‌ ‌5‌ ‌stone‌ ‌tools‌ ‌involve‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌production‌ ‌of‌ ‌microliths,‌ ‌which‌ ‌were‌ ‌used‌ ‌in‌ ‌composite‌ ‌tools,‌ ‌mainly‌ ‌fastened‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌shaft.‌ ‌\n○Examples‌ ‌include‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Magdalenian‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Such‌ ‌a‌ ‌technology‌ ‌makes‌ ‌much‌ ‌more‌ ‌efficient‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌available‌ ‌materials‌ ‌like‌ ‌flint,‌ ‌although‌ ‌required‌ ‌greater‌ ‌skill‌ ‌in‌ ‌manufacturing‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nsmall‌ ‌flakes.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Mounting‌ ‌sharp‌ ‌flint‌ ‌edges‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌wood‌ ‌or‌ ‌bone‌ ‌handle‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌key‌ ‌innovation‌ ‌in‌ ‌microliths,‌ ‌essentially‌ ‌because‌ ‌the‌ ‌handle‌ ‌gives‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌user‌ ‌protection‌ ‌against‌ ‌the‌ ‌flint‌ ‌and‌ ‌also‌ ‌improves‌ ‌leverage‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌device.‌ ‌\n ‌\n■Blade‌ ‌and‌ ‌burin‌ ‌industry‌ ‌of‌ ‌Upper‌ ‌Paleolithic‌ ‌:‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌blade‌ ‌and‌ ‌burin‌ ‌industry‌ ‌of‌ ‌Upper‌ ‌Palaeolithic‌ ‌comprises‌ ‌three‌ ‌traditions‌ ‌mainly:‌ ‌\n(1)‌ ‌Aurignacian‌ ‌ ‌\n(2)‌ ‌Solutrean‌ ‌and‌ ‌ ‌\n(3)‌ ‌Magdalenian.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n(1)‌ ‌‌Aurignacian‌ ‌tradition‌ ‌:‌ ‌\n■This‌ ‌tradition‌ ‌is‌ ‌named‌ ‌after‌ ‌the‌ ‌type‌ ‌–‌ ‌site,‌ ‌a‌ ‌rock‌ ‌shelter‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌Aurignac‌ ‌in‌ ‌South‌ ‌France.‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌leading‌ ‌tool‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌stage‌ ‌include‌ ‌the‌ ‌steep-ended‌ ‌scrapers,‌ ‌nosed‌ ‌scrapers,‌ ‌blade‌ ‌artefacts‌ ‌with‌ ‌split-based‌ ‌\nbone‌ ‌lance‌ ‌points,‌ ‌batton-‌ ‌de-‌ ‌commandment,‌ ‌chisels,‌ ‌pierced‌ ‌teeth‌ ‌and‌ ‌shells,‌ ‌decorated‌ ‌bits‌ ‌of‌ ‌bone,‌ ‌ivory‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nstone.‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌Aurgnacian‌ ‌people‌ ‌were‌ ‌artistic.‌ ‌ ‌\n■They‌ ‌are‌ ‌experts‌ ‌in‌ ‌engraving,‌ ‌sculpture‌ ‌and‌ ‌painters.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Main‌ ‌responsible‌ ‌representatives‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌phase‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌Cro-magnon‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌men‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌Cro-magnon‌ ‌people‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌placed‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌men‌ ‌of‌ ‌Late‌ ‌Pleistocene‌ ‌and‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌runners‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nNeanthropic‌ ‌race,‌ ‌the‌ ‌homo‌ ‌sapiens.‌ ‌\n ‌\n(2)‌‌ ‌Solutrean‌ ‌tradition‌ ‌:‌ ‌\n■This‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌phase‌ ‌is‌ ‌named‌ ‌after‌ ‌the‌ ‌type‌ ‌site‌ ‌located‌ ‌at‌ ‌La-Solutre‌ ‌near‌ ‌central‌ ‌France.‌ ‌ ‌\n■This‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌phase‌ ‌is‌ ‌notable‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌finest‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌flint‌ ‌workmanship‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Palaeolithic‌ ‌period.‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌Solutrean‌ ‌tradition‌ ‌is‌ ‌recognized‌ ‌by‌ ‌three‌ ‌fold‌ ‌division:‌ ‌\n○Proto‌ ‌Solutrean‌ ‌\n○Typical‌ ‌Solutrean‌ ‌\n272‌ ‌\n○Upper‌ ‌Solutrean‌ ‌\n■Main‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌remains‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Solutrean‌ ‌peoples‌ ‌are‌ ‌willow‌ ‌leaf‌ ‌point,‌ ‌laurel-leaf‌ ‌points,‌ ‌tanged‌ ‌points,‌ ‌gravers,‌ ‌burins‌ ‌\netc.‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌culture‌ ‌has‌ ‌limited‌ ‌distribution.‌ ‌An‌ ‌early‌ ‌form‌ ‌is‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌deposits‌ ‌of‌ ‌Hungary,‌ ‌Poland‌ ‌and‌ ‌elsewhere‌ ‌in‌ ‌central‌ ‌\nEurope.‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌Solutrean‌ ‌people‌ ‌are‌ ‌expert‌ ‌in‌ ‌making‌ ‌the‌ ‌beautiful‌ ‌but‌ ‌small‌ ‌laurel‌ ‌leaf‌ ‌points.‌ ‌\n ‌\n(3)‌ ‌‌Magdalenian‌ ‌traditions:‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌last‌ ‌phase‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Palaeolithic‌ ‌period‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌Magdalenian‌ ‌phase‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌noted‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌wealth‌ ‌of‌ ‌bone‌ ‌and‌ ‌antler‌ ‌\ntools‌ ‌and‌ ‌specially‌ ‌remarkable‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌works‌ ‌of‌ ‌art.‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌flint‌ ‌industry‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Magdalenian‌ ‌people‌ ‌bore‌ ‌a‌ ‌blade‌ ‌tool‌ ‌tradition.‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌main‌ ‌tools‌ ‌of‌ ‌Magdalenian‌ ‌tradition‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌different‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌harpoons‌ ‌(single‌ ‌row‌ ‌barbs,‌ ‌double‌ ‌row‌ ‌barbs,‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nlateral‌ ‌barbs),‌ ‌long‌ ‌and‌ ‌parallel‌ ‌sided‌ ‌blades‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌Magdalenian‌ ‌phase‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌richest‌ ‌stage‌ ‌of‌ ‌Palaeolithic.‌ ‌ ‌\n■They‌ ‌use‌ ‌pigments‌ ‌of‌ ‌ochres,‌ ‌minerals,‌ ‌burnt‌ ‌bones‌ ‌etc.,‌ ‌to‌ ‌get‌ ‌different‌ ‌colours.‌ ‌\n■They‌ ‌converted‌ ‌these‌ ‌pigments‌ ‌into‌ ‌paint‌ ‌by‌ ‌mixing‌ ‌with‌ ‌some‌ ‌fatty‌ ‌medium.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Human‌ ‌skeletal‌ ‌remains‌ ‌of‌ ‌modern‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌man‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌unearthed‌ ‌from‌ ‌several‌ ‌sites.‌ ‌ ‌\n■They‌ ‌are‌ ‌undoubtedly‌ ‌the‌ ‌Neanthropic‌ ‌man‌ ‌and‌ ‌perhaps‌ ‌the‌ ‌representatives‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Chancelade‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌men‌ ‌of‌ ‌late‌ ‌\nPleistocene.‌ ‌\n ‌\n273‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n1.8‌ ‌(b)‌ ‌Cultural‌ ‌Evolution—Broad‌ ‌Outlines‌ ‌of‌ ‌Prehistoric‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌:‌ ‌Paleolithic,‌ ‌Mesolithic,‌ ‌Neolithic,‌ ‌Chalcolithic,‌ ‌Copper-Bronze‌ ‌Age,‌ ‌\nIron‌ ‌Age-‌ ‌Part-III‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nThe‌ ‌Stone‌ ‌Age‌ ‌\n274‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●The‌ ‌S‌tone‌ ‌Age‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌three-age‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌archaeology,‌ ‌which‌ ‌divides‌ ‌human‌ ‌technological‌ ‌prehistory‌ ‌into‌ ‌three‌ ‌periods:‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nStone‌ ‌Age,‌ ‌Bronze‌ ‌Age,‌ ‌and‌ ‌Iron‌ ‌Age.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Stone‌ ‌Age‌ ‌lasted‌ ‌roughly‌ ‌3.4‌ ‌million‌ ‌years,‌ ‌from‌ ‌‌30,000‌ ‌BCE‌ ‌to‌ ‌about‌ ‌3,000‌ ‌BCE‌,‌ ‌and‌ ‌ended‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌advent‌ ‌of‌ ‌metalworking.‌ ‌\n ‌\nThe‌ ‌Stone‌ ‌Age‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌divided‌ ‌into‌ ‌three‌ ‌distinct‌ ‌periods:‌ ‌\n ‌\n○Paleolithic‌ ‌Period‌ ‌or‌ ‌Old‌ ‌Stone‌ ‌Age‌ ‌(30,000‌ ‌BCE–10,000‌ ‌BCE)‌ ‌\n○Mesolithic‌ ‌Period‌ ‌or‌ ‌Middle‌ ‌Stone‌ ‌Age‌ ‌(10,000‌ ‌BCE–8,000‌ ‌BCE)‌ ‌\n○Neolithic‌ ‌Period‌ ‌or‌ ‌New‌ ‌Stone‌ ‌Age‌ ‌(8,000‌ ‌BCE–3,000‌ ‌BCE)‌ ‌\n ‌\n●The‌ ‌art‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Stone‌ ‌Age‌ ‌represents‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌accomplishments‌ ‌in‌ ‌human‌ ‌creativity,‌ ‌preceding‌ ‌the‌ ‌invention‌ ‌of‌ ‌writing.‌ ‌ ‌\n●While‌ ‌numerous‌ ‌artifacts‌ ‌still‌ ‌exist‌ ‌today,‌ ‌the‌ ‌lack‌ ‌of‌ ‌writing‌ ‌systems‌ ‌from‌ ‌this‌ ‌era‌ ‌greatly‌ ‌limits‌ ‌our‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌of‌ ‌prehistoric‌ ‌art‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nculture‌ ‌.‌ ‌\n ‌\nPaleolithic‌ ‌\nEarly‌ ‌Stone‌ ‌Age‌ ‌\n ‌\n275‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Introduction:‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌Palaeolithic‌ ‌('Old‌ ‌Stone‌ ‌Age')‌ ‌makes‌ ‌up‌ ‌the‌ ‌earliest‌ ‌chunk‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Stone‌ ‌Age‌ ‌–‌ ‌the‌ ‌large‌ ‌swathe‌ ‌of‌ ‌time‌ ‌during‌ ‌which‌ ‌hominins‌ ‌\nused‌ ‌stone‌ ‌to‌ ‌make‌ ‌tools‌ ‌–‌ ‌and‌ ‌ranges‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌known‌ ‌tool‌ ‌use‌ ‌roughly‌ ‌2.6‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌end‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌last‌ ‌Ice‌ ‌Age‌ ‌c.‌ ‌\n12,000‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago,‌ ‌with‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌its‌ ‌stone‌ ‌tool‌ ‌culture‌ ‌continuing‌ ‌up‌ ‌until‌ ‌c.‌ ‌10,000‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago‌ ‌in‌ ‌some‌ ‌areas.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌occurred‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Pleistocene‌ ‌Epoch.‌ ‌\n○Although‌ ‌Paleolithic‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌left‌ ‌no‌ ‌written‌ ‌records‌,‌ ‌the‌ ‌shift‌ ‌from‌ ‌nomadic‌ ‌life‌ ‌to‌ ‌settlement‌ ‌and‌ ‌agriculture‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌inferred‌ ‌from‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nrange‌ ‌of‌ ‌archaeological‌ ‌evidence.‌ ‌ ‌\n276‌ ‌\n○Such‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌includes‌ ‌ancient‌ ‌tools,cave‌ ‌paintings,‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌prehistoric‌ ‌art,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Venus‌ ‌of‌ ‌Willendorf.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n○Human‌ ‌remains‌ ‌also‌ ‌provide‌ ‌‌direct‌ ‌evidence,‌ ‌both‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌examination‌ ‌of‌ ‌bones,‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌mummies.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Though‌ ‌concrete‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌is‌ ‌limited,‌ ‌scientists‌ ‌and‌ ‌historians‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌able‌ ‌to‌ ‌form‌ ‌significant‌ ‌inferences‌ ‌about‌ ‌the‌ ‌lifestyle‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nculture‌ ‌of‌ ‌various‌ ‌prehistoric‌ ‌peoples,‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌role‌ ‌technology‌ ‌played‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌lives.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Tool‌ ‌culture‌ ‌&‌ ‌Geographical‌ ‌Location:‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌‌first‌ ‌identified‌ ‌industry‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌Oldowan‌ ‌industry,‌ ‌named‌ ‌after‌ ‌Olduvai‌ ‌Gorge‌ ‌in‌ ‌Tanzania,‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌hunter-gatherers‌ ‌used‌ ‌simple‌ ‌\nstone‌ ‌cores‌ ‌as‌ ‌choppers‌ ‌and‌ ‌hammerstones,‌ ‌for‌ ‌example‌ ‌for‌ ‌butchering‌ ‌animals‌ ‌and‌ ‌crushing‌ ‌their‌ ‌bones‌ ‌to‌ ‌get‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌nutritious‌ ‌\nmarrow,‌ ‌or‌ ‌pounding‌ ‌up‌ ‌plants‌ ‌and‌ ‌seeds.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌Oldowan‌ ‌was‌ ‌‌mostly‌ ‌found‌ ‌within‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌(in‌ ‌spots‌ ‌that‌ ‌correspond‌ ‌with,‌ ‌for‌ ‌example,‌ ‌present-day‌ ‌Tanzania,‌ ‌Kenya,‌ ‌Ethiopia,‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌South‌ ‌Africa)‌ ‌but‌ ‌was‌ ‌l‌ater‌ ‌on‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Near‌ ‌East‌ ‌and‌ ‌eastern‌ ‌Asia,‌ ‌too,‌ ‌most‌ ‌likely‌ ‌by‌ ‌courtesy‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌long‌ ‌legs‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nadventurous‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌erectus.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌overlaps‌ ‌a‌ ‌bit‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌Acheulean‌ ‌industry‌ ‌which‌ ‌popped‌ ‌up‌ ‌a‌ ‌bit‌ ‌later,‌ ‌around‌ ‌1,7‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago‌,‌ ‌and‌ ‌has‌ ‌no‌ ‌proper‌ ‌endpoint;‌ ‌\nrather,‌ ‌it‌ ‌seems‌ ‌to‌ ‌have‌ ‌gradually‌ ‌petered‌ ‌out‌ ‌in‌ ‌various‌ ‌areas‌ ‌and‌ ‌given‌ ‌way‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌Acheulean.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌Acheulean,‌ ‌characterised‌ ‌by‌ ‌large‌ ‌bifaces‌ ‌that‌ ‌were‌ ‌turned‌ ‌into‌ ‌all‌ ‌kinds‌ ‌of‌ ‌scary‌ ‌things‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌hand‌ ‌axes,‌ ‌picks,‌ ‌and‌ ‌cleavers,‌ ‌\nfirst‌ ‌developed‌ ‌in‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌and‌ ‌then‌ ‌spread‌ ‌through‌ ‌Eurasia.‌ ‌\n277‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌accompanied‌ ‌the‌ ‌migrations‌ ‌of‌ ‌such‌ ‌humans‌ ‌as‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌and‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌heidelbergensis‌ ‌across‌ ‌Europe‌ ‌and‌ ‌Asia‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nenabled‌ ‌them‌ ‌to‌ ‌process‌ ‌their‌ ‌kills‌ ‌and‌ ‌side-dishes‌ ‌much‌ ‌more‌ ‌effectively.‌ ‌ ‌\n○These‌ ‌humans‌ ‌also‌ ‌gradually‌ ‌figured‌ ‌out‌ ‌how‌ ‌to‌ ‌harness‌ ‌fire‌ ‌properly‌ ‌and‌ ‌by‌ ‌at‌ ‌least‌ ‌400,000‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago‌ ‌habitual‌ ‌fire‌ ‌use‌ ‌became‌ ‌\nvisible‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌archaeological‌ ‌record,‌ ‌allowing‌ ‌cooking‌ ‌to‌ ‌help‌ ‌kick‌ ‌off‌ ‌all‌ ‌sorts‌ ‌of‌ ‌bodily‌ ‌developments‌ ‌(bigger‌ ‌brains!).‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Palaeolithic‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌further‌ ‌subdivided‌ ‌into‌ ‌three‌ ‌phases—lower‌ ‌Palaeolithic,‌ ‌Middle‌ ‌Palaeolithic‌ ‌and‌ ‌Upper‌ ‌Palaeolithic.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Lower‌ ‌Paleolithic‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌is‌ ‌earliest‌ ‌subdivision‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Paleolithic‌ ‌or‌ ‌Old‌ ‌Stone‌ ‌Age.‌ ‌It‌ ‌spans‌ ‌the‌ ‌time‌ ‌from‌ ‌around‌ ‌2.5‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago(Pleistocene‌ ‌\nepoch)‌ ‌when‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌of‌ ‌craft‌ ‌and‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌stone‌ ‌tools‌ ‌by‌ ‌hominids‌ ‌appears‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌current‌ ‌archaeological‌ ‌record,‌ ‌until‌ ‌\naround‌ ‌300,000‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago,‌ ‌spanning‌ ‌the‌ ‌Oldowan‌ ‌(\"mode‌ ‌1\")‌ ‌and‌ ‌Acheulean‌ ‌(\"mode‌ ‌2\")‌ ‌lithic‌ ‌technology.‌ ‌\n■Stone‌ ‌tool‌ ‌use:‌ ‌‌early‌ ‌human‌ ‌(hominid)‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌stone‌ ‌tool‌ ‌technology,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌hand‌ ‌axe,‌ ‌was‌ ‌similar‌ ‌to‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌primates,‌ ‌\nwhich‌ ‌is‌ ‌found‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌limited‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌intelligence‌ ‌levels‌ ‌of‌ ‌modern‌ ‌children‌ ‌aged‌ ‌3‌ ‌to‌ ‌5‌ ‌years.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Ancestors‌ ‌of‌ ‌homo‌ ‌sapiens‌ ‌(modern‌ ‌man)‌ ‌used‌ ‌stone‌ ‌tools‌ ‌as‌ ‌follows:‌ ‌\n●Homo‌ ‌habilis‌ ‌(\"handy‌ ‌man\")‌ ‌–‌ ‌first‌ ‌\"homo\"‌ ‌species.‌ ‌It‌ ‌lived‌ ‌from‌ ‌approximately‌ ‌2.3‌ ‌to‌ ‌1.4‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago‌ ‌in‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌created‌ ‌stone‌ ‌tools‌ ‌called‌ ‌‌Oldowan‌ ‌tools‌.‌ ‌\n●Homo‌ ‌ergaster‌ ‌‌–‌ ‌in‌ ‌eastern‌ ‌and‌ ‌southern‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌about‌ ‌2.5‌ ‌to‌ ‌1.7‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago,‌ ‌it‌ ‌refined‌ ‌‌Oldowan‌ ‌tools‌ ‌‌and‌ ‌\ndeveloped‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌‌Acheulean‌ ‌bifacial‌ ‌axes‌.‌ ‌\n●Homo‌ ‌erectus‌ ‌(\"upright‌ ‌man\")‌ ‌‌–‌ ‌lived‌ ‌about‌ ‌1.8‌ ‌to‌ ‌1.3‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago‌ ‌in‌ ‌West‌ ‌Asia‌ ‌and‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌and‌ ‌is‌ ‌thought‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌first‌ ‌hominid‌ ‌to‌ ‌hunt‌ ‌in‌ ‌coordinated‌ ‌groups,‌ ‌use‌ ‌complex‌ ‌tools,‌ ‌and‌ ‌care‌ ‌for‌ ‌infirm‌ ‌or‌ ‌weaker‌ ‌companions.‌ ‌\n●Homo‌ ‌antecessor‌ ‌‌–‌ ‌earliest‌ ‌hominid‌ ‌in‌ ‌Northern‌ ‌Europe.‌ ‌It‌ ‌lived‌ ‌from‌ ‌1.2‌ ‌million‌ ‌to‌ ‌800,000‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago‌ ‌and‌ ‌‌used‌ ‌\nstone‌ ‌tools‌.‌ ‌\n●Homo‌ ‌heidelbergensis‌ ‌–‌ ‌lived‌ ‌between‌ ‌600,000‌ ‌and‌ ‌400,000‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago‌ ‌and‌ ‌used‌ ‌stone‌ ‌tool‌ ‌technology‌ ‌similar‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nthe‌‌ ‌‌Acheulean‌ ‌tools‌ ‌used‌ ‌by‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌erectus.‌ ‌\n■Control‌ ‌of‌ ‌fire‌ ‌by‌ ‌early‌ ‌humans‌ ‌–‌ ‌European‌ ‌and‌ ‌Asian‌ ‌sites‌ ‌dating‌ ‌back‌ ‌1.5‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago‌ ‌seem‌ ‌to‌ ‌indicate‌ ‌controlled‌ ‌\nuse‌ ‌of‌ ‌fire‌ ‌by‌ ‌H.‌ ‌erectus.‌ ‌ ‌\n■A‌ ‌northern‌ ‌Israel‌ ‌site‌ ‌from‌ ‌about‌ ‌690,000‌ ‌to‌ ‌790,000‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago‌ ‌suggests‌ ‌controlled‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌fire‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌hearth‌ ‌from‌ ‌pre-existing‌ ‌\nnatural‌ ‌fires‌ ‌or‌ ‌embers.‌ ‌\n■Burial‌‌ ‌–‌ ‌the‌ ‌act‌ ‌of‌ ‌placing‌ ‌a‌ ‌deceased‌ ‌person‌ ‌into‌ ‌the‌ ‌ground.‌ ‌\n●Homo‌ ‌heidelbergensis‌ ‌–‌ ‌may‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌species‌ ‌to‌ ‌bury‌ ‌their‌ ‌dead‌ ‌about‌ ‌500,000‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nMiddle‌ ‌Paleolithic‌ ‌\n●Middle‌ ‌Paleolithic‌ ‌period‌ ‌–‌ ‌in‌ ‌Europe‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌Near‌ ‌East‌ ‌during‌ ‌which‌ ‌the‌ ‌Neanderthals‌ ‌lived‌ ‌(c.‌ ‌300,000–28,000‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago).‌ ‌ ‌\n●Their‌ ‌technology‌ ‌is‌ ‌mainly‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Mousterian‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌earliest‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌(Mungo‌ ‌Man)‌ ‌of‌ ‌settlement‌ ‌in‌ ‌Australia‌ ‌dates‌ ‌to‌ ‌around‌ ‌55,000‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago‌ ‌when‌ ‌modern‌ ‌humans‌ ‌likely‌ ‌\ncrossed‌ ‌from‌ ‌Asia‌ ‌by‌ ‌island-hopping.‌ ‌ ‌\n278‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Bhimbetka‌ ‌rock‌ ‌shelters‌ ‌exhibit‌ ‌the‌ ‌earliest‌ ‌traces‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌life‌ ‌in‌ ‌India,‌ ‌some‌ ‌of‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌approximately‌ ‌30,000‌ ‌years‌ ‌\nold.‌ ‌\n●Homo‌ ‌neanderthalensis‌ ‌\n■Stone‌ ‌tools‌ ‌‌–‌ ‌homo‌ ‌neanderthalensis‌ ‌used‌ ‌‌Mousterian‌ ‌stone‌ ‌tools‌ ‌that‌ ‌date‌ ‌back‌ ‌to‌ ‌around‌ ‌300,000‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago‌ ‌and‌ ‌\ninclude‌ ‌smaller,‌ ‌knife-like‌ ‌and‌ ‌scraper‌ ‌tools.‌ ‌\n■Burials‌ ‌–‌ ‌homo‌ ‌neanderthalensis‌ ‌buried‌ ‌their‌ ‌dead,‌ ‌doing‌ ‌so‌ ‌in‌ ‌shallow‌ ‌graves‌ ‌along‌ ‌with‌ ‌stone‌ ‌tools‌ ‌and‌ ‌animal‌ ‌\nbones,‌ ‌although‌ ‌the‌ ‌reasons‌ ‌and‌ ‌significance‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌burials‌ ‌are‌ ‌disputed.‌ ‌\n●Homo‌ ‌sapiens‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌only‌ ‌living‌ ‌species‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌genus‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌originated‌ ‌in‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌about‌ ‌200,000‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Greater‌ ‌mental‌ ‌capability‌ ‌and‌ ‌ability‌ ‌to‌ ‌walk‌ ‌erect‌ ‌provided‌ ‌freed‌ ‌hands‌ ‌for‌ ‌manipulating‌ ‌objects,‌ ‌which‌ ‌allowed‌ ‌for‌ ‌far‌ ‌\ngreater‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌tools.‌ ‌\n●Burial‌ ‌‌–‌ ‌intentional‌ ‌burial,‌ ‌particularly‌ ‌with‌ ‌grave‌ ‌goods,‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌earliest‌ ‌detectable‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌religious‌ ‌practice‌ ‌\nsince‌ ‌it‌ ‌may‌ ‌signify‌ ‌a‌ ‌\"concern‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌dead‌ ‌that‌ ‌transcends‌ ‌daily‌ ‌life.\"‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌earliest‌ ‌undisputed‌ ‌human‌ ‌burial‌ ‌so‌ ‌far‌ ‌dates‌ ‌back‌ ‌130,000‌ ‌years.‌ ‌Human‌ ‌skeletal‌ ‌remains‌ ‌stained‌ ‌with‌ ‌red‌ ‌ochre‌ ‌were‌ ‌\ndiscovered‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Skhul‌ ‌cave‌ ‌at‌ ‌Qafzeh,‌ ‌Israel‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌variety‌ ‌of‌ ‌grave‌ ‌goods.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Upper‌ ‌Paleolithic‌ ‌ ‌\n●Upper‌ ‌Paleolithic‌ ‌Revolution‌ ‌–‌ ‌theoretical‌ ‌occurrence‌ ‌between‌ ‌60,000‌ ‌and‌ ‌30,000‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago,‌ ‌possibly‌ ‌the‌ ‌origin‌ ‌of‌ ‌language,‌ ‌\nresulting‌ ‌in‌ ‌modern‌ ‌human‌ ‌behavior,‌ ‌accompanied‌ ‌radical‌ ‌advancements‌ ‌in‌ ‌technology‌ ‌made‌ ‌possible‌ ‌by‌ ‌it.‌ ‌\n●Behavioral‌ ‌modernity‌ ‌–‌ ‌a‌ ‌set‌ ‌of‌ ‌traits‌ ‌that‌ ‌distinguish‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌sapiens‌ ‌from‌ ‌extinct‌ ‌hominid‌ ‌lineages.‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌sapiens‌ ‌reached‌ ‌\nfull‌ ‌behavior‌ ‌modernity‌ ‌around‌ ‌50,000‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌highly‌ ‌developed‌ ‌brain‌ ‌capable‌ ‌of‌ ‌abstract‌ ‌reasoning,‌ ‌language,‌ ‌\nintrospection,‌ ‌and‌ ‌problem‌ ‌solving.‌ ‌\n●Tools‌ ‌–‌‌ ‌included‌ ‌‌Aurignacian‌ ‌tools,‌‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌stone‌ ‌bladed‌ ‌tools,‌ ‌tools‌ ‌made‌ ‌of‌ ‌antlers,‌ ‌and‌ ‌tools‌ ‌made‌ ‌of‌ ‌bones.‌ ‌\n●Clothing‌ ‌‌–‌ ‌evidence,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌possible‌ ‌sewing‌ ‌needles‌ ‌from‌ ‌around‌ ‌40,000‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago‌ ‌and‌ ‌dyed‌ ‌flax‌ ‌fibers‌ ‌dated‌ ‌36,000‌ ‌BP‌ ‌\nfound‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌prehistoric‌ ‌cave‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Republic‌ ‌of‌ ‌Georgia‌ ‌suggest‌ ‌that‌ ‌people‌ ‌were‌ ‌wearing‌ ‌clothes‌ ‌at‌ ‌this‌ ‌time.‌ ‌\n●Human‌ ‌beings‌ ‌may‌ ‌have‌ ‌begun‌ ‌wearing‌ ‌clothing‌ ‌as‌ ‌far‌ ‌back‌ ‌as‌ ‌190,000‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago.‌ ‌\n●Art‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Upper‌ ‌Paleolithic‌ ‌–‌ ‌included‌ ‌cave‌ ‌painting,‌ ‌sculpture‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Venus‌ ‌figurines‌,‌ ‌carvings‌ ‌and‌ ‌engravings‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nbone‌ ‌and‌ ‌ivory,‌ ‌and‌ ‌musical‌ ‌instruments‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌flutes.‌ ‌The‌ ‌most‌ ‌common‌ ‌subject‌ ‌matter‌ ‌was‌ ‌large‌ ‌animals‌ ‌that‌ ‌were‌ ‌\nhunted‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌people‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌time.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nMesolithic/Middle‌ ‌Stone‌ ‌Age‌ ‌\n ‌\n279‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nIntroduction‌ ‌\n●Mesolithic,‌ ‌also‌ ‌called‌ ‌Middle‌ ‌Stone‌ ‌Age,‌ ‌‌ancient‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌stage‌ ‌that‌ ‌existed‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌Paleolithic‌ ‌(Old‌ ‌Stone‌ ‌Age),‌ ‌with‌ ‌its‌ ‌chipped‌ ‌stone‌ ‌\ntools,‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌Neolithic‌ ‌(New‌ ‌Stone‌ ‌Age),‌ ‌with‌ ‌its‌ ‌polished‌ ‌stone‌ ‌tools.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌transitional‌ ‌period‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Paleolithic‌ ‌hunter-gatherers,‌ ‌beginning‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌Holocene‌ ‌warm‌ ‌period‌ ‌around‌ ‌11,660‌ ‌BP‌ ‌and‌ ‌ending‌ ‌\nwith‌ ‌the‌ ‌Neolithic‌ ‌introduction‌ ‌of‌ ‌farmin‌g,‌ ‌the‌ ‌date‌ ‌of‌ ‌which‌ ‌varied‌ ‌in‌ ‌each‌ ‌geographical‌ ‌region.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Because‌ ‌the‌ ‌Mesolithic‌ ‌is‌ ‌characterized‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌suite‌ ‌of‌ ‌material‌ ‌culture,‌ ‌‌its‌ ‌timing‌ ‌varies‌ ‌depending‌ ‌upon‌ ‌location.‌ ‌In‌ ‌northwestern‌ ‌\nEurope,‌ ‌for‌ ‌instance,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Mesolithic‌ ‌began‌ ‌about‌ ‌8000‌ ‌BCE,‌ ‌after‌ ‌the‌ ‌end‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Pleistocene‌ ‌Epoch‌ ‌(i.e.,‌ ‌about‌ ‌2,600,000‌ ‌to‌ ‌11,700‌ ‌\nyears‌ ‌ago),‌ ‌and‌ ‌lasted‌ ‌until‌ ‌about‌ ‌2700‌ ‌BCE‌.‌ ‌Elsewhere‌ ‌the‌ ‌dates‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Mesolithic‌ ‌are‌ ‌somewhat‌ ‌different.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Adaptation‌ ‌was‌ ‌required‌ ‌during‌ ‌this‌ ‌period‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌climate‌ ‌changes‌ ‌that‌ ‌affected‌ ‌the‌ ‌environment‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌available‌ ‌food.‌ ‌\n●Mesolithic‌ ‌material‌ ‌culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌characterized‌ ‌by‌ ‌greater‌ ‌innovation‌ ‌and‌ ‌diversity‌ ‌than‌ ‌is‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Paleolithic.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Among‌ ‌the‌ ‌new‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌chipped‌ ‌stone‌ ‌tools‌ ‌were‌ ‌microliths‌,‌ ‌very‌ ‌small‌ ‌stone‌ ‌tools‌ ‌intended‌ ‌for‌ ‌mounting‌ ‌together‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌shaft‌ ‌to‌ ‌produce‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nserrated‌ ‌edge.‌ ‌Polished‌ ‌stone‌ ‌was‌ ‌another‌ ‌innovation‌ ‌that‌ ‌occurred‌ ‌in‌ ‌some‌ ‌Mesolithic‌ ‌assemblages.‌ ‌\n●Although‌ ‌culturally‌ ‌and‌ ‌technologically‌ ‌continuous‌ ‌with‌ ‌Paleolithic‌ ‌peoples,‌ ‌Mesolithic‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌developed‌ ‌diverse‌ ‌local‌ ‌adaptations‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nspecial‌ ‌environments.‌ ‌The‌ ‌Mesolithic‌ ‌hunter‌ ‌achieved‌ ‌a‌ ‌greater‌ ‌efficiency‌ ‌than‌ ‌did‌ ‌the‌ ‌Paleolithic‌ ‌and‌ ‌was‌ ‌able‌ ‌to‌ ‌exploit‌ ‌a‌ ‌wider‌ ‌range‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nanimal‌ ‌and‌ ‌vegetable‌ ‌food‌ ‌sources.‌ ‌\nMesolithic‌ ‌technology‌ ‌\n●Stone‌ ‌tool‌ ‌changes‌‌ ‌–‌ ‌small‌ ‌stone‌ ‌tools‌ ‌called‌ ‌Microliths,‌ ‌including‌ ‌small‌ ‌bladelets‌ ‌and‌ ‌microburins,‌ ‌emerged‌ ‌during‌ ‌this‌ ‌period.‌ ‌\n●Weapons‌ ‌–‌ ‌spears‌ ‌or‌ ‌arrows‌ ‌were‌ ‌found‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌earliest‌ ‌known‌ ‌Mesolithic‌ ‌battle‌ ‌site‌ ‌at‌ ‌Cemetery‌ ‌117‌ ‌in‌ ‌Sudan.‌ ‌\n●Holmegaard‌ ‌bows‌ ‌were‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌bogs‌ ‌of‌ ‌Northern‌ ‌Europe‌ ‌dating‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌Mesolithic‌ ‌period.‌ ‌\n●At‌ ‌about‌ ‌6000‌ ‌BCE,‌ ‌when‌ ‌the‌ ‌Maglemosian‌ ‌culture‌ ‌flourished,‌ ‌traces‌ ‌of‌ ‌huts‌ ‌with‌ ‌bark-covered‌ ‌floors‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌found.‌ ‌\n ‌\n280‌ ‌\n ‌\n281‌ ‌\nEpipalaeolithic‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌archaeology,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Epipalaeolithic‌ ‌or‌ ‌Epipaleolithic‌ ‌(sometimes‌ ‌Epi-paleolithic‌ ‌etc.)‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌term‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌period‌ ‌occurring‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Upper‌ ‌\nPaleolithic‌ ‌‌and‌ ‌Neolithic‌ ‌during‌ ‌the‌ ‌Stone‌ ‌Age.‌ ‌‌Mesolithic‌ ‌also‌ ‌falls‌ ‌between‌ ‌these‌ ‌two‌ ‌periods,‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌two‌ ‌are‌ ‌sometimes‌ ‌confused‌ ‌\nor‌ ‌used‌ ‌as‌ ‌synonyms.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Epipalaeolithic‌ ‌hunter-gatherers,‌ ‌generally‌ ‌nomadic,‌ ‌made‌ ‌relatively‌ ‌advanced‌ ‌tools‌ ‌from‌ ‌small‌ ‌flint‌ ‌or‌ ‌obsidian‌ ‌blades,‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌\nmicroliths,‌ ‌that‌ ‌were‌ ‌hafted‌ ‌in‌ ‌wooden‌ ‌implements.‌ ‌\n●There‌ ‌are‌ ‌settlements‌ ‌with‌ ‌\"flimsy‌ ‌structures\",‌ ‌probably‌ ‌not‌ ‌permanently‌ ‌occupied‌ ‌except‌ ‌at‌ ‌some‌ ‌rich‌ ‌sites,‌ ‌but‌ ‌used‌ ‌and‌ ‌returned‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nseasonally.‌ ‌\n ‌\n282‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nNatufian‌ ‌culture‌ ‌\n283‌ ‌\n ‌\n●The‌ ‌Natufian‌ ‌culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌‌Late‌ ‌Epipaleolithic‌ ‌archaeological‌ ‌culture‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Levant,‌ ‌dating‌ ‌to‌ ‌around‌ ‌15,000‌ ‌to‌ ‌11,500‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago.‌ ‌\n●Radiocarbon‌ ‌dating‌ ‌places‌ ‌the‌ ‌Natufian‌ ‌culture‌ ‌at‌ ‌an‌ ‌epoch‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌t‌erminal‌ ‌Pleistocene‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌very‌ ‌beginning‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Holocene,‌ ‌a‌ ‌time‌ ‌\nperiod‌ ‌between‌ ‌12,500‌ ‌and‌ ‌9,500‌ ‌BC.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌culture‌ ‌was‌ ‌unusual‌ ‌in‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌‌supported‌ ‌a‌ ‌sedentary‌ ‌or‌ ‌semi-sedentary‌ ‌population‌ ‌‌even‌ ‌before‌ ‌the‌ ‌introduction‌ ‌of‌ ‌agriculture.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Natufian‌ ‌communities‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌the‌ ‌ancestors‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌builders‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌Neolithic‌ ‌settlements‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌region,‌ ‌which‌ ‌may‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nearliest‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌world.‌ ‌ ‌\n284‌ ‌\n●Natufians‌ ‌founded‌ ‌a‌ ‌settlement‌ ‌where‌ ‌Jericho(‌a‌ ‌Palestinian‌ ‌city‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌West‌ ‌Bank‌)‌ ‌is‌ ‌today,‌ ‌which‌ ‌may‌ ‌therefore‌ ‌be‌ ‌the‌ ‌longest‌ ‌\ncontinuously‌ ‌inhabited‌ ‌urban‌ ‌area‌ ‌on‌ ‌Earth.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Some‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌suggests‌ ‌‌deliberate‌ ‌cultivation‌ ‌of‌ ‌cereals,‌ ‌specifically‌ ‌rye,‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌Natufian‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\n●Generally,‌ ‌though,‌ ‌Natufians‌ ‌exploited‌ ‌wild‌ ‌cereals.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Animals‌ ‌hunted‌ ‌included‌ ‌gazelles.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Natufian‌ ‌culture‌ ‌was‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌by‌ ‌‌British‌ ‌archaeologist‌ ‌Dorothy‌ ‌Garrod‌ ‌during‌ ‌her‌ ‌excavations‌ ‌of‌ ‌Shuqba‌ ‌cave‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Judaean‌ ‌\nHills‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌West‌ ‌Bank‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Jordan‌ ‌River.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nKhiamian‌ ‌\n285‌ ‌\n ‌\n●The‌ ‌Khiamian‌ ‌(also‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to‌ ‌as‌ ‌El‌ ‌Khiam‌ ‌or‌ ‌El-Khiam)‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌period‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Near-Eastern‌ ‌Neolithic,‌ ‌marking‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌transition‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nNatufian‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌Pre-Pottery‌ ‌Neolithic.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Some‌ ‌sources‌ ‌date‌ ‌it‌ ‌from‌ ‌about‌ ‌10,000‌ ‌to‌ ‌9,500‌ ‌BCE‌ ‌(12,000–11,500‌ ‌BP).‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Khiamian‌ ‌owes‌ ‌its‌ ‌name‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌site‌ ‌of‌ ‌El‌ ‌Khiam,‌ ‌situated‌ ‌on‌ ‌banks‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Dead‌ ‌Sea,‌ ‌where‌ ‌researchers‌ ‌have‌ ‌recovered‌ ‌the‌ ‌oldest‌ ‌\nchert‌ ‌arrowheads,‌ ‌with‌ ‌lateral‌ ‌notches,‌ ‌the‌ ‌so-called‌ ‌\"El‌ ‌Khiam‌ ‌points\".‌ ‌\n●El‌ ‌Khiam‌ ‌culture‌ ‌were‌ ‌still‌ ‌hunter-gatherers,‌ ‌and‌ ‌agriculture‌ ‌at‌ ‌that‌ ‌time‌ ‌was‌ ‌then‌ ‌still‌ ‌rather‌ ‌primitive,‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌what‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌reported‌ ‌\non‌ ‌sites‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌period.‌ ‌\n ‌\nTahunian‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Tahunian‌ ‌is‌ ‌variously‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to‌ ‌as‌ ‌an‌ ‌archaeological‌ ‌culture,‌ ‌flint‌ ‌industry‌ ‌and‌ ‌period‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Palestinian‌ ‌Stone‌ ‌Age‌ ‌around‌ ‌Wadi‌ ‌\n286‌ ‌\nTahuna‌ ‌near‌ ‌Bethlehem.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌was‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌and‌ ‌termed‌ ‌by‌ ‌‌Denis‌ ‌Buzy‌‌ ‌during‌ ‌excavations‌ ‌in‌ ‌1928.‌ ‌\n ‌\nHeavy‌ ‌Neolithic‌ ‌(alternatively,‌ ‌Gigantolithic)‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌style‌ ‌of‌ ‌large‌ ‌stone‌ ‌and‌ ‌flint‌ ‌tools‌ ‌(or‌ ‌industry)‌ ‌associated‌ ‌primarily‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌Qaraoun‌ ‌culture‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Beqaa‌ ‌Valley,‌ ‌Lebanon,‌ ‌dating‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌Epipaleolithic‌ ‌or‌ ‌early‌ ‌Pre-Pottery‌ ‌Neolithic‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌end‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Stone‌ ‌Age.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌type‌ ‌site‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Qaraoun‌ ‌culture‌ ‌‌is‌ ‌Qaraoun‌ ‌II.‌ ‌\n ‌\nThe‌ ‌Pre-Pottery‌ ‌Neolithic‌ ‌(PPN)‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌represents‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌early‌ ‌Neolithic‌ ‌‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Levantine‌ ‌and‌ ‌upper‌ ‌Mesopotamian‌ ‌region‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Fertile‌ ‌Crescent,‌ ‌dating‌ ‌to‌ ‌c. 12,000‌ ‌–‌ ‌c. 8,500‌ ‌\nyears‌ ‌ago,‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌10,000-6,500‌ ‌BCE.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌succeeds‌ ‌the‌ ‌Natufian‌ ‌culture‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Epipalaeolithic‌ ‌Near‌ ‌East‌ ‌(also‌ ‌called‌ ‌Mesolithic),‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌domestication‌ ‌of‌ ‌plants‌ ‌and‌ ‌animals‌ ‌was‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nits‌ ‌formative‌ ‌stages,‌ ‌having‌ ‌possibly‌ ‌been‌ ‌induced‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌Younger‌ ‌Dryas.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Pre-Pottery‌ ‌Neolithic‌ ‌culture‌ ‌came‌ ‌to‌ ‌an‌ ‌end‌ ‌around‌ ‌the‌ ‌time‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌8.2‌ ‌kiloyear‌ ‌event,‌ ‌a‌ ‌cool‌ ‌spell‌ ‌centred‌ ‌on‌ ‌6200‌ ‌BCE‌ ‌that‌ ‌lasted‌ ‌\nseveral‌ ‌hundred‌ ‌years.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌succeeded‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌Pottery‌ ‌Neolithic.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nNeolithic/Late‌ ‌Stone‌ ‌Age‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nIntroduction‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌term‌ ‌Neolithic‌ ‌derives‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌Greek‌ ‌literally‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌‌\"New‌ ‌Stone‌ ‌Age‌\".‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Neolithic‌ ‌comprises‌ ‌a‌ ‌progression‌ ‌of‌ ‌behavioral‌ ‌and‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌and‌ ‌changes,‌ ‌including‌ ‌the‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌wild‌ ‌and‌ ‌domestic‌ ‌crops‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌of‌ ‌domesticated‌ ‌animals.‌ ‌\n●Because‌ ‌agriculture‌ ‌developed‌ ‌at‌ ‌different‌ ‌times‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌regions‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌world,‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌single‌ ‌date‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌beginning‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Neolithic‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n287‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌the‌ ‌Near‌ ‌East,‌ ‌agriculture‌ ‌was‌ ‌developed‌ ‌around‌ ‌9,000‌ ‌BCE,‌ ‌in‌ ‌Southeast‌ ‌Europe‌ ‌around‌ ‌7,000‌ ‌BCE,‌ ‌and‌ ‌later‌ ‌in‌ ‌other‌ ‌regions.‌ ‌\nEven‌ ‌within‌ ‌a‌ ‌specific‌ ‌region,‌ ‌agriculture‌ ‌developed‌ ‌during‌ ‌different‌ ‌times.‌ ‌For‌ ‌example,‌ ‌agriculture‌ ‌first‌ ‌developed‌ ‌in‌ ‌Southeast‌ ‌\nEurope‌ ‌about‌ ‌7,000‌ ‌BCE,‌ ‌in‌ ‌Central‌ ‌Europe‌ ‌about‌ ‌5,500‌ ‌BCE,‌ ‌and‌ ‌Northern‌ ‌Europe‌ ‌about‌ ‌4,000‌ ‌BCE.‌ ‌In‌ ‌East‌ ‌Asia,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Neolithic‌ ‌\ngoes‌ ‌from‌ ‌6000‌ ‌to‌ ‌2000‌ ‌BCE.‌ ‌\nNeolithic‌ ‌Revolution‌ ‌\n●Neolithic‌ ‌Revolution‌ ‌–‌ ‌first‌ ‌agricultural‌ ‌revolution,‌ ‌representing‌ ‌a‌ ‌transition‌ ‌from‌ ‌hunting‌ ‌and‌ ‌gathering‌ ‌nomadic‌ ‌life‌ ‌to‌ ‌an‌ ‌agriculture‌ ‌\nexistence.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌evolved‌ ‌independently‌ ‌in‌ ‌six‌ ‌separate‌ ‌locations‌ ‌worldwide‌ ‌circa‌ ‌10,000–7000‌ ‌years‌ ‌BP‌ ‌(8,000–5,000‌ ‌BC).‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌earliest‌ ‌known‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌exists‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌tropical‌ ‌and‌ ‌subtropical‌ ‌areas‌ ‌of‌ ‌southwestern/southern‌ ‌Asia,‌ ‌northern/central‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌and‌ ‌Central‌ ‌\nAmerica.‌ ‌\n●Vere‌ ‌Gordon‌ ‌Childe‌‌ ‌gave‌ ‌the‌ ‌name‌ ‌Neolithic‌ ‌Revolution‌ ‌to‌ ‌this‌ ‌process‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌1920s.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌thought‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌as‌ ‌important‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌Industrial‌ ‌Revolution‌ ‌(which‌ ‌happened‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌18th‌ ‌and‌ ‌19th‌ ‌century).‌ ‌\n ‌\nDefining‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌\n●Introduction‌ ‌of‌ ‌agriculture‌ ‌‌–‌ ‌a‌ ‌defining‌ ‌characteristic‌ ‌of‌ ‌Neolithic‌ ‌societies,‌ ‌which‌ ‌resulted‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌swing‌ ‌from‌ ‌a‌ ‌nomadic‌ ‌lifestyle‌ ‌to‌ ‌one‌ ‌that‌ ‌\nwas‌ ‌more‌ ‌sedentary,and‌ ‌the‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌agricultural‌ ‌tools‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌plough,‌ ‌digging‌ ‌stick‌ ‌and‌ ‌hoe‌ ‌(tool).‌ ‌\n●Domestication‌ ‌‌–‌ ‌of‌ ‌animals,‌ ‌including‌ ‌dogs.‌ ‌\n●Pottery‌‌ ‌–‌ ‌emerged‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌defining‌ ‌characteristic‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Neolithic‌ ‌period.‌ ‌\n●Permanent‌ ‌Settlement‌ ‌-‌ ‌Living‌ ‌in‌ ‌permanent‌ ‌settlements‌ ‌brought‌ ‌new‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌organization.‌ ‌As‌ ‌the‌ ‌subsistence‌ ‌strategies‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nNeolithic‌ ‌communities‌ ‌became‌ ‌more‌ ‌efficient,‌ ‌the‌ ‌population‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌different‌ ‌settlements‌ ‌increased.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Architecture‌ ‌‌–‌ ‌included‌ ‌houses‌ ‌and‌ ‌villages‌ ‌built‌ ‌of‌ ‌mud-brick‌ ‌and‌ ‌wattle‌ ‌and‌ ‌daub‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌construction‌ ‌of‌ ‌storage‌ ‌facilities,‌ ‌tombs‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nmonuments.‌ ‌\n●Metalworking‌‌ ‌–‌ ‌copper‌ ‌use‌ ‌began‌ ‌as‌ ‌early‌ ‌as‌ ‌9000‌ ‌BC‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Middle‌ ‌East;‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌copper‌ ‌pendant‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌northern‌ ‌Iraq‌ ‌dated‌ ‌to‌ ‌8700‌ ‌BCE.‌ ‌\n●Numeric‌ ‌counting‌‌ ‌–‌ ‌record‌ ‌keeping‌ ‌evolved‌ ‌from‌ ‌a‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌counting‌ ‌using‌ ‌small‌ ‌clay‌ ‌tokens‌ ‌that‌ ‌began‌ ‌in‌ ‌Sumer‌ ‌about‌ ‌8000‌ ‌BCE.‌ ‌\n●Proto-writing‌ ‌‌–‌ ‌ideographic‌ ‌and/or‌ ‌early‌ ‌mnemonic‌ ‌symbols‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌convey‌ ‌information,‌ ‌probably‌ ‌devoid‌ ‌of‌ ‌direct‌ ‌linguistic‌ ‌content.‌ ‌These‌ ‌\nsystems‌ ‌emerged‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌early‌ ‌Neolithic‌ ‌period,‌ ‌as‌ ‌early‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌7th‌ ‌millennium‌ ‌BCE.‌ ‌\n●Stone‌ ‌tools‌ ‌‌–‌ ‌ground‌ ‌and‌ ‌polished‌ ‌tools‌ ‌were‌ ‌created‌ ‌during‌ ‌the‌ ‌Neolithic‌ ‌period.‌ ‌\n●Religious‌ ‌structures‌‌ ‌–‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌Göbekli‌ ‌Tepe‌ ‌built‌ ‌about‌ ‌12,000‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago.‌ ‌\n●Wheel‌ ‌‌–‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌late‌ ‌Neolithic‌ ‌period,‌ ‌the‌ ‌wheel‌ ‌was‌ ‌introduced‌ ‌for‌ ‌making‌ ‌pottery.‌ ‌\n●By‌ ‌adopting‌ ‌a‌ ‌sedentary‌ ‌way‌ ‌of‌ ‌life,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Neolithic‌ ‌groups‌ ‌increased‌ ‌their‌ ‌awareness‌ ‌of‌ ‌territoriality.‌ ‌During‌ ‌the‌ ‌9600-6900‌ ‌BCE‌ ‌period‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nNear‌ ‌East,‌ ‌there‌ ‌were‌ ‌also‌ ‌innovations‌ ‌in‌ ‌arrowheads,‌ ‌yet‌ ‌no‌ ‌important‌ ‌changes‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌animals‌ ‌hunted‌ ‌were‌ ‌detected.‌ ‌ ‌\n●However,‌ ‌human‌ ‌skeletons‌ ‌were‌ ‌found‌ ‌with‌ ‌arrowheads‌ ‌embedded‌ ‌in‌ ‌them‌ ‌and‌ ‌also‌ ‌some‌ ‌settlements‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌Jericho‌ ‌were‌ ‌surrounded‌ ‌\nwith‌ ‌a‌ ‌massive‌ ‌wall‌ ‌and‌ ‌ditch‌ ‌around‌ ‌this‌ ‌time.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌seems‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌period‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌testimony‌ ‌of‌ ‌inter-communal‌ ‌conflicts,‌ ‌not‌ ‌far‌ ‌from‌ ‌organized‌ ‌warfare.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n288‌ ‌\nChalcolithic‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌‌Chalcolithic,‌ ‌or‌ ‌Copper‌ ‌Age,‌ ‌‌also‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Eneolithic‌ ‌or‌ ‌Aeneolithic‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌archaeological‌ ‌period‌ ‌which‌ ‌‌researchers‌ ‌now‌ ‌regard‌ ‌\nas‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌broader‌ ‌Neolithic‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Earlier‌ ‌scholars‌ ‌defined‌ ‌it‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌transitional‌ ‌period‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌Neolithic‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌Bronze‌ ‌Age.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌the‌ ‌context‌ ‌of‌ ‌Eastern‌ ‌Europe,‌ ‌archaeologists‌ ‌often‌ ‌prefer‌ ‌the‌ ‌term‌ ‌\"Eneolithic\"‌ ‌to‌ ‌\"Chalcolithic\"‌ ‌or‌ ‌other‌ ‌alternatives.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌the‌ ‌Chalcolithic‌ ‌period,‌ ‌copper‌ ‌predominated‌ ‌in‌ ‌metalworking‌ ‌technology.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Hence‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌period‌ ‌before‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌that‌ ‌by‌ ‌adding‌ ‌tin‌ ‌to‌ ‌copper‌ ‌one‌ ‌could‌ ‌create‌ ‌bronze,‌ ‌a‌ ‌metal‌ ‌alloy‌ ‌harder‌ ‌and‌ ‌stronger‌ ‌\nthan‌ ‌either‌ ‌component.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌archaeological‌ ‌site‌ ‌of‌ ‌‌Belovode,‌ ‌on‌ ‌Rudnik‌ ‌mountain‌ ‌in‌ ‌Serbia,‌ ‌has‌ ‌the‌ ‌world's‌ ‌oldest‌ ‌securely-dated‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌of‌ ‌copper‌ ‌smelting‌ ‌at‌ ‌\nhigh‌ ‌temperature,‌ ‌from‌ ‌c.‌ ‌5000‌ ‌BC‌ ‌(7000‌ ‌BP).‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌the‌ ‌Chalcolithic‌ ‌period,‌ ‌copper‌ ‌predominated‌ ‌in‌ ‌metalworking‌ ‌technology.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Hence,‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌period‌ ‌before‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌that‌ ‌by‌ ‌adding‌ ‌tin‌ ‌to‌ ‌copper‌ ‌one‌ ‌could‌ ‌create‌ ‌bronze,‌ ‌a‌ ‌metal‌ ‌alloy‌ ‌harder‌ ‌and‌ ‌stronger‌ ‌\nthan‌ ‌either‌ ‌component.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌archaeological‌ ‌‌site‌ ‌of‌ ‌Belovode,‌ ‌on‌ ‌Rudnik‌ ‌mountain‌ ‌in‌ ‌Serbia,‌ ‌has‌ ‌the‌ ‌worldwide‌ ‌oldest‌ ‌securely-dated‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌of‌ ‌copper‌ ‌smelting‌ ‌at‌ ‌\nhigh‌ ‌temperature,‌ ‌from‌ ‌c.‌ ‌5000‌ ‌BC‌ ‌(7000‌ ‌BP)‌.‌ ‌\n ‌\nThe‌ ‌End‌ ‌of‌ ‌Neolithic‌ ‌\n●Towards‌ ‌the‌ ‌end‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Neolithic‌ ‌era,‌ ‌copper‌ ‌metallurgy‌ ‌is‌ ‌introduced,‌ ‌which‌ ‌marks‌ ‌a‌ ‌transition‌ ‌period‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌Bronze‌ ‌Age,‌ ‌sometimes‌ ‌\nreferred‌ ‌to‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌Chalcolithic‌ ‌or‌ ‌Eneolithic‌ ‌Era.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Bronze‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌mixture‌ ‌of‌ ‌copper‌ ‌and‌ ‌tin,‌ ‌which‌ ‌has‌ ‌a‌ ‌greater‌ ‌hardness‌ ‌than‌ ‌copper,‌ ‌better‌ ‌casting‌ ‌properties,‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌lower‌ ‌melting‌ ‌point.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Bronze‌ ‌could‌ ‌be‌ ‌used‌ ‌for‌ ‌making‌ ‌weapons,‌ ‌something‌ ‌that‌ ‌was‌ ‌not‌ ‌possible‌ ‌with‌ ‌copper,‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌hard‌ ‌enough‌ ‌to‌ ‌endure‌ ‌combat‌ ‌\nconditions.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌time,‌ ‌‌bronze‌ ‌became‌ ‌the‌ ‌primary‌ ‌material‌ ‌for‌ ‌tools‌ ‌and‌ ‌weapons,‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌good‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌stone‌ ‌technology‌ ‌became‌ ‌obsolete,‌ ‌signalling‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nend‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Neolithic‌ ‌and‌ ‌thus,‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Stone‌ ‌Age.‌ ‌\n ‌\n289‌ ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌Addition‌ ‌\n ‌\n290‌ ‌\nCopper-Bronze‌ ‌Age‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●The‌ ‌Bronze‌ ‌Age‌ ‌is‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌three-age‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌archaeology‌ ‌that‌ ‌divides‌ ‌human‌ ‌technological‌ ‌prehistory‌ ‌into‌ ‌three‌ ‌periods:‌ ‌the‌ ‌Stone‌ ‌\nAge,‌ ‌Bronze‌ ‌Age,‌ ‌and‌ ‌Iron‌ ‌Age‌ ‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Bronze‌ ‌Age‌ ‌spanned‌ ‌from‌ ‌3,000‌ ‌to‌ ‌1,200‌ ‌BCE‌ ‌and‌ ‌is‌ ‌characterized‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌copper‌ ‌and‌ ‌its‌ ‌alloy‌ ‌bronze‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌chief‌ ‌hard‌ ‌materials‌ ‌\nin‌ ‌the‌ ‌manufacturing‌ ‌of‌ ‌implements‌ ‌and‌ ‌weapons.‌ ‌This‌ ‌period‌ ‌ended‌ ‌with‌ ‌further‌ ‌advancements‌ ‌in‌ ‌metallurgy‌ ‌,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌ability‌ ‌to‌ ‌smelt‌ ‌\niron‌ ‌ore.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌‌Stone‌ ‌Age‌ ‌developed‌ ‌into‌ ‌the‌ ‌Bronze‌ ‌Age‌ ‌after‌ ‌the‌ ‌Neolithic‌ ‌Revolution.‌ ‌The‌ ‌Neolithic‌ ‌Revolution‌ ‌involved‌ ‌radical‌ ‌changes‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nagricultural‌ ‌technology‌ ‌which‌ ‌included‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌agriculture,‌ ‌animal‌ ‌domestication,‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌adoption‌ ‌of‌ ‌permanent‌ ‌settlements.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Bronze‌ ‌Age‌ ‌is‌ ‌‌characterised‌ ‌by‌ ‌metal‌ ‌smelting‌ ‌of‌ ‌copper‌ ‌and‌ ‌its‌ ‌alloy‌ ‌bronze‌,‌ ‌an‌ ‌alloy‌ ‌of‌ ‌tin‌ ‌and‌ ‌copper,‌ ‌to‌ ‌create‌ ‌implements‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nweapons.‌ ‌Polished‌ ‌stone‌ ‌tools‌ ‌continued‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌used‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌their‌ ‌abundance‌ ‌compared‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌less‌ ‌common‌ ‌metals‌ ‌(especially‌ ‌tin).‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌technological‌ ‌trend‌ ‌apparently‌ ‌began‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Fertile‌ ‌Crescent,‌ ‌and‌ ‌spread‌ ‌outward.‌ ‌\n291‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌Fertile‌ ‌Crescent‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌crescent-shaped‌ ‌region‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Middle‌ ‌East,‌ ‌spanning‌ ‌modern-day‌ ‌Iraq,‌ ‌Syria,‌ ‌Lebanon,‌ ‌Palestine,‌ ‌Israel,‌ ‌\nJordan,‌ ‌and‌ ‌Egypt,‌ ‌together‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌southeastern‌ ‌region‌ ‌of‌ ‌Turkey‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌western‌ ‌fringes‌ ‌of‌ ‌Iran.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n●The‌ ‌term‌ ‌also‌ ‌denotes‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌period‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌metal‌ ‌was‌ ‌used.‌ ‌‌The‌ ‌date‌ ‌at‌ ‌which‌ ‌the‌ ‌age‌ ‌began‌ ‌varied‌ ‌with‌ ‌regions;‌ ‌in‌ ‌Greece‌ ‌and‌ ‌China,‌ ‌\nfor‌ ‌instance,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Bronze‌ ‌Age‌ ‌began‌ ‌before‌ ‌3000‌ ‌BCE,‌ ‌whereas‌ ‌in‌ ‌Britain‌ ‌it‌ ‌did‌ ‌not‌ ‌start‌ ‌until‌ ‌about‌ ‌1900‌ ‌BCE.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌beginning‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌period‌ ‌is‌ ‌sometimes‌ ‌called‌ ‌the‌ ‌Chalcolithic‌ ‌(Copper-Stone)‌ ‌Age,‌ ‌referring‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌initial‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌pure‌ ‌copper‌ ‌(along‌ ‌with‌ ‌its‌ ‌\npredecessor‌ ‌toolmaking‌ ‌material,‌ ‌stone).‌ ‌ ‌\n●By‌ ‌3000‌ ‌the‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌copper‌ ‌was‌ ‌well‌ ‌known‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Middle‌ ‌East,‌ ‌had‌ ‌extended‌ ‌westward‌ ‌into‌ ‌the‌ ‌Mediterranean‌ ‌area,‌ ‌and‌ ‌was‌ ‌beginning‌ ‌to‌ ‌\ninfiltrate‌ ‌the‌ ‌Neolithic‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌of‌ ‌Europe.‌ ‌\n●Bronze‌ ‌Age‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌‌differed‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌writing‌.‌ ‌According‌ ‌to‌ ‌archaeological‌ ‌evidence,‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌in‌ ‌Mesopotamia‌ ‌\n(cuneiform‌ ‌script)‌ ‌and‌ ‌Egypt‌ ‌(hieroglyphs)‌ ‌developed‌ ‌the‌ ‌earliest‌ ‌practical‌ ‌writing‌ ‌systems.‌ ‌\n ‌\nCharacteristics‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌era‌ ‌saw‌ ‌the‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌civilization‌ ‌in‌ ‌every‌ ‌region‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Mediterranean‌ ‌and‌ ‌in‌ ‌every‌ ‌aspect.‌ ‌The‌ ‌Bronze‌ ‌Age‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌period‌ ‌best‌ ‌\nknown‌ ‌for‌ ‌its‌ ‌advances‌ ‌in‌ ‌culture,‌ ‌language,‌ ‌technology,‌ ‌religion,‌ ‌art,‌ ‌architecture,‌ ‌politics,‌ ‌warfare,‌ ‌and‌ ‌trade.‌ ‌\n●Art:‌ ‌‌The‌ ‌best‌ ‌examples‌ ‌of‌ ‌Bronze‌ ‌Age‌ ‌art‌ ‌appeared‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌'cradle‌ ‌of‌ ‌civilization'‌ ‌around‌ ‌the‌ ‌Mediterranean‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Near‌ ‌East,‌ ‌during‌ ‌the‌ ‌rise‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌Mesopotamia‌ ‌(present-day‌ ‌Iraq).‌ ‌\n○Egyptian‌ ‌art‌ ‌was‌ ‌also‌ ‌established‌ ‌during‌ ‌the‌ ‌Bronze‌ ‌Age,‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌monumental‌ ‌architecture‌ ‌-‌ ‌notably‌ ‌the‌ ‌Egyptian‌ ‌Pyramids‌ ‌-‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌also‌ ‌included‌ ‌a‌ ‌range‌ ‌of‌ ‌murals,‌ ‌pottery‌ ‌and‌ ‌sculpture.‌ ‌\n292‌ ‌\n○Examples‌ ‌of‌ ‌Bronze‌ ‌Age‌ ‌art‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌Mediterranean‌ ‌area‌ ‌include:‌ ‌a‌ ‌wide‌ ‌range‌ ‌of‌ ‌painted‌ ‌ceramics,‌ ‌fresco‌ ‌murals,‌ ‌including‌ ‌\nlandscapes‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌figurative‌ ‌pictures‌ ‌of‌ ‌humans‌ ‌and‌ ‌animals.‌ ‌Religious‌ ‌relief‌ ‌and‌ ‌free-standing‌ ‌sculpture,‌ ‌mostly‌ ‌carved‌ ‌from‌ ‌\nstone,‌ ‌although‌ ‌wood‌ ‌carving‌ ‌was‌ ‌also‌ ‌common.‌ ‌\n●Where‌ ‌societies‌ ‌developed‌ ‌early‌ ‌writing‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌said‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌historic‌ ‌(as‌ ‌opposed‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌prehistoric)‌ ‌time‌ ‌period.‌ ‌The‌ ‌ancient‌ ‌Egyptians‌ ‌\ncould‌ ‌record‌ ‌their‌ ‌own‌ ‌histories‌ ‌and‌ ‌laws‌ ‌using‌ ‌hieroglyphs.‌ ‌\n●Irrigation‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌metal‌ ‌plough‌ ‌transformed‌ ‌the‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌agriculture‌ ‌and‌ ‌meant‌ ‌that,‌ ‌where‌ ‌the‌ ‌climate‌ ‌permitted,‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌possible‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nfarm‌ ‌year‌ ‌round.‌ ‌Forest‌ ‌clearance‌ ‌led‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌large‌ ‌farms‌ ‌and‌ ‌fields‌ ‌were‌ ‌separated‌ ‌by‌ ‌walls.‌ ‌\n●Growth‌ ‌of‌ ‌trade‌ ‌for‌ ‌bronze‌ ‌and‌ ‌bronze‌ ‌products‌ ‌was‌ ‌aided‌ ‌by‌ ‌improved‌ ‌navigation‌ ‌skills.‌ ‌Knowledge‌ ‌of‌ ‌astronomy‌ ‌and‌ ‌mathematics‌ ‌also‌ ‌\ndeveloped‌ ‌during‌ ‌this‌ ‌period.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌invention‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌wheel‌ ‌meant‌ ‌that‌ ‌animal-drawn‌ ‌vehicles‌ ‌could‌ ‌drive‌ ‌along‌ ‌tracks‌ ‌and‌ ‌roads.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌potter's‌ ‌wheel‌ ‌and‌ ‌textile‌ ‌production‌ ‌meant‌ ‌that‌ ‌better‌ ‌pottery‌ ‌and‌ ‌clothing‌ ‌could‌ ‌be‌ ‌produced.‌ ‌\n●Metal‌ ‌workers‌ ‌and‌ ‌those‌ ‌who‌ ‌traded‌ ‌in‌ ‌metals‌ ‌were‌ ‌probably‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌important‌ ‌and‌ ‌wealthiest‌ ‌people‌ ‌in‌ ‌Bronze‌ ‌Age‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n●Some‌ ‌Bronze‌ ‌Age‌ ‌societies‌ ‌developed‌ ‌a‌ ‌ruling‌ ‌class‌ ‌who‌ ‌were‌ ‌supported‌ ‌by‌ ‌military‌ ‌power.‌ ‌Some‌ ‌Bronze‌ ‌Age‌ ‌kings‌ ‌ruled‌ ‌empires‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nadministered‌ ‌laws.‌ ‌\n ‌\nThe‌ ‌Bronze‌ ‌Age‌ ‌Collapse‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Bronze‌ ‌Age‌ ‌Collapse‌ ‌‌(also‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌Late‌ ‌Bronze‌ ‌Age‌ ‌Collapse)‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌modern-day‌ ‌term‌ ‌‌referring‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌decline‌ ‌and‌ ‌fall‌ ‌of‌ ‌major‌ ‌\nMediterranean‌ ‌civilizations‌ ‌during‌ ‌the‌ ‌13th-12th‌ ‌centuries‌ ‌BCE.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌precise‌ ‌cause‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Bronze‌ ‌Age‌ ‌Collapse‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌debated‌ ‌by‌ ‌scholars‌ ‌for‌ ‌over‌ ‌a‌ ‌century‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌date‌ ‌it‌ ‌probably‌ ‌began‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nwhen‌ ‌it‌ ‌ended‌ ‌but‌ ‌no‌ ‌consensus‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌reached.‌ ‌ ‌\n●What‌ ‌is‌ ‌clearly‌ ‌known‌ ‌is‌ ‌that,‌ ‌between‌ ‌c.‌ ‌1250‌ ‌-‌ ‌c.‌ ‌1150‌ ‌BCE,‌ ‌major‌ ‌cities‌ ‌were‌ ‌destroyed,‌ ‌whole‌ ‌civilizations‌ ‌fell,‌ ‌diplomatic‌ ‌and‌ ‌trade‌ ‌\nrelations‌ ‌were‌ ‌severed,‌ ‌writing‌ ‌systems‌ ‌vanished,‌ ‌and‌ ‌there‌ ‌was‌ ‌widespread‌ ‌devastation‌ ‌and‌ ‌death‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌scale‌ ‌never‌ ‌experienced‌ ‌before.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌primary‌ ‌causes‌ ‌advanced‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌Bronze‌ ‌Age‌ ‌Collapse‌ ‌are:‌ ‌\n●Natural‌ ‌Catastrophes‌ ‌(earthquakes)‌ ‌\n●Climate‌ ‌Change‌ ‌(which‌ ‌caused‌ ‌drought‌ ‌and‌ ‌famine)‌ ‌\n●Internal‌ ‌Rebellions‌ ‌(class‌ ‌wars)‌ ‌\n●Invasions‌ ‌(primarily‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌Sea‌ ‌Peoples)‌ ‌\n●Disruption‌ ‌of‌ ‌Trade‌ ‌Relations/Systems‌ ‌Collapse‌ ‌(political‌ ‌instability)‌ ‌\n●When‌ ‌the‌ ‌collapse‌ ‌had‌ ‌run‌ ‌its‌ ‌course,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Mediterranean‌ ‌region‌ ‌entered‌ ‌a‌ ‌“dark‌ ‌age”‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌iron‌ ‌replaced‌ ‌bronze‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌metal‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nchoice,‌ ‌diplomatic‌ ‌and‌ ‌trade‌ ‌relations‌ ‌were‌ ‌nearly‌ ‌non-existent,‌ ‌and‌ ‌art,‌ ‌architecture,‌ ‌and‌ ‌general‌ ‌quality‌ ‌of‌ ‌life‌ ‌all‌ ‌suffered‌ ‌in‌ ‌\n293‌ ‌\ncomparison‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌Bronze‌ ‌Age.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n294‌ ‌\nIron‌ ‌Age‌ ‌\n ‌\n●The‌ ‌Iron‌ ‌Age‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌final‌ ‌epoch‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌three-age‌ ‌division‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌prehistory‌ ‌and‌ ‌protohistory‌ ‌of‌ ‌humanity.‌ ‌It‌ ‌was‌ ‌preceded‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌Bronze‌ ‌Age‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌the‌ ‌Stone‌ ‌Age‌ ‌‌(Paleolithic,‌ ‌Mesolithic,‌ ‌Neolithic,‌ ‌and‌ ‌Chalcolithic).‌ ‌The‌ ‌concept‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌mostly‌ ‌applied‌ ‌to‌ ‌Europe‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌Ancient‌ ‌\nNear‌ ‌East,‌ ‌and,‌ ‌by‌ ‌analogy,‌ ‌also‌ ‌to‌ ‌other‌ ‌parts‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Old‌ ‌World.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌duration‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Iron‌ ‌Age‌ ‌varies‌ ‌depending‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌region‌ ‌under‌ ‌consideration.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌defined‌ ‌by‌ ‌archaeological‌ ‌convention.‌ ‌‌The‌ ‌\"Iron‌ ‌Age\"‌ ‌\nbegins‌ ‌locally‌ ‌when‌ ‌the‌ ‌production‌ ‌of‌ ‌iron‌ ‌or‌ ‌steel‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌brought‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌point‌ ‌where‌ ‌iron‌ ‌tools‌ ‌and‌ ‌weapons‌ ‌superior‌ ‌to‌ ‌their‌ ‌bronze‌ ‌\nequivalents‌ ‌become‌ ‌widespread.‌ ‌\n○Humans‌ ‌may‌ ‌have‌ ‌smelted‌ ‌iron‌ ‌sporadically‌ ‌throughout‌ ‌the‌ ‌Bronze‌ ‌Age,‌ ‌though‌ ‌they‌ ‌likely‌ ‌saw‌ ‌iron‌ ‌as‌ ‌an‌ ‌inferior‌ ‌metal.‌ ‌Iron‌ ‌tools‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌weapons‌ ‌weren’t‌ ‌as‌ ‌hard‌ ‌or‌ ‌durable‌ ‌as‌ ‌their‌ ‌bronze‌ ‌counterparts.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌iron‌ ‌became‌ ‌more‌ ‌widespread‌ ‌after‌ ‌people‌ ‌learned‌ ‌how‌ ‌to‌ ‌make‌ ‌steel,‌ ‌a‌ ‌much‌ ‌harder‌ ‌metal,‌ ‌by‌ ‌heating‌ ‌iron‌ ‌with‌ ‌carbon.‌ ‌\nThe‌ ‌Hittites—who‌ ‌lived‌ ‌during‌ ‌the‌ ‌Bronze‌ ‌Age‌ ‌in‌ ‌what‌ ‌is‌ ‌now‌ ‌Turkey—may‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌to‌ ‌make‌ ‌steel.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌the‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌subcontinent,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Iron‌ ‌Age‌ ‌is‌ ‌taken‌ ‌to‌ ‌begin‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌iron‌ ‌working‌ ‌Painted‌ ‌Gray‌ ‌Ware‌ ‌culture‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌18th‌ ‌century‌ ‌BC,‌ ‌and‌ ‌to‌ ‌end‌ ‌\nwith‌ ‌the‌ ‌reign‌ ‌of‌ ‌Ashoka‌ ‌(3rd‌ ‌century‌ ‌BC).‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Iron‌ ‌Age‌ ‌involved‌ ‌the‌ ‌adoption‌ ‌of‌ ‌iron‌ ‌or‌ ‌steel‌ ‌smelting‌ ‌technology,‌ ‌either‌ ‌by‌ ‌casting‌ ‌or‌ ‌forging.‌ ‌Iron‌ ‌replaced‌ ‌bronze,and‌ ‌made‌ ‌it‌ ‌\npossible‌ ‌to‌ ‌produce‌ ‌tools‌ ‌which‌ ‌were‌ ‌stronger,‌ ‌lighter‌ ‌and‌ ‌cheaper‌ ‌to‌ ‌make‌ ‌than‌ ‌bronze‌ ‌equivalents.[42]‌ ‌The‌ ‌best‌ ‌tools‌ ‌and‌ ‌weapons‌ ‌were‌ ‌\nmade‌ ‌from‌ ‌steel.‌ ‌\n●Other‌ ‌societal‌ ‌changes‌ ‌often‌ ‌accompanied‌ ‌the‌ ‌introduction‌ ‌of‌ ‌iron,‌‌ ‌including‌ ‌practice‌ ‌changes‌ ‌in‌ ‌art,‌ ‌religion‌ ‌and‌ ‌agriculture‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Iron‌ ‌Age‌ ‌ends‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌beginning‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌historic‌ ‌periods,‌ ‌generally‌ ‌marked‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌written‌ ‌language‌ ‌that‌ ‌enabled‌ ‌creation‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌historic‌ ‌records.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌timing‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌adoption‌ ‌of‌ ‌iron‌ ‌depended‌ ‌upon‌ ‌\"the‌ ‌availability‌ ‌of‌ ‌iron‌ ‌ore‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌state‌ ‌of‌ ‌knowledge\".‌ ‌\n●Iron‌ ‌was‌ ‌smelted‌ ‌in‌ ‌Egypt‌ ‌about‌ ‌6000‌ ‌B.C.‌ ‌and‌ ‌iron‌ ‌replaced‌ ‌bronze‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Middle‌ ‌East‌ ‌about‌ ‌1500‌ ‌B.C.‌ ‌\n● ‌Chinese‌ ‌began‌ ‌casting‌ ‌iron‌ ‌about‌ ‌5000‌ ‌B.C.‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌methods‌ ‌for‌ ‌casting‌ ‌iron‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌precursor‌ ‌to‌ ‌modern‌ ‌steel‌ ‌manufacturing‌ ‌methods.‌ ‌\nMost‌ ‌of‌ ‌Asia,‌ ‌however,‌ ‌did‌ ‌not‌ ‌adopt‌ ‌production‌ ‌of‌ ‌iron‌ ‌until‌ ‌the‌ ‌historic‌ ‌period.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌Europe,‌ ‌iron‌ ‌was‌ ‌introduced‌ ‌about‌ ‌1100‌ ‌B.C.‌ ‌and‌ ‌had‌ ‌replaced‌ ‌bronze‌ ‌for‌ ‌creating‌ ‌weapons‌ ‌and‌ ‌tools‌ ‌by‌ ‌500‌ ‌B.C.‌ ‌They‌ ‌made‌ ‌iron‌ ‌\nthrough‌ ‌the‌ ‌forging‌ ‌smelting‌ ‌process‌ ‌and‌ ‌integrated‌ ‌casting‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Middle‌ ‌Ages.‌ ‌\n●Large‌ ‌hill‌ ‌forts‌ ‌or‌ ‌oppida‌ ‌were‌ ‌built‌ ‌either‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌refuge‌ ‌in‌ ‌time‌ ‌of‌ ‌war,‌ ‌or‌ ‌sometimes‌ ‌as‌ ‌permanent‌ ‌settlements.‌ ‌Agricultural‌ ‌practices‌ ‌were‌ ‌\nmade‌ ‌more‌ ‌efficient‌ ‌with‌ ‌more‌ ‌effective‌ ‌and‌ ‌varied‌ ‌iron‌ ‌tools.‌ ‌\n●Iron‌ ‌was‌ ‌extracted‌ ‌from‌ ‌metal‌ ‌ore‌ ‌starting‌ ‌about‌ ‌2000‌ ‌B.C.‌ ‌in‌ ‌Africa.‌ ‌\n295‌ ‌\n●Lifestyle:‌ ‌Before‌ ‌the‌ ‌Industrial‌ ‌Revolution,‌ ‌which‌ ‌would‌ ‌take‌ ‌place‌ ‌centuries‌ ‌later,‌ ‌the‌ ‌majority‌ ‌of‌ ‌people‌ ‌lived‌ ‌an‌ ‌agrarian‌ ‌lifestyle.‌ ‌Most‌ ‌\npeople‌ ‌were‌ ‌farmers,‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌lives‌ ‌revolved‌ ‌around‌ ‌the‌ ‌farming‌ ‌seasons.‌ ‌Societies‌ ‌consisted‌ ‌of‌ ‌villages‌ ‌where‌ ‌communities‌ ‌of‌ ‌families‌ ‌\nworked‌ ‌the‌ ‌land‌ ‌and‌ ‌made‌ ‌necessities‌ ‌for‌ ‌living‌ ‌by‌ ‌hand.‌ ‌All‌ ‌essentials‌ ‌were‌ ‌made‌ ‌or‌ ‌grown‌ ‌locally.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌production‌ ‌of‌ ‌iron‌ ‌tools‌ ‌helped‌ ‌make‌ ‌the‌ ‌farming‌ ‌process‌ ‌easier‌ ‌and‌ ‌more‌ ‌efficient.‌ ‌Farmers‌ ‌could‌ ‌plow‌ ‌tougher‌ ‌soil,‌ ‌making‌ ‌it‌ ‌possible‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌harvest‌ ‌new‌ ‌crops‌ ‌and‌ ‌freeing‌ ‌time‌ ‌for‌ ‌more‌ ‌leisure.‌ ‌New‌ ‌varieties‌ ‌of‌ ‌crops‌ ‌and‌ ‌livestock‌ ‌were‌ ‌introduced‌ ‌at‌ ‌different‌ ‌times‌ ‌over‌ ‌the‌ ‌span‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌the‌ ‌Iron‌ ‌Age.‌ ‌\n●More‌ ‌time‌ ‌also‌ ‌meant‌ ‌that‌ ‌people‌ ‌could‌ ‌make‌ ‌extra‌ ‌supplies‌ ‌to‌ ‌sell‌ ‌or‌ ‌exchange.‌ ‌Some‌ ‌farming‌ ‌families‌ ‌spent‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌time‌ ‌making‌ ‌salt,‌ ‌\nquern‌ ‌stones‌ ‌or‌ ‌iron.‌ ‌Most‌ ‌settlements‌ ‌have‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌of‌ ‌making‌ ‌clothes,‌ ‌woodworking‌ ‌and‌ ‌even‌ ‌blacksmithing.‌ ‌\n●Iron‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌enhancing‌ ‌the‌ ‌quality‌ ‌of‌ ‌life‌ ‌for‌ ‌centuries.‌ ‌As‌ ‌more‌ ‌advanced‌ ‌technologies‌ ‌for‌ ‌processing‌ ‌iron‌ ‌were‌ ‌discovered,‌ ‌the‌ ‌world‌ ‌\nwould‌ ‌experience‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌rapid‌ ‌period‌ ‌of‌ ‌growth.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n296‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n297‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌addition‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n298‌ ‌\n‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n299‌ ‌\n2.1‌ ‌The‌ ‌Nature‌ ‌of‌ ‌Culture‌ ‌:‌ ‌The‌ ‌Concept‌ ‌and‌ ‌Characteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌civilization;‌ ‌Ethnocentrism‌ ‌vis-a-vis‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌Relativism‌ ‌\n ‌\nIntroduction‌ ‌\n●Culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌‌set‌ ‌of‌ ‌traditional‌ ‌beliefs‌ ‌and‌ ‌values‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌transmitted‌ ‌and‌ ‌shared‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌given‌ ‌society‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌the‌ ‌total‌ ‌way‌ ‌of‌ ‌life‌ ‌and‌ ‌thinking‌ ‌patterns,‌ ‌speech,‌ ‌action‌ ‌and‌ ‌artifacts‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌passed‌ ‌from‌ ‌generation‌ ‌to‌ ‌generation.‌ ‌\n●However,‌ ‌this‌ ‌is‌ ‌dependent‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌man’s‌ ‌capacity‌ ‌for‌ ‌learning‌ ‌and‌ ‌transmitting‌ ‌knowledge‌ ‌to‌ ‌succeeding‌ ‌generations.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌nutshell,‌ ‌culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌total‌ ‌sum‌ ‌of‌ ‌customs,‌ ‌rituals,‌ ‌artifacts,‌ ‌beliefs‌ ‌and‌ ‌values.‌ ‌\n○“According‌ ‌to‌ ‌UNESCO,‌ ‌culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌usually‌ ‌“Interpreted‌ ‌as‌ ‌art,‌ ‌we‌ ‌speak‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌in‌ ‌connection‌ ‌with‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌of‌ ‌people‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌moral‌ ‌\nvalues‌ ‌and‌ ‌human‌ ‌relations.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Social‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌distinguish‌ ‌between”‌ ‌“material”‌ ‌and‌ ‌“nonmaterial”‌ ‌culture‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌former‌ ‌includes‌ ‌technology,‌ ‌art‌ ‌forms,‌ ‌architecture,‌ ‌material‌ ‌goods‌ ‌and‌ ‌equipment‌ ‌used‌ ‌in‌ ‌daily‌ ‌life,‌ ‌house‌ ‌hold,‌ ‌agriculture,‌ ‌trade‌ ‌and‌ ‌\ncommerce‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌social‌ ‌activities.‌ ‌In‌ ‌the‌ ‌latter‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌literary‌ ‌and‌ ‌intellectual‌ ‌traditions,‌ ‌beliefs,‌ ‌myths,‌ ‌legends‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌oral‌ ‌\ntradition.‌ ‌\n●Culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌social‌ ‌Heritage------->gift‌ ‌of‌ ‌society‌ ‌to‌ ‌individuals‌.‌ ‌\n ‌\nDefinition‌ ‌by‌ ‌various‌ ‌Thinkers:‌ ‌\nCulture‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌defined‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌ways,‌ ‌some‌ ‌thinkers‌ ‌include‌ ‌in‌ ‌cultur‌e‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌major‌ ‌social‌ ‌components‌ ‌that‌ ‌bind‌ ‌men‌ ‌together‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌society‌.‌ ‌\nOthers‌ ‌take‌ ‌a‌ ‌narrow‌ ‌view‌ ‌and‌ ‌include‌ ‌in‌ ‌culture‌ ‌‌only‌ ‌the‌ ‌non-material‌ ‌parts;‌ ‌some‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌definitions‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌following:‌ ‌\n●Culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌“that‌ ‌complex‌ ‌whole‌ ‌which‌ ‌includes‌ ‌knowledge,‌ ‌belief,‌ ‌art,‌ ‌morals,‌ ‌law,‌ ‌custom‌ ‌and‌ ‌any‌ ‌other‌ ‌capabilities‌ ‌acquired‌ ‌by‌ ‌man‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nmember‌ ‌of‌ ‌society.”‌ ‌—‌Tylor‌.‌ ‌\n●Culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌“the‌ ‌handiwork‌ ‌of‌ ‌man‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌medium‌ ‌through‌ ‌which‌ ‌he‌ ‌achieves‌ ‌his‌ ‌ends.”—‌Malinowski‌ ‌\n●Culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌“an‌ ‌organised‌ ‌body‌ ‌of‌ ‌conventional‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌manifested‌ ‌in‌ ‌art‌ ‌and‌ ‌artifact,‌ ‌which,‌ ‌persisting‌ ‌through‌ ‌tradition,‌ ‌characterises‌ ‌\na‌ ‌human‌ ‌group.”—‌Redfield‌ ‌\n●Culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌“the‌ ‌super‌ ‌organic‌ ‌environment‌ ‌as‌ ‌distinguished‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌organic,‌ ‌or‌ ‌physical,‌ ‌the‌ ‌world‌ ‌of‌ ‌plants‌ ‌and‌ ‌animals.”‌ ‌—‌Spencer‌ ‌\n●Culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌symbolic,‌ ‌cumulative‌ ‌and‌ ‌progressive‌ ‌process”‌ ‌---‌White‌ ‌\n●Culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌“the‌ ‌embodiment‌ ‌in‌ ‌customs,‌ ‌tradition,‌ ‌etc.,‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌learning‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌social‌ ‌group‌ ‌over‌ ‌the‌ ‌generation.”—‌Lapiere‌.‌ ‌\n●“Culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌sum‌ ‌total‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌achievements,‌ ‌material‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌non-material,‌ ‌capable‌ ‌of‌ ‌transmission,‌ ‌sociologically,‌ ‌by‌ ‌tradition‌ ‌and‌ ‌\ncommunication,‌ ‌vertically‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌horizontally.”‌ ‌—‌Mazumdar,‌ ‌H.T‌.‌ ‌\n300‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Culture‌ ‌has‌ ‌three‌ ‌dimensions.‌ ‌ ‌\n○First,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌‌normative‌ ‌system‌,‌ ‌by‌ ‌which‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌social‌ ‌control‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌sanctions,‌ ‌which‌ ‌make‌ ‌people‌ ‌follow‌ ‌generally‌ ‌\naccepted‌ ‌moral/‌ ‌ethical‌ ‌norms.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Secondly‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌‌expressive‌ ‌system‌;‌ ‌music,‌ ‌art,‌ ‌literature‌ ‌and‌ ‌so‌ ‌on‌ ‌are‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌expressions‌ ‌of‌ ‌people.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Thirdly‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌which‌ ‌enables‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌society‌ ‌to‌ ‌interpret‌ ‌the‌ ‌world‌ ‌meaningfully‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌process‌ ‌through‌ ‌which‌ ‌\nculture‌ ‌influences‌ ‌a‌ ‌social‌ ‌system‌ ‌is‌ ‌called‌ ‌institutionalization.‌ ‌ ‌\nCharacteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌Culture:‌ ‌\n●Culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌acquired‌ ‌quality:‌ ‌\n○Culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌innate.‌ ‌Culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌learned.‌ ‌Any‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌socially‌ ‌acquired‌ ‌is‌ ‌called‌ ‌learned‌ ‌behaviour.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌social,‌ ‌not‌ ‌individual‌ ‌heritage‌ ‌of‌ ‌man:‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌inclusive‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌expectations‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌groups.‌‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌social‌ ‌product‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌shared‌ ‌by‌ ‌most‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌group.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌idealistic:‌ ‌\n301‌ ‌\n○Culture‌ ‌embodies‌ ‌the‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌and‌ ‌norms‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌sum-total‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌ideal‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌and‌ ‌norms‌ ‌of‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌group.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nmanifestation‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌human‌ ‌mind‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌course‌ ‌of‌ ‌history.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌total‌ ‌social‌ ‌heritage:‌ ‌\n○Culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌linked‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌past.‌ ‌The‌ ‌past‌ ‌endures‌ ‌because‌ ‌it‌ ‌lives‌ ‌in‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌passed‌ ‌from‌ ‌one‌ ‌generation‌ ‌to‌ ‌another‌ ‌through‌ ‌\ntraditions‌ ‌and‌ ‌customs.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Culture‌ ‌fulfills‌ ‌some‌ ‌needs:‌ ‌\n○Culture‌ ‌‌fulfills‌ ‌those‌ ‌ethical‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌needs‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌groups‌‌ ‌which‌ ‌end‌ ‌in‌ ‌themselves.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌integrated‌ ‌system:‌ ‌\n○Culture‌ ‌possesses‌ ‌an‌ ‌order‌ ‌and‌ ‌system.‌ ‌Its‌ ‌various‌ ‌parts‌ ‌are‌ ‌integrated‌ ‌with‌ ‌each‌ ‌other‌ ‌and‌ ‌any‌ ‌new‌ ‌element‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌introduced‌ ‌is‌ ‌\nalso‌ ‌integrated.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Language‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌chief‌ ‌vehicle‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture:‌ ‌\n○Man‌ ‌lives‌ ‌not‌ ‌only‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌present‌ ‌but‌ ‌also‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌past‌ ‌and‌ ‌future.‌ ‌This‌ ‌is‌ ‌enabled‌ ‌to‌ ‌do‌ ‌because‌ ‌he‌ ‌‌possesses‌ ‌language‌ ‌which‌ ‌\ntransmits‌ ‌to‌ ‌him‌ ‌what‌ ‌was‌ ‌learnt‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌past‌ ‌and‌ ‌enables‌ ‌him‌ ‌to‌ ‌transmit‌ ‌the‌ ‌accumulated‌ ‌wisdom.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Culture‌ ‌evolves‌ ‌into‌ ‌more‌ ‌complex‌ ‌forms‌ ‌ ‌\n302‌ ‌\n○Through‌ ‌division‌ ‌of‌ ‌labour‌ ‌which‌ ‌develops‌ ‌special‌ ‌skills‌ ‌and‌ ‌increases‌ ‌the‌ ‌interdependence‌ ‌of‌ ‌society’s‌ ‌members.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nElements‌ ‌of‌ ‌Culture‌ ‌\n●Belief:‌ ‌ ‌\n○Beliefs‌ ‌consist‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌large‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌verbal‌ ‌or‌ ‌mental‌ ‌statements‌ ‌about‌ ‌any‌ ‌object‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌person's‌ ‌specific‌ ‌information‌ ‌and‌ ‌\njudgment‌ ‌of‌ ‌something‌ ‌about‌ ‌that‌ ‌object.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Based‌ ‌on‌ ‌beliefs,‌ ‌a‌ ‌person‌ ‌decides‌ ‌what‌ ‌is‌ ‌right,‌ ‌wrong,‌ ‌what‌ ‌is‌ ‌good‌ ‌or‌ ‌bad.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Belief‌ ‌about‌ ‌anything‌ ‌has‌ ‌different‌ ‌dimensions.‌ ‌\n●Values:‌ ‌\n○Values‌ ‌are‌ ‌also‌ ‌beliefs.‌ ‌‌But,‌ ‌these‌ ‌are‌ ‌those‌ ‌beliefs‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌less‌ ‌in‌ ‌number,‌ ‌core‌ ‌in‌ ‌nature‌ ‌and‌ ‌very‌ ‌difficult‌ ‌to‌ ‌change‌ ‌and‌ ‌are‌ ‌\nshared‌ ‌by‌ ‌most‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌society‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Values‌ ‌guide‌ ‌that‌ ‌what‌ ‌is‌ ‌good‌ ‌and‌ ‌desirable‌ ‌versus‌ ‌what‌ ‌is‌ ‌bad‌ ‌and‌ ‌undesirable.‌ ‌\n●Customs:‌ ‌\n○Customs‌ ‌are‌ ‌apparent‌ ‌modes‌ ‌of‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌that‌ ‌form‌ ‌culturally‌ ‌approved‌‌ ‌or‌ ‌acceptable‌ ‌ways‌ ‌of‌ ‌behaving‌ ‌in‌ ‌particular‌ ‌situations.‌ ‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌consist‌ ‌of‌ ‌every‌ ‌day‌ ‌or‌ ‌routine‌ ‌behaviour.‌ ‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌example‌,‌ ‌bargaining‌ ‌for‌ ‌goods‌ ‌and‌ ‌services‌ ‌is‌ ‌common‌ ‌in‌ ‌India.‌ ‌In‌ ‌the‌ ‌west‌ ‌it‌ ‌could‌ ‌be‌ ‌considered‌ ‌rude.‌ ‌\n●Rituals:‌ ‌ ‌\n303‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌ritual‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌series‌ ‌of‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌behaviours‌ ‌‌that‌ ‌occur‌ ‌in‌ ‌fixed‌ ‌sequence‌ ‌and‌ ‌are‌ ‌repeated‌ ‌most‌ ‌often.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌India,‌ ‌Dhothi‌ ‌and‌ ‌Kurta‌ ‌of‌ ‌Khadi‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌ritual‌ ‌during‌ ‌the‌ ‌independence‌ ‌movement.‌ ‌\n●Language‌ ‌and‌ ‌symbols:‌ ‌\n○Language‌ ‌is‌ ‌considered‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌a‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌communicating‌ ‌with‌ ‌other‌ ‌people‌ ‌using‌ ‌sounds,‌ ‌symbols‌ ‌and‌ ‌words‌ ‌in‌ ‌expressing‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nmeaning,‌ ‌idea‌ ‌or‌ ‌thought.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Many‌ ‌languages‌ ‌use‌ ‌gestures,‌ ‌sounds,‌ ‌symbols,‌ ‌or‌ ‌words,‌ ‌and‌ ‌aim‌ ‌at‌ ‌communicating‌ ‌concepts,‌ ‌ideas,‌ ‌meanings‌ ‌and‌ ‌thoughts.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌language‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌used‌ ‌in‌ ‌many‌ ‌forms,‌ ‌primarily‌ ‌through‌ ‌oral‌ ‌and‌ ‌written‌ ‌communications‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌using‌ ‌expressions‌ ‌through‌ ‌\nbody‌ ‌language.‌ ‌\n○Symbol‌ ‌is‌ ‌anything‌ ‌that‌ ‌stands‌ ‌for‌ ‌something‌ ‌else.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌are‌ ‌a‌ ‌subtle‌ ‌notion,‌ ‌as‌ ‌are‌ ‌all‌ ‌symbols.‌ ‌Symbols‌ ‌are‌ ‌seen‌ ‌in‌ ‌every‌ ‌act‌ ‌of‌ ‌faith.‌ ‌\n●Stories:‌ ‌\n○Culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌often‌ ‌embedded‌ ‌and‌ ‌transmitted‌ ‌through‌ ‌stories,‌ ‌whether‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌deep‌ ‌and‌ ‌obviously‌ ‌indented‌ ‌as‌ ‌learning‌ ‌devices‌ ‌or‌ ‌\nwhether‌ ‌they‌ ‌appear‌ ‌more‌ ‌subtly.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌power‌ ‌of‌ ‌stories‌ ‌is‌ ‌in‌ ‌when‌ ‌and‌ ‌how‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌told,‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌effect‌ ‌they‌ ‌have‌ ‌on‌ ‌their‌ ‌recipients.‌ ‌\n●Artifacts:‌ ‌\n●Artifacts‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌physical‌ ‌things‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌found‌ ‌and‌ ‌that‌ ‌have‌ ‌particular‌ ‌symbolism‌ ‌for‌ ‌culture,‌ ‌when‌ ‌people‌ ‌see‌ ‌them,‌ ‌they‌ ‌think‌ ‌\nabout‌ ‌their‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌and‌ ‌hence‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌reminded‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌identity‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌member‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌culture,‌ ‌and‌ ‌by‌ ‌association,‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌rules‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nculture.‌ ‌\n304‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌addition‌ ‌\nSubcultures:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Subcultures‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌traits‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌group‌ ‌or‌ ‌category.‌ ‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌are‌ ‌of‌ ‌course‌‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌general‌ ‌culture‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌society,‌ ‌yet‌ ‌are‌ ‌distinguishable‌ ‌from‌ ‌it.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Thus,‌ ‌the‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌of‌ ‌occupational‌ ‌groups,‌ ‌religious‌ ‌groups,‌ ‌caste,‌ ‌social‌ ‌Class,‌ ‌age‌ ‌group,‌ ‌sex‌ ‌group‌ ‌and‌ ‌many‌ ‌others‌ ‌are‌ ‌Sub-cultures.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Hindu‌ ‌culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌sub-culture‌ ‌of‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Likewise,‌ ‌the‌ ‌adult‌ ‌culture,‌ ‌teen-age‌ ‌culture,‌ ‌army‌ ‌culture,‌ ‌college‌ ‌culture‌ ‌are‌ ‌subcultures.‌ ‌It‌ ‌need‌ ‌not‌ ‌be‌ ‌said‌ ‌that‌ ‌a‌ ‌society‌ ‌has‌ ‌a‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nsub-cultures‌ ‌in‌ ‌addition‌ ‌to‌ ‌universals.‌ ‌Specialities‌ ‌lead‌ ‌to‌ ‌sub-cultures.‌ ‌\n ‌\nContra‌ ‌Cultures:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●The‌ ‌term‌ ‌contra‌ ‌culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌applied‌ ‌to‌ ‌designate‌ ‌those‌ ‌groups‌ ‌which‌ ‌not‌ ‌only‌ ‌differ‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌prevailing‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌but‌ ‌sharply‌ ‌challenge‌ ‌them.‌ ‌ ‌\n305‌ ‌\n●Thus‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌dacoits‌ ‌has‌ ‌its‌ ‌own‌ ‌norms‌ ‌and‌ ‌standards‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌compulsory‌ ‌for‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌group‌ ‌but‌ ‌these‌ ‌norms‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nstandards‌ ‌sharply‌ ‌differ‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌conventional‌ ‌prevailing‌ ‌patterns.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌people‌ ‌trained‌ ‌in‌ ‌these‌ ‌norms‌ ‌are‌ ‌influenced‌ ‌against‌ ‌the‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌norms;‌ ‌hence‌ ‌the‌ ‌term‌ ‌contra‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌The‌ ‌“hippie”‌ ‌culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌\ncontra‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nCultural‌ ‌diversity‌ ‌\n●Cultural‌ ‌differences‌ ‌that‌ ‌exist‌ ‌between‌ ‌people,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌language,‌ ‌dress‌ ‌and‌ ‌traditions,‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌also‌ ‌significant‌ ‌variations‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌way‌ ‌\nsocieties‌ ‌organize‌ ‌themselves,‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌shared‌ ‌conception‌ ‌of‌ ‌morality,‌ ‌and‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌ways‌ ‌they‌ ‌interact‌ ‌with‌ ‌their‌ ‌environment.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Cultural‌ ‌diversity‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌variety‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌specific‌ ‌region‌ ‌or‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌world‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌whole‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Cultural‌ ‌diversity‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌necessity‌ ‌for‌ ‌human‌ ‌kind‌ ‌as‌ ‌biodiversity‌ ‌is‌ ‌for‌ ‌nature.‌ ‌\nDimensions‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌diversity‌ ‌ ‌\n●Cultural‌ ‌beliefs.‌ ‌\n●Norms‌ ‌\n●Age‌ ‌\n●Gender‌ ‌\n●Language‌ ‌\n●Communication‌ ‌style‌ ‌\n●Ethnicity‌ ‌ ‌\n●Religious‌ ‌beliefs‌ ‌\n●Education‌ ‌\n●Life‌ ‌experience‌ ‌\n●Geography‌ ‌\n●Opinions‌ ‌\n●Socio‌ ‌economic‌ ‌status‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nCulture‌ ‌and‌ ‌fields‌ ‌of‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌\n ‌\n(a)‌ ‌Biological‌ ‌anthropology-‌ ‌the‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌Culture‌ ‌\n●Discussion‌ ‌concerning‌ ‌culture‌ ‌among‌ ‌biological‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌.centers‌ ‌around‌ ‌two‌ ‌debates.‌ ‌ ‌\n●First,‌ ‌is‌ ‌culture‌ ‌uniquely‌ ‌human,‌ ‌or‌ ‌shared‌ ‌by‌ ‌other‌ ‌species‌ ‌(most‌ ‌notably,‌ ‌other‌ ‌primates).‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌important‌ ‌question,‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌holds‌ ‌that‌ ‌humans‌ ‌are‌ ‌descended‌ ‌from‌ ‌non-human‌ ‌primates.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Second,‌ ‌how‌ ‌did‌ ‌culture‌ ‌evolve‌ ‌among‌ ‌human‌ ‌beings.‌ ‌\n ‌\n(b)‌ ‌Archeological‌ ‌approaches‌ ‌to‌ ‌Culture‌ ‌-‌ ‌matter‌ ‌and‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌\n306‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌the‌ ‌19th‌ ‌century‌ ‌archeology‌ ‌was‌ ‌often‌ ‌a‌ ‌supplement‌ ‌to‌ ‌history,‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌goal‌ ‌of‌ ‌archeologists‌ ‌was‌ ‌to‌ ‌identify‌ ‌artifacts‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌their‌ ‌\ntypology‌ ‌and‌ ‌stratigraphy,‌ ‌thus‌ ‌marking‌ ‌their‌ ‌location‌ ‌in‌ ‌time‌ ‌and‌ ‌space.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Franz‌ ‌Boas‌ ‌established‌ ‌that‌ ‌archeology‌ ‌is‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌‌American‌ ‌anthropology’s‌ ‌four‌ ‌fields‌,‌ ‌and‌ ‌debates‌ ‌among‌ ‌archeologists‌ ‌have‌ ‌often‌ ‌\nparalleled‌ ‌debates‌ ‌among‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌anthropologists.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌the‌ ‌1920s‌ ‌and‌ ‌“1930s,‌ ‌Australian-British‌ ‌archeologist‌ ‌‌V.‌ ‌Gordon‌ ‌Childe‌ ‌and‌ ‌American‌ ‌archeologist‌ ‌‌W.‌ ‌C‌ ‌McKern‌ ‌independently‌ ‌began‌ ‌\nmoving‌ ‌from‌ ‌asking‌ ‌about‌ ‌the‌ ‌date‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌artifact‌ ‌to‌ ‌asking‌ ‌about‌ ‌the‌ ‌people‌ ‌who‌ ‌produced‌ ‌it‌ ‌—‌ ‌when‌ ‌archeologists‌ ‌work‌ ‌alongside‌ ‌\nhistorians,‌ ‌historical‌ ‌materials‌ ‌generally‌ ‌help‌ ‌answer‌ ‌these‌ ‌questions,‌ ‌but‌ ‌when‌ ‌historical‌ ‌materials‌ ‌are‌ ‌unavailable,archeologists‌ ‌had‌ ‌to‌ ‌\ndevelop‌ ‌new‌ ‌methods.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Child‌ ‌and‌ ‌McKern‌ ‌focused‌ ‌on‌ ‌analyzing‌ ‌the‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌among‌ ‌objects‌ ‌found‌ ‌together;‌ ‌their‌ ‌work‌ ‌established‌ ‌the‌ ‌foundation‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nthree-tiered‌ ‌model:‌ ‌\n■An‌ ‌individual‌ ‌artifact,‌ ‌which‌ ‌has‌ ‌surface,‌ ‌shape,‌ ‌and‌ ‌technological‌ ‌attributes‌ ‌.‌ ‌\n■A‌ ‌sub-assemblage,‌ ‌consisting‌ ‌of‌ ‌artifacts‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌found,‌ ‌and‌ ‌were‌ ‌likely‌ ‌used‌ ‌together‌ ‌\n■An‌ ‌assemblage‌ ‌of‌ ‌sub‌ ‌assemblages‌ ‌that‌ ‌together‌ ‌constitute‌ ‌the‌ ‌archeological‌ ‌site.‌ ‌\n ‌\n(c)‌ ‌Language/Linguistic‌ ‌and‌ ‌Culture‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌connection‌ ‌between‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌language‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌noted‌ ‌as‌ ‌far‌ ‌back‌ ‌as”‌ ‌the‌ ‌classical,‌ ‌period,‌ ‌and‌ ‌probably‌ ‌long‌ ‌before.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌ancient‌ ‌Greeks,‌ ‌for‌ ‌example,‌ ‌distinguished‌ ‌between‌ ‌civilized‌ ‌peoples‌ ‌and‌ ‌barbaros‌ ‌“those‌ ‌who‌ ‌babble”,‌ ‌i.e.‌ ‌those‌ ‌who‌ ‌speak‌ ‌\nunintelligible‌ ‌languages.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌fact‌ ‌that‌ ‌different‌ ‌groups‌ ‌speak‌ ‌different‌ ‌unintelligible‌ ‌languages‌ ‌is‌ ‌often‌ ‌considered‌ ‌more‌ ‌tangible‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌for‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌differences‌ ‌than‌ ‌\nother‌ ‌less‌ ‌obvious‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌traits.‌ ‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌community’s‌ ‌ways‌ ‌of‌ ‌speaking‌ ‌or‌ ‌signing‌ ‌are‌ ‌a‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌community’s‌ ‌culture,‌ ‌just‌ ‌as‌ ‌other‌ ‌shared‌ ‌practices‌ ‌are.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Language‌ ‌use‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌way‌ ‌of‌ ‌establishing‌ ‌and‌ ‌displaying‌ ‌group‌ ‌identity.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n(d)‌ ‌Cultural‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌\n●Universal‌ ‌versus‌ ‌particular:‌ ‌\n○Franz‌ ‌Boas‌ ‌greatest‌ ‌accomplishments‌ ‌was‌ ‌to‌ ‌demonstrate‌ ‌convincingly‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌existing‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌model‌ ‌is‌ ‌fundamentally‌ ‌flawed,‌ ‌\nempirically,‌ ‌methodologically,‌ ‌and‌ ‌theoretically.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Boas‌ ‌understood‌ ‌the‌ ‌capacity‌ ‌for‌ ‌culture‌ ‌to‌ ‌involve‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌thought‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌learning,‌ ‌and‌ ‌considered‌ ‌the‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌capacity‌ ‌\nfor‌ ‌culture‌ ‌to‌ ‌coincide‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌other,‌ ‌biological‌ ‌features‌ ‌defining‌ ‌genus‌ ‌Homo.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Others‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌Ruth‌ ‌Benedict‌ ‌and‌ ‌Margaret‌ ‌Mead‌ ‌produced‌ ‌monographs‌ ‌or‌ ‌comparative‌ ‌studies‌ ‌analyzing‌ ‌the‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌creativity‌ ‌\npossible‌ ‌to‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌within‌ ‌specific‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌configurations.‌ ‌\n●Present-Local‌ ‌versus‌ ‌Global:‌ ‌\n●Boas‌ ‌and‌ ‌Malinowski‌ ‌established‌ ‌ethnographic‌ ‌research‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌highly‌ ‌localized‌ ‌method‌ ‌for‌ ‌studying‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\n●Yet‌ ‌Boas‌ ‌emphasized‌ ‌that‌ ‌culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌dynamic,‌ ‌moving‌ ‌from‌ ‌one‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌people‌ ‌to‌ ‌another,‌ ‌and‌ ‌that‌ ‌specific‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌forms‌ ‌have‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌\nanalyzed‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌larger‌ ‌context.‌ ‌This‌ ‌has‌ ‌led‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌to‌ ‌explore‌ ‌different‌ ‌ways‌ ‌of‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌the‌ ‌global‌ ‌dimensions‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n307‌ ‌\nVariability‌ ‌of‌ ‌Culture:‌ ‌\n●We‌ ‌defined‌ ‌culture‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌acquired‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌group.‌ ‌ ‌\n●If‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌so‌ ‌then‌ ‌it‌ ‌means‌ ‌that‌ ‌there‌ ‌will‌ ‌be‌ ‌as‌ ‌many‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌as‌ ‌groups.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌distinctive‌ ‌character‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌nation,‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌or‌ ‌a‌ ‌period‌ ‌of‌ ‌history.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌why‌ ‌we‌ ‌speak‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌culture‌ ‌of‌ ‌India,‌ ‌of‌ ‌Japan‌ ‌or‌ ‌of‌ ‌America.‌ ‌A‌ ‌popular‌ ‌joke‌ ‌about‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌different‌ ‌nations‌ ‌gives‌ ‌us‌ ‌an‌ ‌insight‌ ‌\ninto‌ ‌the‌ ‌different‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌of‌ ‌different‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌\n●Once‌ ‌three‌ ‌students—a‌ ‌Japanese,‌ ‌an‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌and‌ ‌an‌ ‌American—visited‌ ‌Niagara‌ ‌Falls.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌Japanese‌ ‌boy‌ ‌was‌ ‌bewitched‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌beauty‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌grand‌ ‌spectacle,‌ ‌while‌ ‌the‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌student‌ ‌began‌ ‌to‌ ‌philosophize‌ ‌about‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nSupreme‌ ‌Being‌ ‌manifest‌ ‌in‌ ‌this‌ ‌phenomenon‌ ‌of‌ ‌nature.‌ ‌The‌ ‌silent‌ ‌communion‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌two‌ ‌Orientals‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌Niagara‌ ‌Falls‌ ‌was‌ ‌\nsharply‌ ‌interrupted‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌American‌ ‌student‌ ‌asked:‌ ‌“Friends,‌ ‌how‌ ‌much‌ ‌horse-power‌ ‌is‌ ‌there‌ ‌in‌ ‌these‌ ‌Falls.”‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Why‌ ‌is‌ ‌there‌ ‌variability‌ ‌in‌ ‌culture?‌ ‌ ‌\n○How‌ ‌is‌ ‌it‌ ‌that‌ ‌even‌ ‌such‌ ‌a‌ ‌simple‌ ‌phenomenon‌ ‌as‌ ‌sex‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌is‌ ‌differently‌ ‌convicted‌ ‌by‌ ‌different‌ ‌groups.‌ ‌Among‌ ‌some‌ ‌groups‌ ‌\nwe‌ ‌find‌ ‌monogamy,‌ ‌others‌ ‌believe‌ ‌in‌ ‌polygamy‌ ‌or‌ ‌polyandry.‌ ‌In‌ ‌some‌ ‌societies‌ ‌the‌ ‌bride-groom‌ ‌goes‌ ‌to‌ ‌live‌ ‌at‌ ‌his‌ ‌wife’s‌ ‌house,‌ ‌\nwhile‌ ‌in‌ ‌others‌ ‌the‌ ‌bride‌ ‌comes‌ ‌to‌ ‌and‌ ‌lives‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌house‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌bridegroom.‌ ‌Among‌ ‌some‌ ‌groups‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌joint‌ ‌family‌ ‌system‌ ‌\nwhereas‌ ‌in‌ ‌others‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌taboo.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Some‌ ‌people‌ ‌live‌ ‌naked,‌ ‌while‌ ‌others‌ ‌are‌ ‌dressed‌ ‌from‌ ‌head‌ ‌to‌ ‌foot.‌ ‌The‌ ‌Crow‌ ‌Indians‌ ‌were‌ ‌a‌ ‌very‌ ‌warlike‌ ‌people:‌ ‌the‌ ‌Eskimos‌ ‌\nare‌ ‌peaceful.‌ ‌Certain‌ ‌groups‌ ‌regard‌ ‌fighting‌ ‌a‌ ‌manly‌ ‌virtue,‌ ‌whereas‌ ‌others‌ ‌regard‌ ‌it‌ ‌a‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌rowdyism,‌ ‌close‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌barbaric.‌ ‌In‌ ‌\nIndia‌ ‌non-violence‌ ‌is‌ ‌considered‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌a‌ ‌great‌ ‌virtue,‌ ‌while‌ ‌in‌ ‌Russia‌ ‌violence‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Russian‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\n○ ‌\n○Among‌ ‌certain‌ ‌groups‌ ‌men‌ ‌and‌ ‌women‌ ‌mix‌ ‌and‌ ‌move‌ ‌freely‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌roads,‌ ‌whereas‌ ‌among‌ ‌other‌ ‌groups‌ ‌the‌ ‌free‌ ‌mixing‌ ‌of‌ ‌men‌ ‌\nand1‌ ‌women‌ ‌is‌ ‌severely‌ ‌condemned.‌ ‌Thus,‌ ‌we‌ ‌find‌ ‌group‌ ‌variations‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌among‌ ‌different‌ ‌peoples‌ ‌over‌ ‌the‌ ‌world‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌also‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌peoples‌ ‌at‌ ‌different‌ ‌periods‌ ‌of‌ ‌history.‌ ‌These‌ ‌variations‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌interpreted‌ ‌as‌ ‌merely‌ ‌amusing‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nmotivated.‌ ‌They‌ ‌influence‌ ‌and‌ ‌redirect‌ ‌the‌ ‌expression‌ ‌of‌ ‌deeply‌ ‌motivated‌ ‌behaviours.‌ ‌\n ‌\nFactors‌ ‌of‌ ‌Cultural‌ ‌Variability:‌ ‌\n ‌\n(i)‌ ‌Historical‌ ‌Accidents:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Some‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌customs‌ ‌whose‌ ‌origin‌ ‌is‌ ‌difficult‌ ‌to‌ ‌trace‌ ‌must‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌originated‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌some‌ ‌personal‌ ‌or‌ ‌group‌ ‌unconscious‌ ‌behaviour.‌ ‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌man‌ ‌might‌ ‌have‌ ‌unconsciously‌ ‌done‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌action;‌ ‌others‌ ‌imitated‌ ‌him‌ ‌and‌ ‌through‌ ‌imitation‌ ‌by‌ ‌and‌ ‌large‌ ‌it‌ ‌became‌ ‌a‌ ‌custom,‌ ‌a‌ ‌\npart‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\n ‌\n(ii)‌ ‌Geographical‌ ‌Environment:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●In‌ ‌India‌ ‌snake‌ ‌worship‌ ‌is‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌abundance‌ ‌of‌ ‌reptiles;‌ ‌the‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌dates‌ ‌are‌ ‌fixed‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌harvesting‌ ‌time‌ ‌and‌ ‌agricultural‌ ‌\npursuits‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌people.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Eskimos‌ ‌build‌ ‌their‌ ‌houses‌ ‌of‌ ‌snow,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Bushmen‌ ‌of‌ ‌South‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌have‌ ‌no‌ ‌houses,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Manus‌ ‌of‌ ‌New‌ ‌Guinea‌ ‌live‌ ‌in‌ ‌wooden‌ ‌huts‌ ‌built‌ ‌\non‌ ‌piles‌ ‌driven‌ ‌into‌ ‌the‌ ‌sea,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Indians‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌build‌ ‌their‌ ‌houses‌ ‌of‌ ‌unbaked‌ ‌bricks.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Eskimos‌ ‌depend‌ ‌on‌ ‌seal,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Indians‌ ‌have‌ ‌corn.‌ ‌ ‌\n308‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌production‌ ‌of‌ ‌pottery‌ ‌is‌ ‌dependent‌ ‌upon‌ ‌the‌ ‌supply‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌proper‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌earth.‌ ‌\n● ‌The‌ ‌clay‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Euphrates‌ ‌Valley‌ ‌was‌ ‌favourable‌ ‌for‌ ‌making‌ ‌small‌ ‌clay‌ ‌blocks‌ ‌on‌ ‌which‌ ‌the‌ ‌writing‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌cuneiform‌ ‌was‌ ‌developed.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Papyrus‌ ‌was‌ ‌native‌ ‌to‌ ‌Egypt,‌ ‌where‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌used‌ ‌for‌ ‌paper.‌ ‌Certainly‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌nature‌ ‌that‌ ‌presents‌ ‌materials‌ ‌for‌ ‌culture‌ ‌to‌ ‌use.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●The‌ ‌fact‌ ‌that‌ ‌different‌ ‌parts‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌world‌ ‌have‌ ‌different‌ ‌materials‌ ‌for‌ ‌culture‌ ‌to‌ ‌use‌ ‌has‌ ‌led‌ ‌to‌ ‌different‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌Extensive‌ ‌flat‌ ‌grazing‌ ‌lands‌ ‌\nwhen‌ ‌there‌ ‌were‌ ‌large‌ ‌herds‌ ‌of‌ ‌cattle‌ ‌led‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌nomadic‌ ‌life‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌effective‌ ‌military‌ ‌organisation‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌culture‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌strong‌ ‌masculine‌ ‌\ndomination.‌ ‌The‌ ‌hoe‌ ‌culture‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌river‌ ‌valleys‌ ‌gave‌ ‌rise‌ ‌to‌ ‌villages‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌sedentary‌ ‌life.‌ ‌\n ‌\n(iii)‌ ‌Mobility‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌organism:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌because‌ ‌human‌ ‌organism‌ ‌is‌ ‌flexible‌ ‌and‌ ‌mobile‌ ‌that‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌variability;‌ ‌Man‌ ‌has‌ ‌always‌ ‌adjusted‌ ‌himself‌ ‌to‌ ‌his‌ ‌natural‌ ‌\nenvironment,‌ ‌in‌ ‌his‌ ‌group‌ ‌and‌ ‌to‌ ‌his‌ ‌fellows‌ ‌and‌ ‌on‌ ‌account‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌constrain‌ ‌adjustment‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌has‌ ‌shown‌ ‌great‌ ‌variability‌ ‌\namour‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌people‌ ‌during‌ ‌different‌ ‌periods‌ ‌of‌ ‌history.‌ ‌\n ‌\n(iv)‌ ‌Inventions‌ ‌and‌ ‌Discoveries:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Inventions‌ ‌and‌ ‌discoveries‌ ‌bring‌ ‌about‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌variability.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌influence‌ ‌of‌ ‌technological‌ ‌factors‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌change‌ ‌and‌ ‌there‌ ‌we‌ ‌showed‌ ‌how‌ ‌advancement‌ ‌affects‌ ‌our‌ ‌traditions,‌ ‌custom‌ ‌beliefs‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nfaith.‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌country‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌technologically‌ ‌advanced‌ ‌will‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌culture‌ ‌different‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌of‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌technologically‌ ‌backward.‌ ‌\n ‌\n(v)‌ ‌Individual‌ ‌Peculiarities‌ ‌or‌ ‌Personal‌ ‌Eccentricities:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Sometimes‌ ‌individual‌ ‌peculiarities‌ ‌or‌ ‌personal‌ ‌eccentricities‌ ‌also‌ ‌influence‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌behaviour.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Gandhi‌ ‌cap‌ ‌has‌ ‌come‌ ‌to‌ ‌our‌ ‌culture‌ ‌through‌ ‌individual‌ ‌peculiarity.‌ ‌Not‌ ‌being‌ ‌very‌ ‌conscious‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌efforts‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌may‌ ‌change‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌current‌ ‌modes‌ ‌behaviour.‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌efforts‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌revolt‌ ‌against‌ ‌certain‌ ‌irritating‌ ‌manners‌ ‌or‌ ‌may‌ ‌have‌ ‌some‌ ‌economic‌ ‌or‌ ‌political‌ ‌significance.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌change‌ ‌to‌ ‌Khadi‌ ‌has‌ ‌also‌ ‌an‌ ‌economic‌ ‌significance.‌ ‌\n ‌\n(vi)‌ ‌Change‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Modes‌ ‌of‌ ‌Production:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Karl‌ ‌Marx‌ ‌held‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌mode‌ ‌of‌ ‌production‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌sole‌ ‌determinant‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌culture‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌people-their‌ ‌art,‌ ‌morals,‌ ‌customs,‌ ‌laws,‌ ‌literature‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Any‌ ‌change‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌mode‌ ‌of‌ ‌production‌ ‌affects‌ ‌the‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌The‌ ‌culture‌ ‌of‌ ‌capitalistic‌ ‌countries‌ ‌differs‌ ‌from‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌socialistic‌ ‌countries.‌ ‌\n ‌\n(vii)‌ ‌Dominant‌ ‌Cultural‌ ‌Themes:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Maurice‌ ‌Opler‌ ‌is‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌view‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌central‌ ‌‘focus‌ ‌of‌ ‌interest’‌ ‌or‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌theme‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌dynamic‌ ‌force‌ ‌in‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌superiority‌ ‌of‌ ‌men‌ ‌over‌ ‌women‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌main‌ ‌theme‌ ‌around‌ ‌which‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌built.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Egypt‌ ‌was‌ ‌organised‌ ‌about‌ ‌‘‌nether‌ ‌world‌’‌ ‌themes.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌American‌ ‌society‌ ‌is‌ ‌organised‌ ‌around‌ ‌the‌ ‌themes‌ ‌of‌ ‌free‌ ‌enterprise‌ ‌and‌ ‌equality.‌ ‌ ‌\n309‌ ‌\n●Marxism‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌theme‌ ‌of‌ ‌Russian‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\n ‌\nConclusion:‌ ‌\n●Whereas‌ ‌the‌ ‌above‌ ‌factors‌ ‌explain‌ ‌the‌ ‌reason‌ ‌for‌ ‌variability‌ ‌in‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌they‌ ‌also‌ ‌point‌ ‌out‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌idea‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌world-wide‌ ‌common‌ ‌culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌\nnot‌ ‌a‌ ‌realizable‌ ‌one.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Although‌ ‌all‌ ‌societies‌ ‌have‌ ‌similar‌ ‌needs‌ ‌to‌ ‌satisfy,‌ ‌yet‌ ‌they‌ ‌will‌ ‌continue‌ ‌to‌ ‌satisfy‌ ‌these‌ ‌needs‌ ‌differently‌ ‌on‌ ‌account‌ ‌of‌ ‌different‌ ‌\nenvironmental‌ ‌conditions.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌may‌ ‌also‌ ‌be‌ ‌said‌ ‌that‌ ‌even‌ ‌though‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌vary,‌ ‌everywhere‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌universals.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Men‌ ‌quarrel,‌ ‌love,‌ ‌associate‌ ‌and‌ ‌procreate‌ ‌no‌ ‌matter‌ ‌what‌ ‌the‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Only‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌few‌ ‌societies‌ ‌a‌ ‌large‌ ‌percentage‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌population‌ ‌remain‌ ‌unmarried.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Murdock‌ ‌has‌ ‌compiled‌ ‌a‌ ‌list‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌universals‌ ‌based‌ ‌upon‌ ‌an‌ ‌inventory‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌human‌ ‌cultures.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌existence‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌universals‌ ‌indicates‌ ‌their‌ ‌utility‌ ‌and‌ ‌suggests‌ ‌that‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌practices‌ ‌to‌ ‌which‌ ‌a‌ ‌man‌ ‌is‌ ‌well‌ ‌adapted‌ ‌and‌ ‌for‌ ‌which‌ ‌\nhe‌ ‌has‌ ‌a‌ ‌need.‌ ‌\n ‌\nThe‌ ‌Functions‌ ‌of‌ ‌Culture:‌ ‌\n ‌\nWe‌ ‌may‌ ‌consider‌ ‌the‌ ‌functions‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌under‌ ‌two‌ ‌heads:‌ ‌\n ‌\n(a)‌ ‌For‌ ‌individual;‌ ‌and‌ ‌\n ‌\n(b)‌ ‌For‌ ‌the‌ ‌group.‌ ‌\n ‌\nFor‌ ‌Individual‌ ‌\n ‌\n(i)‌ ‌Culture‌ ‌makes‌ ‌man‌ ‌a‌ ‌human‌ ‌being:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌culture‌ ‌that‌ ‌makes‌ ‌the‌ ‌human‌ ‌animal‌ ‌a‌ ‌man,‌ ‌regulates‌ ‌his‌ ‌conduct‌ ‌and‌ ‌prepares‌ ‌him‌ ‌for‌ ‌group‌ ‌life.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌teaches‌ ‌him‌ ‌what‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌food‌ ‌he‌ ‌should‌ ‌take‌ ‌and‌ ‌in‌ ‌what‌ ‌manner,‌ ‌how‌ ‌he‌ ‌should‌ ‌cover‌ ‌himself‌ ‌and‌ ‌behave‌ ‌with‌ ‌his‌ ‌fellows,‌ ‌how‌ ‌he‌ ‌\nshould‌ ‌speak‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌people‌ ‌and‌ ‌how‌ ‌he‌ ‌should‌ ‌co-operate‌ ‌or‌ ‌compete‌ ‌with‌ ‌others.‌ ‌\n●An‌ ‌individual‌ ‌abstracted‌ ‌from‌ ‌culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌less‌ ‌than‌ ‌human,‌ ‌he‌ ‌is‌ ‌what‌ ‌we‌ ‌call‌ ‌a‌ ‌feral‌ ‌man.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Just‌ ‌as‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌necessary‌ ‌that‌ ‌fish‌ ‌must‌ ‌live‌ ‌in‌ ‌water,‌ ‌so‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌necessary‌ ‌and‌ ‌natural‌ ‌that‌ ‌man‌ ‌must‌ ‌live‌ ‌within‌ ‌a‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌framework.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌short,‌ ‌the‌ ‌qualities‌ ‌required‌ ‌to‌ ‌live‌ ‌a‌ ‌social‌ ‌life‌ ‌are‌ ‌acquired‌ ‌by‌ ‌man‌ ‌from‌ ‌his‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌Without‌ ‌it‌ ‌he‌ ‌would‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌forced‌ ‌to‌ ‌find‌ ‌his‌ ‌\nown‌ ‌way‌ ‌which‌ ‌would‌ ‌have‌ ‌meant‌ ‌a‌ ‌loss‌ ‌of‌ ‌energy‌ ‌in‌ ‌satisfying‌ ‌his‌ ‌elementary‌ ‌needs.‌ ‌\n ‌\n(ii)‌ ‌Culture‌ ‌provides‌ ‌solutions‌ ‌for‌ ‌complicated‌ ‌situations:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Secondly,‌ ‌culture‌ ‌provides‌ ‌man‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌set‌ ‌of‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌even‌ ‌for‌ ‌complicated‌ ‌situations.‌ ‌e.g.,‌ ‌forming‌ ‌a‌ ‌queue‌ ‌when‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌rush‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nbooking-window‌ ‌or‌ ‌driving‌ ‌left‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌busy‌ ‌streets.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌the‌ ‌absence‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌he‌ ‌would‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌baffled‌ ‌even‌ ‌by‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌simplest‌ ‌situations.‌ ‌\n○Horton‌ ‌and‌ ‌Hunt‌ ‌write:‌ ‌“From‌ ‌before‌ ‌he‌ ‌is‌ ‌born‌ ‌until‌ ‌after‌ ‌he‌ ‌is‌ ‌dead,‌ ‌man‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌prisoner‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\n310‌ ‌\n○His‌ ‌culture‌ ‌directs‌ ‌and‌ ‌confines‌ ‌his‌ ‌behaviour,‌ ‌limits‌ ‌his‌ ‌goals,‌ ‌and‌ ‌measures‌ ‌his‌ ‌rewards.‌ ‌ ‌\n○His‌ ‌culture‌ ‌gels‌ ‌into‌ ‌his‌ ‌mind‌ ‌and‌ ‌schuller's‌ ‌his‌ ‌vision‌ ‌so‌ ‌that‌ ‌he‌ ‌sees‌ ‌what‌ ‌he‌ ‌is‌ ‌supposed‌ ‌to‌ ‌see,‌ ‌dreams‌ ‌what‌ ‌he‌ ‌is‌ ‌expected‌ ‌to‌ ‌\ndream,‌ ‌and‌ ‌hungers‌ ‌for‌ ‌what‌ ‌he‌ ‌is‌ ‌trained‌ ‌to‌ ‌hunger.‌ ‌ ‌\n○He‌ ‌may‌ ‌imagine‌ ‌that‌ ‌he‌ ‌is‌ ‌making‌ ‌choices,‌ ‌or‌ ‌that‌ ‌he‌ ‌rules‌ ‌his‌ ‌destiny‌ ‌but‌ ‌the‌ ‌choices‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌normal‌ ‌person‌ ‌always‌ ‌fall‌ ‌within‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nseries‌ ‌of‌ ‌possibilities‌ ‌which‌ ‌the‌ ‌culture‌ ‌tolerates.”‌ ‌\n ‌\n(iii)‌ ‌Culture‌ ‌provides‌ ‌traditional‌ ‌interpretations‌ ‌to‌ ‌certain‌ ‌situations:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Lastly,‌ ‌through‌ ‌culture‌ ‌man‌ ‌gets‌ ‌traditional‌ ‌interpretations‌ ‌for‌ ‌many‌ ‌situations‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌which‌ ‌he‌ ‌determines‌ ‌his‌ ‌behaviour.‌ ‌If‌ ‌a‌ ‌cat‌ ‌\ncrosses‌ ‌his‌ ‌way‌ ‌he‌ ‌postpones‌ ‌the‌ ‌journey.‌ ‌If‌ ‌he‌ ‌sees‌ ‌an‌ ‌owl‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌top‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌house,‌ ‌he‌ ‌regards‌ ‌it‌ ‌as‌ ‌inauspicious.‌ ‌It‌ ‌may,‌ ‌however,‌ ‌be‌ ‌\nnoted‌ ‌that‌ ‌these‌ ‌traditional‌ ‌interpretations‌ ‌differ‌ ‌from‌ ‌culture‌ ‌lo‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌Among‌ ‌some‌ ‌culture‌ ‌the‌ ‌owl‌ ‌is‌ ‌regarded‌ ‌a‌ ‌symbol‌ ‌of‌ ‌wisdom‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nnot‌ ‌a‌ ‌symbol‌ ‌of‌ ‌idiocy.‌ ‌\n ‌\nFor‌ ‌the‌ ‌Group:‌ ‌\n ‌\n(i)‌ ‌Culture‌ ‌keeps‌ ‌social‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌intact:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Life‌ ‌would‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌poor,‌ ‌nasty,‌ ‌brutish‌ ‌and‌ ‌short‌ ‌if‌ ‌there‌ ‌had‌ ‌been‌ ‌no‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌regulations.‌ ‌ ‌\n●People‌ ‌behave‌ ‌the‌ ‌way‌ ‌in‌ ‌society‌ ‌because‌ ‌their‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌meet‌ ‌with‌ ‌social‌ ‌disapproval.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Culture‌ ‌has‌ ‌provided‌ ‌a‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌checks‌ ‌upon‌ ‌irrational‌ ‌conduct‌ ‌and‌ ‌suggestibility.‌ ‌\n●Cultural‌ ‌aids‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌schooling‌ ‌or‌ ‌scientific‌ ‌training‌ ‌lessen‌ ‌the‌ ‌chances‌ ‌that‌ ‌a‌ ‌man‌ ‌will‌ ‌behave‌ ‌irrationally‌ ‌or‌ ‌irresponsibly.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌group‌ ‌characterized‌ ‌though‌ ‌they‌ ‌be‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌consciousness‌ ‌of‌ ‌kind,‌ ‌are‌ ‌all‌ ‌once‌ ‌competing‌ ‌with‌ ‌one‌ ‌another‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌good‌ ‌\nthings‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌life‌ ‌and‌ ‌for‌ ‌status.‌ ‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌are‌ ‌held‌ ‌in‌ ‌line‌ ‌by‌ ‌constraints‌ ‌prescribed‌ ‌by‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌ ‌\n●So‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌culture,‌ ‌which‌ ‌has‌ ‌kept‌ ‌social‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌intact.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Group‌ ‌solidarity‌ ‌rests‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌foundation‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\n ‌\n(ii)‌ ‌Culture‌ ‌broadens‌ ‌the‌ ‌vision‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Secondly,‌ ‌culture‌ ‌has‌ ‌given‌ ‌a‌ ‌new‌ ‌vision‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual‌ ‌by‌ ‌providing‌ ‌him‌ ‌a‌ ‌set‌ ‌of‌ ‌rules‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌co-operation‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌individuals.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌thinks‌ ‌not‌ ‌only‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌own‌ ‌self‌ ‌but‌ ‌also‌ ‌of‌ ‌others.‌ ‌\n●Culture‌ ‌teaches‌ ‌him‌ ‌to‌ ‌think‌ ‌of‌ ‌himself‌ ‌a‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌larger‌ ‌whole.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌provides‌ ‌him‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌concepts‌ ‌of‌ ‌family,‌ ‌slate,‌ ‌nation‌ ‌and‌ ‌class‌ ‌and‌ ‌makes‌ ‌possible‌ ‌the‌ ‌coordination‌ ‌and‌ ‌division‌ ‌of‌ ‌labour.‌ ‌\n ‌\n(iii)‌ ‌Culture‌ ‌creates‌ ‌new‌ ‌needs:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Lastly,‌ ‌culture‌ ‌also‌ ‌creates‌ ‌new‌ ‌needs‌ ‌and‌ ‌new‌ ‌drives,‌ ‌for‌ ‌example,‌ ‌thirst‌ ‌for‌ ‌knowledge,‌ ‌and‌ ‌arranges‌ ‌for‌ ‌their‌ ‌satisfaction.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌satisfies‌ ‌the‌ ‌aesthetic,‌ ‌moral‌ ‌and‌ ‌religious‌ ‌interests‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌group.‌ ‌\n● ‌In‌ ‌this‌ ‌way‌ ‌groups‌ ‌also‌ ‌owe‌ ‌much‌ ‌to‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Any‌ ‌change‌ ‌in‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌valuations‌ ‌will‌ ‌have‌ ‌wide‌ ‌repercussions‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌personality‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual‌ ‌and‌ ‌structure‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌group.‌ ‌\n311‌ ‌\n ‌\nCultural‌ ‌Diffusion:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Cultural‌ ‌diffusion‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌process‌ ‌by‌ ‌which‌ ‌the‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌traits‌ ‌invented‌ ‌or‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌in‌ ‌one‌ ‌society‌ ‌are‌ ‌spread‌ ‌directly‌ ‌or‌ ‌indirectly‌ ‌to‌ ‌other‌ ‌\nsocieties.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Ordinarily,‌ ‌diffusion‌ ‌is‌ ‌thought‌ ‌of‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌movement‌ ‌of‌ ‌traits‌ ‌through‌ ‌space.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Diffusion‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌either‌ ‌direct‌ ‌or‌ ‌indirect.‌ ‌Direct‌ ‌diffusion‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌when‌ ‌persons‌ ‌or‌ ‌groups‌ ‌have‌ ‌actual‌ ‌physical‌ ‌contact.‌ ‌Indirect‌ ‌diffusion‌ ‌is‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌spread‌ ‌of‌ ‌traits‌ ‌without‌ ‌personal‌ ‌contact,‌ ‌for‌ ‌example,‌ ‌through‌ ‌radios,‌ ‌printed‌ ‌materials‌ ‌and‌ ‌transport‌ ‌of‌ ‌goods‌ ‌in‌ ‌commerce.‌ ‌\n●Graebner,‌ ‌Ankermann‌ ‌and‌ ‌Sehint‌,‌ ‌all‌ ‌German‌ ‌scholars,‌ ‌have‌ ‌done‌ ‌much‌ ‌towards‌ ‌the‌ ‌popularization‌ ‌the‌ ‌principle‌ ‌of‌ ‌diffusion‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌different‌ ‌from‌ ‌transmission‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌movement‌ ‌of‌ ‌traits‌ ‌through‌ ‌time,‌ ‌that‌ ‌is,‌ ‌from‌ ‌generation‌ ‌to‌ ‌generation.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Although‌ ‌the‌ ‌exact‌ ‌origin‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌specific‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌trait‌ ‌is‌ ‌difficult‌ ‌to‌ ‌trace,‌ ‌the‌ ‌diffusion‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌trait‌ ‌can‌ ‌fairly‌ ‌be‌ ‌traced.‌ ‌Historically,‌ ‌more‌ ‌is‌ ‌known‌ ‌\nabout‌ ‌diffusion‌ ‌than‌ ‌origin‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌history‌ ‌certain‌ ‌societies‌ ‌have‌ ‌served‌ ‌as‌ ‌centres‌ ‌from‌ ‌which‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌traits‌ ‌have‌ ‌spread‌ ‌to‌ ‌other‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌These‌ ‌centres‌ ‌of‌ ‌diffusion‌ ‌\nwere‌ ‌more‌ ‌progressive‌ ‌societies‌ ‌and‌ ‌had‌ ‌developed‌ ‌rapidly‌ ‌by‌ ‌invention‌ ‌and‌ ‌discovery.‌ ‌\n○Egypt‌ ‌was‌ ‌for‌ ‌many‌ ‌centuries‌ ‌a‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌centre‌ ‌from‌ ‌where‌ ‌many‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌traits‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌field‌ ‌of‌ ‌art‌ ‌and‌ ‌political‌ ‌organisation‌ ‌spread‌ ‌\nnorth-west‌ ‌in‌ ‌Europe‌ ‌and‌ ‌east‌ ‌as‌ ‌far‌ ‌as‌ ‌India.‌ ‌\n○Subsequently,‌ ‌Rome‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌great‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌centre‌ ‌from‌ ‌where‌ ‌Roman‌ ‌law‌ ‌spread‌ ‌in‌ ‌most‌ ‌countries‌ ‌of‌ ‌Europe.‌ ‌In‌ ‌Asia‌ ‌the‌ ‌Chinese‌ ‌\nMiddle‌ ‌Kingdom‌ ‌was‌ ‌from‌ ‌early‌ ‌times‌ ‌the‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌centre‌ ‌from‌ ‌where‌ ‌culture‌ ‌spread‌ ‌throughout‌ ‌the‌ ‌Asiatic‌ ‌mainland.‌ ‌\nAbout‌ ‌the‌ ‌fourteenth‌ ‌century‌ ‌western‌ ‌Europe‌ ‌became‌ ‌the‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌centre.‌ ‌Now,‌ ‌the‌ ‌United‌ ‌States‌ ‌is‌ ‌exporting‌ ‌its‌ ‌culture‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌other‌ ‌countries.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●It‌ ‌may‌ ‌not,‌ ‌however,‌ ‌be‌ ‌supposed‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌centres‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌diffusion‌ ‌have‌ ‌always‌ ‌been‌ ‌the‌ ‌places‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌development.‌ ‌In‌ ‌some‌ ‌\ncases‌ ‌they‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌mere‌ ‌places‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌than‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌development.‌ ‌Thus,‌ ‌early‌ ‌Greek‌ ‌was‌ ‌more‌ ‌a‌ ‌trader‌ ‌in‌ ‌culture‌ ‌than‌ ‌\nan‌ ‌originator‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌People‌ ‌from‌ ‌different‌ ‌lands‌ ‌assembled‌ ‌in‌ ‌Greek‌ ‌cities‌ ‌for‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌of‌ ‌goods‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌consequence‌ ‌that‌ ‌there‌ ‌\noccurred‌ ‌a‌ ‌considerable‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌traits.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌Greeks‌ ‌drew‌ ‌upon‌ ‌many‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌city-state‌ ‌mode‌ ‌of‌ ‌organisation.‌ ‌From‌ ‌Greece‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌systems‌ ‌\nspread‌ ‌west.‌ ‌Likewise,‌ ‌England‌ ‌obtained‌ ‌a‌ ‌great‌ ‌many‌ ‌widely‌ ‌varied‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌items‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌Venetians,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Portuguese,‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nSpaniards‌ ‌who‌ ‌came‌ ‌to‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌goods‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌Germanic,‌ ‌Baltic‌ ‌and‌ ‌Scandinavian‌
