‌traders.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Several‌ ‌factors‌ ‌influence‌ ‌the‌ ‌borrowing‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌One‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌physical‌ ‌isolation.‌ ‌The‌ ‌poor‌ ‌means‌ ‌of‌ ‌transport‌ ‌may‌ ‌preclude‌ ‌a‌ ‌\npeople‌ ‌from‌ ‌borrowing‌ ‌from‌ ‌other‌ ‌countries.‌ ‌That‌ ‌the‌ ‌people‌ ‌living‌ ‌in‌ ‌high‌ ‌altitudes‌ ‌are‌ ‌generally‌ ‌more‌ ‌conservative‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌modes‌ ‌of‌ ‌living‌ ‌\nas‌ ‌compared‌ ‌to‌ ‌those‌ ‌who‌ ‌live‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌plains‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌their‌ ‌physical‌ ‌isolation.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌rapid‌ ‌means‌ ‌of‌ ‌transport‌ ‌and‌ ‌communication‌ ‌has‌ ‌recently‌ ‌lessened‌ ‌the‌ ‌fact‌ ‌of‌ ‌physical‌ ‌isolation.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Today‌ ‌the‌ ‌greater‌ ‌reason‌ ‌for‌ ‌obstructing‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌borrowings‌ ‌is‌ ‌social‌ ‌isolation,‌ ‌the‌ ‌refusal‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌to‌ ‌borrow‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌group.‌ ‌Such‌ ‌\na‌ ‌group‌ ‌becomes‌ ‌an‌ ‌island‌ ‌of‌ ‌indigenous‌ ‌culture,‌ ‌untouched‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌developments‌ ‌of‌ ‌even‌ ‌the‌ ‌neighbouring‌ ‌peoples.‌ ‌\n ‌\nAttributes‌ ‌of‌ ‌Culture‌ ‌\n●Ethos‌ ‌and‌ ‌Eidos‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌distinction‌ ‌as‌ ‌given‌ ‌by‌ ‌Kroeber‌ ‌highlights‌ ‌two‌ ‌different‌ ‌aspects‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\n○Eidos‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌formal‌ ‌appearance‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌culture‌ ‌derived‌ ‌from‌ ‌its‌ ‌constituents.‌ ‌Ethos‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌hand‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌disposition‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌culture‌ ‌\n312‌ ‌\nwhich‌ ‌determines‌ ‌its‌ ‌quality,‌ ‌its‌ ‌main‌ ‌themes‌ ‌and‌ ‌interests.‌ ‌\n○According‌ ‌to‌ ‌Batson‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌consisting‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌total‌ ‌emotional‌ ‌emphasis‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌called‌ ‌ethos‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌second‌ ‌consisting‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nemphasis‌ ‌resulting‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌cognitive‌ ‌processes‌ ‌operative‌ ‌within‌ ‌a‌ ‌culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌called‌ ‌eidos.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nCivilization‌ ‌\nIntroduction‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌Civilization‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌‌complex‌ ‌society‌ ‌or‌ ‌culture‌ ‌group‌ ‌characterized‌ ‌by‌ ‌dependence‌ ‌on‌ ‌agriculture,‌ ‌long‌ ‌distance‌ ‌trade,‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌Government,‌ ‌\noccupational‌ ‌specialization‌ ‌urbanism‌ ‌and‌ ‌class‌ ‌stratification.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Along‌ ‌with‌ ‌these‌ ‌core‌ ‌elements,‌ ‌civilization‌ ‌is‌ ‌often‌ ‌marked‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌combination‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌secondary‌ ‌elements‌ ‌,‌ ‌including‌ ‌a‌ ‌developed‌ ‌\ntransportation‌ ‌system,‌ ‌writing,‌ ‌standards‌ ‌of‌ ‌measurement,‌ ‌formal‌ ‌legal‌ ‌system,‌ ‌great‌ ‌art‌ ‌style,‌ ‌monumental‌ ‌architecture,‌ ‌the‌ ‌mathematics‌ ‌\nsophisticated‌ ‌metallurgy,‌ ‌and‌ ‌astronomy.‌ ‌\n ‌\nDefinitions‌ ‌\n●An‌ ‌advanced‌ ‌state‌ ‌of‌ ‌intellectual,‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌and‌ ‌material‌ ‌development‌ ‌in‌ ‌human‌ ‌society‌ ‌marked‌ ‌by‌ ‌progress‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌arts‌ ‌and‌ ‌sciences,‌ ‌that‌ ‌\nextensive‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌record‌ ‌keeping,‌ ‌including‌ ‌writing‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌appearance‌ ‌of‌ ‌complex‌ ‌political‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌institutions.‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌‌Albert‌ ‌Schweitzern‌ ‌“‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌sum‌ ‌total‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌progress‌ ‌made‌ ‌by‌ ‌man‌ ‌every‌ ‌sphere‌ ‌of‌ ‌action‌ ‌and‌ ‌from‌ ‌every‌ ‌point‌ ‌of‌ ‌view‌ ‌in‌ ‌so‌ ‌\nfar‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌progress‌ ‌helps‌ ‌towards‌ ‌the‌ ‌spiritual‌ ‌perfecting‌ ‌of‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌Progress‌”‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌Oxford‌ ‌English‌ ‌Dictionary‌ ‌civilization‌ ‌is‌ ‌“the‌ ‌action‌ ‌or‌ ‌process‌ ‌of‌ ‌civilizing‌ ‌or‌ ‌of‌ ‌being‌ ‌civilized,‌ ‌developed‌ ‌or‌ ‌advanced‌ ‌state‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nhuman‌ ‌society.”‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nCharacteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌Civilization‌ ‌\n●Civilization‌ ‌distinguished‌ ‌by‌ ‌traits‌ ‌\n○Civilizations‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌distinguished‌ ‌by‌ ‌their‌ ‌means‌ ‌of‌ ‌subsistence,‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌livelihood,‌ ‌settlement‌ ‌Patterns,‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌government,‌ ‌\nsocial‌ ‌stratification,‌ ‌economic‌ ‌systems,‌ ‌literacy‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌traits.‌ ‌\n●Dependence‌ ‌on‌ ‌agriculture‌ ‌for‌ ‌subsistence‌ ‌\n○Growing‌ ‌food‌ ‌in‌ ‌farms‌ ‌results‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌surplus‌ ‌of‌ ‌food,‌ ‌particularly‌ ‌when‌ ‌people‌ ‌use‌ ‌intensive‌ ‌agricultural‌ ‌techniques‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌irrigation‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌crop‌ ‌rotation.‌ ‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌surplus‌ ‌of‌ ‌food‌ ‌permits‌ ‌the‌ ‌people‌ ‌to‌ ‌do‌ ‌things‌ ‌besides‌ ‌produce‌ ‌food‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌living‌ ‌and‌ ‌also‌ ‌results‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌division‌ ‌of‌ ‌labour‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌more‌ ‌\ndiverse‌ ‌range‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌activity.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Different‌ ‌Settlement‌ ‌Patterns‌ ‌\n○ ‌Civilizations‌ ‌have‌ ‌distinctly‌ ‌different‌ ‌settlement‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌from‌ ‌other‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌\n●Complex‌ ‌Political‌ ‌Structure‌ ‌\n313‌ ‌\n○Compared‌ ‌with‌ ‌other‌ ‌societies,‌ ‌civilizations‌ ‌have‌ ‌moved‌ ‌to‌ ‌complex‌ ‌political‌ ‌structures,‌ ‌namely‌ ‌the‌ ‌State.‌ ‌\n○There‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌greater‌ ‌difference‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌classes.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌ruling‌ ‌class‌ ‌normally‌ ‌concentrated‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌cities,‌ ‌has‌ ‌control‌ ‌over‌ ‌much‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌surplus‌ ‌and‌ ‌exercises‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌actions‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌\ngovernment‌ ‌or‌ ‌bureaucracy.‌ ‌\n●Display‌ ‌more‌ ‌complex‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌of‌ ‌ownership.‌ ‌\n○Living‌ ‌in‌ ‌one‌ ‌place‌ ‌allows‌ ‌people‌ ‌to‌ ‌accumulate‌ ‌more‌ ‌personal‌ ‌possessions‌ ‌than‌ ‌nomadic‌ ‌people.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Some‌ ‌people‌ ‌also‌ ‌acquire‌ ‌landed‌ ‌property‌ ‌or‌ ‌private‌ ‌ownership‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌land.‌ ‌\n●Development‌ ‌of‌ ‌Writing‌ ‌\n○Writing,‌ ‌developed‌ ‌first‌ ‌by‌ ‌people‌ ‌in‌ ‌summer,‌ ‌is‌ ‌considered‌ ‌a‌ ‌hallmark‌ ‌of‌ ‌civilization.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Trader’s,bureaucrats‌ ‌relied‌ ‌on‌ ‌writing‌ ‌to‌ ‌keep‌ ‌accurate‌ ‌records.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Like‌ ‌money,‌ ‌writing‌ ‌was‌ ‌necessitated‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌size‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌population‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌city‌ ‌and‌ ‌complexity‌ ‌of‌ ‌its‌ ‌commerce‌ ‌among‌ ‌people‌ ‌who‌ ‌did‌ ‌\nnot‌ ‌personally‌ ‌acquire‌ ‌it‌ ‌with‌ ‌early‌ ‌others.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nCulture‌ ‌vs‌ ‌Civilization‌ ‌\n ‌\n(i)‌ ‌Civilization‌ ‌has‌ ‌a‌ ‌precise‌ ‌standard‌ ‌of‌ ‌measurement,‌ ‌but‌ ‌not‌ ‌culture:‌ ‌\n●Civilization‌ ‌is‌ ‌susceptible‌ ‌to‌ ‌being‌ ‌quantitatively‌ ‌measured‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌grounds‌ ‌of‌ ‌efficiency.‌ ‌ ‌\n●When‌ ‌comparing‌ ‌the‌ ‌products‌ ‌of‌ ‌civilization‌ ‌we‌ ‌can‌ ‌prove‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌superior‌ ‌and‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌inferior.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Their‌ ‌efficiency‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌estimated‌ ‌and‌ ‌in‌ ‌fact‌ ‌be‌ ‌measured.‌ ‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌lorry‌ ‌runs‌ ‌faster‌ ‌than‌ ‌a‌ ‌bullock‌ ‌cart,‌ ‌an‌ ‌aeroplane‌ ‌runs‌ ‌faster‌ ‌than‌ ‌a‌ ‌lorry,‌ ‌a‌ ‌power‌ ‌loom‌ ‌produces‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌a‌ ‌handloom.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌tractor‌ ‌is‌ ‌superior‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌hand‌ ‌plough.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌modern‌ ‌currency‌ ‌system‌ ‌is‌ ‌superior‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌barter‌ ‌system.‌ ‌\n●None‌ ‌can‌ ‌dispute‌ ‌these‌ ‌facts.‌ ‌Or‌ ‌the‌ ‌contrary,‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌measuring‌ ‌rod‌ ‌by‌ ‌which‌ ‌we‌ ‌can‌ ‌assess‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌objects.‌ ‌\n●Different‌ ‌ages‌ ‌and‌ ‌different‌ ‌groups‌ ‌have‌ ‌their‌ ‌own‌ ‌standards‌ ‌of‌ ‌judgments.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌paintings‌ ‌of‌ ‌Picasso‌ ‌may‌ ‌appear‌ ‌to‌ ‌some‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌an‌ ‌abomination‌ ‌while‌ ‌to‌ ‌others‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌invaluable‌ ‌models‌ ‌of‌ ‌art.‌ ‌\n○Bernard‌ ‌Shaw‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌better‌ ‌dramatist‌ ‌than‌ ‌Shakespeare.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Some‌ ‌like‌ ‌folk‌ ‌songs,‌ ‌others‌ ‌prefer‌ ‌film‌ ‌songs.‌ ‌\n ‌\n(ii)‌ ‌Civilization‌ ‌is‌ ‌always‌ ‌advancing,‌ ‌but‌ ‌not‌ ‌culture:‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌MacIver,‌ ‌“Civilization‌ ‌not‌ ‌only‌ ‌marches,‌ ‌it‌ ‌marches‌ ‌always‌ ‌ahead,‌ ‌provided‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌catastrophic‌ ‌break‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌continuity‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌same‌ ‌direction.”‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌unilinear‌ ‌and‌ ‌cumulative‌ ‌and‌ ‌tends‌ ‌to‌ ‌advance‌ ‌indefinitely.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Since‌ ‌man‌ ‌invented‌ ‌the‌ ‌automobile,‌ ‌it‌ ‌has‌ ‌continuously‌ ‌improved.‌ ‌\n○Similar‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌case‌ ‌with‌ ‌other‌ ‌means‌ ‌of‌ ‌transportation‌ ‌like‌ ‌railway,‌ ‌ship,‌ ‌aeroplane‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌constantly‌ ‌growing‌ ‌more‌ ‌swift,‌ ‌more‌ ‌\nefficient‌ ‌and‌ ‌better‌ ‌designed.‌ ‌They‌ ‌are‌ ‌vastly‌ ‌superior‌ ‌to‌ ‌those‌ ‌employed‌ ‌by‌ ‌our‌ ‌ancestors.‌ ‌\n●Culture,‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌hand,‌ ‌advances‌ ‌slowly‌ ‌and‌ ‌is‌ ‌often‌ ‌subject‌ ‌to‌ ‌retrogression.‌ ‌ ‌\n314‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌march‌ ‌assuredly‌ ‌to‌ ‌higher‌ ‌or‌ ‌improved‌ ‌standards.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Our‌ ‌paintings‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌as‌ ‌good‌ ‌as‌ ‌or‌ ‌better‌ ‌than‌ ‌those‌ ‌of‌ ‌Ajanta‌ ‌Caves.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Can‌ ‌we‌ ‌say‌ ‌that‌ ‌our‌ ‌poetry,‌ ‌drama‌ ‌and‌ ‌literature‌ ‌are‌ ‌superior‌ ‌to‌ ‌those‌ ‌of‌ ‌ancient‌ ‌times!‌ ‌\n ‌\n(iii)‌ ‌Civilization‌ ‌is‌ ‌passed‌ ‌on‌ ‌without‌ ‌effort,‌ ‌but‌ ‌not‌ ‌culture:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌transmitted‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌different‌ ‌principle‌ ‌from‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌civilization.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌former‌ ‌can‌ ‌only‌ ‌be‌ ‌assimilated‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌like-minded.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌had‌ ‌only‌ ‌by‌ ‌those‌ ‌who‌ ‌are‌ ‌worthy‌ ‌of‌ ‌it.‌ ‌ ‌\n○No‌ ‌one‌ ‌without‌ ‌the‌ ‌quality‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌artist‌ ‌can‌ ‌appreciate‌ ‌art,‌ ‌nor‌ ‌classical‌ ‌music‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌judged‌ ‌by‌ ‌those‌ ‌who‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌have‌ ‌an‌ ‌ear‌ ‌for‌ ‌it.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Civilization‌ ‌in‌ ‌general‌ ‌makes‌ ‌no‌ ‌such‌ ‌demand.‌ ‌\n○We‌ ‌can‌ ‌enjoy‌ ‌its‌ ‌products‌ ‌without‌ ‌sharing‌ ‌the‌ ‌capacity‌ ‌which‌ ‌creates‌ ‌them.‌ ‌Everyone‌ ‌can‌ ‌use‌ ‌the‌ ‌cool‌ ‌air‌ ‌from‌ ‌an‌ ‌air‌ ‌conditioner‌ ‌\nwhether‌ ‌he‌ ‌knows‌ ‌the‌ ‌mechanism‌ ‌or‌ ‌not.‌ ‌ ‌\n●A.‌ ‌J.‌ ‌Toynbee‌ ‌writes,‌ ‌“It‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌easiest‌ ‌thing‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌world‌ ‌for‌ ‌commerce‌ ‌to‌ ‌export‌ ‌a‌ ‌new‌ ‌Western‌ ‌technique.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌infinitely‌ ‌harder‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌Western‌ ‌\npoet‌ ‌or‌ ‌saint‌ ‌to‌ ‌kindle‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌non-‌ ‌Western‌ ‌soul‌ ‌the‌ ‌spiritual‌ ‌flame‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌alight‌ ‌in‌ ‌his‌ ‌own.”‌ ‌\n ‌\n(iv)‌ ‌The‌ ‌works‌ ‌of‌ ‌civilization‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌improved‌ ‌by‌ ‌any‌ ‌body‌ ‌but‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌possible‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌case‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Lesser‌ ‌minds‌ ‌can‌ ‌improve‌ ‌the‌ ‌work‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌great‌ ‌inventors,‌ ‌but‌ ‌lesser‌ ‌artists‌ ‌instead‌ ‌of‌ ‌improving‌ ‌may‌ ‌rather‌ ‌spoil‌ ‌the‌ ‌poems‌ ‌of‌ ‌Milton‌ ‌or‌ ‌\nTagore.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌accomplishments‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌perfected‌ ‌only‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌persons‌ ‌who‌ ‌produced‌ ‌them.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Again,‌ ‌the‌ ‌product‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌artist‌ ‌is‌ ‌more‌ ‌revelatory‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌personality‌ ‌than‌ ‌is‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌technician.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Culture,‌ ‌being‌ ‌the‌ ‌immediate‌ ‌expression‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌human‌ ‌spirit,‌ ‌can‌ ‌advance‌ ‌only‌ ‌if‌ ‌that‌ ‌spirit‌ ‌is‌ ‌capable‌ ‌of‌ ‌finer‌ ‌efforts,‌ ‌and‌ ‌has‌ ‌itself‌ ‌\nsomething‌ ‌more‌ ‌to‌ ‌express.‌ ‌\n ‌\n(v)‌ ‌Civilization‌ ‌is‌ ‌external‌ ‌and‌ ‌mechanical‌ ‌while‌ ‌culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌internal‌ ‌and‌ ‌organic:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Civilization‌ ‌is‌ ‌inclusive‌ ‌of‌ ‌external‌ ‌things,‌ ‌culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌internal‌ ‌thoughts,‌ ‌feelings,‌ ‌ideals,‌ ‌values‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌ ‌\n●MacIver‌ ‌‌remarks,‌ ‌“Civilization‌ ‌is‌ ‌what‌ ‌we‌ ‌have,‌ ‌culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌what‌ ‌we‌ ‌are.’‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌‌Mathew‌ ‌Arnold‌’s‌ ‌words,‌ ‌culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌“the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌perfection‌ ‌and‌ ‌of‌ ‌harmonious‌ ‌perfection;‌ ‌general‌ ‌perfection‌ ‌and‌ ‌perfection‌ ‌which‌ ‌consists‌ ‌\nin‌ ‌becoming‌ ‌something,‌ ‌rather‌ ‌than‌ ‌in‌ ‌having‌ ‌something,‌ ‌in‌ ‌an‌ ‌inward‌ ‌condition‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌mind‌ ‌and‌ ‌spirit,‌ ‌not‌ ‌in‌ ‌an‌ ‌outward‌ ‌set‌ ‌of‌ ‌\ncircumstances.”‌ ‌\n ‌\n(vi)‌ ‌Civilization‌ ‌is‌ ‌borrowed‌ ‌without‌ ‌change‌ ‌or‌ ‌loss,‌ ‌but‌ ‌not‌ ‌culture:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●The‌ ‌transference‌ ‌of‌ ‌civilization‌ ‌from‌ ‌one‌ ‌generation‌ ‌to‌ ‌another‌ ‌is‌ ‌quick‌ ‌and‌ ‌easy.‌ ‌ ‌\n315‌ ‌\n●Given‌ ‌adequate‌ ‌means‌ ‌of‌ ‌communication‌ ‌things‌ ‌of‌ ‌civilization‌ ‌can‌ ‌quickly‌ ‌spread‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌whole‌ ‌world.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Radio,‌ ‌television.‌ ‌X-ray,‌ ‌automobiles‌ ‌are‌ ‌no‌ ‌longer‌ ‌the‌ ‌monopoly‌ ‌of‌ ‌any‌ ‌one‌ ‌country.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌corporate‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌industry‌ ‌has‌ ‌encroached‌ ‌everywhere‌ ‌on‌ ‌older‌ ‌forms.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌factory‌ ‌has‌ ‌displaced‌ ‌the‌ ‌domestic‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌production.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌new‌ ‌techniques‌ ‌of‌ ‌constructing‌ ‌buildings‌ ‌and‌ ‌building‌ ‌roads‌ ‌nave‌ ‌everywhere‌ ‌been‌ ‌adopted.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Culture,‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌hand,‌ ‌has‌ ‌an‌ ‌intrinsic‌ ‌quality‌ ‌and‌ ‌can‌ ‌only‌ ‌be‌ ‌imbibed.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌will‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌limited‌ ‌appeal.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌India‌ ‌we‌ ‌have‌ ‌borrowed‌ ‌much‌ ‌western‌ ‌civilization,‌ ‌but‌ ‌not‌ ‌western‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌Though‌ ‌there‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌some‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌“borrowings”‌ ‌but‌ ‌\nthey‌ ‌are‌ ‌insignificant‌ ‌compared‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌borrowings‌ ‌of‌ ‌civilization.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌only‌ ‌a‌ ‌few‌ ‌aspects‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌borrowed‌ ‌and‌ ‌even‌ ‌in‌ ‌this‌ ‌act‌ ‌of‌ ‌borrowing,‌ ‌borrowed‌ ‌culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌largely‌ ‌modified‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌\npersonality‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌borrowers.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Thus‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌clear‌ ‌that‌ ‌expansion‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌civilization‌ ‌follows‌ ‌different‌ ‌principles‌ ‌from‌ ‌those‌ ‌which‌ ‌determine‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌development.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Civilization‌ ‌proceeds‌ ‌more‌ ‌rapidly,‌ ‌more‌ ‌simply,‌ ‌less‌ ‌selectively,‌ ‌always‌ ‌spreading‌ ‌outward‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌focus‌ ‌of‌ ‌technological‌ ‌advance.‌ ‌\n ‌\nCulture‌ ‌and‌ ‌civilization‌ ‌are‌ ‌interdependent:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌civilization,‌ ‌different‌ ‌as‌ ‌they‌ ‌are,‌ ‌will‌ ‌hardly‌ ‌exist‌ ‌apart‌ ‌from‌ ‌each‌ ‌other.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌two‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌only‌ ‌interdependent‌ ‌but‌ ‌also‌ ‌interactive.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌articles‌ ‌of‌ ‌civilization‌ ‌called‌ ‌artifacts‌ ‌are‌ ‌influenced‌ ‌by‌ ‌culture‌ ‌called‌ ‌“mentifacts”‌ ‌and‌ ‌culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌influenced‌ ‌by‌ ‌articles‌ ‌of‌ ‌civilization.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Man‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌simply‌ ‌want‌ ‌a‌ ‌thing‌ ‌but‌ ‌he‌ ‌wants‌ ‌a‌ ‌thing‌ ‌which‌ ‌may‌ ‌also‌ ‌be‌ ‌beautiful‌ ‌and‌ ‌appealing‌ ‌to‌ ‌his‌ ‌senses.‌ ‌\n○Here‌ ‌culture‌ ‌influences‌ ‌civilization.‌ ‌An‌ ‌automobile‌ ‌or‌ ‌radio‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌a‌ ‌useful‌ ‌thing,‌ ‌but‌ ‌the‌ ‌models‌ ‌and‌ ‌finish‌ ‌are‌ ‌determined‌ ‌by‌ ‌our‌ ‌\nculture.‌ ‌Similarly,‌ ‌our‌ ‌philosophies,‌ ‌novels,‌ ‌and‌ ‌all‌ ‌our‌ ‌learning‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌much‌ ‌influenced‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌printing‌ ‌press.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌objects‌ ‌of‌ ‌civilization‌ ‌after‌ ‌some‌ ‌time‌ ‌acquire‌ ‌a‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌aspect:‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌tools‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌communities‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌merely‌ ‌tools,‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌that.‌ ‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌symbols‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌numerous‌ ‌articles‌ ‌like‌ ‌pot,‌ ‌clothing,‌ ‌coins,‌ ‌tools,‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌excavations‌ ‌reveal‌ ‌the‌ ‌culture‌ ‌of‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌people.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Likewise‌ ‌a‌ ‌constitution‌ ‌or‌ ‌code‌ ‌of‌ ‌laws‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌simply‌ ‌a‌ ‌means‌ ‌of‌ ‌government,‌ ‌but‌ ‌it‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌time‌ ‌expresses‌ ‌the‌ ‌spirit‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌people‌ ‌and‌ ‌is‌ ‌\ntreasured‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌embodiment‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌this‌ ‌way‌ ‌the‌ ‌objects‌ ‌that‌ ‌fall‌ ‌mainly‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌realms‌ ‌of‌ ‌civilization‌ ‌have‌ ‌generally‌ ‌a‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌aspect.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌addition‌ ‌\nHistory‌ ‌of‌ ‌Civilization‌ ‌\nOur‌ ‌knowledge‌ ‌of‌ ‌prehistory‌ ‌derives‌ ‌from‌ ‌surviving‌ ‌objects-‌ ‌the‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌of‌ ‌archaeology.‌ ‌\nHistory,‌ ‌by‌ ‌contrast,‌ ‌is‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌documents.‌ ‌These‌ ‌various‌ ‌interconnections‌ ‌mean‌ ‌that‌ ‌history,‌ ‌civilization‌ ‌and‌ ‌\n316‌ ‌\nwriting‌ ‌all‌ ‌begin‌ ‌at‌ ‌that‌ ‌time.‌ ‌That‌ ‌time‌ ‌is‌ ‌about‌ ‌3100‌ ‌BC‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Mesopotamia‌ ‌and‌ ‌Egypt:3100‌ ‌BC‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌about‌ ‌3200BC‌ ‌the‌ ‌two‌ ‌earliest‌ ‌civilizations‌ ‌developed‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌region‌ ‌where‌ ‌southwest‌ ‌Asia‌ ‌joins‌ ‌northeast‌ ‌\n○Africa.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Great‌ ‌rivers‌ ‌are‌ ‌a‌ ‌crucial‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌story.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌Sumerians‌ ‌settle‌ ‌in‌ ‌what‌ ‌is‌ ‌now‌ ‌southern‌ ‌lraq,‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌mouths‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Euphrates‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌Tigris.‌ ‌\n○Egypt‌ ‌develops‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌long‌ ‌narrow‌ ‌strip‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Nile‌ ‌valley.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Rivers‌ ‌offer‌ ‌two‌ ‌main‌ ‌advantages‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌developing‌ ‌civilization.‌ ‌They‌ ‌provide‌ ‌water‌ ‌to‌ ‌irrigate‌ ‌the‌ ‌fields,‌ ‌and‌ ‌they‌ ‌offer‌ ‌the‌ ‌easiest‌ ‌\nmethod‌ ‌of‌ ‌transport‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌society‌ ‌without‌ ‌paved‌ ‌roads.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Rivers‌ ‌will‌ ‌play‌ ‌an‌ ‌equally‌ ‌important‌ ‌role‌ ‌in‌ ‌two‌ ‌other‌ ‌early‌ ‌civilizations-‌ ‌those‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Indus‌ ‌and‌ ‌northern‌ ‌China.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Indus:‌ ‌2500BC‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌known‌ ‌whether‌ ‌contact‌ ‌with‌ ‌Mesopotamia‌ ‌inspires‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌civilization‌ ‌of‌ ‌India‌ ‌or‌ ‌whether‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌spontaneous‌ ‌Local‌ ‌\ndevelopment,‌ ‌but‌ ‌by‌ ‌about‌ ‌2500‌ ‌BC‌ ‌the‌ ‌Neolithic‌ ‌villages‌ ‌along‌ ‌the‌ ‌banks‌ ‌if‌ ‌the‌ ‌Indus‌ ‌are‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌verge‌ ‌of‌ ‌combining‌ ‌into‌ ‌a‌ ‌unified‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌sophisticated‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌Indus‌ ‌civilization,‌ ‌with‌ ‌its‌ ‌two‌ ‌large‌ ‌cities‌ ‌of‌ ‌Harappa‌ ‌and‌ ‌Mohenjo-daro‌ ‌expands‌ ‌over‌ ‌a‌ ‌larger‌ ‌region‌ ‌than‌ ‌Egypt‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nMesopotamia‌ ‌combined.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌will‌ ‌survive,‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌remarkably‌ ‌consistent‌ ‌form,‌ ‌for‌ ‌about‌ ‌1000‌ ‌years.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●The‌ ‌Aegean:2000BC‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌next‌ ‌region‌ ‌to‌ ‌develop‌ ‌a‌ ‌distinctive‌ ‌civilization‌ ‌centres‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌Aegean‌ ‌Sea.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌bays‌ ‌and‌ ‌inlets‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌rugged‌ ‌coastal‌ ‌regions‌ ‌of‌ ‌Greece,‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌many‌ ‌small‌ ‌islands‌ ‌strung‌ ‌like‌ ‌pearls‌ ‌across‌ ‌this‌ ‌relatively‌ ‌\nsheltered‌ ‌sea,‌ ‌combine‌ ‌to‌ ‌make‌ ‌this‌ ‌an‌ ‌ideal‌ ‌area‌ ‌for‌ ‌trade‌ ‌among‌ ‌people‌ ‌whose‌ ‌levels‌ ‌of‌ ‌nautical‌ ‌skill‌ ‌make‌ ‌short‌ ‌hops‌ ‌a‌ ‌necessary‌ ‌\nprecaution.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌Aegean‌ ‌civilization‌ ‌stands‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌start‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌very‌ ‌lively‌ ‌tradition‌ ‌of‌ ‌Mediterranean‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n●China:1600‌ ‌BC‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌longest‌ ‌consistent‌ ‌civilization‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌human‌ ‌story‌ ‌so‌ ‌far‌ ‌is‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌China.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌vast‌ ‌eastern‌ ‌empire‌ ‌seems‌ ‌set‌ ‌apart‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌rest‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌world,‌ ‌fiercely‌ ‌proud‌ ‌of‌ ‌its‌ ‌own‌ ‌traditions,‌ ‌resisting‌ ‌foreign‌ ‌influences.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Its‌ ‌history‌ ‌begins‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌characteristically‌ ‌independent‌ ‌manner.‌ ‌ ‌\n○There‌ ‌are‌ ‌no‌ ‌identifiable‌ ‌precedents‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌civilization‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Shang‌ ‌dynasty,‌ ‌which‌ ‌emerges‌ ‌in‌ ‌china‌ ‌in‌ ‌about‌ ‌1600‌ ‌BC.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Its‌ ‌superb‌ ‌bronze‌ ‌vessels‌ ‌seem‌ ‌to‌ ‌achieve‌ ‌an‌ ‌instant‌ ‌technological‌ ‌perfection.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Its‌ ‌written‌ ‌texts‌ ‌introduce‌ ‌characters‌ ‌recognizably‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌Chinese‌ ‌writing‌ ‌today.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●America:‌ ‌1200‌ ‌BC‌ ‌\n317‌ ‌\n○Around‌ ‌this‌ ‌time‌ ‌the‌ ‌earliest‌ ‌American‌ ‌civilizations‌ ‌have‌ ‌their‌ ‌beginnings,‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌Olmecs‌ ‌in‌ ‌Central‌ ‌America‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌Chavin‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nAndes.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Both‌ ‌these‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌developed‌ ‌large‌ ‌town,‌ ‌centered‌ ‌on‌ ‌temples.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Both‌ ‌are‌ ‌now‌ ‌famous‌ ‌for‌ ‌their‌ ‌sculpture‌ ‌and‌ ‌each,‌ ‌in‌ ‌its‌ ‌own‌ ‌region,‌ ‌is‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌start‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌succession‌ ‌of‌ ‌civilizations‌ ‌leading‌ ‌directly‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌two‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌and‌ ‌destroyed‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌16th‌ ‌century‌ ‌by‌ ‌Spanish-the‌ ‌Aztecs‌ ‌in‌ ‌central‌ ‌America‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌Incas‌ ‌the‌ ‌Andes.‌ ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌Addition‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n318‌ ‌\nEthnocentrism‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Ethnocentrism‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌term‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌use‌ ‌to‌ ‌describe‌‌ ‌the‌ ‌opinion‌ ‌that‌ ‌one’s‌ ‌own‌ ‌way‌ ‌of‌ ‌life‌ ‌is‌ ‌natural‌ ‌or‌ ‌correct.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌universal‌ ‌phenomena‌ ‌which‌ ‌‌gives‌ ‌an‌ ‌attitude‌ ‌of‌ ‌superiority‌ ‌that‌ ‌exist‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌time‌ ‌and‌ ‌all‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌root‌ ‌of‌ ‌ethnocentrism‌ ‌lies‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌primordial‌ ‌feeling‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌identification‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌group.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌arises‌ ‌out‌ ‌of‌ ‌any‌ ‌intense‌ ‌‘We‌ ‌feeling’‌ ‌which‌ ‌unite‌ ‌the‌ ‌member‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌group.‌ ‌we‌ ‌feeling‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌bad‌ ‌but‌ ‌it‌ ‌becomes‌ ‌so‌ ‌when‌ ‌it‌ ‌grow‌ ‌to‌ ‌such‌ ‌\nproportions‌ ‌that‌ ‌we‌ ‌develop‌ ‌hatred‌ ‌towards‌ ‌other‌ ‌attempts‌ ‌to‌ ‌impose‌ ‌our‌ ‌own‌ ‌will‌ ‌upon‌ ‌them‌ ‌with‌ ‌an‌ ‌aim‌ ‌of‌ ‌superiority‌ ‌and‌ ‌hence‌ ‌give‌ ‌rise‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌to‌ ‌prejudice.‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌tunnel‌ ‌vision‌ ‌often‌ ‌results‌ ‌in:‌ ‌ ‌\n○an‌ ‌inability‌ ‌to‌ ‌adequately‌ ‌understand‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌different‌ ‌from‌ ‌one’s‌ ‌own‌ ‌and‌ ‌ ‌\n○value‌ ‌judgments‌ ‌that‌ ‌preference‌ ‌the‌ ‌in-group‌ ‌and‌ ‌assert‌ ‌its‌ ‌inherent‌ ‌superiority,‌ ‌thus‌ ‌linking‌ ‌the‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌ethnocentrism‌ ‌to‌ ‌multiple‌ ‌\nforms‌ ‌of‌ ‌chauvinism‌ ‌and‌ ‌prejudice,‌ ‌including‌ ‌nationalism,‌ ‌tribalism,‌ ‌racism,‌ ‌and‌ ‌even‌ ‌sexism‌ ‌and‌ ‌disability‌ ‌discrimination‌ ‌\n●Example‌ ‌of‌ ‌ethnocentrism‌ ‌is‌ ‌colonialism‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Colonialism‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌defined‌ ‌as‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌domination‌ ‌with‌ ‌enforced‌ ‌social‌ ‌change.‌ ‌Colonialism‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌system‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌the‌ ‌\npolitical‌ ‌conquests‌ ‌by‌ ‌one‌ ‌society‌ ‌of‌ ‌another‌ ‌leads‌ ‌to‌ ‌“cultural‌ ‌domination‌ ‌with‌ ‌enforced‌ ‌social‌ ‌change”.‌ ‌A‌ ‌good‌ ‌example‌ ‌to‌ ‌look‌ ‌at‌ ‌\nwhen‌ ‌examining‌ ‌colonialism‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌British‌ ‌overtake‌ ‌of‌ ‌India.‌ ‌The‌ ‌British‌ ‌had‌ ‌little‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌culture‌ ‌in‌ ‌India‌ ‌which‌ ‌created‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nlot‌ ‌of‌ ‌problems‌ ‌an‌ ‌unrest‌ ‌during‌ ‌their‌ ‌rule.‌ ‌\n ‌\nThree‌ ‌Levels‌ ‌of‌ ‌ethnocentrism:‌ ‌Positive,‌ ‌Negative‌ ‌and‌ ‌Extreme‌ ‌Negative‌ ‌\n ‌\n319‌ ‌\n1.Positive‌ ‌ethnocentrism:‌ ‌In‌ ‌which‌ ‌one's‌ ‌own‌ ‌way‌ ‌of‌ ‌life‌ ‌is‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌preferred‌ ‌to‌ ‌all‌ ‌others‌ ‌and‌ ‌if‌ ‌people‌ ‌sense‌ ‌peoplehood,‌ ‌group‌ ‌identity‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nplace‌ ‌in‌ ‌history.‌ ‌\n ‌\n2.Negative‌ ‌ethnocentrism:‌ ‌ ‌It‌ ‌forms‌ ‌when‌ ‌one's‌ ‌own‌ ‌group‌ ‌become‌ ‌the‌ ‌centre‌ ‌of‌ ‌everything‌ ‌and‌ ‌all‌ ‌other‌ ‌rated‌ ‌with‌ ‌reference‌ ‌to‌ ‌it‌ ‌\n ‌\n3.Extreme‌ ‌Negative‌ ‌ethnocentrism:‌  ‌when‌ ‌a‌ ‌more‌ ‌powerful‌ ‌group‌ ‌not‌ ‌only‌ ‌imposes‌ ‌its‌ ‌rule‌ ‌on‌ ‌another‌ ‌group‌ ‌but‌ ‌also‌ ‌actively‌ ‌depreciates‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌things‌ ‌that‌ ‌hold‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌valued.‌ ‌\nAn‌ ‌extreme‌ ‌example‌ ‌would‌ ‌be‌ ‌how‌ ‌Nazi‌ ‌Germans‌ ‌under‌ ‌the‌ ‌leadership‌ ‌of‌ ‌Adolf‌ ‌Hitler‌ ‌were‌ ‌under‌ ‌the‌ ‌impression‌ ‌that‌ ‌Jewish‌ ‌people‌ ‌were‌ ‌\ninferior.‌ ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌Addition‌ ‌\n ‌\nPsychological‌ ‌factors‌ ‌of‌ ‌Ethnocentrism‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nEthnocentrism‌ ‌Stereotype‌ ‌and‌ ‌Prejudice‌ ‌\n320‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nConsumer‌ ‌Ethnocentrism‌ ‌\n●Consumer‌ ‌Ethnocentrism‌ ‌Consumer‌ ‌ethnocentrism‌ ‌focuses‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌responsibility‌ ‌and‌ ‌morality‌ ‌of‌ ‌purchasing‌ ‌foreign-‌ ‌made‌ ‌products‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nloyalty‌ ‌of‌ ‌consumers‌ ‌to‌ ‌products‌ ‌manufactured‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌home‌ ‌country‌ ‌Shimp‌ ‌and‌ ‌Sharma(1987).‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌main‌ ‌reason‌ ‌that‌ ‌might‌ ‌lead‌ ‌ethnocentric‌ ‌consumers‌ ‌to‌ ‌prefer‌ ‌to‌ ‌consume‌ ‌internal‌ ‌products‌ ‌rather‌ ‌than‌ ‌foreign‌ ‌ones‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌desire‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nboost‌ ‌the‌ ‌economy‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌country‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌to‌ ‌promote‌ ‌local‌ ‌producers‌ ‌in‌ ‌that‌ ‌country.‌ ‌\n●Ethnocentrism‌ ‌of‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌consumers‌ ‌is‌ ‌influenced‌ ‌by‌ ‌education,‌ ‌income,‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌openness,‌ ‌and‌ ‌collecti-‌ ‌vism.‌ ‌The‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌between‌ ‌\nethnocentrism‌ ‌and‌ ‌attitudes‌ ‌was‌ ‌moderated‌ ‌by‌ ‌perceived‌ ‌economic‌ ‌threat.(AtmaNirbhar‌ ‌Bharat)‌ ‌\n321‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nCultural‌ ‌Relativism‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Cultural‌ ‌relativism‌ ‌is‌ ‌‌the‌ ‌idea‌ ‌that‌ ‌a‌ ‌person's‌ ‌beliefs,‌ ‌values,‌ ‌and‌ ‌practices‌ ‌should‌ ‌be‌ ‌understood‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌that‌ ‌person's‌ ‌own‌ ‌\nculture,‌ ‌and‌ ‌not‌ ‌be‌ ‌judged‌ ‌against‌ ‌the‌ ‌criteria‌ ‌of‌ ‌another.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌other‌ ‌words,‌ ‌‌“right”‌ ‌and‌ ‌“wrong”‌ ‌are‌ ‌culture-specific‌;‌ ‌In‌ ‌one‌ ‌culture,‌ ‌what‌ ‌is‌ ‌considered‌ ‌good‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌viewed‌ ‌as‌ ‌immoral‌ ‌in‌ ‌another.‌ ‌\nBecause‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌universal‌ ‌definition‌ ‌of‌ ‌morality,‌ ‌no‌ ‌one‌ ‌has‌ ‌the‌ ‌right‌ ‌to‌ ‌judge‌ ‌the‌ ‌practices‌ ‌of‌ ‌another‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\n322‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌relativism‌ ‌as‌ ‌we‌ ‌know‌ ‌and‌ ‌use‌ ‌it‌ ‌today‌ ‌was‌ ‌‌established‌ ‌as‌ ‌an‌ ‌analytic‌ ‌tool‌ ‌by‌ ‌German-American‌ ‌anthropologist‌ ‌\nFranz‌ ‌Boas‌‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌early‌ ‌20th‌ ‌century.‌ ‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌example,‌ ‌what‌ ‌constitutes‌ ‌breakfast‌ ‌varies‌ ‌widely‌ ‌from‌ ‌place‌ ‌to‌ ‌place.‌ ‌What‌ ‌is‌ ‌considered‌ ‌a‌ ‌typical‌ ‌breakfast‌ ‌in‌ ‌Turkey,‌ ‌as‌ ‌illustrated‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌above‌ ‌image,‌ ‌is‌ ‌quite‌ ‌different‌ ‌from‌ ‌what‌ ‌is‌ ‌considered‌ ‌a‌ ‌typical‌ ‌breakfast‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌U.S.‌ ‌or‌ ‌Japan.‌ ‌While‌ ‌it‌ ‌might‌ ‌seem‌ ‌strange‌ ‌to‌ ‌eat‌ ‌fish‌ ‌\nsoup‌ ‌or‌ ‌stewed‌ ‌vegetables‌ ‌for‌ ‌breakfast‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌U.S.,‌ ‌in‌ ‌other‌ ‌places,‌ ‌this‌ ‌is‌ ‌perfectly‌ ‌normal.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Absolute‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌relativism‌‌ ‌is‌ ‌displayed‌ ‌in‌ ‌many‌ ‌cultures,‌ ‌especially‌ ‌Africa,‌ ‌that‌ ‌practice‌ ‌female‌ ‌genital‌ ‌cutting.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌procedure‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌partial‌ ‌or‌ ‌total‌ ‌removal‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌external‌ ‌female‌ ‌genitalia‌ ‌or‌ ‌any‌ ‌other‌ ‌trauma‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌female‌ ‌\nreproductive/genital‌ ‌organs.‌ ‌By‌ ‌allowing‌ ‌this‌ ‌procedure‌ ‌to‌ ‌happen,‌ ‌females‌ ‌are‌ ‌considered‌ ‌women‌ ‌and‌ ‌then‌ ‌are‌ ‌able‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌married.‌ ‌\nFGC‌ ‌is‌ ‌practiced‌ ‌mainly‌ ‌because‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture,‌ ‌religion‌ ‌and‌ ‌tradition.‌ ‌Outside‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌United‌ ‌States‌ ‌look‌ ‌down‌ ‌upon‌ ‌FGC,‌ ‌\nbut‌ ‌are‌ ‌unable‌ ‌to‌ ‌stop‌ ‌this‌ ‌practice‌ ‌from‌ ‌happening‌ ‌because‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌protected‌ ‌by‌ ‌its‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\n●Another‌ ‌Example:‌ ‌For‌ ‌most‌ ‌of‌ ‌us,‌ ‌the‌ ‌killing‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌newborn‌ ‌would‌ ‌be‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌heinous‌ ‌of‌ ‌immoral‌ ‌acts;‌ ‌a‌ ‌perpetrator‌ ‌would‌ ‌need‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nbe‌ ‌purely‌ ‌evil‌ ‌or‌ ‌completely‌ ‌mad.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Inuit‌ ‌Eskimos,‌ ‌however,‌ ‌regularly‌ ‌practiced‌ ‌female‌ ‌infanticide‌ ‌during‌ ‌their‌ ‌prehistory,‌ ‌and‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌neither‌ ‌evil‌ ‌nor‌ ‌insane.‌ ‌Their‌ ‌brutal‌ ‌\nliving‌ ‌conditions‌ ‌required‌ ‌a‌ ‌population‌ ‌imbalance‌ ‌tipped‌ ‌toward‌ ‌hunters‌ ‌(males).‌ ‌Without‌ ‌that‌ ‌gender‌ ‌selecting,‌ ‌the‌ ‌plain‌ ‌fact‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌entire‌ ‌\ngroup‌ ‌faced‌ ‌starvation.‌ ‌\n ‌\nEthnocentrism‌ ‌vs‌ ‌Cultural‌ ‌Relativism‌ ‌\n323‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌Addition‌ ‌\nCultural‌ ‌Relativism‌ ‌and‌ ‌Universal‌ ‌Human‌ ‌Rights‌ ‌\n ‌\n324‌ ‌\n ‌\nUniversal‌ ‌Declaration‌ ‌of‌ ‌Human‌ ‌Rights‌ ‌\n●Everyone‌ ‌is‌ ‌entitled‌ ‌to‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌rights‌ ‌and‌ ‌freedoms‌ ‌set‌ ‌forth‌ ‌in‌ ‌this‌ ‌Declaration,‌ ‌without‌ ‌distinction‌ ‌of‌ ‌any‌ ‌kind,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌race,‌ ‌colour,‌ ‌sex,‌ ‌\nlanguage,‌ ‌religion,‌ ‌political‌ ‌or‌ ‌other‌ ‌opinion,‌ ‌national‌ ‌or‌ ‌social‌ ‌origin,‌ ‌property,‌ ‌birth‌ ‌or‌ ‌other‌ ‌status.‌ ‌\n●No‌ ‌distinction‌ ‌shall‌ ‌be‌ ‌made‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌political,‌ ‌jurisdictional‌ ‌or‌ ‌international‌ ‌status‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌country‌ ‌or‌ ‌territory‌ ‌to‌ ‌which‌ ‌a‌ ‌person‌ ‌\nbelongs,‌ ‌whether‌ ‌it‌ ‌be‌ ‌independent,‌ ‌trust,‌ ‌non-self-governing‌ ‌or‌ ‌under‌ ‌any‌ ‌other‌ ‌limitation‌ ‌of‌ ‌sovereignty.‌ ‌\nEthical‌ ‌Universalism‌ ‌\n●There‌ ‌is‌ ‌some‌ ‌kind‌ ‌of‌ ‌action‌ ‌that’s‌ ‌always‌ ‌right‌ ‌or‌ ‌always‌ ‌wrong.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌relevant‌ ‌kind‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌something‌ ‌very‌ ‌general,‌ ‌e.g.‌ ‌‘doing‌ ‌something‌ ‌that‌ ‌brings‌ ‌about‌ ‌the‌ ‌greatest‌ ‌good‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌greatest‌ ‌number’‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nDebate‌ ‌\n ‌\n325‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nSome‌ ‌related‌ ‌term:‌ ‌\nEnculturation:‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌process‌ ‌by‌ ‌which‌ ‌one‌ ‌learns‌ ‌the‌ ‌way‌ ‌of‌ ‌life‌ ‌and‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌of‌ ‌one's‌ ‌own‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌For‌ ‌example‌ ‌children‌ ‌learning‌ ‌from‌ ‌\nparents‌ ‌about‌ ‌family‌ ‌custom.‌ ‌\nAcculturation:‌ ‌\n326‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌changes‌ ‌that‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌in‌ ‌one‌ ‌culture‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌continuous‌ ‌contact‌ ‌with‌ ‌another‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌For‌ ‌example:‌ ‌The‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌fast‌ ‌food‌ ‌gradually‌ ‌\nadopted‌ ‌from‌ ‌Britishers.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n2.2‌‌ ‌‌The‌ ‌Nature‌ ‌of‌ ‌Society‌ ‌:‌ ‌Concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌Society;‌ ‌Society‌ ‌and‌ ‌Culture;‌ ‌Social‌ ‌Institution;‌ ‌Social‌ ‌groups;-Part-I‌ ‌\n ‌\nConcept‌ ‌of‌ ‌Society‌ ‌\nIntroduction‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌common‌ ‌parlance‌ ‌the‌ ‌word‌ ‌society‌ ‌is‌ ‌usually‌ ‌‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌designate‌ ‌the‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌specific‌ ‌in-group‌ ‌persons‌ ‌rather‌ ‌than‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌\nrelationships‌ ‌of‌ ‌those‌ ‌persons‌.‌ ‌\n●Sometimes‌ ‌the‌ ‌word‌ ‌society‌ ‌is‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌designate‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌like‌ ‌Arya‌ ‌Samaj‌ ‌Society‌ ‌and‌ ‌Culture‌ ‌(society)‌ ‌or‌ ‌Brahmo‌ ‌Samaj.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Society‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌word‌ ‌used‌ ‌in‌ ‌routine‌ ‌life‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌meaning.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Everyone‌ ‌often‌ ‌defines‌ ‌society‌ ‌as‌ ‌an‌ ‌aggregation‌ ‌or‌ ‌collection‌ ‌of‌ ‌individuals.‌ ‌But‌ ‌in‌ ‌sociology‌ ‌and‌ ‌anthropology,‌ ‌the‌ ‌term‌ ‌is‌ ‌used‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌\ndifferent‌ ‌sense.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌term‌ ‌“society”‌ ‌refers‌ ‌not‌ ‌just‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌people‌ ‌but‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌complex‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌of‌ ‌norms‌ ‌of‌ ‌interaction‌ ‌that‌ ‌exist‌ ‌among‌ ‌them.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌common‌ ‌sense,‌ ‌society‌ ‌is‌ ‌understood‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌tangible‌ ‌object,‌ ‌whereas‌ ‌in‌ ‌sociology‌ ‌and‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌it‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌an‌ ‌intangible‌ ‌entity.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌mental‌ ‌construct,‌ ‌which‌ ‌we‌ ‌realise‌ ‌in‌ ‌everyday‌ ‌life‌ ‌but‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌see‌ ‌it.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌important‌ ‌aspect‌ ‌of‌ ‌society‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌relationships,‌ ‌the‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌norms‌ ‌of‌ ‌interaction‌ ‌by‌ ‌which‌ ‌the‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌society‌ ‌\nmaintain‌ ‌themselves.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Some‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌say‌ ‌that‌ ‌society‌ ‌exists‌ ‌only‌ ‌when‌ ‌the‌ ‌members‌ ‌know‌ ‌each‌ ‌other‌ ‌and‌ ‌possess‌ ‌common‌ ‌interests‌ ‌or‌ ‌objects.‌ ‌\n ‌\nMeaning‌ ‌and‌ ‌Definition‌ ‌of‌ ‌Society‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌sociologists,‌ ‌‌a‌ ‌Society‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌people‌ ‌with‌ ‌common‌ ‌territory,‌ ‌interaction,‌ ‌and‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\n●Society‌ ‌is‌ ‌both‌ ‌a‌ ‌‌structural‌ ‌and‌ ‌functional‌ ‌organisation‌.‌ ‌It‌ ‌consists‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌mutual‌ ‌interaction‌ ‌and‌ ‌mutual‌ ‌interrelation‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual‌ ‌but‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌\nalso‌ ‌a‌ ‌structure‌ ‌formed‌ ‌by‌ ‌these‌ ‌relations.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌pattern,‌ ‌a‌ ‌system‌ ‌and‌ ‌not‌ ‌the‌ ‌people.‌ ‌\n●From‌ ‌a‌ ‌functional‌ ‌point‌ ‌of‌ ‌view,‌ ‌society‌ ‌is‌ ‌defined‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌complex‌ ‌of‌ ‌groups‌ ‌in‌ ‌reciprocal‌ ‌relationship,‌ ‌interacting‌ ‌upon‌ ‌one‌ ‌another,‌ ‌enabling‌ ‌\nhuman‌ ‌organisation‌ ‌to‌ ‌carry‌ ‌on‌ ‌their‌ ‌life‌ ‌activities‌ ‌and‌ ‌helping‌ ‌each‌ ‌person‌ ‌to‌ ‌fulfill‌ ‌his‌ ‌wishes‌ ‌and‌ ‌accomplish‌ ‌his‌ ‌interest‌ ‌in‌ ‌Association‌ ‌with‌ ‌\nhis‌ ‌fellows.‌ ‌\n●From‌ ‌the‌ ‌structural‌ ‌point‌ ‌of‌ ‌view,‌ ‌society‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌total‌ ‌social‌ ‌heritage‌ ‌of‌ ‌folkways‌ ‌and‌ ‌Institutions‌ ‌of‌ ‌habit‌ ‌sentiments‌ ‌ideals.‌ ‌\n●Ginsberg,‌ ‌Giddings,‌ ‌Cole‌ ‌‌and‌ ‌Cuber‌ ‌‌take‌ ‌a‌ ‌structural‌ ‌view‌ ‌of‌ ‌society‌ ‌while‌ ‌‌McIver,‌ ‌Parsons,‌ ‌Lapiere,‌ ‌Cooley‌ ‌‌and‌ ‌Leacock‌ ‌‌have‌ ‌given‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nfunctional‌ ‌definition‌ ‌of‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n ‌\n327‌ ‌\nDefinition‌ ‌of‌ ‌society‌ ‌by‌ ‌thinkers:‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌‌MacIver‌‌ ‌“society‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌web‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌relationships”‌ ‌\n●Auguste‌ ‌Comte‌‌ ‌the‌ ‌father‌ ‌of‌ ‌sociology‌ ‌society‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌social‌ ‌organism‌ ‌possessing‌ ‌a‌ ‌harmony‌ ‌of‌ ‌structure‌ ‌and‌ ‌functions.‌ ‌\n●Emile‌ ‌Durkheim‌,‌ ‌the‌ ‌founding‌ ‌father‌ ‌of‌ ‌modern‌ ‌sociology‌ ‌treated‌ ‌society‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌reality‌ ‌in‌ ‌its‌ ‌own‌ ‌right.‌ ‌\n●MacIver‌ ‌and‌ ‌Page‌ ‌‌found‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌usages‌ ‌and‌ ‌procedures‌ ‌of‌ ‌authority‌ ‌and‌ ‌mutual‌ ‌aid‌ ‌of‌ ‌many‌ ‌groupings‌ ‌and‌ ‌divisions,‌ ‌of‌ ‌controls‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌human‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌and‌ ‌liberties;‌ ‌a‌ ‌web‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌relationship.‌ ‌\n●G.H‌ ‌Mead‌‌ ‌conceived‌ ‌society‌ ‌as‌ ‌an‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌of‌ ‌gestures‌ ‌which‌ ‌involves‌ ‌the‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌symbols‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nCharacteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌Society‌ ‌\n ‌\n1.Likeness:‌ ‌\n○Likeness‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌important‌ ‌characteristic‌ ‌of‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Famous‌ ‌sociologist‌‌ ‌Maclver‌ ‌‌opines‌ ‌that‌ ‌society‌ ‌means‌ ‌likeness.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Without‌ ‌a‌ ‌sense‌ ‌of‌ ‌likeness,‌ ‌there‌ ‌could‌ ‌be‌ ‌no‌ ‌mutual‌ ‌recognition‌ ‌of’‌ ‌belonging‌ ‌together’‌ ‌and‌ ‌therefore‌ ‌no‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌sense‌ ‌of‌ ‌likeness‌ ‌was‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌early‌ ‌society‌ ‌on‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌and‌ ‌in‌ ‌modern‌ ‌societies‌ ‌the‌ ‌conditions‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌likeness‌ ‌have‌ ‌\nbroadened‌ ‌out‌ ‌into‌ ‌the‌ ‌principles‌ ‌of‌ ‌nationality.‌ ‌\n○Society‌ ‌consists‌ ‌of‌ ‌like‌ ‌bodied‌ ‌and‌ ‌likeminded‌ ‌individuals.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Friendship‌ ‌intimacy‌ ‌and‌ ‌association‌ ‌of‌ ‌any‌ ‌kind‌ ‌would‌ ‌be‌ ‌impossible‌ ‌without‌ ‌likeness.‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌also‌ ‌helps‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌of‌ ‌one‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌other.‌ ‌ ‌\n○That‌ ‌is‌ ‌why‌ ‌F.H.‌ ‌Giddings‌ ‌opines‌ ‌that‌ ‌society‌ ‌rests‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌‘Consciousness‌ ‌of‌ ‌Kind’.‌ ‌\n ‌\n2.Differences‌ ‌:‌ ‌\n○Along‌ ‌with‌ ‌likeness,‌ ‌differences‌ ‌are‌ ‌another‌ ‌important‌ ‌characteristic‌ ‌of‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Because‌ ‌society‌ ‌involves‌ ‌differences‌ ‌and‌ ‌it‌ ‌depends‌ ‌on‌ ‌it‌ ‌as‌ ‌much‌ ‌as‌ ‌on‌ ‌likeness.‌ ‌ ‌\n○That‌ ‌is‌ ‌why‌ ‌Maclver‌ ‌opines‌ ‌that‌ ‌“primary‌ ‌likeness‌ ‌and‌ ‌secondary‌ ‌differences‌ ‌create‌ ‌the‌ ‌greatest‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌institutions-the‌ ‌division‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nlabour‌”.‌ ‌Because‌ ‌differences‌ ‌are‌ ‌complementary‌ ‌to‌ ‌social‌ ‌relationships.‌ ‌ ‌\n○If‌ ‌people‌ ‌were‌ ‌alike‌ ‌in‌ ‌all‌ ‌respects‌ ‌society‌ ‌could‌ ‌not‌ ‌be‌ ‌formed‌ ‌and‌ ‌‌there‌ ‌would‌ ‌be‌ ‌little‌ ‌reciprocity‌ ‌and‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌became‌ ‌limited.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Family‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌society‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌biological‌ ‌differences‌ ‌and‌ ‌differences‌ ‌in‌ ‌aptitude,‌ ‌interest‌ ‌and‌ ‌capacity.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Though‌ ‌differences‌ ‌are‌ ‌necessary‌ ‌for‌ ‌society‌ ‌but‌ ‌differences‌ ‌by‌ ‌itself‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌create‌ ‌society.‌ ‌Hence‌ ‌differences‌ ‌is‌ ‌subordinate‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nlikeness.‌ ‌\n ‌\n3.Inter-dependence‌ ‌:‌ ‌\n○Interdependence‌ ‌is‌ ‌another‌ ‌important‌ ‌characteristic‌ ‌of‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌fact‌ ‌of‌ ‌interdependence‌ ‌is‌ ‌visible‌ ‌in‌ ‌every‌ ‌aspect‌ ‌of‌ ‌present‌ ‌day‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Famous‌ ‌Greek‌ ‌Philosopher,‌ ‌Aristotle‌ ‌remarked‌ ‌that‌ ‌‘Man‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌social‌ ‌animal’‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n328‌ ‌\n○As‌ ‌a‌ ‌social‌ ‌animal‌ ‌he‌ ‌is‌ ‌dependent‌ ‌on‌ ‌others.‌ ‌The‌ ‌survival‌ ‌and‌ ‌well‌ ‌being‌ ‌of‌ ‌each‌ ‌member‌ ‌is‌ ‌very‌ ‌much‌ ‌dependent‌ ‌on‌ ‌this‌ ‌\ninterdependence.‌ ‌No‌ ‌individual‌ ‌is‌ ‌self‌ ‌sufficient.‌ ‌\n○He‌ ‌has‌ ‌to‌ ‌depend‌ ‌on‌ ‌others‌ ‌for‌ ‌food,‌ ‌shelter‌ ‌and‌ ‌security‌ ‌and‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌fulfillment‌ ‌of‌ ‌many‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌needs‌ ‌and‌ ‌necessities.‌ ‌ ‌\n○With‌ ‌the‌ ‌advancement‌ ‌of‌ ‌society‌ ‌this‌ ‌degree‌ ‌of‌ ‌interdependence‌ ‌increases‌ ‌manifold.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Family‌ ‌being‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌society‌ ‌is‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌biological‌ ‌interdependence‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌sexes.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Not‌ ‌only‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌are‌ ‌interdependent‌ ‌but‌ ‌also‌ ‌the‌ ‌groups,‌ ‌communities‌ ‌and‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌\n ‌\n4.Cooperation‌ ‌and‌ ‌Conflict:‌ ‌\n○Both‌ ‌cooperation‌ ‌and‌ ‌conflict‌ ‌are‌ ‌two‌ ‌other‌ ‌important‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Because‌ ‌famous‌ ‌sociologist‌ ‌Maclver‌ ‌once‌ ‌remarked‌ ‌that‌ ‌“Society‌ ‌is‌ ‌Co­operation‌ ‌crossed‌ ‌by‌ ‌conflict”‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Co-operation‌ ‌is‌ ‌essentially‌ ‌essential‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌formation‌ ‌of‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Without‌ ‌cooperation‌ ‌there‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌no‌ ‌society.‌ ‌People‌ ‌can’t‌ ‌maintain‌ ‌a‌ ‌happy‌ ‌life‌ ‌without‌ ‌co-operation.‌ ‌\n○Family‌ ‌being‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌society‌ ‌rests‌ ‌on‌ ‌co-operation.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Co-operation‌ ‌avoids‌ ‌mutual‌ ‌destructiveness‌ ‌and‌ ‌results‌ ‌in‌ ‌an‌ ‌economy‌ ‌in‌ ‌expenditure.‌ ‌\n○Like‌ ‌cooperation,‌ ‌conflict‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌necessary‌ ‌for‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Conflict‌ ‌acts‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌cementing‌ ‌factor‌ ‌for‌ ‌strengthening‌ ‌social‌ ‌relations.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌a‌ ‌healthy‌ ‌and‌ ‌well‌ ‌developed‌ ‌society‌ ‌both‌ ‌co-operation‌ ‌and‌ ‌conflict‌ ‌co-exist.‌ ‌Because‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌help‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌two‌ ‌universal‌ ‌\nprocesses‌ ‌society‌ ‌is‌ ‌formed.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Conflict‌ ‌makes‌ ‌cooperation‌ ‌meaningful.‌ ‌Conflict‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌direct‌ ‌and‌ ‌indirect.‌ ‌However‌ ‌both‌ ‌are‌ ‌necessary‌ ‌for‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n ‌\n5.Society‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌network‌ ‌or‌ ‌web‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌relationship:‌ ‌\n○Social‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌foundation‌ ‌of‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n○That‌ ‌is‌ ‌why‌ ‌famous‌ ‌sociologist‌ ‌‌Maclver‌ ‌‌remarked‌ ‌that‌ ‌society‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌network‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌relationships.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Hence‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌difficult‌ ‌to‌ ‌classify‌ ‌social‌ ‌relationships.‌ ‌But‌ ‌this‌ ‌social‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌is‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌mutual‌ ‌awareness‌ ‌or‌ ‌recognition‌ ‌to‌ ‌which‌ ‌\nCooley‌ ‌‌calls‌ ‌we-feeling,‌ ‌Giddings‌ ‌call‌ ‌consciousness‌ ‌of‌ ‌kind‌ ‌and‌ ‌Thomas‌ ‌as‌ ‌common‌ ‌propensity.‌ ‌Without‌ ‌these‌ ‌social‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌\nno‌ ‌society‌ ‌could‌ ‌be‌ ‌formed.‌ ‌\n○As‌ ‌social‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌are‌ ‌abstract‌ ‌in‌ ‌nature‌ ‌so‌ ‌also‌ ‌the‌ ‌society‌ ‌is‌ ‌abstract‌ ‌in‌ ‌nature.‌ ‌Different‌ ‌kinds‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌processes‌ ‌like‌ ‌\nco-operation,‌ ‌conflict‌ ‌constantly‌ ‌takes‌ ‌place‌ ‌in‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n○And‌ ‌the‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌established‌ ‌around‌ ‌these‌ ‌create‌ ‌society.‌ ‌Hence‌ ‌a‌ ‌network‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌which‌ ‌created‌ ‌among‌ ‌\nindividuals‌ ‌constitutes‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n ‌\n6.Permanent‌ ‌Nature:‌ ‌\n○Permanency‌ ‌is‌ ‌another‌ ‌important‌ ‌characteristic‌ ‌of‌ ‌society.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌a‌ ‌temporary‌ ‌organisation‌ ‌of‌ ‌individuals.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Society‌ ‌continues‌ ‌to‌ ‌exist‌ ‌even‌ ‌after‌ ‌the‌ ‌death‌ ‌of‌ ‌individual‌ ‌members.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Society‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌coherent‌ ‌organisation.‌ ‌\n ‌\n329‌ ‌\n7.Society‌ ‌is‌ ‌Abstract:‌ ‌\n○Society‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌abstract‌ ‌concept.‌ ‌ ‌\n○As‌ ‌Maclver‌ ‌opines‌ ‌society‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌web‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌relationships.‌ ‌We‌ ‌can’t‌ ‌see‌ ‌this‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌but‌ ‌we‌ ‌can‌ ‌feel‌ ‌it.‌ ‌‌Hence‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌abstract‌ ‌\nconcept.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Wright‌ ‌has‌ ‌rightly‌ ‌remarked‌ ‌that‌ ‌“society‌ ‌in‌ ‌essence‌ ‌means‌ ‌a‌ ‌state‌ ‌or‌ ‌condition,‌ ‌a‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌and‌ ‌is,‌ ‌therefore,‌ ‌necessarily‌ ‌an‌ ‌\nabstraction”.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Besides‌ ‌society‌ ‌consists‌ ‌of‌ ‌customs,‌ ‌traditions,‌ ‌folkways,‌ ‌mores‌ ‌and‌ ‌culture‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌also‌ ‌abstract‌.‌ ‌Hence‌ ‌society‌ ‌is‌ ‌abstract‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nnature.‌ ‌\n ‌\n8.Society‌ ‌is‌ ‌Dynamic‌ ‌:‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌very‌ ‌nature‌ ‌of‌ ‌society‌ ‌is‌ ‌dynamic‌ ‌and‌ ‌changeable.‌ ‌ ‌\n○No‌ ‌society‌ ‌is‌ ‌static.‌ ‌Every‌ ‌society‌ ‌changes‌ ‌and‌ ‌changes‌ ‌continuously.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Old‌ ‌customs,‌ ‌traditions,‌ ‌folkways,‌ ‌mores,‌ ‌values‌ ‌and‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌got‌ ‌changed‌ ‌and‌ ‌new‌ ‌customs‌ ‌and‌ ‌values‌ ‌took‌ ‌place.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Society‌ ‌changes‌ ‌from‌ ‌its‌ ‌traditional‌ ‌nature‌ ‌to‌ ‌modern‌ ‌nature.‌ ‌Hence‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌important‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n ‌\n9.Comprehensive‌ ‌Culture:‌ ‌\n○Culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌another‌ ‌important‌ ‌characteristic‌ ‌of‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Each‌ ‌and‌ ‌every‌ ‌society‌ ‌has‌ ‌it’s‌ ‌own‌ ‌culture‌ ‌which‌ ‌distinguishes‌ ‌it‌ ‌from‌ ‌others.‌ ‌‌Culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌way‌ ‌of‌ ‌life‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌society‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌includes‌ ‌their‌ ‌values,‌ ‌beliefs,‌ ‌art,‌ ‌morals‌ ‌etc‌.‌ ‌\n○Hence‌ ‌culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌comprehensive‌ ‌because‌ ‌it‌ ‌fulfills‌ ‌the‌ ‌necessities‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌life‌ ‌and‌ ‌is‌ ‌culturally‌ ‌self-sufficient.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Besides‌ ‌each‌ ‌and‌ ‌every‌ ‌society‌ ‌transmits‌ ‌its‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌succeeding‌ ‌generations.‌ ‌\n ‌\n10.Something‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌mere‌ ‌collection‌ ‌of‌ ‌individuals:‌ ‌\n○No‌ ‌doubt‌ ‌society‌ ‌consists‌ ‌of‌ ‌individuals.‌ ‌But‌ ‌mere‌ ‌collection‌ ‌of‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌something‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌that‌ ‌and‌ ‌something‌ ‌beyond‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Durkheim‌ ‌‌is‌ ‌right‌ ‌when‌ ‌he‌ ‌remarked‌ ‌that‌ ‌society‌ ‌is‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌the‌ ‌sum‌ ‌of‌ ‌its‌ ‌parts‌ ‌i.e.‌ ‌individuals.‌ ‌\n ‌\n11.Accommodation‌ ‌and‌ ‌Assimilation:‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌two‌ ‌associative‌ ‌social‌ ‌processes‌ ‌are‌ ‌also‌ ‌important‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌smooth‌ ‌functioning‌ ‌and‌ ‌continuity‌ ‌of‌ ‌society.‌ ‌Hence‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌\nanother‌ ‌characteristic‌ ‌of‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n●Example:‌ ‌‌When‌ ‌people‌ ‌arrive‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌India‌ ‌from‌ ‌other‌ ‌countries,‌ ‌they‌ ‌most‌ ‌likely‌ ‌speak‌ ‌a‌ ‌foreign‌ ‌language.‌ ‌As‌ ‌they‌ ‌live‌ ‌here,‌ ‌they‌ ‌\ngenerally‌ ‌learn‌ ‌at‌ ‌least‌ ‌some‌ ‌Hindi,‌ ‌and‌ ‌many‌ ‌become‌ ‌fluent.‌ ‌Their‌ ‌children‌ ‌are‌ ‌most‌ ‌likely‌ ‌bilingual,‌ ‌speaking‌ ‌Hindi‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nlanguage‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌parents.‌ ‌By‌ ‌the‌ ‌third‌ ‌generation,‌ ‌the‌ ‌language‌ ‌originally‌ ‌spoken‌ ‌by‌ ‌their‌ ‌grandparents‌ ‌is‌ ‌often‌ ‌lost.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n7‌ ‌Most‌ ‌Important‌ ‌Elements‌ ‌of‌ ‌Society‌ ‌\n330‌ ‌\nBut‌ ‌besides‌ ‌the‌ ‌above‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌famous‌ ‌sociologists‌ ‌‌Maclver‌ ‌and‌ ‌Page‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌definition‌ ‌mentioned‌ ‌some‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌elements‌ ‌of‌ ‌society‌ ‌which‌ ‌\nare‌ ‌described‌ ‌below:‌ ‌\n1.Usages‌ ‌:‌ ‌\n○Every‌ ‌society‌ ‌has‌ ‌some‌ ‌usages‌ ‌concerned‌ ‌with‌ ‌marriage,‌ ‌religion,‌ ‌education‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌These‌ ‌usages‌ ‌differ‌ ‌from‌ ‌society‌ ‌to‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n ‌\n2.Procedures‌ ‌:‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌every‌ ‌society‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌some‌ ‌procedures‌ ‌like‌ ‌modes‌ ‌of‌ ‌action‌ ‌which‌ ‌help‌ ‌to‌ ‌maintain‌ ‌it’s‌ ‌unity.‌ ‌\n ‌\n3.Authority:‌ ‌\n○Every‌ ‌society‌ ‌has‌ ‌some‌ ‌sort‌ ‌of‌ ‌authority.‌ ‌Every‌ ‌member‌ ‌of‌ ‌society‌ ‌has‌ ‌to‌ ‌obey‌ ‌this‌ ‌authority.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Some‌ ‌sort‌ ‌of‌ ‌authority‌ ‌is‌ ‌necessary‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌maintenance‌ ‌of‌ ‌order‌ ‌in‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n ‌\n4.Mutual‌ ‌Aid‌ ‌:‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌every‌ ‌society‌ ‌there‌ ‌exists‌ ‌a‌ ‌feeling‌ ‌of‌ ‌mutual‌ ‌aid‌ ‌among‌ ‌its‌ ‌members.‌ ‌Everyone‌ ‌needs‌ ‌help‌ ‌from‌ ‌others.‌ ‌\n ‌\n5.Groupings‌ ‌and‌ ‌Divisions‌ ‌:‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌every‌ ‌society‌ ‌there‌ ‌exist‌ ‌several‌ ‌groupings‌ ‌and‌ ‌divisions‌ ‌like‌ ‌family,‌ ‌village,‌ ‌city‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌which‌ ‌constitute‌ ‌a‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n ‌\n6.Controls:‌ ‌\n○Every‌ ‌society‌ ‌exercises‌ ‌some‌ ‌sort‌ ‌of‌ ‌controls‌ ‌over‌ ‌its‌ ‌members.‌ ‌Hence‌ ‌control‌ ‌is‌ ‌necessary‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌smooth‌ ‌organisation‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n ‌\n7.Liberty:‌ ‌\n○Along‌ ‌with‌ ‌control‌ ‌every‌ ‌society‌ ‌gives‌ ‌some‌ ‌liberty‌ ‌to‌ ‌its‌ ‌members‌ ‌some‌ ‌sort‌ ‌of‌ ‌liberty‌ ‌or‌ ‌freedom‌ ‌is‌ ‌necessary‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌organisation‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nsociety.‌ ‌But‌ ‌control‌ ‌and‌ ‌liberty‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌opposite‌ ‌to‌ ‌each‌ ‌other.‌ ‌\n ‌\nThus,‌ ‌Society‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌permanent‌ ‌institution.‌ ‌Its‌ ‌exact‌ ‌origin‌ ‌is‌ ‌unknown‌ ‌to‌ ‌history.‌ ‌It‌ ‌emerged‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌original‌ ‌instincts‌ ‌of‌ ‌man‌ ‌and‌ ‌continues‌ ‌to‌ ‌exist‌ ‌till‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌existence‌ ‌of‌ ‌man.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌a‌ ‌mere‌ ‌structure.‌ ‌It‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌whole‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌relationships.‌ ‌It‌ ‌rests‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌state‌ ‌of‌ ‌mind‌ ‌of‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌who‌ ‌\ncompose‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n ‌\nTheories‌ ‌of‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌of‌ ‌Man‌ ‌and‌ ‌Society‌ ‌\n1.Social‌ ‌Contact‌ ‌Theory‌-Social‌ ‌contract‌ ‌Theory‌ ‌was‌ ‌originated‌ ‌by‌ ‌three‌ ‌eminent‌ ‌philosophers‌ ‌namely,‌ ‌‌Thomas‌ ‌Hobbes‌,‌ ‌‌John‌ ‌Locke‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nJean‌ ‌Jacques‌ ‌Rousseau‌.‌ ‌The‌ ‌exponents‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌theory‌ ‌believed‌ ‌that‌ ‌people‌ ‌lived‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌‘State‌ ‌of‌ ‌Nature’‌ ‌before‌ ‌the‌ ‌society‌ ‌came‌ ‌into‌ ‌\nexistence.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Individuals‌ ‌made‌ ‌Mutual‌ ‌agreements‌ ‌and‌ ‌created‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n○Hobbes‌-Man‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌state‌ ‌of‌ ‌nature‌ ‌was‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌perpetual‌ ‌conflict‌ ‌with‌ ‌his‌ ‌neighbours‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌amount‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌rights‌ ‌like‌ ‌food,‌ ‌shelter,‌ ‌peace‌ ‌\netc.‌ ‌\n331‌ ‌\n○Every‌ ‌man‌ ‌was‌ ‌an‌ ‌enemy‌ ‌to‌ ‌every‌ ‌man.‌ ‌to‌ ‌protect‌ ‌himself‌ ‌against‌ ‌the‌ ‌evil‌ ‌consequences,‌ ‌mein‌ ‌into‌ ‌society‌ ‌in‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌live‌ ‌in‌ ‌peace‌ ‌\nwith‌ ‌all.‌ ‌\n○John‌ ‌Lockke‌-There‌ ‌was‌ ‌no‌ ‌recognised‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌law‌ ‌and‌ ‌Justice‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌state‌ ‌of‌ ‌native‌ ‌where‌ ‌man‌ ‌lifted.‌ ‌ ‌\n○To‌ ‌make‌ ‌good‌ ‌these‌ ‌deficiencies‌ ‌and‌ ‌ensure‌ ‌the‌ ‌exercise‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌Liberty‌ ‌men‌ ‌increased‌ ‌into‌ ‌a‌ ‌contract‌ ‌by‌ ‌which‌ ‌power‌ ‌was‌ ‌conferred‌ ‌\nupon‌ ‌the‌ ‌community.‌ ‌\n2.Organic‌ ‌theory‌-The‌ ‌organic‌ ‌theory‌ ‌was‌ ‌propounded‌ ‌by‌ ‌‌Herbert‌ ‌Spencer,‌ ‌Novico,‌ ‌Spengler,‌ ‌Bluntschli‌ ‌and‌ ‌others‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌nineteenth‌ ‌\ncentury.‌ ‌This‌ ‌theory‌ ‌states‌ ‌that‌ ‌society‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌kind‌ ‌of‌ ‌living‌ ‌organism‌ ‌\n○Society‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌regarded‌ ‌as‌ ‌organism‌ ‌metaphysical.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Plato‌ ‌‌and‌‌ ‌Aristotle‌‌ ‌compared‌ ‌society‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌magnified‌ ‌human‌ ‌being..‌ ‌\n○Spencer‌-‌ ‌society‌ ‌is‌ ‌subjected‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌laws‌ ‌of‌ ‌growth‌ ‌and‌ ‌decay‌ ‌to‌ ‌which‌ ‌the‌ ‌human‌ ‌body‌ ‌is.‌ ‌it‌ ‌has‌ ‌its‌ ‌youth,‌ ‌its‌ ‌rhyme,‌ ‌old‌ ‌age‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌death.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Like‌ ‌the‌ ‌human‌ ‌organism‌ ‌it‌ ‌has‌ ‌subsidiary‌ ‌facilities‌ ‌and‌ ‌workshops‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌elementary‌ ‌organ‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌wholesaler,‌ ‌retailer‌ ‌Banker‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌Main‌ ‌corresponds‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌vascular‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌organism.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌professional-‌ ‌doctor,‌ ‌lawyer,‌ ‌priest‌ ‌the‌ ‌Thinker‌ ‌perform‌ ‌function‌ ‌of‌ ‌brain‌ ‌and‌ ‌nervous‌ ‌system.‌ ‌\n ‌\nPoint‌ ‌of‌ ‌resemblance‌ ‌between‌ ‌society‌ ‌and‌ ‌individual‌ ‌organism:‌ ‌\n●Starting‌ ‌a‌ ‌small‌ ‌aggregates‌ ‌both‌ ‌through‌ ‌large‌ ‌in‌ ‌size.‌ ‌\n●As‌ ‌they‌ ‌grow‌ ‌Initial‌ ‌relative‌ ‌simplicity‌ ‌is‌ ‌replaced‌ ‌by‌ ‌increasing‌ ‌complexity‌ ‌of‌ ‌structure.‌ ‌\n●Life‌ ‌and‌ ‌normal‌ ‌function‌ ‌of‌ ‌each‌ ‌become‌ ‌dependent‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌life‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌whole.‌ ‌\n ‌\nPoint‌ ‌of‌ ‌differences‌ ‌between‌ ‌society‌ ‌and‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌organism:‌ ‌\n●Society‌ ‌has‌ ‌no‌ ‌specific‌ ‌form‌ ‌comparable‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌body‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual.‌ ‌\n●Unit‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌society‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌fixed‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌respective‌ ‌position‌ ‌like‌ ‌those‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌organism.‌ ‌\n●Society‌ ‌has‌ ‌no‌ ‌common‌ ‌sensory‌ ‌organ‌ ‌or‌ ‌central‌ ‌organ‌ ‌of‌ ‌perception‌ ‌and‌ ‌thought‌ ‌as‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nWhy‌ ‌is‌ ‌man‌ ‌called‌ ‌a‌ ‌social‌ ‌animal‌ ‌?‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Aristotle‌,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Greek‌ ‌philosopher‌ ‌writes‌ ‌“Man‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌social‌ ‌animal.‌ ‌He‌ ‌who‌ ‌lives‌ ‌without‌ ‌society‌ ‌is‌ ‌either‌ ‌a‌ ‌beast‌ ‌or‌ ‌God”.‌ ‌Thus,‌ ‌man‌ ‌is‌ ‌by‌ ‌\nnature‌ ‌a‌ ‌social‌ ‌animal.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌is‌ ‌born‌ ‌in‌ ‌society,‌ ‌lives‌ ‌in‌ ‌society‌ ‌and‌ ‌dies‌ ‌in‌ ‌society.‌ ‌Society‌ ‌is‌ ‌indispensable‌ ‌for‌ ‌man.‌ ‌Man‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌live‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌man,‌ ‌without‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Isolation‌ ‌from‌ ‌society‌ ‌is‌ ‌regarded‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌punishment.‌ ‌Solitary‌ ‌life‌ ‌is‌ ‌unbearable‌ ‌for‌ ‌him.‌ ‌Social‌ ‌life‌ ‌is‌ ‌necessary‌ ‌for‌ ‌man.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌instinct‌ ‌for‌ ‌some‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌life‌ ‌is‌ ‌innate‌ ‌in‌ ‌human‌ ‌beings.‌ ‌Professor‌ ‌Park‌ ‌says,‌ ‌“Man‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌born‌ ‌human‌ ‌but‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌made‌ ‌human”.‌ ‌\nMan‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌called‌ ‌social‌ ‌animal‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌following‌ ‌reasons:‌ ‌\n ‌\n332‌ ‌\n1)‌ ‌Man‌ ‌is‌ ‌social‌ ‌by‌ ‌nature:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Human‌ ‌nature‌ ‌is‌ ‌such‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌but‌ ‌live‌ ‌in‌ ‌society.‌ ‌Man’s‌ ‌nature‌ ‌impels‌ ‌him‌ ‌to‌ ‌live‌ ‌in‌ ‌society.‌ ‌The‌ ‌human‌ ‌child‌ ‌is‌ ‌endowed‌ ‌with‌ ‌some‌ ‌\nlatent‌ ‌capacities.‌ ‌Human‌ ‌qualities‌ ‌like‌ ‌capacity‌ ‌to‌ ‌learn‌ ‌language,‌ ‌enquire‌ ‌and‌ ‌think,‌ ‌play‌ ‌and‌ ‌work‌ ‌,help‌ ‌or‌ ‌harm‌ ‌others,‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌are‌ ‌\ndeveloped‌ ‌in‌ ‌human‌ ‌society‌ ‌only.‌ ‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌capacities‌ ‌grow‌ ‌through‌ ‌social‌ ‌interaction‌ ‌with‌ ‌others.‌ ‌One‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌develop‌ ‌into‌ ‌a‌ ‌normal‌ ‌person‌ ‌in‌ ‌isolation.‌ ‌There‌ ‌are‌ ‌eminent‌ ‌\nsociologists‌ ‌like‌ ‌Maciver‌ ‌and‌ ‌others‌ ‌who‌ ‌have‌ ‌cited‌ ‌a‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌cases.‌ ‌Studies.‌ ‌These‌ ‌case‌ ‌studies‌ ‌show‌ ‌the‌ ‌fact‌ ‌that‌ ‌man‌ ‌develops‌ ‌\nhuman‌ ‌qualities‌ ‌only‌ ‌in‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n ‌\n(i)‌ ‌The‌ ‌case‌ ‌of‌ ‌Kasper‌ ‌Houser:‌ ‌\n ‌\nKasper‌ ‌Hauser,‌ ‌a‌ ‌young‌ ‌German‌ ‌boy,‌ ‌was‌ ‌isolated‌ ‌from‌ ‌all‌ ‌kinds‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌contact‌ ‌when‌ ‌he‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌small‌ ‌child.‌ ‌He‌ ‌lived‌ ‌in‌ ‌isolation‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌forest‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nNuremberg‌ ‌till‌ ‌he‌ ‌reached‌ ‌the‌ ‌age‌ ‌of‌ ‌seventeen.‌ ‌He‌ ‌was‌ ‌brought‌ ‌out‌ ‌form‌ ‌the‌ ‌forest‌ ‌in‌ ‌1928‌ ‌and‌ ‌was‌ ‌taken‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌city‌ ‌of‌ ‌Nuremberg.‌ ‌It‌ ‌was‌ ‌found‌ ‌\nthat‌ ‌he‌ ‌could‌ ‌neither‌ ‌walk‌ ‌nor‌ ‌talk‌ ‌properly.‌ ‌He‌ ‌simply‌ ‌muttered‌ ‌a‌ ‌few-meaningless‌ ‌phrase.‌ ‌He‌ ‌could‌ ‌not‌ ‌distinguish‌ ‌between‌ ‌inanimate‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nanimate‌ ‌objects‌ ‌after‌ ‌his‌ ‌death,‌ ‌the‌ ‌post-mortem.‌ ‌Report‌ ‌revealed‌ ‌that‌ ‌his‌ ‌mental‌ ‌development‌ ‌was‌ ‌not‌ ‌normal‌ ‌In‌ ‌spite‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌subsequent‌ ‌\neducation‌ ‌be‌ ‌could‌ ‌never‌ ‌become‌ ‌a‌ ‌normal‌ ‌man.‌ ‌\n ‌\nii)‌ ‌The‌ ‌case‌ ‌of‌ ‌Amala‌ ‌and‌ ‌Kamala‌ ‌\n ‌\nTwo‌ ‌Hindu‌ ‌children‌ ‌Amala‌ ‌and‌ ‌Kamala‌ ‌were‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌Wolf‌ ‌den‌ ‌in‌ ‌1928.‌ ‌By‌ ‌then‌ ‌Amala‌ ‌was‌ ‌two‌ ‌years‌ ‌old‌ ‌and‌ ‌Kamala‌ ‌was‌ ‌nearly‌ ‌eight‌ ‌at‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌time,‌ ‌when‌ ‌they‌ ‌were‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌den.‌ ‌Amala‌ ‌died‌ ‌soon‌ ‌after‌ ‌discovery.‌ ‌Kamala‌ ‌continued‌ ‌to‌ ‌live‌ ‌until‌ ‌1929.‌ ‌It‌ ‌was‌ ‌found‌ ‌that‌ ‌she‌ ‌\nbehaved‌ ‌like‌ ‌a‌ ‌beast‌ ‌and‌ ‌walked‌ ‌like‌ ‌a‌ ‌four-footed‌ ‌animal.‌ ‌She‌ ‌could‌ ‌not‌ ‌speak‌ ‌and‌ ‌growled‌ ‌like‌ ‌a‌ ‌wolf.‌ ‌She‌ ‌was‌ ‌shy‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌contact.‌ ‌It‌ ‌was‌ ‌\nonly‌ ‌after‌ ‌careful‌ ‌and‌ ‌sympathetic‌ ‌training‌ ‌that‌ ‌she‌ ‌could‌ ‌learn‌ ‌some‌ ‌social‌ ‌habits‌ ‌like‌ ‌simple‌ ‌speech,‌ ‌eating,‌ ‌dressing‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌like.‌ ‌\n ‌\niii)‌ ‌The‌ ‌case‌ ‌of‌ ‌Anna.‌ ‌\n ‌\nThe‌ ‌case‌ ‌of‌ ‌Anna,‌ ‌an‌ ‌elegant‌ ‌American‌ ‌child,‌ ‌was‌ ‌studied‌ ‌by‌ ‌some‌ ‌sociologists‌ ‌and‌ ‌psychologists.‌ ‌Anna‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌age‌ ‌of‌ ‌six‌ ‌months‌ ‌was‌ ‌placed‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nroom‌ ‌in‌ ‌complete‌ ‌isolation‌ ‌for‌ ‌nearly‌ ‌five‌ ‌years.‌ ‌She‌ ‌was‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌in‌ ‌1938.‌ ‌On‌ ‌the‌ ‌discovery,‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌found‌ ‌that‌ ‌she‌ ‌could‌ ‌not‌ ‌walk‌ ‌or‌ ‌speak‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nwas‌ ‌indifferent‌ ‌to‌ ‌people‌ ‌around‌ ‌her.‌ ‌She‌ ‌was‌ ‌given‌ ‌careful‌ ‌training‌ ‌after‌ ‌which‌ ‌she‌ ‌rapidly‌ ‌developed‌ ‌human‌ ‌qualities.‌ ‌She‌ ‌died‌ ‌in‌ ‌1942.‌ ‌The‌ ‌\ncase‌ ‌of‌ ‌Anna‌ ‌proves‌ ‌that‌ ‌human‌ ‌nature‌ ‌develops‌ ‌only‌ ‌when‌ ‌he‌ ‌is‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌many‌ ‌people‌ ‌sharing‌ ‌a‌ ‌common‌ ‌life.‌ ‌\n ‌\nThese‌ ‌cases‌ ‌prove‌ ‌that‌ ‌human‌ ‌being‌ ‌is‌ ‌social‌ ‌by‌ ‌nature.‌ ‌Human‌ ‌nature‌ ‌develops‌ ‌in‌ ‌man‌ ‌only‌ ‌when‌ ‌he‌ ‌lives‌ ‌in‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n ‌\n2)‌ ‌Development‌ ‌of‌ ‌self.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌human‌ ‌infant,‌ ‌at‌ ‌his‌ ‌birth,‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌fully‌ ‌aware‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌own‌ ‌“self’.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌develops‌ ‌the‌ ‌idea‌ ‌of‌ ‌self‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌interaction‌ ‌with‌ ‌others.‌ ‌Charles‌ ‌H.Cooley‌ ‌says‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌very‌ ‌idea‌ ‌of‌ ‌“self’‌ ‌or‌ ‌“I”‌ ‌can‌ ‌arise‌ ‌only‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nrelationship‌ ‌with‌ ‌other‌ ‌people.‌ ‌ ‌\n●G.H.Mead‌ ‌says‌ ‌that‌ ‌at‌ ‌first‌ ‌the‌ ‌child‌ ‌performs‌ ‌the‌ ‌role‌ ‌of‌ ‌others‌ ‌with‌ ‌his‌ ‌parents‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌persons‌ ‌at‌ ‌home.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Then,‌ ‌gradually‌ ‌he‌ ‌takes‌ ‌the‌ ‌role‌ ‌of‌ ‌other‌ ‌persons‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌playmates,‌ ‌friends‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌In‌ ‌this‌ ‌way‌ ‌self‌ ‌develops.‌ ‌\n ‌\n333‌ ‌\n3)‌ ‌Social‌ ‌heritage‌ ‌determines‌ ‌Human‌ ‌personality‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Man‌ ‌is‌ ‌social‌ ‌because‌ ‌he‌ ‌depends‌ ‌on‌ ‌social‌ ‌heritage‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌mixture‌ ‌of‌ ‌customs‌ ‌beliefs‌ ‌and‌ ‌ideals‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Society‌ ‌preserves‌ ‌social‌ ‌heritage‌ ‌and‌ ‌transmits‌ ‌it‌ ‌from‌ ‌one‌ ‌generation‌ ‌to‌ ‌another.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Social‌ ‌heritage‌ ‌molds‌ ‌man’s‌ ‌attitudes,‌ ‌beliefs,‌ ‌morals‌ ‌and‌ ‌ideals.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌said‌ ‌that‌ ‌“Man‌ ‌only‌ ‌becomes‌ ‌man‌ ‌among‌ ‌Men”.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Man‌ ‌is‌ ‌born‌ ‌with‌ ‌some‌ ‌inborn‌ ‌potentialities.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌heritage,‌ ‌which‌ ‌determines‌ ‌the‌ ‌manner‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌his‌ ‌innate‌ ‌potentialities‌ ‌express‌ ‌\nthemselves‌ ‌in‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Emotional‌ ‌development,‌ ‌intellectual‌ ‌maturity‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌possible‌ ‌without‌ ‌society.‌ ‌Therefore,‌ ‌society‌ ‌determines‌ ‌our‌ ‌mental‌ ‌equipment.‌ ‌It‌ ‌\nshapes‌ ‌our‌ ‌identity,‌ ‌our‌ ‌thoughts‌ ‌and‌ ‌our‌ ‌emotions.‌ ‌\n ‌\n4)‌ ‌Necessity‌ ‌makes‌ ‌a‌ ‌man‌ ‌social.‌ ‌\n●Necessity‌ ‌compels‌ ‌man‌ ‌to‌ ‌live‌ ‌in‌ ‌society.‌ ‌Man‌ ‌has‌ ‌a‌ ‌variety‌ ‌of‌ ‌needs.‌ ‌If‌ ‌he‌ ‌leads‌ ‌a‌ ‌cooperative‌ ‌life‌ ‌with‌ ‌his‌ ‌fellow‌ ‌beings‌ ‌in‌ ‌society‌ ‌he‌ ‌can‌ ‌\neasily‌ ‌get‌ ‌his‌ ‌needs‌ ‌fulfilled.‌ ‌Many‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌needs‌ ‌will‌ ‌remain‌ ‌unsatisfied‌ ‌if‌ ‌he‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌lead‌ ‌a‌ ‌cooperative‌ ‌life‌ ‌with‌ ‌his‌ ‌fellow‌ ‌beings.‌ ‌The‌ ‌\nhuman‌ ‌child‌ ‌is‌ ‌born‌ ‌helpless.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Without‌ ‌proper‌ ‌care‌ ‌he‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌develop‌ ‌himself.‌ ‌During‌ ‌infancy‌ ‌he‌ ‌must‌ ‌be‌ ‌provided‌ ‌with‌ ‌nutrition,‌ ‌shelter‌ ‌and‌ ‌affection.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌society,‌ ‌which‌ ‌\nextends‌ ‌protection,‌ ‌attention‌ ‌and‌ ‌opportunities‌ ‌necessary‌ ‌for‌ ‌his‌ ‌survival‌ ‌and‌ ‌growth.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nSociety‌ ‌and‌ ‌Culture‌ ‌\n●Culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌sum‌ ‌total‌ ‌of‌ ‌learned,‌ ‌shared‌ ‌and‌ ‌socially‌ ‌transmitted‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌that‌ ‌includes‌ ‌ideas,‌ ‌values,‌ ‌and‌ ‌customs‌ ‌of‌ ‌groups‌ ‌of‌ ‌people.‌ ‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌fairly‌ ‌large‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌people‌ ‌living‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌territory‌ ‌constitute‌ ‌a‌ ‌society.‌ ‌Members‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌society‌ ‌share‌ ‌a‌ ‌common‌ ‌language,‌ ‌which‌ ‌\nfacilitates‌ ‌day-to-day‌ ‌exchanges‌ ‌with‌ ‌others‌ ‌and‌ ‌participate‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌common‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\n●Nadel‌ ‌in‌ ‌his‌ ‌work‌ ‌says‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌necessary‌ ‌to‌ ‌make‌ ‌a‌ ‌distinction‌ ‌between‌ ‌“Culture”‌ ‌from‌ ‌its‌ ‌companion‌ ‌term‌ ‌“society‌.”‌ ‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌him‌ ‌culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌way‌ ‌of‌ ‌life‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌people;‌ ‌while‌ ‌a‌ ‌society‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌organised,‌ ‌interacting‌ ‌aggregate‌ ‌of‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌who‌ ‌follow‌ ‌a‌ ‌\ngiven‌ ‌way‌ ‌of‌ ‌life.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌simple‌ ‌terms‌ ‌a‌ ‌society‌ ‌is‌ ‌composed‌ ‌of‌ ‌people;‌ ‌the‌ ‌way‌ ‌they‌ ‌behave‌ ‌is‌ ‌their‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\n●Early‌ ‌notion‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌was‌ ‌popularised‌ ‌among‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌in‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌understand‌ ‌homogeneous‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌the‌ ‌modern‌ ‌world‌ ‌the‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌between‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌society‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌complex‌ ‌one.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌produced‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌given‌ ‌society‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌framework‌ ‌set‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌socio-economic‌ ‌structure.‌ ‌The‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌process‌ ‌perpetually‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌\namong‌ ‌the‌ ‌different‌ ‌groups‌ ‌and‌ ‌classes‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌society,‌ ‌and‌ ‌also‌ ‌affects‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure.‌ ‌\n●Culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌society‌ ‌are‌ ‌intricately‌ ‌related.‌ ‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌culture‌ ‌consists‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌“objects”‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌society,‌ ‌whereas‌ ‌a‌ ‌society‌ ‌consists‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌people‌ ‌who‌ ‌share‌ ‌a‌ ‌common‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌ ‌\n●When‌ ‌the‌ ‌terms‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌society‌ ‌first‌ ‌acquired‌ ‌their‌ ‌current‌ ‌meanings,‌ ‌most‌ ‌people‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌world‌ ‌worked‌ ‌and‌ ‌lived‌ ‌in‌ ‌small‌ ‌groups‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nsame‌ ‌locale.‌ ‌ ‌\n334‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌today's‌ ‌world‌ ‌of‌ ‌6‌ ‌billion‌ ‌people,‌ ‌these‌ ‌terms‌ ‌have‌ ‌lost‌ ‌some‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌usefulness‌ ‌because‌ ‌increasing‌ ‌numbers‌ ‌of‌ ‌people‌ ‌interact‌ ‌and‌ ‌share‌ ‌\nresources‌ ‌globally.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Still,‌ ‌people‌ ‌tend‌ ‌to‌ ‌use‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌society‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌more‌ ‌traditional‌ ‌sense:‌ ‌For‌ ‌example,‌ ‌being‌ ‌a‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌“racial‌ ‌culture”‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌larger‌ ‌“U.S.‌ ‌\nsociety.”‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●One‌ ‌way‌ ‌to‌ ‌think‌ ‌about‌ ‌the‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌between‌ ‌society‌ ‌and‌ ‌culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌to‌ ‌consider‌ ‌the‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌phone.‌ ‌The‌ ‌phone‌ ‌\nitself‌ ‌is‌ ‌like‌ ‌society,‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌apps‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌phone‌ ‌are‌ ‌like‌ ‌culture:‌ ‌\n ‌\n○Society‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌=‌ ‌the‌ ‌physical‌ ‌phone/protective‌ ‌phone‌ ‌case‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌phone‌ ‌has‌ ‌a‌ ‌tangible‌ ‌structure,‌ ‌just‌ ‌as‌ ‌society‌ ‌has‌ ‌specific‌ ‌structures‌ ‌and‌ ‌institutions.‌ ‌Social‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌are‌ ‌like‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌hardware‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌phone.‌ ‌\n○Culture‌ ‌=‌ ‌software/apps‌ ‌\n○Apps‌ ‌and‌ ‌software‌ ‌are‌ ‌instructions‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌phone‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌intangible,‌ ‌just‌ ‌as‌ ‌intangible‌ ‌culture‌ ‌provides‌ ‌the‌ ‌rules‌ ‌and‌ ‌\ninput‌ ‌that‌ ‌make‌ ‌society‌ ‌function.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌software‌ ‌and‌ ‌apps‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌phone‌ ‌could‌ ‌be‌ ‌compared‌ ‌to‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌These‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌pieces‌ ‌that‌ ‌give‌ ‌the‌ ‌phone‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nrecognizable‌ ‌“personality”,‌ ‌just‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌culture‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌describes‌ ‌its‌ ‌beliefs,‌ ‌practices,‌ ‌and‌ ‌guidelines‌ ‌for‌ ‌living.‌ ‌And‌ ‌\njust‌ ‌as‌ ‌phone‌ ‌apps‌ ‌go‌ ‌through‌ ‌updates‌ ‌or‌ ‌changes,‌ ‌culture‌ ‌can‌ ‌also‌ ‌evolve‌ ‌over‌ ‌time.‌ ‌\n ‌\nSocial‌ ‌Institutions‌ ‌\n ‌\nIntroduction‌ ‌\n335‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌social‌ ‌institution‌ ‌consists‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌people‌ ‌who‌ ‌have‌ ‌come‌ ‌together‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌common‌ ‌purpose.‌ ‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌are‌ ‌a‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌order‌ ‌of‌ ‌society,‌ ‌and‌ ‌they‌ ‌govern‌ ‌the‌ ‌behavior‌ ‌and‌ ‌expectations‌ ‌of‌ ‌individuals.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nDefinition‌ ‌by‌ ‌thinkers‌ ‌and‌ ‌scholars‌ ‌\n●Brown‌ ‌has‌ ‌defined‌ ‌the‌ ‌institution‌ ‌as,‌ ‌“an‌ ‌established‌ ‌or‌ ‌socially‌ ‌recognised‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌norms‌ ‌or‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌of‌ ‌conduct‌ ‌referring‌ ‌to‌ ‌some‌ ‌\naspect‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌life.”‌ ‌An‌ ‌example‌ ‌of‌ ‌institution‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌which‌ ‌sets‌ ‌the‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌of‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌members‌ ‌in‌ ‌relation‌ ‌to‌ ‌one‌ ‌\nanother.‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌‌Sumner‌ ‌and‌ ‌Keller‌‌ ‌institution‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌vital‌ ‌interest‌ ‌or‌ ‌activity‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌surrounded‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌cluster‌ ‌of‌ ‌mores‌ ‌and‌ ‌folkways.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Sumner‌ ‌conceived‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌institution‌ ‌not‌ ‌only‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌concept,‌ ‌idea‌ ‌or‌ ‌interest‌ ‌but‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌institution‌ ‌as‌ ‌well.‌ ‌By‌ ‌structure‌ ‌he‌ ‌meant‌ ‌\nan‌ ‌apparatus‌ ‌or‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌functionaries.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Lester‌ ‌F‌ ‌Ward‌‌ ‌regarded‌ ‌an‌ ‌institution‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌means‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌control‌ ‌and‌ ‌utilization‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌energy.‌ ‌\n●L.T‌ ‌Hobhouse‌‌ ‌described‌ ‌the‌ ‌institution‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌whole‌ ‌or‌ ‌any‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌established‌ ‌and‌ ‌recognized‌ ‌apparatus‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌life.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Robert‌ ‌Maclver‌‌ ‌regarded‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌as‌ ‌established‌ ‌forms‌ ‌or‌ ‌conditions‌ ‌of‌ ‌procedure‌ ‌characteristic‌ ‌of‌ ‌group‌ ‌activity.‌ ‌\n●One‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌inclusive‌ ‌and‌ ‌descriptive‌ ‌definitions‌ ‌is‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌Joyce‌ ‌O.‌ ‌Hertzler‌ ‌(Social‌ ‌Institutions,‌ ‌1946),‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌as‌ ‌follows:‌ ‌\n“Social‌ ‌institution‌ ‌are‌ ‌purposive,‌ ‌regulatory,‌ ‌and‌ ‌consequently‌ ‌primary‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌configura­tions,‌ ‌formed‌ ‌unconsciously‌ ‌and/or‌ ‌\ndeliberately,‌ ‌to‌ ‌satisfy‌ ‌individual‌ ‌wants‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌needs‌ ‌bound‌ ‌up‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌efficient‌ ‌operation‌ ‌of‌ ‌any‌ ‌plurality‌ ‌of‌ ‌persons.‌ ‌They‌ ‌consist‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌codes,‌ ‌rules‌ ‌and‌ ‌ideologies‌ ‌….‌ ‌and‌ ‌essential‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌organisational‌ ‌and‌ ‌material‌ ‌implementa­tions.”‌ ‌In‌ ‌this‌ ‌definition,‌ ‌Hertzler‌ ‌has‌ ‌\nexplained‌ ‌the‌ ‌purpose,‌ ‌function,‌ ‌mechanism‌ ‌and‌ ‌structure—all‌ ‌the‌ ‌four‌ ‌important‌ ‌elements‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌institution.‌ ‌\n ‌\nNeed‌ ‌of‌ ‌Institution‌ ‌\n●Sociologists‌ ‌agree‌ ‌that‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌arise‌ ‌and‌ ‌persist‌ ‌because‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌definite‌ ‌felt‌ ‌need‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n●While‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌essential‌ ‌agreement‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌general‌ ‌origin‌ ‌of‌ ‌institutions,‌ ‌sociologists‌ ‌have‌ ‌differed‌ ‌about‌ ‌the‌ ‌specific‌ ‌motivating‌ ‌\nfactors.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Sumner‌ ‌and‌ ‌Keller‌‌ ‌maintained‌ ‌that‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌come‌ ‌into‌ ‌existence‌ ‌to‌ ‌satisfy‌ ‌vital‌ ‌interests‌ ‌of‌ ‌man.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Ward‌‌ ‌believed‌ ‌that‌ ‌they‌ ‌arise‌ ‌because‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌demand‌ ‌or‌ ‌social‌ ‌necessity.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Lewis‌ ‌H‌ ‌Morgan‌‌ ‌ascribed‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌every‌ ‌institution‌ ‌to‌ ‌what‌ ‌he‌ ‌called‌ ‌a‌ ‌perpetual‌ ‌want.‌ ‌\n ‌\nCharacteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌Institution:‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌cluster‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌usage:‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌system‌ ‌exists‌ ‌and‌ ‌all‌ ‌follow‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌practices‌ ‌and‌ ‌traditions.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●The‌ ‌relative‌ ‌degree‌ ‌of‌ ‌permanence:‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌beliefs‌ ‌are‌ ‌laid‌ ‌out‌ ‌and‌ ‌tried‌ ‌and‌ ‌tested‌ ‌over‌ ‌time.‌ ‌If‌ ‌they‌ ‌sustain‌ ‌then‌ ‌they‌ ‌become‌ ‌the‌ ‌fundamental‌ ‌beliefs‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌institution‌ ‌and‌ ‌\ngain‌ ‌permanent‌ ‌recognition.‌ ‌\n ‌\n336‌ ‌\n●Well-known‌ ‌defined‌ ‌Objectives:‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌Objectives‌ ‌resonate‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌norms.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌kept‌ ‌in‌ ‌mind‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌people‌ ‌are‌ ‌made‌ ‌to‌ ‌understand‌ ‌the‌ ‌difference‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nObjectives‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌functions.‌ ‌\n ‌\nTypes‌ ‌of‌ ‌Institutions‌ ‌\nAccording‌ ‌to‌ ‌‌W.G.‌ ‌Sumner‌‌ ‌(Folkways,‌ ‌1906),‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌are‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌types:‌ ‌\n ‌ ‌\n(1)‌ ‌Crescive:‌ ‌\n●Institutions‌ ‌that‌ ‌take‌ ‌shape‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌mores‌ ‌are‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌crescive‌ ‌institutions.‌ ‌Property,‌ ‌marriage,‌ ‌religion‌ ‌are‌ ‌all‌ ‌crescive‌ ‌institutions.‌ ‌\n ‌\n(2)‌ ‌Enacted:‌ ‌\n●Institutions‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌productions‌ ‌of‌ ‌rational‌ ‌invention‌ ‌and‌ ‌intention‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌schools,‌ ‌colleges,‌ ‌corpora­tions,‌ ‌banks‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n ‌\nE.W.‌ ‌Burgess‌ ‌has‌ ‌offered‌ ‌four-fold‌ ‌classification:‌ ‌\n●Cultural‌ ‌institutions‌‌ ‌for‌ ‌transmitting‌ ‌social‌ ‌heritage‌ ‌like‌ ‌family,‌ ‌school,‌ ‌church‌ ‌(religious‌ ‌institutions).‌ ‌\n●Economic‌ ‌institutions‌‌ ‌for‌ ‌organising‌ ‌services‌ ‌of‌ ‌utility‌ ‌like‌ ‌bank,‌ ‌labour‌ ‌union,‌ ‌commercial‌ ‌and‌ ‌industrial‌ ‌enterprises.‌ ‌\n●Recreational‌ ‌institutions‌‌ ‌for‌ ‌satisfying‌ ‌human‌ ‌desire‌ ‌of‌ ‌enter­tainment,‌ ‌amusement‌ ‌and‌ ‌play‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n●Social‌ ‌control‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌‌for‌ ‌solving‌ ‌social‌ ‌problems‌ ‌of‌ ‌society‌ ‌and‌ ‌personal.‌ ‌\n ‌\nPrimary‌ ‌Institutions‌ ‌&‌ ‌Secondary‌ ‌Institution‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Sociologists‌ ‌often‌ ‌reserve‌ ‌the‌ ‌term‌ ‌\"institution\"‌ ‌to‌ ‌describe‌ ‌normative‌ ‌systems‌ ‌that‌ ‌operate‌ ‌in‌ ‌five‌ ‌basic‌ ‌areas‌ ‌of‌ ‌life,‌ ‌which‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌\ndesignated‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌primary‌ ‌institutions.‌ ‌\n(1)‌ ‌In‌ ‌determining‌ ‌Kinship;‌ ‌\n(2)‌ ‌in‌ ‌providing‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌legitimate‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌power;‌ ‌\n(3)‌ ‌in‌ ‌regulating‌ ‌the‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌of‌ ‌goods‌ ‌and‌ ‌services;‌ ‌\n(4)‌ ‌in‌ ‌transmitting‌ ‌knowledge‌ ‌from‌ ‌one‌ ‌generation‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌next;‌ ‌and‌ ‌\n(5)‌ ‌in‌ ‌regulating‌ ‌our‌ ‌relation‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌supernatural.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌shorthand‌ ‌form,‌ ‌or‌ ‌as‌ ‌concepts,‌ ‌these‌ ‌five‌ ‌basic‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌are‌ ‌called‌ ‌the‌ ‌family,‌ ‌government,‌ ‌economy,‌ ‌education‌ ‌and‌ ‌religion.‌ ‌\n337‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●The‌ ‌five‌ ‌primary‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌are‌ ‌found‌ ‌among‌ ‌all‌ ‌human‌ ‌groups.‌ ‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌always‌ ‌as‌ ‌highly‌ ‌elaborated‌ ‌or‌ ‌as‌ ‌distinct‌ ‌from‌ ‌one‌ ‌another‌ ‌but‌ ‌in‌ ‌rudimentary‌ ‌form‌ ‌at‌ ‌last,‌ ‌they‌ ‌exist‌ ‌everywhere.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Their‌ ‌universality‌ ‌indicates‌ ‌that‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌deeply‌ ‌rooted‌ ‌in‌ ‌human‌ ‌nature‌ ‌and‌ ‌that‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌essential‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌development‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nmaintenance‌ ‌of‌ ‌orders.‌ ‌\n ‌\n338‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n339‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n340‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nImportance‌ ‌of‌ ‌Institution‌ ‌\n ‌\n1.Any‌ ‌human‌ ‌society‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌world,‌ ‌weather‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌or‌ ‌modern‌ ‌is‌ ‌characterized‌ ‌by‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌The‌ ‌‌Survival‌ ‌of‌ ‌society‌ ‌depends‌ ‌largely‌ ‌on‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌working‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture.Therefore,‌ ‌social‌ ‌Institutions‌ ‌the‌ ‌media‌ ‌through‌ ‌which‌ ‌the‌ ‌culture‌ ‌works‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌working‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌proper‌ ‌\nmanner‌ ‌is‌ ‌ensured‌ ‌by‌ ‌them.‌ ‌\n2.The‌ ‌medium‌ ‌in‌ ‌any‌ ‌society‌ ‌the‌ ‌moral,‌ ‌ideal‌ ‌knowledge‌ ‌and‌ ‌mode‌ ‌of‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌are‌ ‌transferred‌ ‌from‌ ‌one‌ ‌generation‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌other.‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nyounger‌ ‌generation‌ ‌turn‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌institution‌ ‌for‌ ‌answer‌ ‌to‌ ‌various‌ ‌problem‌ ‌they‌ ‌confront‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌lives.‌ ‌\n3.It‌ ‌entrains‌ ‌Unity‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌as‌ ‌it‌ ‌indicates‌ ‌the‌ ‌right‌ ‌path‌ ‌of‌ ‌every‌ ‌individual‌ ‌has‌ ‌to‌ ‌follow‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n4.Impose‌ ‌social‌ ‌control‌ ‌or‌ ‌human‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌and‌ ‌compel‌ ‌its‌ ‌people‌ ‌to‌ ‌work‌ ‌collectively‌ ‌in‌ ‌conformity‌ ‌with‌ ‌social‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nSocial‌ ‌Group‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌social‌ ‌group‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌collectivity‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌or‌ ‌more‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌who‌ ‌are‌ ‌in‌ ‌state‌ ‌of‌ ‌interaction‌ ‌with‌ ‌one‌ ‌another.‌ ‌ ‌\n●State‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌interaction‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌reciprocal‌ ‌influence‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌wert‌ ‌on‌ ‌one‌ ‌another‌ ‌through‌ ‌inter-stimulation‌ ‌and‌ ‌response.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌state‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌interaction‌ ‌or‌ ‌inter-influence‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌compulsory‌ ‌characteristic‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌social‌ ‌group.‌ ‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌boys‌ ‌discussing‌ ‌the‌ ‌last‌ ‌watched‌ ‌movie‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌social‌ ‌group‌ ‌because‌ ‌through‌ ‌their‌ ‌verbal‌ ‌interaction,‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌influencing‌ ‌\none‌ ‌another.‌ ‌\n●Examples:‌ ‌A‌ ‌family‌ ‌living‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌home‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌employees‌ ‌working‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌same‌ ‌organization,‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌classmates,‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌members‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌a‌ ‌meeting‌ ‌and‌ ‌so‌ ‌on.‌ ‌\nDefinitions:‌ ‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌social‌ ‌group‌ ‌is‌ ‌defined‌ ‌as‌ ‌When‌ ‌two‌ ‌or‌ ‌more‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌come‌ ‌together‌ ‌and‌ ‌influence‌ ‌one‌ ‌another,‌ ‌they‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌called‌ ‌a‌ ‌social‌ ‌\ngroup'-‌ ‌‌William‌ ‌Ogburn‌ ‌\n●Social‌ ‌group‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌or‌ ‌more‌ ‌persons‌ ‌who‌ ‌are‌ ‌in‌ ‌state‌ ‌of‌ ‌interaction‌ ‌with‌ ‌one‌ ‌another.‌ ‌-‌ ‌‌Mayer‌ ‌Nimkoff‌ ‌\n ‌\nTypes‌ ‌of‌ ‌Social‌ ‌Group:‌ ‌\nON‌ ‌THE‌ ‌BASIS‌ ‌OF‌ ‌CONTACT‌ ‌\nOn‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌contact‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌members,‌ ‌social‌ ‌groups‌ ‌are‌ ‌divided‌ ‌into‌ ‌two‌ ‌types:‌ ‌Primary‌ ‌and‌ ‌Secondary‌ ‌Group.‌ ‌\n1.Primary‌ ‌Group‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌Primary‌ ‌Group‌ ‌is‌ ‌given‌ ‌by‌ ‌‌C.H‌ ‌Cooley‌.‌ ‌Primary‌ ‌groups‌ ‌have‌ ‌following‌ ‌characteristics:‌ ‌\n■There‌ ‌is‌ ‌face-to-face‌ ‌interaction‌ ‌among‌ ‌its‌ ‌members.‌ ‌ ‌\n■There‌ ‌are‌ ‌frequent‌ ‌interactions‌ ‌among‌ ‌its‌ ‌members.‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌relations‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌members‌ ‌are‌ ‌too‌ ‌personal,‌ ‌intimate‌ ‌and‌ ‌intense.‌ ‌ ‌\n■There‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌sense‌ ‌of‌ ‌'we-feeling'‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌members.‌ ‌ ‌\n341‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌members‌ ‌possess‌ ‌similar‌ ‌background‌ ‌attributes‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌language,‌ ‌interests,‌ ‌culture,‌ ‌\n■religion‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌ ‌\n■There‌ ‌is‌ ‌physical‌ ‌proximity‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌members.‌ ‌ ‌\n■These‌ ‌groups‌ ‌are‌ ‌smaller‌ ‌in‌ ‌size.‌ ‌\n○Examples:‌‌ ‌Family,‌ ‌Neighborhood,‌ ‌Local‌ ‌brotherhood,‌ ‌Close‌ ‌friends‌ ‌and‌ ‌peers.‌ ‌\n○Primary‌ ‌groups‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌great‌ ‌importance.‌ ‌For‌ ‌instance,‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌provides‌ ‌food,‌ ‌shelter‌ ‌and‌ ‌care‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌kid.‌ ‌An‌ ‌individual‌ ‌learns‌ ‌his‌ ‌\nculture‌ ‌and‌ ‌develops‌ ‌a‌ ‌healthy‌ ‌personality‌ ‌within‌ ‌his‌ ‌primary‌ ‌groups‌ ‌to‌ ‌become‌ ‌a‌ ‌productive‌ ‌citizen‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n ‌\n2.Secondary‌ ‌Group‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌Secondary‌ ‌Group‌ ‌is‌ ‌given‌ ‌by‌ ‌‌Maclver‌.‌ ‌Secondary‌ ‌groups‌ ‌have‌ ‌following‌ ‌characteristics:‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌group‌ ‌is‌ ‌formed‌ ‌by‌ ‌relations‌ ‌secondary‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌primary‌ ‌group.‌ ‌\n○There‌ ‌is‌ ‌comparatively‌ ‌less‌ ‌face-to-face‌ ‌interaction.‌ ‌\n○There‌ ‌is‌ ‌comparatively‌ ‌less‌ ‌frequent‌ ‌interaction.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌relations‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌members‌ ‌are‌ ‌impersonal‌ ‌and‌ ‌secondary.‌ ‌ ‌\n○These‌ ‌relations‌ ‌are‌ ‌relatively‌ ‌less‌ ‌personal,‌ ‌less‌ ‌intimate‌ ‌and‌ ‌less‌ ‌intense.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌members‌ ‌have‌ ‌specific‌ ‌aims‌ ‌or‌ ‌interests‌ ‌to‌ ‌achieve.‌ ‌\n○There‌ ‌is‌ ‌less‌ ‌physical‌ ‌proximity‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌members.‌ ‌\n○These‌ ‌groups‌ ‌are‌ ‌larger‌ ‌in‌ ‌size.‌ ‌\n●Examples:‌ ‌A‌ ‌shopkeeper-customer‌ ‌relation,‌ ‌A‌ ‌doctor-patient‌ ‌relation,‌ ‌An‌ ‌advocate‌ ‌client‌ ‌relation,‌ ‌A‌ ‌teacher-student‌ ‌relation,‌ ‌A‌ ‌\ncandidate-voter‌ ‌relation.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nON‌ ‌THE‌ ‌BASIS‌ ‌OF‌ ‌IDENTIFICATION‌ ‌\nW.G‌ ‌Sumner‌ ‌‌has‌ ‌divided‌ ‌social‌ ‌groups‌ ‌into‌ ‌two‌ ‌types:‌ ‌In-group‌ ‌and‌ ‌Out-group.‌ ‌\n1.In-group‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌group,‌ ‌to‌ ‌which‌ ‌we‌ ‌directly‌ ‌belong,‌ ‌is‌ ‌called‌ ‌our‌ ‌in-group.‌ ‌It‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌our‌ ‌own‌ ‌family,‌ ‌tribe,‌ ‌sex,‌ ‌occupation,‌ ‌games‌ ‌or‌ ‌interest‌ ‌group.‌ ‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌example‌,‌ ‌ ‌\n■if‌ ‌I‌ ‌am‌ ‌a‌ ‌player‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌basketball‌ ‌team,‌ ‌my‌ ‌basketball-team‌ ‌is‌ ‌in-group‌ ‌for‌ ‌me.‌ ‌ ‌\n■A‌ ‌religious‌ ‌group‌ ‌is‌ ‌in-group‌ ‌for‌ ‌its‌ ‌followers.‌ ‌ ‌\n■A‌ ‌geographical‌ ‌community‌ ‌is‌ ‌in-group‌ ‌for‌ ‌its‌ ‌residents.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌term‌ ‌'in-group'‌ ‌is‌ ‌used‌ ‌when‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌wants‌ ‌to‌ ‌identify‌ ‌himself‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌or‌ ‌show‌ ‌an‌ ‌association‌ ‌with‌ ‌his‌ ‌group,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌\nby‌ ‌saying:‌ ‌We‌ ‌are‌ ‌Americans.‌ ‌We‌ ‌are‌ ‌English.‌ ‌We‌ ‌are‌ ‌Christians.‌ ‌We‌ ‌are‌ ‌Muslims.‌ ‌We‌ ‌are‌ ‌students.‌ ‌We‌ ‌are‌ ‌doctors.‌ ‌We‌ ‌are‌ ‌\nmusicians.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌in-group‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌sense‌ ‌of‌ ‌'we-feelings'‌ ‌and‌ ‌belongingness‌ ‌towards‌ ‌their‌ ‌ingroup.‌ ‌\n2.Out-group‌ ‌\n342‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌group,‌ ‌to‌ ‌which‌ ‌we‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌belong,‌ ‌is‌ ‌called‌ ‌an‌ ‌out-group.‌ ‌It‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌any‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌others‌ ‌(not‌ ‌ours)‌ ‌including‌ ‌a‌ ‌family,‌ ‌tribe,‌ ‌ethnicity,‌ ‌\nsex,‌ ‌occupations‌ ‌or‌ ‌interest‌ ‌groups.‌ ‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌example,‌ ‌ ‌\n■if‌ ‌I‌ ‌am‌ ‌a‌ ‌student‌ ‌of‌ ‌Mathematics,‌ ‌the‌ ‌students‌ ‌of‌ ‌mathematics‌ ‌are‌ ‌in-group‌ ‌for‌ ‌me,‌ ‌but‌ ‌the‌ ‌students‌ ‌of‌ ‌any‌ ‌other‌ ‌discipline‌ ‌\n(other‌ ‌than‌ ‌psychology)‌ ‌are‌ ‌an‌ ‌out-group‌ ‌for‌ ‌me.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌term‌ ‌'out-group‌ ‌is‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌distinguish‌ ‌one's‌ ‌identity‌ ‌from‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌others‌ ‌or‌ ‌to‌ ‌compare‌ ‌one's‌ ‌identity‌ ‌to‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌other,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌by‌ ‌\nsaying:‌ ‌We‌ ‌are‌ ‌Americans‌ ‌(in-group)‌ ‌and‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌Indians‌ ‌(out-group).‌ ‌We‌ ‌are‌ ‌Muslims‌ ‌(in-group)‌ ‌and‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌Christians‌ ‌\n(out-group).‌ ‌We‌ ‌are‌ ‌doctors‌ ‌(in-group)‌ ‌and‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌engineers‌ ‌(out-group).‌ ‌\n○There‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌sense‌ ‌of‌ ‌'they-feeling'‌ ‌while‌ ‌referring‌ ‌to‌ ‌an‌ ‌out-group.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nON‌ ‌THE‌ ‌BASIS‌ ‌OF‌ ‌RULES‌ ‌AND‌ ‌REGULATIONS‌ ‌\nThere‌ ‌are‌ ‌two‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌groups‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌rules‌ ‌and‌ ‌regulations:‌ ‌Formal‌ ‌and‌ ‌Informal‌ ‌Group‌ ‌\n1.Formal‌ ‌Group‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌that‌ ‌has‌ ‌well-defined‌ ‌rules‌ ‌and‌ ‌regulations‌ ‌for‌ ‌joining‌ ‌the‌ ‌group,‌ ‌staying‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌group‌ ‌and‌ ‌leaving‌ ‌the‌ ‌group.‌ ‌\n●Those,‌ ‌who‌ ‌fulfill‌ ‌these‌ ‌rules‌ ‌and‌ ‌regulations,‌ ‌can‌ ‌join‌ ‌and‌ ‌engage‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌activities‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌group.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌membership‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌canceled‌ ‌if‌ ‌the‌ ‌member‌ ‌violates‌ ‌the‌ ‌rules.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌‌examples‌‌ ‌include‌ ‌organizations,‌ ‌banks,‌ ‌hospitals,‌ ‌educational‌ ‌institutions,‌ ‌official‌ ‌associations‌ ‌and‌ ‌firms‌ ‌and‌ ‌so‌ ‌on.‌ ‌\n2.Informal‌ ‌Group‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌which‌ ‌has‌ ‌prescribed‌ ‌rules‌ ‌and‌ ‌regulation‌ ‌for‌ ‌joining‌ ‌the‌ ‌group,‌ ‌staying‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌group‌ ‌and‌ ‌leaving‌ ‌the‌ ‌group.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Any‌ ‌person‌ ‌can‌ ‌join‌ ‌the‌ ‌group,‌ ‌participate‌ ‌in‌ ‌it‌ ‌and‌ ‌leave‌ ‌it‌ ‌whenever‌ ‌he‌ ‌wants.‌ ‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌example‌,‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌students‌ ‌sitting‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌playground‌ ‌and‌ ‌gossiping‌ ‌with‌ ‌one‌ ‌another.‌ ‌Any‌ ‌other‌ ‌classmate‌ ‌can‌ ‌come‌ ‌and‌ ‌join‌ ‌it.‌ ‌\nOther‌ ‌examples‌ ‌include:‌ ‌People‌ ‌gathered‌ ‌to‌ ‌see‌ ‌a‌ ‌Joker‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌public‌ ‌place,‌ ‌informal‌ ‌clubs‌ ‌and‌ ‌associations.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nON‌ ‌THE‌ ‌BASIS‌ ‌OF‌ ‌STRUCTURE‌ ‌\nSanderson‌ ‌‌has‌ ‌divided‌ ‌social‌ ‌groups‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌structure‌ ‌into‌ ‌three‌ ‌types:‌ ‌Voluntary,‌ ‌Involuntary‌ ‌and‌ ‌Delegate‌ ‌group‌ ‌\n1.Involuntary‌ ‌Group‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌that‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌join‌ ‌or‌ ‌leave‌ ‌by‌ ‌his‌ ‌or‌ ‌her‌ ‌own‌ ‌choice.‌ ‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌example,‌ ‌a‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌involuntary‌ ‌group‌ ‌because‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌has‌ ‌no‌ ‌control‌ ‌over‌ ‌his‌ ‌birth‌ ‌-‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌born‌ ‌or‌ ‌not‌ ‌born‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌specific‌ ‌\nfamily.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Similarly,‌ ‌the‌ ‌sex-group‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌involuntary‌ ‌group‌ ‌to‌ ‌which‌ ‌we‌ ‌are‌ ‌born‌ ‌without‌ ‌our‌ ‌choice‌ ‌and‌ ‌we‌ ‌have‌ ‌no‌ ‌control‌ ‌on‌ ‌changing‌ ‌our‌ ‌\nsex-group‌ ‌(e.g.‌ ‌from‌ ‌male‌ ‌to‌ ‌female‌ ‌or‌ ‌vice‌ ‌versa).‌ ‌Age-group‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌an‌ ‌involuntary‌ ‌group.‌ ‌We‌ ‌belong‌ ‌to‌ ‌our‌ ‌age‌ ‌group‌ ‌which‌ ‌\nchanges‌ ‌with‌ ‌growth‌ ‌but‌ ‌we‌ ‌have‌ ‌no‌ ‌control‌ ‌on‌ ‌changing‌ ‌our‌ ‌age‌ ‌group.‌ ‌\n2.Voluntary‌ ‌Group‌ ‌\n343‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌that‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌can‌ ‌join‌ ‌or‌ ‌leave‌ ‌by‌ ‌his‌ ‌or‌ ‌her‌ ‌own‌ ‌choice.‌ ‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌example‌,‌ ‌you‌ ‌can‌ ‌join‌ ‌people‌ ‌watching‌ ‌a‌ ‌game‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌playground,‌ ‌you‌ ‌can‌ ‌become‌ ‌a‌ ‌student‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌college,‌ ‌you‌ ‌can‌ ‌join‌ ‌an‌ ‌\norganization‌ ‌and‌ ‌so‌ ‌on.‌ ‌\n●Sometimes,‌ ‌you‌ ‌are‌ ‌required‌ ‌to‌ ‌fulfill‌ ‌criteria‌ ‌to‌ ‌join‌ ‌a‌ ‌voluntary‌ ‌group‌ ‌but‌ ‌still,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌in‌ ‌your‌ ‌control‌ ‌to‌ ‌fulfill‌ ‌the‌ ‌criteria‌ ‌and‌ ‌join‌ ‌it.‌ ‌\n3.Delegate‌ ‌Group‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌that‌ ‌serves‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌representative‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌larger‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌people.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌members‌ ‌are‌ ‌either‌ ‌elected‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌people‌ ‌or‌ ‌nominated‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌certain‌ ‌criteria.‌ ‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌parliament‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌delegate‌ ‌group‌ ‌as‌ ‌it‌ ‌represents‌ ‌wishes‌ ‌and‌ ‌needs‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌public.‌ ‌\n●Similarly,‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌experts,‌ ‌sent‌ ‌to‌ ‌another‌ ‌country‌ ‌to‌ ‌discuss‌ ‌an‌ ‌issue‌ ‌on‌ ‌behalf‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌country,‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌delegate‌ ‌group.‌ ‌\n ‌\nON‌ ‌THE‌ ‌BASIS‌ ‌OF‌ ‌RELATIONS‌ ‌TO‌ ‌SOCIETY‌ ‌\nGeorge‌ ‌Hassen‌ ‌‌has‌ ‌divided‌ ‌social‌ ‌groups‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌its‌ ‌relation‌ ‌to‌ ‌society‌ ‌into‌ ‌following‌ ‌four‌ ‌types:‌ ‌\n1.Un-social‌ ‌Group‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌that‌ ‌remains‌ ‌detached‌ ‌within‌ ‌a‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌participate‌ ‌in‌ ‌society‌ ‌and‌ ‌remain‌ ‌alone.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌examples‌ ‌are‌ ‌introverts,‌ ‌people‌ ‌with‌ ‌adjustment‌ ‌problems‌ ‌or‌ ‌psychological‌ ‌anomalies,‌ ‌drug‌ ‌addicts,‌ ‌criminals,‌ ‌thieves,‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nmurders.‌ ‌\n2.Anti-social‌ ‌Groups‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌that‌ ‌acts‌ ‌against‌ ‌the‌ ‌interest‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌destroy‌ ‌public‌ ‌property‌ ‌and‌ ‌peace.‌ ‌They‌ ‌intend‌ ‌to‌ ‌spread‌ ‌fear‌ ‌and‌ ‌aggression‌ ‌to‌ ‌pursue‌ ‌their‌ ‌aims.‌ ‌Examples‌ ‌include‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nterrorist‌ ‌groups,‌ ‌criminals,‌ ‌thieves,‌ ‌and‌ ‌murderers.‌ ‌Similarly,‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌laborers‌ ‌on‌ ‌strike‌ ‌against‌ ‌the‌ ‌administration‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌factory,‌ ‌\nstudents‌ ‌demonstrating‌ ‌protest,‌ ‌people‌ ‌gathered‌ ‌to‌ ‌demonstrate‌ ‌against‌ ‌the‌ ‌government‌ ‌may‌ ‌also‌ ‌sometimes‌ ‌become‌ ‌violent‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nanti-social‌ ‌groups.‌ ‌\n3.Pro-Social‌ ‌Group‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌that‌ ‌works‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌betterment‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌society.‌ ‌They‌ ‌engage‌ ‌in‌ ‌activities‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌development,‌ ‌prosperity,‌ ‌welfare,‌ ‌and‌ ‌peace‌ ‌\nin‌ ‌the‌ ‌society.‌ ‌All‌ ‌the‌ ‌governmental‌ ‌and‌ ‌nongovernmental‌ ‌welfare‌ ‌organizations‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌examples‌ ‌of‌ ‌pro-social‌ ‌groups‌ ‌who‌ ‌work‌ ‌\npromoting‌ ‌education,‌ ‌reducing‌ ‌poverty,‌ ‌providing‌ ‌health‌ ‌care,‌ ‌treating‌ ‌drug‌ ‌addicts,‌ ‌helping‌ ‌the‌ ‌underprivileged‌ ‌people‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nrehabilitating‌ ‌the‌ ‌grieved‌ ‌ones‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n4.Pseudo-Social‌ ‌Group‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌that‌ ‌participates‌ ‌in‌ ‌society‌ ‌only‌ ‌for‌ ‌their‌ ‌own‌ ‌interest‌ ‌and‌ ‌gains.‌ ‌They‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌care‌ ‌about‌ ‌the‌ ‌interest‌ ‌of‌ ‌others‌ ‌or‌ ‌\nbetterment‌ ‌of‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌are‌ ‌concerned‌ ‌only‌ ‌about‌ ‌their‌ ‌own‌ ‌gains‌ ‌and‌ ‌benefits.‌ ‌They‌ ‌behave‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌predatory‌ ‌or‌ ‌parasitic‌ ‌way‌ ‌in‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌Addition‌ ‌\n ‌\nExplain‌ ‌Social‌ ‌structure,‌ ‌its‌ ‌features‌ ‌and‌ ‌constituents‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌Radcliffe‌ ‌Brown‌ ‌\n344‌ ‌\n ‌\nSocial‌ ‌structure‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌his‌ ‌book‌ ‌Novum‌ ‌organon‌ ‌renovatum,‌ ‌Whewell,‌ ‌has‌ ‌rightly‌ ‌said,‌ ‌“The‌ ‌fundamental‌ ‌principle‌ ‌and‌ ‌supreme‌ ‌rule‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌scientific‌ ‌terminology‌ ‌\nis‌ ‌that‌ ‌terms‌ ‌must‌ ‌be‌ ‌constructed‌ ‌and‌ ‌appropriated‌ ‌so‌ ‌as‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌fitted‌ ‌to‌ ‌enunciate‌ ‌simply‌ ‌and‌ ‌clearly‌ ‌true‌ ‌general‌ ‌proposition.”‌ ‌ ‌\n●Agreeing‌ ‌with‌ ‌this‌ ‌principle‌ ‌Radcliffe‌ ‌Brown,‌ ‌in‌ ‌his‌ ‌Book,‌ ‌Method‌ ‌in‌ ‌Social‌ ‌Anthropology,‌ ‌starts‌ ‌with‌ ‌giving‌ ‌clear‌ ‌definitions‌ ‌of‌ ‌various‌ ‌\nmethods‌ ‌and‌ ‌concepts‌ ‌in‌ ‌social‌ ‌anthropology.‌ ‌\n●As‌ ‌he‌ ‌he‌ ‌says,‌ ‌clarifying‌ ‌the‌ ‌necessity‌ ‌of‌ ‌conceptual‌ ‌clarification,‌ ‌“One‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌difficulties‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌reader‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌literature‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌has‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌face‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌fact‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌word‌ ‌is‌ ‌used‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌meanings‌ ‌by‌ ‌different‌ ‌writers,‌ ‌and‌ ‌many‌ ‌anthropological‌ ‌terms‌ ‌are‌ ‌sometimes‌ ‌used‌ ‌\nambiguously‌ ‌or‌ ‌without‌ ‌precise‌ ‌definition.”‌ ‌Therefore,‌ ‌while‌ ‌defining‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure,‌ ‌Brown‌ ‌has‌ ‌taken‌ ‌special‌ ‌organization‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌related‌ ‌\nconcepts.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌‌Social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌organization‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Before‌ ‌defining‌ ‌the‌ ‌elements‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure,‌ ‌Brown‌ ‌has‌ ‌clarified‌ ‌the‌ ‌distinction‌ ‌between‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌organization.‌ ‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌him,‌ ‌‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌an‌ ‌arrangement‌ ‌of‌ ‌person‌s.‌ ‌ ‌\n●On‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌hand,‌ ‌“Social‌ ‌organization‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌arrangement‌ ‌of‌ ‌activities‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌or‌ ‌more‌ ‌persons‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌adjusted,‌ ‌to‌ ‌give‌ ‌united‌ ‌combined‌ ‌\nactivity,”‌ ‌Social‌ ‌organization‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌explained‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌example‌ ‌of‌ ‌modern‌ ‌army‌ ‌or‌ ‌tribal‌ ‌group’s‌ ‌industrial‌ ‌groups,‌ ‌sports‌ ‌groups‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n●Social‌ ‌structure,‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌hand,‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌explained‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌example‌ ‌of‌ ‌modern‌ ‌army‌ ‌or‌ ‌tribal‌ ‌groups,‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌distinction‌ ‌between‌ ‌social‌ ‌organization‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌will‌ ‌be‌ ‌further‌ ‌clear‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌definition‌ ‌and‌ ‌explanation‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌term‌ ‌‘Social‌ ‌\nStructure’,‌ ‌which‌ ‌now‌ ‌follows.‌ ‌\n ‌\nMeaning‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌\n ‌\n●In‌ ‌the‌ ‌words‌ ‌of‌ ‌Radcliffe‌ ‌Brown,‌ ‌“‌Social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌therefore‌ ‌is‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌defined‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌continuing‌ ‌arrangement‌ ‌of‌ ‌persons‌ ‌in‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌\ndefined‌ ‌or‌ ‌controlled‌ ‌by‌ ‌institutions,‌ ‌i.e.,‌ ‌socially‌ ‌established‌ ‌norms‌ ‌or‌ ‌patters‌ ‌of‌ ‌behaviour‌.”‌ ‌In‌ ‌this‌ ‌definition‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure,‌ ‌two‌ ‌phrases‌ ‌\nrequire‌ ‌further‌ ‌clarification,‌ ‌the‌ ‌continuing‌ ‌arrangement‌ ‌of‌ ‌persons‌ ‌and‌ ‌socially‌ ‌established‌ ‌norms‌ ‌or‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌of‌ ‌behaviour.‌ ‌\n345‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nWhat‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌three‌ ‌major‌ ‌views‌ ‌of‌ ‌Social‌ ‌Structure?‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌word‌ ‌structure‌ ‌originally‌ ‌means‌ ‌the‌ ‌construction‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌building.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Gradually,‌ ‌structure‌ ‌began‌ ‌to‌ ‌imply‌ ‌inter-relations‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌parts‌ ‌of‌ ‌any‌ ‌whole.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌became‌ ‌popular‌ ‌amongst‌ ‌the‌ ‌sociologists,‌ ‌a‌ ‌few‌ ‌years‌ ‌after‌ ‌World‌ ‌War‌ ‌II.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌this‌ ‌period‌ ‌of‌ ‌time‌ ‌the‌ ‌term‌ ‌Social‌ ‌Structure‌ ‌came‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌applied‌ ‌to‌ ‌‘almost‌ ‌any‌ ‌ordered‌ ‌arrangement‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌phenomenon.’‌ ‌\n ‌\nThere‌ ‌are‌ ‌three‌ ‌major‌ ‌views‌ ‌of‌ ‌Social‌ ‌Structure.‌ ‌\n1.‌ ‌Structural-functionalist‌ ‌view‌ ‌\n ‌ ‌\n2.‌ ‌Structuralist‌ ‌view‌ ‌\n ‌\n3.‌ ‌Marxist‌ ‌view‌ ‌\n ‌\n1.‌ ‌‌Structural-functionalist‌ ‌view:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌founded‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌analogy‌ ‌between‌ ‌a‌ ‌society‌ ‌and‌ ‌an‌ ‌organism,‌ ‌modelled‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌natural‌ ‌science‌ ‌methods‌ ‌of‌ ‌biology.‌ ‌These‌ ‌sociologists‌ ‌\nwere‌ ‌of‌ ‌importance‌ ‌here,‌ ‌like‌ ‌Herbert‌ ‌Spencer,‌ ‌Emile‌ ‌Durkheim,‌ ‌Radcliffe‌ ‌Brown,‌ ‌etc‌ ‌\n●Spencer‌ ‌introduced‌ ‌the‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌in‌ ‌sociology‌.‌ ‌For‌ ‌Spencer,‌ ‌a‌ ‌society‌ ‌is‌ ‌made‌ ‌up‌ ‌of‌ ‌different‌ ‌parts,‌ ‌all‌ ‌of‌ ‌which‌ ‌have‌ ‌to‌ ‌\n346‌ ‌\nwork‌ ‌in‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌remain‌ ‌healthy.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌of‌ ‌some‌ ‌sort‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌is‌ ‌implicit‌ ‌in‌ ‌Durkheim’s‌ ‌writings.‌ ‌One‌ ‌can‌ ‌say‌ ‌that‌ ‌for‌ ‌‌Durkheim‌ ‌to‌ ‌study‌ ‌the‌ ‌collective‌ ‌\nconsciousness‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌society‌ ‌was‌ ‌similar‌ ‌to‌ ‌discussing‌ ‌its‌ ‌social‌
