‌structure.‌ ‌\n●Radcliffe‌ ‌Brown‌ ‌defined‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌far‌ ‌more‌ ‌precisely‌ ‌than‌ ‌Durkheim‌,‌ ‌who‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌source‌ ‌of‌ ‌many‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌major‌ ‌ideas.‌ ‌Radcliffe‌ ‌Brown‌ ‌\ndefined‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌as‌ ‌‘an‌ ‌arrangement‌ ‌of‌ ‌parts‌ ‌or‌ ‌components‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌one‌ ‌another‌ ‌in‌ ‌some‌ ‌sort‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌larger‌ ‌unity’.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌arrangement‌ ‌of‌ ‌persons‌ ‌in‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌institutionally‌ ‌defined‌ ‌and‌ ‌regulated,’‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌king‌ ‌and‌ ‌his‌ ‌\nsubject,‌ ‌between‌ ‌husband‌ ‌and‌ ‌wife,‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌In‌ ‌this‌ ‌way‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌within‌ ‌society‌ ‌are‌ ‌ordered‌ ‌by‌ ‌various‌ ‌mores‌ ‌and‌ ‌norms.‌ ‌\n ‌\n2.‌ ‌Structuralist‌ ‌point‌ ‌of‌ ‌view:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Claude‌ ‌Levi-Strauss‌‌ ‌of‌ ‌France‌ ‌is‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌major‌ ‌structuralists.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Levi‌ ‌Strauss‌ ‌holds‌ ‌that‌ ‌‘social‌ ‌structure’‌ ‌has‌ ‌nothing‌ ‌to‌ ‌do‌ ‌with‌ ‌empirical‌ ‌reality‌ ‌but‌ ‌it‌ ‌should‌ ‌deal‌ ‌with‌ ‌models‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌built‌ ‌after‌ ‌it.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Thus,‌ ‌‌Levi‌ ‌Strauss‌ ‌says‌ ‌that‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌‘can‌ ‌by‌ ‌no‌ ‌means‌ ‌be‌ ‌reduced‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌ensemble‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌relations‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌described‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌given‌ ‌\nsociety.’‌ ‌\n ‌\n3.‌ ‌Marxist‌ ‌point‌ ‌of‌ ‌view:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Marxist‌ ‌theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌is‌ ‌free‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌bias‌ ‌of‌ ‌organic‌ ‌analogy‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌structural‌ ‌functionalists.‌ ‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌Marx,‌ ‌the‌ ‌relations‌ ‌of‌ ‌production‌ ‌constitutes‌ ‌‘the‌ ‌economic‌ ‌structure’,‌ ‌the‌ ‌real‌ ‌basis‌ ‌on‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌created‌ ‌a‌ ‌judicial‌ ‌and‌ ‌political‌ ‌\nsuperstructure‌ ‌and‌ ‌to‌ ‌which‌ ‌correspond‌ ‌the‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌determined‌ ‌social‌ ‌conscience.‌ ‌\n●‘‌ ‌In‌ ‌this‌ ‌explanation‌ ‌Marx‌ ‌has‌ ‌used‌ ‌the‌ ‌term‌ ‌structure,‌ ‌not‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌biological‌ ‌sense,‌ ‌but‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌sense‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌building‌ ‌or‌ ‌construction.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nContinuing‌ ‌arrangement‌ ‌of‌ ‌persons‌ ‌\n ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌Brown‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌‌continuing‌ ‌arrangement‌ ‌of‌ ‌persons‌ ‌in‌ ‌relation‌ ‌to‌ ‌each‌ ‌other‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌arrangement‌ ‌of‌ ‌persons‌ ‌is‌ ‌different‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌village,‌ ‌a‌ ‌city‌ ‌or‌ ‌a‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌tribe.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌arrangement‌ ‌are‌ ‌in‌ ‌fact‌ ‌the‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure.‌ ‌In‌ ‌other‌ ‌words,‌ ‌the‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌\nare‌ ‌the‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌groups‌ ‌which‌ ‌constitute‌ ‌it.‌ ‌\n ‌\nStructural‌ ‌features‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌life‌ ‌\nAccording‌ ‌to‌ ‌Brown,‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌important‌ ‌structural‌ ‌features‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌life‌ ‌are‌ ‌as‌ ‌follows;‌ ‌\n ‌\n1.‌‌ ‌Existence‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌groups‌-‌ ‌Social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌consists‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌kinds‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌groups‌ ‌within‌ ‌it.‌ ‌\n ‌\n2.‌ ‌Internal‌ ‌structure‌ ‌of‌ ‌groups-‌ ‌These‌ ‌groups,‌ ‌again,‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌specific‌ ‌internal‌ ‌structure.‌ ‌For‌ ‌example,‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌group‌ ‌consists‌ ‌of‌ ‌*he‌ ‌relations‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nfather,‌ ‌mother‌ ‌and‌ ‌children‌ ‌to‌ ‌each‌ ‌other.‌ ‌\n ‌\n3.‌ ‌‌Arrangement‌ ‌into‌ ‌social‌ ‌classes-‌ ‌These‌ ‌groups,‌ ‌again,‌ ‌are‌ ‌arranged‌ ‌into‌ ‌social‌ ‌classes‌ ‌and‌ ‌categories‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌castes‌ ‌in‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌society‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌the‌ ‌economic‌ ‌classes‌ ‌in‌ ‌western‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌\n4.‌ ‌Social‌ ‌distinctions‌-‌ ‌There‌ ‌is‌ ‌again‌ ‌a‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌distinctions‌ ‌between‌ ‌different‌ ‌classes‌ ‌based‌ ‌upon‌ ‌sex,‌ ‌authority,‌ ‌economic‌ ‌distinctions,‌ ‌\n347‌ ‌\ncaste‌ ‌distinctions‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌One‌ ‌finds‌ ‌a‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌distance‌ ‌between‌ ‌them‌ ‌as‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌seen‌ ‌between‌ ‌Brahmins‌ ‌and‌ ‌Sudras‌ ‌in‌ ‌India.‌ ‌\n5.‌ ‌Arrangement‌ ‌of‌ ‌persons‌ ‌in‌ ‌dyadic‌ ‌relationship‌-‌ ‌Dyadic‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌are‌ ‌person‌ ‌to‌ ‌person‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌those‌ ‌found‌ ‌between‌ ‌master‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌servant.‌ ‌In‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌one‌ ‌finds‌ ‌arrangement‌ ‌of‌ ‌persons‌ ‌in‌ ‌dyadic‌ ‌relationship.‌ ‌\n6.‌ ‌Interactions‌ ‌between‌ ‌groups‌ ‌and‌ ‌persons‌-‌ ‌Finally,‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌important‌ ‌feature‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌interaction‌ ‌between‌ ‌groups‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌\ninteractions‌ ‌between‌ ‌persons.‌ ‌An‌ ‌example‌ ‌of‌ ‌interactions‌ ‌between‌ ‌groups‌ ‌is‌ ‌seen‌ ‌when‌ ‌one‌ ‌nation‌ ‌goes‌ ‌to‌ ‌war‌ ‌with‌ ‌another.‌ ‌Interactions‌ ‌between‌ ‌\npersons‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌seen‌ ‌in‌ ‌social‌ ‌processes‌ ‌involving‌ ‌cooperation,‌ ‌conflict,‌ ‌accommodation‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n ‌\nConstituents‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌\n ‌\nAs‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌already‌ ‌pointed‌ ‌out,‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌is‌ ‌constituted‌ ‌by‌ ‌continuing‌ ‌arrangement‌ ‌of‌ ‌persons‌ ‌in‌ ‌relationship.‌ ‌These‌ ‌arrangements‌ ‌of‌ ‌\npersons‌ ‌are‌ ‌generally‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌groups.‌ ‌According‌ ‌to‌ ‌Brown,‌ ‌“By‌ ‌social‌ ‌group‌ ‌we‌ ‌mean‌ ‌a‌ ‌body‌ ‌of‌ ‌persons‌ ‌having‌ ‌certain‌ ‌cohesion.”‌ ‌The‌ ‌\nsocial‌ ‌groups‌ ‌are‌ ‌named‌ ‌differently‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌their‌ ‌different‌ ‌forms‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌family,‌ ‌a‌ ‌horde,‌ ‌a‌ ‌clan,‌ ‌a‌ ‌kinship,‌ ‌a‌ ‌tribe‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌Radecliffe‌ ‌Brown‌ ‌has‌ ‌\ndefined‌ ‌each‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌groups‌ ‌clearly.‌ ‌\n ‌\n1.‌ ‌The‌ ‌Family‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌Brown,‌ ‌“The‌ ‌family‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌was‌ ‌formed‌ ‌by‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌birth‌ ‌of‌ ‌children‌ ‌and‌ ‌came‌ ‌to‌ ‌an‌ ‌end‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌separate‌ ‌group‌ ‌on‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌death‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌husband,‌ ‌thus‌ ‌having‌ ‌continuous‌ ‌existence‌ ‌for‌ ‌only‌ ‌a‌ ‌limited‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌years.”‌ ‌Thus,‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌composed‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌man‌ ‌with‌ ‌his‌ ‌\nwife‌ ‌or‌ ‌wives‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌young‌ ‌children.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌domestic‌ ‌group.‌ ‌It‌ ‌has‌ ‌its‌ ‌own‌ ‌hearth,‌ ‌shelter‌ ‌and‌ ‌food‌ ‌supply.‌ ‌Several‌ ‌families‌ ‌constitute‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nhorde.‌ ‌\n ‌\n2.‌ ‌The‌ ‌Horde‌ ‌\n●Thus‌ ‌the‌ ‌internal‌ ‌structure‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌horde‌ ‌consists‌ ‌of‌ ‌family.‌ ‌According‌ ‌to‌ ‌Radcliffe‌ ‌Brown,‌ ‌“A‌ ‌horde‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌described‌ ‌as‌ ‌being‌ ‌politically‌ ‌\nautonomous,‌ ‌under‌ ‌the‌ ‌authority‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌old‌ ‌men,‌ ‌and‌ ‌as‌ ‌being‌ ‌very‌ ‌largely‌ ‌self-sufficient‌ ‌economically.”‌ ‌The‌ ‌hordes‌ ‌constitute‌ ‌a‌ ‌clan.‌ ‌They‌ ‌\noccupy‌ ‌the‌ ‌territory‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌clan.‌ ‌ ‌\n3.‌ ‌The‌ ‌Clan‌ ‌\n●Several‌ ‌hordes‌ ‌together‌ ‌constitute‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌clan.‌ ‌Men‌ ‌connected‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌territory‌ ‌form‌ ‌a‌ ‌distinct‌ ‌social‌ ‌group‌ ‌\nknown‌ ‌as‌ ‌clan.‌ ‌According‌ ‌to‌ ‌Radcliffe‌ ‌Brown,‌ ‌“The‌ ‌clan‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌continuing‌ ‌group‌ ‌which‌ ‌the‌ ‌natives‌ ‌themselves‌ ‌thought‌ ‌of‌ ‌as‌ ‌having‌ ‌come‌ ‌\ninto‌ ‌existence‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌beginning‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌world‌ ‌and‌ ‌as‌ ‌being‌ ‌eternal:‌ ‌as‌ ‌members‌ ‌were‌ ‌losf‌ ‌by‌ ‌depth‌ ‌they‌ ‌were‌ ‌replaced‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌birth‌ ‌of‌ ‌new‌ ‌\nmembers.”‌ ‌The‌ ‌clan‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌unit‌ ‌of‌ ‌fundamental‌ ‌importance‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure.‌ ‌A‌ ‌woman‌ ‌belonged‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌clan‌ ‌of‌ ‌her‌ ‌father.‌ ‌Marriage‌ ‌\nbetween‌ ‌persons‌ ‌of‌ ‌one‌ ‌clan‌ ‌was‌ ‌forbidden.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌country‌ ‌was‌ ‌usually‌ ‌divided‌ ‌into‌ ‌clans.‌ ‌The‌ ‌male‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌clan‌ ‌constituted‌ ‌the‌ ‌continuing‌ ‌Nucleus‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Horde.‌ ‌The‌ ‌female‌ ‌\nmembers‌ ‌moved‌ ‌out‌ ‌after‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌female‌ ‌members‌ ‌moved‌ ‌in‌ ‌as‌ ‌wives‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌men.‌ ‌The‌ ‌clans‌ ‌constituted‌ ‌a‌ ‌wider‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nstructure‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌tribe.‌ ‌\n ‌\n4.‌ ‌The‌ ‌Tribe‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌the‌ ‌words‌ ‌of‌ ‌Radcliffe‌ ‌Brown,‌ ‌“A‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌clans‌ ‌had‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌language,‌ ‌and‌ ‌had‌ ‌similar‌ ‌customs;‌ ‌they‌ ‌therefore‌ ‌formed‌ ‌a‌ ‌linguistic‌ ‌\ncommunity‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to‌ ‌as‌ ‌aTribe.”‌ ‌Tribe‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌a‌ ‌politically‌ ‌united‌ ‌group.‌ ‌Its‌ ‌members‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌Amite‌ ‌in‌ ‌any‌ ‌combined‌ ‌action.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nhordes‌ ‌of‌ ‌some‌ ‌tribe‌ ‌or‌ ‌different‌ ‌tribes‌ ‌which‌ ‌engage‌ ‌in‌ ‌fighting.‌ ‌\n ‌\n5.‌ ‌The‌ ‌Kinship‌ ‌system‌ ‌\n●Persons‌ ‌of‌ ‌different‌ ‌hordes‌ ‌and‌ ‌of‌ ‌different‌ ‌tribes‌ ‌are‌ ‌linked‌ ‌by‌ ‌means‌ ‌of‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌system.‌ ‌Explaining‌ ‌the‌ ‌nature‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌system,‌ ‌\n348‌ ‌\nRadcliffe‌ ‌Brown‌ ‌has‌ ‌said,‌ ‌“The‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌recounting‌ ‌consisted‌ ‌of‌ ‌actual‌ ‌genealogical‌ ‌relationships,‌ ‌including‌ ‌the‌ ‌relations‌ ‌between‌ ‌\nfellow-members‌ ‌of‌ ‌one‌ ‌clan.‌ ‌\n●Thus,‌ ‌the‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌system‌ ‌cuts‌ ‌across‌ ‌the‌ ‌tribal‌ ‌relationship.‌ ‌Kinship‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌were‌ ‌classified‌ ‌into‌ ‌a‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌categories.‌ ‌Each‌ ‌category‌ ‌\nwas‌ ‌denoted‌ ‌by‌ ‌one‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌term‌ ‌distinguished‌ ‌as‌ ‌being‌ ‌nearer‌ ‌or‌ ‌more‌ ‌distant‌ ‌to‌ ‌other‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌relationship.‌ ‌The‌ ‌arrangement‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nrelationships‌ ‌was‌ ‌dyadic,‌ ‌i.e.,‌ ‌person‌ ‌to‌ ‌person‌ ‌relationship.‌ ‌Persons‌ ‌use‌ ‌to‌ ‌visit‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌members‌ ‌in‌ ‌other‌ ‌clans‌ ‌and‌ ‌tribes.‌ ‌Thus‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌\ncuts‌ ‌across‌ ‌club‌ ‌each‌ ‌person‌ ‌had‌ ‌his‌ ‌own‌ ‌particular‌ ‌position‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌total‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌structure‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌his‌ ‌status‌ ‌in‌ ‌descent,‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n ‌\n6.‌ ‌The‌ ‌Moieties‌ ‌\n●Sometimes‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌is‌ ‌divided‌ ‌into‌ ‌two‌ ‌moieties.‌ ‌Each‌ ‌moiety‌ ‌includes‌ ‌a‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌tribes.‌ ‌Each‌ ‌clan‌ ‌belongs‌ ‌to‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nmoieties.‌ ‌Thus‌ ‌a‌ ‌moiety‌ ‌is‌ ‌wider‌ ‌than‌ ‌tribes.‌ ‌In‌ ‌the‌ ‌words‌ ‌of‌ ‌Radcliffe‌ ‌Brown,‌ ‌“Essentially‌ ‌the‌ ‌system‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌classification‌ ‌or‌ ‌grounding‌ ‌of‌ ‌class,‌ ‌\nwhich‌ ‌cuts‌ ‌across‌ ‌the‌ ‌classification‌ ‌into‌ ‌tribes‌ ‌or‌ ‌linguistic‌ ‌communities.”‌ ‌\n ‌\n7.‌ ‌Social‌ ‌sections‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌Brown,‌ ‌the‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌society‌ ‌may‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌further‌ ‌dichotomy‌ ‌into‌ ‌two‌ ‌alternating‌ ‌generation‌ ‌divisions.‌ ‌Each‌ ‌clan‌ ‌contains‌ ‌at‌ ‌all‌ ‌\ntimes‌ ‌the‌ ‌adult‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌children,‌ ‌male‌ ‌and‌ ‌female,‌ ‌thus‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌four‌ ‌fold‌ ‌division‌ ‌of‌ ‌society‌ ‌into‌ ‌sections‌ ‌which‌ ‌have‌ ‌particular‌ ‌names.‌ ‌\nThese‌ ‌sections‌ ‌determine‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌and‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌relationships.‌ ‌\n ‌\n8.‌ ‌Totemic‌ ‌group.‌ ‌\n●Each‌ ‌clan‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌distinct‌ ‌totemic‌ ‌group‌ ‌having‌ ‌its‌ ‌own‌ ‌sacred‌ ‌totem‌ ‌centres,‌ ‌its‌ ‌own‌ ‌myths,‌ ‌its‌ ‌own‌ ‌rites.‌ ‌Each‌ ‌clan‌ ‌has‌ ‌its‌ ‌own‌ ‌totemic‌ ‌\nsolidarity‌ ‌and‌ ‌continuity‌ ‌which‌ ‌differentiates‌ ‌it‌ ‌from‌ ‌other‌ ‌clan.‌ ‌There‌ ‌are‌ ‌totemic‌ ‌ceremonies.‌ ‌Thus‌ ‌totemic‌ ‌group‌ ‌maintains‌ ‌solidarity‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nprimitive‌ ‌society.‌ ‌They‌ ‌provide‌ ‌the‌ ‌religious‌ ‌structure‌ ‌of‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n ‌\n9.‌ ‌Social‌ ‌classes‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌Brown,‌ ‌in‌ ‌some‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌societies‌ ‌one‌ ‌may‌ ‌find‌ ‌division‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌into‌ ‌social‌ ‌classes.‌ ‌An‌ ‌example‌ ‌of‌ ‌such‌ ‌a‌ ‌division‌ ‌is‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌division‌ ‌between‌ ‌chiefs‌ ‌and‌ ‌commoners‌ ‌in‌ ‌Polynesia.‌ ‌Social‌ ‌classes,‌ ‌however,‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌\n ‌\nPrinciples‌ ‌of‌ ‌description‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌\n●From‌ ‌the‌ ‌above‌ ‌mentioned‌ ‌description‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌structural‌ ‌system‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌people‌ ‌Radcliffe‌ ‌Brown‌ ‌formulates‌ ‌the‌ ‌important‌ ‌principles‌ ‌\nconcerning‌ ‌the‌ ‌description‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌description‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌should‌ ‌include‌ ‌not‌ ‌only‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌groups‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌classes-but‌ ‌the‌ ‌whole‌ ‌set‌ ‌of‌ ‌socially‌ ‌fixed‌ ‌\nrelationships‌ ‌of‌ ‌person‌ ‌to‌ ‌person‌ ‌as‌ ‌in‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌system.‌ ‌\n●Thus‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌at‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌place‌ ‌and‌ ‌time‌ ‌consists‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌whole‌ ‌set‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌among‌ ‌members.‌ ‌\n●Social‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌should‌ ‌be‌ ‌defined‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌institutions.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nWhat,‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌Radcliffe‌ ‌Brown,‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌importance‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌Institutions‌ ‌in‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure?‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Brown‌ ‌has‌ ‌defined‌ ‌the‌ ‌institution‌ ‌as,‌ ‌“an‌ ‌established‌ ‌or‌ ‌socially‌ ‌recognised‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌norms‌ ‌or‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌of‌ ‌conduct‌ ‌referring‌ ‌to‌ ‌some‌ ‌\n349‌ ‌\naspect‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌life.”‌ ‌An‌ ‌example‌ ‌of‌ ‌institution‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌which‌ ‌sets‌ ‌the‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌of‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌members‌ ‌in‌ ‌relation‌ ‌to‌ ‌one‌ ‌another.‌ ‌\n●Thus‌ ‌Social‌ ‌Institutions‌ ‌provide‌ ‌the‌ ‌measure‌ ‌to‌ ‌proper‌ ‌conduct‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌person‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌certain‌ ‌relationship.‌ ‌They‌ ‌define‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌person‌ ‌how‌ ‌he‌ ‌is‌ ‌\nexpected‌ ‌to‌ ‌behave‌ ‌and‌ ‌also‌ ‌how‌ ‌he‌ ‌may‌ ‌expect‌ ‌others‌ ‌to‌ ‌behave.‌ ‌Deviance‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌norms‌ ‌of‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌is‌ ‌derogated.‌ ‌Each‌ ‌institution‌ ‌\ncarries‌ ‌a‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌sanction‌ ‌behind‌ ‌it.‌ ‌\n●Institutional‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌determine‌ ‌the‌ ‌structural‌ ‌features‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌life.‌ ‌In‌ ‌the‌ ‌words‌ ‌of‌ ‌Brown,‌ ‌“Social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌therefore‌ ‌has‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌\ndescribed‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌which‌ ‌define‌ ‌the‌ ‌proper‌ ‌or‌ ‌expected‌ ‌conduct‌ ‌of‌ ‌persons‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌various‌ ‌relationships.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n2.2‌ ‌The‌ ‌Nature‌ ‌of‌ ‌Society‌ ‌:‌ ‌Social‌ ‌stratification-Part-II‌ ‌\n ‌\nSocial‌ ‌Stratification‌ ‌\n ‌\nIntroduction‌ ‌\n●Social‌ ‌stratification‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌‌particular‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌inequality‌.‌ ‌All‌ ‌societies‌ ‌arrange‌ ‌their‌ ‌members‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌superiority,‌ ‌inferiority‌ ‌and‌ ‌equality.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Social‌ ‌stratification‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌society’s‌ ‌categorization‌ ‌of‌ ‌its‌ ‌people‌ ‌into‌ ‌rankings‌ ‌of‌ ‌socioeconomic‌ ‌tiers‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌factors‌ ‌like‌ ‌wealth,‌ ‌\nincome,‌ ‌race,‌ ‌education,‌ ‌and‌ ‌power.‌ ‌\n ‌\n350‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nDefinition:‌ ‌\n ‌\n1.‌‌ ‌Ogburn‌ ‌and‌ ‌Nimkoff:‌ ‌\n●‘The‌ ‌process‌ ‌by‌ ‌which‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌and‌ ‌groups‌ ‌are‌ ‌ranked‌ ‌in‌ ‌more‌ ‌or‌ ‌less‌ ‌enduring‌ ‌hierarchy‌ ‌of‌ ‌status‌ ‌is‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌stratification”‌ ‌\n ‌ ‌\n2.‌‌ ‌Lundberg:‌ ‌\n●“A‌ ‌stratified‌ ‌society‌ ‌is‌ ‌one‌ ‌marked‌ ‌by‌ ‌inequality,‌ ‌by‌ ‌differences‌ ‌among‌ ‌people‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌evaluated‌ ‌by‌ ‌them‌ ‌as‌ ‌being‌ ‌“lower”‌ ‌and‌ ‌“higher”.‌ ‌\n ‌\n3.‌‌ ‌Gisbert:‌ ‌\n●“Social‌ ‌stratification‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌division‌ ‌of‌ ‌society‌ ‌into‌ ‌permanent‌ ‌groups‌ ‌of‌ ‌categories‌ ‌linked‌ ‌with‌ ‌each‌ ‌other‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌of‌ ‌superiority‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nsubordinations”.‌ ‌\n ‌ ‌\n4.‌ ‌‌Williams:‌ ‌\n●Social‌ ‌Stratification‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌“The‌ ‌ranking‌ ‌of‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌scale‌ ‌of‌ ‌superiority-inferiority-equality,‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌some‌ ‌commonly‌ ‌accepted‌ ‌\nbasis‌ ‌of‌ ‌valuation.‌ ‌\n351‌ ‌\n ‌\n5.‌ ‌‌Raymond‌ ‌W.‌ ‌Murray:‌ ‌\n●Social‌ ‌stratification‌ ‌is‌ ‌horizontal‌ ‌division‌ ‌of‌ ‌society‌ ‌into‌ ‌“higher”‌ ‌and‌ ‌“lower”‌ ‌social‌ ‌units.”‌ ‌\n ‌\n6.‌ ‌‌Melvin‌ ‌M‌ ‌Tumin:‌ ‌\n●“Social‌ ‌stratification‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌“arrangement‌ ‌of‌ ‌any‌ ‌social‌ ‌group‌ ‌or‌ ‌society‌ ‌into‌ ‌hierarchy‌ ‌of‌ ‌positions‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌unequal‌ ‌with‌ ‌regard‌ ‌to‌ ‌power,‌ ‌\nproperty,‌ ‌social‌ ‌evaluation‌ ‌and‌ ‌psychic‌ ‌gratification”.‌ ‌\n7.‌‌ ‌Sarokin:‌ ‌\n●Social‌ ‌stratification‌ ‌means‌ ‌the‌ ‌differentiation‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌given‌ ‌population‌ ‌into‌ ‌hierarchically‌ ‌super‌ ‌post‌ ‌classes.‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌manifested‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌existence‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nupper‌ ‌and‌ ‌lower‌ ‌social‌ ‌Layers.‌ ‌its‌ ‌basis‌ ‌and‌ ‌very‌ ‌essence‌ ‌consists‌ ‌in‌ ‌an‌ ‌equal‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌of‌ ‌rights‌ ‌and‌ ‌privileges,‌ ‌duties‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nresponsibilities.‌ ‌social‌ ‌values‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌power‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌member‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌society‌ ‌\n ‌\nOrigin‌ ‌of‌ ‌Stratification:‌ ‌\nRegarding‌ ‌the‌ ‌origin‌ ‌of‌ ‌stratification‌ ‌many‌ ‌views‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌given.‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌Davis,‌ ‌social‌ ‌stratification‌ ‌has‌ ‌come‌ ‌into‌ ‌being‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌functional‌ ‌necessity‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌system.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Professor‌ ‌Sorokin‌ ‌attributed‌ ‌social‌ ‌stratification‌ ‌mainly‌ ‌to‌ ‌inherited‌ ‌difference‌ ‌in‌ ‌environmental‌ ‌conditions.‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌Karl‌ ‌Mrax,‌ ‌social‌ ‌factors‌ ‌are‌ ‌responsible‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌emergence‌ ‌of‌ ‌different‌ ‌social‌ ‌strata,‌ ‌i.e.‌ ‌social‌ ‌stratification.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌Spengler,‌ ‌social‌ ‌stratification‌ ‌is‌ ‌founded‌ ‌upon‌ ‌scarcity‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌created‌ ‌whenever‌ ‌society‌ ‌differentiates‌ ‌positive‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nfunctions‌ ‌and‌ ‌powers.‌ ‌\n352‌ ‌\n ‌\nTypes‌ ‌of‌ ‌Social‌ ‌Stratification:‌ ‌\nSocial‌ ‌stratification‌ ‌is‌ ‌based‌ ‌upon‌ ‌a‌ ‌variety‌ ‌of‌ ‌principles.‌ ‌So‌ ‌we‌ ‌find‌ ‌different‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌stratification.‌ ‌\n ‌\nThe‌ ‌major‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌stratification‌ ‌are‌ ‌\n ‌\n1.Caste‌ ‌\na.Caste‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌hereditary‌ ‌endogamous‌ ‌social‌ ‌group‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌a‌ ‌person’s‌ ‌rank‌ ‌and‌ ‌its‌ ‌accompanying‌ ‌rights‌ ‌and‌ ‌obligations‌ ‌are‌ ‌ascribed‌ ‌on‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌birth‌ ‌into‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌group.‌ ‌For‌ ‌example-Brahmins,‌ ‌Kshyatryas,‌ ‌Vaishyas‌ ‌and‌ ‌Sudra‌ ‌Caste.‌ ‌\n2.Class‌ ‌\na.Class-Stratification‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌class‌ ‌is‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌in‌ ‌modern‌ ‌society.‌ ‌In‌ ‌this,‌ ‌a‌ ‌person’s‌ ‌position‌ ‌depends‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌very‌ ‌great‌ ‌extent‌ ‌\nupon‌ ‌achievement‌ ‌and‌ ‌his‌ ‌ability‌ ‌to‌ ‌use‌ ‌to‌ ‌advantage‌ ‌the‌ ‌inborn‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌and‌ ‌wealth‌ ‌that‌ ‌he‌ ‌may‌ ‌possess.‌ ‌\n3.Estate‌ ‌\na.Estate‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌medieval‌ ‌Europe‌ ‌provides‌ ‌another‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌stratification‌ ‌which‌ ‌gave‌ ‌much‌ ‌emphasis‌ ‌to‌ ‌birth‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌to‌ ‌wealth‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌possessions.‌ ‌Each‌ ‌estate‌ ‌had‌ ‌a‌ ‌state.‌ ‌\n4.Slavery‌ ‌\n●Slavery‌ ‌had‌ ‌economic‌ ‌basis.‌ ‌In‌ ‌slavery,‌ ‌every‌ ‌slave‌ ‌had‌ ‌his‌ ‌master‌ ‌to‌ ‌whom‌ ‌he‌ ‌was‌ ‌subjected.‌ ‌The‌ ‌master’s‌ ‌power‌ ‌over‌ ‌the‌ ‌slave‌ ‌\nwas‌ ‌unlimited.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌Addition‌ ‌\n ‌\nCaste‌ ‌\n●Caste‌ ‌is‌ ‌closely‌ ‌connected‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌Hindu‌ ‌philosophy‌ ‌and‌ ‌religion,‌ ‌custom‌ ‌and‌ ‌tradition‌ ‌.It‌ ‌is‌ ‌believed‌ ‌to‌ ‌have‌ ‌had‌ ‌a‌ ‌divine‌ ‌origin‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nsanction.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌deeply‌ ‌rooted‌ ‌social‌ ‌institution‌ ‌in‌ ‌India.‌ ‌There‌ ‌are‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌2800‌ ‌castes‌ ‌and‌ ‌sub-castes‌ ‌with‌ ‌all‌ ‌their‌ ‌peculiarities.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌caste‌ ‌stratification‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌society‌ ‌had‌ ‌its‌ ‌origin‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌chaturvarna‌ ‌system.‌ ‌According‌ ‌to‌ ‌this‌ ‌doctrine‌ ‌the‌ ‌Hindu‌ ‌society‌ ‌was‌ ‌\ndivided‌ ‌into‌ ‌four‌ ‌main‌ ‌varnas‌ ‌-‌ ‌Brahmins,‌ ‌Kshatriyas,‌ ‌Vaishyas‌ ‌and‌ ‌Shudras.‌ ‌The‌ ‌Varna‌ ‌system‌ ‌prevalent‌ ‌during‌ ‌the‌ ‌Vedic‌ ‌period‌ ‌was‌ ‌\nmainly‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌division‌ ‌of‌ ‌labor‌ ‌and‌ ‌occupation.‌ ‌\n●Earlier‌ ‌there‌ ‌were‌ ‌only‌ ‌three‌ ‌varnas,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Shudras‌ ‌were‌ ‌added‌ ‌later‌ ‌and‌ ‌occupational‌ ‌division‌ ‌was‌ ‌not‌ ‌rigid.‌ ‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌fifth‌ ‌group‌ ‌that‌ ‌falls‌ ‌outside‌ ‌the‌ ‌Varna‌ ‌system‌ ‌and‌ ‌is‌ ‌called‌ ‌Avarna‌ ‌or‌ ‌outcaste‌ ‌or‌ ‌untouchable‌ ‌also‌ ‌exists.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Ghurye‌‌ ‌says‌ ‌any‌ ‌attempt‌ ‌to‌ ‌define‌ ‌caste‌ ‌is‌ ‌bound‌ ‌to‌ ‌fail‌ ‌because‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌complexity‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌phenomenon.‌ ‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌‌Risley‌ ‌caste‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌collection‌ ‌of‌ ‌families‌ ‌bearing‌ ‌a‌ ‌common‌ ‌name‌ ‌claiming‌ ‌a‌ ‌common‌ ‌descent‌ ‌from‌ ‌a‌ ‌mythical‌ ‌ancestor‌ ‌\nprofessing‌ ‌to‌ ‌follow‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌hereditary‌ ‌calling‌ ‌and‌ ‌regarded‌ ‌by‌ ‌those‌ ‌who‌ ‌are‌ ‌competent‌ ‌to‌ ‌give‌ ‌an‌ ‌opinion‌ ‌as‌ ‌forming‌ ‌a‌ ‌single‌ ‌\nhomogeneous‌ ‌community.‌ ‌\n353‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Characteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌Caste‌ ‌System‌ ‌\n○Segmental‌ ‌division‌ ‌of‌ ‌society‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌is‌ ‌divided‌ ‌into‌ ‌carcaste‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌well-developed‌ ‌life‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌own,‌ ‌the‌ ‌member‌ ‌of‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌determined‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌consideration‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nbirth.‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌is‌ ‌hereditary‌ ‌in‌ ‌nature.‌ ‌\n■Individual‌ ‌their‌ ‌moral‌ ‌allegiance‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌caste‌ ‌first‌ ‌rather‌ ‌than‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌community‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌whole.‌ ‌ ‌\n○On‌ ‌feeling‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌intercourse‌ ‌\n■Each‌ ‌caste‌ ‌developed‌ ‌its‌ ‌own‌ ‌subculture.‌ ‌\n■These‌ ‌restrictions‌ ‌on‌ ‌feeling‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌intercourse‌ ‌are‌ ‌laid‌ ‌down‌ ‌with‌ ‌regard‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌kind‌ ‌of‌ ‌food‌ ‌that‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌accepted‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nperson‌ ‌and‌ ‌from‌ ‌which‌ ‌caste.‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌theory‌ ‌that‌ ‌pollution‌ ‌being‌ ‌communicated‌ ‌by‌ ‌some‌ ‌cast‌ ‌members‌ ‌to‌ ‌other‌ ‌higher‌ ‌ones,‌ ‌places‌ ‌restriction‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nextinction‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌intercourse.‌ ‌\n■Even‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌restrictions‌ ‌with‌ ‌regard‌ ‌to‌ ‌distances.‌ ‌\n○ ‌‌Endogamy‌ ‌\n■Essence‌ ‌of‌ ‌caste‌ ‌system‌ ‌a‌ ‌person‌ ‌born‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌caste‌ ‌remains‌ ‌in‌ ‌it‌ ‌for‌ ‌life‌ ‌and‌ ‌dies‌ ‌in‌ ‌it.‌ ‌\n354‌ ‌\n■ ‌every‌ ‌caste‌ ‌is‌ ‌subdivided‌ ‌into‌ ‌sub‌ ‌caste‌ ‌everyone‌ ‌of‌ ‌which‌ ‌for‌ ‌BITS‌ ‌is‌ ‌member‌ ‌to‌ ‌marry‌ ‌person‌ ‌outside‌ ‌it‌ ‌and‌ ‌violating‌ ‌this‌ ‌\ncan‌ ‌cause‌ ‌outcast‌ ‌and‌ ‌punishment.‌ ‌\n○Social‌ ‌and‌ ‌religious‌ ‌hierarchy‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌whole‌ ‌society‌ ‌is‌ ‌divided‌ ‌into‌ ‌distinct‌ ‌classes‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌high‌ ‌and‌ ‌low.‌ ‌\n■Brahmins‌ ‌are‌ ‌considered‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌pure‌ ‌and‌ ‌enjoy‌ ‌religious‌ ‌merit‌ ‌where‌ ‌Sudras‌ ‌are‌ ‌forbidden‌ ‌to‌ ‌enter‌ ‌into‌ ‌religious‌ ‌places‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nare‌ ‌subjected‌ ‌to‌ ‌manifold‌ ‌difficulties.‌ ‌\nClass‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌the‌ ‌modern‌ ‌world‌ ‌the‌ ‌class‌ ‌system‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌stratification‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌legal‌ ‌distinction‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌classes‌ ‌all‌ ‌are‌ ‌\nsubjected‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌law‌ ‌and‌ ‌all‌ ‌have‌ ‌equal‌ ‌citizens‌ ‌rights.‌ ‌\n●Position‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌order‌ ‌of‌ ‌ranking‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌determined‌ ‌by‌ ‌birth‌ ‌but‌ ‌depends‌ ‌upon‌ ‌his‌ ‌or‌ ‌her‌ ‌achievement‌ ‌and‌ ‌ability‌ ‌to‌ ‌use‌ ‌the‌ ‌inborn‌ ‌\ncharacteristic‌ ‌and‌ ‌wealth.‌ ‌\n ‌Factors‌ ‌determining‌ ‌class‌ ‌status‌ ‌\n● ‌Wealth/‌ ‌property‌ ‌\n○ ‌Land‌ ‌and‌ ‌capital‌ ‌Choir‌ ‌social‌ ‌standing‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌society,‌ ‌power‌ ‌also‌ ‌goes‌ ‌with‌ ‌property.‌ ‌\n● ‌Income‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌of‌ ‌income‌ ‌in‌ ‌capitalist‌ ‌society‌ ‌determines‌ ‌rank‌ ‌or‌ ‌status‌ ‌where‌ ‌I‌ ‌am‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌socialist‌ ‌society.‌ ‌There‌ ‌are‌ ‌also‌ ‌marked‌ ‌\ndifferences‌ ‌in‌ ‌income‌ ‌that‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌lead‌ ‌to‌ ‌very‌ ‌unequal‌ ‌status‌ ‌for‌ ‌standard‌ ‌of‌ ‌life.‌ ‌\n●Occupation‌ ‌\n○It's‌ ‌an‌ ‌aspect‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌economic‌ ‌system‌ ‌which‌ ‌often‌ ‌influences‌ ‌social‌ ‌class/‌ ‌status/‌ ‌rank.Prestige‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌attached‌ ‌to‌ ‌occupation.‌ ‌\n● ‌Education‌ ‌\n○ ‌Certain‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌education‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌Convent,‌ ‌Public‌ ‌School‌ ‌10th‌ ‌to‌ ‌help‌ ‌in‌ ‌getting‌ ‌some‌ ‌of‌ ‌better‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌jobs.‌ ‌\n ‌\nEstate‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌mediaeval‌ ‌Europe‌ ‌provides‌ ‌another‌ ‌social‌ ‌stratification.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌imposes‌ ‌on‌ ‌birth‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌on‌ ‌wealth.‌ ‌\n●Unlike‌ ‌the‌ ‌caste‌ ‌system‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌legally‌ ‌defined.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌was‌ ‌legally‌ ‌recognised‌ ‌with‌ ‌respective‌ ‌status‌ ‌and‌ ‌rights‌ ‌and‌ ‌duties.‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌instance‌ ‌in‌ ‌Revolutionary‌ ‌Russia‌ ‌there‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌state‌ ‌society‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌clergy,‌ ‌the‌ ‌nobility,‌ ‌the‌ ‌merchants‌ ‌and‌ ‌pieces‌ ‌were‌ ‌separated‌ ‌into‌ ‌\nsocial‌ ‌Strata‌ ‌that‌ ‌depend‌ ‌on‌ ‌birth‌ ‌wealth‌ ‌controlled‌ ‌by‌ ‌law.‌ ‌\n355‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nCharacteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌Social‌ ‌Stratification:‌ ‌\nOn‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌different‌ ‌definitions‌ ‌given‌ ‌by‌ ‌eminent‌ ‌scholars,‌ ‌social‌ ‌stratification‌ ‌may‌ ‌have‌ ‌the‌ ‌following‌ ‌characteristics.‌ ‌\n ‌\n(a)‌ ‌Social‌ ‌stratification‌ ‌is‌ ‌universal:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●There‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌society‌ ‌in‌ ‌this‌ ‌world‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌free‌ ‌from‌ ‌stratification.‌ ‌Modern‌ ‌stratification‌ ‌differs‌ ‌from‌ ‌stratification‌ ‌of‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nworldwide‌ ‌phenomenon.‌ ‌According‌ ‌to‌ ‌Sorokin‌ ‌“all‌ ‌permanently‌ ‌organized‌ ‌groups‌ ‌are‌ ‌stratified.”‌ ‌\n ‌\nIs‌ ‌Social‌ ‌Stratification‌ ‌Universal?‌ ‌\n●Most‌ ‌if‌ ‌not‌ ‌all‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌dispute‌ ‌the‌ ‌\"universal\"‌ ‌nature‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌stratification,‌ ‌holding‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌the‌ ‌standard‌ ‌among‌ ‌all‌ ‌\nsocieties.‌ ‌ ‌\n●John‌ ‌Gowdy‌ ‌(2006)‌ ‌writes,‌ ‌\"Assumptions‌ ‌about‌ ‌human‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌that‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌market‌ ‌societies‌ ‌believe‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌universal,‌ ‌that‌ ‌\nhumans‌ ‌are‌ ‌naturally‌ ‌competitive‌ ‌and‌ ‌acquisitive,‌ ‌and‌ ‌that‌ ‌social‌ ‌stratification‌ ‌is‌ ‌natural,‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌apply‌ ‌to‌ ‌many‌ ‌hunter-gatherer‌ ‌\npeoples.‌ ‌\n356‌ ‌\n●Non-stratified‌ ‌egalitarian‌ ‌or‌ ‌acephalous‌ ‌(\"headless\")‌ ‌societies‌ ‌exist‌ ‌which‌ ‌have‌ ‌little‌ ‌or‌ ‌no‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌hierarchy,‌ ‌political‌ ‌or‌ ‌\neconomic‌ ‌status,‌ ‌class,‌ ‌or‌ ‌even‌ ‌permanent‌ ‌leadership.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n(b)‌ ‌Stratification‌ ‌is‌ ‌social:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌true‌ ‌that‌ ‌biological‌ ‌qualities‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌determine‌ ‌one’s‌ ‌superiority‌ ‌and‌ ‌inferiority.‌ ‌Factors‌ ‌like‌ ‌age,‌ ‌sex,‌ ‌intelligence‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌strength‌ ‌often‌ ‌\ncontribute‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌on‌ ‌which‌ ‌statues‌ ‌are‌ ‌distinguished.‌ ‌But‌ ‌one’s‌ ‌education,‌ ‌property,‌ ‌power,‌ ‌experience,‌ ‌character,‌ ‌personality‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌are‌ ‌\nfound‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌more‌ ‌important‌ ‌than‌ ‌biological‌ ‌qualities.‌ ‌Hence,‌ ‌stratification‌ ‌is‌ ‌social‌ ‌by‌ ‌nature.‌ ‌\n ‌\n(c)‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌ancient:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●The‌ ‌Stratification‌ ‌system‌ ‌is‌ ‌very‌ ‌old.‌ ‌It‌ ‌was‌ ‌present‌ ‌even‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌small‌ ‌wondering‌ ‌bonds.‌ ‌In‌ ‌almost‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌ancient‌ ‌civilizations,‌ ‌the‌ ‌differences‌ ‌\nbetween‌ ‌the‌ ‌rich‌ ‌and‌ ‌poor,‌ ‌humble‌ ‌and‌ ‌powerful‌ ‌existed.‌ ‌During‌ ‌the‌ ‌period‌ ‌of‌ ‌Plato‌ ‌and‌ ‌Kautilya‌ ‌even‌ ‌emphasis‌ ‌was‌ ‌given‌ ‌to‌ ‌political,‌ ‌social‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌economic‌ ‌inequalities.‌ ‌\n ‌\n(d)‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌in‌ ‌diverse‌ ‌forms:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●The‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌stratification‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌uniform‌ ‌in‌ ‌all‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌In‌ ‌the‌ ‌modern‌ ‌world‌ ‌class,‌ ‌caste‌ ‌and‌ ‌estate‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌general‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌stratification.‌ ‌\nIn‌ ‌India‌ ‌a‌ ‌special‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌stratification‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌caste‌ ‌is‌ ‌found.‌ ‌The‌ ‌ancient‌ ‌Aryas‌ ‌were‌ ‌divided‌ ‌into‌ ‌four‌ ‌varnas:‌ ‌the‌ ‌Brahmins,‌ ‌\nKshatriyas,‌ ‌Vaishyas‌ ‌and‌ ‌Shudras.‌ ‌The‌ ‌ancient‌ ‌Greeks‌ ‌were‌ ‌divided‌ ‌into‌ ‌freemen‌ ‌and‌ ‌slaves‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌ancient‌ ‌Romans‌ ‌were‌ ‌divided‌ ‌into‌ ‌the‌ ‌\npatricians‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌plebeians.‌ ‌So‌ ‌every‌ ‌society,‌ ‌past‌ ‌or‌ ‌present,‌ ‌big‌ ‌or‌ ‌small‌ ‌is‌ ‌characterized‌ ‌by‌ ‌diverse‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌stratification.‌ ‌\n ‌\n(e)‌ ‌Social‌ ‌stratification‌ ‌is‌ ‌Consequential:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Social‌ ‌stratification‌ ‌has‌ ‌two‌ ‌important‌ ‌consequences‌ ‌one‌ ‌is‌ ‌“life‌ ‌chances”‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌one‌ ‌is‌ ‌“lifestyle”.‌ ‌A‌ ‌class‌ ‌system‌ ‌not‌ ‌only‌ ‌affects‌ ‌the‌ ‌\n“life-‌ ‌chances”‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌but‌ ‌also‌ ‌their‌ ‌“life‌ ‌style”.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌class‌ ‌have‌ ‌similar‌ ‌social‌ ‌chances‌ ‌but‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌chances‌ ‌vary‌ ‌in‌ ‌every‌ ‌society.‌ ‌It‌ ‌includes‌ ‌chances‌ ‌of‌ ‌survival‌ ‌and‌ ‌of‌ ‌good‌ ‌\nphysical‌ ‌and‌ ‌mental‌ ‌health,‌ ‌opportunities‌ ‌for‌ ‌education,‌ ‌chances‌ ‌of‌ ‌obtaining‌ ‌justice,‌ ‌marital‌ ‌conflict,‌ ‌separation‌ ‌and‌ ‌divorce‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n●Life‌ ‌style‌ ‌denotes‌ ‌a‌ ‌style‌ ‌of‌ ‌life‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌distinctive‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌social‌ ‌status.‌ ‌Life-styles‌ ‌include‌ ‌such‌ ‌matters‌ ‌like‌ ‌the‌ ‌residential‌ ‌areas‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nevery‌ ‌community‌ ‌which‌ ‌have‌ ‌gradations‌ ‌of‌ ‌prestige-ranking,‌ ‌mode‌ ‌of‌ ‌housing,‌ ‌means‌ ‌of‌ ‌recreation,‌ ‌the‌ ‌kinds‌ ‌of‌ ‌dress,‌ ‌the‌ ‌kinds‌ ‌of‌ ‌books,‌ ‌\nTV‌ ‌shows‌ ‌to‌ ‌which‌ ‌one‌ ‌is‌ ‌exposed‌ ‌and‌ ‌so‌ ‌on.‌ ‌Life-style‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌viewed‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌subculture‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌one‌ ‌stratum‌ ‌differs‌ ‌from‌ ‌another‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nframework‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌commonly‌ ‌shared‌ ‌over-all‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\n ‌\n357‌ ‌\nProcess‌ ‌of‌ ‌Social‌ ‌Stratification‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nNature‌ ‌of‌ ‌Social‌ ‌Stratification‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Moral‌ ‌Phenomenon‌-Its‌ ‌utilized‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌people‌ ‌to‌ ‌evaluate‌ ‌one‌ ‌another.‌ ‌\n●Structural‌ ‌Phenomenon‌-‌ ‌It‌ ‌brings‌ ‌about‌ ‌structural‌ ‌&‌ ‌social‌ ‌differentiation‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌human‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n●Behavioural‌ ‌Phenomenon‌-‌ ‌People‌ ‌act‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌evaluation‌ ‌they‌ ‌have‌ ‌made‌ ‌about‌ ‌one‌ ‌another‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n●Material‌ ‌Phenomenon‌-‌ ‌It‌ ‌creates‌ ‌differential‌ ‌access‌ ‌to‌ ‌goods,‌ ‌service‌ ‌&‌ ‌opportunities‌ ‌for‌ ‌people‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌\n●Existential‌ ‌Phenomenon‌-‌ ‌People‌ ‌experience‌ ‌their‌ ‌status‌ ‌&‌ ‌respond‌ ‌to‌ ‌them‌ ‌cognitively.‌ ‌\n ‌\n358‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nSocial‌ ‌Stratification‌ ‌and‌ ‌Social‌ ‌Mobility:‌ ‌\n●Social‌ ‌mobility‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌movement‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure,‌ ‌from‌ ‌one‌ ‌social‌ ‌position‌ ‌to‌ ‌another.‌ ‌It‌ ‌means‌ ‌a‌ ‌change‌ ‌in‌ ‌social‌ ‌status.‌ ‌ ‌\n●All‌ ‌societies‌ ‌provide‌ ‌some‌ ‌opportunity‌ ‌for‌ ‌social‌ ‌mobility.‌ ‌ ‌\n●But‌ ‌the‌ ‌societies‌ ‌differ‌ ‌from‌ ‌each‌ ‌other‌ ‌to‌ ‌an‌ ‌extent‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌can‌ ‌move‌ ‌from‌ ‌one‌ ‌class‌ ‌or‌ ‌status‌ ‌level‌ ‌to‌ ‌another.‌ ‌\nIt‌ ‌is‌ ‌said‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌greater‌ ‌the‌ ‌amount‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌mobility,‌ ‌the‌ ‌more‌ ‌open‌ ‌the‌ ‌class‌ ‌structure‌.‌ ‌The‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌mobility‌ ‌has‌ ‌fundamental‌ ‌\nimportance‌ ‌in‌ ‌ascertaining‌ ‌the‌ ‌relative‌ ‌“openness”‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure.‌ ‌The‌ ‌nature,‌ ‌forms,‌ ‌direction‌ ‌and‌ ‌magnitude‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌mobility‌ ‌depends‌ ‌on‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌nature‌ ‌and‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌stratification.‌ ‌Sociologists‌ ‌study‌ ‌social‌ ‌mobility‌ ‌in‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌find‌ ‌out‌ ‌the‌ ‌relative‌ ‌‘openness’‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure.‌ ‌\n ‌\nAny‌ ‌group‌ ‌that‌ ‌improves‌ ‌its‌ ‌standard‌ ‌will‌ ‌also‌ ‌improve‌ ‌its‌ ‌social‌ ‌status.‌ ‌But‌ ‌the‌ ‌rate‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌mobility‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌uniform‌ ‌in‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌countries.‌ ‌It‌ ‌differs‌ ‌\nfrom‌ ‌society‌ ‌to‌ ‌society‌ ‌from‌ ‌time‌ ‌to‌ ‌time.‌ ‌In‌ ‌India‌ ‌the‌ ‌rate‌ ‌of‌ ‌mobility‌ ‌is‌ ‌naturally‌ ‌low‌ ‌because‌ ‌of‌ ‌agriculture‌ ‌being‌ ‌the‌ ‌predominant‌ ‌occupation‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌continuity‌ ‌of‌ ‌caste‌ ‌system‌ ‌as‌ ‌compared‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌countries‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌world.‌ ‌\n ‌\nTypes‌ ‌of‌ ‌Social‌ ‌Mobility:‌ ‌\n359‌ ‌\nIn‌ ‌social‌ ‌stratification‌ ‌the‌ ‌movement‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌in‌ ‌three‌ ‌directions.‌ ‌\n ‌\n(a)‌ ‌From‌ ‌lower‌ ‌to‌ ‌higher‌ ‌\n ‌\n(b)‌ ‌From‌ ‌higher‌ ‌to‌ ‌lower‌ ‌\n ‌ ‌\n(c)‌ ‌Between‌ ‌two‌ ‌positions‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌level.‌ ‌\n ‌\nSocial‌ ‌mobility‌ ‌is‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌types:‌ ‌\n ‌\n(i)‌ ‌Vertical‌ ‌mobility‌ ‌\n ‌\n(ii)‌ ‌Horizontal‌ ‌mobility‌ ‌\n ‌\n(i)‌ ‌Vertical‌ ‌mobility:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●It‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌movement‌ ‌of‌ ‌people‌ ‌from‌ ‌one‌ ‌stratum‌ ‌to‌ ‌another‌ ‌or‌ ‌from‌ ‌one‌ ‌status‌ ‌to‌ ‌another.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌brings‌ ‌changes‌ ‌in‌ ‌class,‌ ‌occupation‌ ‌and‌ ‌power.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌involves‌ ‌movement‌ ‌from‌ ‌lower‌ ‌to‌ ‌higher‌ ‌or‌ ‌higher‌ ‌to‌ ‌lower.‌ ‌ ‌\n●There‌ ‌are‌ ‌two‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌vertical‌ ‌mobility.‌ ‌One‌ ‌is‌ ‌upward‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌is‌ ‌downward‌ ‌mobility.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●When‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌moves‌ ‌from‌ ‌lower‌ ‌status‌ ‌to‌ ‌higher‌ ‌status,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌called‌ ‌upward‌ ‌mobility.‌ ‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌example,‌ ‌if‌ ‌the‌ ‌son‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌peon‌ ‌joins‌ ‌a‌ ‌bank‌ ‌as‌ ‌an‌ ‌officer,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌said‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌upward‌ ‌social‌ ‌mobility‌ ‌but‌ ‌if‌ ‌he‌ ‌loses‌ ‌the‌ ‌job‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌any‌ ‌other‌ ‌\nreason‌ ‌or‌ ‌inefficiency,‌ ‌he‌ ‌is‌ ‌downwardly‌ ‌mobile‌ ‌from‌ ‌his‌ ‌previous‌ ‌job.‌ ‌ ‌\n●So‌ ‌downward‌ ‌mobility‌ ‌takes‌ ‌place‌ ‌when‌ ‌a‌ ‌person‌ ‌moves‌ ‌down‌ ‌from‌ ‌one‌ ‌position‌ ‌to‌ ‌another‌ ‌and‌ ‌change‌ ‌his‌ ‌status.‌ ‌\n ‌\n360‌ ‌\n(ii)‌ ‌Horizontal‌ ‌Mobility:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●It‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌movement‌ ‌of‌ ‌people‌ ‌from‌ ‌one‌ ‌social‌ ‌group‌ ‌to‌ ‌another‌ ‌situated‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌level.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌means‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌ranks‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌two‌ ‌groups‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌different.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌indicates‌ ‌change‌ ‌in‌ ‌position‌ ‌without‌ ‌the‌ ‌change‌ ‌in‌ ‌status.‌ ‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌example,‌ ‌if‌ ‌a‌ ‌teacher‌ ‌leaves‌ ‌one‌ ‌school‌ ‌and‌ ‌joins‌ ‌another‌ ‌school‌ ‌or‌ ‌a‌ ‌bank‌ ‌officer‌ ‌leaves‌ ‌one‌ ‌branch‌ ‌to‌ ‌work‌ ‌in‌ ‌another‌ ‌or‌ ‌change‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nresidence‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌horizontal‌ ‌mobility.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nApart‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌above‌ ‌two‌ ‌broad‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌stratification,‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌two‌ ‌other‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌stratification‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌dimension‌ ‌of‌ ‌time.‌ ‌They‌ ‌\nare:‌ ‌\n ‌\n(i)‌ ‌Intergenerational‌ ‌mobility:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●When‌ ‌changes‌ ‌in‌ ‌status‌ ‌occur‌ ‌from‌ ‌one‌ ‌generation‌ ‌to‌ ‌another,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌called‌ ‌intergenerational‌ ‌mobility.‌ ‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌example,‌ ‌if‌ ‌the‌ ‌son‌ ‌changes‌ ‌his‌ ‌status‌ ‌either‌ ‌by‌ ‌taking‌ ‌upon‌ ‌occupation‌ ‌of‌ ‌higher‌ ‌or‌ ‌lower‌ ‌rank‌ ‌with‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌father,‌ ‌there‌ ‌\nintergenerational‌ ‌mobility‌ ‌takes‌ ‌place.‌ ‌\n ‌\n(ii)‌ ‌Intra-generational‌ ‌mobility:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●When‌ ‌changes‌ ‌in‌ ‌status‌ ‌occur‌ ‌within‌ ‌one‌ ‌generation,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌called‌ ‌intra-generational‌ ‌mobility.‌ ‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌example,‌ ‌the‌ ‌rise‌ ‌and‌ ‌fall‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌occupational‌ ‌structure‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌family‌ ‌which‌ ‌leads‌ ‌to‌ ‌change‌ ‌in‌ ‌its‌ ‌social‌ ‌status‌ ‌within‌ ‌one‌ ‌generation‌ ‌is‌ ‌\ncalled‌ ‌intra-generational‌ ‌mobility.‌ ‌\n ‌\nStratification‌ ‌and‌ ‌Caste:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Under‌ ‌the‌ ‌caste‌ ‌system‌ ‌status‌ ‌is‌ ‌hereditary.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌birth,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌purely‌ ‌an‌ ‌ascribed‌ ‌status.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Once‌ ‌such‌ ‌positions‌ ‌are‌ ‌assigned,‌ ‌they‌ ‌can‌ ‌not‌ ‌advance‌ ‌and‌ ‌improve‌ ‌their‌ ‌social‌ ‌status‌ ‌in‌ ‌any‌ ‌way.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Hence,‌ ‌caste‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌major‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌stratification‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌facilitate‌ ‌vertical‌ ‌social‌ ‌mobility.‌ ‌\n ‌\nSocial‌ ‌Stratification‌ ‌and‌ ‌Class:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Class‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌“open”‌ ‌system.‌ ‌Under‌ ‌this‌ ‌system‌ ‌vertical‌ ‌mobility‌ ‌is‌ ‌absolutely‌ ‌free.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Movement‌ ‌from‌ ‌one‌ ‌status‌ ‌to‌ ‌another‌ ‌has‌ ‌no‌ ‌barrier.‌ ‌Status‌ ‌is‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌achievement.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌determined‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌talents,‌ ‌wealth,‌ ‌money,‌ ‌intelligence,‌ ‌power,‌ ‌education,‌ ‌income,‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌person.‌ ‌ ‌\n361‌ ‌\n●There‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌of‌ ‌parental‌ ‌status.‌ ‌\n ‌\nGender:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Like‌ ‌caste‌ ‌and‌ ‌class‌ ‌‌gender‌ ‌is‌ ‌another‌ ‌kind‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌stratification‌ ‌system.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Gender,‌ ‌perhaps‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌oldest‌ ‌and‌ ‌permanent‌ ‌source‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌differentiation.‌ ‌But‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌broad‌ ‌hierarchy‌ ‌of‌ ‌caste‌ ‌and‌ ‌class,‌ ‌gender‌ ‌\ncuts‌ ‌across‌ ‌caste‌ ‌and‌ ‌class.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌present‌ ‌day‌ ‌‌Indian‌ ‌society‌ ‌caste,‌ ‌class‌ ‌and‌ ‌gender‌ ‌are‌ ‌dynamic‌ ‌phenomena‌ ‌which‌ ‌vary‌ ‌between‌ ‌groups,‌ ‌communities‌ ‌and‌ ‌regions.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Recent‌ ‌years‌ ‌have‌ ‌witnessed‌ ‌a‌ ‌thorough‌ ‌and‌ ‌widespread‌ ‌discussion‌ ‌on‌ ‌gender.‌ ‌It‌ ‌has‌ ‌claimed‌ ‌critical‌ ‌address‌ ‌within‌ ‌ender‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌concept‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌set‌ ‌of‌ ‌practices‌ ‌has‌ ‌occurred‌ ‌during‌ ‌the‌ ‌last‌ ‌three‌ ‌decades.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌origin‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌concept‌ ‌gender‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌traced‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌19th‌ ‌century‌ ‌women’s‌ ‌movement‌ ‌and‌ ‌in‌ ‌Marxism.‌ ‌\n● ‌But‌ ‌it‌ ‌seems‌ ‌to‌ ‌have‌ ‌first‌ ‌appeared‌ ‌among‌ ‌American‌ ‌Feminists‌ ‌who‌ ‌wanted‌ ‌to‌ ‌reject‌ ‌biological‌ ‌determinism.‌ ‌Feminists‌ ‌prefer‌ ‌the‌ ‌term‌ ‌\ngender‌ ‌than‌ ‌sex.‌ ‌\n●But‌ ‌the‌ ‌term‌ ‌gender‌ ‌means‌ ‌much‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌sex‌ ‌and‌ ‌more‌ ‌inclusive‌ ‌than‌ ‌sex.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌socially‌ ‌constructed‌ ‌category‌ ‌rather‌ ‌than‌ ‌biologically‌ ‌\ndetermined.‌ ‌The‌ ‌gender‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌man‌ ‌is‌ ‌masculine‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌woman‌ ‌is‌ ‌feminine.‌ ‌Neither‌ ‌a‌ ‌man‌ ‌nor‌ ‌a‌ ‌woman‌ ‌is‌ ‌sex‌ ‌alone.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Gender‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌socially‌ ‌constructed‌ ‌and‌ ‌culturally‌ ‌determined‌ ‌role‌ ‌that‌ ‌men‌ ‌and‌ ‌women‌ ‌play‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌day-to-day‌ ‌lives.‌ ‌‌Gender‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nmost‌ ‌potent‌ ‌significant‌ ‌and‌ ‌enormously‌ ‌useful‌ ‌analytical‌ ‌concept‌ ‌used‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌feminists.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌matter‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌ascription,‌ ‌a‌ ‌socio-cultural‌ ‌construction‌ ‌and‌ ‌provided‌ ‌a‌ ‌deeper‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌of‌ ‌inequalities‌ ‌existing‌ ‌between‌ ‌male‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nfemale.‌ ‌It‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌institutionalization‌ ‌of‌ ‌sexual‌ ‌difference.‌ ‌In‌ ‌feminist‌ ‌literature‌ ‌gender‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌a‌ ‌value‌ ‌free‌ ‌concept‌ ‌rather‌ ‌a‌ ‌value‌ ‌\nloaded‌ ‌term‌ ‌and‌ ‌has‌ ‌acquired‌ ‌new‌ ‌dimensions.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌conceptual‌ ‌tool‌ ‌for‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌and‌ ‌is‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌highlight‌ ‌different‌ ‌structural‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌inequality‌ ‌between‌ ‌men‌ ‌and‌ ‌women.‌ ‌As‌ ‌a‌ ‌socially‌ ‌constructed‌ ‌difference‌ ‌and‌ ‌relations‌ ‌between‌ ‌males‌ ‌and‌ ‌females‌ ‌it‌ ‌very‌ ‌from‌ ‌time‌ ‌to‌ ‌\ntime‌ ‌and‌ ‌from‌ ‌place‌ ‌to‌ ‌place.‌ ‌\n●Gender‌ ‌is‌ ‌defined‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌construction‌ ‌of‌ ‌relations‌ ‌between‌ ‌women‌ ‌and‌ ‌men‌ ‌and‌ ‌among‌ ‌various‌ ‌groups‌ ‌of‌ ‌women‌ ‌and‌ ‌men.‌ ‌\nFeminist‌ ‌consider‌ ‌gender‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌socio-cultural‌ ‌manifestation‌ ‌of‌ ‌being‌ ‌a‌ ‌man‌ ‌or‌ ‌a‌ ‌woman.‌ ‌\n ‌\n(1)‌ ‌According‌ ‌to‌ ‌‌N.‌ ‌Kabeer‌ ‌“Gender‌ ‌is‌ ‌seen‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌process‌ ‌by‌ ‌which‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌who‌ ‌are‌ ‌born‌ ‌into‌ ‌biological‌ ‌categories‌ ‌of‌ ‌male‌ ‌or‌ ‌female‌ ‌\nbecome‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌categories‌ ‌of‌ ‌men‌ ‌and‌ ‌women‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌acquisition‌ ‌of‌ ‌locally‌ ‌defined‌ ‌attributes‌ ‌of‌ ‌masculinity‌ ‌and‌ ‌femininity.”‌ ‌\n ‌\n(2)‌ ‌According‌ ‌to‌ ‌A.‌ ‌Masefield‌—”Gender‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌defined‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌notion‌ ‌that‌ ‌offers‌ ‌a‌ ‌set‌ ‌of‌ ‌frameworks‌ ‌within‌ ‌which‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌and‌ ‌ideological‌ ‌\nconstruction‌ ‌and‌ ‌representation‌ ‌of‌ ‌differences‌ ‌between‌ ‌sexes‌ ‌are‌ ‌explained.”‌ ‌\n ‌\n(3)‌ ‌According‌ ‌to‌ ‌‌ILO‌,‌ ‌“Gender‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌differences‌ ‌and‌ ‌relations‌ ‌between‌ ‌men‌ ‌and‌ ‌women,‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌learned,‌ ‌which‌ ‌vary‌ ‌widely‌ ‌\namong‌ ‌societies‌ ‌and‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌and‌ ‌change‌ ‌over‌ ‌time.”‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Thus,‌ ‌gender‌ ‌involves‌ ‌power‌ ‌structure‌ ‌and‌ ‌economic‌ ‌relationships.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌analyze‌ ‌the‌ ‌role,‌ ‌responsibilities,‌ ‌constraints,‌ ‌needs‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nmen‌ ‌and‌ ‌women‌ ‌in‌ ‌all‌ ‌areas.‌ ‌It‌ ‌encompasses‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌division‌ ‌and‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌distinctions‌ ‌between‌ ‌women‌ ‌and‌ ‌men.‌ ‌It‌ ‌plays‌ ‌an‌ ‌important‌ ‌\nrole‌ ‌in‌ ‌shaping‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌and‌ ‌practices‌ ‌in‌ ‌every‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n362‌ ‌\nValue‌ ‌Addition‌ ‌\n ‌\nStatus‌ ‌and‌ ‌Role‌ ‌\nThe‌ ‌term‌ ‌has‌ ‌two‌ ‌sociological‌ ‌uses:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●R.‌ ‌Linton‌ ‌(1936)‌‌ ‌defined‌ ‌status‌ ‌simply‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌position‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌social‌ ‌system,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌child‌ ‌or‌ ‌parent.‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌Role‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌set‌ ‌of‌ ‌norms,‌ ‌values,‌ ‌behaviors,‌ ‌and‌ ‌personality‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌attached‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌status.‌ ‌‌An‌ ‌individual‌ ‌may‌ ‌occupy‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nstatuses‌ ‌of‌ ‌student,‌ ‌employee,‌ ‌and‌ ‌club‌ ‌president‌ ‌and‌ ‌play‌ ‌one‌ ‌or‌ ‌more‌ ‌roles‌ ‌with‌ ‌each‌ ‌one.‌ ‌\n○Example:‌ ‌Status‌ ‌as‌ ‌student‌ ‌\nRole‌ ‌1:‌ ‌Classroom:‌ ‌Attending‌ ‌class,‌ ‌taking‌ ‌notes,‌ ‌and‌ ‌communicating‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌professor‌ ‌\nRole‌ ‌2:‌ ‌Fellow‌ ‌student:‌ ‌Participating‌ ‌in‌ ‌study‌ ‌groups,‌ ‌sharing‌ ‌ideas,‌ ‌quizzing‌ ‌other‌ ‌students‌ ‌\n ‌\n○Status‌ ‌as‌ ‌employee‌ ‌\nRole‌ ‌1:‌ ‌Warehouse:‌ ‌Unloading‌ ‌boxes,‌ ‌labeling‌ ‌products,‌ ‌restocking‌ ‌shelves‌ ‌\nRole‌ ‌2:‌ ‌Customer‌ ‌service:‌ ‌Answering‌ ‌questions,‌ ‌solving‌ ‌problems,‌ ‌researching‌ ‌information‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n363‌ ‌\n●Status‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌what‌ ‌a‌ ‌person‌ ‌is,‌ ‌whereas‌ ‌the‌ ‌closely‌ ‌linked‌ ‌notion‌ ‌of‌ ‌role‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌expected‌ ‌of‌ ‌people‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌status.Societies‌ ‌\ndecide‌ ‌what‌ ‌is‌ ‌considered‌ ‌appropriate‌ ‌role‌ ‌behavior‌ ‌for‌ ‌different‌ ‌statuses.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●A‌ ‌status‌ ‌is‌ ‌simply‌ ‌a‌ ‌rank‌ ‌or‌ ‌position‌ ‌that‌ ‌one‌ ‌holds‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌group.‌ ‌One‌ ‌occupies‌ ‌the‌ ‌status‌ ‌of‌ ‌son‌ ‌or‌ ‌daughter,‌ ‌pupil,‌ ‌radical,‌ ‌militant‌ ‌and‌ ‌so‌ ‌on.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Eventually‌ ‌one‌ ‌occupies‌ ‌the‌ ‌statuses‌ ‌of‌ ‌husband,‌ ‌mother,‌ ‌bread-winner,‌ ‌cricket‌ ‌fan,‌ ‌and‌ ‌so‌ ‌on,‌ ‌one‌ ‌has‌ ‌as‌ ‌many‌ ‌statuses‌ ‌as‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌\ngroups‌ ‌of‌ ‌which‌ ‌one‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌member.‌ ‌For‌ ‌analytical‌ ‌purposes,‌ ‌statuses‌ ‌are‌ ‌divided‌ ‌into‌ ‌two‌ ‌basic‌ ‌types:‌ ‌\n ‌\n1.Ascribed‌-Ascribed‌ ‌statuses‌ ‌are‌ ‌those‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌fixed‌ ‌for‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌at‌ ‌birth.‌ ‌Ascribed‌ ‌statuses‌ ‌that‌ ‌exist‌ ‌in‌ ‌all‌ ‌societies‌ ‌include‌ ‌\nthose‌ ‌based‌ ‌upon‌ ‌sex,‌ ‌age,‌ ‌race‌ ‌ethnic‌ ‌group‌ ‌and‌ ‌family‌ ‌background.‌ ‌\n2.Achieved‌-Achieved‌ ‌statuses‌ ‌are‌ ‌those‌ ‌which‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual‌ ‌acquires‌ ‌during‌ ‌his‌ ‌or‌ ‌her‌ ‌lifetime‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌result‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌exercise‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nknowledge,‌ ‌ability,‌ ‌skill‌ ‌and/or‌ ‌perseverance.‌ ‌Occupation‌ ‌provides‌ ‌an‌ ‌example‌ ‌of‌ ‌status‌ ‌that‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌either‌ ‌ascribed‌ ‌or‌ ‌achieved,‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nwhich‌ ‌serves‌ ‌to‌ ‌differentiate‌ ‌caste-like‌ ‌societies‌ ‌from‌ ‌modern‌ ‌ones.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nRole‌ ‌Conflict‌ ‌\n●Role‌ ‌Conflict‌ ‌results‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌competing‌ ‌demands‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌or‌ ‌more‌ ‌roles‌ ‌that‌ ‌vie‌ ‌for‌ ‌our‌ ‌time‌ ‌and‌ ‌energy.‌ ‌ ‌\n364‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌more‌ ‌statuses‌ ‌we‌ ‌have,‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌more‌ ‌roles‌ ‌we‌ ‌take‌ ‌on,‌ ‌the‌ ‌more‌ ‌likely‌ ‌we‌ ‌are‌ ‌to‌ ‌experience‌ ‌role‌ ‌conflict.‌ ‌\n●Example:‌ ‌‌A‌ ‌working‌ ‌father‌ ‌is‌ ‌expected‌ ‌at‌ ‌work‌ ‌on‌ ‌time‌ ‌but‌ ‌is‌ ‌late‌ ‌because‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌children‌ ‌is‌ ‌sick.‌ ‌His‌ ‌roles‌ ‌as‌ ‌father‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nemployee‌ ‌are‌ ‌then‌ ‌in‌ ‌conflict.‌ ‌A‌ ‌role‌ ‌for‌ ‌his‌ ‌father‌ ‌status‌ ‌dictates‌ ‌that‌ ‌he‌ ‌care‌ ‌for‌ ‌his‌ ‌sick‌ ‌child,‌ ‌while‌ ‌a‌ ‌role‌ ‌for‌ ‌his‌ ‌employee‌ ‌status‌ ‌\ndemands‌ ‌that‌ ‌he‌ ‌arrive‌ ‌at‌ ‌work‌ ‌on‌ ‌time.‌ ‌\nRole‌ ‌Strain‌ ‌\n●Role‌ ‌strain‌ ‌occurs‌‌ ‌when‌ ‌we‌ ‌have‌ ‌trouble‌ ‌meeting‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌roles‌ ‌expected‌ ‌of‌ ‌u‌s.‌ ‌\n●People‌ ‌can‌ ‌also‌ ‌experience‌ ‌both‌ ‌role‌ ‌conflict‌ ‌(when‌ ‌two‌ ‌roles‌ ‌have‌ ‌demands‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌mutually‌ ‌exclusive)‌ ‌and‌ ‌role‌ ‌overload‌ ‌(when‌ ‌\none‌ ‌doesn't‌ ‌have‌ ‌the‌ ‌resources‌ ‌to‌ ‌meet‌ ‌the‌ ‌demands‌ ‌of‌ ‌multiple‌ ‌roles).‌ ‌\n●Role‌ ‌strain‌ ‌is‌ ‌thought‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌a‌ ‌common‌ ‌experience‌ ‌in‌ ‌modern‌ ‌society,‌ ‌and‌ ‌people‌ ‌engage‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌variety‌ ‌of‌ ‌strategies‌ ‌to‌ ‌cope‌ ‌with‌ ‌role‌ ‌\nstrain.‌ ‌\n ‌\n2.3‌ ‌Marriage‌ ‌:‌ ‌Definition‌ ‌and‌ ‌universality‌ ‌\n ‌Laws‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌(endogamy,‌ ‌exogamy,‌ ‌hypergamy,‌ ‌hypogamy,‌ ‌incest‌ ‌taboo);‌ ‌\n ‌Type‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌(monogamy,‌ ‌polygamy,‌ ‌polyandry,‌ ‌group‌ ‌marriage).‌ ‌\n ‌Functions‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage;‌ ‌\n ‌Marriage‌ ‌regulations‌ ‌(preferential,‌ ‌prescriptive‌ ‌and‌ ‌proscriptive)‌ ‌\n ‌Marriage‌ ‌payments‌ ‌(bride‌ ‌wealth‌ ‌and‌ ‌dowry)‌ ‌\n‌ ‌\n ‌\nMarriage‌ ‌:‌ ‌Definition‌ ‌and‌ ‌universality;‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nIntroduction:‌ ‌\n●Marriage‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌‌ubiquitous‌ ‌feature‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌organization‌ ‌and‌ ‌its‌ ‌development‌ ‌assumed‌ ‌a‌ ‌critical‌ ‌role‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌history‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌\ninstitutions‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌institution‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌central‌ ‌draft‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌society‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌a‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌civilization.‌ ‌The‌ ‌significance‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌\ninstitution‌ ‌of‌ ‌Marriage‌ ‌lies‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌fact‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌results‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌cause‌ ‌and‌ ‌effect‌ ‌of‌ ‌procreation‌ ‌besides‌ ‌providing‌ ‌a‌ ‌moral‌ ‌and‌ ‌ethical‌ ‌social‌ ‌\nbonding.‌ ‌Marriage‌ ‌not‌ ‌only‌ ‌brings‌ ‌about‌ ‌the‌ ‌union‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌persons‌ ‌but‌ ‌two‌ ‌families‌ ‌as‌ ‌well.‌ ‌\n●Several‌ ‌widely‌ ‌occurring‌ ‌functions‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌notable‌ ‌behavioural‌ ‌universals:‌ ‌\n365‌ ‌\n○Parental‌ ‌responsibility‌ ‌for‌ ‌long‌ ‌term‌ ‌infant‌ ‌nurturing‌ ‌and‌ ‌education,‌ ‌\n○Social‌ ‌regulation‌ ‌of‌ ‌sexual‌ ‌competition,‌ ‌\n○Organization‌ ‌of‌ ‌gendered‌ ‌divisions‌ ‌of‌ ‌labour,‌ ‌\n○Assignment‌ ‌of‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌to‌ ‌social‌ ‌groups‌ ‌and‌ ‌statuses,‌ ‌and‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌formation‌ ‌of‌ ‌intergroup‌ ‌alliances‌ ‌and‌ ‌exchanges.‌ ‌\n●Yet‌ ‌in‌ ‌spite‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌general‌ ‌features,‌ ‌‌different‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌have‌ ‌developed‌ ‌a‌ ‌fascinating‌ ‌diversity‌ ‌of‌ ‌regulations‌ ‌and‌ ‌customs‌ ‌concerning‌ ‌\nprohibitions‌ ‌and‌ ‌preferences‌ ‌for‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌partners‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌expectations‌ ‌between‌ ‌spouses‌ ‌and‌ ‌in-laws.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Prominent‌ ‌variations,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌arranged‌ ‌marriages,‌ ‌polygamy,‌ ‌and‌ ‌same-sexed‌ ‌unions‌ ‌provide‌ ‌a‌ ‌rich‌ ‌ethnographic‌ ‌record‌ ‌for‌ ‌speculating‌ ‌\nabout‌ ‌why‌ ‌societies‌ ‌differ.‌ ‌They‌ ‌also‌ ‌challenge‌ ‌our‌ ‌tolerance‌ ‌of‌ ‌different‌ ‌moral‌ ‌conventions‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌basic‌ ‌level‌ ‌\n ‌\nDefinition‌ ‌by‌ ‌Anthropologist:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●GP‌ ‌Murdock‌ ‌(An‌ ‌American‌ ‌anthropologist)-‌Universal‌ ‌institution‌ ‌that‌ ‌involves‌ ‌residential,‌ ‌cohabitation,‌ ‌economic‌ ‌cooperation‌ ‌and‌ ‌formation‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌family.‌ ‌\n●Westermarck‌ ‌‌(‌ ‌Finnish‌ ‌anthropologist)-‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌of‌ ‌one‌ ‌or‌ ‌more‌ ‌men‌ ‌to‌ ‌one‌ ‌for‌ ‌more‌ ‌women‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌recognised‌ ‌by‌ ‌custom‌ ‌or‌ ‌law‌ ‌and‌ ‌\ninvolves‌ ‌certain‌ ‌rights‌ ‌and‌ ‌duties‌ ‌both‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌case‌ ‌of‌ ‌parties‌ ‌entering‌ ‌the‌ ‌Union‌ ‌and‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌case‌ ‌of‌ ‌children‌ ‌born‌ ‌of‌ ‌it.‌ ‌\n●William‌ ‌N.‌ ‌Stephens‌ ‌defined‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌as‌ ‌‘a‌ ‌socially‌ ‌legitimate‌ ‌sexual‌ ‌union,‌ ‌begun‌ ‌with‌ ‌public‌ ‌pronouncement‌ ‌undertaken‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌idea‌ ‌of‌ ‌\npermanence,‌ ‌assumed‌ ‌with‌ ‌more‌ ‌or‌ ‌less‌ ‌explicit‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌contract‌ ‌which‌ ‌spells‌ ‌out‌ ‌reciprocal‌ ‌economic‌ ‌obligations‌ ‌between‌ ‌spouses,‌ ‌and‌ ‌\ntheir‌ ‌future‌ ‌children.‌ ‌\n●Kathleen‌ ‌Gough‌ ‌(‌ ‌British‌ ‌anthropologist):‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌her‌ ‌‌classic‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌Nayar‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌arrangements‌,‌ ‌Kathleen‌ ‌Gough,‌ ‌‌considers‌ ‌both‌ ‌the‌ ‌general‌ ‌anthropological‌ ‌position‌ ‌that‌ ‌\nmarriage‌ ‌is‌ ‌universal‌ ‌and‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌performs‌ ‌a‌ ‌similar‌ ‌set‌ ‌of‌ ‌functions‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌Nayar‌ ‌are‌ ‌an‌ ‌upper‌ ‌caste‌ ‌group,‌ ‌who‌ ‌are‌ ‌organized‌ ‌politically‌ ‌into‌ ‌small‌ ‌kingdoms‌ ‌and‌ ‌territorially‌ ‌into‌ ‌localized‌ ‌\nmatrilineal‌ ‌descent‌ ‌groups.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Although‌ ‌many‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌practices‌ ‌have‌ ‌changed‌ ‌after‌ ‌the‌ ‌imposition‌ ‌of‌ ‌British‌ ‌colonial‌ ‌rule,‌ ‌a‌ ‌reconstruction‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌traditional‌ ‌\nsystem‌ ‌suggests‌ ‌that‌ ‌no‌ ‌substantial‌ ‌marital‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌were‌ ‌present,‌ ‌at‌ ‌least‌ ‌from‌ ‌a‌ ‌Western‌ ‌perspective.‌ ‌ ‌\n■On‌ ‌reaching‌ ‌puberty,‌ ‌a‌ ‌woman‌ ‌could‌ ‌entertain‌ ‌an‌ ‌indefinite‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌lovers,‌ ‌usually‌ ‌between‌ ‌three‌ ‌and‌ ‌eight,‌ ‌without‌ ‌any‌ ‌\npublic‌ ‌concern‌ ‌over‌ ‌sexual‌ ‌fidelity‌ ‌or‌ ‌paternal‌ ‌responsibility,‌ ‌the‌ ‌two‌ ‌basic‌ ‌features‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌in‌ ‌European‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Women‌ ‌would‌ ‌assume‌ ‌the‌ ‌responsibility‌ ‌for‌ ‌raising‌ ‌children‌ ‌within‌ ‌matrilineally‌ ‌constructed‌ ‌households,‌ ‌focusing‌ ‌on‌ ‌mothers,‌ ‌\ndaughters,‌ ‌and‌ ‌sisters.‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌domestic‌ ‌group‌ ‌also‌ ‌included‌ ‌male‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌matrilineage,‌ ‌i.e.‌ ‌the‌ ‌women's‌ ‌brothers.‌ ‌\n■However,‌ ‌since‌ ‌their‌ ‌main‌ ‌activities‌ ‌were‌ ‌devoted‌ ‌to‌ ‌warfare,‌ ‌all‌ ‌but‌ ‌the‌ ‌eldest‌ ‌men‌ ‌were‌ ‌usually‌ ‌absent‌ ‌during‌ ‌the‌ ‌better‌ ‌part‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌the‌ ‌year.‌ ‌\n■In‌ ‌spite‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌apparently‌ ‌casual‌ ‌attitudes‌ ‌towards‌ ‌sex‌ ‌and‌ ‌fatherhood,‌ ‌a‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌rules‌ ‌were‌ ‌strictly‌ ‌applied‌ ‌and‌ ‌failure‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nobserve‌ ‌them‌ ‌could‌ ‌lead‌ ‌to‌ ‌severest‌ ‌punishments:‌ ‌ostracism‌ ‌and‌ ‌death.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌most‌ ‌important‌ ‌focused‌ ‌on‌ ‌two‌ ‌ritual‌ ‌acts:‌ ‌the‌ ‌tying‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌tali‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌payment‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌midwife's‌ ‌fees.‌ ‌ ‌\n366‌ ‌\n■In‌ ‌the‌ ‌tali‌ ‌ritual,‌ ‌girls‌ ‌and‌ ‌boys‌ ‌from‌ ‌allied‌ ‌lineages‌ ‌collectively‌ ‌performed‌ ‌a‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌wedding‌ ‌ceremony‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌each‌ ‌\n\"groom\"‌ ‌tied‌ ‌a‌ ‌gold‌ ‌ornament‌ ‌on‌ ‌his‌ ‌\"brides\"‌ ‌neck.‌ ‌ ‌\n■In‌ ‌the‌ ‌successive‌ ‌rites‌ ‌the‌ ‌couple‌ ‌was‌ ‌secluded‌ ‌and‌ ‌may‌ ‌or‌ ‌may‌ ‌not‌ ‌have‌ ‌engaged‌ ‌in‌ ‌sexual‌ ‌activity‌ ‌(usually‌ ‌the‌ ‌girl‌ ‌was‌ ‌too‌ ‌\nyoung).‌ ‌\n■At‌ ‌the‌ ‌conclusion‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌ritual‌ ‌no‌ ‌specific‌ ‌rights‌ ‌or‌ ‌obligations‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌couple‌ ‌were‌ ‌established,‌ ‌other‌ ‌than‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nexpectation‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌\"wife\"‌ ‌and‌ ‌her‌ ‌children‌ ‌would‌ ‌make‌ ‌special‌ ‌mourning‌ ‌observances‌ ‌when‌ ‌her‌ ‌\"husband\"‌ ‌died.‌ ‌ ‌\n■However,‌ ‌without‌ ‌the‌ ‌tying‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌tali,‌ ‌a‌ ‌woman‌ ‌could‌ ‌not‌ ‌engage‌ ‌in‌ ‌any‌ ‌sexual‌ ‌activity.‌ ‌If‌ ‌she‌ ‌gave‌ ‌birth,‌ ‌her‌ ‌child‌ ‌would‌ ‌be‌ ‌\nconsidered‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌illegitimate.‌ ‌ ‌\n■After‌ ‌the‌ ‌ceremony,‌ ‌she‌ ‌could‌ ‌start‌ ‌receiving‌ ‌lovers‌ ‌provided‌ ‌that‌ ‌they‌ ‌did‌ ‌not‌ ‌come‌ ‌from‌ ‌a‌ ‌lower‌ ‌hereditary‌ ‌caste‌ ‌or‌ ‌subcaste‌ ‌\nas‌ ‌she‌ ‌did.‌ ‌ ‌\n■When‌ ‌the‌ ‌woman‌ ‌bore‌ ‌children,‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌lovers‌ ‌was‌ ‌expected‌ ‌to‌ ‌acknowledge‌ ‌his‌ ‌paternity‌ ‌by‌ ‌presenting‌ ‌gifts‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nmidwife‌ ‌who‌ ‌assisted‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌delivery.‌ ‌ ‌\n■While‌ ‌this,‌ ‌like‌ ‌the‌ ‌tali‌ ‌tying,‌ ‌was‌ ‌an‌ ‌almost‌ ‌exclusively‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌act‌ ‌and‌ ‌incurred‌ ‌no‌ ‌subsequent‌ ‌responsibility,‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌\nconsidered‌ ‌essential‌ ‌to‌ ‌both‌ ‌the‌ ‌legitimacy‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌status‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌child‌ ‌insofar‌ ‌as‌ ‌it‌ ‌provided‌ ‌an‌ ‌assurance‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌not‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nproduct‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌between‌ ‌its‌ ‌mother‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌socially‌ ‌inferior‌ ‌man.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌Nayar‌ ‌case‌ ‌imposes‌ ‌a‌ ‌strict‌ ‌test‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage,‌ ‌as‌ ‌it‌ ‌completely‌ ‌dispenses‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌child-care‌ ‌functions‌ ‌so‌ ‌\nstrongly‌ ‌emphasized‌ ‌in‌ ‌Western‌ ‌understandings‌ ‌and‌ ‌differs‌ ‌in‌ ‌its‌ ‌concepts‌ ‌of‌ ‌sexual‌ ‌exclusiveness‌ ‌and‌ ‌propriety.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌does‌ ‌however‌ ‌impose‌ ‌an‌ ‌important‌ ‌set‌ ‌of‌ ‌rules‌ ‌and‌ ‌fulfills‌ ‌functions‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌quite‌ ‌understandable‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌context‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌lineage‌ ‌and‌ ‌\ncaste‌ ‌based‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌rites‌ ‌and‌ ‌regulations‌ ‌assume‌ ‌the‌ ‌following‌ ‌significance‌ ‌appropriate‌ ‌the‌ ‌broader‌ ‌Nayar‌ ‌social‌ ‌order:‌ ‌\n■They‌ ‌reflect‌ ‌and‌ ‌enforce‌ ‌a‌ ‌morality‌ ‌that‌ ‌permits‌ ‌open‌ ‌sexual‌ ‌relations‌ ‌provided‌ ‌that‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌contracted‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌limits‌ ‌of‌ ‌\ncaste‌ ‌membership‌ ‌and‌ ‌uphold‌ ‌standards‌ ‌of‌ ‌hereditary‌ ‌purity.‌ ‌\n■They‌ ‌contribute‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌focusing‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌caste.‌ ‌\n■They‌ ‌represent‌ ‌and‌ ‌underscore‌ ‌long‌ ‌term‌ ‌alliances‌ ‌among‌ ‌localized‌ ‌matrilineages,‌ ‌which‌ ‌along‌ ‌with‌ ‌caste‌ ‌groups‌ ‌constitute‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌core‌ ‌components‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n■They‌ ‌underwrite‌ ‌the‌ ‌legitimacy‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌statuses‌ ‌of‌ ‌newly‌ ‌born‌ ‌children.‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌these‌ ‌observations,‌ ‌along‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌consideration‌ ‌of‌ ‌other‌ ‌variations‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌woman-woman‌ ‌marriage,Gough‌ ‌suggests‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nbroadened‌ ‌definition‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌as‌ ‌follows:‌ ‌\n ‌\n○“Marriage‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌established‌ ‌between‌ ‌a‌ ‌woman‌ ‌and‌ ‌one‌ ‌or‌ ‌more‌ ‌other‌ ‌persons,‌ ‌which‌ ‌provides‌ ‌that‌ ‌a‌ ‌child‌ ‌born‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌the‌ ‌woman‌ ‌under‌ ‌circumstances‌ ‌not‌ ‌prohibited‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌rules‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌relationship,‌ ‌is‌ ‌accorded‌ ‌full‌ ‌birth-status‌ ‌rights‌ ‌\ncommon‌ ‌to‌ ‌normal‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌society‌ ‌or‌ ‌social‌ ‌stratum”.‌ ‌\n○Although‌ ‌her‌ ‌example‌ ‌and‌ ‌definition‌ ‌have‌ ‌attracted‌ ‌a‌ ‌‌good‌ ‌deal‌ ‌of‌ ‌criticism‌ ‌‌(Bell‌ ‌1997),‌ ‌they‌ ‌at‌ ‌least‌ ‌point‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌range‌ ‌of‌ ‌variation‌ ‌\nthat‌ ‌marital‌ ‌forms‌ ‌and‌ ‌functions‌ ‌have‌ ‌assumed‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌problem‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌cross-culturally‌ ‌valid‌ ‌designation.‌ ‌\n ‌\n367‌ ‌\nValue‌ ‌addition‌ ‌\nMurstein‌ ‌Filter‌ ‌Theory‌ ‌\nFilter‌ ‌theory‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌sociological‌ ‌theory‌ ‌concerning‌ ‌dating‌ ‌and‌ ‌mate‌ ‌selection‌.‌ ‌Most‌ ‌often,‌ ‌this‌ ‌takes‌ ‌place‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌homogamy,‌ ‌as‌ ‌people‌ ‌seek‌ ‌to‌ ‌date‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌marry‌ ‌only‌ ‌those‌ ‌similar‌ ‌to‌ ‌them‌ ‌(characteristics‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌often‌ ‌taken‌ ‌into‌ ‌account‌ ‌are‌ ‌age,‌ ‌race,‌ ‌social‌ ‌status‌ ‌and‌ ‌religion).‌ ‌ ‌\n●Homogamy‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌idea‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌between‌ ‌spouses‌ ‌who‌ ‌share‌ ‌similar‌ ‌characteristics,‌ ‌where‌ ‌\n●Heterogamy‌ ‌denotes‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌between‌ ‌spouses‌ ‌of‌ ‌different‌ ‌characteristics.‌ ‌ ‌\nThe‌ ‌idea‌ ‌of‌ ‌\"opposites‌ ‌attract:‌ ‌‌is‌ ‌heterogamous‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌idea‌ ‌that‌ ‌one‌ ‌spouse‌ ‌has‌ ‌complementing,‌ ‌not‌ ‌similar‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nother.‌ ‌\n ‌\nThe‌ ‌process‌ ‌of‌ ‌filtering‌ ‌narrows‌ ‌down‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌until‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌only‌ ‌one‌ ‌acceptable‌ ‌partner‌ ‌remaining‌ ‌These‌ ‌filters‌ ‌involve:‌ ‌\n1.Field‌ ‌of‌ ‌Eligibles‌-‌ ‌Involves‌ ‌possible‌ ‌options.‌ ‌Looks‌ ‌at‌ ‌who‌ ‌is‌ ‌out‌ ‌there‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌general‌ ‌population.‌ ‌\n2.Propinquity‌ ‌Filter‌-‌ ‌Provides‌ ‌an‌ ‌available‌ ‌group‌ ‌to‌ ‌choose‌ ‌from.‌ ‌Who‌ ‌happens‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌close‌ ‌to‌ ‌us‌ ‌in‌ ‌proximity.‌ ‌\n3.Attraction‌ ‌Filter‌-‌ ‌Judgement‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌appearance‌ ‌and‌ ‌individual‌ ‌characteristics.‌ ‌\n4.Homogamy‌ ‌Filter‌-‌ ‌How‌ ‌similar‌ ‌age,‌ ‌race,‌ ‌education,‌ ‌socio-economic‌ ‌class,‌ ‌religion‌ ‌are‌ ‌\n5.Compatibility‌ ‌Filter‌-‌ ‌Involves‌ ‌attitudes,‌ ‌values,‌ ‌needs,‌ ‌habits,‌ ‌and‌ ‌roles.‌ ‌Similarities‌ ‌to‌ ‌these‌ ‌qualities‌ ‌are‌ ‌judged.‌ ‌\n6.Trial‌ ‌Filter-‌‌ ‌Commitment.‌ ‌Tests‌ ‌compatibility‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌previous‌ ‌filters.‌ ‌\n7.Decision‌ ‌Filter‌-‌ ‌Final‌ ‌decision‌ ‌is‌ ‌made‌ ‌here‌ ‌to‌ ‌see‌ ‌if‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌right‌ ‌choice.‌ ‌\n8.‌ ‌Marriage‌ ‌\n368‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nUniversality‌ ‌of‌ ‌Marriage‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌established‌ ‌fact‌ ‌that‌ ‌every‌ ‌human‌ ‌society,‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌simple‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌complex‌ ‌has‌ ‌the‌ ‌Institution‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌however‌ ‌cross‌ ‌\ncultural‌ ‌variations‌ ‌exist‌ ‌regarding‌ ‌form‌ ‌and‌ ‌nature.‌ ‌\n●How‌ ‌does‌ ‌one‌ ‌marry?‌ ‌Whom‌ ‌do‌ ‌they‌ ‌marry?‌ ‌How‌ ‌many‌ ‌people‌ ‌at‌ ‌a‌ ‌time‌ ‌the‌ ‌Marry?‌ ‌\nAnswers‌ ‌to‌ ‌this‌ ‌varies‌ ‌from‌ ‌society‌ ‌to‌ ‌society.‌ ‌the‌ ‌religion,‌ ‌communities‌ ‌caste‌ ‌and‌ ‌tribes‌ ‌\n●Example:‌ ‌‌Among‌ ‌Bhils‌ ‌(Tribal‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌Rajasthan)‌ ‌during‌ ‌Holi‌ ‌festival,‌ ‌young‌ ‌men‌ ‌and‌ ‌women‌ ‌dance‌ ‌around‌ ‌a‌ ‌pool‌ ‌or‌ ‌a‌ ‌tree‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌top‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nwhich‌ ‌a‌ ‌coconut‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌piece‌ ‌of‌ ‌jaggery‌ ‌is‌ ‌tied.‌ ‌\nThe‌ ‌women‌ ‌made‌ ‌a‌ ‌circle‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌man‌ ‌made‌ ‌the‌ ‌outer‌ ‌circle.‌ ‌men‌ ‌try‌ ‌to‌ ‌enter‌ ‌the‌ ‌circle‌ ‌to‌ ‌eat‌ ‌jaggery‌ ‌and‌ ‌coconut‌ ‌but‌ ‌women‌ ‌resist‌ ‌.‌ ‌\nWhoever‌ ‌succeeds‌ ‌in‌ ‌that‌ ‌can‌ ‌choose‌ ‌his‌ ‌made‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌women.‌ ‌\n●So,‌ ‌the‌ ‌definition‌ ‌may‌ ‌not‌ ‌be‌ ‌applicable‌ ‌to‌ ‌all‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n369‌ ‌\n●Example:‌ ‌Nairs‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Malabar‌ ‌coast‌ ‌of‌ ‌India‌ ‌formerly‌ ‌noted‌ ‌for‌ ‌polyandry‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌matrilineal‌ ‌social‌ ‌organization.‌ ‌Among‌ ‌them‌ ‌husband‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nwife‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌live‌ ‌separately.‌ ‌they‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌have‌ ‌economic‌ ‌cooperation‌ ‌and‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌form‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌family.‌ ‌The‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌among‌ ‌\nNair‌ ‌is‌ ‌Peculiar‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌hardly‌ ‌fits‌ ‌into‌ ‌the‌ ‌definition‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌supposed‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌universal.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nLaws‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌(endogamy,‌ ‌exogamy,‌ ‌hypergamy,‌ ‌hypogamy,‌ ‌incest‌ ‌taboo);‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n370‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n1)‌ ‌Prescriptive‌ ‌rules:‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌guides‌ ‌whom‌ ‌a‌ ‌person‌ ‌can‌ ‌marry.‌‌ ‌It‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌do's‌ ‌and‌ ‌don'ts‌ ‌after‌ ‌marriage.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌‌Endogamy‌ ‌and‌ ‌Exogamy‌.‌ ‌\n●Endogamy:‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌rule,‌ ‌which‌ ‌compares‌ ‌the‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌‌to‌ ‌marry‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌caste,‌ ‌tribe‌ ‌and‌ ‌religion‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○All‌ ‌the‌ ‌tribes‌ ‌and‌ ‌castes‌ ‌groups‌ ‌are‌ ‌endogamous.‌ ‌This‌ ‌means‌ ‌a‌ ‌man‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌tribal‌ ‌identity‌ ‌marries‌ ‌a‌ ‌woman‌ ‌from‌ ‌his‌ ‌own‌ ‌\ntribal‌ ‌group.‌ ‌\n371‌ ‌\n○As‌ ‌per‌ ‌‌Conard‌ ‌Philip‌ ‌Kottak‌,‌ ‌an‌ ‌extreme‌ ‌example‌ ‌of‌ ‌Endogamy‌ ‌is‌ ‌India's‌ ‌caste‌ ‌system‌ ‌which‌ ‌was‌ ‌formally‌ ‌abolished‌ ‌in‌ ‌1949.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌belief‌ ‌that‌ ‌inter‌ ‌caste‌ ‌sexual‌ ‌Union‌ ‌leads‌ ‌to‌ ‌ritual‌ ‌impurity‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌higher‌ ‌caste‌ ‌partner‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌important‌ ‌in‌ ‌maintaining‌ ‌\nEndogamy‌.‌ ‌\n○Examples‌:‌ ‌The‌ ‌‌Yanomamo‌ ‌of‌ ‌Amazonia‌ ‌Practice‌ ‌a‌ ‌marked‌ ‌Endogamous‌ ‌system‌ ‌by‌ ‌forming‌ ‌settlements‌ ‌composed‌ ‌of‌ ‌shared‌ ‌\nlocalised‌ ‌lineage,‌ ‌without‌ ‌bound‌ ‌to‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌women‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌specific‌ ‌‌cross‌ ‌cousin‌ ‌marriage‌.‌ ‌\n○Village‌ ‌endogamy,‌ ‌though‌ ‌widespread,‌ ‌is‌ ‌far‌ ‌from‌ ‌universal.‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌Igbo‌ ‌of‌ ‌Nigeria‌,‌ ‌for‌ ‌example,‌ ‌follow‌ ‌the‌ ‌opposite‌ ‌tradition‌ ‌of‌ ‌village‌ ‌exogamy,‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌which‌ ‌inhabitants‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌\nsettlement,‌ ‌who‌ ‌are‌ ‌usually‌ ‌but‌ ‌not‌ ‌necessarily‌ ‌patrilineally‌ ‌related,‌ ‌are‌ ‌forbidden‌ ‌to‌ ‌marry.‌ ‌\n○Reason‌ ‌behind‌ ‌practicing‌ ‌Endogamy‌ ‌are:‌ ‌\n■People‌ ‌prefer‌ ‌their‌ ‌own‌ ‌group‌ ‌as‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌show‌ ‌more‌ ‌or‌ ‌less‌ ‌similar‌ ‌physical‌ ‌characteristics.‌ ‌\n■A‌ ‌group‌ ‌always‌ ‌wants‌ ‌to‌ ‌keep‌ ‌their‌ ‌human‌ ‌resource‌ ‌potential‌ ‌in‌ ‌original‌ ‌form.‌ ‌So‌ ‌the‌ ‌members‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌want‌ ‌to‌ ‌establish‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nmarriage‌ ‌relation‌ ‌with‌ ‌outsiders.‌ ‌\n■Conception‌ ‌of‌ ‌high‌ ‌and‌ ‌low‌ ‌rank‌ ‌plays‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌groups,‌ ‌which‌ ‌resists‌ ‌a‌ ‌high-rank‌ ‌group‌ ‌to‌ ‌develop‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nlow-rank‌ ‌group.‌ ‌\n■Dissimilarity‌ ‌in‌ ‌religion‌ ‌gets‌ ‌differences‌ ‌in‌ ‌norms‌ ‌and‌ ‌values,‌ ‌belief‌ ‌and‌ ‌practices.‌ ‌So‌ ‌people‌ ‌have‌ ‌to‌ ‌select‌ ‌their‌ ‌mates‌ ‌from‌ ‌\ntheir‌ ‌own‌ ‌religious‌ ‌group‌ ‌for‌ ‌maintaining‌ ‌good‌ ‌adjustment.‌ ‌\n■Geographical‌ ‌barriers‌ ‌between‌ ‌two‌ ‌places‌ ‌often‌ ‌discourage‌ ‌the‌ ‌group‌ ‌to‌ ‌establish‌ ‌marital‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌because‌ ‌of‌ ‌difficulties‌ ‌\nin‌ ‌access.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Exogamy:‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌general‌ ‌rule‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌‌which‌ ‌insists‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌person‌ ‌to‌ ‌marry‌ ‌outside‌ ‌his‌ ‌or‌ ‌her‌ ‌skin‌ ‌or‌ ‌territory.‌ ‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌family,‌ ‌Clan‌ ‌and‌ ‌lineage‌ ‌are‌ ‌some‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌exogamous‌ ‌groups‌ ‌and‌ ‌village‌ ‌exogamy‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌rule‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌North‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌\npopulation.‌ ‌\n●Emile‌ ‌Durkheim‌ ‌‌suggested‌ ‌that‌ ‌‌the‌ ‌origin‌ ‌of‌ ‌exogamy‌ ‌is‌ ‌religious‌.‌ ‌In‌ ‌his‌ ‌argument‌ ‌regarding‌ ‌the‌ ‌taboo‌ ‌against‌ ‌incest,‌ ‌‌Durkheim‌ ‌stated‌ ‌that‌ ‌\nits‌ ‌root‌ ‌lay‌ ‌the‌ ‌law‌ ‌of‌ ‌exogamy,‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌defined‌ ‌as‌ ‌prohibition‌ ‌to‌ ‌marry‌ ‌inside‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌clan,‌ ‌where‌ ‌a‌ ‌clan‌ ‌is‌ ‌defined‌ ‌by‌ ‌people‌ ‌who‌ ‌have‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌same‌ ‌totem.‌ ‌\n●Lewis‌ ‌Henry‌ ‌Morgan‌,‌ ‌in‌ ‌his‌ ‌work‌ ‌on‌ ‌kinship,‌ ‌maintained‌ ‌that‌ ‌exogamy‌ ‌was‌ ‌introduced‌ ‌to‌ ‌prevent‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌between‌ ‌blood‌ ‌relatives,‌ ‌\nespecially‌ ‌between‌ ‌brother‌ ‌and‌ ‌sister,‌ ‌which‌ ‌had‌ ‌been‌ ‌common‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌previous‌ ‌state‌ ‌of‌ ‌promiscuity.‌ ‌\n●Reason‌ ‌behind‌ ‌practicing‌ ‌Endogamy‌ ‌are:‌ ‌\n○Kin‌ ‌group‌ ‌members‌ ‌are‌ ‌considered‌ ‌as‌ ‌blood‌ ‌relatives.‌ ‌Therefore,‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌group‌ ‌member‌ ‌is‌ ‌considered‌ ‌as‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌\namong‌ ‌brothers‌ ‌and‌ ‌sisters.‌ ‌\n○Attractions‌ ‌get‌ ‌lost‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌close‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌small‌ ‌group.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌exogamy:‌ ‌\n○Gotra‌ ‌Exogamy:‌ ‌‌The‌ ‌Hindu‌ ‌practice‌ ‌of‌ ‌one‌ ‌marrying‌ ‌outside‌ ‌one's‌ ‌own‌ ‌gotra.‌ ‌\n372‌ ‌\n○Pravara‌ ‌Exogamy:‌ ‌Those‌ ‌who‌ ‌belong‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌pravara‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌marry‌ ‌among‌ ‌themselves.People‌ ‌who‌ ‌utter‌ ‌the‌ ‌name‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌\ncommon‌ ‌saint‌ ‌at‌ ‌religious‌ ‌functions‌ ‌are‌ ‌believed‌ ‌to‌ ‌belong‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌pravar.‌ ‌\n(The‌ ‌Hindu‌ ‌Marriage‌ ‌Disabilities‌ ‌Removal‌ ‌Act,‌ ‌1949‌ ‌has‌ ‌removed‌ ‌all‌ ‌restrictions‌ ‌regarding‌ ‌gotra‌ ‌and‌ ‌pravar‌ ‌exogamy.)‌ ‌\n○Village‌ ‌Exogamy:‌ ‌Many‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌tribes‌ ‌like‌ ‌Naga,Garo,Munda‌ ‌etc‌ ‌have‌ ‌the‌ ‌practice‌ ‌of‌ ‌marrying‌ ‌outside‌ ‌their‌ ‌village.The‌ ‌Naga‌ ‌tribe‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nAssam‌ ‌is‌ ‌divided‌ ‌into‌ ‌khels.‌ ‌Khel‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌name‌ ‌given‌ ‌to‌ ‌residents‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌place‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌people‌ ‌of‌ ‌one‌ ‌khel‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌inter-marry.‌ ‌\n○Pinda‌ ‌Exogamy:‌ ‌‌Those‌ ‌who‌ ‌belong‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌panda‌ ‌or‌ ‌sapinda(‌ ‌common‌ ‌parentage)‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌marry‌ ‌within‌ ‌themselves.‌ ‌\n ‌\nSociological‌ ‌theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌Exogamy‌ ‌include:‌ ‌\n●Role‌ ‌theory‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌position‌ ‌was‌ ‌elucidated‌ ‌by‌ ‌‌Malinowski‌ ‌and‌ ‌maintains‌ ‌that‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌and‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌systems‌ ‌are‌ ‌important‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌assignment‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nunambiguously‌ ‌defined‌ ‌and‌ ‌distributed‌ ‌social‌ ‌roles.‌ ‌ ‌\n○If‌ ‌close‌ ‌kin‌ ‌were‌ ‌allowed‌ ‌to‌ ‌intermarry,‌ ‌they‌ ‌would‌ ‌assume‌ ‌an‌ ‌alternative‌ ‌set‌ ‌of‌ ‌roles,‌ ‌rights,‌ ‌and‌ ‌responsibilities‌ ‌to‌ ‌those‌ ‌already‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nforce‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌resulting‌ ‌confusion‌ ‌and‌ ‌conflict‌ ‌over‌ ‌role‌ ‌definitions‌ ‌would‌ ‌undermine‌ ‌social‌ ‌order.‌ ‌\n●Alliance‌ ‌theory‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌position,‌ ‌championed‌ ‌by‌ ‌‌Levi-Strauss‌,‌ ‌maintains‌ ‌that‌ ‌small‌ ‌close-knit‌ ‌groups‌ ‌must‌ ‌force‌ ‌their‌ ‌members‌ ‌to‌ ‌marry‌ ‌outside‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌\nimmediate‌ ‌circle‌ ‌‌in‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌achieve‌ ‌the‌ ‌cultural,‌ ‌political,‌ ‌and‌ ‌economic‌ ‌benefits‌ ‌that‌ ‌a‌ ‌society‌ ‌builds‌ ‌on‌ ‌extensive‌ ‌interactions‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nalliances.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nAccording‌ ‌to‌ ‌considerations‌ ‌of‌ ‌exogamy‌ ‌and‌ ‌endogamy,‌ ‌we‌ ‌can‌ ‌represent‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌as‌ ‌determined‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌society's‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌\ndistance‌ ‌as‌ ‌indicated‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌following‌ ‌diagram:‌ ‌\n ‌\n373‌ ‌\n ‌\nThe‌ ‌diagram‌ ‌specifies‌ ‌three‌ ‌ranges‌ ‌of‌ ‌relationship:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●an‌ ‌inner‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌close‌ ‌relatives‌ ‌with‌ ‌whom‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌is‌ ‌forbidden,‌ ‌\n●an‌ ‌intermediate‌ ‌range‌ ‌of‌ ‌relatives,‌ ‌associates,‌ ‌and‌ ‌allies‌ ‌with‌ ‌whom‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌relations‌ ‌are‌ ‌encouraged‌ ‌and‌ ‌often‌ ‌required,‌ ‌and‌ ‌\n●an‌ ‌outer‌ ‌range‌ ‌of‌ ‌outsiders‌ ‌with‌ ‌whom‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌or‌ ‌other‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌interaction‌ ‌must‌ ‌be‌ ‌avoided.‌ ‌\n ‌\n374‌ ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌Addition:‌ ‌\nExo-Endogamy‌ ‌\n●Rani‌ ‌Khera,‌ ‌a‌ ‌village‌ ‌in‌ ‌India,‌ ‌has‌ ‌266‌ ‌married‌ ‌women‌ ‌who‌ ‌have‌ ‌come‌ ‌from‌ ‌about‌ ‌200‌ ‌different‌ ‌villages‌ ‌averaging‌ ‌between‌ ‌12‌ ‌and‌ ‌24‌ ‌\nmiles‌ ‌away.‌ ‌220‌ ‌local‌ ‌women‌ ‌had‌ ‌gone‌ ‌to‌ ‌200‌ ‌other‌ ‌villages‌ ‌to‌ ‌marry.‌ ‌ ‌\n●As‌ ‌a‌ ‌result‌ ‌of‌ ‌Exogamous‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌the‌ ‌150‌ ‌households‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌village‌ ‌were‌ ‌linked‌ ‌to‌ ‌400‌ ‌other‌ ‌villages.‌ ‌\nReciprocal‌ ‌exogamy‌ ‌\n●Reciprocal‌ ‌exogamy‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌social‌ ‌arrangement‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌groups‌ ‌are‌ ‌bound‌ ‌together‌ ‌through‌ ‌marital‌ ‌unions‌ ‌and‌ ‌kinship.‌ ‌Reciprocal‌ ‌exogamy‌ ‌\nis‌ ‌best‌ ‌illustrated‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌simplest‌ ‌system‌ ‌described‌ ‌by‌ ‌Levi-Strauss,‌ ‌restricted‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌between‌ ‌two‌ ‌exogamous‌ ‌kin‌ ‌groups.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌two‌ ‌groups‌ ‌are‌ ‌patrilocal‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌two‌ ‌families‌ ‌trade‌ ‌their‌ ‌kinswomen‌ ‌to‌ ‌obtain‌ ‌wives‌ ‌in‌ ‌return,‌ ‌building‌ ‌alliances‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌process.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Upon‌ ‌marriage,‌ ‌wife‌ ‌Ego‌ ‌moves‌ ‌to‌ ‌her‌ ‌husband's‌ ‌group.‌ ‌Because‌ ‌Ego‌ ‌breeds‌ ‌and‌ ‌raises‌ ‌her‌ ‌children‌ ‌there,‌ ‌the‌ ‌A‌ ‌family‌ ‌will‌ ‌have‌ ‌\ngrandchildren,‌ ‌nieces,‌ ‌nephews,‌ ‌and‌ ‌cousins‌ ‌living‌ ‌in‌ ‌group‌ ‌B,‌ ‌with‌ ‌whom‌ ‌they‌ ‌will‌ ‌come‌ ‌into‌ ‌contact‌ ‌when‌ ‌the‌ ‌two‌ ‌families,‌ ‌or‌ ‌the‌ ‌two‌ ‌\ngroups,‌ ‌visit‌ ‌each‌ ‌other.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Given‌ ‌that‌ ‌this‌ ‌process‌ ‌is‌ ‌generalized‌ ‌to‌ ‌all‌ ‌marriages‌ ‌and‌ ‌works‌ ‌in‌ ‌both‌ ‌directions,‌ ‌the‌ ‌resulting‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌network‌ ‌encompasses‌ ‌the‌ ‌two‌ ‌\nintermarrying‌ ‌groups‌ ‌which‌ ‌become‌ ‌quite‌ ‌intricately‌ ‌connected.‌ ‌\n375‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n2)‌ ‌Preferential‌ ‌rules:‌ ‌\n●Under‌ ‌this‌ ‌rule‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌a‌ ‌person‌ ‌is‌ ‌‌expected‌ ‌to‌ ‌prefer‌ ‌for‌ ‌certain‌ ‌categories‌ ‌of‌ ‌relatives‌ ‌or‌ ‌other‌ ‌categories‌ ‌of‌ ‌relatives‌ ‌for‌ ‌marriage.‌ ‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌preferential‌ ‌mating‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌classified‌ ‌as‌ ‌follows:-‌ ‌\n○Cross-cousin‌ ‌marriage.‌ ‌\n○Parallel-cousin‌ ‌marriage.‌ ‌\n○Sororate‌ ‌\n○Levirate‌ ‌\n○Uncle-Niece‌ ‌Marriage‌ ‌\n ‌\n376‌ ‌\n ‌\nCross-cousin‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌‌marriage‌ ‌which‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌cousins‌ ‌whose‌ ‌parents‌ ‌are‌ ‌brother‌ ‌and‌ ‌sister.‌ ‌\n■This‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌is‌ ‌found‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌prevalent‌ ‌among‌ ‌most‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌tribes‌ ‌of‌ ‌‌North-East‌ ‌India‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌Garos,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Khasis,‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nKukis,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Karbis,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Noctes,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Nagas‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌The‌ ‌Gonds,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Oraons,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Baigas‌ ‌and‌ ‌some‌ ‌other‌ ‌tribes‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌rest‌ ‌of‌ ‌India‌ ‌\npractise‌ ‌this‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage.‌ ‌\n■Virtually‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌tribes‌ ‌of‌ ‌N‌orth‌ ‌and‌ ‌Central‌ ‌Melanesia‌ ‌practise‌ ‌cross‌ ‌cousin‌ ‌marriage.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌practised‌ ‌in‌ ‌Ceylon‌ ‌(Sri‌ ‌\nLanka),‌ ‌Australia,‌ ‌Polynesia,‌ ‌South‌ ‌and‌ ‌East‌ ‌Africa,‌ ‌Siberia‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n■Marriage‌ ‌with‌ ‌mother’s‌ ‌brother’s‌ ‌daughter‌ ‌is‌ ‌called‌ ‌Matrilateral‌ ‌cross-cousin‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌and‌ ‌that‌ ‌with‌ ‌father’s‌ ‌sister’s‌ ‌daughter‌ ‌\nis‌ ‌termed‌ ‌as‌ ‌patrilateral‌ ‌cross-cousin‌ ‌marriage.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Father's‌ ‌sister‌ ‌children‌ ‌(‌ ‌Paternal‌ ‌cross‌ ‌cousin)‌ ‌\n●Mother's‌ ‌brother‌ ‌children‌ ‌(Maternal‌ ‌cross‌ ‌cousin)‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌Trobriand‌ ‌Islanders‌ ‌of‌ ‌Melanesia‌ ‌permit‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌only‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌father's‌ ‌sister’s‌ ‌daughter.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nThere‌ ‌are‌ ‌two‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌cross-cousin‌ ‌marriages:‌ ‌ ‌\n(a)‌ ‌Symmetrical‌ ‌\n○When‌ ‌both‌ ‌mother’s‌ ‌brother’s‌ ‌daughter‌ ‌and‌ ‌father’s‌ ‌sister’s‌ ‌daughter‌ ‌are‌ ‌acceptable‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌mate,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌called‌ ‌a‌ ‌‌Symmetrical‌ ‌cross-cousin‌ ‌\nmarriage.‌‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌termed‌ ‌as‌ ‌bilateral‌ ‌cross-cousin‌ ‌marriage.‌ ‌ ‌\n377‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌Assam‌ ‌symmetrical‌ ‌cross-cousin‌ ‌marriages‌ ‌are‌ ‌prevalent.‌ ‌Similarly‌ ‌the‌ ‌Dravidians‌ ‌practise‌ ‌symmetrical‌ ‌cross-cousin‌ ‌marriage.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌ ‌(b)‌ ‌Asymmetrical.‌ ‌\n●Asymmetrical‌ ‌cross-cousin‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌one‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌which,‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌is‌ ‌preferred‌ ‌with‌ ‌‌either‌ ‌the‌ ‌mother's‌ ‌brother’s‌ ‌daughter‌ ‌or‌ ‌\nfather’s‌ ‌sister’s‌ ‌daughter‌ ‌and‌ ‌not‌ ‌with‌ ‌both.‌ ‌\n●That‌ ‌is‌ ‌if‌ ‌one‌ ‌marries‌ ‌mother’s‌ ‌brother’s‌ ‌daughter,‌ ‌he‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌marry‌ ‌father’‌ ‌sister’s‌ ‌daughter‌ ‌and‌ ‌vice‌ ‌versa.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌Murngins‌ ‌of‌ ‌Australia‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌Miwork‌ ‌of‌ ‌California‌ ‌practise‌ ‌asymmetrical‌ ‌cross-cousin‌ ‌marriage.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nRationale‌ ‌:‌ ‌\n●Cross-cousin‌ ‌marriages‌ ‌are‌ ‌often‌ ‌devised‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌balance‌ ‌against‌ ‌the‌ ‌high‌ ‌bride‌ ‌price,‌ ‌the‌ ‌bargaining‌ ‌of‌ ‌price‌ ‌is‌ ‌often‌ ‌minimized‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nfamiliar‌ ‌kin.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Moreover,‌ ‌the‌ ‌amount‌ ‌lost‌ ‌in‌ ‌paying‌ ‌bride-price‌ ‌for‌ ‌getting‌ ‌a‌ ‌bride‌ ‌is‌ ‌regained‌ ‌in‌ ‌due‌ ‌course‌ ‌when‌ ‌a‌ ‌girl‌ ‌from‌ ‌his‌ ‌family‌ ‌has‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌given‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nmarriage‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌family.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌simple‌ ‌implication‌ ‌here‌ ‌is‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌bride-price‌ ‌paid‌ ‌for‌ ‌Ego’s‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌would‌ ‌be‌ ‌returned‌ ‌to‌ ‌his‌ ‌family‌ ‌when‌ ‌a‌ ‌daughter‌ ‌would‌ ‌marry‌ ‌her‌ ‌\nmother’s‌ ‌brother’s‌ ‌son.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Gonds‌ ‌of‌ ‌Madhya‌ ‌Pradesh‌ ‌express‌ ‌mother’s‌ ‌brother’s‌ ‌daughter‌ ‌as‌ ‌‘dudhlautawa’,‌ ‌i.e.,‌ ‌return‌ ‌of‌ ‌milk.‌ ‌\n ‌\nParallel-cousin‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌\n378‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌between‌ ‌children‌ ‌of‌ ‌siblings‌ ‌of‌ ‌same‌ ‌sex.‌ ‌i.e.‌ ‌the‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌of‌ ‌man‌ ‌with‌ ‌either‌ ‌his‌ ‌father’s‌ ‌brother’s‌ ‌daughter‌ ‌or‌ ‌\nmother’s‌ ‌sister’s‌ ‌daughter.‌ ‌\n○Example‌,‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌prevalent‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Semitic‌ ‌Arabs‌ ‌and‌ ‌also‌ ‌found‌ ‌amongst‌ ‌the‌ ‌Muslim‌ ‌of‌ ‌India.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌practised‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌Riangs‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nTripura.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌‌Kurds‌ ‌of‌ ‌eastern‌ ‌and‌ ‌southeastern‌ ‌Turkey‌‌ ‌still‌ ‌continue‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌practice‌ ‌of‌ ‌parallel‌ ‌cousin‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●It‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌said‌ ‌that‌ ‌marriages‌ ‌with‌ ‌close‌ ‌relatives‌ ‌lead‌ ‌to‌ ‌fewer‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌issues.‌ ‌That‌ ‌is‌ ‌why‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌kind‌ ‌is‌ ‌discarded‌ ‌in‌ ‌many‌ ‌\nsocieties.‌ ‌\n●Rationale‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌this‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌‌marriage‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌Muslims,‌ ‌women‌ ‌traditionally‌ ‌inherit‌ ‌the‌ ‌property,‌ ‌perhaps‌ ‌to‌ ‌control‌ ‌the‌ ‌property‌ ‌devolution,‌ ‌they‌ ‌\npreferred‌ ‌parallel-cousin‌ ‌marriage‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Again,‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌Bedwins‌ ‌of‌ ‌Arab,‌ ‌this‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌is‌ ‌very‌ ‌popular.‌ ‌The‌ ‌Bedwins‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌nomadic‌ ‌people.‌ ‌‌Such‌ ‌marriages‌ ‌help‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nkeep‌ ‌their‌ ‌males‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌band‌ ‌and‌ ‌so‌ ‌manpower‌ ‌is‌ ‌protected‌ ‌for‌ ‌fighting‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌purpose‌ ‌of‌ ‌defence.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nSororate‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌custom‌ ‌by‌ ‌which‌ ‌a‌ ‌man‌ ‌is‌ ‌‌obliged‌ ‌to‌ ‌marry‌ ‌the‌ ‌sister‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌deceased‌ ‌wife‌.‌ ‌In‌ ‌some‌ ‌cases‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌mandatory‌ ‌and‌ ‌in‌ ‌others,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌performed‌ ‌\non‌ ‌a‌ ‌permissive‌ ‌basis.‌ ‌\n379‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○Sororate‌ ‌is‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌types:‌ ‌\n(i)‌ ‌‌Senior‌ ‌sororate‌-‌ ‌When‌ ‌the‌ ‌bereaved‌ ‌husband‌ ‌marries‌ ‌his‌ ‌‌deceased‌ ‌wife’s‌ ‌elder‌ ‌sister‌,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌called‌ ‌Senior‌ ‌Sororate‌ ‌and‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌very‌ ‌\nlimited‌ ‌in‌ ‌its‌ ‌distribution.‌ ‌\n ‌\n(ii)‌ ‌‌Junior‌ ‌sororate‌-‌ ‌When‌ ‌the‌ ‌bereaved‌ ‌husband‌ ‌marries‌ ‌his‌ ‌‌deceased‌ ‌wife’s‌ ‌younger‌ ‌sister,‌ ‌the‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌is‌ ‌called‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nJunior‌ ‌Sororate,‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌‌prevalent‌ ‌in‌ ‌many‌ ‌parts‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌world.‌ ‌Hindus,‌ ‌Muslims,‌ ‌and‌ ‌many‌ ‌tribes‌ ‌of‌ ‌India‌ ‌are‌ ‌found‌ ‌to‌ ‌practise‌ ‌\nsororate‌.‌ ‌ ‌\nIt‌ ‌is‌ ‌practised‌ ‌by‌ ‌v‌irtually‌ ‌every‌ ‌tribe‌ ‌of‌ ‌North‌ ‌America‌ ‌outside‌ ‌the‌ ‌Pueblo‌ ‌area‌ ‌and‌ ‌is‌ ‌found‌ ‌widely‌ ‌distributed‌ ‌throughout‌ ‌the‌ ‌world.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nLevirate‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌custom‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌a‌ ‌woman‌ ‌is‌ ‌o‌bliged‌ ‌to‌ ‌marry‌ ‌the‌ ‌brother‌ ‌of‌ ‌her‌ ‌deceased‌ ‌husband‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌is‌ ‌practised‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌natives‌ ‌of‌ ‌Australia,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Biblical‌ ‌Hebrews,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Incas,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Muslims‌ ‌of‌ ‌India,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Kukis,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Lushais,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Nagas,‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nKarbis,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Vedas,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Chukchee‌ ‌of‌ ‌Siberia‌ ‌etc‌.‌ ‌\n380‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Levirate‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌types:‌ ‌\n(i)‌ ‌If‌ ‌the‌ ‌widow‌ ‌daughter‌ ‌marries‌ ‌her‌ ‌younger‌ ‌brother‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌called‌ ‌Junior‌ ‌Levirate.‌ ‌\nThis‌ ‌is‌ ‌found‌ ‌to‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌practised‌ ‌by‌ ‌Australians;‌ ‌the‌ ‌Biblical‌ ‌Hebrews,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Incas,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Muslims‌ ‌of‌ ‌India‌ ‌the‌ ‌Kukis,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Lushais,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Nagas,‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌Karbis‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌Veddas‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n ‌\n(ii)‌ ‌If‌ ‌the‌ ‌widow‌ ‌remarries‌ ‌her‌ ‌husband's‌ ‌elder‌ ‌brother‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌called‌ ‌Senior‌ ‌Levirate.‌ ‌\nThe‌ ‌Bhumijas‌ ‌of‌ ‌Orissa,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Hos,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Panions‌ ‌(south‌ ‌India),‌ ‌the‌ ‌Kirghiz,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Turks,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Mongloids‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌practise‌ ‌this‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage.‌ ‌\n ‌\nUncle-Niece‌ ‌Marriage/Avunculate‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌\n○An‌ ‌avunculate‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌parent's‌ ‌sibling‌ ‌or‌ ‌with‌ ‌one's‌ ‌sibling's‌ ‌child—i.e.,‌ ‌between‌ ‌an‌ ‌uncle‌ ‌or‌ ‌aunt‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌\nniece‌ ‌or‌ ‌nephew‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Such‌ ‌a‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌may‌ ‌occur‌ ‌between‌ ‌biological‌ ‌(consanguine)‌ ‌relatives‌ ‌or‌ ‌between‌ ‌persons‌ ‌related‌ ‌by‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌(affinity).‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌some‌ ‌countries,‌ ‌avunculate‌ ‌marriages‌ ‌are‌ ‌prohibited‌ ‌by‌ ‌law,‌ ‌while‌ ‌in‌ ‌others‌ ‌marriages‌ ‌between‌ ‌such‌ ‌biological‌ ‌relatives‌ ‌are‌ ‌both‌ ‌\nlegal‌ ‌and‌ ‌common,‌ ‌though‌ ‌now‌ ‌far‌ ‌less‌ ‌common.‌ ‌\n○Avunculate‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌is‌ ‌permitted‌ ‌in‌ ‌Norway,‌ ‌Chile,‌ ‌Argentina,‌ ‌Australia,Canada,Finland,Malaysia,The‌ ‌Netherlands,and‌ ‌Russia.‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌the‌ ‌United‌ ‌States‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌permitted‌ ‌in‌ ‌some‌ ‌circumstances‌ ‌in‌ ‌two‌ ‌states.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Avunculate‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌preferred‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌union‌ ‌in‌ ‌some‌ ‌pre-modern‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌‌Marriages‌ ‌between‌ ‌such‌ ‌close‌ ‌relatives‌ ‌were‌ ‌\nfrequent‌ ‌in‌ ‌Ancient‌ ‌Egypt,‌ ‌at‌ ‌least‌ ‌among‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌ruling‌ ‌dynasties.‌ ‌\n○Such‌ ‌marriages‌ ‌have‌ ‌traditionally‌ ‌been‌ ‌‌illegal‌ ‌in‌ ‌Islamic‌ ‌societies‌ ‌and‌ ‌are‌ ‌regarded‌ ‌as‌ ‌prohibited‌ ‌by‌ ‌Islam.‌ ‌\n381‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n3)‌ ‌Proscriptive‌ ‌rules:‌ ‌\nA‌ ‌proscriptive‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌system‌ ‌is‌ ‌one‌ ‌that‌ ‌specifies‌ ‌‌whom‌ ‌Ego‌ ‌may‌ ‌not‌ ‌marry,‌ ‌leaving‌ ‌a‌ ‌broad‌ ‌choice‌ ‌of‌ ‌others.‌ ‌\n ‌\nIncest‌ ‌taboo‌ ‌\n●Incest‌ ‌taboo‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌universal‌ ‌norm‌ ‌for‌ ‌almost‌ ‌all‌ ‌societies,‌ ‌which‌ ‌pertains‌ ‌to‌ ‌restrictions‌ ‌in‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌and‌ ‌sexual‌ ‌relations‌ ‌among‌ ‌certain‌ ‌\ncategories‌ ‌of‌ ‌close‌ ‌relatives‌ ‌generally‌ ‌‌related‌ ‌by‌ ‌blood‌ ‌like‌ ‌father‌ ‌and‌ ‌daughter,‌ ‌mother‌ ‌and‌ ‌son‌ ‌and‌ ‌sometimes‌ ‌also‌ ‌parallel‌ ‌cousins.‌ ‌ ‌\n382‌ ‌\n●Though,‌ ‌incest‌ ‌taboo‌ ‌was‌ ‌not‌ ‌prevalent‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌earlier‌ ‌Greek‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌Hawaiian‌ ‌royal‌ ‌families‌ ‌where‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌prescribed‌ ‌norm‌ ‌for‌ ‌\nmarriage.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌these‌ ‌ancient‌ ‌royal‌ ‌families‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌believed‌ ‌that‌ ‌royalty‌ ‌could‌ ‌only‌ ‌be‌ ‌passed‌ ‌down‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌child‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌royal‌ ‌family‌ ‌members,‌ ‌usually‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nbrother‌ ‌and‌ ‌sister.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌‌Tallensi‌ ‌of‌ ‌Ghana‌ ‌also‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌strongly‌ ‌prescribe‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌norm‌ ‌of‌ ‌incest‌ ‌taboo‌ ‌between‌ ‌brother‌ ‌and‌ ‌sister‌ ‌while‌ ‌a‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌between‌ ‌\na‌ ‌man‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌wife‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌lineage‌ ‌mate‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌unpardonable‌ ‌sin.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌taboo‌ ‌of‌ ‌incest‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌discussed‌ ‌by‌ ‌many‌ ‌social‌ ‌scientists.‌ ‌Anthropologists‌ ‌attest‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌exists‌ ‌in‌ ‌most‌ ‌cultures.‌ ‌ ‌\n○As‌ ‌inbreeding‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌generation‌ ‌would‌ ‌produce‌ ‌expression‌ ‌of‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌traits,‌ ‌the‌ ‌prohibition‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌discussed‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌\npossible‌ ‌functional‌ ‌response‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌requirement‌ ‌of‌ ‌culling‌ ‌those‌ ‌born‌ ‌deformed,‌ ‌or‌ ‌with‌ ‌undesirable‌ ‌traits.‌ ‌\n ‌\nRoyalty‌ ‌and‌ ‌nobility‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌royal‌ ‌and‌ ‌‌noble‌ ‌families‌ ‌of‌ ‌Europe‌ ‌have‌ ‌close‌ ‌blood‌ ‌ties‌ ‌which‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌strengthened‌ ‌by‌ ‌royal‌ ‌intermarriage.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Examples‌ ‌abound‌ ‌in‌ ‌every‌ ‌royal‌ ‌family;‌ ‌in‌ ‌particular,‌ ‌the‌ ‌ruling‌ ‌dynasties‌ ‌of‌ ‌Spain‌ ‌and‌ ‌Portugal‌ ‌were‌ ‌very‌ ‌inbred.‌ ‌Several‌ ‌Habsburgs,‌ ‌\nBourbons,‌ ‌and‌ ‌Wittelsbachs‌ ‌married‌ ‌aunts,‌ ‌uncles,‌ ‌nieces,‌ ‌and‌ ‌nephews.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Even‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌British‌ ‌royal‌ ‌family,‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌very‌ ‌moderate‌ ‌in‌ ‌comparison,‌ ‌there‌ ‌has‌ ‌scarcely‌ ‌been‌ ‌a‌ ‌monarch‌ ‌in‌ ‌300‌ ‌years‌ ‌who‌ ‌has‌ ‌not‌ ‌married‌ ‌\na‌ ‌(near‌ ‌or‌ ‌distant)‌ ‌relative.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Indeed,‌ ‌Queen‌ ‌Elizabeth‌ ‌II‌ ‌and‌ ‌her‌ ‌husband‌ ‌Prince‌ ‌Philip,‌ ‌Duke‌ ‌of‌ ‌Edinburgh‌ ‌are‌ ‌second‌ ‌cousins‌ ‌once‌ ‌removed,‌ ‌both‌ ‌being‌ ‌descended‌ ‌\nfrom‌ ‌King‌ ‌Christian‌ ‌IX‌ ‌of‌ ‌Denmark.‌ ‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌are‌ ‌also‌ ‌third‌ ‌cousins‌ ‌as‌ ‌great-great-grandchildren‌ ‌of‌ ‌Queen‌ ‌Victoria‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌United‌ ‌Kingdom.‌ ‌European‌ ‌monarchies‌ ‌did‌ ‌avoid‌ ‌\nbrother-sister‌ ‌marriages,‌ ‌though‌ ‌Jean‌ ‌V‌ ‌of‌ ‌Armagnac‌ ‌was‌ ‌an‌ ‌exception.‌ ‌\n ‌\nOther‌ ‌examples‌ ‌of‌ ‌royal‌ ‌family‌ ‌intermarriage‌ ‌include:‌ ‌\n●Some‌ ‌Egyptian‌ ‌Pharaohs‌ ‌and‌ ‌Peruvian‌ ‌Sapa‌ ‌Incas‌ ‌married‌ ‌their‌ ‌sisters;‌ ‌in‌ ‌both‌ ‌cases‌ ‌we‌ ‌find‌ ‌a‌ ‌special‌ ‌combination‌ ‌between‌ ‌endogamy‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌polygamy.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Normally‌ ‌the‌ ‌son‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌old‌ ‌ruler‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌ruler's‌ ‌oldest‌ ‌(half-)sister‌ ‌became‌ ‌the‌ ‌new‌ ‌ruler.‌ ‌\n●Cleopatra‌ ‌and‌ ‌Ptolemy‌ ‌XIII,‌ ‌married‌ ‌and‌ ‌named‌ ‌co-rulers‌ ‌of‌ ‌ancient‌ ‌Egypt‌ ‌following‌ ‌their‌ ‌father's‌ ‌death,‌ ‌were‌ ‌brother‌ ‌and‌ ‌sister.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Not‌ ‌only‌ ‌this,‌ ‌but‌ ‌all‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Ptolemaic‌ ‌dynasty‌ ‌from‌ ‌Ptolemy‌ ‌II‌ ‌engaged‌ ‌in‌ ‌inbreeding‌ ‌among‌ ‌brothers‌ ‌and‌ ‌sisters,‌ ‌so‌ ‌as‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nkeep‌ ‌the‌ ‌Ptolemaic‌ ‌blood‌ ‌\"pure.\"‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌House‌ ‌of‌ ‌Habsburg‌ ‌‌inmarried‌ ‌very‌ ‌often.‌ ‌Famous‌ ‌in‌ ‌this‌ ‌case‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌Habsburger‌ ‌(Unter)Lippe‌ ‌(Habsburg‌ ‌jaw/Habsburg‌ ‌lip),‌ ‌typical‌ ‌for‌ ‌\nmany‌ ‌Habsburg‌ ‌relatives‌ ‌over‌ ‌a‌ ‌period‌ ‌of‌ ‌six‌ ‌centuries.‌ ‌\n●Mary,‌ ‌Queen‌ ‌of‌ ‌Scots‌ ‌and‌ ‌Henry‌ ‌Stuart,‌ ‌Lord‌ ‌Darnley‌ ‌were‌ ‌half‌ ‌first‌ ‌cousins,‌ ‌and‌ ‌third‌ ‌cousins‌ ‌once‌ ‌removed.‌ ‌\n●King‌ ‌Louis‌ ‌XIV‌ ‌of‌ ‌France‌ ‌and‌ ‌Infanta‌ ‌Maria‌ ‌Theresa‌ ‌of‌ ‌Spain‌ ‌were‌ ‌double‌ ‌first‌ ‌cousins.‌ ‌\n●King‌ ‌William‌ ‌III‌ ‌and‌ ‌Queen‌ ‌Mary‌ ‌II‌ ‌of‌ ‌England‌ ‌were‌ ‌first‌ ‌cousins.‌ ‌\n●Queen‌ ‌Victoria‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌United‌ ‌Kingdom‌ ‌and‌ ‌Prince‌ ‌Albert‌ ‌of‌ ‌Saxe-Coburg‌ ‌and‌ ‌Gotha‌ ‌were‌ ‌first‌ ‌cousins.‌ ‌\n●Intermarriage‌ ‌in‌ ‌European‌ ‌royal‌ ‌families‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌longer‌ ‌practiced‌ ‌as‌ ‌often‌ ‌as‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌past.‌ ‌ ‌\n383‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌is‌ ‌likely‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌changes‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌importance‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌method‌ ‌of‌ ‌forming‌ ‌political‌ ‌alliances‌ ‌through‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌ties‌ ‌between‌ ‌\nnobility.‌ ‌ ‌\n○These‌ ‌ties‌ ‌were‌ ‌often‌ ‌sealed‌ ‌only‌ ‌upon‌ ‌the‌ ‌birth‌ ‌of‌ ‌progeny‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌arranged‌ ‌marriage.‌ ‌Marriage‌ ‌was‌ ‌seen‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌union‌ ‌of‌ ‌lines‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nnobility,‌ ‌not‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌contract‌ ‌between‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌as‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌often‌ ‌seen‌ ‌today.‌ ‌ ‌\n○During‌ ‌the‌ ‌tumult‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌removal,‌ ‌sometimes‌ ‌by‌ ‌revolution,‌ ‌of‌ ‌most‌ ‌lines‌ ‌of‌ ‌nobility‌ ‌from‌ ‌state‌ ‌government,‌ ‌it‌ ‌became‌ ‌less‌ ‌important‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌marry‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌good‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌respective‌ ‌monarchies‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌states‌ ‌they‌ ‌governed.‌ ‌More‌ ‌marry‌ ‌for‌ ‌\"love,\"‌ ‌well‌ ‌illustrated‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌second‌ ‌\nmarriage‌ ‌of‌ ‌Prince‌ ‌Charles‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌United‌ ‌Kingdom.‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌necessarily‌ ‌the‌ ‌case‌ ‌that‌ ‌there‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌greater‌ ‌amount‌ ‌of‌ ‌inbreeding‌ ‌within‌ ‌royalty‌ ‌than‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌population‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌whole:‌ ‌It‌ ‌\nmay‌ ‌simply‌ ‌be‌ ‌better‌ ‌documented.‌ ‌‌Among‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌populations‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌isolated,‌ ‌opportunities‌ ‌for‌ ‌exogamy‌ ‌are‌ ‌reduced.‌ ‌Isolation‌ ‌\nmay‌ ‌be‌ ‌geographical,‌ ‌leading‌ ‌to‌ ‌inbreeding‌ ‌among‌ ‌peasants‌ ‌in‌ ‌remote‌ ‌mountain‌ ‌valleys.‌ ‌Or‌ ‌isolation‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌social,‌ ‌induced‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nlack‌ ‌of‌ ‌appropriate‌ ‌partners,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌Protestant‌ ‌princesses‌ ‌for‌ ‌Protestant‌ ‌royal‌ ‌heirs.‌ ‌Since‌ ‌the‌ ‌late‌ ‌Middle‌ ‌Ages,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌urban‌ ‌\nmiddle‌ ‌class‌ ‌that‌ ‌has‌ ‌had‌ ‌the‌ ‌widest‌ ‌opportunity‌ ‌for‌ ‌outbreeding.‌ ‌\n ‌\nHypergamy:‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌marriage‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌woman‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌man‌ ‌of‌ ‌higher‌ ‌Varna‌ ‌or‌ ‌superior‌ ‌caste‌ ‌or‌ ‌family.‌ ‌\n●Hypergamy‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌where‌ ‌a‌ ‌man‌ ‌gets‌ ‌his‌ ‌daughter‌ ‌married‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌person‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌or‌ ‌higher‌ ‌social‌ ‌and‌ ‌economical‌ ‌status.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌system‌ ‌is‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌stratified‌ ‌societies‌ ‌like‌ ‌Hindus,‌ ‌wherein‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌practiced‌ ‌to‌ ‌retain‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌status‌ ‌and‌
