‌prestige‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌group.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌Hindu‌ ‌society‌ ‌this‌ ‌is‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌‌Anuloma‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nHypogamy‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌of‌ ‌high‌ ‌caste‌ ‌Woman‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌low‌ ‌caste‌ ‌man‌ ‌\n●Hypogamy‌ ‌is‌ ‌just‌ ‌the‌ ‌opposite‌ ‌of‌ ‌Hypergamy.‌ ‌Here,‌ ‌a‌ ‌man‌ ‌gets‌ ‌his‌ ‌daughter‌ ‌married‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌man‌ ‌of‌ ‌either‌ ‌same‌ ‌or‌ ‌lower‌ ‌social‌ ‌and‌ ‌\neconomical‌ ‌status‌ ‌than‌ ‌his.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌Hindu‌ ‌society‌ ‌this‌ ‌is‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌‌Pratiloma‌.‌ ‌Pratiloma/‌ ‌hypogamy‌ ‌refer‌ ‌to‌ ‌inter-caste‌ ‌marriages‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌approved‌ ‌socially.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n384‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nType‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌(monogamy,‌ ‌polygamy,‌ ‌polyandry,‌ ‌group‌ ‌marriage)‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n1)‌ ‌Monogamy‌ ‌\n385‌ ‌\n●Monogamy‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌practice‌ ‌is‌ ‌to‌ ‌have‌ ‌only‌ ‌one‌ ‌spouse‌ ‌at‌ ‌one‌ ‌time‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nIt‌ ‌has‌ ‌two‌ ‌subforms:‌ ‌\n●Serial‌ ‌Monogamy:‌ ‌‌Serial‌ ‌monogamy‌ ‌pertains‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌state‌ ‌where‌ ‌a‌ ‌man‌ ‌has‌ ‌a‌ ‌series‌ ‌of‌ ‌wives‌ ‌one‌ ‌after‌ ‌the‌ ‌other,‌ ‌but‌ ‌only‌ ‌one‌ ‌wife‌ ‌at‌ ‌any‌ ‌\ngiven‌ ‌point‌ ‌of‌ ‌time.‌ ‌\nFor‌ ‌example-‌ ‌Semangs‌ ‌of‌ ‌Malay‌ ‌forest‌ ‌in‌ ‌Malaysia‌ ‌limit‌ ‌themselves‌ ‌to‌ ‌one‌ ‌wife.‌ ‌in‌ ‌case‌ ‌of‌ ‌divorce‌ ‌or‌ ‌death‌ ‌of‌ ‌wife.‌ ‌Simmons‌ ‌Mary‌ ‌again‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌again‌ ‌and‌ ‌lead‌ ‌a‌ ‌monogamous‌ ‌life‌ ‌\n●Non‌ ‌serial‌ ‌Monogamy:‌ ‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌where‌ ‌a‌ ‌man‌ ‌has‌ ‌a‌ ‌single‌ ‌wife‌ ‌throughout‌ ‌his‌ ‌life.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n2)‌ ‌Polygamy‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌has‌ ‌multiple‌ ‌spouse‌ ‌at‌ ‌any‌ ‌time:‌ ‌\nIt‌ ‌has‌ ‌three‌ ‌some‌ ‌form:‌ ‌\n●Polygyny:‌ ‌‌In‌ ‌which‌ ‌male‌ ‌has‌ ‌multiple‌ ‌wives‌ ‌at‌ ‌any‌ ‌time.‌ ‌Naga,‌ ‌Baiga,‌ ‌and‌ ‌Gond‌ ‌are‌ ‌some‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌tribes‌ ‌who‌ ‌practice‌ ‌Polygyny.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●It‌ ‌exist‌ ‌in‌ ‌two‌ ‌types:‌ ‌\n○Sororal‌ ‌polygyny:‌  ‌In‌ ‌which‌ ‌multiple‌ ‌wives‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌male‌ ‌are‌ ‌sisters.‌ ‌practice‌ ‌in‌ ‌Tribes‌ ‌of‌ ‌Andaman‌ ‌Islands.‌ ‌Kanikkar‌ ‌and‌ ‌Urali‌ ‌tribes‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nKerala.‌ ‌\n386‌ ‌\n○Non‌ ‌sororal‌ ‌polygyny:‌ ‌ ‌In‌ ‌which‌ ‌multiple‌ ‌wives‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌mail‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌sisters.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Polyandry:‌ ‌In‌ ‌which‌ ‌a‌ ‌woman‌ ‌has‌ ‌multiple‌ ‌husbands‌ ‌at‌ ‌a‌ ‌given‌ ‌point‌ ‌of‌ ‌time.‌ ‌shortage‌ ‌of‌ ‌women‌ ‌was‌ ‌explained‌ ‌as‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌reasons‌ ‌for‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌practice‌ ‌of‌ ‌polyandry.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●It‌ ‌exist‌ ‌in‌ ‌to‌ ‌some‌ ‌form:‌ ‌\n○Fraternal‌ ‌polyandry‌ ‌(Adelphic‌ ‌polyandry):‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌multiple‌ ‌husbands‌ ‌of‌ ‌women‌ ‌are‌ ‌brothers.‌ ‌Widely‌ ‌practised‌ ‌in‌ ‌Sirmaur‌ ‌district‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌HP.‌ ‌\nPolyandry‌ ‌is‌ ‌believed‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌more‌ ‌likely‌ ‌in‌ ‌societies‌ ‌with‌ ‌scarce‌ ‌environmental‌ ‌resources.‌ ‌...‌ ‌For‌ ‌example,‌ ‌polyandry‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Himalayan‌ ‌\nmountains‌ ‌is‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌scarcity‌ ‌of‌ ‌land.‌ ‌The‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌brothers‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌family‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌wife‌ ‌allows‌ ‌family‌ ‌land‌ ‌to‌ ‌remain‌ ‌\nintact‌ ‌and‌ ‌undivided.‌ ‌\n○Non-Fraternal‌ ‌polyandry‌ ‌(Non-Adelphic‌ ‌polyandry):‌ ‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌husbands‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌brothers.‌ ‌Toda‌ ‌tribe‌ ‌of‌ ‌Nilgiri‌ ‌Hills.‌ ‌\n ‌\n387‌ ‌\n●Polygynandry:‌ ‌Man‌ ‌has‌ ‌multiple‌ ‌wives‌ ‌and‌ ‌woman‌ ‌has‌ ‌multiple‌ ‌husbands‌ ‌at‌ ‌any‌ ‌given‌ ‌point‌ ‌of‌ ‌time.‌ ‌Coexistence‌ ‌of‌ ‌polygamy‌ ‌and‌ ‌\npolyandry‌ ‌\n ‌\nOther‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌Marriage:‌ ‌\n●Group‌ ‌Marriage‌-Group‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌or‌ ‌conjoint‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌marital‌ ‌arrangement‌ ‌where‌ ‌three‌ ‌or‌ ‌more‌ ‌adults‌ ‌enter‌ ‌into‌ ‌sexual,‌ ‌affective,‌ ‌\nromantic,‌ ‌or‌ ‌otherwise‌ ‌intimate‌ ‌short-‌ ‌or‌ ‌long-term‌ ‌partnerships,‌ ‌and‌ ‌share‌ ‌in‌ ‌any‌ ‌combination‌ ‌of‌ ‌finances,‌ ‌residences,‌ ‌care‌ ‌or‌ ‌kin‌ ‌work.‌ ‌\nGroup‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌is‌ ‌considered‌ ‌a‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌polygamy.‌ ‌\n●Fictive‌ ‌Marriage‌-‌ ‌Legal‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌that‌ ‌allows‌ ‌both‌ ‌partners‌ ‌to‌ ‌acquire‌ ‌social‌ ‌benefits‌ ‌without‌ ‌no‌ ‌family‌ ‌being‌ ‌set‌ ‌up.‌ ‌e.g.,‌ ‌US‌ ‌Nationals‌ ‌&‌ ‌\nimmigrants‌ ‌sometimes‌ ‌marry‌ ‌in‌ ‌order‌ ‌for‌ ‌immigrants‌ ‌to‌ ‌stay‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌country.‌ ‌\n●Ghost‌ ‌Marriage‌-Ghost‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌tradition‌ ‌in‌ ‌several‌ ‌cultures.‌The‌ ‌Nuer‌ ‌practice‌ ‌a‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌levirate‌ ‌called‌ ‌ghost‌ ‌marriage.‌ ‌If‌ ‌an‌ ‌elder‌ ‌\nbrother‌ ‌dies‌ ‌without‌ ‌fathering‌ ‌children,‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌younger‌ ‌brothers‌ ‌must‌ ‌marry‌ ‌his‌ ‌widow.‌ ‌Children‌ ‌resulting‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌ghost‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌are‌ ‌\nconsidered‌ ‌the‌ ‌offspring‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌deceased‌ ‌brother.‌ ‌\n ‌\nDeviation‌ ‌in‌ ‌Marriage‌ ‌\n●Till‌ ‌now‌ ‌we‌ ‌have‌ ‌discussed‌ ‌the‌ ‌general‌ ‌trend‌ ‌that‌ ‌we‌ ‌had‌ ‌seen‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌societies‌ ‌so‌ ‌far‌ ‌that‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌observed‌ ‌and‌ ‌written‌ ‌by‌ ‌\nanthropologists‌ ‌at‌ ‌different‌ ‌times.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌the‌ ‌present‌ ‌era‌ ‌two‌ ‌new‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌has‌ ‌emerged‌ ‌which‌ ‌were‌ ‌not‌ ‌prominent‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌earlier‌ ‌days‌ ‌–‌ ‌‌lesbian‌ ‌and‌ ‌gay‌ ‌relationship‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌lesbian‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌is‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌liking‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌girl‌ ‌for‌ ‌another‌ ‌girl‌ ‌instead‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌man‌ ‌as‌ ‌it‌ ‌happens‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌normal‌ ‌course.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Anthropologist‌ ‌Gill‌ ‌Shepherd‌ ‌explored‌ ‌female‌ ‌sexual‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌among‌ ‌Swahili‌ ‌Muslims‌ ‌in‌ ‌Mombasa,‌ ‌Kenya,‌ ‌and‌ ‌found‌ ‌that‌ ‌\nrelationships‌ ‌between‌ ‌females‌ ‌were‌ ‌perfectly‌ ‌acceptable,‌ ‌as‌ ‌were‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌between‌ ‌men.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Women‌ ‌were‌ ‌allowed‌ ‌to‌ ‌choose‌ ‌other‌ ‌women‌ ‌as‌ ‌sexual‌ ‌partners‌ ‌after‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌married;‌ ‌so‌ ‌many‌ ‌such‌ ‌women‌ ‌also‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nhusband‌ ‌at‌ ‌home,‌ ‌or‌ ‌are‌ ‌widowed‌ ‌or‌ ‌divorced.‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌other‌ ‌cases‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌present‌ ‌day‌ ‌a‌ ‌woman‌ ‌has‌ ‌sanction‌ ‌by‌ ‌law‌ ‌to‌ ‌take‌ ‌up‌ ‌another‌ ‌woman‌ ‌as‌ ‌legally‌ ‌wedded.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Such‌ ‌marriages‌ ‌are‌ ‌certified‌ ‌by‌ ‌law‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌few‌ ‌American‌ ‌States‌ ‌like‌ ‌Connecticut,‌ ‌Iowa,‌ ‌Massachusetts,‌ ‌New‌ ‌Hampshire,‌ ‌Vermont,‌ ‌plus‌ ‌\nWashington,‌ ‌D.C.‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌Coquille‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌Tribe‌ ‌in‌ ‌Oregon.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌2005‌ ‌Canada‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌enactment‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌civil‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌act‌ ‌became‌ ‌the‌ ‌fourth‌ ‌country‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌world‌ ‌to‌ ‌accept‌ ‌same‌ ‌sex‌ ‌marriages.‌ ‌\n●On‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌hand‌ ‌a‌ ‌‘gay‌ ‌relationship’‌ ‌is‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌man‌ ‌having‌ ‌a‌ ‌liking‌ ‌for‌ ‌other‌ ‌man‌ ‌commonly‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌homosexual‌ ‌relationship.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌Nicaragua,‌ ‌the‌ ‌ideal‌ ‌for‌ ‌masculinity‌ ‌is‌ ‌“machismo”,‌ ‌and‌ ‌being‌ ‌described‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌man‌ ‌who‌ ‌is‌ ‌dominant,‌ ‌active,‌ ‌and‌ ‌violent.‌ ‌ ‌\n○While,‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌U.S.,‌ ‌the‌ ‌term‌ ‌machismo‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌man‌ ‌dominating‌ ‌his‌ ‌female‌ ‌partner,‌ ‌often‌ ‌described‌ ‌as‌ ‌male‌ ‌chauvinism.‌ ‌ ‌\n○However,‌ ‌in‌ ‌Nicaragua,‌ ‌this‌ ‌can‌ ‌also‌ ‌be‌ ‌applied‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌sexual‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌between‌ ‌man.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Greek‌ ‌mythology‌ ‌and‌ ‌Greek‌ ‌history‌ ‌is‌ ‌galore‌ ‌with‌ ‌reference‌ ‌to‌ ‌homosexual‌ ‌relationships.‌ ‌ ‌\n○One‌ ‌example‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌story‌ ‌of‌ ‌‌Apollo‌ ‌and‌ ‌Hyacinthus‌;‌ ‌Apollo‌ ‌fell‌ ‌in‌ ‌love‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌mortal‌ ‌boy,‌ ‌Hyacinthus,‌ ‌and‌ ‌became‌ ‌a‌ ‌mentor‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nyouth.‌ ‌ ‌\n○He‌ ‌taught‌ ‌Hyacinthus‌ ‌the‌ ‌art‌ ‌of‌ ‌war‌ ‌and‌ ‌sports‌ ‌and‌ ‌visited‌ ‌him‌ ‌often.‌ ‌Other‌ ‌Greek‌ ‌gods‌ ‌and‌ ‌Greek‌ ‌heroes‌ ‌have‌ ‌stories‌ ‌attributed‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌them‌ ‌about‌ ‌their‌ ‌same-sex‌ ‌relationships,‌ ‌Zeus‌ ‌and‌ ‌Hercules‌ ‌among‌ ‌them.‌ ‌\n●When‌ ‌talking‌ ‌about‌ ‌movements‌ ‌for‌ ‌homosexual‌ ‌rights‌ ‌Brazil‌ ‌emerges‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌country‌ ‌to‌ ‌take‌ ‌up‌ ‌this‌ ‌issue.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Nepal‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌hand‌ ‌has‌ ‌‌accepted‌ ‌same‌ ‌sex‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌‌and‌ ‌thus,‌ ‌many‌ ‌same‌ ‌sex‌ ‌people‌ ‌from‌ ‌different‌ ‌countries‌ ‌come‌ ‌to‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌\ntheir‌ ‌marriages‌ ‌vow’s,‌ ‌which‌ ‌otherwise‌ ‌is‌ ‌banned‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌own‌ ‌country.‌ ‌\n388‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nDivorce‌ ‌\n●Divorce‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌situation‌ ‌wherein‌ ‌the‌ ‌husband‌ ‌and‌ ‌wife‌ ‌separates‌ ‌and‌ ‌gives‌ ‌up‌ ‌the‌ ‌vows‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌can‌ ‌happen‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌many‌ ‌reasons‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌common‌ ‌one‌ ‌is‌ ‌incompatibility‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌two‌ ‌partners.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Divorce‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌situation‌ ‌which‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌unpleasant‌ ‌and‌ ‌painful‌ ‌for‌ ‌both‌ ‌the‌ ‌parties‌ ‌as‌ ‌it‌ ‌leads‌ ‌not‌ ‌only‌ ‌to‌ ‌physical‌ ‌separation‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌people,‌ ‌but‌ ‌\nall‌ ‌that‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌built‌ ‌up‌ ‌during‌ ‌the‌ ‌time‌ ‌together‌ ‌like‌ ‌family,‌ ‌children‌ ‌and‌ ‌material‌ ‌objects.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Divorce‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌a‌ ‌universally‌ ‌accepted‌ ‌norm‌ ‌as‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌but‌ ‌still‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌looked‌ ‌down‌ ‌on‌ ‌in‌ ‌many‌ ‌societies‌ ‌more‌ ‌so‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌case‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌wife‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌\npatrilineal‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nFunctions‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage;‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nSome‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌functions‌ ‌are‌ ‌mentioned‌ ‌herein.‌ ‌\n●Biological‌ ‌Function‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌most‌ ‌‌important‌ ‌function‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌is‌ ‌to‌ ‌beget‌ ‌children‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌society‌ ‌gives‌ ‌recognition‌ ‌to‌ ‌children‌ ‌born‌ ‌out‌ ‌of‌ ‌wedlock‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌children‌ ‌thus‌ ‌born‌ ‌are‌ ‌ascribed‌ ‌status‌ ‌as‌ ‌per‌ ‌the‌ ‌norms‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nsociety.‌ ‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌society‌ ‌basically‌ ‌channelizes‌ ‌the‌ ‌sexual‌ ‌rights‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌institution‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌and‌ ‌it‌ ‌helps‌ ‌in‌ ‌mating‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌rules‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nregulations‌ ‌as‌ ‌ascribed‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌helps‌ ‌in‌ ‌maintaining‌ ‌the‌ ‌norms‌ ‌of‌ ‌incest‌ ‌taboo‌ ‌also.‌ ‌\n●Economic‌ ‌Functions‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌do‌ ‌away‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌discrimination‌ ‌of‌ ‌labour‌ ‌by‌ ‌sex,‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌comes‌ ‌in‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌protective‌ ‌measure‌ ‌wherein‌ ‌the‌ ‌men‌ ‌share‌ ‌their‌ ‌\nproduce‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌wives.‌ ‌\n○Ma‌rriage‌ ‌leads‌ ‌to‌ ‌an‌ ‌economic‌ ‌co-operation‌ ‌between‌ ‌men‌ ‌and‌ ‌women‌ ‌ensuring‌ ‌the‌ ‌survival‌ ‌of‌ ‌every‌ ‌individual‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n●Social‌ ‌Function‌ ‌\n○Marriage‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌way‌ ‌to‌ ‌forming‌ ‌a‌ ‌family.‌ ‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌sanctions‌ ‌the‌ ‌status‌ ‌of‌ ‌both‌ ‌husband‌ ‌and‌ ‌wife‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌society‌ ‌and‌ ‌thus,‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌also‌ ‌collectively‌ ‌accepted‌ ‌by‌ ‌society‌ ‌as‌ ‌\nhusband‌ ‌and‌ ‌wife.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌many‌ ‌societies‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌norms‌ ‌where‌ ‌only‌ ‌a‌ ‌married‌ ‌person‌ ‌can‌ ‌take‌ ‌part‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌rituals.‌ ‌ ‌\n■For‌ ‌example‌‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Hindu‌ ‌society‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌ritual‌ ‌during‌ ‌weddings‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌the‌ ‌bride‌ ‌is‌ ‌blessed‌ ‌with‌ ‌oil.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌this‌ ‌ceremony‌ ‌atleast‌ ‌seven‌ ‌married‌ ‌women‌ ‌hold‌ ‌a‌ ‌ring‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌tip‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌right‌ ‌hand‌ ‌forefinger‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌brides‌ ‌head.‌ ‌\nOil‌ ‌then‌ ‌is‌ ‌poured‌ ‌on‌ ‌this‌ ‌ring‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌married‌ ‌women.‌ ‌ ‌\n389‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌is‌ ‌believed‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌oil‌ ‌which‌ ‌pours‌ ‌down‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌head‌ ‌to‌ ‌below‌ ‌takes‌ ‌away‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌evil‌ ‌and‌ ‌brings‌ ‌in‌ ‌good‌ ‌luck‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nhusband‌ ‌and‌ ‌wife.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Normally,‌ ‌widows‌ ‌and‌ ‌divorcees‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌take‌ ‌part‌ ‌in‌ ‌such‌ ‌rituals.‌ ‌Marriage‌ ‌helps‌ ‌in‌ ‌forming‌ ‌new‌ ‌kinsmen‌ ‌and‌ ‌widening‌ ‌his‌ ‌\nnetwork.‌ ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌Addition‌ ‌\nDo‌ ‌you‌ ‌think‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌social‌ ‌institution‌ ‌is‌ ‌losing‌ ‌its‌ ‌relevance‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌society?‌ ‌\n ‌\nImportance‌ ‌of‌ ‌Marriage‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌social‌ ‌institution:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Humans‌ ‌are‌ ‌social‌ ‌by‌ ‌nature‌ ‌and‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌fit‌ ‌for‌ ‌them‌ ‌to‌ ‌live‌ ‌alone.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Marriage‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌bond‌ ‌like‌ ‌no‌ ‌other.‌ ‌It‌ ‌makes‌ ‌two‌ ‌souls‌ ‌become‌ ‌one.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌gives‌ ‌one‌ ‌a‌ ‌life‌ ‌partner,‌ ‌a‌ ‌teammate,‌ ‌a‌ ‌best‌ ‌friend‌ ‌for‌ ‌life‌ ‌as‌ ‌we‌ ‌move‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌challenges‌ ‌of‌ ‌life‌ ‌together.‌ ‌\n●As‌ ‌common‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌single-parent‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌modern‌ ‌day,‌ ‌it‌ ‌would‌ ‌be‌ ‌wrong‌ ‌to‌ ‌say‌ ‌they‌ ‌don’t‌ ‌function‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌or‌ ‌achieve‌ ‌things‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌\ntwo-parent‌ ‌family.‌ ‌\n●However,‌ ‌studies‌ ‌do‌ ‌suggest‌ ‌that‌ ‌children‌ ‌raised‌ ‌with‌ ‌both‌ ‌mother‌ ‌and‌ ‌father‌ ‌do‌ ‌have‌ ‌certain‌ ‌advantages‌ ‌over‌ ‌children‌ ‌raised‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nhouseholds‌ ‌with‌ ‌one‌ ‌parent.‌ ‌\n●Studies‌ ‌also‌ ‌suggest‌ ‌that‌ ‌children‌ ‌without‌ ‌one‌ ‌parent‌ ‌show‌ ‌an‌ ‌increase‌ ‌in‌ ‌mental‌ ‌and‌ ‌behavioural‌ ‌disorders‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌criminal‌ ‌activities‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌substance‌ ‌abuse.‌ ‌\n●On‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌hand,‌ ‌a‌ ‌child‌ ‌raised‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌healthy‌ ‌family‌ ‌gets‌ ‌to‌ ‌experience‌ ‌the‌ ‌lasting‌ ‌benefits‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌strong‌ ‌family.‌ ‌\n●Marriage‌ ‌also‌ ‌provides‌ ‌an‌ ‌opportunity‌ ‌to‌ ‌grow‌ ‌together‌ ‌and‌ ‌live‌ ‌selflessly‌ ‌as‌ ‌you‌ ‌serve‌ ‌your‌ ‌spouse‌ ‌and‌ ‌children.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nphysical‌ ‌union,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌a‌ ‌spiritual‌ ‌and‌ ‌emotional‌ ‌union.‌ ‌\n ‌\nThe‌ ‌role‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌changed‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌trend‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌social,‌ ‌the‌ ‌culture‌ ‌consequence,‌ ‌the‌ ‌bond‌ ‌between‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌and‌ ‌parenthood.‌ ‌ ‌\nThe‌ ‌reasons‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌are:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Cohabitation:‌ ‌Some‌ ‌people‌ ‌might‌ ‌not‌ ‌marry‌ ‌and‌ ‌cohabit‌ ‌instead,‌ ‌because‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌ready‌ ‌to‌ ‌make‌ ‌a‌ ‌commitment‌ ‌to‌ ‌their‌ ‌partner‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nmight‌ ‌cohabit‌ ‌first‌ ‌instead‌ ‌and‌ ‌‘trying‌ ‌before‌ ‌buying’,‌ ‌with‌ ‌cohabiting‌ ‌together‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌trial‌ ‌run,‌ ‌to‌ ‌experience‌ ‌what‌ ‌it‌ ‌would‌ ‌be‌ ‌like‌ ‌to‌ ‌live‌ ‌with‌ ‌\nthat‌ ‌person.‌ ‌\n●Compromising‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌career:‌ ‌‌As‌ ‌an‌ ‌independent‌ ‌and‌ ‌strong‌ ‌person,‌ ‌he/she‌ ‌is‌ ‌completely‌ ‌bounded‌ ‌towards‌ ‌career‌ ‌and‌ ‌personal‌ ‌growth‌ ‌\nbut‌ ‌when‌ ‌it‌ ‌comes‌ ‌to‌ ‌marriage,‌ ‌there‌ ‌comes‌ ‌a‌ ‌responsibility‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌complete‌ ‌household‌ ‌and‌ ‌in‌ ‌this‌ ‌problem,‌ ‌he/she‌ ‌may‌ ‌have‌ ‌to‌ ‌give‌ ‌up‌ ‌or‌ ‌\ncompromise‌ ‌on‌ ‌his/her‌ ‌career.‌ ‌\n●Increasing‌ ‌divorces:‌ ‌‌Today‌ ‌divorce‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌lot‌ ‌more‌ ‌socially‌ ‌acceptable,‌ ‌with‌ ‌lots‌ ‌of‌ ‌media‌ ‌influence‌ ‌and‌ ‌more‌ ‌benefits‌ ‌for‌ ‌single‌ ‌parents‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌also‌ ‌the‌ ‌fact‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌lot‌ ‌easier.‌ ‌Many‌ ‌people‌ ‌don’t‌ ‌really‌ ‌see‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌as‌ ‌that‌ ‌important‌ ‌anymore‌ ‌and‌ ‌instead‌ ‌of‌ ‌living‌ ‌in‌ ‌an‌ ‌‘empty‌ ‌shell‌ ‌\nmarriage’,‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌when‌ ‌a‌ ‌couple‌ ‌remain‌ ‌legally‌ ‌married‌ ‌even‌ ‌though‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌technically‌ ‌over,‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌eyes‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌husband‌ ‌and‌ ‌wife,‌ ‌they‌ ‌\nsimply‌ ‌get‌ ‌divorced,‌ ‌as‌ ‌we‌ ‌seem‌ ‌to‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌lot‌ ‌more‌ ‌freedom‌ ‌now.‌ ‌\n●Choice:‌ ‌‌Some‌ ‌people‌ ‌have‌ ‌the‌ ‌notion‌ ‌of‌ ‌either‌ ‌marrying‌ ‌or‌ ‌not.‌ ‌It‌ ‌depends‌ ‌on‌ ‌their‌ ‌choice.‌ ‌‌They‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌think‌ ‌about‌ ‌social‌ ‌pressures‌ ‌or‌ ‌the‌ ‌\npressure‌ ‌from‌ ‌their‌ ‌families.‌ ‌‌Young‌ ‌people‌ ‌are‌ ‌mostly‌ ‌sided‌ ‌towards‌ ‌their‌ ‌choice‌ ‌part.‌ ‌\n●Adopting‌ ‌kids‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌more‌ ‌considered‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌taboo:‌ ‌‌Couples‌ ‌can‌ ‌adopt‌ ‌a‌ ‌child‌ ‌and‌ ‌raise‌ ‌it‌ ‌without‌ ‌any‌ ‌other‌ ‌formalities‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage.‌ ‌\n390‌ ‌\n●Expensive‌ ‌affair:‌ ‌Many‌ ‌people‌ ‌don’t‌ ‌see‌ ‌the‌ ‌point‌ ‌in‌ ‌spending‌ ‌thousands‌ ‌on‌ ‌getting‌ ‌married,lots‌ ‌of‌ ‌people‌ ‌are‌ ‌struggling‌ ‌financially‌ ‌and‌ ‌\ncannot‌ ‌afford‌ ‌it,‌ ‌so‌ ‌decide‌ ‌to‌ ‌just‌ ‌‘cohabit’‌ ‌together.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nMarriage‌ ‌payments‌ ‌(bride‌ ‌wealth‌ ‌and‌ ‌dowry)‌ ‌\n●Payments‌ ‌made‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌bride’s‌ ‌side‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌groom's‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌‌dowry‌ ‌and‌ ‌‌payments‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌groom’s‌ ‌parents‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌bride’s‌ ‌\nparents‌ ‌is‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌‌bride‌ ‌price‌ ‌or‌ ‌bride‌ ‌wealth.‌ ‌\n●Women‌ ‌generally‌ ‌join‌ ‌the‌ ‌household‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌groom‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌time‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage,‌ ‌bride‌ ‌price‌ ‌is‌ ‌typically‌ ‌considered‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌the‌ ‌payment‌ ‌a‌ ‌husband‌ ‌\nowes‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌bride’s‌ ‌parents‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌right‌ ‌to‌ ‌her‌ ‌labor‌ ‌and‌ ‌reproductive‌ ‌capabilities.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌amount‌ ‌of‌ ‌bride‌ ‌price‌ ‌required‌ ‌has‌ ‌usually‌ ‌been‌ ‌rather‌ ‌uniform‌ ‌throughout‌ ‌society,‌ ‌where‌ ‌the‌ ‌size‌ ‌is‌ ‌linked‌ ‌directly‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nrights‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌transferred‌ ‌and‌ ‌not‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌wealth‌ ‌level‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌families‌ ‌involved.‌ ‌\n391‌ ‌\n ‌\nSocial‌ ‌Characteristics‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌Occurrence‌ ‌of‌ ‌Marriage‌ ‌Payments‌ ‌\n●Substantial‌ ‌ethnographic‌ ‌research‌ ‌by‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌has‌ ‌aimed‌ ‌at‌ ‌distinguishing‌ ‌between‌ ‌those‌ ‌societies‌ ‌where‌ ‌the‌ ‌burden‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌\npayments‌ ‌falls‌ ‌primarily‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌groom’s‌ ‌family‌ ‌and‌ ‌bride‌ ‌prices‌ ‌are‌ ‌paid,‌ ‌and‌ ‌those‌ ‌where‌ ‌the‌ ‌bulk‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌transfer‌ ‌comes‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌bride’s‌ ‌\nfamily‌ ‌and‌ ‌dowries‌ ‌are‌ ‌paid.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌general‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌seems‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌that‌ ‌bride‌ ‌price‌ ‌exists‌ ‌more‌ ‌frequently‌ ‌in‌ ‌primitive,‌ ‌tribal,‌ ‌and‌ ‌often‌ ‌nomadic‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Several‌ ‌scholars‌ ‌have‌ ‌even‌ ‌contended‌ ‌that‌ ‌dowry‌ ‌marks‌ ‌a‌ ‌transition‌ ‌to‌ ‌more‌ ‌complex‌ ‌societal‌ ‌structures.‌ ‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌example,‌ ‌‌Hughes‌ ‌(1985)‌ ‌argues‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌historical‌ ‌absence‌ ‌of‌ ‌‌bride‌ ‌price‌ ‌in‌ ‌Greece‌ ‌and‌ ‌Rome‌ ‌was‌ ‌an‌ ‌important‌ ‌demarcation‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\ncomplexity‌ ‌of‌ ‌Greco-Roman‌ ‌civilization.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌contrast‌ ‌with‌ ‌contemporary‌ ‌Indo-European‌ ‌peoples‌ ‌(the‌ ‌Germanic‌ ‌tribes)‌ ‌and‌ ‌also‌ ‌the‌ ‌ancient‌ ‌and‌ ‌‌more‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌peoples‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nMediterranean‌ ‌whose‌ ‌legal‌ ‌and‌ ‌religious‌ ‌literature,‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌code‌ ‌of‌ ‌Hammurabi‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌Bible,‌ ‌records‌ ‌the‌ ‌practice‌ ‌of‌ ‌bride‌ ‌price.‌ ‌\n ‌\nPrevalence‌ ‌of‌ ‌Bride‌ ‌price:‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌custom‌ ‌of‌ ‌bride‌ ‌price‌ ‌dates‌ ‌back‌ ‌as‌ ‌far‌ ‌as‌ ‌3000‌ ‌BCE.‌ ‌ ‌\n392‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌ancient‌ ‌civilizations‌ ‌of‌ ‌Egyptians,‌ ‌Mesopotamians,‌ ‌Hebrews,‌ ‌Aztecs,‌ ‌and‌ ‌Incas‌ ‌all‌ ‌used‌ ‌bride‌ ‌price.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌‌Germanic‌ ‌tribes,‌ ‌who‌ ‌date‌ ‌from‌ ‌2000‌ ‌BCE‌ ‌and‌ ‌ruled‌ ‌western‌ ‌Europe‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌600‌ ‌to‌ ‌1000‌ ‌CE,‌ ‌required‌ ‌bride‌ ‌price‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌\nlegal‌ ‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌valid‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌contract‌ ‌in‌ ‌Islamic‌ ‌law‌ ‌required‌ ‌a‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌bride‌ ‌price.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Such‌ ‌transactions‌ ‌are‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌Maghreb‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌early‌ ‌Middle‌ ‌Ages,‌ ‌Bedouin‌ ‌tribes‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Middle‌ ‌East,‌ ‌and‌ ‌countries‌ ‌previously‌ ‌\nunder‌ ‌the‌ ‌Ottoman‌ ‌Empire‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌Iraq,‌ ‌Syria,‌ ‌Egypt,‌ ‌Turkey,‌ ‌Iran,‌ ‌Albania,‌ ‌and‌ ‌Afghanistan.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Subanun‌ ‌of‌ ‌Philippines‌ ‌have‌ ‌an‌ ‌extensive‌ ‌bride‌ ‌price‌ ‌several‌ ‌times‌ ‌the‌ ‌annual‌ ‌income‌ ‌of‌ ‌groom‌ ‌plus‌ ‌3‌ ‌to‌ ‌5years‌ ‌of‌ ‌Bride‌ ‌service.‌ ‌\n●Varieties‌ ‌of‌ ‌currencies‌ ‌and‌ ‌goods‌ ‌are‌ ‌used‌ ‌for‌ ‌paying‌ ‌the‌ ‌bridewealth‌ ‌depending‌ ‌upon‌ ‌the‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Mostly‌ ‌the‌ ‌bridewealth‌ ‌is‌ ‌movable‌ ‌property‌ ‌given‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌groom’s‌ ‌family.‌ ‌For‌ ‌example‌ ‌reindeers‌ ‌are‌ ‌given‌ ‌as‌ ‌bridewealth‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nreindeer-herding‌ ‌Chukchee,‌ ‌sheep‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌Navajo,‌ ‌cattles‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌Nuers,‌ ‌Maasai‌ ‌and‌ ‌Samburu‌ ‌of‌ ‌Africa,‌ ‌spears‌ ‌in‌ ‌Somalia‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌management‌ ‌of‌ ‌bride‌ ‌wealth‌ ‌and‌ ‌wife-acquisition‌ ‌in‌ ‌an‌ ‌African‌ ‌cattle-herding‌ ‌society‌ ‌is‌ ‌fundamentally‌ ‌the‌ ‌management‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌\ncomplementary‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌wealth.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌complicated‌ ‌process‌ ‌that‌ ‌requires‌ ‌recognition‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌fertility‌ ‌rates‌ ‌of‌ ‌animal‌ ‌stock,‌ ‌the‌ ‌fertility‌ ‌rates‌ ‌of‌ ‌women,‌ ‌the‌ ‌typical‌ ‌age‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nmarriage‌ ‌for‌ ‌women‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌level‌ ‌of‌ ‌bride‌ ‌wealth‌ ‌or‌ ‌bride‌ ‌price.‌ ‌\n●Circumstances‌ ‌are‌ ‌very‌ ‌different‌ ‌for‌ ‌those‌ ‌Bedouin‌ ‌who‌ ‌use‌ ‌camels‌ ‌as‌ ‌bride‌ ‌wealth.‌ ‌In‌ ‌this‌ ‌case‌ ‌the‌ ‌growth‌ ‌rate‌ ‌of‌ ‌stock‌ ‌is‌ ‌less‌ ‌than‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nrate‌ ‌of‌ ‌growth‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌human‌ ‌group;‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌camels‌ ‌in‌ ‌bride‌ ‌wealth‌ ‌would‌ ‌impose‌ ‌further‌ ‌reductions‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌growth‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌herd.‌ ‌Hence,‌ ‌it‌ ‌\nis‌ ‌not‌ ‌rational‌ ‌to‌ ‌give‌ ‌a‌ ‌daughter‌ ‌in‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌for‌ ‌camels,‌ ‌unless‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌sufficiently‌ ‌compensating‌ ‌ancillary‌ ‌resources‌ ‌that‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌\naccessed‌ ‌thereby.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌amount‌ ‌of‌ ‌bridewealth‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌paid‌ ‌is‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌various‌ ‌factors‌ ‌of‌ ‌which‌ ‌some‌ ‌are‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌status‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌broom’s‌ ‌family‌ ‌and‌ ‌others‌ ‌on‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌bride‌ ‌and‌ ‌her‌ ‌social‌ ‌acceptance‌ ‌as‌ ‌prescribed‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\nFor‌ ‌example:‌ ‌‌if‌ ‌a‌ ‌woman‌ ‌has‌ ‌given‌ ‌birth‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌prenuptial‌ ‌child‌ ‌than‌ ‌her‌ ‌bridewealth‌ ‌is‌ ‌very‌ ‌low‌ ‌whereas‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌Kipsigis‌ ‌of‌ ‌western‌ ‌Kenya‌ ‌\nif‌ ‌the‌ ‌distance‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌brides‌ ‌natal‌ ‌home‌ ‌is‌ ‌very‌ ‌far‌ ‌away‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌marital‌ ‌home‌ ‌than‌ ‌the‌ ‌bride‌ ‌wealth‌ ‌is‌ ‌very‌ ‌high‌ ‌as‌ ‌she‌ ‌is‌ ‌able‌ ‌to‌ ‌spend‌ ‌less‌ ‌\ntime‌ ‌at‌ ‌her‌ ‌natal‌ ‌home‌ ‌and‌ ‌devote‌ ‌more‌ ‌time‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌domestic‌ ‌chores‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌husbands‌ ‌home.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌societies‌ ‌with‌ ‌little‌ ‌material‌ ‌wealth‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌rules‌ ‌requiring‌ ‌sharing,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌rarely‌ ‌possible‌ ‌to‌ ‌accumulate‌ ‌a‌ ‌bride‌ ‌price.‌ ‌‌As‌ ‌a‌ ‌result,‌ ‌such‌ ‌\nsocieties‌ ‌often‌ ‌have‌ ‌bride‌ ‌service‌ ‌instead‌ ‌as‌ ‌seen‌ ‌among‌ ‌some‌ ‌Gonds‌ ‌and‌ ‌Baigas.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌groom‌ ‌agrees‌ ‌to‌ ‌work‌ ‌for‌ ‌his‌ ‌in-laws‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌set‌ ‌period‌ ‌of‌ ‌time.‌ ‌Among‌ ‌the‌ ‌Yanomamö‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌lowland‌ ‌forest‌ ‌dwellers‌ ‌of‌ ‌South‌ ‌America.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌service‌ ‌may‌ ‌go‌ ‌on‌ ‌for‌ ‌years‌ ‌and‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌Yanomamö‌ ‌men‌ ‌the‌ ‌practice‌ ‌is‌ ‌more‌ ‌difficult‌ ‌as‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌customarily‌ ‌prevented‌ ‌\nfrom‌ ‌speaking‌ ‌directly‌ ‌to‌ ‌their‌ ‌in-laws‌ ‌and‌ ‌must‌ ‌avoid‌ ‌them.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌most‌ ‌the‌ ‌tribes‌ ‌of‌ ‌India,‌ ‌bride‌ ‌price‌ ‌and‌ ‌bride‌ ‌service‌ ‌is‌ ‌reported‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌prevailing‌ ‌like,‌ ‌Kharia,‌ ‌Ho,‌ ‌Juangs,‌ ‌Oraon,‌ ‌etc‌ ‌\n ‌\nPrevalence‌ ‌of‌ ‌Dowry‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌dowry‌ ‌system‌ ‌dates‌ ‌back‌ ‌at‌ ‌least‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌ancient‌ ‌Greek‌ ‌city-states‌ ‌(800‌ ‌to‌ ‌300‌ ‌BCE)‌ ‌and‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌Romans‌ ‌by‌ ‌around‌ ‌200‌ ‌BCE.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Greco-Roman‌ ‌institution‌ ‌of‌ ‌dowry‌ ‌was‌ ‌then‌ ‌eclipsed‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌time‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌Germanic‌ ‌observance‌ ‌of‌ ‌bride‌ ‌price‌ ‌became‌ ‌prevalent‌ ‌throughout‌ ‌\nmuch‌ ‌of‌ ‌Europe,‌ ‌but‌ ‌dowry‌ ‌was‌ ‌widely‌ ‌reinstated‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌late‌ ‌middle‌ ‌Ages‌.‌ ‌\n●Dowry‌ ‌can‌ ‌also‌ ‌be‌ ‌viewed‌ ‌as‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌woman,‌ ‌though‌ ‌this‌ ‌is‌ ‌usually‌ ‌in‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌where‌ ‌both‌ ‌men‌ ‌and‌ ‌women‌ ‌are‌ ‌heirs.‌ ‌ ‌\n393‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌other‌ ‌cases,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌in‌ ‌socially‌ ‌stratified‌ ‌societies,‌ ‌‌a‌ ‌dowry‌ ‌gives‌ ‌a‌ ‌woman‌ ‌the‌ ‌security‌ ‌of‌ ‌knowing‌ ‌that‌ ‌after‌ ‌she‌ ‌is‌ ‌married‌ ‌she‌ ‌can‌ ‌still‌ ‌\nenjoy‌ ‌her‌ ‌usual‌ ‌lifestyle‌ ‌and‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌case‌ ‌of‌ ‌divorce,‌ ‌avoid‌ ‌poverty‌ ‌and‌ ‌discomfort.‌ ‌ ‌\n●If‌ ‌the‌ ‌husband‌ ‌and‌ ‌wife‌ ‌are‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌divorced,‌ ‌the‌ ‌wife‌ ‌is‌ ‌able‌ ‌to‌ ‌get‌ ‌back‌ ‌the‌ ‌dowry‌ ‌that‌ ‌her‌ ‌parents‌ ‌had‌ ‌given.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Usually,‌ ‌‌in‌ ‌many‌ ‌cases‌ ‌a‌ ‌woman‌ ‌who‌ ‌can‌ ‌afford‌ ‌to‌ ‌pay‌ ‌more‌ ‌dowry‌ ‌is‌ ‌able‌ ‌to‌ ‌find‌ ‌herself‌ ‌a‌ ‌rich‌ ‌husband,‌ ‌while‌ ‌in‌ ‌most‌ ‌cases‌ ‌a‌ ‌woman‌ ‌who‌ ‌\ncan‌ ‌dowry‌ ‌is‌ ‌able‌ ‌to‌ ‌only‌ ‌find‌ ‌herself‌ ‌a‌ ‌poor‌ ‌husband.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌Europe‌ ‌and‌ ‌Asia's‌ ‌dowry‌ ‌payment‌ ‌is‌ ‌mainly‌ ‌found‌ ‌among‌ ‌agricultural‌ ‌communities,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌practised‌ ‌in‌ ‌Africa.‌ ‌In‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌context‌ ‌dowry‌ ‌\npayment‌ ‌is‌ ‌widely‌ ‌prevalent‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Hindu‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌tradition‌ ‌of‌ ‌dowry‌ ‌was‌ ‌prohibited‌ ‌in‌ ‌1961‌ ‌under‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌civil‌ ‌law‌ ‌and‌ ‌subsequently‌ ‌by‌ ‌Sections‌ ‌304B‌ ‌and‌ ‌498a‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌Penal‌ ‌\nCode.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌move‌ ‌was‌ ‌made‌ ‌to‌ ‌protect‌ ‌the‌ ‌women‌ ‌from‌ ‌dowry‌ ‌related‌ ‌harassment‌ ‌and‌ ‌domestic‌ ‌violence.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌Addition‌ ‌\nWays‌ ‌of‌ ‌Acquiring‌ ‌a‌ ‌Mate‌ ‌in‌ ‌Tribal‌ ‌Society‌ ‌\n ‌\n1.Marriage‌ ‌by‌ ‌negotiation:‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌very‌ ‌frequently‌ ‌practised‌ ‌way‌ ‌of‌ ‌acquiring‌ ‌a‌ ‌mate.‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌is‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌most‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌simple‌ ‌societies‌ ‌like‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Ituri‌ ‌of‌ ‌Congo‌ ‌region‌ ‌in‌ ‌Africa,Siwai‌ ‌of‌ ‌Solomon‌ ‌Islands,‌ ‌the‌ ‌aboriginals‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nAustralia,‌ ‌Andamanese‌ ‌of‌ ‌Andaman‌ ‌Islands‌ ‌and‌ ‌also‌ ‌in‌ ‌complex‌ ‌societies‌ ‌like‌ ‌the‌ ‌Hindu‌ ‌society‌ ‌of‌ ‌India,‌ ‌China,‌ ‌\nJapan,Europe‌ ‌and‌ ‌America.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌such‌ ‌a‌ ‌system‌ ‌either‌ ‌the‌ ‌girl’s‌ ‌family‌ ‌or‌ ‌the‌ ‌boy’s‌ ‌family‌ ‌(as‌ ‌per‌ ‌the‌ ‌custom)‌ ‌puts‌ ‌forward‌ ‌a‌ ‌proposal‌ ‌for‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌through‌ ‌a‌ ‌third‌ ‌\nparty‌ ‌or‌ ‌mediator.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌third‌ ‌party‌ ‌is‌ ‌generally‌ ‌someone‌ ‌known‌ ‌to‌ ‌both‌ ‌the‌ ‌bride‌ ‌and‌ ‌groom’s‌ ‌family.‌ ‌In‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌context‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌arranged‌ ‌\nmarriage.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌earlier‌ ‌times‌ ‌the‌ ‌bride‌ ‌and‌ ‌groom‌ ‌meet‌ ‌each‌ ‌other‌ ‌only‌ ‌during‌ ‌the‌ ‌wedding,‌ ‌but‌ ‌This‌ ‌rigidity‌ ‌is‌ ‌being‌ ‌relaxed‌ ‌nowadays‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌such‌ ‌a‌ ‌system‌ ‌bride‌ ‌price,‌ ‌bride‌ ‌wealth,‌ ‌dowry‌ ‌also‌ ‌has‌ ‌an‌ ‌important‌ ‌role‌ ‌to‌ ‌play‌ ‌and‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌usually‌ ‌a‌ ‌long‌ ‌drawn‌ ‌process‌ ‌where‌ ‌\nconsensus‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌bride‌ ‌and‌ ‌groom’s‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌all‌ ‌done‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌Mediator.‌ ‌\n2.Marriage‌ ‌by‌ ‌exchange:‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌also‌ ‌forms‌ ‌a‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌by‌ ‌negotiation‌ ‌system.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Herein,‌ ‌‌such‌ ‌a‌ ‌system‌ ‌the‌ ‌bride‌ ‌price‌ ‌or‌ ‌bride‌ ‌wealth,‌ ‌whichever‌ ‌is‌ ‌applicable‌ ‌to‌ ‌society,‌ ‌is‌ ‌waived‌ ‌off‌ ‌by‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌through‌ ‌\nexchange.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌happens‌ ‌generally‌ ‌if‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌daughters‌ ‌or‌ ‌sisters‌ ‌for‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌grooms‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌helps‌ ‌in‌ ‌not‌ ‌only‌ ‌forming‌ ‌an‌ ‌alliance‌ ‌but‌ ‌also‌ ‌strengthens‌ ‌the‌ ‌bond‌ ‌between‌ ‌groups.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Examples‌ ‌of‌ ‌such‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌is‌ ‌seen‌ ‌is‌ ‌societies‌ ‌of‌ ‌‌Australia,‌ ‌Melanesia,‌ ‌Tive‌ ‌of‌ ‌Nigeria‌ ‌and‌ ‌also‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌some‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌tribes‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nIndia-‌ ‌Muria‌ ‌Gonds,‌ ‌Baiga‌ ‌of‌ ‌Bustar‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌Koya‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌Saora‌ ‌of‌ ‌Andhra‌ ‌Pradesh.‌ ‌\n3.Marriage‌ ‌by‌ ‌service:‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌found‌ ‌among‌ ‌some‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌tribes‌ ‌in‌ ‌North‌ ‌East‌ ‌India‌.‌ ‌\n○Among‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Naga’s‌ ‌of‌ ‌North‌ ‌East‌ ‌India‌ ‌the‌ ‌bride‌ ‌wealth‌ ‌forms‌ ‌a‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌negotiation‌ ‌and‌ ‌if‌ ‌the‌ ‌groom’s‌ ‌party‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌able‌ ‌\n394‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌pay‌ ‌the‌ ‌bride‌ ‌wealth‌ ‌then‌ ‌the‌ ‌compensation‌ ‌is‌ ‌through‌ ‌service.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌boy‌ ‌works‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌bride’s‌ ‌family‌ ‌and‌ ‌only‌ ‌when‌ ‌the‌ ‌bride's‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌satisfied‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌is‌ ‌solemnised.‌ ‌\n4.Marriage‌ ‌by‌ ‌probation:‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌involves‌ ‌the‌ ‌consent‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌bride's‌ ‌parents‌ ‌along‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌girls‌ ‌consent‌ ‌wherein‌ ‌the‌ ‌groom‌ ‌stays‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌bride's‌ ‌place‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌trial‌ ‌\nbasis.‌ ‌\n○Herein,‌ ‌the‌ ‌groom‌ ‌is‌ ‌allowed‌ ‌to‌ ‌stay‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌girl‌ ‌so‌ ‌that‌ ‌they‌ ‌both‌ ‌get‌ ‌to‌ ‌know‌ ‌each‌ ‌others‌ ‌temperament‌ ‌and‌ ‌if‌ ‌the‌ ‌girl‌ ‌likes‌ ‌the‌ ‌boy‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌takes‌ ‌place,‌ ‌else‌ ‌the‌ ‌boy‌ ‌has‌ ‌to‌ ‌pay‌ ‌compensation‌ ‌in‌ ‌cash‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌girl’s‌ ‌family.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Among‌ ‌the‌‌ ‌Kukis‌ ‌of‌ ‌Manipur‌ ‌of‌ ‌India‌ ‌such‌ ‌a‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌practised‌ ‌norm‌.‌ ‌\n5.Marriage‌ ‌by‌ ‌capture:‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌many‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌capture‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌a‌ ‌physical‌ ‌capture‌ ‌or‌ ‌a‌ ‌ceremonial‌ ‌one.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Among‌ ‌the‌ ‌tribes‌ ‌of‌ ‌‌Yahomamo‌ ‌of‌ ‌Venezuela,‌ ‌Northern‌ ‌Brazil‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌Nagas‌ ‌of‌ ‌Nagaland‌ ‌in‌ ‌India‌ ‌during‌ ‌raids‌ ‌the‌ ‌men‌ ‌\nfrom‌ ‌one‌ ‌village‌ ‌capture‌ ‌and‌ ‌take‌ ‌home‌ ‌females‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌village‌ ‌and‌ ‌marry‌ ‌them‌ ‌as‌ ‌wives.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Such‌ ‌a‌ ‌situation‌ ‌is‌ ‌ascribed‌ ‌as‌ ‌physical‌ ‌capture.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌ceremonial‌ ‌capture‌ ‌a‌ ‌boy‌ ‌desiring‌ ‌to‌ ‌marry‌ ‌a‌ ‌girl‌ ‌propositions‌ ‌her‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌community‌ ‌fair‌ ‌or‌ ‌festival‌ ‌and‌ ‌makes‌ ‌his‌ ‌intentions‌ ‌\ntowards‌ ‌her‌ ‌known‌ ‌by‌ ‌either‌ ‌holding‌ ‌her‌ ‌hand‌ ‌or‌ ‌marking‌ ‌her‌ ‌with‌ ‌vermillion‌ ‌as‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌case‌ ‌of‌ ‌‌Kharia‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌Birhor‌ ‌of‌ ‌Bihar‌.‌ ‌\n6.Marriage‌ ‌by‌ ‌intrusion:‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌wherein‌ ‌a‌ ‌girl‌ ‌forces‌ ‌her‌ ‌way‌ ‌into‌ ‌the‌ ‌boy’s‌ ‌house‌ ‌and‌ ‌forces‌ ‌him‌ ‌to‌ ‌accept‌ ‌her‌ ‌as‌ ‌his‌ ‌spouse.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Such‌ ‌marriages‌ ‌are‌ ‌seen‌ ‌in‌ ‌‌Birhor‌ ‌and‌ ‌Ho‌ ‌of‌ ‌Bihar‌ ‌and‌ ‌also‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌Kamars‌ ‌of‌ ‌Madhya‌ ‌Pradesh.‌ ‌\n7.Marriage‌ ‌by‌ ‌trial:‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌process‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌the‌ ‌groom‌ ‌has‌ ‌to‌ ‌prove‌ ‌his‌ ‌strength‌ ‌and‌ ‌valour‌ ‌while‌ ‌claiming‌ ‌his‌ ‌bride.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌the‌ ‌two‌ ‌great‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌epics‌ ‌‌Mahabharata‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌Ramayana‌ ‌we‌ ‌have‌ ‌examples‌ ‌of‌ ‌how‌ ‌Draupadi‌ ‌and‌ ‌Sita‌ ‌were‌ ‌claimed‌ ‌by‌ ‌\nArjuna‌ ‌and‌ ‌Lord‌ ‌Rama‌ ‌after‌ ‌they‌ ‌proved‌ ‌their‌ ‌skills‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌swayamvar‌ ‌(a‌ ‌gathering‌ ‌where‌ ‌the‌ ‌eligible‌ ‌males‌ ‌are‌ ‌invited‌ ‌to‌ ‌prove‌ ‌\ntheir‌ ‌strength‌ ‌to‌ ‌claim‌ ‌the‌ ‌bride).‌ ‌ ‌\n○Such‌ ‌marriages‌ ‌by‌ ‌trial‌ ‌are‌ ‌still‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌many‌ ‌societies‌ ‌in‌ ‌India‌ ‌and‌ ‌some‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌examples‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Bhils‌ ‌of‌ ‌Rajasthan‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nNagas‌ ‌of‌ ‌Nagaland.‌ ‌\n8.Marriage‌ ‌by‌ ‌Elopement:‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌customary‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌in‌ ‌some‌ ‌societies‌ ‌whereas‌ ‌looked‌ ‌down‌ ‌in‌ ‌others.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌societies‌ ‌where‌ ‌a‌ ‌huge‌ ‌amount‌ ‌of‌ ‌wealth‌ ‌is‌ ‌required‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌rituals‌ ‌and‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌usually‌ ‌difficult‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌families‌ ‌to‌ ‌bear‌ ‌\nin‌ ‌such‌ ‌societies‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌by‌ ‌elopement‌ ‌has‌ ‌come‌ ‌up‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌customary‌ ‌practice.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Such‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌is‌ ‌quite‌ ‌in‌ ‌vogue‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Karbis‌ ‌of‌ ‌Karbi‌ ‌Anglong‌ ‌district‌ ‌of‌ ‌Assam‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌other‌ ‌cases‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌by‌ ‌elopement‌ ‌takes‌ ‌place‌ ‌when‌ ‌either‌ ‌the‌ ‌prospective‌ ‌groom‌ ‌or‌ ‌bride’s‌ ‌family‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌approve‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nwedding‌ ‌or‌ ‌when‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌is‌ ‌fixed‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌distasteful‌ ‌partner.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌such‌ ‌a‌ ‌case,‌ ‌the‌ ‌bride‌ ‌elopes‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌partner‌ ‌of‌ ‌her‌ ‌choice.‌ ‌Such‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌by‌ ‌elopement‌ ‌is‌ ‌seen‌ ‌in‌ ‌almost‌ ‌all‌ ‌parts‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌world.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nUrbanization‌ ‌and‌ ‌Marriage‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌social‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌cities‌ ‌as‌ ‌marriage,‌ ‌kinship,‌ ‌family,‌ ‌caste‌ ‌and‌ ‌religion‌ ‌could‌ ‌be‌ ‌conceptualized‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌occurrences‌ ‌of‌ ‌\n395‌ ‌\ncomplex‌ ‌sets‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌interactions.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Marriage‌ ‌as‌ ‌an‌ ‌institution‌ ‌has‌ ‌traditionally‌ ‌been‌ ‌embedded‌ ‌and‌ ‌linked‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌institution‌ ‌of‌ ‌caste‌ ‌in‌ ‌India‌ ‌in‌ ‌both‌ ‌rural‌ ‌and‌ ‌urban‌ ‌areas.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Marriages‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌contracted‌ ‌keeping‌ ‌the‌ ‌caste‌ ‌or‌ ‌jati‌ ‌endogamy‌ ‌in‌ ‌mind.‌ ‌Rules‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌in‌ ‌each‌ ‌caste‌ ‌community‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌\nreligions‌ ‌of‌ ‌India‌ ‌follow‌ ‌different‌ ‌rules‌ ‌and‌ ‌regulations.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Giri‌ ‌Raj‌ ‌Gupta‌ ‌(1974)‌ ‌examines‌ ‌a‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌dimensions‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌rituals‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌context‌ ‌of‌ ‌intra-‌ ‌family‌ ‌roles‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌norms,‌ ‌implications‌ ‌of‌ ‌caste‌ ‌per‌ ‌for‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌family,‌ ‌social‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌castes,‌ ‌the‌ ‌‘nata’‌ ‌alliance‌ ‌(remarriage)‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌examines‌ ‌them‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌Rajasthan‌ ‌village.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌the‌ ‌urban‌ ‌cities,‌ ‌the‌ ‌phenomenon‌ ‌of‌ ‌inter‌ ‌caste‌ ‌marriages,‌ ‌inter-communal,‌ ‌inter‌ ‌regional,‌ ‌\n●and‌ ‌inter-‌ ‌religious‌ ‌marriages‌ ‌even‌ ‌though‌ ‌infrequent,‌ ‌must‌ ‌be‌ ‌studied‌ ‌in‌ ‌details‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌help‌ ‌\n●of‌ ‌such‌ ‌methods‌ ‌as‌ ‌extensive‌ ‌depth‌ ‌interviews,‌ ‌caste‌ ‌histories‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌geographies‌ ‌of‌ ‌\n●individuals‌ ‌involved.‌ ‌ ‌\n●“just‌ ‌twenty‌ ‌five‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago‌ ‌the‌ ‌instances‌ ‌of‌ ‌intercaste‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌were‌ ‌very‌ ‌few,‌ ‌and‌ ‌those‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌who‌ ‌dared‌ ‌to‌ ‌marry‌ ‌out‌ ‌side‌ ‌the‌ ‌caste‌ ‌\nhad‌ ‌to‌ ‌undergo‌ ‌truly‌ ‌great‌ ‌hardships.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Today‌ ‌the‌ ‌situation‌ ‌is‌ ‌altogether‌ ‌different‌ ‌not‌ ‌only‌ ‌has‌ ‌the‌ ‌privileges‌ ‌of‌ ‌inter-caste‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌become‌ ‌considerable,‌ ‌but‌ ‌even‌ ‌the‌ ‌difficulties‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌inter‌ ‌caste‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌couple‌ ‌have‌ ‌to‌ ‌face,‌ ‌have‌ ‌become‌ ‌comparatively‌ ‌quite‌ ‌mild.‌ ‌\n●C.‌ ‌T.‌ ‌Kannan’s‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌inter-caste‌ ‌and‌ ‌inter‌ ‌community‌ ‌marriages‌ ‌in‌ ‌Bombay‌ ‌is‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌two‌ ‌hundred‌ ‌inter-caste‌ ‌marriages‌ ‌and‌ ‌fifty‌ ‌\ninter-community‌ ‌marriages‌ ‌in‌ ‌Bombay‌ ‌during‌ ‌1958-59.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌couples‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌year‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌they‌ ‌got‌ ‌married‌ ‌shows‌ ‌a‌ ‌steady‌ ‌increase‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌incidence,‌ ‌a‌ ‌majority‌ ‌of‌ ‌64%‌ ‌\nbeing‌ ‌married‌ ‌after‌ ‌1950.‌ ‌ ‌\nEducation:‌ ‌\n●Kannan‌ ‌says‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌spread‌ ‌of‌ ‌higher‌ ‌education‌ ‌both‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌males‌ ‌and‌ ‌females‌ ‌is‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌reasons‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌increase‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nincidence‌ ‌of‌ ‌inter-caste‌ ‌and‌ ‌inter-religious‌ ‌marriages‌ ‌amongst‌ ‌the‌ ‌younger‌ ‌generations‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌cities.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Indeed,‌ ‌one‌ ‌could‌ ‌safely‌ ‌assert‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌graph‌ ‌of‌ ‌inter-caste‌ ‌marriages‌ ‌is‌ ‌steadily‌ ‌rising,‌ ‌never‌ ‌becoming‌ ‌a‌ ‌plateau,‌ ‌much‌ ‌less‌ ‌declining.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Even‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌newspaper‌ ‌columns,‌ ‌the‌ ‌pros‌ ‌and‌ ‌cons‌ ‌of‌ ‌inter-caste‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌are‌ ‌found‌ ‌freely‌ ‌debated‌ ‌particularly‌ ‌by‌ ‌ladies,‌ ‌a‌ ‌subject‌ ‌which‌ ‌\nwas‌ ‌formerly‌ ‌almost‌ ‌a‌ ‌taboo.‌ ‌\n●Due‌ ‌to‌ ‌modern‌ ‌education‌ ‌full‌ ‌of‌ ‌western‌ ‌thoughts‌ ‌and‌ ‌ideas,‌ ‌emancipation‌ ‌of‌ ‌women‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌association‌ ‌of‌ ‌young‌ ‌men‌ ‌and‌ ‌women‌ ‌with‌ ‌\nvarious‌ ‌political‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌organizations,‌ ‌new‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌incompatible‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌traditional‌ ‌norms‌ ‌and‌ ‌values‌ ‌are‌ ‌nurtured‌ ‌amongst‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌youth‌ ‌in‌ ‌cities.‌ ‌ ‌\n●As‌ ‌a‌ ‌result‌ ‌their‌ ‌attitudes‌ ‌towards‌ ‌traditional‌ ‌norms‌ ‌changes‌ ‌and‌ ‌new‌ ‌values‌ ‌develop‌ ‌which‌ ‌affects‌ ‌marriage,‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌and‌ ‌family.‌ ‌\n●Kannan‌ ‌in‌ ‌his‌ ‌study‌ ‌mentioned‌ ‌earlier‌ ‌found‌ ‌that‌ ‌besides‌ ‌schools‌ ‌and‌ ‌colleges,‌ ‌social‌ ‌organizations‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌Jati‌ ‌Seva‌ ‌Dal,‌ ‌Lok‌ ‌Sena,‌ ‌\nSwastik‌ ‌League,‌ ‌Kshariakya‌ ‌Parisad,‌ ‌etc.,‌ ‌have‌ ‌played‌ ‌a‌ ‌great‌ ‌role‌ ‌in‌ ‌influencing‌ ‌the‌ ‌younger‌ ‌generations‌ ‌in‌ ‌selection‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌partners.‌ ‌\nDecision‌ ‌making:‌ ‌\n●Most‌ ‌significant‌ ‌aspect‌ ‌of‌ ‌change‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌noticed‌ ‌was‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌young‌ ‌generation‌ ‌becomes‌ ‌individualistic‌ ‌by‌ ‌such‌ ‌influences‌ ‌and‌ ‌they‌ ‌take‌ ‌\ntheir‌ ‌own‌ ‌decision‌ ‌even‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌matter‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage.‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌become‌ ‌less‌ ‌caste-conscious‌ ‌than‌ ‌their‌ ‌elders‌ ‌and,‌ ‌therefore,‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌inter‌ ‌group‌ ‌relations‌ ‌they‌ ‌ignore‌ ‌caste‌ ‌and‌ ‌creed‌ ‌differences.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌many‌ ‌cases‌ ‌the‌ ‌objections‌ ‌to‌ ‌such‌ ‌inter-caste‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌parents‌ ‌was‌ ‌there‌ ‌but‌ ‌not‌ ‌always‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌caste‌ ‌considerations.‌ ‌ ‌\nCost:‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌observed‌ ‌that‌ ‌far‌ ‌more‌ ‌important‌ ‌considerations‌ ‌existed‌ ‌behind‌ ‌parental‌ ‌opposition‌ ‌than‌ ‌caste‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌child’s‌ ‌bride/‌ ‌groom.‌ ‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌were‌ ‌mainly‌ ‌the‌ ‌lack‌ ‌of‌ ‌wealth‌ ‌and‌ ‌status‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌partner.‌ ‌Where‌ ‌these‌ ‌factors‌ ‌were‌ ‌favourable,‌ ‌the‌ ‌parents‌ ‌had‌ ‌given‌ ‌their‌ ‌consent‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌cooperation‌ ‌to‌ ‌marriage,‌ ‌ignoring‌ ‌caste‌ ‌differences.‌ ‌Thus,‌ ‌education‌ ‌and‌ ‌socio‌ ‌economic‌ ‌background‌ ‌matters‌ ‌more‌ ‌in‌ ‌cities‌ ‌than‌ ‌\n396‌ ‌\ncaste.‌ ‌\nConjugal‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌a‌ ‌study‌ ‌by‌ ‌B.‌ ‌V.‌ ‌Shah‌ ‌of‌ ‌male‌ ‌students‌ ‌of‌ ‌Baroda‌ ‌University,‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌found‌ ‌that‌ ‌a‌ ‌higher‌ ‌proportion‌ ‌of‌ ‌unbetrothed‌ ‌students‌ ‌from‌ ‌urban‌ ‌\nbackground‌ ‌(cities,‌ ‌63%;‌ ‌towns‌ ‌14%)‌ ‌than‌ ‌from‌ ‌rural‌ ‌background‌ ‌(18%)‌ ‌existed.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌case‌ ‌of‌ ‌selection‌ ‌of‌ ‌bride‌ ‌too‌ ‌a‌ ‌higher‌ ‌proportion‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌urban‌ ‌background‌ ‌(cities‌ ‌61%;‌ ‌towns;‌ ‌47%)‌ ‌favoured‌ ‌at‌ ‌least‌ ‌a‌ ‌matriculate‌ ‌\n(i.e.‌ ‌high‌ ‌school‌ ‌graduate)‌ ‌than‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌rural‌ ‌background‌ ‌(only‌ ‌13%).‌ ‌ ‌\n●Thus,‌ ‌the‌ ‌non-traditionality‌ ‌as‌ ‌regards‌ ‌bride‌ ‌selection‌ ‌is‌ ‌found‌ ‌largely‌ ‌in‌ ‌urban‌ ‌areas,‌ ‌whereas‌ ‌traditionality‌ ‌is‌ ‌found‌ ‌proportionately‌ ‌\ngreater‌ ‌in‌ ‌rural‌ ‌areas‌ ‌than‌ ‌in‌ ‌urban‌ ‌areas.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌found‌ ‌that‌ ‌a‌ ‌‘‌new‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌wifehood‌’‌ ‌(i.e.‌ ‌emphasis‌ ‌on‌ ‌conjugal‌ ‌relationship)‌ ‌has‌ ‌emerged‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌urban‌ ‌\nliving‌ ‌in‌ ‌contemporary‌ ‌society‌ ‌in‌ ‌India.‌ ‌ ‌\n●M.‌ ‌S.‌ ‌Gore‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌community‌ ‌near‌ ‌Delhi‌ ‌found‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌urban‌ ‌educated‌ ‌respondents‌ ‌who‌ ‌had‌ ‌changed‌ ‌their‌ ‌occupation‌ ‌felt‌ ‌‘closer‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌their‌ ‌wife’‌ ‌than‌ ‌their‌ ‌mother.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Thus,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌found‌ ‌that‌ ‌in‌ ‌urban‌ ‌society‌ ‌the‌ ‌joint‌ ‌family‌ ‌living‌ ‌in‌ ‌India‌ ‌which‌ ‌traditionally‌ ‌deemphasizes‌ ‌the‌ ‌direct‌ ‌conjugal‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌\nbetween‌ ‌man‌ ‌and‌ ‌his‌ ‌wife‌ ‌seems‌ ‌to‌ ‌have‌ ‌changed‌ ‌as‌ ‌nearly‌ ‌three-quarters‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌highly‌ ‌urbanized‌ ‌male‌ ‌respondents‌ ‌tend‌ ‌to‌ ‌favour‌ ‌\ncloseness‌ ‌to‌ ‌wife.’‌ ‌\nMarriage‌ ‌Age:‌ ‌\n●Another‌ ‌change‌ ‌observed‌ ‌by‌ ‌sociologists‌ ‌of‌ ‌urban‌ ‌areas‌ ‌is‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌age‌ ‌at‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌has‌ ‌increased.‌ ‌\n●But‌ ‌the‌ ‌question‌ ‌of‌ ‌self‌ ‌choice‌ ‌or‌ ‌‘arranged‌ ‌marriage’‌ ‌still‌ ‌remains‌ ‌a‌ ‌debatable‌ ‌point.‌ ‌\n●Therefore,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌quite‌ ‌clear‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌available‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌situation‌ ‌in‌ ‌urban‌ ‌India‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌automatically‌ ‌conducive‌ ‌to‌ ‌increase‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nfreedom‌ ‌of‌ ‌choice‌ ‌for‌ ‌one’s‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌since‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌is‌ ‌still‌ ‌closely‌ ‌tied‌ ‌to‌ ‌family‌ ‌(and‌ ‌hence‌ ‌to‌ ‌parental‌ ‌authority‌ ‌and‌ ‌kin-constraint)‌ ‌and‌ ‌\ncaste.‌ ‌\n●Aileen‌ ‌Ross‌ ‌in‌ ‌her‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Hindu‌ ‌families‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌city‌ ‌of‌ ‌Bangalore‌ ‌found‌ ‌that‌ ‌young‌ ‌people‌ ‌tend‌ ‌to‌ ‌select‌ ‌their‌ ‌spouse‌ ‌themselves‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nthen‌ ‌take‌ ‌the‌ ‌approval‌ ‌from‌ ‌their‌ ‌parents.‌ ‌But‌ ‌Vatuk‌ ‌is‌ ‌opposed‌ ‌to‌ ‌this‌ ‌view.‌ ‌ ‌\n●She‌ ‌studied‌ ‌two‌ ‌middle‌ ‌class‌ ‌neighborhoods‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌North‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌city‌ ‌of‌ ‌Meerut.‌ ‌She‌ ‌found‌ ‌only‌ ‌four‌ ‌cases‌ ‌of‌ ‌so-called‌ ‌“love‌ ‌marriages”‌ ‌\n(i.e.‌ ‌marriages‌ ‌of‌ ‌personal‌ ‌choice)‌ ‌during‌ ‌her‌ ‌field-work‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌mohalla‌ ‌residents.‌ ‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌occurred‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌circle‌ ‌of‌ ‌relatives‌ ‌and‌ ‌friends,‌ ‌involving‌ ‌either‌ ‌fellow‌ ‌students‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌co-educational‌ ‌college,‌ ‌fellow‌ ‌workers‌ ‌in‌ ‌an‌ ‌\noffice,‌ ‌affinal‌ ‌kins‌ ‌or‌ ‌residents‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌dwelling‌ ‌\n●During‌ ‌her‌ ‌study‌ ‌she‌ ‌did‌ ‌not‌ ‌find‌ ‌even‌ ‌a‌ ‌single‌ ‌case‌ ‌of‌ ‌arranged‌ ‌inter-caste‌ ‌marriage.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌significance‌ ‌of‌ ‌caste‌ ‌endogamy‌ ‌too‌ ‌remains‌ ‌largely‌ ‌unchanged‌ ‌as‌ ‌‘arranged‌ ‌marriages’‌ ‌are‌ ‌contracted‌ ‌traditionally‌ ‌within‌ ‌one’s‌ ‌own‌ ‌\ncaste.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n‘Live-in‌ ‌relationship’‌ ‌ ‌\n●Cohabitation‌ ‌or‌ ‌live-in‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌in‌ ‌India‌ ‌though‌ ‌not‌ ‌illegal,‌ ‌is‌ ‌considered‌ ‌socially‌ ‌and‌ ‌morally‌ ‌improper.‌ ‌Cohabitation‌ ‌is‌ ‌prevalent‌ ‌\nmostly‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌people‌ ‌living‌ ‌in‌ ‌metro‌ ‌cities‌ ‌in‌ ‌India.‌ ‌\n●Couples‌ ‌cohabit,‌ ‌rather‌ ‌than‌ ‌marry,‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌variety‌ ‌of‌ ‌reasons.‌ ‌They‌ ‌may‌ ‌want‌ ‌to‌ ‌test‌ ‌their‌ ‌compatibility‌ ‌before‌ ‌they‌ ‌commit‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌legal‌ ‌union.‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌may‌ ‌want‌ ‌to‌ ‌maintain‌ ‌their‌ ‌single‌ ‌status‌ ‌for‌ ‌financial‌ ‌reasons.‌ ‌In‌ ‌some‌ ‌cases,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌those‌ ‌involving‌ ‌gay‌ ‌or‌ ‌lesbian‌ ‌couples,‌ ‌or‌ ‌\nindividuals‌ ‌already‌ ‌married‌ ‌to‌ ‌another‌ ‌person,‌ ‌the‌ ‌law‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌allow‌ ‌them‌ ‌to‌ ‌marry.‌ ‌In‌ ‌other‌ ‌cases,‌ ‌the‌ ‌partners‌ ‌may‌ ‌feel‌ ‌that‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌is‌ ‌\n397‌ ‌\nunnecessary.‌ ‌\n●Marriage‌ ‌gives‌ ‌permanence‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌temporary‌ ‌union,‌ ‌pushing‌ ‌two‌ ‌divergent‌ ‌personalities‌ ‌to‌ ‌adjust‌ ‌and‌ ‌care‌ ‌for‌ ‌each‌ ‌other.‌ ‌It‌ ‌asks‌ ‌for‌ ‌\ncommitment‌ ‌and‌ ‌sacrifices.‌ ‌It‌ ‌asks‌ ‌to‌ ‌redeem‌ ‌your‌ ‌ego‌ ‌in‌ ‌favor‌ ‌of‌ ‌harmony.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌provides‌ ‌you‌ ‌to‌ ‌bring‌ ‌balance‌ ‌in‌ ‌life‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌cost‌ ‌of‌ ‌self‌ ‌determination;‌ ‌at‌ ‌age‌ ‌twenty‌ ‌five‌ ‌plus,‌ ‌it‌ ‌doesn’t‌ ‌get‌ ‌easier.‌ ‌\n●Advantages‌ ‌of‌ ‌such‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌are:‌ ‌\n○That‌ ‌you‌ ‌need‌ ‌not‌ ‌stick‌ ‌together‌ ‌if‌ ‌both‌ ‌partners‌ ‌are‌ ‌really‌ ‌incompatible.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌trauma‌ ‌is‌ ‌much‌ ‌less‌ ‌than‌ ‌divorce‌ ‌because‌ ‌divorce‌ ‌itself‌ ‌is‌ ‌hurtful‌ ‌with‌ ‌false‌ ‌allegations‌ ‌and‌ ‌counter‌ ‌allegations‌ ‌making‌ ‌it‌ ‌a‌ ‌\ncruel‌ ‌battle‌ ‌of‌ ‌wits‌ ‌where‌ ‌no‌ ‌one‌ ‌wins‌ ‌except‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌the‌ ‌lawyers.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nNow‌ ‌the‌ ‌question‌ ‌that‌ ‌arises‌ ‌is‌ ‌whether‌ ‌live-in‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌should‌ ‌be‌ ‌allowed‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌societies‌ ‌or‌ ‌not.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n●The‌ ‌opinions‌ ‌greatly‌ ‌vary.‌ ‌Most‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌traditional‌ ‌Indians‌ ‌are‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌view‌ ‌that‌ ‌if‌ ‌a‌ ‌couple‌ ‌is‌ ‌so‌ ‌much‌ ‌in‌ ‌love‌ ‌with‌ ‌each‌ ‌other;‌ ‌they‌ ‌should‌ ‌get‌ ‌\nmarried‌ ‌and‌ ‌then‌ ‌stay‌ ‌together‌ ‌instead‌ ‌of‌ ‌staying‌ ‌together‌ ‌unmarried.‌ ‌\n●But‌ ‌21stcentury‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌century‌ ‌of‌ ‌Westernization.‌ ‌There‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌common‌ ‌saying‌ ‌“You‌ ‌have‌ ‌to‌ ‌pay‌ ‌a‌ ‌price‌ ‌for‌ ‌everything”.‌ ‌This‌ ‌saying‌ ‌is‌ ‌indeed‌ ‌\ntrue.‌ ‌When‌ ‌Indians‌ ‌are‌ ‌accepting‌ ‌almost‌ ‌everything‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌western‌ ‌culture,‌ ‌their‌ ‌dressing‌ ‌sense,‌ ‌their‌ ‌language,‌ ‌their‌ ‌food,‌ ‌their‌ ‌\nmannerisms,‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌things‌ ‌would‌ ‌most‌ ‌certainly‌ ‌follow.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌youth‌ ‌today,‌ ‌almost‌ ‌all‌ ‌of‌ ‌them‌ ‌are‌ ‌deeply‌ ‌fond‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Western‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌result‌ ‌obviously‌ ‌is‌ ‌blindly‌ ‌following‌ ‌the‌ ‌Western‌ ‌culture‌ ‌\neven‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌evils‌ ‌of‌ ‌excessive‌ ‌smoking‌ ‌and‌ ‌drinking‌ ‌for‌ ‌instance.‌ ‌\n●Youth‌ ‌today‌ ‌are‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌opinion‌ ‌that‌ ‌since‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌financially‌ ‌independent‌ ‌and‌ ‌after‌ ‌they‌ ‌attain‌ ‌adulthood,‌ ‌they‌ ‌have‌ ‌the‌ ‌right‌ ‌to‌ ‌live‌ ‌as‌ ‌they‌ ‌\nwant‌ ‌and‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌person‌ ‌they‌ ‌want.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌most‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌educated‌ ‌and‌ ‌upper‌ ‌class‌ ‌societies,‌ ‌live-‌ ‌in‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌commo‌ ‌phenomenon.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌more‌ ‌Westernization‌ ‌is‌ ‌being‌ ‌accepted‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌society,‌ ‌the‌ ‌more‌ ‌live-‌ ‌in‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌system‌ ‌is‌ ‌gaining‌ ‌significance.‌ ‌\n●At‌ ‌times‌ ‌the‌ ‌question‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌whether‌ ‌live-‌ ‌in‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌are‌ ‌right‌ ‌or‌ ‌wrong,‌ ‌the‌ ‌question‌ ‌that‌ ‌arises‌ ‌is‌ ‌that‌ ‌have‌ ‌Indians‌ ‌totally‌ ‌forgotten‌ ‌\ntheir‌ ‌own‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌its‌ ‌significance.‌ ‌\n ‌\nConclusion‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌youth‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌believe‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌sacred‌ ‌institution‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌but‌ ‌the‌ ‌fact‌ ‌is‌ ‌that‌ ‌their‌ ‌priorities‌ ‌have‌ ‌changed.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Couples‌ ‌today‌ ‌feel‌ ‌that‌ ‌they‌ ‌need‌ ‌to‌ ‌understand‌ ‌each‌ ‌other‌ ‌properly‌ ‌before‌ ‌entering‌ ‌into‌ ‌the‌ ‌sacred‌ ‌institution‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌way‌ ‌of‌ ‌thinking‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌people‌ ‌has‌ ‌changed‌ ‌which‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌considered‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌fruit‌ ‌of‌ ‌Westernization.‌ ‌\nAdditional‌ ‌Reading:‌ ‌Updated‌ ‌on‌ ‌International‌ ‌Women’s‌ ‌Day-8th‌ ‌March‌ ‌2021‌ ‌\n ‌\nA‌ ‌feminist‌ ‌anthropologist‌ ‌who‌ ‌pioneered‌ ‌studies‌ ‌on‌ ‌matriliny,‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌\n ‌\nLeela‌ ‌Dube,‌ ‌was‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌early‌ ‌pioneers‌ ‌of‌ ‌feminist‌ ‌scholarship‌ ‌in‌ ‌India‌ ‌along‌ ‌with‌ ‌Irawati‌ ‌Karve,‌ ‌Vina‌ ‌Majumdar,‌ ‌and‌ ‌Lotika‌ ‌Sarkar.‌ ‌Scan‌ ‌\nthrough‌ ‌the‌ ‌acknowledgements‌ ‌and‌ ‌citations‌ ‌of‌ ‌any‌ ‌sociological‌ ‌or‌ ‌anthropological‌ ‌book‌ ‌on‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌or‌ ‌gender‌ ‌in‌ ‌India,‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌1960s‌ ‌till‌ ‌the‌ ‌\npresent,‌ ‌and‌ ‌her‌ ‌name‌ ‌comes‌ ‌up‌ ‌with‌ ‌unfailing‌ ‌regularity.‌ ‌\n ‌\n398‌ ‌\nIn‌ ‌a‌ ‌delightful‌ ‌autobiographical‌ ‌essay‌ ‌published‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Economic‌ ‌and‌ ‌Political‌ ‌Weekly‌ ‌in‌ ‌2000‌ ‌(‘Doing‌ ‌Kinship‌ ‌and‌ ‌Gender'),‌ ‌Leela‌ ‌Dube‌ ‌nee‌ ‌\nAmbardekar‌ ‌describes‌ ‌the‌ ‌early‌ ‌influences‌ ‌that‌ ‌determined‌ ‌her‌ ‌future‌ ‌interests‌ ‌–‌ ‌her‌ ‌middle‌ ‌class‌ ‌Marathi‌ ‌Brahmin‌ ‌upbringing‌ ‌(her‌ ‌sister,‌ ‌Sumati‌ ‌\nMutatkar‌ ‌went‌ ‌on‌ ‌to‌ ‌become‌ ‌a‌ ‌renowned‌ ‌classical‌ ‌vocalist),‌ ‌her‌ ‌mother's‌ ‌generosity‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌family,‌ ‌literature‌ ‌that‌ ‌showed‌ ‌both‌ ‌the‌ ‌suffering‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌strength‌ ‌of‌ ‌women,‌ ‌the‌ ‌everyday‌ ‌gossip‌ ‌around‌ ‌familial‌ ‌politics‌ ‌and‌ ‌intrigues,‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌nationalist‌ ‌movement.‌ ‌Given‌ ‌the‌ ‌inchoate‌ ‌feminism‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌time,‌ ‌she‌ ‌felt‌ ‌she‌ ‌had‌ ‌to‌ ‌marry‌ ‌but‌ ‌if‌ ‌she‌ ‌was‌ ‌to‌ ‌do‌ ‌so,‌ ‌she‌ ‌wanted‌ ‌a‌ ‌partner‌ ‌who‌ ‌would‌ ‌encourage‌ ‌rather‌ ‌than‌ ‌stultify‌ ‌her‌ ‌intellectually.‌ ‌While‌ ‌\ndoing‌ ‌an‌ ‌MA‌ ‌in‌ ‌Political‌ ‌Science‌ ‌at‌ ‌Nagpur‌ ‌University‌ ‌she‌ ‌heard‌ ‌of‌ ‌Shyama‌ ‌Charan‌ ‌Dube,‌ ‌a‌ ‌reputedly‌ ‌brilliant‌ ‌student,‌ ‌and‌ ‌decided‌ ‌to‌ ‌propose‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nhim.‌ ‌He‌ ‌later‌ ‌became‌ ‌a‌ ‌well-known‌ ‌anthropologist.‌ ‌Inevitably,‌ ‌Leela‌ ‌Dube‌ ‌had‌ ‌to‌ ‌carve‌ ‌her‌ ‌career‌ ‌around‌ ‌his,‌ ‌the‌ ‌fate‌ ‌of‌ ‌many‌ ‌women‌ ‌not‌ ‌just‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nher‌ ‌generation‌ ‌but‌ ‌also‌ ‌today.‌ ‌However,‌ ‌as‌ ‌with‌ ‌other‌ ‌such‌ ‌inspiring‌ ‌women,‌ ‌she‌ ‌managed‌ ‌to‌ ‌balance‌ ‌both‌ ‌home‌ ‌and‌ ‌work,‌ ‌and‌ ‌one‌ ‌might‌ ‌even‌ ‌\nsay,‌ ‌surpassed‌ ‌her‌ ‌husband‌ ‌in‌ ‌her‌ ‌sociological‌ ‌legacy.‌ ‌She‌ ‌taught‌ ‌at‌ ‌Sagar‌ ‌University‌ ‌from‌ ‌1960-75,‌ ‌and‌ ‌held‌ ‌several‌ ‌fellowships‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌ICSSR,‌ ‌\nTeen‌ ‌Murti,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Centre‌ ‌for‌ ‌Women's‌ ‌Development‌ ‌Studies‌ ‌among‌ ‌others.‌ ‌\n ‌\nLeela‌ ‌Dube's‌ ‌Ph.D.‌ ‌(1953,‌ ‌Anthropology)‌ ‌was‌ ‌on‌ ‌women‌ ‌in‌ ‌three‌ ‌adivasi‌ ‌groups,‌ ‌comparing‌ ‌their‌ ‌lives‌ ‌to‌ ‌upper‌ ‌caste‌ ‌women,‌ ‌but‌ ‌she‌ ‌is‌ ‌best‌ ‌\nknown‌ ‌for‌ ‌her‌ ‌work‌ ‌on‌ ‌Muslim‌ ‌matriliny‌ ‌in‌ ‌Lakshwadeep,‌ ‌Matriliny‌ ‌and‌ ‌Islam:‌ ‌Religion‌ ‌and‌ ‌society‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Laccadives‌ ‌(1969)‌ ‌and‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nkinship‌ ‌relations‌ ‌more‌ ‌broadly.‌ ‌Like‌ ‌many‌ ‌women‌ ‌scholars,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌her‌ ‌own‌ ‌experience‌ ‌which‌ ‌deeply‌ ‌shaped‌ ‌her‌ ‌interests‌ ‌-‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌as‌ ‌she‌ ‌\ndescribes‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌relation‌ ‌of‌ ‌both‌ ‌“gratification”‌ ‌and‌ ‌“agony”.‌ ‌In‌ ‌between,‌ ‌she‌ ‌also‌ ‌collaborated‌ ‌with‌ ‌S.C.‌ ‌Dube‌ ‌on‌ ‌research‌ ‌among‌ ‌rural‌ ‌\ncommunities‌ ‌in‌ ‌Uttar‌ ‌Pradesh‌ ‌and‌ ‌Maharashtra.‌ ‌However,‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌her‌ ‌work‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌member‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌National‌ ‌Committee‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌Status‌ ‌of‌ ‌Women‌ ‌\nbetween‌ ‌1971‌ ‌and‌ ‌1974‌ ‌which‌ ‌transformed‌ ‌her‌ ‌into‌ ‌an‌ ‌established‌ ‌and‌ ‌internationally‌ ‌recognised‌ ‌feminist‌ ‌scholar.‌ ‌She‌ ‌served‌ ‌on‌ ‌several‌ ‌boards,‌ ‌\nincluding‌ ‌as‌ ‌chairperson‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Commission‌ ‌on‌ ‌Women‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌International‌ ‌Union‌ ‌of‌ ‌Anthropological‌ ‌and‌ ‌Ethnological‌ ‌Sciences,‌ ‌from‌ ‌1976-1993,‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌as‌ ‌series‌ ‌editor‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌women‌ ‌and‌ ‌household‌ ‌volumes‌ ‌published‌ ‌by‌ ‌Sage.‌ ‌\n ‌\nIn‌ ‌2007,‌ ‌Leela‌ ‌Dube‌ ‌was‌ ‌given‌ ‌the‌ ‌Lifetime‌ ‌Achievement‌ ‌Award‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌Sociological‌ ‌Society,‌ ‌and‌ ‌was‌ ‌awarded‌ ‌the‌ ‌UGC‌ ‌National‌ ‌Swami‌ ‌\nPranavananda‌ ‌Saraswati‌ ‌Award‌ ‌for‌ ‌2005.‌ ‌She‌ ‌remained‌ ‌active‌ ‌and‌ ‌engaged‌ ‌with‌ ‌scholarship‌ ‌till‌ ‌almost‌ ‌the‌ ‌very‌ ‌end.‌ ‌Her‌ ‌book,‌ ‌Anthropological‌ ‌\nExplorations‌ ‌in‌ ‌Gender:‌ ‌Intersecting‌ ‌fields,‌ ‌was‌ ‌published‌ ‌by‌ ‌Sage‌ ‌in‌ ‌2001.‌ ‌Of‌ ‌a‌ ‌generation‌ ‌of‌ ‌multilingual‌ ‌scholars‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌now‌ ‌sadly‌ ‌passing‌ ‌\naway,‌ ‌her‌ ‌very‌ ‌last‌ ‌publication‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌Marathi‌ ‌Manavashastratil‌ ‌lingbhavachi‌ ‌shodhamohim‌ ‌(2009).‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n2.4‌ ‌Family‌ ‌:‌ ‌Definition‌ ‌and‌ ‌Universality;‌ ‌Family,‌ ‌household‌ ‌and‌ ‌Domestic‌ ‌groups;‌ ‌Functions‌ ‌of‌ ‌family;-Part-I‌ ‌\n ‌\nDefinition‌ ‌and‌ ‌universality;‌ ‌\nIntroduction‌ ‌\n●Family‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌‌basic‌ ‌social‌ ‌unit‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌society‌.‌ ‌\n399‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌nature‌ ‌and‌ ‌structure‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌vary‌ ‌from‌ ‌society.‌ ‌‌Basically‌ ‌a‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌social‌ ‌and‌ ‌economic‌ ‌unit‌ ‌consisting‌ ‌of‌ ‌parents‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌\nchildren.‌ ‌\n●Members‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌family‌ ‌are‌ ‌certain‌ ‌rights‌ ‌norms‌ ‌and‌ ‌obligations.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌‌interpersonal‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌makes‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌an‌ ‌endurable‌ ‌social‌ ‌unit.‌ ‌\n●Families‌ ‌usually‌ ‌live‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌single‌ ‌household.‌ ‌It‌ ‌provides‌ ‌a‌ ‌learning‌ ‌environment‌ ‌for‌ ‌children.‌ ‌\n●Anthropologists‌ ‌generally‌ ‌classify‌ ‌most‌ ‌family‌ ‌organizations‌ ‌as‌ ‌matrifocal‌ ‌(a‌ ‌mother‌ ‌and‌ ‌her‌ ‌children);‌ ‌patrifocal‌ ‌(a‌ ‌father‌ ‌and‌ ‌his‌ ‌children);‌ ‌\nconjugal‌ ‌(a‌ ‌wife,‌ ‌her‌ ‌husband,‌ ‌and‌ ‌children,‌ ‌also‌ ‌called‌ ‌the‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌family);‌ ‌avuncular‌ ‌(for‌ ‌example,‌ ‌a‌ ‌grandparent,‌ ‌a‌ ‌brother,‌ ‌his‌ ‌sister,‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nher‌ ‌children);‌ ‌or‌ ‌extended‌ ‌(parents‌ ‌and‌ ‌children‌ ‌co-reside‌ ‌with‌ ‌other‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌one‌ ‌parent's‌ ‌family).‌ ‌\n●Sociologists‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌agree‌ ‌on‌ ‌one‌ ‌standard‌ ‌definition‌ ‌of‌ ‌‘the‌ ‌family’.‌ ‌\n●Functionalist‌ ‌sociologists‌ ‌traditionally‌ ‌used‌ ‌narrow‌ ‌definitions‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family,‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌unit‌ ‌had‌ ‌to‌ ‌consist‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌man‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌woman‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌\ncommitted‌ ‌sexual‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌living‌ ‌together‌ ‌with‌ ‌their‌ ‌children.‌ ‌\n●More‌ ‌contemporary‌ ‌‌Postmodern‌ ‌sociologists‌ ‌prefer‌ ‌much‌ ‌broader‌ ‌definitions‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌which‌ ‌extend‌ ‌the‌ ‌concept‌ ‌to‌ ‌include‌ ‌anyone‌ ‌an‌ ‌\nindividual‌ ‌thinks‌ ‌of‌ ‌as‌ ‌being‌ ‌‘part‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family’,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌friends‌ ‌or‌ ‌even‌ ‌pets.‌ ‌\n●There‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌‘right’‌ ‌or‌ ‌‘wrong’‌ ‌definition‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family,‌ ‌but‌ ‌you‌ ‌do‌ ‌need‌ ‌to‌ ‌know‌ ‌how‌ ‌sociologists‌ ‌define‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌to‌ ‌really‌ ‌understand‌ ‌their‌ ‌\nperspective‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌family,‌ ‌and‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌able‌ ‌to‌ ‌evaluate‌ ‌the‌ ‌different‌ ‌perspectives.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Functionalism‌ ‌‌considers‌ ‌‌a‌ ‌culture‌ ‌as‌ ‌an‌ ‌interrelated‌ ‌whole,‌ ‌not‌ ‌a‌ ‌collection‌ ‌of‌ ‌isolated‌ ‌traits‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Like‌ ‌a‌ ‌human‌ ‌being‌ ‌has‌ ‌various‌ ‌organs‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌interconnected‌ ‌and‌ ‌necessary‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌body‌ ‌to‌ ‌function‌ ‌correctly,‌ ‌so‌ ‌society‌ ‌\nis‌ ‌a‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌interconnected‌ ‌parts‌ ‌that‌ ‌make‌ ‌the‌ ‌whole‌ ‌function‌ ‌efficiently.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Structural‌ ‌functionalism‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌functionalism‌ ‌that‌ ‌arose‌ ‌in‌ ‌Great‌ ‌Britain.‌ ‌‌In‌ ‌the‌ ‌structural‌ ‌functionalist‌ ‌approach,‌ ‌\nsociety,‌ ‌its‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌and‌ ‌roles,‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌appropriate‌ ‌thing‌ ‌to‌ ‌study.‌ ‌Cultural‌ ‌traits‌ ‌supported‌ ‌or‌ ‌helped‌ ‌to‌ ‌preserve‌ ‌social‌ ‌\nstructures.‌ ‌\n●Postmodernists‌ ‌‌claim‌ ‌that‌ ‌‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌impossible‌ ‌for‌ ‌anyone‌ ‌to‌ ‌have‌ ‌objective‌ ‌and‌ ‌neutral‌ ‌knowledge‌ ‌of‌ ‌another‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nDefinitions‌ ‌by‌ ‌Thinkers‌ ‌\n●Westermarck‌ ‌who‌ ‌had‌ ‌done‌ ‌a‌ ‌detailed‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌institution‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌concluded‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌family‌ ‌emerged‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌male‌ ‌possessiveness‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌jealousy.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌his‌ ‌work‌ ‌‌The‌ ‌History‌ ‌of‌ ‌Human‌ ‌Marriage‌ ‌(1922)‌ ‌he‌ ‌asserted‌ ‌that‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌growing‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌property,‌ ‌males‌ ‌started‌ ‌the‌ ‌\ninstitution‌ ‌of‌ ‌family‌ ‌to‌ ‌protect‌ ‌and‌ ‌safeguard‌ ‌their‌ ‌property.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌theory‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌‌direct‌ ‌criticism‌ ‌of‌ ‌Morgan’s‌ ‌theory‌ ‌wherein‌ ‌the‌ ‌origin‌ ‌of‌ ‌family‌ ‌was‌ ‌ascribed‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌bonding‌ ‌of‌ ‌mother-‌ ‌siblings‌.‌ ‌\nWestermarck‌ ‌though‌ ‌an‌ ‌adherent‌ ‌follower‌ ‌of‌ ‌evolutionism‌ ‌went‌ ‌a‌ ‌bit‌ ‌too‌ ‌far‌ ‌while‌ ‌postulating‌ ‌the‌ ‌origin‌ ‌of‌ ‌monogamy‌ ‌as‌ ‌he‌ ‌traced‌ ‌it‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌the‌ ‌mammals‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌birds‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Functionalist‌ ‌definition‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌\n○Functionalist‌ ‌Sociologist‌ ‌George‌ ‌Peter‌ ‌Murdock‌ ‌used‌ ‌the‌ ‌following‌ ‌definition‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌starting‌ ‌point‌ ‌in‌ ‌his‌ ‌classic‌ ‌cross‌ ‌\nnational‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌families‌ ‌in‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌250‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌\n400‌ ‌\n○According‌ ‌to‌ ‌‌G.P.‌ ‌Murdock‌,‌ ‌a‌ ‌social‌ ‌group‌ ‌characterized‌ ‌by‌ ‌residence‌ ‌economic‌ ‌cooperation‌ ‌and‌ ‌reproduction.‌ ‌It‌ ‌includes‌ ‌adults‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nboth‌ ‌sexes‌ ‌at‌ ‌least‌ ‌two‌ ‌of‌ ‌them‌ ‌who‌ ‌maintain‌ ‌a‌ ‌socially‌ ‌approved‌ ‌sexual‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌and‌ ‌one‌ ‌or‌ ‌more‌ ‌children‌ ‌phone‌ ‌or‌ ‌adopted‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌socially‌ ‌cohabiting‌ ‌adults.‌ ‌\n○Murdock‌ ‌distinguished‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌family‌ ‌and‌ ‌extended‌ ‌family.‌ ‌He‌ ‌also‌ ‌argued‌ ‌that‌ ‌“the‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌universal‌ ‌social‌ ‌\ngroup.‌ ‌Either‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌soul‌ ‌prevailing‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌basic‌ ‌unit‌ ‌from‌ ‌which‌ ‌more‌ ‌Complex‌ ‌forms‌ ‌are‌ ‌compounded.‌ ‌If‌ ‌they‌ ‌\nexist‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌unique‌ ‌and‌ ‌strongly‌ ‌functional‌ ‌group‌ ‌in‌ ‌every‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\nMurdock‌ ‌suggested‌ ‌there‌ ‌were‌ ‌‘four‌ ‌essential‌ ‌functions’‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌family:‌ ‌\n ‌\n1.‌ ‌Stable‌ ‌satisfaction‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌sex‌ ‌drive‌ ‌–‌ ‌within‌ ‌monogamous‌ ‌relationships,‌ ‌which‌ ‌prevents‌ ‌sexual‌ ‌jealousy.‌ ‌\n2.‌ ‌The‌ ‌biological‌ ‌reproduction‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌next‌ ‌generation‌ ‌–‌ ‌without‌ ‌which‌ ‌society‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌continue.‌ ‌\n3.‌ ‌Socialisation‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌young‌ ‌–‌ ‌teaching‌ ‌basic‌ ‌norms‌ ‌and‌ ‌values‌ ‌\n4.‌ ‌Meeting‌ ‌its‌ ‌members‌ ‌economic‌ ‌needs‌ ‌–‌ ‌producing‌ ‌food‌ ‌and‌ ‌shelter‌ ‌for‌ ‌example.‌ ‌\n ‌\nCriticisms‌ ‌of‌ ‌Murdock‌ ‌\n○Feminist‌ ‌Sociologists‌ ‌argue‌ ‌that‌ ‌arguing‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌essential‌ ‌is‌ ‌ideological‌ ‌because‌ ‌traditional‌ ‌family‌ ‌structures‌ ‌typically‌ ‌\ndisadvantage‌ ‌women.‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌feasible‌ ‌that‌ ‌other‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌could‌ ‌perform‌ ‌the‌ ‌functions‌ ‌above.‌ ‌\n○Anthropological‌ ‌research‌ ‌has‌ ‌shown‌ ‌that‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌some‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌which‌ ‌don’t‌ ‌appear‌ ‌to‌ ‌have‌ ‌‘families’‌ ‌–‌ ‌the‌ ‌Nayar‌ ‌for‌ ‌example.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌‌Charles‌ ‌Cooley‌,‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌primary‌ ‌group‌ ‌and‌ ‌we‌ ‌are‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌primary‌ ‌group.‌ ‌the‌ ‌history‌ ‌of‌ ‌mankind‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌history‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nfamily.At‌ ‌birth‌ ‌a‌ ‌child‌ ‌is‌ ‌only‌ ‌a‌ ‌biological‌ ‌being,‌ ‌his‌ ‌needs‌ ‌are‌ ‌fulfilled‌ ‌by‌ ‌his‌ ‌family.‌ ‌Right‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌birth‌ ‌to‌ ‌death,‌ ‌The‌ ‌family‌ ‌exert‌ ‌a‌ ‌constant‌ ‌\ninfluence‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌child.‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌‌Anderson‌,‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌a‌ ‌single‌ ‌person‌ ‌who‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌a‌ ‌member‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌family‌ ‌in‌ ‌one‌ ‌or‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌way.‌ ‌According‌ ‌to‌ ‌him‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌\ntwo‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌family.‌ ‌\n○Family‌ ‌of‌ ‌orientation-‌ ‌where‌ ‌we‌ ‌are‌ ‌born,‌ ‌we‌ ‌are‌ ‌a‌ ‌member‌ ‌\n○Family‌ ‌of‌ ‌procreation-‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌urge‌ ‌is‌ ‌fulfilled‌ ‌to‌ ‌give‌ ‌birth‌ ‌to‌ ‌another.‌ ‌family‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌we‌ ‌procreate‌ ‌or‌ ‌give‌ ‌birth.‌ ‌\n●MacIver‌ ‌&‌ ‌Page‌:‌ ‌In‌ ‌their‌ ‌book‌ ‌'The‌ ‌society'‌ ‌–‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌defined‌ ‌by‌ ‌sex‌ ‌relationship,‌ ‌sufficiently‌ ‌precise‌ ‌and‌ ‌enduring‌ ‌to‌ ‌provide‌ ‌for‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌procreation‌ ‌and‌ ‌upbringing‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌children.‌ ‌\n●Dgbourn‌ ‌&‌ ‌Nimkoff:‌ ‌‌In‌ ‌their‌ ‌book‌ ‌'A‌ ‌handbook‌ ‌of‌ ‌sociology'‌ ‌–‌ ‌\"Family‌ ‌is‌ ‌more‌ ‌or‌ ‌less‌ ‌a‌ ‌durable‌ ‌association‌ ‌of‌ ‌husband‌ ‌and‌ ‌wife‌ ‌with‌ ‌or‌ ‌\nwithout‌ ‌children‌ ‌or‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌man‌ ‌or‌ ‌woman‌ ‌along‌ ‌with‌ ‌their‌ ‌children\".‌ ‌\n●Kingsley‌ ‌Davis:‌ ‌In‌ ‌his‌ ‌book‌ ‌\"Human‌ ‌society\"‌ ‌–‌ ‌defines‌ ‌family‌ ‌as‌ ‌–‌ ‌\"Family‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌persons‌ ‌whose‌ ‌relation‌ ‌to‌ ‌one‌ ‌another‌ ‌are‌ ‌based‌ ‌\nupon‌ ‌consequinity‌ ‌and‌ ‌who‌ ‌are‌ ‌therefore‌ ‌kin‌ ‌to‌ ‌one‌ ‌another\".‌ ‌He‌ ‌means‌ ‌where‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌blood‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌although‌ ‌hubby‌ ‌and‌ ‌wife‌ ‌have‌ ‌sex‌ ‌\nrelation.‌ ‌\n●Postmodern‌ ‌definitions‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌\n401‌ ‌\n●Because‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌diversity‌ ‌within‌ ‌family‌ ‌life‌ ‌in‌ ‌contemporary‌ ‌Britain,‌ ‌‌post-modern‌ ‌thinkers‌ ‌suggest‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌better‌ ‌to‌ ‌use‌ ‌a‌ ‌broader‌ ‌\ndefinition‌ ‌of‌ ‌‘the‌ ‌family’,‌ ‌which‌ ‌includes‌ ‌a‌ ‌range‌ ‌of‌ ‌family‌ ‌types‌ ‌–‌ ‌one‌ ‌suggested‌ ‌definition‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌‘a‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌people‌ ‌who‌ ‌are‌ ‌\nrelated‌ ‌by‌ ‌either‌ ‌blood‌ ‌or‌ ‌marriage/‌ ‌similar‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌committed‌ ‌relationship.‌ ‌\n●Because‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌problems‌ ‌of‌ ‌defining‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌often‌ ‌easier‌ ‌to‌ ‌analyse‌ ‌families‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌households.‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌household‌ ‌is‌ ‌much‌ ‌easier‌ ‌to‌ ‌define‌ ‌than‌ ‌a‌ ‌family‌ ‌–‌ ‌A‌ ‌household‌ ‌is‌ ‌simply‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌people‌ ‌who‌ ‌share‌ ‌a‌ ‌residence‌ ‌in‌ ‌common‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nshare‌ ‌such‌ ‌things‌ ‌as‌ ‌meals,‌ ‌bills,‌ ‌facilities‌ ‌or‌ ‌chores,‌ ‌or‌ ‌one‌ ‌person‌ ‌living‌ ‌alone.‌ ‌Of‌ ‌course,‌ ‌families‌ ‌can‌ ‌spread‌ ‌themselves‌ ‌across‌ ‌\nmany‌ ‌households.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nThe‌ ‌6‌ ‌stages‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌life‌ ‌cycle‌ ‌are‌ ‌identified‌ ‌as:‌ ‌ ‌\n1)‌ ‌family‌ ‌formation‌ ‌(marriage‌ ‌to‌ ‌first‌ ‌birth),‌ ‌ ‌\n2)‌ ‌family‌ ‌expansion‌ ‌(first‌ ‌birth‌ ‌to‌ ‌last‌ ‌childbirth),‌ ‌ ‌\n3)‌ ‌completion‌ ‌of‌ ‌expansion‌ ‌(child‌ ‌raising‌ ‌to‌ ‌departure‌ ‌of‌ ‌first‌ ‌child‌ ‌from‌ ‌home),‌ ‌ ‌\n4)‌ ‌family‌ ‌contraction‌ ‌(through‌ ‌departure‌ ‌of‌ ‌last‌ ‌child‌ ‌from‌ ‌home),‌ ‌ ‌\n5)‌ ‌completion‌ ‌of‌ ‌contraction‌ ‌(last‌ ‌child‌ ‌departure‌ ‌through‌ ‌spouse‌ ‌death),‌ ‌and‌ ‌ ‌\n6)‌ ‌dissolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌(death‌ ‌of‌ ‌one‌ ‌spouse‌ ‌to‌ ‌death‌ ‌of‌ ‌another).‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nIs‌ ‌Family‌ ‌Universal?‌ ‌\n●To‌ ‌discuss‌ ‌whether‌ ‌family‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌concept‌ ‌is‌ ‌universal‌ ‌or‌ ‌not,‌ ‌one‌ ‌needs‌ ‌to‌ ‌know‌ ‌functions‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌family.‌ ‌Murdock‌ ‌described‌ ‌four‌ ‌essential‌ ‌\nfunctions‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌while‌ ‌studying‌ ‌approx‌ ‌250‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌are:‌ ‌\n○Stable‌ ‌gratification‌ ‌of‌ ‌sexual‌ ‌needs.‌ ‌\n○Childbirth‌ ‌\n○Socialization‌ ‌\n○Economic‌ ‌functions.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●The‌ ‌first‌ ‌two‌ ‌functions‌ ‌as‌ ‌described‌ ‌by‌ ‌Murdock‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌universal.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Nayar‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌and‌ ‌woman‌ ‌to‌ ‌woman‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌among‌ ‌neurs‌ ‌of‌ ‌Sudan,‌ ‌ghost‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌among‌ ‌British‌ ‌Columbians‌ ‌etc‌ ‌\nsuggest‌ ‌non-universality.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌third‌ ‌function‌ ‌is‌ ‌socialization.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌important‌ ‌to‌ ‌make‌ ‌a‌ ‌biological‌ ‌being‌ ‌into‌ ‌a‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌being.‌ ‌In‌ ‌a‌ ‌large‌ ‌extended‌ ‌family,‌ ‌socialization‌ ‌is‌ ‌performed‌ ‌by‌ ‌3rd‌ ‌\ngeneration,‌ ‌hardly‌ ‌by‌ ‌parents.‌ ‌In‌ ‌the‌ ‌west,‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌high‌ ‌divorce‌ ‌rates,‌ ‌single‌ ‌parents‌ ‌socialization‌ ‌is‌ ‌becoming‌ ‌more‌ ‌common.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌traditional‌ ‌miners’‌ ‌family‌ ‌in‌ ‌China,‌ ‌the‌ ‌whole‌ ‌family‌ ‌never‌ ‌contributed‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌socialization‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌child.‌ ‌\n402‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌fourth‌ ‌function‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌economic‌ ‌function.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌the‌ ‌modern‌ ‌welfare‌ ‌state,‌ ‌the‌ ‌state‌ ‌has‌ ‌taken‌ ‌over‌ ‌many‌ ‌economic‌ ‌functions‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌family‌ ‌e.g.‌ ‌old‌ ‌age‌ ‌homes,‌ ‌free‌ ‌boarding‌ ‌\nschools‌ ‌for‌ ‌certain‌ ‌sections‌ ‌of‌ ‌society‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌Among‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌kibbutz‌ ‌of‌ ‌Israel‌,‌ ‌economic‌ ‌functions‌ ‌are‌ ‌never‌ ‌shared‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌family.‌ ‌A‌ ‌\nchild‌ ‌becomes‌ ‌a‌ ‌liability‌ ‌of‌ ‌state‌ ‌after‌ ‌birth.‌ ‌ ‌\n●No‌ ‌single‌ ‌function‌ ‌till‌ ‌now‌ ‌is‌ ‌enough‌ ‌to‌ ‌establish‌ ‌that‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌universal.‌ ‌‌According‌ ‌to‌ ‌Gough,‌ ‌a‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌universal,‌ ‌neither‌ ‌\nstructurally‌ ‌nor‌ ‌functionally.‌ ‌According‌ ‌to‌ ‌her,‌ ‌only‌ ‌the‌ ‌mother-child‌ ‌unit‌ ‌is‌ ‌universal‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌only‌ ‌universal‌ ‌function‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌unit‌ ‌is‌ ‌\nprimary‌ ‌socialization.‌ ‌ ‌\n●To‌ ‌conclude,‌ ‌Gough‌ ‌argues‌ ‌that‌ ‌if‌ ‌we‌ ‌have‌ ‌to‌ ‌call‌ ‌family‌ ‌as‌ ‌universal‌ ‌we‌ ‌need‌ ‌to‌ ‌revise‌ ‌the‌ ‌traditional‌ ‌definition‌ ‌of‌ ‌family‌ ‌so‌ ‌as‌ ‌to‌ ‌\ninclude‌ ‌larger‌ ‌kin‌ ‌groups.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RIf2f77tjJ8‌ ‌\nIsraeli‌ ‌kibbutz:‌ ‌Communal‌ ‌idealism‌ ‌or‌ ‌a‌ ‌privileged‌ ‌few?‌ ‌\n●Founded‌ ‌over‌ ‌100‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago,‌ ‌before‌ ‌there‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌nation‌ ‌called‌ ‌Israel,‌ ‌the‌ ‌kibbutz‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌cooperative‌ ‌settlement‌ ‌unique‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nmodern‌ ‌country‌ ‌and‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌socialist‌ ‌values‌ ‌and‌ ‌on‌ ‌Zionist‌ ‌aspirations.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌early‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌kibbutz‌ ‌was‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌economic‌ ‌cooperation‌ ‌that‌ ‌in‌ ‌many‌ ‌ways‌ ‌resembles‌ ‌communism,‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nsettlements‌ ‌continue‌ ‌to‌ ‌formally‌ ‌exalt‌ ‌the‌ ‌idea‌ ‌of‌ ‌equality‌ ‌-‌ ‌and‌ ‌often‌ ‌the‌ ‌practice‌ ‌of‌ ‌it,‌ ‌too.‌ ‌\n●Adults‌ ‌have‌ ‌private‌ ‌quarters,‌ ‌but‌ ‌children‌ ‌are‌ ‌generally‌ ‌housed‌ ‌and‌ ‌cared‌ ‌for‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌group.‌ ‌Cooking‌ ‌and‌ ‌dining‌ ‌are‌ ‌in‌ ‌common.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n403‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n404‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nRainbow‌ ‌Family‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Rainbow‌ ‌Family‌ ‌of‌ ‌Living‌ ‌Light‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌‌counter-culture‌,‌ ‌in‌ ‌existence‌ ‌since‌ ‌approximately‌ ‌1970.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌loose‌ ‌affiliation‌ ‌of‌ ‌individuals,‌ ‌some‌ ‌nomadic,‌ ‌generally‌ ‌asserting‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌has‌ ‌no‌ ‌leader.‌ ‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌put‌ ‌on‌ ‌yearly,‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌camping‌ ‌events‌ ‌on‌ ‌public‌ ‌land‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌Rainbow‌ ‌Gatherings.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nOrigins‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Family:‌ ‌\n●Several‌ ‌sociologists‌ ‌hold‌ ‌that‌ ‌in‌ ‌older‌ ‌times‌ ‌there‌ ‌was‌ ‌nothing‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌family.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Men‌ ‌and‌ ‌women‌ ‌did‌ ‌not‌ ‌think‌ ‌of‌ ‌any‌ ‌institutional‌ ‌control‌ ‌being‌ ‌imposed‌ ‌upon‌ ‌their‌ ‌desire‌ ‌to‌ ‌mate,‌ ‌and‌ ‌mating‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌among‌ ‌human‌ ‌\nbeings‌ ‌was‌ ‌not‌ ‌far‌ ‌different‌ ‌from‌ ‌that‌ ‌in‌ ‌animals.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Incidentally,‌ ‌such‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌could‌ ‌have‌ ‌remained‌ ‌limited‌ ‌among‌ ‌a‌ ‌few‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌only,‌ ‌instead‌ ‌of‌ ‌becoming‌ ‌grossly‌ ‌permissive,‌ ‌but‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nparticipants‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌sex‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌never‌ ‌intended‌ ‌the‌ ‌establishing‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌permanent‌ ‌relation‌ ‌between‌ ‌them.‌ ‌\n○Subscribers‌ ‌to‌ ‌this‌ ‌view‌ ‌include‌ ‌‌L.H.‌ ‌Morgan‌ ‌and‌ ‌R.‌ ‌Briffault‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n405‌ ‌\n●Even‌ ‌Westermarck‌ ‌wrote‌ ‌in‌ ‌his‌ ‌History‌ ‌of‌ ‌Human‌ ‌Marriage‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌resulted‌ ‌from‌ ‌male‌ ‌possessiveness‌ ‌and‌ ‌jealousy,‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌\nmale‌ ‌claimed‌ ‌monopolistic‌ ‌rights‌ ‌over‌ ‌his‌ ‌women‌ ‌and‌ ‌guarded‌ ‌them‌ ‌by‌ ‌force,‌ ‌until‌ ‌custom‌ ‌established‌ ‌the‌ ‌institution‌ ‌of‌ ‌family‌ ‌and‌ ‌secured‌ ‌\nhis‌ ‌rights.‌ ‌‌Briffault,‌ ‌of‌ ‌course,‌ ‌dissents‌ ‌and‌ ‌maintains‌ ‌that‌ ‌matriarchy‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌rule‌ ‌even‌ ‌when‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌came‌ ‌into‌ ‌being‌.‌ ‌\n●However,‌ ‌if‌ ‌we‌ ‌accept‌ ‌the‌ ‌assumptions‌ ‌of‌ ‌pre-familial‌ ‌permissiveness,‌ ‌‌it‌ ‌would‌ ‌follow‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌a‌ ‌universal‌ ‌system‌ ‌‌and‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌\nis‌ ‌a‌ ‌mere‌ ‌development‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌stage‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌society‌ ‌and‌ ‌therefore‌ ‌not‌ ‌enduring.‌ ‌The‌ ‌assumption‌ ‌is‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌certain‌ ‌observations‌ ‌\nmade‌ ‌by‌ ‌them‌ ‌as‌ ‌to‌ ‌certain‌ ‌practices‌ ‌among‌ ‌human‌ ‌kind.‌ ‌\n○Certain‌ ‌tribes‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌wives‌ ‌or‌ ‌even‌ ‌offer‌ ‌wives‌ ‌by‌ ‌way‌ ‌of‌ ‌hospitality‌ ‌and,‌ ‌among‌ ‌some,‌ ‌festivals‌ ‌of‌ ‌fertility‌ ‌rites‌ ‌raise‌ ‌presumptions‌ ‌\nas‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌strictness‌ ‌of‌ ‌moral‌ ‌codes‌ ‌of‌ ‌ancient‌ ‌times‌ ‌relating‌ ‌to‌ ‌sex.‌ ‌\n○Among‌ ‌certain‌ ‌tribes‌ ‌like‌ ‌‌central‌ ‌Australasians‌ ‌and‌ ‌Trobriand‌ ‌islanders,‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌marked‌ ‌ignorance‌ ‌as‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌causes‌ ‌of‌ ‌paternity,‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nsome‌ ‌like‌ ‌the‌ ‌Fox‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌Hopi‌ ‌Indians‌ ‌of‌ ‌America‌ ‌determine‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌not‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌individuals,‌ ‌but‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌\ngeneral‌ ‌divisions‌ ‌of‌ ‌age‌ ‌and‌ ‌sex‌ ‌in‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌example‌,‌ ‌all‌ ‌old‌ ‌people‌ ‌would‌ ‌be‌ ‌regarded‌ ‌as‌ ‌mother‌ ‌or‌ ‌father,‌ ‌certain‌ ‌groups‌ ‌will‌ ‌be‌ ‌termed‌ ‌as‌ ‌husbands‌ ‌or‌ ‌wives,‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nyoungsters‌ ‌may‌ ‌all‌ ‌be‌ ‌children.‌ ‌ ‌\n○But‌ ‌whatever‌ ‌be‌ ‌the‌ ‌nature‌ ‌of‌ ‌certain‌ ‌practices‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌nature‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌organization‌ ‌in‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌familial‌ ‌groups,‌ ‌one‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌say‌ ‌that‌ ‌\nsexual‌ ‌permissiveness‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌rule‌ ‌at‌ ‌any‌ ‌time;‌ ‌at‌ ‌least,‌ ‌one‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌get‌ ‌any‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌of‌ ‌such.‌ ‌\n●As‌ ‌the‌ ‌exception‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌prove‌ ‌the‌ ‌rule,‌ ‌practices‌ ‌that‌ ‌work‌ ‌as‌ ‌exceptions‌ ‌to‌ ‌our‌ ‌own‌ ‌standards‌ ‌of‌ ‌sex‌ ‌morality‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌establish‌ ‌an‌ ‌argument‌ ‌\nthat‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌society‌ ‌was‌ ‌totally‌ ‌permissive.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Even‌ ‌among‌ ‌these‌ ‌persons,‌ ‌research‌ ‌studies‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌reveal‌ ‌any‌ ‌practice‌ ‌of‌ ‌permissive‌ ‌sex‌ ‌relationships;‌ ‌and‌ ‌wherever‌ ‌paternity‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌very,‌ ‌\nconfused‌ ‌idea,‌ ‌one‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌necessarily‌ ‌find‌ ‌a‌ ‌total‌ ‌absence‌ ‌of‌ ‌familial‌ ‌institutions.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Primitive‌ ‌tribes‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Andamans‌ ‌and‌ ‌in‌ ‌South‌ ‌Australia‌ ‌too‌ ‌have‌ ‌similar‌ ‌institutions,‌ ‌and‌ ‌merely‌ ‌because‌ ‌certain‌ ‌persons’‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nfamily‌ ‌are‌ ‌different‌ ‌from‌ ‌ours,‌ ‌we‌ ‌need‌ ‌not‌ ‌be‌ ‌presumptuous‌ ‌enough‌ ‌to‌ ‌conclude‌ ‌that‌ ‌they‌ ‌live‌ ‌without‌ ‌families‌.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Families‌ ‌might‌ ‌therefore‌ ‌be‌ ‌regarded‌ ‌as‌ ‌groups‌ ‌that‌ ‌existed‌ ‌at‌ ‌all‌ ‌times,‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌universal‌ ‌factor‌ ‌about‌ ‌all‌ ‌types‌ ‌and‌ ‌all‌ ‌variations‌ ‌of‌ ‌families‌ ‌\nis‌ ‌that‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌basic‌ ‌and‌ ‌common‌ ‌function‌ ‌of‌ ‌child-bearing‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌upbringing‌ ‌of‌ ‌it‌ ‌jointly‌ ‌by‌ ‌certain‌ ‌individuals.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nMain‌ ‌characteristics/features‌ ‌of‌ ‌family‌ ‌\n ‌\n●The‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌regarded‌ ‌by‌ ‌sociologists‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌very‌ ‌nucleus‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌primary‌ ‌groups.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌fundamental‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌primary‌ ‌groups,‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌creature‌ ‌needs‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌beings‌ ‌are‌ ‌best‌ ‌satisfied‌ ‌in‌ ‌it.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌and‌ ‌all-pervading‌ ‌factor‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌child’s‌ ‌education‌ ‌at‌ ‌socialization‌ ‌and,‌ ‌even‌ ‌though‌ ‌other‌ ‌groups‌ ‌have‌ ‌their‌ ‌share‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nimportance‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌later‌ ‌stages‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌grown-up‌ ‌child,‌ ‌the‌ ‌influence‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌only‌ ‌primary‌ ‌but‌ ‌of‌ ‌lasting‌ ‌\ncharacter.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌the‌ ‌family,‌ ‌the‌ ‌child‌ ‌learns‌ ‌to‌ ‌discharge‌ ‌certain‌ ‌functions‌ ‌which,‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌larger‌ ‌world,‌ ‌serve‌ ‌the‌ ‌purpose‌ ‌of‌ ‌training‌ ‌and‌ ‌education.‌ ‌\n●One‌ ‌learns‌ ‌to‌ ‌cooperate‌ ‌with‌ ‌other‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌and‌ ‌to‌ ‌share‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌and‌ ‌interests‌ ‌and‌ ‌thereby‌ ‌become‌ ‌attuned‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌demands‌ ‌of‌ ‌\ncollective‌ ‌life.‌ ‌ ‌\n406‌ ‌\n●As‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌maintained‌ ‌by‌ ‌some,‌ ‌‘all‌ ‌culture‌ ‌begins‌ ‌at‌ ‌home’;‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌habit‌ ‌of‌ ‌sharing‌ ‌food,‌ ‌property,‌ ‌thoughts‌ ‌and‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌family,‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌\nobtains‌ ‌his‌ ‌lessons‌ ‌as‌ ‌to‌ ‌matters‌ ‌of‌ ‌political,‌ ‌economic,‌ ‌moral‌ ‌and‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌consequences.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nMcIver‌ ‌and‌ ‌page‌ ‌have‌ ‌stated‌ ‌the‌ ‌following‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌essential‌ ‌features‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌family:‌ ‌\n●Universality:‌ ‌ ‌\n○There‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌human‌ ‌society‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌some‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌appear.‌ ‌\n○Malinowski‌ ‌writes‌ ‌the‌ ‌typical‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌consisting‌ ‌of‌ ‌mother,‌ ‌father‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌progeny‌ ‌is‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌all‌ ‌\ncommunities,savage,barbarians‌ ‌and‌ ‌civilized‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌irresistible‌ ‌sex‌ ‌need,‌ ‌the‌ ‌urge‌ ‌for‌ ‌reproduction‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌common‌ ‌economic‌ ‌needs‌ ‌have‌ ‌contributed‌ ‌to‌ ‌this‌ ‌universality.‌ ‌\n○There‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌a‌ ‌single‌ ‌man‌ ‌who‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌belong‌ ‌to‌ ‌one‌ ‌or‌ ‌other‌ ‌kind‌ ‌of‌ ‌family\"-‌Anderson‌.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Emotional‌ ‌basis:‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌grounded‌ ‌in‌ ‌emotions‌ ‌and‌ ‌sentiments.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌our‌ ‌impulses‌ ‌of‌ ‌mating,‌ ‌procreation,‌ ‌maternal‌ ‌devotion,‌ ‌fraternal‌ ‌love‌ ‌and‌ ‌parental‌ ‌care‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌built‌ ‌upon‌ ‌sentiments‌ ‌of‌ ‌love,‌ ‌affection,‌ ‌sympathy,‌ ‌cooperation‌ ‌and‌ ‌friendship.‌ ‌\n●Limited‌ ‌size:‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌smaller‌ ‌in‌ ‌size.‌ ‌As‌ ‌a‌ ‌primary‌ ‌group‌ ‌its‌ ‌size‌ ‌is‌ ‌necessarily‌ ‌limited.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌smallest‌ ‌social‌ ‌unit.‌ ‌\n○\"Husband,‌ ‌wife‌ ‌and‌ ‌children\".‌ ‌Family‌ ‌is‌ ‌limited‌ ‌in‌ ‌size‌ ‌in‌ ‌comparison‌ ‌to‌ ‌other‌ ‌groups.-‌ ‌Gisbert‌ ‌ ‌\n●Formative‌ ‌influence:‌ ‌ ‌\n○Each‌ ‌family‌ ‌has‌ ‌a‌ ‌certain‌ ‌form.‌ ‌Orientation‌ ‌and‌ ‌Procreations‌ ‌(Mac‌ ‌Iver).‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌family‌ ‌welds‌ ‌an‌ ‌environment‌ ‌which‌ ‌surrounds‌ ‌trains‌ ‌and‌ ‌educates‌ ‌the‌ ‌child.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌shapes‌ ‌the‌ ‌personality‌ ‌and‌ ‌moulds‌ ‌the‌ ‌character‌ ‌of‌ ‌its‌ ‌members.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌emotionally‌ ‌conditions‌ ‌the‌ ‌child.‌ ‌\n●Nuclear‌ ‌position‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure:‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌nucleus‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌other‌ ‌social‌ ‌organizations.‌ ‌The‌ ‌whole‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌is‌ ‌built‌ ‌of‌ ‌family‌ ‌units.‌ ‌\n○According‌ ‌to‌ ‌Charles‌ ‌Cooley‌ ‌\"Family‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌primary‌ ‌group‌ ‌and‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌fundamental‌ ‌unit‌ ‌of‌ ‌society‌ ‌(the‌ ‌network‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌we‌ ‌\ncall‌ ‌it‌ ‌society)\".‌ ‌\n●Responsibility‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌members:‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌have‌ ‌certain‌ ‌responsibilities,‌ ‌duties‌ ‌and‌ ‌obligations.Maclver‌ ‌points‌ ‌out‌ ‌that‌ ‌in‌ ‌times‌ ‌of‌ ‌crisis‌ ‌men‌ ‌may‌ ‌\nwork‌ ‌and‌ ‌fight‌ ‌and‌ ‌die‌ ‌for‌ ‌their‌ ‌country‌ ‌but‌ ‌they‌ ‌toil‌ ‌for‌ ‌their‌ ‌families‌ ‌all‌ ‌their‌ ‌lives.‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌a‌ ‌family,‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌learns‌ ‌to‌ ‌work‌ ‌hard‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌benefit‌ ‌not‌ ‌only‌ ‌of‌ ‌himself‌ ‌but‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌group‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌whole.‌ ‌ ‌\n○He‌ ‌learns‌ ‌it‌ ‌spontaneously‌ ‌and‌ ‌less‌ ‌ungrudgingly‌ ‌than‌ ‌under‌ ‌specific‌ ‌circumstances.‌ ‌A‌ ‌parent‌ ‌willfully‌ ‌undertakes‌ ‌heavy‌ ‌\nresponsibilities‌ ‌for‌ ‌rearing‌ ‌the‌ ‌child‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌child,‌ ‌when‌ ‌he‌ ‌grows‌ ‌up,‌ ‌is‌ ‌found‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌willing‌ ‌to‌ ‌make‌ ‌sacrifices‌ ‌rather‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌parents‌ ‌\nthan‌ ‌for‌ ‌other‌ ‌persons.‌ ‌ ‌\n407‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌bonds‌ ‌between‌ ‌family‌ ‌members‌ ‌are‌ ‌so‌ ‌close‌ ‌and‌ ‌so‌ ‌enduring‌ ‌that‌ ‌no‌ ‌other‌ ‌organization‌ ‌can‌ ‌think‌ ‌of‌ ‌vying‌ ‌with‌ ‌it‌ ‌or‌ ‌becoming‌ ‌its‌ ‌\nsubstitute.‌ ‌\n●Social‌ ‌regulation:‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌guarded‌ ‌both‌ ‌by‌ ‌social‌ ‌taboos‌ ‌and‌ ‌by‌ ‌legal‌ ‌regulations.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌society‌ ‌takes‌ ‌precaution‌ ‌to‌ ‌safeguard‌ ‌this‌ ‌organization‌ ‌from‌ ‌any‌ ‌possible‌ ‌breakdown.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌law‌ ‌regulates‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌not‌ ‌only‌ ‌by‌ ‌prescribing‌ ‌the‌ ‌standards‌ ‌of‌ ‌valid‌ ‌marriages‌ ‌but‌ ‌also‌ ‌by‌ ‌bringing‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌element‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nrecognition‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌child‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌born‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌and‌ ‌by‌ ‌prescribing‌ ‌sex‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌among‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌family.‌ ‌\n●Permanent‌ ‌and‌ ‌Temporary‌ ‌in‌ ‌nature:‌ ‌\n○McIver‌ ‌and‌ ‌Page‌ ‌observe‌ ‌that‌ ‌while‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌as‌ ‌an‌ ‌institute‌ ‌is‌ ‌enduring‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌permanent‌ ‌feature‌ ‌in‌ ‌human‌ ‌society,‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌\nfamily‌ ‌is‌ ‌only‌ ‌temporary.‌ ‌ ‌\n○When‌ ‌a‌ ‌man‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌woman‌ ‌come‌ ‌together‌ ‌and‌ ‌live‌ ‌in‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌for‌ ‌procreation,‌ ‌they‌ ‌begin‌ ‌a‌ ‌family;‌ ‌but‌ ‌as‌ ‌life‌ ‌itself‌ ‌is‌ ‌ephemeral,‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nsame‌ ‌progenitor‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌continue‌ ‌forever,‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌undergoes‌ ‌several‌ ‌changes‌ ‌through‌ ‌generations‌ ‌as‌ ‌it‌ ‌maintains‌ ‌the‌ ‌\ncontinuity‌ ‌of‌ ‌tradition.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Yet‌ ‌it‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌be‌ ‌said‌ ‌that‌ ‌any‌ ‌given‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌continuing.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Parents‌ ‌die‌ ‌and‌ ‌so‌ ‌end‌ ‌their‌ ‌families,‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌children‌ ‌open‌ ‌out‌ ‌into‌ ‌new‌ ‌families,‌ ‌each‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌them‌ ‌temporary,‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌\ngenealogical‌ ‌tree‌ ‌tending‌ ‌to‌ ‌remain‌ ‌permanent.‌ ‌\n ‌\nHousehold‌ ‌and‌ ‌Domestic‌ ‌groups‌ ‌\nHousehold:‌ ‌\n●Characteristic‌ ‌feature‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌household‌ ‌is‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌has‌ ‌a‌ ‌common‌ ‌residence.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Household‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌social‌ ‌groups‌ ‌that‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌ties,‌ ‌non-kinship‌ ‌ties.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Members‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌household‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌necessarily‌ ‌related‌ ‌by‌ ‌blood,‌ ‌it‌ ‌could‌ ‌be‌ ‌classmate,‌ ‌friendship,‌ ‌no‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌ties.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Majority‌ ‌of‌ ‌households‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌small‌ ‌in‌ ‌size.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Most‌ ‌definitions‌ ‌of‌ ‌family‌ ‌overlap‌ ‌with‌ ‌household‌ ‌and‌ ‌domestic‌ ‌groups.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Household‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌actual‌ ‌domestic‌ ‌arrangement‌ ‌found‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌ground‌ ‌and‌ ‌are‌ ‌highly‌ ‌adaptive,‌ ‌flexible,‌ ‌and‌ ‌responsive‌ ‌to‌ ‌change.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Members‌ ‌live‌ ‌together,‌ ‌share‌ ‌common‌ ‌residence‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌household‌ ‌cook‌ ‌food‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌kitchen‌ ‌and‌ ‌eat‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌common‌ ‌kitchen/hearth‌ ‌together‌ ‌under‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌dwelling.‌ ‌\n●Members‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌household‌ ‌reside‌ ‌together,‌ ‌share‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌kitchen‌ ‌and‌ ‌may/‌ ‌may‌ ‌not‌ ‌be‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌each‌ ‌other‌ ‌by‌ ‌blood‌ ‌or‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌or‌ ‌\nadoption.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Classmates‌ ‌who‌ ‌stay‌ ‌away‌ ‌from‌ ‌family‌ ‌and‌ ‌share‌ ‌a‌ ‌rented‌ ‌apartment‌ ‌may‌ ‌form‌ ‌a‌ ‌household.‌ ‌\n●Members‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌household‌ ‌could‌ ‌be‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌each‌ ‌other‌ ‌by‌ ‌friendship,‌ ‌partners,classmates‌ ‌and‌ ‌co-inhabiting‌ ‌or‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌live-in‌ ‌couples.‌ ‌\n ‌\nHousehold‌ ‌vs‌ ‌Family‌ ‌\n●Many‌ ‌times‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌confusion‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌term‌ ‌family‌ ‌and‌ ‌household.‌ ‌So‌ ‌let’s‌ ‌first‌ ‌try‌ ‌to‌ ‌understand‌ ‌the‌ ‌term‌ ‌household‌ ‌and‌ ‌what‌ ‌it‌ ‌\ncomprises.‌ ‌ ‌\n408‌ ‌\n●Household‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌defined‌ ‌by‌ ‌‌Haviland,‌ ‌‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌basic‌ ‌residential‌ ‌unit‌ ‌where‌ ‌economic‌ ‌production,‌ ‌consumption,‌ ‌inheritance,‌ ‌child‌ ‌\nrearing‌ ‌and‌ ‌shelter‌ ‌are‌ ‌organised‌ ‌and‌ ‌implemented.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌household‌ ‌at‌ ‌times‌ ‌share‌ ‌a‌ ‌common‌ ‌hearth.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Let’s‌ ‌take‌ ‌the‌ ‌example‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Mundurucu‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Amazon‌ ‌who‌ ‌organise‌ ‌themselves‌ ‌around‌ ‌a‌ ‌household.‌ ‌They‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌unique‌ ‌\nsystem‌ ‌by‌ ‌which‌ ‌all‌ ‌men‌ ‌and‌ ‌boys‌ ‌above‌ ‌13‌ ‌years‌ ‌of‌ ‌age‌ ‌live‌ ‌together‌ ‌whereas‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌women‌ ‌and‌ ‌children‌ ‌below‌ ‌13‌ ‌years‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nage‌ ‌live‌ ‌together‌ ‌(Haviland,‌ ‌2003).‌ ‌Herein,‌ ‌we‌ ‌see‌ ‌that‌ ‌household‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌extention‌ ‌of‌ ‌family,‌ ‌a‌ ‌family‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌a‌ ‌household‌ ‌but‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nhousehold‌ ‌need‌ ‌not‌ ‌be‌ ‌a‌ ‌family.‌ ‌ ‌\n○To‌ ‌make‌ ‌this‌ ‌statement‌ ‌clear‌ ‌let’s‌ ‌take‌ ‌another‌ ‌example‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌present‌ ‌day‌ ‌situation.‌ ‌We‌ ‌see‌ ‌a‌ ‌lot‌ ‌of‌ ‌students‌ ‌moving‌ ‌out‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌their‌ ‌native‌ ‌place‌ ‌and‌ ‌settling‌ ‌in‌ ‌some‌ ‌other‌ ‌city‌ ‌or‌ ‌going‌ ‌abroad‌ ‌for‌ ‌higher‌ ‌education.‌ ‌ ‌\nThese‌ ‌students‌ ‌usually‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌shoe‌ ‌string‌ ‌budget‌ ‌like‌ ‌to‌ ‌share‌ ‌accomodation‌ ‌with‌ ‌fellow‌ ‌stduents.‌ ‌Thus,‌ ‌two‌ ‌to‌ ‌three‌ ‌students‌ ‌\ntake‌ ‌up‌ ‌residence‌ ‌and‌ ‌start‌ ‌sharing‌ ‌space‌ ‌and‌ ‌eating‌ ‌together.‌ ‌This‌ ‌makes‌ ‌them‌ ‌share‌ ‌a‌ ‌hearth‌ ‌but‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌necessarily‌ ‌\nmembers‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌family‌ ‌but‌ ‌belong‌ ‌to‌ ‌different‌ ‌families.‌ ‌\n ‌\nDomestic‌ ‌groups:‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌study‌ ‌any‌ ‌social‌ ‌institution‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌holistic‌ ‌manner,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌important‌ ‌to‌ ‌consider‌ ‌it‌ ‌ecologically,‌ ‌economically,‌ ‌demographically,‌ ‌\npsychologically‌ ‌and‌ ‌physiologically‌ ‌which‌ ‌affects‌ ‌its‌ ‌size‌ ‌and‌ ‌composition.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Domestic‌ ‌group‌ ‌is‌ ‌rooted‌ ‌in‌ ‌environmental,‌ ‌biological,‌ ‌psychological‌ ‌substratum.‌ ‌\n●Domestic‌ ‌group‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌resource‌ ‌owning‌ ‌groups.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Members‌ ‌of‌ ‌domestic‌ ‌groups‌ ‌pool‌ ‌together‌ ‌and‌ ‌contribute‌ ‌their‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌labor‌ ‌and‌ ‌do‌ ‌various‌ ‌kinds‌ ‌of‌ ‌production‌ ‌activity‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌division‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nlabor‌ ‌specifically‌ ‌on‌ ‌age,‌ ‌gender‌ ‌and‌ ‌position/status‌ ‌of‌ ‌member.‌ ‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌also‌ ‌have‌ ‌political‌ ‌functions,‌ ‌they‌ ‌train‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌completely‌ ‌so‌ ‌that‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌can‌ ‌enter‌ ‌the‌ ‌politico-jural‌ ‌domain.‌ ‌Since‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌\nresource‌ ‌owning‌ ‌groups,‌ ‌the‌ ‌domestic‌ ‌group‌ ‌acts‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌production‌ ‌unit.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Domestic‌ ‌group‌ ‌members‌ ‌are‌ ‌engaged‌ ‌in‌ ‌harnessing‌ ‌the‌ ‌resources‌ ‌that‌ ‌group‌ ‌have‌ ‌and‌ ‌involve‌ ‌in‌ ‌economic‌ ‌production.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌reason‌ ‌that‌ ‌definitions‌ ‌of‌ ‌family‌ ‌overlap‌ ‌with‌ ‌domestic‌ ‌groups.‌ ‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌domestic‌ ‌group‌ ‌comprising‌ ‌labor,‌ ‌urban‌ ‌and‌ ‌economic‌ ‌production,‌ ‌once‌ ‌these‌ ‌resources‌ ‌are‌ ‌harvested,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌divided‌ ‌among‌ ‌different‌ ‌\nconsumption‌ ‌unit.‌ ‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌units‌ ‌often‌ ‌have‌ ‌separate‌ ‌kitchens,‌ ‌separate‌ ‌residential‌ ‌units‌ ‌and‌ ‌may‌ ‌have‌ ‌different‌ ‌consumption‌ ‌units.‌ ‌Example:‌ ‌polygynous‌ ‌\nsocieties.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Consumption‌ ‌unit‌ ‌of‌ ‌production‌ ‌act‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌unit‌ ‌of‌ ‌reproduction.‌ ‌Say,‌ ‌husband‌ ‌and‌ ‌wife‌ ‌are‌ ‌still‌ ‌young‌ ‌and‌ ‌giving‌ ‌birth‌ ‌to‌ ‌offspring,‌ ‌but‌ ‌when‌ ‌\nwife‌ ‌attains‌ ‌menopause‌ ‌or‌ ‌husband‌ ‌becomes‌ ‌older,‌ ‌incapable‌ ‌of‌ ‌reproduction‌ ‌then‌ ‌they‌ ‌look‌ ‌for‌ ‌consumption‌ ‌units.‌ ‌\n●Meyer‌ ‌Fortes‌ ‌said‌ ‌‌domestic‌ ‌groups‌ ‌are‌ ‌essentially‌ ‌householding‌ ‌and‌ ‌housekeeping‌ ‌group‌ ‌which‌ ‌organize‌ ‌to‌ ‌provide‌ ‌material‌ ‌resources‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌resources‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌needed‌ ‌to‌ ‌maintain‌ ‌and‌ ‌raise‌ ‌or‌ ‌bring‌ ‌up‌ ‌its‌ ‌members.‌ ‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌undergo‌ ‌cyclical‌ ‌developments.‌ ‌These‌ ‌cycles‌ ‌are‌ ‌always‌ ‌in‌ ‌process.‌ ‌This‌ ‌is‌ ‌particularly‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌developmental‌ ‌cycle‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌\ndomestic‌ ‌group‌ ‌which‌ ‌covers‌ ‌the‌ ‌life‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌unfolding‌ ‌of‌ ‌group‌ ‌dynamics.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌further‌ ‌said‌ ‌that‌ ‌every‌ ‌domestic‌ ‌group‌ ‌passes‌ ‌through‌ ‌three‌ ‌phases‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌developmental‌ ‌cycle‌ ‌of‌ ‌domestic‌ ‌group:‌ ‌\ni.‌ ‌Phase‌ ‌of‌ ‌expansion:‌ ‌\n409‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌starts‌ ‌with‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌and‌ ‌further‌ ‌expands‌ ‌by‌ ‌birth‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌child‌ ‌and‌ ‌it‌ ‌continues‌ ‌to‌ ‌expand‌ ‌till‌ ‌the‌ ‌birth‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌last‌ ‌child.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌phase‌ ‌is‌ ‌dependent‌ ‌on‌ ‌fertility‌ ‌of‌ ‌wife/woman‌ ‌and‌ ‌physiological‌ ‌factors‌ ‌like‌ ‌wife’s‌ ‌menopause‌ ‌and‌ ‌husband’s‌ ‌inability‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nprocreate.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌determines‌ ‌the‌ ‌length‌ ‌of‌ ‌expansion,‌ ‌span‌ ‌and‌ ‌duration.‌ ‌\nii.‌ ‌Phase‌ ‌of‌ ‌dispersion:‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌starts‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌first/eldest‌ ‌child‌ ‌and‌ ‌it‌ ‌continues‌ ‌till‌ ‌the‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌last/youngest‌ ‌child.‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌the‌ ‌Patrilineal‌ ‌system,‌ ‌sons‌ ‌generally‌ ‌set‌ ‌up‌ ‌a‌ ‌new‌ ‌household,‌ ‌new‌ ‌unit‌ ‌of‌ ‌production‌ ‌&‌ ‌consumption‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌own‌ ‌domestic‌ ‌group.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌some‌ ‌domestic‌ ‌groups,‌ ‌the‌ ‌youngest‌ ‌son‌ ‌stays‌ ‌with‌ ‌father‌ ‌and‌ ‌gets‌ ‌property-land/house,‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\niii.‌ ‌Phase‌ ‌of‌ ‌replacement:‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌starts‌ ‌with‌ ‌ageing‌ ‌of‌ ‌parents‌ ‌and‌ ‌continues‌ ‌till‌ ‌their‌ ‌death‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌passage‌ ‌\n○of‌ ‌time,‌ ‌parents‌ ‌become‌ ‌old‌ ‌and‌ ‌have‌ ‌no‌ ‌stamina‌ ‌to‌ ‌perform‌ ‌any‌ ‌physical‌ ‌activity.‌ ‌They‌ ‌rely‌ ‌on‌ ‌their‌ ‌children;‌ ‌they‌ ‌request‌ ‌them‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nrepresent‌
