‌and‌ ‌perform‌ ‌their‌ ‌function.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌this‌ ‌process‌ ‌parents‌ ‌no‌ ‌longer‌ ‌take‌ ‌part‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌economic‌ ‌unit,‌ ‌thus‌ ‌their‌ ‌authority/power‌ ‌declines‌ ‌slowly.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Children‌ ‌grow‌ ‌in‌ ‌autonomous‌ ‌manner‌ ‌and‌ ‌take‌ ‌decisions.‌ ‌Children‌ ‌replace‌ ‌parents/head‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌and‌ ‌then‌ ‌undergo‌ ‌the‌ ‌phase‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nexpansion.‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌3‌ ‌phases‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌necessarily‌ ‌follow‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌sequence‌ ‌of‌ ‌phases.‌ ‌Some‌ ‌groups‌ ‌may‌ ‌skip‌ ‌the‌ ‌phase‌ ‌of‌ ‌expansion,‌ ‌couples‌ ‌who‌ ‌are‌ ‌\nunable‌ ‌to‌ ‌procreate.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Domestic‌ ‌group‌ ‌is‌ ‌like‌ ‌a‌ ‌human‌ ‌factory‌ ‌which‌ ‌shapes,‌ ‌polishes,‌ ‌nurtures‌ ‌the‌ ‌child/individual.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Life‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌pass‌ ‌through‌ ‌four‌ ‌phases‌ ‌of‌ ‌life:‌ ‌\n○Matricentral‌ ‌cell:‌‌ ‌Mother-child‌ ‌dyad,‌ ‌starts‌ ‌when‌ ‌the‌ ‌child‌ ‌is‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌mother's‌ ‌womb.‌ ‌\n○Patricentral‌ ‌cell:‌ ‌‌when‌ ‌the‌ ‌child‌ ‌starts‌ ‌crawling,‌ ‌father‌ ‌comes‌ ‌closer‌ ‌to‌ ‌child‌ ‌and‌ ‌takes‌ ‌interest‌ ‌in‌ ‌his‌ ‌responsibility.‌ ‌Child‌ ‌acquires‌ ‌\nbasic‌ ‌skills‌ ‌from‌ ‌parents‌ ‌and‌ ‌comes‌ ‌close‌ ‌to‌ ‌them.‌ ‌\n○Entering‌ ‌domestic‌ ‌group‌:‌ ‌child‌ ‌starts‌ ‌walking,‌ ‌not‌ ‌allowed‌ ‌to‌ ‌step‌ ‌out‌ ‌of‌ ‌home,‌ ‌constantly‌ ‌under‌ ‌guidance‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nparents/elders/siblings.‌ ‌Child‌ ‌learns‌ ‌skills‌ ‌from‌ ‌people‌ ‌other‌ ‌than‌ ‌his/her‌ ‌parents.‌ ‌\n○Entering‌ ‌politico-jural‌ ‌domain:‌ ‌‌Child‌ ‌enters‌ ‌public‌ ‌domain,‌ ‌outside‌ ‌domestic‌ ‌domain‌ ‌&‌ ‌takes‌ ‌up‌ ‌responsibilities,‌ ‌positions‌ ‌in‌ ‌\noffices.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nLatest‌ ‌Developments‌ ‌and‌ ‌Trends‌ ‌\n●Concepts‌ ‌of‌ ‌family,‌ ‌household‌ ‌and‌ ‌domestic‌ ‌group‌ ‌can‌ ‌never‌ ‌be‌ ‌studied‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌static,‌ ‌fixed‌ ‌state.‌ ‌\n●Society‌ ‌is‌ ‌changing,‌ ‌concepts‌ ‌are‌ ‌changing‌ ‌therefore‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌important‌ ‌to‌ ‌study‌ ‌any‌ ‌social‌ ‌institution‌ ‌in‌ ‌dynamics‌ ‌and‌ ‌in‌ ‌its‌ ‌relation‌ ‌with‌ ‌other‌ ‌\nsocial‌ ‌institutions.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌estimated‌ ‌that‌ ‌in‌ ‌today’s‌ ‌world‌ ‌at‌ ‌least‌ ‌16%‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌children‌ ‌live‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌single-parent‌ ‌family.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌the‌ ‌present‌ ‌world,‌ ‌lesbian‌ ‌and‌ ‌gay‌ ‌couples‌ ‌are‌ ‌emerging‌ ‌which‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌fit‌ ‌into‌ ‌definitions‌ ‌of‌ ‌family.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It’s‌ ‌a‌ ‌challenge‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌family‌ ‌that‌ ‌one‌ ‌member‌ ‌has‌ ‌sexual‌ ‌orientation‌ ‌different‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌majority.‌ ‌\n●Sexual‌ ‌orientation‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual’s‌ ‌belief,‌ ‌attractions‌ ‌and‌ ‌behaviors‌ ‌toward‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌opposite‌ ‌and‌ ‌same‌ ‌sex.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Nowadays,‌ ‌the‌ ‌issues‌ ‌of‌ ‌equal‌ ‌civil‌ ‌rights,‌ ‌gay‌ ‌couples‌ ‌legally‌ ‌adopting‌ ‌children‌ ‌are‌ ‌emergin‌ ‌\n410‌ ‌\n●More‌ ‌divorced‌ ‌cases‌ ‌are‌ ‌happening‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌present‌ ‌day‌ ‌world.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Family‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌are‌ ‌dwindling‌ ‌and‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌last‌ ‌long.‌ ‌People‌ ‌have‌ ‌started‌ ‌opting‌ ‌for‌ ‌short-term‌ ‌relationships.‌ ‌ ‌\n●All‌ ‌the‌ ‌changes‌ ‌in‌ ‌psychological,‌ ‌biological‌ ‌and‌ ‌socio-cultural‌ ‌thoughts‌ ‌are‌ ‌giving‌ ‌rise‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌dynamics.‌ ‌ ‌\n●T‌here‌ ‌are‌ ‌many‌ ‌factors‌ ‌like‌ ‌job,‌ ‌marriage,‌ ‌migration,‌ ‌which‌ ‌creates‌ ‌frictions,‌ ‌tensions‌ ‌among‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌domestic‌ ‌group,‌ ‌and‌ ‌which‌ ‌\noften‌ ‌cause‌ ‌the‌ ‌members‌ ‌to‌ ‌lose‌ ‌their‌ ‌control‌ ‌over‌ ‌their‌ ‌child‌ ‌which‌ ‌may‌ ‌lead‌ ‌to‌ ‌dispersion/separation.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌modern‌ ‌day‌ ‌family‌ ‌challenges-‌ ‌With‌ ‌time,‌ ‌definitions‌ ‌of‌ ‌family‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌altered/modified‌ ‌because‌ ‌of‌ ‌advancement‌ ‌and‌ ‌changes‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nrelationships.‌ ‌ ‌\n●With‌ ‌globalization‌ ‌and‌ ‌urbanization,‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌getting‌ ‌affected‌ ‌and‌ ‌is‌ ‌faced‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌following‌ ‌challenges:‌ ‌\n○Communication‌ ‌problem‌ ‌\n○Grief‌ ‌and‌ ‌loss‌ ‌\n○Divorce‌ ‌\n○Frequent‌ ‌fights,‌ ‌arguments‌ ‌\n○Financial‌ ‌problem‌ ‌\n○Live-in‌ ‌relationships,‌ ‌co‌ ‌inhabitation‌ ‌\n○Separations‌ ‌\n○Gay‌ ‌couple‌ ‌adopting‌ ‌children‌ ‌\n○Single‌ ‌parent‌ ‌families‌ ‌\n○Illegitimate‌ ‌child‌ ‌and‌ ‌mother‌ ‌\n○Late‌ ‌marriages‌ ‌\n○Old‌ ‌people‌ ‌left‌ ‌alone‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nDevelopment‌ ‌across‌ ‌the‌ ‌life‌ ‌cycle-Vertical‌ ‌and‌ ‌horizontal‌ ‌stressors‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌life‌ ‌cycle:‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌include‌ ‌predictable‌ ‌developmental‌ ‌stresses‌ ‌(births‌ ‌and‌ ‌deaths,‌ ‌acquiring‌ ‌new‌ ‌family‌ ‌members‌ ‌through‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌or‌ ‌relationships,‌ ‌\netc.)‌ ‌and‌ ‌unpredictable‌ ‌events‌ ‌and‌ ‌stressors‌ ‌(such‌ ‌as‌ ‌chronic‌ ‌illness,‌ ‌accident‌ ‌or‌ ‌unemployment).‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌model‌ ‌shows‌ ‌both‌ ‌vertical‌ ‌and‌ ‌horizontal‌ ‌stressors‌ ‌affecting‌ ‌family‌ ‌life.‌ ‌\n ‌\n411‌ ‌\n ‌\n412‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nFunction‌ ‌of‌ ‌Family:‌ ‌ ‌\n●Economic‌ ‌function:‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌family‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌social‌ ‌group‌ ‌is‌ ‌responsible‌ ‌for‌ ‌‌satisfying‌ ‌the‌ ‌basic‌ ‌needs‌ ‌of‌ ‌its‌ ‌members‌ ‌like‌ ‌food,‌ ‌clothes‌ ‌and‌ ‌shelter.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌achieve‌ ‌this‌ ‌objective‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌family‌ ‌cooperate‌ ‌and‌ ‌divide‌ ‌the‌ ‌work‌ ‌among‌ ‌themselves‌ ‌and‌ ‌make‌ ‌\ncontribution‌ ‌towards‌ ‌the‌ ‌upkeep‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family.‌ ‌ ‌\n413‌ ‌\n○Emile‌ ‌Durkheim‌ ‌in‌ ‌his‌ ‌book‌ ‌‌Division‌ ‌of‌ ‌labour‌ ‌has‌ ‌brought‌ ‌forth‌ ‌this‌ ‌fact‌ ‌and‌ ‌laid‌ ‌emphasis‌ ‌on‌ ‌economic‌ ‌satisfaction‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌need‌ ‌of‌ ‌\na‌ ‌family.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌thus‌ ‌serves‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌organisation‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌complementary‌ ‌division‌ ‌of‌ ‌labour‌ ‌between‌ ‌spouses‌ ‌which‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌time‌ ‌allocates‌ ‌to‌ ‌each‌ ‌\nmember‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌certain‌ ‌rights‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌labour‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌and‌ ‌in‌ ‌such‌ ‌goods‌ ‌or‌ ‌property‌ ‌as‌ ‌they‌ ‌may‌ ‌acquire‌ ‌through‌ ‌their‌ ‌\nindividual‌ ‌or‌ ‌joint‌ ‌efforts.‌ ‌\n●Biological‌ ‌function:‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌family‌ ‌as‌ ‌an‌‌ ‌institution‌ ‌regularises‌ ‌the‌ ‌satisfaction‌ ‌of‌ ‌biological‌ ‌needs‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌serves‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌institutionalisation‌ ‌of‌ ‌mating‌ ‌a‌ ‌primodial‌ ‌need‌ ‌among‌ ‌all‌ ‌humans.‌ ‌\n○Family‌ ‌helps‌ ‌in‌ ‌channeling‌ ‌of‌ ‌sexual‌ ‌outlets‌ ‌by‌ ‌defining‌ ‌the‌ ‌norms‌ ‌with‌ ‌whom‌ ‌one‌ ‌can‌ ‌mate‌ ‌and‌ ‌who‌ ‌are‌ ‌out‌ ‌of‌ ‌bound‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nincest‌ ‌taboo.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Family‌ ‌thus‌ ‌helps‌ ‌in‌ ‌establishing‌ ‌a‌ ‌legal‌ ‌father‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌woman’s‌ ‌children‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌legal‌ ‌mother‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌man’s‌ ‌children.‌ ‌\n●Psychological‌ ‌function:‌ ‌\n○Family‌ ‌provides‌ ‌security‌ ‌to‌ ‌its‌ ‌members.‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌protects‌ ‌the‌ ‌aged‌ ‌and‌ ‌sick‌ ‌person‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌family.‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌gives‌ ‌emotional‌ ‌support‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual‌ ‌junior‌ ‌members‌ ‌to‌ ‌get‌ ‌the‌ ‌elder‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌guide‌ ‌or‌ ‌advisor‌ ‌in‌ ‌major‌ ‌events‌ ‌of‌ ‌life.‌ ‌\n●Social‌ ‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌child‌ ‌as‌ ‌we‌ ‌have‌ ‌learnt‌ ‌is‌ ‌born‌ ‌into‌ ‌a‌ ‌family.‌ ‌As‌ ‌soon‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌child‌ ‌is‌ ‌born‌ ‌into‌ ‌a‌ ‌family‌ ‌he‌ ‌is‌ ‌entitled‌ ‌to‌ ‌certain‌ ‌social‌ ‌position,‌ ‌system‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌beliefs,‌ ‌language,‌ ‌parents‌ ‌and‌ ‌kins‌ ‌as‌ ‌per‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌system‌ ‌that‌ ‌he‌ ‌is‌ ‌born‌ ‌into.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌family‌ ‌nurtures‌ ‌the‌ ‌child‌ ‌and‌ ‌imbibe‌ ‌in‌ ‌him‌ ‌the‌ ‌ways‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌society‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌process‌ ‌of‌ ‌enculturation‌ ‌preparing‌ ‌him‌ ‌to‌ ‌accept‌ ‌\nstatuses‌ ‌of‌ ‌adulthood‌.‌ ‌\n●Educational‌ ‌function:‌ ‌\n○Family‌ ‌takes‌ ‌care‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌child.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌period‌ ‌of‌ ‌upbringing‌ ‌varies‌ ‌from‌ ‌society‌ ‌to‌ ‌society.‌ ‌a‌ ‌child‌ ‌begins‌ ‌to‌ ‌learn‌ ‌the‌ ‌custom‌ ‌and‌ ‌tradition‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌society‌ ‌gradually‌ ‌from‌ ‌\nchildhood.‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌the‌ ‌family,‌ ‌the‌ ‌parents‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌elders‌ ‌teach‌ ‌the‌ ‌children‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌norms‌ ‌and‌ ‌values‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌society.‌ ‌The‌ ‌family‌ ‌plays‌ ‌a‌ ‌major‌ ‌role‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nsocialization.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌educator's‌ ‌role‌ ‌is‌ ‌vital‌ ‌in‌ ‌modern‌ ‌times‌ ‌as‌ ‌many‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌anti-social‌ ‌activities‌ ‌are‌ ‌increasing.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌basic‌ ‌functions‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌performed‌ ‌with‌ ‌varying‌ ‌degrees‌ ‌of‌ ‌effectiveness‌ ‌from‌ ‌culture‌ ‌to‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌way‌ ‌the‌ ‌details‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌functions‌ ‌are‌ ‌carried‌ ‌out‌ ‌can‌ ‌produce‌ ‌remarkably‌ ‌different‌ ‌individual‌ ‌personalities‌ ‌of‌ ‌children‌ ‌and‌ ‌adult‌ ‌\n(Madan‌ ‌&‌ ‌Majumdar)‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n414‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n415‌ ‌\n2.4‌ ‌Types‌ ‌of‌ ‌family‌ ‌(from‌ ‌the‌ ‌perspectives‌ ‌of‌ ‌structure,‌ ‌blood‌ ‌relation,‌ ‌marriage,‌ ‌residence‌ ‌and‌ ‌succession);‌ ‌Impact‌ ‌of‌ ‌urbanization,‌ ‌\nindustrialization‌ ‌and‌ ‌feminist‌ ‌movements‌ ‌on‌ ‌family-Part-II‌ ‌\n‌ ‌\n ‌\nTypes‌ ‌of‌ ‌family‌ ‌(from‌ ‌the‌ ‌perspectives‌ ‌of‌ ‌structure,‌ ‌blood‌ ‌relation,‌ ‌marriage,‌ ‌residence‌ ‌and‌ ‌succession);‌ ‌\n ‌\nEvolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌Family:‌ ‌\nMorgan‌ ‌‌-‌ ‌He‌ ‌has‌ ‌listed‌ ‌successive‌ ‌‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌family‌.‌ ‌He‌ ‌has‌ ‌postulated‌ ‌a‌ ‌sequential‌ ‌growth‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌division‌ ‌and‌ ‌origin‌ ‌of‌ ‌family.‌ ‌He‌ ‌has‌ ‌divided‌ ‌on‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌distinctive‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage.‌ ‌\n ‌\nBackground‌ ‌\n●Ancient‌ ‌Society‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌1877‌ ‌book‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌American‌ ‌anthropologist‌ ‌Lewis‌ ‌H.‌ ‌Morgan.‌ ‌Building‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌data‌ ‌about‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌\norganization‌ ‌presented‌ ‌in‌ ‌his‌ ‌1871‌ ‌Systems‌ ‌of‌ ‌Consanguinity‌ ‌and‌ ‌Affinity‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Human‌ ‌Family,‌ ‌Morgan‌ ‌develops‌ ‌his‌ ‌theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌three‌ ‌\nstages‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌progress,‌ ‌i.e.,‌ ‌from‌ ‌Savagery‌ ‌through‌ ‌Barbarism‌ ‌to‌ ‌Civilization.‌ ‌Contemporary‌ ‌European‌ ‌social‌ ‌theorists‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌Karl‌ ‌\nMarx‌ ‌and‌ ‌Friedrich‌ ‌Engels‌ ‌were‌ ‌influenced‌ ‌by‌ ‌Morgan's‌ ‌work‌ ‌on‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌and‌ ‌material‌ ‌culture,‌ ‌as‌ ‌shown‌ ‌by‌ ‌Engels'‌ ‌The‌ ‌Origin‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌Family,‌ ‌Private‌ ‌Property,‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌State‌ ‌(1884).‌ ‌\n○He‌ ‌gives‌ ‌the‌ ‌analogy‌ ‌an‌ ‌anthropological‌ ‌twist‌ ‌and‌ ‌introduces‌ ‌the‌ ‌comparative‌ ‌method‌ ‌coming‌ ‌into‌ ‌vogue‌ ‌in‌ ‌other‌ ‌disciplines.‌ ‌Lewis‌ ‌\nnames‌ ‌units‌ ‌called‌ ‌ethna,‌ ‌by‌ ‌which‌ ‌he‌ ‌means‌ ‌inventions,‌ ‌discoveries‌ ‌and‌ ‌domestic‌ ‌institutions.‌ ‌The‌ ‌ethna‌ ‌are‌ ‌compared‌ ‌and‌ ‌\njudged‌ ‌higher‌ ‌or‌ ‌lower‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌scale,‌ ‌pair‌ ‌by‌ ‌pair.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌lines‌ ‌of‌ ‌progress‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌substitutions‌ ‌of‌ ‌ethna‌ ‌better‌ ‌than‌ ‌the‌ ‌previous‌ ‌follow‌ ‌several‌ ‌lines‌ ‌of‌ ‌progress.‌ ‌\n ‌\n416‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nThe‌ ‌ethnical‌ ‌periods‌ ‌\n●Morgan‌ ‌‌rejects‌ ‌the‌ ‌Ages‌ ‌of‌ ‌Stone,‌ ‌of‌ ‌Bronze,‌ ‌of‌ ‌Iron,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Three-Age‌ ‌System‌ ‌of‌ ‌pre-history,‌ ‌as‌ ‌being‌ ‌insufficient‌ ‌characterizations‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nprogress.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Morgan‌ ‌believed‌ ‌the‌ ‌prehistoric‌ ‌stages‌ ‌as‌ ‌defined‌ ‌were‌ ‌difficult‌ ‌to‌ ‌distinguish,‌ ‌as‌ ‌they‌ ‌overlapped‌ ‌and‌ ‌refer‌ ‌only‌ ‌to‌ ‌material‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nimplements‌ ‌or‌ ‌tools.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌addition,‌ ‌Morgan‌ ‌thought‌ ‌they‌ ‌did‌ ‌not‌ ‌fit‌ ‌the‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌he‌ ‌was‌ ‌finding‌ ‌among‌ ‌Native‌ ‌American‌ ‌societies‌ ‌in‌ ‌North‌ ‌America,‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌he‌ ‌\nhad‌ ‌closely‌ ‌studied‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌as‌ ‌an‌ ‌indicator‌ ‌of‌ ‌stages‌ ‌of‌ ‌civilization.‌ ‌\n●Based‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌lines‌ ‌of‌ ‌progress‌,‌ ‌he‌ ‌distinguishes‌ ‌ethnical‌ ‌periods,‌ ‌which‌ ‌each‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌distinct‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌mode‌ ‌of‌ ‌life‌ ‌and‌ ‌do‌ ‌\nnot‌ ‌overlap‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌region.‌ ‌ ‌\n417‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌does‌ ‌admit‌ ‌to‌ ‌exceptions‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌difficulty‌ ‌of‌ ‌determining‌ ‌precise‌ ‌borders‌ ‌between‌ ‌periods.‌ ‌Scientific‌ ‌archaeology‌ ‌was‌ ‌being‌ ‌developed‌ ‌\nat‌ ‌this‌ ‌time;‌ ‌‌Morgan‌ ‌did‌ ‌not‌ ‌have‌ ‌the‌ ‌techniques‌ ‌of‌ ‌stratigraphy‌ ‌or‌ ‌scientific‌ ‌dating‌ ‌available,‌ ‌but‌ ‌based‌ ‌his‌ ‌arguments‌ ‌on‌ ‌linguistic‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nhistorical‌ ‌speculation.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nMorgan‌ ‌-‌ ‌successive‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌family‌ ‌\n●Consanguine‌ ‌family:‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌was‌ ‌founded‌ ‌upon‌ ‌the‌ ‌intermarriage‌ ‌of‌ ‌brothers‌ ‌and‌ ‌sisters‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌group.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Evidence‌ ‌still‌ ‌remains‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌oldest‌ ‌of‌ ‌existing‌ ‌systems‌ ‌of‌ ‌Consanguinity,‌ ‌‌the‌ ‌Malayan,‌ ‌tending‌ ‌to‌ ‌show‌ ‌that‌ ‌this,‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nfamily,‌ ‌was‌ ‌anciently‌ ‌as‌ ‌universal‌ ‌as‌ ‌this‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌consanguinity‌ ‌which‌ ‌it‌ ‌created.‌ ‌\n●Punaluan‌ ‌family:‌ ‌\n○Its‌ ‌name‌ ‌is‌ ‌derived‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌‌ ‌Hawaiian‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌of‌ ‌Punalua‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌was‌ ‌founded‌ ‌upon‌ ‌the‌ ‌i‌ntermarriage‌ ‌of‌ ‌several‌ ‌brothers‌ ‌to‌ ‌each‌ ‌other’s‌ ‌wives‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌group;‌ ‌and‌ ‌of‌ ‌several‌ ‌sisters‌ ‌to‌ ‌each‌ ‌other’s‌ ‌\nhusbands‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌group.‌ ‌ ‌\n418‌ ‌\n○But‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌term‌ ‌brother,‌ ‌as‌ ‌here‌ ‌used,‌ ‌included‌ ‌the‌ ‌first,‌ ‌second,‌ ‌third,‌ ‌and‌ ‌even‌ ‌more‌ ‌remote‌ ‌male‌ ‌cousins‌,‌ ‌all‌ ‌of‌ ‌whom‌ ‌were‌ ‌\nconsidered‌ ‌brothers‌ ‌to‌ ‌each‌ ‌other,‌ ‌as‌ ‌we‌ ‌consider‌ ‌own‌ ‌brothers;‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌term‌ ‌sister‌ ‌included‌ ‌the‌ ‌first,‌ ‌second,‌ ‌third,‌ ‌and‌ ‌even‌ ‌more‌ ‌\nremote‌ ‌female‌ ‌cousins,‌ ‌all‌ ‌of‌ ‌whom‌ ‌were‌ ‌sisters‌ ‌to‌ ‌each‌ ‌other,‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌as‌ ‌own‌ ‌sisters‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌supervened‌ ‌upon‌ ‌the‌ ‌consanguine.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌created‌ ‌the‌ ‌Turanian‌ ‌and‌ ‌Ganowanian‌ ‌systems‌ ‌of‌ ‌consanguinity.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Both‌ ‌this‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌previous‌ ‌form‌ ‌belong‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Period‌ ‌of‌ ‌savagery.‌ ‌\n●Syndyasmian‌ ‌\n○Syndyasmian‌ ‌or‌ ‌pairing‌ ‌of‌ ‌families‌ ‌founded‌ ‌upon‌ ‌the‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌of‌ ‌single‌ ‌pairs,‌ ‌without‌ ‌giving‌ ‌the‌ ‌right‌ ‌of‌ ‌exclusive‌ ‌cohabitation‌ ‌to‌ ‌any‌ ‌\nperson‌ ‌over‌ ‌the‌ ‌other.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌term‌ ‌Syndyasmian‌ ‌is‌ ‌derived‌ ‌from‌ ‌syndyazo,‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌to‌ ‌pair.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌germ‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Monogamian‌ ‌Family‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Divorce‌ ‌or‌ ‌separation‌ ‌was‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌option‌ ‌of‌ ‌both‌ ‌husband‌ ‌and‌ ‌wife.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌failed‌ ‌to‌ ‌create‌ ‌a‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌consanguinity.‌ ‌\n●Patriarchal‌ ‌family:‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌comprises‌ ‌the‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌of‌ ‌one‌ ‌man‌ ‌to‌ ‌several‌ ‌wives,‌ ‌each‌ ‌wife‌ ‌being‌ ‌secluded‌ ‌from‌ ‌every‌ ‌other.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌term‌ ‌is‌ ‌here‌ ‌used‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌restricted‌ ‌sense‌ ‌to‌ ‌define‌ ‌the‌ ‌special‌ ‌family‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Hebrew‌ ‌pastoral‌ ‌tribes,‌ ‌the‌ ‌chiefs‌ ‌and‌ ‌principal‌ ‌men‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nwhich‌ ‌practised‌ ‌polygamy.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌exercised‌ ‌but‌ ‌little‌ ‌influence‌ ‌upon‌ ‌human‌ ‌affairs‌ ‌for‌ ‌want‌ ‌of‌ ‌universality.‌ ‌\n●Monogamian‌ ‌family‌ ‌\n○I‌t‌ ‌was‌ ‌founded‌ ‌upon‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌between‌ ‌single‌ ‌pairs,‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌married‌ ‌couple‌ ‌having‌ ‌exclusive‌ ‌cohabitation‌ ‌with‌ ‌one‌ ‌another,‌ ‌the‌ ‌latter‌ ‌\nconstituting‌ ‌the‌ ‌essential‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌institution‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌pre-eminently‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌of‌ ‌civilized‌ ‌society,‌ ‌and‌ ‌was‌ ‌therefore‌ ‌essentially‌ ‌modern.‌ ‌This‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌also‌ ‌created‌ ‌an‌ ‌\nindependent‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌consanguinity‌ ‌\n ‌\nTypes‌ ‌of‌ ‌Family‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Families‌ ‌are‌ ‌constituted‌ ‌by‌ ‌several‌ ‌factors‌ ‌coming‌ ‌together‌ ‌into‌ ‌play‌ ‌and‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌consideration‌ ‌of‌ ‌each‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌factors,‌ ‌one‌ ‌may‌ ‌\ndetermine‌ ‌the‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌that‌ ‌one‌ ‌may‌ ‌find‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌societies‌ ‌and‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌parts‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌world.‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌factors‌ ‌relate‌ ‌to:‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌choice‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌mate‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌mate’s‌ ‌identity,‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌mates‌ ‌that‌ ‌a‌ ‌person‌ ‌can‌ ‌lawfully‌ ‌take,‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌place‌ ‌of‌ ‌cohabitation,‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌location‌ ‌of‌ ‌authority‌ ‌with‌ ‌one‌ ‌or‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌partner,‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌line‌ ‌of‌ ‌descent‌ ‌and‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌accommodation‌ ‌of‌ ‌immediate‌ ‌relatives‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌distant‌ ‌ones.‌ ‌\n●Based‌ ‌on‌ ‌above‌ ‌factors,‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌following‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌families:‌ ‌\n419‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Family‌ ‌types‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌Birth‌ ‌\n○Family‌ ‌of‌ ‌Orientation:‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌family‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌is‌ ‌born‌ ‌is‌ ‌his‌ ‌family‌ ‌of‌ ‌orientation.‌ ‌\n○Family‌ ‌of‌ ‌Procreation:‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌family‌ ‌where‌ ‌an‌ ‌‌individual‌ ‌sets‌ ‌up‌ ‌after‌ ‌his/her‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌is‌ ‌his/her‌ ‌family‌ ‌of‌ ‌procreation.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌family‌ ‌of‌ ‌orientation‌ ‌and‌ ‌procreation‌ ‌may‌ ‌live‌ ‌together‌ ‌under‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌roof,‌ ‌but‌ ‌can‌ ‌still‌ ‌be‌ ‌distinguished‌.‌ ‌\n ‌\n420‌ ‌\n●Family‌ ‌types‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌Marriage‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○Monogamous‌ ‌Family:‌ ‌\n■This‌ ‌family‌ ‌consists‌ ‌of‌ ‌one‌ ‌husband‌ ‌and‌ ‌wife,‌ ‌including‌ ‌children‌ ‌and‌ ‌is‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌monogamous‌ ‌marriages.‌ ‌\n○Polygynous‌ ‌Family:‌ ‌\n■A‌ ‌family‌ ‌consisting‌ ‌of‌ ‌‌one‌ ‌husband,‌ ‌and‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌one‌ ‌wife,‌ ‌and‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌children‌ ‌born‌ ‌to‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌wives‌ ‌or‌ ‌adopted‌ ‌by‌ ‌each‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nthem‌.‌ ‌This‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌family‌ ‌has‌ ‌its‌ ‌basis‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌polygynous‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage.‌ ‌\n○Polyandrous‌ ‌Family:‌ ‌\n■A‌ ‌family‌ ‌made‌ ‌up‌ ‌of‌ ‌‌one‌ ‌wife‌ ‌and‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌one‌ ‌husband,‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌children,‌ ‌either‌ ‌born‌ ‌or‌ ‌adopted‌ ‌with‌ ‌each‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌them.‌ ‌\nThis‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌poly­androus‌ ‌marriage.‌ ‌\n■Example:‌ ‌ ‌\n■A‌ ‌distinct‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌people‌ ‌called‌ ‌‌Paharis‌ ‌live‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌lower‌ ‌ranges‌ ‌of‌ ‌Himalayas‌ ‌in‌ ‌Northern‌ ‌India‌ ‌from‌ ‌southeastern‌ ‌Kashmir‌ ‌\nall‌ ‌the‌ ‌way‌ ‌through‌ ‌Nepal.‌ ‌ ‌\n421‌ ‌\n■Polyandry‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌reported‌ ‌among‌ ‌these‌ ‌people‌ ‌in‌ ‌many‌ ‌districts‌ ‌but‌ ‌studied‌ ‌in‌ ‌great‌ ‌detail‌ ‌in‌ ‌‌Jaunsar-Bawar‌.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌region‌ ‌\nin‌ ‌Dehradun‌ ‌district‌ ‌in‌ ‌Uttarakhand.‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌practice‌ ‌is‌ ‌believed‌ ‌to‌ ‌have‌ ‌descended‌ ‌from‌ ‌their‌ ‌ancestors‌ ‌who‌ ‌had‌ ‌earlier‌ ‌settled‌ ‌down‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌plains‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nHimalayas.‌ ‌\n●Polyandrous‌ ‌union‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌in‌ ‌this‌ ‌region‌ ‌when‌ ‌a‌ ‌woman‌ ‌marries‌ ‌the‌ ‌eldest‌ ‌son‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌family.‌ ‌The‌ ‌woman‌ ‌automatically‌ ‌\nbecomes‌ ‌the‌ ‌wife‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌his‌ ‌brothers‌ ‌upon‌ ‌her‌ ‌marriage.‌ ‌The‌ ‌brothers‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌married‌ ‌to‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌one‌ ‌woman‌ ‌if‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nfirst‌ ‌woman‌ ‌was‌ ‌sterile‌ ‌or‌ ‌if‌ ‌the‌ ‌age‌ ‌difference‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌brothers‌ ‌were‌ ‌large.‌ ‌The‌ ‌wife‌ ‌is‌ ‌shared‌ ‌equally‌ ‌by‌ ‌all‌ ‌brothers‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌no‌ ‌one‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌group‌ ‌has‌ ‌exclusive‌ ‌privilege‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌wife.‌ ‌The‌ ‌woman‌ ‌considers‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌men‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌group‌ ‌her‌ ‌\nhusband‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌children‌ ‌recognise‌ ‌them‌ ‌all‌ ‌as‌ ‌their‌ ‌father.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●In‌ ‌India,‌ ‌until‌ ‌recently‌ ‌polygamous‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌were‌ ‌recognized‌ ‌except‌ ‌in‌ ‌cases‌ ‌of‌ ‌Christians,‌ ‌and‌ ‌even‌ ‌now‌ ‌Muslim‌ ‌men‌ ‌can‌ ‌lawfully‌ ‌\npractise‌ ‌polygyny.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Eskimo‌ ‌men‌ ‌practise‌ ‌polygyny‌ ‌and‌ ‌for‌ ‌obvious‌ ‌reasons‌ ‌too.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌tendency‌ ‌to‌ ‌polygamy‌ ‌becomes‌ ‌prominent‌ ‌when‌ ‌the‌ ‌sex‌ ‌ratio‌ ‌tends‌ ‌to‌ ‌show‌ ‌aberrations.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Of‌ ‌course,‌ ‌such‌ ‌maladjustment‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌sex‌ ‌ratio‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌ignored‌ ‌by‌ ‌law‌ ‌which‌ ‌may‌ ‌impose‌ ‌the‌ ‌constraints‌ ‌of‌ ‌monogamy‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌furtherance‌ ‌of‌ ‌\ndistinct‌ ‌social‌ ‌interests.‌ ‌When‌ ‌a‌ ‌woman‌ ‌takes‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌one‌ ‌man‌ ‌as‌ ‌her‌ ‌husband,‌ ‌these‌ ‌men‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌either‌ ‌brothers‌ ‌or‌ ‌strangers.‌ ‌\n●When‌ ‌several‌ ‌brothers‌ ‌are‌ ‌married‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌woman,‌ ‌as‌ ‌in‌ ‌some‌ ‌regions‌ ‌of‌ ‌Sikkim,‌ ‌Ladakh‌ ‌and‌ ‌Tibet,‌ ‌the‌ ‌system‌ ‌is‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌‘fraternal’‌ ‌\npolyandry‌.‌ ‌\n●Fraternal‌ ‌polyandry‌ ‌exists‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌Khasa‌ ‌of‌ ‌Dehradun;‌ ‌and‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌Gallong‌ ‌and‌ ‌Memba‌ ‌of‌ ‌Arunachal‌ ‌Pradesh,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Mala‌ ‌Madessar,‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌Mavilan,‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌of‌ ‌Kerala.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Non-fraternal‌ ‌polyandry‌ ‌exists‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌K‌ota;‌ ‌and‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌Karvazhi,‌ ‌Pulaya,‌ ‌Muthuvan,‌ ‌and‌ ‌Mannan‌ ‌in‌ ‌Kerala.‌ ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌Addition‌ ‌\nPolygamy‌ ‌in‌ ‌India‌ ‌\n●Polygamy‌ ‌in‌ ‌India‌ ‌is‌ ‌outlawed.‌ ‌While‌ ‌polygamy‌ ‌was‌ ‌not‌ ‌prohibited‌ ‌in‌ ‌Ancient‌ ‌India‌ ‌and‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌common‌ ‌among‌ ‌aristocrats‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nemperors,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌believed‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌not‌ ‌a‌ ‌major‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌practice.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌contrast‌ ‌to‌ ‌Europe,‌ ‌polygamy‌ ‌prevailed‌ ‌in‌ ‌ancient‌ ‌India‌ ‌for‌ ‌rulers‌ ‌and‌ ‌kings.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌British‌ ‌colonial‌ ‌Empire‌ ‌of‌ ‌India‌ ‌permitted‌ ‌Islamic‌ ‌provinces‌ ‌to‌ ‌allow‌ ‌husbands‌ ‌to‌ ‌have‌ ‌multiple‌ ‌wives.‌ ‌ ‌\n○When‌ ‌Maharaja‌ ‌Ranjit‌ ‌Singh‌ ‌was‌ ‌cremated‌ ‌in‌ ‌Lahore,‌ ‌four‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌wives‌ ‌and‌ ‌seven‌ ‌concubines‌ ‌took‌ ‌to‌ ‌Sati,‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌\nurn-like‌ ‌memorials‌ ‌exist‌ ‌at‌ ‌his‌ ‌Samadhi.‌ ‌\n●Legal‌ ‌developments‌ ‌\n○Section‌ ‌494‌ ‌and‌ ‌495‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌Penal‌ ‌Code‌ ‌of‌ ‌1860,‌ ‌prohibited‌ ‌polygamy‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌Christians.‌ ‌In‌ ‌1955,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Hindu‌ ‌Marriage‌ ‌\nAct‌ ‌was‌ ‌drafted,‌ ‌which‌ ‌prohibited‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌Hindu‌ ‌whose‌ ‌spouse‌ ‌was‌ ‌still‌ ‌living.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Thus‌ ‌polygamy‌ ‌became‌ ‌illegal‌ ‌in‌ ‌India‌ ‌in‌ ‌1956,‌ ‌uniformly‌ ‌for‌ ‌all‌ ‌of‌ ‌its‌ ‌citizens‌ ‌except‌ ‌for‌ ‌Muslims‌,‌ ‌who‌ ‌are‌ ‌permitted‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nhave‌ ‌four‌ ‌wives‌ ‌and‌ ‌for‌ ‌Hindus‌ ‌in‌ ‌Goa‌ ‌and‌ ‌along‌ ‌the‌ ‌western‌ ‌coast‌ ‌where‌ ‌bigamy‌ ‌is‌ ‌legal.‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌polygamous‌ ‌Hindu‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌is‌ ‌null‌ ‌and‌ ‌void.‌ ‌While‌ ‌the‌ ‌punishment‌ ‌specified‌ ‌in‌ ‌Sections‌ ‌494‌ ‌and‌ ‌495‌ ‌is‌ ‌\napplicable‌,‌‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌rare‌ ‌if‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌spouse‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌have‌ ‌an‌ ‌objection.‌ ‌\n422‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Muslim‌ ‌Polygamy‌ ‌\n○Muslims‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌rest‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌country‌ ‌are‌ ‌subject‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌The‌ ‌Muslim‌ ‌Personal‌ ‌Law‌ ‌(Shariat)‌ ‌Application‌ ‌Act‌ ‌of‌ ‌1937,‌ ‌\ninterpreted‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌All‌ ‌India‌ ‌Muslim‌ ‌Personal‌ ‌Law‌ ‌Board.‌ ‌\n○However,‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌judgment‌ ‌in‌ ‌February‌ ‌2015,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Supreme‌ ‌court‌ ‌of‌ ‌India‌ ‌stated‌ ‌that‌ ‌\"‌Polygamy‌ ‌was‌ ‌not‌ ‌an‌ ‌integral‌ ‌or‌ ‌\nfundamental‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Muslim‌ ‌religion,‌ ‌and‌ ‌monogamy‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌reform‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌power‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌State‌ ‌under‌ ‌Article‌ ‌25.”‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Hindu‌ ‌Polygamy‌ ‌in‌ ‌modern‌ ‌India-Case‌ ‌Study‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Bollywood‌ ‌star‌ ‌and‌ ‌Lok‌ ‌Sabha‌ ‌member‌ ‌Dharmendra‌ ‌was‌ ‌already‌ ‌married‌ ‌to‌ ‌Prakash‌ ‌Kaur‌ ‌when‌ ‌he‌ ‌married‌ ‌actress‌ ‌\nHema‌ ‌Malini‌ ‌in‌ ‌1980.‌ ‌ ‌\n●While‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌reported‌ ‌that‌ ‌he‌ ‌had‌ ‌converted‌ ‌to‌ ‌Islam‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌sake‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌marriage,[8]‌ ‌he‌ ‌denied‌ ‌getting‌ ‌converted.‌ ‌\n●Legally‌ ‌the‌ ‌second‌ ‌wife‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌Hindu‌ ‌would‌ ‌be‌ ‌a‌ ‌mistress,‌ ‌although‌ ‌religiously‌ ‌and‌ ‌socially‌ ‌she‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌considered‌ ‌a‌ ‌wife.‌ ‌\n●Polygamy‌ ‌among‌ ‌Hindus‌ ‌is‌ ‌sometimes‌ ‌accepted‌ ‌in‌ ‌some‌ ‌rural‌ ‌areas,[10]‌ ‌often‌ ‌with‌ ‌approval‌ ‌by‌ ‌earlier‌ ‌wives.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌2005-06‌ ‌National‌ ‌Family‌ ‌Health‌ ‌Survey‌ ‌(NFHS-3)‌ ‌found‌ ‌that‌ ‌2%‌ ‌of‌ ‌women‌ ‌reported‌ ‌that‌ ‌their‌ ‌husband‌ ‌had‌ ‌other‌ ‌wives‌ ‌\nbesides‌ ‌herself.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Husbands‌ ‌of‌ ‌women‌ ‌with‌ ‌no‌ ‌children‌ ‌are‌ ‌more‌ ‌likely‌ ‌to‌ ‌have‌ ‌multiple‌ ‌wives.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Christian‌ ‌Polygamy‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌Mizoram‌ ‌state,‌ ‌a‌ ‌Christian‌ ‌‌religious‌ ‌sect‌ ‌‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌\"Pu‌ ‌Chana‌ ‌Páwl\"‌ ‌or‌ ‌simply‌ ‌\"Chana,\"‌ ‌formed‌ ‌in‌ ‌June‌ ‌1942,‌ ‌permits‌ ‌\npolygamy.‌ ‌ ‌\n○As‌ ‌of‌ ‌2011‌ ‌its‌ ‌leader,‌ ‌Ziona‌ ‌(born‌ ‌1945),‌ ‌had‌ ‌39‌ ‌wives,‌ ‌94‌ ‌children,‌ ‌and‌ ‌33‌ ‌grandchildren,‌ ‌all‌ ‌living‌ ‌under‌ ‌one‌ ‌roof.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n423‌ ‌\n●Family‌ ‌types‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌Residence‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○Family‌ ‌of‌ ‌Matrilocal‌ ‌Residence‌ ‌or‌ ‌uxorilocal‌ ‌residence:‌ ‌\n■When‌ ‌a‌ ‌couple‌ ‌stays‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌wife’s‌ ‌house,‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌of‌ ‌matrilocal‌ ‌residence.‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌is‌ ‌founded‌ ‌with‌ ‌two‌ ‌or‌ ‌more‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌families‌ ‌affiliated‌ ‌through‌ ‌an‌ ‌extension‌ ‌of‌ ‌mother‌ ‌daughter‌ ‌relationship.‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌consists‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌family‌ ‌consisting‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌woman,‌ ‌her‌ ‌daughters‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌daughters’‌ ‌husbands‌ ‌and‌ ‌children.‌ ‌\n424‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌makes‌ ‌15%‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌society‌ ‌(roughly).‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n■Matrilocal‌ ‌residence‌ ‌is‌ ‌found‌ ‌most‌ ‌often‌ ‌in‌ ‌horticultural‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌\n●Examples‌ ‌of‌ ‌matrilocal‌ ‌societies‌ ‌include‌ ‌the‌ ‌people‌ ‌of‌ ‌‌Ngazidja‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Comoros,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Ancestral‌ ‌Puebloans‌ ‌of‌ ‌Chaco‌ ‌\nCanyon,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Nair‌ ‌community‌ ‌in‌ ‌Kerala‌ ‌in‌ ‌South‌ ‌India,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Moso‌ ‌of‌ ‌Yunnan‌ ‌and‌ ‌Sichuan‌ ‌in‌ ‌southwestern‌ ‌China,‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nSiraya‌ ‌of‌ ‌Taiwan,‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌Minangkabau‌ ‌of‌ ‌western‌ ‌Sumatra.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Among‌ ‌indigenous‌ ‌people‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Amazon‌ ‌basin‌ ‌this‌ ‌residence‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌is‌ ‌often‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌customary‌ ‌practice‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌brideservice,‌ ‌as‌ ‌seen‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Urarina‌ ‌of‌ ‌northeastern‌ ‌Peru‌.‌ ‌\n ‌\n○Family‌ ‌of‌ ‌Patrilocal‌ ‌Residence‌ ‌or‌ ‌virilocal‌ ‌residence:‌ ‌\n■When‌ ‌a‌ ‌family‌ ‌stays‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌house‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌husband,‌ ‌the‌ ‌fam­ily‌ ‌is‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌family‌ ‌of‌ ‌patrilocal‌ ‌residence.‌ ‌\n■Such‌ ‌a‌ ‌family‌ ‌comprises‌ ‌a‌ ‌man‌ ‌and‌ ‌his‌ ‌wife‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌sons‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌sons’‌ ‌wives‌ ‌and‌ ‌childrens.‌ ‌\n425‌ ‌\n■Among‌ ‌the‌ ‌Veddas‌ ‌of‌ ‌Ceylon,‌ ‌the‌ ‌groom‌ ‌comes‌ ‌to‌ ‌stay‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌bride‌ ‌s‌ ‌family,‌ ‌but‌ ‌in‌ ‌most‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌modern‌ ‌\nsocieties‌ ‌the‌ ‌patrilocal‌ ‌system‌ ‌is‌ ‌followed.‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌bride‌ ‌comes‌ ‌to‌ ‌live‌ ‌either‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌groom’s‌ ‌household‌ ‌among‌ ‌his‌ ‌relatives,‌ ‌or‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌groom’s‌ ‌house‌ ‌but‌ ‌not‌ ‌with‌ ‌his‌ ‌\nrelatives.‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌makes‌ ‌67%‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌society‌ ‌(roughly).‌ ‌\n ‌\n426‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n■Neanderthals‌ ‌and‌ ‌early‌ ‌hominins‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌claimed‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌practice‌ ‌was‌ ‌also‌ ‌prevalent‌ ‌in‌ ‌some‌ ‌Neanderthal‌ ‌populations.‌ ‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌49,000-year-old‌ ‌grave‌ ‌was‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌Spain‌ ‌in‌ ‌2010‌ ‌which‌ ‌contained‌ ‌three‌ ‌related-to-each-other‌ ‌males,‌ ‌with‌ ‌three‌ ‌\nunrelated-to-each-other‌ ‌females,‌ ‌suggesting‌ ‌they‌ ‌were‌ ‌the‌ ‌partners‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌males.‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌2011‌ ‌study‌ ‌using‌ ‌ratios‌ ‌of‌ ‌strontium‌ ‌isotopes‌ ‌in‌ ‌teeth‌ ‌also‌ ‌suggested‌ ‌that‌ ‌roughly‌ ‌2‌ ‌million‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago,‌ ‌among‌ ‌\nAustralopithecus‌ ‌and‌ ‌Paranthropus‌ ‌robustus‌ ‌‌groups‌ ‌in‌ ‌southern‌ ‌Africa,‌ ‌women‌ ‌tended‌ ‌to‌ ‌settle‌ ‌farther‌ ‌from‌ ‌their‌ ‌\nregion‌ ‌of‌ ‌birth‌ ‌than‌ ‌men‌ ‌did.‌ ‌\n427‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○Family‌ ‌of‌ ‌Changing‌ ‌Residence:‌ ‌\n■When‌ ‌a‌ ‌family‌ ‌stays‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌husband’s‌ ‌house‌ ‌for‌ ‌some‌ ‌time,‌ ‌and‌ ‌moves‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌wife's‌ ‌house,‌ ‌stays‌ ‌there‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌period‌ ‌of‌ ‌time,‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌then‌ ‌moves‌ ‌back‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌husband's‌ ‌parents,‌ ‌or‌ ‌starts‌ ‌living‌ ‌in‌ ‌another‌ ‌place,‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌called‌ ‌a‌ ‌family‌ ‌of‌ ‌changing‌ ‌\nresidence.‌ ‌\n○Other‌ ‌types:‌ ‌\n■Neolocal‌ ‌Residence:‌ ‌\n●American‌ ‌society‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌customary‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌newly‌ ‌wedded‌ ‌couple‌ ‌to‌ ‌take‌ ‌up‌ ‌residence‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌place‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌own,‌ ‌apart‌ ‌from‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌relatives‌ ‌of‌ ‌either‌ ‌spouse.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌is‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌neolocal‌ ‌residence‌ ‌(that‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌new‌ ‌place).‌ ‌ ‌\n■Avunculocal‌ ‌Residence:‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌some‌ ‌societies‌ ‌like‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Ashanti‌ ‌of‌ ‌Ghana‌ ‌a‌ ‌couple‌ ‌after‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌resides‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌groom’s‌ ‌mother’s‌ ‌brother’s‌ ‌\nfamily‌ ‌or‌ ‌maternal‌ ‌uncles‌ ‌house‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌avunculocal‌ ‌residence.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌consists‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌or‌ ‌more‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌families‌ ‌affiliated‌ ‌through‌ ‌an‌ ‌extension‌ ‌of‌ ‌maternal-uncle‌ ‌and‌ ‌sisters‌ ‌son‌ ‌\nrelationship.‌ ‌\n●Such‌ ‌a‌ ‌family‌ ‌includes‌ ‌a‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌family‌ ‌formed‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌man,‌ ‌his‌ ‌wife‌ ‌and‌ ‌daughter‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌family‌ ‌formed‌ ‌by‌ ‌his‌ ‌\nsister’s‌ ‌son‌ ‌and‌ ‌wife‌ ‌and‌ ‌children.‌ ‌\n428‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌makes‌ ‌4%‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌society‌ ‌(roughly).‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Cultures‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌formal‌ ‌Avunculate‌ ‌\n○According‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Kazakh‌ ‌common‌ ‌law,‌ ‌the‌ ‌avunculate‌ ‌nephews‌ ‌could‌ ‌take‌ ‌anything‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌relatives‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nmother‌ ‌up‌ ‌to‌ ‌three‌ ‌times.‌ ‌In‌ ‌the‌ ‌Kyrgyz‌ ‌past‌ ‌a‌ ‌nephew,‌ ‌at‌ ‌a‌ ‌feast‌ ‌at‌ ‌his‌ ‌maternal‌ ‌uncle‌ ‌or‌ ‌grandfather,‌ ‌could‌ ‌\ntake‌ ‌any‌ ‌horse‌ ‌from‌ ‌their‌ ‌herd‌ ‌or‌ ‌any‌ ‌delicacy.‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌the‌ ‌Southwest‌ ‌United‌ ‌States,‌ ‌‌the‌ ‌Apache‌ ‌tribe‌ ‌practices‌ ‌a‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌this,‌ ‌where‌ ‌the‌ ‌uncle‌ ‌is‌ ‌responsible‌ ‌for‌ ‌\nteaching‌ ‌the‌ ‌children‌ ‌social‌ ‌values‌ ‌and‌ ‌proper‌ ‌behavior‌ ‌while‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌and‌ ‌ancestry‌ ‌is‌ ‌reckoned‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nmother's‌ ‌family‌ ‌alone‌.‌ ‌Modern‌ ‌day‌ ‌influences‌ ‌have‌ ‌somewhat‌ ‌but‌ ‌not‌ ‌completely‌ ‌erased‌ ‌this‌ ‌tradition.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌‌Chamorros‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Mariana‌ ‌Islands‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌Taíno‌ ‌of‌ ‌Turks‌ ‌and‌ ‌Caicos‌ ‌Islands‌ ‌are‌ ‌examples‌ ‌of‌ ‌societies‌ ‌\nthat‌ ‌have‌ ‌practiced‌ ‌avunculocal‌ ‌residence.‌ ‌\n■Ambilocal‌ ‌or‌ ‌bilocal‌ ‌residence:‌ ‌\n●Again‌ ‌in‌ ‌some‌ ‌societies‌ ‌a‌ ‌married‌ ‌couple‌ ‌has‌ ‌the‌ ‌choice‌ ‌of‌ ‌living‌ ‌with‌ ‌relatives‌ ‌of‌ ‌either‌ ‌spouse‌ ‌(the‌ ‌husband‌ ‌or‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nwife).‌ ‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌residence‌ ‌thus‌ ‌formed‌ ‌is‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌ambilocal‌ ‌or‌ ‌bilocal‌ ‌residence.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌combination‌ ‌of‌ ‌patrilocal‌ ‌extended‌ ‌family‌ ‌and‌ ‌matrilocal‌ ‌extended‌ ‌family.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌extended‌ ‌family‌ ‌consists‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌or‌ ‌more‌ ‌lineally‌ ‌related‌ ‌kinfolk‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌sex‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌spouses‌ ‌and‌ ‌offspring‌ ‌\noccupying‌ ‌a‌ ‌single‌ ‌household‌ ‌and‌ ‌under‌ ‌the‌ ‌authority‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌household‌ ‌head.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌makes‌ ‌7%‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌society‌ ‌(roughly).‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n429‌ ‌\n●Family‌ ‌types‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌Ancestry/Descent‌ ‌\n ‌\n○Matrilineal‌ ‌Family:‌ ‌\n430‌ ‌\n■When‌ ‌ancestry‌ ‌or‌ ‌descent‌ ‌is‌ ‌traced‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌female‌ ‌line,‌ ‌or‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌mother’s‌ ‌side,‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌called‌ ‌matrilineal‌ ‌\nfamily.‌ ‌\n ‌\n■Examples‌ ‌ ‌\n■Include‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Cherokee,‌ ‌Choctaw,‌ ‌Sicewa,‌ ‌Seneca,‌ ‌Minotoan‌ ‌Gitksan,‌ ‌Haida,‌ ‌Hopi,‌ ‌Iroquois,‌ ‌Lenape,‌ ‌Navajo‌ ‌and‌ ‌Tlingit‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nNorth‌ ‌America;‌ ‌ ‌\n■the‌‌ ‌Kuna‌ ‌people‌ ‌of‌ ‌Panama;‌ ‌the‌ ‌Kogi‌ ‌and‌ ‌Carib‌ ‌of‌ ‌South‌ ‌Americ‌a;‌ ‌ ‌\n■the‌ ‌Minangkabau‌ ‌people‌ ‌of‌ ‌West‌ ‌Sumatra,‌ ‌Indonesia‌ ‌ ‌\n■Negeri‌ ‌Sembilan,‌ ‌Malaysia;‌ ‌ ‌\n■the‌ ‌Trobrianders,‌ ‌Dobu‌ ‌and‌ ‌Nagovisi‌ ‌of‌ ‌Melanesia;‌ ‌ ‌\n■the‌ ‌Thiyyas,‌ ‌Nairs‌ ‌and‌ ‌Muslims‌ ‌of‌ ‌Kerala‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌Billavas‌ ‌&‌ ‌the‌ ‌Bunts‌ ‌of‌ ‌Karnataka‌ ‌in‌ ‌south‌ ‌India;‌ ‌the‌ ‌Khasi,‌ ‌Jaintia‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌Garo‌ ‌of‌ ‌Meghalaya‌ ‌in‌ ‌northeast‌ ‌India;‌ ‌ ‌\n■the‌ ‌Ngalops‌ ‌and‌ ‌Sharchops‌ ‌of‌ ‌Bhutan;‌ ‌ ‌\n■Muslims‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌Tamils‌ ‌in‌ ‌eastern‌ ‌Sri‌ ‌Lanka;‌ ‌ ‌\n■the‌ ‌Mosuo‌ ‌of‌ ‌China;‌ ‌ ‌\n■the‌ ‌Kayah‌ ‌of‌ ‌Southeast‌ ‌Asia,‌ ‌ ‌\n■the‌ ‌Picti‌ ‌of‌ ‌Scotland,‌ ‌ ‌\n■the‌ ‌Basques‌ ‌of‌ ‌Spain‌ ‌and‌ ‌France;‌ ‌ ‌\n■the‌ ‌Ainu‌ ‌of‌ ‌Japan,‌ ‌ ‌\n■the‌ ‌Akan‌ ‌including‌ ‌the‌ ‌Ashanti,‌ ‌Bono,‌ ‌Akwamu,‌ ‌Fante‌ ‌of‌ ‌Ghana;‌ ‌ ‌\n○Most‌ ‌groups‌ ‌across‌ ‌the‌ ‌so-called‌ ‌\"matrilineal‌ ‌belt\"‌ ‌of‌ ‌south-central‌ ‌Africa;‌ ‌the‌ ‌Tuareg‌ ‌of‌ ‌west‌ ‌and‌ ‌north‌ ‌Africa;‌ ‌the‌ ‌Serer‌ ‌of‌ ‌Senegal,‌ ‌\nThe‌ ‌Gambia‌ ‌and‌ ‌Mauritania.‌ ‌\n431‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○Patrilineal‌ ‌Family:‌ ‌\n■A‌ ‌family‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌the‌ ‌authority‌ ‌is‌ ‌carried‌ ‌down‌ ‌the‌ ‌male‌ ‌line,‌ ‌and‌ ‌descent‌ ‌is‌ ‌traced‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌male‌ ‌line‌ ‌or‌ ‌the‌ ‌father’s‌ ‌side,‌ ‌\nis‌ ‌called‌ ‌a‌ ‌patrilineal‌ ‌family.‌ ‌\n■In‌ ‌India,‌ ‌barring‌ ‌a‌ ‌few‌ ‌small‌ ‌communities,‌ ‌the‌ ‌patrilineal‌ ‌form‌ ‌is‌ ‌predominant‌ ‌as‌ ‌also‌ ‌in‌ ‌most‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Western,‌ ‌Middle‌ ‌Eastern‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌African‌ ‌countries‌.‌ ‌\n432‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Family‌ ‌types‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌nature‌ ‌&‌ ‌relation‌ ‌\n●Conjugal‌ ‌Family:‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌conjugal‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌made‌ ‌up‌ ‌of‌ ‌adults‌ ‌among‌ ‌whom‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌sexual‌ ‌relationship.‌ ‌It‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌family‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌spouses‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌their‌ ‌dependent‌ ‌children.‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌emphasis‌ ‌is‌ ‌placed‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌marital‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌that‌ ‌exists‌ ‌between‌ ‌spouses.‌ ‌ ‌\n■In‌ ‌modern‌ ‌times,‌ ‌the‌ ‌term‌ ‌‘conjugal‌ ‌family’‌ ‌is‌ ‌being‌ ‌used‌ ‌for‌ ‌partners,‌ ‌who‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌long-‌ ‌term‌ ‌sexual‌ ‌relationship,‌ ‌but‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌\nactually‌ ‌married.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Consanguine‌ ‌Family:‌ ‌\n■A‌ ‌consanguine‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌made‌ ‌up‌ ‌of‌ ‌members‌ ‌among‌ ‌whom‌ ‌a‌ ‌blood‌ ‌relation‌ ‌exists,‌ ‌or‌ ‌those‌ ‌who‌ ‌are‌ ‌consanguineal‌ ‌kin,‌ ‌i.e.,‌ ‌\na‌ ‌family‌ ‌consisting‌ ‌of‌ ‌parent(s)‌ ‌and‌ ‌children,‌ ‌or‌ ‌siblings‌ ‌(brothers,‌ ‌sisters,‌ ‌or‌ ‌brothers‌ ‌and‌ ‌sisters).‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n433‌ ‌\n●Family‌ ‌types‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌Authority‌ ‌\n ‌\n●In‌ ‌Roman‌ ‌times,‌ ‌‌an‌ ‌excess‌ ‌of‌ ‌authority‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌male‌ ‌head‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌had‌ ‌been‌ ‌noticed‌ ‌in‌ ‌his‌ ‌power‌ ‌of‌ ‌life‌ ‌and‌ ‌death‌ ‌over‌ ‌family‌ ‌\nmembers;‌ ‌and‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌societies,‌ ‌including‌ ‌the‌ ‌major‌ ‌parts‌ ‌of‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌society,‌ ‌the‌ ‌patriarchal‌ ‌system‌ ‌prevails‌ ‌though‌ ‌not‌ ‌with‌ ‌such‌ ‌brute‌ ‌\nauthority‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌‘matriarchal’‌ ‌system‌ ‌envisages‌ ‌the‌ ‌authority‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌female‌ ‌who‌ ‌devises‌ ‌the‌ ‌ways‌ ‌and‌ ‌means‌ ‌of‌ ‌conducting‌ ‌the‌ ‌affairs‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family.‌ ‌\n○Matriarchal‌ ‌Family:‌ ‌\n■Matriarchal‌ ‌families‌ ‌are‌ ‌generally‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌matrilineal‌ ‌societies‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌these‌ ‌families,‌ ‌a‌ ‌woman‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌head‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family,‌ ‌and‌ ‌authority‌ ‌is‌ ‌vested‌ ‌in‌ ‌her.‌ ‌Succession‌ ‌of‌ ‌property‌ ‌is‌ ‌through‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌female‌ ‌line,‌ ‌i.e‌ ‌only‌ ‌daughters‌ ‌inherit‌ ‌the‌ ‌property.‌ ‌\n■After‌ ‌marriage,‌ ‌the‌ ‌husband‌ ‌resides‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌wife’s‌ ‌house‌ ‌and‌ ‌descent‌ ‌is‌ ‌traced‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌mother’s‌ ‌side.‌ ‌Here,‌ ‌children‌ ‌are‌ ‌\nbrought‌ ‌up‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌mother's‌ ‌house.‌ ‌ ‌\n434‌ ‌\n●Thus,‌ ‌in‌ ‌matriarchal‌ ‌societies,‌ ‌the‌ ‌matrilocal‌ ‌system‌ ‌exists.‌ ‌Matriarchal‌ ‌families‌ ‌are‌ ‌found‌ ‌only‌ ‌in‌ ‌matrilineal‌ ‌societies,‌ ‌\nwhich‌ ‌are‌ ‌very‌ ‌limited‌ ‌in‌ ‌number‌ ‌all‌ ‌over‌ ‌the‌ ‌world.‌ ‌They‌ ‌are‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌parts‌ ‌of‌ ‌Latin‌ ‌America,‌ ‌Ceylon,‌ ‌parts‌ ‌of‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌India‌ ‌(the‌ ‌Khasis‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌Garos).‌ ‌\n○Patriarchal‌ ‌Family:‌ ‌\n■Patriarchal‌ ‌families‌ ‌are‌ ‌commonly‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌all‌ ‌parts‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌world,‌ ‌since‌ ‌most‌ ‌societies‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌world‌ ‌are‌ ‌patrilineal‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌ ‌\n■In‌ ‌patriarchal‌ ‌families,‌ ‌the‌ ‌head‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌male,‌ ‌and‌ ‌authority‌ ‌is‌ ‌vested‌ ‌in‌ ‌him.‌ ‌\n■Descent‌ ‌and‌ ‌property‌ ‌is‌ ‌passed‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌male‌ ‌line‌ ‌and‌ ‌children‌ ‌are‌ ‌brought‌ ‌up‌ ‌in‌ ‌father’s‌ ‌house.‌ ‌Such‌ ‌families‌ ‌are‌ ‌\npatrilocal‌ ‌in‌ ‌nature.‌ ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌Addition:‌ ‌\nReasons‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌persistence‌ ‌of‌ ‌patriarchy‌ ‌in‌ ‌our‌ ‌society:‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nIntroduction‌ ‌\n●Patriarchy‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌dominance‌ ‌in‌ ‌society‌ ‌by‌ ‌male‌ ‌counterparts,‌ ‌intruding‌ ‌considerably‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌autonomy‌ ‌of‌ ‌females.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌essentially‌ ‌a‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌male‌ ‌domination‌ ‌in‌ ‌diverse‌ ‌aspects‌ ‌of‌ ‌life‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌moral‌ ‌authority,‌ ‌social‌ ‌privilege,‌ ‌decision‌ ‌making,‌ ‌control‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nproperty,‌ ‌political‌ ‌leadership‌ ‌et‌ ‌al.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌has‌ ‌hampered‌ ‌the‌ ‌position‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌middle‌ ‌class‌ ‌working‌ ‌women‌ ‌in‌ ‌India‌ ‌in‌ ‌contemporary‌ ‌times‌ ‌owing‌ ‌to‌ ‌prolonged‌ ‌practices‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌past‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌submissiveness‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌females.‌ ‌\n ‌\nReasons:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●The‌ ‌‌first‌ ‌lessons‌ ‌of‌ ‌patriarchy‌ ‌are‌ ‌learnt‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌where‌ ‌the‌ ‌head‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌man/‌ ‌father.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Man‌ ‌is‌ ‌considered‌ ‌the‌ ‌head‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌and‌ ‌controls‌ ‌women’s‌ ‌sexuality,‌ ‌labour‌ ‌or‌ ‌production,‌ ‌reproduction‌ ‌and‌ ‌mobility.‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌a‌ ‌patriarchal‌ ‌family‌ ‌the‌ ‌birth‌ ‌of‌ ‌male‌ ‌child‌ ‌is‌ ‌preferred‌ ‌to‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌female.‌ ‌\n○Patriarchal‌ ‌societies‌ ‌propagate‌ ‌the‌ ‌ideology‌ ‌of‌ ‌motherhood‌ ‌which‌ ‌restricts‌ ‌women’s‌ ‌mobility‌ ‌and‌ ‌burdens‌ ‌them‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nresponsibilities‌ ‌to‌ ‌nurture‌ ‌and‌ ‌rear‌ ‌children.‌ ‌\n●Family‌ ‌is‌ ‌therefore‌ ‌important‌ ‌for‌ ‌socializing‌ ‌the‌ ‌next‌ ‌generation‌ ‌in‌ ‌patriarchal‌ ‌values.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌boys‌ ‌learn‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌dominating‌ ‌and‌ ‌aggressive‌ ‌and‌ ‌girls‌ ‌learn‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌caring,‌ ‌loving‌ ‌and‌ ‌submissive.‌ ‌ ‌\n○These‌ ‌stereotypes‌ ‌of‌ ‌masculinity‌ ‌and‌ ‌femininity‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌only‌ ‌social‌ ‌constructs‌ ‌but‌ ‌also‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌internalized‌ ‌by‌ ‌both‌ ‌men‌ ‌and‌ ‌\n○While‌ ‌the‌ ‌pressure‌ ‌to‌ ‌earn‌ ‌and‌ ‌look‌ ‌after‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌more‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌man,‌ ‌the‌ ‌women‌ ‌are‌ ‌supposed‌ ‌to‌ ‌do‌ ‌the‌ ‌menial‌ ‌jobs‌ ‌and‌ ‌take‌ ‌\ncare‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌children‌ ‌and‌ ‌even‌ ‌other‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌because‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌gender‌ ‌stereotypes‌ ‌that‌ ‌women‌ ‌are‌ ‌at‌ ‌a‌ ‌disadvantage‌ ‌and‌ ‌are‌ ‌vulnerable‌ ‌to‌ ‌violence‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌kinds‌ ‌of‌ ‌\ndiscriminations‌ ‌and‌ ‌injustices.‌ ‌\n●Systemic‌ ‌deprivation‌ ‌and‌ ‌violence‌ ‌against‌ ‌women:‌ ‌rape,‌ ‌sexual‌ ‌harassment,‌ ‌sexual‌ ‌abuse,‌ ‌female‌ ‌feticide,‌ ‌infanticide,‌ ‌sati,‌ ‌dowry‌ ‌\ndeaths,‌ ‌wife-beating,‌ ‌high‌ ‌level‌ ‌of‌ ‌female‌ ‌illiteracy,‌ ‌malnutrition,‌ ‌undernourishment‌ ‌and‌ ‌continued‌ ‌sense‌ ‌of‌ ‌insecurity‌ ‌keeps‌ ‌women‌ ‌bound‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌home,‌ ‌economically‌ ‌exploited,‌ ‌socially‌ ‌suppressed‌ ‌and‌ ‌politically‌ ‌passive.‌ ‌\n○Patriarchal‌ ‌constructions‌ ‌of‌ ‌knowledge‌ ‌perpetuate‌ ‌patriarchal‌ ‌ideology‌ ‌and‌ ‌this‌ ‌is‌ ‌reflected‌ ‌in‌ ‌educational‌ ‌institutions,‌ ‌knowledge‌ ‌\nsystem‌ ‌and‌ ‌media‌ ‌which‌ ‌reinforce‌ ‌male‌ ‌dominance.‌ ‌\n●Patriarchal‌ ‌constructions‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌practices‌ ‌are‌ ‌legitimized‌ ‌by‌ ‌religion‌ ‌and‌ ‌religious‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌as‌ ‌most‌ ‌religious‌ ‌practices‌ ‌regard‌ ‌male‌ ‌\n435‌ ‌\nauthority‌ ‌as‌ ‌superior‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌laws‌ ‌and‌ ‌norms‌ ‌regarding‌ ‌family,‌ ‌marriage,‌ ‌divorce‌ ‌and‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌are‌ ‌linked‌ ‌to‌ ‌patriarchal‌ ‌control‌ ‌over‌ ‌\nproperty‌ ‌biased‌ ‌against‌ ‌women‌ ‌\n●Male‌ ‌dominated‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌and‌ ‌states‌ ‌also‌ ‌lay‌ ‌down‌ ‌rules‌ ‌regarding‌ ‌women’s‌ ‌reproductive‌ ‌capacity.‌ ‌\n ‌\nPatriarchal‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌\n ‌\n●India‌ ‌\n○Women‌ ‌in‌ ‌India‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌denied‌ ‌opportunities‌ ‌for‌ ‌growth‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌name‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion‌ ‌and‌ ‌socio-cultural‌ ‌practices.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Thus,‌ ‌women‌ ‌in‌ ‌India‌ ‌have‌ ‌few‌ ‌freedoms‌ ‌even‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌homes,‌ ‌hold‌ ‌an‌ ‌unequal‌ ‌and‌ ‌inferior‌ ‌status‌ ‌in‌ ‌society,‌ ‌and‌ ‌are‌ ‌subject‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nrule‌ ‌of‌ ‌male‌ ‌heads‌ ‌of‌ ‌household‌ ‌(their‌ ‌fathers‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌childhoods‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌husbands‌ ‌after‌ ‌marriage).‌ ‌ ‌\n○Additionally,‌ ‌girls‌ ‌are‌ ‌viewed‌ ‌as‌ ‌less‌ ‌valuable‌ ‌than‌ ‌boys,‌ ‌so‌ ‌many‌ ‌families‌ ‌will‌ ‌choose‌ ‌to‌ ‌under‌ ‌educate‌ ‌their‌ ‌daughters.‌ ‌ ‌\n○As‌ ‌a‌ ‌result,‌ ‌India‌ ‌is‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌43‌ ‌countries‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌world‌ ‌where‌ ‌the‌ ‌male‌ ‌literacy‌ ‌rate‌ ‌is‌ ‌higher‌ ‌than‌ ‌the‌ ‌female‌ ‌literacy‌ ‌rate.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Peru‌ ‌\n○While‌ ‌physical‌ ‌abuse‌ ‌and‌ ‌violence‌ ‌against‌ ‌women‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌problem‌ ‌worldwide,‌ ‌nowhere‌ ‌is‌ ‌it‌ ‌more‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌problem‌ ‌than‌ ‌in‌ ‌Peru.‌ ‌\n○ ‌In‌ ‌rural‌ ‌areas‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌country,‌ ‌61%‌ ‌of‌ ‌women‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌victims‌ ‌of‌ ‌physical‌ ‌abuse.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌the‌ ‌entire‌ ‌country,‌ ‌the‌ ‌World‌ ‌Health‌ ‌Organization‌ ‌reports‌ ‌that‌ ‌52‌ ‌percent‌ ‌of‌ ‌Peruvian‌ ‌women‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌slapped‌ ‌by‌ ‌their‌ ‌partner.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n●The‌ ‌United‌ ‌States‌ ‌\n○Philip‌ ‌Cohen,‌ ‌a‌ ‌professor‌ ‌of‌ ‌sociology‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌University‌ ‌of‌ ‌Maryland,‌ ‌argues‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌U.S.‌ ‌remains‌ ‌a‌ ‌patriarchy‌ ‌because‌ ‌it's‌ ‌\"ruled‌ ‌\nby‌ ‌men.\"‌ ‌ ‌\n○By‌ ‌the‌ ‌numbers,‌ ‌this‌ ‌is‌ ‌undeniably‌ ‌true:‌ ‌as‌ ‌reported‌ ‌by‌ ‌Vox,‌ ‌only‌ ‌24‌ ‌Fortune‌ ‌500‌ ‌companies‌ ‌had‌ ‌female‌ ‌CEOs‌ ‌in‌ ‌2018‌ ‌(down‌ ‌from‌ ‌\nan‌ ‌all-time‌ ‌high‌ ‌of‌ ‌32‌ ‌in‌ ‌2017);‌ ‌the‌ ‌Center‌ ‌for‌ ‌American‌ ‌Women‌ ‌and‌ ‌Politics‌ ‌(CAWP)‌ ‌reports‌ ‌that‌ ‌women‌ ‌hold‌ ‌only‌ ‌23.7‌ ‌%‌ ‌of‌ ‌seats‌ ‌\nin‌ ‌the‌ ‌House‌ ‌of‌ ‌Representatives‌ ‌and‌ ‌25%‌ ‌of‌ ‌Senate‌ ‌seats;‌ ‌and‌ ‌Cohen‌ ‌notes‌ ‌that‌ ‌among‌ ‌American‌ ‌families,‌ ‌only‌ ‌6%‌ ‌of‌ ‌U.S.-born‌ ‌\nmarried‌ ‌women‌ ‌had‌ ‌surnames‌ ‌that‌ ‌differed‌ ‌from‌ ‌their‌ ‌husbands'‌ ‌in‌ ‌2004.‌ ‌\n ‌\nDifference‌ ‌between‌ ‌public‌ ‌and‌ ‌private‌ ‌patriarchy:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Private‌ ‌Patriarchy:‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌patriarchy‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌household.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌sees‌ ‌one‌ ‌individual‌ ‌patriarch‌ ‌(the‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌male)‌ ‌dominate‌ ‌and‌ ‌oppress‌ ‌the‌ ‌subjugated‌ ‌female.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌acts‌ ‌as‌ ‌an‌ ‌exclusionary‌ ‌tactic‌ ‌as‌ ‌women‌ ‌are‌ ‌prevented‌ ‌from‌ ‌taking‌ ‌part‌ ‌in‌ ‌public‌ ‌discourse.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Public‌ ‌Patriarchy:‌ ‌ ‌\n○As‌ ‌inferred‌ ‌from‌ ‌its‌ ‌name,‌ ‌this‌ ‌patriarchy‌ ‌operates‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌public‌ ‌world.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Most‌ ‌often‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌working‌ ‌world,‌ ‌public‌ ‌patriarchy‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌existence‌ ‌of‌ ‌oppressive‌ ‌factors‌ ‌that‌ ‌still‌ ‌function.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌public‌ ‌life,‌ ‌women‌ ‌are‌ ‌more‌ ‌collectively‌ ‌separated‌ ‌from‌ ‌power,‌ ‌wealth,‌ ‌and‌ ‌influence‌ ‌than‌ ‌men‌ ‌are‌ ‌\n ‌\n●In‌ ‌the‌ ‌west,‌ ‌there‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌a‌ ‌shift‌ ‌in‌ ‌patriarchies.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌believed‌ ‌that‌ ‌where‌ ‌private‌ ‌patriarchy‌ ‌was‌ ‌once‌ ‌far‌ ‌more‌ ‌common‌ ‌than‌ ‌its‌ ‌public‌ ‌\ncounterpart,‌ ‌domination‌ ‌of‌ ‌women‌ ‌through‌ ‌a‌ ‌male-orientated‌ ‌world‌ ‌is‌ ‌now‌ ‌more‌ ‌prevalent‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌public‌ ‌realm.‌ ‌\n436‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Family‌ ‌types‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌size‌ ‌and‌ ‌structure:‌ ‌\nThe‌ ‌chart‌ ‌presented‌ ‌below‌ ‌shows‌ ‌the‌ ‌different‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌families‌ ‌as‌ ‌constructed‌ ‌by‌ ‌‌George‌ ‌Peter‌ ‌Murdock.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n1.Nuclear‌ ‌Family‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○Also‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Monogamous‌ ‌family.‌ ‌ ‌\n437‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌is‌ ‌formed‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌result‌ ‌of‌ ‌monogamous‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌between‌ ‌one‌ ‌man‌ ‌and‌ ‌one‌ ‌woman.‌ ‌Thus,‌ ‌it‌ ‌consists‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌married‌ ‌couple‌ ‌\n(man‌ ‌and‌ ‌woman)‌ ‌with‌ ‌their‌ ‌children‌ ‌own‌ ‌or‌ ‌adopted.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌certain‌ ‌cases‌ ‌one‌ ‌or‌ ‌more‌ ‌additional‌ ‌persons‌ ‌may‌ ‌also‌ ‌reside‌ ‌with‌ ‌them.‌ ‌This‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌prevalent‌ ‌in‌ ‌almost‌ ‌all‌ ‌\nsocieties.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Nuclear‌ ‌family‌ ‌also‌ ‌known‌ ‌as:‌ ‌\n■ ‌Elementary‌ ‌family‌ ‌\n■ ‌Basic‌ ‌family‌ ‌\n■ ‌Conjugal‌ ‌family‌ ‌\n■ ‌Primary‌ ‌family‌ ‌\n○Compact‌ ‌in‌ ‌nature‌ ‌this‌ ‌type‌ ‌is‌ ‌very‌ ‌popular‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌present‌ ‌day‌ ‌world‌ ‌where‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌continuous‌ ‌struggle‌ ‌for‌ ‌economic‌ ‌\nsubsistence.‌ ‌\n2.Composite‌ ‌family:‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌composed‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌or‌ ‌more‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌families,‌ ‌It‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌through‌ ‌marriages‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌through‌ ‌parent‌ ‌child‌ ‌relationships.‌ ‌It‌ ‌\ncan‌ ‌be‌ ‌divided‌ ‌into‌ ‌polygamous‌ ‌family‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌extended‌ ‌family.‌ ‌\ni.‌ ‌Polygamous‌ ‌family‌ ‌\n○Consist‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌or‌ ‌more‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌families‌ ‌formed‌ ‌through‌ ‌plural‌ ‌marriages.‌ ‌It‌ ‌includes‌ ‌two‌ ‌varients‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌\nPolygamous‌ ‌and‌ ‌Polyandrous.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Polygamous‌-‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌kind‌ ‌of‌ ‌polygamous‌ ‌family‌ ‌fromed‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌man‌ ‌with‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌one‌ ‌Woman.‌ ‌\n■Polyandrous‌-‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌kind‌ ‌of‌ ‌polygamous‌ ‌family‌ ‌fromed‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌woman‌ ‌with‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌one‌ ‌man.‌ ‌She‌ ‌\nlived‌ ‌together‌ ‌with‌ ‌all‌ ‌her‌ ‌husband‌ ‌and‌ ‌children.‌ ‌E.g.‌ ‌Todas‌ ‌of‌ ‌Nilgiri‌ ‌\n438‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nii.‌ ‌Extended‌ ‌family‌ ‌\n439‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌consists‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌or‌ ‌more‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌families‌ ‌affiliated‌ ‌through‌ ‌extension‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌parent‌ ‌child‌ ‌relationship.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Based‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌post-marital‌ ‌residence,‌ ‌an‌ ‌extended‌ ‌family‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌following‌ ‌types:‌ ‌\n○Patrilocal‌ ‌family‌ ‌\n○Matrilocal‌ ‌family‌ ‌\n○Avunculocal‌ ‌extended‌ ‌family‌ ‌\n○Bilocal‌ ‌extended‌ ‌family‌ ‌\n○Fraternal‌ ‌Joint‌ ‌Family‌ ‌\n ‌\nAll‌ ‌these‌ ‌discussed‌ ‌above‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌Addition‌ ‌\nCharacteristic‌ ‌of‌ ‌Tribal‌ ‌Family:‌ ‌\n(i)‌ ‌A‌ ‌family‌ ‌has‌ ‌a‌ ‌limited‌ ‌size.‌ ‌\n(ii)‌ ‌The‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌of‌ ‌permanent‌ ‌nature.‌ ‌\n(iii)‌ ‌Husband‌ ‌and‌ ‌wife‌ ‌are‌ ‌permanent‌ ‌sexual‌ ‌partners.‌ ‌\n440‌ ‌\n(iv)‌ ‌At‌ ‌least‌ ‌one‌ ‌member‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌has‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌bread‌ ‌earner‌ ‌for‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌members.‌ ‌\n(v)‌ ‌Members‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌common‌ ‌habitation.‌ ‌\n(vi)‌ ‌Members‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌common‌ ‌nomenclature.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nFamily‌ ‌–‌ ‌a‌ ‌Universal‌ ‌social‌ ‌institution‌ ‌in‌ ‌India:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●The‌ ‌family,‌ ‌in‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌society,‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌institution‌ ‌by‌ ‌itself‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌typical‌ ‌symbol‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌collectivist‌ ‌culture‌ ‌of‌ ‌India‌ ‌right‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nancient‌ ‌times.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌joint‌ ‌family‌ ‌system‌ ‌or‌ ‌an‌ ‌extended‌ ‌family‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌an‌ ‌important‌ ‌feature‌ ‌of‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌culture,‌ ‌till‌ ‌a‌ ‌blend‌ ‌of‌ ‌urbanization‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌western‌ ‌influence,‌ ‌began‌ ‌to‌ ‌affect‌ ‌in‌ ‌home‌ ‌and‌ ‌hearth.‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌is‌ ‌especially‌ ‌true‌ ‌of‌ ‌urban‌ ‌areas,‌ ‌where‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌families‌ ‌have‌ ‌become‌ ‌the‌ ‌order‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌day.‌ ‌\n●There‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌denying‌ ‌the‌ ‌fact‌ ‌that‌ ‌socio-economic‌ ‌factors‌ ‌have‌ ‌played‌ ‌their‌ ‌role‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌joint‌ ‌family‌ ‌system‌ ‌getting‌ ‌diluted.‌ ‌\n●Families‌ ‌play‌ ‌an‌ ‌important‌ ‌role‌ ‌in‌ ‌preserving‌ ‌and‌ ‌promoting‌ ‌the‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌values‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n●Children‌ ‌who‌ ‌grow‌ ‌up‌ ‌in‌ ‌an‌ ‌extended‌ ‌family‌ ‌not‌ ‌only‌ ‌imbibe‌ ‌qualities‌ ‌of‌ ‌tolerance,‌ ‌patience,‌ ‌democratic‌ ‌attitude‌ ‌of‌ ‌\naccepting‌ ‌others’‌ ‌viewpoints,‌ ‌but‌ ‌also‌ ‌develop‌ ‌sportsman’s‌ ‌spirit‌ ‌while‌ ‌playing‌ ‌with‌ ‌siblings‌ ‌and‌ ‌cousins.‌ ‌\n●Various‌ ‌age-old‌ ‌traditions,‌ ‌customs‌ ‌and‌ ‌ways‌ ‌of‌ ‌living‌ ‌are‌ ‌all‌ ‌products‌ ‌of‌ ‌family‌ ‌system.‌ ‌In‌ ‌fact,‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌system‌ ‌lays‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nseeds‌ ‌for‌ ‌social‌ ‌cohesion‌ ‌and‌ ‌democratic‌ ‌thinking.‌ ‌\n●Family‌ ‌system‌ ‌creates‌ ‌a‌ ‌strong‌ ‌bond‌ ‌of‌ ‌unity‌ ‌at‌ ‌an‌ ‌early‌ ‌age,‌ ‌paves‌ ‌the‌ ‌way‌ ‌for‌ ‌social‌ ‌cohesion‌ ‌and‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌broader‌ ‌sense‌ ‌\npromotes‌ ‌national‌ ‌unity.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌qualities‌ ‌of‌ ‌sharing‌ ‌and‌ ‌caring‌ ‌by‌ ‌senior‌ ‌family‌ ‌members‌ ‌automatically‌ ‌lead‌ ‌them‌ ‌to‌ ‌think‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌secure‌ ‌future‌ ‌for‌ ‌their‌ ‌\nchildren‌ ‌by‌ ‌making‌ ‌savings.‌ ‌This‌ ‌in‌ ‌turn‌ ‌helps‌ ‌in‌ ‌strengthening‌ ‌the‌ ‌national‌ ‌economy.‌ ‌\n●Living‌ ‌with‌ ‌close‌ ‌family‌ ‌members‌ ‌rather‌ ‌than‌ ‌spending‌ ‌time‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌crèche‌ ‌or‌ ‌play‌ ‌school‌ ‌will‌ ‌immensely‌ ‌contribute‌ ‌towards‌ ‌\nmaking‌ ‌childhood‌ ‌memorable‌ ‌and‌ ‌happier,‌ ‌a‌ ‌crucial‌ ‌factor‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌overall‌ ‌personality‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual.‌ ‌\n●Family‌ ‌can‌ ‌shape‌ ‌the‌ ‌world‌ ‌view,‌ ‌foster‌ ‌and‌ ‌reinforce‌ ‌the‌ ‌value‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌and‌ ‌therefore,‌ ‌consequently,‌ ‌be‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌warp‌ ‌and‌ ‌weft‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌sustainable,‌ ‌peaceful,‌ ‌inclusive,‌ ‌prosperous‌ ‌world.‌ ‌\n ‌\nChanges‌ ‌in‌ ‌universal‌ ‌quality‌ ‌of‌ ‌family‌ ‌system‌ ‌in‌ ‌India:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Decline‌ ‌of‌ ‌Extended‌ ‌Family‌ ‌System:‌ ‌\n○There‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌worldwide‌ ‌movement‌ ‌towards‌ ‌small,‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌family‌ ‌maintaining‌ ‌a‌ ‌separate‌ ‌and‌ ‌independent‌ ‌household‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌breaking‌ ‌down‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌traditional‌ ‌extended‌ ‌(joint)‌ ‌family‌ ‌system‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌kin‌ ‌groups.‌ ‌\n○Their‌ ‌influence‌ ‌is‌ ‌declining‌ ‌in‌ ‌every‌ ‌field‌ ‌of‌ ‌life.‌ ‌A‌ ‌modified‌ ‌extended‌ ‌family‌ ‌structure‌ ‌is‌ ‌emerging‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌individual‌ ‌\nnuclear‌ ‌families‌ ‌retain‌ ‌considerable‌ ‌autonomy‌ ‌and‌ ‌yet‌ ‌maintain‌ ‌connections‌ ‌with‌ ‌other‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌families‌ ‌or‌ ‌so-called‌ ‌\n‘joint‌ ‌family’.‌ ‌\n●Changing‌ ‌Authority‌ ‌Pattern:‌ ‌\n○There‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌change‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌division‌ ‌of‌ ‌labour‌ ‌and‌ ‌authority‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌family.‌ ‌Male‌ ‌authority‌ ‌is‌ ‌declining‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌modern‌ ‌\nfamily.‌ ‌The‌ ‌authority‌ ‌is‌ ‌slipping‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌hands‌ ‌of‌ ‌family‌ ‌elders‌ ‌because‌ ‌of‌ ‌new‌ ‌economic‌ ‌and‌ ‌political‌ ‌opportunities.‌ ‌\n○Young‌ ‌couples‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌rely‌ ‌on‌ ‌family‌ ‌elders‌ ‌for‌ ‌job‌ ‌instructions‌ ‌or‌ ‌education‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌children.‌ ‌Because‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\n441‌ ‌\ndual-career‌ ‌marriages,‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌significant‌ ‌change‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌attitude‌ ‌towards‌ ‌equality‌ ‌between‌ ‌married‌ ‌partners.‌ ‌\n●Changing‌ ‌Status‌ ‌of‌ ‌Women:‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌rights‌ ‌of‌ ‌women‌ ‌are‌ ‌becoming‌ ‌more‌ ‌recognized‌ ‌in‌ ‌respect‌ ‌to‌ ‌both‌ ‌initi­ation‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌and‌ ‌decision-making‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌family.‌ ‌\n●Changing‌ ‌Economic‌ ‌Functions:‌ ‌\n○Modern‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌longer‌ ‌united‌ ‌by‌ ‌shared‌ ‌work‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌farm.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌now‌ ‌a‌ ‌unit‌ ‌of‌ ‌consumption‌ ‌instead‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌unit‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nproduction‌ ‌as‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌agrarian‌ ‌society.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌now‌ ‌united‌ ‌by‌ ‌feelings‌ ‌of‌ ‌companionship,‌ ‌affection‌ ‌and‌ ‌recre­ation‌ ‌\nonly.‌ ‌\n●Decline‌ ‌in‌ ‌Family‌ ‌Size:‌ ‌\n○Economic‌ ‌considerations‌ ‌force‌ ‌the‌ ‌young‌ ‌to‌ ‌have‌ ‌smaller‌ ‌family‌ ‌with‌ ‌one‌ ‌or‌ ‌two‌ ‌children.‌ ‌\n●Changing‌ ‌Attitudes‌ ‌towards‌ ‌Marriage:‌ ‌\n○There‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌increase‌ ‌in‌ ‌male-female‌ ‌couples‌ ‌who‌ ‌choose‌ ‌to‌ ‌live‌ ‌together‌ ‌without‌ ‌marriage.‌ ‌This‌ ‌has‌ ‌given‌ ‌rise‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌concepts‌ ‌of‌ ‌‘living‌ ‌together,’‌ ‌‘living‌ ‌arrangements’‌ ‌or‌ ‌‘live-in‌ ‌relationships.‌ ‌\n○Also‌ ‌new‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌families‌ ‌crop‌ ‌with‌ ‌where‌ ‌same‌ ‌gender‌ ‌couples‌ ‌also‌ ‌cohabitate.‌ ‌\n○As‌ ‌a‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌revolution,‌ ‌the‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌family‌ ‌emphasizes‌ ‌the‌ ‌importance‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌freedom‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual‌ ‌to‌ ‌choose‌ ‌\nhis/her‌ ‌own‌ ‌life‌ ‌and‌ ‌control‌ ‌his/her‌ ‌own‌ ‌destiny.‌ ‌\n○There’s‌ ‌no‌ ‌‘ideal‌ ‌family’‌ ‌defined‌ ‌by‌ ‌children‌ ‌or‌ ‌lineage.‌ ‌It‌ ‌comes‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌shapes‌ ‌and‌ ‌sizes.‌ ‌And‌ ‌it‌ ‌has‌ ‌grown‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nembrace‌ ‌individual‌ ‌choices,‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌realities:‌ ‌single‌ ‌children,‌ ‌divorce,‌ ‌double‌ ‌incomes,‌ ‌sexual‌ ‌freedom.‌ ‌\n○Accelerated‌ ‌rate‌ ‌of‌ ‌rural-urban‌ ‌migration,‌ ‌diversification‌ ‌of‌ ‌gainful‌ ‌economic‌ ‌activities‌ ‌and‌ ‌individual-friendly‌ ‌\nproperty‌ ‌laws,‌ ‌have‌ ‌had‌ ‌consequential‌ ‌impact‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌drastic‌ ‌reduction‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌size‌ ‌of‌ ‌family‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌country.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nImpact‌ ‌of‌ ‌urbanization,‌ ‌industrialization‌ ‌and‌ ‌feminist‌ ‌movements‌ ‌on‌ ‌family.‌ ‌\n ‌\nImpact‌ ‌of‌ ‌Urbanization‌ ‌on‌ ‌Family‌ ‌\n ‌\nIntroduction:‌ ‌\n●Urbanization‌ ‌has‌ ‌affected‌ ‌family‌ ‌structure;‌ ‌intra‌ ‌and‌ ‌inter‌ ‌family‌ ‌relations‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌functions‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌urban‌ ‌joint‌ ‌families‌ ‌are‌ ‌being‌ ‌gradually‌ ‌replaced‌ ‌by‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌families.‌ ‌Sizes‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌families‌ ‌are‌ ‌shrinking‌ ‌and‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌are‌ ‌\ngetting‌ ‌confined‌ ‌to‌ ‌two‌ ‌or‌ ‌three‌ ‌generations‌ ‌only‌.‌ ‌\n●Despite‌ ‌changes‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌structure,‌ ‌the‌ ‌spirit‌ ‌of‌ ‌individualism‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌growing.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Further,‌ ‌‌the‌ ‌husband‌ ‌dominated‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌being‌ ‌replaced‌ ‌by‌ ‌an‌ ‌equalitarian‌ ‌family‌ ‌where‌ ‌the‌ ‌wife‌ ‌is‌ ‌given‌ ‌a‌ ‌share‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌decision‌ ‌making‌ ‌\nprocess‌.‌ ‌\n●Parents‌ ‌no‌ ‌longer‌ ‌impose‌ ‌their‌ ‌authority‌ ‌over‌ ‌children‌ ‌and‌ ‌children‌ ‌no‌ ‌longer‌ ‌blindly‌ ‌obey‌ ‌the‌ ‌commands‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌parents.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Even‌ ‌in‌ ‌joint‌ ‌families,‌ ‌the‌ ‌eldest‌ ‌male‌ ‌consults‌ ‌with‌ ‌children‌ ‌and‌ ‌this‌ ‌consultation‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌formal.‌ ‌\n ‌\nContinuity‌ ‌and‌ ‌Change:‌ ‌The‌ ‌Institution‌ ‌of‌ ‌Family‌ ‌\n442‌ ‌\n●Family‌ ‌in‌ ‌India‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌generally‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌kinds,‌ ‌joint‌ ‌or‌ ‌extended‌ ‌family‌ ‌comprising‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌two‌ ‌generations‌ ‌of‌ ‌members‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nmarried‌ ‌couple,‌ ‌their‌ ‌children,‌ ‌married‌ ‌or‌ ‌unmarried‌ ‌and‌ ‌one‌ ‌or‌ ‌both‌ ‌parents.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌other‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌family‌ ‌consisting‌ ‌of‌ ‌husband,‌ ‌wife‌ ‌and‌ ‌unmarried‌ ‌children.‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌was‌ ‌initially‌ ‌assumed‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌process‌ ‌of‌ ‌urbanization‌ ‌led‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌decline‌ ‌in‌ ‌family‌ ‌size,‌ ‌weakening‌ ‌of‌ ‌family‌ ‌ties‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌break‌ ‌\nup‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌joint‌ ‌family‌ ‌system‌ ‌into‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌families.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌assumption‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌result‌ ‌of‌ ‌application‌ ‌of‌ ‌Western‌ ‌notions‌ ‌of‌ ‌evolution.‌ ‌F.‌ ‌Tonnies,‌ ‌E.‌ ‌Durkheim,‌ ‌Louis‌ ‌Wirth‌ ‌etc‌.,‌ ‌\nadvanced‌ ‌theories‌ ‌which‌ ‌explained‌ ‌these‌ ‌developments‌ ‌in‌ ‌society‌ ‌as‌ ‌it‌ ‌moved‌ ‌from‌ ‌simple‌ ‌to‌ ‌complex.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Industrialization‌ ‌and‌ ‌urbanization‌ ‌brought‌ ‌about‌ ‌these‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌changes‌ ‌in‌ ‌society‌ ‌and‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌families‌ ‌came‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌associated‌ ‌\nwith‌ ‌the‌ ‌modern‌ ‌industrial‌ ‌urban‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌ ‌\n■In‌ ‌India,‌ ‌too,‌ ‌this‌ ‌assumption‌ ‌presupposes‌ ‌that‌ ‌joint‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌institution‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌rural‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌and‌ ‌as‌ ‌society‌ ‌gets‌ ‌\nurbanized‌ ‌the‌ ‌joint‌ ‌families,associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌rural‌ ‌agrarian‌ ‌economy‌ ‌will‌ ‌give‌ ‌way‌ ‌to‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌family‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌increase‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nnon-agrarian‌ ‌occupations.‌ ‌\n●But‌ ‌as‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌gathered‌ ‌by‌ ‌sociologists‌ ‌studying‌ ‌family‌ ‌in‌ ‌urban‌ ‌India‌ ‌reveals,‌ ‌this‌ ‌hypothesis‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌hold‌ ‌much‌ ‌credence‌ ‌\nsince‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌matter‌ ‌of‌ ‌fact‌ ‌joint‌ ‌families‌ ‌are‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌urban‌ ‌areas‌ ‌as‌ ‌well.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌correlation‌ ‌of‌ ‌“joint”‌ ‌family‌ ‌with‌ ‌rural‌ ‌areas‌ ‌and‌ ‌“nuclear‌ ‌family‌ ‌with‌ ‌urban‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌tenable.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌fact,‌ ‌sociologists‌ ‌like‌ ‌‌A.M,‌ ‌Shah,‌ ‌Kapadia,‌ ‌Gore,‌ ‌and‌ ‌others‌ ‌observe‌ ‌a‌ ‌cyclical‌ ‌change‌ ‌from‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌to‌ ‌joint‌ ‌to‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌family‌ ‌\nwithin‌ ‌a‌ ‌period‌ ‌of‌ ‌time.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌household‌ ‌dimension‌ ‌of‌ ‌family‌ ‌in‌ ‌India‌ ‌which‌ ‌indicates‌ ‌that‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌‌no‌ ‌correlation‌ ‌between‌ ‌urbanization‌ ‌and‌ ‌\n‘separate’‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌households.‌ ‌\n●A.‌ ‌M.‌ ‌Shah‌‌ ‌dispels‌ ‌the‌ ‌myth‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌breakdown‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌joint‌ ‌family‌ ‌in‌ ‌urban‌ ‌India.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌studied‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌history‌ ‌of‌ ‌Gujarat‌ ‌and‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌findings,‌ ‌he‌ ‌claims‌ ‌that‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌past‌ ‌the‌ ‌sanskritized‌ ‌castes‌ ‌(i.e.‌ ‌those‌ ‌\ncastes‌ ‌which‌ ‌have‌ ‌adopted‌ ‌the‌ ‌values,‌ ‌customs‌ ‌and‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌upper‌ ‌castes)‌ ‌formed‌ ‌a‌ ‌much‌ ‌higher‌ ‌proportion‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\npopulation‌ ‌in‌ ‌towns‌ ‌(or‌ ‌cities)‌ ‌than‌ ‌in‌ ‌villages.‌ ‌ ‌\n■This‌ ‌implies‌ ‌the‌ ‌principle‌ ‌of‌ ‌residential‌ ‌unity.‌ ‌\n■This‌ ‌shows‌ ‌that‌ ‌towns‌ ‌included‌ ‌a‌ ‌considerable‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌households‌ ‌composed‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌or‌ ‌more‌ ‌married‌ ‌brothers‌ ‌living‌ ‌\ntogether‌ ‌after‌ ‌their‌ ‌parent’s‌ ‌death.‌ ‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌may‌ ‌also‌ ‌have‌ ‌included‌ ‌a‌ ‌few‌ ‌large‌ ‌households‌ ‌where‌ ‌married‌ ‌cousins‌ ‌lived‌ ‌together‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌household‌ ‌even‌ ‌after‌ ‌the‌ ‌\ndeath‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌father‌ ‌and‌ ‌grandfather;‌ ‌the‌ ‌households‌ ‌composed‌ ‌of‌ ‌parents‌ ‌and‌ ‌two‌ ‌or‌ ‌more‌ ‌married‌ ‌sons‌ ‌formed‌ ‌a‌ ‌greater‌ ‌\nproportion‌ ‌of‌ ‌households‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌town.‌ ‌\n●Shah‌ ‌believes‌ ‌that‌ ‌these‌ ‌findings‌ ‌are‌ ‌very‌ ‌important‌ ‌because‌ ‌they‌ ‌debunk‌ ‌the‌ ‌two‌ ‌notions‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌widely‌ ‌prevalent‌ ‌amongst‌ ‌urban‌ ‌\nsociologists‌ ‌in‌ ‌India.‌ ‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌notions‌ ‌are:‌ ‌ ‌\n(1)‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌people‌ ‌who‌ ‌migrate‌ ‌from‌ ‌villages‌ ‌are‌ ‌governed‌ ‌by‌ ‌strong‌ ‌emphasis‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌principle‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌residential‌ ‌unity‌ ‌of‌ ‌patrikins‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌their‌ ‌wives;‌ ‌and‌ ‌ ‌\n(2)‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌urban‌ ‌area‌ ‌into‌ ‌which‌ ‌they‌ ‌come‌ ‌to‌ ‌live‌ ‌is‌ ‌necessarily‌ ‌an‌ ‌area‌ ‌having‌ ‌a‌ ‌weak‌ ‌emphasis‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌principle‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌residential‌ ‌\nunity‌ ‌of‌ ‌patrikin‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌wives.’‌ ‌\n443‌ ‌\n●I.‌ ‌P.‌ ‌Desia‌ ‌in‌ ‌his‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌Mahuva‌ ‌considers‌ ‌‘jointness’‌ ‌of‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌family‌ ‌when‌ ‌seen‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌light‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌actions‌ ‌of‌ ‌members‌ ‌guided‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌\ntraditional‌ ‌norms,‌ ‌and‌ ‌then‌ ‌examines‌ ‌the‌ ‌effects‌ ‌of‌ ‌urbanization‌ ‌on‌ ‌‘jointness’.‌ ‌ ‌\n○He‌ ‌operationalizes‌ ‌urbanization‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌‘duration‌ ‌of‌ ‌stay‌ ‌in‌ ‌Mahuva’.‌ ‌ ‌\n○During‌ ‌his‌ ‌study‌ ‌he‌ ‌found‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌older‌ ‌families‌ ‌tend‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌more‌ ‌joint‌ ‌than‌ ‌the‌ ‌younger‌ ‌ones‌ ‌and‌ ‌where‌ ‌the‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌families‌ ‌\npreponderate‌ ‌over‌ ‌the‌ ‌older‌ ‌families,‌ ‌nuclearity‌ ‌may‌ ‌also‌ ‌preponderate‌ ‌over‌ ‌the‌ ‌joint‌ ‌families.‌ ‌ ‌\n○He‌ ‌found‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌families‌ ‌under‌ ‌investigation‌ ‌were‌ ‌more‌ ‌joint‌ ‌than‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌ownership‌ ‌of‌ ‌property‌ ‌and‌ ‌mutual‌ ‌obligations.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌case‌ ‌of‌ ‌residentiality‌ ‌too,‌ ‌he‌ ‌found‌ ‌enough‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌that‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌families‌ ‌continue‌ ‌to‌ ‌grow‌ ‌joint‌ ‌and‌ ‌joint‌ ‌becomes‌ ‌nuclear.‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌this‌ ‌sense,‌ ‌his‌ ‌findings‌ ‌conform‌ ‌with‌ ‌‌A.‌ ‌M.‌ ‌Shah’s‌ ‌suggestion‌ ‌that‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌fruitfu‌ ‌approaches‌ ‌in‌ ‌this‌ ‌case‌ ‌would‌ ‌be‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nexamine‌ ‌the‌ ‌developmental‌ ‌process‌ ‌of‌ ‌(family)‌ ‌households,‌ ‌both‌ ‌progressive‌ ‌and‌ ‌regressive‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌assumed‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌operative‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nvillages,‌ ‌towns,‌ ‌and‌ ‌we‌ ‌believe,‌ ‌the‌ ‌cities‌ ‌of‌ ‌India.‌ ‌\n●Ram‌ ‌Krishna‌ ‌Mukherjee‌ ‌‌studied‌ ‌the‌ ‌rural-urban‌ ‌differences‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌familial‌ ‌organization‌ ‌of‌ ‌West‌ ‌Bengal‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n○He‌ ‌too,‌ ‌while‌ ‌examining‌ ‌the‌ ‌co-resident‌ ‌and‌ ‌commensal‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌amongst‌ ‌kin‌ ‌groups‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌locally‌ ‌functioning‌ ‌family‌ ‌units‌ ‌\nfound‌ ‌the‌ ‌presence‌ ‌of‌ ‌extended‌ ‌or‌ ‌non-nuclear‌ ‌family‌ ‌types‌ ‌amongst‌ ‌the‌ ‌cities,‌ ‌towns‌ ‌and‌ ‌villages‌ ‌equally.‌ ‌ ‌\n○But‌ ‌as‌ ‌he‌ ‌mentions,‌ ‌paradoxically,‌ ‌‌the‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌found‌ ‌most‌ ‌frequently‌ ‌in‌ ‌villages,‌ ‌then‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌towns,‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌least‌ ‌\nfrequently‌ ‌in‌ ‌cities.‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌a‌ ‌different‌ ‌study,‌ ‌Mukherjee‌ ‌reports‌ ‌that‌ ‌unlike‌ ‌the‌ ‌common‌ ‌assumption,‌ ‌‌his‌ ‌data‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌support‌ ‌the‌ ‌belief‌ ‌that‌ ‌joint‌ ‌family‌ ‌\norganization‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌linked‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌urban‌ ‌way‌ ‌of‌ ‌life.‌ ‌ ‌\n■His‌ ‌study‌ ‌indicates‌ ‌clearly‌ ‌that‌ ‌‌joint‌ ‌family‌ ‌organization‌ ‌increases‌ ‌progressively‌ ‌as‌ ‌one‌ ‌shifts‌ ‌from‌ ‌villages‌ ‌to‌ ‌small‌ ‌towns‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nlarge‌ ‌cities‌ ‌or‌ ‌from‌ ‌non-industrial‌ ‌through‌ ‌partly‌ ‌industrial‌ ‌to‌ ‌highly‌ ‌industrial‌ ‌towns.‌ ‌ ‌\n■He‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌that‌ ‌t‌he‌ ‌upper‌ ‌castes,‌ ‌who‌ ‌also‌ ‌generally‌ ‌belong‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌upper‌ ‌economic‌ ‌classes‌ ‌gave‌ ‌more‌ ‌importance‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌\njoint‌ ‌family‌ ‌organization‌ ‌than‌ ‌the‌ ‌lower‌ ‌castes‌ ‌and‌ ‌lower‌ ‌economic‌ ‌classes.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Mukherjee’s‌ ‌findings‌ ‌support‌ ‌Shah’s‌ ‌correlation‌ ‌between‌ ‌household,‌ ‌caste‌ ‌and‌ ‌rural-urban‌ ‌communities.‌ ‌\n●Similarly,‌ ‌M.‌ ‌S.‌ ‌Gore‌ ‌(1968)‌ ‌came‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌similar‌ ‌conclusion‌ ‌while‌ ‌testing‌ ‌a‌ ‌similar‌ ‌kind‌ ‌of‌ ‌hypothesis‌ ‌in‌ ‌three‌ ‌communities‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌supposed‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌be‌ ‌represented‌ ‌by‌ ‌three‌ ‌stages‌ ‌of‌ ‌urbanization,‌ ‌viz.‌ ‌the‌ ‌city‌ ‌of‌ ‌Delhi,‌ ‌villages‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌fringe‌ ‌of‌ ‌Delhi,‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌villages‌ ‌away‌ ‌from‌ ‌Delhi.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌spite‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌fact‌ ‌that‌ ‌he‌ ‌confined‌ ‌his‌ ‌empirical‌ ‌study‌ ‌(using‌ ‌questionnaire‌ ‌interview‌ ‌method)‌ ‌to‌ ‌only‌ ‌the‌ ‌merchant‌ ‌caste‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nAggarwals,‌ ‌he‌ ‌took‌ ‌almost‌ ‌equal‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌families‌ ‌from‌ ‌rural‌ ‌and‌ ‌urban‌ ‌communities,‌ ‌almost‌ ‌equally‌ ‌divided‌ ‌between‌ ‌‘nuclear’‌ ‌and‌ ‌\n‘joint’‌ ‌families‌ ‌in‌ ‌each‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌community.‌ ‌ ‌\n○According‌ ‌to‌ ‌Gore,‌ ‌‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌distinction‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌processes‌ ‌of‌ ‌industrialization‌ ‌and‌ ‌urbanization.‌ ‌ ‌\n○He‌ ‌uses‌ ‌the‌ ‌latter‌ ‌i.e.‌ ‌urbanization‌ ‌to‌ ‌refer‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌increasing‌ ‌ratio‌ ‌of‌ ‌urban‌ ‌dwelling‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌non-urban‌ ‌dwelling‌ ‌persons‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌county.‌ ‌ ‌\n○He‌ ‌further‌ ‌states‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌change‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌induced‌ ‌by‌ ‌such‌ ‌factors‌ ‌as‌ ‌higher‌ ‌education,‌ ‌\n○modern‌ ‌professions‌ ‌and‌ ‌bureaucratic‌ ‌populations‌ ‌(considering‌ ‌that‌ ‌these‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌attributes‌ ‌of‌ ‌urban‌ ‌life).‌ ‌ ‌\n○However,‌ ‌h‌e‌ ‌found‌ ‌that‌ ‌neither‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌factors,‌ ‌not‌ ‌even‌ ‌industrial‌ ‌occupations‌ ‌were‌ ‌found‌ ‌to‌ ‌have‌ ‌any‌ ‌significant‌ ‌change‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌joint‌ ‌\nfamily.‌ ‌\n●Kapadia‌ ‌‌in‌ ‌his‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌National‌ ‌Register‌ ‌data‌ ‌on‌ ‌households‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌towns‌ ‌of‌ ‌Navasari‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌fifteen‌ ‌villages‌ ‌around‌ ‌Navasari‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nSouth‌ ‌Gujarat‌ ‌similarly‌ ‌ ‌\n444‌ ‌\n○Found‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌assumption‌ ‌that‌ ‌people‌ ‌in‌ ‌cities‌ ‌and‌ ‌towns‌ ‌live‌ ‌in‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌families‌ ‌while‌ ‌joint‌ ‌families‌ ‌are‌ ‌stronger‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌villages‌ ‌is‌ ‌\nincorrect‌ ‌contrary‌ ‌to‌ ‌this‌ ‌opinion,‌ ‌he‌ ‌found‌ ‌during‌ ‌his‌ ‌studies‌ ‌of‌ ‌531‌ ‌high‌ ‌school‌ ‌teachers‌ ‌(279‌ ‌Gujarati,‌ ‌187‌ ‌Maharashtrian‌ ‌and‌ ‌47‌ ‌\nKannadiga‌ ‌in‌ ‌Bombay‌ ‌city,‌ ‌that‌ ‌so‌ ‌far‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌residential‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌concerned,‌ ‌219‌ ‌(42‌ ‌per‌ ‌cent)‌ ‌out‌ ‌of‌ ‌513‌ ‌teachers‌ ‌lived‌ ‌in‌ ‌elementary‌ ‌\nfamilies‌ ‌i.e.‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌families,‌ ‌while‌ ‌67‌ ‌per‌ ‌cent‌ ‌(294‌ ‌teachers)‌ ‌lived‌ ‌in‌ ‌joint‌ ‌families.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Not‌ ‌only‌ ‌a‌ ‌high‌ ‌degree‌ ‌of‌ ‌jointness‌ ‌was‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌residential‌ ‌group,‌ ‌but‌ ‌outside‌ ‌the‌ ‌residential‌ ‌group.‌ ‌\n●Saroj‌ ‌Kapoor’s‌ ‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌family‌ ‌and‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌Khatris,‌ ‌a‌ ‌wealthy‌ ‌caste‌ ‌of‌ ‌businessmen‌ ‌in‌ ‌Delhi‌ ‌ ‌\n○Also‌ ‌found‌ ‌that‌ ‌at‌ ‌least‌ ‌42.9‌ ‌%‌ ‌of‌ ‌complex‌ ‌households‌ ‌existed‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌neighbourhood‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌metropolitan‌ ‌city‌ ‌of‌ ‌Delhi.‌ ‌\n○We‌ ‌find‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌of‌ ‌several‌ ‌studies‌ ‌of‌ ‌family‌ ‌and‌ ‌household‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌urban‌ ‌context‌ ‌that‌ ‌not‌ ‌only‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌is‌ ‌found‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌an‌ ‌\nimportant‌ ‌principle‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌organization‌ ‌in‌ ‌cities‌ ‌but‌ ‌also‌ ‌that‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌structural‌ ‌congruity‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌joint‌ ‌family‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌one‌ ‌hand‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌the‌ ‌requirements‌ ‌of‌ ‌industrial‌ ‌and‌ ‌urban‌ ‌life‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌other.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Milton‌ ‌Singer’s‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌19‌ ‌families‌ ‌of‌ ‌outstanding‌ ‌business‌ ‌leaders‌ ‌in‌ ‌Chennai‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌that‌ ‌these‌ ‌leaders‌ ‌could‌ ‌effectively‌ ‌\n‘compartmentalize’‌ ‌traditional‌ ‌values‌ ‌and‌ ‌life‌ ‌style‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌area‌ ‌of‌ ‌home‌ ‌and‌ ‌modern‌ ‌professional‌ ‌outlook‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌business‌ ‌or‌ ‌company‌ ‌\nat‌ ‌their‌ ‌offices.‌ ‌ ‌\n○There‌ ‌need‌ ‌not‌ ‌be‌ ‌any‌ ‌conflict‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌two.‌ ‌ ‌\n○He‌ ‌argued‌ ‌that‌ ‌a‌ ‌modified‌ ‌version‌ ‌of‌ ‌traditional‌ ‌joint‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌consistent‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌urban‌ ‌industrial‌ ‌setting.‌ ‌\n●Sudha‌ ‌Kaldate‌‌ ‌however,‌ ‌holds‌ ‌a‌ ‌different‌ ‌opinion.‌ ‌ ‌\n○She‌ ‌says‌ ‌that‌ ‌‌all‌ ‌these‌ ‌studies‌ ‌assert‌ ‌that‌ ‌‘although‌ ‌structurally‌ ‌the‌ ‌traditional‌ ‌(joint)‌ ‌family‌ ‌appears‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌breaking‌ ‌down,‌ ‌functionally‌ ‌\nit‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌so.‌ ‌ ‌\n■These‌ ‌try‌ ‌to‌ ‌maintain‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌joint‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌disintegrating‌ ‌in‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌function‌ ‌as‌ ‌independent‌ ‌units‌ ‌(nuclear)‌ ‌but‌ ‌adapting‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌new‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌which‌ ‌have‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌degrees‌ ‌of‌ ‌jointness.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌strong‌ ‌protagonists‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌views‌ ‌are‌ ‌Kapadia‌ ‌(1954)‌ ‌and‌ ‌Desai‌ ‌(1956),‌ ‌these‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌looking‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌varying‌ ‌outside‌ ‌\nfactors.’‌ ‌\n○She‌ ‌says‌ ‌that‌ ‌‘any‌ ‌social‌ ‌institution‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌exposed‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌varying‌ ‌outside‌ ‌factors‌ ‌should‌ ‌result‌ ‌in‌ ‌change.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Urbanization,‌ ‌in‌ ‌addition‌ ‌to‌ ‌reflecting‌ ‌technological‌ ‌change,‌ ‌creates‌ ‌a‌ ‌new‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌economic‌ ‌organization‌ ‌and‌ ‌gives‌ ‌rise‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nnew‌ ‌way‌ ‌of‌ ‌life,‌ ‌Cultural‌ ‌uniformity‌ ‌and‌ ‌traditional‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌of‌ ‌belief‌ ‌and‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌tend‌ ‌to‌ ‌change‌ ‌under‌ ‌the‌ ‌impact‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nabove‌ ‌changes‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌change‌ ‌gets‌ ‌accelerated.’‌ ‌\n○Kaldate‌ ‌‌believes‌ ‌that‌ ‌these‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌changes‌ ‌in‌ ‌social‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌affect‌ ‌the‌ ‌areas‌ ‌where‌ ‌a‌ ‌large‌ ‌proportion‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌indigenous‌ ‌\npopulation‌ ‌is‌ ‌resident‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌village‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌urban‌ ‌framework.‌ ‌ ‌\n○To‌ ‌the‌ ‌extent‌ ‌that‌ ‌these‌ ‌populations‌ ‌remains‌ ‌outside‌ ‌from‌ ‌urban‌ ‌contacts‌ ‌they‌ ‌tend‌ ‌to‌ ‌retain‌ ‌their‌ ‌‘folk‌ ‌society’‌ ‌\ncharacteristics.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌fact‌ ‌is‌ ‌very‌ ‌important‌ ‌since‌ ‌‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌this‌ ‌reason‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌extent‌ ‌of‌ ‌change‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌institution‌ ‌of‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌found‌ ‌to‌ ‌exist‌ ‌more‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌areas‌ ‌\nwithin‌ ‌the‌ ‌orbit‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌city‌ ‌and‌ ‌less‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌interior‌ ‌communities.‌ ‌ ‌\n○We‌ ‌may‌ ‌give‌ ‌the‌ ‌example‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌pockets‌ ‌of‌ ‌rural‌ ‌areas‌ ‌within‌ ‌and‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌fringes‌ ‌of‌ ‌metropolitan‌ ‌city‌ ‌of‌ ‌Delhi.‌ ‌\n○Kaldate‌ ‌supports‌ ‌her‌ ‌hypothesis‌ ‌with‌ ‌empirical‌ ‌data‌ ‌available.‌ ‌Her‌ ‌basic‌ ‌thesis‌ ‌is‌ ‌that‌ ‌“‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌process‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌disorganization,‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nchanges‌ ‌in‌ ‌family‌ ‌organization‌ ‌tend‌ ‌to‌ ‌take‌ ‌the‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌changes‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌large‌ ‌or‌ ‌joint‌ ‌family‌ ‌system‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌small‌ ‌family‌ ‌system.‌ ‌ ‌\n445‌ ‌\n○Larger‌ ‌proportions‌ ‌of‌ ‌joint‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌quasi-joint‌ ‌families‌ ‌are‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌more‌ ‌traditional‌ ‌communities‌ ‌(existing‌ ‌outside‌ ‌the‌ ‌urban‌ ‌\nframework);‌ ‌and‌ ‌smaller‌ ‌proportions‌ ‌of‌ ‌such‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌families‌ ‌are‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌such‌ ‌communities‌ ‌as‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌more‌ ‌exposed‌ ‌to‌ ‌outside‌ ‌\ninfluence.’‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nImpact‌ ‌of‌ ‌industrialization‌ ‌on‌ ‌family.‌ ‌\n ‌\nIntroduction:‌ ‌\n●Industrialization‌ ‌changed‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌by‌ ‌converting‌ ‌it‌ ‌from‌ ‌a‌ ‌unit‌ ‌of‌ ‌production‌ ‌into‌ ‌a‌ ‌unit‌ ‌of‌ ‌consumption,‌ ‌causing‌ ‌a‌ ‌decline‌ ‌in‌ ‌fertility‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌\ntransformation‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌between‌ ‌spouses‌ ‌and‌ ‌between‌ ‌parents‌ ‌and‌ ‌children.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌change‌ ‌occurred‌ ‌unevenly‌ ‌and‌ ‌gradually,‌ ‌and‌ ‌varied‌ ‌by‌ ‌social‌ ‌class‌ ‌and‌ ‌occupation.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nThere‌ ‌were‌ ‌both‌ ‌positive‌ ‌and‌ ‌negative‌ ‌effects‌ ‌to‌ ‌industrialization.‌ ‌\n ‌ ‌\nNegative:‌ ‌ ‌\n●Divorce‌ ‌rates‌ ‌increased,‌‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌‌rates‌ ‌of‌ ‌suicide‌ ‌and‌ ‌depression‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌also‌ ‌led‌ ‌to‌ ‌an‌ ‌increase‌ ‌in‌ ‌child‌ ‌labor,‌ ‌as‌ ‌more‌ ‌and‌ ‌more‌ ‌children‌ ‌of‌ ‌younger‌ ‌and‌ ‌younger‌ ‌ages‌ ‌worked‌ ‌to‌ ‌help‌ ‌support‌ ‌their‌ ‌families‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Many‌ ‌worked‌ ‌in‌ ‌textile‌ ‌industries‌ ‌(often‌ ‌as‌ ‌repair‌ ‌men‌ ‌who‌ ‌were‌ ‌supposed‌ ‌to‌ ‌crawl‌ ‌in‌ ‌amongst‌ ‌the‌ ‌dangerous‌ ‌moving‌ ‌parts‌ ‌without‌ ‌\nstopping‌ ‌the‌ ‌machine)‌ ‌or‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌power‌ ‌source‌ ‌for‌ ‌hauling‌ ‌the‌ ‌mine‌ ‌cars‌ ‌used‌ ‌in‌ ‌underground‌ ‌coal‌ ‌mine‌ ‌shafts.‌ ‌This‌ ‌led‌ ‌to‌ ‌many‌ ‌\nchildren‌ ‌with‌ ‌health‌ ‌issues,‌ ‌malnutrition,‌ ‌stunted‌ ‌growth,‌ ‌physical‌ ‌deformities,‌ ‌missing‌ ‌and‌ ‌mangled‌ ‌appendages,‌ ‌and‌ ‌death.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌rate‌ ‌of‌ ‌alcohol‌ ‌consumption‌ ‌greatly‌ ‌increased,‌ ‌as‌ ‌men‌ ‌began‌ ‌to‌ ‌spend‌ ‌more‌ ‌and‌ ‌more‌ ‌time‌ ‌after‌ ‌work‌ ‌in‌ ‌pubs‌ ‌and‌ ‌bars‌ ‌instead‌ ‌of‌ ‌at‌ ‌\nhom‌e‌ ‌(directly‌ ‌tied‌ ‌to‌ ‌rates‌ ‌of‌ ‌depression‌ ‌and‌ ‌divorce).‌ ‌\n●Families‌ ‌spent‌ ‌less‌ ‌time‌ ‌together,‌‌ ‌as‌ ‌they‌ ‌were‌ ‌either‌ ‌working‌ ‌or‌ ‌to‌ ‌exhausted‌ ‌from‌ ‌12-14‌ ‌hour‌ ‌days.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Rapid‌ ‌urbanization‌ ‌led‌ ‌to‌ ‌poorly‌ ‌planned‌ ‌cities‌ ‌which‌ ‌were‌ ‌overcrowded,‌ ‌dirty,‌ ‌and‌ ‌poorly‌ ‌sanitized.‌ ‌Also,‌‌ ‌pose‌ ‌risk‌ ‌to‌ ‌family‌ ‌security.‌ ‌\n●Industrialization‌ ‌also‌ ‌led‌ ‌to‌ ‌an‌ ‌decrease‌ ‌in‌ ‌homemade‌ ‌goods‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌main‌ ‌source‌ ‌of‌ ‌finished‌ ‌goods.‌ ‌\n●Personalization,‌ ‌creativity,‌ ‌and‌ ‌family‌ ‌businesses‌ ‌were‌ ‌replaced‌ ‌by‌ ‌cheaper,‌ ‌faster‌ ‌made‌ ‌products.‌ ‌\n ‌ ‌\nPositives:‌ ‌ ‌\n●Urbanization‌ ‌as‌ ‌more‌ ‌and‌ ‌more‌ ‌people‌ ‌moved‌ ‌to‌ ‌cities‌ ‌to‌ ‌find‌ ‌work.‌ ‌‌It‌ ‌led‌ ‌to‌ ‌our‌ ‌modern‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌of‌ ‌consumer‌ ‌society,‌ ‌as‌ ‌people‌ ‌were‌ ‌able‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nbegin‌ ‌to‌ ‌choose‌ ‌different‌ ‌brands‌ ‌to‌ ‌buy,‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌everything‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌price,‌ ‌to‌ ‌quality,‌ ‌to‌ ‌designs,‌ ‌patterns,‌ ‌and‌ ‌colors.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌led‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌more‌ ‌connected‌ ‌world,‌ ‌as‌ ‌new‌ ‌technology‌ ‌like‌ ‌trains,‌ ‌steam‌ ‌engines,‌ ‌and‌ ‌railroads‌ ‌that‌ ‌were‌ ‌designed‌ ‌to‌ ‌more‌ ‌quickly‌ ‌transport‌ ‌\ngoods,‌‌ ‌were‌ ‌also‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌better‌ ‌connect‌ ‌people.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌would‌ ‌eventually‌ ‌‌lead‌ ‌to‌ ‌more‌ ‌rights‌ ‌for‌ ‌workers‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌modern‌ ‌working‌ ‌conditions‌ ‌we‌ ‌have,‌ ‌although‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌start‌ ‌this‌ ‌\nwould‌ ‌not‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌true.‌ ‌It‌ ‌helped‌ ‌women‌ ‌begin‌ ‌to‌ ‌break‌ ‌the‌ ‌cult‌ ‌of‌ ‌domesticity,‌ ‌as‌ ‌more‌ ‌and‌ ‌more‌ ‌young,‌ ‌unmarried‌ ‌women‌ ‌got‌ ‌jobs.‌ ‌ ‌\n446‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌Addition‌ ‌\n ‌\nWhy‌ ‌do‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌families‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌functional‌ ‌fit‌ ‌with‌ ‌industrial‌ ‌society?‌ ‌\n ‌\nNuclear‌ ‌families‌ ‌allow‌ ‌for:‌ ‌\n●Geographical‌ ‌mobility‌‌ ‌(families‌ ‌can‌ ‌move‌ ‌to‌ ‌where‌ ‌the‌ ‌work‌ ‌is)‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Social‌ ‌mobility‌ ‌or‌ ‌meritocracy.‌ ‌Parsons‌ ‌argues‌ ‌that‌ ‌individual‌ ‌status‌ ‌in‌ ‌pre-industrial‌ ‌society‌ ‌was‌ ‌ascribed‌ ‌(you‌ ‌were‌ ‌born‌ ‌into‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌\nstatus)‌ ‌whereas‌ ‌in‌ ‌industrial‌ ‌society‌ ‌people‌ ‌could‌ ‌achieve‌ ‌a‌ ‌new‌ ‌status‌ ‌through‌ ‌hard‌ ‌work.‌ ‌In‌ ‌extended‌ ‌families,‌ ‌social‌ ‌mobility‌ ‌can‌ ‌lead‌ ‌to‌ ‌\ninter-generational‌ ‌conflict,‌ ‌but‌ ‌this‌ ‌is‌ ‌less‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌concern‌ ‌when‌ ‌families‌ ‌are‌ ‌“privatised”‌ ‌as‌ ‌small‌ ‌independent‌ ‌units.‌ ‌Both‌ ‌these‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌mobility‌ ‌\nare‌ ‌facilitated‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌isolated‌ ‌nature‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌family.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Specialised‌ ‌roles.‌ ‌In‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌families,‌ ‌in‌ ‌industrial‌ ‌societies,‌ ‌men‌ ‌and‌ ‌women‌ ‌have‌ ‌separate‌ ‌specialised‌ ‌roles‌ ‌(according‌ ‌to‌ ‌Parsons).‌ ‌He‌ ‌\nwrites‌ ‌about‌ ‌men‌ ‌being‌ ‌instrumental‌ ‌leaders‌ ‌and‌ ‌women‌ ‌being‌ ‌expressive‌ ‌leaders‌ ‌and‌ ‌this‌ ‌being‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌effective‌ ‌division‌ ‌of‌ ‌labour‌ ‌for‌ ‌\nindustrial‌ ‌society.‌ ‌We‌ ‌will‌ ‌return‌ ‌to‌ ‌this‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌section‌ ‌on‌ ‌gender‌ ‌roles.‌ ‌\n ‌\nEvaluating‌ ‌Parsons‌ ‌on‌ ‌industrialism‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌\n ‌\n●The‌ ‌principle‌ ‌difficulty‌ ‌with‌ ‌Parsons‌ ‌theory‌ ‌is‌ ‌that‌ ‌historians‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌agree‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌changes‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌described‌ ‌by‌ ‌Parsons‌ ‌actually‌ ‌match‌ ‌\nwhat‌ ‌really‌ ‌happened.‌ ‌\n●Peter‌ ‌Laslett‌ ‌(1972)‌ ‌‌conducted‌ ‌research‌ ‌into‌ ‌pre-industrial‌ ‌families‌ ‌in‌ ‌his‌ ‌famous‌ ‌work‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌history‌ ‌The‌ ‌World‌ ‌We‌ ‌Have‌ ‌Lost.‌ ‌He‌ ‌found‌ ‌\nthat‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌common‌ ‌family‌ ‌form‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌pre-industrial‌ ‌communities‌ ‌he‌ ‌studied‌ ‌was‌ ‌not‌ ‌the‌ ‌extended‌ ‌family‌ ‌but‌ ‌the‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌family.‌ ‌ ‌\n●People‌ ‌may‌ ‌well‌ ‌have‌ ‌lived‌ ‌close‌ ‌to‌ ‌extended‌ ‌family‌ ‌and‌ ‌worked‌ ‌together,‌ ‌but‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌households,‌ ‌most‌ ‌were‌ ‌made‌ ‌up‌ ‌of‌ ‌parents‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌children.‌ ‌\n●Parsons‌ ‌is‌ ‌criticised,‌ ‌then,‌ ‌for‌ ‌being‌ ‌an‌ ‌armchair‌ ‌theorist.‌ ‌His‌ ‌theory‌ ‌seems‌ ‌quite‌ ‌logical,‌ ‌but‌ ‌had‌ ‌he‌ ‌engaged‌ ‌in‌ ‌extensive‌ ‌empirical‌ ‌\nresearch‌ ‌into‌ ‌the‌ ‌question‌ ‌he‌ ‌may‌ ‌well‌ ‌have‌ ‌found‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌that‌ ‌undermined‌ ‌his‌ ‌theory.‌ ‌Indeed,‌ ‌if‌ ‌his‌ ‌data‌ ‌had‌ ‌replicated‌ ‌the‌ ‌findings‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nLaslett‌ ‌and‌ ‌Anderson,‌ ‌he‌ ‌might‌ ‌have‌ ‌had‌ ‌to‌ ‌turn‌ ‌his‌ ‌theory‌ ‌entirely‌ ‌on‌ ‌its‌ ‌head.‌ ‌\n ‌\nKinds‌ ‌of‌ ‌Family‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Kinds‌ ‌are:‌ ‌ ‌\n1.‌ ‌The‌ ‌Agrarian‌ ‌Family‌ ‌ ‌\n2.‌ ‌Modern‌ ‌Family‌ ‌ ‌\n447‌ ‌\n3.‌ ‌Traditional‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌Family‌ ‌\n ‌\n#‌ ‌1.‌ ‌The‌ ‌Agrarian‌ ‌Family:‌ ‌\n●Under‌ ‌the‌ ‌impact‌ ‌of‌ ‌industrialisation,‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌has‌ ‌undergone‌ ‌tremendous‌ ‌changes‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Western‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Similar‌ ‌changes‌ ‌have‌ ‌just‌ ‌started‌ ‌appearing‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌scene‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌consequence‌ ‌of‌ ‌rapid‌ ‌industrial‌ ‌growth‌ ‌and‌ ‌spread‌ ‌of‌ ‌technology.‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌changes‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌understood‌ ‌better‌ ‌with‌ ‌reference‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌features‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌traditional‌ ‌agrarian‌ ‌family.‌ ‌ ‌\n●An‌ ‌agrarian‌ ‌family‌ ‌is,‌ ‌for‌ ‌obvious‌ ‌reasons,‌ ‌closely‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌landed‌ ‌property,‌ ‌a‌ ‌permanent‌ ‌homestead,‌ ‌livestock,‌ ‌poultry‌ ‌and,‌ ‌\nsometimes‌ ‌handicrafts.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nSuch‌ ‌a‌ ‌family‌ ‌generally‌ ‌exhibits‌ ‌the‌ ‌following‌ ‌characteristics.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Firstly,‌ ‌ ‌\n○Family‌ ‌‌life‌ ‌is‌ ‌built‌ ‌around‌ ‌economic‌ ‌activities‌ ‌and‌ ‌functions‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌housekeeping‌.‌ ‌\n○All‌ ‌elders,‌ ‌including‌ ‌women,‌ ‌are‌ ‌engaged‌ ‌either‌ ‌in‌ ‌agricultural‌ ‌production‌ ‌or‌ ‌in‌ ‌handicrafts,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌weaving,‌ ‌sewing,‌ ‌making‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nfurniture,‌ ‌making‌ ‌or‌ ‌repairing‌ ‌the‌ ‌dwelling‌ ‌shed,‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌such‌ ‌a‌ ‌family,‌ ‌the‌ ‌men‌ ‌usually‌ ‌work‌ ‌outside‌ ‌the‌ ‌home,‌ ‌while‌ ‌the‌ ‌women‌ ‌are‌ ‌expected‌ ‌to‌ ‌look‌ ‌after‌ ‌the‌ ‌home.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Her‌ ‌role‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌described‌ ‌as‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌manager‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌household.‌ ‌\n●Secondly‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌importance‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌wife‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌economic‌ ‌life‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌determines‌ ‌the‌ ‌criteria‌ ‌of‌ ‌choosing‌ ‌one’s‌ ‌mate.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Thus,‌ ‌a‌ ‌man‌ ‌considers‌ ‌the‌ ‌work‌ ‌habits‌ ‌and‌ ‌skills‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌prospective‌ ‌mate‌ ‌while‌ ‌contracting‌ ‌a‌ ‌marriage.‌ ‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌woman,‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌hand,‌ ‌looks‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌good‌ ‌‘provider’.‌ ‌\n○ ‌In‌ ‌either‌ ‌case,‌ ‌affection‌ ‌or‌ ‌love‌ ‌has‌ ‌a‌ ‌subordinate‌ ‌role‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌choice‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌mate.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Thirdly‌ ‌\n○An‌ ‌agrarian‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌generally‌ ‌large-sized.‌ ‌\n○Farming‌ ‌is,‌ ‌by‌ ‌nature,‌ ‌labour-intensive.‌ ‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌large‌ ‌labour‌ ‌force‌ ‌is‌ ‌needed‌ ‌for‌ ‌efficient‌ ‌management‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌farm.‌ ‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌large‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌children‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌natural‌ ‌way‌ ‌to‌ ‌achieve‌ ‌this‌ ‌result,‌ ‌for‌ ‌every‌ ‌new‌ ‌born‌ ‌child‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌addition‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌labour‌ ‌force‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌family.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Fourthly‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌very‌ ‌factor‌ ‌also‌ ‌explains‌ ‌the‌ ‌popularity‌ ‌of‌ ‌joint‌ ‌or‌ ‌extended‌ ‌families‌ ‌in‌ ‌agrarian‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌labour‌ ‌force‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌“may‌ ‌also‌ ‌be‌ ‌augmented‌ ‌by‌ ‌keeping‌ ‌the‌ ‌married‌ ‌sons‌ ‌at‌ ‌home‌ ‌and‌ ‌binging‌ ‌in‌ ‌daughters-in-law.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌family‌ ‌may,‌ ‌thus,‌ ‌expand‌ ‌vertically,‌ ‌as‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌case‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌family‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌three‌ ‌or‌ ‌four‌ ‌generations‌ ‌live‌ ‌under‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌\nroof—grand-parents,‌ ‌parents,‌ ‌children,‌ ‌grand-children,‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n●Sometimes‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌may‌ ‌expand‌ ‌laterally,‌ ‌as‌ ‌in‌ ‌China,‌ ‌where‌ ‌relatives‌ ‌are‌ ‌invited‌ ‌to‌ ‌stay‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌family.‌ ‌\n●Fifthly‌ ‌\n○Since‌ ‌an‌ ‌agrarian‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌“attached‌ ‌to‌ ‌so‌ ‌stable‌ ‌a‌ ‌property‌ ‌as‌ ‌land”,‌ ‌the‌ ‌reputation‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌largely‌ ‌determines‌ ‌the‌ ‌status‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌\nindividual.‌ ‌ ‌\n448‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌person,‌ ‌whatever‌ ‌might‌ ‌be‌ ‌his‌ ‌individual‌ ‌worth,‌ ‌may‌ ‌enjoy‌ ‌a‌ ‌superior‌ ‌status‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌community‌ ‌by‌ ‌virtue‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌reputation‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nfamily‌ ‌to‌ ‌which‌ ‌he‌ ‌belongs.‌ ‌\n○Similarly,‌ ‌a‌ ‌person‌ ‌may‌ ‌suffer‌ ‌in‌ ‌prestige‌ ‌for‌ ‌no‌ ‌fault‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌own‌ ‌but‌ ‌for‌ ‌some‌ ‌bad‌ ‌reputation‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family.‌ ‌There‌ ‌is,‌ ‌thus,‌ ‌a‌ ‌complete‌ ‌\nsubordination‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌family.‌ ‌\n○As‌ ‌Ogburn‌ ‌and‌ ‌Nimkoff‌ ‌say:‌ ‌\n■“The‌ ‌status‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌may‌ ‌become‌ ‌so‌ ‌important‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌overshadows‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual‌ ‌who‌ ‌tends‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌identified‌ ‌as‌ ‌one‌ ‌\nfamily’s‌ ‌son‌ ‌or‌ ‌daughter,‌ ‌not‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌personality‌ ‌in‌ ‌his‌ ‌or‌ ‌her‌ ‌own‌ ‌right”.‌ ‌\n●Finally‌ ‌\n○An‌ ‌agrarian‌ ‌family‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌called‌ ‌a‌ ‌miniature‌ ‌community‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌centre‌ ‌of‌ ‌various‌ ‌kinds‌ ‌of‌ ‌activities:‌ ‌educational,‌ ‌religious,‌ ‌\nprotective‌ ‌and‌ ‌even‌ ‌recreational.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Since‌ ‌the‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌agrarian‌ ‌family‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌stay‌ ‌away‌ ‌from‌ ‌their‌ ‌homes‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌long‌ ‌period,‌ ‌a‌ ‌child‌ ‌grows‌ ‌up‌ ‌under‌ ‌their‌ ‌direct‌ ‌\ninfluence.‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌help‌ ‌him‌ ‌discover‌ ‌what‌ ‌is‌ ‌good‌ ‌or‌ ‌bad,‌ ‌just‌ ‌or‌ ‌unjust,‌ ‌moral‌ ‌or‌ ‌immoral;‌ ‌they‌ ‌help‌ ‌him‌ ‌imbide‌ ‌family‌ ‌tradition,‌ ‌as‌ ‌also‌ ‌the‌ ‌\ntradition‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌larger‌ ‌community.‌ ‌\n○Since‌ ‌mobility‌ ‌is‌ ‌very‌ ‌restricted‌ ‌in‌ ‌an‌ ‌agrarian‌ ‌community,‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌control‌ ‌is‌ ‌pretty‌ ‌rigorous‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌result‌ ‌that‌ ‌deviations‌ ‌from‌ ‌\nsocial‌ ‌norms‌ ‌are‌ ‌few‌ ‌and‌ ‌far‌ ‌between.‌ ‌ ‌\n○An‌ ‌agrarian‌ ‌family‌ ‌performs‌ ‌different‌ ‌kinds‌ ‌of‌ ‌protective‌ ‌functions,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌care‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌sick,‌ ‌the‌ ‌aged‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌unemployed.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Recreation‌ ‌facilities‌ ‌are‌ ‌also‌ ‌generally‌ ‌confined‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌circle‌ ‌in‌ ‌an‌ ‌agrarian‌ ‌community.‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌explained‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌fact‌ ‌than‌ ‌an‌ ‌agrarian‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌large-sized‌ ‌and‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌members‌ ‌spend‌ ‌their‌ ‌leisure-hours‌ ‌together‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Another‌ ‌important‌ ‌factor‌ ‌is,‌ ‌of‌ ‌course,‌ ‌the‌ ‌absence‌ ‌of‌ ‌cheap,‌ ‌commercial‌ ‌entertainment‌ ‌in‌ ‌rural‌ ‌areas.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌interesting‌ ‌to‌ ‌note‌ ‌that‌ ‌even‌ ‌when‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌some‌ ‌community‌ ‌ceremony‌ ‌–‌ ‌say,‌ ‌community‌ ‌worship‌ ‌–‌ ‌the‌ ‌participation‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nfunction‌ ‌is‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌family‌ ‌basis,‌ ‌rather‌ ‌than‌ ‌on‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌basis.‌ ‌\n ‌\n#‌ ‌2.‌ ‌Modern‌ ‌Family:‌ ‌\nCharacteristics:‌ ‌\n●Firstly‌ ‌\n○To‌ ‌begin‌ ‌with,‌ ‌the‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌family‌ ‌has‌ ‌largely‌ ‌replaced‌ ‌the‌ ‌consanguineous‌ ‌family,‌ ‌particularly‌ ‌in‌ ‌Western‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌Such‌ ‌changes‌ ‌are‌ ‌\nalso‌ ‌increasingly‌ ‌taking‌ ‌place‌ ‌in‌ ‌urban‌ ‌areas‌ ‌in‌ ‌India.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌decline‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌economic‌ ‌significance‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌producing‌ ‌unit’‌ ‌has‌ ‌impaired‌ ‌the‌ ‌old-time‌ ‌unity‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌group.‌ ‌\n○When‌ ‌a‌ ‌man‌ ‌gets‌ ‌a‌ ‌job‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌factory‌ ‌and‌ ‌earns‌ ‌his‌ ‌pay‌ ‌independently‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌efforts‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌parents‌ ‌and‌ ‌brothers,‌ ‌he‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌so‌ ‌prone‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nturn‌ ‌over‌ ‌his‌ ‌earnings‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌common‌ ‌family‌ ‌fund,‌ ‌as‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌case‌ ‌when‌ ‌he‌ ‌and‌ ‌his‌ ‌brothers‌ ‌worked‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌soil‌ ‌together.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌change‌ ‌in‌ ‌husband-wife‌ ‌relationship.‌ ‌This‌ ‌economic‌ ‌independence‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌woman‌ ‌has‌ ‌affected‌ ‌her‌ ‌whole‌ ‌attitude‌ ‌towards‌ ‌\nmarriage.‌ ‌ ‌\n○She‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌have‌ ‌to‌ ‌look‌ ‌so‌ ‌much‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌“provider”.‌ ‌Her‌ ‌choice‌ ‌of‌ ‌mate‌ ‌is‌ ‌generally‌ ‌determined‌ ‌by‌ ‌considerations‌ ‌of‌ ‌love,‌ ‌affection‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌similarity‌ ‌of‌ ‌interest‌ ‌or‌ ‌temperament.‌ ‌\n449‌ ‌\n○Since‌ ‌the‌ ‌modern‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌longer‌ ‌a‌ ‌producing‌ ‌unit,‌ ‌a‌ ‌man‌ ‌also‌ ‌usually‌ ‌chooses‌ ‌his‌ ‌bride‌ ‌on‌ ‌similar‌ ‌considerations‌ ‌and‌ ‌not‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nbasis‌ ‌of‌ ‌her‌ ‌skill‌ ‌or‌ ‌capacity‌ ‌for‌ ‌work.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Moreover,‌ ‌economic‌ ‌independence‌ ‌of‌ ‌both‌ ‌men‌ ‌and‌ ‌women‌ ‌has‌ ‌freed‌ ‌them‌ ‌from‌ ‌“parental‌ ‌control‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌pressure‌ ‌\nconcerning‌
