‌whom‌ ‌and‌ ‌when‌ ‌they‌ ‌shall‌ ‌marry”.‌ ‌\n●Secondly,‌ ‌ ‌\n○Husband-wife‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌in‌ ‌modern‌ ‌family‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌looked‌ ‌at‌ ‌from‌ ‌a‌ ‌different‌ ‌angle.‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌agrarian‌ ‌family‌ ‌being‌ ‌an‌ ‌economic‌ ‌organisation,‌ ‌there‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌need‌ ‌for‌ ‌some‌ ‌sort‌ ‌of‌ ‌leadership.‌ ‌Generally,‌ ‌the‌ ‌men-folk‌ ‌\nused‌ ‌to‌ ‌fill‌ ‌this‌ ‌role.‌ ‌\n○But‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌modern‌ ‌urban‌ ‌family,‌ ‌the‌ ‌necessity‌ ‌for‌ ‌leadership‌ ‌and‌ ‌control‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌so‌ ‌great.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Hence‌ ‌both‌ ‌husband‌ ‌and‌ ‌wife‌ ‌confront‌ ‌each‌ ‌other‌ ‌on‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌equality.‌ ‌They‌ ‌discuss‌ ‌the‌ ‌problems‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌together‌ ‌and‌ ‌\narrive‌ ‌at‌ ‌decisions‌ ‌which‌ ‌meet‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌approval‌ ‌of‌ ‌both.‌ ‌\n●Thirdly‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌possibilities‌ ‌of‌ ‌conflict‌ ‌between‌ ‌a‌ ‌husband‌ ‌and‌ ‌his‌ ‌wife‌ ‌are,‌ ‌therefore,‌ ‌greater‌ ‌in‌ ‌modern‌ ‌urban‌ ‌families‌ ‌than‌ ‌those‌ ‌in‌ ‌agrarian‌ ‌\nfamilies‌ ‌of‌ ‌old‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌roles‌ ‌of‌ ‌husbands‌ ‌and‌ ‌wives‌ ‌were‌ ‌clearly‌ ‌determined.‌ ‌\n■These‌ ‌role‌ ‌conflicts‌ ‌are‌ ‌further‌ ‌reinforced‌ ‌by‌ ‌various‌ ‌other‌ ‌factors,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌disappearance‌ ‌or‌ ‌decline‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌economic‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nprotective‌ ‌functions‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family.‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌increased‌ ‌rates‌ ‌of‌ ‌divorce‌ ‌among‌ ‌urban‌ ‌families,‌ ‌not‌ ‌only‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌West‌ ‌but‌ ‌also‌ ‌in‌ ‌India,‌ ‌indicate‌ ‌the‌ ‌strains‌ ‌and‌ ‌stresses‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌which‌ ‌these‌ ‌families‌ ‌are‌ ‌subjected.‌ ‌\n●Fourthly‌ ‌\n○Modern‌ ‌families‌ ‌tend‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌smaller‌ ‌in‌ ‌size‌ ‌than‌ ‌agrarian‌ ‌families.‌ ‌Two‌ ‌reasons‌ ‌are‌ ‌primarily‌ ‌responsible‌ ‌for‌ ‌this‌ ‌trend.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌advances‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌techniques‌ ‌of‌ ‌birth‌ ‌control,‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌hand,‌ ‌made‌ ‌it‌ ‌possible‌ ‌for‌ ‌deliberate‌ ‌planning‌ ‌of‌ ‌parenthood.‌ ‌\n ‌\nFunctions‌ ‌of‌ ‌Modern‌ ‌Family:‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌modern‌ ‌family‌ ‌has‌ ‌parted‌ ‌with‌ ‌many‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌traditional‌ ‌functions‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌agrarian‌ ‌family.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌production‌ ‌functions‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌transferred‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌to‌ ‌economic‌ ‌organisations‌ ‌away‌ ‌from‌ ‌home.‌ ‌Education‌ ‌has‌ ‌similarly‌ ‌been‌ ‌\nmoved‌ ‌outside‌ ‌the‌ ‌home.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌schools‌ ‌provide‌ ‌various‌ ‌kinds‌ ‌of‌ ‌education‌ ‌which‌ ‌no‌ ‌family‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌past‌ ‌could‌ ‌ever‌ ‌provide‌ ‌for‌ ‌children.‌ ‌ ‌\n●With‌ ‌the‌ ‌increased‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌nursery‌ ‌schools‌ ‌and‌ ‌kindergartens‌ ‌much‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌early‌ ‌training‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌child‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌taken‌ ‌over‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌specialists.‌ ‌\n●Moreover,‌ ‌small‌ ‌houses‌ ‌in‌ ‌cities‌ ‌with‌ ‌little‌ ‌or‌ ‌no‌ ‌playground‌ ‌have‌ ‌also‌ ‌tended‌ ‌to‌ ‌put‌ ‌the‌ ‌children‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌streets‌ ‌or‌ ‌on‌ ‌public‌ ‌parks‌ ‌or‌ ‌\nplaygrounds‌ ‌during‌ ‌their‌ ‌leisure‌ ‌time,‌ ‌thereby‌ ‌further‌ ‌removing‌ ‌them‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌influence‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌parents,‌ ‌brothers‌ ‌or‌ ‌sisters.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌fact‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌father,‌ ‌and‌ ‌in‌ ‌some‌ ‌the‌ ‌influence‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌parents‌ ‌brothers‌ ‌or‌ ‌sisters.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌fact‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌father,‌ ‌and‌ ‌in‌ ‌some‌ ‌cases‌ ‌also‌ ‌the‌ ‌mother,‌ ‌work‌ ‌outside‌ ‌the‌ ‌home‌ ‌has‌ ‌necessarily‌ ‌limited‌ ‌their‌ ‌contributions‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌\neducation‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌children.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌protective‌ ‌functions‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌care‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌sick,‌ ‌the‌ ‌aged‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌unemployed‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌taken‌ ‌over‌ ‌either‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nhospitals,‌ ‌nursing‌ ‌homes‌ ‌and‌ ‌clinics‌ ‌or‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌state‌ ‌which‌ ‌provides‌ ‌for‌ ‌social‌ ‌security‌ ‌for‌ ‌its‌ ‌citizens‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌old‌ ‌age‌ ‌pensions,‌ ‌\nunemployment‌ ‌relief,‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n450‌ ‌\n●Recreational‌ ‌facilities‌ ‌are‌ ‌now‌ ‌largely‌ ‌sought‌ ‌outside‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌circle.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌smallness‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌living‌ ‌quarters,‌ ‌the‌ ‌smaller‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family,‌ ‌the‌ ‌difficulty‌ ‌of‌ ‌getting‌ ‌them‌ ‌together,‌ ‌lack‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nrecreational‌ ‌facilities‌ ‌at‌ ‌home,‌ ‌the‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌relatively‌ ‌cheap‌ ‌commercial‌ ‌entertainment‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌theatres,‌ ‌movies,‌ ‌etc.,‌ ‌\ncomparative‌ ‌ease‌ ‌of‌ ‌modern‌ ‌transportation—all‌ ‌these‌ ‌make‌ ‌the‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌seek‌ ‌recreational‌ ‌opportunities‌ ‌outside‌ ‌the‌ ‌home‌ ‌\ncircle.‌ ‌\n ‌\nHaving‌ ‌been‌ ‌thus‌ ‌stripped‌ ‌of‌ ‌most‌ ‌of‌ ‌its‌ ‌traditional‌ ‌functions,‌ ‌the‌ ‌modern‌ ‌family‌ ‌performs‌ ‌mainly‌ ‌the‌ ‌following‌ ‌three‌ ‌functions‌ ‌which‌ ‌\nMaclver‌ ‌and‌ ‌Page‌ ‌characterize‌ ‌as‌ ‌essential‌ ‌functions‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family:‌ ‌\n ‌\n(i)‌ ‌The‌ ‌procreation‌ ‌and‌ ‌rearing‌ ‌of‌ ‌children.‌ ‌Even‌ ‌here‌ ‌some‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌responsibilities‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌taken‌ ‌over‌ ‌by‌ ‌outside‌ ‌agencies,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌\nmaternity‌ ‌homes,‌ ‌antenatal‌ ‌clinics,‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n(ii)‌ ‌Providing‌ ‌a‌ ‌stable‌ ‌basis‌ ‌for‌ ‌satisfaction‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌sex‌ ‌needs‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌partners.‌ ‌The‌ ‌institution‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌provides‌ ‌the‌ ‌partners‌ ‌with‌ ‌an‌ ‌opportunity‌ ‌not‌ ‌\nmerely‌ ‌to‌ ‌seek‌ ‌release‌ ‌for‌ ‌their‌ ‌physical‌ ‌appetite‌ ‌but‌ ‌also‌ ‌to‌ ‌deepen‌ ‌their‌ ‌mutual‌ ‌love‌ ‌and‌ ‌elevate‌ ‌it‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌level‌ ‌higher‌ ‌than‌ ‌the‌ ‌physical.‌ ‌\n(iii)‌ ‌Providing‌ ‌a‌ ‌home‌ ‌for‌ ‌its‌ ‌members‌ ‌who‌ ‌share,‌ ‌not‌ ‌simply‌ ‌a‌ ‌house,‌ ‌but,‌ ‌in‌ ‌addition,‌ ‌intimacy,‌ ‌affection,‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌warm‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌which‌ ‌no‌ ‌other‌ ‌\nassociation‌ ‌can‌ ‌provide.‌ ‌\n ‌\n#‌ ‌3.‌ ‌Traditional‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌Family:‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌traditional‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌in‌ ‌India‌ ‌is‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌joint‌ ‌family.‌ ‌Just‌ ‌how‌ ‌great‌ ‌an‌ ‌antiquity‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌ascribed‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌joint‌ ‌family‌ ‌system‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nIndia‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌known.‌ ‌In‌ ‌Vedic‌ ‌times,‌ ‌sons‌ ‌did‌ ‌not‌ ‌acquire‌ ‌co-ownership‌ ‌in‌ ‌family‌ ‌property‌ ‌at‌ ‌birth.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Vedas,‌ ‌however,‌ ‌spoke‌ ‌of‌ ‌several‌ ‌families‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌stock‌ ‌residing‌ ‌together‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌house.‌ ‌By‌ ‌the‌ ‌time‌ ‌of‌ ‌Chandragupta,‌ ‌about‌ ‌\n300‌ ‌B.C.,‌ ‌some‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌joint‌ ‌family‌ ‌was‌ ‌common.‌ ‌\n●When‌ ‌the‌ ‌codes‌ ‌of‌ ‌Manu‌ ‌were‌ ‌being‌ ‌written‌ ‌about‌ ‌two‌ ‌or‌ ‌three‌ ‌centuries‌ ‌later,‌ ‌the‌ ‌joint‌ ‌family‌ ‌became‌ ‌quite‌ ‌common.‌ ‌The‌ ‌legal‌ ‌framework‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌the‌ ‌joint‌ ‌family‌ ‌was‌ ‌crystallized‌ ‌about‌ ‌the‌ ‌11th‌ ‌century‌ ‌A.D.‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Mitakshara,‌ ‌a‌ ‌commentary‌ ‌on‌ ‌earlier‌ ‌sacred‌ ‌writings.‌ ‌\n●We‌ ‌presume‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌author‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Mitakshara‌ ‌only‌ ‌formulated‌ ‌practices‌ ‌that‌ ‌must‌ ‌then‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌long‌ ‌and‌ ‌well‌ ‌established,‌ ‌having‌ ‌been‌ ‌in‌ ‌\noperation‌ ‌for‌ ‌centuries.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Since‌ ‌then,‌ ‌for‌ ‌some‌ ‌nine‌ ‌centuries‌ ‌the‌ ‌rights‌ ‌and‌ ‌duties‌ ‌of‌ ‌family‌ ‌members‌ ‌towards‌ ‌each‌ ‌other,‌ ‌the‌ ‌general‌ ‌structure‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Hindu‌ ‌family,‌ ‌\netc.‌ ‌have‌ ‌followed‌ ‌without‌ ‌great‌ ‌deviation‌ ‌the‌ ‌prescriptions‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Mitakshara.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌traditional‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌joint‌ ‌family‌ ‌consists‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌married‌ ‌couples‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌children‌ ‌who‌ ‌live‌ ‌together‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌household.‌ ‌All‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nmen‌ ‌are‌ ‌related‌ ‌by‌ ‌blood—as‌ ‌a‌ ‌man‌ ‌and‌ ‌his‌ ‌sons‌ ‌and‌ ‌his‌ ‌grandsons,‌ ‌or‌ ‌a‌ ‌set‌ ‌of‌ ‌brothers‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌sons‌ ‌and‌ ‌grandsons;‌ ‌the‌ ‌women‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nhousehold‌ ‌as‌ ‌their‌ ‌wives,‌ ‌unmarried‌ ‌daughters‌ ‌and‌ ‌perhaps‌ ‌the‌ ‌widow‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌deceased‌ ‌kinsman.‌ ‌\n●After‌ ‌marriage,‌ ‌a‌ ‌girl‌ ‌leaves‌ ‌her‌ ‌ancestral‌ ‌family‌ ‌and‌ ‌becomes‌ ‌a‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌joint‌ ‌family‌ ‌of‌ ‌her‌ ‌husband.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Even‌ ‌now‌ ‌in‌ ‌rural‌ ‌areas‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌households‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌three‌ ‌or‌ ‌four‌ ‌generations‌ ‌are‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌found‌ ‌living‌ ‌under‌ ‌one‌ ‌roof,‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nmembers‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌group‌ ‌may‌ ‌approach‌ ‌one‌ ‌hundred.‌ ‌The‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌such‌ ‌a‌ ‌family‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌as‌ ‌are‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌all‌ ‌agrarian‌ ‌\nfamilies.‌ ‌\n●There‌ ‌is,‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌place,‌ ‌a‌ ‌common‌ ‌kitchen‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌food‌ ‌is‌ ‌prepared‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌whole‌ ‌household.‌ ‌\n●Secondly,‌ ‌ ‌\n451‌ ‌\n○all‌ ‌property‌ ‌is‌ ‌held‌ ‌in‌ ‌common.‌  ‌There‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌common‌ ‌purse‌ ‌into‌ ‌which‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌contribute‌ ‌their‌ ‌gains‌ ‌and‌ ‌earnings‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌from‌ ‌which‌ ‌the‌ ‌expenses‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌members,‌ ‌earners‌ ‌and‌ ‌non-earners‌ ‌alike,‌ ‌are‌ ‌paid.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌eldest‌ ‌male‌ ‌member‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌household‌ ‌generally‌ ‌handles‌ ‌this‌ ‌common‌ ‌family‌ ‌fund.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Thirdly,‌ ‌ ‌\n○the‌ ‌joint‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌only‌ ‌a‌ ‌single‌ ‌consumer‌ ‌unit,‌ ‌but‌ ‌typically‌ ‌a‌ ‌single‌ ‌producer‌ ‌unit‌ ‌as‌ ‌well.‌ ‌\n○Among‌ ‌the‌ ‌agricultural‌ ‌population,‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌cultivate‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌fields‌ ‌and‌ ‌work‌ ‌the‌ ‌harvest‌ ‌together.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Among‌ ‌the‌ ‌artisan‌ ‌castes‌ ‌too,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌producing‌ ‌unit,‌ ‌since‌ ‌the‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌co-operate‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌output‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nhandicraft‌ ‌goods.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Fourthly,‌ ‌l‌ ‌\n○ike‌ ‌agrarian‌ ‌families‌ ‌in‌ ‌other‌ ‌parts‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌world,‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌joint‌ ‌families‌ ‌also‌ ‌perform‌ ‌educational‌ ‌and‌ ‌protective‌ ‌functions.‌ ‌\n●Fifthly,‌ ‌ ‌\n○the‌ ‌traditional‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌family‌ ‌is,‌ ‌barring‌ ‌a‌ ‌few‌ ‌exceptions,‌ ‌patrilineal‌ ‌and‌ ‌patrilocal‌ ‌in‌ ‌form.‌ ‌\n●Sixthly,‌ ‌ ‌\n○the‌ ‌family‌ ‌group‌ ‌is‌ ‌bound‌ ‌together‌ ‌by‌ ‌sraddha,‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌rite‌ ‌of‌ ‌commemorating‌ ‌the‌ ‌ancestors‌ ‌at‌ ‌which‌ ‌balls‌ ‌of‌ ‌rice‌ ‌called‌ ‌pinda‌ ‌are‌ ‌\noffered‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌dead.‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌believed‌ ‌that‌ ‌three‌ ‌generations‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌dead‌ ‌are‌ ‌beneficiaries‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌benefits‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌ceremony.‌ ‌Sons,‌ ‌grandsons‌ ‌and‌ ‌great‌ ‌\ngrandsons‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌deceased‌ ‌join‌ ‌together‌ ‌in‌ ‌sraddha.‌ ‌“Thus‌ ‌the‌ ‌dead‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌living‌ ‌are‌ ‌linked‌ ‌together‌ ‌by‌ ‌this‌ ‌rite,‌ ‌which,‌ ‌like‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nancestor‌ ‌worship‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Chinese,‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌most‌ ‌potent‌ ‌force‌ ‌in‌ ‌consolidating‌ ‌the‌ ‌family”.‌ ‌The‌ ‌family‌ ‌group‌ ‌is‌ ‌defined‌ ‌by‌ ‌sraddha.‌ ‌\n○Those‌ ‌who‌ ‌are‌ ‌entitled‌ ‌to‌ ‌participate‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌ceremony‌ ‌are‌ ‌called‌ ‌sapinda‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌group.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Finally,‌ ‌ ‌\n○the‌ ‌traditional‌ ‌Hindu‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌practice‌ ‌exhibits‌ ‌elements‌ ‌of‌ ‌both‌ ‌endogamy‌ ‌and‌ ‌exogamy.‌ ‌Both‌ ‌the‌ ‌partners‌ ‌must‌ ‌belong‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌\ncaste.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌caste‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌prospective‌ ‌mate‌ ‌is,‌ ‌therefore,‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌considered‌ ‌first.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌second‌ ‌thing‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌considered‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌gotra‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌prospective‌ ‌mate.‌ ‌Gotra‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌defined‌ ‌as‌ ‌“a‌ ‌patrilineal‌ ‌clan‌ ‌which‌ ‌reckons‌ ‌descent‌ ‌\nfrom‌ ‌some‌ ‌common‌ ‌and‌ ‌usually‌ ‌mythical‌ ‌ancestor”.‌ ‌\n●Basham‌ ‌explains‌ ‌the‌ ‌origin‌ ‌of‌ ‌gotra‌ ‌thus:‌ ‌\n○“The‌ ‌original‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌of‌ ‌gotra‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌‘cowshed’,‌ ‌or‌ ‌‘a‌ ‌herd‌ ‌of‌ ‌cows’;‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Atharva‌ ‌Veda,‌ ‌the‌ ‌word‌ ‌first‌ ‌appears‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌of‌ ‌\n‘clan’,‌ ‌which‌ ‌it‌ ‌has‌ ‌retained‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌special‌ ‌connotation.‌ ‌Some‌ ‌ancient‌ ‌Indo-European‌ ‌peoples,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌Romans,‌ ‌had‌ ‌exogamous‌ ‌\nclans,‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌generally‌ ‌endogamous‌ ‌tribes.‌ ‌It‌ ‌may‌ ‌well‌ ‌be‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌gotra-system‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌survival‌ ‌of‌ ‌Indo-European‌ ‌origin‌ ‌which‌ ‌had‌ ‌\ndeveloped‌ ‌specially‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌features”.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌partner‌ ‌must‌ ‌not‌ ‌come‌ ‌from‌ ‌a‌ ‌family‌ ‌having‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌gotra.‌ ‌Here‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌element‌ ‌of‌ ‌exogamy‌ ‌exhibited‌ ‌by‌ ‌Hindu‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌\npractice.‌ ‌There‌ ‌is‌ ‌another‌ ‌element‌ ‌of‌ ‌exogamy.‌ ‌\n●Among‌ ‌many‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌upper‌ ‌castes‌ ‌of‌ ‌Northern‌ ‌India,‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌is‌ ‌prohibited‌ ‌among‌ ‌partners‌ ‌who‌ ‌are‌ ‌connected‌ ‌with‌ ‌one‌ ‌another‌ ‌within‌ ‌\ncertain‌ ‌degrees‌ ‌of‌ ‌relationship,‌ ‌called‌ ‌sapinda.‌ ‌It‌ ‌means‌ ‌that‌ ‌a‌ ‌man’s‌ ‌wife‌ ‌may‌ ‌not‌ ‌be‌ ‌a‌ ‌sixth‌ ‌cousin‌ ‌as‌ ‌reckoned‌ ‌Arough‌ ‌the‌ ‌male‌ ‌line‌ ‌or‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nfourth‌ ‌cousin‌ ‌as‌ ‌reckoned‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌female‌ ‌line.‌ ‌\n452‌ ‌\n●Another‌ ‌interesting‌ ‌feature‌ ‌is‌ ‌that‌ ‌before‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌is‌ ‌settled,‌ ‌the‌ ‌horoscopes‌ ‌of‌ ‌both‌ ‌the‌ ‌bride‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌groom‌ ‌are‌ ‌compared.‌ ‌If‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nastrologers‌ ‌agree‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌comparison‌ ‌is‌ ‌favourable,‌ ‌only‌ ‌then‌ ‌the‌ ‌wedding‌ ‌can‌ ‌take‌ ‌place.‌ ‌If‌ ‌hot,‌ ‌the‌ ‌negotiations‌ ‌are‌ ‌cancelled.‌ ‌\n●Another‌ ‌unique‌ ‌feature‌ ‌of‌ ‌traditional‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌that‌ ‌divorce‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌sanctioned‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌sacred‌ ‌writings‌.‌ ‌Marriage‌ ‌is‌ ‌for‌ ‌eternity,‌ ‌irrespective‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌whether‌ ‌the‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌proves‌ ‌happy‌ ‌or‌ ‌unhappy,‌ ‌fecund‌ ‌or‌ ‌barren.‌ ‌This‌ ‌has,‌ ‌of‌ ‌course,‌ ‌been‌ ‌superseded‌ ‌by‌ ‌Hindu‌ ‌Marriage‌ ‌Act‌ ‌which‌ ‌\npermits‌ ‌divorce.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌traditional‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌joint‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌relations‌ ‌among‌ ‌adults‌ ‌rather‌ ‌than‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌conjugal‌ ‌bonds‌ ‌between‌ ‌spouses.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌chances‌ ‌of‌ ‌break-up‌ ‌of‌ ‌such‌ ‌a‌ ‌family‌ ‌into‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌households‌ ‌because‌ ‌of‌ ‌intense‌ ‌conjugal‌ ‌bond‌ ‌are‌ ‌lessened‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌few‌ ‌other‌ ‌\narrangements.‌ ‌ ‌\n●One‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌arranged‌ ‌marriages‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌the‌ ‌guardians‌ ‌on‌ ‌both‌ ‌sides‌ ‌play‌ ‌important‌ ‌roles.‌ ‌\n●Segregation‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌sexes‌ ‌for‌ ‌most‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌day‌ ‌after‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌further‌ ‌lowers‌ ‌the‌ ‌possibility.‌ ‌There‌ ‌are‌ ‌certain‌ ‌norms‌ ‌which‌ ‌still‌ ‌further‌ ‌\nlessen‌ ‌the‌ ‌chances‌ ‌of‌ ‌break-up‌ ‌of‌ ‌joint‌ ‌families‌ ‌into‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌households.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Husband‌ ‌and‌ ‌wife‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌expected‌ ‌to‌ ‌show‌ ‌much‌ ‌affection‌ ‌toward‌ ‌each‌ ‌other‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌presence‌ ‌of‌ ‌others.‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌father‌ ‌is‌ ‌‌not‌ ‌expected‌ ‌to‌ ‌express‌ ‌tenderness‌ ‌and‌ ‌affection‌ ‌towards‌ ‌his‌ ‌children‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌care‌ ‌of‌ ‌them‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌exclusion‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌other‌ ‌children‌ ‌\nin‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌.‌ ‌These‌ ‌and‌ ‌many‌ ‌other‌ ‌rules‌ ‌“block‌ ‌the‌ ‌normal‌ ‌tendency‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌family‌ ‌to‌ ‌break‌ ‌away‌ ‌and‌ ‌to‌ ‌form‌ ‌a‌ ‌separate‌ ‌\nhousehold”.‌ ‌\n●There‌ ‌are,‌ ‌however,‌ ‌strong‌ ‌pressures‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌opposite‌ ‌direction‌ ‌also.‌ ‌Wives‌ ‌come‌ ‌from‌ ‌outside‌ ‌and‌ ‌they‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌be‌ ‌expected‌ ‌to‌ ‌share‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nweakness‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌husbands‌ ‌toward‌ ‌other‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌joint‌ ‌household.‌ ‌If‌ ‌the‌ ‌husband‌ ‌earns‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌his‌ ‌other‌ ‌brothers‌ ‌and‌ ‌nephews,‌ ‌\nhis‌ ‌contribution‌ ‌towards‌ ‌the‌ ‌common‌ ‌pool‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌would‌ ‌naturally‌ ‌be‌ ‌high.‌ ‌This‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌resented‌ ‌by‌ ‌his‌ ‌wife.‌ ‌\n●Such‌ ‌tensions‌ ‌and‌ ‌simmering‌ ‌discontent‌ ‌would‌ ‌grow‌ ‌when‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌lazy‌ ‌members‌ ‌whose‌ ‌families‌ ‌have‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌fed,‌ ‌protected‌ ‌and‌ ‌taken‌ ‌care‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌by‌ ‌more‌ ‌diligent‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family.‌ ‌In‌ ‌an‌ ‌agrarian‌ ‌society,‌ ‌such‌ ‌problems‌ ‌did‌ ‌not‌ ‌exist‌ ‌because‌ ‌the‌ ‌expenses‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌joint‌ ‌household‌ ‌\nwere‌ ‌met‌ ‌out‌ ‌of‌ ‌income‌ ‌drawn‌ ‌from‌ ‌common‌ ‌ancestral‌ ‌property.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌an‌ ‌industrialised‌ ‌society,‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌brothers,‌ ‌for‌ ‌instance,‌ ‌may‌ ‌not‌ ‌be‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌level‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌income.‌ ‌Such‌ ‌disparities‌ ‌in‌ ‌income‌ ‌have‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌potential‌ ‌of‌ ‌breaking‌ ‌up‌ ‌the‌ ‌joint‌ ‌family‌ ‌household‌ ‌into‌ ‌a‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌households.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌nature‌ ‌of‌ ‌centripetal‌ ‌and‌ ‌centrifugal‌ ‌forces‌ ‌which‌ ‌operate‌ ‌in‌ ‌respect‌ ‌of‌ ‌joint‌ ‌family‌ ‌households.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌difficult‌ ‌to‌ ‌make‌ ‌a‌ ‌generalized‌ ‌\nstatement‌ ‌this‌ ‌way‌ ‌or‌ ‌that‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌vast‌ ‌country‌ ‌like‌ ‌India.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌picture‌ ‌that‌ ‌comes‌ ‌out‌ ‌from‌ ‌a‌ ‌survey‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌region‌ ‌may‌ ‌not‌ ‌agree‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌picture‌ ‌which‌ ‌emerges‌ ‌from‌ ‌another‌ ‌survey‌ ‌in‌ ‌another‌ ‌\nregion.‌ ‌\n●Contradictory‌ ‌statements‌ ‌about‌ ‌the‌ ‌state‌ ‌of‌ ‌joint‌ ‌family‌ ‌households‌ ‌in‌ ‌India‌ ‌are,‌ ‌therefore,‌ ‌made‌ ‌by‌ ‌sociologists.‌ ‌\n●Goode,‌ ‌for‌ ‌instance,‌ ‌observes:‌ ‌\n○“It‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌surprising,‌ ‌then,‌ ‌that‌ ‌surveys‌ ‌over‌ ‌the‌ ‌past‌ ‌decade‌ ‌show‌ ‌that‌ ‌a‌ ‌majority‌ ‌of‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌families‌ ‌live‌ ‌in‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌household”‌ ‌\n●William‌ ‌Kapp,‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌hand,‌ ‌makes‌ ‌an‌ ‌exactly‌ ‌opposite‌ ‌observation:‌ ‌\n○“It‌ ‌is‌ ‌often‌ ‌believed‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌joint‌ ‌families‌ ‌in‌ ‌relation‌ ‌to‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌families‌ ‌is‌ ‌declining‌ ‌especially‌ ‌under‌ ‌the‌ ‌impact‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nurbanisation.‌ ‌However,‌ ‌such‌ ‌limited‌ ‌data‌ ‌as‌ ‌are‌ ‌available‌ ‌on‌ ‌this‌ ‌subject‌ ‌seem‌ ‌to‌ ‌refute‌ ‌this‌ ‌belief.‌ ‌Thus,‌ ‌it‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌found‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌\njoint‌ ‌family‌ ‌structure‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌disintegrating‌ ‌and‌ ‌that‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌almost‌ ‌as‌ ‌many‌ ‌joint‌ ‌families‌ ‌in‌ ‌urban‌ ‌areas‌ ‌as‌ ‌in‌ ‌rural‌ ‌areas”.‌ ‌\n453‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌fact‌ ‌is,‌ ‌however,‌ ‌undeniable‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌centrifugal‌ ‌forces‌ ‌are‌ ‌more‌ ‌powerful‌ ‌and‌ ‌are‌ ‌increasingly‌ ‌being‌ ‌strengthened‌ ‌by‌ ‌urbanisation,‌ ‌\nindustrialisation‌ ‌and‌ ‌many‌ ‌other‌ ‌modernizing‌ ‌influences.‌ ‌During‌ ‌the‌ ‌transitional‌ ‌period,‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌family‌ ‌system‌ ‌is‌ ‌exhibiting‌ ‌diverse‌ ‌forms‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nfeatures‌ ‌and‌ ‌will‌ ‌defy‌ ‌all‌ ‌attempts‌ ‌at‌ ‌neat‌ ‌categorization.‌ ‌\n●One‌ ‌such‌ ‌form‌ ‌which‌ ‌stands‌ ‌out‌ ‌very‌ ‌prominently‌ ‌in‌ ‌so‌ ‌far‌ ‌as‌ ‌rural‌ ‌families‌ ‌are‌ ‌concerned‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌stem‌ ‌family‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌the‌ ‌main‌ ‌trunk‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌located‌ ‌in‌ ‌its‌ ‌own‌ ‌ancestral‌ ‌house‌ ‌while‌ ‌most‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌members,‌ ‌particularly‌ ‌those‌ ‌belonging‌ ‌to‌ ‌comparatively‌ ‌younger‌ ‌age-‌ ‌\ngroup,‌ ‌live‌ ‌most‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌time‌ ‌in‌ ‌urban‌ ‌centres‌ ‌and‌ ‌work‌ ‌there.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is,‌ ‌however,‌ ‌interesting‌ ‌to‌ ‌‘note‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌bonds‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌joint‌ ‌family‌ ‌are‌ ‌rarely‌ ‌severed‌ ‌completely.‌ ‌The‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌joint‌ ‌family‌ ‌who‌ ‌work‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌live‌ ‌in‌ ‌cities‌ ‌generally‌ ‌remit‌ ‌something‌ ‌to‌ ‌their‌ ‌village‌ ‌homes‌ ‌towards‌ ‌the‌ ‌expenses‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌joint‌ ‌family‌ ‌because‌ ‌some‌ ‌members,‌ ‌usually‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌elderly‌ ‌ones‌ ‌and‌ ‌women,‌ ‌remain‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌ancestral‌ ‌village‌ ‌and‌ ‌maintain‌ ‌the‌ ‌old‌ ‌family‌ ‌patterns.‌ ‌\n●Those‌ ‌who‌ ‌stay‌ ‌in‌ ‌urban‌ ‌centres‌ ‌sometimes‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌feeling‌ ‌that‌ ‌their‌ ‌real‌ ‌home‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌in‌ ‌urban‌ ‌centres‌ ‌or‌ ‌towns‌ ‌but‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌joint‌ ‌household‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌the‌ ‌village.‌ ‌They‌ ‌generally‌ ‌visit‌ ‌their‌ ‌village‌ ‌homes‌ ‌in‌ ‌connection‌ ‌with‌ ‌some‌ ‌religious‌ ‌festivals‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌functions.‌ ‌The‌ ‌most‌ ‌important‌ ‌\nsuch‌ ‌occasion‌ ‌is,‌ ‌of‌ ‌course,‌ ‌a‌ ‌wedding‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌usually‌ ‌a‌ ‌common‌ ‌family‌ ‌enterprise.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌who‌ ‌may‌ ‌have‌ ‌stayed‌ ‌away‌ ‌from‌ ‌ancestral‌ ‌village‌ ‌home‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌long‌ ‌period‌ ‌come‌ ‌back‌ ‌to‌ ‌participate‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌\npreparation‌ ‌and‌ ‌celebration‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌wedding‌ ‌ceremony.‌ ‌Such‌ ‌deep‌ ‌attachment‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌ancestral‌ ‌village‌ ‌household‌ ‌explains‌ ‌the‌ ‌migratory‌ ‌\ncharacter‌ ‌of‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌labour.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nFamilies‌ ‌and‌ ‌Economy‌ ‌\n●Residence‌ ‌rules‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌size‌ ‌of‌ ‌family‌ ‌residential‌ ‌groups‌ ‌often‌ ‌change‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌economy‌ ‌changes.‌ ‌In‌ ‌other‌ ‌words,‌ ‌family‌ ‌household‌ ‌type‌ ‌\ncorrelates‌ ‌with‌ ‌subsistence‌ ‌base.‌ ‌The‌ ‌following‌ ‌graph‌ ‌summarizes‌ ‌this‌ ‌relationship.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n454‌ ‌\nAdditional‌ ‌Study‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌‌classic‌ ‌sociological‌ ‌theory‌ ‌about‌ ‌the‌ ‌link‌ ‌between‌ ‌families‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌economy‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌debate‌ ‌about‌ ‌the‌ ‌impact‌ ‌of‌ ‌industrialisation‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nfamily,‌ ‌and‌ ‌particularly‌ ‌Talcott‌ ‌Parsons’‌ ‌theory‌ ‌that‌ ‌industrialisation‌ ‌led‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌family‌.‌ ‌\n●While‌ ‌sociologists‌ ‌today‌ ‌are‌ ‌more‌ ‌interested‌ ‌in‌ ‌more‌ ‌contemporary‌ ‌economic‌ ‌change,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌impact‌ ‌of‌ ‌globalisation,‌ ‌we‌ ‌should‌ ‌look‌ ‌at‌ ‌\nthis‌ ‌classic‌ ‌debate.‌ ‌\n●Talcott‌ ‌Parsons‌ ‌(1951)‌ ‌argued‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌process‌ ‌of‌ ‌industrialisation‌ ‌led‌ ‌to‌ ‌huge‌ ‌changes‌ ‌in‌ ‌both‌ ‌the‌ ‌structure‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌role‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌roles‌ ‌of‌ ‌family‌ ‌members.‌ ‌\n●Industrialisation‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌process‌ ‌whereby‌ ‌the‌ ‌economy‌ ‌shifted‌ ‌from‌ ‌being‌ ‌based‌ ‌largely‌ ‌around‌ ‌agriculture‌ ‌to‌ ‌being‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌industry‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nmanufacturing.‌ ‌In‌ ‌the‌ ‌UK,‌ ‌this‌ ‌processes‌ ‌happened‌ ‌rapidly,‌ ‌particularly‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌18th‌ ‌and‌ ‌19th‌ ‌centuries,‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌industrial‌ ‌revolution.‌ ‌Alongside‌ ‌\nindustrialisation‌ ‌there‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌closely-related‌ ‌process‌ ‌of‌ ‌urbanisation.‌ ‌This‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌process‌ ‌where‌ ‌people‌ ‌move‌ ‌from‌ ‌rural‌ ‌communities‌ ‌into‌ ‌\ntowns‌ ‌and‌ ‌cities,‌ ‌resulting‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌rapid‌ ‌growth‌ ‌of‌ ‌those‌ ‌towns‌ ‌and‌ ‌cities.‌ ‌\n●Such‌ ‌massive‌ ‌social‌ ‌change‌ ‌inevitably‌ ‌impacts‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌family,‌ ‌but‌ ‌Parsons‌ ‌argues‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌transformative:‌ ‌it‌ ‌created‌ ‌the‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌family.‌ ‌\n●Parsons,‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌functionalist,‌ ‌believes‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌in‌ ‌society‌ ‌work‌ ‌together‌ ‌like‌ ‌the‌ ‌organs‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌human‌ ‌body‌ ‌in‌ ‌order‌ ‌for‌ ‌society‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nwork‌ ‌properly.‌ ‌Therefore,‌ ‌when‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌social‌ ‌change,‌ ‌other‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌also‌ ‌have‌ ‌to‌ ‌change‌ ‌to‌ ‌ensure‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌functional‌ ‌fit:‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌\ninstitutions‌ ‌fit‌ ‌society‌ ‌as‌ ‌it‌ ‌is,‌ ‌rather‌ ‌than‌ ‌as‌ ‌it‌ ‌was.‌ ‌For‌ ‌Parsons,‌ ‌the‌ ‌pre-industrial,‌ ‌agrarian‌ ‌society‌ ‌was‌ ‌populated‌ ‌with‌ ‌extended‌ ‌families.‌ ‌\nThere‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌functional‌ ‌fit‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌extended‌ ‌family‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌rural‌ ‌economy.‌ ‌Where‌ ‌people‌ ‌worked‌ ‌the‌ ‌land,‌ ‌the‌ ‌more‌ ‌family‌ ‌members‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nlend‌ ‌a‌ ‌hand‌ ‌the‌ ‌better:‌ ‌aunts,‌ ‌uncles,‌ ‌cousins‌ ‌and‌ ‌numerous‌ ‌children‌ ‌were‌ ‌economic‌ ‌assets.‌ ‌Everyone‌ ‌who‌ ‌was‌ ‌fit‌ ‌and‌ ‌able‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌\nhad‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌economically‌ ‌active,‌ ‌and‌ ‌so‌ ‌the‌ ‌presence‌ ‌of‌ ‌older‌ ‌relatives‌ ‌provided‌ ‌essential‌ ‌services‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌childcare,‌ ‌education‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nhealthcare.‌ ‌Families‌ ‌remained‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌communities‌ ‌and‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌land‌ ‌for‌ ‌generations,‌ ‌and‌ ‌so‌ ‌there‌ ‌was‌ ‌no‌ ‌requirement‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌\ngeographically‌ ‌mobile‌ ‌to‌ ‌seek‌ ‌work,‌ ‌so‌ ‌a‌ ‌large‌ ‌family‌ ‌was‌ ‌not‌ ‌a‌ ‌burden.‌ ‌\n●However,‌ ‌when‌ ‌people‌ ‌started‌ ‌moving‌ ‌from‌ ‌rural‌ ‌areas‌ ‌into‌ ‌towns‌ ‌and‌ ‌cities,‌ ‌in‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌get‌ ‌jobs‌ ‌in‌ ‌factories‌ ‌and‌ ‌mills,‌ ‌this‌ ‌all‌ ‌changed.‌ ‌Work‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌home‌ ‌were‌ ‌now‌ ‌separated.‌ ‌Families‌ ‌needed‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌geographically‌ ‌mobile:‌ ‌they‌ ‌could‌ ‌not‌ ‌take‌ ‌large‌ ‌numbers‌ ‌of‌ ‌dependents‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nextended‌ ‌family‌ ‌with‌ ‌them‌ ‌into‌ ‌the‌ ‌city.‌ ‌There‌ ‌was‌ ‌paid‌ ‌work‌ ‌for‌ ‌men‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌factories‌ ‌and‌ ‌mills,‌ ‌and‌ ‌so‌ ‌a‌ ‌clear‌ ‌gender‌ ‌division‌ ‌of‌ ‌labour‌ ‌\nemerged,‌ ‌with‌ ‌women‌ ‌staying‌ ‌at‌ ‌home‌ ‌to‌ ‌look‌ ‌after‌ ‌the‌ ‌children‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌house.‌ ‌Increasingly‌ ‌the‌ ‌state‌ ‌took‌ ‌over‌ ‌many‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌roles‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nfamily‌ ‌listed‌ ‌by‌ ‌Murdock,‌ ‌leaving‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌two‌ ‌irreducible‌ ‌functions‌ ‌previously‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to.‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌Parsons,‌ ‌this‌ ‌social‌ ‌change‌ ‌precipitated‌ ‌a‌ ‌clear‌ ‌change‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌from‌ ‌extended‌ ‌families‌ ‌with‌ ‌many‌ ‌functions,‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌\npreindustrial‌ ‌society,‌ ‌to‌ ‌privatised‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌families‌ ‌with‌ ‌fewer‌ ‌functions‌ ‌in‌ ‌industrial‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nImpact‌ ‌of‌ ‌feminist‌ ‌movements‌ ‌on‌ ‌family‌ ‌\n●Feminism‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌term‌ ‌that‌ ‌includes‌ ‌movements‌ ‌and‌ ‌ideologies‌ ‌which‌ ‌have‌ ‌an‌ ‌impact‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌emancipation‌ ‌and‌ ‌liberation‌ ‌of‌ ‌women.‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌also‌ ‌includes‌ ‌establishment‌ ‌of‌ ‌equal‌ ‌rights‌ ‌for‌ ‌women‌ ‌and‌ ‌opposes‌ ‌all‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌male‌ ‌domination.‌ ‌\n○Great‌ ‌diversity‌ ‌in‌ ‌feminist‌ ‌movments‌ ‌and‌ ‌positions‌ ‌is‌ ‌recognized.‌ ‌\n○Feminism‌ ‌has‌ ‌never‌ ‌been‌ ‌a‌ ‌united‌ ‌or‌ ‌homogenous‌ ‌movement‌ ‌ever‌ ‌since‌ ‌its‌ ‌origin‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌late‌ ‌18th‌ ‌century.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌feminist‌ ‌movements‌ ‌are‌ ‌working‌ ‌towards‌ ‌twin‌ ‌goals‌ ‌of‌ ‌struggle‌ ‌for‌ ‌‌equal‌ ‌rights‌ ‌for‌ ‌women‌ ‌on‌ ‌par‌ ‌with‌ ‌men‌ ‌under‌ ‌the‌ ‌law‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nsecond‌ ‌for‌ ‌equal‌ ‌opportunities‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌fields‌ ‌of‌ ‌education‌ ‌and‌ ‌occupation‌ ‌\n455‌ ‌\n●Laws‌ ‌worldwide‌ ‌continue‌ ‌to‌ ‌discriminate‌ ‌against‌ ‌women‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌ways‌ ‌and‌ ‌in‌ ‌variety‌ ‌of‌ ‌contexts.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌feminists‌ ‌are‌ ‌also‌ ‌fighting‌ ‌for‌ ‌women's‌ ‌rights‌ ‌to‌ ‌have‌ ‌control‌ ‌over‌ ‌their‌ ‌own‌ ‌body‌ ‌and‌ ‌reproductive‌ ‌functions.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌radical‌ ‌feminists‌ ‌believe‌ ‌that‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌of‌ ‌patriarchal‌ ‌origin‌ ‌need‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌thrown‌ ‌out.‌ ‌\n●Others‌ ‌argue‌ ‌that‌ ‌there‌ ‌should‌ ‌be‌ ‌redistribution‌ ‌of‌ ‌rights‌ ‌and‌ ‌obligations‌ ‌between‌ ‌males‌ ‌and‌ ‌females‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌structure.‌ ‌\n●Feminists‌ ‌are‌ ‌against‌ ‌male‌ ‌dominated‌ ‌male‌ ‌imposed‌ ‌attitudes‌ ‌and‌ ‌roles‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌domains‌ ‌of‌ ‌sexuality,reproduction‌ ‌and‌ ‌child‌ ‌bearing‌‌ ‌.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌true‌ ‌that‌ ‌women‌ ‌have‌ ‌to‌ ‌spend‌ ‌considerable‌ ‌time‌ ‌looking‌ ‌after‌ ‌the‌ ‌home,family‌ ‌and‌ ‌apart‌ ‌from‌ ‌working‌ ‌outside‌ ‌for‌ ‌earning.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌unpaid‌ ‌work‌ ‌at‌ ‌home,necessary‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌wellbeing‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌has‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌shared‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌husband‌ ‌also.‌ ‌\n●Feminists‌ ‌believe‌ ‌that‌ ‌this‌ ‌unpaid‌ ‌work‌ ‌should‌ ‌get‌ ‌due‌ ‌recognition‌ ‌and‌ ‌housewives‌ ‌should‌ ‌be‌ ‌valued‌ ‌and‌ ‌respected‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌menfolk.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌element‌ ‌of‌ ‌choice‌ ‌should‌ ‌be‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌women's‌ ‌will.‌ ‌\n●Feminists‌ ‌raise‌ ‌voice‌ ‌against‌ ‌patriarchy‌ ‌and‌ ‌male‌ ‌domination‌ ‌and‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌against‌ ‌family‌ ‌system.‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌believe‌ ‌that‌ ‌a‌ ‌just,social‌ ‌and‌ ‌economic‌ ‌order‌ ‌should‌ ‌prevail‌ ‌at‌ ‌home‌ ‌and‌ ‌this‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌possible‌ ‌if‌ ‌all‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌inequalities‌ ‌are‌ ‌removed.‌ ‌\n ‌\nImpact:‌ ‌\n●Feminist‌ ‌movement‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌increase‌ ‌in‌ ‌tree‌ ‌of‌ ‌women‌ ‌into‌ ‌the‌ ‌workplace‌ ‌beginning‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌20th‌ ‌century‌ ‌affected‌ ‌gender‌ ‌role‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌division‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌labour‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌family.‌ ‌\n●Better‌ ‌education‌ ‌has‌ ‌resulted‌ ‌in‌ ‌Greater‌ ‌financial‌ ‌Independence‌ ‌and‌ ‌more‌ ‌career‌ ‌choices‌ ‌for‌ ‌women.‌ ‌\n●Women‌ ‌have‌ ‌begun‌ ‌to‌ ‌Sham‌ ‌marriage.‌ ‌Even‌ ‌after‌ ‌Mary‌ ‌many‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌women‌ ‌put‌ ‌their‌ ‌career‌ ‌ahead‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌children‌ ‌or‌ ‌put‌ ‌off‌ ‌having‌ ‌a‌ ‌family‌ ‌\nfor‌ ‌several‌ ‌years‌.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌changing‌ ‌status‌ ‌of‌ ‌women‌ ‌has‌ ‌led‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌more‌ ‌equal‌ ‌division‌ ‌of‌ ‌household‌ ‌responsibility.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌most‌ ‌pressing‌ ‌problem‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌family‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌result‌ ‌of‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌of‌ ‌child‌ ‌care.‌  ‌A‌ ‌majority‌ ‌of‌ ‌working‌ ‌mothers‌ ‌pay‌ ‌for‌ ‌child‌ ‌care‌ ‌even‌ ‌if‌ ‌not‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌\ndaily‌ ‌basis.‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌has‌ ‌resulted‌ ‌in‌ ‌children‌ ‌feeling‌ ‌deprived‌ ‌of‌ ‌mother‌ ‌attention.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Many‌ ‌believe‌ ‌that‌ ‌this‌ ‌will‌ ‌affect‌ ‌children‌ ‌adversely‌ ‌leading‌ ‌to‌ ‌psychological‌ ‌problems‌ ‌and‌ ‌deviant‌ ‌behaviour.‌ ‌but‌ ‌various‌ ‌studies‌ ‌\nhave‌ ‌proved‌ ‌this‌ ‌motion‌ ‌wrong.‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌has‌ ‌affected‌ ‌be‌ ‌sex‌ ‌role‌ ‌attitude‌ ‌of‌ ‌children.‌ ‌In‌ ‌general‌ ‌when‌ ‌Mother‌ ‌works‌ ‌The‌ ‌children‌ ‌are‌ ‌likely‌ ‌to‌ ‌approve‌ ‌of‌ ‌working‌ ‌women‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌more‌ ‌egalitarian‌ ‌vision‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌basic‌ ‌task.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌have‌ ‌improved‌ ‌the‌ ‌standard‌ ‌of‌ ‌family‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌women‌ ‌work.‌ ‌\n●Women‌ ‌becoming‌ ‌more‌ ‌Independent‌ ‌and‌ ‌assertive‌ ‌the‌ ‌type‌ ‌or‌ ‌straight‌ ‌have‌ ‌shown‌ ‌an‌ ‌increasing‌ ‌Trend.‌ ‌\n●All‌ ‌these‌ ‌changes‌ ‌are‌ ‌substantial‌ ‌in‌ ‌some‌ ‌societies‌ ‌but‌ ‌insignificant‌ ‌in‌ ‌many.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nFeminist‌ ‌Perspectives‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌Family‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌liberal,‌ ‌marxist‌ ‌and‌ ‌radical‌ ‌feminist‌ ‌views‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌traditional‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌family‌ ‌\n456‌ ‌\n●\n ‌\n●Almost‌ ‌all‌ ‌feminists‌ ‌agree‌ ‌that‌ ‌gender‌ ‌is‌ ‌socially‌ ‌constructed.‌ ‌This‌ ‌means‌ ‌that‌ ‌gender‌ ‌roles‌ ‌are‌ ‌learnt‌ ‌rather‌ ‌than‌ ‌determined‌ ‌by‌ ‌biology,‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌significant‌ ‌institution‌ ‌where‌ ‌we‌ ‌are‌ ‌socialised‌ ‌into‌ ‌our‌ ‌appropriate‌ ‌roles‌ ‌and‌ ‌norms‌ ‌of‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌family.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌proof‌ ‌for‌ ‌this‌ ‌theory‌ ‌is‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌sometimes‌ ‌radically‌ ‌different‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌we‌ ‌see‌ ‌between‌ ‌women‌ ‌from‌ ‌different‌ ‌societies‌ ‌i.e.‌ ‌\ndifferent‌ ‌societies‌ ‌construct‌ ‌being‌ ‌“women”‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌ways‌ ‌(This‌ ‌is‌ ‌obviously‌ ‌true‌ ‌for‌ ‌men‌ ‌as‌ ‌well).‌ ‌\n ‌\nFeminism‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌Family‌ ‌\n●Feminists‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌central‌ ‌in‌ ‌criticising‌ ‌gender‌ ‌roles‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌traditional‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌family,‌ ‌especially‌ ‌since‌ ‌the‌ ‌1950s.‌ ‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌have‌ ‌argued‌ ‌the‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌family‌ ‌has‌ ‌traditionally‌ ‌performed‌ ‌two‌ ‌key‌ ‌functions‌ ‌which‌ ‌oppressed‌ ‌women:‌ ‌\na)‌ ‌socialising‌ ‌girls‌ ‌to‌ ‌accept‌ ‌subservient‌ ‌roles‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌family,‌ ‌whilst‌ ‌socialising‌ ‌boys‌ ‌to‌ ‌believe‌ ‌they‌ ‌were‌ ‌superior‌ ‌–‌ ‌this‌ ‌happens‌ ‌\nthrough‌ ‌children‌ ‌witnessing‌ ‌then‌ ‌recreating‌ ‌the‌ ‌parental‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌\n ‌\nb)‌ ‌socialising‌ ‌women‌ ‌into‌ ‌accepting‌ ‌the‌ ‌“housewife”‌ ‌role‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌only‌ ‌possible/acceptable‌ ‌role‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌woman.‌ ‌Indeed‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌only‌ ‌way‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nbe‌ ‌feminine/to‌ ‌be‌ ‌a‌ ‌woman.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n457‌ ‌\n●Essentially,‌ ‌feminists‌ ‌viewed‌ ‌the‌ ‌function‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌breeding‌ ‌ground‌ ‌where‌ ‌patriarchal‌ ‌values‌ ‌were‌ ‌learned‌ ‌by‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual,‌ ‌which‌ ‌\nin‌ ‌turn‌ ‌created‌ ‌a‌ ‌patriarchal‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n●Feminism‌ ‌today‌ ‌tends‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌split‌ ‌into‌ ‌three‌ ‌distinct‌ ‌branches:‌ ‌ ‌\n○Liberal‌ ‌Feminists,‌ ‌ ‌\n○Marxist‌ ‌Feminists‌ ‌and‌ ‌ ‌\n○Radical‌ ‌Feminists.‌ ‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌differ‌ ‌significantly‌ ‌over‌ ‌the‌ ‌extent‌ ‌to‌ ‌which‌ ‌they‌ ‌believe‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌still‌ ‌patriarchal‌ ‌and‌ ‌in‌ ‌what‌ ‌the‌ ‌underlying‌ ‌causes‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nexistence‌ ‌of‌ ‌patriarchy‌ ‌might‌ ‌be.‌ ‌(Remember‌ ‌–‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌theories‌ ‌below‌ ‌are‌ ‌discussing‌ ‌the‌ ‌“nuclear”‌ ‌family)‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Liberal‌ ‌Feminism‌ ‌\n○suggests‌ ‌proposals‌ ‌to‌ ‌improve‌ ‌family‌ ‌life‌ ‌for‌ ‌women‌ ‌that‌ ‌involve‌ ‌modest‌ ‌policy‌ ‌reforms‌ ‌rather‌ ‌than‌ ‌revolutionary‌ ‌change.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Causes‌ ‌of‌ ‌inequality‌ ‌in‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌ia‌ ‌a‌ ‌combination‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌things:‌ ‌\n(1)‌ ‌Mainstream‌ ‌working‌ ‌culture‌ ‌which‌ ‌requires‌ ‌long‌ ‌and‌ ‌inflexible‌ ‌working‌ ‌hours‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌still‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌idea‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌main‌ ‌\nbreadwinner,‌ ‌ ‌\n(2)‌ ‌Men‌ ‌refusing‌ ‌to‌ ‌pull‌ ‌their‌ ‌weight‌ ‌in‌ ‌relationships(that‌ ‌high‌ ‌rates‌ ‌of‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌breakdowns‌ ‌will‌ ‌continue‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌the‌ ‌norm‌ ‌which‌ ‌\nwill‌ ‌lead‌ ‌to‌ ‌more‌ ‌complex‌ ‌familial‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌as‌ ‌women‌ ‌end‌ ‌one‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌and‌ ‌attempt‌ ‌to‌ ‌rebuild‌ ‌the‌ ‌next‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌new‌ ‌(typically‌ ‌\nmale)‌ ‌partner.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Solutions‌ ‌to‌ ‌Inequality‌:‌ ‌\n○Greater‌ ‌gender‌ ‌equality‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌public‌ ‌sphere.‌ ‌\n○Achieving‌ ‌equal‌ ‌access‌ ‌to‌ ‌education,‌ ‌\n○Equal‌ ‌pay,‌ ‌ ‌\n○Ending‌ ‌gender‌ ‌differences‌ ‌in‌ ‌subject‌ ‌and‌ ‌career‌ ‌choice‌ ‌won‌ ‌primarily‌ ‌through‌ ‌legal‌ ‌changes.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●A‌ ‌key‌ ‌thinker‌ ‌who‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌characterised‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌liberal‌ ‌feminist‌ ‌is‌ ‌Jennifer‌ ‌Somerville.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Evaluation‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Liberal‌ ‌Feminist‌ ‌Perspective‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌Family‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌more‌ ‌appealing‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌wider‌ ‌range‌ ‌of‌ ‌women‌ ‌than‌ ‌radical‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌more‌ ‌practical‌ ‌–‌ ‌the‌ ‌system‌ ‌is‌ ‌more‌ ‌likely‌ ‌to‌ ‌accept‌ ‌small‌ ‌policy‌ ‌changes,‌ ‌while‌ ‌it‌ ‌would‌ ‌resist‌ ‌revolutionary‌ ‌change‌ ‌\n○Difference‌ ‌Feminists‌ ‌argue‌ ‌that‌ ‌this‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌ethnocentric‌ ‌view‌ ‌–‌ ‌it‌ ‌reflects‌ ‌the‌ ‌experiences‌ ‌of‌ ‌mainly‌ ‌white,‌ ‌middle‌ ‌class‌ ‌women.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Radical‌ ‌Feminists‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌Delphy,‌ ‌Leonard‌ ‌and‌ ‌Greer‌ ‌argue‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌fails‌ ‌to‌ ‌deal‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌Patriarchal‌ ‌structures‌ ‌and‌ ‌culture‌ ‌in‌ ‌\ncontemporary‌ ‌family‌ ‌life.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Marxist‌ ‌Feminism‌ ‌\n○(Marxist‌ ‌feminists‌ ‌argue‌ ‌the‌ ‌main‌ ‌cause‌ ‌of‌ ‌women’s‌ ‌oppression‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌men,‌ ‌but‌ ‌capitalism.‌ ‌They‌ ‌argue‌ ‌that‌ ‌women’s‌ ‌\noppression‌ ‌performs‌ ‌several‌ ‌functions‌ ‌for‌ ‌Capitalism‌ ‌\n○Women‌ ‌reproduce‌ ‌the‌ ‌labour‌ ‌force‌ ‌–‌ ‌through‌ ‌their‌ ‌unpaid‌ ‌domestic‌ ‌labour,‌ ‌by‌ ‌socialising‌ ‌the‌ ‌next‌ ‌generation‌ ‌of‌ ‌workers‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nservicing‌ ‌the‌ ‌current‌ ‌workers‌ ‌(their‌ ‌husbands!)‌ ‌\n458‌ ‌\n○Women‌ ‌absorb‌ ‌anger.‌ ‌The‌ ‌Marxist-Feminist‌ ‌interpretation‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌is‌ ‌that‌ ‌women‌ ‌are‌ ‌just‌ ‌absorbing‌ ‌the‌ ‌anger‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌proletariat.‌ ‌\n○Women‌ ‌are‌ ‌a‌ ‌‘reserve‌ ‌army‌ ‌of‌ ‌cheap‌ ‌labour’‌ ‌–‌ ‌if‌ ‌women’s‌ ‌primary‌ ‌role‌ ‌is‌ ‌domestic,‌ ‌and‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌restricted‌ ‌from‌ ‌working,‌ ‌this‌ ‌also‌ ‌\nmeans‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌in‌ ‌reserve,‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌taken‌ ‌on‌ ‌temporarily‌ ‌as‌ ‌necessary.‌ ‌\n●Key‌ ‌thinker‌ ‌‌–‌ ‌‌Fran‌ ‌Ansley‌ ‌‌argues‌ ‌women‌ ‌absorb‌ ‌the‌ ‌anger‌ ‌that‌ ‌would‌ ‌otherwise‌ ‌be‌ ‌directed‌ ‌at‌ ‌capitalism.‌ ‌Ansley‌ ‌argues‌ ‌women’s‌ ‌male‌ ‌\npartners‌ ‌are‌ ‌inevitably‌ ‌frustrated‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌exploitation‌ ‌they‌ ‌experience‌ ‌at‌ ‌work‌ ‌and‌ ‌women‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌victims‌ ‌of‌ ‌this,‌ ‌including‌ ‌domestic‌ ‌\nviolence.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Marxist‌ ‌Feminism‌ ‌–‌ ‌Solutions‌ ‌to‌ ‌Gender‌ ‌Inequalities‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌Marxist‌ ‌Feminists,‌ ‌the‌ ‌solutions‌ ‌to‌ ‌gender‌ ‌inequality‌ ‌are‌ ‌economic‌ ‌–‌ ‌We‌ ‌need‌ ‌to‌ ‌tackle‌ ‌Capitalism‌ ‌to‌ ‌tackle‌ ‌Patriarchy.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Softer‌ ‌solutions‌ ‌include‌ ‌paying‌ ‌women‌ ‌for‌ ‌childcare‌ ‌and‌ ‌housework‌ ‌–‌ ‌thus‌ ‌putting‌ ‌an‌ ‌economic‌ ‌value‌ ‌on‌ ‌what‌ ‌is‌ ‌still‌ ‌largely‌ ‌\nwomen’s‌ ‌work,‌ ‌stronger‌ ‌solutions‌ ‌include‌ ‌the‌ ‌abolition‌ ‌of‌ ‌Capitalism‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌ushering‌ ‌in‌ ‌of‌ ‌Communism.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Evaluations‌ ‌of‌ ‌Marxist‌ ‌Feminism‌ ‌\n○One‌ ‌limitation‌ ‌is‌ ‌that‌ ‌this‌ ‌sounds‌ ‌very‌ ‌dated‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌2020s:‌ ‌women‌ ‌today‌ ‌are‌ ‌just‌ ‌as‌ ‌likely‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌in‌ ‌paid‌ ‌work‌ ‌as‌ ‌men,‌ ‌and‌ ‌so‌ ‌they‌ ‌\nno‌ ‌longer‌ ‌act‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌‘reserve‌ ‌army‌ ‌of‌ ‌labour’‌ ‌for‌ ‌example.‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌further‌ ‌limitation‌ ‌is‌ ‌that‌ ‌women’s‌ ‌oppression‌ ‌was‌ ‌clearly‌ ‌in‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌before‌ ‌capitalism‌ ‌–‌ ‌if‌ ‌anything,‌ ‌women‌ ‌are‌ ‌probably‌ ‌more‌ ‌\noppressed‌ ‌in‌ ‌pre-capitalist,‌ ‌tribal‌ ‌societies‌ ‌compared‌ ‌to‌ ‌within‌ ‌capitalist‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌\n○There‌ ‌appears‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌a‌ ‌correlation‌ ‌between‌ ‌capitalist‌ ‌development‌ ‌and‌ ‌women’s‌ ‌liberation‌ ‌–‌ ‌suggesting‌ ‌that‌ ‌capitalism‌ ‌has‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nopposite‌ ‌effect‌ ‌from‌ ‌that‌ ‌suggested‌ ‌by‌ ‌Marxist‌ ‌Feminists.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Radical‌ ‌Feminism‌ ‌\n○Radical‌ ‌feminists‌ ‌argue‌ ‌that‌ ‌all‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌between‌ ‌men‌ ‌and‌ ‌women‌ ‌are‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌patriarchy‌ ‌–‌ ‌essentially‌ ‌men‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌cause‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nwomen’s‌ ‌exploitation‌ ‌and‌ ‌oppression.‌ ‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌radical‌ ‌feminists,‌ ‌the‌ ‌entire‌ ‌patriarchal‌ ‌system‌ ‌needs‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌overturned,‌ ‌in‌ ‌particular‌ ‌the‌ ‌family,‌ ‌which‌ ‌they‌ ‌view‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌root‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nwomen’s‌ ‌oppression.‌ ‌\n○Against‌ ‌Liberal‌ ‌Feminism,‌ ‌they‌ ‌argue‌ ‌that‌ ‌paid‌ ‌work‌ ‌has‌ ‌not‌ ‌been‌ ‌‘liberating’.‌ ‌Instead‌ ‌women‌ ‌have‌ ‌acquired‌ ‌the‌ ‌‘dual‌ ‌burden’‌ ‌of‌ ‌\npaid‌ ‌work‌ ‌and‌ ‌unpaid‌ ‌housework‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌remains‌ ‌patriarchal‌ ‌–‌ ‌men‌ ‌benefit‌ ‌from‌ ‌women’s‌ ‌paid‌ ‌earnings‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌domestic‌ ‌\nlabour.‌ ‌\n○Some‌ ‌Radical‌ ‌Feminists‌ ‌go‌ ‌further‌ ‌arguing‌ ‌that‌ ‌women‌ ‌suffer‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌‘triple‌ ‌shift’‌ ‌where‌ ‌they‌ ‌have‌ ‌to‌ ‌do‌ ‌paid‌ ‌work,‌ ‌domestic‌ ‌work‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌‘emotion‌ ‌work’‌ ‌–‌ ‌being‌ ‌expected‌ ‌to‌ ‌take‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌emotional‌ ‌burden‌ ‌of‌ ‌caring‌ ‌for‌ ‌children.‌ ‌\n○Radical‌ ‌Feminists‌ ‌also‌ ‌argue‌ ‌that,‌ ‌for‌ ‌many‌ ‌women,‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌‘dark‌ ‌side‌ ‌of‌ ‌family‌ ‌life’‌ ‌–‌ ‌According‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌British‌ ‌Crime‌ ‌Survey‌ ‌\ndomestic‌ ‌violence‌ ‌accounts‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌sixth‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌violent‌ ‌crime‌ ‌and‌ ‌nearly‌ ‌1‌ ‌in‌ ‌4‌ ‌women‌ ‌will‌ ‌experience‌ ‌DV‌ ‌at‌ ‌some‌ ‌point‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌lifetime‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌women‌ ‌are‌ ‌much‌ ‌more‌ ‌likely‌ ‌to‌ ‌experience‌ ‌this‌ ‌than‌ ‌men‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Key‌ ‌thinker‌‌ ‌–‌Kate‌ ‌Millet‌‌ ‌was‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌leading‌ ‌American‌ ‌Second‌ ‌Wave‌ ‌Feminists‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌1960s‌ ‌and‌ ‌70s.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Solutions‌ ‌to‌ ‌gender‌ ‌inequality‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌short,‌ ‌Radical‌ ‌Feminists‌ ‌advocate‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌abolition‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌traditional,‌ ‌patriarchal‌ ‌(as‌ ‌they‌ ‌see‌ ‌it)‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌family‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nestablishment‌ ‌of‌ ‌alternative‌ ‌family‌ ‌structures‌ ‌and‌ ‌sexual‌ ‌relations.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌various‌ ‌alternatives‌ ‌suggested‌ ‌by‌ ‌Radical‌ ‌Feminists‌ ‌include‌ ‌separatism‌ ‌–‌ ‌women‌ ‌only‌ ‌communes,‌ ‌and‌ ‌Matrifocal‌ ‌households.‌ ‌ ‌\n459‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Evaluations‌ ‌of‌ ‌Radical‌ ‌Feminism‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌some‌ ‌ways‌ ‌this‌ ‌perspective‌ ‌is‌ ‌less‌ ‌relevant‌ ‌today‌ ‌than‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌1960s‌ ‌–‌ ‌women‌ ‌are‌ ‌much‌ ‌less‌ ‌likely‌ ‌to‌ ‌suffer‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌dual‌ ‌burden‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌triple‌ ‌shift.‌ ‌But‌ ‌the‌ ‌recent‌ ‌Lockdown‌ ‌scenario‌ ‌during‌ ‌COVID-19‌ ‌pandemic‌ ‌support‌ ‌the‌ ‌fact.‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌some‌ ‌ways,‌ ‌however,‌ ‌it‌ ‌still‌ ‌seems‌ ‌very‌ ‌relevant.‌ ‌For‌ ‌example,‌ ‌the‌ ‌ME‌ ‌TOO‌ ‌campaign‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌Harvey‌ ‌Weinstein‌ ‌scandal‌ ‌both‌ ‌\nshow‌ ‌that‌ ‌harassment‌ ‌and‌ ‌sexual‌ ‌abuse‌ ‌of‌ ‌women‌ ‌remain‌ ‌common.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n2.5‌ ‌Kinship‌ ‌:‌ ‌Consanguinity‌ ‌and‌ ‌Affinity;‌ ‌Principles‌ ‌and‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌descent‌ ‌(Unilineal,‌ ‌Double,‌ ‌Bilateral‌ ‌Ambilineal);‌ ‌Forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌descent‌ ‌\ngroups‌ ‌(lineage,‌ ‌clan,‌ ‌phratry,‌ ‌moiety‌ ‌and‌ ‌kindred);‌ ‌-Part-I‌ ‌\n‌ ‌\nKinship‌ ‌:‌ ‌Consanguinity‌ ‌and‌ ‌Affinity;‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌anthropology,‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌web‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌that‌ ‌form‌ ‌an‌ ‌important‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌lives‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌humans‌ ‌in‌ ‌all‌ ‌societies,‌ ‌‌although‌ ‌its‌ ‌\nexact‌ ‌meanings‌ ‌even‌ ‌within‌ ‌this‌ ‌discipline‌ ‌are‌ ‌often‌ ‌debated.‌ ‌ ‌\n460‌ ‌\n●Anthropologist‌ ‌Robin‌ ‌Fox‌ ‌‌states‌ ‌that‌ ‌\"the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌what‌ ‌man‌ ‌does‌ ‌with‌ ‌these‌ ‌basic‌ ‌facts‌ ‌of‌ ‌life‌ ‌–‌ ‌mating,‌ ‌gestation,‌ ‌\nparenthood,‌ ‌socialization,‌ ‌siblingship‌ ‌etc.‌\"‌ ‌\n●Simply,‌ ‌Kinship‌ ‌is‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌main‌ ‌organizing‌ ‌principles‌ ‌of‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌basic‌ ‌social‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌every‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌institution‌ ‌establishes‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌between‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌and‌ ‌groups.‌ ‌ ‌\n●People‌ ‌in‌ ‌all‌ ‌societies‌ ‌are‌ ‌bound‌ ‌together‌ ‌by‌ ‌various‌ ‌kinds‌ ‌of‌ ‌bonds.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌most‌ ‌basic‌ ‌bonds‌ ‌are‌ ‌those‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌and‌ ‌reproduction.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Kinship‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌these‌ ‌bonds,‌ ‌and‌ ‌all‌ ‌other‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌resulting‌ ‌from‌ ‌them.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Thus,‌ ‌the‌ ‌institu­tion‌ ‌of‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌set‌ ‌of‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌and‌ ‌relatives‌ ‌formed‌ ‌thereof,‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌‌blood‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌(consanguineal),‌ ‌\nor‌‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌(affinal)‌.‌ ‌\n ‌\nFamily‌ ‌vs‌ ‌Kinship‌ ‌\n●While‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌denotes‌ ‌a‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌spouses‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌children,‌ ‌who‌ ‌are‌ ‌described‌ ‌as‌ ‌'siblings',‌ ‌the‌ ‌kin‌ ‌includes‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nbound‌ ‌a‌ ‌large‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌persons;‌ ‌and‌ ‌what‌ ‌creates‌ ‌a‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌will‌ ‌necessarily‌ ‌depend‌ ‌upon‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌organization‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌context‌ ‌of‌ ‌which‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌ ‌\nterm‌ ‌is‌ ‌applied.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nDefinitions‌ ‌by‌ ‌Thinkers/Scholars‌ ‌\n●‘Kinship‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌socially‌ ‌recognized‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌between‌ ‌people‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌culture,‌ ‌who‌ ‌are‌ ‌either‌ ‌held‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌biologically‌ ‌related‌ ‌or‌ ‌given‌ ‌the‌ ‌status‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌relatives‌ ‌by‌ ‌marriage,‌ ‌adoption,‌ ‌or‌ ‌other‌ ‌rituals.‌ ‌\nKinship‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌b‌road-ranging‌ ‌term‌ ‌for‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌that‌ ‌people‌ ‌are‌ ‌born‌ ‌into‌ ‌or‌ ‌create‌ ‌later‌ ‌in‌ ‌life‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌considered‌ ‌binding‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌eyes‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌their‌ ‌society‌.‌ ‌ ‌\nAlthough‌ ‌customs‌ ‌vary‌ ‌as‌ ‌to‌ ‌which‌ ‌bonds‌ ‌are‌ ‌accorded‌ ‌more‌ ‌weight,‌ ‌their‌ ‌very‌ ‌acknowledgement‌ ‌defines‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌and‌ ‌roles‌ ‌that‌ ‌society‌ ‌\nexpects‌ ‌them‌ ‌to‌ ‌play.’–‌Encyclopedia‌ ‌Britannica‌ ‌\n●‘Kinship‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌recognition‌ ‌of‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌between‌ ‌persons‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌descent‌ ‌or‌ ‌marriage‌.‌ ‌If‌ ‌the‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌between‌ ‌one‌ ‌person‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nanother‌ ‌is‌ ‌considered‌ ‌by‌ ‌them‌ ‌to‌ ‌involve‌ ‌descent,‌ ‌the‌ ‌two‌ ‌are‌ ‌‌consanguine‌ ‌‌(“blood”)‌ ‌relatives.‌ ‌If‌ ‌the‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌established‌ ‌\nthrough‌ ‌marriage,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌‌affinal‌.’–‌ ‌‌L.‌ ‌Stone‌ ‌\n●As‌ ‌per‌ ‌DN‌ ‌Majumdar‌ ‌(‌An‌ ‌India‌ ‌anthropologist)‌ ‌in‌ ‌all‌ ‌societies‌ ‌people‌ ‌are‌ ‌bound‌ ‌together‌ ‌in‌ ‌groups‌ ‌to‌ ‌buy‌ ‌various‌ ‌kinds‌ ‌of‌ ‌bonds.‌ ‌The‌ ‌most‌ ‌\nuniversal‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌basic‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌bonds‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌reproduction‌ ‌and‌ ‌inherent‌ ‌human‌ ‌right‌ ‌is‌ ‌called‌ ‌kinship.‌ ‌\n●‘Kinship‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌expressed‌ ‌in‌ ‌biological‌ ‌idiom‌ ‌using‌ ‌terms‌ ‌like‌ ‌“mother”,‌ ‌“son”,‌ ‌and‌ ‌so‌ ‌on.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌best‌ ‌\nvisualized‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌mass‌ ‌of‌ ‌networks‌ ‌of‌ ‌related-‌ ‌ness,‌ ‌not‌ ‌two‌ ‌of‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌identical,‌ ‌that‌ ‌radiate‌ ‌from‌ ‌each‌ ‌individual.‌ ‌Kinship‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌basic‌ ‌\norganizing‌ ‌principle‌ ‌in‌ ‌small-scale‌ ‌societies‌ ‌like‌ ‌those‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Aborigines‌ ‌and‌ ‌pro­vides‌ ‌a‌ ‌model‌ ‌for‌ ‌interpersonal‌ ‌behaviour.’–‌ ‌‌R.‌ ‌Tonkinson‌ ‌\n●‘Kinship‌ ‌encompasses‌ ‌the‌ ‌norms,‌ ‌roles,‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌and‌ ‌cognitive‌ ‌processes‌ ‌refer­ring‌ ‌to‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌that‌ ‌people‌ ‌are‌ ‌born‌ ‌into,‌ ‌\nor‌ ‌create‌ ‌later‌ ‌in‌ ‌life,‌ ‌and‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌expressed‌ ‌through,‌ ‌but‌ ‌not‌ ‌limited‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌biological‌ ‌idiom.’–‌ ‌‌Laurent‌ ‌Dousset‌ ‌\n ‌\n461‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nTypes‌ ‌of‌ ‌Kinship:‌ ‌\nIn‌ ‌any‌ ‌society,‌ ‌kin‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌are‌ ‌based‌ ‌either‌ ‌on‌ ‌birth‌ ‌(blood‌ ‌relations),‌ ‌or‌ ‌marriage.‌ ‌These‌ ‌two‌ ‌aspects‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌life‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌two‌ ‌\nmain‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌in‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n ‌\n1.‌ ‌Consanguineal‌ ‌Kinship:‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌blood,‌ ‌i.e.‌ ‌the‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌between‌ ‌parents‌ ‌and‌ ‌children,‌ ‌and‌ ‌between‌ ‌siblings‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌basic‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nuniversal‌ ‌kin‌ ‌relations.‌ ‌\n ‌\n2.‌ ‌Affinal‌ ‌Kinship:‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌formed‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage.‌ ‌The‌ ‌most‌ ‌basic‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌that‌ ‌results‌ ‌from‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌is‌ ‌that‌ ‌between‌ ‌husband‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌wife.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nDegree‌ ‌of‌ ‌Kinship:‌ ‌\n●Any‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌between‌ ‌two‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌is‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌degree‌ ‌of‌ ‌closeness‌ ‌or‌ ‌distance‌ ‌of‌ ‌that‌ ‌relationship.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌closeness‌ ‌or‌ ‌distance‌ ‌of‌ ‌any‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌depends‌ ‌upon‌ ‌how‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌are‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌each‌ ‌other.‌ ‌\n ‌\n462‌ ‌\nKinship‌ ‌basically‌ ‌has‌ ‌three‌ ‌degrees,‌ ‌which‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌explained‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌following‌ ‌ways:‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nPrimary‌ ‌Kinship:‌ ‌\n●Primary‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌direct‌ ‌relations.‌ ‌People‌ ‌who‌ ‌are‌ ‌directly‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌each‌ ‌other‌ ‌are‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌primary‌ ‌kin.‌ ‌ ‌\n●There‌ ‌are‌ ‌basically‌ ‌eight‌ ‌primary‌ ‌kins—wife,‌ ‌father‌ ‌son,‌ ‌father‌ ‌daugh­ter,‌ ‌mother‌ ‌son,‌ ‌wife;‌ ‌father‌ ‌son,‌ ‌father‌ ‌daughter,‌ ‌mother‌ ‌son,‌ ‌mother‌ ‌\ndaughter;‌ ‌brother‌ ‌sister;‌ ‌and‌ ‌younger‌ ‌brother/sister‌ ‌older‌ ‌brother/sister.‌ ‌\n●Primary‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌is‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌kinds:‌ ‌\n1.‌ ‌‌Primary‌ ‌Consanguineal‌ ‌Kinship:‌ ‌\n●Primary‌ ‌consanguineal‌ ‌kin‌ ‌are‌ ‌those‌ ‌kin,‌ ‌who‌ ‌are‌ ‌directly‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌each‌ ‌other‌ ‌by‌ ‌birth.‌ ‌The‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌between‌ ‌parents‌ ‌and‌ ‌children‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nbetween‌ ‌siblings‌ ‌form‌ ‌primary‌ ‌kinship.‌ ‌These‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌only‌ ‌primary‌ ‌consanguineal‌ ‌kin‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌societies‌ ‌all‌ ‌over‌ ‌the‌ ‌world.‌ ‌\n2.‌ ‌‌Primary‌ ‌Affinal‌ ‌Kinship:‌ ‌\n●Primary‌ ‌affinal‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌direct‌ ‌relation­ship‌ ‌formed‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌result‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage.‌ ‌The‌ ‌only‌ ‌direct‌ ‌affinal‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌rela­tionship‌ ‌\nbetween‌ ‌husband‌ ‌and‌ ‌wife.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nSecondary‌ ‌Kinship:‌ ‌\n●Secondary‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌primary‌ ‌kin’s‌ ‌of‌ ‌primary‌ ‌kin.‌ ‌In‌ ‌other‌ ‌words,‌ ‌those‌ ‌who‌ ‌are‌ ‌directly‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌primary‌ ‌kin‌ ‌(primary‌ ‌kin’s‌ ‌\nprimary‌ ‌kin)‌ ‌become‌ ‌one’s‌ ‌secondary‌ ‌kin.‌ ‌There‌ ‌are‌ ‌33‌ ‌secondary‌ ‌kin.‌ ‌\nSecondary‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌kinds:‌ ‌\n1.‌ ‌Secondary‌ ‌Consanguineal‌ ‌kinship:‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌primary‌ ‌con­sanguineal‌ ‌kin’s‌ ‌primary‌ ‌consanguineal‌ ‌kin.‌ ‌The‌ ‌most‌ ‌basic‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌secondary‌ ‌consan­guineal‌ ‌\nkinship‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌between‌ ‌grandparents‌ ‌and‌ ‌grandchildren.‌ ‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌Ego,‌ ‌his‌ ‌parents‌ ‌are‌ ‌his‌ ‌primary‌ ‌consanguineal‌ ‌kin.‌ ‌However,‌ ‌for‌ ‌Ego’s‌ ‌par­ents,‌ ‌their‌ ‌parents‌ ‌are‌ ‌their‌ ‌primary‌ ‌consanguineal‌ ‌kin.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Therefore,‌ ‌for‌ ‌Ego,‌ ‌his‌ ‌grandpar­ents‌ ‌are‌ ‌his‌ ‌primary‌ ‌consanguineal‌ ‌kin’s‌ ‌(his‌ ‌parents)‌ ‌primary‌ ‌kin.‌ ‌For‌ ‌him,‌ ‌they‌ ‌become‌ ‌secondary‌ ‌\nconsanguineal‌ ‌kin.‌ ‌\n463‌ ‌\n ‌\n2.‌ ‌Secondary‌ ‌Affinal‌ ‌Kinship:‌ ‌\n●Secondary‌ ‌affinal‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌one’s‌ ‌primary‌ ‌affinal‌ ‌kins‌ ‌primary‌ ‌kin.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌includes‌ ‌the‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌between‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌and‌ ‌all‌ ‌his/her‌ ‌sisters-in-law,‌ ‌brothers-in-law,‌ ‌and‌ ‌parents-in-law.‌ ‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual,‌ ‌his/her‌ ‌spouse‌ ‌is‌ ‌his/her‌ ‌primary‌ ‌affinal‌ ‌kin,‌ ‌and‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌spouse,‌ ‌his/her‌ ‌parents‌ ‌and‌ ‌siblings‌ ‌are‌ ‌his/her‌ ‌primary‌ ‌kin.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Therefore,‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual,‌ ‌the‌ ‌parents‌ ‌of‌ ‌brother/sister-in-law‌ ‌will‌ ‌become‌ ‌his/her‌ ‌secondary‌ ‌affinal‌ ‌kin.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Similarly,‌ ‌any‌ ‌sibling’s‌ ‌spouse‌ ‌or‌ ‌sibling’s‌ ‌parents-in-law‌ ‌will‌ ‌become‌ ‌secondary‌ ‌affinal‌ ‌kin‌ ‌for‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual.‌ ‌\n ‌\nTertiary‌ ‌Kinship:‌ ‌\n●Tertiary‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌primary‌ ‌kin‌ ‌of‌ ‌primary‌ ‌kin’s‌ ‌primary‌ ‌kin‌ ‌or‌ ‌secondary‌ ‌kin‌ ‌of‌ ‌primary‌ ‌kin‌ ‌primary‌ ‌kin‌ ‌of‌ ‌secondary‌ ‌kin.‌ ‌Roughly‌ ‌\n151‌ ‌tertiary‌ ‌kin‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌identi­fied.‌ ‌\nLike‌ ‌other‌ ‌two‌ ‌degrees‌ ‌of‌ ‌kinship,‌ ‌tertiary‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌also‌ ‌has‌ ‌two‌ ‌categories:‌ ‌\n1.‌ ‌Tertiary‌ ‌Consanguineal‌ ‌Kinship:‌ ‌\n●Tertiary‌ ‌consanguineal‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual’s‌ ‌primary‌ ‌consanguineal‌ ‌kin‌ ‌(parents),‌ ‌their‌ ‌primary‌ ‌kin‌ ‌(parents’‌ ‌parents),‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌\nprimary‌ ‌kin‌ ‌(parent’s‌ ‌parent’s‌ ‌parents).‌ ‌ ‌\n●Thus,‌ ‌the‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌is‌ ‌between‌ ‌great‌ ‌grand­children‌ ‌and‌ ‌great‌ ‌grandparents,‌ ‌and‌ ‌great‌ ‌grand‌ ‌aunts‌ ‌and‌ ‌uncles,‌ ‌and‌ ‌consequently‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nrelationship‌ ‌between‌ ‌great‌ ‌grand‌ ‌uncles‌ ‌and‌ ‌aunts‌ ‌and‌ ‌great‌ ‌grand‌ ‌nieces‌ ‌and‌ ‌nephews.‌ ‌\n●Ego’s‌ ‌primary‌ ‌kin‌ ‌are‌ ‌his‌ ‌parents,‌ ‌their‌ ‌primary‌ ‌kin‌ ‌are‌ ‌his‌ ‌grandparents‌ ‌and‌ ‌his‌ ‌grandparent’s‌ ‌primary‌ ‌kin‌ ‌(who‌ ‌are‌ ‌Ego’s‌ ‌primary‌ ‌kin’s‌ ‌\nprimary‌ ‌kin’s‌ ‌primary‌ ‌kin)‌ ‌are‌ ‌his‌ ‌great‌ ‌grandparents.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Thus,‌ ‌tertiary‌ ‌kin‌ ‌are‌ ‌primary‌ ‌kin’s‌ ‌primary‌ ‌kin’s‌ ‌pri­mary‌ ‌kin.‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌seen‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌ways‌ ‌–‌ ‌Ego’s‌ ‌tertiary‌ ‌kin‌ ‌are‌ ‌his‌ ‌pri­mary‌ ‌kin’s‌ ‌(parents)‌ ‌secondary‌ ‌kin‌ ‌(father’s‌ ‌grandparents),‌ ‌thus‌ ‌\nshowing‌ ‌that‌ ‌tertiary‌ ‌kin‌ ‌are‌ ‌primary‌ ‌kin’s‌ ‌secondary‌ ‌kin.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Another‌ ‌way‌ ‌of‌ ‌looking‌ ‌at‌ ‌this‌ ‌same‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌is‌ ‌by‌ ‌showing‌ ‌that‌ ‌Ego’s‌ ‌tertiary‌ ‌kin‌ ‌are‌ ‌his‌ ‌secondary‌ ‌consanguineal‌ ‌kin‌ ‌(his‌ ‌grandpar­ents)‌ ‌\nprimary‌ ‌kin‌ ‌(grandfather’s‌ ‌parents),‌ ‌which‌ ‌proves‌ ‌that‌ ‌tertiary‌ ‌kin‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌second­ary‌ ‌kin’s‌ ‌primary‌ ‌kin.‌ ‌\n2.‌ ‌Tertiary‌ ‌Affinal‌ ‌Kinship:‌ ‌\n●Tertiary‌ ‌affinal‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌primary‌ ‌affinal‌ ‌kin’s‌ ‌pri­mary‌ ‌kin’s‌ ‌primary‌ ‌kin,‌ ‌or‌ ‌secondary‌ ‌affinal‌ ‌kin’s‌ ‌primary‌ ‌kin,‌ ‌or‌ ‌primary‌ ‌affinal‌ ‌kin’s‌ ‌\nsecondary‌ ‌kin.‌ ‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌are‌ ‌many,‌ ‌and‌ ‌some‌ ‌examples‌ ‌will‌ ‌suffice‌ ‌at‌ ‌this‌ ‌stage‌ ‌of‌ ‌tertiary‌ ‌affinal‌ ‌kin‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌spouse’s‌ ‌grandparents,‌ ‌or‌ ‌grand‌ ‌\nuncles‌ ‌and‌ ‌aunts,‌ ‌or‌ ‌they‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌brother‌ ‌or‌ ‌sister-in-law’s‌ ‌spouses‌ ‌or‌ ‌their‌ ‌children.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nPrinciples‌ ‌and‌ ‌Types‌ ‌of‌ ‌Descent‌ ‌(Unilineal,‌ ‌Double,‌ ‌Bilateral‌ ‌Ambilineal);‌ ‌ ‌\nThe‌ ‌Principles‌ ‌of‌ ‌Descent‌ ‌\n464‌ ‌\n●Descent‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌principle‌ ‌whereby‌ ‌a‌ ‌child‌ ‌is‌ ‌socially‌ ‌affiliated‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌or‌ ‌her‌ ‌parents.‌ ‌Socially‌ ‌recognized‌ ‌links‌ ‌between‌ ‌ancestors‌ ‌\n&‌ ‌descendants‌.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌some‌ ‌societies‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌child‌ ‌is‌ ‌regarded‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌descendant‌ ‌equally‌ ‌of‌ ‌both‌ ‌the‌ ‌father‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌mother,‌ ‌except‌ ‌that‌ ‌titles‌ ‌and‌ ‌surnames‌ ‌are‌ ‌\nusually‌ ‌passed‌ ‌down‌ ‌along‌ ‌the‌ ‌allele‌ ‌line.‌ ‌Such‌ ‌a‌ ‌system‌ ‌is‌ ‌termed‌ ‌Bilateral‌ ‌or‌ ‌Cognatic‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌world‌ ‌trace‌ ‌descent‌ ‌are‌ ‌unilineal‌ ‌and‌ ‌cognatic‌ ‌(or‌ ‌non-lineal):‌ ‌\n○Unilineal‌ ‌systems‌ ‌:‌‌ ‌Unilineal‌ ‌descent‌ ‌recognizes‌ ‌only‌ ‌a‌ ‌single‌ ‌line‌ ‌of‌ ‌ancestors‌ ‌through‌ ‌males‌ ‌or‌ ‌females.‌ ‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌in‌ ‌two‌ ‌forms--patrilineal,‌ ‌which‌ ‌follows‌ ‌the‌ ‌male‌ ‌line,‌ ‌and‌ ‌matrilineal,‌ ‌which‌ ‌follows‌ ‌the‌ ‌female‌ ‌line.‌ ‌The‌ ‌patrilineal‌ ‌\nform‌ ‌is‌ ‌more‌ ‌common.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Cognatic‌ ‌systems‌ ‌:‌ ‌‌descent‌ ‌traced‌ ‌through‌ ‌either‌ ‌or‌ ‌both‌ ‌parents.‌ ‌\n■With‌ ‌cognatic‌ ‌descent,‌ ‌both‌ ‌the‌ ‌mother's‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌father's‌ ‌ancestors‌ ‌to‌ ‌some‌ ‌degree‌ ‌are‌ ‌considered‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌\nline.‌ ‌Cognatic‌ ‌descent‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌in‌ ‌four‌ ‌forms--bilineal,‌ ‌parallel,‌ ‌ambilineal,‌ ‌and‌ ‌bilateral‌ ‌descent.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n(While‌ ‌people‌ ‌of‌ ‌European‌ ‌ancestry‌ ‌are‌ ‌more‌ ‌familiar‌ ‌with‌ ‌cognatic‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌institutions,‌ ‌only‌ ‌30%‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌world's‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌\nreckon‌ ‌descent‌ ‌and‌ ‌group‌ ‌membership‌ ‌on‌ ‌this‌ ‌basis.‌ ‌The‌ ‌remaining‌ ‌majority‌ ‌of‌ ‌societies,‌ ‌including‌ ‌India‌ ‌and‌ ‌China,‌ ‌follow‌ ‌\nunilineal‌ ‌principles‌ ‌(Murdock).‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌individual‌ ‌belongs‌ ‌simultaneously‌ ‌to‌ ‌several‌ ‌descent‌ ‌groups‌ ‌-‌ ‌those‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌two‌ ‌parents,‌ ‌the‌ ‌four‌ ‌grandparents,‌ ‌the‌ ‌eight‌ ‌\ngreat-grandparents,‌ ‌and‌ ‌so‌ ‌on.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌link‌ ‌is‌ ‌limited‌ ‌only‌ ‌by‌ ‌memory‌ ‌or‌ ‌by‌ ‌some‌ ‌conventionally‌ ‌determined‌ ‌cut-off‌ ‌point‌ ‌at,‌ ‌say,‌ ‌four‌ ‌or‌ ‌five‌ ‌degrees‌ ‌1‌ ‌removal.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌small‌ ‌intermarrying‌ ‌communities,‌ ‌membership‌ ‌will‌ ‌probably‌ ‌overlap,‌ ‌and‌ ‌in‌ ‌case‌ ‌of‌ ‌dispute‌ ‌or‌ ‌feud,‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual‌ ‌might‌ ‌find‌ ‌his‌ ‌or‌ ‌her‌ ‌\nloyalties‌ ‌divided‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n●There‌ ‌are‌ ‌some‌ ‌cognatic‌ ‌systems‌ ‌where‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual‌ ‌has‌ ‌the‌ ‌right‌ ‌by‌ ‌descent‌ ‌to‌ ‌membership‌ ‌of‌ ‌several‌ ‌cogniatically‌ ‌recruited‌ ‌groups,‌ ‌but‌ ‌\nthis‌ ‌right‌ ‌is‌ ‌actualised‌ ‌only‌ ‌if‌ ‌the‌ ‌person‌ ‌is‌ ‌able‌ ‌to‌ ‌reside‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌group's‌ ‌territory.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Modern‌ ‌nationality‌ ‌laws‌ ‌often‌ ‌make‌ ‌this‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌requirement.‌ ‌\n465‌ ‌\n ‌\nUnilineal‌ ‌Descent‌ ‌\n●Most‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌severely‌ ‌limit‌ ‌the‌ ‌range‌ ‌of‌ ‌people‌ ‌through‌ ‌whom‌ ‌descent‌ ‌is‌ ‌traced‌ ‌by‌ ‌using‌ ‌a‌ ‌unilineal‌ ‌to‌ ‌hear‌ ‌the‌ ‌preceding‌ ‌term‌ ‌pronounced‌ ‌\ndescent‌ ‌principle.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌traces‌ ‌descent‌ ‌only‌ ‌through‌ ‌a‌ ‌single‌ ‌line‌ ‌of‌ ‌ancestors,‌ ‌male‌ ‌or‌ ‌female.‌ ‌Both‌ ‌males‌ ‌and‌ ‌females‌ ‌are‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌unilineal‌ ‌family,‌ ‌but‌ ‌\ndescent‌ ‌links‌ ‌are‌ ‌only‌ ‌recognized‌ ‌through‌ ‌relatives‌ ‌of‌ ‌one‌ ‌gender.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌two‌ ‌basic‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌unilineal‌ ‌descent‌ ‌are‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to‌ ‌as:‌ ‌\n○Patrilineal‌ ‌Descent‌ ‌\n■With‌ ‌patrilineal‌ ‌descent,‌ ‌both‌ ‌males‌ ‌and‌ ‌females‌ ‌belong‌ ‌to‌ ‌their‌ ‌father's‌ ‌kin‌ ‌group‌ ‌but‌ ‌not‌ ‌their‌ ‌mother's.‌ ‌However,‌ ‌only‌ ‌\nmales‌ ‌pass‌ ‌on‌ ‌their‌ ‌family‌ ‌identity‌ ‌to‌ ‌their‌ ‌children.‌ ‌A‌ ‌woman's‌ ‌children‌ ‌are‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌her‌ ‌husband's‌ ‌patrilineal‌ ‌line.‌ ‌The‌ ‌\nred‌ ‌people‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌diagram‌ ‌below‌ ‌are‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌each‌ ‌other‌ ‌patrilineally.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○Matrilineal‌ ‌Descent‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌unilineal‌ ‌descent‌ ‌that‌ ‌follows‌ ‌a‌ ‌female‌ ‌line‌ ‌is‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌matrilineal.‌ ‌When‌ ‌using‌ ‌this‌ ‌pattern,‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌are‌ ‌\nrelatives‌ ‌if‌ ‌they‌ ‌can‌ ‌trace‌ ‌descent‌ ‌through‌ ‌females‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌female‌ ‌ancestor.‌ ‌ ‌\n■While‌ ‌both‌ ‌male‌ ‌and‌ ‌female‌ ‌children‌ ‌are‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌mother's‌ ‌matrilineal‌ ‌descent‌ ‌group,‌ ‌only‌ ‌daughters‌ ‌can‌ ‌pass‌ ‌on‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌family‌ ‌line‌ ‌to‌ ‌their‌ ‌offspring.‌ ‌The‌ ‌green‌ ‌people‌ ‌below‌ ‌are‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌each‌ ‌other‌ ‌matrilineally.‌ ‌\n466‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n■In‌ ‌societies‌ ‌using‌ ‌matrilineal‌ ‌descent,‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌between‌ ‌children‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌biological‌ ‌father‌ ‌tends‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌different‌ ‌\nthan‌ ‌most‌ ‌people‌ ‌would‌ ‌expect‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌fact‌ ‌that‌ ‌he‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌a‌ ‌member‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌matrilineal‌ ‌family.‌ ‌In‌ ‌the‌ ‌case‌ ‌of‌ ‌ego‌ ‌below,‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌man‌ ‌who‌ ‌would‌ ‌have‌ ‌the‌ ‌formal‌ ‌responsibilities‌ ‌that‌ ‌various‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌assign‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌father‌ ‌would‌ ‌be‌ ‌his‌ ‌mother's‌ ‌brother‌ ‌\n(MoBr),‌ ‌since‌ ‌he‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌closest‌ ‌elder‌ ‌male‌ ‌kinsmen.‌ ‌Ego's‌ ‌father‌ ‌would‌ ‌have‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌kind‌ ‌of‌ ‌responsibilities‌ ‌for‌ ‌his‌ ‌sister's‌ ‌\nchildren.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n■Inheritance‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌for‌ ‌men‌ ‌in‌ ‌matrilineal‌ ‌societies‌ ‌also‌ ‌often‌ ‌reflect‌ ‌the‌ ‌importance‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌mother's‌ ‌brother.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nCognatic‌ ‌Descent‌ ‌\n●At‌ ‌least‌ ‌40%‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌societies‌ ‌around‌ ‌the‌ ‌world‌ ‌today‌ ‌trace‌ ‌descent‌ ‌through‌ ‌both‌ ‌the‌ ‌mother's‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌father's‌ ‌ancestors‌ ‌to‌ ‌some‌ ‌degree‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌follow‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌several‌ ‌‌nonunilineal‌ ‌or‌ ‌cognatic‌ ‌descent‌ ‌‌principles.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌result‌ ‌is‌ ‌usually‌ ‌more‌ ‌varied‌ ‌and‌ ‌complex‌ ‌family‌ ‌systems‌ ‌than‌ ‌are‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌societies‌ ‌with‌ ‌patrilineal‌ ‌or‌ ‌matrilineal‌ ‌descent‌ ‌patterns.‌ ‌\nCognatic‌ ‌descent‌ ‌is‌ ‌known‌ ‌to‌ ‌occur‌ ‌in‌ ‌four‌ ‌variations:‌ ‌\n○Bilineal‌ ‌Descent‌ ‌\n■When‌ ‌both‌ ‌patrilineal‌ ‌and‌ ‌matrilineal‌ ‌descent‌ ‌principles‌ ‌are‌ ‌combined,‌ ‌the‌ ‌result‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌bilineal,‌ ‌or‌ ‌double,‌ ‌descent‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌\nshown‌ ‌below.‌ ‌With‌ ‌this‌ ‌rare‌ ‌hybrid‌ ‌system,‌ ‌every‌ ‌individual‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌member‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌or‌ ‌her‌ ‌mother's‌ ‌matrilineage‌ ‌and‌ ‌father's‌ ‌\npatrilineage.‌ ‌\n467‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n■As‌ ‌a‌ ‌result,‌ ‌everyone,‌ ‌except‌ ‌siblings,‌ ‌potentially‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌unique‌ ‌combination‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌unilineal‌ ‌family‌ ‌lines,‌ ‌as‌ ‌shown‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌\ndiagram‌ ‌below.‌ ‌Note‌ ‌that‌ ‌parents‌ ‌only‌ ‌share‌ ‌either‌ ‌their‌ ‌children's‌ ‌matrilineal‌ ‌line‌ ‌or‌ ‌patrilineal‌ ‌line‌ ‌of‌ ‌descent.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○Parallel‌ ‌Descent‌ ‌\n■A‌ ‌similarly‌ ‌rare‌ ‌combination‌ ‌of‌ ‌unilineal‌ ‌descent‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌is‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌parallel‌ ‌click‌ ‌this‌ ‌icon‌ ‌to‌ ‌hear‌ ‌the‌ ‌preceding‌ ‌term‌ ‌\npronounced‌ ‌descent.‌ ‌With‌ ‌this‌ ‌system,‌ ‌men‌ ‌trace‌ ‌their‌ ‌ancestry‌ ‌through‌ ‌male‌ ‌lines‌ ‌and‌ ‌women‌ ‌trace‌ ‌theirs‌ ‌through‌ ‌female‌ ‌\nlines.‌ ‌Unlike‌ ‌bilineal‌ ‌descent,‌ ‌each‌ ‌individual‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌member‌ ‌of‌ ‌only‌ ‌one‌ ‌descent‌ ‌group.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n468‌ ‌\n■Example:‌ ‌‌Samoans‌ ‌of‌ ‌South‌ ‌Pacific‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n○Ambilineal‌ ‌Descent‌ ‌\n■Ambilineal‌ ‌descent‌ ‌is‌ ‌still‌ ‌another‌ ‌unusual‌ ‌descent‌ ‌system‌ ‌that,‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌sense,‌ ‌combines‌ ‌unilineal‌ ‌patterns.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Descent‌ ‌from‌ ‌either‌ ‌males‌ ‌or‌ ‌females‌ ‌is‌ ‌recognized,‌ ‌but‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌may‌ ‌select‌ ‌only‌ ‌one‌ ‌line‌ ‌to‌ ‌trace‌ ‌descent.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Since‌ ‌each‌ ‌generation‌ ‌can‌ ‌choose‌ ‌which‌ ‌parent‌ ‌to‌ ‌trace‌ ‌descent‌ ‌through,‌ ‌a‌ ‌family‌ ‌line‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌patrilineal‌ ‌in‌ ‌one‌ ‌generation‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌matrilineal‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌next.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○Bilateral‌ ‌Descent‌ ‌\n■Bilateral‌ ‌descent‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌cognatic‌ ‌system‌ ‌that‌ ‌traces‌ ‌descent‌ ‌from‌ ‌all‌ ‌biological‌ ‌ancestors‌ ‌regardless‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌gender‌ ‌and‌ ‌side‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌family.‌ ‌ ‌\n■In‌ ‌addition,‌ ‌all‌ ‌male‌ ‌and‌ ‌female‌ ‌children‌ ‌are‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌both‌ ‌their‌ ‌father's‌ ‌and‌ ‌mother's‌ ‌families.‌ ‌Everyone‌ ‌shown‌ ‌in‌ ‌red‌ ‌\nbelow‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌bilateral‌ ‌relative‌ ‌of‌ ‌ego.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n■In‌ ‌some‌ ‌societies‌ ‌that‌ ‌use‌ ‌bilateral‌ ‌descent,‌ ‌the‌ ‌non-red‌ ‌people‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌diagram‌ ‌may‌ ‌also‌ ‌be‌ ‌considered‌ ‌relatives.‌ ‌However,‌ ‌\nthis‌ ‌is‌ ‌often‌ ‌a‌ ‌matter‌ ‌of‌ ‌individual‌ ‌choice.‌  ‌In‌ ‌North‌ ‌America,‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to‌ ‌as‌ ‌in-laws‌ ‌and‌ ‌are‌ ‌generally‌ ‌considered‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌\nmore‌ ‌distant‌ ‌kinsmen.‌ ‌ ‌\n469‌ ‌\n■While‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌inherent‌ ‌gender‌ ‌bias‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌bilateral‌ ‌descent‌ ‌principle,‌ ‌there‌ ‌often‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌slight‌ ‌male‌ ‌bias‌ ‌in‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌practices‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌creation‌ ‌of‌ ‌families.‌  ‌This‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌seen‌ ‌in‌ ‌India‌ ‌today‌ ‌when‌ ‌a‌ ‌man's‌ ‌last‌ ‌name‌ ‌is‌ ‌used‌ ‌by‌ ‌his‌ ‌wife‌ ‌and‌ ‌children.‌ ‌\nWith‌ ‌this‌ ‌exception,‌ ‌however,‌ ‌there‌ ‌usually‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌other‌ ‌similarity‌ ‌with‌ ‌patrilineal‌ ‌descent.‌ ‌\n■Bilateral‌ ‌descent‌ ‌is‌ ‌rare‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌societies‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌world‌,‌ ‌though,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌common‌ ‌if‌ ‌you‌ ‌count‌ ‌people‌ ‌instead‌ ‌of‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌is‌ ‌characteristic‌ ‌of‌ ‌large‌ ‌agricultural‌ ‌and‌ ‌industrial‌ ‌nations‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌hunters‌ ‌and‌ ‌gatherers‌ ‌in‌ ‌harsh,‌ ‌relatively‌ ‌non‌ ‌\nproductive‌ ‌environments‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌deserts‌ ‌and‌ ‌arctic‌ ‌wastelands.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌found‌ ‌among‌ ‌some‌ ‌transhumance‌ ‌pastoralists‌ ‌\nliving‌ ‌in‌ ‌poor‌ ‌environments.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nForms‌ ‌of‌ ‌descent‌ ‌groups‌ ‌(lineage,‌ ‌clan,‌ ‌phratry,‌ ‌moiety‌ ‌and‌ ‌kindred);‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nIn‌ ‌all‌ ‌societies‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌social‌ ‌groups‌ ‌whose‌ ‌membership‌ ‌is‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌descent;‌ ‌members‌ ‌share‌ ‌a‌ ‌common‌ ‌ancestor‌ ‌or‌ ‌living‌ ‌relative.‌ ‌Descent‌ ‌\ngroups‌ ‌help‌ ‌to‌ ‌define‌ ‌the‌ ‌pool‌ ‌of‌ ‌potential‌ ‌mates,‌ ‌the‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌people‌ ‌who‌ ‌are‌ ‌obligated‌ ‌to‌ ‌help‌ ‌in‌ ‌economic‌ ‌and‌ ‌political‌ ‌issues,‌ ‌and‌ ‌may‌ ‌even‌ ‌\ndictate‌ ‌which‌ ‌religion‌ ‌is‌ ‌followed,‌ ‌particularly‌ ‌in‌ ‌unilineal‌ ‌descent‌ ‌groups.‌ ‌\n ‌\nDemonstrated‌ ‌and‌ ‌Stipulated‌ ‌Descent:‌ ‌ ‌\n●Demonstrated‌ ‌Descent:‌‌ ‌Descent‌ ‌is‌ ‌traced‌ ‌through‌ ‌all‌ ‌linking‌ ‌males/females‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌ancestor.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Stipulated‌ ‌descent:‌‌ ‌Descent‌ ‌from‌ ‌ancestor‌ ‌is‌ ‌assumed‌ ‌and‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌be‌ ‌traced‌ ‌through‌ ‌linking‌ ‌kin.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n470‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Lineages‌:‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌lineage‌ ‌is‌ ‌usually‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌smallest‌ ‌group‌ ‌with‌ ‌corporate‌ ‌functions‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌culture‌ ‌with‌ ‌unilineal‌ ‌descent.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Members‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌lineage‌ ‌can‌ ‌trace‌ ‌their‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌through‌ ‌males‌ ‌(in‌ ‌a‌ ‌patrilineal‌ ‌system)‌ ‌or‌ ‌through‌ ‌females‌ ‌(in‌ ‌a‌ ‌matrilineal‌ ‌system)‌ ‌\nback‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌common‌ ‌male‌ ‌or‌ ‌female‌ ‌ancestor.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Most‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌are‌ ‌only‌ ‌able‌ ‌to‌ ‌do‌ ‌this‌ ‌back‌ ‌perhaps‌ ‌four‌ ‌or‌ ‌five‌ ‌generations.‌ ‌If‌ ‌they‌ ‌believe‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌related,‌ ‌but‌ ‌can‌ ‌not‌ ‌actually‌ ‌trace‌ ‌\ntheir‌ ‌relationship,‌ ‌then‌ ‌the‌ ‌resulting‌ ‌groups‌ ‌are‌ ‌called‌ ‌clans.‌ ‌Normally,‌ ‌several‌ ‌lineages‌ ‌would‌ ‌be‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌clan,‌ ‌as‌ ‌depicted‌ ‌graphically‌ ‌\n471‌ ‌\nbelow:‌ ‌\n ‌\n○Lineage‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌‌exogamous‌ ‌unit‌.‌ ‌Ancestors‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌lineage‌ ‌is‌ ‌never‌ ‌a‌ ‌mythological‌ ‌all‌ ‌legendary‌ ‌figure‌ ‌and‌ ‌his‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nmember‌ ‌is‌ ‌clearly‌ ‌established.‌ ‌E.g.Patrilineage,‌ ‌Matrilineage.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Clans‌ ‌ ‌\n○are‌ ‌groups‌ ‌who‌ ‌acknowledge‌ ‌a‌ ‌common‌ ‌ancestor‌ ‌but‌ ‌the‌ ‌exact‌ ‌genealogy‌ ‌might‌ ‌not‌ ‌be‌ ‌remembered.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Oftentimes,‌ ‌the‌ ‌ancestor‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌so‌ ‌far‌ ‌back‌ ‌in‌ ‌time‌ ‌that‌ ‌history‌ ‌becomes‌ ‌distorted‌ ‌so‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌ancestor‌ ‌takes‌ ‌on‌ ‌heroic‌ ‌proportions.‌ ‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌instance,‌ ‌‌Native‌ ‌American‌ ‌groups‌ ‌have‌ ‌clans,‌ ‌an‌ ‌ancient‌ ‌lineage‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌often‌ ‌just‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to‌ ‌as‌ ‌an‌ ‌animal‌ ‌‌(wolf,‌ ‌raven).‌ ‌ ‌\n○Clans‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌quite‌ ‌big,‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌large‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌people.‌ ‌\n○Clans‌ ‌are‌ ‌therefore‌ ‌unilineal‌ ‌descent‌ ‌groups.‌ ‌Clans‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌either‌ ‌patriclans,‌ ‌in‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌with‌ ‌patrilineal‌ ‌descent,‌ ‌or‌ ‌matriclans,‌ ‌in‌ ‌\ncultures‌ ‌with‌ ‌matrilineal‌ ‌descent.‌ ‌In‌ ‌the‌ ‌Yanomamo,‌ ‌lineages‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌largest‌ ‌kin‌ ‌group;‌ ‌in‌ ‌both‌ ‌the‌ ‌Nuer‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌traditional‌ ‌Hmong,‌ ‌it‌ ‌\nis‌ ‌the‌ ‌clan.‌ ‌\n○Clans,‌ ‌like‌ ‌lineages,‌ ‌are‌ ‌exogamous,‌ ‌and‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌patrilineal‌ ‌system,‌‌ ‌everyone‌ ‌takes‌ ‌their‌ ‌clan‌ ‌from‌ ‌their‌ ‌father.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Clan‌ ‌members‌ ‌do‌ ‌consider‌ ‌themselves‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌related,‌ ‌even‌ ‌though‌ ‌they‌ ‌can‌ ‌not‌ ‌precisely‌ ‌trace‌ ‌how.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Clans‌ ‌are‌ ‌often‌ ‌named‌ ‌(as‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Hmong)‌ ‌and‌ ‌sometimes‌ ‌the‌ ‌common‌ ‌clan‌ ‌ancestor‌ ‌is‌ ‌partly‌ ‌mythical‌ ‌and/or‌ ‌supernatural.‌ ‌Clans‌ ‌\nmay‌ ‌have‌ ‌corporate‌ ‌functions‌ ‌in‌ ‌some‌ ‌cultures,‌ ‌including‌ ‌settling‌ ‌disputes,‌ ‌owning‌ ‌property,‌ ‌and‌ ‌organizing‌ ‌the‌ ‌clan‌ ‌to‌ ‌support‌ ‌its‌ ‌\nmembers.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Phratries‌ ‌‌are‌ ‌groups‌ ‌of‌ ‌clans‌ ‌(at‌ ‌least‌ ‌three‌ ‌clans)‌ ‌who‌ ‌are‌ ‌believed‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌related‌ ‌by‌ ‌kinship.‌ ‌There‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌usually‌ ‌economic‌ ‌ties‌ ‌between‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌clans.‌ ‌ ‌\n472‌ ‌\n●Members‌ ‌of‌ ‌Phratry‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌able‌ ‌to‌ ‌demonstrate‌ ‌their‌ ‌genealogical‌ ‌link‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌common‌ ‌ancestor‌ ‌though‌ ‌they‌ ‌strongly‌ ‌believe‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌\ncommon‌ ‌ancestor.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌will‌ ‌or‌ ‌may‌ ‌not‌ ‌be‌ ‌exogamous.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Phratries‌ ‌are‌ ‌also‌ ‌large‌ ‌groups‌ ‌based‌ ‌upon‌ ‌unilineal‌ ‌descent,‌ ‌each‌ ‌consisting‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌or‌ ‌more‌ ‌clans.‌ ‌ ‌\n●With‌ ‌phratries‌ ‌however,‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌two‌ ‌such‌ ‌large‌ ‌groups‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌culture,‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌difference‌ ‌between‌ ‌phratries‌ ‌and‌ ‌moieties.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Moieties‌‌ ‌are‌ ‌also‌ ‌linked‌ ‌clans;‌ ‌however,‌ ‌in‌ ‌this‌ ‌case,‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌only‌ ‌two‌ ‌clans‌ ‌involved.‌ ‌ ‌\n●There‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌economic‌ ‌ties‌ ‌between‌ ‌moieties.Moieties‌ ‌like‌ ‌clans‌ ‌are‌ ‌exogamous,‌ ‌and‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌patrilineal‌ ‌system‌ ‌Ego‌ ‌would‌ ‌take‌ ‌his‌ ‌moiety‌ ‌\nfrom‌ ‌his‌ ‌father.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Since‌ ‌moieties‌ ‌are‌ ‌exogamous,‌ ‌and‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌only‌ ‌two‌ ‌such‌ ‌groups‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌culture,‌ ‌everyone‌ ‌in‌ ‌moiety‌ ‌1‌ ‌must‌ ‌take‌ ‌their‌ ‌spouse‌ ‌from‌ ‌moiety‌ ‌\n2,‌ ‌and‌ ‌vice‌ ‌versa.‌ ‌In‌ ‌this‌ ‌way,‌ ‌everyone‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌either‌ ‌close‌ ‌kin‌ ‌(in‌ ‌your‌ ‌moiety)‌ ‌or‌ ‌a‌ ‌potential‌ ‌spouse‌ ‌or‌ ‌in-law.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌moiety‌ ‌system‌ ‌(not‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌any‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌we‌ ‌are‌ ‌looking‌ ‌at)‌ ‌is‌ ‌thus‌ ‌an‌ ‌ingenious‌ ‌way‌ ‌to‌ ‌encourage‌ ‌appropriate‌ ‌social‌ ‌behavior‌ ‌\nbetween‌ ‌individuals,‌ ‌and‌ ‌thus‌ ‌maintain‌ ‌social‌ ‌control.‌ ‌(Incidentally,‌ ‌Ego's‌ ‌cross‌ ‌cousins‌ ‌would‌ ‌not‌ ‌only‌ ‌be‌ ‌outside‌ ‌his‌ ‌lineage,‌ ‌but‌ ‌also‌ ‌his‌ ‌\nclan‌ ‌and‌ ‌his‌ ‌moiety!‌ ‌Hence‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌always‌ ‌available‌ ‌for‌ ‌marriage.)‌ ‌\n473‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Tribe‌‌ ‌Is‌ ‌unilineal‌ ‌endogamous‌ ‌Descent‌ ‌group.‌ ‌It‌ ‌consists‌ ‌of‌ ‌several‌ ‌bands/‌ ‌lineage/‌ ‌Clan.‌ ‌\n ‌the‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌tribe‌ ‌claim‌ ‌Descent‌ ‌from‌ ‌a‌ ‌common‌ ‌ancestor.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nNon-Unilineal‌ ‌Descent‌ ‌Groups‌ ‌\n○There‌ ‌is‌‌ ‌only‌ ‌one‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌non-unilineal‌ ‌descent‌ ‌group,‌‌ ‌‌the‌ ‌kindred.‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌ephemeral‌ ‌grouping‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌neither‌ ‌permanent‌ ‌nor‌ ‌a‌ ‌continuing‌ ‌one‌ ‌through‌ ‌generations‌ ‌in‌ ‌any‌ ‌fixed‌ ‌pattern.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Kindreds‌ ‌count‌ ‌all‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌from‌ ‌each‌ ‌parent‌ ‌as‌ ‌relatives.‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌reckoning‌ ‌of‌ ‌kindred‌ ‌changes‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual‌ ‌who‌ ‌reckons‌ ‌his/her‌ ‌circle‌ ‌of‌ ‌relatives.‌ ‌\n474‌ ‌\n■This‌ ‌is‌ ‌because‌ ‌the‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌any‌ ‌particular‌ ‌kindred‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌have‌ ‌nor‌ ‌reckon‌ ‌an‌ ‌ancestor‌ ‌in‌ ‌common‌ ‌to‌ ‌all‌ ‌of‌ ‌them‌ ‌instead‌ ‌\nwhat‌ ‌they‌ ‌all‌ ‌have‌ ‌or‌ ‌recognize‌ ‌in‌ ‌common‌ ‌is‌ ‌ego.‌ ‌\n■Every‌ ‌individual‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌society‌ ‌has‌ ‌a‌ ‌kindred‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌kindred‌ ‌of‌ ‌each‌ ‌individual‌ ‌will‌ ‌overlap‌ ‌with‌ ‌his/her‌ ‌next‌ ‌of‌ ‌kin‌ ‌\n■No‌ ‌kindred‌ ‌is‌ ‌common‌ ‌for‌ ‌any‌ ‌two‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌besides‌ ‌siblings.‌ ‌\n■A‌ ‌kindred‌ ‌is‌ ‌thus‌ ‌not‌ ‌ancestor-focused‌ ‌but‌ ‌ego-centred.‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌kind‌ ‌of‌ ‌descent‌ ‌group‌ ‌is‌ ‌usually‌ ‌seen‌ ‌where‌ ‌small‌ ‌family‌ ‌groups‌ ‌are‌ ‌more‌ ‌adaptive‌ ‌than‌ ‌large‌ ‌ones‌ ‌and‌ ‌individual‌ ‌mobility‌ ‌is‌ ‌high,‌ ‌e.g.,‌ ‌\nindustrial‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌Often,‌ ‌kindreds‌ ‌fall‌ ‌apart‌ ‌when‌ ‌the‌ ‌unifying‌ ‌individual‌ ‌dies.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n475‌ ‌\n2.5‌ ‌Kinship‌ ‌terminology‌ ‌(descriptive‌ ‌and‌ ‌classificatory);‌ ‌Descent,‌ ‌Filiation‌ ‌and‌ ‌Complementary‌ ‌Filiation;Descent‌ ‌and‌ ‌Alliance-Part-II‌ ‌\n‌ ‌\n ‌\nKinship‌ ‌terminology‌ ‌(descriptive‌ ‌and‌ ‌classificatory);‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nBackground‌ ‌\n ‌\n●In‌ ‌every‌ ‌society,‌ ‌people‌ ‌make‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌special‌ ‌terms/names‌ ‌to‌ ‌differentiate‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌different‌ ‌kins.‌ ‌E.g.‌ ‌terms‌ ‌like‌ ‌father,‌ ‌mother,‌ ‌uncle,‌ ‌\naunt,‌ ‌brother,‌ ‌sister,‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌terms‌ ‌in‌ ‌social‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌are‌ ‌termed‌ ‌as‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌terminology.‌ ‌In‌ ‌other‌ ‌words,‌ ‌these‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌terminologies‌ ‌classify‌ ‌our‌ ‌relatives‌ ‌and‌ ‌\ntheir‌ ‌relationships.‌ ‌\n●Kinship‌ ‌terminologies‌ ‌include‌ ‌the‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌address‌ ‌used‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌languages‌ ‌or‌ ‌communities‌ ‌for‌ ‌different‌ ‌relatives‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nreference‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌identify‌ ‌the‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌relatives‌ ‌to‌ ‌ego‌ ‌or‌ ‌to‌ ‌each‌ ‌other.‌ ‌\n●Societies‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌parts‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌world‌ ‌and‌ ‌using‌ ‌different‌ ‌languages‌ ‌may‌ ‌share‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌basic‌ ‌terminology‌ ‌patterns;‌ ‌in‌ ‌such‌ ‌cases‌ ‌one‌ ‌can‌ ‌\nvery‌ ‌easily‌ ‌translate‌ ‌the‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌one‌ ‌language‌ ‌into‌ ‌another,‌ ‌although‌ ‌connotations‌ ‌may‌ ‌vary.‌ ‌ ‌\n●But‌ ‌translators‌ ‌usually‌ ‌find‌ ‌it‌ ‌impossible‌ ‌to‌ ‌translate‌ ‌directly‌ ‌the‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌society‌ ‌that‌ ‌uses‌ ‌one‌ ‌system‌ ‌into‌ ‌the‌ ‌language‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nsociety‌ ‌that‌ ‌uses‌ ‌a‌ ‌different‌ ‌system.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n476‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Kinship‌ ‌terms‌ ‌are‌ ‌label‌ ‌name‌ ‌or‌ ‌designation‌ ‌applied‌ ‌to‌ ‌relatives.‌ ‌it‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌classified‌ ‌into‌ ‌three‌ ‌different‌ ‌types:‌ ‌\n○Classification‌ ‌by‌ ‌linguistic‌ ‌structure‌ ‌\n○Classification‌ ‌by‌ ‌mode‌ ‌of‌ ‌use‌ ‌\n○Classification‌ ‌by‌ ‌range‌ ‌of‌ ‌application‌ ‌\n ‌\nClassification‌ ‌by‌ ‌linguistic‌ ‌structure‌ ‌\n ‌\n●As‌ ‌per,‌ ‌Linguistic‌ ‌structure‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌terms‌ ‌are‌ ‌classified‌ ‌as‌ ‌Elementary,‌ ‌Derivative‌ ‌and‌ ‌Descriptive‌ ‌type:‌ ‌ ‌\n477‌ ‌\n○Elementary‌ ‌term‌ ‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌c‌onsists‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌irreducible‌ ‌word.‌ ‌For‌ ‌example‌ ‌'father'‌ ‌or‌ ‌'mother'.‌ ‌\n○Derivative‌ ‌term‌ ‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌compound‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌elementary‌ ‌term‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌lexicon.‌ ‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌is‌ ‌similar‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌English‌ ‌words‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌grandfather,‌ ‌sister-in-law,‌ ‌stepson,‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌ ‌\n■In‌ ‌the‌ ‌term‌ ‌'grandfather',‌ ‌'father'‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌elementary‌ ‌term‌ ‌and‌ ‌'grand'‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌lexicon‌ ‌without‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌meaning.‌ ‌ ‌\n■But‌ ‌when‌ ‌'grand'‌ ‌and‌ ‌'father'‌ ‌is‌ ‌combined,‌ ‌it‌ ‌gives‌ ‌a‌ ‌meaning.‌ ‌\n○Descriptive‌ ‌term‌ ‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌is‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌specify‌ ‌or‌ ‌describe‌ ‌the‌ ‌person's‌ ‌direct‌ ‌blood‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌person‌ ‌being‌ ‌addressed.‌ ‌\n■e.g.‌ ‌when‌ ‌I‌ ‌say‌ ‌my‌ ‌father,‌ ‌my‌ ‌mother,‌ ‌then‌ ‌I‌ ‌am‌ ‌talking‌ ‌about‌ ‌my‌ ‌biological‌ ‌parents‌ ‌and‌ ‌no‌ ‌one‌ ‌else.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Therefore,‌ ‌the‌ ‌two‌ ‌terms‌ ‌father‌ ‌and‌ ‌mother‌ ‌are‌ ‌descriptive‌ ‌terminologies.‌ ‌Some‌ ‌of‌ ‌its‌ ‌characteristic‌ ‌features‌ ‌are‌ ‌\n1.‌ ‌These‌ ‌terms‌ ‌refer‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌blood‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌person.‌ ‌\n2.‌ ‌These‌ ‌terms‌ ‌keep‌ ‌the‌ ‌collateral‌ ‌lines‌ ‌clear‌ ‌and‌ ‌distinct‌ ‌from‌ ‌each‌ ‌other.‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌is‌ ‌like‌ ‌Swedish‌ ‌word‌ ‌'farbror'‌ ‌(father's‌ ‌brother)‌ ‌which‌ ‌combines‌ ‌two‌ ‌or‌ ‌more‌ ‌elementary‌ ‌terms‌ ‌to‌ ‌denote‌ ‌a‌ ‌specific‌ ‌relative.‌ ‌\n'Ammamma'‌ ‌and‌ ‌'Achchachan'‌ ‌in‌ ‌Malayalam‌ ‌are‌ ‌some‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌examples‌ ‌of‌ ‌descriptive‌ ‌terms.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nClassification‌ ‌by‌ ‌mode‌ ‌of‌ ‌use‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌mode‌ ‌of‌ ‌use,‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌terms‌ ‌are‌ ‌classified‌ ‌into‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌address‌ ‌and‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌reference.‌ ‌\n○Term‌ ‌of‌ ‌address‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌is‌ ‌used,to‌ ‌call‌ ‌someone‌ ‌directly.‌ ‌Example‌ ‌Atta‌ ‌in‌ ‌Telugu;‌ ‌Amma‌ ‌in‌ ‌Tamil/Malayalam‌ ‌\n○Term‌ ‌of‌ ‌reference‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌is‌ ‌how‌ ‌you‌ ‌address‌ ‌someone‌ ‌when‌ ‌talking‌ ‌about‌ ‌them.‌ ‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌is‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌designate‌ ‌a‌ ‌relative‌ ‌in‌ ‌speaking‌ ‌about‌ ‌the‌ ‌person‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌third‌ ‌person.‌ ‌ ‌\n■For‌ ‌Example,‌ ‌in‌ ‌traditional‌ ‌Kerala‌ ‌society,‌ ‌some‌ ‌women‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌refer‌ ‌to‌ ‌their‌ ‌husbands‌ ‌in‌ ‌third‌ ‌person‌ ‌as‌ ‌'the‌ ‌father‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nchildren'‌ ‌instead‌ ‌of‌ ‌using‌ ‌'husband'.‌ ‌ ‌\n■In‌ ‌Telugu,‌ ‌father's‌ ‌sister‌ ‌is‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to‌ ‌as‌ ‌'Menatta'‌ ‌but‌ ‌addressed‌ ‌as‌ ‌'Atta'.‌ ‌\n ‌\nClassification‌ ‌by‌ ‌range‌ ‌of‌ ‌application‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌range‌ ‌of‌ ‌application,‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌terms‌ ‌are‌ ‌classified‌ ‌into‌ ‌Denotative‌ ‌and‌ ‌Classificatory‌ ‌terms.‌ ‌\n○Denotative‌ ‌term‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌denotes‌ ‌only‌ ‌one‌ ‌category‌ ‌of‌ ‌kins.‌ ‌ ‌\n■For‌ ‌example‌ ‌in‌ ‌English,‌ ‌father,‌ ‌mother,‌ ‌husband‌ ‌and‌ ‌wife‌ ‌are‌ ‌denotative‌ ‌terms‌ ‌as‌ ‌they‌ ‌denote‌ ‌a‌ ‌single‌ ‌relationship.‌ ‌\n○Classificatory‌ ‌term‌ ‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌is‌ ‌one‌ ‌that‌ ‌applies‌ ‌to‌ ‌two‌ ‌or‌ ‌more‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌categories.‌ ‌ ‌\n478‌ ‌\n■Terms‌ ‌like‌ ‌an‌ ‌aunt,‌ ‌uncle‌ ‌or‌ ‌brother,‌ ‌sister,‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌refer‌ ‌to‌ ‌persons‌ ‌who‌ ‌stand‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌e.g.‌ ‌when‌ ‌I‌ ‌say‌ ‌'uncle'‌ ‌it‌ ‌\nmay‌ ‌mean‌ ‌my‌ ‌father's‌ ‌brother,‌ ‌mother's‌ ‌brother‌ ‌or‌ ‌my‌ ‌father's‌ ‌friend,‌ ‌or‌ ‌even‌ ‌my‌ ‌aunt's‌ ‌husband.‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌term‌ ‌'uncle'‌ ‌is,‌ ‌therefore,‌ ‌a‌ ‌classificatory‌ ‌term.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Relationships‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌may‌ ‌vary‌ ‌from‌ ‌person‌ ‌to‌ ‌person‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌role‌ ‌and‌ ‌status‌ ‌they‌ ‌have‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌particular‌ ‌\nfamily.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Some‌ ‌relatives‌ ‌try‌ ‌to‌ ‌share‌ ‌lighter‌ ‌moments‌ ‌with‌ ‌each‌ ‌other,‌ ‌while‌ ‌they‌ ‌keep‌ ‌distance‌ ‌with‌ ‌some‌ ‌others.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Some‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌characteristic‌ ‌features‌ ‌are‌ ‌:‌ ‌\n1.‌ ‌The‌ ‌same‌ ‌term‌ ‌is‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌designate‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌one‌ ‌person‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌kin‌ ‌relations.‌ ‌\n2.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌method‌ ‌of‌ ‌dividing‌ ‌the‌ ‌kins‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌social‌ ‌relations‌ ‌and‌ ‌not‌ ‌always‌ ‌blood‌ ‌relations.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nSix‌ ‌basic‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌of‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌terminologies:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Hawaiian‌ ‌kinship:‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌least‌ ‌complex‌ ‌classificatory‌;‌ ‌‌only‌ ‌distinguishes‌ ‌between‌ ‌sex‌ ‌and‌ ‌generation‌.‌ ‌\n○Thus,‌ ‌siblings‌ ‌and‌ ‌cousins‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌distinguished‌ ‌(the‌ ‌same‌ ‌terms‌ ‌are‌ ‌used‌ ‌for‌ ‌both‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌relatives).‌ ‌ ‌\n○All‌ ‌relatives‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌sex‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌generation‌ ‌are‌ ‌reffered‌ ‌by‌ ‌same‌ ‌term.‌\n ‌\n○The‌ ‌Hawaiian‌ ‌terminological‌ ‌system‌ ‌is‌ ‌used‌ ‌by‌ ‌about‌ ‌a‌ ‌third‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌world's‌ ‌societies,‌ ‌though‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌relatively‌ ‌small‌ ‌ones.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌found‌ ‌widely‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌islands‌ ‌of‌ ‌Polynesia‌ ‌where‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌usually‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌ambilineal‌ ‌descent.‌ ‌ ‌\n479‌ ‌\n○Since‌ ‌both‌ ‌sides‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌are‌ ‌treated‌ ‌equally,‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual's‌ ‌choice‌ ‌of‌ ‌ancestral‌ ‌line‌ ‌to‌ ‌trace‌ ‌is‌ ‌less‌ ‌biased.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Sudanese‌ ‌kinship:‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌most‌ ‌descriptive‌;‌ ‌‌no‌ ‌two‌ ‌relatives‌ ‌share‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌term‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○At‌ ‌the‌ ‌opposite‌ ‌extreme‌ ‌in‌ ‌complexity‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌Sudanese‌ ‌system.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Most‌ ‌kinsmen‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌lumped‌ ‌together‌ ‌under‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌reference.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Each‌ ‌category‌ ‌of‌ ‌relative‌ ‌is‌ ‌given‌ ‌a‌ ‌distinct‌ ‌term‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌genealogical‌ ‌distance‌ ‌from‌ ‌ego‌ ‌and‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌side‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family.‌ ‌ ‌\n○There‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌eight‌ ‌different‌ ‌cousin‌ ‌terms,‌ ‌all‌ ‌of‌ ‌whom‌ ‌are‌ ‌distinguished‌ ‌from‌ ‌ego's‌ ‌brother‌ ‌and‌ ‌sister.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○The‌ ‌‌Sudanese‌ ‌system‌ ‌is‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌Sudan,‌ ‌Turkey,‌ ‌and‌ ‌some‌ ‌other‌ ‌societies‌ ‌with‌ ‌patrilineal‌ ‌descent‌ ‌and‌ ‌considerable‌ ‌social‌ ‌\ncomplexity.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌fine‌ ‌distinctions‌ ‌made‌ ‌between‌ ‌kinsmen‌ ‌mirrors‌ ‌the‌ ‌society's‌ ‌desire‌ ‌to‌ ‌distinguish‌ ‌people‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌class,‌ ‌occupation,‌ ‌and‌ ‌\npolitical‌ ‌power.‌ ‌\n ‌\n480‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Eskimo:‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌has‌ ‌both‌ ‌classificatory‌ ‌and‌ ‌descriptive‌ ‌terms‌;‌ ‌‌in‌ ‌addition‌ ‌to‌ ‌sex‌ ‌and‌ ‌generation,‌ ‌also‌ ‌distinguishes‌ ‌between‌ ‌lineal‌ ‌relatives‌ ‌\n(those‌ ‌related‌ ‌directly‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌line‌ ‌of‌ ‌descent)‌ ‌and‌ ‌collateral‌ ‌relatives‌ ‌(those‌ ‌related‌ ‌by‌ ‌blood,‌ ‌but‌ ‌not‌ ‌directly‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌line‌ ‌of‌ ‌\ndescent)‌.‌ ‌\n○Lineal‌ ‌relatives‌ ‌have‌ ‌highly‌ ‌descriptive‌ ‌terms,‌ ‌collateral‌ ‌relatives‌ ‌have‌ ‌highly‌ ‌classificatory‌ ‌terms.‌ ‌\n○Within‌ ‌the‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌family‌ ‌all‌ ‌kingsman‌ ‌have‌ ‌distinctive‌ ‌titles.‌ ‌\n○Other‌ ‌than‌ ‌ones‌ ‌own‌ ‌siblings,‌ ‌all‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌in‌ ‌one‌ ‌own‌ ‌generation‌ ‌are‌ ‌addressed‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌term‌ ‌without‌ ‌gender‌ ‌\ndifferentiation.‌ ‌\n○Aunts‌ ‌and‌ ‌uncles‌ ‌are‌ ‌distinguished‌ ‌from‌ ‌parents‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Eskimo‌ ‌system‌ ‌and‌ ‌separated‌ ‌only‌ ‌by‌ ‌gender.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌spouses‌ ‌of‌ ‌aunts‌ ‌and‌ ‌uncles‌ ‌may‌ ‌also‌ ‌be‌ ‌given‌ ‌these‌ ‌kin‌ ‌terms.‌ ‌All‌ ‌cousins‌ ‌are‌ ‌lumped‌ ‌together.‌ ‌ ‌\n○No‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌distinction‌ ‌is‌ ‌made‌ ‌between‌ ‌uncles,‌ ‌aunts,‌ ‌and‌ ‌cousins‌ ‌with‌ ‌regard‌ ‌to‌ ‌side‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family.‌ ‌ ‌\n481‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌instance,‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌kin‌ ‌term‌ ‌for‌ ‌aunts‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌mother's‌ ‌side‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌in‌ ‌contrast‌ ‌to‌ ‌those‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌father's‌ ‌side--they‌ ‌are‌ ‌all‌ ‌\ncalled‌ ‌aunt.‌ ‌\n ‌\n○The‌ ‌Eskimo‌ ‌kin‌ ‌naming‌ ‌system‌ ‌is‌ ‌found‌ ‌mainly‌ ‌in‌ ‌societies‌ ‌that‌ ‌use‌ ‌the‌ ‌bilateral‌ ‌principle‌ ‌of‌ ‌descent‌ ‌and‌ ‌that‌ ‌strongly‌ ‌emphasize‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nnuclear‌ ‌family‌ ‌over‌ ‌more‌ ‌distant‌ ‌kinsmen.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Both‌ ‌ego's‌ ‌mother's‌ ‌and‌ ‌father's‌ ‌collateral‌ ‌relatives‌ ‌are‌ ‌considered‌ ‌equally‌ ‌important.‌ ‌That‌ ‌is‌ ‌to‌ ‌say,‌ ‌no‌ ‌distinction‌ ‌is‌ ‌made‌ ‌between‌ ‌\nrelatives‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌mother's‌ ‌and‌ ‌father's‌ ‌side‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family.‌ ‌This‌ ‌is‌ ‌reflected‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌kin‌ ‌names.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Despite‌ ‌the‌ ‌fact‌ ‌that‌ ‌some‌ ‌relatives‌ ‌are‌ ‌lumped‌ ‌together‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌linguistic‌ ‌terms‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Eskimo‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌kin‌ ‌naming‌ ‌systems,‌ ‌\npeople‌ ‌do‌ ‌make‌ ‌distinctions‌ ‌between‌ ‌them‌ ‌as‌ ‌unique‌ ‌individuals.‌ ‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌instance,‌ ‌you‌ ‌would‌ ‌make‌ ‌a‌ ‌distinction‌ ‌between‌ ‌your‌ ‌uncle‌ ‌X‌ ‌and‌ ‌your‌ ‌uncle‌ ‌Y‌ ‌by‌ ‌using‌ ‌their‌ ‌first‌ ‌names‌ ‌along‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌\nterm.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌Eskimo‌ ‌system‌ ‌is‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌simplest,‌ ‌despite‌ ‌the‌ ‌fact‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌found‌ ‌among‌ ‌some‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌technologically‌ ‌complex‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌found‌ ‌among‌ ‌hunters‌ ‌and‌ ‌gatherers‌ ‌living‌ ‌in‌ ‌harsh‌ ‌environments,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌Inuit,‌ ‌or‌ ‌Eskimo.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌both‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌extremes,‌ ‌the‌ ‌common‌ ‌denominator‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌Eskimo‌ ‌kin‌ ‌naming‌ ‌system‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌economy‌ ‌that‌ ‌forces‌ ‌the‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌family‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌be‌ ‌mostly‌ ‌independent.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌Eskimo‌ ‌system‌ ‌is‌ ‌used‌ ‌today‌ ‌by‌ ‌about‌ ‌10%‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌world's‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌\n482‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Iroquois:‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌has‌ ‌both‌ ‌classificatory‌ ‌and‌ ‌descriptive‌ ‌terms;‌ ‌in‌ ‌addition‌ ‌to‌ ‌sex‌ ‌and‌ ‌generation,‌ ‌also‌ ‌distinguishes‌ ‌between‌ ‌siblings‌ ‌of‌ ‌opposite‌ ‌\nsexes‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌parental‌ ‌generation.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Siblings‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌sex‌ ‌class‌ ‌as‌ ‌blood‌ ‌relatives,‌ ‌but‌ ‌siblings‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌opposite‌ ‌sex‌ ‌count‌ ‌as‌ ‌relatives‌ ‌by‌ ‌marriage.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Ones‌ ‌own‌ ‌parents‌ ‌and‌ ‌maternal‌ ‌aunt‌ ‌and‌ ‌paternal‌ ‌aunt‌ ‌have‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌mother‌ ‌and‌ ‌father‌ ‌respectively.‌ ‌\n○Ones‌ ‌own‌ ‌siblings‌ ‌and‌ ‌parallel‌ ‌cousin‌ ‌have‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌term‌ ‌with‌ ‌gender‌ ‌difference.Cross‌ ‌cousin‌ ‌have‌ ‌same‌ ‌kinship.‌ ‌\n○ ‌The‌ ‌Other‌ ‌kinsman‌ ‌have‌ ‌different‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌term.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○The‌ ‌Iroquois‌ ‌system‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌either‌ ‌patrilineal‌ ‌or‌ ‌matrilineal‌ ‌and‌ ‌is‌ ‌usually‌ ‌not‌ ‌as‌ ‌strongly‌ ‌one‌ ‌or‌ ‌the‌ ‌other.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌Iroquois‌ ‌system‌ ‌lumps‌ ‌together‌ ‌parallel‌ ‌cousins‌ ‌from‌ ‌both‌ ‌sides‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌with‌ ‌siblings‌ ‌but‌ ‌distinguishes‌ ‌them‌ ‌by‌ ‌gender.‌ ‌ ‌\n○What‌ ‌sets‌ ‌the‌ ‌Iroquois‌ ‌system‌ ‌apart‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌fact‌ ‌that‌ ‌cross‌ ‌cousins‌ ‌are‌ ‌also‌ ‌lumped‌ ‌together‌ ‌and‌ ‌distinguished‌ ‌by‌ ‌gender.‌ ‌ ‌\n○ ‌The‌ ‌reason‌ ‌is‌ ‌that‌ ‌there‌ ‌usually‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌preference‌ ‌for‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌to‌ ‌cross‌ ‌cousins‌ ‌in‌ ‌societies‌ ‌that‌ ‌use‌ ‌the‌ ‌Iroquois‌ ‌system.‌ ‌\n483‌ ‌\n●Crow:‌ ‌ ‌\n○Like‌ ‌Iroquois,‌ ‌but‌ ‌further‌ ‌distinguishes‌ ‌between‌ ‌mother's‌ ‌side‌ ‌and‌ ‌father's‌ ‌side.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Relatives‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌mother's‌ ‌side‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌have‌ ‌more‌ ‌descriptive‌ ‌terms,‌ ‌and‌ ‌relatives‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌father's‌ ‌side‌ ‌have‌ ‌more‌ ‌classificatory‌ ‌\nterms.‌ ‌\n○An‌ ‌almost‌ ‌mirror‌ ‌image‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Omaha‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌matrilineally‌ ‌based‌ ‌Crow‌ ‌kin‌ ‌naming‌ ‌system.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Relatives‌ ‌are‌ ‌also‌ ‌lumped‌ ‌together‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌descent‌ ‌and‌ ‌gender.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Siblings‌ ‌and‌ ‌parallel‌ ‌cousins‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌gender‌ ‌are‌ ‌given‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌term‌ ‌of‌ ‌reference.‌ ‌Mother‌ ‌and‌ ‌mother's‌ ‌sister‌ ‌also‌ ‌have‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nsame‌
