‌kin‌ ‌term‌ ‌ ‌\n○Ones‌ ‌own‌ ‌sibling‌ ‌and‌ ‌parallel‌ ‌cousin‌ ‌have‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌term‌ ‌with‌ ‌gender‌ ‌difference.‌ ‌\n○ ‌Father's‌ ‌sister‌ ‌and‌ ‌father's‌ ‌sister's‌ ‌daughter‌ ‌have‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌term.‌ ‌\n○ ‌Father’s‌ ‌brother‌ ‌and‌ ‌father’s‌ ‌sister’s‌ ‌sun‌ ‌have‌ ‌same‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌term.‌ ‌All‌ ‌other‌ ‌kinsmen‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌distinctive‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌term.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Omaha:‌ ‌ ‌\n○like‌ ‌Iroquois,‌ ‌but‌ ‌further‌ ‌distinguishes‌ ‌between‌ ‌mother's‌ ‌side‌ ‌and‌ ‌father's‌ ‌side.‌ ‌Relatives‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌mother's‌ ‌side‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌have‌ ‌\nmore‌ ‌classificatory‌ ‌terms,‌ ‌and‌ ‌relatives‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌father's‌ ‌side‌ ‌have‌ ‌more‌ ‌descriptive‌ ‌terms.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌Omaha‌ ‌kin‌ ‌naming‌ ‌system‌ ‌is‌ ‌characteristic‌ ‌of‌ ‌societies‌ ‌that‌ ‌use‌ ‌patrilineal‌ ‌descent.‌ ‌Relatives‌ ‌are‌ ‌lumped‌ ‌together‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌descent‌ ‌and‌ ‌gender.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Siblings‌ ‌and‌ ‌parallel‌ ‌cousins‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌gender‌ ‌are‌ ‌given‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌term‌ ‌of‌ ‌reference.‌ ‌Father‌ ‌and‌ ‌father's‌ ‌brothers‌ ‌also‌ ‌have‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nsame‌ ‌kin‌ ‌term.‌ ‌\n484‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nDifferences‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌Omaha‌ ‌and‌ ‌Crow‌ ‌systems:‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌seen‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌reference‌ ‌for‌ ‌cross‌ ‌cousins‌ ‌and‌ ‌whether‌ ‌or‌ ‌not‌ ‌uncles‌ ‌and‌ ‌aunts‌ ‌are‌ ‌lumped‌ ‌with‌ ‌them.‌ ‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌differences‌ ‌stem‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌fact‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌Omaha‌ ‌system‌ ‌is‌ ‌patrilineal‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌Crow‌ ‌is‌ ‌matrilineal.‌ ‌Compare‌ ‌the‌ ‌two‌ ‌kin‌ ‌naming‌ ‌systems‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌note‌ ‌the‌ ‌similarities‌ ‌and‌ ‌differences.‌ ‌\n485‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n486‌ ‌\n2.5‌ ‌Filiation‌ ‌and‌ ‌Complementary‌ ‌Filiation;‌ ‌Descent‌ ‌and‌ ‌Alliance-‌ ‌Part-III‌ ‌\n‌ ‌\n ‌\nDescent‌ ‌Filiation‌ ‌and‌ ‌Complementary‌ ‌Filiation;‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌addition:‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌the‌ ‌mid-1970s,‌ ‌David‌ ‌M.‌ ‌Schneider‌ ‌rocked‌ ‌the‌ ‌anthropological‌ ‌world‌ ‌with‌ ‌his‌ ‌announcement‌ ‌that‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌did‌ ‌not‌ ‌exist‌ ‌in‌ ‌any‌ ‌culture‌ ‌\nknown‌ ‌to‌ ‌humankind.‌ ‌ ‌\n●At‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌time,‌ ‌it‌ ‌laid‌ ‌the‌ ‌groundwork‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌re-emergence‌ ‌of‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌studies‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌centerpiece‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropological‌ ‌theory‌ ‌and‌ ‌practice.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Now‌ ‌a‌ ‌mainstay‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌studies,‌ ‌Schneider's‌ ‌conception‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌relativism‌ ‌revolutionized‌ ‌thinking‌ ‌about‌ ‌kinship,‌ ‌family,‌ ‌gender,‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nculture.‌ ‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌feminist‌ ‌anthropologists,‌ ‌his‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌freed‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌limitations‌ ‌of‌ ‌biology,‌ ‌providing‌ ‌a‌ ‌context‌ ‌for‌ ‌establishing‌ ‌gender‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌\nconstruct.‌ ‌\n487‌ ‌\n●Today,‌ ‌his‌ ‌work‌ ‌bears‌ ‌on‌ ‌high-profile‌ ‌issues‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌gay‌ ‌and‌ ‌lesbian‌ ‌partners‌ ‌and‌ ‌parents,‌ ‌surrogate‌ ‌motherhood,‌ ‌and‌ ‌new‌ ‌reproductive‌ ‌\ntechnologies.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Contributors‌ ‌to‌ ‌\"The‌ ‌Cultural‌ ‌Analysis‌ ‌of‌ ‌Kinship\"‌ ‌appraise‌ ‌Schneider's‌ ‌contributions‌ ‌and‌ ‌his‌ ‌place‌ ‌in‌ ‌anthropological‌ ‌history,‌ ‌particularly‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropological‌ ‌theory.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Filiation‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌which‌ ‌exists‌ ‌between‌ ‌a‌ ‌child‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌child’s‌ ‌parents,‌ ‌whether‌ ‌the‌ ‌parents‌ ‌are‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌or‌ ‌the‌ ‌opposite‌ ‌sex.‌ ‌\nThe‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌established‌ ‌by‌ ‌blood,‌ ‌by‌ ‌law‌ ‌in‌ ‌certain‌ ‌cases,‌ ‌or‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌judgment‌ ‌of‌ ‌adoption.‌ ‌Once‌ ‌filiation‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌\nestablished,‌ ‌it‌ ‌creates‌ ‌rights‌ ‌and‌ ‌obligations‌ ‌for‌ ‌both‌ ‌the‌ ‌child‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌parents,‌ ‌regardless‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌circumstances‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌child’s‌ ‌birth.It‌ ‌\ndecides‌ ‌the‌ ‌line‌ ‌of‌ ‌property‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌and‌ ‌succession‌ ‌to‌ ‌political‌ ‌office.‌ ‌\n○Example‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌patrilineal‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌descent,‌ ‌filiation‌ ‌is‌ ‌two‌ ‌fathers‌ ‌line‌ ‌thus‌ ‌resulting‌ ‌into‌ ‌Transfer‌ ‌of‌ ‌Property‌ ‌from‌ ‌Father‌ ‌to‌ ‌Son..‌ ‌\n○Similarly‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌matrilineal‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌descent‌ ‌the‌ ‌child‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌belong‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌father‌ ‌descent‌ ‌group.‌ ‌hence‌ ‌he‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌have‌ ‌any‌ ‌\nclaim‌ ‌on‌ ‌this‌ ‌property.‌ ‌Instead‌ ‌his‌ ‌claim‌ ‌to‌ ‌lineage‌ ‌property‌ ‌goes‌ ‌to‌ ‌his‌ ‌mother's‌ ‌brother‌ ‌property.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Complementary‌ ‌Filiation‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌was‌ ‌introduced‌ ‌by‌ ‌descent‌ ‌theorists‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌‌M‌ ‌Fortes‌ ‌ ‌through‌ ‌his‌ ‌studies‌ ‌on‌ ‌Tallensi‌ ‌of‌ ‌Ghana.‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌concept‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌describe‌ ‌an‌ ‌important‌ ‌ethnographic‌ ‌characteristic‌ ‌of‌ ‌many‌ ‌African‌ ‌societies,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Tallensi‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nGhana‌‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌anthropologists’‌ ‌theory‌ ‌was‌ ‌little‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌a‌ ‌paraphrase‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌people‌ ‌they‌ ‌had‌ ‌studied.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Thus‌ ‌Fortes‌ ‌described‌ ‌how‌ ‌Tallensi‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌saw‌ ‌their‌ ‌complementary‌ ‌filiation‌ ‌links‌ ‌as‌ ‌different‌ ‌from‌ ‌their‌ ‌lineage‌ ‌links,‌ ‌yet‌ ‌\nessential‌ ‌to‌ ‌their‌ ‌well-being‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌fact‌ ‌that‌ ‌in‌ ‌societies‌ ‌with‌ ‌unilineal‌ ‌descent‌ ‌groups‌ ‌people‌ ‌recognise‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌with‌ ‌relatives‌ ‌who‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌belong‌ ‌to‌ ‌their‌ ‌\nown‌ ‌descent‌ ‌group.‌ ‌\n○Thus,‌ ‌in‌ ‌societies‌ ‌with‌ ‌patrilineal‌ ‌descent‌ ‌groups,‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌have‌ ‌important‌ ‌socially‌ ‌defined‌ ‌links‌ ‌with‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌mother’s‌ ‌\nfamily,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as,‌ ‌for‌ ‌example,‌ ‌their‌ ‌mother’s‌ ‌brother‌ ‌or‌ ‌their‌ ‌maternal‌ ‌grandparents,‌ ‌while‌ ‌in‌ ‌matrilineal‌ ‌societies‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌have‌ ‌\nsimilar‌ ‌ties‌ ‌to‌ ‌their‌ ‌father’s‌ ‌family.‌ ‌\n○According‌ ‌to‌ ‌‌J.‌ ‌Goody‌ ‌‌one‌ ‌inherited‌ ‌from‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌property‌ ‌and‌ ‌status‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Centro(Filiation)‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌property‌ ‌and‌ ‌status‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌line‌ ‌of‌ ‌complementary‌ ‌filiation‌ ‌\nSignificance‌ ‌\n○While‌ ‌lineage‌ ‌links‌ ‌always‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌political‌ ‌and‌ ‌hierarchical‌ ‌character,‌ ‌complementary‌ ‌filiation‌ ‌is‌ ‌more‌ ‌emotional‌ ‌and‌ ‌more‌ ‌personal.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Lineage‌ ‌based‌ ‌society‌ ‌it‌ ‌provide‌ ‌important‌ ‌Residual‌ ‌and‌ ‌security‌ ‌or‌ ‌insurance‌ ‌Against‌ ‌The‌ ‌breakdown‌ ‌of‌ ‌filiation‌ ‌relationship.‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌example‌ ‌when‌ ‌bride‌ ‌price‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌paid,‌ ‌rights‌ ‌to‌ ‌women‌ ‌children‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌transferred‌ ‌to‌ ‌husband‌ ‌lineage.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌Matrilineal‌ ‌society‌ ‌there‌ ‌exists‌ ‌severe‌ ‌emotional‌ ‌conflict‌ ‌between‌ ‌a‌ ‌father's‌ ‌emotional‌ ‌attachment‌ ‌to‌ ‌his‌ ‌children‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌rule‌ ‌of‌ ‌\ninheritance‌ ‌which‌ ‌debars‌ ‌his‌ ‌children‌ ‌fom‌ ‌inheriting‌ ‌the‌ ‌property.‌ ‌this‌ ‌is‌ ‌satisfied‌ ‌through‌ ‌complementary‌ ‌Filiation‌ ‌ties.‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌Fortes’s‌ ‌later‌ ‌work‌ ‌the‌ ‌notion‌ ‌of‌ ‌complementary‌ ‌filiation‌ ‌was‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌support‌ ‌a‌ ‌much‌ ‌more‌ ‌general‌ ‌claim.‌ ‌ ‌\n488‌ ‌\n■Fortes‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌other‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌argued‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌existence‌ ‌of‌ ‌groups‌ ‌was,‌ ‌at‌ ‌bottom,‌ ‌always‌ ‌similar‌ ‌and‌ ‌always‌ ‌\ninvolved‌ ‌the‌ ‌recognition‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌complementary‌ ‌role‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌two‌ ‌parents.‌ ‌\n■Thus,‌ ‌in‌ ‌patrilineal‌ ‌societies,‌ ‌while‌ ‌for‌ ‌political,‌ ‌jural‌ ‌and‌ ‌military‌ ‌purposes‌ ‌lineages‌ ‌ignored‌ ‌links‌ ‌through‌ ‌mothers,‌ ‌there‌ ‌\nnonetheless‌ ‌existed‌ ‌a‌ ‌domestic‌ ‌level‌ ‌where‌ ‌links‌ ‌through‌ ‌women‌ ‌were‌ ‌recognized‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌complementary‌ ‌filiation.‌ ‌\nCritical‌ ‌Analysis‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌this‌ ‌wider‌ ‌theoretical‌ ‌implication‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌theory‌ ‌which‌ ‌came‌ ‌under‌ ‌attack‌ ‌from‌ ‌such‌ ‌writers‌ ‌as‌ ‌Edmund‌ ‌Leach‌ ‌(1961),‌ ‌who‌ ‌argued‌ ‌\nthat‌ ‌in‌ ‌those‌ ‌patrilineal‌ ‌societies‌ ‌would‌ ‌qualify‌ ‌as‌ ‌having‌ ‌an‌ ‌elementary‌ ‌structure,‌ ‌links‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌mother‌ ‌were‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌seen,‌ ‌not‌ ‌as‌ ‌\nmanifesting‌ ‌a‌ ‌kind‌ ‌of‌ ‌muted‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌but‌ ‌rather‌ ‌as‌ ‌being‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌affinal‌ ‌links.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Thus‌ ‌in‌ ‌such‌ ‌societies‌ ‌one’s‌ ‌mother‌ ‌was‌ ‌not‌ ‌seen‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌‘mother’‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌European‌ ‌sense,‌ ‌nor‌ ‌her‌ ‌brother‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌man‌ ‌linked‌ ‌to‌ ‌her,‌ ‌but‌ ‌\nboth‌ ‌would‌ ‌be‌ ‌seen‌ ‌as‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌group‌ ‌who‌ ‌give‌ ‌sexual‌ ‌partners‌ ‌to‌ ‌your‌ ‌own‌ ‌group.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Such‌ ‌a‌ ‌distinction‌ ‌might‌ ‌seem‌ ‌of‌ ‌little‌ ‌importance‌ ‌but‌ ‌in‌ ‌fact‌ ‌hides‌ ‌a‌ ‌fundamental‌ ‌theoretical‌ ‌claim,‌ ‌namely‌ ‌that‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌\nnothing‌ ‌universal‌ ‌or‌ ‌‘biological’‌ ‌to‌ ‌human‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌which‌ ‌constrains‌ ‌its‌ ‌representation.‌ ‌\n ‌\nFiliation‌ ‌vs‌ ‌Complementary‌ ‌Filiation‌ ‌\n●While‌ ‌lineage‌ ‌links‌ ‌always‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌political‌ ‌and‌ ‌hierarchical‌ ‌character,‌ ‌complementary‌ ‌filiation‌ ‌is‌ ‌more‌ ‌emotional‌ ‌and‌ ‌more‌ ‌\npersonal.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌is‌ ‌because‌ ‌all‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌descent‌ ‌group‌ ‌have‌ ‌different‌ ‌ties‌ ‌of‌ ‌complementary‌ ‌filiation‌ ‌from‌ ‌one‌ ‌another,‌ ‌but‌ ‌are‌ ‌undifferentiated‌ ‌on‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌descent,‌ ‌so‌ ‌that‌ ‌complementary‌ ‌filiation‌ ‌gives‌ ‌an‌ ‌idiom‌ ‌to‌ ‌feelings‌ ‌of‌ ‌individuality‌ ‌and‌ ‌independence.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nDescent‌ ‌and‌ ‌Alliance.‌ ‌\nDescent‌ ‌Theory‌ ‌\n●Development‌ ‌of‌ ‌Descent‌ ‌Theory‌ ‌\n○Descent‌ ‌theory‌ ‌also‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌lineage‌ ‌theory‌ ‌came‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌fore‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌1940s‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌publication‌ ‌of‌ ‌books‌ ‌like‌ ‌‌The‌ ‌Nuer‌ ‌\n(1940),‌ ‌African‌ ‌Political‌ ‌Systems‌ ‌‌(1940)‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Descent‌ ‌theory‌ ‌when‌ ‌it‌ ‌first‌ ‌became‌ ‌popular,‌ ‌it‌ ‌seemed‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌a‌ ‌new‌ ‌idea,‌ ‌a‌ ‌revelation,‌ ‌but‌ ‌deeper‌ ‌studies‌ ‌exhibit‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌\nactually‌ ‌a‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌ongoing‌ ‌changes‌ ‌in‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌and‌ ‌notions‌ ‌which‌ ‌took‌ ‌place‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropology.‌ ‌\n○Descent‌ ‌theory,‌ ‌in‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌explained‌ ‌clearly‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌divided‌ ‌into‌ ‌two‌ ‌periods,‌ ‌\n■Classical‌ ‌\n■Modern‌ ‌\n○Both‌ ‌these‌ ‌periods‌ ‌have‌ ‌three‌ ‌stages‌ ‌each.‌ ‌ ‌\nClassical:‌ ‌\n■First‌ ‌phase:‌ ‌‌The‌ ‌creation‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌new‌ ‌models‌ ‌of‌ ‌descent‌ ‌which‌ ‌was‌ ‌done‌ ‌by‌ ‌Henry‌ ‌Maine‌ ‌and‌ ‌Lewis‌ ‌H.‌ ‌Morgan.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Second‌ ‌phase:‌ ‌These‌ ‌models‌ ‌were‌ ‌revised‌ ‌and‌ ‌given‌ ‌a‌ ‌new‌ ‌form‌ ‌by‌ ‌some‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌of‌ ‌that‌ ‌time,‌ ‌more‌ ‌notably‌ ‌\nby‌ ‌John‌ ‌F.‌ ‌McLennan.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Third:‌ ‌‌Finally,‌ ‌these‌ ‌models‌ ‌were‌ ‌empirically‌ ‌made‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌in‌ ‌field‌ ‌studies‌ ‌by‌ ‌students‌ ‌of‌ ‌Franz‌ ‌Boas.‌ ‌ ‌\nModern:‌ ‌\n489‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌classical‌ ‌phase‌ ‌reached‌ ‌a‌ ‌low‌ ‌and‌ ‌remained‌ ‌mere‌ ‌speculations‌ ‌after‌ ‌this‌ ‌but‌ ‌were‌ ‌revived‌ ‌all‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌sudden‌ ‌by‌ ‌\nBritish‌ ‌Africanists,‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌modern‌ ‌phase‌ ‌of‌ ‌descent‌ ‌theory‌ ‌came‌ ‌up.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌main‌ ‌issues‌ ‌in‌ ‌both‌ ‌the‌ ‌periods‌ ‌however‌ ‌were‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌even‌ ‌though‌ ‌the‌ ‌approach‌ ‌applied‌ ‌to‌ ‌study‌ ‌them‌ ‌differed.‌ ‌The‌ ‌\nissues‌ ‌were‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌between‌ ‌blood‌ ‌and‌ ‌soil,‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌and‌ ‌territory,‌ ‌family‌ ‌and‌ ‌clan‌ ‌etc‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Main‌ ‌Exponents‌ ‌ ‌\n●Henry‌ ‌S‌ ‌Maine‌ ‌formulates‌ ‌and‌ ‌discusses‌ ‌the‌ ‌patriarchal‌ ‌theory‌ ‌in‌ ‌his‌ ‌work‌ ‌‌Ancient‌ ‌Law‌ ‌(1861)‌ ‌which‌ ‌postulates‌ ‌how‌ ‌society‌ ‌was‌ ‌\nformed‌ ‌and‌ ‌grounded‌ ‌by‌ ‌families‌ ‌ruled‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌eldest‌ ‌surviving‌ ‌male‌ ‌in‌ ‌it.‌ ‌ ‌\n■He‌ ‌also‌ ‌talked‌ ‌about‌ ‌how‌ ‌families‌ ‌formed‌ ‌aggregations.‌ ‌With‌ ‌the‌ ‌death‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌father,‌ ‌the‌ ‌sons‌ ‌stay‌ ‌behind‌ ‌together‌ ‌\ncreating‌ ‌extended‌ ‌ties‌ ‌of‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌broader‌ ‌polity‌ ‌of‌ ‌sorts‌ ‌which‌ ‌formed‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌It‌ ‌was‌ ‌much‌ ‌later‌ ‌\nthat‌ ‌attachment‌ ‌to‌ ‌territory‌ ‌created‌ ‌rivalry‌ ‌among‌ ‌blood‌ ‌ties,‌ ‌which‌ ‌became‌ ‌a‌ ‌matter‌ ‌of‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌organisation.‌ ‌ ‌\n■This‌ ‌extended‌ ‌patriarchal‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌unilineal‌ ‌development.‌ ‌It‌ ‌allowed‌ ‌jural‌ ‌stability‌ ‌and‌ ‌endurance.‌ ‌His‌ ‌\nopposition‌ ‌towards‌ ‌concepts‌ ‌of‌ ‌societies‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌and‌ ‌those‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌territory‌ ‌became‌ ‌the‌ ‌accepted‌ ‌norm‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nhis‌ ‌subsequent‌ ‌generation.‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌was‌ ‌‌Mclennan‌ ‌and‌ ‌Morgan‌ ‌‌who‌ ‌deliberated‌ ‌that‌ ‌human‌ ‌societies‌ ‌are‌ ‌fundamentally‌ ‌promiscuous‌ ‌rather‌ ‌than‌ ‌being‌ ‌based‌ ‌\non‌ ‌family.‌ ‌ ‌\n■In‌ ‌fact‌ ‌promiscuity‌ ‌only‌ ‌led‌ ‌to‌ ‌matriliny‌ ‌first‌ ‌instead‌ ‌of‌ ‌patriliny‌ ‌as‌ ‌it‌ ‌first‌ ‌created‌ ‌the‌ ‌mother/‌ ‌child‌ ‌bond.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Patriliny‌ ‌developed‌ ‌much‌ ‌later‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌introduction‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌and‌ ‌legal‌ ‌paternity.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌descent‌ ‌model‌ ‌of‌ ‌society‌ ‌developed‌ ‌in‌ ‌two‌ ‌ways,‌ ‌ ‌\n○One‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌theorists‌ ‌rearranged‌ ‌the‌ ‌fundamentals‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌new‌ ‌way‌ ‌to‌ ‌produce‌ ‌assumed‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌of‌ ‌historical‌ ‌development.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌second‌ ‌way‌ ‌was‌ ‌by‌ ‌using‌ ‌the‌ ‌model‌ ‌to‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌sources‌ ‌and‌ ‌to‌ ‌ethnographic‌ ‌work‌ ‌of‌ ‌native‌ ‌communities.‌ ‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌example,‌ ‌McLennan‌ ‌and‌ ‌Morgan‌ ‌stressed‌ ‌about‌ ‌the‌ ‌importance‌ ‌of‌ ‌exogamy‌ ‌in‌ ‌clans‌ ‌or‌ ‌totemism,‌ ‌was‌ ‌found‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌a‌ ‌\ncommon‌ ‌factor‌ ‌in‌ ‌kin‌ ‌groups.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Emile‌ ‌Durkheim,‌ ‌in‌ ‌his‌ ‌Division‌ ‌of‌ ‌Labour‌ ‌in‌ ‌Society‌ ‌(1893)‌ ‌tried‌ ‌to‌ ‌understand‌ ‌how‌ ‌clan‌ ‌based‌ ‌societies‌ ‌operated‌ ‌in‌ ‌reality.‌ ‌\n●Another‌ ‌development‌ ‌in‌ ‌this‌ ‌theory‌ ‌took‌ ‌place‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌early‌ ‌twentieth‌ ‌century‌ ‌where‌ ‌Boas’‌ ‌students‌ ‌made‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌Morgan’s‌ ‌model‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nreference‌ ‌to‌ ‌studies‌ ‌they‌ ‌conducted‌ ‌among‌ ‌American‌ ‌Indians.‌ ‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌Example‌,‌ ‌John‌ ‌Swanton‌ ‌wrote‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌organisation‌ ‌of‌ ‌American‌ ‌Indians.‌ ‌ ‌\n■He‌ ‌questioned‌ ‌the‌ ‌historical‌ ‌validity‌ ‌of‌ ‌matrilineal‌ ‌clans‌ ‌as‌ ‌postulated‌ ‌by‌ ‌Morgan.‌ ‌ ‌\n■His‌ ‌work‌ ‌showed‌ ‌that‌ ‌many‌ ‌North‌ ‌American‌ ‌tribes‌ ‌were‌ ‌not‌ ‌matrilineal‌ ‌and‌ ‌if‌ ‌at‌ ‌all‌ ‌matrilineal‌ ‌than‌ ‌they‌ ‌were‌ ‌not‌ ‌\nadvanced‌ ‌than‌ ‌family‌ ‌based‌ ‌units‌ ‌as‌ ‌deduced‌ ‌by‌ ‌Morgan.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Another‌ ‌ethnographer,‌ ‌‌Frank‌ ‌Speck‌ ‌demonstrated‌ ‌in‌ ‌1915‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌Algonkian‌ ‌hunter-gatherers‌ ‌have‌ ‌families‌ ‌and‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌\nalso‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌territories.‌ ‌ ‌\n■This‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌too‌ ‌refuted‌ ‌Morgan’s‌ ‌claims.‌ ‌\n○R.H.‌ ‌Lowie‌‌ ‌summarized‌ ‌the‌ ‌critique‌ ‌of‌ ‌Morgan‌ ‌by‌ ‌noting‌ ‌that‌ ‌all‌ ‌data‌ ‌showed‌ ‌that‌ ‌\nfamily‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌present‌ ‌in‌ ‌all‌ ‌stages‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\n■He‌ ‌also‌ ‌noted‌ ‌that‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌fixed‌ ‌succession‌ ‌of‌ ‌maternal‌ ‌and‌ ‌paternal‌ ‌descent.‌ ‌\n490‌ ‌\n■Both‌ ‌higher‌ ‌and‌ ‌lower‌ ‌civilizations‌ ‌in‌ ‌many‌ ‌cases‌ ‌give‌ ‌importance‌ ‌to‌ ‌paternal‌ ‌side‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family.‌ ‌ ‌\n■His‌ ‌final‌ ‌postulation‌ ‌was,‌ ‌family‌ ‌(bilateral)‌ ‌and‌ ‌clan,‌ ‌sib,‌ ‌moiety‌ ‌(unilateral)‌ ‌are‌ ‌rooted‌ ‌in‌ ‌local‌ ‌and‌ ‌consanguinal‌ ‌factor.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌prominent‌ ‌British‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌of‌ ‌that‌ ‌time,‌ ‌like‌ ‌Rivers‌ ‌and‌ ‌Radcliffe-Brown,‌ ‌were‌ ‌clearly‌ ‌associated‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌views‌ ‌with‌ ‌\ntheir‌ ‌American‌ ‌counterparts,‌ ‌more‌ ‌so‌ ‌with‌ ‌Maine‌ ‌and‌ ‌McLennan‌ ‌than‌ ‌with‌ ‌Morgan.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌British‌ ‌and‌ ‌American‌ ‌scholars‌ ‌only‌ ‌differed‌ ‌from‌ ‌each‌ ‌other‌ ‌when‌ ‌Rivers‌ ‌and‌ ‌Radcliffe-Brown‌ ‌started‌ ‌investigating‌ ‌the‌ ‌\ncorporate‌ ‌role‌ ‌of‌ ‌descent‌ ‌groups.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Rivers‌ ‌talked‌ ‌about‌ ‌‘descent’‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌way‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌membership‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌is‌ ‌recognised‌ ‌and‌ ‌also‌ ‌for‌ ‌modes‌ ‌of‌ ‌\ntransmission‌ ‌of‌ ‌property,‌ ‌rank‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌but‌ ‌the‌ ‌second‌ ‌notion‌ ‌was‌ ‌not‌ ‌accepted‌ ‌as‌ ‌these‌ ‌processes‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌correspond‌ ‌to‌ ‌each‌ ‌\nother‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌time.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Radcliffe-Brown’s‌ ‌essay‌ ‌on‌ ‌“Patrilineal‌ ‌and‌ ‌Matrilineal‌ ‌Succession”‌ ‌gave‌ ‌Rivers’‌ ‌points‌ ‌a‌ ‌concrete‌ ‌basis.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌was‌ ‌A.L.‌ ‌Kroeber‌ ‌who‌ ‌however‌ ‌put‌ ‌forward‌ ‌a‌ ‌critique‌ ‌of‌ ‌Radcliffe‌ ‌Brown’s‌ ‌study.‌ ‌ ‌\n○His‌ ‌critique‌ ‌was‌ ‌mainly‌ ‌on‌ ‌descent‌ ‌theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌Radcliffe‌ ‌Brown,‌ ‌where‌ ‌he‌ ‌disagreed‌ ‌to‌ ‌his‌ ‌claim‌ ‌of‌ ‌placing‌ ‌descent‌ ‌\ngroups‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌centre‌ ‌in‌ ‌Australia.‌ ‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌Kroeber,‌ ‌moiety,‌ ‌clan‌ ‌and‌ ‌any‌ ‌other‌ ‌unilateral‌ ‌descent‌ ‌groups‌ ‌play‌ ‌secondary‌ ‌parts‌ ‌in‌ ‌many‌ ‌societies‌ ‌and‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌\ncentral.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Family‌ ‌or‌ ‌clan‌ ‌did‌ ‌not‌ ‌actually‌ ‌have‌ ‌any‌ ‌historical‌ ‌character‌ ‌about‌ ‌who‌ ‌followed‌ ‌whom.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌societies‌ ‌where‌ ‌clans‌ ‌played‌ ‌an‌ ‌important‌ ‌role,‌ ‌they‌ ‌were‌ ‌always‌ ‌found‌ ‌with‌ ‌basic‌ ‌family‌ ‌units.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌clan‌ ‌model‌ ‌did‌ ‌not‌ ‌die‌ ‌away‌ ‌but‌ ‌came‌ ‌back‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌forefront‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌functional‌ ‌model‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌lineage‌ ‌model.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌was‌ ‌basically‌ ‌used‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌of‌ ‌contemporary‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌between‌ ‌institutions,‌ ‌more‌ ‌so‌ ‌to‌ ‌study‌ ‌\nparticular‌ ‌African‌ ‌example‌ ‌of‌ ‌segmentary‌ ‌lineage‌ ‌system.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Critical‌ ‌Analysis‌ ‌\n○Although‌ ‌descent‌ ‌theory‌ ‌dominated‌ ‌early‌ ‌to‌ ‌mid-20th-century‌ ‌British‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌studies,‌ ‌a‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌problems‌ ‌soon‌ ‌emerged.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌became‌ ‌apparent‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌depiction‌ ‌of‌ ‌societies‌ ‌as‌ ‌neatly‌ ‌ordered‌ ‌by‌ ‌unilineal‌ ‌descent‌ ‌into‌ ‌clearly‌ ‌bounded,‌ ‌nested‌ ‌units‌ ‌of‌ ‌\ndifferent‌ ‌scale‌ ‌was‌ ‌quite‌ ‌far‌ ‌from‌ ‌everyday‌ ‌political‌ ‌reality.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Personal‌ ‌experiences‌ ‌of‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌could‌ ‌vary‌ ‌considerably‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌normative‌ ‌models‌ ‌described‌ ‌by‌ ‌some‌ ‌anthropologists;‌ ‌ ‌\n■Evans-Pritchard,‌ ‌for‌ ‌instance,‌ ‌demonstrated‌ ‌that‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌could‌ ‌not‌ ‌always‌ ‌unequivocally‌ ‌identify‌ ‌the‌ ‌lineage‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nwhich‌ ‌they‌ ‌belonged.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Furthermore,‌ ‌as‌ ‌scholars‌ ‌from‌ ‌Britain,‌ ‌France,‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌United‌ ‌States‌ ‌increasingly‌ ‌undertook‌ ‌fieldwork‌ ‌outside‌ ‌\nAfrica—for‌ ‌example,‌ ‌in‌ ‌Polynesia,‌ ‌Southeast‌ ‌Asia,‌ ‌or‌ ‌New‌ ‌Guinea—it‌ ‌became‌ ‌clear‌ ‌that‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌was‌ ‌not‌ ‌always‌ ‌\norganized‌ ‌through‌ ‌unilineal‌ ‌descent.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Despite‌ ‌Radcliffe-Brown’s‌ ‌assertions‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌contrary,‌ ‌bilateral‌ ‌(sometimes‌ ‌called‌ ‌“cognatic”)‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌bilateral‌ ‌\ndescent‌ ‌groups‌ ‌(reckoned‌ ‌in‌ ‌both‌ ‌the‌ ‌mother’s‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌father’s‌ ‌lines)‌ ‌were‌ ‌found‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌statistically‌ ‌common,‌ ‌even‌ ‌though‌ ‌\nthey‌ ‌did‌ ‌not‌ ‌provide‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌kind‌ ‌of‌ ‌clearly‌ ‌demarcated‌ ‌groupings‌ ‌as‌ ‌unilineal‌ ‌versions‌ ‌of‌ ‌kinship.‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌further‌ ‌issue‌ ‌of‌ ‌contention‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌extent‌ ‌to‌ ‌which‌ ‌descent‌ ‌theory‌ ‌minimized‌ ‌the‌ ‌importance‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌structuring‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌kinship.‌ ‌ ‌\n491‌ ‌\n○Both‌ ‌Evans-Pritchard‌ ‌and‌ ‌Fortes‌ ‌asserted‌ ‌the‌ ‌importance‌ ‌of‌ ‌various‌ ‌links‌ ‌between‌ ‌descent‌ ‌groups.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Such‌ ‌links‌ ‌assured‌ ‌the‌ ‌wider‌ ‌integration‌ ‌of‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌groups‌ ‌over‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌territory‌ ‌and‌ ‌could‌ ‌include‌ ‌links‌ ‌formed‌ ‌through‌ ‌\nmarital‌ ‌connections‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌recognition‌ ‌of‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌ties‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌line‌ ‌that‌ ‌was‌ ‌complementary‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌principal‌ ‌line‌ ‌of‌ ‌\ndescent‌ ‌(i.e.,‌ ‌matrilateral‌ ‌ties‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌patrilineal‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌system‌ ‌or‌ ‌patrilateral‌ ‌ones‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌matrilineal‌ ‌system).‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌their‌ ‌opinion,‌ ‌however,‌ ‌the‌ ‌principle‌ ‌of‌ ‌descent‌ ‌remained‌ ‌paramount‌ ‌in‌ ‌assuring‌ ‌the‌ ‌stable‌ ‌functioning‌ ‌of‌ ‌societies‌ ‌without‌ ‌\nstates.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Many‌ ‌prominent‌ ‌British‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌era‌ ‌were‌ ‌soon‌ ‌locked‌ ‌in‌ ‌forceful‌ ‌debate‌ ‌with‌ ‌their‌ ‌colleagues‌ ‌elsewhere‌ ‌over‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌significance‌ ‌of‌ ‌descent‌ ‌relative‌ ‌to‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Conclusion‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌contemporary‌ ‌anthropological‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌systems,‌ ‌the‌ ‌descent‌ ‌model‌ ‌has‌ ‌no‌ ‌credibility.‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌look‌ ‌into‌ ‌the‌ ‌local‌ ‌models‌ ‌or‌ ‌notions‌ ‌that‌ ‌societies‌ ‌possess‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌own‌ ‌realm.‌ ‌ ‌\n○And‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌a‌ ‌‘repetitive‌ ‌series’‌ ‌of‌ ‌descent‌ ‌groups‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌essential‌ ‌for‌ ‌organising‌ ‌political‌ ‌and‌ ‌economic‌ ‌events.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌however‌ ‌helps‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌in‌ ‌anthropology,‌ ‌as‌ ‌it‌ ‌gives‌ ‌us‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌about‌ ‌how‌ ‌earlier‌ ‌societies‌ ‌were‌ ‌made‌ ‌up.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌also‌ ‌helps‌ ‌in‌ ‌moulding‌ ‌itself‌ ‌into‌ ‌other‌ ‌broader‌ ‌models‌ ‌of‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Beyond‌ ‌these‌ ‌Descent‌ ‌theories‌ ‌offer‌ ‌no‌ ‌significant‌ ‌contribution‌ ‌in‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌today‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nAlliance‌ ‌Theory‌ ‌\n●Claude‌ ‌Levi‌ ‌Strauss‌ ‌has‌ ‌advocated‌ ‌the‌ ‌theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌Alliance‌ ‌in‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌know‌ ‌the‌ ‌structure‌ ‌of‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌him,‌ ‌there‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌total‌ ‌Anarchy‌ ‌at‌ ‌one‌ ‌time‌ ‌and‌ ‌Society‌ ‌was‌ ‌in‌ ‌total‌ ‌disorder.‌ ‌\n●After‌ ‌sometime,‌ ‌society‌ ‌had‌ ‌become‌ ‌ordered‌ ‌and‌ ‌different‌ ‌group‌ ‌came‌ ‌into‌ ‌being‌ ‌because‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌emergence‌ ‌of‌ ‌rule‌ ‌like‌ ‌incest‌ ‌taboo‌ ‌and‌ ‌\ndualism‌ ‌of‌ ‌mind‌ ‌(our‌ ‌group‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌group).‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌decided‌ ‌to‌ ‌live‌ ‌at‌ ‌peace‌ ‌with‌ ‌each‌ ‌other‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌basic‌ ‌aim‌ ‌of‌ ‌every‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n●As‌ ‌a‌ ‌result‌ ‌the‌ ‌device‌ ‌certain‌ ‌mechanism‌ ‌to‌ ‌ensure‌ ‌peace‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌society.‌ ‌this‌ ‌mechanism‌ ‌was‌ ‌of‌ ‌exchange.‌ ‌\n●Claude‌ ‌Levi‌ ‌Strauss‌ ‌gave‌ ‌three‌ ‌basic‌ ‌principle‌ ‌of‌ ‌exchange:‌ ‌\n○Exchange‌ ‌of‌ ‌goods‌ ‌and‌ ‌services‌ ‌\n○Exchange‌ ‌of‌ ‌Idea‌ ‌\n○ ‌Exchange‌ ‌men‌ ‌or‌ ‌women‌ ‌depending‌ ‌on‌ ‌whether‌ ‌matrilineal‌ ‌society‌ ‌came‌ ‌first‌ ‌or‌ ‌patrilineal.‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌CL‌ ‌Strauss,‌ ‌the‌ ‌earliest‌ ‌society‌ ‌was‌ ‌patrilineal‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n●Ancient‌ ‌people‌ ‌had‌ ‌nothing‌ ‌to‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌except‌ ‌women‌ ‌or‌ ‌men‌ ‌because‌ ‌every‌ ‌group‌ ‌have‌ ‌similar‌ ‌kind‌ ‌of‌ ‌production‌ ‌and‌ ‌ideas.‌ ‌\n●Consequently‌ ‌in‌ ‌absence‌ ‌of‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌of‌ ‌goods‌ ‌and‌ ‌services‌ ‌and‌ ‌ideas,‌ ‌people‌ ‌started‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌of‌ ‌women‌ ‌in‌ ‌society‌ ‌was‌ ‌patrilineal‌ ‌\naccording‌ ‌to‌ ‌him.‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌exchange,‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌principle‌ ‌of‌ ‌alliance‌ ‌which‌ ‌emerged‌ ‌in‌ ‌human‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌said‌ ‌that‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌two‌ ‌kinds‌ ‌of‌ ‌exchange:‌ ‌\n○Restricted‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌\n492‌ ‌\n○Generalized‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌\n●With‌ ‌negative‌ ‌prescription‌ ‌of‌ ‌incest‌ ‌Taboo‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌positive‌ ‌counterpart‌ ‌of‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌of‌ ‌women.‌ ‌\n●Thus‌ ‌the‌ ‌idea‌ ‌of‌ ‌Alliance‌ ‌theory‌ ‌is‌ ‌of‌ ‌reciprocal‌ ‌or‌ ‌generalized‌ ‌exchange.‌ ‌which‌ ‌builds‌ ‌affinity.‌ ‌\n●By‌ ‌necessitating‌ ‌exogamy,‌ ‌wife‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌arrangement‌ ‌promote‌ ‌intergroup‌ ‌Alliance‌ ‌and‌ ‌serves‌ ‌to‌ ‌form‌ ‌the‌ ‌structure‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌networks.‌ ‌\n○Restricted‌ ‌for‌ ‌reciprocal‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌is‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌society‌ ‌characterized‌ ‌by‌ ‌dual‌ ‌organisation‌ ‌which‌ ‌means‌ ‌only‌ ‌two‌ ‌groups‌ ‌are‌ ‌involved‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌process‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nexchange.‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌is‌ ‌seen‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌society‌ ‌where‌ ‌moiety‌ ‌like‌ ‌situations‌ ‌exist.‌ ‌\n■Each‌ ‌group‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌wife‌ ‌giver‌ ‌and‌ ‌receiver‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌generation.‌ ‌They‌ ‌marry‌ ‌their‌ ‌mother's‌ ‌brother's‌ ‌daughter.‌ ‌\n■Example:‌ ‌‌Bilateral‌ ‌cross‌ ‌cousin‌ ‌marriage.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○Generalized‌ ‌or‌ ‌asymmetrical‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌involved‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌two‌ ‌groups‌ ‌where‌ ‌a‌ ‌phatry-like‌ ‌situation‌ ‌existed.‌ ‌\n■This‌ ‌group‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌further‌ ‌divided‌ ‌into‌ ‌continuous‌ ‌and‌ ‌discontinuous‌ ‌exchange,‌ ‌\n●Continuous‌ ‌exchange:‌ ‌\n○Here‌ ‌the‌ ‌flow‌ ‌of‌ ‌women‌ ‌is‌ ‌only‌ ‌in‌ ‌one‌ ‌Direction‌ ‌and‌ ‌all‌ ‌generations.‌ ‌\n493‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌example‌ ‌matrilineal‌ ‌cross‌ ‌cousin‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌In‌ ‌patrilineal‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌called‌ ‌as‌ ‌open‌ ‌type‌ ‌exchange.‌ ‌Continuous‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌put‌ ‌into‌ ‌action‌ ‌a‌ ‌long‌ ‌cycle,‌ ‌which‌ ‌CL‌ ‌\nStrauss‌ ‌called‌ ‌circulatory‌ ‌connubium.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Discontinuous‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌discontinuous‌ ‌exchange,‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌of‌ ‌women‌ ‌not‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌immediate‌ ‌generation‌ ‌but‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌next‌ ‌\ngeneration.‌ ‌\n494‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌example‌‌ ‌Patrilineal‌ ‌cross‌ ‌cousin‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌in‌ ‌patrilineal‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Generalized‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌is‌ ‌more‌ ‌integrative‌ ‌as‌ ‌compared‌ ‌to‌ ‌restricted‌ ‌change‌ ‌and‌ ‌allow‌ ‌integration‌ ‌of‌ ‌indefinite‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌groups.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nCriticism:‌ ‌\n○Levi-Strauss’‌ ‌alliance‌ ‌theory‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌without‌ ‌its‌ ‌flaws.‌ ‌His‌ ‌arguments‌ ‌are‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌societies‌ ‌about‌ ‌which‌ ‌he‌ ‌has‌ ‌given‌ ‌examples,‌ ‌\nwhich‌ ‌are‌ ‌clearly‌ ‌viripotestal‌ ‌and‌ ‌also‌ ‌that‌ ‌his‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌were‌ ‌simple.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌fundamental‌ ‌character‌ ‌and‌ ‌explanatory‌ ‌value‌ ‌of‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌as‌ ‌defined‌ ‌by‌ ‌Levi‌ ‌Strauss‌ ‌faced‌ ‌some‌ ‌extreme‌ ‌criticism.‌ ‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌supporters‌ ‌of‌ ‌consanguinity‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌self-explanatory‌ ‌system,‌ ‌the‌ ‌prohibiton‌ ‌of‌ ‌incest‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌difference‌ ‌in‌ ‌consanguinity‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌affinity‌ ‌is‌ ‌redundant.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Marriage‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌seen‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌was‌ ‌also‌ ‌questioned,‌ ‌one‌ ‌because‌ ‌women‌ ‌were‌ ‌seen‌ ‌as‌ ‌possessions,‌ ‌private‌ ‌\nproperties‌ ‌and‌ ‌also‌ ‌because‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌was‌ ‌used‌ ‌in‌ ‌too‌ ‌wide‌ ‌a‌ ‌sense‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌lost‌ ‌its‌ ‌meaning.‌ ‌\n495‌ ‌\n○According‌ ‌to‌ ‌Strauss,‌ ‌Allianz‌ ‌dominate‌ ‌the‌ ‌structure‌ ‌and‌ ‌not‌ ‌the‌ ‌descent.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Descent‌ ‌theories‌ ‌criticised‌ ‌alliance‌ ‌theory,‌ ‌and‌ ‌said‌ ‌that‌ ‌descent‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌and‌ ‌not‌ ‌alliance‌ ‌because‌ ‌\ndescent‌ ‌rule‌ ‌only‌ ‌specified‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌of‌ ‌patrilineal‌ ‌category‌ ‌of‌ ‌spouse.‌ ‌Women‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌takes‌ ‌place‌ ‌in‌ ‌patrilineal‌ ‌society‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌not‌ ‌matrilineal‌ ‌one.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Conclusion‌ ‌\n○Alliance‌ ‌theory‌ ‌though‌ ‌quite‌ ‌categorical‌ ‌did‌ ‌not‌ ‌continue‌ ‌to‌ ‌work‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌speculation‌ ‌which‌ ‌bore‌ ‌definite‌ ‌fruits.‌ ‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌lot‌ ‌more‌ ‌was‌ ‌anticipated‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌theory.‌ ‌The‌ ‌inference‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌alliance‌ ‌for‌ ‌status,‌ ‌economy,‌ ‌and‌ ‌political‌ ‌organisation‌ ‌was‌ ‌\nnever‌ ‌clearly‌ ‌explained.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌etymological‌ ‌investigation‌ ‌remained‌ ‌defectively‌ ‌structural.‌ ‌The‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌terminologies‌ ‌did‌ ‌not‌ ‌finally‌ ‌help‌ ‌in‌ ‌comprehending‌ ‌or‌ ‌\nbettering‌ ‌this‌ ‌theory.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Though‌ ‌alliance‌ ‌theory‌ ‌had‌ ‌much‌ ‌greater‌ ‌explanatory‌ ‌value‌ ‌than‌ ‌descent‌ ‌theory,‌ ‌yet‌ ‌in‌ ‌today’s‌ ‌contemporary‌ ‌anthropological‌ ‌setting,‌ ‌\ninvestigations‌ ‌have‌ ‌minimized‌ ‌their‌ ‌interest‌ ‌in‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌studies‌ ‌to‌ ‌understand‌ ‌the‌ ‌diversity‌ ‌of‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌systems.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Hence‌ ‌the‌ ‌question‌ ‌of‌ ‌universal‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌structures‌ ‌remains‌ ‌unanswered‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌which‌ ‌the‌ ‌debates‌ ‌between‌ ‌descent‌ ‌and‌ ‌alliance‌ ‌\ntheories‌ ‌have‌ ‌shrunk.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n496‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n3.‌ ‌Economic‌ ‌Organization:Meaning,‌ ‌scope‌ ‌and‌ ‌relevance‌ ‌of‌ ‌economic‌ ‌anthropology;‌ ‌Formalist‌ ‌and‌ ‌Substantivist‌ ‌debate;‌ ‌Part-I‌ ‌\n‌ ‌\nMeaning,‌ ‌scope‌ ‌and‌ ‌relevance‌ ‌of‌ ‌economic‌ ‌anthropology;‌ ‌ ‌\nIntroduction‌ ‌\n●There‌ ‌are‌ ‌‌vast‌ ‌differences‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌economies‌ ‌of‌ ‌isolated,‌ ‌small,‌ ‌self-sufficient‌ ‌societies‌ ‌and‌ ‌large-scale‌ ‌ones‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌integrated‌ ‌into‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌modern‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌global‌ ‌commerce.‌ ‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌differences‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌only‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌scale‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌economies.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Their‌ ‌systems‌ ‌of‌ ‌production,‌ ‌distribution,‌ ‌and‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌concepts‌ ‌of‌ ‌property‌ ‌ownership‌ ‌are‌ ‌often‌ ‌radically‌ ‌different.‌ ‌\n○Like‌ ‌the‌ ‌economic‌ ‌organisation‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌hunting‌ ‌and‌ ‌gathering‌ ‌society‌ ‌is‌ ‌different‌ ‌from‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌Agricultural‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n●But‌ ‌all‌ ‌societies‌ ‌in‌ ‌this‌ ‌word‌ ‌have‌ ‌economic‌ ‌organisations,‌ ‌irrespective‌ ‌of‌ ‌whether‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌tribal,‌ ‌peasant‌ ‌or‌ ‌urban‌.‌ ‌\n●To‌ ‌satisfy‌ ‌the‌ ‌basic‌ ‌need‌ ‌of‌ ‌survival.‌ ‌Food‌ ‌is‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌important‌ ‌basic‌ ‌requirements.‌ ‌we‌ ‌either‌ ‌collect‌ ‌it‌ ‌from‌ ‌our‌ ‌surrounding‌ ‌or‌ ‌\nproduce‌ ‌it‌ ‌manually.‌ ‌\n○But‌ ‌when‌ ‌we‌ ‌lead‌ ‌a‌ ‌social‌ ‌life,‌ ‌we‌ ‌need‌ ‌to‌ ‌satisfy‌ ‌the‌ ‌requirements‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌this,‌ ‌the‌ ‌resources‌ ‌have‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌used‌ ‌in‌ ‌an‌ ‌equitable‌ ‌manner,‌ ‌the‌ ‌product‌ ‌be‌ ‌distributed‌ ‌among‌ ‌all‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌whole‌ ‌\nprocess‌ ‌be‌ ‌organised‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌social‌ ‌cause.‌ ‌\n●Thus,‌ ‌economic‌ ‌organisation‌ ‌is‌ ‌essential‌ ‌to‌ ‌ensure‌ ‌production/‌ ‌collection,‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌and‌ ‌consumption‌ ‌in‌ ‌an‌ ‌equitable‌ ‌way.‌ ‌\n●Otherwise‌ ‌it‌ ‌will‌ ‌result‌ ‌in‌ ‌poverty‌ ‌and‌ ‌famine.‌ ‌ ‌\n●To‌ ‌get‌ ‌a‌ ‌vivid‌ ‌picture‌ ‌of‌ ‌‌economic‌ ‌organisation‌‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌various‌ ‌definitions‌ ‌given‌ ‌by‌ ‌anthropologists:‌ ‌\n○Economic‌ ‌organisations‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌defined‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌human‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌by‌ ‌which‌ ‌goods‌ ‌are‌ ‌produced,‌ ‌allocated,‌ ‌distributed,‌ ‌used‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nconsumed-‌ ‌‌Hoebel‌ ‌and‌ ‌Weaver‌.‌ ‌\n○Economic‌ ‌organisation‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌action.‌ ‌It‌ ‌involves‌ ‌the‌ ‌combination‌ ‌of‌ ‌various‌ ‌kinds‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌service‌ ‌with‌ ‌one‌ ‌another‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nwith‌ ‌goods‌ ‌such‌ ‌a‌ ‌way‌ ‌that‌ ‌they‌ ‌serve‌ ‌the‌ ‌given‌ ‌ends-‌ ‌‌Raymond‌ ‌Firth‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n497‌ ‌\n○Economic‌ ‌organisation‌ ‌consists‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌ordering‌ ‌and‌ ‌organisation‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌relation‌ ‌and‌ ‌human‌ ‌efforts‌ ‌in‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌predict‌ ‌your‌ ‌as‌ ‌\nmany‌ ‌as‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌necessities‌ ‌of‌ ‌day-to-day‌ ‌life‌ ‌as‌ ‌possible,‌ ‌with‌ ‌expenditure‌ ‌of‌ ‌minimum‌ ‌effort.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌attempted‌ ‌to‌ ‌secure‌ ‌the‌ ‌maximum‌ ‌\nsatisfaction‌ ‌possible‌ ‌through‌ ‌adapting‌ ‌limited‌ ‌means‌ ‌to‌ ‌unlimited‌ ‌ends‌ ‌in‌ ‌an‌ ‌organised‌ ‌manner.-‌ ‌‌Majumdar‌ ‌and‌ ‌Madan‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nMeaning‌ ‌and‌ ‌Definition:‌ ‌\n ‌\nWhat‌ ‌is‌ ‌Economic‌ ‌Anthropology?‌ ‌\n●Economic‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌process‌ ‌of‌ ‌production‌ ‌circulation‌ ‌and‌ ‌consumption‌ ‌of‌ ‌different‌ ‌shots‌ ‌of‌ ‌objects‌ ‌in‌ ‌social‌ ‌settings.‌ ‌\n●‘‌Objects‌‘‌ ‌include‌ ‌material‌ ‌things‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌what‌ ‌people‌ ‌do‌ ‌for‌ ‌each‌ ‌other‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌labour‌ ‌and‌ ‌services‌ ‌and‌ ‌less‌ ‌visible‌ ‌objects‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌\nideas‌ ‌Innovation‌ ‌and‌ ‌so‌ ‌forth.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌setting‌ ‌ranges‌ ‌from‌ ‌small‌ ‌and‌ ‌intimate‌ ‌social‌ ‌units‌ ‌like‌ ‌household‌ ‌through‌ ‌intermediate‌ ‌once‌ ‌like‌ ‌firm,‌ ‌village‌ ‌or‌ ‌local‌ ‌market‌ ‌two‌ ‌very‌ ‌\nlarge‌ ‌into‌ ‌these‌ ‌like‌ ‌regional‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌ceremonial‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌or‌ ‌global‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌advertising‌ ‌consumption.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌term‌ ‌‘economic‌ ‌anthropology’‌ ‌was‌ ‌coined‌ ‌by‌ ‌N.S.B.Gras,‌ ‌an‌ ‌economic‌ ‌historian,‌ ‌who‌ ‌defined‌ ‌it‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌‘synthesis‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropological‌ ‌and‌ ‌\neconomic‌ ‌studies’‌ ‌dealing‌ ‌with‌ ‌‘the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌ways‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌people‌ ‌obtained‌ ‌a‌ ‌living.’‌ ‌ ‌\n●While‌ ‌Economic‌ ‌Anthropologists‌ ‌study‌ ‌the‌ ‌economic‌ ‌process,‌ ‌their‌ ‌approach‌ ‌is‌ ‌different‌ ‌from‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌economist.‌ ‌\n●Economists‌ ‌actually‌ ‌restrict‌ ‌themselves‌ ‌and‌ ‌try‌ ‌to‌ ‌develop‌ ‌the‌ ‌former‌ ‌abstract‌ ‌mode‌ ‌of‌ ‌economic‌ ‌system.‌ ‌\n498‌ ‌\n●Economic‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌hand‌ ‌usually‌ ‌are‌ ‌concerned‌ ‌with‌ ‌all‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌production,‌ ‌circulation‌ ‌and‌ ‌consumption,‌ ‌monetary‌ ‌or‌ ‌\nnot.‌ ‌\n●Further‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌concerned‌ ‌with‌ ‌less‌ ‌developing‌ ‌formal‌ ‌models‌ ‌and‌ ‌more‌ ‌with‌ ‌trying‌ ‌to‌ ‌describe‌ ‌and‌ ‌understand‌ ‌economic‌ ‌actions‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌\nsocial‌ ‌and‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌context.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌a‌ ‌nutshell,‌ ‌economic‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌takes‌ ‌the‌ ‌best‌ ‌of‌ ‌economics‌ ‌and‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌create‌ ‌a‌ ‌hybrid‌ ‌that‌ ‌allow‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌investigation‌ ‌of‌ ‌\neconomic‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌as‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌lived‌ ‌and‌ ‌practiced.‌ ‌\n●Economic‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌describe‌ ‌analyse‌ ‌and‌ ‌interpretate‌ ‌the‌ ‌economic‌ ‌life‌ ‌of‌ ‌people‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌socio-‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌context‌ ‌in‌ ‌all‌ ‌places‌ ‌at‌ ‌all‌ ‌times.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nDefinition‌ ‌by‌ ‌Anthropologist/Thinkers‌ ‌\n●Nash‌‌ ‌tells‌ ‌that‌ ‌economic‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌analyzes‌ ‌economic‌ ‌life‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌subsystem‌ ‌of‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n●Beals‌ ‌and‌ ‌Hoijer‌ ‌‌say‌ ‌that‌ ‌economic‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌studies‌ ‌the‌ ‌production‌ ‌of‌ ‌goods‌ ‌and‌ ‌services‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌and‌ ‌consumption‌ ‌as‌ ‌\nthese‌ ‌are‌ ‌institutionalized‌ ‌or‌ ‌formalized‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌socio-cultural‌ ‌subsystem.‌ ‌\n●Platter‌ ‌‌also‌ ‌says‌ ‌that‌ ‌economic‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌studies‌ ‌economic‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌as‌ ‌orderly‌ ‌embedded‌ ‌in‌ ‌socio‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌aspects.‌ ‌\nOrigin‌ ‌of‌ ‌Economic‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌\n499‌ ‌\n●Its‌ ‌origins‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌subfield‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌began‌ ‌with‌ ‌work‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Polish‌ ‌founder‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌Bronislaw‌ ‌Malinowski‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌French‌ ‌Marcel‌ ‌\nMauss‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌nature‌ ‌of‌ ‌reciprocity‌ ‌as‌ ‌an‌ ‌alternative‌ ‌to‌ ‌market‌ ‌exchange.‌ ‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌part,‌ ‌studies‌ ‌in‌ ‌economic‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌focus‌ ‌on‌ ‌exchange.‌ ‌In‌ ‌contrast,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Marxian‌ ‌school‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌\"political‌ ‌economy\"‌ ‌\nfocuses‌ ‌on‌ ‌production.‌ ‌\n●Post-World‌ ‌War‌ ‌II,‌ ‌economic‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌was‌ ‌highly‌ ‌influenced‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌work‌ ‌of‌ ‌economic‌ ‌historian‌ ‌Karl‌ ‌Polanyi.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Polanyi‌ ‌drew‌ ‌on‌ ‌anthropological‌ ‌studies‌ ‌to‌ ‌argue‌ ‌that‌ ‌true‌ ‌market‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌was‌ ‌limited‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌restricted‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌western,‌ ‌industrial‌ ‌\nsocieties.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Applying‌ ‌formal‌ ‌economic‌ ‌theory‌ ‌(Formalism)‌ ‌to‌ ‌non-industrial‌ ‌societies‌ ‌was‌ ‌mistaken,‌ ‌he‌ ‌argued.‌ ‌In‌ ‌non-industrial‌ ‌societies,‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌was‌ ‌\n\"embedded\"‌ ‌in‌ ‌such‌ ‌non-market‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌as‌ ‌kinship,‌ ‌religion,‌ ‌and‌ ‌politics‌ ‌(an‌ ‌idea‌ ‌he‌ ‌borrowed‌ ‌from‌ ‌Mauss).‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌labelled‌ ‌this‌ ‌approach‌ ‌Substantivism.‌ ‌The‌ ‌formalist–substantivist‌ ‌debate‌ ‌was‌ ‌highly‌ ‌influential‌ ‌and‌ ‌defined‌ ‌an‌ ‌era.‌ ‌\n ‌\nScope‌ ‌of‌ ‌economic‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌\nDuring‌ ‌its‌ ‌formative‌ ‌period,‌ ‌its‌ ‌scope‌ ‌was‌ ‌restricted‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌economic‌ ‌life‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌primitives.‌ ‌The‌ ‌major‌ ‌debates‌ ‌in‌ ‌economic‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌\nhave‌ ‌centered‌ ‌around‌ ‌ ‌\n(a)‌ ‌the‌ ‌universal‌ ‌applicability‌ ‌of‌ ‌Western‌ ‌generated‌ ‌categories‌ ‌of‌ ‌analysis,‌ ‌ ‌\n(b)‌ ‌the‌ ‌question‌ ‌of‌ ‌value,‌ ‌ ‌\n(c)‌ ‌the‌ ‌question‌ ‌of‌ ‌history‌ ‌and‌ ‌connectedness‌ ‌between‌ ‌polities,‌ ‌and‌ ‌ ‌\n(d)‌ ‌the‌ ‌weight‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌(meaning)‌ ‌in‌ ‌economic‌ ‌processes.‌ ‌\n ‌\nIts‌ ‌coverage‌ ‌has‌ ‌widened‌ ‌to‌ ‌include‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌economic‌ ‌life‌ ‌of‌ ‌primitives,‌ ‌peasants‌ ‌and‌ ‌modern‌ ‌societies.It‌ ‌has‌ ‌now‌ ‌amplified‌ ‌in‌ ‌several‌ ‌\nbranches:‌ ‌\n1.‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌of‌ ‌Subsistence‌ ‌Systems,‌ ‌ ‌\n2.‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌of‌ ‌Economic‌ ‌History,‌ ‌ ‌\n3.‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌of‌ ‌Primitive‌ ‌Economy,‌ ‌ ‌\n4.‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌of‌ ‌Peasant‌ ‌Economies,‌ ‌ ‌\n5.‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌of‌ ‌Urban‌ ‌Economies,‌ ‌ ‌\n6.‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌of‌ ‌Entrepreneurship,‌ ‌ ‌\n7.‌ ‌Business‌ ‌Anthropology,‌ ‌ ‌\n8.‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌of‌ ‌Economic‌ ‌Holism‌ ‌ ‌\n9.‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌of‌ ‌Economic‌ ‌Development.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nI.‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌of‌ ‌subsistence‌ ‌System‌-It‌ ‌studies‌ ‌subsistence‌ ‌systems‌ ‌as‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌socio-economic‌ ‌systems.‌ ‌\nForde.‌ ‌Wispel‌ ‌and‌ ‌several‌ ‌other‌ ‌examined‌ ‌the‌ ‌complex‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌and‌ ‌studied‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌that‌ ‌create‌ ‌major‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌of‌ ‌socio-economic‌ ‌\nadaptations‌ ‌like‌ ‌hunting-gathering.‌ ‌horticulture,‌ ‌pastoralism‌ ‌and‌ ‌agriculture.‌ ‌\n ‌\n500‌ ‌\nII.‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌of‌ ‌Economic‌ ‌History-‌ ‌It‌ ‌studies‌ ‌the‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌economic‌ ‌systems.‌ ‌Morgan,‌ ‌Tylor‌ ‌and‌ ‌Wheeler,‌ ‌etc‌ ‌have‌ ‌shown‌ ‌that‌ ‌simple‌ ‌\neconomic‌ ‌systems‌ ‌gave‌ ‌rise‌ ‌to‌ ‌complex‌ ‌economic‌ ‌systems.‌ ‌The‌ ‌technology‌ ‌has‌ ‌played‌ ‌a‌ ‌key‌ ‌role‌ ‌in‌ ‌every‌ ‌stage‌ ‌of‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌systems‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nproduction,‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌and‌ ‌consumption‌ ‌in‌ ‌diverse‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌\n ‌\nIII.‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌of‌ ‌Primitive‌ ‌Economies-‌ ‌It‌ ‌studies‌ ‌and‌ ‌services‌ ‌in‌ ‌simple‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌Malinowski,‌ ‌Firth,‌ ‌Herskovits,‌ ‌Thurnwald,‌ ‌etc‌ ‌have‌ ‌shown‌ ‌\nthat‌ ‌the‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌economies‌ ‌are‌ ‌characterized‌ ‌by‌ ‌simple‌ ‌tools,‌ ‌Limited‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌tools,‌ ‌little‌ ‌specialization‌ ‌of‌ ‌labour,‌ ‌early‌ ‌work‌ ‌apprenticeship‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nfamilial‌ ‌and‌ ‌custodial‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌production.‌ ‌\n ‌\nIV.‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌of‌ ‌Peasant‌ ‌Economies-‌ ‌It‌ ‌studies‌ ‌the‌ ‌economic‌ ‌systems‌ ‌of‌ ‌rural‌ ‌agriculturists.‌ ‌Nash,‌ ‌Foster‌ ‌etc‌ ‌studied‌ ‌the‌ ‌peasant‌ ‌economies.‌ ‌\npeasant‌ ‌societies‌ ‌are‌ ‌partly‌ ‌self-sufficient.‌ ‌The‌ ‌means‌ ‌and‌ ‌results‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌production‌ ‌are‌ ‌controlled‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌outside‌ ‌elite‌ ‌groups.‌ ‌\n ‌\nV.‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌of‌ ‌urban‌ ‌Economies-‌ ‌‌It‌ ‌studies‌ ‌the‌ ‌economic‌ ‌life‌ ‌of‌ ‌migrants‌ ‌and‌ ‌poor‌ ‌in‌ ‌urban‌ ‌centres‌ ‌Gluckvan,‌ ‌Oscar‌ ‌Lewis,‌ ‌Polanyi,‌ ‌\nBohannan,‌ ‌Sahlins‌ ‌(1960),‌ ‌Service‌ ‌etc‌ ‌show‌ ‌that‌ ‌economic‌ ‌system‌ ‌are.‌ ‌\n ‌\nVI.‌ ‌Business‌ ‌Anthropology-‌ ‌It‌ ‌analyses‌ ‌the‌ ‌internal‌ ‌operations‌ ‌of‌ ‌companies,‌ ‌sometimes‌ ‌carrying‌ ‌out‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌audits,‌ ‌it‌ ‌surveys‌ ‌market‌ ‌potential‌ ‌\nfor‌ ‌products,‌ ‌help‌ ‌business‌ ‌improve‌ ‌their‌ ‌efficiency.‌ ‌Anne‌ ‌weber,‌ ‌Brian,‌ ‌Hendrich,‌ ‌Soya,‌ ‌etc‌ ‌studied‌ ‌Business‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌\nVII.‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌of‌ ‌Entrepreneurship‌-It‌ ‌studies‌ ‌entrepreneurs‌ ‌in‌ ‌primitive,‌ ‌peasant‌ ‌and‌ ‌industrial‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌Firth,‌ ‌Timberg.‌ ‌Mortin‌ ‌,‌ ‌Geetz‌ ‌,‌ ‌\nsinger‌ ‌(1963)etc‌ ‌have‌ ‌contributed‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌field.‌ ‌They‌ ‌have‌ ‌shown‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌successes‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌entrepreneurs‌ ‌depend‌ ‌upon‌ ‌their‌ ‌resourcefulness,‌ ‌\norganizational‌ ‌skills‌ ‌and‌ ‌correct‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌of‌ ‌regional,‌ ‌national‌ ‌and‌ ‌international‌ ‌situations‌ ‌for‌ ‌products‌ ‌and‌ ‌services.‌ ‌\n ‌\nVIII.‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌of‌ ‌Economic‌ ‌Holism‌-It‌ ‌deals‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌inter-relatives‌ ‌of‌ ‌economic‌ ‌life‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌holistic‌ ‌manner.‌ ‌Forde‌ ‌(1948)‌ ‌examined‌ ‌economy‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nrelation‌ ‌to‌ ‌habitat‌ ‌and‌ ‌society.‌ ‌Evans-Pritchard‌ ‌(1940)‌ ‌analysed‌ ‌the‌ ‌interrelations‌ ‌of‌ ‌Nuer‌ ‌econonic‌ ‌and‌ ‌linguistic‌ ‌aspects.‌ ‌Malinowski‌ ‌(1935)‌ ‌\nexamined‌ ‌the‌ ‌close‌ ‌relations‌ ‌between‌ ‌magic‌ ‌and‌ ‌economic‌ ‌life‌ ‌of‌ ‌Trobrianders.‌ ‌Fried‌ ‌(1960,‌ ‌1967)‌ ‌has‌ ‌shown‌ ‌how‌ ‌econonic‌ ‌life‌ ‌and‌ ‌political‌ ‌life‌ ‌are‌ ‌\ninterwoven‌ ‌with‌ ‌each‌ ‌other.‌ ‌Rappopart‌ ‌and‌ ‌Sahlins‌ ‌(1968,‌ ‌1972)‌ ‌studied‌ ‌the‌ ‌inter-relations‌ ‌of‌ ‌magic,‌ ‌religion‌ ‌and‌ ‌economies.‌ ‌Bohannan‌ ‌(1963)‌ ‌\nanalysed‌ ‌the‌ ‌correspondence‌ ‌of‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌and‌ ‌economy.‌ ‌\n ‌\nIX.‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌of‌ ‌Economic‌ ‌Development-‌ ‌It‌ ‌deals‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌variety‌ ‌of‌ ‌strategies‌ ‌designed‌ ‌for‌ ‌increasing‌ ‌thecapabilities‌ ‌of‌ ‌national‌ ‌economic‌ ‌\nsystems‌ ‌to‌ ‌improve‌ ‌human‌ ‌welfare.‌ ‌It‌ ‌shows‌ ‌role‌ ‌of‌ ‌individuals,‌ ‌nations,‌ ‌and‌ ‌international‌ ‌aid‌ ‌agencies‌ ‌to‌ ‌achieve‌ ‌economic‌ ‌development‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nimpact‌ ‌of‌ ‌different‌ ‌personal,‌ ‌political,‌ ‌religious‌ ‌and‌ ‌ethnic‌ ‌beliefs‌ ‌and‌ ‌values‌ ‌on‌ ‌Economic‌ ‌Anthropology.‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌of‌ ‌worker‌ ‌system‌ ‌is‌ ‌another‌ ‌\ninterest.‌ ‌\nEconomic‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌has‌ ‌adopted‌ ‌substantive‌ ‌and‌ ‌formal‌ ‌approaches‌ ‌to‌ ‌study‌ ‌the‌ ‌static‌ ‌and‌ ‌dynamic‌ ‌aspects‌ ‌of‌ ‌economic‌ ‌life‌ ‌of‌ ‌primitive,‌ ‌\npeasant‌ ‌and‌ ‌urban‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌Thus‌ ‌economic‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌has‌ ‌acquired‌ ‌vast‌ ‌scope‌ ‌as‌ ‌it‌ ‌has‌ ‌developed‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌past‌ ‌six‌ ‌decades.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nRelevance:‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌methods‌ ‌of‌ ‌economic‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌basic‌ ‌methods‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌anthropology.‌ ‌ ‌\n501‌ ‌\n●Focus‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌informal‌ ‌sector‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌economy‌ ‌has‌ ‌also‌ ‌contributed‌ ‌a‌ ‌major‌ ‌breakthrough‌ ‌by‌ ‌\nexpanding‌ ‌the‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌'work.'‌ ‌ ‌\nResearch‌ ‌on‌ ‌informal‌ ‌relations‌ ‌economic‌ ‌or‌ ‌otherwise)‌ ‌is‌ ‌bound‌ ‌to‌ ‌prove‌ ‌fruitful‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌realities‌ ‌of‌ ‌flexible‌ ‌production,‌ ‌the‌ ‌weakening‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nnation-state‌ ‌model,‌ ‌the‌ ‌informational‌ ‌revolution,‌ ‌and‌ ‌massive‌ ‌population‌ ‌movements‌ ‌point‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌increasing‌ ‌value‌ ‌of‌ ‌\npersonal‌ ‌networks‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌structuring‌ ‌of‌ ‌contemporary‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Earlier‌ ‌anthropologist‌ ‌didn't‌ ‌recognize‌ ‌the‌ ‌economic‌ ‌thread‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌culture‌ ‌,this‌ ‌purpose‌ ‌was‌ ‌served‌ ‌\nby‌ ‌an‌ ‌economic‌ ‌anthropologist.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Presently,‌ ‌economic‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌is‌ ‌moving‌ ‌beyond‌ ‌the‌ ‌boundaries‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌conceptual‌ ‌economic‌ ‌domain.‌ ‌ ‌\nWhile‌ ‌it‌ ‌remains‌ ‌useful‌ ‌to‌ ‌retain‌ ‌the‌ ‌material‌ ‌emphasis‌ ‌of‌ ‌economic‌ ‌processes,‌ ‌in‌ ‌practice,‌ ‌material‌ ‌relations‌ ‌should‌ ‌be‌ ‌studied‌ ‌together‌ ‌with‌ ‌\ntheir‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌expressions.‌ ‌ ‌\nOn‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌hand,‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌of‌ ‌worldwide‌ ‌connectedness-in‌ ‌systems‌ ‌of‌ ‌provisioning,‌ ‌relations‌ ‌of‌ ‌production,‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌of‌ ‌consumption,‌ ‌labor‌ ‌\nmigration,‌ ‌etc.-need‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌taken‌ ‌into‌ ‌account.‌ ‌The‌ ‌practice‌ ‌of‌ ‌economic‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌seems‌ ‌bound‌ ‌toward‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌reproduction‌ ‌\nas‌ ‌a‌ ‌whole.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Economic‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌great‌ ‌tool‌ ‌to‌ ‌understand‌ ‌the‌ ‌tribal‌ ‌socio‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌structure.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nFormalist‌ ‌and‌ ‌Substantivist‌ ‌debate;‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nWhat‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌Debate?‌ ‌\nThere‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌‌debate‌ ‌in‌ ‌economic‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌formalist‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌substantivist‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌concern‌ ‌question‌ ‌is‌ ‌whether‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌laws‌ ‌of‌ ‌\neconomics‌ ‌are‌ ‌universal.‌ ‌\n ‌\n502‌ ‌\n●Formalists‌ ‌‌argue‌ ‌that‌ ‌economics‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌science‌ ‌and‌ ‌that‌ ‌economic‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌is‌ ‌closely‌ ‌related.‌ ‌economic‌ ‌rationality‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌basic‌ ‌law.‌ ‌ ‌\n○People‌ ‌choose‌ ‌what‌ ‌is‌ ‌their‌ ‌best‌ ‌interest‌ ‌and‌ ‌reject‌ ‌what‌ ‌is‌ ‌not.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌permits‌ ‌comparison‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌made‌ ‌between‌ ‌radically‌ ‌different‌ ‌cultures.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Substantivist‌ ‌argue‌ ‌against‌ ‌universal‌ ‌law‌ ‌economics‌ ‌especially‌ ‌the‌ ‌idea‌ ‌of‌ ‌economic‌ ‌rationality.‌ ‌Instead‌ ‌they‌ ‌emphasize‌ ‌economics‌ ‌as‌ ‌\nembedded‌ ‌in‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Different‌ ‌spheres‌ ‌of‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌operate‌ ‌differently‌ ‌in‌ ‌various‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌ ‌\n○There‌ ‌are‌ ‌different‌ ‌attitudes‌ ‌to‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌and‌ ‌work‌ ‌and‌ ‌different‌ ‌concepts‌ ‌of‌ ‌values‌ ‌attached‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌good‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nThe‌ ‌issue‌ ‌of‌ ‌debates‌ ‌are:‌ ‌\n●Concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌insufficiency,‌ ‌scarcity‌ ‌and‌ ‌choice.‌ ‌\n●Types‌ ‌of‌ ‌economy‌ ‌\n●Market‌ ‌money‌ ‌and‌ ‌trade‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nOverview‌ ‌\n\n\nSubstantivism‌ ‌\n\t\nFormalism‌ ‌\n\n\n●The‌ ‌substantivists‌ ‌are‌ ‌Malinowski‌ ‌(1922),‌ ‌Karl‌ ‌Polanyi,‌ ‌George‌ ‌\nDalton,‌ ‌Cyril‌ ‌Belshaw‌ ‌and‌ ‌Paul‌ ‌Bohannan.‌ ‌\n\t\n●The‌ ‌formalists‌ ‌are‌ ‌Raymond‌ ‌Firth,‌ ‌Herskovits‌ ‌and‌ ‌Burlings.‌ ‌\n\n\n●The‌ ‌substantive‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌holds‌ ‌good‌ ‌to‌ ‌primitive,‌ ‌peasant‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nadvanced‌ ‌economic‌ ‌life.‌ ‌\n\t\n●The‌ ‌formal‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌holds‌ ‌good‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌economies‌ ‌of‌ ‌advanced‌ ‌\nsocieties.‌ ‌\n\n\n●Anthropologists‌ ‌who‌ ‌adhered‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌substantive‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌and‌ ‌\ndescribed,‌ ‌analyzed‌ ‌and‌ ‌explained‌ ‌the‌ ‌economic‌ ‌life‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\npeople‌ ‌came‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌recognized‌ ‌as‌ ‌\"substantivists‌ ‌\n\t\n●Anthropologists‌ ‌who‌ ‌used‌ ‌formal‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌in‌ ‌examining,‌ ‌\nanalyzing‌ ‌and‌ ‌interpreting‌ ‌economic‌ ‌processes‌ ‌came‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌\nbranded‌ ‌as‌ ‌\"formalists\".‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n503‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nConcept‌ ‌of‌ ‌insufficiency,‌ ‌scarcity‌ ‌and‌ ‌choice‌ ‌-‌ ‌Scarcity‌ ‌is‌ ‌insufficiency‌ ‌of‌ ‌means‌ ‌and‌ ‌choices‌ ‌are‌ ‌induced‌ ‌by‌ ‌that‌ ‌insufficiency‌ ‌\n\n\nSubstantivism‌ ‌\n\t\nFormalism‌ ‌\n\n\n●Scarcity‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌socially‌ ‌determined‌ ‌condition.‌ ‌\n\t\n●Man‌ ‌has‌ ‌unlimited‌ ‌wants.‌ ‌\n\n\n●Scarcity‌ ‌prevails‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌society‌ ‌which‌ ‌places‌ ‌Great‌ ‌Value‌ ‌on‌ ‌\nmaterial‌ ‌acquisition‌ ‌relative‌ ‌to‌ ‌other‌ ‌goal‌ ‌attainment.‌ ‌\n\t\n●Means‌ ‌to‌ ‌satisfy‌ ‌them‌ ‌are‌ ‌limited.‌ ‌Therefore‌ ‌scarcity‌ ‌is‌ ‌\nuniversal.‌ ‌\n\n\n●In‌ ‌a‌ ‌society‌ ‌where‌ ‌desirable‌ ‌objects‌ ‌are‌ ‌unlimited‌ ‌themselves,‌ ‌\nscarcity‌ ‌may‌ ‌not‌ ‌obtain‌ ‌at‌ ‌all.‌ ‌\n\t\n●This‌ ‌scarcity‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌merely‌ ‌a‌ ‌physical‌ ‌storage‌ ‌but‌ ‌a‌ ‌condition‌ ‌of‌ ‌\ninsufficiency‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌desire‌ ‌and‌ ‌wants.‌ ‌Therefore,‌ ‌choice‌ ‌will‌ ‌\nbe‌ ‌induced‌ ‌by‌ ‌insufficiency.‌ ‌\n\n\n●If‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌scarcity‌ ‌there‌ ‌will‌ ‌be‌ ‌no‌ ‌need‌ ‌for‌ ‌economizing.‌ ‌\n\t\n●There‌ ‌must‌ ‌be‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌one‌ ‌use‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌means‌ ‌and‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌\non‌ ‌end‌ ‌ordered‌ ‌in‌ ‌sequence‌ ‌of‌ ‌preferences.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nTypes‌ ‌of‌ ‌economy‌ ‌\n\n\nSubstantivism‌ ‌\n\t\nFormalism‌ ‌\n\n\n●The‌ ‌economy‌ ‌is‌ ‌of‌ ‌2‌ ‌types:‌ ‌\ni)‌ ‌The‌ ‌empirical‌ ‌economy‌ ‌\nii)‌ ‌The‌ ‌formal‌ ‌economy‌ ‌\nEmpirical‌ ‌economy‌ ‌exists‌ ‌in‌ ‌simple‌ ‌and‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌societies‌ ‌but‌ ‌\nformal‌ ‌economy‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌in‌ ‌modern‌ ‌complex‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌\n\t\n●Formal‌ ‌economic‌ ‌theory‌ ‌is‌ ‌equally‌ ‌and‌ ‌universally‌ ‌applicable‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌economic‌ ‌systems‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌\n\n\n●The‌ ‌substantivists‌ ‌assert‌ ‌that‌ ‌'economic‌ ‌theory‌ ‌developed‌ ‌by‌ ‌\n\t\n●Edward‌ ‌Leclair‌ ‌and‌ ‌Scott‌ ‌Hook‌ ‌questioned‌ ‌the‌ ‌need‌ ‌for‌ ‌dividing‌ ‌\n504‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌economists‌ ‌is‌ ‌applicable‌ ‌to‌ ‌only‌ ‌market‌ ‌economies‌ ‌but‌ ‌not‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌empirical‌ ‌economies.‌ ‌\n\t\nthe‌ ‌economy‌ ‌as‌ ‌substantivists‌ ‌did‌ ‌And‌ ‌why‌ ‌there‌ ‌should‌ ‌be‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nsubstantive‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌of‌ ‌economy‌ ‌at‌ ‌all.‌ ‌ ‌\n\n\n●An‌ ‌empirical‌ ‌economy(according‌ ‌to‌ ‌Polanyi)‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌instituted‌ ‌\nprocess‌ ‌of‌ ‌interaction‌ ‌between‌ ‌man‌ ‌and‌ ‌environment‌ ‌and‌ ‌it‌ ‌\nresults‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌continuous‌ ‌supply‌ ‌of‌ ‌want‌ ‌satisfying‌ ‌material‌ ‌means.‌ ‌\n\t\n●They‌ ‌argued‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌extreme‌ ‌conclusions‌ ‌of‌ ‌substantivists‌ ‌are‌ ‌\nbased‌ ‌on‌ ‌\"Fallacious‌ ‌logic,‌ ‌Prendo‌ ‌individualism,‌ ‌ultimately‌ ‌\nreducible‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌status‌ ‌of‌ ‌metaphysical‌ ‌propositions\".‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nMarket‌ ‌money‌ ‌and‌ ‌trade‌ ‌ ‌\n\n\nSubstantivism‌ ‌\n\t\nFormalism‌ ‌\n\n\n●Trade‌ ‌is‌ ‌relatively‌ ‌a‌ ‌peaceful‌ ‌method‌ ‌of‌ ‌acquiring‌ ‌goods‌ ‌which‌ ‌\nare‌ ‌not‌ ‌available‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌spot.‌ ‌\n\t\n●Market‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌locus‌ ‌of‌ ‌exchange.‌ ‌\n ‌\n\n\n●Trade‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌activity‌ ‌but‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌activity.‌ ‌Therefore,‌ ‌\ndifferent‌ ‌communities‌ ‌meet‌ ‌at‌ ‌a‌ ‌place‌ ‌for‌ ‌different‌ ‌purposes‌ ‌and‌ ‌\none‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌purposes‌ ‌being‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌of‌ ‌goods.‌ ‌\n\t\n●Trade‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌real‌ ‌exchange.‌ ‌\n ‌\n\n\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌Dalton,‌ ‌in‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌societies‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌only‌ ‌\nmarketplaces,‌ ‌but‌ ‌not‌ ‌market‌ ‌systems.‌ ‌In‌ ‌economic‌ ‌\nanthropology,‌ ‌market‌ ‌mews‌ ‌market‌ ‌place‌ ‌(primitive‌ ‌societies),‌ ‌\nan‌ ‌actual‌ ‌site‌ ‌where‌ ‌goods‌ ‌change‌ ‌hands‌ ‌by‌ ‌purchase‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nsale.‌ ‌\n\t\n●Money‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌means‌ ‌of‌ ‌exchange.‌ ‌\n ‌\n\n\n●In‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌societies‌ ‌money‌ ‌is‌ ‌absent.‌ ‌Therefore,‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌barter.‌ ‌\nPrimitive‌ ‌economy‌ ‌is‌ ‌restricted‌ ‌to‌ ‌production‌ ‌of‌ ‌material‌ ‌items,‌ ‌\nin‌ ‌such‌ ‌economies‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌price‌ ‌system.‌ ‌And‌ ‌also‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌\nno‌ ‌feedback‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌price‌ ‌system‌ ‌in‌ ‌non-market‌ ‌spheres‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\neconomy.‌ ‌\n\t\n●Trade‌ ‌is‌ ‌directed‌ ‌by‌ ‌prices‌ ‌and‌ ‌prices‌ ‌are‌ ‌a‌ ‌function‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nmarket.‌ ‌Therefore,‌ ‌all‌ ‌trade‌ ‌is‌ ‌market‌ ‌trade‌ ‌just‌ ‌as‌ ‌all‌ ‌money‌ ‌is‌ ‌\nexchange‌ ‌money.‌ ‌\n\n\n●The‌ ‌substantivism,‌ ‌argue‌ ‌money‌ ‌is‌ ‌independent‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌market.‌ ‌It‌ ‌\nis‌ ‌derived‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌definite‌ ‌uses‌ ‌to‌ ‌which‌ ‌\"quantifiable‌ ‌objects\"‌ ‌\nare‌ ‌put.‌ ‌Money‌ ‌is‌ ‌\"only‌ ‌useful‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌payment,‌ ‌standard‌ ‌\n\t\n ‌\n505‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌exchange.‌ ‌It‌ ‌has‌ ‌emerged‌ ‌independent‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌market‌ ‌\nsystem.‌ ‌\n\t\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nCriticism:‌ ‌\n●Formalist:‌ ‌\n○Critics‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌formalist‌ ‌position‌ ‌question‌ ‌its‌ ‌central‌ ‌assumptions,‌ ‌in‌ ‌particular‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌universality‌ ‌of‌ ‌rational‌ ‌choice‌ ‌and‌ ‌utility‌ ‌\nmaximization‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌assumed‌ ‌across‌ ‌all‌ ‌cultures,‌ ‌including‌ ‌its‌ ‌reductionism‌ ‌to‌ ‌explain‌ ‌even‌ ‌modern‌ ‌Western‌ ‌economies.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Prattis‌ ‌noted‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌premise‌ ‌of‌ ‌utility‌ ‌maximization‌ ‌is‌ ‌tautological;‌ ‌whatever‌ ‌a‌ ‌person‌ ‌does,‌ ‌may‌ ‌it‌ ‌be‌ ‌work‌ ‌or‌ ‌leisure,‌ ‌is‌ ‌declared‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nbe‌ ‌utility‌ ‌maximization,‌ ‌a‌ ‌premise‌ ‌that‌ ‌can‌ ‌never‌ ‌be‌ ‌contradicted‌ ‌or‌ ‌disproven.‌ ‌ ‌\n■If‌ ‌he‌ ‌or‌ ‌she‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌maximize‌ ‌money‌ ‌then‌ ‌it‌ ‌must‌ ‌be‌ ‌pleasure‌ ‌or‌ ‌some‌ ‌other‌ ‌value.‌ ‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌example‌,‌ ‌a‌ ‌person‌ ‌may‌ ‌sacrifice‌ ‌their‌ ‌own‌ ‌time,‌ ‌finances,‌ ‌or‌ ‌even‌ ‌health‌ ‌to‌ ‌help‌ ‌others.‌ ‌\n○Formalists‌ ‌would‌ ‌then‌ ‌pronounce‌ ‌that‌ ‌they‌ ‌do‌ ‌so‌ ‌because‌ ‌they‌ ‌value‌ ‌helping‌ ‌others,‌ ‌and‌ ‌so‌ ‌sacrifice‌ ‌other‌ ‌goals‌ ‌in‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nmaximize‌ ‌this‌ ‌value‌ ‌(e.g.‌ ‌meaning,‌ ‌satisfaction‌ ‌of‌ ‌having‌ ‌helped,‌ ‌approval‌ ‌from‌ ‌others‌ ‌etc.),‌ ‌even‌ ‌though‌ ‌it‌ ‌contradicts‌ ‌formalists‌ ‌\nusual‌ ‌dictum‌ ‌of‌ ‌profit‌ ‌maximization.‌ ‌\n●Substantivism‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌has‌ ‌also‌ ‌had‌ ‌its‌ ‌critics.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Prattis‌ ‌argued‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌strict‌ ‌distinction‌ ‌between‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌and‌ ‌modern‌ ‌economies‌ ‌in‌ ‌substantivism‌ ‌is‌ ‌problematic.‌ ‌ ‌\n○He‌ ‌implies‌ ‌that‌ ‌substantivism‌ ‌focuses‌ ‌on‌ ‌social‌ ‌structures‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌expense‌ ‌of‌ ‌analyzing‌ ‌individual‌ ‌agency.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Non-maximizing‌ ‌adaptation‌ ‌strategies‌ ‌occur‌ ‌in‌ ‌all‌ ‌societies,‌ ‌not‌ ‌just‌ ‌in‌ ‌\"primitive\"‌ ‌ones.‌ ‌\n○Similarly,‌ ‌Plattner‌ ‌argues‌ ‌that‌ ‌generalization‌ ‌across‌ ‌different‌ ‌societies‌ ‌is‌ ‌still‌ ‌possible,‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌that‌ ‌Western‌ ‌and‌ ‌non-Western‌ ‌\neconomics‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌entirely‌ ‌different.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌an‌ ‌age‌ ‌of‌ ‌globalization‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌no‌ ‌\"pure\"‌ ‌preindustrial‌ ‌societies‌ ‌left.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Conditions‌ ‌of‌ ‌resource‌ ‌scarcity‌ ‌exist‌ ‌everywhere‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌world.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Anthropological‌ ‌fieldwork‌ ‌has‌ ‌demonstrated‌ ‌rational‌ ‌behavior‌ ‌and‌ ‌complex‌ ‌economic‌ ‌choices‌ ‌amongst‌ ‌peasants.‌ ‌\n■For‌ ‌example,‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌in‌ ‌communist‌ ‌societies‌ ‌can‌ ‌still‌ ‌engage‌ ‌in‌ ‌rational‌ ‌utility‌ ‌maximizing‌ ‌behavior‌ ‌by‌ ‌building‌ ‌\nrelationships‌ ‌with‌ ‌bureaucrats‌ ‌who‌ ‌control‌ ‌distribution,‌ ‌or‌ ‌by‌ ‌using‌ ‌small‌ ‌plots‌ ‌of‌ ‌land‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌garden‌ ‌to‌ ‌supplement‌ ‌official‌ ‌\nfood‌ ‌rations.‌ ‌\n○Cook‌ ‌observed‌ ‌that‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌significant‌ ‌conceptual‌ ‌problems‌ ‌with‌ ‌substantivists’‌ ‌theories:‌ ‌\n■\"They‌ ‌define‌ ‌economics‌ ‌as‌ ‌an‌ ‌aspect‌ ‌of‌ ‌everything‌ ‌that‌ ‌provisions‌ ‌society‌ ‌but‌ ‌nothing‌ ‌that‌ ‌provisions‌ ‌society‌ ‌is‌ ‌defined‌ ‌as‌ ‌\neconomic.\"‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nConclusion:‌ ‌\n506‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌two‌ ‌approaches‌ ‌are‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌viewpoints‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌single‌ ‌theme.‌ ‌If‌ ‌we‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌apply‌ ‌the‌ ‌formative‌ ‌definition‌ ‌to‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌systems,‌ ‌equally‌ ‌\nbusiness‌ ‌aim‌ ‌at‌ ‌times‌ ‌to‌ ‌discover‌ ‌the‌ ‌economic‌ ‌rationality‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌good‌ ‌deal‌ ‌of‌ ‌Western‌ ‌economic‌ ‌behaviour.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌factors‌ ‌that‌ ‌economic‌ ‌processes‌ ‌in‌ ‌some‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌society‌ ‌which‌ ‌came‌ ‌in‌ ‌contact‌ ‌with‌ ‌advanced‌ ‌societies,‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌successfully‌ ‌studied‌ ‌\nusing‌ ‌the‌ ‌formal‌ ‌economic‌ ‌theory.‌ ‌\n●On‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌hand,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Economics‌ ‌of‌ ‌some‌ ‌other‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌societies‌ ‌which‌ ‌still‌ ‌maintain‌ ‌their‌ ‌age-old‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌of‌ ‌life,‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌fruitfully‌ ‌examined‌ ‌\nusing‌ ‌substantive‌ ‌economic‌ ‌theory.‌ ‌\n●Finally‌ ‌in‌ ‌any‌ ‌empirical‌ ‌study‌ ‌the‌ ‌synthesis‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌two‌ ‌approaches‌ ‌will‌ ‌be‌ ‌of‌ ‌great‌ ‌use‌ ‌in‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌and‌ ‌interpreting‌ ‌the‌ ‌economic‌ ‌life‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌and‌ ‌peasants‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n3.Economic‌ ‌Organization:Principles‌ ‌governing‌ ‌production,‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌and‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌(reciprocity,‌ ‌redistribution‌ ‌and‌ ‌market),‌ ‌in‌ ‌\ncommunities,‌ ‌subsisting‌ ‌on‌ ‌hunting‌ ‌and‌ ‌gathering,‌ ‌fishing,‌ ‌swiddening,‌ ‌pastoralism,‌ ‌horticulture,‌ ‌and‌ ‌agriculture;‌ ‌Globalization‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nindigenous‌ ‌economic‌ ‌systems-Part-II‌ ‌\n ‌\n‌ ‌\nPrinciples‌ ‌governing‌ ‌production,‌ ‌Distribution‌ ‌and‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌(reciprocity,‌ ‌redistribution‌ ‌and‌ ‌market),‌ ‌in‌ ‌communities,‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nKey‌ ‌Components‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌Economic‌ ‌System‌ ‌\n1.Production‌ ‌\n2.Distribution‌ ‌\n3.Exchange‌ ‌\n4.Consumption‌ ‌\n507‌ ‌\n ‌\nProduction‌ ‌\n●Production‌ ‌is‌ ‌defined‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌various‌ ‌modes‌ ‌used‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌society‌ ‌to‌ ‌procure‌ ‌their‌ ‌material‌ ‌means‌ ‌of‌ ‌existence.‌ ‌The‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nmajority‌ ‌encompasses‌ ‌embossed‌ ‌areas‌ ‌of‌ ‌economic‌ ‌activities.‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌activities‌ ‌range‌ ‌from:‌ ‌\n○Food‌ ‌Collection,‌ ‌ ‌\n○Food‌ ‌Production,‌ ‌ ‌\n■Horticulture‌ ‌\n■Pastoralism‌ ‌\n■Intensive‌ ‌Agriculture‌ ‌\n○Then‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌highly‌ ‌organised‌ ‌Industrial‌ ‌Operation.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌productive‌ ‌operations‌ ‌represent‌ ‌a‌ ‌combination‌ ‌of‌ ‌three‌ ‌primary‌ ‌factors‌ ‌that‌ ‌depends‌ ‌very‌ ‌heavily‌ ‌on‌ ‌one‌ ‌another-‌ ‌land‌ ‌labour‌ ‌and‌ ‌\ncapital.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nFood‌ ‌Collection‌ ‌\n●Definition:‌ ‌\n508‌ ‌\n○Food‌ ‌collection,‌ ‌encompassing‌ ‌the‌ ‌production‌ ‌strategies‌ ‌of‌ ‌hunting,‌ ‌fishing‌ ‌and‌ ‌gathering,‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌all‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌subsistence‌ ‌\ntechnology‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌food‌ ‌is‌ ‌secured‌ ‌from‌ ‌naturally‌ ‌occurring‌ ‌resources‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌wild‌ ‌plants‌ ‌and‌ ‌animals,‌ ‌without‌ ‌significant‌ ‌\ndomestication‌ ‌of‌ ‌either.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Food‌ ‌collection‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌oldest‌ ‌survival‌ ‌strategy‌ ‌known‌ ‌to‌ ‌man.‌ ‌But‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌present‌ ‌day,‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌very‌ ‌few‌ ‌communities‌ ‌left‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌world‌ ‌\nwho‌ ‌are‌ ‌entirely‌ ‌dependent‌ ‌on‌ ‌hunting‌ ‌and‌ ‌gathering‌ ‌for‌ ‌livelihood‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Australian‌ ‌aborigines,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Inuits‌ ‌living‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌\narctic‌ ‌regions‌ ‌of‌ ‌Canada,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Andamanese‌ ‌tribes‌ ‌like‌ ‌the‌ ‌Onge‌ ‌and‌ ‌Jarawa‌‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌ ‌\n●However,‌ ‌a‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌communities‌ ‌continue‌ ‌to‌ ‌practice‌ ‌hunting-gathering‌ ‌and‌ ‌fishing‌ ‌to‌ ‌supplement‌ ‌their‌ ‌nutrition‌ ‌from‌ ‌agriculture.‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌instance,‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌state‌ ‌of‌ ‌Assam,‌ ‌many‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌tribes‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌Karbis,‌ ‌Tiwas,‌ ‌Mishings,‌ ‌Rabhas‌ ‌‌etc.‌ ‌are‌ ‌experts‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌art‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌fishing‌ ‌and‌ ‌hunting,‌ ‌which‌ ‌they‌ ‌practice‌ ‌in‌ ‌conjunction‌ ‌with‌ ‌agriculture.‌ ‌\n ‌\nObservation:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●While‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌exclusively‌ ‌hunter-gatherer‌ ‌communities‌ ‌may‌ ‌help‌ ‌us‌ ‌arrive‌ ‌at‌ ‌some‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌of‌ ‌man’s‌ ‌life‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌past,‌ ‌\nEmber‌ ‌and‌ ‌Ember‌ ‌(1994)‌ ‌cautions‌ ‌against‌ ‌the‌ ‌excessive‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌contemporary‌ ‌observations‌ ‌to‌ ‌draw‌ ‌inferences‌ ‌about‌ ‌the‌ ‌past‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nnumber‌ ‌of‌ ‌reasons.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌their‌ ‌view,‌ ‌we‌ ‌must‌ ‌understand‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌earlier‌ ‌hunter-gatherers‌ ‌lived‌ ‌in‌ ‌almost‌ ‌all‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌environments,‌ ‌including‌ ‌some‌ ‌very‌ ‌\nbountiful‌ ‌ones‌ ‌and‌ ‌not‌ ‌like‌ ‌the‌ ‌contemporary‌ ‌ones‌ ‌who‌ ‌live‌ ‌mostly‌ ‌in‌ ‌marginal‌ ‌areas‌ ‌and,‌ ‌therefore,‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌comparable.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Moreover,‌ ‌the‌ ‌contemporary‌ ‌hunter‌ ‌gatherers‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌relics‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌past‌ ‌and‌ ‌like‌ ‌us‌ ‌have‌ ‌evolved‌ ‌continuously.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Nor‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌past‌ ‌did‌ ‌hunter-gathering‌ ‌communities‌ ‌have‌ ‌the‌ ‌opportunity‌ ‌to‌ ‌interact‌ ‌with‌ ‌agriculturists,‌ ‌pastoralists,‌ ‌industrial/capitalist‌ ‌\nsocieties.‌ ‌\n●Contemporary‌ ‌hunters-gatherers‌ ‌live‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌variety‌ ‌of‌ ‌geographical‌ ‌locations‌ ‌and‌ ‌climates‌ ‌but‌ ‌mostly‌ ‌in‌ ‌marginalised‌ ‌areas‌ ‌where‌ ‌\nagriculture‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌feasible.‌ ‌\n●Nevertheless,‌ ‌such‌ ‌groups‌ ‌seem‌ ‌to‌ ‌share‌ ‌a‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌attributes‌ ‌like‌ ‌the‌ ‌fact‌ ‌that‌ ‌most‌ ‌live‌ ‌in‌ ‌small‌ ‌groups‌ ‌in‌ ‌sparsely‌ ‌\npopulated‌ ‌areas‌ ‌and‌ ‌adhere‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌nomadic‌ ‌lifestyle.‌ ‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌them,‌ ‌the‌ ‌camp‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌main‌ ‌center‌ ‌of‌ ‌daily‌ ‌activity‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌place‌ ‌where‌ ‌food‌ ‌sharing‌ ‌actually‌ ‌occurs.‌ ‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌Honigmann‌ ‌(1973),‌ ‌the‌ ‌hunter-gatherer‌ ‌society‌ ‌is‌ ‌egalitarian,‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌recognise‌ ‌individual‌ ‌land‌ ‌rights‌ ‌and‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌\naccumulate‌ ‌surplus‌ ‌foodstuffs,‌ ‌often‌ ‌an‌ ‌important‌ ‌source‌ ‌of‌ ‌status‌ ‌in‌ ‌agricultural‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Such‌ ‌communities‌ ‌usually‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌class‌ ‌system‌ ‌or‌ ‌specialised‌ ‌or‌ ‌full-time‌ ‌political‌ ‌officials.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Division‌ ‌of‌ ‌labour‌ ‌is‌ ‌largely‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌age‌ ‌and‌ ‌sex.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Ethnographic‌ ‌and‌ ‌archaeological‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌indicate‌ ‌that‌ ‌with‌ ‌few‌ ‌exceptions,‌ ‌such‌ ‌societies‌ ‌generally‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌sexual‌ ‌division‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nlabour,‌ ‌where‌ ‌men‌ ‌hunt‌ ‌and‌ ‌usually‌ ‌do‌ ‌the‌ ‌fishing‌ ‌while‌ ‌women‌ ‌gather‌ ‌wild‌ ‌plant‌ ‌foods.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Sahlins‌ ‌(1968)‌ ‌calls‌ ‌them‌ ‌the‌ ‌‘original‌ ‌affluent‌ ‌society’‌ ‌despite‌ ‌the‌ ‌fact‌ ‌that‌ ‌hunter-gatherers‌ ‌consume‌ ‌less‌ ‌energy‌ ‌per‌ ‌capita‌ ‌per‌ ‌year‌ ‌\nthan‌ ‌any‌ ‌other‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌beings.‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌Sahlins,‌ ‌ethnographic‌ ‌data‌ ‌indicates‌ ‌that‌ ‌hunter-gatherers‌ ‌worked‌ ‌far‌ ‌fewer‌ ‌hours‌ ‌and‌ ‌enjoyed‌ ‌more‌ ‌leisure‌ ‌than‌ ‌typical‌ ‌\nmembers‌ ‌of‌ ‌industrial‌ ‌society,‌ ‌and‌ ‌they‌ ‌still‌ ‌ate‌ ‌well.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Their‌ ‌‘affluence’‌ ‌came‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌idea‌ ‌that‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌satisfied‌ ‌with‌ ‌very‌ ‌little‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌material‌ ‌sense.‌ ‌\n509‌ ‌\n ‌\nFood‌ ‌Production‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌origins‌ ‌of‌ ‌food‌ ‌production‌ ‌began‌ ‌about‌ ‌10,000‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Neolithic‌ ‌period‌ ‌when‌ ‌man‌ ‌took‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌steps‌ ‌from‌ ‌merely‌ ‌utilising‌ ‌to‌ ‌\ntransforming‌ ‌nature‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌cultivation‌ ‌and‌ ‌domestication‌ ‌of‌ ‌plants‌ ‌and‌ ‌animals.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Archaeological‌ ‌data‌ ‌indicate‌ ‌that‌ ‌various‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌domestication‌ ‌of‌ ‌plants‌ ‌and‌ ‌animals‌ ‌arose‌ ‌independently‌ ‌in‌ ‌six‌ ‌separate‌ ‌locales‌ ‌worldwide‌ ‌\nduring‌ ‌the‌ ‌period‌ ‌from‌ ‌8000‌ ‌to‌ ‌5000‌ ‌BC,‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌earliest‌ ‌known‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌found‌ ‌throughout‌ ‌the‌ ‌tropical‌ ‌and‌ ‌subtropical‌ ‌areas‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nsouthwestern‌ ‌and‌ ‌southern‌ ‌Asia,‌ ‌northern‌ ‌and‌ ‌central‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌and‌ ‌Central‌ ‌America.‌ ‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌anthropologists,‌ ‌on‌ ‌its‌ ‌own,‌ ‌the‌ ‌physical‌ ‌environment‌ ‌has‌ ‌more‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌limiting‌ ‌rather‌ ‌than‌ ‌a‌ ‌determining‌ ‌impact‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌kinds‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nsubsistence‌ ‌choices‌ ‌made.‌ ‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌instance,‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌Binford,‌ ‌further‌ ‌away‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌equator,‌ ‌food‌ ‌collectors‌ ‌depends‌ ‌much‌ ‌less‌ ‌on‌ ‌plants‌ ‌for‌ ‌food‌ ‌and‌ ‌much‌ ‌more‌ ‌on‌ ‌\nanimals‌ ‌and‌ ‌fish.‌ ‌\n○Food‌ ‌production‌ ‌systems‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌generally‌ ‌divided‌ ‌into‌ ‌three‌ ‌main‌ ‌kinds:‌ ‌horticulture,‌ ‌pastoralism‌ ‌and‌ ‌intensive‌ ‌agriculture.‌ ‌\n○Horticulture‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌term‌ ‌‘horticulture’,‌ ‌denotes‌ ‌a‌ ‌simple‌ ‌food‌ ‌production‌ ‌strategy‌ ‌involving‌ ‌the‌ ‌growing‌ ‌of‌ ‌crops‌ ‌using‌ ‌simple‌ ‌hand‌ ‌tools‌ ‌such‌ ‌\nas‌ ‌the‌ ‌digging‌ ‌stick‌ ‌and‌ ‌hoe,‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌absence‌ ‌of‌ ‌permanently‌ ‌cultivated‌ ‌fields.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Primitive‌ ‌agriculture‌ ‌is‌ ‌called‌ ‌horticulture‌ ‌by‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌rather‌ ‌than‌ ‌farming‌ ‌because‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌carried‌ ‌on‌ ‌like‌ ‌simple‌ ‌\ngardening,‌ ‌supplementary‌ ‌to‌ ‌hunting‌ ‌and‌ ‌gathering.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Horticulture‌ ‌generally‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌involve‌ ‌any‌ ‌efforts‌ ‌at‌ ‌fertilisation,‌ ‌irrigation,‌ ‌or‌ ‌other‌ ‌means‌ ‌to‌ ‌restore‌ ‌the‌ ‌fertility‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌soil‌ ‌\nonce‌ ‌the‌ ‌growing‌ ‌season‌ ‌is‌ ‌over.‌ ‌\n■ ‌As‌ ‌far‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌attributes‌ ‌of‌ ‌horticulturist‌ ‌societies‌ ‌are‌ ‌concerned,‌ ‌land‌ ‌is‌ ‌generally‌ ‌owned‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌community‌ ‌or‌ ‌kin‌ ‌\ngroups.‌ ‌\n■Horticultural‌ ‌practices‌ ‌are‌ ‌generally‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌kinds.‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌most‌ ‌common‌ ‌one‌ ‌is‌ ‌extensive‌ ‌or‌ ‌shifting‌ ‌cultivation‌ ‌also‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌swidden‌ ‌or‌ ‌slash-and-burn‌ ‌(jhum‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌\ncontext).‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌method‌ ‌of‌ ‌horticulture‌ ‌involves‌ ‌the‌ ‌cultivation‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌plot‌ ‌of‌ ‌land‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌short‌ ‌time,‌ ‌followed‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌long‌ ‌fallow‌ ‌\nperiod,‌ ‌when‌ ‌the‌ ‌land‌ ‌is‌ ‌left‌ ‌alone‌ ‌to‌ ‌regain‌ ‌its‌ ‌fertility.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌process‌ ‌of‌ ‌preparation‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌piece‌ ‌of‌ ‌land‌ ‌for‌ ‌shifting‌ ‌cultivation‌ ‌involves‌ ‌clearing‌ ‌the‌ ‌undergrowth‌ ‌and‌ ‌felling‌ ‌of‌ ‌\ntrees‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌then‌ ‌left‌ ‌to‌ ‌dry.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Just‌ ‌before‌ ‌the‌ ‌seasonal‌ ‌rains‌ ‌are‌ ‌to‌ ‌begin,‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌set‌ ‌afire.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌ash‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌supposed‌ ‌to‌ ‌rejuvenate‌ ‌the‌ ‌soil‌ ‌and‌ ‌immediately‌ ‌after‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌shower‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌season,‌ ‌a‌ ‌mix‌ ‌of‌ ‌crop‌ ‌\nseeds‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌maise,‌ ‌gourd‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌are‌ ‌sown‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌help‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌digging‌ ‌stick.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Generally,‌ ‌all‌ ‌adults‌ ‌are‌ ‌involved‌ ‌in‌ ‌food‌ ‌production,‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌division‌ ‌of‌ ‌labour‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌sex.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌particular‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultivation‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌derided‌ ‌by‌ ‌many‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌main‌ ‌reason‌ ‌for‌ ‌deforestation‌ ‌and‌ ‌decimation‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nforests,‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌environmental‌ ‌problems‌ ‌stemming‌ ‌from‌ ‌it.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌India,‌ ‌shifting‌ ‌cultivation‌ ‌continues‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌widely‌ ‌practiced‌ ‌in‌ ‌many‌ ‌states‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌North-East‌ ‌like‌ ‌Assam,‌ ‌Meghalaya‌ ‌\netc.‌ ‌and‌ ‌there‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌many‌ ‌policy‌ ‌initiatives‌ ‌to‌ ‌wean‌ ‌away‌ ‌communities‌ ‌from‌ ‌this‌ ‌practice.‌ ‌\n510‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌other‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌horticulture‌ ‌pertains‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌planting‌ ‌of‌ ‌long-growing‌ ‌tree‌ ‌crops‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌coconut‌ ‌and‌ ‌banana‌ ‌\n●which‌ ‌after‌ ‌a‌ ‌few‌ ‌years,‌ ‌continues‌ ‌to‌ ‌yield‌ ‌crops‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌years.‌ ‌\n■Most‌ ‌horticultural‌ ‌societies,‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌Ember‌ ‌and‌ ‌Ember‌ ‌(1994),‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌rely‌ ‌\n■on‌ ‌crops‌ ‌alone‌ ‌for‌ ‌food‌ ‌but‌ ‌rely‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌combination‌ ‌of‌ ‌subsistence‌ ‌strategies‌ ‌which‌ ‌includes‌ ‌hunting,‌ ‌fishing,‌ ‌the‌ ‌raising‌ ‌of‌ ‌\ndomestic‌ ‌animals‌ ‌like‌ ‌pigs,‌ ‌chickens,‌ ‌goats‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n ‌\n○Pastoralism‌ ‌\n■Pastoralism‌ ‌is‌ ‌characterised‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌heavy‌ ‌though‌ ‌rarely‌ ‌exclusive‌ ‌reliance‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌herding‌ ‌of‌ ‌domesticated‌ ‌animals‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌living.‌ ‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌is‌ ‌usually‌ ‌practised‌ ‌in‌ ‌areas‌ ‌not‌ ‌particularly‌ ‌amenable‌ ‌to‌ ‌agriculture‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌grasslands‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌semi‌ ‌arid‌ ‌habitats.‌ ‌\n■A‌ ‌classic‌ ‌attribute‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌pastoral‌ ‌society‌ ‌is‌ ‌mobility‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌or‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌society‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌normal‌ ‌and‌ ‌natural‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌life.‌ ‌ ‌\n■This‌ ‌mobility‌ ‌might‌ ‌be‌ ‌permanent‌ ‌(nomadism)‌ ‌or‌ ‌seasonal,‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to‌ ‌as‌ ‌transhumance.‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌reason‌ ‌behind‌ ‌the‌ ‌mobile‌ ‌nature‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌lives‌ ‌lies‌ ‌in‌ ‌that‌ ‌fact‌ ‌that‌ ‌their‌ ‌territory,‌ ‌by‌ ‌necessity,‌ ‌has‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌spread‌ ‌over‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nlarge‌ ‌area.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Once‌ ‌their‌ ‌herds‌ ‌have‌ ‌grazed‌ ‌in‌ ‌an‌ ‌area‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌maximum,‌ ‌it‌ ‌has‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌left‌ ‌alone‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌grass‌ ‌to‌ ‌renew‌ ‌and‌ ‌they‌ ‌have‌ ‌to‌ ‌move‌ ‌\non‌ ‌in‌ ‌search‌ ‌of‌ ‌newer‌ ‌pastures.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Pastoral‌ ‌communities‌ ‌are‌ ‌generally‌ ‌small‌ ‌in‌ ‌size.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌India,‌ ‌for‌ ‌instance,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Bakarwals‌ ‌are‌ ‌a‌ ‌pastoral‌ ‌nomadic‌ ‌community‌ ‌inhabiting‌ ‌the‌ ‌high‌ ‌altitude‌ ‌meadows‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nHimalayas‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌Pir-Panjal‌ ‌ranges.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Every‌ ‌year,‌ ‌they‌ ‌take‌ ‌their‌ ‌sheep‌ ‌high‌ ‌into‌ ‌the‌ ‌mountains,‌ ‌above‌ ‌the‌ ‌tree-line‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌meadows,‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌reachable‌ ‌\nonly‌ ‌after‌ ‌a‌ ‌long‌ ‌arduous‌ ‌journey.‌ ‌\n■Among‌ ‌pastoral‌ ‌nomads,‌ ‌grazing‌ ‌lands‌ ‌are‌ ‌generally‌ ‌held‌ ‌communally‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌chief‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌the‌ ‌designated‌ ‌owner‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌land.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Pastoralist‌ ‌systems‌ ‌are‌ ‌commonly‌ ‌organised‌ ‌into‌ ‌patrilineal‌ ‌clans‌ ‌and‌ ‌lineages‌ ‌that‌ ‌function‌ ‌as‌ ‌corporate‌ ‌livestock‌ ‌owning‌ ‌\nunits,‌ ‌with‌ ‌men‌ ‌being‌ ‌typically‌ ‌the‌ ‌owners‌ ‌of‌ ‌livestock‌ ‌wealth.‌ ‌ ‌\n■There‌ ‌is‌ ‌sexual‌ ‌division‌ ‌of‌ ‌labour,‌ ‌with‌ ‌men‌ ‌being‌ ‌in‌ ‌charge‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌herding,‌ ‌while‌ ‌women‌ ‌process‌ ‌the‌ ‌herd’s‌ ‌products‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌\nmilk.‌ ‌ ‌\n■While‌ ‌pastoralism‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌an‌ ‌effective‌ ‌and‌ ‌sustainable‌ ‌economic‌ ‌strategy‌ ‌in‌ ‌resource-poor‌ ‌environments,‌ ‌it‌ ‌could‌ ‌lead‌ ‌to‌ ‌\noverexploitation‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌environment‌ ‌when‌ ‌outside‌ ‌forces‌ ‌constrict‌ ‌the‌ ‌available‌ ‌space.‌ ‌\n○Intensive‌ ‌Agriculture‌ ‌\n■Intensive‌ ‌agriculture‌ ‌enables‌ ‌human‌ ‌beings‌ ‌to‌ ‌cultivate‌ ‌fields‌ ‌permanently‌ ‌by‌ ‌adopting‌ ‌a‌ ‌variety‌ ‌of‌ ‌techniques.‌ ‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌involves‌ ‌the‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌fertilizers,‌ ‌both‌ ‌organic‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌cow‌ ‌dung‌ ‌and‌ ‌inorganic‌ ‌chemical‌ ‌fertilisers,‌ ‌the‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌technologies‌ ‌\nranging‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌humble‌ ‌plough‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌tractor‌ ‌and‌ ‌could‌ ‌also‌ ‌incorporate‌ ‌complex‌ ‌systems‌ ‌of‌ ‌irrigation‌ ‌and‌ ‌water‌ ‌control.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Societies‌ ‌practicing‌ ‌intensive‌ ‌agriculture‌ ‌generally‌ ‌have‌ ‌individual‌ ‌ownership‌ ‌of‌ ‌land‌ ‌\n■Such‌ ‌societies‌ ‌are‌ ‌also‌ ‌likely‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌characterised‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌higher‌ ‌degree‌ ‌of‌ ‌economic‌ ‌specialisation,‌ ‌more‌ ‌complex‌ ‌political‌ ‌\norganisation,‌ ‌and‌ ‌disparities‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌of‌ ‌wealth‌ ‌and‌ ‌power‌ ‌among‌ ‌different‌ ‌sections‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌basic‌ ‌unit‌ ‌of‌ ‌production‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌and‌ ‌division‌ ‌of‌ ‌labour‌ ‌takes‌ ‌place‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌gender‌ ‌and‌ ‌age.‌ ‌ ‌\n511‌ ‌\n■Women‌ ‌in‌ ‌such‌ ‌a‌ ‌society‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌duties‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌food‌ ‌processing‌ ‌stage‌ ‌but‌ ‌they‌ ‌also‌ ‌spend‌ ‌a‌ ‌lot‌ ‌of‌ ‌time‌ ‌\nin‌ ‌the‌ ‌fields.‌ ‌ ‌\n■In‌ ‌fact,‌ ‌apart‌ ‌from‌ ‌ploughing‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌taboo‌ ‌in‌ ‌many‌ ‌communities‌ ‌of‌ ‌rural‌ ‌and‌ ‌tribal‌ ‌India,‌ ‌women‌ ‌have‌ ‌an‌ ‌important‌ ‌role‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nintensive‌ ‌agriculture,‌ ‌particularly‌ ‌wet‌ ‌paddy‌ ‌cultivation,‌ ‌including‌ ‌planting‌ ‌of‌ ‌seedlings‌ ‌in‌ ‌nurseries,‌ ‌transplanting‌ ‌them‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nflooded‌ ‌fields,‌ ‌weeding,‌ ‌harvesting‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n■Contemporary‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌agriculture‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌characterised‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌increased‌ ‌trend‌ ‌of‌ ‌farmers,‌ ‌motivated‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌market,‌ ‌to‌ ‌grow‌ ‌\nmore‌ ‌cash‌ ‌than‌ ‌food‌ ‌crops.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Such‌ ‌a‌ ‌trend‌ ‌coupled‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌fact‌ ‌that‌ ‌intensive‌ ‌agriculturists‌ ‌may‌ ‌rely‌ ‌more‌ ‌often‌ ‌on‌ ‌single‌ ‌crops,‌ ‌subject‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌vagaries‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌weather‌ ‌could‌ ‌result‌ ‌in‌ ‌food‌ ‌shortage.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nDistribution‌ ‌and‌ ‌Exchange‌ ‌\n●Distribution:‌ ‌It‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌manner‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌the‌ ‌goods‌ ‌are‌ ‌divided‌ ‌amongst‌ ‌the‌ ‌member‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n●Exchange:‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌process‌ ‌whereby‌ ‌those‌ ‌receiving‌ ‌goods‌ ‌are‌ ‌in‌ ‌turn‌ ‌obligated‌ ‌to‌ ‌reciprocate‌ ‌by‌ ‌giving‌ ‌the‌ ‌goods‌ ‌in‌ ‌return.‌ ‌of‌ ‌goods‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nservice‌ ‌to‌ ‌all‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌organised‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n ‌Such‌ ‌system‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌divided‌ ‌into:‌ ‌\n1.Reciprocity‌ ‌\n2.Redistribution‌ ‌\n3.Market‌ ‌Exchange‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nReciprocity‌ ‌\n●Reciprocity‌ ‌constitutes‌ ‌the‌ ‌main‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌in‌ ‌most‌ ‌non-market‌ ‌economies.‌ ‌\n●Reciprocity‌ ‌requires‌ ‌adequacy‌ ‌of‌ ‌response‌ ‌but‌ ‌not‌ ‌necessarily‌ ‌mathematical‌ ‌equality.‌ ‌In‌ ‌India,‌ ‌for‌ ‌instance,‌ ‌when‌ ‌adults‌ ‌give‌ ‌a‌ ‌Diwali‌ ‌gift‌ ‌\nthat‌ ‌cost‌ ‌Rs‌ ‌500‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌five‌ ‌year‌ ‌old‌ ‌child,‌ ‌they‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌expect‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌child‌ ‌will‌ ‌reciprocate‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌gift‌ ‌that‌ ‌also‌ ‌cost‌ ‌Rs‌ ‌500.‌ ‌If‌ ‌the‌ ‌child‌ ‌\nreciprocates‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌small‌ ‌painting‌ ‌he‌ ‌or‌ ‌she‌ ‌made‌ ‌in‌ ‌school,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌usually‌ ‌considered‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌a‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌adequate‌ ‌response.‌ ‌\n512‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌Sahlins,‌ ‌reciprocity‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌defined‌ ‌into‌ ‌three‌ ‌types‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌criterion‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌stipulation‌ ‌of‌ ‌material‌ ‌returns,‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌as‌ ‌\nfollows:‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\na)‌ ‌‌Generalised‌ ‌reciprocity‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌involving‌ ‌unstipulated‌ ‌reciprocation,‌ ‌is‌ ‌gift‌ ‌giving‌ ‌without‌ ‌consideration‌ ‌of‌ ‌any‌ ‌immediate‌ ‌or‌ ‌planned‌ ‌return.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌such‌ ‌a‌ ‌case,‌ ‌the‌ ‌value‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌gift‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌calculated‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌time‌ ‌of‌ ‌repayment‌ ‌not‌ ‌specified.‌ ‌\n513‌ ‌\n○Such‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌reciprocity‌ ‌generally‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌only‌ ‌among‌ ‌close‌ ‌kin‌ ‌or‌ ‌people‌ ‌sharing‌ ‌close‌ ‌emotional‌ ‌bonds‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌between‌ ‌parents‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌children,‌ ‌between‌ ‌siblings,‌ ‌close‌ ‌friends‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n ‌\nb)‌‌ ‌Balanced‌ ‌or‌ ‌Symmetrical‌ ‌reciprocity‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌when‌ ‌someone‌ ‌gives‌ ‌to‌ ‌someone‌ ‌else,‌ ‌expecting‌ ‌a‌ ‌fair‌ ‌and‌ ‌tangible‌ ‌return‌ ‌-‌ ‌at‌ ‌a‌ ‌specified‌ ‌amount,‌ ‌time,‌ ‌and‌ ‌place.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Here,‌ ‌the‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌owing‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌desire‌ ‌or‌ ‌need‌ ‌for‌ ‌certain‌ ‌objects.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Giving,‌ ‌receiving‌ ‌and‌ ‌sharing‌ ‌constitute‌ ‌a‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌security‌ ‌and‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌Honigman,‌ ‌it‌ ‌promotes‌ ‌an‌ ‌egalitarian‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nwealth‌ ‌over‌ ‌the‌ ‌long‌ ‌run.‌ ‌ ‌\n○While‌ ‌generally‌ ‌practiced‌ ‌among‌ ‌equals‌ ‌who‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌closely‌ ‌related,‌ ‌balanced‌ ‌reciprocity‌ ‌principles‌ ‌may‌ ‌also‌ ‌be‌ ‌evident‌ ‌in‌ ‌gift‌ ‌giving‌ ‌\namong‌ ‌kin.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Example,‌ ‌among‌ ‌relatives‌ ‌in‌ ‌many‌ ‌parts‌ ‌of‌ ‌India,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌common‌ ‌practice‌ ‌for‌ ‌kin‌ ‌to‌ ‌give‌ ‌valuable‌ ‌items‌ ‌and‌ ‌even‌ ‌monetary‌ ‌\ncontribution‌ ‌when‌ ‌a‌ ‌relative’s‌ ‌daughter‌ ‌is‌ ‌being‌ ‌married‌ ‌off.‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌implicit‌ ‌expectation‌ ‌being‌ ‌that‌ ‌when‌ ‌their‌ ‌own‌ ‌daughter‌ ‌is‌ ‌married‌ ‌off,‌ ‌similar‌ ‌contributions‌ ‌could‌ ‌be‌ ‌expected‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nreceivers.‌ ‌\n○Sometimes‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌fine‌ ‌line‌ ‌between‌ ‌generalised‌ ‌and‌ ‌balanced‌ ‌reciprocity‌ ‌particularly‌ ‌gift‌ ‌giving‌ ‌in‌ ‌urban‌ ‌society,‌ ‌where‌ ‌though‌ ‌it‌ ‌\nmight‌ ‌appear‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌generalised‌ ‌reciprocity,‌ ‌there‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌strong‌ ‌expectations‌ ‌of‌ ‌balance.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n514‌ ‌\n■For‌ ‌instance,‌ ‌two‌ ‌families‌ ‌residing‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌neighbourhood‌ ‌in‌ ‌Delhi‌ ‌may‌ ‌try‌ ‌to‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌gifts‌ ‌of‌ ‌fairly‌ ‌equal‌ ‌value,‌ ‌say‌ ‌\nbased‌ ‌on‌ ‌calculations‌ ‌of‌ ‌what‌ ‌last‌ ‌year’s‌ ‌Diwali‌ ‌gift’s‌ ‌cost.‌ ‌\n○While‌ ‌balanced‌ ‌reciprocity‌ ‌generally‌ ‌operates‌ ‌on‌ ‌egalitarian‌ ‌principles,‌ ‌it‌ ‌could‌ ‌also‌ ‌take‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌competitive‌ ‌form.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Normally,‌ ‌it‌ ‌might‌ ‌be‌ ‌a‌ ‌means‌ ‌for‌ ‌villagers‌ ‌to‌ ‌‘bank’‌ ‌surplus‌ ‌food‌ ‌by‌ ‌storing‌ ‌up‌ ‌‘social‌ ‌credit’‌ ‌with‌ ‌fellow‌ ‌villagers‌ ‌by‌ ‌giving‌ ‌feasts,‌ ‌with‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌expectation‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌credit‌ ‌will‌ ‌be‌ ‌returned.‌ ‌\n○But‌ ‌affluent‌ ‌villagers‌ ‌might‌ ‌use‌ ‌this‌ ‌mechanism‌ ‌to‌ ‌enhance‌ ‌their‌ ‌social‌ ‌status‌ ‌by‌ ‌throwing‌ ‌lavish‌ ‌feasts‌ ‌and‌ ‌giving‌ ‌costly‌ ‌gifts.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌seems‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌the‌ ‌primary‌ ‌objective‌ ‌of‌ ‌chiefs‌ ‌among‌ ‌many‌ ‌Native‌ ‌American‌ ‌groups‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Northwest‌ ‌coast‌ ‌in‌ ‌holding‌ ‌a‌ ‌potlatch‌ ‌\n(ceremonial‌ ‌festival),‌ ‌where‌ ‌he‌ ‌would‌ ‌give‌ ‌away‌ ‌gifts,‌ ‌food‌ ‌and‌ ‌even‌ ‌destroy‌ ‌items‌ ‌of‌ ‌value‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌spirit‌ ‌of‌ ‌competition‌ ‌with‌ ‌rival‌ ‌chiefs‌ ‌.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n(c)‌ ‌Negative‌ ‌reciprocity‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌of‌ ‌goods‌ ‌and‌ ‌services‌ ‌where‌ ‌each‌ ‌party‌ ‌intends‌ ‌to‌ ‌profit‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌exchange,‌ ‌often‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌expense‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌\n○Practiced‌ ‌against‌ ‌strangers‌ ‌and‌ ‌enemies,‌ ‌it‌ ‌could‌ ‌range‌ ‌from‌ ‌barter,‌ ‌deceitful‌ ‌bargaining‌ ‌to‌ ‌theft,‌ ‌and‌ ‌finds‌ ‌social‌ ‌sanction‌ ‌among‌ ‌\nmany‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌instance,‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌Navajo,‌ ‌to‌ ‌deceive‌ ‌when‌ ‌trading‌ ‌with‌ ‌foreign‌ ‌tribes‌ ‌is‌ ‌considered‌ ‌morally‌ ‌acceptable.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Barter‌ ‌is‌ ‌believed‌ ‌to‌ ‌fall‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌realm‌ ‌of‌ ‌negative‌ ‌reciprocity,‌ ‌as‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌means‌ ‌by‌ ‌which‌ ‌scarce‌ ‌items‌ ‌from‌ ‌one‌ ‌group‌ ‌are‌ ‌\nexchanged‌ ‌for‌ ‌desirable‌ ‌goods‌ ‌from‌ ‌another‌ ‌group.‌ ‌\n○According‌ ‌to‌ ‌Honigmann,‌ ‌relative‌ ‌value‌ ‌is‌ ‌calculated‌ ‌and‌ ‌despite‌ ‌an‌ ‌outward‌ ‌show‌ ‌of‌ ‌indifference,‌ ‌sharp‌ ‌trading‌ ‌is‌ ‌more‌ ‌the‌ ‌rule.‌ ‌\n○While‌ ‌talking‌ ‌about‌ ‌the‌ ‌kinds‌ ‌of‌ ‌reciprocity,‌ ‌Sahlins‌ ‌points‌ ‌out‌ ‌that‌ ‌reciprocity‌ ‌leans‌ ‌toward‌ ‌generalised‌ ‌extreme‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌close‌ ‌\nkinship‌ ‌and‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌moves‌ ‌towards‌ ‌the‌ ‌negative‌ ‌extreme‌ ‌in‌ ‌proportion‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌diminution‌ ‌in‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌propinquity,‌ ‌and‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌varies‌ ‌with‌ ‌\nother‌ ‌factors‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌social‌ ‌rank,‌ ‌relative‌ ‌wealth‌ ‌and‌ ‌need,‌ ‌and‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌goods.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nRedistribution‌ ‌\n515‌ ‌\n●Redistribution‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌kind‌ ‌of‌ ‌economic‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌characterised‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌accumulation‌ ‌of‌ ‌goods‌ ‌(or‌ ‌labour),‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌objective‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nsubsequent‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌within‌ ‌a‌ ‌social‌ ‌group‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌culturally-specific‌ ‌principles.‌ ‌ ‌\n●While‌ ‌redistribution‌ ‌exists‌ ‌in‌ ‌all‌ ‌societies‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌where‌ ‌labour‌ ‌or‌ ‌products‌ ‌or‌ ‌income‌ ‌are‌ ‌pooled‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌common‌ ‌good,‌ ‌it‌ ‌emerges‌ ‌\nas‌ ‌an‌ ‌important‌ ‌mechanism‌ ‌in‌ ‌societies‌ ‌with‌ ‌political‌ ‌hierarchies.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌the‌ ‌latter,‌ ‌it‌ ‌requires‌ ‌a‌ ‌centralised‌ ‌political‌ ‌mechanism‌ ‌to‌ ‌coordinate‌ ‌the‌ ‌collection‌ ‌and‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌of‌ ‌goods.‌ ‌ ‌\n●While‌ ‌it‌ ‌serves‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌mechanism‌ ‌for‌ ‌dispensing‌ ‌goods‌ ‌within‌ ‌a‌ ‌society,‌ ‌it‌ ‌could‌ ‌also‌ ‌be‌ ‌a‌ ‌means‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌chief‌ ‌to‌ ‌consolidate‌ ‌his‌ ‌political‌ ‌power‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌gain‌ ‌in‌ ‌prestige.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌seems‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌an‌ ‌objective‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌potlatch‌ ‌where‌ ‌chiefs‌ ‌compete‌ ‌with‌ ‌each‌ ‌other‌ ‌to‌ ‌give‌ ‌away‌ ‌and‌ ‌destroy‌ ‌goods‌ ‌of‌ ‌value.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌less‌ ‌centralised‌ ‌societies‌ ‌that‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌have‌ ‌formal‌ ‌chiefs,‌ ‌the‌ ‌economic‌ ‌entrepreneur‌ ‌or‌ ‌the‌ ‌‘big‌ ‌man’‌ ‌may‌ ‌carry‌ ‌out‌ ‌such‌ ‌acts.‌ ‌In‌ ‌modern‌ ‌\nmarket‌ ‌economies,‌ ‌redistribution‌ ‌takes‌ ‌place‌ ‌through‌ ‌taxation‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌state,‌ ‌whereby‌ ‌resources‌ ‌are‌ ‌allocated‌ ‌back‌ ‌to‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌or‌ ‌groups‌ ‌\nwithin‌ ‌society,‌ ‌either‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌provision‌ ‌of‌ ‌public‌ ‌services‌ ‌or‌ ‌directly‌ ‌through‌ ‌welfare‌ ‌benefits.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nMarket/Market‌ ‌Exchange‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌very‌ ‌broad‌ ‌terms,‌ ‌a‌ ‌market/‌ ‌market‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌involves‌ ‌the‌ ‌buying‌ ‌and‌ ‌selling‌ ‌of‌ ‌goods,‌ ‌labour,‌ ‌land,‌ ‌rentals,‌ ‌credit‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌by‌ ‌persons,‌ ‌using‌ ‌\nan‌ ‌intermediary‌ ‌token‌ ‌of‌ ‌common‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌value.‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌Honigmann,‌ ‌such‌ ‌a‌ ‌two‌ ‌party‌ ‌market‌ ‌transaction‌ ‌could‌ ‌very‌ ‌well‌ ‌become‌ ‌a‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌negative‌ ‌reciprocity,‌ ‌unless‌ ‌some‌ ‌sort‌ ‌of‌ ‌\narrangement‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌made‌ ‌to‌ ‌ensure‌ ‌at‌ ‌least‌ ‌an‌ ‌approach‌ ‌to‌ ‌balance.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Although‌ ‌market‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌need‌ ‌not‌ ‌necessarily‌ ‌involve‌ ‌money,‌ ‌most‌ ‌commercial‌ ‌transactions,‌ ‌particularly‌ ‌nowadays‌ ‌do‌ ‌involve‌ ‌money.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Again,‌ ‌while‌ ‌most‌ ‌of‌ ‌such‌ ‌transactions‌ ‌take‌ ‌place‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌specifically‌ ‌designated‌ ‌market‌ ‌place,‌ ‌a‌ ‌market‌ ‌may‌ ‌exist‌ ‌without‌ ‌a‌ ‌designated‌ ‌\nphysical‌ ‌place.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌is‌ ‌more‌ ‌so‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌contemporary‌ ‌world,‌ ‌where‌ ‌significant‌ ‌market‌ ‌transactions‌ ‌take‌ ‌place‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌internet.‌ ‌ ‌\n●On‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌hand,‌ ‌in‌ ‌simple‌ ‌societies,‌ ‌a‌ ‌market‌ ‌place‌ ‌may‌ ‌signify‌ ‌much‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌a‌ ‌place‌ ‌where‌ ‌economic‌ ‌transactions‌ ‌are‌ ‌performed.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌rural‌ ‌and‌ ‌tribal‌ ‌India,‌ ‌even‌ ‌today,‌ ‌weekly‌ ‌haats‌ ‌or‌ ‌markets‌ ‌provide‌ ‌an‌ ‌opportunity‌ ‌for‌ ‌people‌ ‌to‌ ‌renew‌ ‌friendships,‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌local‌ ‌gossip,‌ ‌\narrange‌ ‌marriages,‌ ‌while‌ ‌some‌ ‌may‌ ‌also‌ ‌have‌ ‌deep‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌significance.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Reliance‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌market‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌general‌ ‌purpose‌ ‌money‌ ‌is‌ ‌increasing‌ ‌universally,‌ ‌with‌ ‌traditional‌ ‌subsistence‌ ‌giving‌ ‌way‌ ‌to‌ ‌\ncommercialisation‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌factors‌ ‌like‌ ‌demand,‌ ‌increased‌ ‌interaction‌ ‌with‌ ‌other‌ ‌societies‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nThe‌ ‌Distribution‌ ‌of‌ ‌Goods‌ ‌&‌ ‌Services:‌ ‌Case‌ ‌Studies‌ ‌\n ‌\nKula‌ ‌Ring‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌Malinowski‌ ‌(1922),‌ ‌Kula‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌ceremonial‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌among‌ ‌Trobriand‌ ‌Islanders‌ ‌of‌ ‌New‌ ‌Guinea.‌ ‌Kula‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌kula‌ ‌\nexchange‌ ‌or‌ ‌kula‌ ‌ring.‌ ‌ ‌\n516‌ ‌\n ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌complex‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌visits‌ ‌and‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌kinds‌ ‌of‌ ‌ornaments‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌trading‌ ‌of‌ ‌food‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌commodities‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌people‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌other‌ ‌(nearby‌ ‌or‌ ‌far‌ ‌off)‌ ‌islands.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Because‌ ‌the‌ ‌islands‌ ‌are‌ ‌differentially‌ ‌endowed‌ ‌with‌ ‌different‌ ‌natural‌ ‌resources,‌ ‌each‌ ‌island‌ ‌could‌ ‌produce‌ ‌only‌ ‌a‌ ‌few‌ ‌specialised‌ ‌products‌ ‌\nor‌ ‌commodities‌ ‌and‌ ‌have‌ ‌to‌ ‌depend‌ ‌upon‌ ‌other‌ ‌islands‌ ‌for‌ ‌other‌ ‌essential‌ ‌things‌ ‌and‌ ‌objects.‌ ‌\n●Because‌ ‌trading‌ ‌involves‌ ‌visiting‌ ‌distant‌ ‌and‌ ‌strange‌ ‌islands‌ ‌which‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌risky,the‌ ‌Trobrianders‌ ‌have‌ ‌worked‌ ‌out‌ ‌kula‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌safe‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nsecure‌ ‌trade‌ ‌by‌ ‌establishing‌ ‌trade‌ ‌partnership‌ ‌by‌ ‌means‌ ‌of‌ ‌exchanging‌ ‌kula‌ ‌ornaments‌ ‌and‌ ‌also‌ ‌gift‌ ‌giving.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌essence‌ ‌of‌ ‌such‌ ‌trade‌ ‌relations‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌the‌ ‌trade‌ ‌in‌ ‌itself‌ ‌but‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌subdued‌ ‌or‌ ‌embedded‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌ceremonial‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌of‌ ‌valued‌ ‌shell‌ ‌\nornaments.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Kula‌ ‌ornaments‌ ‌are‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌types.‌ ‌One‌ ‌consists‌ ‌of‌ ‌shell-disc‌ ‌necklaces‌ ‌(veigun‌ ‌or‌ ‌Soulava)‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌traded‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌north‌ ‌(circling‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nring‌ ‌in‌ ‌clockwise‌ ‌direction)‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌are‌ ‌shell‌ ‌armbands‌ ‌(Mwali)‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌traded‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌southern‌ ‌direction‌ ‌(circling‌ ‌counter-clockwise).‌ ‌ ‌\n●Mwali‌ ‌was‌ ‌given‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌right‌ ‌hand,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Soulava‌ ‌given‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌left‌ ‌hand,‌ ‌first‌ ‌between‌ ‌villages‌ ‌then‌ ‌from‌ ‌island‌ ‌to‌ ‌island.‌ ‌ ‌\n●If‌ ‌the‌ ‌opening‌ ‌gift‌ ‌was‌ ‌an‌ ‌armband,‌ ‌then‌ ‌the‌ ‌closing‌ ‌gift‌ ‌must‌ ‌be‌ ‌a‌ ‌necklace‌ ‌and‌ ‌vice‌ ‌\n●versa.‌ ‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌are‌ ‌exchanged‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌ceremonial‌ ‌ambience‌ ‌purely‌ ‌for‌ ‌purposes‌ ‌of‌ ‌enhancing‌ ‌mutual‌ ‌trust‌ ‌relationships,‌ ‌securing‌ ‌trade,‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nenhancing‌ ‌one’s‌ ‌social‌ ‌status‌ ‌and‌ ‌prestige.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Kula‌ ‌ornaments‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌in‌ ‌themselves‌ ‌remarkably‌ ‌valuable.‌ ‌However,‌ ‌these‌ ‌ornaments‌ ‌are‌ ‌loaded‌ ‌with‌ ‌folklore,‌
