‌myths,‌ ‌ritual,‌ ‌history‌ ‌\netc‌ ‌which‌ ‌generate‌ ‌a‌ ‌lot‌ ‌of‌ ‌enthusiasm‌ ‌and‌ ‌bind‌ ‌together‌ ‌the‌ ‌trading‌ ‌partners.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Exchange‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌ornaments‌ ‌facilitates‌ ‌trading‌ ‌of‌ ‌goods‌ ‌with‌ ‌ease‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌island‌ ‌visited‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌\n●trading‌ ‌partner‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌host‌ ‌island‌ ‌helps‌ ‌the‌ ‌visitor(s).‌ ‌ ‌\n●However,‌ ‌people‌ ‌participating‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Kula‌ ‌ring‌ ‌never‌ ‌indulge‌ ‌in‌ ‌any‌ ‌bargaining‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌objects‌ ‌given‌ ‌and‌ ‌taken.‌ ‌\n●Individual‌ ‌members‌ ‌trade‌ ‌goods‌ ‌while‌ ‌circulating‌ ‌the‌ ‌Soulava‌ ‌and‌ ‌Mwali‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌cordial‌ ‌atmosphere.‌ ‌\n517‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nPotlatch‌ ‌\n●Potlatch‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌elabourate‌ ‌feast‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌American‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌groups‌ ‌of‌ ‌Northwest‌ ‌Coast‌ ‌at‌ ‌which‌ ‌huge‌ ‌quantities‌ ‌of‌ ‌food‌ ‌and‌ ‌valuable‌ ‌\ngoods‌ ‌(such‌ ‌as‌ ‌blankets,copper‌ ‌pieces,‌ ‌canoes,‌ ‌etc.)‌ ‌are‌ ‌pompously‌ ‌and‌ ‌competitively‌ ‌distributed‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌guests‌ ‌in‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌humiliate‌ ‌them‌ ‌\nas‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌to‌ ‌gain‌ ‌prestige‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌host.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Burning‌ ‌huge‌ ‌quantities‌ ‌of‌ ‌goods‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌common.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Potlatches‌ ‌are‌ ‌organised‌ ‌by‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌like‌ ‌village‌ ‌chiefs‌ ‌or‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌or‌ ‌village‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌chief‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌village‌ ‌invites‌ ‌a‌ ‌neighbouring‌ ‌village‌ ‌to‌ ‌attend‌ ‌the‌ ‌potlatch‌ ‌which‌ ‌the‌ ‌latter‌ ‌invariably‌ ‌has‌ ‌to‌ ‌accept.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌guests‌ ‌in‌ ‌turn‌ ‌invite‌ ‌the‌ ‌hosts‌ ‌to‌ ‌attend‌ ‌the‌ ‌potlatch‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌given‌ ‌by‌ ‌them.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Though‌ ‌such‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌of‌ ‌gifts‌ ‌take‌ ‌place‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌competitive‌ ‌way,‌ ‌it‌ ‌also‌ ‌serves‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌leveling‌ ‌mechanism‌ ‌where‌ ‌food‌ ‌and‌ ‌gifts‌ ‌get‌ ‌equally‌ ‌\ndistributed‌ ‌among‌ ‌various‌ ‌villages‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌wide‌ ‌area‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌long‌ ‌run.‌ ‌\n●Similar‌ ‌feasts‌ ‌are‌ ‌organised‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌Melanesian‌ ‌societies‌ ‌(New‌ ‌Guinea)‌ ‌wherein‌ ‌large‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌(in‌ ‌hundreds)‌ ‌pigs‌ ‌are‌ ‌slaughtered.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Several‌ ‌villages‌ ‌attend‌ ‌these‌ ‌feasts.‌ ‌It‌ ‌appears‌ ‌that‌ ‌such‌ ‌large‌ ‌scale‌ ‌feasts‌ ‌are‌ ‌a‌ ‌waste.‌ ‌But‌ ‌these‌ ‌feats‌ ‌serve‌ ‌the‌ ‌mechanism‌ ‌of‌ ‌‘storing’‌ ‌\nsurplus‌ ‌food‌ ‌produced‌ ‌during‌ ‌good‌ ‌seasons,‌ ‌not‌ ‌by‌ ‌storing‌ ‌in‌ ‌bins,‌ ‌but‌ ‌by‌ ‌feeding‌ ‌the‌ ‌pigs.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Thus‌ ‌pigs‌ ‌become‌ ‌food-storing‌ ‌repositories‌ ‌which‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌used‌ ‌as‌ ‌food‌ ‌during‌ ‌lean‌ ‌seasons.‌ ‌If‌ ‌successive‌ ‌years‌ ‌are‌ ‌also‌ ‌good,‌ ‌there‌ ‌will‌ ‌\nbe‌ ‌over‌ ‌production‌ ‌of‌ ‌food‌ ‌that‌ ‌goes‌ ‌to‌ ‌pigs.‌ ‌ ‌\n●As‌ ‌a‌ ‌result,‌ ‌the‌ ‌size‌ ‌of‌ ‌drove‌ ‌grows‌ ‌into‌ ‌an‌ ‌unmanageable‌ ‌proportion,‌ ‌pigs‌ ‌destroy‌ ‌crops.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌reduce‌ ‌the‌ ‌drove‌ ‌size,‌ ‌a‌ ‌large‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌pigs‌ ‌are‌ ‌slaughtered‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌huge‌ ‌feasts‌ ‌is‌ ‌organised‌ ‌by‌ ‌inviting‌ ‌guests‌ ‌from‌ ‌other‌ ‌\nvillages.‌ ‌ ‌\n●As‌ ‌a‌ ‌result,‌ ‌the‌ ‌pig‌ ‌population‌ ‌gets‌ ‌drastically‌ ‌reduced‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌menace‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌fields‌ ‌also‌ ‌gets‌ ‌reduced.‌ ‌\n●Such‌ ‌feasts‌ ‌take‌ ‌place‌ ‌between‌ ‌villages‌ ‌reciprocally‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌excess‌ ‌food‌ ‌(pigs)‌ ‌gets‌ ‌redistributed.‌ ‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌feasts‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌necessarily‌ ‌competitive‌ ‌but‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌few‌ ‌cases,‌ ‌in‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌keep‌ ‌up‌ ‌one’s‌ ‌status,‌ ‌some‌ ‌‘Big‌ ‌men’‌ ‌of‌ ‌Melanesian‌ ‌societies‌ ‌\norganise‌ ‌such‌ ‌huge‌ ‌feasts.‌ ‌\n ‌\n518‌ ‌\n ‌\nCase‌ ‌Study:‌ ‌\nThe‌ ‌Moka‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌system‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌moka‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌system‌ ‌was‌ ‌(and‌ ‌it‌ ‌probably‌ ‌still‌ ‌is,‌ ‌in‌ ‌some‌ ‌form)‌ ‌a‌ ‌highly‌ ‌ritualised‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌system‌ ‌prevalent‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Mount‌ ‌Hagen‌ ‌\narea‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Highlands‌ ‌of‌ ‌New‌ ‌Guinea.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌reciprocal‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌of‌ ‌pigs,‌ ‌by‌ ‌means‌ ‌of‌ ‌which‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual’s‌ ‌social‌ ‌status‌ ‌is‌ ‌identified.‌ ‌What‌ ‌is‌ ‌crucial‌ ‌is‌ ‌to‌ ‌give‌ ‌more‌ ‌\npigs‌ ‌than‌ ‌you‌ ‌receive,‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌how‌ ‌personal‌ ‌prestige‌ ‌is‌ ‌obtained‌ ‌and‌ ‌thereby‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌clear‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual‌ ‌excels‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Other‌ ‌potential‌ ‌gifts‌ ‌are‌ ‌rare‌ ‌sea‌ ‌shells‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌obtained‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌coast‌ ‌through‌ ‌exchanges.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌received‌ ‌gift‌ ‌creates‌ ‌an‌ ‌obligation,‌ ‌the‌ ‌actual‌ ‌profit‌ ‌from‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌success‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌donor.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌recipients‌ ‌should‌ ‌not‌ ‌only‌ ‌strive‌ ‌to‌ ‌settle‌ ‌their‌ ‌“debts”‌ ‌rapidly‌ ‌but‌ ‌also‌ ‌to‌ ‌transfer‌ ‌them‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌primary‌ ‌donor.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌is‌ ‌achieved‌ ‌simply‌ ‌by‌ ‌returning‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌you‌ ‌had‌ ‌obtained.‌ ‌ ‌\n●At‌ ‌its‌ ‌highest‌ ‌level‌ ‌this‌ ‌moka‌ ‌system‌ ‌became‌ ‌a‌ ‌platform‌ ‌for‌ ‌competition‌ ‌between‌ ‌a‌ ‌limited‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌men‌ ‌who‌ ‌enjoyed‌ ‌the‌ ‌benefits‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nhaving‌ ‌a‌ ‌high‌ ‌social‌ ‌status.‌ ‌ ‌\n●From‌ ‌this‌ ‌foundation‌ ‌the‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌system‌ ‌expanded‌ ‌to‌ ‌include‌ ‌many‌ ‌hundreds‌ ‌of‌ ‌other‌ ‌men,‌ ‌all‌ ‌vying‌ ‌with‌ ‌each‌ ‌other‌ ‌for‌ ‌both‌ ‌prestige‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌social‌ ‌recognition.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nTRADITIONAL‌ ‌ECONOMIC‌ ‌SYSTEM‌ ‌\n●Traditional‌ ‌economic‌ ‌systems‌ ‌are‌ ‌usually‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌simple‌ ‌societies‌ ‌like‌ ‌the‌ ‌tribal‌ ‌societies,‌ ‌rural‌ ‌societies,‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n519‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌chiefly‌ ‌characterised‌ ‌by‌ ‌subsistence‌ ‌mode‌ ‌of‌ ‌production‌ ‌with‌ ‌little‌ ‌surplus‌ ‌production.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nDifferent‌ ‌modes‌ ‌of‌ ‌exchanges‌ ‌prevailing‌ ‌among‌ ‌different‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌\n●Barter‌ ‌System‌ ‌\n○Barter‌ ‌system‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌direct‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌of‌ ‌goods‌ ‌and‌ ‌services‌ ‌i.e‌ ‌an‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌goods‌ ‌for‌ ‌goods,‌ ‌goods‌ ‌for‌ ‌services,‌ ‌service‌ ‌for‌ ‌\nservice‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌considered‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌the‌ ‌earliest‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌in‌ ‌Human‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Barter‌ ‌usually‌ ‌replaced‌ ‌money‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌method‌ ‌of‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌during‌ ‌crisis‌ ‌like‌ ‌war,‌ ‌natural‌ ‌calamity,‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n●Silent‌ ‌Trade‌ ‌\n○Silent‌ ‌trade‌ ‌(also‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌silent‌ ‌barter‌ ‌or‌ ‌trade‌ ‌and‌ ‌dumb‌ ‌barter)‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌peculiar‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌where‌ ‌the‌ ‌exchanging‌ ‌parties‌ ‌do‌ ‌\nnot‌ ‌come‌ ‌into‌ ‌face‌ ‌to‌ ‌face‌ ‌interaction‌ ‌during‌ ‌the‌ ‌process‌ ‌of‌ ‌exchange.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌exchanging‌ ‌partners‌ ‌could‌ ‌be‌ ‌enemies‌ ‌or‌ ‌antagonised.‌ ‌ ‌\n○One‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌people‌ ‌leaves‌ ‌a‌ ‌certain‌ ‌quantity‌ ‌of‌ ‌products‌ ‌at‌ ‌a‌ ‌customary‌ ‌place‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌taken‌ ‌by‌ ‌another‌ ‌group,‌ ‌who‌ ‌in‌ ‌turn‌ ‌leaves‌ ‌\nback‌ ‌some‌ ‌other‌ ‌products.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌pygmy‌ ‌Semang‌ ‌and‌ ‌Sakai‌ ‌of‌ ‌Malaya‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌Vedda‌ ‌and‌ ‌Sinhalese‌ ‌of‌ ‌Sri‌ ‌Lanka‌ ‌practice‌ ‌silent‌ ‌trade.‌ ‌\n●Jajmani‌ ‌System‌ ‌\n○William‌ ‌H‌ ‌Wiser‌ ‌(1988)‌ ‌has‌ ‌introduced‌ ‌the‌ ‌term‌ ‌Jajmani‌ ‌system‌ ‌in‌ ‌his‌ ‌book,‌ ‌The‌ ‌Hindu‌ ‌Jajmani‌ ‌System:‌ ‌A‌ ‌Socio-Economic‌ ‌System‌ ‌\nInterrelating‌ ‌Members‌ ‌Of‌ ‌A‌ ‌Hindu‌ ‌Village‌ ‌Community‌ ‌In‌ ‌Services‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌gives‌ ‌detail‌ ‌how‌ ‌different‌ ‌caste‌ ‌groups‌ ‌interact‌ ‌with‌ ‌each‌ ‌other‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌agriculture‌ ‌based‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌production,‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nexchange‌ ‌of‌ ‌goods‌ ‌and‌ ‌services.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌different‌ ‌parts‌ ‌of‌ ‌India‌ ‌different‌ ‌terms‌ ‌are‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌describe‌ ‌this‌ ‌economic‌ ‌interaction‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌castes.‌ ‌\n520‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌example‌ ‌in‌ ‌‌Maharashtra‌ ‌the‌ ‌term‌ ‌Balutadar‌ ‌or‌ ‌bara‌ ‌batute‌ ‌and‌ ‌mera‌ ‌or‌ ‌mirasi‌ ‌in‌ ‌rural‌ ‌Rayalaseema‌ ‌of‌ ‌Andhra‌ ‌Pradesh,‌ ‌\njajmani‌ ‌in‌ ‌North‌ ‌India,‌ ‌mirasi‌ ‌in‌ ‌Tamil‌ ‌Nadu‌ ‌and‌ ‌adade‌ ‌in‌ ‌Karnataka.‌ ‌\n○Jajmani‌ ‌system‌ ‌is‌ ‌reciprocal‌ ‌(usually‌ ‌asymmetrical‌ ‌and‌ ‌some‌ ‌scholars‌ ‌term‌ ‌it‌ ‌non-reciprocal)‌ ‌social‌ ‌and‌ ‌economic‌ ‌arrangements‌ ‌\nbetween‌ ‌families‌ ‌of‌ ‌different‌ ‌castes‌ ‌within‌ ‌a‌ ‌village‌ ‌community‌ ‌in‌ ‌India‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌of‌ ‌goods‌ ‌and‌ ‌services.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Here,‌ ‌one‌ ‌family‌ ‌exclusively‌ ‌performs‌ ‌certain‌ ‌services‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌other,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌ministering‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌rituals‌ ‌or‌ ‌providing‌ ‌agricultural‌ ‌labour,‌ ‌\nor‌ ‌some‌ ‌goods‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌agricultural‌ ‌implements,‌ ‌pots,‌ ‌baskets‌ ‌etc‌ ‌in‌ ‌return‌ ‌for‌ ‌payment,‌ ‌protection,‌ ‌and‌ ‌employment‌ ‌security.‌ ‌ ‌\n○These‌ ‌relations‌ ‌are‌ ‌supposed‌ ‌to‌ ‌continue‌ ‌from‌ ‌one‌ ‌generation‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌next,‌ ‌and‌ ‌payment‌ ‌is‌ ‌normally‌ ‌made‌ ‌traditionally,‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌\na‌ ‌fixed‌ ‌share‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌harvest‌ ‌rather‌ ‌than‌ ‌in‌ ‌cash.‌ ‌\n○Speaking‌ ‌about‌ ‌the‌ ‌composition‌ ‌of‌ ‌villages‌ ‌Williams‌ ‌1988‌ ‌stated‌ ‌that‌ ‌each‌ ‌village‌ ‌is‌ ‌composed‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌jatis/castes‌ ‌each‌ ‌\nhaving‌ ‌its‌ ‌occupational‌ ‌specialty.‌ ‌\n○Through‌ ‌jajmani‌ ‌relations‌ ‌these‌ ‌occupational‌ ‌jatis‌ ‌get‌ ‌linked‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌land‌ ‌owning‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌caste.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌jajmani‌ ‌system‌ ‌operates‌ ‌around‌ ‌the‌ ‌families‌ ‌belonging‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌land‌ ‌owning‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌caste‌ ‌the‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌called‌ ‌\njajmans‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌occupational/artisanal‌ ‌and‌ ‌service‌ ‌castes‌ ‌called‌ ‌‌Kameens‌ ‌in‌ ‌North‌ ‌India‌ ‌and‌ ‌panollu‌ ‌in‌ ‌Andhra‌ ‌Pradesh‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌term‌ ‌Kameen‌ ‌or‌ ‌panollu‌ ‌means‌ ‌one‌ ‌who‌ ‌works‌ ‌for‌ ‌somebody‌ ‌or‌ ‌serves‌ ‌him.‌ ‌\n●Williams‌ ‌further‌ ‌delineated‌ ‌the‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌jasmani‌ ‌system‌ ‌as‌ ‌stated‌ ‌below:‌ ‌\n○Unbroken‌ ‌relationship:‌ ‌ ‌\n■Under‌ ‌the‌ ‌jajmani‌ ‌system‌ ‌the‌ ‌kameen‌ ‌remains‌ ‌obliged‌ ‌to‌ ‌render‌ ‌the‌ ‌services‌ ‌throughout‌ ‌his‌ ‌life‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌jajman‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌\njajman‌ ‌in‌ ‌turn‌ ‌has‌ ‌the‌ ‌responsibility‌ ‌of‌ ‌hiring‌ ‌services‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌kameen.‌ ‌\n○Hereditary‌ ‌relationship:‌ ‌ ‌\n■Jajmani‌ ‌rights‌ ‌are‌ ‌enjoyed‌ ‌hereditarily.‌ ‌After‌ ‌the‌ ‌death‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌man‌ ‌his‌ ‌son‌ ‌is‌ ‌entitled‌ ‌to‌ ‌work‌ ‌as‌ ‌kameen‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌jajman‌ ‌\nfamily‌ ‌or‌ ‌families.‌ ‌The‌ ‌son‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌jajman‌ ‌also‌ ‌accepts‌ ‌the‌ ‌son‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌kameen‌ ‌as‌ ‌his‌ ‌kameen.‌ ‌\n○Multidimensional‌ ‌relationship:‌ ‌ ‌\n■Due‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌permanency‌ ‌of‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌both‌ ‌the‌ ‌jajman‌ ‌and‌ ‌kameen‌ ‌families‌ ‌become‌ ‌mutually‌ ‌dependent‌ ‌on‌ ‌each‌ ‌other.‌ ‌ ‌\n■They‌ ‌often‌ ‌take‌ ‌part‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌personal‌ ‌and‌ ‌family‌ ‌affairs,‌ ‌family‌ ‌rituals‌ ‌and‌ ‌ceremonies.‌ ‌\n○Barter‌ ‌exchange:‌ ‌ ‌\n■Under‌ ‌the‌ ‌jajmani‌ ‌system‌ ‌the‌ ‌payments‌ ‌are‌ ‌made‌ ‌mainly‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌goods‌ ‌and‌ ‌commodities.‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌kameen‌ ‌gets‌ ‌his‌ ‌necessities‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌jajman‌ ‌in‌ ‌return‌ ‌for‌ ‌his‌ ‌services.‌ ‌\n ‌\nAnalysis‌ ‌of‌ ‌Jajmani‌ ‌System:‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌system‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌regarded‌ ‌as‌ ‌essentially‌ ‌exploitative,‌ ‌characterised‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌latent‌ ‌conflict‌ ‌of‌ ‌interest‌ ‌which‌ ‌could‌ ‌not‌ ‌crystallise‌ ‌due‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌the‌ ‌prevalent‌ ‌social‌ ‌setup.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌jajmani‌ ‌system‌ ‌has‌ ‌gradually‌ ‌decayed‌ ‌in‌ ‌modern‌ ‌society‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌many‌ ‌reasons.‌ ‌\n○Modern‌ ‌economic‌ ‌systems‌ ‌measure‌ ‌everything‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌its‌ ‌monetary‌ ‌value.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌decline‌ ‌of‌ ‌belief‌ ‌in‌ ‌caste‌ ‌system‌ ‌and‌ ‌hereditary‌ ‌occupation‌ ‌has‌ ‌given‌ ‌a‌ ‌strong‌ ‌blow‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌system.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Growth‌ ‌of‌ ‌better‌ ‌employment‌ ‌opportunities‌ ‌outside‌ ‌the‌ ‌village‌ ‌and‌ ‌introduction‌ ‌of‌ ‌new‌ ‌transport‌ ‌options‌ ‌have‌ ‌also‌ ‌led‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌downfall‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌the‌ ‌jajmani‌ ‌system.‌ ‌\n●Ceremonial‌ ‌Exchange‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌kind‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌system‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌goods‌ ‌and‌ ‌services‌ ‌are‌ ‌given‌ ‌to‌ ‌relatives,‌ ‌friends‌ ‌and‌ ‌neighbours‌ ‌on‌ ‌various‌ ‌social‌ ‌occasions‌ ‌\nlike‌ ‌birth‌ ‌ritual,‌ ‌marriage,‌ ‌death‌ ‌rituals,‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌basic‌ ‌initiative‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌is‌ ‌to‌ ‌establish‌ ‌good‌ ‌relations‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌various‌ ‌social‌ ‌groups‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌society‌ ‌\n ‌\n521‌ ‌\n ‌\nSubsisting‌ ‌on‌ ‌hunting‌ ‌and‌ ‌gathering,‌ ‌fishing,‌ ‌swiddening,‌ ‌pastoralism,‌ ‌horticulture,‌ ‌and‌ ‌agriculture;‌ ‌\n ‌\nHunting‌ ‌and‌ ‌gathering‌ ‌economic‌ ‌organization‌ ‌\n●Characteristics‌ ‌&‌ ‌Examples‌ ‌\n○Characterized‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌nomadism‌ ‌and‌ ‌semi‌ ‌nomadism.‌ ‌\n○Lowest‌ ‌population‌ ‌density‌ ‌\n○Self‌ ‌sufficient‌ ‌economic‌ ‌unit.‌ ‌\n○Actions‌ ‌of‌ ‌surplus‌ ‌and‌ ‌trade(‌ ‌forest‌ ‌to‌ ‌mouth‌ ‌existence),few‌ ‌societies‌ ‌engage‌ ‌in‌ ‌barter.‌ ‌\n○Generalised‌ ‌reciprocity‌ ‌is‌ ‌seen‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌hospitality,‌ ‌generosity,‌ ‌sharing‌ ‌of‌ ‌gifts‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌between‌ ‌close‌ ‌relatives.‌ ‌\n○Balanced‌ ‌reciprocity‌ ‌may‌ ‌also‌ ‌exist‌ ‌in‌ ‌foraging‌ ‌society;‌ ‌it‌ ‌exists‌ ‌between‌ ‌equal‌ ‌but‌ ‌not‌ ‌relatives.‌ ‌\n○Informal‌ ‌political‌ ‌leadership:‌ ‌Situational‌ ‌leadership,‌ ‌egalitarian‌ ‌society,‌ ‌Social‌ ‌difference‌ ‌are‌ ‌very‌ ‌less‌ ‌social‌ ‌distinction‌ ‌in‌ ‌relation‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nage‌ ‌and‌ ‌sex‌ ‌are‌ ‌present.‌ ‌\n○Examples:‌ ‌ ‌Chenchu‌ ‌of‌ ‌Andhra‌ ‌Pradesh,‌ ‌Kadar‌ ‌of‌ ‌Kerala,‌ ‌Onge‌ ‌of‌ ‌Andaman‌ ‌and‌ ‌Nicobar‌ ‌\n●Factors‌ ‌of‌ ‌Production‌ ‌\n○Technology:‌ ‌‌Simplest‌ ‌Technology(‌ ‌bows‌ ‌arrows‌ ‌spears‌ ‌etc)‌ ‌ ‌\n○Division‌ ‌of‌ ‌Labour:‌ ‌Full‌ ‌time‌ ‌craft‌ ‌specialist‌ ‌is‌ ‌absent.‌ ‌main‌ ‌division‌ ‌of‌ ‌labour‌ ‌is‌ ‌between‌ ‌sexes.‌ ‌men‌ ‌engage‌ ‌themselves‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nhunting‌ ‌women‌ ‌do‌ ‌most‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌gathering‌ ‌work.‌ ‌\n○Land‌ ‌Ownership:‌‌ ‌Hunters‌ ‌and‌ ‌gatherers‌ ‌determine‌ ‌who‌ ‌can‌ ‌hunt‌ ‌and‌ ‌gather‌ ‌where.‌ ‌\n○Capital:‌‌ ‌few‌ ‌simple‌ ‌tools‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nFishing‌ ‌societies‌ ‌ ‌\n●Characteristics‌ ‌&‌ ‌Examples‌ ‌\n○Specialised‌ ‌hunting‌ ‌and‌ ‌gathering‌ ‌societies‌ ‌adapted‌ ‌to‌ ‌aquatic‌ ‌environments‌ ‌rather‌ ‌than‌ ‌Terrestrial‌ ‌environments.‌ ‌\n○Sedentary‌ ‌lifestyle.‌ ‌\n○Support‌ ‌higher‌ ‌population‌ ‌density.‌ ‌\n○Self‌ ‌sufficient‌ ‌local‌ ‌group.‌ ‌\n○Characterized‌ ‌by‌ ‌surplus‌ ‌production‌ ‌and‌ ‌trade.‌ ‌\n○All‌ ‌fishing‌ ‌societies‌ ‌are‌ ‌more‌ ‌or‌ ‌less‌ ‌involved‌ ‌in‌ ‌trade‌ ‌activities‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌day‌ ‌surplus‌ ‌fish‌ ‌are‌ ‌sold‌ ‌or‌ ‌exchanged‌ ‌for‌ ‌other‌ ‌products.‌ ‌\n○Favour‌ ‌formal‌ ‌political‌ ‌leadership,‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌of‌ ‌catch‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌equal.‌ ‌leaders‌ ‌get‌ ‌major‌ ‌share‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌leaders‌ ‌will‌ ‌also‌ ‌get‌ ‌tribute‌ ‌there‌ ‌\nis‌ ‌a‌ ‌hierarchy‌ ‌of‌ ‌formal‌ ‌leaders‌ ‌for‌ ‌maintaining‌ ‌solidarity.‌ ‌\n○Examples:‌ ‌‌Manus‌ ‌in‌ ‌New‌ ‌Guinea,‌ ‌Solomon‌ ‌Islanders‌ ‌in‌ ‌Polynesia‌ ‌\n●Factors‌ ‌of‌ ‌Production‌ ‌\n○Technology:‌ ‌ ‌elaborate‌ ‌Technology(‌ ‌Canoes,‌ ‌dogsledder,‌ ‌harpoons,‌ ‌nets,‌ ‌hooks‌ ‌and‌ ‌traps.‌ ‌\n522‌ ‌\n○Division‌ ‌of‌ ‌Labour:‌‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌age‌ ‌sex‌ ‌and‌ ‌specialisation,‌ ‌some‌ ‌specialise‌ ‌in‌ ‌woodworking,‌ ‌canoe‌ ‌building.‌ ‌\n○Land‌ ‌Ownership:‌‌ ‌specific‌ ‌Marine‌ ‌Area‌ ‌on‌ ‌water‌ ‌zones‌ ‌determined‌ ‌\n○Capital:‌‌ ‌require‌ ‌capital‌ ‌as‌ ‌large‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌goods‌ ‌are‌ ‌used‌ ‌in‌ ‌fishing.‌ ‌\n ‌\nPastoral‌ ‌Societies‌ ‌\n●Characteristics‌ ‌&‌ ‌Examples‌ ‌\n○ ‌Nomadism,‌ ‌semi-nomadism,‌ ‌transhumane,‌ ‌sedentarism.‌ ‌\n○ ‌Support‌ ‌low‌ ‌population‌ ‌density.‌ ‌\n○ ‌Favor‌ ‌small‌ ‌community‌ ‌size.‌ ‌\n○Characterized‌ ‌by‌ ‌surplus‌ ‌and‌ ‌trade.‌ ‌\n○Interdependence‌ ‌between‌ ‌pastoral‌ ‌people‌ ‌and‌ ‌agricultural‌ ‌groups.‌ ‌\n○Favor‌ ‌part‌ ‌time‌ ‌and‌ ‌full‌ ‌time‌ ‌political‌ ‌leadership‌ ‌\n○Examples:‌ ‌ ‌todas‌ ‌of‌ ‌Nilgiri,‌ ‌Gaddi‌ ‌of‌ ‌Rajasthan,‌ ‌Bhils‌ ‌of‌ ‌Rajasthan‌ ‌\n●Factors‌ ‌of‌ ‌Production‌ ‌\n○Technology:‌ ‌ ‌Include‌ ‌several‌ ‌tools‌ ‌utensils‌ ‌and‌ ‌containers‌ ‌besides‌ ‌numerous‌ ‌technique‌ ‌of‌ ‌stock‌ ‌Rising.‌ ‌\n○Division‌ ‌of‌ ‌Labour:‌ ‌Men‌ ‌herd‌ ‌animals‌ ‌and‌ ‌milk‌ ‌them,‌ ‌women‌ ‌attend‌ ‌preparation‌ ‌of‌ ‌curd‌ ‌cheese‌ ‌butter‌ ‌yoghurt.‌ ‌little‌ ‌specialisation‌ ‌\nin‌ ‌branding‌ ‌animal‌ ‌trimming‌ ‌horntail‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n○Land‌ ‌Ownership:‌‌ ‌Governed‌ ‌by‌ ‌specific‌ ‌rules‌ ‌to‌ ‌determine‌ ‌who‌ ‌has‌ ‌the‌ ‌right‌ ‌to‌ ‌watering‌ ‌places‌ ‌and‌ ‌grazing‌ ‌land.‌ ‌\n○Capital:‌‌ ‌Cattles‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌major‌ ‌investment.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nHorticultural‌ ‌Societies‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Characteristics‌ ‌&‌ ‌Examples‌ ‌\n○Sedentary‌ ‌lifestyle.‌ ‌\n○Low‌ ‌to‌ ‌moderate‌ ‌population‌ ‌density.‌ ‌\n○Moderate‌ ‌size‌ ‌and‌ ‌self‌ ‌sufficient‌ ‌local‌ ‌group.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌Horticulturist‌ ‌raise‌ ‌millet,‌ ‌roots‌ ‌rhizomes.‌ ‌production‌ ‌is‌ ‌very‌ ‌high‌ ‌even‌ ‌though‌ ‌the‌ ‌method‌ ‌of‌ ‌farming‌ ‌sarp‌ ‌relative.‌ ‌There‌ ‌is‌ ‌\ngood‌ ‌surplus.‌ ‌\n523‌ ‌\n○ ‌the‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌of‌ ‌goods‌ ‌is‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌reciprocity‌ ‌and‌ ‌redistribution.‌ ‌Kula‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌the‌ ‌Trobiand‌ ‌islanders‌ ‌provide‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌best‌ ‌example‌ ‌of‌ ‌Balanced‌ ‌reciprocity.‌ ‌\n○ ‌the‌ ‌goods‌ ‌produced‌ ‌some‌ ‌are‌ ‌consumed‌ ‌immediately‌ ‌and‌ ‌some‌ ‌are‌ ‌preserved‌ ‌for‌ ‌stored‌ ‌for‌ ‌future‌ ‌use.‌ ‌\n○Full‌ ‌time‌ ‌leaders‌ ‌are‌ ‌quite‌ ‌common,‌ ‌chief‌ ‌and‌ ‌chiefdom‌ ‌exist.‌ ‌\n○Examples:‌ ‌‌Maria,‌ ‌Gond,‌ ‌Rengma,‌ ‌Naga,‌ ‌Arapesh,‌ ‌Hopi,‌ ‌Red‌ ‌Indians,‌ ‌zuni‌ ‌\n●Factors‌ ‌of‌ ‌Production‌ ‌\n○Technology:‌ ‌ ‌Simple‌ ‌hand‌ ‌tool‌ ‌digging‌ ‌stick‌ ‌etc‌ ‌\n○Division‌ ‌of‌ ‌Labour:‌‌ ‌Based‌ ‌on‌ ‌sexual‌ ‌difference.‌ ‌Women‌ ‌contribute‌ ‌is‌ ‌greater‌ ‌than‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌men‌ ‌in‌ ‌Horticulture‌ ‌society‌ ‌\n○Land‌ ‌Ownership:‌‌ ‌Horticulturist‌ ‌decides‌ ‌how‌ ‌farmland‌ ‌is‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌acquired,‌ ‌worked‌ ‌and‌ ‌passed.‌ ‌\n○Capital:‌‌ ‌Horticulture‌ ‌frequently‌ ‌uses‌ ‌the‌ ‌splashing‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌digging‌ ‌stick‌ ‌on‌ ‌Hoi‌ ‌as‌ ‌their‌ ‌primary‌ ‌tools‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌freely‌ ‌shared.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nAgricultural‌ ‌Societies‌ ‌\n●Characteristics‌ ‌&‌ ‌Examples‌ ‌\n○Sedentary‌ ‌lifestyle.‌ ‌\n○Support‌ ‌higher‌ ‌population‌ ‌density.‌ ‌\n○Characterized‌ ‌by‌ ‌permanent‌ ‌urban‌ ‌community‌ ‌\n○Frequent‌ ‌food‌ ‌storage‌ ‌and‌ ‌trade‌ ‌market‌ ‌\n○Favour‌ ‌formation‌ ‌of‌ ‌state/‌ ‌Kingdom‌ ‌m‌ ‌and‌ ‌existence‌ ‌of‌ ‌many‌ ‌full-time‌ ‌political‌ ‌official‌ ‌\n●Factors‌ ‌of‌ ‌Production‌ ‌\n○Technology:‌ ‌ ‌Complex‌ ‌agricultural‌ ‌tools‌ ‌and‌ ‌several‌ ‌methods‌ ‌of‌ ‌production‌ ‌\n○Division‌ ‌of‌ ‌Labour:‌‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌age‌ ‌sex‌ ‌and‌ ‌high‌ ‌degree‌ ‌of‌ ‌specialisation‌ ‌\n○Land‌ ‌Ownership:‌‌ ‌include‌ ‌a‌ ‌set‌ ‌of‌ ‌complex‌ ‌rules‌ ‌relating‌ ‌to‌ ‌allocation‌ ‌of‌ ‌land‌ ‌resources.‌ ‌\n○Capital:‌‌ ‌Money,‌ ‌Animals,‌ ‌plough,‌ ‌spades‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n524‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nGlobalization‌ ‌and‌ ‌indigenous‌ ‌economic‌ ‌systems.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Globalization‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌process‌ ‌of‌ ‌transformation‌ ‌of‌ ‌regional‌ ‌or‌ ‌local‌ ‌phenomena‌ ‌into‌ ‌global‌ ‌ones.‌ ‌\n●Globalization‌ ‌is‌ ‌multidimensional‌ ‌and‌ ‌it‌ ‌directly‌ ‌or‌ ‌indirectly‌ ‌makes‌ ‌a‌ ‌considerable‌ ‌impact‌ ‌on‌ ‌human‌ ‌life.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌the‌ ‌name‌ ‌of‌ ‌upgrading‌ ‌the‌ ‌lifestyle‌ ‌of‌ ‌tribal‌ ‌people,‌ ‌the‌ ‌market‌ ‌forces‌ ‌have‌ ‌created‌ ‌wealth‌ ‌for‌ ‌their‌ ‌interests‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌cost‌ ‌of‌ ‌livelihood‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nsecurity‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌tribes.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌tribals‌ ‌who‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌original‌ ‌settlers‌ ‌mostly‌ ‌live‌ ‌in‌ ‌forest,‌ ‌hills‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌naturally‌ ‌isolated‌ ‌regions‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌rich‌ ‌in‌ ‌mineral‌ ‌resources.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Globalization‌ ‌has‌ ‌various‌ ‌dimensions‌ ‌which‌ ‌sometimes‌ ‌affect‌ ‌tribal‌ ‌communities‌ ‌positively‌ ‌and‌ ‌sometimes‌ ‌negatively.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Since‌ ‌the‌ ‌emergence‌ ‌of‌ ‌liberalization,‌ ‌privatization‌ ‌and‌ ‌globalization‌ ‌(LPG),‌ ‌the‌ ‌areas‌ ‌inhabited‌ ‌by‌ ‌tribal‌ ‌populations‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌subject‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nvarious‌ ‌protests‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌involuntary‌ ‌displacement.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌regions‌ ‌inhabited‌ ‌by‌ ‌tribal‌ ‌people‌ ‌are‌ ‌facing‌ ‌wrath‌ ‌of‌ ‌not‌ ‌only‌ ‌economic‌ ‌exploitation‌ ‌but‌ ‌environmental‌ ‌degradation‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌excessive‌ ‌\nextraction‌ ‌of‌ ‌resources‌ ‌\n ‌\nFeatures‌ ‌of‌ ‌Tribal‌ ‌Economy‌ ‌\n●Tribal‌ ‌economy‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌very‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌and‌ ‌simple‌ ‌economy.‌ ‌Their‌ ‌technology‌ ‌is‌ ‌very‌ ‌backward‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌compensated‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌network.‌ ‌\n●Indigenous‌ ‌economy‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌subsistence‌ ‌economy.‌ ‌They‌ ‌are‌ ‌mainly‌ ‌Hunters‌ ‌and‌ ‌gatherers,‌ ‌pastoralist,‌ ‌horticulturist‌ ‌and‌ ‌shifting‌ ‌cultivators.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌these‌ ‌kinds‌ ‌of‌ ‌societies‌ ‌various‌ ‌kinds‌ ‌of‌ ‌exchanges‌ ‌found‌ ‌the‌ ‌ceremonial‌ ‌reciprocity‌ ‌redistribution,‌ ‌barter‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌economy‌ ‌is‌ ‌non‌ ‌monetized.‌ ‌They‌ ‌lack‌ ‌surplus‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌consumption‌ ‌is‌ ‌routinized.‌ ‌\n●Indigenous‌ ‌people‌ ‌are‌ ‌inextricably‌ ‌link‌ ‌with‌ ‌their‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌with‌ ‌environment‌ ‌so‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌tribal‌ ‌economy‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌following‌ ‌manner:‌ ‌\n○Spiritual‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌with‌ ‌nature‌ ‌and‌ ‌forest.‌ ‌sacred‌ ‌groves‌ ‌\n○Strong‌ ‌attachment‌ ‌with‌ ‌land.‌ ‌\n○Tribals‌ ‌live‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌forested‌ ‌area‌ ‌rich‌ ‌in‌ ‌natural‌ ‌resources‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌oil,‌ ‌timber,‌ ‌farmland‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n ‌\nImpact‌ ‌of‌ ‌Globalization‌ ‌on‌ ‌Indigenous‌ ‌Economies:‌ ‌\n●Negative‌ ‌Impact:‌ ‌\n○Tribal‌ ‌economies‌ ‌are‌ ‌facing‌ ‌Challenges‌ ‌of‌ ‌extinction‌ ‌or‌ ‌survival‌ ‌and‌ ‌renewal‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌globalised‌ ‌world.‌ ‌\n○Impact‌ ‌of‌ ‌globalisation‌ ‌is‌ ‌strongest‌ ‌on‌ ‌these‌ ‌communities;‌ ‌they‌ ‌don't‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌voice‌ ‌and‌ ‌are‌ ‌swept‌ ‌away‌ ‌easily‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌Invisible‌ ‌hands‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌the‌ ‌market.‌ ‌\n○At‌ ‌front‌ ‌line‌ ‌of‌ ‌globalisation‌ ‌expansion,‌ ‌resources‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌forest‌ ‌mineral,‌ ‌water‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌are‌ ‌indigenous‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌tribal‌ ‌economy.‌ ‌new‌ ‌\nadvances‌ ‌of‌ ‌Technology‌ ‌have‌ ‌bought‌ ‌export‌ ‌led‌ ‌development‌ ‌which‌ ‌has‌ ‌resulted‌ ‌in‌ ‌extermination‌ ‌of‌ ‌countless‌ ‌native‌ ‌communities‌ ‌\nwith‌ ‌the‌ ‌extermination‌ ‌of‌ ‌forest‌ ‌for‌ ‌raw‌ ‌materials.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Traditional‌ ‌sovereignty‌ ‌of‌ ‌tribals‌ ‌over‌ ‌hunting‌ ‌and‌ ‌gathering‌ ‌rights‌ ‌is‌ ‌thrown‌ ‌and‌ ‌questioned‌ ‌as‌ ‌national‌ ‌governments‌ ‌bind‌ ‌\nthemselves‌ ‌to‌ ‌new‌ ‌global‌ ‌treaties.‌ ‌\n525‌ ‌\n○New‌ ‌trade‌ ‌and‌ ‌investment‌ ‌agreements‌ ‌have‌ ‌resulted‌ ‌in‌ ‌opening‌ ‌up‌ ‌of‌ ‌inaccessible‌ ‌tribal‌ ‌areas‌ ‌for‌ ‌industrial‌ ‌expansion,‌ ‌big‌ ‌dams,‌ ‌\npipelines,‌ ‌minerals,‌ ‌roads,‌ ‌energy‌ ‌development‌ ‌etc‌ ‌which‌ ‌threaten‌ ‌native‌ ‌economies.‌ ‌\n○Patenting‌ ‌of‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌resources‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌WTO‌ ‌mechanism‌ ‌has‌ ‌resulted‌ ‌in‌ ‌Privatisation‌ ‌of‌ ‌indigenous‌ ‌knowledge‌ ‌depriving‌ ‌\nindigenous‌ ‌people‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌life.‌ ‌\n○Land‌ ‌ownership‌ ‌and‌ ‌tribal‌ ‌people‌ ‌was‌ ‌collective‌ ‌ownership‌ ‌but‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌globalisation‌ ‌and‌ ‌individualism,‌ ‌private‌ ‌property‌ ‌is‌ ‌entering‌ ‌\ntribal‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\n○Distribution:‌ ‌Earlier‌ ‌equal‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌but‌ ‌now‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌is‌ ‌uneven‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌and‌ ‌hierarchies‌ ‌are‌ ‌found.‌ ‌\n○Consumption:‌ ‌Earlier‌ ‌no‌ ‌storage‌ ‌of‌ ‌food‌ ‌and‌ ‌consumed‌ ‌immediately‌ ‌but‌ ‌now‌ ‌storage‌ ‌of‌ ‌food‌ ‌is‌ ‌resulting‌ ‌in‌ ‌inequality.‌ ‌\n○Sale‌ ‌of‌ ‌factors‌ ‌of‌ ‌production‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌Land,‌ ‌labour‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌indebtedness.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Positive‌ ‌Impact‌ ‌\n○Popularization‌ ‌of‌ ‌indigenous‌ ‌art‌ ‌and‌ ‌monetary‌ ‌benefit‌ ‌to‌ ‌Tribal.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Examples‌ ‌of‌ ‌global‌ ‌recognition‌ ‌of‌ ‌various‌ ‌artforms‌ ‌like‌ ‌Madhubani‌ ‌Paintings,‌ ‌Warli‌ ‌painting,‌ ‌UNESCOs‌ ‌intangible‌ ‌list‌ ‌included‌ ‌\nvarious‌ ‌tribal‌ ‌arts‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n○Traditional‌ ‌knowledge‌ ‌digital‌ ‌library‌ ‌project‌ ‌of‌ ‌India:‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌‌Traditional‌ ‌Knowledge‌ ‌Digital‌ ‌Library‌ ‌(TKDL)‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌digital‌ ‌knowledge‌ ‌repository‌ ‌of‌ ‌traditional‌ ‌knowledge,‌ ‌especially‌ ‌\nabout‌ ‌medicinal‌ ‌plants‌ ‌and‌ ‌formulations‌ ‌used‌ ‌in‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌systems‌ ‌of‌ ‌medicine.‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌objective‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌library‌ ‌is‌ ‌to‌ ‌protect‌ ‌the‌ ‌ancient‌ ‌and‌ ‌traditional‌ ‌knowledge‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌country‌ ‌from‌ ‌exploitation‌ ‌through‌ ‌\nbiopiracy‌ ‌and‌ ‌unethical‌ ‌patents,‌ ‌by‌ ‌documenting‌ ‌it‌ ‌electronically‌ ‌and‌ ‌classifying‌ ‌it‌ ‌as‌ ‌per‌ ‌international‌ ‌patent‌ ‌classification‌ ‌\nsystems.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n4.‌ ‌Political‌ ‌Organization:‌ ‌Band,‌ ‌tribe,‌ ‌chiefdom,‌ ‌kingdom‌ ‌and‌ ‌State;-‌ ‌Part-I‌ ‌\n ‌\nBe‌ ‌the‌ ‌Contributor:‌ ‌Topic-I‌ ‌\n ‌\n“Legal‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌and‌ ‌Human‌ ‌rights”‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nPolitical‌ ‌Organization‌ ‌:‌ ‌Band,‌ ‌tribe,‌ ‌chiefdom,‌ ‌kingdom‌ ‌and‌ ‌State;‌ ‌\n ‌\nIntroduction:‌ ‌\n526‌ ‌\n●Anthropology‌ ‌has‌ ‌a‌ ‌noteworthy‌ ‌contribution‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌traditional‌ ‌societies,‌ ‌the‌ ‌tribes‌ ‌or‌ ‌peasant‌ ‌communities.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌ethnographic‌ ‌contributions‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌have‌ ‌helped‌ ‌us‌ ‌understand‌ ‌different‌ ‌aspects‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌and‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌life‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌political‌ ‌\nsystem‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌communities.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Studies‌ ‌of‌ ‌tribes‌ ‌in‌ ‌India,‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌or‌ ‌in‌ ‌Australia‌ ‌have‌ ‌recorded‌ ‌the‌ ‌fact‌ ‌that‌ ‌every‌ ‌society‌ ‌has‌ ‌definite‌ ‌norms,‌ ‌values‌ ‌and‌ ‌recognised‌ ‌rules‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nconduct.‌ ‌\n●Primitive‌ ‌&‌ ‌Stateless‌ ‌Societies‌ ‌\n○According‌ ‌to‌ ‌‌Fortes‌ ‌and‌ ‌Evans‌ ‌Pritchard‌ ‌‌(1940)‌ ‌‌the‌ ‌societies‌ ‌which‌ ‌have‌ ‌centralised‌ ‌authority,‌ ‌administrative‌ ‌machinery,‌ ‌and‌ ‌\njudicial‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌were‌ ‌labeled‌ ‌as‌ ‌‘primitive‌ ‌states’.‌ ‌\n■Some‌ ‌groups‌ ‌like‌ ‌the‌‌ ‌Zulu,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Ngwato,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Bemba,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Banyankole‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌Kede‌‌ ‌are‌ ‌regarded‌ ‌as‌ ‌“primitive‌ ‌states”.‌ ‌ ‌\n■They‌ ‌observed‌ ‌sharp‌ ‌differences‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌of‌ ‌wealth,‌ ‌status‌ ‌and‌ ‌privileges,‌ ‌corresponding‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌of‌ ‌power‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌authority‌ ‌in‌ ‌all‌ ‌‘primitive’‌ ‌states.‌ ‌\n○Stateless‌ ‌societies‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌hand,‌ ‌had‌ ‌no‌ ‌great‌ ‌distinctions‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌rank,‌ ‌status,‌ ‌or‌ ‌wealth‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌members.‌ ‌But‌ ‌they‌ ‌may‌ ‌\nnot‌ ‌be‌ ‌egalitarian‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Fortes‌ ‌and‌ ‌Evans-Pritchard‌ ‌have‌ ‌defined‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌societies‌ ‌which‌ ‌lack‌ ‌centralised‌ ‌authority,‌ ‌administrative‌ ‌machinery,‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nconstituted‌ ‌judicial‌ ‌institutions-in‌ ‌short‌ ‌which‌ ‌lack‌ ‌government-and‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌no‌ ‌sharp‌ ‌divisions‌ ‌of‌ ‌rank,‌ ‌status,‌ ‌or‌ ‌\nwealth‌ ‌are‌ ‌called‌‌ ‌stateless‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌ ‌\n■They‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Logoli,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Tallensi‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌Nuer‌ ‌in‌ ‌Africa‌.‌ ‌Examples‌ ‌of‌ ‌such‌ ‌tribes‌ ‌in‌ ‌India‌ ‌are‌ ‌some‌ ‌Andaman‌ ‌Islander‌ ‌\ntribes‌ ‌namely,‌ ‌Jarwa,‌ ‌Sentinelese‌,‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Some‌ ‌other‌ ‌hunters‌ ‌and‌ ‌gatherer‌ ‌groups‌ ‌where‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌centralised‌ ‌political‌ ‌system‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌included‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌stateless‌ ‌\nsocieties.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nPolitical‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌\n●Political‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌subfield‌ ‌of‌ ‌sociocultural‌ ‌anthropology,‌ ‌but‌ ‌like‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌whole,‌ ‌it‌ ‌remains‌ ‌immune‌ ‌to‌ ‌precise‌ ‌delimitation.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌core‌ ‌of‌ ‌political‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌comparative,‌ ‌fieldwork-based‌ ‌examination‌ ‌of‌ ‌politics‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌broad‌ ‌range‌ ‌of‌ ‌historical,‌ ‌social,‌ ‌and‌ ‌\ncultural‌ ‌settings.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌had‌ ‌come‌ ‌into‌ ‌‌being‌ ‌only‌ ‌towards‌ ‌the‌ ‌beginning‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌second‌ ‌half‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌nineteenth‌ ‌century‌ ‌simulated‌ ‌the‌ ‌publication‌ ‌of‌ ‌African‌ ‌Political‌ ‌\nSystems,‌ ‌edited‌ ‌by‌ ‌‌Meyer‌ ‌Fortes‌‌ ‌and‌‌ ‌Evans-Pritchard‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌studies‌ ‌the‌ ‌spatial,‌ ‌structural,‌ ‌organisational‌ ‌and‌ ‌functional‌ ‌aspects‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌political‌ ‌system‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌and‌ ‌peasant‌ ‌population‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nsome‌ ‌extent‌ ‌the‌ ‌Urban‌ ‌population‌ ‌in‌ ‌relation‌ ‌to‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n527‌ ‌\n ‌\nGraphic‌ ‌representation‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌difference‌ ‌between‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌(left)‌ ‌and‌ ‌political‌ ‌organisation‌ ‌(right)‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌political‌ ‌\nanthropology.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nDefinition‌ ‌by‌ ‌Thinkers‌ ‌\n●Morton‌ ‌Herbert‌ ‌Fried‌ ‌defined‌ ‌Political‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌as‌ ‌‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌that‌ ‌deals‌ ‌with‌ ‌political‌ ‌organisation‌ ‌that‌ ‌specifically‌ ‌relates‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nindividual‌ ‌all‌ ‌group‌ ‌that‌ ‌manages‌ ‌the‌ ‌affairs‌ ‌of‌ ‌public‌ ‌policy‌ ‌or‌ ‌seek‌ ‌to‌ ‌control‌ ‌appointment‌ ‌for‌ ‌activities‌ ‌of‌ ‌those‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌or‌ ‌group.‌ ‌\nScope:‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌‌scope‌ ‌of‌ ‌political‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌is‌ ‌comprehensive‌.‌ ‌It‌ ‌has‌ ‌apportioned‌ ‌it‌ ‌subject‌ ‌matter‌ ‌among‌ ‌several‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌branches:‌ ‌\n○Anthropology‌ ‌of‌ ‌political‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌\n○Anthropology‌ ‌of‌ ‌political‌ ‌system‌ ‌\n○Anthropology‌ ‌of‌ ‌political‌ ‌process‌ ‌\n○Anthropology‌ ‌of‌ ‌ethnicity‌ ‌\n○Legal‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌\n○Anthropology‌ ‌of‌ ‌International‌ ‌Relation‌ ‌\n○Anthropology‌ ‌of‌ ‌warfare‌ ‌\n○Anthropology‌ ‌of‌ ‌politics‌ ‌and‌ ‌development‌ ‌\n ‌\nPolitical‌ ‌Organization‌ ‌\n528‌ ‌\n●Anthropologists‌ ‌use‌ ‌a‌ ‌typological‌ ‌system‌ ‌when‌ ‌discussing‌ ‌political‌ ‌organization.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Introduced‌ ‌by‌ ‌‌Elman‌ ‌Service‌ ‌in‌ ‌1962,‌ ‌the‌ ‌system‌ ‌uses‌ ‌“types‌ ‌of‌ ‌leadership,‌ ‌societal‌ ‌integration‌ ‌and‌ ‌cohesion,‌ ‌decision-making‌ ‌\nmechanisms,‌ ‌and‌ ‌degree‌ ‌of‌ ‌control‌ ‌over‌ ‌people”‌ ‌to‌ ‌categorize‌ ‌a‌ ‌group’s‌ ‌political‌ ‌organization.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Service‌ ‌identified‌ ‌‌four‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌political‌ ‌organizations‌‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌closely‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌subsistence‌ ‌strategies.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Bands,‌ ‌ ‌\n○Tribes,‌ ‌ ‌\n○Chiefdoms,‌ ‌and‌ ‌ ‌\n○States‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●The‌ ‌political‌ ‌organisation‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌further‌ ‌categorised‌ ‌into‌ ‌‌Centralised‌ ‌‌and‌ ‌‌Non-centralized‌:‌ ‌\n○Non‌ ‌centralised‌ ‌also‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌‌Stateless/Acephalous‌‌ ‌Political‌ ‌Organization.‌ ‌Is‌ ‌categorised‌ ‌into‌ ‌ ‌\n■Band‌ ‌\n■Tribe‌ ‌\n●Tribe‌ ‌is‌ ‌further‌ ‌categorised‌ ‌on‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌based‌ ‌and‌ ‌non‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌based.‌ ‌\n○Kinship‌ ‌based‌ ‌is‌ ‌either‌ ‌Clan‌ ‌based‌ ‌or‌ ‌lineage‌ ‌based.‌ ‌\n○Non‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌age‌ ‌group‌ ‌based‌ ‌club‌ ‌based,‌ ‌melanesian‌ ‌big‌ ‌man.‌ ‌\n○ ‌Centralised‌ ‌also‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌‌State/‌ ‌Non-Acephalous‌‌ ‌Political‌ ‌Organization.‌ ‌\n●Distinction‌ ‌\n○Non‌ ‌centralised‌ ‌political‌ ‌organisation‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌multicentric‌ ‌authority‌ ‌system‌ ‌where‌ ‌the‌ ‌centralised‌ ‌political‌ ‌organisation‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌unicentric‌ ‌\nauthority‌ ‌system.‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌a‌ ‌‌centralised‌ ‌political‌ ‌‌organisation‌ ‌there‌ ‌will‌ ‌be‌ ‌no‌ ‌centralised‌ ‌authority‌ ‌capable‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌tribal‌ ‌society‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌whole.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Contrary‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌centralised‌ ‌political‌ ‌organisation‌ ‌there‌ ‌will‌ ‌be‌ ‌a‌ ‌centralised‌ ‌authority‌ ‌applicable‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌whole‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n ‌\n529‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nNon-Centralized‌ ‌Political‌ ‌Organization‌ ‌\n ‌\nBAND‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌rudimentary‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌political‌ ‌system,‌ ‌which‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌among‌ ‌primitive.‌ ‌\n●Band‌ ‌political‌ ‌organisation‌ ‌its‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌mostly‌ ‌hunting‌ ‌and‌ ‌gathering‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n530‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌total‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌people‌ ‌‌within‌ ‌these‌ ‌societies‌ ‌rarely‌ ‌exceeds‌ ‌a‌ ‌few‌ ‌dozen.‌ ‌Bands‌ ‌are‌ ‌essentially‌ ‌associations‌ ‌of‌ ‌families‌ ‌living‌ ‌together.‌ ‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌are‌ ‌loosely‌ ‌allied‌ ‌by‌ ‌marriage,‌ ‌descent,‌ ‌friendship,‌ ‌and‌ ‌common‌ ‌interest.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌primary‌ ‌integrating‌ ‌mechanism‌ ‌for‌ ‌these‌ ‌societies‌ ‌is‌ ‌kinship.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Bands‌ ‌are‌ ‌extremely‌ ‌egalitarian--‌ ‌all‌ ‌families‌ ‌are‌ ‌essentially‌ ‌equal.‌ ‌There‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌economic‌ ‌cla‌ ‌differentiation.‌ ‌\n●However,‌ ‌‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌often‌ ‌clear‌ ‌status‌ ‌differences‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌gender‌ ‌and‌ ‌age.‌ ‌\n●There‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌horizontal‌ ‌status‌ ‌and‌ ‌power‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌in‌ ‌bands‌ ‌between‌ ‌all‌ ‌adults‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌gender‌.‌ ‌They‌ ‌are‌ ‌more‌ ‌or‌ ‌less‌ ‌equal‌ ‌as‌ ‌far‌ ‌as‌ ‌\ncommunity‌ ‌decision‌ ‌making‌ ‌is‌ ‌concerned.‌ ‌ ‌\n●However,‌ ‌‌some‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌band‌ ‌stand‌ ‌out‌ ‌for‌ ‌their‌ ‌skills‌ ‌and‌ ‌knowledge.‌ ‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌often‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌people‌ ‌who‌ ‌have‌ ‌the‌ ‌best‌ ‌memories,‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌best‌ ‌hunters,‌ ‌most‌ ‌successful‌ ‌curers,‌ ‌most‌ ‌gifted‌ ‌speakers,‌ ‌or‌ ‌have‌ ‌some‌ ‌\nother‌ ‌special‌ ‌ability.‌ ‌Such‌ ‌people‌ ‌become‌ ‌informal‌ ‌leaders.‌ ‌‌Thus,‌ ‌leadership‌ ‌is‌ ‌situational‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌each‌ ‌band‌ ‌decision‌ ‌making‌ ‌is‌ ‌open‌ ‌to‌ ‌all‌ ‌and‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌consensus.‌ ‌No‌ ‌one‌ ‌gives‌ ‌order‌ ‌by‌ ‌virtue‌ ‌of‌ ‌holding‌ ‌an‌ ‌established‌ ‌office.‌ ‌\n●Social‌ ‌disagreements‌ ‌are‌ ‌usually‌ ‌followed‌ ‌by‌ ‌Fist‌ ‌fights,‌ ‌songs‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌contest‌ ‌which‌ ‌the‌ ‌rest‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌band‌ ‌watches‌ ‌in‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nenforce‌ ‌the‌ ‌contest‌ ‌rules.‌ ‌\n●Each‌ ‌when‌ ‌the‌ ‌mechanisms‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌control‌ ‌are‌ ‌based‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌informal‌ ‌political‌ ‌structure.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌absence‌ ‌of‌ ‌large‌ ‌scale‌ ‌political‌ ‌organisation,‌ ‌coercive‌ ‌authority,‌ ‌formal‌ ‌leadership‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌stratification‌ ‌is‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌lack‌ ‌of‌ ‌control‌ ‌\nover‌ ‌productive‌ ‌resources.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌principle‌ ‌goal‌ ‌of‌ ‌politics‌ ‌in‌ ‌‌most‌ ‌bands‌ ‌is‌ ‌making‌ ‌sure‌ ‌that‌ ‌people‌ ‌get‌ ‌along‌ ‌with‌ ‌each‌ ‌other.‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌easy‌ ‌given‌ ‌human‌ ‌nature.‌ ‌There‌ ‌is‌ ‌always‌ ‌the‌ ‌potential‌ ‌for‌ ‌social‌ ‌disruption‌ ‌brought‌ ‌about‌ ‌by‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌failing‌ ‌to‌ ‌share‌ ‌food,‌ ‌\nsexual‌ ‌competition‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌mate,‌ ‌or‌ ‌other‌ ‌personal‌ ‌conflicts.‌ ‌\n●Given‌ ‌the‌ ‌small‌ ‌size‌ ‌of‌ ‌bands‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌fact‌ ‌that‌ ‌everyone‌ ‌is‌ ‌involved‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌lives‌ ‌of‌ ‌everyone‌ ‌else,‌ ‌quarrels‌ ‌quickly‌ ‌become‌ ‌community‌ ‌\nproblems‌ ‌that‌ ‌have‌ ‌the‌ ‌potential‌ ‌for‌ ‌splitting‌ ‌the‌ ‌band‌ ‌along‌ ‌family‌ ‌lines.‌ ‌\n●Ethnographic‌ ‌accounts‌ ‌suggest‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌political‌ ‌power‌ ‌and‌ ‌status‌ ‌of‌ ‌women‌ ‌in‌ ‌many‌ ‌pedestrian‌ ‌foraging‌ ‌bands‌ ‌was‌ ‌surprisingly‌ ‌high‌,‌ ‌\nespecially‌ ‌compared‌ ‌to‌ ‌pastoralist‌ ‌and‌ ‌agricultural‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌\n○Since‌ ‌forager‌ ‌women‌ ‌in‌ ‌all‌ ‌but‌ ‌the‌ ‌cold‌ ‌polar‌ ‌regions‌ ‌usually‌ ‌provided‌ ‌most‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌food‌ ‌calories‌ ‌consumed,‌ ‌they‌ ‌performed‌ ‌\neconomically‌ ‌critical‌ ‌roles‌ ‌for‌ ‌their‌ ‌families‌ ‌and‌ ‌society‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌whole.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Men‌ ‌generally‌ ‌hunted‌ ‌for‌ ‌meat.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌was‌ ‌often‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌desirable‌ ‌but‌ ‌usually‌ ‌the‌ ‌least‌ ‌dependable‌ ‌food‌ ‌source.‌ ‌\n○ ‌The‌ ‌central‌ ‌economic‌ ‌role‌ ‌for‌ ‌women‌ ‌in‌ ‌providing‌ ‌vegetarian‌ ‌foods,‌ ‌along‌ ‌with‌ ‌traditions‌ ‌of‌ ‌diffused‌ ‌political‌ ‌power‌ ‌in‌ ‌bands,‌ ‌allowed‌ ‌\nwomen‌ ‌to‌ ‌voice‌ ‌their‌ ‌opinions‌ ‌at‌ ‌important‌ ‌community‌ ‌meetings.‌ ‌\n●Examples:‌ ‌\n○No‌ ‌band‌ ‌level‌ ‌societies‌ ‌survive‌ ‌today‌ ‌with‌ ‌their‌ ‌traditional‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌political‌ ‌organization‌ ‌intact.‌ ‌\n○However,‌ ‌they‌ ‌did‌ ‌until‌ ‌the‌ ‌last‌ ‌half‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌19th‌ ‌century‌ ‌in‌ ‌‌far-flung‌ ‌regions‌ ‌of‌ ‌northern‌ ‌Siberia,‌ ‌the‌ ‌desert‌ ‌and‌ ‌sub-arctic‌ ‌regions‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nNorth‌ ‌America‌ ‌and‌ ‌Greenland,‌ ‌the‌ ‌tropical‌ ‌lowlands‌ ‌of‌ ‌Central‌ ‌and‌ ‌South‌ ‌America,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Australian‌ ‌desert‌ ‌interior‌ ‌and‌ ‌tropical‌ ‌north,‌ ‌\nas‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌few‌ ‌isolated‌ ‌areas‌ ‌of‌ ‌Southeast‌ ‌Asia.‌ ‌\n ‌\n531‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nTRIBE‌ ‌\n●Tribal‌ ‌societies‌ ‌are‌ ‌usually‌‌ ‌pastorist‌ ‌or‌ ‌horticulturalist.‌ ‌ ‌\n●As‌ ‌the‌ ‌population‌ ‌size‌ ‌increases‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌shift‌ ‌in‌ ‌subsistence‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌from‌ ‌foraging‌ ‌to‌ ‌horticulture‌ ‌or‌ ‌pastoralism,‌ ‌it‌ ‌eventually‌ ‌reaches‌ ‌a‌ ‌point‌ ‌\nat‌ ‌which‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌ties‌ ‌and‌ ‌friendship‌ ‌are‌ ‌no‌ ‌longer‌ ‌sufficient‌ ‌to‌ ‌hold‌ ‌society‌ ‌together.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌is‌ ‌especially‌ ‌the‌ ‌case‌ ‌when‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌hundreds‌ ‌of‌ ‌people‌ ‌and‌ ‌multiple‌ ‌communities.‌  ‌Tribes‌ ‌also‌ ‌are‌ ‌characteristic‌ ‌of‌ ‌some‌ ‌large‌ ‌\nequestrian‌ ‌and‌ ‌rich‌ ‌aquatic‌ ‌foraging‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌is‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌clan‌ ‌and‌ ‌lineage,‌ ‌age‌ ‌and‌ ‌gender‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌important‌ ‌as‌ ‌in‌ ‌age‌ ‌grade‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌acephalous-without‌ ‌leader.‌ ‌\n●Sometimes‌ ‌they‌ ‌have‌ ‌leader‌ ‌who‌ ‌can‌ ‌influence‌ ‌and‌ ‌build‌ ‌a‌ ‌personal‌ ‌following‌ ‌through‌ ‌distributing‌ ‌wealth‌ ‌and‌ ‌favours‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌‌Big‌ ‌man‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nNew‌ ‌Guinea.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Like‌ ‌bands,‌ ‌‌most‌ ‌tribal‌ ‌societies‌ ‌are‌ ‌still‌ ‌essentially‌ ‌egalitarian‌ ‌in‌ ‌that‌ ‌no‌ ‌one‌ ‌family‌ ‌or‌ ‌residential‌ ‌group‌ ‌is‌ ‌politically‌ ‌or‌ ‌economically‌ ‌superior‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌others.‌ ‌ ‌\n○All‌ ‌families‌ ‌are‌ ‌basically‌ ‌alike,‌ ‌including‌ ‌those‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌headmen.‌ ‌They‌ ‌are‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌part‌ ‌self-sufficient‌ ‌in‌ ‌regards‌ ‌to‌ ‌food‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌\nbasic‌ ‌necessities.‌ ‌H‌owever,‌ ‌tribes‌ ‌differ‌ ‌from‌ ‌bands‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌way‌ ‌that‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌integrated.‌ ‌They‌ ‌are‌ ‌also‌ ‌larger‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌\n●Tribal‌ ‌societies‌ ‌have‌ ‌suffered‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌consequence‌ ‌of‌ ‌contact‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌large-scale‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌There‌ ‌no‌ ‌longer‌ ‌are‌ ‌any‌ ‌tribes‌ ‌that‌ ‌have‌ ‌\nbeen‌ ‌able‌ ‌to‌ ‌maintain‌ ‌their‌ ‌traditional‌ ‌political‌ ‌systems‌ ‌unaltered‌ ‌by‌ ‌outside‌ ‌influences.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n532‌ ‌\n ‌\nKINSHIP‌ ‌based‌ ‌Political‌ ‌System‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌political‌ ‌system‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌a‌ ‌commercial‌ ‌group‌ ‌works‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌political‌ ‌body‌ ‌is‌ ‌called‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌oriented‌ ‌political‌ ‌system.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌oriented‌ ‌system‌ ‌includes‌ ‌lineage‌ ‌based‌ ‌and‌ ‌Clan‌ ‌based.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌‌Lineage‌ ‌based‌ ‌political‌ ‌system‌ ‌\n●Horticulture‌‌ ‌Tiv‌ ‌of‌ ‌Nigeria‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌pastoral‌ ‌Nuer‌ ‌of‌ ‌Sudan‌,‌ ‌serve‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌typical‌ ‌example‌ ‌of‌ ‌lineage‌ ‌based‌ ‌political‌ ‌system.‌ ‌\n○Nuer‌ ‌have‌ ‌institutionalised‌ ‌arbiters‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌Leopard‌ ‌skin‌ ‌chief,‌ ‌his‌ ‌responsibility‌ ‌is‌ ‌to‌ ‌minimise‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌destructive‌ ‌effects‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌interlineage‌ ‌feuds.‌ ‌\n○He‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌mediator‌ ‌with‌ ‌no‌ ‌coersive‌ ‌force‌ ‌an‌ ‌example‌ ‌of‌ ‌legitimacy‌ ‌without‌ ‌force.‌ ‌\n●Tribal‌ ‌growth‌ ‌takes‌ ‌place‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌segments.‌ ‌Lineage‌ ‌starts‌ ‌with‌ ‌maximum‌ ‌lineage‌ ‌to‌ ‌major‌ ‌lineage‌ ‌to‌ ‌minor‌ ‌lineage‌ ‌to‌ ‌minimum‌ ‌\nlineage.‌ ‌\n●Complementary‌ ‌opposition‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌means‌ ‌of‌ ‌unifying‌ ‌higher‌ ‌order‌ ‌lineage‌ ‌politically.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌whole‌ ‌group‌ ‌come‌ ‌together‌ ‌during‌ ‌a‌ ‌conflict‌ ‌between‌ ‌minimal‌ ‌segment‌ ‌or‌ ‌when‌ ‌attacking‌ ‌or‌ ‌being‌ ‌attacked‌ ‌by‌ ‌an‌ ‌outsider.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nClan‌ ‌based‌ ‌political‌ ‌organization‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌different‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌and‌ ‌situations,‌ ‌a‌ ‌clan‌ ‌usually‌ ‌has‌ ‌different‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌than‌ ‌other‌ ‌kin-based‌ ‌groups,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌tribes‌ ‌and‌ ‌bands‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Often,‌ ‌‌the‌ ‌distinguishing‌ ‌factor‌ ‌is‌ ‌that‌ ‌a‌ ‌clan‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌smaller,‌ ‌integral‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌larger‌ ‌society‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌tribe,‌ ‌chiefdom,‌ ‌or‌ ‌a‌ ‌state.‌ ‌In‌ ‌some‌ ‌\nsocieties,‌ ‌clans‌ ‌may‌ ‌have‌ ‌an‌ ‌official‌ ‌leader‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌chief,‌ ‌matriarch‌ ‌or‌ ‌patriarch;‌ ‌or‌ ‌such‌ ‌leadership‌ ‌role‌ ‌is‌ ‌performed‌ ‌by‌ ‌elders.‌ ‌In‌ ‌others,‌ ‌\nleadership‌ ‌positions‌ ‌may‌ ‌have‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌achieved.‌ ‌\n●Examples‌ ‌‌include‌ ‌‌Irish,‌ ‌Scottish,‌ ‌Chinese,‌ ‌Korean,‌ ‌and‌ ‌Japanese‌ ‌clans‌,‌ ‌which‌ ‌exist‌ ‌as‌ ‌kin‌ ‌groups‌ ‌within‌ ‌their‌ ‌respective‌ ‌nations.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Biblical‌ ‌tribes‌ ‌of‌ ‌Israel‌ ‌were‌ ‌composed‌ ‌of‌ ‌many‌ ‌clans.‌ ‌\n533‌ ‌\n●Arab‌ ‌clans‌ ‌are‌ ‌sub-tribal‌ ‌groups‌ ‌within‌ ‌Arab‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Native‌ ‌American‌ ‌and‌ ‌First‌ ‌Nations‌ ‌peoples,‌ ‌often‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to‌ ‌as‌ ‌\"tribes\",‌ ‌also‌ ‌have‌ ‌clans.‌ ‌For‌ ‌instance,‌ ‌Ojibwa‌ ‌bands‌ ‌are‌ ‌smaller‌ ‌parts‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nOjibwa‌ ‌people‌ ‌or‌ ‌tribe‌ ‌in‌ ‌North‌ ‌America.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Somalia‌ ‌clan‌ ‌politics.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nNon-KINSHIP‌ ‌based‌ ‌Political‌ ‌System‌ ‌\n●Age‌ ‌grade‌ ‌based‌ ‌political‌ ‌system‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌factor‌ ‌of‌ ‌‌Pan‌ ‌tribal‌ ‌integration.‌ ‌\n○Each‌ ‌age‌ ‌group‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌organised‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌people‌ ‌with‌ ‌membership‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌age.‌ ‌\n○People‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌age‌ ‌group‌ ‌belong‌ ‌to‌ ‌one‌ ‌age‌ ‌grade.‌ ‌\n○Each‌ ‌age‌ ‌grade‌ ‌is‌ ‌cut‌ ‌across‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌and‌ ‌territorial‌ ‌lines‌ ‌because‌ ‌people‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌age‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌villages‌ ‌belong‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌age‌ ‌\ngrade.‌ ‌\n○Each‌ ‌tribe‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌divided‌ ‌into‌ ‌two‌ ‌or‌ ‌more‌ ‌age‌ ‌grade‌ ‌and‌ ‌each‌ ‌grade‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌specific‌ ‌political‌ ‌function.‌ ‌\n○Example:‌‌ ‌The‌ ‌‌Kipsigis‌ ‌Community‌ ‌of‌ ‌Kenya‌ ‌has‌ ‌two‌ ‌age‌ ‌grades:‌ ‌Warrior‌ ‌and‌ ‌Elders.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Club‌ ‌based‌ ‌political‌ ‌organisation‌ ‌\n○Common‌ ‌interest,‌ ‌Association‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌secret‌ ‌societies‌ ‌or‌ ‌tribal‌ ‌fraternity‌ ‌and‌ ‌military‌ ‌club‌ ‌can‌ ‌also‌ ‌form‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌political‌ ‌\norganisation‌ ‌of‌ ‌tribal‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Example:‌‌ ‌The‌ ‌Cheyenne‌ ‌Warriors‌ ‌Club‌ ‌\n●Headmen/Big‌ ‌Man‌ ‌\n○Admin‌ ‌aur‌ ‌Pata‌ ‌chieftain‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌head‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌local‌ ‌community‌ ‌the‌ ‌head‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌lineage‌ ‌or‌ ‌a‌ ‌homestead‌ ‌or‌ ‌village.‌ ‌\n○Adventure‌ ‌ship‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌recognised‌ ‌status‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌group,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌official‌ ‌position‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌different‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌leadership‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌band‌ ‌\nsocieties.‌ ‌\n○Though‌ ‌a‌ ‌man‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌a‌ ‌legitimate‌ ‌successor‌ ‌to‌ ‌head‌ ‌manship‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌occupying‌ ‌the‌ ‌position‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌admired‌ ‌Personal‌ ‌qualities.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nBig‌ ‌Man‌ ‌\n ‌\n534‌ ‌\n ‌\n●From‌ ‌the‌ ‌middle‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌last‌ ‌century,‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌working‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌island‌ ‌of‌ ‌New‌ ‌Guinea‌ ‌described‌ ‌a‌ ‌unique‌ ‌kind‌ ‌of‌ ‌political‌ ‌behavior.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Although‌ ‌the‌ ‌majority‌ ‌of‌ ‌societies‌ ‌are‌ ‌classified‌ ‌as‌ ‌‘stateless’—that‌ ‌is,‌ ‌without‌ ‌formal‌ ‌political‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌circumscribing‌ ‌social‌ ‌and‌ ‌\npolitical‌ ‌boundaries‌ ‌and‌ ‌no‌ ‌formal‌ ‌positions‌ ‌of‌ ‌power‌ ‌for‌ ‌men‌ ‌to‌ ‌occupy—there‌ ‌were‌ ‌men‌ ‌who‌ ‌clearly‌ ‌held‌ ‌culturally‌ ‌recognized‌ ‌\npositions‌ ‌of‌ ‌leadership.‌ ‌These‌ ‌were‌ ‌labeled‌ ‌‘Big‌ ‌Man’‌ ‌systems.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Big‌ ‌Man‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌a‌ ‌hereditary‌ ‌position,‌ ‌but‌ ‌one‌ ‌earned‌ ‌through‌ ‌a‌ ‌power‌ ‌of‌ ‌persuasion‌ ‌empathy,‌ ‌and‌ ‌an‌ ‌ability‌ ‌to‌ ‌secure‌ ‌resources‌ ‌and‌ ‌\ndistribute‌ ‌them‌ ‌fairly‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌tribe‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Big‌ ‌Man’s‌ ‌position‌ ‌is‌ ‌constantly‌ ‌challenged‌ ‌by‌ ‌other‌ ‌men‌ ‌who‌ ‌seek‌ ‌to‌ ‌gather‌ ‌resources‌ ‌and‌ ‌prove‌ ‌themselves‌ ‌more‌ ‌capable‌ ‌than‌ ‌the‌ ‌\ncurrent‌ ‌Big‌ ‌Man.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nCHIEFDOMS‌ ‌\n●Much‌ ‌of‌ ‌our‌ ‌ethnographic‌ ‌knowledge‌ ‌about‌ ‌chiefdoms‌ ‌came‌ ‌from‌ ‌‌Polynesia‌ ‌(Kirch‌ ‌2000),‌ ‌where‌ ‌they‌ ‌were‌ ‌common‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌time‌ ‌of‌ ‌European‌ ‌\nexploration‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌chiefdoms,‌ ‌social‌ ‌relations‌ ‌are‌ ‌mainly‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌‌kinship,‌ ‌marriage,‌ ‌descent,‌ ‌age,‌ ‌generation,‌ ‌and‌ ‌gender‌ ‌–‌ ‌as‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌in‌ ‌bands‌ ‌and‌ ‌\ntribes.‌ ‌\n535‌ ‌\n○Unlike‌ ‌bands‌ ‌and‌ ‌tribes,‌ ‌however,‌ ‌chiefdoms‌ ‌are‌ ‌characterized‌ ‌by‌ ‌permanent‌ ‌political‌ ‌regulation‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌territory‌ ‌they‌ ‌administer.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Chiefdoms‌ ‌might‌ ‌include‌ ‌thousands‌ ‌of‌ ‌people‌ ‌living‌ ‌in‌ ‌many‌ ‌villages‌ ‌and‌ ‌or‌ ‌hamlets.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Chiefdom‌ ‌constitutes‌ ‌a‌ ‌political‌ ‌organisation‌ ‌characterized‌ ‌by‌ ‌social‌ ‌hierarchies‌ ‌and‌ ‌consolidation‌ ‌of‌ ‌political‌ ‌power‌ ‌into‌ ‌full-time‌ ‌specialist‌ ‌\nwho‌ ‌control‌ ‌production‌ ‌and‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌of‌ ‌resources.‌ ‌\n●Sometimes‌ ‌the‌ ‌prestige‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌leader‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌is‌ ‌here‌ ‌but‌ ‌not‌ ‌always‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌leader‌ ‌or‌ ‌chief‌ ‌was‌ ‌bit‌ ‌like‌ ‌a‌ ‌bigman,‌ ‌but‌ ‌they‌ ‌were‌ ‌reliant‌ ‌on‌ ‌their‌ ‌persuade‌ ‌skill‌ ‌but‌ ‌had‌ ‌more‌ ‌control‌ ‌over‌ ‌resources.‌ ‌\n●Sometimes‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌advisory‌ ‌council‌ ‌as‌ ‌well,‌ ‌but‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌bureaucracy‌ ‌of‌ ‌professional‌ ‌administrators.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌government‌ ‌is‌ ‌essentially‌ ‌just‌ ‌the‌ ‌chief.‌ ‌Some‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌more‌ ‌advanced‌ ‌chiefdoms‌ ‌in‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌are‌ ‌an‌ ‌exception‌ ‌in‌ ‌that‌ ‌they‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nparamount‌ ‌chief‌ ‌and‌ ‌lesser‌ ‌chiefs‌ ‌who‌ ‌perform‌ ‌administrative‌ ‌functions.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌Baganda‌ ‌and‌ ‌Bunyoro‌ ‌of‌ ‌Uganda‌ ‌are‌ ‌examples‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌chiefdoms‌ ‌of‌ ‌‌ancient‌ ‌Hawaii‌ ‌and‌ ‌elsewhere‌ ‌in‌ ‌Polynesia‌ ‌were‌ ‌similar‌ ‌in‌ ‌having‌ ‌several‌ ‌levels‌ ‌of‌ ‌chiefs.‌ ‌Chiefdoms‌ ‌also‌ ‌are‌ ‌\nknown‌ ‌historically‌ ‌from‌ ‌Europe,‌ ‌Asia,‌ ‌the‌ ‌southeastern‌ ‌United‌ ‌States,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Caribbean‌ ‌islands,‌ ‌Panama,‌ ‌Colombia,‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌Amazon‌ ‌\nBasin‌ ‌of‌ ‌Brazil.‌ ‌\n●Successive‌ ‌leadership‌ ‌usually‌ ‌well‌ ‌within‌ ‌family‌ ‌line.‌ ‌\n●All‌ ‌chief‌ ‌down‌ ‌that‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌anthropologically‌ ‌identified‌ ‌were‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌Horticulture‌ ‌or‌ ‌intensive‌ ‌agriculture‌ ‌with‌ ‌‌one‌ ‌notable‌ ‌exception‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌Pacific‌ ‌Northwest‌ ‌of‌ ‌North‌ ‌America‌ ‌chiefdom‌ ‌emerged‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌foraging.‌ ‌\n●An‌ ‌important‌ ‌advantage‌ ‌that‌ ‌chiefdoms‌ ‌have‌ ‌over‌ ‌band‌ ‌and‌ ‌tribal‌ ‌level‌ ‌societies‌ ‌‌when‌ ‌conflicts‌ ‌arise‌ ‌between‌ ‌them‌ ‌is‌ ‌that‌ ‌chiefdoms‌ ‌are‌ ‌\nusually‌ ‌more‌ ‌effective‌ ‌in‌ ‌warfare.‌ ‌This‌ ‌is‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌fact‌ ‌that‌ ‌chiefdoms‌ ‌have‌ ‌two‌ ‌important‌ ‌advantages.‌ ‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌have‌ ‌larger‌ ‌populations‌ ‌so‌ ‌they‌ ‌can‌ ‌assemble‌ ‌larger‌ ‌military‌ ‌forces.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌addition,‌ ‌the‌ ‌chief‌ ‌can‌ ‌provide‌ ‌centralized‌ ‌direction‌ ‌which‌ ‌potentially‌ ‌allows‌ ‌more‌ ‌decisive‌ ‌action.‌ ‌Some‌ ‌chiefdoms‌ ‌in‌ ‌Western‌ ‌\nSouth‌ ‌America‌ ‌had‌ ‌in‌ ‌excess‌ ‌of‌ ‌100,000‌ ‌people.‌ ‌The‌ ‌Chibcha‌ ‌of‌ ‌Colombia‌ ‌was‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌them.‌ ‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌became‌ ‌a‌ ‌militarily‌ ‌powerful‌ ‌force‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌mountain‌ ‌regions‌ ‌that‌ ‌made‌ ‌up‌ ‌their‌ ‌homeland.‌ ‌\n○Once‌ ‌functioning,‌ ‌the‌ ‌position‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌chief‌ ‌usually‌ ‌becomes‌ ‌essential‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌functioning‌ ‌of‌ ‌society.‌ ‌Chiefdoms‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌go‌ ‌back‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌\ntribal‌ ‌level‌ ‌unless‌ ‌their‌ ‌population‌ ‌drops‌ ‌significantly.‌ ‌\n●Examples:‌ ‌\n○Trobriand‌ ‌and‌ ‌Tonga‌ ‌Islanders‌ ‌of‌ ‌Pacific‌ ‌\n○Polynesians‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Hawaiian‌ ‌Islands‌ ‌ ‌\n○Maori‌ ‌of‌ ‌New‌ ‌Zealand‌ ‌\n○Ancient‌ ‌Olmec‌ ‌of‌ ‌Mexico‌ ‌\n○Zulu‌ ‌&‌ ‌Ashanti‌ ‌of‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌\n ‌\nSTATE‌ ‌\n●State‌ ‌level‌ ‌political‌ ‌systems‌ ‌first‌ ‌appeared‌ ‌in‌ ‌‌societies‌ ‌with‌ ‌large-scale‌ ‌intensive‌ ‌agriculture‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌began‌ ‌as‌ ‌chiefdoms‌ ‌and‌ ‌then‌ ‌evolved‌ ‌into‌ ‌more‌ ‌centralized,‌ ‌authoritarian‌ ‌kingdoms‌ ‌when‌ ‌their‌ ‌populations‌ ‌grew‌ ‌into‌ ‌tens‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nthousands‌ ‌of‌ ‌people.‌ ‌ ‌\n536‌ ‌\n●While‌ ‌chiefdoms‌ ‌are‌ ‌societies‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌everyone‌ ‌is‌ ‌ranked‌ ‌relative‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌chief,‌ ‌states‌ ‌are‌ ‌socially‌ ‌stratified‌ ‌into‌ ‌largely‌ ‌distinct‌ ‌classes‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nterms‌ ‌of‌ ‌wealth,‌ ‌power,‌ ‌and‌ ‌prestige.‌ ‌\n●Around‌ ‌5,500‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago,‌ ‌the‌ ‌early‌ ‌kingdoms‌ ‌of‌ ‌Ancient‌ ‌Egypt‌ ‌and‌ ‌Mesopotamia‌ ‌(now‌ ‌Iraq)‌ ‌developed‌ ‌such‌ ‌state‌ ‌levels‌ ‌of‌ ‌political‌ ‌\nintegratio‌n.‌ ‌Shortly‌ ‌thereafter,‌ ‌states‌ ‌evolved‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌subcontinent‌ ‌and‌ ‌China.‌ ‌ ‌\n●By‌ ‌4,500‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago,‌ ‌states‌ ‌were‌ ‌developing‌ ‌in‌ ‌Mesoamerica‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌central‌ ‌Andean‌ ‌mountain‌ ‌region‌ ‌of‌ ‌western‌ ‌South‌ ‌America.‌ ‌The‌ ‌early‌ ‌\nstates‌ ‌in‌ ‌these‌ ‌six‌ ‌regions‌ ‌became‌ ‌the‌ ‌well‌ ‌known‌ ‌ancient‌ ‌civilizations.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●While‌ ‌these‌ ‌six‌ ‌centers‌ ‌of‌ ‌early‌ ‌civilization‌ ‌had‌ ‌major‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌and‌ ‌historical‌ ‌differences,‌ ‌they‌ ‌created‌ ‌remarkably‌ ‌similar‌ ‌political‌ ‌solutions‌ ‌for‌ ‌\ndealing‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌problems‌ ‌of‌ ‌feeding‌ ‌and‌ ‌controlling‌ ‌large‌ ‌complex‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌ ‌\n537‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌new‌ ‌political‌ ‌systems‌ ‌had‌ ‌a‌ ‌pyramid‌ ‌of‌ ‌authority‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌small‌ ‌hereditary‌ ‌elite‌ ‌class‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌top‌ ‌headed‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌king‌ ‌and‌ ‌royal‌ ‌family.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n●At‌ ‌the‌ ‌bottom‌ ‌were‌ ‌the‌ ‌commoners‌ ‌who‌ ‌were‌ ‌the‌ ‌bulk‌ ‌of‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌were‌ ‌mostly‌ ‌the‌ ‌food‌ ‌producing‌ ‌farmers‌ ‌upon‌ ‌whom‌ ‌the‌ ‌entire‌ ‌society‌ ‌ultimately‌ ‌depended.‌ ‌In‌ ‌between‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌small‌ ‌middle‌ ‌class‌ ‌\nconsisting‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌groups.‌ ‌ ‌\n○First,‌ ‌there‌ ‌were‌ ‌professional‌ ‌craftsmen‌ ‌and‌ ‌traders‌ ‌who‌ ‌mainly‌ ‌produced‌ ‌or‌ ‌acquired‌ ‌luxury‌ ‌items‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌elite.‌ ‌ ‌\n538‌ ‌\n○Second,‌ ‌there‌ ‌were‌ ‌professional‌ ‌bureaucrats‌ ‌who‌ ‌administered‌ ‌the‌ ‌state‌ ‌religion‌ ‌and‌ ‌government‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌daily‌ ‌basis.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●As‌ ‌independent‌ ‌kingdoms‌ ‌within‌ ‌each‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌geographic‌ ‌regions‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌ancient‌ ‌civilization‌ ‌competed‌ ‌for‌ ‌land,‌ ‌water,‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌important‌ ‌\nresources,‌ ‌warfare‌ ‌became‌ ‌more‌ ‌frequent‌ ‌and‌ ‌larger‌ ‌in‌ ‌scale.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Professional‌ ‌armies‌ ‌were‌ ‌created‌ ‌along‌ ‌with‌ ‌more‌ ‌efficient‌ ‌weapons.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌the‌ ‌Old‌ ‌World,‌ ‌these‌ ‌included‌ ‌horse‌ ‌drawn‌ ‌chariots,‌ ‌war‌ ‌ships,‌ ‌and‌ ‌metal‌ ‌swords,‌ ‌arrow,‌ ‌and‌ ‌spear‌ ‌tips.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌consequence‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌wars‌ ‌of‌ ‌conquest‌ ‌was‌ ‌powerful‌ ‌kingdoms‌ ‌destroying‌ ‌and‌ ‌annexing‌ ‌weaker‌ ‌ones.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Eventually‌ ‌the‌ ‌victors‌ ‌ruled‌ ‌enormous‌ ‌multi-city,‌ ‌multi-cultural,‌ ‌and‌ ‌multi-language‌ ‌empires‌ ‌with‌ ‌millions‌ ‌of‌ ‌people‌ ‌living‌ ‌over‌ ‌\nvast‌ ‌areas.‌ ‌ ‌\n■These‌ ‌super-states‌ ‌required‌ ‌even‌ ‌more‌ ‌centralization‌ ‌of‌ ‌authority‌ ‌and‌ ‌larger‌ ‌permanent‌ ‌armies.‌ ‌\n●All‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌ancient‌ ‌civilizations‌ ‌were‌ ‌pre‌ ‌industrial‌ ‌agricultural‌ ‌societies‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌majority‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌populations‌ ‌living‌ ‌in‌ ‌hamlets‌ ‌and‌ ‌small‌ ‌\nvillages.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Most‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌essentially‌ ‌rural‌ ‌societies‌ ‌only‌ ‌had‌ ‌one‌ ‌or‌ ‌a‌ ‌few‌ ‌small‌ ‌cities‌ ‌of‌ ‌about‌ ‌5,000-50,000‌ ‌people.‌ ‌These‌ ‌urban‌ ‌areas‌ ‌were‌ ‌primarily‌ ‌\ncenters‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌elite‌ ‌ruling‌ ‌class‌ ‌along‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌state‌ ‌government‌ ‌bureaucracy‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌majority‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌fulltime‌ ‌craft‌ ‌specialists‌ ‌and‌ ‌traders‌ ‌\nwho‌ ‌worked‌ ‌for‌ ‌them.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌addition,‌ ‌cities‌ ‌were‌ ‌the‌ ‌locations‌ ‌of‌ ‌major‌ ‌temples‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌state‌ ‌religions.‌ ‌ ‌\n●At‌ ‌the‌ ‌top‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌religious,‌ ‌political,‌ ‌and‌ ‌military‌ ‌hierarchies‌ ‌were‌ ‌key‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌ruling‌ ‌elite.‌ ‌There‌ ‌was‌ ‌not‌ ‌the‌ ‌separation‌ ‌of‌ ‌church‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌state‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌characteristic‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌U.‌ ‌S.‌ ‌and‌ ‌many‌ ‌other‌ ‌large‌ ‌nation‌ ‌states‌ ‌today.‌ ‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌instance,‌ ‌a‌ ‌prince‌ ‌could‌ ‌serve‌ ‌as‌ ‌an‌ ‌army‌ ‌general,‌ ‌a‌ ‌province‌ ‌governor,‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌head‌ ‌priest‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌time.‌ ‌This‌ ‌was‌ ‌not‌ ‌\nviewed‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌conflict‌ ‌of‌ ‌interest.‌ ‌\n●Ancient‌ ‌states‌ ‌were‌ ‌far‌ ‌from‌ ‌being‌ ‌egalitarian‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○There‌ ‌were‌ ‌a‌ ‌few‌ ‌rich,‌ ‌politically‌ ‌powerful‌ ‌people‌ ‌and‌ ‌many‌ ‌more‌ ‌comparatively‌ ‌poor‌ ‌commoners‌ ‌who‌ ‌had‌ ‌little‌ ‌political‌ ‌influence‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌almost‌ ‌no‌ ‌possibility‌ ‌of‌ ‌acquiring‌ ‌it.‌ ‌ ‌\n○As‌ ‌single-city‌ ‌kingdoms‌ ‌became‌ ‌multi-city‌ ‌empires‌ ‌with‌ ‌vast‌ ‌territories,‌ ‌the‌ ‌political‌ ‌systems‌ ‌generally‌ ‌became‌ ‌more‌ ‌rigid.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Not‌ ‌uncommonly,‌ ‌the‌ ‌ruler‌ ‌became‌ ‌a‌ ‌god-king‌ ‌with‌ ‌absolute‌ ‌authority.‌ ‌The‌ ‌Pharaohs‌ ‌of‌ ‌Egypt‌ ‌are‌ ‌a‌ ‌prime‌ ‌example‌ ‌of‌ ‌this.‌ ‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌were‌ ‌thought‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌not‌ ‌just‌ ‌mortals‌ ‌but‌ ‌god-kings.‌ ‌As‌ ‌living‌ ‌gods,‌ ‌their‌ ‌authority‌ ‌was‌ ‌absolute‌ ‌\n539‌ ‌\n●Most‌ ‌ancient‌ ‌states‌ ‌had‌ ‌slavery‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌conquest‌ ‌of‌ ‌competitor‌ ‌states‌ ‌usually‌ ‌provided‌ ‌most‌ ‌of‌ ‌them.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Slaves‌ ‌were‌ ‌not‌ ‌always‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌bottom‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌pyramid‌ ‌of‌ ‌power‌ ‌in‌ ‌these‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌Egypt‌ ‌and‌ ‌Mesopotamia,‌ ‌women‌ ‌slaves‌ ‌were‌ ‌often‌ ‌integrated‌ ‌into‌ ‌the‌ ‌households‌ ‌of‌ ‌wealthy,‌ ‌powerful‌ ‌men‌ ‌as‌ ‌servants‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nconcubines.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Slave‌ ‌children‌ ‌fathered‌ ‌by‌ ‌their‌ ‌owner‌ ‌sometimes‌ ‌acquired‌ ‌freedom‌ ‌and‌ ‌far‌ ‌higher‌ ‌status,‌ ‌wealth,‌ ‌and‌ ‌power‌ ‌than‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌\ncommoners.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nSummary:‌ ‌\n540‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nImportant‌ ‌Concepts:‌ ‌\nState‌ ‌political‌ ‌system:‌ ‌-‌ ‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌state‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌autonomous‌ ‌political‌ ‌unit‌ ‌that‌ ‌encompasses‌ ‌many‌ ‌communities‌ ‌within‌ ‌its‌ ‌territory.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌has‌ ‌a‌ ‌centralised‌ ‌government‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌power‌ ‌to‌ ‌collect‌ ‌taxes,‌ ‌engage‌ ‌men‌ ‌for‌ ‌work‌ ‌or‌ ‌war‌ ‌and‌ ‌decree‌ ‌and‌ ‌enforce‌ ‌laws.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌state‌ ‌discharges‌ ‌its‌ ‌function‌ ‌through‌ ‌Government.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌state‌ ‌has‌ ‌a‌ ‌complex‌ ‌centralised‌ ‌political‌ ‌structure‌ ‌that‌ ‌includes‌ ‌a‌ ‌wide‌ ‌range‌ ‌of‌ ‌permanent‌ ‌institution‌ ‌like‌ ‌legislative,‌ ‌executive,‌ ‌\njudiciary‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌states‌ ‌the‌ ‌government‌ ‌tries‌ ‌to‌ ‌maintain‌ ‌a‌ ‌monopoly‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌physical‌ ‌force‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌police‌ ‌force‌ ‌and‌ ‌army.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌modern‌ ‌nation-states‌ ‌and‌ ‌chiefdoms‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌examples‌ ‌of‌ ‌state‌ ‌systems.‌ ‌\n ‌\nStateless‌ ‌political‌ ‌system:‌ ‌ ‌\n●Stateless‌ ‌political‌ ‌system‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌an‌ ‌organised‌ ‌one.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Here‌ ‌laws‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌written,‌ ‌and‌ ‌are‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌oral‌ ‌transmission‌ ‌of‌ ‌tradition‌ ‌and‌ ‌customs.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌has‌ ‌the‌ ‌sense‌ ‌of‌ ‌collective‌ ‌responsibilities‌ ‌rather‌ ‌than‌ ‌individual’s‌ ‌rights‌ ‌and‌ ‌privileges.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌mode‌ ‌of‌ ‌punishment‌ ‌is‌ ‌deterrent‌ ‌which‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌awarded‌ ‌not‌ ‌only‌ ‌to‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌but‌ ‌to‌ ‌any‌ ‌kinsmen‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌accused.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Evidences‌ ‌are‌ ‌based‌ ‌not‌ ‌only‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌presence‌ ‌of‌ ‌witness‌ ‌but‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌mode‌ ‌of‌ ‌oath‌ ‌and‌ ‌ordeals.‌ ‌\n●Magic‌ ‌and‌ ‌religion‌ ‌have‌ ‌an‌ ‌important‌ ‌role‌ ‌in‌ ‌all‌ ‌walks‌ ‌of‌ ‌life‌ ‌in‌ ‌stateless‌ ‌political‌ ‌systems.‌ ‌The‌ ‌band‌ ‌and‌ ‌tribal‌ ‌political‌ ‌organisations‌ ‌can‌ ‌\nbe‌ ‌taken‌ ‌as‌ ‌examples‌ ‌of‌ ‌stateless‌ ‌political‌ ‌systems.‌ ‌\n ‌\n541‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nKingdom‌ ‌\n●Kingdom‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌highly‌ ‌centralized‌ ‌monarchy‌ ‌ ‌\n●Citizenship‌ ‌-‌ ‌All‌ ‌kingdoms‌ ‌have‌ ‌citizens.‌ ‌A‌ ‌country‌ ‌has‌ ‌citizens,‌ ‌but‌ ‌mans‌ ‌organization‌ ‌can‌ ‌also‌ ‌function‌ ‌as‌ ‌kingdoms‌ ‌and‌ ‌require‌ ‌\nmembership.‌ ‌Nations‌ ‌and‌ ‌organizations‌ ‌are‌ ‌both‌ ‌kingdom‌ ‌systems.‌ ‌Membership‌ ‌is‌ ‌similar‌ ‌to‌ ‌citizenship‌ ‌and‌ ‌identifies‌ ‌those‌ ‌who‌ ‌are‌ ‌\nsubmitted‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌systems‌ ‌involved.‌ ‌Whenever‌ ‌membership‌ ‌is‌ ‌required‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌sure‌ ‌signs‌ ‌that‌ ‌some‌ ‌sort‌ ‌of‌ ‌kingdom‌ ‌is‌ ‌at‌ ‌work,‌ ‌and‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌\nalways‌ ‌power‌ ‌in‌ ‌it!‌ ‌Citizens‌ ‌or‌ ‌members‌ ‌are‌ ‌always‌ ‌under‌ ‌the‌ ‌authority‌ ‌structure‌ ‌of‌ ‌that‌ ‌kingdom.‌ ‌They‌ ‌will‌ ‌be‌ ‌controlled‌ ‌by‌ ‌it.‌ ‌ ‌\n●An‌ ‌Oath‌ ‌or‌ ‌Pledge‌ ‌of‌ ‌Allegiance‌ ‌-‌ ‌Kingdoms‌ ‌have‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌pledging‌ ‌allegiance.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Temples‌ ‌and‌ ‌Priests,‌ ‌Palaces‌ ‌and‌ ‌Princes.‌ ‌ ‌\n○All‌ ‌Kingdoms‌ ‌have‌ ‌temples,‌ ‌priests,‌ ‌palaces‌ ‌and‌ ‌princes‌ ‌of‌ ‌some‌ ‌kind.‌ ‌A‌ ‌priest‌ ‌represented‌ ‌the‌ ‌divine‌ ‌authority‌ ‌through‌ ‌which‌ ‌a‌ ‌King‌ ‌\nis‌ ‌able‌ ‌to‌ ‌rule.‌ ‌A‌ ‌shaman‌ ‌represents‌ ‌the‌ ‌gods‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌chief‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌tribe‌ ‌and‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌people.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌chief‌ ‌rules,‌ ‌but‌ ‌the‌ ‌authority‌ ‌comes‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌gods‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌priests‌ ‌acts‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌\"broker\"‌ ‌of‌ ‌sorts.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Holy‌ ‌Days‌ ‌and‌ ‌Rituals‌ ‌and‌ ‌High‌ ‌Places‌ ‌Another‌ ‌sure‌ ‌sign‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌kingdom‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌holy‌ ‌days‌ ‌of‌ ‌celebrations‌ ‌and‌ ‌ritual.‌ ‌In‌ ‌fact,‌ ‌the‌ ‌god‌ ‌being‌ ‌\nserved‌ ‌is‌ ‌often‌ ‌easy‌ ‌to‌ ‌identify‌ ‌at‌ ‌these‌ ‌times.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Power‌ ‌Objects‌ ‌-‌ ‌Talismans,‌ ‌Charms,‌ ‌Fetishes‌ ‌In‌ ‌Kingdoms‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌kinds‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌three‌ ‌main‌ ‌purposes‌ ‌to‌ ‌these‌ ‌power‌ ‌objects.‌ ‌A‌ ‌charm‌ ‌\nbrought‌ ‌blessing‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌user;‌ ‌a‌ ‌fetish‌ ‌had‌ ‌power‌ ‌over‌ ‌others,‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌talisman‌ ‌would‌ ‌bring‌ ‌protection‌ ‌to‌ ‌its‌ ‌owner.‌ ‌\n●Gates,‌ ‌Flag‌ ‌Poles‌ ‌and‌ ‌Totems‌ ‌Every‌ ‌kingdom‌ ‌will‌ ‌have‌ ‌identifiable‌ ‌geographic‌ ‌markers.‌ ‌These‌ ‌delineate‌ ‌the‌ ‌boundaries,‌ ‌the‌ ‌focal‌ ‌points,‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌the‌ ‌\"sign‌ ‌posts\"‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌kingdom.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Capital‌ ‌Cities‌ ‌Capital‌ ‌cities‌ ‌were‌ ‌thought‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌special‌ ‌places‌ ‌where‌ ‌the‌ ‌gods‌ ‌enabled‌ ‌kings‌ ‌to‌ ‌rule.‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌have‌ ‌organized‌ ‌courts‌ ‌to‌ ‌dispense‌ ‌justice.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌kingdom‌ ‌is‌ ‌divided‌ ‌into‌ ‌counties‌ ‌and‌ ‌sub-counties‌ ‌for‌ ‌political‌ ‌organization.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌kingdom‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌divided‌ ‌in‌ ‌social‌ ‌classes‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌royal‌ ‌family‌ ‌occupying‌ ‌the‌ ‌top‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌hierarchy,‌ ‌then‌ ‌ruling‌ ‌class,‌ ‌the‌ ‌chiefs‌ ‌who‌ ‌ruled‌ ‌\nover‌ ‌the‌ ‌peasants‌ ‌or‌ ‌commoners.‌ ‌ ‌\n●At‌ ‌the‌ ‌bottom‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌class‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌slaves‌ ‌who‌ ‌are‌ ‌acquired‌ ‌mainly‌ ‌through‌ ‌raids‌ ‌on‌ ‌neighbouring‌ ‌communities.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n542‌ ‌\n ‌\n4.Political‌ ‌Organization‌ ‌and‌ ‌Social‌ ‌Control‌ ‌:‌ ‌Band,‌ ‌tribe,‌ ‌chiefdom,‌ ‌kingdom‌ ‌and‌ ‌State;‌ ‌Concepts‌ ‌of‌ ‌power,‌ ‌authority‌ ‌and‌ ‌legitimacy;‌ ‌\nSocial‌ ‌control,‌ ‌law‌ ‌and‌ ‌justice‌ ‌in‌ ‌simple‌ ‌Societies-Part‌ ‌II‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nSocial‌ ‌control‌ ‌\n ‌\nIntroduction:‌ ‌\n●Social‌ ‌control‌ ‌which‌ ‌implies‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌intercourse‌ ‌is‌ ‌regulated‌ ‌in‌ ‌accordance‌ ‌with‌ ‌established‌ ‌and‌ ‌recognised‌ ‌standards,‌ ‌is‌ ‌comprehensive,‌ ‌\nomnipotent‌ ‌and‌ ‌effective‌ ‌to‌ ‌stimulate‌ ‌order,‌ ‌discipline‌ ‌and‌ ‌mutuality;‌ ‌and‌ ‌to‌ ‌discourage,‌ ‌and‌ ‌if‌ ‌need‌ ‌be,‌ ‌to‌ ‌punish‌ ‌the‌ ‌deviance‌.‌ ‌\n●Social‌ ‌control‌ ‌works‌ ‌always‌ ‌and‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌time.‌ ‌But‌ ‌in‌ ‌view‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌fact‌ ‌that‌ ‌society‌ ‌is‌ ‌subject‌ ‌to‌ ‌external‌ ‌impact,‌ ‌and‌ ‌internal‌ ‌revulsions,‌ ‌that‌ ‌\ncontinuity‌ ‌and‌ ‌change‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌character‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌system,‌ ‌the‌ ‌enforcement‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌control‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌simple.‌ ‌\n●Social‌ ‌control‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌term‌ ‌sociologists‌ ‌apply‌ ‌to‌ ‌those‌ ‌mechanisms‌ ‌by‌ ‌which‌ ‌any‌ ‌society‌ ‌maintains‌ ‌a‌ ‌normative‌ ‌social‌ ‌system.‌ ‌It‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌all‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌ways‌ ‌and‌ ‌means‌ ‌by‌ ‌which‌ ‌society‌ ‌enforces‌ ‌conformity‌ ‌to‌ ‌its‌ ‌norms.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nDefinition:‌ ‌\n●G.A‌ ‌Lundberg‌ ‌has‌ ‌defined‌ ‌social‌ ‌control‌ ‌as‌ ‌designating‌ ‌those‌ ‌social‌ ‌behaviors‌ ‌which‌ ‌influ-ence‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌or‌ ‌groups‌ ‌towards‌ ‌conformity‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nestablished‌ ‌or‌ ‌desired‌ ‌norms.‌ ‌\n●Kimball‌ ‌Young‌ ‌defines‌ ‌social‌ ‌control‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌coercion,‌ ‌force,‌ ‌restraint,‌ ‌suggestion‌ ‌or‌ ‌persuasion‌ ‌of‌ ‌one‌ ‌group‌ ‌over‌ ‌another‌ ‌or‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌\ngroup‌ ‌over‌ ‌its‌ ‌members‌ ‌or‌ ‌of‌ ‌persons‌ ‌over‌ ‌others‌ ‌to‌ ‌enforce‌ ‌the‌ ‌prescribed‌ ‌rules‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌game.‌ ‌These‌ ‌rules‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌set‌ ‌down‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nmembers‌ ‌themselves‌ ‌as‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌professional‌ ‌code‌ ‌of‌ ‌ethics‌ ‌or‌ ‌they‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌those‌ ‌laid‌ ‌down‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌larger,‌ ‌more‌ ‌inclusive‌ ‌group‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌regulation‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌other‌ ‌smaller‌ ‌groups.‌ ‌\n●Mannheim‌ ‌defines‌ ‌social‌ ‌control‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌sum‌ ‌of‌ ‌those‌ ‌methods‌ ‌by‌ ‌which‌ ‌a‌ ‌society‌ ‌tries‌ ‌to‌ ‌influence‌ ‌human‌ ‌behavior‌ ‌to‌ ‌maintain‌ ‌a‌ ‌given‌ ‌\norder.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Ogburn‌ ‌and‌ ‌Nimkoff‌ ‌the‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌of‌ ‌pressure‌ ‌which‌ ‌a‌ ‌society‌ ‌exerts‌ ‌to‌ ‌maintain‌ ‌order‌ ‌E‌ ‌Ross‌ ‌defines‌ ‌it‌ ‌the‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌devices‌ ‌whereby‌ ‌\nsociety‌ ‌brings‌ ‌its‌ ‌members‌ ‌into‌ ‌conformity‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌accepted‌ ‌standards‌ ‌of‌ ‌behavior.‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌Maclver‌,”‌ ‌Social‌ ‌control‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌way‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌the‌ ‌entire‌ ‌social‌ ‌order‌ ‌coheres‌ ‌and‌ ‌maintains‌ ‌itself‌ ‌–‌ ‌how‌ ‌it‌ ‌operates‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌whole,‌ ‌\nas‌ ‌a‌ ‌changing‌ ‌equilibrium.”‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nSignificance‌ ‌of‌ ‌Social‌ ‌Control:‌ ‌\n ‌\n543‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌‌Kimball‌ ‌Young‌,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌necessary‌ ‌“to‌ ‌bring‌ ‌about‌ ‌conformity,‌ ‌solidarity‌ ‌and‌ ‌continuity‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌group‌ ‌or‌ ‌society”.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌\npossible‌ ‌only‌ ‌through‌ ‌social‌ ‌control.‌ ‌Society‌ ‌has‌ ‌to‌ ‌make‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌its‌ ‌mechanism‌ ‌to‌ ‌accomplish‌ ‌the‌ ‌necessary‌ ‌order‌ ‌and‌ ‌discipline.‌ ‌\n●Herbert‌ ‌Spencer‌‌ ‌has‌ ‌put‌ ‌forward‌ ‌the‌ ‌view‌ ‌that‌ ‌society‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌collection‌ ‌of‌ ‌groups‌ ‌of‌ ‌individuals.‌ ‌Man‌ ‌lives‌ ‌in‌ ‌society‌ ‌because‌ ‌it‌ ‌has‌ ‌a‌ ‌utility.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Through‌ ‌society‌ ‌he‌ ‌is‌ ‌able‌ ‌to‌ ‌preserve‌ ‌his‌ ‌identity‌ ‌and‌ ‌views.‌ ‌In‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌preserve‌ ‌his‌ ‌identity‌ ‌and‌ ‌characteristics,‌ ‌he‌ ‌has‌ ‌to‌ ‌exercise‌ ‌\nsome‌ ‌control‌ ‌for‌ ‌which‌ ‌certain‌ ‌rules‌ ‌and‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌are‌ ‌created.‌ ‌ ‌\n○These‌ ‌agencies‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌control‌ ‌are‌ ‌helpful‌ ‌for‌ ‌preserving‌ ‌the‌ ‌identity‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌and‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n ‌\nNeed‌ ‌of‌ ‌Social‌ ‌Control:‌ ‌\n ‌\n1.Re-establishing‌ ‌the‌ ‌Old‌ ‌Social‌ ‌System:‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌main‌ ‌need‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌control‌ ‌is‌ ‌to‌ ‌keep‌ ‌the‌ ‌existing‌ ‌order‌ ‌intact.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌other‌ ‌words‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌desire‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌society‌ ‌to‌ ‌make‌ ‌its‌ ‌members‌ ‌live‌ ‌in‌ ‌manner‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌their‌ ‌forefathers‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌living.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Although‌ ‌enforcement‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌old‌ ‌order‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌changing‌ ‌society‌ ‌may‌ ‌hinder‌ ‌social‌ ‌progress,‌ ‌yet‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌necessary‌ ‌to‌ ‌maintain‌ ‌continuity‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nuniformity‌ ‌in‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n ‌\n2.‌ ‌Regulation‌ ‌of‌ ‌Individual‌ ‌Social‌ ‌Behaviour:‌ ‌\n●Social‌ ‌control‌ ‌is‌ ‌necessary‌ ‌in‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌regulate‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌in‌ ‌accordance‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌objectives‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌values.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌helps‌ ‌to‌ ‌maintain‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌order.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Unless‌ ‌the‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌live‌ ‌up‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌prescribed‌ ‌norms‌ ‌of‌ ‌conduct‌ ‌and‌ ‌unless‌ ‌their‌ ‌self-seeking‌ ‌impulses‌ ‌are‌ ‌subjugated‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌welfare‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nwhole,‌ ‌it‌ ‌would‌ ‌be‌ ‌quite‌ ‌difficult‌ ‌to‌ ‌maintain‌ ‌social‌ ‌organisation‌ ‌effectively.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Hence,‌ ‌social‌ ‌control‌ ‌is‌ ‌necessary‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌society‌ ‌in‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌exist‌ ‌and‌ ‌progress.‌ ‌\n ‌\n3.‌ ‌Obedience‌ ‌to‌ ‌Social‌ ‌Decisions:‌ ‌\n●Society‌ ‌takes‌ ‌certain‌ ‌decisions.‌ ‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌decisions‌ ‌are‌ ‌taken‌ ‌in‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌maintain‌ ‌and‌ ‌uphold‌ ‌the‌ ‌values‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Through‌ ‌social‌ ‌control,‌ ‌an‌ ‌attempt‌ ‌is‌ ‌made‌ ‌to‌ ‌get‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌decision‌ ‌obeyed.‌ ‌\n ‌\n4.‌ ‌To‌ ‌Establish‌ ‌Social‌ ‌Unity:‌ ‌\n●Unity‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌possible‌ ‌without‌ ‌social‌ ‌control.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Social‌ ‌control‌ ‌regulates‌ ‌the‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌of‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌in‌ ‌accordance‌ ‌with‌ ‌established‌ ‌norms‌ ‌which‌ ‌brings‌ ‌uniformity‌ ‌of‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌and‌ ‌brings‌ ‌\nunity‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌individuals.‌ ‌\n ‌\n5.‌ ‌To‌ ‌bring‌ ‌Solidarity:‌ ‌\n●Social‌ ‌control‌ ‌is‌ ‌to‌ ‌create‌ ‌the‌ ‌feeling‌ ‌of‌ ‌solidarity‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌minds‌ ‌of‌ ‌people.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌the‌ ‌competitive‌ ‌world,‌ ‌the‌ ‌weaker‌ ‌group‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌exploited‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌stronger‌ ‌group‌ ‌or‌ ‌equally‌ ‌powerful‌ ‌groups‌ ‌may‌ ‌clash‌ ‌among‌ ‌themselves.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌affects‌ ‌the‌ ‌harmony‌ ‌and‌ ‌order.‌ ‌Some‌ ‌groups‌ ‌may‌ ‌develop‌ ‌antisocial‌ ‌attitudes‌ ‌and‌ ‌pose‌ ‌danger‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌organisation‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n544‌ ‌\n●Therefore,‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌necessity‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌different‌ ‌groups‌ ‌and‌ ‌institutions.‌ ‌\n ‌\n6.‌ ‌To‌ ‌bring‌ ‌Conformity‌ ‌in‌ ‌Society:‌ ‌\n●Social‌ ‌control‌ ‌is‌ ‌intended‌ ‌to‌ ‌bring‌ ‌about‌ ‌uniformity‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌society‌ ‌and‌ ‌to‌ ‌bring‌ ‌about‌ ‌different‌ ‌\ntypes‌ ‌of‌ ‌conformities‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌\n ‌\n7.‌ ‌To‌ ‌Provide‌ ‌Social‌ ‌Sanction:‌ ‌\n●Any‌ ‌marked‌ ‌deviation‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌accepted‌ ‌norms,‌ ‌is‌ ‌considered‌ ‌a‌ ‌threat‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌welfare‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌group‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌whole.‌ ‌Hence,‌ ‌sanctions‌ ‌are‌ ‌used‌ ‌by‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌group‌ ‌to‌ ‌control‌ ‌the‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌individuals.‌ ‌\n ‌\n8.‌ ‌To‌ ‌Check‌ ‌Cultural‌ ‌Maladjustment:‌ ‌\n●Society‌ ‌is‌ ‌continuously‌ ‌undergoing‌ ‌changes.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌individual‌ ‌has‌ ‌to‌ ‌adjust‌ ‌his‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌changes‌ ‌taking‌ ‌place‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n●But‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌adjust‌ ‌themselves‌ ‌to‌ ‌new‌ ‌situations.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Some‌ ‌may‌ ‌become‌ ‌deviants.‌ ‌Thus,‌ ‌social‌ ‌control‌ ‌is‌ ‌necessary‌ ‌to‌ ‌cheek‌ ‌maladjustment‌ ‌of‌ ‌individuals.‌ ‌\n●No‌ ‌doubt‌ ‌social‌ ‌control‌ ‌is‌ ‌needed‌ ‌to‌ ‌prevent‌ ‌the‌ ‌society‌ ‌from‌ ‌disintegration.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌need‌ ‌is‌ ‌greater‌ ‌in‌ ‌modern‌ ‌society‌ ‌because‌ ‌of‌ ‌its‌ ‌highly‌ ‌complex‌ ‌character‌ ‌and‌ ‌disintegrating‌ ‌forces‌ ‌present‌ ‌in‌ ‌it,‌ ‌says‌ ‌Kimball‌ ‌Young.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌has‌ ‌become‌ ‌the‌ ‌habit‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌people‌ ‌to‌ ‌violate‌ ‌rules‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌norms.‌ ‌If‌ ‌the‌ ‌agencies‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌control‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌act‌ ‌effectively‌ ‌society‌ ‌may‌ ‌\nsuffer‌ ‌from‌ ‌chaos‌ ‌and‌ ‌disintegration.‌ ‌\n ‌\nTypes‌ ‌or‌ ‌Forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌Social‌ ‌Control:‌ ‌\n●Different‌ ‌social‌ ‌thinkers‌ ‌have‌ ‌categorised‌ ‌social‌ ‌control‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌ways.‌ ‌A‌ ‌few‌ ‌classifications‌ ‌in‌ ‌regard‌ ‌to‌ ‌types‌ ‌and‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌control‌ ‌\nare‌ ‌as‌ ‌follows:‌ ‌\n ‌\nGeneral‌ ‌views‌ ‌about‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌control:‌ ‌\n(a)‌ ‌Formal‌ ‌social‌ ‌control:‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌control‌ ‌is‌ ‌exercised‌ ‌by‌ ‌known‌ ‌and‌ ‌deliberate‌ ‌agencies‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌control,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌law,‌ ‌punishment,‌ ‌army,‌ ‌Constitution‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\nMan‌ ‌is‌ ‌forced‌ ‌to‌ ‌accept‌ ‌these‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌control.‌ ‌Generally‌ ‌these‌ ‌forms‌ ‌are‌ ‌exercised‌ ‌by‌ ‌secondary‌ ‌groups.‌ ‌\n ‌\n(b)‌ ‌Informal‌ ‌social‌ ‌control:‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌agencies‌ ‌of‌ ‌Social‌ ‌Control‌ ‌have‌ ‌grown‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌needs‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌society.‌ ‌Folk‌ ‌ways,‌ ‌mores,‌ ‌customs,‌ ‌social‌ ‌norms‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌fall‌ ‌under‌ ‌\nthis‌ ‌category‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌control.‌ ‌Generally‌ ‌primary‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌exercise‌ ‌this‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌control.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n(1)‌ ‌Forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌control‌ ‌as‌ ‌given‌ ‌by‌ ‌Karl‌ ‌Mannheim:‌ ‌\n(a)‌ ‌Direct‌ ‌social‌ ‌control‌ ‌\n545‌ ‌\n●That‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌control‌ ‌which‌ ‌directly‌ ‌regulates‌ ‌and‌ ‌controls‌ ‌the‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual‌ ‌is‌ ‌called‌ ‌Direct‌ ‌Social‌ ‌Control.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌control‌ ‌is‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌family,‌ ‌neighbourhood,‌ ‌play-groups‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌primary‌ ‌groups.‌ ‌In‌ ‌these‌ ‌institutions,‌ ‌parents,‌ ‌\nneighbours,‌ ‌teachers,‌ ‌classmates‌ ‌etc.,‌ ‌keep‌ ‌control‌ ‌over‌ ‌the‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌individuals.‌ ‌\n(b)‌ ‌Indirect‌ ‌social‌ ‌control:‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌this‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌control‌ ‌distant‌ ‌factors‌ ‌keep‌ ‌control‌ ‌over‌ ‌the‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual.‌ ‌Such‌ ‌a‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌control‌ ‌is‌ ‌exercised‌ ‌by‌ ‌secondary‌ ‌\ngroups‌ ‌through‌ ‌customs;‌ ‌traditions,‌ ‌rationalised‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌and‌ ‌public‌ ‌opinion‌ ‌are‌ ‌important‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌indirect‌ ‌social‌ ‌control.‌ ‌\n ‌\n(2)‌ ‌Forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌control‌ ‌as‌ ‌given‌ ‌by‌ ‌Gurvitch:‌ ‌\n ‌\n(a)‌ ‌Organised‌ ‌social‌ ‌control:‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌this‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌control,‌ ‌the‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual‌ ‌is‌ ‌regulated‌ ‌either‌ ‌through‌ ‌voluntary‌ ‌means‌ ‌or‌ ‌through‌ ‌democratic‌ ‌ways.‌ ‌This‌ ‌is‌ ‌\ndone‌ ‌through‌ ‌natural‌ ‌ways‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌control.‌ ‌ ‌\n(b)‌ ‌Unorganised‌ ‌social‌ ‌control:‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌social‌ ‌control‌ ‌is‌ ‌exercised‌ ‌by‌ ‌values‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌usages,‌ ‌traditions,‌ ‌fashion,‌ ‌symbol‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌This‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌elastic‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌control‌ ‌and‌ ‌is‌ ‌\nrelated‌ ‌to‌ ‌day-to-day‌ ‌life.‌ ‌\n(c)‌ ‌Spontaneous‌ ‌social‌ ‌control:‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌control‌ ‌is‌ ‌exercised‌ ‌by‌ ‌ideas,‌ ‌rules‌ ‌and‌ ‌regulations,‌ ‌values,‌ ‌norms‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n(d)‌ ‌More‌ ‌spontaneous‌ ‌social‌ ‌control:‌ ‌\n●Social‌ ‌control‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌exercised‌ ‌by‌ ‌direct‌ ‌social‌ ‌and‌ ‌group‌ ‌experience,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as,‌ ‌aspirations,‌ ‌decisions,‌ ‌desires,‌ ‌etc.,‌ ‌is‌ ‌called‌ ‌more‌ ‌\nspontaneous‌ ‌social‌ ‌control.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n(3)‌ ‌Forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌control‌ ‌as‌ ‌given‌ ‌by‌ ‌Kimball‌ ‌Young:‌ ‌\n(a)‌ ‌Positive‌ ‌social‌ ‌control:‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌this‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌control‌ ‌positive‌ ‌steps‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌reward,‌ ‌the‌ ‌policy‌ ‌of‌ ‌appreciation‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌are‌ ‌used‌ ‌for‌ ‌keeping‌ ‌the‌ ‌person‌ ‌under‌ ‌control.‌ ‌As‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nresult‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌steps‌ ‌man‌ ‌tries‌ ‌to‌ ‌behave‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌best‌ ‌possible‌ ‌manner‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n ‌\n(b)‌ ‌Negative‌ ‌social‌ ‌control:‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌is‌ ‌just‌ ‌reverse‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌positive‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌control.‌ ‌In‌ ‌this‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌control‌ ‌individual‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌fear‌ ‌of‌ ‌punishment‌ ‌and‌ ‌derecognition‌ ‌\nby‌ ‌the‌ ‌society‌ ‌are‌ ‌made‌ ‌to‌ ‌behave‌ ‌in‌ ‌conformity‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌values‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n ‌\n(4)‌ ‌Hayes’s‌ ‌classification‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌control:‌ ‌\n(a)‌ ‌Control‌ ‌by‌ ‌sanction‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌this‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌control,‌ ‌those‌ ‌who‌ ‌act‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌values‌ ‌of‌ ‌the’‌ ‌society‌ ‌are‌ ‌rewarded,‌ ‌while‌ ‌those‌ ‌who‌ ‌act‌ ‌against‌ ‌the‌ ‌norms‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌society‌ ‌are‌ ‌punished.‌ ‌\n ‌\n546‌ ‌\n(b)‌ ‌Control‌ ‌by‌ ‌socialisation‌ ‌and‌ ‌education:‌ ‌\n●Through‌ ‌education‌ ‌and‌ ‌socialisation,‌ ‌the‌ ‌child‌ ‌is‌ ‌taught‌ ‌to‌ ‌act‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌norms‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n ‌\n(5)‌ ‌Forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌control‌ ‌as‌ ‌given‌ ‌by‌ ‌Lumbey:‌ ‌\n(a)‌ ‌Physical‌ ‌force‌ ‌method‌ ‌\n●Under‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌form,‌ ‌man‌ ‌is‌ ‌made‌ ‌to‌ ‌behave‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌manner‌ ‌by‌ ‌application‌ ‌of‌ ‌physical‌ ‌force,‌ ‌\n(b)‌ ‌Human‌ ‌symbol‌ ‌method‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌the‌ ‌second‌ ‌form,‌ ‌he‌ ‌is‌ ‌made‌ ‌to‌ ‌behave‌ ‌in‌ ‌conformity‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌values‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌society‌ ‌through‌ ‌language,‌ ‌traditions,‌ ‌customs,‌ ‌religion,‌ ‌rituals,‌ ‌\netc.‌ ‌\n ‌\n(6)‌ ‌Forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌control‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌Cooley:‌ ‌\n(a)‌ ‌Conscious‌ ‌\n●Through‌ ‌conscious‌ ‌form‌ ‌or‌ ‌social‌ ‌control,‌ ‌society‌ ‌compels‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌to‌ ‌act‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌its‌ ‌accepted‌ ‌objectives.‌ ‌Law,‌ ‌Propaganda,‌ ‌\nEducation‌ ‌are‌ ‌such‌ ‌forms.‌ ‌ ‌\n(b)‌ ‌Unconscious‌ ‌\n●Through‌ ‌unconscious‌ ‌method,‌ ‌social‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌religion,‌ ‌customs,‌ ‌traditions,‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌keep‌ ‌control‌ ‌over‌ ‌the‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nMeans‌ ‌of‌ ‌Social‌ ‌Control‌ ‌\n ‌\nInformal‌ ‌means‌ ‌of‌ ‌Social‌ ‌Control:‌ ‌\n1.‌ ‌Norms:‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌provide‌ ‌the‌ ‌standard‌ ‌of‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌and‌ ‌are‌ ‌regulatory‌ ‌in‌ ‌character.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌choice‌ ‌of‌ ‌individual‌ ‌for‌ ‌striving‌ ‌towards‌ ‌the‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌goal‌ ‌is‌ ‌limited‌ ‌by‌ ‌institutional‌ ‌norms.‌ ‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌provide‌ ‌the‌ ‌guideline‌ ‌for‌ ‌action.‌ ‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌influence‌ ‌the‌ ‌attitudes‌ ‌of‌ ‌individuals.‌ ‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌social‌ ‌norm‌ ‌operative‌ ‌in‌ ‌one‌ ‌social‌ ‌system‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌equally‌ ‌operative‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌other.‌ ‌Conformity‌ ‌to‌ ‌norms‌ ‌is‌ ‌qualified‌ ‌in‌ ‌view‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌socially‌ ‌\ndefined‌ ‌situation.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Violator‌ ‌of‌ ‌norm‌ ‌may‌ ‌invite‌ ‌loss‌ ‌of‌ ‌prestige,‌ ‌social‌ ‌ridicule‌ ‌or‌ ‌even‌ ‌a‌ ‌more‌ ‌severe‌ ‌punishment.‌ ‌\n ‌\n2.‌ ‌Value:‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌consists‌ ‌of‌ ‌culturally‌ ‌defined‌ ‌goals.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌held‌ ‌out‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌legitimate‌ ‌object‌ ‌of‌ ‌realisation‌ ‌for‌ ‌all‌ ‌or‌ ‌for‌ ‌diversely‌ ‌located‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌involves‌ ‌various‌ ‌degrees‌ ‌of‌ ‌“sentiments‌ ‌and‌ ‌significance”.‌ ‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌may‌ ‌consist‌ ‌of‌ ‌inspirational‌ ‌reference.‌ ‌Values‌ ‌are‌ ‌“goals‌ ‌worth‌ ‌striving‌ ‌for”.‌ ‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌are‌ ‌basic,‌ ‌though‌ ‌not‌ ‌exclusive.‌ ‌\n547‌ ‌\n ‌\n3.‌ ‌Folkways:‌ ‌\n●Folk‌ ‌are‌ ‌a‌ ‌people‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌community‌ ‌sense.‌ ‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌uniform‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌common‌ ‌way‌ ‌of‌ ‌living.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌constitutes‌ ‌the‌ ‌folkway.‌ ‌ ‌\n○These‌ ‌are,‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌F.B.‌ ‌Renter‌ ‌and‌ ‌C.W.‌ ‌Hart,‌ ‌“simple‌ ‌habits‌ ‌of‌ ‌action‌ ‌common‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌group;‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌ways‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌folk‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌somewhat‌ ‌standardized‌ ‌and‌ ‌have‌ ‌some‌ ‌degree‌ ‌of‌ ‌traditional‌ ‌sanction‌ ‌for‌ ‌their‌ ‌persistence”.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n4.‌ ‌Mores:‌ ‌\n●Mores‌ ‌are‌ ‌such‌ ‌folkways‌ ‌as‌ ‌are‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌value‌ ‌judgement‌ ‌and‌ ‌are‌ ‌deeply‌ ‌rooted‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌community‌ ‌life.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Any‌ ‌disregard‌ ‌shown‌ ‌to‌ ‌these‌ ‌invokes‌ ‌sanction.‌ ‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌Green,‌ ‌mores‌ ‌are‌ ‌“Common‌ ‌ways‌ ‌of‌ ‌acting‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌more‌ ‌definitely‌ ‌regarded‌ ‌as‌ ‌right‌ ‌and‌ ‌proper‌ ‌than‌ ‌the‌ ‌folkways‌ ‌and‌ ‌which‌ ‌\nbrings‌ ‌greater‌ ‌certainty‌ ‌and‌ ‌severity‌ ‌of‌ ‌punishment‌ ‌if‌ ‌violated”‌ ‌\n ‌\n5.‌ ‌Custom:‌ ‌\n●Custom‌ ‌is‌ ‌“a‌ ‌rule‌ ‌or‌ ‌norm‌ ‌of‌ ‌action.”‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌result‌ ‌of‌ ‌some‌ ‌social‌ ‌expediency.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌followed‌ ‌as‌ ‌it‌ ‌involves‌ ‌sentiment‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌some‌ ‌rational‌ ‌element.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌automatic‌ ‌in‌ ‌character;‌ ‌no‌ ‌special‌ ‌agency‌ ‌is‌ ‌required‌ ‌to‌ ‌enforce‌ ‌it.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Any‌ ‌disregard‌ ‌shown‌ ‌to‌ ‌it‌ ‌invokes‌ ‌social‌ ‌censure;‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌enforced‌ ‌as‌ ‌it‌ ‌is.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌be‌ ‌stretched‌ ‌to‌ ‌meet‌ ‌the‌ ‌changing‌ ‌requirements.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌may‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌change‌ ‌of‌ ‌circumstances‌ ‌fade‌ ‌into‌ ‌nonexistence.‌ ‌It‌ ‌at‌ ‌a‌ ‌given‌ ‌time,‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌force,‌ ‌and‌ ‌reflects‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌consensus.‌ ‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌law‌ ‌maker‌ ‌has‌ ‌to‌ ‌take‌ ‌it‌ ‌into‌ ‌consideration.‌ ‌He‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌disregard‌ ‌it.‌ ‌Custom‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌handiwork‌ ‌of‌ ‌time.‌ ‌As‌ ‌a‌ ‌blueprint‌ ‌for‌ ‌specific‌ ‌social‌ ‌\npurpose‌ ‌it‌ ‌develops‌ ‌over‌ ‌the‌ ‌time.‌ ‌It‌ ‌takes‌ ‌time‌ ‌to,‌ ‌evolve‌ ‌itself.‌ ‌\n ‌\n6.‌ ‌Belief‌ ‌System:‌ ‌\n●Belief‌ ‌system‌ ‌has‌ ‌deeply‌ ‌influenced‌ ‌man’s‌ ‌behaviour.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌has‌ ‌provided‌ ‌the‌ ‌sanction‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌norms‌ ‌and‌ ‌conditioned‌ ‌the‌ ‌growth‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\n●Belief‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌existence‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌unseen‌ ‌power‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌with‌ ‌man‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌age.‌ ‌The‌ ‌feeling‌ ‌of‌ ‌fear‌ ‌made‌ ‌him‌ ‌believe‌ ‌that‌ ‌he‌ ‌is‌ ‌being‌ ‌\nwatched.‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌seems‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌the‌ ‌spirit‌ ‌behind‌ ‌the‌ ‌prayer‌ ‌and‌ ‌meditation.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌raising‌ ‌of‌ ‌hands‌ ‌in‌ ‌supplication,‌ ‌the‌ ‌kneeling‌ ‌before‌ ‌the‌ ‌symbol‌ ‌of‌ ‌faith‌ ‌or‌ ‌such‌ ‌other‌ ‌practices‌ ‌and‌ ‌ceremonials‌ ‌are‌ ‌indicative‌ ‌of‌ ‌it.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌belief‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌incarnation‌ ‌is‌ ‌motivated‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌faith‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌continuity‌ ‌of‌ ‌life.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌motivated‌ ‌man’s‌ ‌belief‌ ‌in‌ ‌goodness.‌ ‌Wrongful‌ ‌actions,‌ ‌he‌ ‌felt,‌ ‌were‌ ‌bound‌ ‌to‌ ‌have‌ ‌bad‌ ‌consequences.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He,‌ ‌therefore‌ ‌avoided‌ ‌these‌ ‌as‌ ‌best‌ ‌as‌ ‌he‌ ‌could.‌ ‌The‌ ‌belief‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌Karma,‌ ‌for‌ ‌this‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌accepted‌ ‌fundamental‌ ‌in‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌\nreligious‌ ‌systems.‌ ‌The‌ ‌belief‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌immortality‌ ‌of‌ ‌soul‌ ‌has‌ ‌largely‌ ‌motivated‌ ‌religious‌ ‌thinking‌ ‌and‌ ‌practices.‌ ‌\n ‌\n7.‌ ‌Ideology:‌ ‌\n548‌ ‌\n●Social‌ ‌determination‌ ‌of‌ ‌thinking‌ ‌is‌ ‌ideology.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Social‌ ‌thinking‌ ‌has‌ ‌always‌ ‌been‌ ‌influenced‌ ‌by‌ ‌ideology.‌ ‌Our‌ ‌social‌ ‌thinking‌ ‌has‌ ‌remained‌ ‌influenced‌ ‌by‌ ‌Varnashrama‌ ‌Dharma,‌ ‌Punarjanam‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌Dhamma.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Politically,‌ ‌unity‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌country‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌the‌ ‌ideology.‌ ‌\n ‌\n8.‌ ‌Social‌ ‌Suggestions:‌ ‌\n●Social‌ ‌suggestions‌ ‌and‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌are‌ ‌an‌ ‌important‌ ‌method‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌control.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Through‌ ‌these‌ ‌suggestions‌ ‌and‌ ‌ideologies,‌ ‌the‌ ‌society‌ ‌controls‌ ‌the‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌of‌ ‌its‌ ‌members.‌ ‌\n●Society‌ ‌generally‌ ‌controls‌ ‌and‌ ‌regulates‌ ‌the‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌of‌ ‌its‌ ‌members‌ ‌through‌ ‌many‌ ‌several‌ ‌ways‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌through‌ ‌books,‌ ‌writings‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nspoken‌ ‌words,‌ ‌inculcation‌ ‌of‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n ‌\n9.‌ ‌Religion:‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌includes‌ ‌those‌ ‌customs,‌ ‌rituals,‌ ‌prohibitions,‌ ‌standard‌ ‌of‌ ‌conduct‌ ‌and‌ ‌roles‌ ‌primarily‌ ‌concerned‌ ‌with‌ ‌or‌ ‌justified‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nsupernatural‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌sacred.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Religion‌ ‌is‌ ‌powerful‌ ‌agency‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌control.‌ ‌It‌ ‌controls‌ ‌man’s‌ ‌relations‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌forces‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌physical‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌environment.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌extent‌ ‌to‌ ‌which‌ ‌religion‌ ‌controls‌ ‌the‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌of‌ ‌men‌ ‌depends‌ ‌upon‌ ‌the‌ ‌degree‌ ‌to‌ ‌which‌ ‌its‌ ‌adherents‌ ‌accept‌ ‌its‌ ‌teachings.‌ ‌\n ‌\n10.‌ ‌Art:‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌method‌ ‌of‌ ‌sublimation‌ ‌and‌ ‌redirection‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌instinct‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌combination‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion,‌ ‌morality,‌ ‌ideal‌ ‌and‌ ‌so‌ ‌many‌ ‌things.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Art‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌indirect‌ ‌and‌ ‌inadvertent‌ ‌manner‌ ‌which‌ ‌trains‌ ‌the‌ ‌child‌ ‌or‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌for‌ ‌either‌ ‌way‌ ‌of‌ ‌life.‌ ‌\n ‌\nFormal‌ ‌Means‌ ‌of‌ ‌Social‌ ‌Control:‌ ‌\n1.‌ ‌Education:‌ ‌\n●Education‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌great‌ ‌vehicle‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌control.‌ ‌ ‌\n●After‌ ‌the‌ ‌family,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌class‌ ‌room,‌ ‌the‌ ‌peer‌ ‌group‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌leaders‌ ‌which‌ ‌exercise‌ ‌influence‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌child‌ ‌by‌ ‌our‌ ‌ancients.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌differences‌ ‌between-Dvija‌ ‌and‌ ‌Ekaja‌ ‌emphasised‌ ‌the‌ ‌importance‌ ‌of‌ ‌education‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌ancient‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n●Education‌ ‌inculcates‌ ‌moral,‌ ‌intellectual‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌values‌ ‌in‌ ‌individuals.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌imparts‌ ‌a‌ ‌sense‌ ‌of‌ ‌continuity.‌ ‌It‌ ‌links‌ ‌one‌ ‌to‌ ‌one’s‌ ‌heritage‌ ‌and‌ ‌sets‌ ‌a‌ ‌perspective‌ ‌before‌ ‌him.‌ ‌It‌ ‌gives‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌vision‌ ‌of‌ ‌uniformity‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nindividual‌ ‌and‌ ‌fits‌ ‌him‌ ‌for‌ ‌social‌ ‌role.‌ ‌\n2.‌ ‌Law:‌ ‌\n●Any‌ ‌disregard‌ ‌shown‌ ‌to‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌bound‌ ‌to‌ ‌invite‌ ‌penalty.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌earliest‌ ‌law‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌custom‌ ‌which‌ ‌was‌ ‌enforced‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌accepted‌ ‌authority.‌ ‌ ‌\n●As‌ ‌a‌ ‌prescribed‌ ‌course‌ ‌of‌ ‌action,‌ ‌it‌ ‌developed‌ ‌out‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌general‌ ‌usages‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family,‌ ‌tribe‌ ‌or‌ ‌clans.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Some‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌faded‌ ‌away‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌change‌ ‌of‌ ‌circumstances,‌ ‌and‌ ‌those‌ ‌which‌ ‌were‌ ‌repeated‌ ‌generation‌ ‌after‌ ‌generation‌ ‌gained‌ ‌influence.‌ ‌ ‌\n549‌ ‌\n●Custom‌ ‌thus‌ ‌came‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌an‌ ‌important‌ ‌source‌ ‌of‌ ‌law.‌ ‌The‌ ‌other‌ ‌sources‌ ‌of‌ ‌law‌ ‌are‌ ‌Religion,‌ ‌Equity,‌ ‌Scientific‌ ‌commentaries,‌ ‌judicial‌ ‌\ndecisions‌ ‌and‌ ‌legislation.‌ ‌\n ‌\n3.‌ ‌Coercion:‌ ‌\n●Force‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌means‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌control‌ ‌is‌ ‌as‌ ‌ancient‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌society‌ ‌itself.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌variating‌ ‌degrees,‌ ‌it‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌used‌ ‌by‌ ‌all‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Some‌ ‌societies‌ ‌even‌ ‌now‌ ‌resort‌ ‌to‌ ‌force‌ ‌against‌ ‌the‌ ‌deviants.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Our‌ ‌society‌ ‌has‌ ‌not‌ ‌given‌ ‌it‌ ‌a‌ ‌high‌ ‌recognition.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Traditionally,‌ ‌our‌ ‌political‌ ‌ethics‌ ‌is‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌nonviolence‌ ‌or‌ ‌at‌ ‌least‌ ‌violence.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌only‌ ‌state‌ ‌that‌ ‌gave‌ ‌up‌ ‌force‌ ‌and‌ ‌coercion‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌instrument‌ ‌of‌ ‌State‌ ‌policy‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌Asokan‌ ‌State.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Gandhi‌ ‌made‌ ‌nonviolence‌ ‌a‌ ‌weapon,‌ ‌against‌ ‌the‌ ‌strongest‌ ‌empire,‌ ‌the‌ ‌British.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌all‌ ‌civilized‌ ‌societies,‌ ‌penal‌ ‌codes‌ ‌are‌ ‌reviewed‌ ‌to‌ ‌humanize‌ ‌the‌ ‌law‌ ‌of‌ ‌crime.‌ ‌Force‌ ‌breeds‌ ‌revenge,‌ ‌it‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌reform.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nAgencies‌ ‌of‌ ‌Social‌ ‌Control:‌ ‌\n1.‌ ‌Family:‌ ‌\n●Family‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌very‌ ‌important‌ ‌instrument‌ ‌agency‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌control.‌ ‌ ‌\n●On‌ ‌the‌ ‌one‌ ‌hand‌ ‌it‌ ‌socialises‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌and‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌it‌ ‌trains‌ ‌him‌ ‌about‌ ‌social‌ ‌behaviour.‌ ‌\n●Family‌ ‌prescribes‌ ‌rules‌ ‌and‌ ‌regulations‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌members‌ ‌have‌ ‌to‌ ‌follow.‌ ‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌rules‌ ‌and‌ ‌regulations‌
