‌form‌ ‌a‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌control.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Family‌ ‌teaches‌ ‌the‌ ‌child‌ ‌to‌ ‌conform‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌norms‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌society.‌ ‌It‌ ‌exercises‌ ‌control‌ ‌over‌ ‌its‌ ‌members‌ ‌to‌ ‌bring‌ ‌about‌ ‌the‌ ‌desired‌ ‌action.‌ ‌\n ‌\n2.‌ ‌State:‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌such‌ ‌a‌ ‌social‌ ‌order‌ ‌the‌ ‌State‌ ‌exercises‌ ‌control‌ ‌through‌ ‌rules‌ ‌and‌ ‌regulations‌ ‌in!‌ ‌a‌ ‌more‌ ‌effective‌ ‌way.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Law‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌important‌ ‌method‌ ‌of‌ ‌man-made‌ ‌social‌ ‌control.‌ ‌ ‌\n●State‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌agency‌ ‌of‌ ‌society‌ ‌that‌ ‌exercises‌ ‌its‌ ‌social‌ ‌control‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌effective‌ ‌manner.‌ ‌\n ‌\n3.‌ ‌Educational‌ ‌Institutions:‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌educational‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌–‌ ‌schools‌ ‌are‌ ‌powerful‌ ‌agencies‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌control‌ ‌and‌ ‌these‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌are‌ ‌committed‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌moulding‌ ‌of‌ ‌\ncitizens.‌ ‌ ‌\n●As‌ ‌Gillin‌ ‌and‌ ‌Gillin‌ ‌say,‌ ‌“The‌ ‌only‌ ‌sense,‌ ‌therefore,‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌education‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌used‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌means‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌control‌ ‌is‌ ‌that‌ ‌in‌ ‌teaching‌ ‌people‌ ‌\nhow‌ ‌to‌ ‌arrive‌ ‌at‌ ‌truth,‌ ‌it‌ ‌trains‌ ‌them‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌intelligence‌ ‌and‌ ‌thus‌ ‌enlarges‌ ‌the‌ ‌scope‌ ‌of‌ ‌control‌ ‌through‌ ‌feelings,‌ ‌customs‌ ‌and‌ ‌\ntraditions”.‌ ‌\n ‌\n4.‌ ‌Neighbourhood:‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌neighbourhood‌ ‌reinforces‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual‌ ‌family‌ ‌as‌ ‌an‌ ‌agency‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌control.‌ ‌ ‌\n550‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌the‌ ‌neighbourhood‌ ‌group‌ ‌controls‌ ‌traditionally‌ ‌take‌ ‌the‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌mores.‌ ‌They‌ ‌are‌ ‌kept‌ ‌alive‌ ‌and‌ ‌enforced‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌older‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nlocality.‌ ‌\n ‌\n5.‌ ‌Public‌ ‌Opinion:‌ ‌\n●Opinion‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌people‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌important‌ ‌method‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌control‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌democratic‌ ‌set‌ ‌up.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Every‌ ‌man‌ ‌tries‌ ‌to‌ ‌escape‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌criticism‌ ‌and‌ ‌condemnation‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌therefore,‌ ‌tries‌ ‌to‌ ‌act‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌public‌ ‌opinion‌ ‌and‌ ‌public‌ ‌sentiments.‌ ‌In‌ ‌a‌ ‌democratic‌ ‌set‌ ‌up,‌ ‌public‌ ‌opinion‌ ‌is‌ ‌more‌ ‌effective‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nimportant‌ ‌than‌ ‌any‌ ‌other‌ ‌agency.‌ ‌\n ‌\n6.‌ ‌Propaganda‌ ‌and‌ ‌Press:‌ ‌\n●Propaganda‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌deliberate‌ ‌effort‌ ‌to‌ ‌control‌ ‌the‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌and‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌groups‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌methods‌ ‌which‌ ‌affect‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nfeelings‌ ‌and‌ ‌attitudes‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌who‌ ‌make‌ ‌up‌ ‌the‌ ‌group.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Radio,‌ ‌television,‌ ‌press‌ ‌and‌ ‌literature‌ ‌not‌ ‌only‌ ‌influence‌ ‌the‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌people‌ ‌but‌ ‌also‌ ‌bring‌ ‌about‌ ‌the‌ ‌changes‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌way‌ ‌of‌ ‌life‌ ‌and‌ ‌way‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌thinking.‌ ‌\n ‌\n7.‌ ‌Economic‌ ‌Organisation:‌ ‌\n●With‌ ‌the‌ ‌rise‌ ‌of‌ ‌modern‌ ‌industrial‌ ‌organisation,‌ ‌the‌ ‌increase‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌size‌ ‌of‌ ‌communities,‌ ‌a‌ ‌shift‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌control‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nmajor‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌has‌ ‌occurred.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌agencies‌ ‌which‌ ‌have‌ ‌risen‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌forefront‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌control‌ ‌are‌ ‌economic‌ ‌organisation,‌ ‌education‌ ‌and‌ ‌Government.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌fear‌ ‌of‌ ‌losing‌ ‌a‌ ‌job‌ ‌compels‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌to‌ ‌follow‌ ‌the‌ ‌rules‌ ‌and‌ ‌regulations‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌industry.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nConcepts‌ ‌of‌ ‌power,‌ ‌authority‌ ‌and‌ ‌legitimacy;‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nPower‌ ‌\n●Power‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌multifaceted‌ ‌notion.‌ ‌Power‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌vital‌ ‌element‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌survival‌ ‌and‌ ‌it‌ ‌has‌ ‌signs‌ ‌and‌ ‌manifestations‌ ‌in‌ ‌every‌ ‌aspect‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌life,‌ ‌\nfrom‌ ‌interpersonal‌ ‌relations‌ ‌through‌ ‌economic‌ ‌transactions,‌ ‌to‌ ‌spiritual‌ ‌and‌ ‌political‌ ‌disagreements.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌of‌ ‌power‌ ‌is‌‌ ‌very‌ ‌broad‌ ‌and‌ ‌implies‌ ‌the‌ ‌ability‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌person‌ ‌to‌ ‌get‌ ‌his‌ ‌wishes‌ ‌carried‌ ‌out.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌simply‌ ‌means‌ ‌the‌ ‌capacity‌ ‌or‌ ‌ability‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌person‌ ‌to‌ ‌influence‌ ‌others.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌most‌ ‌important‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌power‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌ability‌ ‌to‌ ‌determine‌ ‌the‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌of‌ ‌other‌ ‌in‌ ‌accordance‌ ‌with‌ ‌one‌ ‌wish‌ ‌despite‌ ‌resistance‌ ‌or‌ ‌\nopposition.‌ ‌\n●Power‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌institutionalized‌ ‌by‌ ‌nature;‌ ‌political‌ ‌activity‌ ‌among‌ ‌other‌ ‌things‌ ‌involves‌ ‌the‌ ‌competition‌ ‌of‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌or‌ ‌groups‌ ‌for‌ ‌such‌ ‌an‌ ‌\nincrease‌ ‌in‌ ‌power.‌ ‌\n●Power‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌fuel‌ ‌that‌ ‌repel‌ ‌the‌ ‌political‌ ‌structure‌ ‌into‌ ‌action.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌easy‌ ‌to‌ ‌identify‌ ‌authorities‌ ‌structures‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌society‌ ‌but‌ ‌the‌ ‌power‌ ‌structures‌ ‌\nare‌ ‌very‌ ‌amorphous‌ ‌and‌ ‌hence‌ ‌difficult‌ ‌to‌ ‌identify.‌ ‌\n●Power‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌characteristic‌ ‌phenomenon‌ ‌both‌ ‌in‌ ‌democratic‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌authoritarian‌ ‌system.‌ ‌\n551‌ ‌\n●There‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌submission‌ ‌of‌ ‌people‌ ‌to‌ ‌overall‌ ‌power‌ ‌structure‌ ‌in‌ ‌both‌ ‌these‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌\n●Definition:‌ ‌‌German‌ ‌sociologist‌ ‌Max‌ ‌Weber,‌ ‌said‌ ‌that‌ ‌power‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌ability‌ ‌to‌ ‌exercise‌ ‌one’s‌ ‌will‌ ‌over‌ ‌others.‌ ‌\nPower‌ ‌is‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌politics,‌ ‌authority,‌ ‌and‌ ‌wealth.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌idea‌ ‌of‌ ‌power‌ ‌is‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌being‌ ‌able‌ ‌to‌ ‌influence‌ ‌the‌ ‌actions‌ ‌or‌ ‌decisions‌ ‌of‌ ‌another,‌ ‌whether‌ ‌there‌ ‌will‌ ‌be‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nsoft-power‌ ‌tactics‌ ‌or‌ ‌blatant‌ ‌force.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Historically,‌ ‌power‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌considered‌ ‌by‌ ‌such‌ ‌criteria‌ ‌as‌ ‌population‌ ‌size‌ ‌and‌ ‌region,‌ ‌natural‌ ‌resources,‌ ‌economic‌ ‌strength,‌ ‌military‌ ‌force‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌social‌ ‌constancy.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌documented‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌notion‌ ‌of‌ ‌power‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌powerful‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌arena‌ ‌of‌ ‌Political‌ ‌Science.‌ ‌\n●Many‌ ‌theorists‌ ‌like‌ ‌Socrates.‌ ‌Plato,‌ ‌Aristotle‌ ‌have‌ ‌affirmed‌ ‌the‌ ‌importance‌ ‌of‌ ‌power‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌own‌ ‌way.‌ ‌In‌ ‌India,‌ ‌Acharya‌ ‌Kautilya‌ ‌(Chanakya)‌ ‌\ngave‌ ‌importance‌ ‌to‌ ‌power‌ ‌in‌ ‌his‌ ‌famous‌ ‌book‌ ‌Kautilya‌ ‌Arthasastra‌ ‌because‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌life.‌ ‌\n ‌\nTypes‌ ‌of‌ ‌power:‌ ‌\n●Positional‌ ‌ ‌\n○Positional‌ ‌power‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌situation‌ ‌where‌ ‌a‌ ‌man‌ ‌exercises‌ ‌power‌ ‌by‌ ‌virtue‌ ‌of‌ ‌its‌ ‌position‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Legitimate‌ ‌power‌ ‌or‌ ‌illegitimate‌ ‌power‌ ‌\n○Legitimate‌ ‌power‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌power‌ ‌recognised‌ ‌by‌ ‌society‌ ‌and‌ ‌accepted‌ ‌by‌ ‌it‌,‌ ‌legitimate‌ ‌power‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌one‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌well‌ ‌accepted‌ ‌by‌ ‌\nsociety.‌ ‌\n● ‌‌Discrete‌ ‌and‌ ‌indirect‌ ‌power‌ ‌\n○Discrete‌ ‌power‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌power‌ ‌that‌ ‌manifests‌ ‌informal‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌from‌ ‌an‌ ‌officer‌ ‌to‌ ‌his‌ ‌subordinate.‌ ‌\n○When‌ ‌power‌ ‌is‌ ‌exercised‌ ‌indirectly‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌covert‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌may‌ ‌not‌ ‌be‌ ‌aware‌ ‌that‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌being‌ ‌influenced‌ ‌as‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌seen‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nprimary‌ ‌group.‌ ‌\n ‌\nSources‌ ‌of‌ ‌Power:‌ ‌\n●Power‌ ‌comes‌ ‌from‌ ‌numerous‌ ‌sources,‌ ‌each‌ ‌of‌ ‌which‌ ‌has‌ ‌different‌ ‌effects‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌targets‌ ‌of‌ ‌that‌ ‌power.‌ ‌Some‌ ‌originate‌ ‌from‌ ‌individual‌ ‌\ncharacteristics;‌ ‌others‌ ‌draw‌ ‌on‌ ‌aspects‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌organization's‌ ‌structure.‌ ‌There‌ ‌are‌ ‌six‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌power‌ ‌that‌ ‌include‌ ‌legitimate,‌ ‌referent,‌ ‌expert,‌ ‌\nreward,‌ ‌coercive,‌ ‌and‌ ‌informational.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Legitimate‌ ‌Power:‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌\"positional‌ ‌power\".‌ ‌This‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌power‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌have‌ ‌from‌ ‌their‌ ‌role‌ ‌and‌ ‌status‌ ‌within‌ ‌an‌ ‌organization.‌ ‌Legitimate‌ ‌\npower‌ ‌usually‌ ‌involves‌ ‌formal‌ ‌authority‌ ‌delegated‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌holder‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌position.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Referent‌ ‌Power:‌ ‌ ‌\n○Referent‌ ‌power‌ ‌originates‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌ability‌ ‌of‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌to‌ ‌attract‌ ‌others‌ ‌and‌ ‌build‌ ‌their‌ ‌faithfulness.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌personality‌ ‌and‌ ‌interpersonal‌ ‌skills‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌power‌ ‌holder.‌ ‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌person‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌admired‌ ‌because‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌specific‌ ‌personal‌ ‌mannerism,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌charisma‌ ‌or‌ ‌likability,‌ ‌and‌ ‌these‌ ‌positive‌ ‌feelings‌ ‌\nbecome‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌for‌ ‌interpersonal‌ ‌influence‌.‌ ‌\n552‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Expert‌ ‌Power:‌ ‌ ‌\n○Expert‌ ‌power‌ ‌draws‌ ‌from‌ ‌a‌ ‌person's‌ ‌ability‌ ‌and‌ ‌knowledge‌ ‌and‌ ‌is‌ ‌especially‌ ‌strong‌ ‌when‌ ‌an‌ ‌organization‌ ‌has‌ ‌a‌ ‌high‌ ‌need‌ ‌for‌ ‌them.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Narrower‌ ‌than‌ ‌most‌ ‌sources‌ ‌of‌ ‌power,‌ ‌the‌ ‌power‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌expert‌ ‌typically‌ ‌applies‌ ‌only‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌specific‌ ‌area‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌person's‌ ‌expertise‌ ‌and‌ ‌\ncredibility‌.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Reward‌ ‌Power:‌ ‌ ‌\n○Reward‌ ‌power‌ ‌comes‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌ability‌ ‌to‌ ‌bestow‌ ‌valued‌ ‌material‌ ‌rewards‌ ‌or‌ ‌create‌ ‌other‌ ‌positive‌ ‌incentives.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌extent‌ ‌to‌ ‌which‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual‌ ‌can‌ ‌provide‌ ‌external‌ ‌motivation‌ ‌to‌ ‌others‌ ‌through‌ ‌benefits‌ ‌or‌ ‌gifts.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Coercive‌ ‌Power:‌ ‌ ‌\n○Coercive‌ ‌power‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌menace‌ ‌and‌ ‌application‌ ‌of‌ ‌sanctions‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌negative‌ ‌outcomes.‌ ‌\n○These‌ ‌can‌ ‌include‌ ‌direct‌ ‌punishment‌ ‌or‌ ‌the‌ ‌withholding‌ ‌of‌ ‌desired‌ ‌resources‌ ‌or‌ ‌rewards.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Coercive‌ ‌power‌ ‌relies‌ ‌on‌ ‌fear‌ ‌to‌ ‌induce‌ ‌compliance.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Informational‌ ‌Power:‌ ‌ ‌\n○Informational‌ ‌power‌ ‌derives‌ ‌from‌ ‌access‌ ‌to‌ ‌facts‌ ‌and‌ ‌knowledge‌ ‌that‌ ‌others‌ ‌find‌ ‌helpful‌ ‌or‌ ‌valuable.‌ ‌ ‌\n○That‌ ‌access‌ ‌can‌ ‌signify‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌with‌ ‌other‌ ‌power‌ ‌holders‌ ‌and‌ ‌convey‌ ‌status‌ ‌that‌ ‌creates‌ ‌a‌ ‌positive‌ ‌impression‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Informational‌ ‌power‌ ‌has‌ ‌numerous‌ ‌benefits‌ ‌in‌ ‌building‌ ‌credibility‌ ‌and‌ ‌rational‌ ‌persuasion.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌may‌ ‌also‌ ‌serve‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌for‌ ‌beneficial‌ ‌exchanges‌ ‌with‌ ‌others‌ ‌who‌ ‌seek‌ ‌that‌ ‌information.‌ ‌\n ‌\nAuthority‌ ‌\n●Authority‌ ‌is‌ ‌institutionalized‌ ‌power‌ ‌or‌ ‌legitimate‌ ‌power.‌ ‌\n●Authorities‌ ‌the‌ ‌power‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌consent.‌ ‌\n●Authority‌ ‌=‌ ‌Power‌ ‌+Legitimacy‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌‌Characteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌Authority‌ ‌\n●Legitimacy‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌determines‌ ‌the‌ ‌effectiveness‌ ‌of‌ ‌authority.‌ ‌This‌ ‌kind‌ ‌is‌ ‌often‌ ‌said‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌legitimate.‌ ‌legitimate‌ ‌power‌ ‌is‌ ‌often‌ ‌called‌ ‌authority.‌ ‌\n● ‌Dominance‌ ‌\n○ ‌Authority‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌capacity‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌to‌ ‌command‌ ‌authority.‌ ‌\n●Rationality‌ ‌\n○ ‌Basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌authority‌ ‌is‌ ‌logic‌ ‌or‌ ‌reason‌ ‌\n● ‌‌Accountability‌ ‌\n○ ‌The‌ ‌individual‌ ‌or‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌individual‌ ‌who‌ ‌possess‌ ‌authority‌ ‌are‌ ‌responsible‌ ‌to‌ ‌higher‌ ‌authority‌ ‌\n● ‌‌Limit‌ ‌of‌ ‌authority‌ ‌\n553‌ ‌\n○Authority‌ ‌is‌ ‌always‌ ‌subject‌ ‌to‌ ‌Limit‌ ‌if‌ ‌the‌ ‌limit‌ ‌is‌ ‌violated‌ ‌by‌ ‌those‌ ‌who‌ ‌positivity‌ ‌the‌ ‌subordinate‌ ‌can‌ ‌ignore‌ ‌oppose‌ ‌it.‌ ‌\n ‌\nAccording‌ ‌to‌ ‌Max‌ ‌Weber‌(The‌ ‌Three‌ ‌Types‌ ‌of‌ ‌Legitimate‌ ‌Rule‌ ‌which‌ ‌was‌ ‌published‌ ‌in‌ ‌his‌ ‌masterwork‌ ‌Economy‌ ‌and‌ ‌Society),‌ ‌the‌ ‌three‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nlegitimate‌ ‌authority‌ ‌are‌ ‌traditional,‌ ‌rational-legal,‌ ‌and‌ ‌charismatic:‌ ‌\n ‌\n554‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nLegitimacy‌ ‌\n●Legitimation‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌social‌ ‌sciences‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌process‌ ‌whereby‌ ‌an‌ ‌act,‌ ‌process,‌ ‌or‌ ‌ideology‌ ‌becomes‌ ‌legitimate‌ ‌by‌ ‌its‌ ‌attachment‌ ‌to‌ ‌norms‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌values‌ ‌within‌ ‌a‌ ‌given‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌process‌ ‌of‌ ‌making‌ ‌something‌ ‌acceptable‌ ‌and‌ ‌normative‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌or‌ ‌audience.‌ ‌\n●Political‌ ‌system‌ ‌combines‌ ‌authority‌ ‌and‌ ‌power‌ ‌both‌ ‌of‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌required‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌regulation‌ ‌of‌ ‌public‌ ‌affairs.‌ ‌\n555‌ ‌\n●Political‌ ‌systems‌ ‌are‌ ‌concerned‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌maintenance‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌order‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌force‌ ‌but‌ ‌force‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌crude‌ ‌and‌ ‌expensive‌ ‌technique‌ ‌\nfor‌ ‌the‌ ‌implementation‌ ‌of‌ ‌decisions.‌ ‌\n●Something‌ ‌besides‌ ‌Coercion‌ ‌is‌ ‌needed‌ ‌to‌ ‌make‌ ‌a‌ ‌political‌ ‌system‌ ‌to‌ ‌work‌ ‌this‌ ‌additional‌ ‌ingredient‌ ‌is‌ ‌legitimacy.‌ ‌\nCharacteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌legitimacy:‌ ‌\n○Legitimacy‌ ‌is‌ ‌culture‌ ‌bound‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌involves‌ ‌right‌ ‌decision‌ ‌making‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌involve‌ ‌compliance‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌rightful‌ ‌decision‌ ‌\n○Legitimacy‌ ‌and‌ ‌religion‌ ‌are‌ ‌interlinked.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nSignificance‌ ‌of‌ ‌legitimacy:‌ ‌\n●Legitimacy‌ ‌is‌ ‌significant‌ ‌for‌ ‌all‌ ‌regimes.‌ ‌‌Legitimacy‌ ‌sustains‌ ‌political‌ ‌constancy‌ ‌as‌ ‌it‌ ‌establishes‌ ‌the‌ ‌reasonableness‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌regime,‌ ‌or‌ ‌says,‌ ‌\nprovides‌ ‌reason‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌regime‌ ‌to‌ ‌exist.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Weber‌ ‌points‌ ‌out‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌regime‌ ‌must‌ ‌arouse‌ ‌the‌ ‌legitimacy‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌people‌ ‌if‌ ‌they‌ ‌tend‌ ‌to‌ ‌maintain‌ ‌their‌ ‌rule.‌ ‌‌Election,‌ ‌a‌ ‌significant‌ ‌element‌ ‌of‌ ‌\ndemocracy,‌ ‌is‌ ‌very‌ ‌important‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌process‌ ‌of‌ ‌legitimization.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Authoritarian‌ ‌regimes‌ ‌also‌ ‌tend‌ ‌to‌ ‌continue‌ ‌elections,‌ ‌even‌ ‌non-competitive‌ ‌elections.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌because‌ ‌elections‌ ‌contribute‌ ‌to‌ ‌provide‌ ‌\njustification‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌existence‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌regime,‌ ‌thus‌ ‌consolidating‌ ‌its‌ ‌legitimacy.‌ ‌\n●Another‌ ‌device‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌regime‌ ‌to‌ ‌get‌ ‌legitimacy‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌constitution.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Being‌ ‌a‌ ‌set‌ ‌of‌ ‌rules‌ ‌which‌ ‌lays‌ ‌down‌ ‌a‌ ‌framework‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌government‌ ‌and‌ ‌political‌ ‌activity‌ ‌are‌ ‌conducted,‌ ‌its‌ ‌legitimation‌ ‌function‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌\nanalysed‌ ‌in‌ ‌two‌ ‌ways.‌ ‌ ‌\n○First,‌ ‌constitution‌ ‌is‌ ‌almost‌ ‌a‌ ‌prerequisite‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌state‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌recognized‌ ‌by‌ ‌other‌ ‌states,‌ ‌where‌ ‌the‌ ‌external‌ ‌legitimacy‌ ‌comes‌ ‌from.‌ ‌ ‌\n○On‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌hand,‌ ‌constitution‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌promote‌ ‌respect‌ ‌and‌ ‌compliance‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌domestic‌ ‌population,‌ ‌thus‌ ‌building‌ ‌up‌ ‌\ninternal‌ ‌legitimacy.‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌‌Samuel‌ ‌Huntington‌,‌ ‌a‌ ‌regime‌ ‌with‌ ‌strong‌ ‌legitimacy‌ ‌must‌ ‌have‌ ‌three‌ ‌kinds‌ ‌of‌ ‌legitimacy:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Ideological‌ ‌legitimacy:‌ ‌that‌ ‌is,‌ ‌the‌ ‌value‌ ‌proposition‌ ‌of‌ ‌regime‌ ‌must‌ ‌be‌ ‌generally,‌ ‌voluntarily‌ ‌recognized‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌people.‌ ‌Enforced‌ ‌ideological‌ ‌\nindoctrination‌ ‌is‌ ‌difficult‌ ‌to‌ ‌sustain‌ ‌such‌ ‌kind‌ ‌of‌ ‌legitimacy.‌ ‌\n●Procedure‌ ‌legitimacy‌:‌ ‌The‌ ‌formation,‌ ‌change‌ ‌and‌ ‌operation‌ ‌of‌ ‌regime‌ ‌must‌ ‌be‌ ‌checked‌ ‌by‌ ‌citizen's‌ ‌vote.‌ ‌The‌ ‌ruling‌ ‌authority‌ ‌is‌ ‌limited‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nrestricted‌ ‌by‌ ‌constitution‌ ‌or‌ ‌legal‌ ‌procedures.‌ ‌\n●Performance‌ ‌legitimacy:‌‌ ‌which‌ ‌means‌ ‌that‌ ‌a‌ ‌regime‌ ‌supported‌ ‌by‌ ‌people‌ ‌should‌ ‌have‌ ‌satisfied‌ ‌performance.‌ ‌\n●Single‌ ‌legitimacy:‌ ‌‌If‌ ‌her‌ ‌performance‌ ‌is‌ ‌unsatisfied,‌ ‌people‌ ‌may‌ ‌question‌ ‌the‌ ‌value‌ ‌and‌ ‌procedures‌ ‌which‌ ‌the‌ ‌regime‌ ‌based‌ ‌on,‌ ‌thus‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nlegitimacy‌ ‌crisis‌ ‌would‌ ‌occur.‌ ‌ ‌\nTherefore,‌ ‌he‌ ‌stated‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌economic‌ ‌crisis‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌political‌ ‌barrier‌ ‌that‌ ‌makes‌ ‌it‌ ‌difficult‌ ‌for‌ ‌authoritarian‌ ‌regimes‌ ‌to‌ ‌come‌ ‌across.‌ ‌ ‌\n556‌ ‌\nIt‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌said‌ ‌that‌ ‌Political‌ ‌legitimacy‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌people’s‌ ‌recognition‌ ‌and‌ ‌acceptance‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌validity‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌rules‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌entire‌ ‌political‌ ‌system‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌\ndecisions‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌rulers.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nLaw‌ ‌and‌ ‌justice‌ ‌in‌ ‌simple‌ ‌Societies‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Laws‌ ‌implemented‌ ‌by‌ ‌societies‌ ‌are‌ ‌typically‌ ‌unwritten‌ ‌laws,‌ ‌There‌ ‌is‌ ‌neither‌ ‌any‌ ‌Court‌ ‌nor‌ ‌any‌ ‌codified‌ ‌body‌ ‌of‌ ‌law.‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌laws‌ ‌vary‌ ‌from‌ ‌society‌ ‌to‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n●Every‌ ‌society‌ ‌has‌ ‌its‌ ‌own‌ ‌specified‌ ‌customs‌ ‌and‌ ‌conventions,‌ ‌which‌ ‌comply‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌norms‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌representatives‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌Characteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌law:‌ ‌\n●Primitive‌ ‌law‌ ‌is‌ ‌conceived‌ ‌largely‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌rather‌ ‌than‌ ‌territorial‌ ‌terms.‌ ‌\n●Primitive‌ ‌insights‌ ‌more‌ ‌closely‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌ethical‌ ‌notion,‌ ‌hence‌ ‌public‌ ‌opinion‌ ‌in‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌societies‌ ‌originate‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌moral‌ ‌notion‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nconcerned.‌ ‌\n●There‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌exception‌ ‌for‌ ‌it‌ ‌and‌ ‌so‌ ‌on‌ ‌no‌ ‌protection‌ ‌against‌ ‌it.‌ ‌Hence,‌ ‌in‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌societies‌ ‌public‌ ‌opinion‌ ‌is‌ ‌more‌ ‌powerful.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌fails‌ ‌to‌ ‌discriminate‌ ‌between‌ ‌public‌ ‌and‌ ‌private‌ ‌wrong‌ ‌as‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌text‌ ‌of‌ ‌our‌ ‌jurisprudence.‌ ‌\n●Primitive‌ ‌law‌ ‌is‌ ‌predominantly‌ ‌a‌ ‌criminal‌ ‌law.‌ ‌the‌ ‌scope‌ ‌of‌ ‌civil‌ ‌law‌ ‌in‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌jurisprudence‌ ‌is‌ ‌limited.‌ ‌\n●Everybody‌ ‌in‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌society‌ ‌is‌ ‌its‌ ‌representative‌ ‌police‌ ‌man.‌ ‌\n●As‌ ‌law‌ ‌coincides‌ ‌with‌ ‌ethical‌ ‌norms‌ ‌a‌ ‌breach‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌nose‌ ‌would‌ ‌often‌ ‌amount‌ ‌to‌ ‌sin.‌ ‌sin‌ ‌is‌ ‌feared‌ ‌as‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌believed‌ ‌to‌ ‌bring‌ ‌Supernatural‌ ‌\npunishment.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌societies‌ ‌intention‌ ‌and‌ ‌provocation‌ ‌in‌ ‌determining‌ ‌legal‌ ‌action‌ ‌are‌ ‌irrelevant‌ ‌because‌ ‌of‌ ‌supernatural‌ ‌punishment.‌ ‌\n●Punishment‌ ‌in‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌society‌ ‌is‌ ‌normally‌ ‌Eye‌ ‌for‌ ‌an‌ ‌eye,‌ ‌Murder‌ ‌for‌ ‌Murder‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n○Fear‌ ‌of‌ ‌killing‌ ‌Tiv‌ ‌of‌ ‌Nigeria‌ ‌\nEvidence‌ ‌in‌ ‌giving‌ ‌justice‌ ‌in‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌society‌ ‌is‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌types:‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌accused‌ ‌is‌ ‌asked‌ ‌to‌ ‌go‌ ‌through‌ ‌an‌ ‌ordeal‌ ‌like‌ ‌putting‌ ‌hands‌ ‌in‌ ‌boiling‌ ‌water,‌ ‌walking‌ ‌on‌ ‌fire‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌if‌ ‌the‌ ‌accused‌ ‌escapes‌ ‌without‌ ‌any‌ ‌\ninjury‌ ‌he‌ ‌is‌ ‌considered‌ ‌not‌ ‌guilty.‌ ‌\n●Oath‌ ‌is‌ ‌administered‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌name‌ ‌of‌ ‌god.‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌Maler,‌ ‌oath‌ ‌is‌ ‌taken‌ ‌by‌ ‌touching‌ ‌the‌ ‌sacred‌ ‌Sword‌ ‌and‌ ‌another‌ ‌day‌ ‌I‌ ‌will‌ ‌die‌ ‌if‌ ‌I‌ ‌tell‌ ‌a‌ ‌lie.‌ ‌\n ‌\nVarious‌ ‌ways‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌justice‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌delivered:‌ ‌\n557‌ ‌\n●Collective‌ ‌responsibility:‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌collective‌ ‌responsibility‌ ‌is‌ ‌carried‌ ‌in‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n○Example‌‌ ‌in‌ ‌clan‌ ‌the‌ ‌members‌ ‌considered‌ ‌themselves‌ ‌blood‌ ‌relatives.‌ ‌therefore‌ ‌if‌ ‌someone‌ ‌is‌ ‌wrong‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌collective‌ ‌responsibility.‌ ‌\n○Most‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌tribal‌ ‌people‌ ‌believe‌ ‌that‌ ‌crime‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌violation‌ ‌of‌ ‌divine‌ ‌system‌ ‌or‌ ‌rules.‌ ‌Hence,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌believed‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌criminal‌ ‌is‌ ‌evil‌ ‌who‌ ‌\nshould‌ ‌be‌ ‌given‌ ‌suitable‌ ‌punishment,‌ ‌so‌ ‌that‌ ‌s/he‌ ‌may‌ ‌become‌ ‌free‌ ‌from‌ ‌evil.‌ ‌Besides‌ ‌retribution‌ ‌another‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌punishment‌ ‌is‌ ‌\ncompensation‌ ‌of‌ ‌loss.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Punishment‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌fine‌ ‌is‌ ‌usually‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌this‌ ‌principle.‌ ‌Principle‌ ‌of‌ ‌collective‌ ‌responsibilities‌ ‌is‌ ‌another‌ ‌important‌ ‌feature‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nsimple‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n○According‌ ‌to‌ ‌this‌ ‌principle‌ ‌punishment‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌necessarily‌ ‌awarded‌ ‌to‌ ‌individual‌ ‌who‌ ‌has‌ ‌committed‌ ‌the‌ ‌crime‌ ‌but‌ ‌his‌ ‌family,‌ ‌clan‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nlocal‌ ‌group‌ ‌may‌ ‌also‌ ‌be‌ ‌punished.‌ ‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌example‌ ‌punishment‌ ‌of‌ ‌death‌ ‌is‌ ‌for‌ ‌murder‌ ‌but‌ ‌this‌ ‌punishment‌ ‌may‌ ‌not‌ ‌be‌ ‌awarded‌ ‌to‌ ‌him‌ ‌who‌ ‌has‌ ‌murdered.‌ ‌In‌ ‌his‌ ‌place‌ ‌\nsome‌ ‌other‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌family‌ ‌group‌ ‌or‌ ‌clan‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌killed,‌ ‌since‌ ‌the‌ ‌group‌ ‌is‌ ‌collectively‌ ‌responsible‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌criminal‌ ‌act‌ ‌of‌ ‌each‌ ‌\nother.‌ ‌\n●Determination‌ ‌of‌ ‌crime:‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌direct‌ ‌perception‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌act‌ ‌of‌ ‌crime‌ ‌is‌ ‌sometimes‌ ‌not‌ ‌necessarily‌ ‌available.‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌the‌ ‌absence‌ ‌of‌ ‌such‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌the‌ ‌determination‌ ‌is‌ ‌left‌ ‌to‌ ‌supernatural‌ ‌power‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌person‌ ‌concerned‌ ‌has‌ ‌to‌ ‌go‌ ‌through‌ ‌several‌ ‌\ntests.‌ ‌ ‌\n○If‌ ‌you‌ ‌pass‌ ‌the‌ ‌test‌ ‌he‌ ‌is‌ ‌considered‌ ‌innocent.‌ ‌\n○Among‌ ‌‌Maler‌,‌ ‌the‌ ‌accused‌ ‌is‌ ‌after‌ ‌licking‌ ‌Red‌ ‌Hot‌ ‌sacred‌ ‌axe‌ ‌three‌ ‌times,if‌ ‌escape‌ ‌unhurt‌ ‌then‌ ‌considered‌ ‌innocent.‌ ‌\n●Criminal‌ ‌intent‌ ‌or‌ ‌motive:‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌criminal‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌only‌ ‌punished‌ ‌for‌ ‌his‌ ‌action‌ ‌but‌ ‌more‌ ‌for‌ ‌his‌ ‌intention‌ ‌or‌ ‌motive.‌ ‌\n●Evidence:‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌process‌ ‌by‌ ‌which‌ ‌the‌ ‌innocence‌ ‌or‌ ‌guilt‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌person‌ ‌is‌ ‌established‌ ‌is‌ ‌called‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌simple‌ ‌societies,‌ ‌and‌ ‌no‌ ‌judge‌ ‌or‌ ‌\nprosecutor‌ ‌is‌ ‌found‌ ‌who‌ ‌is‌ ‌expert‌ ‌in‌ ‌cross‌ ‌examination.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Therefore‌ ‌to‌ ‌get‌ ‌the‌ ‌accurate‌ ‌facts‌ ‌people‌ ‌have‌ ‌to‌ ‌rely‌ ‌on‌ ‌super‌ ‌natural‌ ‌support.‌ ‌However,‌ ‌the‌ ‌two‌ ‌main‌ ‌ways‌ ‌of‌ ‌setting‌ ‌the‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌\nare‌‌ ‌oath‌ ‌and‌ ‌ordeal‌ ‌\n○Oath‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌promise‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌name‌ ‌of‌ ‌God‌ ‌not‌ ‌to‌ ‌tell‌ ‌a‌ ‌lie.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌said‌ ‌that,‌ ‌if‌ ‌the‌ ‌facts‌ ‌furnished‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌person‌ ‌is‌ ‌proved‌ ‌false,‌ ‌the‌ ‌person‌ ‌\nwill‌ ‌be‌ ‌punished‌ ‌by‌ ‌God.‌ ‌\n■This‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌technique‌ ‌of‌ ‌compelling‌ ‌one‌ ‌to‌ ‌confess‌ ‌his‌ ‌own‌ ‌guilt‌ ‌voluntarily‌ ‌\n■Usually‌ ‌a‌ ‌sinner‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌conceal‌ ‌his‌ ‌guilt‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌fear‌ ‌of‌ ‌supernatural‌ ‌wrath.‌ ‌\n■Among‌ ‌the‌ ‌Oroans‌ ‌and‌ ‌Mundas‌ ‌of‌ ‌Chotanagpur‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌before‌ ‌producing‌ ‌his‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌is‌ ‌asked‌ ‌to‌ ‌take‌ ‌an‌ ‌oath‌ ‌\nsitting‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌tiger’s‌ ‌skin‌ ‌or‌ ‌tiger’s‌ ‌jaw.‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌guilty‌ ‌person‌ ‌never‌ ‌dares‌ ‌to‌ ‌tell‌ ‌a‌ ‌lie‌ ‌for‌ ‌fear‌ ‌of‌ ‌being‌ ‌killed‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌tiger.‌ ‌Similarly,‌ ‌in‌ ‌modern‌ ‌law‌ ‌also‌ ‌witnesses‌ ‌had‌ ‌to‌ ‌take‌ ‌\nan‌ ‌oath‌ ‌before‌ ‌giving‌ ‌evidence.‌ ‌\n○Ordeal‌ ‌ ‌\n558‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌process‌ ‌of‌ ‌determining‌ ‌the‌ ‌guilt‌ ‌or‌ ‌innocence‌ ‌by‌ ‌submitting‌ ‌the‌ ‌accused‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌dangerous‌ ‌or‌ ‌painful‌ ‌test‌ ‌under‌ ‌\nsupernatural‌ ‌control.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Among‌ ‌the‌ ‌pre-literates‌ ‌such‌ ‌tests‌ ‌are‌ ‌usually‌ ‌done‌ ‌with‌ ‌fire,‌ ‌charcoal‌ ‌and‌ ‌water.‌ ‌ ‌\n■For‌ ‌example‌,‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Oraons‌ ‌a‌ ‌piece‌ ‌of‌ ‌burning‌ ‌charcoal‌ ‌is‌ ‌placed‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌palm‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌men‌ ‌who‌ ‌are‌ ‌suspected‌ ‌of‌ ‌theft.‌ ‌If‌ ‌\none‌ ‌of‌ ‌them‌ ‌is‌ ‌enable‌ ‌to‌ ‌bear‌ ‌the‌ ‌hot‌ ‌charcoal‌ ‌on‌ ‌his‌ ‌palm,‌ ‌he‌ ‌is‌ ‌considered‌ ‌as‌ ‌innocent‌ ‌whereas‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌is‌ ‌guilty.‌ ‌\n ‌\n● ‌Weird‌ ‌guild:‌ ‌\n○Like‌ ‌the‌ ‌civilised‌ ‌societies‌ ‌most‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌simple‌ ‌societies‌ ‌have‌ ‌provision‌ ‌for‌ ‌compensation‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌loss‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌crime.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌fine‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌charged‌ ‌in‌ ‌cash‌ ‌or‌ ‌in‌ ‌kind‌ ‌or‌ ‌in‌ ‌both,‌ ‌depending‌ ‌upon‌ ‌the‌ ‌seriousness‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌crime‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌capacity‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌culprit‌ ‌to‌ ‌\npay‌ ‌it.‌ ‌\n○Among‌ ‌some‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌native‌ ‌Americans‌ ‌compensation‌ ‌is‌ ‌sought‌ ‌by‌ ‌destroying‌ ‌some‌ ‌valuable‌ ‌possession‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌criminals.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Among‌ ‌Samoan‌ ‌tribe‌ ‌a‌ ‌criminal‌ ‌has‌ ‌to‌ ‌give‌ ‌some‌ ‌valuable‌ ‌presents‌ ‌as‌ ‌compensation.‌ ‌In‌ ‌some‌ ‌other‌ ‌tribes,‌ ‌compensation‌ ‌is‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nform‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌feast‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌whole‌ ‌village.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n5.Religion:Anthropological‌ ‌approaches‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion‌ ‌(evolutionary,‌ ‌psychological‌ ‌and‌ ‌functional);‌ ‌Monotheism‌ ‌and‌ ‌polytheism;‌ ‌\nSacred‌ ‌and‌ ‌profane;‌ ‌-Part-I‌ ‌\n ‌\nTopic‌ ‌:2‌ ‌\nHow‌ ‌and‌ ‌why‌ ‌did‌ ‌religion‌ ‌evolve?‌ ‌\n(‌https://www.bbc.com/future/article/20190418-how-and-why-did-religion-evolve‌)‌ ‌\n559‌ ‌\n ‌\n‌ ‌\nIntroduction‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌word,‌ ‌religion‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌derived‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌root‌ ‌word‌ ‌religio,‌ ‌which‌ ‌means‌ ‌'‌to‌ ‌bind‌ ‌together‌'‌ ‌and‌ ‌religion‌ ‌actually‌ ‌does‌ ‌it.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌has‌ ‌played‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌profound‌ ‌influence‌ ‌over‌ ‌human‌ ‌thought‌ ‌since‌ ‌the‌ ‌ancient‌ ‌past.‌ ‌\n●Anthropology‌ ‌looks‌ ‌at‌ ‌religion‌ ‌from‌ ‌a‌ ‌historical‌ ‌and‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌perspective,‌ ‌going‌ ‌into‌ ‌its‌ ‌origin‌ ‌and‌ ‌development.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌also‌ ‌looks‌ ‌at‌ ‌religion‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌functional‌ ‌perspective,‌ ‌exploring‌ ‌its‌ ‌contemporary‌ ‌practices‌ ‌and‌ ‌manifestations.‌ ‌\n●Archaeologists‌ ‌have‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌of‌ ‌‌religious‌ ‌beliefs‌ ‌and‌ ‌practices‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌archaic‌ ‌Homo‌ ‌sapiens,‌ ‌or‌ ‌Neanderthals,‌ ‌that‌ ‌\ndate‌ ‌back‌ ‌to‌ ‌60,000‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Religio‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌universal,‌ ‌although‌ ‌specific‌ ‌beliefs‌ ‌and‌ ‌practices‌ ‌vary‌ ‌significantly‌ ‌from‌ ‌one‌ ‌society‌ ‌to‌ ‌another.‌ ‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌example‌,‌ ‌some‌ ‌religions‌ ‌are‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌worshiping‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌all-‌ ‌knowing,‌ ‌all-powerful‌ ‌supreme‌ ‌being,‌ ‌whereas‌ ‌others‌ ‌have‌ ‌many‌ ‌\ndeities.‌ ‌There‌ ‌are‌ ‌some‌ ‌other‌ ‌religions‌ ‌without‌ ‌deities‌ ‌at‌ ‌all.‌ ‌ ‌\n●All‌ ‌religions‌ ‌have‌ ‌an‌ ‌underlying‌ ‌belief.‌ ‌That‌ ‌is,‌ ‌the‌ ‌proper‌ ‌performance‌ ‌of‌ ‌religious‌ ‌practices‌ ‌or‌ ‌observances‌ ‌would‌ ‌result‌ ‌in‌ ‌specific‌ ‌benefits:‌ ‌\nhealth,‌ ‌long‌ ‌life,‌ ‌children,‌ ‌material‌ ‌well‌ ‌being,‌ ‌success‌ ‌in‌ ‌hunting,‌ ‌rain,‌ ‌good‌ ‌crops,‌ ‌victory‌ ‌in‌ ‌war‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n ‌\nScope‌ ‌of‌ ‌studying‌ ‌Religious‌ ‌in‌ ‌Anthropology:‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌studying‌ ‌the‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion,‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌concerned‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌‘truth’‌ ‌or‌ ‌‘falsity’‌ ‌of‌ ‌any‌ ‌particular‌ ‌religion.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌major‌ ‌questions‌ ‌posed‌ ‌by‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌are:‌ ‌ ‌\n○How‌ ‌do‌ ‌religious‌ ‌beliefs‌ ‌become‌ ‌established‌ ‌within‌ ‌a‌ ‌society?‌ ‌ ‌\n○And‌ ‌how‌ ‌do‌ ‌religious‌ ‌beliefs‌ ‌affect,‌ ‌relate‌ ‌to‌ ‌and‌ ‌reflect‌ ‌the‌ ‌socio-cultural‌ ‌condition‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌people?‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nDefinition:‌ ‌\nThere‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌single‌ ‌definition‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion‌ ‌that‌ ‌could‌ ‌have‌ ‌universal‌ ‌application.‌ ‌\n●British‌ ‌anthropologist‌ ‌‌E‌ ‌B‌ ‌Tylor‌‌ ‌has‌ ‌given‌ ‌the‌ ‌minimal‌ ‌definition‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion‌ ‌as‌ ‌‌“a‌ ‌belief‌ ‌in‌ ‌spiritual‌ ‌beings”‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌definition‌ ‌is‌ ‌criticised‌ ‌in‌ ‌two‌ ‌ways:‌ ‌\n■First,‌ ‌it‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌include‌ ‌the‌ ‌ritual‌ ‌aspects‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion.‌ ‌\n■Second,‌ ‌it‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌say‌ ‌whose‌ ‌beliefs‌ ‌in‌ ‌spiritual‌ ‌beings‌ ‌are‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to:‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual’s‌ ‌private‌ ‌beliefs,‌ ‌the‌ ‌beliefs‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nparticular‌ ‌small‌ ‌community‌ ‌or‌ ‌the‌ ‌beliefs‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌worldwide‌ ‌system.‌ ‌\n560‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌French‌ ‌sociologist‌ ‌‌Emile‌ ‌Durkhiem‌,‌ ‌“‌a‌ ‌religion‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌unified‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌beliefs‌ ‌and‌ ‌practices‌ ‌relative‌ ‌to‌ ‌sacred‌ ‌things,‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌say,‌ ‌things‌ ‌set‌ ‌apart‌ ‌and‌ ‌forbidden‌ ‌–‌ ‌beliefs‌ ‌and‌ ‌practices‌ ‌which‌ ‌unite‌ ‌into‌ ‌one‌ ‌single‌ ‌moral‌ ‌community‌ ‌called‌ ‌a‌ ‌church,‌ ‌all‌ ‌those‌ ‌who‌ ‌\nadhere‌ ‌to‌ ‌them”.‌ ‌\n○He‌ ‌emphasises‌ ‌on‌ ‌three‌ ‌aspects‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion:‌ ‌social‌ ‌context,‌ ‌the‌ ‌sacred‌ ‌aspect‌ ‌and‌ ‌moral‌ ‌basis.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Religion‌ ‌expresses‌ ‌beliefs‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌society‌ ‌about‌ ‌the‌ ‌universe.‌ ‌It‌ ‌consists‌ ‌only‌ ‌of‌ ‌sacred‌ ‌phenomena‌ ‌,‌ ‌as‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌concerned‌ ‌with‌ ‌an‌ ‌\nextraordinary‌ ‌supernatural‌ ‌world.‌ ‌\n○Religion‌ ‌has‌ ‌a‌ ‌moral‌ ‌basis,‌ ‌because‌ ‌it‌ ‌imposes‌ ‌a‌ ‌moral‌ ‌pressure‌ ‌upon‌ ‌people‌ ‌and‌ ‌directs‌ ‌people‌ ‌to‌ ‌do‌ ‌right‌ ‌things‌ ‌only.‌ ‌\n●F‌ ‌C‌ ‌Wallace‌‌ ‌defines‌ ‌religion‌ ‌as‌ ‌“the‌ ‌beliefs‌ ‌and‌ ‌practices‌ ‌concerned‌ ‌with‌ ‌supernatural‌ ‌beings,‌ ‌powers‌ ‌and‌ ‌forces”‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌‌definition‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion‌ ‌by‌ ‌F‌ ‌C‌ ‌Wallace‌ ‌serves‌ ‌as‌ ‌an‌ ‌improvement‌ ‌over‌ ‌Tylor’s‌ ‌definition.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌clear‌ ‌that‌ ‌religious‌ ‌belief‌ ‌in‌ ‌one‌ ‌kind‌ ‌or‌ ‌other‌ ‌exists‌ ‌all‌ ‌over‌ ‌the‌ ‌world.‌ ‌\n●Clifford‌ ‌Geertz‌,‌ ‌\"A‌ ‌religion‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌symbols‌ ‌which‌ ‌acts‌ ‌to‌ ‌establish‌ ‌powerful,‌ ‌pervasive,‌ ‌and‌ ‌long-lasting‌ ‌moods‌ ‌and‌ ‌motivations‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nmembers,‌ ‌formulating‌ ‌conceptions‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌general‌ ‌order‌ ‌of‌ ‌existence‌ ‌and‌ ‌clothing‌ ‌these‌ ‌conceptions‌ ‌with‌ ‌such‌ ‌an‌ ‌aura‌ ‌of‌ ‌factuality‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nmoods‌ ‌and‌ ‌motivations‌ ‌seem‌ ‌uniquely‌ ‌realistic.\"‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌functional‌ ‌definition‌ ‌focuses‌ ‌on‌ ‌motivation‌ ‌and‌ ‌legitimation.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌Addition‌ ‌\nPersistent‌ ‌functions‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion‌ ‌\nPositive‌ ‌Functions‌ ‌\n●Close‌ ‌the‌ ‌gap‌ ‌between‌ ‌hope‌ ‌and‌ ‌reality‌ ‌(e.g.,‌ ‌the‌ ‌final‌ ‌victory‌ ‌over‌ ‌death,‌ ‌evil,‌ ‌etc.,‌ ‌is‌ ‌in‌ ‌heaven).‌ ‌\n●Make‌ ‌virtue‌ ‌out‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌necessity‌ ‌(encouraging‌ ‌and‌ ‌requiring‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual‌ ‌to‌ ‌sacrifice‌ ‌for‌ ‌others,‌ ‌ego‌ ‌surrender‌ ‌where‌ ‌the‌ ‌functioning‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nsociety‌ ‌conflicts‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌functioning‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual).‌ ‌\n●Support‌ ‌and‌ ‌console‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌and‌ ‌groups.‌ ‌\n●Enhance‌ ‌social‌ ‌stability‌ ‌through‌ ‌projecting‌ ‌sacredness‌ ‌upon‌ ‌social‌ ‌norms,‌ ‌and‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌creation‌ ‌of‌ ‌authoritative‌ ‌sources‌ ‌of‌ ‌opinion‌ ‌\nregarding‌ ‌moral‌ ‌matters--the‌ ‌\"priestly‌ ‌function\"‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion.‌ ‌\n●Promote‌ ‌social‌ ‌change‌ ‌when‌ ‌religion‌ ‌is‌ ‌in‌ ‌conflict‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌prevailing‌ ‌order‌ ‌of‌ ‌society,‌ ‌through‌ ‌social‌ ‌criticism‌ ‌and‌ ‌prophecy--the‌ ‌\"prophetic‌ ‌\nfunction\"‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion.‌ ‌\n●Provide‌ ‌a‌ ‌source‌ ‌of‌ ‌personal‌ ‌identity‌ ‌in‌ ‌pluralistic‌ ‌societies‌ ‌afflicted‌ ‌with‌ ‌anomie.‌ ‌\n●Facilitate‌ ‌personal‌ ‌growth‌ ‌and‌ ‌maturation,‌ ‌as‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌conceptualized‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌religion.‌ ‌\n●Adjust‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌life‌ ‌cycle‌ ‌of‌ ‌changing‌ ‌social‌ ‌status.‌ ‌\n●Rationalize‌ ‌social,‌ ‌political,‌ ‌and‌ ‌economic‌ ‌inequality,‌ ‌reducing‌ ‌conflict‌ ‌in‌ ‌stratified‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌\n ‌\nNegative‌ ‌Functions‌ ‌\n●Excessive‌ ‌guilt‌ ‌and‌ ‌repression:‌ ‌\n○Causing‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌to‌ ‌suffer‌ ‌emotionally‌ ‌for‌ ‌failure‌ ‌to‌ ‌live‌ ‌up‌ ‌to‌ ‌religious‌ ‌ideals.‌ ‌\n561‌ ‌\n●Authoritarianism:‌ ‌\n○Supporting‌ ‌oppressive‌ ‌authority‌ ‌in‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n●Self-mortification‌:‌ ‌\n○Inducing‌ ‌people‌ ‌to‌ ‌endure‌ ‌physical‌ ‌suffering‌ ‌unnecessarily‌ ‌or‌ ‌to‌ ‌cause‌ ‌themselves‌ ‌to‌ ‌suffer‌ ‌deliberately‌ ‌for‌ ‌religious‌ ‌reasons.‌ ‌\n●Ethnocentrism:‌ ‌\n○Causing‌ ‌people‌ ‌to‌ ‌have‌ ‌narrow,‌ ‌culturally‌ ‌centered‌ ‌perceptions‌ ‌of‌ ‌other‌ ‌groups,‌ ‌arming‌ ‌them‌ ‌with‌ ‌absolute‌ ‌convictions‌ ‌that‌ ‌can‌ ‌\njustify‌ ‌repression‌ ‌and‌ ‌violence‌ ‌toward‌ ‌them.‌ ‌\n●Promotes‌ ‌intergroup‌ ‌conflict:‌ ‌\n○By‌ ‌causing‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌to‌ ‌feel‌ ‌urgent‌ ‌about‌ ‌exporting‌ ‌their‌ ‌religion,‌ ‌and‌ ‌to‌ ‌feel‌ ‌offended‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌religions‌ ‌of‌ ‌other‌ ‌peoples.‌ ‌\n●Rationalizes‌ ‌social,‌ ‌political,‌ ‌and‌ ‌economic‌ ‌inequality,‌ ‌preventing‌ ‌social‌ ‌change‌ ‌necessary‌ ‌to‌ ‌reduce‌ ‌social‌ ‌conflict.‌ ‌\n ‌\nElements‌ ‌of‌ ‌Religion‌ ‌\n●Soteriological‌ ‌(having‌ ‌to‌ ‌do‌ ‌with‌ ‌salvation):‌ ‌ ‌\n○Post-archaic‌ ‌religions‌ ‌are‌ ‌schemes‌ ‌of‌ ‌salvation,‌ ‌concerned‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌source,‌ ‌nature,‌ ‌and‌ ‌appropriate‌ ‌methods‌ ‌of‌ ‌removal‌ ‌of‌ ‌some‌ ‌evil‌ ‌\nbelieved‌ ‌to‌ ‌afflict‌ ‌humans.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Most‌ ‌religions‌ ‌are‌ ‌equally‌ ‌concerned‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌achievement‌ ‌of‌ ‌blessedness,‌ ‌release,‌ ‌or‌ ‌fulfillment‌ ‌that‌ ‌transcends‌ ‌evil,‌ ‌in‌ ‌either‌ ‌this‌ ‌\nworld‌ ‌or‌ ‌the‌ ‌next,‌ ‌or‌ ‌possibly‌ ‌both.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Salvation‌ ‌is‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌basic‌ ‌concerns‌ ‌of‌ ‌post-archaic‌ ‌religion.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Kaivalya,‌ ‌Moksha‌ ‌and‌ ‌Nirvana‌ ‌\n●Theological‌ ‌(the‌ ‌rationalization‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion):‌ ‌ ‌\n○Theology‌ ‌deals‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌nature‌ ‌of‌ ‌supreme‌ ‌being,‌ ‌or‌ ‌whatever‌ ‌functions‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌religion‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌source‌ ‌of‌ ‌supreme‌ ‌validity.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Gods‌ ‌are‌ ‌objects‌ ‌of‌ ‌religious‌ ‌devotion‌ ‌and‌ ‌practice,‌ ‌and‌ ‌only‌ ‌secondarily‌ ‌are‌ ‌regarded‌ ‌as‌ ‌conceptions‌ ‌or‌ ‌hypothetical‌ ‌entities‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌\ntreated‌ ‌with‌ ‌speculative‌ ‌interest.‌ ‌ ‌\n○To‌ ‌understand‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌religious‌ ‌outlook‌ ‌calls‌ ‌for‌ ‌knowledge‌ ‌and‌ ‌appreciation‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌way‌ ‌its‌ ‌adherents‌ ‌relate‌ ‌belief‌ ‌and‌ ‌practice‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nsupremely‌ ‌important‌ ‌beings.‌ ‌ ‌\n○To‌ ‌deal‌ ‌properly‌ ‌with‌ ‌theology,‌ ‌one‌ ‌must‌ ‌look‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌manner‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌adherents‌ ‌understand‌ ‌their‌ ‌relation‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌objects‌ ‌of‌ ‌devotion,‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌systems‌ ‌of‌ ‌thought‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌this‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌is‌ ‌expressed.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Anthropological‌ ‌(nature‌ ‌and‌ ‌possibilities‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌being):‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌aspect‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion‌ ‌is‌ ‌intertwined‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌soteriological‌ ‌aspect,‌ ‌since‌ ‌in‌ ‌many‌ ‌religious‌ ‌systems‌ ‌(Christianity,‌ ‌Hinduism,‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nBuddhism,‌ ‌for‌ ‌example),‌ ‌images‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌nature‌ ‌define‌ ‌the‌ ‌problem‌ ‌of‌ ‌evil‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌ways‌ ‌adherents‌ ‌try‌ ‌to‌ ‌escape‌ ‌from‌ ‌evil.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌orthodox‌ ‌Christianity,‌ ‌sin‌ ‌is‌ ‌characteristic‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌nature.‌ ‌This‌ ‌belief‌ ‌sets‌ ‌the‌ ‌stage‌ ‌for‌ ‌salvation‌ ‌by‌ ‌divine‌ ‌grace‌ ‌through‌ ‌God‌ ‌\nforgiving‌ ‌sin.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌Buddhism,‌ ‌suffering‌ ‌is‌ ‌deeply‌ ‌embedded‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌human‌ ‌psyche,‌ ‌and‌ ‌this‌ ‌belief‌ ‌sets‌ ‌the‌ ‌stage‌ ‌for‌ ‌salvation‌ ‌through‌ ‌intellectual‌ ‌\ngrowth.‌ ‌ ‌\n○So‌ ‌for‌ ‌each‌ ‌religion,‌ ‌the‌ ‌problem‌ ‌of‌ ‌evil,‌ ‌the‌ ‌conceptions‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌nature,‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌methods‌ ‌of‌ ‌salvation‌ ‌are‌ ‌interrelate‌ ‌\n●Ethics‌ ‌(relations‌ ‌between‌ ‌humans):‌ ‌ ‌\n562‌ ‌\n○Religion‌ ‌defines‌ ‌appropriate‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌conduct‌ ‌between‌ ‌people.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Ethics‌ ‌are‌ ‌institutionalized‌ ‌as‌ ‌informal‌ ‌norms,‌ ‌or‌ ‌formal‌ ‌codes‌ ‌and‌ ‌laws.‌ ‌ ‌\n○From‌ ‌the‌ ‌point‌ ‌of‌ ‌view‌ ‌of‌ ‌many‌ ‌social‌ ‌scientists,‌ ‌the‌ ‌ethical‌ ‌function‌ ‌is‌ ‌religion's‌ ‌most‌ ‌important‌ ‌contribution‌ ‌to‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n ‌\nReligion‌ ‌:‌ ‌Anthropological‌ ‌approaches‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion‌ ‌(evolutionary,‌ ‌psychological‌ ‌and‌ ‌functional);‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nIntroduction:‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌concerned‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌significance‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion‌ ‌and‌ ‌its‌ ‌role‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌lives‌ ‌of‌ ‌people‌ ‌in‌ ‌belief‌ ‌and‌ ‌practice,‌ ‌\nwhether‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌technologically‌ ‌less‌ ‌or‌ ‌more‌ ‌advanced.‌ ‌\n●Given‌ ‌its‌ ‌complexity‌ ‌in‌ ‌forms,‌ ‌‌variations‌ ‌Concepts‌ ‌and‌ ‌Approaches‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌Study‌ ‌of‌ ‌Religion‌ ‌and‌ ‌practices‌ ‌no‌ ‌precise‌ ‌definition‌ ‌could‌ ‌be‌ ‌\ngiven,‌ ‌and‌ ‌as‌ ‌such‌ ‌the‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌have‌ ‌developed‌ ‌new‌ ‌concepts‌ ‌and‌ ‌used‌ ‌some‌ ‌known‌ ‌terms‌ ‌with‌ ‌specific‌ ‌meanings‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌discourse‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌comprehending‌ ‌religion.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Some‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌important‌ ‌ones‌ ‌are:‌ ‌‌supernatural‌ ‌beings,‌ ‌animism,‌ ‌animatism,‌ ‌naturism,‌ ‌totemism,‌ ‌ritual,myth,‌ ‌symbols,‌ ‌ancestor‌ ‌\nworship,‌ ‌magic,‌ ‌witchcraft,‌ ‌sorcery‌ ‌and‌ ‌evil‌ ‌eye.‌ ‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌are‌ ‌interrelated‌ ‌and‌ ‌often‌ ‌fine‌ ‌distinction‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌made‌ ‌between‌ ‌some‌ ‌concepts.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌explain‌ ‌this‌ ‌universal‌ ‌phenomenon,‌ ‌the‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌offered‌ ‌various‌ ‌theoretical‌ ‌perspectives,‌ ‌These‌ ‌include‌ ‌‌Evolutionary,‌ ‌\nPsychological,‌ ‌Functional‌,‌ ‌‌Marxist‌ ‌‌and‌ ‌‌Symbolic‌ ‌‌perspectives.‌ ‌\n●While‌ ‌all‌ ‌these‌ ‌frameworks‌ ‌attempt‌ ‌to‌ ‌explain‌ ‌religion‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌own‌ ‌terms‌ ‌and‌ ‌try‌ ‌to‌ ‌grasp‌ ‌the‌ ‌reality,‌ ‌no‌ ‌single‌ ‌framework‌ ‌explains‌ ‌\neverything.‌ ‌\n ‌\nBackground:‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌early‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌religious‌ ‌phenomena‌ ‌in‌ ‌‌Tylorian,‌ ‌Morganian‌ ‌and‌ ‌Frazerian‌ ‌style‌ ‌was‌ ‌replaced‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌structure-functionalist‌ ‌\napproach‌ ‌initiated‌ ‌by‌ ‌Malinowski‌ ‌and‌ ‌Radcliffe-Brown.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌more‌ ‌recent‌ ‌years,‌ ‌social‌ ‌anthropologists,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌Evans-Pritchard,‌ ‌Lienhardt‌ ‌and‌ ‌Worsley,‌ ‌have‌ ‌developed‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌\nreligions‌ ‌further.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nEvolutionary‌ ‌Approach:‌ ‌\nEarly‌ ‌Anthropologists‌ ‌used‌ ‌the‌ ‌data‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌studies‌ ‌of‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌societies‌ ‌to‌ ‌speculate‌ ‌about‌ ‌the‌ ‌Genesis‌ ‌of‌ ‌function‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion.‌  ‌They‌ ‌believe‌ ‌that‌ ‌\nreligion‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌problem-solving‌ ‌phenomenon‌ ‌\n●John‌ ‌Lubbock‌,‌ ‌an‌ ‌English‌ ‌anthropologist,‌ ‌‌made‌ ‌an‌ ‌early‌ ‌attempt‌ ‌to‌ ‌combine‌ ‌archaeological‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌of‌ ‌prehistoric‌ ‌people,‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌one‌ ‌\nhand,‌ ‌and‌ ‌anthropological‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌of‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌people,‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌other,‌ ‌to‌ ‌trace‌ ‌the‌ ‌origin‌ ‌and‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌this‌ ‌scheme,‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌beginning‌ ‌there‌ ‌was‌ ‌absence‌ ‌of‌ ‌religious‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌and‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌fetishism,‌ ‌followed‌ ‌by‌ ‌nature‌ ‌worship,‌ ‌and‌ ‌\ntotemism‌ ‌(a‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌belief‌ ‌involving‌ ‌the‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌of‌ ‌specific‌ ‌animals‌ ‌to‌ ‌clans),‌ ‌shamanism,‌ ‌anthropomorphism,monotheism‌ ‌(belief‌ ‌in‌ ‌\none‌ ‌god),‌ ‌and‌ ‌finally‌ ‌ethical‌ ‌monotheism.‌ ‌This‌ ‌has‌ ‌foreshadowed‌ ‌other‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌evolutionism,‌ ‌which‌ ‌were‌ ‌to‌ ‌become‌ ‌popular‌ ‌later.‌ ‌\n ‌\n563‌ ‌\nAtheism‌>‌Fetishism‌>‌Nature‌ ‌Worship‌>‌Totemism‌>‌Shamanism‌>‌Anthropomorphism‌>‌Monotheism‌ ‌‌>‌Ethical‌ ‌monotheism.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●In‌ ‌the‌ ‌late‌ ‌nineteenth‌ ‌century‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌influential‌ ‌works‌ ‌of‌ ‌‌Max‌ ‌Muller,‌ ‌W.‌ ‌Robertson,‌ ‌Smith,‌ ‌Edward‌ ‌B.‌ ‌Tylor,‌ ‌Marrett,‌ ‌and‌ ‌Sir‌ ‌James‌ ‌G.‌ ‌\nFrazer,‌ ‌‌anthropological‌ ‌study‌ ‌on‌ ‌religion‌ ‌grew‌ ‌at‌ ‌a‌ ‌fast‌ ‌pace.‌ ‌ ‌\n●E.B.‌ ‌Tylor,‌‌ ‌expounds‌ ‌in‌ ‌his‌ ‌book,‌ ‌‌Primitive‌ ‌Culture‌ ‌(1871)‌,‌ ‌that‌ ‌animism‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌earliest‌ ‌and‌ ‌most‌ ‌basic‌ ‌religious‌ ‌form.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Out‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌evolved‌ ‌fetishism,‌ ‌belief‌ ‌in‌ ‌demons,‌ ‌polytheism,‌ ‌and,‌ ‌finally,‌ ‌monotheism‌ ‌is‌ ‌derived‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌exaltation‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌great‌ ‌god,‌ ‌\nsuch‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌sky‌ ‌god,‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌polytheistic‌ ‌context.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n(Fetishism‌>‌Belief‌ ‌in‌ ‌Demons)‌Animism‌>‌Polytheism‌>‌Monotheism‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○He‌ ‌defines‌ ‌religion‌ ‌in‌ ‌such‌ ‌a‌ ‌way‌ ‌that‌ ‌all‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌it‌ ‌could‌ ‌be‌ ‌included,‌ ‌namely,‌ ‌as‌ ‌‘the‌ ‌belief‌ ‌in‌ ‌Spiritual‌ ‌Beings’.‌ ‌ ‌\n○He‌ ‌firmly‌ ‌states‌ ‌that‌ ‌religion‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌universal,‌ ‌for‌ ‌no‌ ‌known‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌are‌ ‌without‌ ‌such‌ ‌beliefs.‌ ‌\n○ ‌Belief‌ ‌in‌ ‌spirits‌ ‌began‌ ‌as‌ ‌an‌ ‌uncritical‌ ‌but‌ ‌nonetheless‌ ‌rational‌ ‌effort‌ ‌to‌ ‌explain‌ ‌such‌ ‌puzzling‌ ‌empirical‌ ‌phenomenon‌ ‌as‌ ‌death,‌ ‌\ndreams‌ ‌and‌ ‌possessions.‌ ‌\n●Herbet‌ ‌Spencer‌‌ ‌also‌ ‌‌considered‌ ‌a‌ ‌system‌ ‌similar‌ ‌to‌ ‌Tylor,‌ ‌but‌ ‌felt‌ ‌that‌ ‌ancestors'‌ ‌worship‌ ‌preceded‌ ‌Animism.‌ ‌\n●R.R.‌ ‌Marrett‌,‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌hand,‌ ‌‌regarded‌ ‌animatism‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌beginning‌ ‌of‌ ‌religious‌ ‌ideas.‌ ‌ ‌\n○His‌ ‌derivation‌ ‌is‌ ‌from‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌as‌ ‌‌mana‌ ‌(power)‌,‌ ‌‌mulungu‌ ‌(supreme‌ ‌creator)‌,‌ ‌o‌renda‌ ‌(magic‌ ‌power)‌,‌ ‌concepts‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Pacific,‌ ‌\nAfrica,‌ ‌and‌ ‌America‌,‌ ‌respectively,‌ ‌referring‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌supernatural‌ ‌power‌ ‌(a‌ ‌kind‌ ‌of‌ ‌supernatural‌ ‌‘electricity’)‌ ‌that‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌necessarily‌ ‌\nhave‌ ‌the‌ ‌personal‌ ‌connotation‌ ‌of‌ ‌animistic‌ ‌entities‌ ‌and‌ ‌that‌ ‌becomes‌ ‌especially‌ ‌present‌ ‌in‌ ‌certain‌ ‌men,‌ ‌spirits,‌ ‌or‌ ‌natural‌ ‌objects.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Marrett‌ ‌criticizes‌ ‌Tylor‌ ‌for‌ ‌an‌ ‌overly‌ ‌intellectual‌ ‌approach,‌ ‌as‌ ‌though‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌men‌ ‌used‌ ‌personal‌ ‌forces‌ ‌as‌ ‌explanatory‌ ‌hypotheses‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌account‌ ‌for‌ ‌dreams,‌ ‌natural‌ ‌events,‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌Concepts‌ ‌and‌ ‌Approaches‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌Study‌ ‌of‌ ‌Religion‌ ‌phenomena‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌Marrett,‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌religion‌ ‌is‌ ‌‘not‌ ‌so‌ ‌much‌ ‌thought‌ ‌out‌ ‌as‌ ‌danced‌ ‌out,’‌ ‌and‌ ‌‌its‌ ‌primary‌ ‌emotional‌ ‌attitude‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌so‌ ‌much‌ ‌fear‌ ‌as‌ ‌\nawe.‌ ‌\n○According‌ ‌to‌ ‌him‌ ‌animatism‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌belief‌ ‌in‌ ‌some‌ ‌impersonal‌ ‌power‌ ‌behind‌ ‌every‌ ‌material‌ ‌objects‌ ‌besides‌ ‌living‌ ‌beings.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌impersonal‌ ‌power‌ ‌influences‌ ‌human‌ ‌and‌ ‌can‌ ‌also‌ ‌be‌ ‌controlled‌ ‌under‌ ‌certain‌ ‌conditions.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Marett‌ ‌considered‌ ‌animatism‌ ‌to‌ ‌have‌ ‌existed‌ ‌even‌ ‌earlier‌ ‌to‌ ‌animism.‌ ‌It‌ ‌was‌ ‌only‌ ‌later‌ ‌in‌ ‌human‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌that‌ ‌people‌ ‌added‌ ‌souls‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌other‌ ‌spiritual‌ ‌beings‌ ‌to‌ ‌their‌ ‌theologies.‌ ‌\n○Manaism:‌ ‌According‌ ‌to‌ ‌animatistic‌ ‌beliefs,‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌impersonal‌ ‌mysterious‌ ‌power.‌ ‌Melanesians‌ ‌and‌ ‌Polynesians‌ ‌call‌ ‌it‌ ‌mana.‌ ‌The‌ ‌\npower‌ ‌of‌ ‌mana‌ ‌can‌ ‌dwell‌ ‌in‌ ‌persons,‌ ‌places,‌ ‌animal,‌ ‌plants,‌ ‌and‌ ‌sometimes‌ ‌in‌ ‌inanimate‌ ‌objects.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n564‌ ‌\nValue‌ ‌Addition‌ ‌\n●Mana‌ ‌Theory:‌ ‌ ‌\n○Robert‌ ‌Ranulph‌ ‌Marett‌ ‌(1866‌ ‌–‌ ‌1943),‌ ‌an‌ ‌English‌ ‌anthropologist‌ ‌gives‌ ‌a‌ ‌new‌ ‌direction‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌\nreligion.‌ ‌ ‌\n○He‌ ‌declared‌ ‌his‌ ‌opposition‌ ‌to‌ ‌naturalism‌ ‌and‌ ‌speculative‌ ‌idealism.‌ ‌\n■They‌ ‌explain‌ ‌the‌ ‌success‌ ‌of‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌society‌ ‌by‌ ‌their‌ ‌possession‌ ‌of‌ ‌quantities‌ ‌of‌ ‌mana.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Individuals‌ ‌can‌ ‌acquire‌ ‌mana‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌ways.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌believed‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌the‌ ‌key‌ ‌to‌ ‌success.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Objects‌ ‌containing‌ ‌mana‌ ‌can‌ ‌change‌ ‌people’s‌ ‌fortune.‌ ‌ ‌\n■A‌ ‌woman‌ ‌may‌ ‌place‌ ‌a‌ ‌rock‌ ‌in‌ ‌her‌ ‌garden‌ ‌and‌ ‌find‌ ‌the‌ ‌yields‌ ‌improved‌ ‌dramatically.‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌explanation‌ ‌is‌ ‌believed‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌mana,‌ ‌the‌ ‌sacred‌ ‌force‌ ‌contained‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌rock.‌ ‌\n■Though‌ ‌both‌ ‌the‌ ‌Melanesians‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌Polynesians‌ ‌believe‌ ‌in‌ ‌Mana,‌ ‌they‌ ‌differ‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌and‌ ‌\noperational‌ ‌elements‌ ‌of‌ ‌mana.‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌Melanesians‌ ‌believe‌ ‌that‌ ‌mana‌ ‌is‌ ‌acquired‌ ‌while‌ ‌the‌ ‌Polynesians‌ ‌believe‌ ‌that‌ ‌mana‌ ‌is‌ ‌inherited.‌ ‌The‌ ‌\nMelanesians‌ ‌believe‌ ‌that‌ ‌mana‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌key‌ ‌to‌ ‌success,‌ ‌while‌ ‌Polynesians‌ ‌believe‌ ‌that‌ ‌though‌ ‌mana‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌key‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌success,‌ ‌it‌ ‌can‌ ‌also‌ ‌be‌ ‌dangerous.‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌belief‌ ‌of‌ ‌Polynesians‌ ‌in‌ ‌mana‌ ‌is‌ ‌comparable‌ ‌to‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌electricity‌ ‌in‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌can‌ ‌flow‌ ‌from‌ ‌one‌ ‌person‌ ‌or‌ ‌\nthing‌ ‌to‌ ‌another.‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌rulers‌ ‌and‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌royal‌ ‌families‌ ‌have‌ ‌greater‌ ‌quantities‌ ‌of‌ ‌mana‌ ‌than‌ ‌ordinary‌ ‌people.‌ ‌\n■Contact‌ ‌with‌ ‌royal‌ ‌family‌ ‌members‌ ‌is‌ ‌dangerous‌ ‌to‌ ‌commoners.‌ ‌\n■They‌ ‌believe‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌mana‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌king‌ ‌flows‌ ‌out‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌person‌ ‌everywhere‌ ‌he‌ ‌walks;‌ ‌it‌ ‌can‌ ‌infect‌ ‌the‌ ‌ground,‌ ‌\nmaking‌ ‌it‌ ‌dangerous‌ ‌for‌ ‌ordinary‌ ‌people‌ ‌to‌ ‌walk‌ ‌in‌ ‌his‌ ‌footsteps.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Mana‌ ‌is‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌notion‌ ‌of‌ ‌taboo.‌ ‌Because‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌mana‌ ‌residing,‌ ‌the‌ ‌contact‌ ‌between‌ ‌royal‌ ‌family‌ ‌and‌ ‌\ncommoners‌ ‌is‌ ‌considered‌ ‌taboo.‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌beliefs‌ ‌in‌ ‌mana‌ ‌exist‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌slightly‌ ‌different‌ ‌form‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌tribes‌ ‌of‌ ‌North‌ ‌America,‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌and‌ ‌in‌ ‌other‌ ‌\nparts‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌world.‌ ‌\n○Hence‌ ‌what‌ ‌he‌ ‌offers‌ ‌us‌ ‌is‌ ‌neither‌ ‌naturalistic‌ ‌nor‌ ‌metaphysical‌ ‌explanation‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌origin‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion.‌ ‌ ‌\n○He‌ ‌tries‌ ‌not‌ ‌so‌ ‌much‌ ‌to‌ ‌explain‌ ‌but‌ ‌to‌ ‌describe.‌ ‌ ‌\n○He‌ ‌concentrated‌ ‌his‌ ‌attention‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌psychological‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌or‌ ‌rudimentary‌ ‌religion.‌ ‌His‌ ‌aim‌ ‌is‌ ‌to‌ ‌translate‌ ‌a‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nreligious‌ ‌experience‌ ‌remote‌ ‌from‌ ‌our‌ ‌own‌ ‌into‌ ‌such‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌our‌ ‌consciousness.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌idea‌ ‌of‌ ‌Mana‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌central‌ ‌theme‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌description.‌ ‌\n○To‌ ‌explain‌ ‌the‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌word‌ ‌Maret‌ ‌obtains‌ ‌the‌ ‌help‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌English‌ ‌Missionary,‌ ‌Bishop‌ ‌R.H.‌ ‌Codrington‌ ‌and‌ ‌he‌ ‌\ndescribes‌ ‌Mana‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌force‌ ‌altogether‌ ‌distinct‌ ‌from‌ ‌physical‌ ‌power,‌ ‌which‌ ‌acts‌ ‌in‌ ‌all‌ ‌kinds‌ ‌of‌ ‌ways‌ ‌for‌ ‌good‌ ‌and‌ ‌evil.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌kind‌ ‌of‌ ‌occult‌ ‌power.‌ ‌This‌ ‌occult‌ ‌force‌ ‌is‌ ‌supposed‌ ‌to‌ ‌attach‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌wide‌ ‌range‌ ‌of‌ ‌natural‌ ‌objects‌ ‌and‌ ‌persons.‌ ‌ ‌\n○To‌ ‌this‌ ‌force‌ ‌is‌ ‌attributed‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌success‌ ‌in‌ ‌war,‌ ‌prosperity‌ ‌in‌ ‌agriculture,‌ ‌powers‌ ‌in‌ ‌hunting‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌ ‌\n565‌ ‌\n○Mana‌ ‌negatively‌ ‌seen‌ ‌is‌ ‌taboo.‌ ‌That‌ ‌which‌ ‌possesses‌ ‌mana‌ ‌is‌ ‌taboo.‌ ‌This‌ ‌means‌ ‌mana‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌lightly‌ ‌\napproached‌ ‌or‌ ‌else‌ ‌its‌ ‌power‌ ‌break‌ ‌forth‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌harmful‌ ‌and‌ ‌destructive‌ ‌manner.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Sir‌ ‌James‌ ‌Frazer-‌ ‌‌human‌ ‌thought‌ ‌is‌ ‌best‌ ‌understood‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌progression‌ ‌from‌ ‌magic‌ ‌to‌ ‌religion‌ ‌to‌ ‌science.‌ ‌ ‌\n○By‌ ‌publishing‌ ‌his‌ ‌two‌ ‌volume‌ ‌book‌ ‌titled‌ ‌‌The‌ ‌Golden‌ ‌Bough‌ ‌(1890)‌,‌ ‌he‌ ‌attempts‌ ‌to‌ ‌construct‌ ‌a‌ ‌universal‌ ‌theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌magic,‌ ‌religion‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌science.‌ ‌ ‌\n○According‌ ‌to‌ ‌Frazer,‌ ‌‌magic‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌primordial‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌thought.‌ ‌He‌ ‌further‌ ‌postulates‌ ‌that‌ ‌early‌ ‌man‌ ‌was‌ ‌dominated‌ ‌by‌ ‌magic,‌ ‌\nwhich‌ ‌viewed‌ ‌nature‌ ‌as‌ ‌‘a‌ ‌series‌ ‌of‌ ‌events‌ ‌occurring‌ ‌in‌ ‌an‌ ‌invariable‌ ‌order‌ ‌without‌ ‌the‌ ‌intervention‌ ‌of‌ ‌personal‌ ‌agency‌’.‌ ‌ ‌\n○These‌ ‌magicians,‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌Frazer,‌ ‌believed‌ ‌in‌ ‌nature‌ ‌and‌ ‌developed‌ ‌imaginary‌ ‌laws,‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌of‌ ‌course,‌ ‌not‌ ‌real.‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌Durkheim,‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌advancement‌ ‌consists‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌emergence‌ ‌of‌ ‌specific,‌ ‌analytic,‌ ‌profane‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌about‌ ‌the‌ ‌‘cause’‌ ‌or‌ ‌‘category’‌ ‌or‌ ‌\n‘relationship’‌ ‌from‌ ‌diffuse,‌ ‌global,‌ ‌sacred‌ ‌images.‌ ‌ ‌\n○These‌ ‌‘collective‌ ‌representations,’‌ ‌as‌ ‌he‌ ‌calls‌ ‌them,‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌order‌ ‌and‌ ‌its‌ ‌moral‌ ‌force‌ ‌included‌ ‌such‌ ‌sacra‌ ‌as‌ ‌‘mana’,‌ ‌‘totem’‌ ‌and‌ ‌\n‘god’.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Emile‌ ‌Durkheim‌ ‌thinks‌ ‌that‌ ‌emotions‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌and‌ ‌collective‌ ‌consciousness‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌social‌ ‌environment‌ ‌shape‌ ‌the‌ ‌individuals’‌ ‌\nreligious‌ ‌feelings.‌ ‌\n ‌\nCounter‌ ‌View:‌ ‌\n●Anthropologists‌ ‌like‌ ‌‌Franz‌ ‌Boas,‌ ‌Ruth‌ ‌Benedict,‌ ‌Margaret‌ ‌Mead‌ ‌‌and‌ ‌Alfred‌ ‌Kroeber‌ ‌discredit‌ ‌the‌ ‌speculative‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌perspective‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌seek‌ ‌explanations‌ ‌for‌ ‌similarities‌ ‌of‌ ‌rituals,‌ ‌myths‌ ‌and‌ ‌symbols‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌through‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌contact.‌ ‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌them‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌dispersion,‌ ‌instead‌ ‌of‌ ‌independent‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌religious‌ ‌thoughts‌ ‌and‌ ‌actions,‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌reason‌ ‌for‌ ‌such‌ ‌similarities.‌ ‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌emphasise‌ ‌the‌ ‌need‌ ‌for‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌culture‌ ‌as‌ ‌an‌ ‌integrated‌ ‌whole‌ ‌and‌ ‌interpreting‌ ‌the‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌elements‌ ‌in‌ ‌that‌ ‌pattern,‌ ‌including‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌religious‌ ‌activities,‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌meaningful‌ ‌way.‌ ‌\n ‌\nPsychological‌ ‌Approach‌ ‌\n●After‌ ‌the‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌perspective,‌ ‌psychological‌ ‌approach‌ ‌to‌ ‌religion‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌‌Sigmund‌ ‌Freud’s‌ ‌‌approaches‌ ‌of‌ ‌psychoanalysis‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nneurotic‌ ‌symptoms‌ ‌has‌ ‌become‌ ‌a‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌approach‌ ‌to‌ ‌understand‌ ‌religion‌ ‌in‌ ‌anthropology.‌ ‌\n●Sigmund‌ ‌Freud:‌ ‌‌Few‌ ‌years‌ ‌before‌ ‌World‌ ‌War-I,‌ ‌there‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌rise‌ ‌of‌ ‌systematic‌ ‌psychologism‌ ‌of‌ ‌psychoanalysis‌ ‌of‌ ‌Sigmund‌ ‌Freud.‌ ‌ ‌\n○His‌ ‌thesis‌ ‌is‌ ‌that‌ ‌religious‌ ‌rituals‌ ‌and‌ ‌beliefs‌ ‌are‌ ‌homologous‌ ‌with‌ ‌neurotic‌ ‌symptoms.‌ ‌\n○Freud's‌ ‌psychoanalytic‌ ‌perspective‌ ‌viewed‌ ‌religion‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌unconscious‌ ‌mind's‌ ‌need‌ ‌for‌ ‌wish‌ ‌fulfillment.‌ ‌Because‌ ‌people‌ ‌need‌ ‌to‌ ‌feel‌ ‌\nsecure‌ ‌and‌ ‌absolve‌ ‌themselves‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌own‌ ‌guilt,‌ ‌Freud‌ ‌believed‌ ‌that‌ ‌they‌ ‌choose‌ ‌to‌ ‌believe‌ ‌in‌ ‌God,‌ ‌who‌ ‌represents‌ ‌a‌ ‌powerful‌ ‌\nfather-figure.‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌some‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌best-known‌ ‌writings,‌ ‌he‌ ‌suggested‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌an‌ ‌\"illusion,\"‌ ‌a‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌neurosis,‌ ‌and‌ ‌even‌ ‌an‌ ‌attempt‌ ‌to‌ ‌gain‌ ‌control‌ ‌\nover‌ ‌the‌ ‌external‌ ‌world.‌ ‌\n○Among‌ ‌some‌ ‌of‌ ‌Freud's‌ ‌most‌ ‌famous‌ ‌quotes‌ ‌on‌ ‌religion,‌ ‌in‌ ‌his‌ ‌book‌ ‌\"New‌ ‌Introductory‌ ‌Lectures‌ ‌on‌ ‌Psychoanalysis\"‌ ‌(1933),‌ ‌he‌ ‌\nsuggested‌ ‌that‌ ‌\"religion‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌illusion‌ ‌and‌ ‌it‌ ‌derives‌ ‌its‌ ‌strength‌ ‌from‌ ‌its‌ ‌readiness‌ ‌to‌ ‌fit‌ ‌in‌ ‌with‌ ‌our‌ ‌instinctual‌ ‌wishful‌ ‌impulses.\"‌ ‌\n566‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Wihhelm‌ ‌Wundt‌ ‌‌considered‌ ‌religion‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌projection‌ ‌of‌ ‌fear‌ ‌into‌ ‌the‌ ‌environment.‌ ‌\n●William‌ ‌James‌‌ ‌viewed‌ ‌religion‌ ‌has‌ ‌a‌ ‌strong‌ ‌emotional‌ ‌base‌ ‌not‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌any‌ ‌particular‌ ‌emotion.‌ ‌\n ‌\nFunctionalist‌ ‌Approach‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌explains‌ ‌the‌ ‌functional‌ ‌significance‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌role‌ ‌it‌ ‌plays‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌life‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌and‌ ‌Society.‌ ‌\n●Functionalism‌ ‌‌emphasises‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌interrelations‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌various‌ ‌elements‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌social‌ ‌system,‌ ‌and,‌ ‌therefore,‌ ‌pays‌ ‌less‌ ‌attention‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nevolutionary‌ ‌origins‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌notion‌ ‌of‌ ‌“survivals”‌‌ ‌–‌ ‌the‌ ‌continuation‌ ‌of‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌elements‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\n●Numerous‌ ‌functional‌ ‌aspects‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion‌ ‌include‌ ‌providing‌ ‌explanation‌ ‌or‌ ‌comfort;‌ ‌sanctions‌ ‌on‌ ‌social,‌ ‌economic‌ ‌and‌ ‌political‌ ‌norms‌ ‌and‌ ‌\ninstitutions;‌ ‌and‌ ‌aiding‌ ‌ecological‌ ‌adaptation‌ ‌and‌ ‌unifying‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌group.‌ ‌\n●Functionalists‌ ‌believe‌ ‌that‌ ‌part‌ ‌function‌ ‌therefore‌ ‌society‌ ‌continues.‌ ‌Religion‌ ‌is‌ ‌one‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n●Anthropologists‌ ‌like‌ ‌‌Malinowski,‌ ‌Evans-Pritchard,‌ ‌Radcliffe-Brown‌,‌ ‌etc.,‌ ‌who‌ ‌approached‌ ‌religion‌ ‌from‌ ‌‌functionalist‌ ‌perspective‌ ‌provide‌ ‌\nexplanation‌ ‌that‌ ‌satisfies‌ ‌human‌ ‌needs‌ ‌and‌ ‌solidarity‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌group‌ ‌\n●Malinowski‌,‌ ‌Considered‌ ‌religion‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌device‌ ‌to‌ ‌secure‌ ‌mental‌ ‌and‌ ‌psychological‌ ‌stability‌ ‌in‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌life.‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌his‌ ‌work‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Trobriand‌ ‌Islanders‌‌ ‌emphasises‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌close‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌between‌ ‌myth‌ ‌and‌ ‌ritual.‌ ‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌mortuary‌ ‌ritual,‌ ‌for‌ ‌instance,‌ ‌is‌ ‌intended‌ ‌to‌ ‌release‌ ‌the‌ ‌soul‌ ‌and‌ ‌prevent‌ ‌it‌ ‌from‌ ‌returning‌ ‌to‌ ‌haunt‌ ‌the‌ ‌living.‌ ‌Like‌ ‌Frazer,‌ ‌he‌ ‌\ndistinguishes‌ ‌magic‌ ‌from‌ ‌religion‌ ‌which‌ ‌aims‌ ‌at‌ ‌something‌ ‌beyond‌ ‌itself.‌ ‌\n○Criticism:‌ ‌‌Evans-Pritchard‌ ‌observes‌ ‌that‌ ‌while‌ ‌emotions,‌ ‌desires,‌ ‌and‌ ‌impulses‌ ‌undoubtedly‌ ‌play‌ ‌a‌ ‌part‌ ‌in‌ ‌religion,‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nperformance‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌religious‌ ‌or‌ ‌magical‌ ‌act‌ ‌need‌ ‌not‌ ‌automatically‌ ‌produce‌ ‌the‌ ‌psychological‌ ‌effects,‌ ‌as‌ ‌Malinowski‌ ‌supposes.‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌‌Emile‌ ‌Durkheim‌,‌ ‌religion‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌media‌ ‌through‌ ‌which‌ ‌a‌ ‌society‌ ‌understands‌ ‌the‌ ‌universe‌ ‌and‌ ‌also‌ ‌seeks‌ ‌justification‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌existing‌ ‌social‌ ‌order‌ ‌through‌ ‌religion.‌ ‌\n●Radcliffe-Brown‌ ‌‌provides‌ ‌an‌ ‌account‌ ‌of‌ ‌Andamanese‌ ‌religious‌ ‌beliefs‌ ‌and‌ ‌ceremonies.‌ ‌ ‌\n○He‌ ‌asserts‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Andaman‌ ‌Islanders‌’‌ ‌main‌ ‌supernatural‌ ‌beings‌ ‌are‌ ‌spirits‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌dead,‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌sky,‌ ‌forest,‌ ‌and‌ ‌sea,‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌nature‌ ‌spirits,‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌thought‌ ‌of‌ ‌as‌ ‌personifications‌ ‌of‌ ‌natural‌ ‌phenomena.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Applying‌ ‌Durkheimian‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌he‌ ‌presents‌ ‌an‌ ‌organic‌ ‌picture‌ ‌of‌ ‌society;‌ ‌religion‌ ‌integrates‌ ‌society‌ ‌and‌ ‌rituals‌ ‌bring‌ ‌in‌ ‌solidarity‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌group.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌India‌ ‌‌M.N.‌ ‌Srinivas'‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌society‌ ‌and‌ ‌religion‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌Coorgs‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌outstanding‌ ‌contribution‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nfunctionalist‌ ‌perspective.‌ ‌ ‌\n○He‌ ‌very‌ ‌innovatively‌ ‌integrates‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌with‌ ‌religion‌ ‌which‌ ‌he‌ ‌finds‌ ‌it‌ ‌operating‌ ‌at‌ ‌different‌ ‌levels‌ ‌–‌ ‌local,‌ ‌regional,‌ ‌peninsular‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌all‌ ‌India.‌ ‌\n○Drawing‌ ‌the‌ ‌difference‌ ‌between‌ ‌Indological‌ ‌and‌ ‌sociological‌ ‌approach,‌ ‌he‌ ‌adopts‌ ‌the‌ ‌latter‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌meaningful‌ ‌treatment‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nrelation‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Coorg.‌ ‌ ‌\n○He‌ ‌demonstrates‌ ‌that‌ ‌various‌ ‌rituals‌ ‌organised‌ ‌at‌ ‌family,‌ ‌patrilineal‌ ‌joint‌ ‌family‌ ‌(okka),‌ ‌village‌ ‌and‌ ‌level‌ ‌bring‌ ‌in‌ ‌solidarity‌ ‌and‌ ‌unity‌ ‌\namong‌ ‌different‌ ‌social‌ ‌segments.‌ ‌\n ‌\nStructuralist‌ ‌Approach‌ ‌\n567‌ ‌\n●Rejecting‌ ‌functionalist,‌ ‌sociological‌ ‌and‌ ‌psychological‌ ‌approaches‌ ‌as‌ ‌being‌ ‌too‌ ‌light‌ ‌in‌ ‌interpreting‌ ‌mythology,‌ ‌‌Levi-Strauss’‌ ‌‌new‌ ‌\n“structuralism”‌ ‌posited‌ ‌a‌ ‌universal‌ ‌logical‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌human‌ ‌mind‌ ‌and‌ ‌in‌ ‌this‌ ‌perspective‌ ‌religion‌ ‌is‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌totally‌ ‌different‌ ‌phenomenon‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nnature‌ ‌\n○He‌ ‌points‌ ‌out‌ ‌that‌ ‌although‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌have‌ ‌tried‌ ‌studying‌ ‌mythology‌ ‌it‌ ‌has‌ ‌not‌ ‌been‌ ‌successful‌ ‌as‌ ‌myths‌ ‌are‌ ‌still‌ ‌widely‌ ‌\ninterpreted‌ ‌in‌ ‌conflicting‌ ‌ways:‌ ‌as‌ ‌collective‌ ‌dreams,‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌outcome‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌kind‌ ‌of‌ ‌esthetical‌ ‌play,‌ ‌or‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌ritual.‌ ‌ ‌\n○He‌ ‌explains‌ ‌that‌ ‌myth‌ ‌is‌ ‌language:‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌known,‌ ‌and‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌told;‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌speech‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌structural‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌of‌ ‌myth,‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌pioneering‌ ‌work‌ ‌of‌ ‌Levi-Strauss‌ ‌in‌ ‌anthropology,‌ ‌has‌ ‌influenced‌ ‌many‌ ‌scholars‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌21st‌ ‌\ncentury.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Levi-Strauss‌ ‌contends‌ ‌that‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌religious‌ ‌systems‌ ‌are‌ ‌like‌ ‌all‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌systems,‌ ‌fundamentally‌ ‌communication‌ ‌systems.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌Indian‌‌ ‌context‌ ‌Dumont‌ ‌‌(1959)‌ ‌takes‌ ‌the‌ ‌structuralist‌ ‌perspective‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion‌ ‌manifested‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌worship‌ ‌of‌ ‌village‌ ‌deities.‌ ‌ ‌\n○He‌ ‌finds‌ ‌the‌ ‌opposition‌ ‌between‌ ‌‘purity’‌ ‌and‌ ‌‘impurity’‌ ‌and‌ ‌interdependency‌ ‌of‌ ‌both‌ ‌the‌ ‌values‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌religious‌ ‌thoughts.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌‘purity’‌ ‌is‌ ‌strongly‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌vegetarian‌ ‌food‌ ‌offered‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌sanskritic‌ ‌gods‌ ‌and‌ ‌‘impurity’‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌non-sanskritic‌ ‌\ngods‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌spiritual‌ ‌beings‌ ‌that‌ ‌receive‌ ‌the‌ ‌offering‌ ‌of‌ ‌non-vegetarian‌ ‌foods.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌purity‌ ‌is‌ ‌superior‌ ‌to‌ ‌impurity,‌ ‌and‌ ‌these‌ ‌values‌ ‌have‌ ‌transcended‌ ‌to‌ ‌form‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌caste‌ ‌system.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nMarxist‌ ‌Approach‌ ‌\n●Karl‌ ‌Marx‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌an‌ ‌influential‌ ‌theorist‌ ‌who‌ ‌was‌ ‌very‌ ‌critical‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion,‌ ‌and‌ ‌his‌ ‌approach‌ ‌depicts‌ ‌religion‌ ‌and‌ ‌religious‌ ‌belief‌ ‌as‌ ‌fictions‌ ‌\nthat‌ ‌support‌ ‌the‌ ‌status‌ ‌quo‌ ‌and‌ ‌that‌ ‌maintain‌ ‌class‌ ‌differences.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Religion‌ ‌reflects‌ ‌false‌ ‌consciousness‌ ‌of‌ ‌people‌ ‌that‌ ‌diverts‌ ‌their‌ ‌attention‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌miseries‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌lives.‌ ‌\n●Maurice‌ ‌Godelier‌ ‌‌finds‌ ‌Marx’s‌ ‌view‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion‌ ‌as‌ ‌reflection‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌real‌ ‌world‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌human‌ ‌mind;‌ ‌nature‌ ‌is‌ ‌personified‌ ‌unconsciously‌ ‌as‌ ‌\nobjective‌ ‌realities,‌ ‌and‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌both‌ ‌transcendent‌ ‌and‌ ‌independent‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌human‌ ‌mind.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌dealing‌ ‌with‌ ‌nature,‌ ‌he‌ ‌says,‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌internal‌ ‌structure‌ ‌of‌ ‌relations‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌humans‌ ‌alienate‌ ‌themselves.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Example:‌  ‌while‌ ‌analysing‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Mbuti‌ ‌Pygmy’s‌ ‌relation‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌forest‌ ‌as‌ ‌hunters.‌ ‌The‌ ‌forest‌ ‌provides‌ ‌animal‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌plant‌ ‌food,‌ ‌\nbut‌ ‌the‌ ‌Mbuti‌ ‌imagine‌ ‌the‌ ‌forest‌ ‌as‌ ‌kinsman‌ ‌and‌ ‌offer‌ ‌prayer‌ ‌of‌ ‌thanks,‌ ‌as‌ ‌forest‌ ‌is‌ ‌considered‌ ‌as‌ ‌omnipotent,‌ ‌omnipresent‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nomniscient‌ ‌divinity‌ ‌as‌ ‌it‌ ‌yields‌ ‌food‌ ‌that‌ ‌sustains‌ ‌them.‌ ‌ ‌\n○When‌ ‌a‌ ‌Mbuti‌ ‌dies,‌ ‌his‌ ‌or‌ ‌her‌ ‌breath‌ ‌leaves‌ ‌and‌ ‌mixes‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌wind,‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌breath‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌forest.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Various‌ ‌rituals‌ ‌that‌ ‌they‌ ‌organise‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌belief‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌show‌ ‌social‌ ‌and‌ ‌organic‌ ‌unity‌ ‌with‌ ‌nature.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Thus,‌ ‌he‌ ‌argues‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌religion‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Mbuti‌ ‌represents‌ ‌both‌ ‌a‌ ‌real‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌action‌ ‌upon‌ ‌the‌ ‌real‌ ‌and‌ ‌imaginary‌ ‌conditions.‌ ‌\n ‌\nSymbolic‌ ‌Approach‌ ‌\n●Evans-Pritchard‌ ‌first‌ ‌recognised‌ ‌the‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌aspect‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion,‌ ‌and‌ ‌this‌ ‌has‌ ‌inspired‌ ‌several‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌to‌ ‌approach‌ ‌religion‌ ‌through‌ ‌\nsymbols,‌ ‌the‌ ‌meanings‌ ‌given‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌participants‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌elements‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion‌ ‌and‌ ‌rituals,‌ ‌and‌ ‌interpretations‌ ‌that‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌can‌ ‌offer.‌ ‌ ‌\n568‌ ‌\n●Victor‌ ‌Turner,‌ ‌Mary‌ ‌Douglas‌ ‌and‌ ‌Clifford‌ ‌Geertz‌ ‌‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌important‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌that‌ ‌have‌ ‌contributed‌ ‌to‌ ‌our‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion‌ ‌\nfrom‌ ‌a‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌perspective.‌ ‌\n●Victor‌ ‌Turner’s‌ ‌work‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Ndembu‌ ‌rituals‌ ‌‌provides‌ ‌a‌ ‌highly‌ ‌detailed‌ ‌and‌ ‌enormous‌ ‌work‌ ‌on‌ ‌Ndembu‌ ‌religious‌ ‌life‌ ‌which‌ ‌consists‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nrituals‌ ‌falling‌ ‌under‌ ‌these‌ ‌two‌ ‌categories‌ ‌–‌ ‌Life‌ ‌cycle‌ ‌crisis‌ ‌ritual‌ ‌and‌ ‌ritual‌ ‌of‌ ‌affliction.‌ ‌ ‌\n○His‌ ‌work‌ ‌shows‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Ndembu‌ ‌society‌ ‌is‌ ‌greatly‌ ‌marked‌ ‌by‌ ‌different‌ ‌ceremonies‌ ‌replete‌ ‌with‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌meanings‌ ‌in‌ ‌every‌ ‌act‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nperformance.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Along‌ ‌with‌ ‌that‌ ‌his‌ ‌powerful‌ ‌analytic‌ ‌concepts‌ ‌of‌ ‌‘structure’‌ ‌and‌ ‌‘anti-structure’‌ ‌in‌ ‌analysing‌ ‌the‌ ‌Ndembu‌ ‌society‌ ‌brought‌ ‌about‌ ‌a‌ ‌new‌ ‌\ndimension‌ ‌in‌ ‌looking‌ ‌at‌ ‌rituals‌ ‌and‌ ‌its‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌relevance‌ ‌in‌ ‌ritual‌ ‌context.‌ ‌\n ‌\nConclusion:‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌functional‌ ‌and‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌approaches‌ ‌have‌ ‌dominated‌ ‌the‌ ‌anthropological‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌late‌ ‌twentieth‌ ‌century‌ ‌as‌ ‌researchers‌ ‌\nhave‌ ‌become‌ ‌increasingly‌ ‌concerned‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌meaning.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Biological,‌ ‌neurological‌ ‌and‌ ‌cognitive‌ ‌approaches,‌ ‌are‌ ‌gradually‌ ‌gaining‌ ‌popularity‌ ‌and‌ ‌may‌ ‌dominate‌ ‌the‌ ‌future‌ ‌studies‌ ‌in‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nreligion.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nMonotheism‌ ‌and‌ ‌polytheism;‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nMonotheism:‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌worship‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌single,‌ ‌supreme‌ ‌deity.‌ ‌\n●Today,‌ ‌about‌ ‌half‌ ‌the‌ ‌world’s‌ ‌population‌ ‌practices‌ ‌one‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌monotheism‌ ‌or‌ ‌another.‌ ‌Yet‌ ‌for‌ ‌much‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌history,‌ ‌monotheism‌ ‌was‌ ‌far‌ ‌\nfrom‌ ‌popular.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Most‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌world’s‌ ‌religions‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌polytheistic,‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌that‌ ‌they‌ ‌worship‌ ‌a‌ ‌collection‌ ‌of‌ ‌gods,‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌pantheon.‌ ‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌gods‌ ‌came‌ ‌in‌ ‌all‌ ‌shapes‌ ‌and‌ ‌sizes,‌ ‌from‌ ‌animistic‌ ‌spirits‌ ‌of‌ ‌natural‌ ‌forces,‌ ‌like‌ ‌animals,‌ ‌trees,‌ ‌rivers,‌ ‌etc.,‌ ‌to‌ ‌anthropomorphic‌ ‌gods,‌ ‌\nwhich‌ ‌take‌ ‌the‌ ‌shape‌ ‌and‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌humans,‌ ‌to‌ ‌anything‌ ‌in‌ ‌between.‌ ‌\n ‌\nTypes‌ ‌of‌ ‌Monotheism:‌ ‌\n●Exclusive‌ ‌Monotheism:‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌belief‌ ‌that‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌only‌ ‌one‌ ‌deity‌ ‌and‌ ‌all‌ ‌other‌ ‌claimed‌ ‌deities‌ ‌are‌ ‌distinct‌ ‌from‌ ‌it‌ ‌and‌ ‌false.‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌position‌ ‌is‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌main‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌‌Judaism,‌ ‌Christianity,‌ ‌and‌ ‌Islam‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○There‌ ‌are‌ ‌two‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌exclusive‌ ‌monotheism:‌ ‌ethical‌ ‌monotheism‌ ‌and‌ ‌intellectual‌ ‌monotheism.‌ ‌ ‌\n■In‌ ‌‌ethical‌ ‌monotheism‌,‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌choose‌ ‌one‌ ‌god,‌ ‌because‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌god‌ ‌whom‌ ‌they‌ ‌need‌ ‌and‌ ‌whom‌ ‌they‌ ‌can‌ ‌adore,‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌that‌ ‌god‌ ‌becomes‌ ‌for‌ ‌them‌ ‌the‌ ‌one‌ ‌and‌ ‌only‌ ‌god.‌ ‌\n■In‌ ‌‌intellectual‌ ‌monotheism‌,‌ ‌the‌ ‌one‌ ‌god‌ ‌is‌ ‌nothing‌ ‌but‌ ‌the‌ ‌logical‌ ‌result‌ ‌of‌ ‌questions‌ ‌concerning‌ ‌the‌ ‌origin‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌world.‌ ‌ ‌\n569‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌many‌ ‌‌African‌ ‌religions‌ ‌the‌ ‌one‌ ‌god‌ ‌postulated‌ ‌behind‌ ‌the‌ ‌many‌ ‌gods‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌active‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌world‌ ‌and‌ ‌in‌ ‌human‌ ‌life‌ ‌is‌ ‌little‌ ‌more‌ ‌\nthan‌ ‌the‌ ‌prime‌ ‌mover‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌universe‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○That‌ ‌god‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌intellectual‌ ‌apex‌ ‌necessitated‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌system.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌Christian‌ ‌theology,‌ ‌‌heavily‌ ‌influenced‌ ‌as‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌by‌ ‌Greek‌ ‌philosophy,‌ ‌both‌ ‌conceptions‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌found,‌ ‌usually‌ ‌together.‌ ‌\n● ‌Inclusive‌ ‌monotheism:‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌belief‌ ‌that‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌only‌ ‌one‌ ‌deity‌ ‌and‌ ‌all‌ ‌other‌ ‌claims‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌are‌ ‌just‌ ‌different‌ ‌names‌ ‌of‌ ‌it.‌ ‌\n○Such‌ ‌conceptions‌ ‌characterized‌ ‌the‌ ‌ancient‌ ‌‌Hellenistic‌ ‌religions‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌well-known‌ ‌example‌ ‌is‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌goddess‌ ‌Isis‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Greco-Roman‌ ‌mystery‌ ‌religion‌‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌named‌ ‌after‌ ‌her.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Inclusive‌ ‌monotheism‌ ‌fits‌ ‌very‌ ‌well‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌notions‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion,‌ ‌particularly‌ ‌in‌ ‌Hinduism‌ ‌\n●Substance‌ ‌monotheism:‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌belief‌ ‌that‌ ‌many‌ ‌gods‌ ‌are‌ ‌just‌ ‌different‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌single‌ ‌underlying‌ ‌substance.‌ ‌such‌ ‌a‌ ‌belief‌ ‌exists‌ ‌in‌ ‌some‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌indigenous‌ ‌\nAfrican‌ ‌religions.‌ ‌\n●Henotheism‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌‌devotion‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌single‌ ‌God‌ ‌while‌ ‌accepting‌ ‌the‌ ‌existence‌ ‌of‌ ‌other‌ ‌gods‌ ‌without‌ ‌denying‌ ‌that‌ ‌other‌ ‌can‌ ‌with‌ ‌equal‌ ‌trust‌ ‌can‌ ‌worship‌ ‌\ndifferent‌ ‌gods.‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌called‌ ‌monotheism‌ ‌in‌ ‌principle‌ ‌and‌ ‌polytheism‌ ‌in‌ ‌fact.‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌was‌ ‌especially‌ ‌prevalent‌ ‌in‌ ‌some‌ ‌periods‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌history‌ ‌of‌ ‌Babylonia‌ ‌and‌ ‌Egypt.‌ ‌\n●Misotheism:‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌belief‌ ‌that‌ ‌a‌ ‌God‌ ‌exist‌ ‌but‌ ‌is‌ ‌actually‌ ‌Evil.‌ ‌\n○ ‌It‌ ‌connotes‌ ‌an‌ ‌attitude‌ ‌of‌ ‌hatred‌ ‌towards‌ ‌God.‌ ‌\n● ‌‌Dystheism:‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌belief‌ ‌that‌ ‌God‌ ‌exist,‌ ‌but‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌wholly‌ ‌good(evil)‌ ‌\n●Ethical‌ ‌monotheism:‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌belief‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌people‌ ‌chose‌ ‌one‌ ‌God,‌ ‌who‌ ‌they‌ ‌think‌ ‌as‌ ‌superior‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌God.‌ ‌\n●Pluriformity:‌ ‌\n○One‌ ‌god‌ ‌in‌ ‌many‌ ‌forms.‌ ‌\n ‌\nPolytheism‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌belief‌ ‌in‌ ‌many‌ ‌gods.‌ ‌Polytheism‌ ‌characterizes‌ ‌virtually‌ ‌all‌ ‌religions‌ ‌other‌ ‌than‌ ‌Judaism,‌ ‌Christianity,‌ ‌and‌ ‌Islam,‌ ‌which‌ ‌share‌ ‌a‌ ‌\ncommon‌ ‌tradition‌ ‌of‌ ‌monotheism,‌ ‌the‌ ‌belief‌ ‌in‌ ‌one‌ ‌God.‌ ‌\n●Polytheism‌ ‌can‌ ‌bear‌ ‌various‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌to‌ ‌other‌ ‌beliefs.‌ ‌It‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌incompatible‌ ‌with‌ ‌some‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌theism,‌ ‌as‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Semitic‌ ‌religions;‌ ‌it‌ ‌\ncan‌ ‌coexist‌ ‌with‌ ‌theism,‌ ‌as‌ ‌in‌ ‌Vaishnavism;‌ ‌it‌ ‌can‌ ‌exist‌ ‌at‌ ‌a‌ ‌lower‌ ‌level‌ ‌of‌ ‌understanding,‌ ‌ultimately‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌transcended,‌ ‌as‌ ‌in‌ ‌Mahayana‌ ‌\nBuddhism;‌ ‌and‌ ‌it‌ ‌can‌ ‌exist‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌tolerated‌ ‌adjunct‌ ‌to‌ ‌belief‌ ‌in‌ ‌transcendental‌ ‌liberation,‌ ‌as‌ ‌in‌ ‌Theravada‌ ‌Buddhism.‌ ‌\nTypes‌ ‌of‌‌ ‌‌Polytheism:‌ ‌\n●Monolatry:‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌belief‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌existence‌ ‌of‌ ‌many‌ ‌gods.‌ ‌\n570‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌‌Egyptian‌ ‌pantheon‌ ‌evolved‌ ‌into‌ ‌a‌ ‌complex‌ ‌form;‌ ‌many‌ ‌deities‌ ‌were‌ ‌theriomorphic‌ ‌but‌ ‌were‌ ‌presided‌ ‌over‌ ‌by‌ ‌such‌ ‌great‌ ‌gods‌ ‌as‌ ‌\nRe,‌ ‌the‌ ‌sun‌ ‌god,‌ ‌and‌ ‌Nut,‌ ‌the‌ ‌sky‌ ‌goddess.‌ ‌Re’s‌ ‌transformation‌ ‌as‌ ‌Horus,‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌hawk’s‌ ‌head,‌ ‌was‌ ‌connected‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌Osiris‌ ‌legend.‌ ‌\nThe‌ ‌pharaoh‌ ‌was‌ ‌identified‌ ‌with‌ ‌him‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌“living‌ ‌Horus.”‌ ‌ ‌\n●Kathenotheism:‌ ‌\n○T‌he‌ ‌belief‌ ‌that‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌many‌ ‌Gods‌ ‌and‌ ‌only‌ ‌one‌ ‌deity‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌time‌ ‌should‌ ‌be‌ ‌worshipped.‌ ‌\n●Monism:‌ ‌\n○There‌ ‌is‌ ‌one‌ ‌Reality‌ ‌That‌ ‌rules‌ ‌the‌ ‌world,‌ ‌like‌ ‌energy,‌ ‌matter,‌ ‌wind‌ ‌etc‌ ‌\n●Pantheism:‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌belief‌ ‌that‌ ‌everything‌ ‌is‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌all-encompassing‌ ‌immanent‌ ‌abstract‌ ‌God.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌Addition:‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nPluriform‌ ‌monotheism‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌complicated‌ ‌relations‌ ‌that‌ ‌exist‌ ‌between‌ ‌monotheism‌ ‌and‌ ‌polytheism‌ ‌‌become‌ ‌clear‌ ‌when‌ ‌one‌ ‌considers‌ ‌pluriform‌ ‌monotheism,‌ ‌\nin‌ ‌which‌ ‌the‌ ‌various‌ ‌gods‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌pantheon,‌ ‌without‌ ‌losing‌ ‌their‌ ‌independence,‌ ‌are‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌time‌ ‌considered‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌manifestations‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌one‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌divine‌ ‌substance.‌ ‌ ‌\n571‌ ‌\n●Pluriform‌ ‌monotheism‌ ‌is‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌efforts‌ ‌to‌ ‌solve‌ ‌the‌ ‌problem‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌coexistence‌ ‌of‌ ‌divine‌ ‌unity‌ ‌and‌ ‌divine‌ ‌pluriformity‌ ‌(multiplicity‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nforms),‌ ‌which‌ ‌was‌ ‌not‌ ‌recognized‌ ‌by‌ ‌an‌ ‌older‌ ‌generation‌ ‌of‌ ‌scholars,‌ ‌although‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌material‌ ‌was‌ ‌already‌ ‌available.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌seems,‌ ‌indeed,‌ ‌that‌ ‌in‌ ‌many‌ ‌parts‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌world‌ ‌and‌ ‌in‌ ‌many‌ ‌times‌ ‌religious‌ ‌thinkers‌ ‌have‌ ‌struggled‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌perplexing‌ ‌problem‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌unity‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌pluriformity‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌divine.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌‌Nuer,‌ ‌a‌ ‌Nilotic‌ ‌pastoral‌ ‌people‌ ‌of‌ ‌eastern‌ ‌South‌ ‌Sudan‌,‌ ‌venerate‌ ‌a‌ ‌being‌ ‌called‌ ‌Kwoth,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Nuer‌ ‌term‌ ‌for‌ ‌“spirit”‌ ‌(also‌ ‌\ntranslated‌ ‌as‌ ‌“God”).‌ ‌ ‌\n○He‌ ‌is‌ ‌considered‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌the‌ ‌spirit‌ ‌in‌ ‌or‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌sky.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Like‌ ‌all‌ ‌spirits,‌ ‌Kwoth‌ ‌is‌ ‌invisible‌ ‌and‌ ‌omnipresent,‌ ‌but‌ ‌he‌ ‌manifests‌ ‌himself‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌forms.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Each‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌manifestations‌ ‌bears‌ ‌a‌ ‌name‌ ‌of‌ ‌its‌ ‌own,‌ ‌but‌ ‌though‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌addressed‌ ‌and‌ ‌treated‌ ‌as‌ ‌separate‌ ‌entities,‌ ‌they‌ ‌\nare‌ ‌essentially‌ ‌nothing‌ ‌but‌ ‌manifestations‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌one‌ ‌spiritual‌ ‌being‌ ‌Kwoth‌ ‌and‌ ‌are‌ ‌themselves‌ ‌considered‌ ‌spirits‌ ‌and‌ ‌called‌ ‌\nkwoth.‌ ‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌sacrifice‌ ‌offered‌ ‌to‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌manifestations—e.g.,‌ ‌a‌ ‌spirit‌ ‌of‌ ‌air,‌ ‌totem,‌ ‌or‌ ‌place—is‌ ‌not‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌time‌ ‌an‌ ‌offering‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nanother,‌ ‌but‌ ‌all‌ ‌sacrifices,‌ ‌to‌ ‌whatever‌ ‌spirit‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌offered,‌ ‌are‌ ‌sacrifices‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌supreme‌ ‌Kwoth,‌ ‌or‌ ‌God.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Nuer‌ ‌religion‌ ‌is‌ ‌certainly‌ ‌no‌ ‌clear‌ ‌monotheism‌ ‌as‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌understood‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Bible‌ ‌and‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Qurʾān‌ ‌(the‌ ‌sacred‌ ‌book‌ ‌of‌ ‌Islam),‌ ‌\nbut‌ ‌neither‌ ‌is‌ ‌it‌ ‌polytheism‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌popular‌ ‌sense‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌word.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●The‌ ‌case‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Nuer‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌unique.‌ ‌An‌ ‌interesting‌ ‌pluriform‌ ‌system‌ ‌is‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Oglala‌ ‌Sioux‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌United‌ ‌States,‌ ‌who‌ ‌venerate‌ ‌16‌ ‌\ngods‌ ‌divided‌ ‌into‌ ‌four‌ ‌groups‌ ‌of‌ ‌four.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Each‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌four‌ ‌forms‌ ‌one‌ ‌god.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Thus,‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌four‌ ‌gods,‌ ‌but‌ ‌these‌ ‌four‌ ‌gods‌ ‌again‌ ‌are‌ ‌one‌ ‌god,‌ ‌Wakan‌ ‌Tanka—the‌ ‌Great‌ ‌Spirit‌ ‌or‌ ‌the‌ ‌Great‌ ‌Mystery.‌ ‌\n ‌\nConcept‌ ‌of‌ ‌Sacred‌ ‌and‌ ‌Profane‌ ‌\n●Durkhiem‌ ‌in‌ ‌his‌ ‌famous‌ ‌book‌ ‌‌Elementary‌ ‌Form‌ ‌of‌ ‌Religious‌ ‌Life‌(1912)‌ ‌used‌ ‌two‌ ‌important‌ ‌concepts,‌ ‌viz,‌ ‌‘sacred’‌ ‌and‌ ‌'profane',‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌\nstill‌ ‌used‌ ‌and‌ ‌debated‌ ‌all‌ ‌over‌ ‌the‌ ‌world‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌‘primitive’‌ ‌religion.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Durkheim‌ ‌considered‌ ‌these‌ ‌two‌ ‌concepts‌ ‌as‌ ‌central‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion.‌ ‌\nSacred:‌ ‌ ‌\n○Durkheim‌ ‌says‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌sacred‌ ‌is‌ ‌ideal‌ ‌and‌ ‌transcends‌ ‌everyday‌ ‌existence,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌extraordinary,‌ ‌potentially‌ ‌\ndangerous,awe-inspiring,fear‌ ‌inducing.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌sacred‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌things‌ ‌set‌ ‌part‌ ‌by‌ ‌man‌ ‌including‌ ‌religious‌ ‌beliefs,rites,duties‌ ‌or‌ ‌anything‌ ‌socially‌ ‌defined‌ ‌as‌ ‌requiring‌ ‌special‌ ‌\nreligious‌ ‌treatment.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Almost‌ ‌anything‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌sacred‌ ‌–‌ ‌a‌ ‌god,‌ ‌a‌ ‌rock,across,the‌ ‌moon,the‌ ‌earth‌ ‌,a‌ ‌tree,‌ ‌an‌ ‌animal‌ ‌or‌ ‌bird‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌ ‌\n○These‌ ‌are‌ ‌sacred‌ ‌only‌ ‌because‌ ‌some‌ ‌community‌ ‌has‌ ‌marked‌ ‌them‌ ‌as‌ ‌sacred.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Once‌ ‌established‌ ‌as‌ ‌sacred‌ ‌they‌ ‌become‌ ‌symbols‌ ‌of‌ ‌religious‌ ‌beliefs,‌ ‌sentiments‌ ‌and‌ ‌practices.‌ ‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌example;‌ ‌the‌ ‌‘Shroud‌ ‌of‌ ‌Torin’‌ ‌would‌ ‌be‌ ‌a‌ ‌sacred‌ ‌object,‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌treated‌ ‌with‌ ‌respect‌ ‌and‌ ‌pilgrimages‌ ‌to‌ ‌this‌ ‌object‌ ‌are‌ ‌ways‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nstrengthening‌ ‌religious‌ ‌beliefs.‌ ‌However,‌ ‌it‌ ‌must‌ ‌be‌ ‌noted‌ ‌that‌ ‌these‌ ‌objects‌ ‌may‌ ‌not‌ ‌be‌ ‌intrinsically‌ ‌special‌ ‌but‌ ‌rather‌ ‌special‌ ‌\nmeaning‌ ‌is‌ ‌attached‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌object‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌group.‌ ‌ ‌\n572‌ ‌\nProfane:‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌profane‌ ‌is‌ ‌mundane,‌ ‌anything‌ ‌ordinary.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌profane‌ ‌embraces‌ ‌those‌ ‌ideas,‌ ‌persons,‌ ‌practices‌ ‌and‌ ‌things‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌regarded‌ ‌with‌ ‌an‌ ‌everyday‌ ‌attitude‌ ‌of‌ ‌commonness,‌ ‌utility‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌familiarity.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌unholy‌ ‌or‌ ‌the‌ ‌profane‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌believed‌ ‌to‌ ‌contaminate‌ ‌the‌ ‌holy‌ ‌or‌ ‌sacred.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌denial‌ ‌or‌ ‌subordination‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌holy‌ ‌in‌ ‌some‌ ‌way.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌attitudes‌ ‌and‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌toward‌ ‌it‌ ‌are‌ ‌charged‌ ‌with‌ ‌negative‌ ‌emotions‌ ‌and‌ ‌hedged‌ ‌about‌ ‌by‌ ‌strong‌ ‌taboos.‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌example;‌ ‌our‌ ‌daily‌ ‌routine/‌ ‌grind‌ ‌of‌ ‌getting‌ ‌up‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌morning,‌ ‌doing‌ ‌our‌ ‌ablutions,‌ ‌going‌ ‌to‌ ‌college.‌ ‌\nThe‌ ‌sacred‌ ‌and‌ ‌profane‌ ‌are‌ ‌closely‌ ‌related‌ ‌because‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌highly‌ ‌emotional‌ ‌attitude‌ ‌towards‌ ‌them.‌ ‌According‌ ‌to‌ ‌Durkheim‌ ‌the‌ ‌circle‌ ‌of‌ ‌sacred‌ ‌\nobjects‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌be‌ ‌determined‌ ‌then‌ ‌once‌ ‌and‌ ‌for‌ ‌all.‌ ‌Its‌ ‌extent‌ ‌varies‌ ‌indefinitely‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌different‌ ‌religions.‌ ‌The‌ ‌significance‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌sacred‌ ‌lies‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌fact‌ ‌of‌ ‌its‌ ‌distinction‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌profane.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n573‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌Addition‌ ‌:‌ ‌\n574‌ ‌\n ‌\nDurkheim's‌ ‌Views‌ ‌on‌ ‌Religion:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●French‌ ‌sociologist‌ ‌Émile‌ ‌Durkheim‌ ‌was‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌theorists‌ ‌to‌ ‌study‌ ‌religion‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌social‌ ‌institution.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌his‌ ‌1912‌ ‌book,‌ ‌The‌ ‌Elementary‌ ‌Forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌Religious‌ ‌Life,‌ ‌Durkheim‌ ‌defined‌ ‌religion‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌\"unified‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌beliefs‌ ‌and‌ ‌practices‌ ‌\nrelative‌ ‌to‌ ‌sacred‌ ‌things,‌ ‌i.e.,‌ ‌things‌ ‌set‌ ‌apart‌ ‌and‌ ‌forbidden—beliefs‌ ‌and‌ ‌practices‌ ‌which‌ ‌unite‌ ‌in‌ ‌one‌ ‌single‌ ‌moral‌ ‌community‌ ‌\ncalled‌ ‌a‌ ‌Church,‌ ‌all‌ ‌those‌ ‌who‌ ‌adhere‌ ‌to‌ ‌them.\"‌ ‌ ‌\n●Durkheim‌ ‌considered‌ ‌how‌ ‌religion‌ ‌creates‌ ‌an‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌sacred‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌profane.‌ ‌\n●Durkheim's‌ ‌definition‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌sacred‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌objects,‌ ‌symbols,‌ ‌and‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌‌awe-inspiring,‌ ‌unexplainable,‌ ‌and‌ ‌spiritually‌ ‌\nsignificant.‌ ‌ ‌\n●His‌ ‌definition‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌profane‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌practical‌ ‌objects‌ ‌and‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌of‌ ‌everyday‌ ‌life.‌ ‌\n●Durkheim‌ ‌was‌ ‌not‌ ‌interested‌ ‌in‌ ‌proving‌ ‌or‌ ‌disproving‌ ‌religious‌ ‌beliefs.‌ ‌Rather,‌ ‌he‌ ‌was‌ ‌interested‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌function‌ ‌religion‌ ‌\nserves‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌or‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n575‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Durkheim‌ ‌proposed‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌dichotomy‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌sacred‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌profane‌ ‌(the‌ ‌nonsacred)‌ ‌characterizes‌ ‌religion.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌argued‌ ‌that‌ ‌classifying‌ ‌something‌ ‌as‌ ‌sacred‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌social‌ ‌act.‌ ‌\n●Durkheim's‌ ‌work‌ ‌has‌ ‌a‌ ‌had‌ ‌great‌ ‌deal‌ ‌of‌ ‌influence‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌sociological‌ ‌approach‌ ‌to‌ ‌religion.‌ ‌\n●One‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion‌ ‌that‌ ‌interested‌ ‌Durkheim‌ ‌is‌ ‌totemism,‌ ‌a‌ ‌broad‌ ‌category‌ ‌of‌ ‌religions‌ ‌that‌ ‌includes‌ ‌many‌ ‌practiced‌ ‌by‌ ‌various‌ ‌\nAfrican‌ ‌peoples,‌ ‌Australian‌ ‌Aborigines,‌ ‌and‌ ‌Native‌ ‌Americans.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Totemism‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌belief‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌or‌ ‌mystical‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌between‌ ‌humans‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌totem—a‌ ‌natural‌ ‌object,‌ ‌animal,‌ ‌or‌ ‌plant‌ ‌\nbelieved‌ ‌to‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌significance.‌ ‌\n●Durkheim‌ ‌believed‌ ‌totemism‌ ‌was‌ ‌religion‌ ‌in‌ ‌its‌ ‌most‌ ‌elemental‌ ‌form.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌his‌ ‌view,‌ ‌studying‌ ‌totemism‌ ‌could‌ ‌answer‌ ‌questions‌ ‌about‌ ‌religion's‌ ‌impact‌ ‌on‌ ‌social‌ ‌life,‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure,‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌change.‌ ‌\n●Durkheim‌ ‌argued‌ ‌that‌ ‌totemism‌ ‌serves‌ ‌several‌ ‌functions‌ ‌in‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌contributes‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌collective‌ ‌conscience,‌ ‌a‌ ‌set‌ ‌of‌ ‌generally‌ ‌accepted‌ ‌social‌ ‌rules,‌ ‌norms,‌ ‌values,‌ ‌and‌ ‌\n576‌ ‌\nbeliefs‌ ‌that‌ ‌have‌ ‌become‌ ‌embodied‌ ‌in‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌and‌ ‌form‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌Addition:‌ ‌\nMalinowski’s‌ ‌View‌ ‌of‌ ‌Religion‌ ‌\n●Malinowski‌ ‌has‌ ‌basically‌ ‌shown‌ ‌the‌ ‌functional‌ ‌value‌ ‌of‌ ‌religious‌ ‌ceremonies.‌ ‌In‌ ‌brief,‌ ‌he‌ ‌has‌ ‌surveyed‌ ‌the‌ ‌main‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌religious‌ ‌acts‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nconcludes‌ ‌that‌ ‌main‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌religious‌ ‌acts‌ ‌have‌ ‌the‌ ‌following‌ ‌functions.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌initiation‌ ‌ceremonies‌ ‌give‌ ‌a‌ ‌sacred‌ ‌character‌ ‌to‌ ‌traditional‌ ‌knowledge.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌event‌ ‌of‌ ‌death‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌society‌ ‌sets‌ ‌in‌ ‌motion‌ ‌a‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌of‌ ‌religious‌ ‌acts,‌ ‌which‌ ‌counteract‌ ‌the‌ ‌forces‌ ‌of‌ ‌fear‌ ‌and‌ ‌\ndestruction.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌rites‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌food,‌ ‌sacrifice‌ ‌and‌ ‌totemistic‌ ‌beliefs‌ ‌bring‌ ‌the‌ ‌people‌ ‌in‌ ‌direct‌ ‌contact‌ ‌with‌ ‌powers,‌ ‌which‌ ‌provide‌ ‌\nsustenance.‌ ‌\n●Malinowski‌ ‌has‌ ‌used‌ ‌the‌ ‌method‌ ‌of‌ ‌providing‌ ‌concrete‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌for‌ ‌his‌ ‌views.‌ ‌Taking‌ ‌examples‌ ‌from‌ ‌his‌ ‌collection‌ ‌of‌ ‌data‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nTrobriand‌ ‌islanders,‌ ‌he‌ ‌has‌ ‌formulated‌ ‌the‌ ‌view‌ ‌that‌ ‌all‌ ‌religious‌ ‌ceremonies‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌social‌ ‌side‌ ‌without‌ ‌which‌ ‌they‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌or‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌exist.‌ ‌ ‌\n●So‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌side‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌religious‌ ‌ceremony‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌necessary‌ ‌but‌ ‌not‌ ‌a‌ ‌sufficient‌ ‌condition.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌emphasises‌ ‌that‌ ‌we‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌understand‌ ‌religion‌ ‌without‌ ‌analysing‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual‌ ‌mind.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌is‌ ‌why‌ ‌you‌ ‌would‌ ‌find‌ ‌that‌ ‌he‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual’s‌ ‌state‌ ‌of‌ ‌mind‌ ‌at‌ ‌every‌ ‌stage‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌religious‌ ‌ceremony.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌Addition:‌ ‌\nFood‌ ‌and‌ ‌Religion‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Malinowski‌ ‌points‌ ‌out‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌act‌ ‌of‌ ‌eating‌ ‌involves‌ ‌an‌ ‌emotional‌ ‌tension‌ ‌for‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌people.‌ ‌‌Ceremonies,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌fruit‌ ‌offerings,‌ ‌\nharvest‌ ‌and‌ ‌seasonal‌ ‌festivities‌ ‌play‌ ‌a‌ ‌significant‌ ‌role‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌agricultural‌ ‌cycle‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Celebrating‌ ‌among‌ ‌fishermen‌ ‌a‌ ‌big‌ ‌catch‌ ‌of‌ ‌fish‌ ‌or‌ ‌among‌ ‌hunters‌ ‌an‌ ‌animal‌ ‌hunt‌ ‌occupies‌ ‌a‌ ‌similar‌ ‌place‌ ‌of‌ ‌importance.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌food‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌link‌ ‌between‌ ‌a‌ ‌person‌ ‌and‌ ‌his‌ ‌or‌ ‌her‌ ‌surroundings‌ ‌and‌ ‌in‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌religion,‌ ‌food‌ ‌is‌ ‌sacred‌ ‌besides‌ ‌being‌ ‌culturally‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nbiologically‌ ‌important.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Consideration‌ ‌of‌ ‌food‌ ‌as‌ ‌sacred‌ ‌leads‌ ‌Malinowski‌ ‌to‌ ‌view‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌new‌ ‌light‌ ‌the‌ ‌ceremonies‌ ‌of‌ ‌‌sacrifice‌ ‌(an‌ ‌act‌ ‌of‌ ‌offering‌ ‌something‌ ‌precious‌ ‌\nusually‌ ‌some‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌food‌ ‌to‌ ‌deity)‌ ‌and‌ ‌communion‌ ‌(an‌ ‌act‌ ‌of‌ ‌sharing‌ ‌food).‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌food‌ ‌is‌ ‌ritually‌ ‌administered‌ ‌in‌ ‌these‌ ‌rites‌ ‌and‌ ‌therefore‌ ‌they‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌linked‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌attitude‌ ‌of‌ ‌reverence‌ ‌towards‌ ‌the‌ ‌abundance‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nfood.‌ ‌ ‌\n○He‌ ‌gives‌ ‌the‌ ‌case‌ ‌of‌ ‌sacramental‌ ‌eating,‌ ‌related‌ ‌with‌ ‌totemic‌ ‌beliefs‌ ‌among‌ ‌Central‌ ‌Australian‌ ‌tribes‌ ‌a‌ ‌limited‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌animals‌ ‌\nand/‌ ‌or‌ ‌plants‌ ‌are‌ ‌selected‌ ‌for‌ ‌its‌ ‌totem‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌tribe.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Malinowski‌ ‌explains‌ ‌that‌ ‌for‌ ‌survival‌ ‌the‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌people‌ ‌have‌ ‌an‌ ‌abiding‌ ‌interest‌ ‌in‌ ‌continuity‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌supply‌ ‌of‌ ‌particular‌ ‌species‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nanimals‌ ‌and‌ ‌plants.‌ ‌ ‌\n577‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌order‌ ‌that‌ ‌they‌ ‌get‌ ‌an‌ ‌abundant‌ ‌supply,‌ ‌they‌ ‌want‌ ‌to‌ ‌control‌ ‌these‌ ‌selected‌ ‌species.‌ ‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌study‌ ‌their‌ ‌habits‌ ‌and‌ ‌movements‌ ‌and‌ ‌develop‌ ‌an‌ ‌attitude‌ ‌of‌ ‌reverence‌ ‌for‌ ‌them.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌this‌ ‌way‌ ‌an‌ ‌abiding‌ ‌interest‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌limited‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌animals‌ ‌and‌ ‌plants‌ ‌and‌ ‌its‌ ‌deification‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌totemic‌ ‌rites‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌natural‌ ‌\noutcome‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌very‌ ‌survival‌ ‌of‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌communities.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n5.‌ ‌Myths‌ ‌and‌ ‌rituals;Forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion‌ ‌in‌ ‌tribal‌ ‌and‌ ‌peasant‌ ‌Societies‌ ‌(animism,‌ ‌animatism,‌ ‌fetishism,‌ ‌naturism‌ ‌and‌ ‌totemism);‌ ‌Religion,‌ ‌\nmagic‌ ‌and‌ ‌science‌ ‌distinguished;‌ ‌Magico-religious‌ ‌functionaries‌ ‌(priest,‌ ‌shaman,‌ ‌medicine‌ ‌man,‌ ‌sorcerer‌ ‌and‌ ‌witch)-Part-II‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nMyths‌ ‌and‌ ‌rituals;‌ ‌\nIntroduction‌ ‌\n●Each‌ ‌religion‌ ‌has‌ ‌its‌ ‌own‌ ‌symbol‌ ‌and‌ ‌myths.‌ ‌‌For‌ ‌instance‌ ‌Church,‌ ‌Temple,‌ ‌mosque,‌ ‌flag,‌ ‌Specific‌ ‌kinds‌ ‌of‌ ‌dress‌ ‌are‌ ‌symbols‌ ‌of‌ ‌various‌ ‌\nreligious‌ ‌cult,‌ ‌similarly‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌mythological‌ ‌stories‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌which‌ ‌religion.‌ ‌\n●Myth‌ ‌‌consists‌ ‌of‌ ‌peoples‌ ‌assumed‌ ‌knowledge,‌ ‌about‌ ‌the‌ ‌universe‌ ‌and‌ ‌natural‌ ‌and‌ ‌Supernatural‌ ‌world.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Tribe‌ ‌who‌ ‌believe‌ ‌in‌ ‌animism‌ ‌have‌ ‌their‌ ‌own‌ ‌Totem,‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌symbolised‌ ‌by‌ ‌animals,‌ ‌plants,‌ ‌trees‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌structural‌ ‌anthropology,‌‌ ‌Claude‌ ‌Levi‌ ‌Strauss‌‌ ‌makes‌ ‌the‌ ‌claim‌ ‌that‌ ‌“myth‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌language”.‌ ‌\n●Through‌ ‌approaching‌ ‌mythology‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌language‌ ‌Levi‌ ‌Strauss‌ ‌suggests‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌approached‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌way‌ ‌as‌ ‌language‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌\napproached‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌structuralist‌ ‌method‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌address‌ ‌language.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nDefinition:‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Nature‌ ‌of‌ ‌Mythology‌ ‌R.J.‌ ‌Schork-‌Myth‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌form‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌generated,‌ ‌shaped,‌ ‌and‌ ‌transmitted‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌creative‌ ‌imagination‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌pre-‌ ‌and‌ ‌extra-logical‌ ‌people‌ ‌as‌ ‌they‌ ‌respond‌ ‌to‌ ‌and‌ ‌encapsulate‌ ‌the‌ ‌wealth‌ ‌of‌ ‌experience.‌ ‌\n●J.‌ ‌Peradotto,‌ ‌Classical‌ ‌Mythology‌-‌ ‌Myth‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌cognitive‌ ‌structure‌ ‌analogous‌ ‌to‌ ‌language‌ ‌through‌ ‌which‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌people‌ ‌organize‌ ‌their‌ ‌\nexperiences.‌ ‌ ‌\n●H.J.‌ ‌Rose,‌ ‌A‌ ‌Handbook‌ ‌of‌ ‌Greek‌ ‌Mythology‌-‌ ‌Myths‌ ‌are‌ ‌certain‌ ‌products‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌imagination‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌people‌ ‌which‌ ‌take‌ ‌the‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌stories.‌ ‌\n●Anthropologist‌ ‌William‌ ‌Bascom‌,‌ ‌“Myths‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌embodiment‌ ‌of‌ ‌dogma…‌ ‌and‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌often‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌theology‌ ‌and‌ ‌ritual.”‌ ‌ ‌\n●Myth,‌ ‌a‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌narrative‌,‌ ‌usually‌ ‌of‌ ‌unknown‌ ‌origin‌ ‌and‌ ‌at‌ ‌least‌ ‌partly‌ ‌traditional,‌ ‌that‌ ‌ostensibly‌ ‌relates‌ ‌actual‌ ‌events‌ ‌and‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌\nespecially‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌religious‌ ‌belief.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌distinguished‌ ‌from‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌(cult,‌ ‌ritual)‌ ‌and‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌places‌ ‌or‌ ‌objects‌ ‌(temples,‌ ‌\nicons).‌ ‌ ‌\n○Myths‌ ‌are‌ ‌specific‌ ‌accounts‌ ‌of‌ ‌gods‌ ‌or‌ ‌superhuman‌ ‌beings‌ ‌involved‌ ‌in‌ ‌extraordinary‌ ‌events‌ ‌or‌ ‌circumstances‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌time‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌\nunspecified‌ ‌but‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌understood‌ ‌as‌ ‌existing‌ ‌apart‌ ‌from‌ ‌ordinary‌ ‌human‌ ‌experience.‌ ‌ ‌\n578‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌term‌ ‌‌mythology‌ ‌‌denotes‌ ‌both‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌myth‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌body‌ ‌of‌ ‌myths‌ ‌belonging‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌religious‌ ‌tradition.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nProblem‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌definitions‌ ‌of‌ ‌‘myth’‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌establishment‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌single,‌ ‌comprehensive‌ ‌definition‌ ‌of‌ ‌myth‌ ‌has‌ ‌proved‌ ‌impossible‌ ‌to‌ ‌attain.‌ ‌\n●No‌ ‌one‌ ‌definition‌ ‌can‌ ‌satisfactorily‌ ‌embrace‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌various‌ ‌kinds‌ ‌of‌ ‌stories‌ ‌that‌ ‌can‌ ‌legitimately‌ ‌be‌ ‌classed‌ ‌as‌ ‌myths‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌one‌ ‌\ncriterion‌ ‌or‌ ‌another.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌attempt‌ ‌to‌ ‌define‌ ‌myth‌ ‌in‌ ‌itself,‌ ‌however‌ ‌intractable‌ ‌a‌ ‌proposition,‌ ‌serves‌ ‌to‌ ‌highlight‌ ‌the‌ ‌very‌ ‌qualities‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌stories‌ ‌that‌ ‌make‌ ‌them‌ ‌so‌ ‌\ndifferent‌ ‌from‌ ‌one‌ ‌another.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nCharacteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌Myth‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌Myth‌ ‌has‌ ‌no‌ ‌identifiable‌ ‌author.‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌Myth‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌written‌ ‌down‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌literary‌ ‌form‌ ‌user‌ ‌story‌ ‌that‌ ‌preceded‌ ‌it.‌ ‌\n●Sometimes‌ ‌the‌ ‌myths‌ ‌are‌ ‌even‌ ‌different‌ ‌in‌ ‌detail.‌ ‌\n●One‌ ‌version‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌mere‌ ‌true‌ ‌than‌ ‌the‌ ‌other.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nThe‌ ‌Purposes‌ ‌of‌ ‌Mythology‌ ‌\n●Myths‌ ‌grant‌ ‌continuity‌ ‌and‌ ‌stability‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\n●Myths‌ ‌present‌ ‌guidelines‌ ‌for‌ ‌living.‌ ‌\n●Myths‌ ‌justify‌ ‌a‌ ‌culture's‌ ‌activities.‌ ‌\n●Myths‌ ‌give‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌to‌ ‌life.‌ ‌\n●Myths‌ ‌explain‌ ‌the‌
