‌unexplainable.‌ ‌\n●Myths‌ ‌offer‌ ‌role‌ ‌models.‌ ‌\n ‌\nMyth‌ ‌vs‌ ‌Mythology:‌ ‌\n●Myth‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌traditional‌ ‌story‌ ‌which‌ ‌embodies‌ ‌a‌ ‌belief‌ ‌regarding‌ ‌some‌ ‌fact‌ ‌or‌ ‌phenomenon‌ ‌of‌ ‌experience,‌ ‌and‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌often‌ ‌the‌ ‌forces‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nnature‌ ‌and‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌soul‌ ‌are‌ ‌personified;‌ ‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌sacred‌ ‌narrative‌ ‌regarding‌ ‌a‌ ‌god,‌ ‌a‌ ‌hero,‌ ‌the‌ ‌origin‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌world‌ ‌or‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌people,‌ ‌etc‌ ‌while‌ ‌mythology‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌collection‌ ‌of‌ ‌myths‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌people,‌ ‌\nconcerning‌ ‌the‌ ‌origin‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌people,‌ ‌history,‌ ‌deities,‌ ‌ancestors‌ ‌and‌ ‌heroes.‌ ‌\n ‌\nFunction‌ ‌of‌ ‌Myth‌ ‌\n ‌\nJoseph‌ ‌Campbell’s‌ ‌“Four‌ ‌Functions‌ ‌of‌ ‌Myth”‌ ‌\n ‌\n579‌ ‌\n●Metaphysical/Mystic:‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌first‌ ‌function‌ ‌of‌ ‌mythology‌ ‌to‌ ‌evoke‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual‌ ‌a‌ ‌sense‌ ‌of‌ ‌grateful,‌ ‌affirmative‌ ‌awe‌ ‌before‌ ‌the‌ ‌monstrous‌ ‌mystery‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌\nexistence.‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌contains‌ ‌stories‌ ‌that‌ ‌express‌ ‌the‌ ‌awe‌ ‌and‌ ‌wonder‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌universe.‌ ‌\n●Cosmological:‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌second‌ ‌function‌ ‌of‌ ‌mythology‌ ‌is‌ ‌to‌ ‌present‌ ‌an‌ ‌image‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌cosmos,‌ ‌an‌ ‌image‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌universe‌ ‌that‌ ‌will‌ ‌maintain‌ ‌and‌ ‌elicit‌ ‌this‌ ‌\nexperience‌ ‌of‌ ‌awe.‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌contains‌ ‌stories‌ ‌that‌ ‌attempt‌ ‌to‌ ‌explain‌ ‌the‌ ‌processes‌ ‌of‌ ‌nature‌ ‌\n●Sociological:‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌third‌ ‌function‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌mythological‌ ‌order‌ ‌is‌ ‌to‌ ‌validate‌ ‌and‌ ‌maintain‌ ‌a‌ ‌certain‌ ‌sociological‌ ‌system‌ ‌a‌ ‌shared‌ ‌set‌ ‌of‌ ‌rights‌ ‌and‌ ‌wrongs,‌ ‌\nproperties‌ ‌of‌ ‌improprieties,‌ ‌on‌ ‌which‌ ‌your‌ ‌particular‌ ‌social‌ ‌unit‌ ‌depends‌ ‌for‌ ‌its‌ ‌existence.‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌contains‌ ‌stories‌ ‌that‌ ‌support‌ ‌and‌ ‌validate‌ ‌a‌ ‌certain‌ ‌social‌ ‌order‌ ‌\n● ‌Pedagogical‌ ‌:‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌myth‌ ‌must‌ ‌carry‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌stages‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌life,‌ ‌from‌ ‌birth‌ ‌through‌ ‌maturity‌ ‌through‌ ‌senility‌ ‌to‌ ‌death.‌ ‌It‌ ‌contains‌ ‌\nstories‌ ‌that‌ ‌explain‌ ‌how‌ ‌to‌ ‌live‌ ‌a‌ ‌full,‌ ‌happy‌ ‌life.‌ ‌\nTypes‌ ‌of‌ ‌Myths‌ ‌by‌ ‌Alexander‌ ‌Eliot:‌ ‌\n●Primitive‌ ‌myths-‌Stories‌ ‌about‌ ‌nature‌ ‌as‌ ‌told‌ ‌by‌ ‌shamans‌ ‌\n●Pagan‌ ‌myths-‌Greek‌ ‌and‌ ‌Roman’s‌ ‌tales‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌interplay‌ ‌between‌ ‌deities‌ ‌and‌ ‌humans‌ ‌\n●Sacred‌ ‌myths-S‌tories‌ ‌from‌ ‌current‌ ‌eastern‌ ‌and‌ ‌western‌ ‌religions‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌Christianity‌ ‌and‌ ‌Hinduism.‌ ‌\n●Scientific‌ ‌myths-‌ ‌‌considered‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌solemn‌ ‌and‌ ‌revered‌ ‌creeds‌ ‌of‌ ‌science‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nRituals‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌most‌ ‌theories,‌ ‌ritual‌ ‌either‌ ‌involves‌ ‌different‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌action‌ ‌from‌ ‌everyday‌ ‌life,‌ ‌or‌ ‌at‌ ‌least‌ ‌different‌ ‌purposes.‌ ‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌example‌,‌ ‌in‌ ‌Christian‌ ‌ritual,‌ ‌the‌ ‌act‌ ‌of‌ ‌ingesting‌ ‌bread‌ ‌during‌ ‌holy‌ ‌communion‌ ‌is‌ ‌different‌ ‌from‌ ‌eating‌ ‌bread‌ ‌at‌ ‌any‌ ‌other‌ ‌time.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌difference‌ ‌relates‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌attached‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌ritual‌ ‌act,‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌suggested‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌symbols.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Paraphrasing‌ ‌‌Clifford‌ ‌Geertz’s‌‌ ‌definition‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture,‌ ‌‌David‌ ‌Kertzer‌‌ ‌defines‌ ‌ritual‌ ‌as‌ ‌‘action‌ ‌wrapped‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌web‌ ‌of‌ ‌symbolism’.‌ ‌This‌ ‌assumes‌ ‌\nthat‌ ‌ritual‌ ‌has‌ ‌a‌ ‌communicative‌ ‌role.‌ ‌\n●Simply,‌ ‌A‌ ‌ritual‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌patterned,‌ ‌repetitive,‌ ‌and‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌enactment‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌belief‌ ‌or‌ ‌value.‌ ‌\n○Ritual‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌service‌ ‌which‌ ‌involves‌ ‌a‌ ‌series‌ ‌of‌ ‌actions‌ ‌performed‌ ‌in‌ ‌effect‌ ‌order‌ ‌which‌ ‌shows‌ ‌a‌ ‌way‌ ‌of‌ ‌behaving‌ ‌that‌ ‌people‌ ‌regularly‌ ‌\ncarry‌ ‌out‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌situation‌ ‌because‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌their‌ ‌custom‌ ‌to‌ ‌do‌ ‌so.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Ritual‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌prescribed‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌tradition‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌community‌ ‌or‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌society‌ ‌or‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌culture‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌sequence‌ ‌of‌ ‌activities‌ ‌involving‌ ‌\ngesture‌ ‌word‌ ‌symbol‌ ‌sign‌ ‌and‌ ‌language‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Members‌ ‌of‌ ‌any‌ ‌religion‌ ‌may‌ ‌have‌ ‌different‌ ‌beliefs‌ ‌but‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌common‌ ‌religious‌ ‌ritual‌ ‌that‌ ‌gives‌ ‌them‌ ‌a‌ ‌feeling,‌ ‌Unity,‌ ‌and‌ ‌\ntogetherness.‌ ‌\n580‌ ‌\n●Emile‌ ‌Durkheim‌‌ ‌Described‌ ‌ritual‌ ‌as‌ ‌an‌ ‌important‌ ‌element‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion.‌ ‌Ritual‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌practice‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion‌ ‌or‌ ‌the‌ ‌action‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Conceptually,‌ ‌Ritual‌ ‌is‌ ‌different‌ ‌from‌ ‌belief,‌ ‌beliefs‌ ‌are‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌of‌ ‌thought‌ ‌and‌ ‌rituals‌ ‌are‌ ‌their‌ ‌implementation.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nTypes‌ ‌of‌ ‌rituals‌ ‌\nThese‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌different‌ ‌types‌ ‌or‌ ‌rituals‌ ‌performed‌ ‌by‌ ‌various‌ ‌groups.‌ ‌Some‌ ‌sects‌ ‌practice‌ ‌one‌ ‌or‌ ‌all‌ ‌different‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌rituals.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Initiation:‌ ‌ ‌\n○Into‌ ‌any‌ ‌group,‌ ‌organization,‌ ‌cult,‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌certain‌ ‌rites‌ ‌and‌ ‌rituals‌ ‌of‌ ‌initiation,‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌the‌ ‌seeker‌ ‌or‌ ‌aspirant‌ ‌must‌ ‌partake‌ ‌in,‌ ‌\nin‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌join.‌ ‌ ‌\n○These‌ ‌might‌ ‌include‌ ‌vows‌ ‌of‌ ‌secrecy,‌ ‌a‌ ‌ceremonial‌ ‌\"rebirth\"‌ ‌of‌ ‌some‌ ‌kind‌ ‌into‌ ‌the‌ ‌group,‌ ‌and‌ ‌an‌ ‌oath‌ ‌of‌ ‌loyalty‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌group.‌ ‌\n●Magical:‌ ‌ ‌\n○Magical‌ ‌rituals‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌practiced‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌group,‌ ‌or‌ ‌by‌ ‌oneself.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Normally,‌ ‌magickal‌ ‌rituals‌ ‌require‌ ‌special‌ ‌ritual‌ ‌tools‌ ‌and‌ ‌an‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌nature‌ ‌of‌ ‌correspondence.‌ ‌\n●Worship:‌ ‌ ‌\n○Rituals‌ ‌of‌ ‌worship‌ ‌include‌ ‌prayer,‌ ‌the‌ ‌consecration‌ ‌of‌ ‌food‌ ‌and‌ ‌drink‌ ‌towards‌ ‌a‌ ‌deity,‌ ‌invoking‌ ‌the‌ ‌name‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌deity‌ ‌\n●Celebration:‌ ‌ ‌\n○Rituals‌ ‌of‌ ‌celebration‌ ‌are‌ ‌much‌ ‌like‌ ‌rituals‌ ‌of‌ ‌worship,‌ ‌except‌ ‌that‌ ‌they‌ ‌usually‌ ‌fall‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌specific‌ ‌recurring‌ ‌day‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌year,‌ ‌much‌ ‌like‌ ‌\nYule‌ ‌or‌ ‌Halloween.‌ ‌\n●Protection:‌ ‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌protection‌ ‌ritual,‌ ‌like‌ ‌the‌ ‌Lesser‌ ‌Banishing‌ ‌Ritual‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Pentagram,‌ ‌is‌ ‌aimed‌ ‌at‌ ‌directing‌ ‌divine‌ ‌energy‌ ‌for‌ ‌protection‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌ritualist.‌ ‌\n●Healing:‌ ‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌healing‌ ‌ritual‌ ‌is‌ ‌often‌ ‌performed‌ ‌in‌ ‌private,‌ ‌with‌ ‌one‌ ‌person‌ ‌acting‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌healer‌ ‌of‌ ‌another.‌ ‌\n●Transformation:‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌type‌ ‌is‌ ‌considered‌ ‌a‌ ‌ritual‌ ‌to‌ ‌transform‌ ‌the‌ ‌self.‌ ‌\n●Storytelling:‌ ‌ ‌\n○Also‌ ‌called‌ ‌a‌ ‌Bardic,‌ ‌this‌ ‌ritual‌ ‌involves‌ ‌the‌ ‌telling‌ ‌of‌ ‌stories,‌ ‌through‌ ‌narrative‌ ‌or‌ ‌through‌ ‌song.‌ ‌\n●Fire‌ ‌Ritual:‌ ‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌ritual‌ ‌that‌ ‌involves‌ ‌the‌ ‌Element‌ ‌of‌ ‌Fire,‌ ‌whether‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌bonfire,‌ ‌a‌ ‌candle,‌ ‌or‌ ‌some‌ ‌other‌ ‌method.‌ ‌\n●Funeral:‌ ‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌funeral‌ ‌ritual‌ ‌involves‌ ‌the‌ ‌sending‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌dead‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌next‌ ‌world.‌ ‌(Not‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌confused‌ ‌with‌ ‌necromancy,‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌just‌ ‌the‌ ‌opposite.)‌ ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌Addition:‌ ‌\nRitual‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌integration‌ ‌\n●Taking‌ ‌their‌ ‌lead‌ ‌from‌ ‌‌Emile‌ ‌Durkheim‌,‌ ‌the‌ ‌British‌ ‌functionalist‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌1950s‌ ‌and‌ ‌1960s‌ ‌concentrated‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌integrative‌ ‌\nfunction‌ ‌of‌ ‌ritual.‌ ‌ ‌\n581‌ ‌\n●Durkheim‌ ‌had‌ ‌argued‌ ‌that‌ ‌because‌ ‌the‌ ‌apparent‌ ‌function‌ ‌of‌ ‌ritual‌ ‌is‌ ‌to‌ ‌strengthen‌ ‌the‌ ‌bonds‌ ‌attaching‌ ‌the‌ ‌believer‌ ‌to‌ ‌god,‌ ‌and‌ ‌god‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌\nmore‌ ‌than‌ ‌a‌ ‌figurative‌ ‌expression‌ ‌of‌ ‌society‌ ‌itself,‌ ‌so‌ ‌ritual‌ ‌in‌ ‌fact‌ ‌serves‌ ‌to‌ ‌attach‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual‌ ‌to‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Because‌ ‌ritual‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌direct‌ ‌representation‌ ‌of‌ ‌society‌ ‌to‌ ‌itself,‌ ‌studying‌ ‌ritual‌ ‌tells‌ ‌us‌ ‌important‌ ‌things‌ ‌about‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌many‌ ‌societies,‌ ‌god‌ ‌comes‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌king‌ ‌or‌ ‌chief.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌strengthening‌ ‌of‌ ‌bonds‌ ‌between‌ ‌kings‌ ‌and‌ ‌subjects‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌most‌ ‌clear‌ ‌demonstration‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌strengthening‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌bonds,‌ ‌or‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nlegitimation‌ ‌of‌ ‌authority.‌ ‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌celebrated‌ ‌example‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌process‌ ‌at‌ ‌work‌ ‌is‌ ‌provided‌ ‌by‌ ‌‌Max‌ ‌Gluckman,‌‌ ‌who‌ ‌examined‌ ‌the‌ ‌incwala‌ ‌ritual‌ ‌performed‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nSouthern‌ ‌African‌ ‌Swazi‌ ‌people‌.‌ ‌This‌ ‌was‌ ‌an‌ ‌annual‌ ‌ritual‌ ‌which‌ ‌reaffirmed‌ ‌the‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌king‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌nation‌ ‌by‌ ‌\ndeliberately‌ ‌drawing‌ ‌attention‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌potential‌ ‌conflict‌ ‌his‌ ‌authority‌ ‌could‌ ‌cause.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Gluckman‌‌ ‌called‌ ‌such‌ ‌rituals‌ ‌‘rituals‌ ‌of‌ ‌rebellion’,the‌ ‌power‌ ‌of‌ ‌which‌ ‌lay‌ ‌in‌ ‌‘exaggerating‌ ‌real‌ ‌conflicts‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌rules‌ ‌and‌ ‌affirming‌ ‌\nthat‌ ‌there‌ ‌was‌ ‌unity‌ ‌despite‌ ‌these‌ ‌conflicts’‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nDifferences‌ ‌between‌ ‌Belief‌ ‌and‌ ‌Ritual‌ ‌are‌ ‌as‌ ‌follows:‌ ‌\n ‌\n(1)‌ ‌Belief:‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌belief‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌state‌ ‌or‌ ‌habit‌ ‌of‌ ‌mind,‌ ‌wherein‌ ‌one‌ ‌places‌ ‌trust‌ ‌or‌ ‌confidence‌ ‌in‌ ‌some‌ ‌person‌ ‌or‌ ‌thing.‌ ‌A‌ ‌belief‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌defined‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nnotion‌ ‌or‌ ‌idea‌ ‌which‌ ‌has‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌value‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌statement‌ ‌of‌ ‌knowledge‌ ‌or‌ ‌truth.‌ ‌\n●Thus,‌‌ ‌Religious‌ ‌beliefs‌ ‌refer‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌Religious‌ ‌tenet‌ ‌or‌ ‌body‌ ‌of‌ ‌tenets‌ ‌held‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌group.‌ ‌Most‌ ‌Religious‌ ‌tenets‌ ‌generally‌ ‌are‌ ‌concerned‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nworship‌ ‌of‌ ‌God‌ ‌or‌ ‌the‌ ‌supernatural.‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌‌Tylor‌,‌ ‌Religion‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌belief‌ ‌in‌ ‌supernatural‌ ‌brings‌ ‌(Animism),‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌Ghosts,‌ ‌spirits,‌ ‌and‌ ‌Gods.‌ ‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌‌Marett‌‌ ‌Religion‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌belief‌ ‌in‌ ‌supernatural‌ ‌power‌ ‌(Animatism),‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌mana.‌ ‌Our‌ ‌statement‌ ‌that‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌belief‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nsupernatural‌ ‌concept‌ ‌implies‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌belongs‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌region‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌beyond‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌natural‌ ‌senses.‌ ‌\n ‌\n(2)‌ ‌Beliefs‌ ‌and‌ ‌Rituals:‌ ‌\n●Beliefs‌ ‌and‌ ‌Rituals‌ ‌are‌ ‌interrelated.‌‌ ‌Normally‌ ‌every‌ ‌Ritual‌ ‌is‌ ‌based,‌ ‌directly‌ ‌or‌ ‌otherwise,‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌series‌ ‌of‌ ‌beliefs.‌ ‌A‌ ‌Ritual‌ ‌without‌ ‌a‌ ‌belief‌ ‌set‌ ‌\nis‌ ‌in‌ ‌fact‌ ‌not‌ ‌possible‌ ‌because‌ ‌beliefs‌ ‌set‌ ‌the‌ ‌stage‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌Ritual‌ ‌to‌ ‌develop‌ ‌or‌ ‌even‌ ‌to‌ ‌emerge.‌ ‌\n●Ritual‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌series‌ ‌of‌ ‌repeated‌ ‌actions‌ ‌and‌ ‌sacred‌ ‌words.‌ ‌We‌ ‌have‌ ‌to‌ ‌refer‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌beliefs‌ ‌to‌ ‌interpret‌ ‌it‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌right‌ ‌way.‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌belief‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌knowledge‌ ‌or‌ ‌a‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌reality‌ ‌shared‌ ‌by‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌group.‌ ‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌Religious‌ ‌belief‌ ‌provides‌ ‌an‌ ‌explanation‌ ‌for‌ ‌happening‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌otherwise‌ ‌hard‌ ‌to‌ ‌explain.‌ ‌\n ‌\n(3)‌ ‌Belief‌ ‌and‌ ‌Ritual:‌ ‌Distinction‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌Religion‌ ‌a‌ ‌distinction‌ ‌is‌ ‌made‌ ‌between‌ ‌belief‌ ‌and‌ ‌Ritual.‌ ‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌belief‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌mode‌ ‌of‌ ‌forming‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌while‌ ‌Ritual‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌mode‌ ‌of‌ ‌action‌ ‌Ritual,‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌defined‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌repeated‌ ‌act‌ ‌or‌ ‌a‌ ‌set‌ ‌of‌ ‌acts,‌ ‌\nusually‌ ‌ceremonial‌ ‌in‌ ‌nature,‌ ‌by‌ ‌means‌ ‌of‌ ‌which‌ ‌a‌ ‌community‌ ‌makes‌ ‌external‌ ‌its‌ ‌faith.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Ritual‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌kind‌ ‌of‌ ‌patterned‌ ‌activity‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌oriented‌ ‌towards‌ ‌the‌ ‌control‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌affairs.‌ ‌\n●Religious‌ ‌beliefs‌ ‌are‌ ‌made‌ ‌overt‌ ‌in‌ ‌Rituals.‌ ‌ ‌\n○An‌ ‌example‌ ‌of‌ ‌Ritual‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌funeral‌ ‌Ritual‌.‌ ‌A‌ ‌Ritual‌ ‌provides‌ ‌an‌ ‌occasion‌ ‌for‌ ‌group‌ ‌assembly‌ ‌and‌ ‌reaffirms‌ ‌social‌ ‌value.‌ ‌Wallace‌ ‌\n582‌ ‌\n(1966)‌ ‌holds‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌primary‌ ‌component‌ ‌of‌ ‌Religion‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌Ritual‌ ‌to‌ ‌mobilize‌ ‌supernatural‌ ‌power.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nForms‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion‌ ‌in‌ ‌tribal‌ ‌and‌ ‌peasant‌ ‌Societies‌ ‌(animism,‌ ‌animatism,‌ ‌fetishism,‌ ‌naturism‌ ‌and‌ ‌totemism);‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n●The‌ ‌religious‌ ‌life‌ ‌of‌ ‌any‌ ‌people‌ ‌is‌ ‌manifested‌ ‌in‌ ‌outward‌ ‌form‌ ‌in‌ ‌belief‌ ‌and‌ ‌rituals.‌ ‌Mere‌ ‌believe‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌constitute‌ ‌religion,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌rites‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌rituals‌ ‌which‌ ‌make‌ ‌religion‌ ‌a‌ ‌living‌ ‌force.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌shape‌ ‌of‌ ‌supernatural‌ ‌power‌ ‌varies‌ ‌from‌ ‌society‌ ‌to‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n●Some‌ ‌religions‌ ‌believe‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌supernatural‌ ‌power‌ ‌has‌ ‌a‌ ‌definite‌ ‌shape‌ ‌and‌ ‌dimension,‌ ‌which‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌represented‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌idol.‌ ‌\n●On‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌such‌ ‌notions‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌have‌ ‌formed‌ ‌following‌ ‌explanations‌ ‌about‌ ‌religion.‌ ‌\nAnimism‌ ‌\n●Animism‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌work‌ ‌of‌ ‌‌E.‌ ‌B.‌ ‌Tylor‌‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌his‌ ‌“Primitive‌ ‌Culture”‌ ‌first‌ ‌published‌ ‌in‌ ‌1871.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌notion‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌religion‌ ‌which‌ ‌endeavoured‌ ‌to‌ ‌account‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌spiritual‌ ‌existence‌ ‌of‌ ‌animals,‌ ‌plants‌ ‌and‌ ‌even‌ ‌\non‌ ‌the‌ ‌occasion‌ ‌of‌ ‌man‌ ‌and‌ ‌inanimate‌ ‌object.‌ ‌\n●Animism‌ ‌is‌ ‌essentially‌ ‌a‌ ‌belief‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌existence‌ ‌of‌ ‌some‌ ‌supra-physical‌ ‌being‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌body‌ ‌of‌ ‌every‌ ‌living‌ ‌being.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌supernatural‌ ‌being‌ ‌survives‌ ‌even‌ ‌after‌ ‌the‌ ‌collapse‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌physical‌ ‌body‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌contained.‌ ‌ ‌\n●After‌ ‌the‌ ‌death‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌person‌ ‌this‌ ‌so-called‌ ‌supernatural‌ ‌being‌ ‌is‌ ‌freed‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌physical‌ ‌limitations‌ ‌and‌ ‌can‌ ‌wander‌ ‌anywhere‌ ‌without‌ ‌being‌ ‌\nrestricted‌ ‌by‌ ‌time‌ ‌and‌ ‌space.‌ ‌\n●Tylor,‌ ‌animism‌ ‌is‌ ‌essentially‌ ‌a‌ ‌belief‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌spirit‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌dead.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Tylor‌ ‌argued‌ ‌that‌ ‌early‌ ‌men‌ ‌had‌ ‌a‌ ‌need‌ ‌to‌ ‌explain‌ ‌dreams,‌ ‌shadows,‌ ‌hallucinations,‌ ‌sleep,‌ ‌and‌ ‌death.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌need‌ ‌to‌ ‌understand‌ ‌such‌ ‌a‌ ‌phenomenon‌ ‌led‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌belief‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌existence‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌soul‌ ‌or‌ ‌an‌ ‌indwelling‌ ‌personality.‌ ‌ ‌\n●When‌ ‌a‌ ‌man‌ ‌dreamt‌ ‌and‌ ‌saw‌ ‌in‌ ‌his‌ ‌dream,‌ ‌a‌ ‌person‌ ‌who‌ ‌was‌ ‌dead,‌ ‌then‌ ‌this‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌man’s‌ ‌spirit‌ ‌or‌ ‌soul‌ ‌visiting‌ ‌him.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Similarly,‌ ‌to‌ ‌dream‌ ‌of‌ ‌oneself‌ ‌in‌ ‌another‌ ‌place‌ ‌was‌ ‌one’s‌ ‌own‌ ‌soul‌ ‌parted‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌body‌ ‌in‌ ‌sleep.‌ ‌\n●Tylor‌ ‌was‌ ‌criticized‌ ‌for‌ ‌being‌ ‌so‌ ‌certain‌ ‌about‌ ‌the‌ ‌logical‌ ‌mind‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌people‌ ‌or‌ ‌identifying‌ ‌a‌ ‌philosopher‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌men.‌ ‌\nHowever,‌ ‌we‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌entirely‌ ‌overlook‌ ‌the‌ ‌role‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌aspect,‌ ‌rather‌ ‌it‌ ‌could‌ ‌have‌ ‌formed‌ ‌one‌ ‌important‌ ‌part‌ ‌in‌ ‌developing‌ ‌religion.‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌belief‌ ‌that‌ ‌not‌ ‌only‌ ‌living‌ ‌creature‌ ‌but‌ ‌also‌ ‌in‌ ‌animate‌ ‌object‌ ‌have‌ ‌life.‌ ‌\n○An‌ ‌important‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌animism‌ ‌is‌ ‌ancestral‌ ‌workship‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌found‌ ‌among‌ ‌most‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌tribes.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌santhals‌ ‌worship‌ ‌the‌ ‌ancestor‌ ‌as‌ ‌family‌ ‌and‌ ‌village‌ ‌deities.‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌western‌ ‌India,‌ ‌The‌ ‌Bhils‌ ‌believe‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌survival‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌dead‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌soul‌ ‌continue‌ ‌to‌ ‌exist‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌spirit‌ ‌again‌ ‌they‌ ‌have‌ ‌numerous‌ ‌\nnature‌ ‌spirit‌ ‌like‌ ‌spirit‌ ‌of‌ ‌hill,‌ ‌stream,‌ ‌forest‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌Kerala,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Malayarayan‌ ‌consider‌ ‌the‌ ‌ancestral‌ ‌spirits‌ ‌as‌ ‌symbol‌ ‌of‌ ‌deities.‌ ‌they‌ ‌believe‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌dead‌ ‌ancestor,‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌\ndeity‌ ‌we‌ ‌will‌ ‌protect‌ ‌their‌ ‌family.‌ ‌\n ‌\nAnimatism‌ ‌\n●Animatism‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌widespread‌ ‌idea‌ ‌among‌ ‌tribal‌ ‌people‌ ‌as‌ ‌compared‌ ‌to‌ ‌animism.‌ ‌ ‌\n583‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌animatism,‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌some‌ ‌impersonal‌ ‌power‌ ‌behind‌ ‌every‌ ‌material‌ ‌thing‌ ‌besides‌ ‌living‌ ‌things.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌tribal‌ ‌religion‌ ‌materials‌ ‌like‌ ‌bones,‌ ‌stones‌ ‌and‌ ‌feathers‌ ‌are‌ ‌worshipped‌ ‌to‌ ‌bring‌ ‌peace‌ ‌and‌ ‌prosperity.‌ ‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌‌RR‌ ‌Marett,‌‌ ‌animatism‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌rudimentary‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion.‌ ‌\n○According‌ ‌to‌ ‌him‌ ‌Animatism‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌belief‌ ‌in‌ ‌some‌ ‌impersonal‌ ‌power‌ ‌Behind‌ ‌every‌ ‌material‌ ‌object‌ ‌besides‌ ‌living‌ ‌beings.‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌impersonal‌ ‌power‌ ‌influences‌ ‌human‌ ‌and‌ ‌can‌ ‌also‌ ‌be‌ ‌controlled‌ ‌under‌ ‌certain‌ ‌conditions.‌ ‌\n○Marret‌ ‌considered‌ ‌animatism‌ ‌to‌ ‌have‌ ‌existed‌ ‌even‌ ‌earlier‌ ‌to‌ ‌animism.‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌was‌ ‌only‌ ‌later‌ ‌in‌ ‌human‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌that‌ ‌people‌ ‌at‌ ‌its‌ ‌soul‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌spiritual‌ ‌being‌ ‌to‌ ‌their‌ ‌theologies.‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌example,‌‌ ‌in‌ ‌Bihar‌ ‌tribe‌ ‌stones‌ ‌and‌ ‌feathers‌ ‌are‌ ‌considered‌ ‌to‌ ‌have‌ ‌magical‌ ‌power.‌ ‌The‌ ‌stones‌ ‌are‌ ‌considered‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌children‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌earth‌ ‌mother.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Even‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Ho‌ ‌people‌ ‌‌believed‌ ‌in‌ ‌an‌ ‌all‌ ‌prevailing‌ ‌life‌ ‌force‌ ‌and‌ ‌behind‌ ‌to‌ ‌please‌ ‌this‌ ‌spirit‌ ‌for‌ ‌their‌ ‌own‌ ‌benefits‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nbetterment.‌ ‌Their‌ ‌chief‌ ‌deity‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌this‌ ‌belief‌ ‌is‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌‘Sing‌ ‌Bonga’.‌ ‌So,‌ ‌animatism‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌faith‌ ‌is‌ ‌material‌ ‌things‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌living‌ ‌\nsoul.‌ ‌\n ‌\nFetishism‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌derived‌ ‌from‌ ‌Portuguese‌ ‌word‌ ‌‘Feiticos’‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌skillfully‌ ‌made‌ ‌object‌ ‌and‌ ‌defined‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌belief‌ ‌in‌ ‌an‌ ‌object‌ ‌of‌ ‌having‌ ‌supernatural‌ ‌\npower‌ ‌for‌ ‌in‌ ‌particular‌ ‌human‌ ‌made‌ ‌object‌ ‌with‌ ‌power.‌ ‌\n● ‌it‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌seen‌ ‌among‌ ‌Bondos‌ ‌tribe‌ ‌having‌ ‌a‌ ‌fetish‌ ‌Rajput‌ ‌sword‌ ‌kept‌ ‌on‌ ‌banyan‌ ‌tree‌ ‌and‌ ‌believe‌ ‌that‌ ‌prayer‌ ‌of‌ ‌it‌ ‌will‌ ‌bring‌ ‌Rajput‌ ‌spirit‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nthem.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌‌Naturism‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌‌German‌ ‌scholar‌ ‌and‌ ‌Indologist‌ ‌Max‌ ‌Muller‌‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌main‌ ‌propounder‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌naturism.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌man‌ ‌was‌ ‌inspired‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌natural‌ ‌phenomena‌ ‌to‌ ‌find‌ ‌out‌ ‌the‌ ‌reason‌ ‌behind‌ ‌some‌ ‌natural‌ ‌calamities‌ ‌and‌ ‌catastrophes.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌origin‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌Max‌ ‌Muller‌ ‌lies‌ ‌in‌ ‌this‌ ‌attempt‌ ‌to‌ ‌explain‌ ‌and‌ ‌describe‌ ‌the‌ ‌reasons‌ ‌behind‌ ‌and‌ ‌implications‌ ‌of‌ ‌natural‌ ‌\nphenomena.‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌example,‌‌ ‌the‌ ‌Munda‌ ‌would‌ ‌go‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌tops‌ ‌of‌ ‌hills‌ ‌and‌ ‌throw‌ ‌down‌ ‌stones‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌sizes‌ ‌and‌ ‌shapes,‌ ‌so‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌rumbling‌ ‌sound‌ ‌of‌ ‌stones‌ ‌\nfalling‌ ‌would‌ ‌resemble‌ ‌the‌ ‌rumbling‌ ‌of‌ ‌thunder‌ ‌and‌ ‌they‌ ‌believe‌ ‌that‌ ‌rains‌ ‌would‌ ‌follow.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Ho‌ ‌would‌ ‌burn‌ ‌faggots‌ ‌so‌ ‌that‌ ‌some‌ ‌may‌ ‌cover‌ ‌the‌ ‌sky‌ ‌resembling‌ ‌cloud‌ ‌and‌ ‌they‌ ‌believe‌ ‌this‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌cloud‌ ‌is‌ ‌capable‌ ‌of‌ ‌bringing‌ ‌real‌ ‌\ncloud‌ ‌and‌ ‌rain.‌ ‌\n●Thus,‌ ‌the‌ ‌outward‌ ‌events‌ ‌that‌ ‌affect‌ ‌life‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌explained‌ ‌and‌ ‌accounted‌ ‌for‌ ‌by‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌people‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌knowledge‌ ‌that‌ ‌they‌ ‌\ngained‌ ‌through‌ ‌experiences‌ ‌and‌ ‌gradually‌ ‌this‌ ‌helped‌ ‌them‌ ‌to‌ ‌develop‌ ‌religion.‌ ‌\n●Max‌ ‌Muller‌ ‌stressed‌ ‌the‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion‌ ‌from‌ ‌naturalism‌ ‌through‌ ‌polytheism‌ ‌and‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌current‌ ‌stage‌ ‌of‌ ‌of‌ ‌monotheism.‌ ‌\n ‌\nTotemism‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌totemism‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion‌ ‌was‌ ‌first‌ ‌formulated‌ ‌by‌ ‌John‌ ‌McLennan,‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌article‌ ‌“The‌ ‌Worship‌ ‌of‌ ‌Animals‌ ‌and‌ ‌plants”‌ ‌\n(1869-1870).‌ ‌The‌ ‌term‌ ‌Totem‌ ‌is‌ ‌derived‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌Obijbwa‌ ‌word‌ ‌ototeman,‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌“one’s‌ ‌brother-sister‌ ‌kin”.‌ ‌\n584‌ ‌\n●Totemism‌ ‌implies‌ ‌a‌ ‌tribal‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌organization‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌sib‌ ‌or‌ ‌clan‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌supernaturalism‌ ‌consisting‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nsome‌ ‌typical‌ ‌attitude‌ ‌towards‌ ‌animals,‌ ‌plants‌ ‌or‌ ‌some‌ ‌other‌ ‌natural‌ ‌objects.‌ ‌Totem‌ ‌is‌ ‌related‌ ‌both‌ ‌to‌ ‌religion‌ ‌and‌ ‌clan‌ ‌organization.‌ ‌\n●Regarding‌ ‌the‌ ‌religious‌ ‌aspect‌ ‌of‌ ‌totem,‌ ‌many‌ ‌scholars‌ ‌have‌ ‌their‌ ‌opinions‌ ‌and‌ ‌writing.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Tylor‌ ‌‌opined‌ ‌totemism‌ ‌emerged‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌religious‌ ‌worship‌ ‌and‌ ‌ancestor‌ ‌worship.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Emile‌ ‌Durkheim‌‌ ‌took‌ ‌totemism‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌elementary‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌religious‌ ‌life‌ ‌and‌ ‌suggested‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌clan‌ ‌worshipping‌ ‌itself‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌\ncollective‌ ‌emblem‌ ‌of‌ ‌society‌ ‌and‌ ‌worship‌ ‌of‌ ‌society‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌source‌ ‌of‌ ‌totemism‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌him‌.‌ ‌\n○Australian‌ ‌aborigines‌ ‌live‌ ‌in‌ ‌small‌ ‌band.‌ ‌each‌ ‌Van‌ ‌has‌ ‌a‌ ‌Totem‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌animal‌ ‌plant‌ ‌or‌ ‌some‌ ‌geographical‌ ‌element.‌ ‌\n○Each‌ ‌band‌ ‌is‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌Totem‌ ‌and‌ ‌believe‌ ‌that‌ ‌its‌ ‌ancestors‌ ‌have‌ ‌descended‌ ‌from‌ ‌back‌ ‌Totem.‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌neither‌ ‌kill‌ ‌nor‌ ‌eat‌ ‌that‌ ‌Totem.‌ ‌\n○Emile‌ ‌Durkheim‌ ‌since‌ ‌the‌ ‌Australian‌ ‌aborigines‌ ‌are‌ ‌most‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌their‌ ‌Belief‌ ‌in‌ ‌Totem‌ ‌must‌ ‌be‌ ‌most‌ ‌elementary‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion.‌ ‌\n○He‌ ‌further‌ ‌argue‌ ‌that‌ ‌when‌ ‌people‌ ‌workship‌ ‌their‌ ‌Totem‌ ‌is‌ ‌sacred‌ ‌emblem‌ ‌that‌ ‌symbolise‌ ‌their‌ ‌social‌ ‌identity‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌actually‌ ‌work‌ ‌\nshipping‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n●An‌ ‌association‌ ‌between‌ ‌human‌ ‌groups‌ ‌or‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌and‌ ‌specific‌ ‌animals‌ ‌or‌ ‌plants‌ ‌which‌ ‌entailed‌ ‌ritualized‌ ‌observances‌ ‌and‌ ‌sometimes‌ ‌\neating‌ ‌avoidances.‌ ‌ ‌\n●James‌ ‌Frazer‌ ‌‌argued‌ ‌that‌ ‌totemism‌ ‌existed‌ ‌were‌ ‌‘savages’‌ ‌had‌ ‌no‌ ‌knowledge‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌role‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌human‌ ‌male‌ ‌in‌ ‌conception.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Herbert‌ ‌Risley‌‌ ‌pointed‌ ‌out,‌ ‌in‌ ‌India,‌ ‌the‌ ‌religious‌ ‌aspect‌ ‌of‌ ‌totemism‌ ‌is‌ ‌almost‌ ‌dead‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌considerable‌ ‌extent,‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌aspect‌ ‌is‌ ‌more‌ ‌\noperative.‌ ‌\n●Most‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌explanations‌ ‌in‌ ‌relation‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌origin‌ ‌of‌ ‌clans‌ ‌among‌ ‌Ho,‌ ‌Munda‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌Santhal‌ ‌conclude‌ ‌that‌ ‌totems‌ ‌originated‌ ‌out‌ ‌of‌ ‌necessity‌ ‌\nat‌ ‌a‌ ‌time‌ ‌when‌ ‌human‌ ‌help‌ ‌failed‌ ‌to‌ ‌provide‌ ‌required‌ ‌relief.‌ ‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌example‌,‌ ‌Hansda‌ ‌clan‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌totem‌ ‌duck,‌ ‌Pansia‌ ‌clan‌ ‌with‌ ‌totem‌ ‌pigeon‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n●Marriage‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌be‌ ‌contracted‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌male‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌female‌ ‌of‌ ‌same‌ ‌Totem‌ ‌because‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌thought‌ ‌to‌ ‌have‌ ‌blood‌ ‌relationship.‌ ‌\n●Totemism‌ ‌reflects‌ ‌the‌ ‌Emblem‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌collective‌ ‌representation‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌social‌ ‌mind.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nReligion,‌ ‌magic‌ ‌and‌ ‌science‌ ‌distinguished;‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nMeaning‌ ‌and‌ ‌Definition‌ ‌of‌ ‌Magic‌ ‌\n●James‌ ‌Frazer‌ ‌‌made‌ ‌a‌ ‌detailed‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌of‌ ‌magic‌ ‌and‌ ‌religion‌ ‌in‌ ‌his‌ ‌book‌ ‌‘Golden‌ ‌Bough’.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌believed‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌process‌ ‌of‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌knowledge‌ ‌and‌ ‌attempted‌ ‌to‌ ‌explain‌ ‌the‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nmagic,‌ ‌religion‌ ‌and‌ ‌science.‌ ‌ ‌\n●From‌ ‌his‌ ‌point‌ ‌of‌ ‌view,‌ ‌the‌ ‌stages‌ ‌of‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌civilization‌ ‌correspond‌ ‌to‌ ‌magic,‌ ‌religion‌ ‌and‌ ‌science.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌most‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌men‌ ‌explained‌ ‌and‌ ‌controlled‌ ‌natural‌ ‌happenings‌ ‌around‌ ‌human‌ ‌beings‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌help‌ ‌of‌ ‌magic‌ ‌and‌ ‌gradually‌ ‌came‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nreligion‌ ‌and‌ ‌science.‌ ‌Frazer‌ ‌categorized‌ ‌magic‌ ‌into‌ ‌–‌ ‌‌Homeopathic‌ ‌magic‌ ‌and‌ ‌Contagious‌ ‌magic‌.‌ ‌\n○Homeopathic‌ ‌magic:‌ ‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌is‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌principle‌ ‌of‌ ‌‘Law‌ ‌of‌ ‌similarity’‌ ‌i.e.‌ ‌like‌ ‌produces‌ ‌like.‌ ‌\n■For‌ ‌example,‌‌ ‌the‌ ‌Khond‌ ‌believes‌ ‌that‌ ‌for‌ ‌rain‌ ‌human‌ ‌sacrifices‌ ‌are‌ ‌essential.‌ ‌As‌ ‌the‌ ‌tear‌ ‌rolls‌ ‌down‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌sufferer’s‌ ‌eyes‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌blood‌ ‌comes‌ ‌out‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌wounds,‌ ‌the‌ ‌rain‌ ‌will‌ ‌come‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌similar‌ ‌way.‌ ‌ ‌\n585‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌causal‌ ‌connection‌ ‌between‌ ‌two‌ ‌events‌ ‌is‌ ‌sought‌ ‌but‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌established‌ ‌in‌ ‌an‌ ‌irrational‌ ‌and‌ ‌imaginary‌ ‌condition.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Effigy‌ ‌burning‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌a‌ ‌way‌ ‌to‌ ‌show‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌principle‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌pain‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌effigy‌ ‌is‌ ‌understand‌ ‌as‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌pain‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌real‌ ‌\nperson‌ ‌concerned.‌ ‌\n○Contagious‌ ‌magic:‌ ‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌is‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌‘Law‌ ‌of‌ ‌contact’.‌ ‌This‌ ‌implies‌ ‌if‌ ‌something‌ ‌is‌ ‌directly‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌person‌ ‌or‌ ‌an‌ ‌animal‌ ‌it‌ ‌becomes‌ ‌a‌ ‌\npart‌ ‌of‌ ‌him‌ ‌or‌ ‌it‌ ‌and‌ ‌that‌ ‌should‌ ‌not‌ ‌be‌ ‌visited‌ ‌by‌ ‌any‌ ‌other‌ ‌as‌ ‌it‌ ‌may‌ ‌cause‌ ‌harm‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌latter.‌ ‌ ‌\n■This‌ ‌association‌ ‌is‌ ‌extended‌ ‌to‌ ‌clothing,‌ ‌nail‌ ‌and‌ ‌hair-trimmings,‌ ‌utensils,‌ ‌personal‌ ‌effects‌ ‌and‌ ‌so‌ ‌on.‌ ‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌is‌ ‌for‌ ‌this‌ ‌reason‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌people‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌give‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌belongings‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌person‌ ‌after‌ ‌his‌ ‌death‌ ‌along‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌dead‌ ‌body.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Frazer‌‌ ‌opined‌ ‌that‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌magical‌ ‌rites‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌society‌ ‌are‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌these‌ ‌two‌ ‌principles.‌ ‌Frazer‌ ‌designated‌ ‌all‌ ‌these‌ ‌as‌ ‌\nsympathetic‌ ‌because‌ ‌to‌ ‌him‌ ‌the‌ ‌cause‌ ‌and‌ ‌effect‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌‘sympathetic‌ ‌relation’.‌ ‌\n●Bronislaw‌ ‌Kasper‌ ‌Malinowski‌,‌ ‌offered‌ ‌yet‌ ‌another‌ ‌definition‌ ‌of‌ ‌magic.‌ ‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌him,‌ ‌magic‌ ‌consists‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌superstitious‌ ‌acts‌ ‌and‌ ‌belief‌ ‌through‌ ‌which‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌try‌ ‌to‌ ‌control‌ ‌nature‌ ‌when‌ ‌their‌ ‌technology‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌rational‌ ‌techniques‌ ‌are‌ ‌insufficient.‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌him,‌ ‌magic‌ ‌comes‌ ‌into‌ ‌existence‌ ‌when‌ ‌people‌ ‌try‌ ‌to‌ ‌reduce‌ ‌their‌ ‌anxiety‌ ‌in‌ ‌uncertainty.‌ ‌\n○Both‌ ‌Frazer‌ ‌and‌ ‌Malinowski‌ ‌argued‌ ‌that‌ ‌magic‌ ‌is‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌science‌ ‌because‌ ‌it‌ ‌comes‌ ‌into‌ ‌existence‌ ‌when‌ ‌the‌ ‌rational‌ ‌techniques‌ ‌are‌ ‌\ninsufficient‌ ‌to‌ ‌control‌ ‌natural‌ ‌phenomena‌ ‌\n●Different‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌view‌ ‌magic‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌ways.‌ ‌Some‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌propositions‌ ‌regarding‌ ‌Magic‌ ‌are‌ ‌as‌ ‌follows.‌ ‌\n○“It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌strategy‌ ‌that‌ ‌people‌ ‌use‌ ‌to‌ ‌control‌ ‌supernatural‌ ‌power”‌ ‌\n○“It‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌attempt‌ ‌to‌ ‌manipulate‌ ‌the‌ ‌forces‌ ‌of‌ ‌nature‌ ‌to‌ ‌derive‌ ‌certain‌ ‌desired‌ ‌results”‌ ‌\n○“It‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌rituals‌ ‌to‌ ‌direct‌ ‌and‌ ‌control‌ ‌supernatural‌ ‌forces”‌ ‌\n○“It‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌control‌ ‌of‌ ‌supernatural‌ ‌forces‌ ‌by‌ ‌means‌ ‌of‌ ‌compulsive‌ ‌formulae”‌ ‌\n○“It‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌attempt‌ ‌to‌ ‌mechanistically‌ ‌control‌ ‌supernatural‌ ‌forces”‌ ‌\n●Majority‌ ‌of‌ ‌definitions‌ ‌of‌ ‌magic‌ ‌emphasise‌ ‌that‌ ‌magic‌ ‌is‌ ‌belief‌ ‌and‌ ‌practice‌ ‌meant‌ ‌for‌ ‌controlling‌ ‌the‌ ‌supernatural‌ ‌forces.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌Kerala,‌ ‌magical‌ ‌practices‌ ‌were‌ ‌adopted‌ ‌to‌ ‌prevent‌ ‌some‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌diseases;effigies‌ ‌(Nokkukuthi)‌ ‌were‌ ‌erected‌ ‌to‌ ‌prevent‌ ‌evil‌ ‌eyes‌ ‌and‌ ‌evil‌ ‌\ntongue.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Moreover,‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌other‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌magical‌ ‌preventive‌ ‌practices‌ ‌and‌ ‌measures‌ ‌like‌ ‌tying‌ ‌of‌ ‌‘magical‌ ‌thread’‌ ‌(manthra‌ ‌charadu),‌ ‌‘magical‌ ‌\namulet’‌ ‌(Urukku)‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Apart‌ ‌from‌ ‌these,‌ ‌certain‌ ‌food,‌ ‌sugar,‌ ‌chilli,‌ ‌lemon,‌ ‌turmeric,‌ ‌water‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌are‌ ‌also‌ ‌used‌ ‌with‌ ‌magical‌ ‌spells‌ ‌for‌ ‌curing‌ ‌diseases.‌ ‌\n●Controlling‌ ‌supernatural‌ ‌power‌ ‌requires‌ ‌different‌ ‌formulas‌ ‌and‌ ‌practices.‌ ‌\n●Performance‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌is‌ ‌done‌ ‌by‌ ‌expert‌ ‌specialists‌ ‌to‌ ‌achieve‌ ‌desired‌ ‌results.‌ ‌Thus,‌ ‌as‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌case‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion,‌ ‌magic‌ ‌also‌ ‌includes‌ ‌different‌ ‌\nelements‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌fulfillment‌ ‌of‌ ‌its‌ ‌function.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nElements‌ ‌of‌ ‌Magic‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌Raymond‌ ‌Firth‌ ‌,‌ ‌magic‌ ‌involves‌ ‌three‌ ‌elements:‌ ‌\n586‌ ‌\n(i)‌ ‌‌The‌ ‌practitioner‌ ‌\n●Raymond‌ ‌Firth‌ ‌says‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌practitioner‌ ‌of‌ ‌magic‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌oneself‌ ‌or‌ ‌a‌ ‌specialist‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌shaman,‌ ‌a‌ ‌magician‌ ‌or‌ ‌a‌ ‌\npriest.‌ ‌\n ‌\n(ii)‌ ‌‌The‌ ‌practical‌ ‌aim‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌practical‌ ‌aim‌ ‌covers‌ ‌a‌ ‌wide‌ ‌range‌ ‌of‌ ‌objectives.‌ ‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌protective‌ ‌in‌ ‌nature‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌protecting‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌attack‌ ‌of‌ ‌animals,‌ ‌to‌ ‌protect‌ ‌crops,‌ ‌to‌ ‌cure‌ ‌from‌ ‌illness‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌Amulets,‌ ‌\n‘manthra‌ ‌charadu’‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌are‌ ‌some‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌protective‌ ‌magical‌ ‌instruments.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌objective‌ ‌of‌ ‌magic‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌productive‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌successful‌ ‌hunting,‌ ‌abundant‌ ‌crops,‌ ‌ample‌ ‌rain‌ ‌and‌ ‌love‌ ‌making.‌ ‌‘Sreechakram’,‌ ‌\n'sudarsana‌ ‌chakram'‌ ‌and‌ ‌'santhana‌ ‌gopala‌ ‌yanthram'.‌ ‌are‌ ‌some‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌instruments‌ ‌of‌ ‌productive‌ ‌magic.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Still‌ ‌other‌ ‌objectives‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌destructive‌ ‌because‌ ‌they‌ ‌include‌ ‌the‌ ‌desire‌ ‌to‌ ‌harm‌ ‌one’s‌ ‌enemy,‌ ‌loss‌ ‌of‌ ‌others‌ ‌crops‌ ‌and‌ ‌harm‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nothers’‌ ‌cattle.‌ ‌'Koodothram’practiced‌ ‌in‌ ‌‌Kerala‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌example‌ ‌of‌ ‌destructive‌ ‌magic‌.‌ ‌\n ‌\n(iii)‌ ‌The‌ ‌magical‌ ‌formula-‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌Raymond‌ ‌Firth‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌three‌ ‌aspects‌ ‌of‌ ‌magical‌ ‌formula:‌ ‌the‌ ‌things‌ ‌used‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌instruments‌ ‌or‌ ‌\nmedicines,‌ ‌‌the‌ ‌things‌ ‌done‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌rites,‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌things‌ ‌spoken‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌called‌ ‌spells‌.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌things‌ ‌used‌ ‌or‌ ‌medicines‌ ‌are‌ ‌of‌ ‌several‌ ‌types.‌ ‌The‌ ‌medicines‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌used‌ ‌for‌ ‌magic‌ ‌are‌ ‌difficult‌ ‌to‌ ‌prepare‌ ‌or‌ ‌obtain.‌ ‌\nIt‌ ‌is‌ ‌said‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌prepared‌ ‌from‌ ‌contact‌ ‌with‌ ‌supernatural‌ ‌beings.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌things‌ ‌done‌ ‌or‌ ‌the‌ ‌rites‌ ‌performed‌ ‌are‌ ‌either‌ ‌simple‌ ‌or‌ ‌complex.‌ ‌Magic‌ ‌may‌ ‌involve‌ ‌one‌ ‌rite‌ ‌or‌ ‌a‌ ‌series‌ ‌of‌ ‌rites.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌things‌ ‌spoken‌ ‌or‌ ‌spells‌ ‌consist‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌verbal‌ ‌aspects‌ ‌of‌ ‌magic.‌ ‌‌It‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌a‌ ‌series‌ ‌of‌ ‌words‌ ‌and‌ ‌phrases,‌ ‌or‌ ‌simply‌ ‌an‌ ‌\novert‌ ‌expression‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌practitioner’s‌ ‌desires.‌‌ ‌Malinowski‌ ‌says‌ ‌that‌ ‌spell‌ ‌is‌ ‌couched‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌specific‌ ‌language.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌secretive,‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nhence,‌ ‌the‌ ‌ordinary‌ ‌persons‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌understand‌ ‌the‌ ‌spells.‌ ‌\n ‌\nOther‌ ‌Classifications‌ ‌of‌ ‌Magic‌ ‌\n●Most‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌classify‌ ‌different‌ ‌magical‌ ‌practices‌ ‌into‌ ‌two‌ ‌distinct‌ ‌forms,‌ ‌namely‌ ‌‌Black‌ ‌magic‌ ‌and‌ ‌White‌ ‌magic‌.‌ ‌This‌ ‌classification‌ ‌is‌ ‌\nmade‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌ends‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌achieved.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Black‌ ‌Magic‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌magic‌ ‌to‌ ‌deliberately‌ ‌harm‌ ‌or‌ ‌destroy‌ ‌another‌ ‌person,‌ ‌group,‌ ‌community,‌ ‌cattle,‌ ‌crops,‌ ‌property‌ ‌or‌ ‌personal‌ ‌\nachievements‌ ‌is‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌black‌ ‌magic.‌ ‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌is‌ ‌malicious‌ ‌and‌ ‌anti-social.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Black‌ ‌magic‌ ‌is‌ ‌used‌ ‌for‌ ‌destructive‌ ‌purposes‌ ‌\n○White‌ ‌Magic‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌magic‌ ‌to‌ ‌do‌ ‌good‌ ‌to‌ ‌another‌ ‌person,‌ ‌group,‌ ‌community,‌ ‌cattle,‌ ‌crops,‌ ‌property‌ ‌or‌ ‌personal‌ ‌achievements‌ ‌is‌ ‌known‌ ‌\nas‌ ‌white‌ ‌magic.‌ ‌ ‌\n587‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌is‌ ‌beneficial‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual‌ ‌and‌ ‌society.‌ ‌It‌ ‌has‌ ‌social‌ ‌approval.white‌ ‌magic‌ ‌is‌ ‌used‌ ‌for‌ ‌productive‌ ‌and‌ ‌protective‌ ‌purposes.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Explaining‌ ‌the‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion,‌ ‌science‌ ‌and‌ ‌magic‌ ‌some‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌have‌ ‌presented‌ ‌functional‌ ‌theories.‌ ‌Of‌ ‌these‌ ‌the‌ ‌theories‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nMalinowski‌ ‌and‌ ‌Radcliffe‌ ‌Brown‌ ‌are‌ ‌worth‌ ‌mentioning.‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌‌Malinowski‌ ‌religion‌ ‌performs‌ ‌many‌ ‌important‌ ‌functions‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌economic‌ ‌field‌ ‌among‌ ‌tribes‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌example,‌ ‌one‌ ‌finds‌ ‌the‌ ‌fishing‌ ‌trade‌ ‌among‌ ‌Trobriand‌ ‌islanders.‌ ‌Most‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌magical‌ ‌and‌ ‌religious‌ ‌activities‌ ‌among‌ ‌them‌ ‌are‌ ‌\nconnected‌ ‌with‌ ‌this.‌ ‌\n○Their‌ ‌scientists‌ ‌are‌ ‌efficient‌ ‌in‌ ‌manufacturing‌ ‌arms,‌ ‌instruments‌ ‌and‌ ‌boats‌ ‌but‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌ebbs‌ ‌and‌ ‌tides‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌sea‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌fear‌ ‌\nleads‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌need‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion‌ ‌to‌ ‌maintain‌ ‌the‌ ‌mental‌ ‌balance.‌ ‌\n588‌ ‌\n●Thus‌ ‌religion‌ ‌also‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌instrument‌ ‌of‌ ‌adjustment.‌ ‌Its‌ ‌purpose‌ ‌is‌ ‌to‌ ‌save‌ ‌men’s‌ ‌minds‌ ‌from‌ ‌so‌ ‌many‌ ‌tensions.‌ ‌It‌ ‌makes‌ ‌for‌ ‌man’s‌ ‌adjustment‌ ‌\nwith‌ ‌supernatural‌ ‌powers‌ ‌which‌ ‌results‌ ‌in‌ ‌mental‌ ‌peace‌ ‌and‌ ‌tranquillity.‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌‌Radcliffe‌ ‌Brown‌‌ ‌the‌ ‌aim‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌only‌ ‌to‌ ‌free‌ ‌man‌ ‌from‌ ‌all‌ ‌kinds‌ ‌of‌ ‌fears‌ ‌and‌ ‌tensions‌ ‌but‌ ‌to‌ ‌create‌ ‌a‌ ‌consciousness‌ ‌of‌ ‌\ndepending‌ ‌upon‌ ‌supernatural‌ ‌powers.‌ ‌The‌ ‌existence‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌group‌ ‌is‌ ‌much‌ ‌more‌ ‌important‌ ‌than‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual‌ ‌and‌ ‌hence‌ ‌he‌ ‌has‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nmake‌ ‌sacrifices‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌group.‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌sense‌ ‌of‌ ‌duty‌ ‌and‌ ‌sacrifice‌ ‌is‌ ‌created‌ ‌by‌ ‌religion.‌ ‌On‌ ‌the‌ ‌one‌ ‌hand,‌ ‌religions‌ ‌makes‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual‌ ‌dependent‌ ‌upon‌ ‌the‌ ‌society,‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nother‌ ‌hand‌ ‌he‌ ‌teaches‌ ‌him‌ ‌to‌ ‌live‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌social‌ ‌norms.‌ ‌Thus‌ ‌religion‌ ‌helps‌ ‌in‌ ‌maintaining‌ ‌social‌ ‌life.‌ ‌ ‌\n●As‌ ‌D.N.‌ ‌Majumdar‌ ‌has‌ ‌pointed‌ ‌out,‌ ‌in‌ ‌fact‌ ‌the‌ ‌views‌ ‌of‌ ‌‌Malinowski‌ ‌and‌ ‌Radcliffe‌ ‌Brown‌ ‌‌are‌ ‌complementary‌ ‌since‌ ‌both‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nsociety‌ ‌are‌ ‌equally‌ ‌important‌ ‌and‌ ‌religion‌ ‌is‌ ‌equally‌ ‌useful‌ ‌for‌ ‌both.‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌‌Durkheim‌,‌ ‌religious‌ ‌conceptions‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌product‌ ‌of‌ ‌collective‌ ‌situations.‌ ‌\n●Religion‌ ‌gives‌ ‌priority‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌moral‌ ‌and‌ ‌physical‌ ‌status‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌collectivity‌ ‌over‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌includes‌ ‌beliefs‌ ‌and‌ ‌activities.‌ ‌Beliefs‌ ‌are‌ ‌its‌ ‌stable‌ ‌aspects‌ ‌while‌ ‌ritualism‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌dynamic‌ ‌aspect.‌ ‌ ‌\n●On‌ ‌religious‌ ‌occasions‌ ‌the‌ ‌beliefs‌ ‌are‌ ‌converted‌ ‌into‌ ‌activities.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌fact,‌ ‌not‌ ‌only‌ ‌religion,‌ ‌but‌ ‌even‌ ‌magic‌ ‌and‌ ‌science‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌means‌ ‌of‌ ‌adjustment‌ ‌of‌ ‌man‌ ‌with‌ ‌his‌ ‌environment.‌ ‌The‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌man‌ ‌takes‌ ‌\nrecourse‌ ‌to‌ ‌magic‌ ‌to‌ ‌use‌ ‌supernatural‌ ‌powers‌ ‌and‌ ‌uses‌ ‌religion‌ ‌also‌ ‌for‌ ‌precisely‌ ‌this‌ ‌purpose.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌civilized‌ ‌societies‌ ‌such‌ ‌functions‌ ‌are‌ ‌done‌ ‌by‌ ‌science.‌ ‌In‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌societies‌ ‌many‌ ‌activities‌ ‌connected‌ ‌with‌ ‌agriculture,‌ ‌animal‌ ‌husbandry‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌fishing‌ ‌require‌ ‌the‌ ‌help‌ ‌of‌ ‌science,‌ ‌religion‌ ‌and‌ ‌even‌ ‌magic‌.‌ ‌\n●On‌ ‌which‌ ‌occasion,‌ ‌which‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌is‌ ‌used,‌ ‌depends‌ ‌upon‌ ‌the‌ ‌beliefs‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual.‌ ‌Both‌ ‌magic‌ ‌and‌ ‌science‌ ‌depend‌ ‌upon‌ ‌mechanical‌ ‌\nactivities.‌ ‌But‌ ‌while‌ ‌science‌ ‌is‌ ‌concerned‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌natural‌ ‌world,‌ ‌magic‌ ‌is‌ ‌concerned‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌supernatural.‌ ‌\n●Similarly,‌ ‌magic‌ ‌and‌ ‌religion‌ ‌are‌ ‌also‌ ‌closely‌ ‌connected.‌ ‌Both‌ ‌create‌ ‌a‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌environment.‌ ‌Both‌ ‌give‌ ‌importance‌ ‌to‌ ‌rituals.‌ ‌Both‌ ‌are‌ ‌\nmeans‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌achievement‌ ‌of‌ ‌man’s‌ ‌purpose.‌ ‌But‌ ‌while‌ ‌religion‌ ‌explains‌ ‌things‌ ‌with‌ ‌reference‌ ‌to‌ ‌gods‌ ‌and‌ ‌goddesses,‌ ‌magic‌ ‌explains‌ ‌with‌ ‌\nreference‌ ‌to‌ ‌supernatural‌ ‌powers.‌ ‌\n ‌\nSimilarities‌ ‌between‌ ‌Religion‌ ‌and‌ ‌Magic‌ ‌\n●Religion‌ ‌is‌ ‌concerned‌ ‌with‌ ‌non-empirical‌ ‌aspects.‌ ‌It‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌be‌ ‌experimentally‌ ‌justified.‌ ‌\n●Magic‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌concerned‌ ‌with‌ ‌non-empirical‌ ‌aspects.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌beyond‌ ‌logic‌ ‌and‌ ‌experimentation.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌be‌ ‌proved‌ ‌through‌ ‌experiment.‌ ‌\n●Both‌ ‌Religion‌ ‌and‌ ‌magic‌ ‌are‌ ‌concerned‌ ‌with‌ ‌supernatural‌ ‌aspects.‌ ‌\n●Religion‌ ‌and‌ ‌magic‌ ‌involves‌ ‌many‌ ‌kinds‌ ‌of‌ ‌taboos‌ ‌and‌ ‌observances.‌ ‌\n●Religion‌ ‌symbolises‌ ‌ordinary‌ ‌objects‌ ‌and‌ ‌considers‌ ‌them‌ ‌having‌ ‌religious‌ ‌powers.‌ ‌\n●Likewise‌ ‌magic‌ ‌manipulates‌ ‌with‌ ‌ordinary‌ ‌objects‌ ‌and‌ ‌considers‌ ‌them‌ ‌with‌ ‌magical‌ ‌powers.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌functions‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion‌ ‌and‌ ‌magic‌ ‌reduce‌ ‌emotional‌ ‌stresses.‌ ‌\n ‌\nSimilarities‌ ‌between‌ ‌Magic‌ ‌and‌ ‌Science‌ ‌\n589‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌early‌ ‌and‌ ‌later‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌like‌ ‌‌Tylor,‌ ‌Frazer,‌ ‌Malinowski‌ ‌‌and‌ ‌others‌ ‌delineated‌ ‌fundamental‌ ‌similarities‌ ‌between‌ ‌magic‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nscience.‌ ‌\n●Science‌ ‌is‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌principle‌ ‌that‌ ‌certain‌ ‌causes‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌result‌ ‌of‌ ‌certain‌ ‌effects.‌ ‌\n●Magic‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌cause‌ ‌and‌ ‌effect‌ ‌relations‌ ‌or‌ ‌causations.‌ ‌\n●Both‌ ‌science‌ ‌and‌ ‌magic‌ ‌are‌ ‌governed‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌body‌ ‌of‌ ‌principles,‌ ‌specifying‌ ‌how‌ ‌one‌ ‌has‌ ‌to‌ ‌proceed‌ ‌to‌ ‌get‌ ‌the‌ ‌desired‌ ‌results.‌ ‌\n●Science‌ ‌and‌ ‌magic‌ ‌are‌ ‌oriented‌ ‌towards‌ ‌desired‌ ‌goals.‌ ‌\n ‌\nDifferences‌ ‌between‌ ‌Religion‌ ‌and‌ ‌Magic‌ ‌\n●Religion‌ ‌and‌ ‌magic‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌two‌ ‌basic‌ ‌techniques‌ ‌of‌ ‌dealing‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌supernatural.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Religion‌ ‌seeks‌ ‌spiritual‌ ‌rapport‌ ‌or‌ ‌is‌ ‌subordinate‌ ‌to‌ ‌animistic‌ ‌beings.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Magic‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌technique‌ ‌which‌ ‌gains‌ ‌control‌ ‌over‌ ‌supernatural‌ ‌powers.‌ ‌Some‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌differences‌ ‌between‌ ‌religion‌ ‌and‌ ‌magic‌ ‌are‌ ‌given‌ ‌below:‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n590‌ ‌\nDifferences‌ ‌between‌ ‌Religion‌ ‌and‌ ‌Science:‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nDifferences‌ ‌between‌ ‌Science‌ ‌and‌ ‌Magic‌ ‌\n●Both‌ ‌science‌ ‌and‌ ‌magic‌ ‌depend‌ ‌upon‌ ‌mechanistic‌ ‌procedures.‌ ‌However,‌ ‌while‌ ‌the‌ ‌former‌ ‌deals‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌natural‌ ‌world,‌ ‌the‌ ‌latter‌ ‌deals‌ ‌with‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌supernatural.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Some‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌differences‌ ‌between‌ ‌Science‌ ‌and‌ ‌Magic‌ ‌are‌ ‌given‌ ‌below:‌ ‌\n591‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nMagico-religious‌ ‌functionaries‌ ‌(priest,‌ ‌shaman,‌ ‌medicine‌ ‌man,‌ ‌sorcerer‌ ‌and‌ ‌witch).‌ ‌\nResearchers‌ ‌suggest‌ ‌four‌ ‌main‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌practitioner‌ ‌which‌ ‌are:‌ ‌\n●Shamans‌ ‌\n●Sorcerer‌ ‌and‌ ‌Witches‌ ‌\n●Priest‌ ‌\n ‌\nShamans‌ ‌\n●Usually‌ ‌a‌ ‌part‌ ‌time‌ ‌specialist‌ ‌having‌ ‌high‌ ‌status‌ ‌in‌ ‌his‌ ‌community‌ ‌and‌ ‌involve‌ ‌healing.‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌enter‌ ‌into‌ ‌a‌ ‌trace‌ ‌to‌ ‌get‌ ‌help‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌Guardian‌ ‌or‌ ‌spirit.‌ ‌shamans‌ ‌interact‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌people‌ ‌and‌ ‌seek‌ ‌to‌ ‌solve‌ ‌their‌ ‌practical‌ ‌problems‌ ‌\nin‌ ‌life‌ ‌like‌ ‌availability‌ ‌of‌ ‌food,‌ ‌health‌ ‌issues,‌ ‌rainfall,‌ ‌drought‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n592‌ ‌\n●Sharman‌ ‌also‌ ‌sometimes‌ ‌brings‌ ‌news‌ ‌or‌ ‌warns‌ ‌people‌ ‌of‌ ‌upcoming‌ ‌disaster.‌ ‌\n●Sharman‌ ‌is‌ ‌thought‌ ‌to‌ ‌have‌ ‌supernatural‌ ‌power‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌virtue‌ ‌of‌ ‌birth‌ ‌training‌ ‌on‌ ‌inspiration.‌ ‌\n●Training‌ ‌can‌ ‌take‌ ‌several‌ ‌years‌ ‌under‌ ‌the‌ ‌guidance‌ ‌of‌ ‌Mater‌ ‌Shaman.‌ ‌\n●Example:‌ ‌ ‌is‌ ‌practiced‌ ‌in‌ ‌some‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌Korea,‌ ‌Rekha‌ ‌America‌ ‌\n ‌\nSorcerer‌ ‌and‌ ‌Witches‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌have‌ ‌low‌ ‌social‌ ‌and‌ ‌economic‌ ‌status‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌societies‌ ‌both‌ ‌sexes‌ ‌are‌ ‌involved‌ ‌in‌ ‌practicing‌ ‌sorcery‌ ‌and‌ ‌witchcraft.‌ ‌\n●Sorcery‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌performance‌ ‌of‌ ‌certain‌ ‌magical‌ ‌rights‌ ‌practice‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌purpose‌ ‌of‌ ‌harming‌ ‌other.‌ ‌\n●With‌ ‌the‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌certain‌ ‌object‌ ‌witchcraft‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌involved‌ ‌involuntary‌ ‌and‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌unconscious‌ ‌capacity‌ ‌to‌ ‌cause‌ ‌harm‌ ‌to‌ ‌other‌ ‌people.‌ ‌\n●Suspected‌ ‌and‌ ‌witches‌ ‌are‌ ‌feared‌ ‌as‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌thought‌ ‌to‌ ‌no‌ ‌how‌ ‌to‌ ‌invoke‌ ‌supernatural‌ ‌to‌ ‌cause‌ ‌bad,‌ ‌illness‌ ‌injury‌ ‌and‌ ‌death.‌ ‌\n●Witchcraft‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌inborn‌ ‌and‌ ‌often‌ ‌an‌ ‌unconscious‌ ‌capacity‌ ‌to‌ ‌work‌ ‌evil.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌person‌ ‌who‌ ‌performs‌ ‌witchcraft‌ ‌is‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌witch.‌ ‌Witches‌ ‌are‌ ‌humans‌ ‌with‌ ‌supernatural‌ ‌powers.‌ ‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌are‌ ‌born‌ ‌with‌ ‌such‌ ‌powers.‌ ‌Like‌ ‌sorcery,‌ ‌witchcraft‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌attempt‌ ‌to‌ ‌harm‌ ‌others‌ ‌through‌ ‌supernatural‌ ‌means.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Witchcraft‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌quality‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual.‌ ‌Sorcery‌ ‌is‌ ‌acquired,‌ ‌but‌ ‌witchcraft‌ ‌is‌ ‌inherited.‌ ‌Witches‌ ‌are‌ ‌distinguished‌ ‌from‌ ‌sorcerers‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌power‌ ‌and‌ ‌its‌ ‌origin.‌ ‌\n(WITCHCRAFT‌ ‌BANNED‌ ‌FROM‌ ‌AFRICAN‌ ‌FOOTBALL‌ ‌MATCHES)‌ ‌\n ‌\nPriest‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌are‌ ‌generally‌ ‌full‌ ‌time‌ ‌male‌ ‌specialists,‌ ‌who‌ ‌officiate‌ ‌public‌ ‌events‌ ‌and‌ ‌are‌ ‌of‌ ‌very‌ ‌high‌ ‌status.‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌have‌ ‌the‌ ‌ability‌ ‌to‌ ‌relate‌ ‌to‌ ‌superior‌ ‌or‌ ‌high‌ ‌gods‌ ‌who‌ ‌are‌ ‌beyond‌ ‌the‌ ‌ordinary‌ ‌person's‌ ‌control.‌ ‌\n●Either‌ ‌through‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌for‌ ‌political‌ ‌appointment‌ ‌priests‌ ‌is‌ ‌decided.‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌are‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌attire‌ ‌,‌ ‌clothing‌ ‌and‌ ‌hairstyle.‌ ‌\n●Their‌ ‌training‌ ‌is‌ ‌vigorous,‌ ‌Long‌ ‌and‌ ‌include‌ ‌praying,‌ ‌physical‌ ‌labour‌ ‌learning‌ ‌the‌ ‌dogma‌ ‌rituals‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌religion‌ ‌like‌ ‌Mantra,‌ ‌slokas,‌ ‌bible,‌ ‌\nquran‌.‌ ‌\n●Priest‌ ‌is‌ ‌supported‌ ‌by‌ ‌donation,‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌get‌ ‌fee‌ ‌for‌ ‌his‌ ‌services‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n593‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n6.‌ ‌Anthropological‌ ‌theories‌ ‌:‌ ‌(a)‌ ‌Classical‌ ‌evolutionism‌ ‌(Tylor,‌ ‌Morgan‌ ‌and‌ ‌Frazer),‌ ‌(f)‌ ‌Neo-evolutionism‌ ‌(Childe,‌ ‌White,‌ ‌Steward,‌ ‌Sahlins‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌Service)-Part-I‌ ‌\n ‌\nIntroduction‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌origin‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropological‌ ‌thought‌ ‌could‌ ‌be‌ ‌‌traced‌ ‌back‌ ‌to‌ ‌early‌ ‌Greek‌ ‌philosophers‌ ‌like‌ ‌Herodotus‌ ‌and‌ ‌Aristotle.‌ ‌\n●However,it‌ ‌emerged‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌separate‌ ‌branch‌ ‌of‌ ‌knowledge‌ ‌during‌ ‌the‌ ‌19th‌ ‌century‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌path‌ ‌breaking‌ ‌theories‌ ‌on‌ ‌biological‌ ‌and‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌\nevolution.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌this‌ ‌regard,‌ ‌the‌ ‌contribution‌ ‌of‌ ‌‌Charles‌ ‌Darwin,‌ ‌E.B.‌ ‌Tylor,‌ ‌LH‌ ‌Morgan‌‌ ‌worth‌ ‌mentioning.‌ ‌\n●Later,‌ ‌other‌ ‌pioneering‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌like‌ ‌‌Franz‌ ‌Boas,‌ ‌WHR‌ ‌River,‌ ‌Malinowaski,‌ ‌Red‌ ‌Cliff‌ ‌Brown,‌ ‌Levis‌ ‌Strauss,‌ ‌Ruth‌ ‌Benedict,‌ ‌\nMargaret‌ ‌Mead‌ ‌‌and‌ ‌several‌ ‌others‌ ‌had‌ ‌significantly‌ ‌contributed‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌Society.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌early‌ ‌anthropological‌ ‌theories‌ ‌develop‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌Society.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌early‌ ‌and‌ ‌political‌ ‌theories‌ ‌developed‌ ‌since‌ ‌the‌ ‌latter‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌19th‌ ‌Century‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌grouped‌ ‌under‌ ‌the‌ ‌following‌ ‌School:‌ ‌\n○Evolutionism‌ ‌\n○Diffusionism‌ ‌\n○Functionalism‌ ‌\n○Structural‌ ‌functionalism‌ ‌\n○Structuralism‌ ‌\n○Culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌personality‌ ‌School‌ ‌of‌ ‌thought‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nWhy‌ ‌Study‌ ‌Anthropological‌ ‌Theories?‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Zero‌ ‌was‌ ‌invented‌ ‌in‌ ‌India‌ ‌and‌ ‌Babylonia‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌time‌ ‌\n●William‌ ‌Ogburn‌ ‌and‌ ‌Dorothy‌ ‌Thomas,‌ ‌in‌ ‌1922,‌ ‌listed‌ ‌a‌ ‌hundred‌ ‌and‌ ‌forty-eight‌ ‌major‌ ‌such‌ ‌simultaneous‌ ‌inventions.‌ ‌Look‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nexcerpts‌ ‌from‌ ‌www.newyorker.com‌ ‌magazine‌ ‌issued‌ ‌on‌ ‌2008/05/12/‌ ‌about‌ ‌some‌ ‌such‌ ‌simultaneous‌ ‌inventions.‌ ‌\n●Here‌ ‌are‌ ‌a‌ ‌few‌ ‌more‌ ‌examples‌.‌ ‌\n○Newton‌ ‌and‌ ‌Leibniz‌ ‌both‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌calculus.‌ ‌\n○Charles‌ ‌Darwin‌ ‌and‌ ‌Alfred‌ ‌Russell‌ ‌Wallace‌ ‌both‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌evolution.‌ ‌\n○Colour‌ ‌photography‌ ‌was‌ ‌invented‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌time‌ ‌by‌ ‌Charles‌ ‌Cros‌ ‌and‌ ‌by‌ ‌Louis‌ ‌Ducos‌ ‌du‌ ‌Hauron,‌ ‌in‌ ‌France.‌ ‌\n○There‌ ‌seem‌ ‌to‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌at‌ ‌least‌ ‌six‌ ‌different‌ ‌inventors‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌thermometer.‌ ‌\n594‌ ‌\n○There‌ ‌were‌ ‌less‌ ‌than‌ ‌nine‌ ‌claimants‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌invention‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌telescope.‌ ‌\n○Typewriting‌ ‌machines‌ ‌were‌ ‌invented‌ ‌simultaneously‌ ‌in‌ ‌England‌ ‌and‌ ‌in‌ ‌America‌ ‌by‌ ‌several‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌in‌ ‌these‌ ‌countries.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌steamboat‌ ‌is‌ ‌claimed‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌“exclusive”‌ ‌discovery‌ ‌of‌ ‌Fulton,‌ ‌Jouffroy,‌ ‌Rumsey,‌ ‌Stevens‌ ‌and‌ ‌Symmington.‌ ‌\n●How‌ ‌does‌ ‌it‌ ‌happen?‌ ‌How‌ ‌did‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌view‌ ‌such‌ ‌phenomenon?‌ ‌‌Early‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌were‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌view‌ ‌that‌ ‌human‌ ‌beings‌ ‌\nall‌ ‌over‌ ‌the‌ ‌world‌ ‌shared‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌basic‌ ‌psychological‌ ‌and‌ ‌cognitive‌ ‌makeup.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌hypothesis‌ ‌was‌ ‌originally‌ ‌formulated‌ ‌by‌ ‌‌Adolf‌ ‌Bastian‌,‌ ‌the‌ ‌father‌ ‌of‌ ‌German‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌and‌ ‌German‌ ‌classical‌ ‌\nevolutionist.‌ ‌ ‌\n○He‌ ‌then‌ ‌passed‌ ‌on‌ ‌this‌ ‌postulate‌ ‌to‌ ‌Franz‌ ‌Boas‌ ‌who‌ ‌in‌ ‌turn,‌ ‌transmitted‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌to‌ ‌all‌ ‌his‌ ‌students.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌principle‌ ‌formed‌ ‌the‌ ‌foundation‌ ‌of‌ ‌19th‌ ‌century‌ ‌evolutionism.‌ ‌It‌ ‌has‌ ‌taken‌ ‌into‌ ‌account‌ ‌the‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌differences.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌psychic‌ ‌unity‌ ‌of‌ ‌humankind‌ ‌has‌ ‌influenced‌ ‌later‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌including‌ ‌Radcliffe‌ ‌Brown‌ ‌and‌ ‌Julian‌ ‌Steward.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌has‌ ‌even‌ ‌laid‌ ‌the‌ ‌foundation‌ ‌for‌ ‌what‌ ‌had‌ ‌later‌ ‌come‌ ‌to‌ ‌know‌ ‌as‌ ‌diffusionism‌ ‌in‌ ‌Anthropology.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Diffusionism‌‌ ‌holds‌ ‌the‌ ‌view‌ ‌that‌ ‌culture‌ ‌traits‌ ‌originate‌ ‌at‌ ‌one‌ ‌place‌ ‌and‌ ‌spread‌ ‌to‌ ‌other‌ ‌places‌ ‌and‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Cultural‌ ‌evolutionists‌ ‌and‌ ‌diffusionists‌ ‌differ‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌independent‌ ‌inventions‌ ‌and‌ ‌spread‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌respectively.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nIt‌ ‌shows,‌ ‌studies‌ ‌among‌ ‌other‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌all‌ ‌over‌ ‌the‌ ‌globe‌ ‌undertaken‌ ‌by‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌have‌ ‌resulted‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌formulation‌ ‌of‌ ‌\ndifferent‌ ‌perspectives‌ ‌and‌ ‌understandings‌ ‌over‌ ‌time.‌ ‌These‌ ‌different‌ ‌perspectives‌ ‌are‌ ‌examined‌ ‌in‌ ‌Anthropological‌ ‌Theories.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n(a)‌ ‌Classical‌ ‌evolutionism‌ ‌(Tylor,‌ ‌Morgan‌ ‌and‌ ‌Frazer)‌ ‌\nIntroduction:‌ ‌\n●Evolution‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌gradual‌ ‌occurring‌ ‌slow‌ ‌process‌ ‌And‌ ‌imperceptible‌ ‌i.e.‌ ‌too‌ ‌small‌ ‌to‌ ‌see.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Evolution‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌idea‌ ‌of‌ ‌time.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌vertical‌ ‌in‌ ‌approach,‌ ‌Theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌by‌ ‌‌Charles‌ ‌Darwin‌‌ ‌In‌ ‌his‌ ‌book‌ ‌‘‌Origin‌ ‌of‌ ‌species.’‌ ‌\nDefinition:‌ ‌\n●Herbert‌ ‌Spencer‌‌ ‌and‌ ‌English‌ ‌philosopher‌ ‌and‌ ‌contemporary‌ ‌of‌ ‌Darwin‌ ‌authored‌ ‌the‌ ‌principle‌ ‌of‌ ‌sociology.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌which‌ ‌he‌ ‌defined‌ ‌‌evolution‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌change‌ ‌from‌ ‌a‌ ‌definite,‌ ‌covalent‌ ‌homogeneity‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌definite‌ ‌and‌ ‌coherence‌ ‌homogeneity‌ ‌through‌ ‌\ncontinuous‌ ‌differentiation‌ ‌and‌ ‌integration.‌ ‌\n●Cultural‌ ‌evolution‌-It‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌defined‌ ‌as‌ ‌‌the‌ ‌process‌ ‌by‌ ‌which‌ ‌different‌ ‌successive‌ ‌forms‌ ‌in‌ ‌socio‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌or‌ ‌culture‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nhumankind‌ ‌are‌ ‌developed‌ ‌over‌ ‌different‌ ‌periods‌ ‌of‌ ‌time.‌ ‌\n ‌\nFor‌ ‌systematic‌ ‌discussion‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌views‌ ‌and‌ ‌contribution‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌evolutionists‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌classified‌ ‌at‌ ‌two‌ ‌level:‌ ‌ ‌\n1.Classical‌ ‌evolutionist‌ ‌\n2.Neo‌ ‌evolutionist‌ ‌\nSecondly,‌ ‌on‌ ‌nationality‌ ‌of‌ ‌proponents‌ ‌evolutionism‌ ‌is‌ ‌divided‌ ‌into:‌ ‌\n1. ‌‌British,‌ ‌American‌ ‌and‌ ‌German-‌ ‌Classical‌ ‌evolutionist‌ ‌\n2. ‌British‌ ‌and‌ ‌American-‌ ‌Neo-evolutionist‌ ‌\n595‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nClassical‌ ‌Evolutionism‌ ‌\n596‌ ‌\n ‌\n●The‌ ‌proponents‌ ‌of‌ ‌classical‌ ‌evolutionism‌ ‌are‌ ‌EB‌ ‌Tylor,‌ ‌James‌ ‌Frazer,‌ ‌RR‌ ‌Marett,‌ ‌Morgan,‌ ‌bachofen‌ ‌Adolf‌ ‌bastien.‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌are‌ ‌also‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌‌unilinear‌ ‌evolutionism‌ ‌‌as‌ ‌they‌ ‌believe‌ ‌that‌ ‌human‌ ‌culture‌ ‌evolved‌ ‌in‌ ‌unilinear‌ ‌sequence,‌ ‌State‌ ‌after‌ ‌state‌ ‌simple‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌complex.‌ ‌\n597‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌unilinear‌ ‌evolutionism,‌ ‌‌culture‌ ‌of‌ ‌mankind‌ ‌was‌ ‌developed‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌earliest‌ ‌stage‌ ‌of‌ ‌savagery‌ ‌to‌ ‌barbarism‌ ‌and‌ ‌finally‌ ‌to‌ ‌\ncivilization.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌Addition:‌ ‌\nUnilineal‌ ‌Evolutionism‌ ‌\n●Unilineal‌ ‌evolution,‌ ‌also‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to‌ ‌as‌ ‌classical‌ ‌social‌ ‌evolution,‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌19th-century‌ ‌social‌ ‌theory‌ ‌about‌ ‌the‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌societies‌ ‌and‌ ‌\ncultures.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌was‌ ‌composed‌ ‌of‌ ‌many‌ ‌competing‌ ‌theories‌ ‌by‌ ‌various‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌and‌ ‌sociologists,‌ ‌who‌ ‌believed‌ ‌that‌ ‌Western‌ ‌culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌\ncontemporary‌ ‌pinnacle‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌evolution.‌ ‌\nUnilineal‌ ‌Theory‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌the‌ ‌19th‌ ‌century‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌was‌ ‌thought‌ ‌to‌ ‌follow‌ ‌a‌ ‌unilineal‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌whereby‌ ‌all‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌progressively‌ ‌develop‌ ‌over‌ ‌time.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌underlying‌ ‌assumption‌ ‌was‌ ‌that‌ ‌Cultural‌ ‌Evolution‌ ‌itself‌ ‌led‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌growth‌ ‌and‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌civilization.‌ ‌\n●Thomas‌ ‌Hobbes‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌17th‌ ‌Century‌ ‌declared‌ ‌indigenous‌ ‌culture‌ ‌to‌ ‌have‌ ‌\"no‌ ‌arts,‌ ‌no‌ ‌letters,‌ ‌no‌ ‌society\"‌ ‌and‌ ‌he‌ ‌described‌ ‌facing‌ ‌life‌ ‌as‌ ‌\n\"solitary,‌ ‌poor,‌ ‌nasty,‌ ‌brutish,‌ ‌and‌ ‌short.\"‌ ‌ ‌\n●He,‌ ‌like‌ ‌other‌ ‌scholars‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌time,‌ ‌reasoned‌ ‌that‌ ‌everything‌ ‌positive‌ ‌and‌ ‌esteemed‌ ‌resulted‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌slow‌ ‌development‌ ‌away‌ ‌from‌ ‌this‌ ‌\npoor‌ ‌lowly‌ ‌state‌ ‌of‌ ‌being.‌ ‌\n●Under‌ ‌the‌ ‌theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌unilineal‌ ‌Cultural‌ ‌Evolution,‌ ‌all‌ ‌societies‌ ‌and‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌develop‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌path.‌ ‌ ‌\n598‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌first‌ ‌to‌ ‌present‌ ‌a‌ ‌general‌ ‌unilineal‌ ‌theory‌ ‌was‌ ‌‌Herbert‌ ‌Spencer‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Spencer‌ ‌suggested‌ ‌that‌ ‌humans‌ ‌develop‌ ‌into‌ ‌more‌ ‌complex‌ ‌beings‌ ‌as‌ ‌culture‌ ‌progresses,‌ ‌where‌ ‌people‌ ‌originally‌ ‌lived‌ ‌in‌ ‌\n\"undifferentiated‌ ‌hordes\"‌ ‌culture‌ ‌progresses‌ ‌and‌ ‌develops‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌point‌ ‌where‌ ‌civilization‌ ‌develops‌ ‌hierarchies.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌concept‌ ‌behind‌ ‌unilineal‌ ‌theory‌ ‌is‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌steady‌ ‌accumulation‌ ‌of‌ ‌knowledge‌ ‌and‌ ‌culture‌ ‌leads‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌separation‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌various‌ ‌\nmodern‌ ‌day‌ ‌sciences‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌build-‌ ‌up‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌norms‌ ‌present‌ ‌in‌ ‌modern-day‌ ‌society‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Evolution‌ ‌must‌ ‌assume‌ ‌that‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌parallel‌ ‌or‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌similarity‌ ‌come‌ ‌into‌ ‌existence‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌psychic‌ ‌unity‌ ‌of‌ ‌humankind,‌ ‌suggesting‌ ‌that‌ ‌\nhuman‌ ‌minds‌ ‌share‌ ‌similar‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌all‌ ‌over‌ ‌the‌ ‌world‌ ‌and‌ ‌every‌ ‌act‌ ‌and‌ ‌think‌ ‌in‌ ‌similar‌ ‌ways‌ ‌in‌ ‌similar‌ ‌environmental‌ ‌conditions.‌ ‌\n○According‌ ‌to‌ ‌this‌ ‌principle,‌ ‌human‌ ‌beings‌ ‌belong‌ ‌to‌ ‌different‌ ‌cultures;‌ ‌they‌ ‌think‌ ‌similarly‌ ‌under‌ ‌similar‌ ‌circumstances‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nconditions.‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌the‌ ‌desert,‌ ‌coastal‌ ‌areas‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌the‌ ‌people‌ ‌may‌ ‌think‌ ‌similarly‌ ‌even‌ ‌don't‌ ‌know‌ ‌historical‌ ‌relations.‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌ability‌ ‌to‌ ‌uninvent,‌ ‌independently‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌psychic‌ ‌unity‌ ‌of‌ ‌mankind.‌ ‌\n●That‌ ‌means‌ ‌all‌ ‌people‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌corresponding‌ ‌societies‌ ‌Go‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌process‌ ‌of‌ ‌development.‌ ‌ ‌\n●As‌ ‌pointed‌ ‌before‌ ‌the‌ ‌invention‌ ‌of‌ ‌‌zero‌ ‌simultaneously‌ ‌in‌ ‌India,‌ ‌BabyLeon‌ ‌and‌ ‌Mayan‌ ‌culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌cited‌ ‌as‌ ‌‌an‌ ‌example‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌psychic‌ ‌unity‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌humankind.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nFeatures‌ ‌of‌ ‌Classical‌ ‌Evolutionism‌ ‌\n●Human‌ ‌culture‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌whole‌ ‌of‌ ‌socio‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌is‌ ‌involved‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌‌unilineal‌ ‌sequence‌ ‌stage‌ ‌after‌ ‌stage-‌ ‌savagery‌ ‌to‌ ‌barbarism‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nfinally‌ ‌to‌ ‌civilization.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌direction‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌is‌ ‌from‌ ‌simple‌ ‌to‌ ‌complex,‌ ‌similarities‌ ‌and‌ ‌dissimilarities‌ ‌from‌ ‌indefinite‌ ‌to‌ ‌definite‌ ‌and‌ ‌from‌ ‌homogeneity‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌heterogeneity.‌ ‌\n●Different‌ ‌stages‌ ‌of‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌established‌ ‌by‌ ‌historical‌ ‌method‌ ‌and‌ ‌comparative‌ ‌method.‌ ‌\n●Similarities‌ ‌in‌ ‌culture‌ ‌or‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌trait‌ ‌are‌ ‌caused‌ ‌by‌ ‌psychic‌ ‌unity‌ ‌of‌ ‌humankind‌ ‌and‌ ‌parallel‌ ‌invention.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌highest‌ ‌age‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture,‌ ‌certain‌ ‌remains‌ ‌of‌ ‌earlier‌ ‌stages‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌traced,‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌termed‌ ‌as‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌survival.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Such‌ ‌remains‌ ‌revealed‌ ‌the‌ ‌condition‌ ‌about‌ ‌the‌ ‌earliest‌ ‌stage‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n599‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nMain‌ ‌Proponents:‌ ‌\nBritish‌ ‌\nE.B.‌ ‌Tylor‌ ‌(1832-1917)‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nAbout:Edward‌ ‌Burnett‌ ‌Tylor‌ ‌\n600‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Sir‌ ‌Edward‌ ‌Burnett‌ ‌Tylor‌ ‌was‌ ‌an‌ ‌English‌ ‌anthropologist,‌ ‌the‌ ‌founder‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌anthropology.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Tylor's‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌typify‌ ‌19th-century‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌evolutionism.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌his‌ ‌works‌ ‌Primitive‌ ‌Culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌Anthropology,‌ ‌he‌ ‌defined‌ ‌the‌ ‌context‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌scientific‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropology,‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌\ntheories‌ ‌of‌ ‌Charles‌ ‌Lyell.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●He‌ ‌talked‌ ‌about‌‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌growth.‌‌ ‌Hence,‌ ‌he‌ ‌was‌ ‌called‌ ‌as‌ ‌‌unilinear‌ ‌evolutionism.‌ ‌\n●Unilinear‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌means‌ ‌for‌ ‌human‌ ‌culture‌ ‌evolved‌ ‌in‌ ‌unilinear‌ ‌sequence,‌ ‌stage‌ ‌after‌ ‌stage,simple‌ ‌to‌ ‌complex.‌ ‌\n●Human‌ ‌culture‌ ‌has‌ ‌developed‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌stage‌ ‌of‌ ‌savagery‌ ‌to‌ ‌barbarism‌ ‌and‌ ‌finally‌ ‌to‌ ‌civilization.‌ ‌\n●Taylor‌ ‌is‌ ‌called‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌father‌ ‌of‌ ‌modern‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌for‌ ‌his‌ ‌contribution‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌He‌ ‌gave‌ ‌the‌ ‌classical‌ ‌definition‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌\nin‌ ‌his‌ ‌book‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌culture‌ ‌(1837).‌ ‌\n○Culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌that‌ ‌Complex‌ ‌whole‌ ‌which‌ ‌include‌ ‌knowledge,‌ ‌believe,‌ ‌art,‌ ‌morals,‌ ‌laws,‌ ‌custom‌ ‌and‌ ‌any‌ ‌other‌ ‌capabilities‌ ‌and‌ ‌habits‌ ‌\nacquired‌ ‌by‌ ‌men‌ ‌as‌ ‌member‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌basic‌ ‌idea‌ ‌underlying‌ ‌Tylor‌ ‌theory‌ ‌was‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌continuity‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌process‌ ‌of‌ ‌its‌ ‌development‌ ‌from‌ ‌previous‌ ‌stages‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nsucceeding‌ ‌state.‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌Taylor‌ ‌the‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌material‌ ‌culture‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌developed‌ ‌from‌ ‌stone‌ ‌age‌ ‌bronze‌ ‌age‌ ‌and‌ ‌finally‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌iron‌ ‌age‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n601‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Humanity‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌whole‌ ‌passed‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌process‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌from‌ ‌Primitive,‌ ‌Prehistoric‌ ‌stage‌ ‌to‌ ‌middle‌ ‌stage‌ ‌and‌ ‌finally‌ ‌to‌ ‌more‌ ‌\nadvanced‌ ‌and‌ ‌civilized‌ ‌state,‌ ‌which‌ ‌has‌ ‌now‌ ‌been‌ ‌attained‌ ‌in‌ ‌our‌ ‌world.‌ ‌\n●Tylor‌ ‌opined‌ ‌that‌ ‌animism,(belief‌ ‌in‌ ‌soul)‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌earliest‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion‌ ‌from‌ ‌which‌ ‌politicians‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌present‌ ‌state‌ ‌of‌ ‌monotheism‌ ‌have‌ ‌\ndeveloped.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nMethodology‌ ‌of‌ ‌Tylor‌ ‌\n●Tylor‌ ‌developed‌ ‌his‌ ‌theory‌ ‌by‌ ‌formulating‌ ‌data‌ ‌from‌ ‌already‌ ‌published‌ ‌literature‌ ‌and‌ ‌visits‌ ‌in‌ ‌Mexican‌ ‌tribe‌ ‌along‌ ‌with‌ ‌archaeologists.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌for‌ ‌his‌ ‌first‌ ‌book‌ ‌‌Anahuac‌;‌ ‌or,‌ ‌Mexico‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌Mexicans‌ ‌Ancient‌ ‌and‌ ‌Modern‌ ‌(1861).‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌used‌ ‌lot‌ ‌of‌ ‌statistical‌ ‌data‌ ‌,comparative‌ ‌method,‌ ‌in‌ ‌arriving‌ ‌at‌ ‌his‌ ‌theory:‌ ‌ ‌\nStages‌ ‌of‌ ‌Evolution:‌ ‌\n ‌\nTechnology:‌ ‌\n ‌\nReligion:‌ ‌\n602‌ ‌\n ‌\nMarriage:‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nCriticism:‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌psychic‌ ‌unity‌ ‌of‌ ‌mankind‌ ‌Criticized‌ ‌by‌ ‌diffusionist.‌ ‌\n○Only‌ ‌a‌ ‌few‌ ‌humans‌ ‌were‌ ‌inventive‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌majority‌ ‌were‌ ‌an‌ ‌uninitiative.‌ ‌\n●Tylor‌ ‌presented‌ ‌a‌ ‌highly‌ ‌ethnocentric‌ ‌culture‌ ‌history‌ ‌model‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌Monogamy‌ ‌and‌ ‌Monotheism‌ ‌are‌ ‌kept‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌top‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌chain‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌all‌ ‌society‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌way‌ ‌to‌ ‌achieve‌ ‌that‌ ‌end.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌survival:‌ ‌who‌ ‌was‌ ‌criticized‌ ‌by‌ ‌functionalists.‌ ‌For‌ ‌then‌ ‌every‌ ‌culture‌ ‌trade‌ ‌has‌ ‌some‌ ‌function‌ ‌without‌ ‌which‌ ‌culture‌ ‌society‌ ‌\ncan't‌ ‌provide.‌ ‌\n ‌\nConclusion:‌ ‌\n●Though‌ ‌Critics‌ ‌prevail‌ ‌the‌ ‌idea‌ ‌of‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌tailor‌ ‌was‌ ‌prominent‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌lead‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌foundation‌ ‌to‌ ‌organise‌ ‌to‌ ‌discipline‌ ‌and‌ ‌formed‌ ‌base‌ ‌for‌ ‌\nfurther‌ ‌research‌ ‌in‌ ‌this‌ ‌discipline.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n603‌ ‌\nJames‌ ‌Frazer‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nAbout:‌ ‌James‌ ‌Frazer‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Sir‌ ‌James‌ ‌George‌ ‌Frazer‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌Scottish‌ ‌social‌ ‌anthropologist‌ ‌and‌ ‌folklorist‌ ‌influential‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌early‌ ‌stages‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌modern‌ ‌studies‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nmythology‌ ‌and‌ ‌comparative‌ ‌religion.‌ ‌ ‌\n●His‌ ‌most‌ ‌famous‌ ‌work,‌ ‌The‌ ‌Golden‌ ‌Bough,‌ ‌documents‌ ‌and‌ ‌details‌ ‌the‌ ‌similarities‌ ‌among‌ ‌magical‌ ‌and‌ ‌religious‌ ‌beliefs‌ ‌around‌ ‌the‌ ‌world.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●James‌ ‌Frazer‌ ‌in‌ ‌his‌ ‌book‌ ‌‘‌The‌ ‌Golden‌ ‌Bough‌’(1892)‌ ‌discussed‌ ‌the‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion‌ ‌and‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌magic,‌ ‌Form‌ ‌of‌ ‌Magic,‌ ‌through‌ ‌\nseveral‌ ‌volumes.‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌extensively‌ ‌wrote‌ ‌on‌ ‌how‌ ‌the‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌in‌ ‌humanity‌ ‌evolved.‌ ‌He‌ ‌developed‌ ‌a‌ ‌concept‌ ‌called‌ ‌‌cosmology‌.‌ ‌He‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nsystem‌ ‌of‌ ‌Ideas‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌of‌ ‌existence‌ ‌in‌ ‌relation‌ ‌to‌ ‌cosmic/‌ ‌universe.‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌collected‌ ‌data‌ ‌from‌ ‌secondary‌ ‌sources.‌The‌ ‌accounts‌ ‌given‌ ‌by‌ ‌Traveller,‌ ‌administrator‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌conducted‌ ‌the‌ ‌human‌ ‌cosmology‌ ‌has‌ ‌gone‌ ‌predominantly‌ ‌through‌ ‌three‌ ‌stages:‌ ‌\n○Magical‌ ‌\n○Religion‌ ‌\n○Scientific‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌marks‌ ‌the‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌three‌ ‌different‌ ‌systems‌ ‌of‌ ‌knowledge.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌early‌ ‌man‌ ‌tried‌ ‌to‌ ‌control‌ ‌nature‌ ‌by‌ ‌evolving‌ ‌several‌ ‌laws,‌ ‌when‌ ‌he‌ ‌could‌ ‌not‌ ‌succeed‌ ‌he‌ ‌surrendered‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌Supernatural‌ ‌entity‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nthus‌ ‌came‌ ‌religion‌ ‌with‌ ‌gradual‌ ‌progress‌ ‌of‌ ‌knowledge‌ ‌the‌ ‌science‌ ‌emerged.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Golden‌ ‌Bough‌ ‌stated‌ ‌that‌ ‌early‌ ‌man‌ ‌had‌ ‌no‌ ‌knowledge‌ ‌of‌ ‌science‌ ‌and‌ ‌tried‌ ‌primarily‌ ‌two‌ ‌erroneous‌ ‌principle‌ ‌of‌ ‌Magic:‌ ‌\n604‌ ‌\n○Law‌ ‌of‌ ‌similarity‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌depends‌ ‌on‌ ‌belief‌ ‌that‌ ‌“like‌ ‌produces‌ ‌like”.‌ ‌ ‌\n■E.g.‌  ‌The‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌Dr‌ ‌Majumdar‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌Ho‌ ‌tribe‌ ‌of‌ ‌Central‌ ‌India‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌mechanism‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌they‌ ‌try‌ ‌to‌ ‌get‌ ‌rain‌.‌ ‌\nThey‌ ‌understood‌ ‌that‌ ‌rain‌ ‌follows‌ ‌thunder‌ ‌and‌ ‌hence‌ ‌they‌ ‌created‌ ‌rumbling‌ ‌noise‌ ‌by‌ ‌Rolling‌ ‌boulders‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌hill‌ ‌slope.‌ ‌\n○Law‌ ‌of‌ ‌contact‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌is‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌principle‌ ‌that‌ ‌“one‌ ‌and‌ ‌contact‌ ‌are‌ ‌always‌ ‌in‌ ‌contact”.‌ ‌\n■ ‌sometime‌ ‌this‌ ‌led‌ ‌to‌ ‌black‌ ‌magic‌ ‌\n■E.g.For‌ ‌destruction‌ ‌of‌ ‌belongings‌ ‌of‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌could‌ ‌lead‌ ‌to‌ ‌his‌ ‌destruction.‌ ‌\nCriticism:‌ ‌\n●His‌ ‌contribution‌ ‌when‌ ‌narrow‌ ‌on‌ ‌religion-‌ ‌magic.‌ ‌\n●Sources‌ ‌of‌ ‌studies:‌ ‌history‌ ‌books,‌ ‌clocks‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌literary‌ ‌sources‌ ‌without‌ ‌any‌ ‌fieldwork.‌ ‌\n●More‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌armchair‌ ‌anthropologist.‌ ‌\n ‌\nConclusion:‌ ‌\n●Though‌ ‌The‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌were‌ ‌narrow,‌ ‌this‌ ‌was‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌only‌ ‌concepts‌ ‌which‌ ‌helped‌ ‌to‌ ‌develop‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌into‌ ‌organised‌ ‌discipline‌ ‌and‌ ‌laid‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌base‌ ‌for‌ ‌further‌ ‌anthropological‌ ‌thought‌ ‌and‌ ‌research.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nR.R.‌ ‌Marett‌ ‌\n ‌\nAbout:R.R.‌ ‌Marett‌ ‌\n605‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●MARETT,‌ ‌R.‌ ‌R.‌ ‌(1866–1943),‌ ‌British‌ ‌philosopher‌ ‌and‌ ‌anthropologist,‌ ‌who‌ ‌introduced‌ ‌the‌ ‌theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌pre‌ ‌animism‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌term‌ ‌animatism‌ ‌\ninto‌ ‌the‌ ‌scholarly‌ ‌debate.‌ ‌\n● ‌Marett's‌ ‌reputation‌ ‌was‌ ‌made‌ ‌virtually‌ ‌overnight,‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌publication‌ ‌in‌ ‌1900‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌paper‌ ‌\"Preanimistic‌ ‌Religion\"‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●A‌ ‌British‌ ‌philosopher‌ ‌and‌ ‌anthropologist,‌ ‌‌who‌ ‌introduced‌ ‌the‌ ‌theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌pre‌ ‌animism‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌term‌ ‌animatism‌ ‌into‌ ‌the‌ ‌scholarly‌ ‌debate.‌ ‌\n●Marett’s‌ ‌views‌ ‌on‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌religion‌ ‌differed‌ ‌somewhat‌ ‌from‌ ‌those‌ ‌of‌ ‌Frazer‌ ‌and‌ ‌Sir‌ ‌Edward‌ ‌Burnett‌ ‌Tylor,‌ ‌generally‌ ‌acknowledged‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌\ngreatest‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌day;‌ ‌Marett‌ ‌opposed‌ ‌their‌ ‌rigid,‌ ‌rational‌ ‌categorizations‌ ‌and‌ ‌spoke‌ ‌of‌ ‌early‌ ‌man’s‌ ‌“primitive‌ ‌logic‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌heart.”‌ ‌ ‌\n●As‌ ‌opposed‌ ‌to‌ ‌‌Tylor’s‌ ‌“animism,”‌ ‌he‌ ‌postulated‌ ‌an‌ ‌impersonal‌ ‌religion,‌ ‌or‌ ‌“animatism,”‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌“awe,”‌ ‌a‌ ‌feeling‌ ‌of‌ ‌“submissiveness‌ ‌\ntempered‌ ‌with‌ ‌admiration,‌ ‌hopefulness,‌ ‌and‌ ‌even‌ ‌love.”‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌regarded‌ ‌animatism‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌beginning‌ ‌of‌ ‌religious‌ ‌ideas.‌ ‌ ‌\n●His‌ ‌derivation‌ ‌is‌ ‌from‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌as‌ ‌mana‌ ‌(power),‌ ‌mulungu‌ ‌(supreme‌ ‌creator),‌ ‌orenda‌ ‌(magic‌ ‌power),‌ ‌concepts‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Pacific,‌ ‌Africa,‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nAmerica,‌ ‌respectively,‌ ‌referring‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌supernatural‌ ‌power‌ ‌(a‌ ‌kind‌ ‌of‌ ‌supernatural‌ ‌‘electricity’)‌ ‌that‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌necessarily‌ ‌have‌ ‌the‌ ‌personal‌ ‌\nconnotation‌ ‌of‌ ‌animistic‌ ‌entities‌ ‌and‌ ‌that‌ ‌becomes‌ ‌especially‌ ‌present‌ ‌in‌ ‌certain‌ ‌men,‌ ‌spirits,‌ ‌or‌ ‌natural‌ ‌objects.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Marrett‌ ‌criticizes‌ ‌Tylor‌ ‌for‌ ‌an‌ ‌overly‌ ‌intellectual‌ ‌approach,‌ ‌as‌ ‌though‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌men‌ ‌used‌ ‌personal‌ ‌forces‌ ‌as‌ ‌explanatory‌ ‌hypotheses‌ ‌to‌ ‌\naccount‌ ‌for‌ ‌dreams,‌ ‌natural‌ ‌events,‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌Concepts‌ ‌and‌ ‌Approaches‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌Study‌ ‌of‌ ‌Religion‌ ‌phenomena.‌ ‌ ‌\n●His‌ ‌major‌ ‌publications‌ ‌include:‌ ‌The‌ ‌Threshold‌ ‌of‌ ‌Religion‌ ‌(1900),‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌(1912),‌ ‌Psychology‌ ‌and‌ ‌Folklore‌ ‌(1920),‌ ‌Faith,‌ ‌Hope‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nCharity‌ ‌in‌ ‌Primitive‌ ‌Religion‌ ‌(1932),‌ ‌Sacraments‌ ‌of‌ ‌Simple‌ ‌Folk‌ ‌(1933),‌ ‌and‌ ‌Head,‌ ‌Heart‌ ‌and‌ ‌Hands‌ ‌in‌ ‌Human‌ ‌Evolution‌ ‌(1935).‌ ‌\n ‌\nConclusion‌ ‌\n●Marett's‌ ‌style‌ ‌was‌ ‌always‌ ‌admirably‌ ‌lucid,‌ ‌often‌ ‌being‌ ‌further‌ ‌illuminated‌ ‌by‌ ‌wit‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌certain‌ ‌irony.‌ ‌\n●Today‌ ‌he‌ ‌tends‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌evaluated‌ ‌chiefly‌ ‌for‌ ‌work‌ ‌done‌ ‌between‌ ‌1899‌ ‌and‌ ‌1910,‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌neglect‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌more‌ ‌mature‌ ‌writings.‌ ‌ ‌\n606‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌will,‌ ‌however,‌ ‌always‌ ‌have‌ ‌an‌ ‌important‌ ‌place‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌history‌ ‌of‌ ‌both‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌and‌ ‌comparative‌ ‌religion,‌ ‌and‌ ‌he‌ ‌was‌ ‌also‌ ‌highly‌ ‌\nsignificant‌ ‌as‌ ‌an‌ ‌advocate‌ ‌of‌ ‌academic‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌and‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌trainer‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropologists.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nAmerican‌ ‌\nL.H.‌ ‌Morgan‌ ‌\n ‌\nAbout:L.H.‌ ‌Morgan‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Lewis‌ ‌Henry‌ ‌Morgan‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌pioneering‌ ‌American‌ ‌anthropologist‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌theorist‌ ‌who‌ ‌worked‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌railroad‌ ‌lawyer.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌is‌ ‌best‌ ‌known‌ ‌for‌ ‌his‌ ‌work‌ ‌on‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure,‌ ‌his‌ ‌theories‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌evolution,‌ ‌and‌ ‌his‌ ‌ethnography‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Iroquois.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●He‌ ‌worked‌ ‌on‌ ‌Iroquois‌ ‌Indians‌ ‌because‌ ‌he‌ ‌felt‌ ‌that‌ ‌Iroquois‌ ‌culture‌ ‌was‌ ‌changing‌ ‌very‌ ‌rapidly‌ ‌so‌ ‌before‌ ‌it‌ ‌diminished‌ ‌it‌ ‌should‌ ‌be‌ ‌\nrecorded.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Morgan‌ ‌collected‌ ‌large‌ ‌data‌ ‌on‌ ‌Iroquois‌ ‌Indians‌ ‌and‌ ‌published‌ ‌a‌ ‌book‌ ‌named‌ ‌“League‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Iroquois”‌ ‌in‌ ‌1851.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌this‌ ‌book‌ ‌he‌ ‌described‌ ‌each‌ ‌and‌ ‌every‌ ‌ethnographical‌ ‌detail‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌political‌ ‌organization,‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌government,‌ ‌family,‌ ‌dances,‌ ‌\nreligion,‌ ‌games,‌ ‌material‌ ‌culture,‌ ‌and‌ ‌language.‌ ‌\n●Moreover,‌ ‌he‌ ‌also‌ ‌emphasized‌ ‌on‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌matrilineal‌ ‌descent.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Morgan‌ ‌gave‌ ‌the‌ ‌“Classificatory‌ ‌terms”‌ ‌&‌ ‌“Descriptive‌ ‌Terms”‌ ‌of‌ ‌“Kinship‌ ‌System”.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Classificatory‌ ‌terms‌ ‌refer‌ ‌to‌ ‌addressing‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌terms‌ ‌to‌ ‌everyone‌ ‌in‌ ‌relations‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌Uncles,‌ ‌aunty.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Descriptive‌ ‌terms‌ ‌refer‌ ‌to‌ ‌single‌ ‌people‌ ‌like‌ ‌father,‌ ‌mother,‌ ‌daughter,‌ ‌Son.‌ ‌ ‌\n607‌ ‌\n●His‌ ‌books‌ ‌are‌ ‌“Systems‌ ‌of‌ ‌Consanguinity‌ ‌and‌ ‌Affinity‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Human‌ ‌Family”‌ ‌in‌ ‌1870.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Some‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌important‌ ‌work‌ ‌of‌ ‌Morgan‌ ‌is‌ ‌“Ancient‌ ‌Society”‌ ‌in‌ ‌this‌ ‌book‌ ‌he‌ ‌divided‌ ‌the‌ ‌three‌ ‌stage;‌ ‌savagery‌ ‌,‌ ‌barbarism,‌ ‌and‌ ‌Civilization.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nMorgan‌ ‌-‌ ‌successive‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌family‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Consanguine‌ ‌family:‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌was‌ ‌founded‌ ‌upon‌ ‌the‌ ‌intermarriage‌ ‌of‌ ‌brothers‌ ‌and‌ ‌sisters‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌group.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Evidence‌ ‌still‌ ‌remains‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌oldest‌ ‌of‌ ‌existing‌ ‌systems‌ ‌of‌ ‌Consanguinity,‌ ‌‌the‌ ‌Malayan,‌ ‌tending‌ ‌to‌ ‌show‌ ‌that‌ ‌this,‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nfamily,‌ ‌was‌ ‌anciently‌ ‌as‌ ‌universal‌ ‌as‌ ‌this‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌consanguinity‌ ‌which‌ ‌it‌ ‌created.‌ ‌\n●Punaluan‌ ‌family:‌ ‌\n○Its‌ ‌name‌ ‌is‌ ‌derived‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌‌ ‌Hawaiian‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌of‌ ‌Punalua‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌was‌ ‌founded‌ ‌upon‌ ‌the‌ ‌i‌ntermarriage‌ ‌of‌ ‌several‌ ‌brothers‌ ‌to‌ ‌each‌ ‌other’s‌ ‌wives‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌group;‌ ‌and‌ ‌of‌ ‌several‌ ‌sisters‌ ‌to‌ ‌each‌ ‌other’s‌ ‌\nhusbands‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌group.‌ ‌ ‌\n○But‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌term‌ ‌brother,‌ ‌as‌ ‌here‌ ‌used,‌ ‌included‌ ‌the‌ ‌first,‌ ‌second,‌ ‌third,‌ ‌and‌ ‌even‌ ‌more‌ ‌remote‌ ‌male‌ ‌cousins‌,‌ ‌all‌ ‌of‌ ‌whom‌ ‌were‌ ‌\nconsidered‌ ‌brothers‌ ‌to‌ ‌each‌ ‌other,‌ ‌as‌ ‌we‌ ‌consider‌ ‌own‌ ‌brothers;‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌term‌ ‌sister‌ ‌included‌ ‌the‌ ‌first,‌ ‌second,‌ ‌third,‌ ‌and‌ ‌even‌ ‌more‌ ‌\nremote‌ ‌female‌ ‌cousins,‌ ‌all‌ ‌of‌ ‌whom‌ ‌were‌ ‌sisters‌ ‌to‌ ‌each‌ ‌other,‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌as‌ ‌own‌ ‌sisters‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌supervened‌ ‌upon‌ ‌the‌ ‌consanguine.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌created‌ ‌the‌ ‌Turanian‌ ‌and‌ ‌Ganowanian‌ ‌systems‌ ‌of‌ ‌consanguinity.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Both‌ ‌this‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌previous‌ ‌form‌ ‌belong‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Period‌ ‌of‌ ‌savagery.‌ ‌\n●Syndyasmian‌ ‌\n○Syndyasmian‌ ‌or‌ ‌pairing‌ ‌of‌ ‌families‌ ‌founded‌ ‌upon‌ ‌the‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌of‌ ‌single‌ ‌pairs,‌ ‌without‌ ‌giving‌ ‌the‌ ‌right‌ ‌of‌ ‌exclusive‌ ‌cohabitation‌ ‌to‌ ‌any‌ ‌\nperson‌ ‌over‌ ‌the‌ ‌other.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌term‌ ‌Syndyasmian‌ ‌is‌ ‌derived‌ ‌from‌ ‌syndyazo,‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌to‌ ‌pair.‌ ‌ ‌\n608‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌germ‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Monogamian‌ ‌Family‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Divorce‌ ‌or‌ ‌separation‌ ‌was‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌option‌ ‌of‌ ‌both‌ ‌husband‌ ‌and‌ ‌wife.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌failed‌ ‌to‌ ‌create‌ ‌a‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌consanguinity.‌ ‌\n●Patriarchal‌ ‌family:‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌comprises‌ ‌the‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌of‌ ‌one‌ ‌man‌ ‌to‌ ‌several‌ ‌wives,‌ ‌each‌ ‌wife‌ ‌being‌ ‌secluded‌ ‌from‌ ‌every‌ ‌other.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌term‌ ‌is‌ ‌here‌ ‌used‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌restricted‌ ‌sense‌ ‌to‌ ‌define‌ ‌the‌ ‌special‌ ‌family‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Hebrew‌ ‌pastoral‌ ‌tribes,‌ ‌the‌ ‌chiefs‌ ‌and‌ ‌principal‌ ‌men‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nwhich‌ ‌practised‌ ‌polygamy.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌exercised‌ ‌but‌ ‌little‌ ‌influence‌ ‌upon‌ ‌human‌ ‌affairs‌ ‌for‌ ‌want‌ ‌of‌ ‌universality.‌ ‌\n●Monogamian‌ ‌family‌ ‌\n○I‌t‌ ‌was‌ ‌founded‌ ‌upon‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌between‌ ‌single‌ ‌pairs,‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌married‌ ‌couple‌ ‌having‌ ‌exclusive‌ ‌cohabitation‌ ‌with‌ ‌one‌ ‌another,‌ ‌the‌ ‌latter‌ ‌\nconstituting‌ ‌the‌ ‌essential‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌institution‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌pre-eminently‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌of‌ ‌civilized‌ ‌society,‌ ‌and‌ ‌was‌ ‌therefore‌ ‌essentially‌ ‌modern.‌ ‌This‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌also‌ ‌created‌ ‌an‌ ‌\nindependent‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌consanguinity‌ ‌\n●Morgan‌ ‌believed‌ ‌that‌ ‌family‌ ‌unit‌ ‌became‌ ‌progressively‌ ‌smaller‌ ‌and‌ ‌more‌ ‌self-contained‌ ‌as‌ ‌human‌ ‌society‌ ‌developed.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nCriticism‌ ‌to‌ ‌Evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌Family‌ ‌and‌ ‌Marriage:‌ ‌\n●His‌ ‌postulated‌ ‌sequence‌ ‌of‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌family‌ ‌however‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌supported‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌enormous‌ ‌amount‌ ‌of‌ ‌ethnographic‌ ‌data‌ ‌collected‌ ‌since‌ ‌his‌ ‌\ntime.‌ ‌\n● ‌No‌ ‌recent‌ ‌society‌ ‌that‌ ‌Morgan‌ ‌would‌ ‌call‌ ‌savage‌ ‌indulge‌ ‌in‌ ‌group‌ ‌marriage.‌ ‌\n ‌\nCriticism:‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌views‌ ‌expressed‌ ‌are‌ ‌ethnocentric,‌ ‌contradictory‌ ‌and‌ ‌speculative.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌was‌ ‌second‌ ‌hand‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌account‌ ‌of‌ ‌Biased‌ ‌European.‌ ‌\n●Many‌ ‌later‌ ‌scholars‌ ‌argue‌ ‌that‌ ‌he‌ ‌first‌ ‌conceived‌ ‌the‌ ‌theory‌ ‌and‌ ‌later‌ ‌searched‌ ‌for‌ ‌communities‌ ‌(cases‌ ‌to‌ ‌support‌ ‌his‌ ‌views)‌ ‌\n●Relied‌ ‌on‌ ‌19th‌ ‌century‌ ‌racist‌ ‌views‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌development‌ ‌and‌ ‌misunderstanding‌ ‌of‌ ‌biological‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌to‌ ‌explain‌ ‌social‌ ‌differences.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nGerman‌ ‌\n609‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nJ.J‌ ‌Bachofen‌ ‌\n ‌\nAbout:J.J‌ ‌Bachofen‌ ‌\n610‌ ‌\n ‌\n●He‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌scholar‌ ‌of‌ ‌mythology‌ ‌and‌ ‌Roman‌ ‌law‌ ‌and‌ ‌history.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Through‌ ‌his‌ ‌most‌ ‌famous‌ ‌books,‌ ‌Gräbersymbolik‌ ‌(1859)‌ ‌and‌ ‌Mutterrecht‌ ‌(Mother‌ ‌right,‌ ‌1861),‌ ‌Bachofen‌ ‌had‌ ‌a‌ ‌great‌ ‌influence‌ ‌on‌ ‌\ntwentieth-century‌ ‌culture,‌ ‌even‌ ‌in‌ ‌fields‌ ‌not‌ ‌closely‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌history‌ ‌of‌ ‌religions.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●J‌ ‌J‌ ‌Bachofen‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌classical‌ ‌continental‌ ‌evolutionist.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌believed‌ ‌that‌ ‌matrilineality‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌early‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌reckoning‌ ‌kinship,‌ ‌whereas‌ ‌patrilineality‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌developed‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌descent.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Bachofen‌ ‌observed‌ ‌that‌ ‌‌matriarchy‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌second‌ ‌stage‌ ‌of‌ ‌development,‌ ‌before‌ ‌which‌ ‌existed‌ ‌a‌ ‌stage‌ ‌of‌ ‌‘heterism’‌ ‌or‌ ‌‘sexual‌ ‌promiscuity’‌ ‌\nor‌ ‌‘sexual‌ ‌communism’.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌present‌ ‌day‌ ‌monogamy‌ ‌has‌ ‌evolved‌ ‌through‌ ‌polyandry‌ ‌and‌ ‌polygyny.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌published‌ ‌his‌ ‌findings‌ ‌on‌ ‌matrilineal‌ ‌societies‌ ‌under‌ ‌the‌ ‌title‌ ‌‌Das‌ ‌Mutterrecht‌ ‌or‌ ‌Mother‌ ‌Right‌ ‌in‌ ‌1861‌.‌ ‌In‌ ‌this‌ ‌book‌ ‌Bachofen‌ ‌\ndeveloped‌ ‌the‌ ‌sequences‌ ‌of‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌patriarchy.‌ ‌\n ‌\n611‌ ‌\n ‌\n●In‌ ‌the‌ ‌early‌ ‌stage,‌ ‌women‌ ‌were‌ ‌merely‌ ‌treated‌ ‌as‌ ‌sexual‌ ‌objects.‌ ‌ ‌\n●When‌ ‌the‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌lines‌ ‌were‌ ‌traced‌ ‌through‌ ‌mother,‌ ‌the‌ ‌women‌ ‌began‌ ‌to‌ ‌assume‌ ‌authority.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌residence‌ ‌was‌ ‌matrilocal‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌of‌ ‌property‌ ‌had‌ ‌been‌ ‌from‌ ‌mother‌ ‌to‌ ‌daughter.‌ ‌When‌ ‌patrilineality‌ ‌followed‌ ‌matrilineality,‌ ‌\nman’s‌ ‌dominance‌ ‌emerged.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nAdolf‌ ‌Bastian‌ ‌\n ‌\nAbout:Adolf‌ ‌Bastian‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Adolf‌ ‌Philipp‌ ‌Wilhelm‌ ‌Bastian‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌19th-century‌ ‌polymath‌ ‌best‌ ‌remembered‌ ‌for‌ ‌his‌ ‌contributions‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌ethnography‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌discipline.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●German‌ ‌Scholar‌ ‌he‌ ‌was‌ ‌interested‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌idea‌ ‌to‌ ‌present‌ ‌the‌ ‌similarities‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌different‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌people‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌man’s‌ ‌psychic‌ ‌unity.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌opined‌ ‌that‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌restricted‌ ‌numbers‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌idea‌ ‌to‌ ‌people.‌ ‌Bastian's‌ ‌\"elementary‌ ‌ideas\"‌ ‌(Elementargedan-‌ ‌ken),‌ ‌\n●Then‌ ‌he‌ ‌argues‌ ‌that‌ ‌these‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌were‌ ‌developed‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌environments‌ ‌called‌ ‌“Geographical‌ ‌provinces”.‌ ‌ ‌\n612‌ ‌\n●Bastian‌ ‌had‌ ‌modes‌ ‌of‌ ‌thought‌ ‌that‌ ‌have‌ ‌led‌ ‌some‌ ‌historians‌ ‌of‌ ‌ethnology‌ ‌to‌ ‌call‌ ‌him‌ ‌an‌ ‌evolutionist.‌ ‌ ‌\n●However,‌ ‌‌unlike‌ ‌orthodox‌ ‌evolutionists,‌ ‌he‌ ‌did‌ ‌not‌ ‌think‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌of‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌elementary‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌was‌ ‌unilinear;‌ ‌rather,‌ ‌this‌ ‌\npattern‌ ‌of‌ ‌development‌ ‌was‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌multiplicity‌ ‌of‌ ‌Völkergedanken‌ ‌developing‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌physical‌ ‌surroundings.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌differed‌ ‌sharply‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌predominant‌ ‌view‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌time‌ ‌in‌ ‌that‌ ‌he‌ ‌conceived‌ ‌of‌ ‌development‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌spiral,‌ ‌an‌ ‌image‌ ‌that‌ ‌foreshadows‌ ‌\nmodern‌ ‌concepts.‌ ‌\n ‌\nCriticism‌ ‌\n●Bastian’s‌ ‌views‌ ‌were‌ ‌strongly‌ ‌opposed‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌famous‌ ‌biologist‌ ‌‌Ernst‌ ‌Haeckel‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌antithesis‌ ‌to‌ ‌Bastian’s‌ ‌monogenetic‌ ‌view‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌origins,‌ ‌Haeckel‌ ‌believed‌ ‌the‌ ‌main‌ ‌human‌ ‌races‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌descended‌ ‌from‌ ‌different‌ ‌\nanthropoid‌ ‌species.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌diffusionists‌ ‌also‌ ‌attacked‌ ‌Bastian.‌ ‌\n ‌\nConclusion‌ ‌\n●Among‌ ‌those‌ ‌who‌ ‌were‌ ‌influenced‌ ‌by‌ ‌Bastian‌ ‌are‌ ‌a‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌distinguished‌ ‌anthropologists,‌ ‌Alfred‌ ‌Cort‌ ‌Haddon,‌ ‌Franz‌ ‌Boas,‌ ‌Richard‌ ‌\nThurnwald,‌ ‌A.‌ ‌R.‌ ‌Radcliffe-Brown,‌ ‌and‌ ‌Bronislaw‌ ‌Malinowski.‌ ‌ ‌\n●C.‌ ‌G.‌ ‌Jung’s‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌collective‌ ‌unconscious‌ ‌was‌ ‌directly‌ ‌derived‌ ‌from‌ ‌Bastian’s‌ ‌elementary‌ ‌ideas.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Finally,‌ ‌Bastian’s‌ ‌campaign‌ ‌to‌ ‌save‌ ‌data‌ ‌from‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌process‌ ‌of‌ ‌disappearing‌ ‌is‌ ‌being‌ ‌continued‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌International‌ ‌\nCommittee‌ ‌on‌ ‌Urgent‌ ‌Anthropo-logical‌ ‌and‌ ‌Ethnological‌ ‌Research,‌ ‌organized‌ ‌by‌ ‌Robert‌ ‌Heine-Geldern.‌ ‌\n613‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nAccomplishment‌ ‌of‌ ‌Unilinear‌ ‌Evolution:‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌early‌ ‌anthropologist‌ ‌tried‌ ‌to‌ ‌establish‌ ‌the‌ ‌scientific‌ ‌discipline‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropology.‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌aided‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌foundations‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌organized‌ ‌discipline‌ ‌where‌ ‌none‌ ‌had‌ ‌existed‌ ‌before.‌ ‌\n● ‌They‌ ‌left‌ ‌Behind‌ ‌three‌ ‌basic‌ ‌assumption:‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌dictum‌ ‌that‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌phenomena‌ ‌are‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌studied‌ ‌in‌ ‌naturalistic‌ ‌fashion‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌premise‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌“psychic‌ ‌unity‌ ‌of‌ ‌mankind,”‌ ‌i.e.,‌ ‌that‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌differences‌ ‌between‌ ‌groups‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌differences‌ ‌in‌ ‌\npsychobiological‌ ‌equipment‌ ‌but‌ ‌to‌ ‌differences‌ ‌in‌ ‌sociocultural‌ ‌experience;‌ ‌and‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌comparative‌ ‌method‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌surrogate‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌experimental‌ ‌and‌ ‌laboratory‌ ‌techniques‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌physical‌ ‌sciences‌ ‌\nCriticism‌ ‌of‌ ‌Classical‌ ‌Evolutionism:‌ ‌\n●Ambitious‌ ‌approach‌-The‌ ‌assumption‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌entire‌ ‌mankind‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌world‌ ‌passed‌ ‌through‌ ‌different‌ ‌stages‌ ‌in‌ ‌sequence‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌hold‌ ‌good‌ ‌\nfor‌ ‌all‌ ‌groups.‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌overlooked‌ ‌diffusion‌ ‌&‌ ‌Migration.‌ ‌\n●Morgan‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌terminology‌ ‌collected‌ ‌data‌ ‌by‌ ‌preparing‌ ‌questionnaires‌ ‌and‌ ‌sending‌ ‌it‌ ‌to‌ ‌people‌ ‌working‌ ‌in‌ ‌longest‌ ‌Westermarck-‌ ‌\nSimple‌ ‌societies‌ ‌have‌ ‌monogamy‌ ‌and‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌families‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌these‌ ‌should‌ ‌be‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌civil‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n614‌ ‌\n●Franz‌ ‌Boas-‌ ‌he‌ ‌criticized‌ ‌the‌ ‌lack‌ ‌of‌ ‌Data‌ ‌Collection‌ ‌my‌ ‌classical‌ ‌evolutionist.‌ ‌this‌ ‌suggested‌ ‌we‌ ‌work‌ ‌study‌ ‌and‌ ‌introduce‌ ‌its‌ ‌critical‌ ‌\napproaches‌ ‌in‌ ‌anthropology.‌ ‌\n●Diffusionist-‌ ‌According‌ ‌to‌ ‌classical‌ ‌evolutionists,‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌only‌ ‌way‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌change‌ ‌and‌ ‌they‌ ‌neglected‌ ‌diffusion‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌way‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌\nchange‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌criticized‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌Diffusionist.‌ ‌\n●Functionalists-‌ ‌ ‌early‌ ‌evolutionists‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌conjectural‌ ‌and‌ ‌they‌ ‌had‌ ‌no‌ ‌data‌ ‌they‌ ‌did‌ ‌not‌ ‌give‌ ‌concrete‌ ‌evidence.‌ ‌\n●Evolutionists‌ ‌would‌ ‌not‌ ‌give‌ ‌any‌ ‌proof‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌psychic‌ ‌unity‌ ‌of‌ ‌mankind.‌ ‌\n●Evolutionists‌ ‌equated‌ ‌contemporary‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌societies‌ ‌with‌ ‌Prehistoric‌ ‌society.‌ ‌but‌ ‌as‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌happened‌ ‌how‌ ‌contemporary‌ ‌society‌ ‌can‌ ‌\nbe‌ ‌equated‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌Prehistoric‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n●Evolution‌ ‌is‌ ‌considered‌ ‌Victorian‌ ‌society‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌highest‌ ‌stage‌ ‌of‌ ‌development‌ ‌which‌ ‌shows‌ ‌there‌ ‌ethnocentrism.‌ ‌\n●Evolution‌ ‌should‌ ‌be‌ ‌seen‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌change‌ ‌rather‌ ‌progressive‌ ‌or‌ ‌retrogressive.‌ ‌\n●Due‌ ‌to‌ ‌all‌ ‌this‌ ‌led‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌formation‌ ‌of‌ ‌Neo-‌ ‌evolutionism.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌Addition‌ ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌Addition‌ ‌\nPostulate‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌psychic‌ ‌unity‌ ‌of‌ ‌mankind‌ ‌\n ‌\n●The‌ ‌postulate‌ ‌of‌ ‌\"the‌ ‌psychic‌ ‌unity‌ ‌of‌ ‌mankind\"‌ ‌states‌ ‌that‌ ‌all‌ ‌human‌ ‌beings,‌ ‌regardless‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌or‌ ‌race,‌ ‌share‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌basic‌ ‌\npsychological‌ ‌and‌ ‌cognitive‌ ‌make-up;‌ ‌we‌ ‌are‌ ‌all‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌kind.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌postulate‌ ‌was‌ ‌originally‌ ‌formulated‌ ‌by‌ ‌Adolf‌ ‌Bastian,‌ ‌the‌ ‌\"father‌ ‌of‌ ‌German‌ ‌anthropology\",‌ ‌who‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌classical‌ ‌German‌ ‌humanist‌ ‌and‌ ‌\na‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌relativist,‌ ‌who‌ ‌believed‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌intrinsic‌ ‌value‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌variation.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Bastian‌ ‌passed‌ ‌it‌ ‌on‌ ‌to‌ ‌his‌ ‌similarly‌ ‌minded‌ ‌student,‌ ‌‌Franz‌ ‌Boas,‌ ‌who,‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌\"father‌ ‌of‌ ‌American‌ ‌anthropology\",‌ ‌transmitted‌ ‌it‌ ‌on‌ ‌to‌ ‌all‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nhis‌ ‌students.‌ ‌Edward‌ ‌B.‌ ‌Tylor‌ ‌introduced‌ ‌it‌ ‌to‌ ‌19th‌ ‌century‌ ‌British‌ ‌evolutionist‌ ‌anthropology,‌ ‌where‌ ‌it‌ ‌became‌ ‌a‌ ‌fixture,‌ ‌defended‌ ‌by‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nmajor‌ ‌British‌ ‌evolutionists.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌postulate,‌ ‌indeed,‌ ‌was‌ ‌essential‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌great‌ ‌comparative‌ ‌projects‌ ‌of‌ ‌evolutionism,‌ ‌which‌ ‌would‌ ‌be‌ ‌futile‌ ‌if‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌differences‌ ‌were‌ ‌\ndetermined‌ ‌by‌ ‌differing‌ ‌biology.‌ ‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌reason,‌ ‌it‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌central‌ ‌to‌ ‌later‌ ‌compative‌ ‌projects,‌ ‌e.g.‌ ‌Radcliffe-Brown's,‌ ‌Barth's,‌ ‌Steward's,‌ ‌Godelier's‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌Today,‌ ‌the‌ ‌\npostulate‌ ‌is‌ ‌shared‌ ‌by‌ ‌all‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌(exceptions‌ ‌are‌ ‌hard‌ ‌to‌ ‌think‌ ‌of).‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n(f)‌ ‌Neo-evolutionism‌ ‌(Childe,‌ ‌White,‌ ‌Steward,‌ ‌Sahlins‌ ‌and‌ ‌Service)‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n615‌ ‌\nNeo-Evolutionism‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌neo-evolutionists‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌ready‌ ‌to‌ ‌accept‌ ‌the‌ ‌unilinear‌ ‌sequence‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌evolution.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌overcome‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌limitations‌ ‌of‌ ‌classical‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌theory,‌ ‌a‌ ‌new‌ ‌scheme‌ ‌was‌ ‌proposed‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌neo-evolutionists.‌ ‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌argued‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌was‌ ‌not‌ ‌unilinear,‌ ‌but‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌parabolic‌ ‌curve.‌ ‌ ‌\n○According‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌parabolic‌ ‌curve‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌evolution,‌ ‌a‌ ‌social‌ ‌institution‌ ‌is‌ ‌born‌ ‌in‌ ‌specific‌ ‌form‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌early‌ ‌stage.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌then‌ ‌develops‌ ‌into‌ ‌an‌ ‌entirely‌ ‌different‌ ‌form‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌directions.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌again‌ ‌moves‌ ‌towards‌ ‌the‌ ‌original‌ ‌form,‌ ‌but‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌modified‌ ‌form.‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌instance,‌ ‌the‌ ‌institution‌ ‌of‌ ‌property‌ ‌born‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌communal‌ ‌ownership‌ ‌took‌ ‌the‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌private‌ ‌ownership.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Today‌ ‌again‌ ‌the‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌common‌ ‌ownership‌ ‌through‌ ‌stages‌ ‌developed.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Similarly,‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌beginning,‌ ‌humans‌ ‌used‌ ‌no‌ ‌clothes‌ ‌and‌ ‌they‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌remain‌ ‌naked.‌ ‌Invention‌ ‌of‌ ‌clothes‌ ‌made‌ ‌it‌ ‌possible‌ ‌to‌ ‌cover‌ ‌the‌ ‌entire‌ ‌\nbody.‌ ‌ ‌\n●But‌ ‌these‌ ‌days‌ ‌crazy‌ ‌notions‌ ‌of‌ ‌fashion‌ ‌make‌ ‌some‌ ‌adopt‌ ‌scantily‌ ‌dress‌ ‌style‌ ‌(Nudism).‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌sequence‌ ‌can‌ ‌also‌ ‌be‌ ‌observed‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌field‌ ‌of‌ ‌sexual‌ ‌relation.‌ ‌In‌ ‌the‌ ‌early‌ ‌stage,‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌sexual‌ ‌promiscuity.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌the‌ ‌process‌ ‌of‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌in‌ ‌successive‌ ‌stages,‌ ‌monogamy‌ ‌came‌ ‌into‌ ‌existence,‌ ‌and‌ ‌again‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌present‌ ‌time,‌ ‌arguments‌ ‌are‌ ‌made‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nfavour‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌freedom‌ ‌of‌ ‌sex.‌ ‌ ‌\n616‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●The‌ ‌neo-evolutionism‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌classified‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌nationalities‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌proponents.‌ ‌ ‌\n●V‌ ‌Gordon‌ ‌Childe‌ ‌of‌ ‌Britain,‌ ‌Julian‌ ‌Steward‌ ‌and‌ ‌Leslie‌ ‌A‌ ‌White‌ ‌of‌ ‌America‌ ‌occupy‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌significant‌ ‌place‌ ‌in‌ ‌neo-evolutionary‌ ‌\ntheory.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Among‌ ‌these‌ ‌scholars,‌ ‌V‌ ‌Gordon‌ ‌Childe‌ ‌is‌ ‌familiar‌ ‌to‌ ‌you‌ ‌as‌ ‌an‌ ‌archaeologist‌ ‌who‌ ‌proposed‌ ‌the‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌“Neolithic‌ ‌Revolution”.‌ ‌ ‌\n617‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n618‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nBritish‌ ‌\nV‌ ‌Gordan‌ ‌Childe‌ ‌\n ‌\nAbout:V‌ ‌Gordan‌ ‌Childe‌ ‌\n ‌\n●V.‌ ‌Gordon‌ ‌Childe,‌ ‌in‌ ‌full‌ ‌Vere‌ ‌Gordon‌ ‌Childe,‌ ‌Australian-born‌ ‌British‌ ‌historian,‌ ‌linguist,‌ ‌and‌ ‌archaeologist‌ ‌whose‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌European‌ ‌\nprehistory‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌2nd‌ ‌and‌ ‌3rd‌ ‌millennia‌ ‌BCE‌ ‌sought‌ ‌to‌ ‌evaluate‌ ‌the‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌between‌ ‌Europe‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌Middle‌ ‌East‌ ‌and‌ ‌to‌ ‌examine‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nstructure‌ ‌and‌ ‌character‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌preliterate‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Western‌ ‌world‌ ‌in‌ ‌antiquity.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌also‌ ‌directed‌ ‌the‌ ‌excavations‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌important‌ ‌Neolithic‌ ‌site‌ ‌Skara‌ ‌Brae‌ ‌in‌ ‌Scotland’s‌ ‌Orkney‌ ‌Islands.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n619‌ ‌\n●Gordon‌ ‌Childe‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌trained‌ ‌archaeologist‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌only‌ ‌pioneer‌ ‌of‌ ‌British‌ ‌school‌ ‌of‌ ‌neo-evolutionists.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌his‌ ‌famous‌ ‌book‌ ‌‌Social‌ ‌Evolution‌ ‌(1951)‌,‌ ‌he‌ ‌described‌ ‌the‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌three‌ ‌major‌ ‌events.‌ ‌\n􏰁‌ ‌Invention‌ ‌of‌ ‌Food‌ ‌Production‌ ‌ ‌\n􏰁‌ ‌Urbanisation‌ ‌\n􏰁‌ ‌Industrialisation‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌Childe,‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌progression‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌majority‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌technological‌ ‌skill‌ ‌for‌ ‌exploiting‌ ‌natural‌
