‌resources.‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌is‌ ‌credited‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌large‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌excavations‌ ‌and‌ ‌divided‌ ‌the‌ ‌archaeological‌ ‌period‌ ‌into,‌ ‌Paleolithic,‌ ‌Mesolithic,‌ ‌Neolithic,‌ ‌copper‌ ‌age,‌ ‌\nBronze‌ ‌age‌ ‌and‌ ‌iron‌ ‌age.‌ ‌\n●Considering‌ ‌Tylor,‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌sequence‌ ‌he‌ ‌listed‌ ‌details‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌history.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Childe’s‌ ‌Evolutionary‌ ‌sequence‌ ‌was‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌belief‌ ‌that‌ ‌Technology‌ ‌determine‌ ‌the‌ ‌course‌ ‌of‌ ‌history.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Scheme‌ ‌provided‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌for‌ ‌classical‌ ‌evolutinist‌ ‌scheme‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌History‌ ‌through‌ ‌paper‌ ‌archaeological‌ ‌evidence,‌ ‌cross‌ ‌check‌ ‌by‌ ‌dating‌ ‌\nmethod.‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌him‌ ‌the‌ ‌existence‌ ‌and‌ ‌lack‌ ‌of‌ ‌Technology‌ ‌skills‌ ‌to‌ ‌exploit‌ ‌resources‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌reason‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌difference‌ ‌within‌ ‌pace‌ ‌of‌ ‌evolution.‌ ‌\n ‌\nConclusion‌ ‌\n●H‌e‌ ‌substantiated‌ ‌Revolutionary‌ ‌idea‌ ‌with‌ ‌archaeological‌ ‌data.‌ ‌however‌ ‌data‌ ‌regarding‌ ‌only‌ ‌material‌ ‌culture‌ ‌was‌ ‌available.‌ ‌\n●Therefore,‌ ‌we‌ ‌should‌ ‌not‌ ‌evaluate‌ ‌the‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌non‌ ‌material‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌we‌ ‌should‌ ‌talk‌ ‌only‌ ‌about‌ ‌material‌ ‌or‌ ‌economic‌ ‌aspect‌ ‌of‌ ‌man.‌ ‌\n ‌\n620‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nAmerican‌ ‌\nJulian‌ ‌Steward‌ ‌\n ‌\nAbout:Julian‌ ‌Steward‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Julian‌ ‌Haynes‌ ‌Steward‌ ‌was‌ ‌an‌ ‌American‌ ‌anthropologist‌ ‌best‌ ‌known‌ ‌for‌ ‌his‌ ‌role‌ ‌in‌ ‌developing‌ ‌\"the‌ ‌concept‌ ‌and‌ ‌method\"‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌\necology,‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌scientific‌ ‌theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌change.‌ ‌ ‌\n621‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●American‌ ‌anthropologist‌ ‌who‌ ‌pioneered‌ ‌the‌ ‌revolutionist‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌book‌‌ ‌theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌Cultural‌ ‌Change.‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌Steward,‌  ‌all‌ ‌societies‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌go‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌revolutionary‌ ‌stages,‌ ‌rather‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌is‌ ‌multilinear‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌different‌ ‌in‌ ‌\ncultures‌ ‌that‌ ‌have‌ ‌different‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌stages.‌ ‌\n●Cross‌ ‌culture‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌is‌ ‌important‌ ‌to‌ ‌understand‌ ‌and‌ ‌study‌ ‌culture‌ ‌parallel‌ ‌regulation.‌ ‌\n○Though‌ ‌he‌ ‌agree‌ ‌with‌ ‌Tylor‌ ‌that,‌ ‌‌cultural‌ ‌Complex‌ ‌whole‌ ‌with‌ ‌independent‌ ‌culture‌ ‌traits‌ ‌and‌ ‌who‌ ‌can‌ ‌sing‌ ‌and‌ ‌be‌ ‌influenced‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nrest‌ ‌of‌ ‌them‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌always‌ ‌possible‌ ‌to‌ ‌find‌ ‌specific‌ ‌stages‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌individual‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌trait.‌ ‌\n●E.g.‌‌ ‌Monotheism‌ ‌and‌ ‌Monogamy‌ ‌need‌ ‌not‌ ‌co-exist‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌rule.‌ ‌\n●Hence,‌ ‌‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌Steward,‌ ‌classical‌ ‌thinkers‌ ‌failed‌ ‌explain‌ ‌not‌ ‌only‌ ‌simply‌ ‌the‌ ‌reason‌ ‌for‌ ‌difference‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌face‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌revolution‌ ‌across‌ ‌\ndifferent‌ ‌societies‌ ‌but‌ ‌also‌ ‌the‌ ‌reason‌ ‌for‌ ‌difference‌ ‌in‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌pace‌ ‌in‌ ‌social‌ ‌institution‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌group.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌his‌ ‌book‌ ‌Theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌Culture‌ ‌Change‌ ‌(1955),‌ ‌he‌ ‌suggested‌ ‌the‌ ‌typology‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌as‌ ‌given‌ ‌below:‌ ‌\n1.‌ ‌Unilinear‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌\n2.‌ ‌Universal‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌\n3.‌ ‌Multi‌ ‌linear‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌\n●Unilinear‌ ‌Evolution:‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌this‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌scheme,‌ ‌‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌postulated‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌pass‌ ‌through‌ ‌different‌ ‌and‌ ‌successive‌ ‌developmental‌ ‌stages,‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌result‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌which,‌ ‌simple‌ ‌forms‌ ‌change‌ ‌into‌ ‌complex‌ ‌ones,‌‌ ‌and‌ ‌homogeneity‌ ‌to‌ ‌heterogeneity.‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌classical‌ ‌evolutionists‌ ‌like‌ ‌E‌ ‌B‌ ‌Tylor‌ ‌and‌ ‌L‌ ‌H‌ ‌Morgan‌ ‌are‌ ‌considered‌ ‌as‌ ‌unilinear‌ ‌evolutionists.‌ ‌\n●Multilinear‌ ‌Evolution:‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌multilinear‌ ‌evolutionists‌ ‌are‌ ‌interested‌ ‌in‌ ‌particular‌ ‌cultures.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Julian‌ ‌Steward‌ ‌belongs‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌multilinear‌ ‌evolutionists.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Steward‌ ‌was‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌opinion‌ ‌that‌ ‌all‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌world‌ ‌have‌ ‌not‌ ‌passed‌ ‌through‌ ‌same‌ ‌developmental‌ ‌stages,‌ ‌rather‌ ‌their‌ ‌stages‌ ‌\nwere‌ ‌different‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌areas.‌ ‌ ‌\n○e.g.‌ ‌‌the‌ ‌sequence‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌development‌ ‌in‌ ‌ice‌ ‌area,‌ ‌desert‌ ‌area,‌ ‌forest‌ ‌area‌ ‌and‌ ‌plain‌ ‌area‌ ‌are‌ ‌different‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌different‌ ‌\nenvironmental‌ ‌conditions.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌study‌ ‌the‌ ‌interaction‌ ‌between‌ ‌environment‌ ‌and‌ ‌culture,‌ ‌he‌ ‌proposed‌ ‌the‌ ‌method‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌ecology.‌ ‌\n○According‌ ‌to‌ ‌him,‌ ‌various‌ ‌stages‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌different‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌uniform‌ ‌throughout‌ ‌the‌ ‌world.‌ ‌\n■Cultural‌ ‌Ecology‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌ecology‌ ‌the‌ ‌emphasis‌ ‌is‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌system‌ ‌and‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌specific‌ ‌environment‌ ‌context‌ ‌with‌ ‌which‌ ‌they‌ ‌\ninteract‌ ‌\n●Cultural‌ ‌Ecology‌ ‌is‌ ‌concerned‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌interrelation‌ ‌between‌ ‌culture‌ ‌system‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌environment‌ ‌with‌ ‌which‌ ‌they‌ ‌exist‌ ‌\n●Human‌ ‌are‌ ‌animal‌ ‌and‌ ‌like‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌animals‌ ‌must‌ ‌maintain‌ ‌adequate‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌with‌ ‌their‌ ‌Ecology‌ ‌in‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nsurvive‌ ‌\n622‌ ‌\n●Although‌ ‌they‌ ‌achieve‌ ‌these‌ ‌adaptation‌ ‌principally‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌medium‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌the‌ ‌process‌ ‌is‌ ‌ultimately‌ ‌subject‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌same‌ ‌rules‌ ‌of‌ ‌natural‌ ‌selection‌ ‌that‌ ‌given‌ ‌biological‌ ‌adaptation.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Universal‌ ‌Evolution:‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌concerned‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌whole.‌ ‌Universal‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌treats‌ ‌the‌ ‌whole‌ ‌culture‌ ‌of‌ ‌humankind‌ ‌rather‌ ‌\nthan‌ ‌particular‌ ‌cultures.‌ ‌ ‌\n○According‌ ‌to‌ ‌this‌ ‌view‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌universal‌ ‌phenomenon‌ ‌and‌ ‌every‌ ‌culture‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌world‌ ‌is‌ ‌subjected‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌process‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nevolution-whether‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌pre-literate‌ ‌or‌ ‌advanced.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌is‌ ‌represented‌ ‌by‌ ‌V‌ ‌Gordon‌ ‌Childe‌ ‌of‌ ‌Britain‌ ‌and‌ ‌Leslie‌ ‌A‌ ‌White‌ ‌of‌ ‌America.‌ ‌\n ‌\nMethodology‌ ‌\n●Steward‌ ‌begin‌ ‌by‌ ‌saying‌ ‌that‌ ‌Not‌ ‌all‌ ‌parts‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌culture‌ ‌are‌ ‌equally‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌environment.‌ ‌‌The‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌are‌ ‌more‌ ‌closely‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nenvironment‌ ‌than‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌part.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌every‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌between‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌environment,‌ ‌people‌ ‌exploit‌ ‌the‌ ‌environment‌ ‌in‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌fulfill‌ ‌their‌ ‌material‌ ‌needs.‌ ‌In‌ ‌the‌ ‌process‌ ‌\nenvironment‌ ‌also‌ ‌get‌ ‌affected.‌ ‌\n●To‌ ‌exploit‌ ‌resource‌ ‌required‌ ‌Technology‌ ‌hence‌ ‌there‌ ‌has‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌a‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌between‌ ‌people‌ ‌and‌ ‌Technology.‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌relations‌ ‌are‌ ‌concerned‌ ‌with‌ ‌Economic‌ ‌value‌ ‌that‌ ‌constitutes‌ ‌the‌ ‌economic‌ ‌system.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Thus,‌ ‌the‌ ‌economic‌ ‌system‌ ‌is‌ ‌more‌ ‌closely‌ ‌related‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌environment‌ ‌hence‌ ‌he‌ ‌says‌ ‌that‌ ‌economic‌ ‌system‌ ‌constituted‌ ‌code‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nculture‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌Institutions‌ ‌are‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌economic‌ ‌system‌ ‌as‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌directly‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌environment‌ ‌e.g.‌ ‌Political,‌ ‌Religious,‌ ‌\nInstitutions‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n●Hence,‌ ‌‌at‌ ‌methodology‌ ‌level‌ ‌he‌ ‌explored‌ ‌the‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌between‌ ‌man‌ ‌and‌ ‌environment‌ ‌by‌ ‌studying‌ ‌the‌ ‌economic‌ ‌system.‌ ‌\n● ‌Environment‌ ‌is‌ ‌changing‌ ‌and‌ ‌man‌ ‌has‌ ‌to‌ ‌survive‌ ‌in‌ ‌this‌ ‌condition.‌ ‌Hence,‌ ‌he‌ ‌has‌ ‌to‌ ‌keep‌ ‌on‌ ‌changing‌ ‌the‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌material‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌tools,‌ ‌\nequipment,‌ ‌weapons‌ ‌for‌ ‌destruction‌ ‌of‌ ‌material‌ ‌resources‌ ‌for‌ ‌his‌ ‌survival.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Thus,‌ ‌over‌ ‌the‌ ‌period‌ ‌of‌ ‌Time‌ ‌society‌ ‌and‌ ‌culture‌ ‌evolved.‌ ‌\n ‌\nCriticism‌ ‌ ‌\n●Steward‌ ‌was‌ ‌criticised‌ ‌by‌ ‌his‌ ‌students‌ ‌who‌ ‌found‌ ‌that‌ ‌in‌ ‌many‌ ‌societies‌ ‌the‌ ‌direct‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌with‌ ‌‌the‌ ‌environment‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌\neconomic‌ ‌system‌ ‌rather‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Roy‌ ‌Rappaport‌ ‌studied‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Tsembaga‌ ‌Maring‌ ‌tribe‌ ‌in‌ ‌Papua‌ ‌New‌ ‌Guinea‌ ‌‌of‌ ‌Melanesia‌ ‌and‌ ‌wrote‌ ‌a‌ ‌book‌ ‌called‌ ‌'Pig‌ ‌for‌ ‌Ancestor.'‌ ‌ ‌\n○He‌ ‌found‌ ‌that‌ ‌there‌ ‌was‌ ‌direct‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌between‌ ‌religion‌ ‌and‌ ‌environment.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Steward‌ ‌said‌ ‌that‌ ‌apart‌ ‌from‌ ‌economic‌ ‌systems‌ ‌all‌ ‌other‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌are‌ ‌simply‌ ‌superstructure.‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌(critics‌ ‌of‌ ‌Steward)‌ ‌showed‌ ‌that‌ ‌rituals‌ ‌regulated‌ ‌the‌ ‌ecological‌ ‌cycle.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌some‌ ‌societies‌ ‌in‌ ‌Melanesia,‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌pig‌ ‌feast.‌ ‌Those‌ ‌who‌ ‌offer‌ ‌more‌ ‌pigs‌ ‌in‌ ‌feast‌ ‌won‌ ‌the‌ ‌title‌ ‌of‌ ‌big‌ ‌man‌ ‌in‌ ‌Melanesia.‌ ‌ ‌\n●From‌ ‌this‌ ‌custom‌ ‌they‌ ‌came‌ ‌to‌ ‌know‌ ‌that‌ ‌religion‌ ‌had‌ ‌a‌ ‌direct‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌environment‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌process‌ ‌of‌ ‌pig‌ ‌feast‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nritual‌ ‌in‌ ‌Melanesia,‌ ‌to‌ ‌commemorate‌ ‌their‌ ‌environment.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌latent‌ ‌function‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌practice‌ ‌is‌ ‌to‌ ‌regulate‌ ‌ecological‌ ‌cycles.‌ ‌ ‌\n623‌ ‌\n●Hence‌ ‌it‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌said‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌economic‌ ‌system‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌always‌ ‌be‌ ‌the‌ ‌core‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Other‌ ‌Institutions‌ ‌can‌ ‌also‌ ‌be‌ ‌a‌ ‌core‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌But‌ ‌steward‌ ‌did‌ ‌not‌ ‌say‌ ‌that‌ ‌one‌ ‌should‌ ‌follow‌ ‌the‌ ‌strict‌ ‌order‌ ‌i.e.‌ ‌economic‌ ‌factor‌ ‌as‌ ‌core‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nculture.‌ ‌ ‌\n○He‌ ‌said‌ ‌that‌ ‌we‌ ‌should‌ ‌look‌ ‌at‌ ‌those‌ ‌aspects‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌directly‌ ‌linked‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌environment.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nConclusion:‌ ‌ ‌\n●Steward‌ ‌gave‌ ‌the‌ ‌concepts‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌ecology‌ ‌and‌ ‌multilinear‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌which‌ ‌make‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌holistic.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nLeslie‌ ‌A.‌ ‌White‌ ‌\n ‌\nAbout:Leslie‌ ‌A.‌ ‌White‌ ‌\n624‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Leslie‌ ‌Alvin‌ ‌White‌ ‌was‌ ‌an‌ ‌American‌ ‌anthropologist‌ ‌known‌ ‌for‌ ‌his‌ ‌advocacy‌ ‌of‌ ‌theories‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌evolution,‌ ‌sociocultural‌ ‌evolution,‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nespecially‌ ‌neoevolutionism‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Leslie‌ ‌White‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌prominent‌ ‌anthropologist,‌ ‌brought‌ ‌up‌ ‌under‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Boasian‌ ‌approach.‌ ‌\n●But‌ ‌he‌ ‌was‌ ‌not‌ ‌satisfied‌ ‌with‌ ‌Boas'‌ ‌quest‌ ‌for‌ ‌data.‌ ‌He‌ ‌said‌ ‌that‌ ‌social‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌can‌ ‌advance‌ ‌only‌ ‌if‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌able‌ ‌to‌ ‌generalise‌ ‌or‌ ‌give‌ ‌theory.‌ ‌\n●Leslie‌ ‌White‌ ‌came‌ ‌in‌ ‌touch‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌writing‌ ‌of‌ ‌Tylor‌ ‌and‌ ‌Morgan.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌concluded‌ ‌that‌ ‌most‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌findings‌ ‌of‌ ‌classical‌ ‌evolutionists‌ ‌were‌ ‌of‌ ‌very‌ ‌high‌ ‌order.‌ ‌ ‌\n625‌ ‌\n○But‌ ‌the‌ ‌problem‌ ‌was‌ ‌that‌ ‌they‌ ‌did‌ ‌not‌ ‌know‌ ‌about‌ ‌the‌ ‌universal‌ ‌standard‌ ‌of‌ ‌measuring‌ ‌evolution.‌ ‌\n ‌\nPremises‌ ‌of‌ ‌Leslie‌ ‌White‌ ‌\n●Evolution‌ ‌has‌ ‌undoubtedly‌ ‌occurred‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌biological‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌sociocultural‌ ‌world.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌study‌ ‌the‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌society‌ ‌and‌ ‌culture,‌ ‌we‌ ‌must‌ ‌find‌ ‌out‌ ‌universal‌ ‌standards‌ ‌of‌ ‌measurement.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Tylor‌ ‌and‌ ‌Morgan‌ ‌did‌ ‌not‌ ‌work‌ ‌out‌ ‌such‌ ‌a‌ ‌universal‌ ‌measurement‌ ‌but‌ ‌Leslie‌ ‌White‌ ‌worked‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌universal‌ ‌standard‌ ‌of‌ ‌measurement‌ ‌which‌ ‌\nhe‌ ‌puts‌ ‌forward‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌energy‌ ‌and‌ ‌technology.‌ ‌\n●Culture‌ ‌evolves‌ ‌when‌ ‌a‌ ‌higher‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌energy‌ ‌is‌ ‌used.‌ ‌‌Thus,‌ ‌White‌ ‌was‌ ‌not‌ ‌interested‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌particular‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌was‌ ‌also‌ ‌not‌ ‌interested‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌particular‌ ‌institutions.‌ ‌\n○He‌ ‌was‌ ‌mainly‌ ‌interested‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌fundamental‌ ‌principle‌ ‌because‌ ‌of‌ ‌which‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌in‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌that‌ ‌was‌ ‌energy.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌described‌ ‌culture‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌kind‌ ‌of‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌and‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌is‌ ‌treated‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌manipulation‌ ‌of‌ ‌energy.‌ ‌\n○E.‌ ‌g.‌ ‌‌In‌ ‌simple‌ ‌societies,‌ ‌the‌ ‌amount‌ ‌of‌ ‌energy‌ ‌used‌ ‌by‌ ‌people‌ ‌was‌ ‌significantly‌ ‌low‌ ‌because‌ ‌sources‌ ‌of‌ ‌energy‌ ‌which‌ ‌were‌ ‌tapped‌ ‌\nby‌ ‌simple‌ ‌society‌ ‌are‌ ‌fewer.‌ ‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌depend‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌minimum‌ ‌amount‌ ‌of‌ ‌energy.‌ ‌They‌ ‌used‌ ‌free‌ ‌floating‌ ‌energy.‌ ‌When‌ ‌man‌ ‌became‌ ‌pastoralist‌ ‌he‌ ‌made‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌animal‌ ‌\npower.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Then‌ ‌the‌ ‌stage‌ ‌of‌ ‌agriculture‌ ‌came‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌the‌ ‌energy‌ ‌harnessed‌ ‌is‌ ‌much‌ ‌more.‌ ‌ ‌\n○White‌ ‌said‌ ‌that‌ ‌higher‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌energy‌ ‌are‌ ‌used‌ ‌where‌ ‌both‌ ‌pastoralism‌ ‌and‌ ‌agriculture‌ ‌is‌ ‌combined‌ ‌to‌ ‌one.‌ ‌ ‌\n○With‌ ‌the‌ ‌passage‌ ‌of‌ ‌time‌ ‌new‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌energy‌ ‌are‌ ‌tapped‌ ‌&‌ ‌incorporated‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌system.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Energy‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌measured‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌harvesting‌ ‌per‌ ‌capita‌ ‌individual.‌ ‌ ‌\n●With‌ ‌the‌ ‌passage‌ ‌of‌ ‌time,‌ ‌quality‌ ‌and‌ ‌quantity‌ ‌of‌ ‌energy‌ ‌harnessed‌ ‌increases.‌ ‌\n○Therefore‌ ‌Civilization‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌a‌ ‌stage‌ ‌marked‌ ‌by‌ ‌writing‌ ‌but‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌stage‌ ‌marked‌ ‌by‌ ‌an‌ ‌increase‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌amount‌ ‌of‌ ‌energy‌ ‌harnessed‌ ‌by‌ ‌\nan‌ ‌individual.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌said‌ ‌the‌ ‌energy‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌harnessed‌ ‌by‌ ‌itself.‌ ‌It‌ ‌required‌ ‌technology‌ ‌or‌ ‌a‌ ‌set‌ ‌of‌ ‌techniques‌ ‌e.g.‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌axe‌ ‌for‌ ‌cutting‌ ‌a‌ ‌tree.‌ ‌ ‌\n626‌ ‌\n●Here‌ ‌axe‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌technique‌ ‌that‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌work‌ ‌on‌ ‌its‌ ‌own‌ ‌unless‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌coupled‌ ‌with‌ ‌energy.‌ ‌Manual‌ ‌energy‌ ‌is‌ ‌harnessed‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌help‌ ‌of‌ ‌\ntechnique.‌ ‌\n●Without‌ ‌technique‌ ‌the‌ ‌energy‌ ‌remains‌ ‌free‌ ‌floating.‌ ‌\n ‌\nMethodology‌ ‌\n●White‌ ‌said‌ ‌the‌ ‌product‌ ‌of‌ ‌energy‌ ‌and‌ ‌technology‌ ‌gives‌ ‌rise‌ ‌to‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌For‌ ‌this,‌ ‌we‌ ‌have‌ ‌to‌ ‌take‌ ‌into‌ ‌consideration‌ ‌three‌ ‌possibilities‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nenergy‌ ‌for‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture:‌ ‌ ‌\n●Energy‌ ‌X‌ ‌Technology‌ ‌=‌ ‌Culture‌ ‌\n○Low‌ ‌Energy‌ ‌X‌ ‌High‌ ‌Technology‌ ‌=‌ ‌Low‌ ‌culture‌ ‌\n○High‌ ‌Energy‌ ‌X‌ ‌Low‌ ‌Technology‌ ‌=‌ ‌Low‌ ‌culture‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌first‌ ‌and‌ ‌2nd‌ ‌the‌ ‌product‌ ‌will‌ ‌be‌ ‌of‌ ‌inferior‌ ‌quality.‌ ‌When‌ ‌energy‌ ‌and‌ ‌tech‌ ‌level‌ ‌both‌ ‌are‌ ‌of‌ ‌optimum‌ ‌type,‌ ‌then‌ ‌the‌ ‌product‌ ‌will‌ ‌be‌ ‌\nsatisfactory.‌ ‌\n○High‌ ‌Energy‌ ‌X‌ ‌High‌ ‌Technology‌ ‌=‌ ‌High‌ ‌Culture‌ ‌ ‌\n●On‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌technology‌ ‌&‌ ‌energy‌ ‌White‌ ‌gave‌ ‌two‌ ‌laws‌ ‌of‌ ‌evolution,‌ ‌later‌ ‌merged‌ ‌into‌ ‌one.‌ ‌\n○1st‌ ‌law‌ ‌:‌ ‌‌Other‌ ‌things‌ ‌remaining‌ ‌equal‌ ‌the‌ ‌degree‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌development‌ ‌directly‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌amount‌ ‌of‌ ‌energy‌ ‌per‌ ‌capita‌ ‌per‌ ‌year‌ ‌\nharnessed‌ ‌&‌ ‌put‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌work‌ ‌ ‌\n○2nd‌ ‌law‌ ‌:‌ ‌Other‌ ‌things‌ ‌kept‌ ‌equal‌ ‌the‌ ‌degree‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌development‌ ‌varies‌ ‌direal‌ ‌as‌ ‌efficiency‌ ‌of‌ ‌technological‌ ‌means‌ ‌with‌ ‌which‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌harnessed‌ ‌energy‌ ‌could‌ ‌be‌ ‌put‌ ‌to‌ ‌work‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌law,‌ ‌the‌ ‌emphasis‌ ‌is‌ ‌on‌ ‌energy‌ ‌&‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌second‌ ‌law‌ ‌the‌ ‌emphasis‌ ‌is‌ ‌on‌ ‌technology‌ ‌\n●Both‌ ‌were‌ ‌combined‌ ‌by‌ ‌White‌ ‌and‌ ‌he‌ ‌gave‌ ‌the‌ ‌law‌ ‌of‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌law‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌development.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Law‌ ‌of‌ ‌Cultural‌ ‌Development:‌ ‌When‌ ‌the‌ ‌amount‌ ‌of‌ ‌energy‌ ‌harnessed‌ ‌by‌ ‌man‌ ‌per‌ ‌capita‌ ‌per‌ ‌year‌ ‌is‌ ‌increased‌ ‌or‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌efficiency‌ ‌of‌ ‌\ntechnological‌ ‌means‌ ‌of‌ ‌putting‌ ‌energy‌ ‌to‌ ‌work‌ ‌is‌ ‌increased‌ ‌or‌ ‌both‌ ‌the‌ ‌factors‌ ‌increased‌ ‌simultaneously‌ ‌then‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌called‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌\ndevelopment.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌put‌ ‌much‌ ‌emphasis‌ ‌on‌ ‌technology‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌why‌ ‌his‌ ‌theory‌ ‌is‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌technological‌ ‌theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌evolution.‌ ‌ ‌\n○But‌ ‌it‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌mean‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌society‌ ‌does‌ ‌occur‌ ‌only‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌level‌ ‌of‌ ‌technology.‌ ‌Rather‌ ‌emphasis‌ ‌is‌ ‌on‌ ‌harnessing‌ ‌\nenergy‌ ‌by‌ ‌technological‌ ‌apparatus.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nCritical‌ ‌evaluation‌ ‌of‌ ‌Leslie‌ ‌White:‌ ‌\n●White's‌ ‌theory‌ ‌was‌ ‌quite‌ ‌convincing‌ ‌since‌ ‌it‌ ‌had‌ ‌shown‌ ‌that‌ ‌over‌ ‌a‌ ‌period‌ ‌of‌ ‌time‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌incremental‌ ‌growth‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌quantity‌ ‌and‌ ‌quality‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nenergy.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Naturally‌ ‌one‌ ‌can‌ ‌say‌ ‌the‌ ‌amount‌ ‌of‌ ‌energy‌ ‌harnessed‌ ‌in‌ ‌simple‌ ‌societies‌ ‌is‌ ‌far‌ ‌less‌ ‌than‌ ‌complex‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌\n○Similarly‌ ‌technology‌ ‌has‌ ‌grown‌ ‌from‌ ‌simple‌ ‌to‌ ‌complex.‌ ‌ ‌\n627‌ ‌\n●However‌ ‌‌White‌ ‌was‌ ‌criticised‌ ‌for‌ ‌giving‌ ‌a‌ ‌negligible‌ ‌place‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌role‌ ‌of‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌in‌ ‌particular‌ ‌society‌ ‌as‌ ‌he‌ ‌talked‌ ‌of‌ ‌universal‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌world.‌ ‌ ‌\n○That‌ ‌is‌ ‌why‌ ‌he‌ ‌is‌ ‌called‌ ‌a‌ ‌‌Universal‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌evolutionist.‌ ‌\n●Apart‌ ‌from‌ ‌this‌ ‌he‌ ‌considered‌ ‌environmental‌ ‌factors‌ ‌as‌ ‌constant.‌ ‌ ‌\n○As‌ ‌a‌ ‌result‌ ‌Steward‌ ‌gave‌ ‌the‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌ecology‌ ‌to‌ ‌show‌ ‌the‌ ‌importance‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌impact‌ ‌environment‌ ‌on‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌change.‌ ‌\nConclusion:‌ ‌ ‌\n●Though‌ ‌White‌ ‌was‌ ‌criticised‌ ‌for‌ ‌ignoring‌ ‌particular‌ ‌culture‌ ‌&‌ ‌environment‌ ‌factors,‌ ‌his‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌energy‌ ‌&‌ ‌technology‌ ‌gives‌ ‌clear‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌about‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌society‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nSpecific‌ ‌&‌ ‌General‌ ‌Evolution‌ ‌\nSahlin‌ ‌&‌ ‌Service‌ ‌\n●Marshall‌ ‌Sahlin‌ ‌and‌ ‌Elman‌ ‌Service‌ ‌combined‌ ‌their‌ ‌beauty‌ ‌and‌ ‌formed‌ ‌two‌ ‌different‌ ‌kind‌ ‌of‌ ‌evolution,‌ ‌specific‌ ‌&‌ ‌general.‌ ‌\n●Sahlin‌ ‌found‌ ‌the‌‌ ‌parallelism‌ ‌and‌ ‌convergence.‌ ‌\n○Sometimes‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌change‌ ‌follows‌ ‌a‌ ‌common‌ ‌pathway‌ ‌in‌ ‌two‌ ‌or‌ ‌more‌ ‌unrelated‌ ‌or‌ ‌distantly-related‌ ‌organisms‌ ‌because‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nsimilar‌ ‌environmental‌ ‌pressures.‌ ‌It‌ ‌culminates‌ ‌in‌ ‌unrelated‌ ‌organisms‌ ‌with‌ ‌similar‌ ‌morphological‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌even‌ ‌though‌ ‌they‌ ‌did‌ ‌\nnot‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌common‌ ‌ancestor.‌ ‌This‌ ‌phenomenon‌ ‌is‌ ‌called‌ ‌‌parallel‌ ‌evolution‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○When‌ ‌parallel‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌under‌ ‌similar‌ ‌environmental‌ ‌conditions‌ ‌in‌ ‌distantly-related‌ ‌organisms‌ ‌results‌ ‌in‌ ‌plants‌ ‌and‌ ‌animals‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌\nmorphologically‌ ‌very‌ ‌similar‌ ‌in‌ ‌overall‌ ‌appearance,‌ ‌this‌ ‌is‌ ‌called‌ ‌‌convergent‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Multilinear‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌dealt‌ ‌with‌ ‌limited‌ ‌parallels‌ ‌of‌ ‌forms,‌ ‌function‌ ‌and‌ ‌sequence‌ ‌which‌ ‌have‌ ‌empirical‌ ‌validity.‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌Steward,‌ ‌multilinear‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌is‌ ‌essentially‌ ‌methodology‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌assumption‌ ‌significant‌ ‌regularity‌ ‌in‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌change‌ ‌\noccurs.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Marshal‌ ‌Sahlin‌ ‌\n ‌\nAbout:‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○The‌ ‌author‌ ‌of‌ ‌revolution‌ ‌and‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌He‌ ‌divided‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌societies‌ ‌into:‌ ‌\n■General‌ ‌\n■Specific‌ ‌\n○General‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌field‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌system‌ ‌increase‌ ‌in‌ ‌complexity,‌ ‌Organised‌ ‌and‌ ‌adaptiveness‌ ‌to‌ ‌their‌ ‌environment.‌ ‌\n○However,‌ ‌as‌ ‌various‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌or‌ ‌not‌ ‌isolated‌ ‌their‌ ‌interaction‌ ‌and‌ ‌diffusion‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌quality.‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌lead‌ ‌to‌ ‌culture‌ ‌to‌ ‌deviate‌ ‌from‌ ‌general‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌and‌ ‌develop‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌specific‌ ‌unique‌ ‌way.‌ ‌I.e.‌ ‌specific‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌\n628‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Elman‌ ‌Service‌ ‌\n ‌\nAbout:‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○He‌ ‌defined‌ ‌four‌ ‌classification‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌stages‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌also‌ ‌four‌ ‌level‌ ‌of‌ ‌political‌ ‌organisation:‌ ‌‌Band,‌ ‌tribe,‌ ‌\nchiefdom‌ ‌and‌ ‌state‌ ‌\n○He‌ ‌also‌ ‌developed‌ ‌the‌ ‌‘managerial‌ ‌benefit‌ ‌theory’‌ ‌that‌ ‌states‌ ‌that‌ ‌chiefdom‌ ‌like‌ ‌society‌ ‌developed‌ ‌because‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌apparently‌ ‌\nconsfical‌ ‌because‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌centralised‌ ‌leadership.‌ ‌\n○Provides‌ ‌benefit‌ ‌to‌ ‌followers‌ ‌which‌ ‌overtime‌ ‌become‌ ‌more‌ ‌complex,‌ ‌benefiting‌ ‌the‌ ‌whole‌ ‌chief‌ ‌town‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌keep‌ ‌the‌ ‌leader‌ ‌in‌ ‌power‌ ‌and‌ ‌allows‌ ‌the‌ ‌bureaucratic‌ ‌organisation‌ ‌to‌ ‌grow.‌ ‌\n ‌\nCriticism‌ ‌of‌ ‌Neo-Evolutionism‌ ‌\n●New‌ ‌evolutionism‌ ‌is‌ ‌more‌ ‌likely‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌a‌ ‌methodology‌ ‌then‌ ‌theory‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌various‌ ‌reasons:‌ ‌\n○New‌ ‌nationalism‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌assumption‌ ‌that‌ ‌regularities‌ ‌in‌ ‌culture‌ ‌change‌ ‌occur‌ ‌and‌ ‌are‌ ‌concerned‌ ‌with‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌law.‌ ‌\n○Neo‌ ‌evolutionism‌ ‌deals‌ ‌with‌ ‌forms,‌ ‌functions‌ ‌and‌ ‌sequence‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture,‌ ‌which‌ ‌have‌ ‌empirical‌ ‌validity.‌ ‌\n○Theory‌ ‌has‌ ‌correctness‌ ‌and‌ ‌specificity‌ ‌e‌ ‌but‌ ‌new‌ ‌evolutionism‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌theory‌ ‌in‌ ‌true‌ ‌sense‌ ‌because‌ ‌it‌ ‌lacks‌ ‌the‌ ‌correctness‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nspecificity.‌ ‌\n○Nature‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌dynamic‌ ‌i.e.‌ ‌culture‌ ‌changes‌ ‌with‌ ‌time‌ ‌and‌ ‌space.‌ ‌new‌ ‌evolutions‌ ‌did‌ ‌not‌ ‌able‌ ‌to‌ ‌solve‌ ‌the‌ ‌problem‌ ‌of‌ ‌time‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nspace‌ ‌to‌ ‌deduce‌ ‌a‌ ‌cross‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌similarity.‌ ‌\nFor‌ ‌all‌ ‌these‌ ‌drawbacks‌ ‌the‌ ‌neo‌ ‌evolutionism‌ ‌remained‌ ‌from‌ ‌being‌ ‌a‌ ‌Theory‌ ‌it‌ ‌regarded‌ ‌as‌ ‌an‌ ‌essential‌ ‌methodology.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n629‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nClassical‌ ‌vs‌ ‌Neo-Evolutionism‌ ‌\n ‌\nS.No‌ ‌\n\t\nFeatures‌ ‌\n\t\nClassical‌ ‌Evolutionism‌ ‌\n\t\nNeo-Evolutionism‌ ‌\n\n\n1‌ ‌\n\t\nNature‌ ‌\n\t\nSynchronic‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌society‌ ‌and‌ ‌culture‌ ‌\n\t\nDiachronic‌ ‌study‌ ‌by‌ ‌rejuvenation‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nevolutionary‌ ‌study‌ ‌\n\n\n2‌ ‌\n\t\nHistorical‌ ‌\nBackground‌ ‌\n\t\nContribution‌ ‌of‌ ‌Pre-Darwinian‌ ‌scholars‌ ‌&‌ ‌influence‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nDarwinism‌ ‌\n\t\nReaction‌ ‌against‌ ‌functionalism‌ ‌and‌ ‌inspired‌ ‌by‌ ‌\nclassical‌ ‌evolutionism‌ ‌\n\n\n3‌ ‌\n\t\nPeriod‌ ‌\n\t\nMid‌ ‌of‌ ‌19th‌ ‌Century‌ ‌\n\t\nDuring‌ ‌first‌ ‌half‌ ‌of‌ ‌20th‌ ‌century‌ ‌\n\n\n4‌ ‌\n\t\nScholars‌ ‌\n\t\nMorgan‌ ‌&‌ ‌Tylor‌ ‌\n\t\nWhite,‌ ‌Steward,‌ ‌Childe,‌ ‌Sahlin‌ ‌&‌ ‌Service‌ ‌\n\n\n5‌ ‌\n\t\nEvidence‌ ‌\n\t\nStudy‌ ‌without‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌\n\t\nStudy‌ ‌with‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌\n\n\n6‌ ‌\n\t\nData‌ ‌\n\t\nSecondary‌ ‌data‌ ‌\n\t\nFirst‌ ‌hand‌ ‌data‌ ‌\n\n\n7‌ ‌\n\t\nDiffusion‌ ‌\n\t\nDid‌ ‌not‌ ‌consider‌ ‌diffusion‌ ‌\n\t\nConsider‌ ‌diffusion‌ ‌\n\n\n8‌ ‌\n\t\nTypes‌ ‌of‌ ‌Evolution‌ ‌\n\t\nUnilinear‌ ‌\n\t\nMultilinear,‌ ‌Universal,‌ ‌General‌ ‌&‌ ‌Specific‌ ‌\n\n\n9‌ ‌\n\t\nCultural‌ ‌Diversity‌ ‌\n\t\nAbsent‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌unilinear‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌\n\t\nPresent‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌Multilinear‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌\n\n\n10‌ ‌\n\t\nPsychic‌ ‌Unity‌ ‌\n\t\nAccepted‌ ‌\n\t\nRejected‌ ‌\n\n\n11‌ ‌\n\t\nEthnocentrism‌ ‌\n\t\nVictorian‌ ‌society‌ ‌is‌ ‌highest‌ ‌stage‌ ‌of‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌\n\t\n-‌ ‌\n\n\n12‌ ‌\n\t\nParallelism‌ ‌\n\t\nCompared‌ ‌contemporary‌ ‌tribal‌ ‌societies‌ ‌with‌ ‌\nprehistoric‌ ‌societies‌ ‌\n\t\nDid‌ ‌not‌ ‌use‌ ‌comparative‌ ‌method‌ ‌of‌ ‌study‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n630‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n6.‌ ‌Anthropological‌ ‌theories‌ ‌:‌ ‌(b)‌ ‌Historical‌ ‌particularism‌ ‌(Boas)‌ ‌Diffusionism‌ ‌(British,‌ ‌German‌ ‌and‌ ‌American)-Part-II‌ ‌\n ‌\nHistorical‌ ‌particularism‌ ‌(Boas)‌ ‌ ‌\nIntroduction‌ ‌\n●Particularism,‌ ‌also‌ ‌called‌ ‌historical‌ ‌particularism,‌ ‌school‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropological‌ ‌thought‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌work‌ ‌of‌ ‌Franz‌ ‌Boas‌ ‌and‌ ‌his‌ ‌students‌ ‌\n(among‌ ‌them‌ ‌A.L.‌ ‌Kroeber,‌ ‌Ruth‌ ‌Benedict,‌ ‌and‌ ‌Margaret‌ ‌Mead),‌ ‌whose‌ ‌studies‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌emphasized‌ ‌the‌ ‌integrated‌ ‌and‌ ‌distinctive‌ ‌way‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nlife‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌given‌ ‌people.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Particularism‌ ‌stood‌ ‌in‌ ‌opposition‌ ‌to‌ ‌theories‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌evolution.‌ ‌\n●Historical‌ ‌particularism‌ ‌claims‌ ‌that‌ ‌each‌ ‌society‌ ‌has‌ ‌its‌ ‌own‌ ‌unique‌ ‌historical‌ ‌development‌ ‌and‌ ‌must‌ ‌be‌ ‌understood‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌its‌ ‌own‌ ‌\nspecific‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌context,‌ ‌especially‌ ‌its‌ ‌historical‌ ‌process.‌ ‌\n●Historical‌ ‌particularism‌ ‌claimed‌ ‌themselves‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌‌free‌ ‌from‌ ‌preconceived‌ ‌ideas.‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌conducted‌ ‌first‌ ‌hand‌ ‌field‌ ‌work‌ ‌and‌ ‌analysed‌ ‌data,‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌raw‌ ‌data‌ ‌they‌ ‌described‌ ‌particular‌ ‌culture‌ ‌instead‌ ‌of‌ ‌establishment‌ ‌of‌ ‌\ngeneral‌ ‌theories.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nDefinition:‌ ‌\nHistorical‌ ‌Particularism‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌term‌ ‌historical‌ ‌particularism‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌idea‌ ‌that‌ ‌each‌ ‌culture‌ ‌has‌ ‌its‌ ‌own‌ ‌particular‌ ‌and‌ ‌unique‌ ‌history‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌governed‌ ‌by‌ ‌\nuniversal‌ ‌laws.‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌idea‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌big‌ ‌component‌ ‌of‌ ‌Boasian‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌because‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌where‌ ‌Boasians‌ ‌put‌ ‌their‌ ‌focus‌ ‌on‌ ‌when‌ ‌studying‌ ‌cultures.‌ ‌Historical‌ ‌\nparticularism‌ ‌was‌ ‌developed‌ ‌in‌ ‌contrast‌ ‌to‌ ‌Boas’‌ ‌rejection‌ ‌of‌ ‌Lewis‌ ‌Henry‌ ‌Morgan’s‌ ‌idea‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌path‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\ncomparative‌ ‌method.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌path‌ ‌used‌ ‌generalities‌ ‌and‌ ‌universal‌ ‌themes‌ ‌to‌ ‌explain‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌similarities,‌ ‌but‌ ‌Boas‌ ‌“contended‌ ‌that‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌traits‌ ‌first‌ ‌\nmust‌ ‌be‌ ‌explained‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌specific‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌contexts‌ ‌rather‌ ‌than‌ ‌by‌ ‌broad‌ ‌reference‌ ‌to‌ ‌general‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌trends”.‌ ‌\n●Boas‌ ‌and‌ ‌his‌ ‌followers‌ ‌would‌ ‌argue‌ ‌that‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌be‌ ‌compared‌ ‌or‌ ‌be‌ ‌subjected‌ ‌to‌ ‌generalities‌ ‌because‌ ‌each‌ ‌culture‌ ‌experienced‌ ‌a‌ ‌\ndifferent‌ ‌and‌ ‌unique‌ ‌history,‌ ‌even‌ ‌if‌ ‌it‌ ‌led‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌similar‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌aspect.‌ ‌\n●Historical‌ ‌particularism‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌diffusion‌ ‌mentioned‌ ‌above‌ ‌actually‌ ‌go‌ ‌quite‌ ‌hand‌ ‌in‌ ‌hand.‌ ‌ ‌\n631‌ ‌\n●Traits‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌similar‌ ‌between‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌may‌ ‌have‌ ‌diffused‌ ‌through‌ ‌interaction‌ ‌between‌ ‌various‌ ‌cultures.‌ ‌However,‌ ‌while‌ ‌these‌ ‌traits‌ ‌are‌ ‌\nsimilar,‌ ‌they‌ ‌will‌ ‌develop‌ ‌different‌ ‌and‌ ‌unique‌ ‌histories‌ ‌from‌ ‌their‌ ‌movement‌ ‌through‌ ‌various‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nNature‌ ‌Vs.‌ ‌Nurture‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌large‌ ‌critique‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Boasian‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌is‌ ‌that‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌nurture‌ ‌vs.‌ ‌nature‌ ‌debate‌ ‌Boas‌ ‌learned‌ ‌a‌ ‌lot‌ ‌more‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌nurture‌ ‌side‌ ‌oftentimes‌ ‌\ndisregarding‌ ‌the‌ ‌biological‌ ‌aspect‌ ‌that‌ ‌takes‌ ‌place‌ ‌within‌ ‌people‌ ‌in‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌believed‌ ‌that‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌behaviors‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌taught‌ ‌and‌ ‌learned‌ ‌within‌ ‌a‌ ‌society‌ ‌which‌ ‌shapes‌ ‌people‌ ‌much‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌their‌ ‌biology.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌is‌ ‌critiqued‌ ‌for‌ ‌dismissing‌ ‌the‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌makeup‌ ‌in‌ ‌his‌ ‌experiments‌ ‌looking‌ ‌only‌ ‌at‌ ‌how‌ ‌social‌ ‌environment‌ ‌affects‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌individuals.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nMethodology‌ ‌\n●Historical‌ ‌particularism‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌approach‌ ‌to‌ ‌understand‌ ‌the‌ ‌nature‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌culture‌ ‌change‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌person.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌\nideology.‌ ‌\n●Boas‌ ‌argued‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌history‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌culture‌ ‌lay‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌its‌ ‌individual‌ ‌traits‌ ‌unfolding‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌limited‌ ‌geographical‌ ‌region.‌ ‌ ‌\n●After‌ ‌many‌ ‌different‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌studied‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌way‌ ‌within‌ ‌a‌ ‌region,‌ ‌the‌ ‌history‌ ‌of‌ ‌individual‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌reconstructed.‌ ‌ ‌\n●By‌ ‌having‌ ‌detailed‌ ‌data‌ ‌from‌ ‌many‌ ‌different‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌common‌ ‌frame‌ ‌of‌ ‌reference,‌ ‌individual‌ ‌culture‌ ‌traits‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌singled‌ ‌out‌ ‌as‌ ‌being‌ ‌\nborrowed‌ ‌or‌ ‌invented.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌crucial‌ ‌element‌ ‌of‌ ‌reconstructing‌ ‌the‌ ‌history‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌ ‌\n●To‌ ‌this‌ ‌end,‌ ‌Boas‌ ‌and‌ ‌his‌ ‌students‌ ‌stressed‌ ‌the‌ ‌importance‌ ‌of‌ ‌gathering‌ ‌as‌ ‌much‌ ‌data‌ ‌as‌ ‌possible‌ ‌about‌ ‌individual‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌before‌ ‌any‌ ‌\nassumptions‌ ‌or‌ ‌interpretations‌ ‌are‌ ‌made‌ ‌regarding‌ ‌a‌ ‌culture‌ ‌or‌ ‌culture‌ ‌change‌ ‌within‌ ‌a‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌ ‌\n○He‌ ‌and‌ ‌his‌ ‌students‌ ‌took‌ ‌great‌ ‌pains‌ ‌to‌ ‌record‌ ‌all‌ ‌manner‌ ‌of‌ ‌information.‌ ‌This‌ ‌included‌ ‌the‌ ‌recording‌ ‌of‌ ‌oral‌ ‌history‌ ‌and‌ ‌tradition‌ ‌\n(salvage‌ ‌ethnology)‌ ‌and‌ ‌basic‌ ‌ethnographic‌ ‌methods‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌participant‌ ‌observation.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌emphasis‌ ‌on‌ ‌intensive‌ ‌participant‌ ‌observation‌ ‌largely‌ ‌paralleled‌ ‌Malinowski’s‌ ‌fieldwork‌ ‌methods‌ ‌being‌ ‌used‌ ‌by‌ ‌European‌ ‌\nanthropologists‌ ‌around‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌time.‌ ‌ ‌\n○However,‌ ‌the‌ ‌people‌ ‌being‌ ‌studied‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌overall‌ ‌theoretical‌ ‌aims‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌two‌ ‌schools‌ ‌were‌ ‌quite‌ ‌different.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Boas‌ ‌also‌ ‌stressed‌ ‌the‌ ‌importance‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌subfields‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌in‌ ‌reconstructing‌ ‌history.‌ ‌\n○Ethnographic‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌must‌ ‌be‌ ‌used‌ ‌with‌ ‌linguistic‌ ‌evidence,‌ ‌archaeological‌ ‌remains‌ ‌and‌ ‌physical‌ ‌and‌ ‌biological‌ ‌evidence.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌approach‌ ‌became‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌four-field‌ ‌method‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌and‌ ‌was‌ ‌spread‌ ‌to‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌departments‌ ‌all‌ ‌over‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nUnited‌ ‌States‌ ‌by‌ ‌Boas’‌ ‌students‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌students.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Four‌ ‌field‌ ‌method‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropology,that‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌integrated‌ ‌approach:‌ ‌\n○Biological‌ ‌\n○Cultural‌ ‌\n○Archaeological‌ ‌\n○Linguistic‌ ‌\n632‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nAccomplishment‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌was‌ ‌much‌ ‌ahead‌ ‌of‌ ‌its‌ ‌time‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌some‌ ‌progressive‌ ‌idea‌ ‌like:‌ ‌\n○Rejection‌ ‌of‌ ‌ethnocentric‌ ‌Style‌ ‌\n○Adoption‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌relativism-all‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌are‌ ‌equal.‌ ‌\n○Emphasized‌ ‌on‌ ‌human‌ ‌values‌ ‌leading‌ ‌to‌ ‌applied‌ ‌anthropology.‌ ‌\n●Many‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌conclusions‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌those‌ ‌of‌ ‌its‌ ‌most‌ ‌noted‌ ‌student‌ ‌have‌ ‌fallen‌ ‌out‌ ‌of‌ ‌favour‌ ‌as‌ ‌more‌ ‌anthropological‌ ‌work‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌carried‌ ‌\nout.‌ ‌\n● ‌In‌ ‌his‌ ‌book‌ ‌‘‌Race‌ ‌language‌ ‌and‌ ‌culture’(1940)‌-‌ ‌integrated‌ ‌approach.‌ ‌\n○He‌ ‌argued‌ ‌that‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌should‌ ‌not‌ ‌run‌ ‌after‌ ‌low‌ ‌formulation;‌ ‌it‌ ‌should‌ ‌be‌ ‌the‌ ‌task‌ ‌of‌ ‌posterity.‌ ‌\n○He‌ ‌said‌ ‌the‌ ‌real‌ ‌task‌ ‌is‌ ‌to‌ ‌study‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌culture‌ ‌in‌ ‌historical‌ ‌folding‌ ‌emphasizing‌ ‌on‌ ‌race,‌ ‌language,‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌process‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nmigration.‌ ‌\n○Such‌ ‌a‌ ‌detailed‌ ‌study‌ ‌can‌ ‌alone‌ ‌take‌ ‌us‌ ‌to‌ ‌really‌ ‌understanding.‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌avoided‌ ‌comparison‌ ‌and‌ ‌was‌ ‌critical‌ ‌of‌ ‌comparative‌ ‌study.‌ ‌\n○He‌ ‌believed‌ ‌that‌ ‌after‌ ‌detailed‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌there‌ ‌may‌ ‌arrive‌ ‌the‌ ‌scope‌ ‌of‌ ‌comparison.‌ ‌\n●During‌ ‌his‌ ‌field‌ ‌work‌ ‌with‌ ‌an‌ ‌interdisciplinary‌ ‌team‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Baffin‌ ‌Land‌ ‌Expedition‌ ‌(1893)‌  ‌developed‌ ‌his‌ ‌interdisciplinary‌ ‌perspective‌ ‌which‌ ‌led‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌his‌ ‌idea‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌relativism.‌ ‌\n●One‌ ‌aspect‌ ‌was‌ ‌no‌ ‌society‌ ‌awarded‌ ‌higher‌ ‌or‌ ‌lower‌ ‌than‌ ‌another‌ ‌and‌ ‌therefore‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌rank‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌savagery,‌ ‌barbarity‌ ‌and‌ ‌civilization.‌ ‌\n633‌ ‌\n●Boas‌ ‌and‌ ‌his‌ ‌students‌ ‌are‌ ‌responsible‌ ‌for‌ ‌taking‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌away‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌Grand‌ ‌theories‌ ‌of‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌and‌ ‌diffusion‌ ‌and‌ ‌refocusing‌ ‌its‌ ‌\nattention‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌different‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌variations‌ ‌Of‌ ‌Cultural‌ ‌experience.‌ ‌\n ‌\nCriticism‌ ‌\n●Why‌ ‌not‌ ‌encourage‌ ‌theory‌ ‌building,‌ ‌Boas‌ ‌took‌ ‌up‌ ‌a‌ ‌regressive‌ ‌step‌ ‌in‌ ‌disciplinary‌ ‌growth.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌nature‌ ‌of‌ ‌field‌ ‌studies‌ ‌subject‌ ‌to‌ ‌criticism.‌ ‌\n ‌\nConclusion‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌idea‌ ‌of‌ ‌Boas‌ ‌like‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌relativism,applied‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌are‌ ‌used‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌later‌ ‌anthropologist.‌ ‌\n●FB‌ ‌was‌ ‌truly‌ ‌ahead‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌time‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌openness‌ ‌and‌ ‌postuity.‌ ‌\n●His‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌give‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌width‌ ‌to‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌department‌ ‌for‌ ‌further‌ ‌resource‌ ‌and‌ ‌thought.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nDiffusionism‌ ‌(British,‌ ‌German‌ ‌and‌ ‌American)‌ ‌\n ‌\n634‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nIntroduction:‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌diffusion‌ ‌emerged‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌early‌ ‌years‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌20th‌ ‌century.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Diffusionists‌ ‌view‌ ‌that‌ ‌various‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌traits‌ ‌and‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌complexes‌ ‌develop‌ ‌at‌ ‌various‌ ‌times‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌parts‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌world‌ ‌and‌ ‌later‌ ‌on‌ ‌\ndiffuse‌ ‌over‌ ‌corresponding‌ ‌parts‌ ‌of‌ ‌earth.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Thus,‌ ‌‌diffusionists‌ ‌are‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌opinion‌ ‌that‌ ‌culture‌ ‌has‌ ‌growth,‌ ‌not‌ ‌because‌ ‌of‌ ‌evolution,‌ ‌but‌ ‌because‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌spread‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌traits‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌complexes‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌historical‌ ‌happenings‌ ‌and‌ ‌mutual‌ ‌contacts.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Cultural‌ ‌diffusion‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌process,‌ ‌by‌ ‌which‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌traits‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌or‌ ‌invented‌ ‌at‌ ‌one‌ ‌place‌ ‌or‌ ‌society‌ ‌is‌ ‌spread‌ ‌directly‌ ‌or‌ ‌indirectly‌ ‌to‌ ‌other‌ ‌\nsocieties‌ ‌or‌ ‌places.‌ ‌\n635‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nConditions‌ ‌for‌ ‌Cultural‌ ‌Diffusion‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Any‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌group‌ ‌adopts‌ ‌the‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌traits‌ ‌of‌ ‌another‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌group,‌ ‌only‌ ‌when‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌meaningful‌ ‌or‌ ‌useful‌ ‌either‌ ‌economically‌ ‌or‌ ‌socially‌ ‌or‌ ‌\nboth.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌course‌ ‌of‌ ‌diffusion,‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌traits‌ ‌will‌ ‌not‌ ‌remain‌ ‌in‌ ‌its‌ ‌original‌ ‌form.‌ ‌‌Changes‌ ‌in‌ ‌it‌ ‌can‌ ‌take‌ ‌place‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌different‌ ‌environmental‌ ‌situations.‌ ‌\n●Process‌ ‌of‌ ‌diffusion‌ ‌is‌ ‌always‌ ‌from‌ ‌high‌ ‌culture‌ ‌to‌ ‌low‌ ‌culture‌ ‌or‌ ‌developed‌ ‌culture‌ ‌to‌ ‌under-developed‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\n636‌ ‌\n●Process‌ ‌of‌ ‌diffusion‌ ‌may‌ ‌create‌ ‌culture‌ ‌change‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌group,‌ ‌adopting‌ ‌the‌ ‌culture‌ ‌traits‌ ‌of‌ ‌other‌ ‌groups.‌ ‌\n●There‌ ‌are‌ ‌some‌ ‌obstacles‌ ‌or‌ ‌barriers‌ ‌for‌ ‌culture‌ ‌diffusion.‌ ‌‌These‌ ‌include‌ ‌lack‌ ‌of‌ ‌transportation‌ ‌and‌ ‌communication‌ ‌or‌ ‌some‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌physical‌ ‌\nbarriers‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌ocean,‌ ‌river,‌ ‌mountain,‌ ‌desert‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n ‌\nSchools‌ ‌of‌ ‌Diffusionism‌ ‌\n●Though‌ ‌diffusionists‌ ‌admit‌ ‌that‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌traits‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌or‌ ‌invented‌ ‌at‌ ‌one‌ ‌place‌ ‌or‌ ‌society,‌ ‌are‌ ‌spread‌ ‌to‌ ‌other‌ ‌places‌ ‌or‌ ‌societies,‌ ‌‌they‌ ‌\nhave‌ ‌not‌ ‌shown‌ ‌unanimity‌ ‌as‌ ‌to‌ ‌which‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌place‌ ‌from‌ ‌where‌ ‌culture‌ ‌traits‌ ‌reached‌ ‌to‌ ‌other‌ ‌parts.‌ ‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌differences‌ ‌resulted‌ ‌in‌ ‌three‌ ‌different‌ ‌‌Diffusionists‌ ‌Schools‌ ‌of‌ ‌thought‌ ‌in‌ ‌Anthropology‌.‌ ‌\n●There‌ ‌are‌ ‌three‌ ‌major‌ ‌schools‌ ‌of‌ ‌diffusion:‌ ‌\n○British‌ ‌School‌ ‌of‌ ‌Diffusion‌ ‌\n○German‌ ‌or‌ ‌Continental‌ ‌School‌ ‌of‌ ‌Diffusion‌ ‌\n○American‌ ‌School‌ ‌of‌ ‌Diffusion‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n637‌ ‌\nBritish‌ ‌School‌ ‌of‌ ‌Diffusionism‌ ‌\n●G‌ ‌E‌ ‌Smith,‌ ‌W‌ ‌J‌ ‌Perry‌ ‌and‌ ‌W‌ ‌H‌ ‌R‌ ‌Rivers‌‌ ‌were‌ ‌the‌ ‌main‌ ‌scholars‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌school.‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌considered‌ ‌‌ancient‌ ‌Egypt‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌cradle‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌world.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n●This‌ ‌school‌ ‌of‌ ‌diffusion‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌‌Pan-Egyptian‌ ‌school‌.‌ ‌\n○ ‌‌G‌ ‌E‌ ‌Smith‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌founder‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌school‌ ‌and‌ ‌W‌ ‌J‌ ‌Perry‌ ‌was‌ ‌his‌ ‌true‌ ‌follower.‌ ‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌are‌ ‌also‌ ‌called‌ ‌as‌ ‌extreme‌ ‌diffusionists‌ ‌because,‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌them,‌ ‌Egypt‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌only‌ ‌centre‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌from‌ ‌where‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌traits‌ ‌\nspread‌ ‌or‌ ‌diffused‌ ‌to‌ ‌other‌ ‌parts‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌world.‌ ‌ ‌\n●As‌ ‌their‌ ‌works‌ ‌and‌ ‌findings‌ ‌mainly‌ ‌concentrated‌ ‌on‌ ‌Egypt,‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌also‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌‌Egyptologists‌.‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌also‌ ‌argued‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌worship‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌sun‌ ‌which‌ ‌originated‌ ‌in‌ ‌Egypt‌ ‌is‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌all‌ ‌other‌ ‌parts‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌world.‌ ‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌used‌ ‌migration‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌main‌ ‌cause‌ ‌of‌ ‌diffusion.‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌‌Smith‌,‌ ‌ancient‌ ‌Egypt‌ ‌was‌ ‌favoured‌ ‌by‌ ‌natural‌ ‌and‌ ‌ecological‌ ‌settings‌ ‌and‌ ‌gave‌ ‌rise‌ ‌to‌ ‌cultivation.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Egptian‌ ‌invented‌ ‌pottery‌ ‌and‌ ‌later‌ ‌on,‌ ‌built‌ ‌cities.‌ ‌They‌ ‌established‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌like‌ ‌religion,‌ ‌government,‌ ‌laws‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌him,‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌traits‌ ‌developed‌ ‌only‌ ‌in‌ ‌Egypt,‌ ‌from‌ ‌where‌ ‌it‌ ‌diffused‌ ‌to‌ ‌other‌ ‌parts‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌world.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Thus,‌ ‌he‌ ‌argued‌ ‌that‌ ‌ancient‌ ‌Egypt‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌cradle‌ ‌of‌ ‌civilisation.‌ ‌\n ‌\nMethodology‌ ‌\n638‌ ‌\n●British‌ ‌School‌ ‌of‌ ‌Thought:‌ ‌Diffusionism‌ ‌occurred‌ ‌in‌ ‌its‌ ‌most‌ ‌extreme‌ ‌form‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌British‌ ‌school‌ ‌of‌ ‌thought.‌ ‌W.‌ ‌H.‌ ‌R.‌ ‌Rivers‌ ‌was‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌founder‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌ideas.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌confined‌ ‌his‌ ‌studies‌ ‌to‌ ‌Oceania,‌ ‌where‌ ‌he‌ ‌tried‌ ‌to‌ ‌organize‌ ‌the‌ ‌ethnography‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌nomothetic‌ ‌principles‌ ‌and‌ ‌sought‌ ‌to‌ ‌explain‌ ‌the‌ ‌\ncontrasts‌ ‌between‌ ‌Melanesian‌ ‌and‌ ‌Polynesian‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌spread‌ ‌of‌ ‌original‌ ‌complexes,‌ ‌which‌ ‌supposedly‌ ‌had‌ ‌been‌ ‌spread‌ ‌by‌ ‌\nsuccessive‌ ‌waves‌ ‌of‌ ‌migrating‌ ‌people.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Rivers‌ ‌states‌ ‌that‌ ‌“a‌ ‌few‌ ‌immigrants‌ ‌possessed‌ ‌of‌ ‌superior‌ ‌technology‌ ‌can‌ ‌impose‌ ‌their‌ ‌customs‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌large‌ ‌autochthonous‌ ‌population”‌‌ ‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌also‌ ‌applied‌ ‌this‌ ‌extreme‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌diffusionism‌ ‌to‌ ‌Australian‌ ‌burial‌ ‌practices.‌ ‌The‌ ‌obvious‌ ‌problem‌ ‌with‌ ‌Rivers’‌ ‌explanations‌ ‌appears‌ ‌\nwhen‌ ‌questioned‌ ‌as‌ ‌to‌ ‌why‌ ‌the‌ ‌technology‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌“newcomers”‌ ‌disappeared‌ ‌if‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌superior.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Rivers‌ ‌solves‌ ‌the‌ ‌problem‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌rather‌ ‌fantastical‌ ‌flare.‌ ‌He‌ ‌claims‌ ‌that‌ ‌because‌ ‌the‌ ‌“newcomers”‌ ‌were‌ ‌small‌ ‌in‌ ‌number,‌ ‌they‌ ‌failed‌ ‌to‌ ‌assert‌ ‌\ntheir‌ ‌“racial‌ ‌strain”‌ ‌into‌ ‌the‌ ‌population‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nBritish:‌ ‌\nG.‌ ‌Elliot‌ ‌Smith‌ ‌(1871-1937)‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nAbout:G.‌ ‌Elliot‌ ‌Smith‌ ‌\n639‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Sir‌ ‌Grafton‌ ‌Elliot‌ ‌Smith,‌ ‌was‌ ‌an‌ ‌Australian-British‌ ‌anatomist,‌ ‌Egyptologist‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌proponent‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌hyperdiffusionist‌ ‌view‌ ‌of‌ ‌prehistory.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌believed‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌idea‌ ‌that‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌innovations‌ ‌occur‌ ‌only‌ ‌once‌ ‌and‌ ‌that‌ ‌they‌ ‌spread‌ ‌geographically.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●He‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌prominent‌ ‌‌British‌ ‌anatomist‌ ‌‌who‌ ‌produced‌ ‌a‌ ‌most‌ ‌curious‌ ‌view‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌arguing‌ ‌that‌ ‌Egypt‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌source‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌\nhigher‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌based‌ ‌this‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌following‌ ‌assumptions:‌ ‌ ‌\n(1)‌ ‌man‌ ‌was‌ ‌uninventive,‌ ‌culture‌ ‌seldom‌ ‌arose‌ ‌independently,‌ ‌and‌ ‌culture‌ ‌only‌ ‌arose‌ ‌in‌ ‌certain‌ ‌circumstances;‌ ‌ ‌\n(2)‌ ‌these‌ ‌circumstances‌ ‌only‌ ‌existed‌ ‌in‌ ‌ancient‌ ‌Egypt,‌ ‌which‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌location‌ ‌from‌ ‌which‌ ‌all‌ ‌culture,‌ ‌except‌ ‌for‌ ‌its‌ ‌simplest‌ ‌elements,‌ ‌had‌ ‌\nspread‌ ‌after‌ ‌the‌ ‌advent‌ ‌of‌ ‌navigation;‌ ‌ ‌\n(3)‌ ‌human‌ ‌history‌ ‌was‌ ‌full‌ ‌of‌ ‌decadence‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌spread‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌civilization‌ ‌was‌ ‌naturally‌ ‌diluted‌ ‌as‌ ‌it‌ ‌radiated‌ ‌outwardly.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nW.‌ ‌H.‌ ‌R.‌ ‌Rivers‌ ‌(1864-1922)‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nAbout:W.‌ ‌H.‌ ‌R.‌ ‌Rivers‌ ‌\n640‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●William‌ ‌Halse‌ ‌Rivers‌ ‌Rivers‌ ‌was‌ ‌an‌ ‌English‌ ‌anthropologist,‌ ‌neurologist,‌ ‌ethnologist‌ ‌and‌ ‌psychiatrist,‌ ‌best‌ ‌known‌ ‌for‌ ‌his‌ ‌work‌ ‌treating‌ ‌First‌ ‌\nWorld‌ ‌War‌ ‌officers‌ ‌who‌ ‌were‌ ‌suffering‌ ‌from‌ ‌shell‌ ‌shock‌ ‌in‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌return‌ ‌them‌ ‌to‌ ‌combat.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n●He‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌‌British‌ ‌doctor‌ ‌and‌ ‌psychiatrist‌ ‌who‌ ‌became‌ ‌interested‌ ‌in‌ ‌ethnology‌ ‌after‌ ‌he‌ ‌went‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌Cambridge‌ ‌expedition‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌Torres‌ ‌Straits‌ ‌in‌ ‌\n1898.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌later‌ ‌pursued‌ ‌research‌ ‌in‌ ‌India‌ ‌and‌ ‌Melanesia.‌ ‌His‌ ‌interest‌ ‌in‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌established‌ ‌him‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌pioneer‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌genealogical‌ ‌method‌ ‌and‌ ‌his‌ ‌\nbackground‌ ‌in‌ ‌psychiatry‌ ‌enabled‌ ‌him‌ ‌to‌ ‌do‌ ‌research‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌area‌ ‌of‌ ‌sensory‌ ‌perception.‌ ‌\n●Rivers‌ ‌was‌ ‌converted‌ ‌to‌ ‌diffusionism‌ ‌while‌ ‌writing‌ ‌his‌ ‌book,‌ ‌‌The‌ ‌History‌ ‌of‌ ‌Melanesian‌ ‌Society‌,‌ ‌and‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌founder‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌diffusionist‌ ‌trend‌ ‌\nin‌ ‌Britain.‌ ‌In‌ ‌1911,‌ ‌He‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌to‌ ‌speak‌ ‌out‌ ‌again‌ ‌evolutionism.‌ ‌\nW.‌ ‌J.‌ ‌Perry‌ ‌\n ‌\nAbout:‌ ‌W.‌ ‌J.‌ ‌Perry‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●W.‌ ‌J.‌ ‌Perry,‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌leader‌ ‌in‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌at‌ ‌University‌ ‌College,‌ ‌London.‌ ‌Megalith‌ ‌culture,‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌him,‌ ‌was‌ ‌transmitted‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nrest‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌world‌ ‌from‌ ‌Egypt.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌convinced‌ ‌hyperdiffusionist‌ ‌and‌ ‌collaborated‌ ‌with‌ ‌Grafton‌ ‌Elliot‌ ‌Smith.‌ ‌\n641‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Smith‌ ‌and‌ ‌W.‌ ‌J.‌ ‌Perry,‌ ‌a‌ ‌student‌ ‌of‌ ‌W.‌ ‌H.‌ ‌R.‌ ‌Rivers‌ ‌hypothesized‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌entire‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌inventory‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌world‌ ‌had‌ ‌diffused‌ ‌from‌ ‌Egypt.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌development‌ ‌began‌ ‌in‌ ‌Egypt,‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌them,‌ ‌about‌ ‌6,000‌ ‌years‌ ‌ago.‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌diffusion‌ ‌is‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌‌heliocentrism‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n●They‌ ‌believed‌ ‌that‌ ‌“‌Natural‌ ‌Man‌”‌ ‌‌inhabited‌ ‌the‌ ‌world‌ ‌before‌ ‌development‌ ‌began‌ ‌and‌ ‌that‌ ‌he‌ ‌had‌ ‌no‌ ‌clothing,‌ ‌houses,‌ ‌agriculture,‌ ‌\ndomesticated‌ ‌animals,‌ ‌religion,‌ ‌social‌ ‌organization,‌ ‌formal‌ ‌laws,‌ ‌ceremonies,‌ ‌or‌ ‌hereditary‌ ‌chiefs.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌discovery‌ ‌of‌ ‌barley‌ ‌in‌ ‌4,000‌ ‌B.‌ ‌C.‌ ‌enabled‌ ‌people‌ ‌to‌ ‌settle‌ ‌in‌ ‌one‌ ‌location.‌ ‌ ‌\n●From‌ ‌that‌ ‌point‌ ‌invention‌ ‌in‌ ‌culture‌ ‌exploded‌ ‌and‌ ‌was‌ ‌spread‌ ‌during‌ ‌Egyptian‌ ‌migrations‌ ‌by‌ ‌land‌ ‌and‌ ‌sea.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌account‌ ‌was‌ ‌similar‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌Biblical‌ ‌version‌ ‌of‌ ‌world‌ ‌history.‌ ‌\n ‌\n642‌ ‌\n‌American‌ ‌\nSchool‌ ‌of‌ ‌Diffusion‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌major‌ ‌proponents‌ ‌of‌ ‌American‌ ‌school‌ ‌of‌ ‌diffusion‌ ‌are‌ ‌Franz‌ ‌Boas,‌ ‌Clark‌ ‌Wissler‌ ‌and‌ ‌A‌ ‌L‌ ‌Kroeber.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Franz‌ ‌Boas‌ ‌‌is‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌founder‌ ‌of‌ ‌‌American‌ ‌School‌ ‌of‌ ‌Diffusionism.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌‌culture‌ ‌area‌‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌theme‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌American‌ ‌school‌ ‌of‌ ‌diffusion.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Besides,‌ ‌a‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌other‌ ‌concepts‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌culture‌ ‌centre,‌ ‌culture‌ ‌margin,‌ ‌culture‌ ‌climax,‌ ‌age‌ ‌area‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌are‌ ‌also‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌explain‌ ‌the‌ ‌nature‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌process‌ ‌of‌ ‌diffusion.‌ ‌\n643‌ ‌\n●American‌ ‌diffusionists‌ ‌divided‌ ‌the‌ ‌world‌ ‌into‌ ‌different‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌areas‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌geographical‌ ‌similarity.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Clark‌ ‌Wissler‌ ‌‌emphasized‌ ‌the‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌area‌ ‌referring‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌area‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌similar‌ ‌culture‌ ‌traits‌ ‌or‌ ‌culture‌ ‌complexes‌ ‌are‌ ‌found.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Hence,‌ ‌‌American‌ ‌school‌ ‌of‌ ‌diffusion‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌culture‌ ‌area‌ ‌school.‌ ‌\n●Wissler‌ ‌also‌ ‌pointed‌ ‌out‌ ‌that‌ ‌in‌ ‌each‌ ‌culture‌ ‌area,‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌culture‌ ‌centre.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌core‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌culture‌ ‌area,‌ ‌from‌ ‌where‌ ‌all‌ ‌social,‌ ‌economic,‌ ‌political‌ ‌and‌ ‌religious‌ ‌activities‌ ‌are‌ ‌controlled‌ ‌and‌ ‌governed.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌geographical‌ ‌area‌ ‌where‌ ‌maximum‌ ‌culture‌ ‌traits‌ ‌are‌ ‌found‌ ‌and‌ ‌from‌ ‌where‌ ‌various‌ ‌culture‌ ‌traits‌ ‌diffuse‌ ‌to‌ ‌other‌ ‌parts.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Cultural‌ ‌margin‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌peripheral‌ ‌area‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌culture‌ ‌where‌ ‌minimum‌ ‌culture‌ ‌traits‌ ‌are‌ ‌found.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌also‌ ‌keeps‌ ‌borders‌ ‌with‌ ‌other‌ ‌cultures.‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌L‌ ‌Kroeber‌ ‌‌used‌ ‌the‌ ‌term‌ ‌culture‌ ‌climax‌ ‌as‌ ‌equivalent‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌term‌ ‌culture‌ ‌centre.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Culture‌ ‌climax‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌portion‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌culture‌ ‌area‌ ‌from‌ ‌where‌ ‌most‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌culture‌ ‌traits‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌area‌ ‌are‌ ‌spread‌ ‌or‌ ‌concentrated.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌also‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌that‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌area‌ ‌where‌ ‌people‌ ‌have‌ ‌the‌ ‌largest‌ ‌contact‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\n●Wissler‌ ‌also‌ ‌put‌ ‌forward‌ ‌the‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌'age‌ ‌area’.‌ ‌‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌relative‌ ‌age‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌traits‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌geographical‌ ‌distribution.‌ ‌It‌ ‌means,‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nmost‌ ‌widely‌ ‌distributed‌ ‌trait‌ ‌around‌ ‌the‌ ‌centre‌ ‌would‌ ‌be‌ ‌the‌ ‌oldest‌ ‌one.‌ ‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌Wissler,‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌mainly‌ ‌two‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌diffusions:‌ ‌ ‌\n○Natural‌ ‌diffusion‌ ‌and‌ ‌Organised‌ ‌diffusion.‌ ‌\n○Natural‌ ‌Diffusion:‌ ‌ ‌\n■In‌ ‌natural‌ ‌diffusion,‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌traits‌ ‌of‌ ‌one‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌group‌ ‌are‌ ‌diffused‌ ‌to‌ ‌one‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌different‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌group.‌ ‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌is‌ ‌transmitted‌ ‌through‌ ‌natural‌ ‌agencies‌ ‌or‌ ‌by‌ ‌trial‌ ‌and‌ ‌error‌ ‌method.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌time-consuming‌ ‌process‌ ‌and‌ ‌develops‌ ‌gradually.‌ ‌\n○Organised‌ ‌diffusion:‌ ‌ ‌\n■In‌ ‌this‌ ‌diffusion,‌ ‌the‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌traits‌ ‌are‌ ‌transmitted‌ ‌through‌ ‌some‌ ‌organized‌ ‌agencies‌ ‌like‌ ‌missionary‌ ‌activities,‌ ‌military‌ ‌invasion‌ ‌\netc.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Organized‌ ‌diffusion‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌very‌ ‌fast‌ ‌and‌ ‌quick‌ ‌process.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nMethodology‌ ‌\n●American‌ ‌School‌ ‌of‌ ‌Thought:‌ ‌The‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌diffusionism‌ ‌was‌ ‌based‌ ‌in‌ ‌American‌ ‌ethnographic‌ ‌research‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌North‌ ‌and‌ ‌South‌ ‌\nAmerican‌ ‌Indians.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌research‌ ‌logically‌ ‌included‌ ‌the‌ ‌mapping‌ ‌and‌ ‌classifying‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌various‌ ‌American‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌tribes.‌ ‌\n644‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌building‌ ‌of‌ ‌ethnographic‌ ‌collections‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌American‌ ‌Museum‌ ‌of‌ ‌Natural‌ ‌History‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌Chicago‌ ‌Field‌ ‌Museum‌ ‌occurred‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌\ntime‌ ‌that‌ ‌American‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌were‌ ‌reacting‌ ‌to‌ ‌some‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌schemes‌ ‌formulated‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌evolutionists.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌stimulated‌ ‌research‌ ‌concerned‌ ‌with‌ ‌determining‌ ‌how‌ ‌culture‌ ‌traits‌ ‌were‌ ‌arranged‌ ‌geographically‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌“delineated‌ ‌aspect‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nenvironment”.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Although‌ ‌“culture‌ ‌area”‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌term‌ ‌originally‌ ‌used‌ ‌in‌ ‌1895‌ ‌by‌ ‌Otis‌ ‌T.‌ ‌Mason,‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌prominent‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌who‌ ‌used‌ ‌the‌ ‌term‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nresearch‌ ‌were‌ ‌Clark‌ ‌Wissler‌ ‌and‌ ‌A.‌ ‌L.‌ ‌Kroeber.‌ ‌They‌ ‌used‌ ‌the‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌areas‌ ‌to‌ ‌help‌ ‌sort‌ ‌out‌ ‌the‌ ‌findings‌ ‌of‌ ‌American‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌\nethnology‌ ‌ ‌\n●\n ‌\nAmerican‌ ‌\nFranz‌ ‌Boas‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nAbout:‌ ‌Franz‌ ‌Boas‌ ‌\n ‌\n645‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Franz‌ ‌Uri‌ ‌Boas‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌German-born‌ ‌American‌ ‌anthropologist‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌pioneer‌ ‌of‌ ‌modern‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌who‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌called‌ ‌the‌ ‌\"Father‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nAmerican‌ ‌Anthropology\".‌ ‌ ‌\n●His‌ ‌work‌ ‌is‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌movements‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌Historical‌ ‌Particularism‌ ‌and‌ ‌Cultural‌ ‌Relativism‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Boas‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌name‌ ‌most‌ ‌often‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌historicist‌ ‌approach‌ ‌to‌ ‌anthropology.‌ ‌He‌ ‌did‌ ‌not‌ ‌believe‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌grand‌ ‌theories‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nsocio-political‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌or‌ ‌diffusion‌ ‌were‌ ‌provable.‌ ‌ ‌\n●To‌ ‌him,‌ ‌the‌ ‌view‌ ‌that‌ ‌all‌ ‌societies‌ ‌are‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌one‌ ‌single‌ ‌human‌ ‌culture‌ ‌evolving‌ ‌towards‌ ‌a‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌pinnacle‌ ‌is‌ ‌flawed,‌ ‌especially‌ ‌when‌ ‌\nproposing‌ ‌a‌ ‌western‌ ‌model‌ ‌of‌ ‌civilization‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌pinnacle.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Boas‌ ‌also‌ ‌depicted‌ ‌the‌ ‌theories‌ ‌regarding‌ ‌independent‌ ‌invention‌ ‌within‌ ‌human‌ ‌culture‌ ‌as‌ ‌inherently‌ ‌incorrect.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌argued‌ ‌that‌ ‌many‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌developed‌ ‌independently,‌ ‌each‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌its‌ ‌own‌ ‌unique‌ ‌set‌ ‌of‌ ‌circumstances‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌geography,‌ ‌climate,‌ ‌\nresources‌ ‌and‌ ‌particular‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌borrowing.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Based‌ ‌on‌ ‌this‌ ‌argument,‌ ‌reconstructing‌ ‌the‌ ‌history‌ ‌of‌ ‌individual‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌requires‌ ‌an‌ ‌in-depth‌ ‌investigation‌ ‌that‌ ‌compares‌ ‌groups‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌\ntraits‌ ‌in‌ ‌specific‌ ‌geographical‌ ‌areas.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Then‌ ‌the‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌culture‌ ‌traits‌ ‌must‌ ‌be‌ ‌plotted.‌ ‌Once‌ ‌the‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌of‌ ‌many‌ ‌sets‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌traits‌ ‌is‌ ‌plotted‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌general‌ ‌\ngeographic‌ ‌area,‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌borrowing‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌determined.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌allows‌ ‌the‌ ‌reconstruction‌ ‌of‌ ‌individual‌ ‌histories‌ ‌of‌ ‌specific‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌by‌ ‌informing‌ ‌the‌ ‌investigator‌ ‌which‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌elements‌ ‌were‌ ‌\nborrowed‌ ‌and‌ ‌which‌ ‌were‌ ‌developed‌ ‌individually.‌ ‌\n●Perhaps‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌important‌ ‌and‌ ‌lasting‌ ‌of‌ ‌Boas’‌ ‌contributions‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌field‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌is‌ ‌his‌ ‌influence‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌generation‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nanthropologists‌ ‌that‌ ‌followed‌ ‌him‌ ‌and‌ ‌developed‌ ‌and‌ ‌improved‌ ‌on‌ ‌his‌ ‌own‌ ‌work.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌was‌ ‌an‌ ‌important‌ ‌figure‌ ‌in‌ ‌encouraging‌ ‌women‌ ‌to‌ ‌enter‌ ‌and‌ ‌thrive‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌field.‌ ‌Some‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌better‌ ‌known‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌students‌ ‌include‌ ‌Kroeber,‌ ‌\nMead,‌ ‌Benedict,‌ ‌Lowie,‌ ‌Radin,‌ ‌Wissler,‌ ‌Spier,‌ ‌Bunzel,‌ ‌Hallowell‌ ‌and‌ ‌Montagu‌ ‌.‌ ‌\n ‌\nA.‌ ‌L.‌ ‌Kroeber‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nAbout:‌ ‌A.‌ ‌L.‌ ‌Kroeber‌ ‌ ‌\n646‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Alfred‌ ‌Louis‌ ‌Kroeber‌ ‌was‌ ‌an‌ ‌American‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌anthropologist.‌ ‌He‌ ‌received‌ ‌his‌ ‌PhD‌ ‌under‌ ‌Franz‌ ‌Boas‌ ‌at‌ ‌Columbia‌ ‌University‌ ‌in‌ ‌1901,‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nfirst‌ ‌doctorate‌ ‌in‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌awarded‌ ‌by‌ ‌Columbia.‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌was‌ ‌also‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌professor‌ ‌appointed‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌Department‌ ‌of‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌University‌ ‌of‌ ‌California,‌ ‌Berkeley.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n●A.‌ ‌L.‌ ‌Kroeber‌ ‌(1876-1960)‌ ‌was‌ ‌an‌ ‌early‌ ‌American‌ ‌student‌ ‌of‌ ‌Franz‌ ‌Boas.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌helped‌ ‌establish‌ ‌the‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌department‌ ‌at‌ ‌Berkeley‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌prominent‌ ‌educational‌ ‌and‌ ‌research‌ ‌institution‌ ‌from‌ ‌which‌ ‌he‌ ‌conducted‌ ‌\nvaluable‌ ‌research‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌California‌ ‌Indians.‌ ‌\n●Kroeber‌ ‌(1931)‌ ‌observed‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌culture-area‌ ‌concept‌ ‌was‌ ‌“a‌ ‌community‌ ‌product‌ ‌of‌ ‌nearly‌ ‌the‌ ‌whole‌ ‌school‌ ‌of‌ ‌American‌ ‌Anthropologists”.‌ ‌\n●Using‌ ‌the‌ ‌culture‌ ‌areas‌ ‌proposed‌ ‌by‌ ‌Otis‌ ‌T.‌ ‌Mason‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌1895‌ ‌Annual‌ ‌Report‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Smithsonian,‌ ‌Kroeber‌ ‌published‌ ‌his‌ ‌well-known‌ ‌book,‌ ‌\nCultural‌ ‌and‌ ‌Natural‌ ‌Areas‌ ‌of‌ ‌Native‌ ‌North‌ ‌America,‌ ‌in‌ ‌1939.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n647‌ ‌\nClark‌ ‌Wissler‌ ‌\n ‌\nAbout:‌ ‌Clark‌ ‌Wissler‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Clark‌ ‌David‌ ‌Wissler‌ ‌was‌ ‌an‌ ‌American‌ ‌anthropologist.‌ ‌Born‌ ‌in‌ ‌Cambridge‌ ‌City‌ ‌near‌ ‌Hagerstown,‌ ‌Indiana,‌ ‌Wissler‌ ‌graduated‌ ‌from‌ ‌Indiana‌ ‌\nUniversity‌ ‌in‌ ‌1897.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌received‌ ‌his‌ ‌doctorate‌ ‌in‌ ‌psychology‌ ‌from‌ ‌Columbia‌ ‌University‌ ‌in‌ ‌1901.‌ ‌After‌ ‌Columbia,‌ ‌Wissler‌ ‌left‌ ‌the‌ ‌field‌ ‌of‌ ‌psychology‌ ‌to‌ ‌focus‌ ‌on‌ ‌\nAnthropology.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Clark‌ ‌Wissler‌ ‌(1870-1947)‌ ‌was‌ ‌an‌ ‌American‌ ‌anthropologist‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌American‌ ‌Museum‌ ‌of‌ ‌Natural‌ ‌History‌ ‌in‌ ‌New‌ ‌York.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Even‌ ‌though‌ ‌he‌ ‌was‌ ‌not‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌university‌ ‌where‌ ‌he‌ ‌could‌ ‌train‌ ‌students,‌ ‌his‌ ‌writings‌ ‌still‌ ‌influenced‌ ‌and‌ ‌inspired‌ ‌many‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌contemporaries.‌ ‌ ‌\n●His‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌culture-area‌ ‌approach‌ ‌were‌ ‌especially‌ ‌significant.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌1917‌ ‌Wissler‌ ‌created‌ ‌a‌ ‌“‌landmark‌ ‌treatment‌”‌ ‌of‌ ‌American‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌ethnology‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌Otis‌ ‌T.‌ ‌Mason’s‌ ‌1895‌ ‌article‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Annual‌ ‌Report‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌the‌ ‌Smithsonian‌ ‌Institution,‌ ‌which‌ ‌identified‌ ‌eighteen‌ ‌American‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌culture‌ ‌areas.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌expanded‌ ‌the‌ ‌idea‌ ‌of‌ ‌“culture‌ ‌center”‌ ‌by‌ ‌proposing‌ ‌a‌ ‌“law‌ ‌of‌ ‌diffusion,”‌ ‌which‌ ‌stated‌ ‌that‌ ‌“‌traits‌ ‌tend‌ ‌to‌ ‌diffuse‌ ‌in‌ ‌all‌ ‌directions‌ ‌from‌ ‌their‌ ‌\ncenter‌ ‌of‌ ‌origin.”‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌law‌ ‌constituted‌ ‌that‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌“age-area‌ ‌principle”‌ ‌which‌ ‌could‌ ‌determine‌ ‌the‌ ‌relative‌ ‌age‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌culture‌ ‌trait‌ ‌by‌ ‌measuring‌ ‌the‌ ‌extent‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nits‌ ‌geographical‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌\n ‌\n648‌ ‌\n ‌\nGerman‌ ‌or‌ ‌Continental‌ ‌School‌ ‌of‌ ‌Diffusionism‌ ‌\n●Unlike‌ ‌the‌ ‌British‌ ‌diffusionists,‌ ‌‌German‌ ‌diffusionists‌ ‌argued‌ ‌that‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌took‌ ‌place‌ ‌not‌ ‌only‌ ‌at‌ ‌particular‌ ‌places‌ ‌like‌ ‌Egypt,‌ ‌\nbut‌ ‌also‌ ‌at‌ ‌different‌ ‌places‌ ‌in‌ ‌several‌ ‌parts‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌world,‌ ‌from‌ ‌where‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌imitated‌ ‌or‌ ‌migrated‌ ‌to‌ ‌other‌ ‌places.‌ ‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌believed‌ ‌that‌ ‌discoveries‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌things‌ ‌were‌ ‌not‌ ‌possible‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌time‌ ‌and‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌place.‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌opined‌ ‌that‌ ‌different‌ ‌circles‌ ‌or‌ ‌districts‌ ‌were‌ ‌developed‌ ‌at‌ ‌different‌ ‌places.‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌them‌ ‌each‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌trait‌ ‌and‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌complex‌ ‌had‌ ‌a‌ ‌circle‌ ‌or‌ ‌district‌ ‌from‌ ‌where‌ ‌they‌ ‌migrated‌ ‌to‌ ‌other‌ ‌places.‌ ‌ ‌\n●As‌ ‌they‌ ‌talked‌ ‌about‌ ‌the‌ ‌spread‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌traits‌ ‌from‌ ‌one‌ ‌circle‌ ‌to‌ ‌another‌ ‌or‌ ‌one‌ ‌district‌ ‌to‌ ‌another,‌ ‌their‌ ‌school‌ ‌is‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌‘Kulturekreise’‌ ‌\nSchool’‌ ‌or‌ ‌culture‌ ‌circle‌ ‌school‌ ‌or‌ ‌culture‌ ‌district‌ ‌school.‌ ‌\n●As‌ ‌this‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌established‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌historical‌ ‌factors,‌ ‌their‌ ‌school‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌‘culture‌ ‌historic‌ ‌school’.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nMethodology‌ ‌\n ‌\n●German‌ ‌School‌ ‌of‌ ‌Thought:‌ ‌German‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌were‌ ‌considered‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌extreme‌ ‌diffusionsists.‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌school‌ ‌of‌ ‌thought‌ ‌was‌ ‌dominated‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌Catholic‌ ‌clergy,‌ ‌who‌ ‌attempted‌ ‌to‌ ‌reconcile‌ ‌anthropological‌ ‌prehistory‌ ‌and‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌\nwith‌ ‌the‌ ‌Book‌ ‌of‌ ‌Genesis.‌ ‌ ‌\n●One‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌best-known‌ ‌leaders‌ ‌in‌ ‌this‌ ‌attempt‌ ‌was‌ ‌Father‌ ‌Wilhelm‌ ‌Schmidt,‌ ‌who‌ ‌had‌ ‌studied‌ ‌and‌ ‌written‌ ‌extensively‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌\nbetween‌ ‌the‌ ‌religions‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌world.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Father‌ ‌Schmidt‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌follower‌ ‌of‌ ‌Fritz‌ ‌Graebner,‌ ‌who‌ ‌was‌ ‌also‌ ‌working‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌world-wide‌ ‌scale‌ ‌with‌ ‌“culture-circles”.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌“culture‌ ‌circle”‌ ‌concept‌ ‌was‌ ‌inspired‌ ‌by‌ ‌Friedrich‌ ‌Ratzel‌ ‌and‌ ‌expanded‌ ‌by‌ ‌Leo‌ ‌Frobenius‌ ‌in‌ ‌his‌ ‌Vienna‌ ‌based‌ ‌Kulturkreise‌ ‌or‌ ‌“Culture‌ ‌\nCircle”‌ ‌approach.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌concept‌ ‌provided‌ ‌the‌ ‌criteria‌ ‌by‌ ‌which‌ ‌Graebner‌ ‌could‌ ‌study‌ ‌Oceania‌ ‌at‌ ‌first‌ ‌and,‌ ‌two‌ ‌years‌ ‌later,‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌world-wide‌ ‌basis.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌“culture‌ ‌circle”‌ ‌concept‌ ‌proposed‌ ‌that‌ ‌a‌ ‌cluster‌ ‌of‌ ‌functionally-related‌ ‌culture‌ ‌traits‌ ‌specific‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌historical‌ ‌time‌ ‌and‌ ‌geographical‌ ‌area‌ ‌\ndiffused‌ ‌out‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌region‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌they‌ ‌evolved.‌ ‌ ‌\n649‌ ‌\n●Graebner‌ ‌and‌ ‌Schmidt‌ ‌claimed‌ ‌that‌ ‌they‌ ‌had‌ ‌reconstructed‌ ‌a‌ ‌“limited‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌original‌ ‌culture‌ ‌circles”.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nGerman‌ ‌\nFreidrich‌ ‌Ratzel‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nAbout:‌ ‌Freidrich‌ ‌Ratzel‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Friedrich‌ ‌Ratzel‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌German‌ ‌geographer‌ ‌and‌ ‌ethnographer,‌ ‌notable‌ ‌for‌ ‌first‌ ‌using‌ ‌the‌ ‌term‌ ‌Lebensraum‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌sense‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌National‌ ‌\nSocialists‌ ‌later‌ ‌would.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n●He‌ ‌(1844-1904)‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌German‌ ‌anthropologist‌ ‌who‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌significant‌ ‌contributor‌ ‌to‌ ‌nineteenth-century‌ ‌theories‌ ‌of‌ ‌diffusion‌ ‌and‌ ‌migration.‌ ‌\n650‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌developed‌ ‌criteria‌ ‌by‌ ‌which‌ ‌the‌ ‌formal,‌ ‌non-functional‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌objects‌ ‌could‌ ‌be‌ ‌compared,‌ ‌because‌ ‌it‌ ‌would‌ ‌be‌ ‌unlikely‌ ‌that‌ ‌\nthese‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌would‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌simultaneously‌ ‌invented‌.‌ ‌\n●Ratzel‌ ‌warned‌ ‌that‌ ‌possible‌ ‌migration‌ ‌or‌ ‌other‌ ‌contact‌ ‌phenomena‌ ‌should‌ ‌be‌ ‌ruled‌ ‌out‌ ‌in‌ ‌each‌ ‌case‌ ‌before‌ ‌cross-cultural‌ ‌similarities‌ ‌were‌ ‌\nattributed‌ ‌to‌ ‌independent‌ ‌invention.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌wrote‌ ‌‌The‌ ‌History‌ ‌of‌ ‌Mankind,‌ ‌a‌ ‌three-volume‌ ‌publication‌ ‌in‌ ‌1896,‌ ‌which‌ ‌was‌ ‌said‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌“a‌ ‌solid‌ ‌foundation‌ ‌in‌ ‌anthropological‌ ‌study”‌ ‌by‌ ‌\nE.‌ ‌B.‌ ‌Tylor,‌ ‌a‌ ‌competing‌ ‌British‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌evolutionist.‌ ‌\n ‌\nWilhelm‌ ‌Schmidt‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nAbout:‌ ‌Wilhelm‌ ‌Schmidt‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Wilhelm‌ ‌Schmidt‌ ‌SVD‌ ‌was‌ ‌an‌ ‌Austrian‌ ‌priest,‌ ‌linguist‌ ‌and‌ ‌ethnologist.‌ ‌He‌ ‌presided‌ ‌over‌ ‌the‌ ‌Fourth‌ ‌International‌ ‌Congress‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nAnthropological‌ ‌and‌ ‌Ethnological‌ ‌Sciences‌ ‌that‌ ‌was‌ ‌held‌ ‌at‌ ‌Vienna‌ ‌in‌ ‌1952.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●He‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌Catholic‌ ‌priest‌ ‌in‌ ‌Germany‌ ‌and‌ ‌an‌ ‌ethnologist‌ ‌who‌ ‌studied‌ ‌religions‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌world‌ ‌and‌ ‌wrote‌ ‌extensively‌ ‌on‌ ‌their‌ ‌inter-relationships.‌ ‌\n●At‌ ‌about‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌time‌ ‌that‌ ‌Fritz‌ ‌Graebner‌ ‌(1906)‌ ‌was‌ ‌applying‌ ‌the‌ ‌culture-circle‌ ‌and‌ ‌culture-strata‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌worldwide‌ ‌scale,‌ ‌Schmidt‌ ‌\nhelped‌ ‌to‌ ‌promote‌ ‌these‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌in‌ ‌part‌ ‌by‌ ‌establishing‌ ‌the‌ ‌venerable‌ ‌journal‌ ‌Anthropos,‌ ‌and‌ ‌by‌ ‌positing‌ ‌his‌ ‌own‌ ‌version‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Kulturkriese.‌ ‌\n●Although‌ ‌both‌ ‌Graebner‌ ‌and‌ ‌Schmidt‌ ‌believed‌ ‌that‌ ‌all‌ ‌culture‌ ‌traits‌ ‌diffused‌ ‌out‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌limited‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌original‌ ‌culture‌ ‌circles,‌ ‌Schmidt’s‌ ‌list‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌Kreise‌ ‌(culture‌ ‌circles)‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌influential.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌proposed‌ ‌four‌ ‌major‌ ‌temporal‌ ‌phases:‌ ‌Primitive,‌ ‌Primary,‌ ‌Secondary,‌ ‌and‌ ‌Tertiary.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Within‌ ‌this‌ ‌framework‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌grouping‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌from‌ ‌various‌ ‌parts‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌world‌ ‌in‌ ‌an‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌scheme,‌ ‌which‌ ‌was‌ ‌basically‌ ‌the‌ ‌very‌ ‌\nfamiliar‌ ‌sequences‌ ‌of‌ ‌“stages”‌ ‌progressing‌ ‌from‌ ‌hunter-gatherer,‌ ‌to‌ ‌horticulturalists,‌ ‌to‌ ‌pastoralists,‌ ‌and‌ ‌ending‌ ‌with‌ ‌complex‌ ‌stratified‌ ‌\ncivilization.‌ ‌ ‌\n651‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nFritz‌ ‌Graebner‌ ‌(1877-1934)‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nAbout:‌ ‌Fritz‌ ‌Graebner‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Robert‌ ‌Fritz‌ ‌Graebner‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌German‌ ‌geographer‌ ‌and‌ ‌ethnologist‌ ‌best‌ ‌known‌ ‌for‌ ‌his‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌Kulturkreis,‌ ‌or‌ ‌culture‌ ‌\ncircle.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌theoretician‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Vienna‌ ‌School‌ ‌of‌ ‌Ethnology.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●He‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌German‌ ‌anthropologist,‌ ‌who‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌leading‌ ‌diffusionist‌ ‌thinker.‌ ‌Graebner‌ ‌supported‌ ‌the‌ ‌school‌ ‌of‌ ‌“culture‌ ‌circles”‌ ‌(Kulturkreis),‌ ‌\nwhich‌ ‌could‌ ‌trace‌ ‌its‌ ‌beginning‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌inspiration‌ ‌of‌ ‌Friedrich‌ ‌Ratzel,‌ ‌the‌ ‌founder‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropogeography.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Leo‌ ‌Frobenius,‌ ‌a‌ ‌pupil‌ ‌of‌ ‌Ratzel,‌ ‌expanded‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌“culture‌ ‌circle”‌ ‌concept,‌ ‌which‌ ‌stimulated‌ ‌Fritz‌ ‌Graebner,‌ ‌then‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌Berlin‌ ‌Ethnological‌ ‌\nMuseum‌ ‌(1904),‌ ‌to‌ ‌write‌ ‌about‌ ‌culture‌ ‌circles‌ ‌and‌ ‌culture‌ ‌strata‌ ‌in‌ ‌Oceania.‌ ‌ ‌\n652‌ ‌\n●Two‌ ‌years‌ ‌later,‌ ‌he‌ ‌applied‌ ‌these‌ ‌concepts‌ ‌to‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌world-wide‌ ‌basis.‌ ‌In‌ ‌1911‌ ‌he‌ ‌published‌ ‌Die‌ ‌Methode‌ ‌der‌ ‌Ethnologie‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌he‌ ‌\nattempted‌ ‌to‌ ‌establish‌ ‌a‌ ‌criterion‌ ‌for‌ ‌identifying‌ ‌affinities‌ ‌and‌ ‌chronologies,‌ ‌called‌ ‌the‌ ‌Criterion‌ ‌of‌ ‌Form.‌ ‌\n ‌\nACCOMPLISHMENTS‌ ‌\n●Lewis‌ ‌Henry‌ ‌Morgan‌ ‌claimed‌ ‌that‌ ‌diffusionism‌ ‌was‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌“mechanisms‌ ‌by‌ ‌which‌ ‌the‌ ‌substantial‌ ‌uniformity‌ ‌of‌ ‌sociocultural‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌\nwas‌ ‌made‌ ‌possible”‌ ‌.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌the‌ ‌United‌ ‌States‌ ‌diffusionism‌ ‌resulted‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌creation‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌areas,‌ ‌which‌ ‌were‌ ‌contiguous‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌elements‌ ‌and‌ ‌\ncomplexes‌ ‌in‌ ‌relatively‌ ‌small,‌ ‌geographical‌ ‌units.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌also‌ ‌resulted‌ ‌in‌ ‌another‌ ‌methodological‌ ‌tool‌ ‌–‌ ‌the‌ ‌age‌ ‌area.‌ ‌Clark‌ ‌Wissler,‌ ‌a‌ ‌contemporary‌ ‌of‌ ‌Boas,‌ ‌formulated‌ ‌both‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌concepts.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌culture‌ ‌area‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌tool‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌used‌ ‌for‌ ‌classifying‌ ‌clusters‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌traits‌ ‌and,‌ ‌early‌ ‌on,‌ ‌benefited‌ ‌museums‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌way‌ ‌of‌ ‌arranging‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌\ndata.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Later‌ ‌the‌ ‌culture‌ ‌area‌ ‌concept‌ ‌was‌ ‌used‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌tool‌ ‌for‌ ‌historical‌ ‌studies.‌ ‌\n●Even‌ ‌though‌ ‌diffusion,‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌school‌ ‌of‌ ‌thought,‌ ‌was‌ ‌replaced‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌more‌ ‌holistic‌ ‌approach‌ ‌during‌ ‌the‌ ‌mid-twentieth‌ ‌century,‌ ‌the‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌\ndiffusion‌ ‌still‌ ‌has‌ ‌value‌ ‌in‌ ‌ethnological‌ ‌studies.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Studies‌ ‌involving‌ ‌the‌ ‌diffusion‌ ‌of‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌and‌ ‌how‌ ‌they‌ ‌affect‌ ‌and‌ ‌motivate‌ ‌innovations‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌of‌ ‌great‌ ‌value‌ ‌in‌ ‌many‌ ‌other‌ ‌fields,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌\nagriculture‌ ‌business‌ ‌studies,‌ ‌education,‌ ‌economic‌ ‌geography,‌ ‌history,‌ ‌political‌ ‌science,‌ ‌and‌ ‌rural‌ ‌sociology.‌ ‌\n●Acculturation‌ ‌studies‌ ‌about‌ ‌European‌ ‌immigrants‌ ‌coming‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌United‌ ‌States‌ ‌during‌ ‌the‌ ‌nineteenth‌ ‌and‌ ‌early‌ ‌twentieth‌ ‌centuries‌ ‌have‌ ‌\nhelped‌ ‌to‌ ‌give‌ ‌insight‌ ‌into‌ ‌problems‌ ‌encountered‌ ‌when‌ ‌people‌ ‌from‌ ‌diverse‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌come‌ ‌into‌ ‌a‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌ ‌\n●At‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌time,‌ ‌studies‌ ‌about‌ ‌minorities‌ ‌already‌ ‌living‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌United‌ ‌States‌ ‌show‌ ‌how‌ ‌some‌ ‌groups‌ ‌are‌ ‌resistant‌ ‌to‌ ‌assimilation,‌ ‌and,‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nsome‌ ‌cases,‌ ‌acculturation.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Studies‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌these‌ ‌could‌ ‌identify‌ ‌where‌ ‌the‌ ‌problems‌ ‌are‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌acculturation‌ ‌and‌ ‌assimilation‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌minority‌ ‌individual‌ ‌or‌ ‌group‌ ‌and‌ ‌how‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌establish‌ ‌better‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌between‌ ‌various‌ ‌groups‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n●An‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌processes‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌gained‌ ‌from‌ ‌such‌ ‌studies.‌ ‌\n ‌\nCriticism‌ ‌\n●Diffusionist‌ ‌approach‌ ‌was‌ ‌slowly‌ ‌being‌ ‌replaced‌ ‌by‌ ‌studies‌ ‌concerning‌ ‌acculturation,Pattern‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌between‌ ‌culture‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌personality.‌ ‌\n●Boas‌ ‌discusses‌ ‌how‌ ‌the‌ ‌impact‌ ‌of‌ ‌one‌ ‌society‌ ‌on‌ ‌another‌ ‌could‌ ‌not‌ ‌be‌ ‌understood‌ ‌mandali‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌addition‌ ‌or‌ ‌subtraction‌ ‌of‌ ‌discrete‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌\ntrade‌ ‌but‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌potentially‌ ‌major‌ ‌transformation‌ ‌of‌ ‌behaviour,‌ ‌value‌ ‌and‌ ‌mode‌ ‌of‌ ‌adaptation.‌ ‌\n●By‌ ‌World‌ ‌War‌ ‌1,‌ ‌diffusionism‌ ‌was‌ ‌also‌ ‌being‌ ‌challenged‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌newly‌ ‌emerging‌ ‌functional‌ ‌school‌ ‌of‌ ‌thought‌ ‌led‌ ‌by‌ ‌Malinowaski‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nRadcliffe‌ ‌Brown.‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌argued‌ ‌that‌ ‌even‌ ‌if‌ ‌one‌ ‌puts‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌imported‌ ‌aspect‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌society,‌ ‌the‌ ‌original‌ ‌culture‌ ‌trait‌ ‌might‌ ‌be‌ ‌so‌ ‌\nchanged‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌serves‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌completely‌ ‌different‌ ‌function‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌society‌ ‌from‌ ‌which‌ ‌it‌ ‌diffused.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌1920,‌ ‌Boas‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌American‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌argued‌ ‌that‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌change‌ ‌had‌ ‌been‌ ‌influenced‌ ‌by‌ ‌many‌ ‌different‌ ‌sources.‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌argued‌ ‌Against‌ ‌The‌ ‌Grain‌ ‌and‌ ‌reconstruction‌ ‌of‌ ‌both‌ ‌evolutionism‌ ‌and‌ ‌diffusionism.‌ ‌\n●James‌ ‌M‌ ‌Blaut‌ ‌Believed‌ ‌that‌ ‌extreme‌ ‌diffusionism‌ ‌was‌ ‌racist.‌ ‌\n653‌ ‌\n○However‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌believed‌ ‌that‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌process‌ ‌of‌ ‌diffusionism‌ ‌was‌ ‌important.‌ ‌\n○He‌ ‌criticized‌ ‌extreme‌ ‌diffusionism‌ ‌because‌ ‌he‌ ‌believed‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌contributed‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌prevalent‌ ‌belief‌ ‌that‌ ‌‘european-style‌ ‌societies’‌ ‌were‌ ‌\nmore‌ ‌innovative‌ ‌than‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌non‌ ‌European‌ ‌society‌ ‌and‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌proper‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌development‌ ‌would‌ ‌progress‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌whether‌ ‌\nor‌ ‌not‌ ‌these‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌traits‌ ‌had‌ ‌diffused‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌European‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n ‌\nDiffusionism‌ ‌vs‌ ‌Evolutionism‌ ‌\n ‌\n●The‌ ‌school‌ ‌of‌ ‌diffusion‌ ‌emerged‌ ‌in‌ ‌response‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌failure‌ ‌of‌ ‌classical‌ ‌evolution.‌ ‌\n●Both‌ ‌the‌ ‌theories‌ ‌tried‌ ‌to‌ ‌answer‌ ‌how‌ ‌the‌ ‌diverse‌ ‌culture‌ ‌emerged‌ ‌and‌ ‌evolved.‌ ‌\n○Classical‌ ‌evolution‌-‌ ‌culture‌ ‌develops‌ ‌as‌ ‌innovation,‌ ‌psychic‌ ‌unity‌ ‌of‌ ‌mankind‌ ‌and‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌parallels.‌ ‌\n○Diffusionism-‌‌ ‌culture‌ ‌developed‌ ‌at‌ ‌Limited‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌locations‌ ‌from‌ ‌which‌ ‌important‌ ‌traits‌ ‌diffused‌ ‌across‌ ‌the‌ ‌world.‌ ‌\n● ‌evolutionism‌ ‌tried‌ ‌to‌ ‌answer‌ ‌the‌ ‌question‌ ‌of‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌quantitatively‌ ‌or‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion,‌ ‌society‌ ‌and‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌whereas‌ ‌\ndiffusionists‌ ‌are‌ ‌more‌ ‌concerned‌ ‌with‌ ‌material‌ ‌distribution,‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌material‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\n●Diffusionists‌ ‌identified‌ ‌how‌ ‌material‌ ‌culture‌ ‌spread‌ ‌without‌ ‌answering‌ ‌questions‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌why‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌traits‌ ‌are‌ ‌accepted‌ ‌or‌ ‌rejected.‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌arrest‌ ‌innovation‌ ‌the‌ ‌culture‌ ‌was‌ ‌considered‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌continuous‌ ‌atleast‌ ‌triggered‌ ‌by‌ ‌relative‌ ‌exogenous‌ ‌variables.‌ ‌That‌ ‌\nmany‌ ‌innovations‌ ‌occurred‌ ‌independently‌ ‌and‌ ‌diffusion‌ ‌had‌ ‌little‌ ‌effect‌ ‌on‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌development.‌ ‌\n●Diffusionists‌ ‌try‌ ‌to‌ ‌relate‌ ‌culture‌ ‌with‌ ‌territory‌ ‌and‌ ‌so‌ ‌when‌ ‌narrow‌ ‌minded‌ ‌in‌ ‌this‌ ‌study.‌ ‌\n●Diffusionist‌ ‌theories‌ ‌were‌ ‌speculative‌ ‌and‌ ‌not‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌strong‌ ‌empirical‌ ‌data.‌ ‌while‌ ‌evolutionism‌ ‌was‌ ‌dependent‌ ‌on‌ ‌secondary‌ ‌data‌ ‌base‌ ‌\nused‌ ‌to‌ ‌explain‌ ‌with‌ ‌respect‌ ‌to‌ ‌data‌ ‌available.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n654‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n6.‌ ‌Anthropological‌ ‌theories:(c)‌ ‌Functionalism‌ ‌(Malinowski);‌ ‌Structural—Functionalism‌ ‌(Radcliffe-Brown),‌ ‌(d)‌ ‌Structuralism‌ ‌(L’evi-Strauss‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌E.‌ ‌Leach)-Part-III‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n(c)‌ ‌Functionalism‌ ‌(Malinowski);‌ ‌Structural—‌ ‌Functionalism‌ ‌(Radcliffe-Brown)‌ ‌\n ‌\nIntroduction‌ ‌\n●Functionalism‌ ‌arose‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌reaction‌ ‌to‌ ‌evolutionism‌ ‌and‌ ‌Diffusionism‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌early‌ ‌20th‌ ‌century.‌ ‌\n●Functionalism‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌whole‌ ‌seeks‌ ‌to‌ ‌discover‌ ‌newly‌ ‌formed‌ ‌connections‌ ‌in‌ ‌and‌ ‌in‌ ‌between‌ ‌societies,‌ ‌hoping‌ ‌to‌ ‌shape‌ ‌a‌ ‌greater‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌the‌ ‌word‌ ‌“interconnectedness”.‌ ‌\n●Functionalism‌ ‌looks‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌function‌ ‌or‌ ‌path‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌played‌ ‌by‌ ‌several‌ ‌aspects‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌in‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌maintain‌ ‌a‌ ‌social‌ ‌system.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌Framework‌ ‌that‌ ‌considers‌ ‌society‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌system‌ ‌whose‌ ‌path‌ ‌works‌ ‌together‌ ‌to‌ ‌promote‌ ‌solidarity‌ ‌and‌ ‌stability.‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌approach‌ ‌of‌ ‌theoretical‌ ‌orientation‌ ‌looks‌ ‌at‌ ‌both‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌function.‌ ‌\n655‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌describes‌ ‌the‌ ‌interrelationship‌ ‌between‌ ‌several‌ ‌parts‌ ‌of‌ ‌any‌ ‌society.‌ ‌These‌ ‌Parts‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌constituent‌ ‌elements‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌society‌ ‌could‌ ‌be‌ ‌named‌ ‌\nas‌ ‌norms,‌ ‌traditions,‌ ‌customs,‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌like‌ ‌economy,‌ ‌kinship,‌ ‌religion‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●These‌ ‌parts‌ ‌are‌ ‌interrelated‌ ‌and‌ ‌interdependent.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Prominent‌ ‌Theorists‌ ‌\n■August‌ ‌Comte‌ ‌\n■Herbert‌ ‌Spencer‌ ‌\n■Bronislaw‌ ‌Malinowski‌ ‌\n■Emile‌ ‌Durkhiem‌ ‌\n■A.R.‌ ‌Radcliffe-Brown‌ ‌\n■E.E.‌ ‌Evans-Pritchard‌ ‌\n■Sir‌ ‌Raymond‌ ‌Firth‌ ‌\n■Sir‌ ‌Edmund‌ ‌Leach‌ ‌(‌ ‌Leach‌ ‌was‌ ‌later‌ ‌influenced‌ ‌by‌ ‌Claude‌ ‌Levi-Strass‌ ‌and‌ ‌adopted‌ ‌a‌ ‌structuralist‌ ‌approach)‌ ‌\n■Lucy‌ ‌Mair‌ ‌\n■Talcott‌ ‌Parsons‌ ‌\n■Robert‌ ‌Merton‌ ‌\n ‌\n656‌ ‌\nMain‌ ‌Schools‌ ‌Of‌ ‌Functionalism‌ ‌\n ‌\n○Two‌ ‌British‌ ‌social‌ ‌anthropologists,‌ ‌‌Bronislaw‌ ‌Malinowski‌‌ ‌and‌ ‌‌Alfred‌ ‌Reginald‌ ‌Radcliffe-Brown‌ ‌‌championed‌ ‌Functionalist‌ ‌theory‌ ‌\nin‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌half‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌20th‌ ‌century.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Although‌ ‌both‌ ‌functionalists,‌ ‌Malinowski's‌ ‌theory‌ ‌focuses‌ ‌on‌ ‌how‌ ‌culture‌ ‌meets‌ ‌the‌ ‌needs‌ ‌of‌ ‌individuals,‌ ‌while‌ ‌\nRadcliffe-Brown's‌ ‌theory,‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌structural‌ ‌functionalism,‌ ‌focuses‌ ‌on‌ ‌how‌ ‌culture‌ ‌meets‌ ‌the‌ ‌needs‌ ‌of‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Both‌ ‌were‌ ‌purely‌ ‌functionalist‌ ‌but‌ ‌their‌ ‌approach‌ ‌slightly‌ ‌different‌ ‌as‌ ‌malinowski‌ ‌is‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌‌functionalist‌‌ ‌but‌ ‌Radcliff‌ ‌brown‌ ‌is‌ ‌\nmainly‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌‌structural‌ ‌functionalist‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nFunctionalism‌ ‌(Malinowski);‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n657‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nAbout:‌ ‌Bronisław‌ ‌Kasper‌ ‌Malinowski‌ ‌ ‌\n658‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Bronisław‌ ‌Kasper‌ ‌Malinowski‌ ‌was‌ ‌an‌ ‌anthropologist‌ ‌whose‌ ‌writings‌ ‌on‌ ‌ethnography,‌ ‌social‌ ‌theory,‌ ‌and‌ ‌field‌ ‌research‌ ‌were‌ ‌a‌ ‌lasting‌ ‌\ninfluence‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌discipline‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropology.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Functionalism‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌complex‌ ‌subtopic‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌encompassing‌ ‌many‌ ‌broad‌ ‌terms‌ ‌and‌ ‌definitions.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Malinowski,‌ ‌the‌ ‌founder‌ ‌of‌ ‌functionalism‌ ‌coined‌ ‌the‌ ‌basic‌ ‌strand‌ ‌of‌ ‌functionalism‌ ‌opposing‌ ‌evolutionism‌ ‌and‌ ‌historical‌ ‌particularism.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Malinowski‌ ‌used‌ ‌the‌ ‌term‌ ‌needs‌ ‌functionalism,‌ ‌believing‌ ‌that‌ ‌“‌humans‌ ‌had‌ ‌set‌ ‌of‌ ‌universal‌ ‌biological‌ ‌needs,‌ ‌and‌ ‌that‌ ‌customs‌ ‌\ndeveloped‌ ‌to‌ ‌fulfill‌ ‌those‌ ‌needs‌.”‌ ‌\n●His‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌functionalism‌ ‌focused‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual‌ ‌and‌ ‌satisfying‌ ‌the‌ ‌basic‌ ‌seven‌ ‌needs‌ ‌of‌ ‌humans‌ ‌which‌ ‌include‌ ‌nutrition,‌ ‌reproduction,‌ ‌\nbodily‌ ‌comforts,‌ ‌safety,‌ ‌movement,‌ ‌health,‌ ‌and‌ ‌growth.‌ ‌\n○An‌ ‌example‌‌ ‌of‌ ‌functionalism‌ ‌operating‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌way‌ ‌to‌ ‌satisfy‌ ‌the‌ ‌need‌ ‌of‌ ‌nutrition‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌way‌ ‌in‌ ‌“which‌ ‌food‌ ‌was‌ ‌grown‌ ‌or‌ ‌prepared,‌ ‌\nwhere‌ ‌the‌ ‌food‌ ‌was‌ ‌consumed,‌ ‌the‌ ‌economic‌ ‌or‌ ‌social‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌of‌ ‌goods,‌ ‌the‌ ‌rules‌ ‌that‌ ‌ensure‌ ‌the‌ ‌steady‌ ‌production‌ ‌of‌ ‌food,‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌authority‌ ‌that‌ ‌enforces‌ ‌those‌ ‌rules.”‌ ‌\n●Thus,‌ ‌the‌ ‌idea‌ ‌that‌ ‌different‌ ‌customs‌ ‌develop‌ ‌to‌ ‌fill‌ ‌the‌ ‌simple‌ ‌basic‌ ‌need‌ ‌of‌ ‌nutrition‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌seen.‌ ‌\n●B‌ ‌K‌ ‌Malinowski‌ ‌says‌ ‌‌culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌instrumental‌ ‌apparatus‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌satisfaction‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌needs.‌ ‌\n●Thus‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌functionalism,‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌culture‌ ‌operate‌ ‌to‌ ‌satisfy‌ ‌human‌ ‌needs‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌needs‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌society‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌whole.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Due‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌emphasis‌ ‌on‌ ‌biological‌ ‌needs‌ ‌in‌ ‌Malinowski‟s‌ ‌approach,his‌ ‌functionalism‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌Biocultural‌ ‌Functionalism.‌ ‌\n●Culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌means‌ ‌to‌ ‌satisfy‌ ‌human‌ ‌needs.‌ ‌\n●Malinowski‌ ‌views‌ ‌that‌ ‌every‌ ‌aspect‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌culture‌ ‌has‌ ‌a‌ ‌function.‌ ‌They‌ ‌are‌ ‌all‌ ‌interdependent‌ ‌and‌ ‌inter-related.‌ ‌ ‌\n●As‌ ‌Malinowski‌ ‌gave‌ ‌importance‌ ‌to‌ ‌individual‌ ‌needs‌ ‌so‌ ‌his‌ ‌functionalism‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌known‌ ‌as,Psychological‌ ‌Functionalism’.‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌cites‌ ‌the‌ ‌example‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌engine,‌ ‌the‌ ‌different‌ ‌parts‌ ‌of‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌interrelated‌ ‌and‌ ‌interdependent.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌main‌ ‌function‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌parts‌ ‌is‌ ‌to‌ ‌bring‌ ‌the‌ ‌engine‌ ‌in‌ ‌motion.‌ ‌If‌ ‌one‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌engine‌ ‌stops,‌ ‌the‌ ‌operation‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌engine‌ ‌also‌ ‌\nstops.‌ ‌\n659‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌indicates‌ ‌that‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌functional‌ ‌unity‌ ‌among‌ ‌different‌ ‌parts‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌engine.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌way,‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌traits‌ ‌and‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌contribute‌ ‌differently‌ ‌to‌ ‌total‌ ‌functioning‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Thus,‌ ‌‌each‌ ‌culture‌ ‌trait‌ ‌or‌ ‌culture‌ ‌institution‌ ‌performs‌ ‌certain‌ ‌functions‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌culture‌ ‌traits‌ ‌and‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌are‌ ‌interrelated‌ ‌and‌ ‌interdependent‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌fulfill‌ ‌the‌ ‌needs‌ ‌of‌ ‌humans.‌ ‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌culture‌ ‌trait,‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌functionless,‌ ‌would‌ ‌not‌ ‌survive,‌ ‌and‌ ‌hence‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌no‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌survivals.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Malinowski‌ ‌says‌ ‌a‌‌ ‌functionless‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌trait‌ ‌would‌ ‌not‌ ‌survive.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Malinowski‌ ‌conceives‌ ‌each‌ ‌institution‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌social‌ ‌system‌ ‌consisting‌ ‌of‌ ‌personnel,‌ ‌a‌ ‌charter,‌ ‌a‌ ‌set‌ ‌of‌ ‌norms‌ ‌or‌ ‌rules,‌ ‌material‌ ‌apparatus‌ ‌\n(technology),‌ ‌activities‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌function.‌ ‌\n●Malinowski’s‌ ‌Theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌Need‌ ‌\n○Culture‌ ‌traits‌ ‌or‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌means‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌satisfaction‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌needs.‌ ‌\n○Malinowski‌ ‌points‌ ‌out‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌humans‌ ‌have‌ ‌different‌ ‌needs‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌social,‌ ‌economic,‌ ‌religious,‌ ‌biological,‌ ‌physical‌ ‌and‌ ‌mental.‌ ‌In‌ ‌\norder‌ ‌to‌ ‌satisfy‌ ‌these‌ ‌needs,‌ ‌the‌ ‌humans‌ ‌had‌ ‌established‌ ‌the‌ ‌social,‌ ‌religious,‌ ‌economic‌ ‌and‌ ‌political‌ ‌institutions.‌ ‌ ‌\n○All‌ ‌these‌ ‌needs‌ ‌are‌ ‌interrelated‌ ‌in‌ ‌one‌ ‌way‌ ‌or‌ ‌another‌ ‌because‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌entire‌ ‌humanity‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌whole.‌ ‌\n○According‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌functional‌ ‌approach‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture,‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌operate‌ ‌to‌ ‌satisfy‌ ‌the‌ ‌needs‌ ‌of‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌or‌ ‌society‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌whole.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌his‌ ‌book,‌ ‌‌Scientific‌ ‌Theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌Culture‌ ‌(1944)‌‌ ‌which‌ ‌was‌ ‌published‌ ‌posthumously,‌ ‌Malinowski‌ ‌distinguishes‌ ‌three‌ ‌levels‌ ‌of‌ ‌needs‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌a‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n660‌ ‌\n1.‌ ‌Primary/Basic/Biological‌ ‌needs.‌ ‌\n2.‌ ‌Instrumental‌ ‌needs/‌ ‌Derived‌ ‌needs.‌ ‌\n3.‌ ‌Integrative‌ ‌needs.‌ ‌\n○Under‌ ‌primary‌ ‌needs,‌ ‌he‌ ‌includes‌ ‌sex‌ ‌and‌ ‌feeding.‌ ‌These‌ ‌are‌ ‌satisfied‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌like‌ ‌marriage,‌ ‌family‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nkinship.‌ ‌\n○Instrumental‌ ‌needs‌ ‌include‌ ‌those‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌economic,‌ ‌educational,‌ ‌legal‌ ‌and‌ ‌political,‌ ‌which‌ ‌help‌ ‌to‌ ‌achieve‌ ‌primary‌ ‌needs.‌ ‌ ‌\n○By‌ ‌integrative‌ ‌needs,‌ ‌he‌ ‌means‌ ‌those‌ ‌that‌ ‌help‌ ‌society‌ ‌to‌ ‌integrate‌ ‌(cohere‌ ‌or‌ ‌unite)‌ ‌and‌ ‌include‌ ‌knowledge,‌ ‌religion,‌ ‌magic,‌ ‌art,‌ ‌\nmorals‌ ‌and‌ ‌values.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌need‌ ‌provides‌ ‌a‌ ‌framework‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌functional‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌relation‌ ‌among‌ ‌biological,‌ ‌psychological‌ ‌and‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌\naspects.‌ ‌\n○Malinowski‌ ‌also‌ ‌proposed‌ ‌the‌ ‌method‌ ‌of‌ ‌fieldwork‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌retrieving‌ ‌of‌ ‌data‌ ‌usually‌ ‌by‌ ‌first-hand‌ ‌observation‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌and‌ ‌\ncultural‌ ‌context‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌being‌ ‌studied.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Ethnography‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌further‌ ‌branch‌ ‌of‌ ‌Malinowski’s‌ ‌idea‌ ‌of‌ ‌fieldwork,‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌account‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌culture‌ ‌or‌ ‌community.‌ ‌\n○Malinowski‌ ‌also‌ ‌stressed‌ ‌the‌ ‌interrelation‌ ‌of‌ ‌customs‌ ‌and‌ ‌that‌ ‌practicing‌ ‌field‌ ‌work‌ ‌or‌ ‌ethnography‌ ‌would‌ ‌lead‌ ‌one‌ ‌to‌ ‌examine‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nentirety‌ ‌of‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌example‌,‌ ‌‌Malinowski‌ ‌in‌ ‌his‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Trobriand‌ ‌Islanders‌,‌ ‌acknowledged‌ ‌the‌ ‌magic‌ ‌rituals‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌tribe,‌ ‌which‌ ‌they‌ ‌then‌ ‌\nused‌ ‌when‌ ‌fishing,‌ ‌leading‌ ‌him‌ ‌to‌ ‌study‌ ‌the‌ ‌entire‌ ‌social‌ ‌and‌ ‌economic‌ ‌aspects‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌community.‌ ‌\n■In‌ ‌further‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Trobriand‌ ‌Islanders‌,‌ ‌Malinowski‌ ‌theorized‌ ‌the‌ ‌kula‌ ‌ring,‌ ‌which‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌economic‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌\nbetween‌ ‌the‌ ‌islanders.‌ ‌In‌ ‌this‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌necklaces‌ ‌were‌ ‌exchanged‌ ‌clockwise‌ ‌and‌ ‌armshells‌ ‌counter-clockwise.‌ ‌\n■This‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌highlighted‌ ‌Malinowski’s‌ ‌proposal‌ ‌indefinitely‌ ‌in‌ ‌that‌ ‌society‌ ‌is‌ ‌filled‌ ‌with‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌operating‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌own‌ ‌way‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌fully‌ ‌functional‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Functionalism‌ ‌studies‌ ‌societies‌ ‌at‌ ‌one‌ ‌time‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌synchronic,‌ ‌rather‌ ‌than‌ ‌diachronic,‌ ‌or‌ ‌across‌ ‌time.‌ ‌\n■Malinowski‌ ‌saw‌ ‌society‌ ‌as‌ ‌an‌ ‌organism,‌ ‌a‌ ‌term‌ ‌he‌ ‌borrowed‌ ‌from‌ ‌Durkheim’s‌ ‌organic‌ ‌solidarity,‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌system‌ ‌that‌ ‌\nfunctions‌ ‌as‌ ‌one‌ ‌with‌ ‌each‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌system‌ ‌operating‌ ‌on‌ ‌its‌ ‌own‌ ‌performing‌ ‌its‌ ‌own‌ ‌special‌ ‌role.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Functional‌ ‌Approach‌ ‌to‌ ‌study‌ ‌religion‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌basic‌ ‌assumption‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌functional‌ ‌approach‌ ‌to‌ ‌religion‌ ‌is‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌universally‌ ‌found‌ ‌because‌ ‌it‌ ‌has‌ ‌invited‌ ‌function‌ ‌in‌ ‌maintaining‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌social‌ ‌system‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌whole.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌main‌ ‌perspective‌ ‌is‌ ‌that‌ ‌religion‌ ‌contributes‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌need‌ ‌of‌ ‌fulfillment‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌order‌ ‌and‌ ‌stability‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌order.‌ ‌\n○Religion‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌society‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌common‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌group‌ ‌its‌ ‌belief‌ ‌and‌ ‌belief‌ ‌acquired‌ ‌by‌ ‌all‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌group.‌ ‌common‌ ‌belief‌ ‌\nthrough‌ ‌common‌ ‌ritual‌ ‌enhances‌ ‌Cohesion,‌ ‌solidarity‌ ‌in‌ ‌group‌ ‌promoting‌ ‌fulfilling‌ ‌social‌ ‌order‌ ‌and‌ ‌stability.‌ ‌\n○Situation‌ ‌1:‌ ‌ ‌\n■In‌ ‌many‌ ‌societies‌ ‌Totem‌ ‌is‌ ‌sacred‌ ‌and‌ ‌considered‌ ‌a‌ ‌symbol‌ ‌of‌ ‌society‌ ‌itself.‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌people‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌group‌ ‌gather‌ ‌regularly‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌common‌ ‌ritual‌ ‌and‌ ‌share‌ ‌beliefs‌ ‌to‌ ‌Totem.‌ ‌\n■This‌ ‌in‌ ‌turn‌ ‌develops‌ ‌from‌ ‌band‌ ‌of‌ ‌Cohesion‌ ‌and‌ ‌solidarity‌ ‌leading‌ ‌to‌ ‌strong‌ ‌social‌ ‌order.‌ ‌\n■This‌ ‌is‌ ‌how‌ ‌the‌ ‌need‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌order‌ ‌is‌ ‌fulfilled‌ ‌by‌ ‌institution‌ ‌cultured‌ ‌Totem‌ ‌functional‌ ‌approach.‌ ‌\n661‌ ‌\n○Situation‌ ‌2:‌ ‌ ‌\n■Malinowski‌ ‌in‌ ‌Trobriand‌ ‌Islanders‌ ‌Observed‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌major‌ ‌events‌ ‌in‌ ‌life‌ ‌are‌ ‌surrounded‌ ‌by‌ ‌religious‌ ‌ritual,‌ ‌death‌ ‌being‌ ‌most‌ ‌\ntraumatic.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌both‌ ‌cases‌ ‌the‌ ‌richest‌ ‌actors‌ ‌showed‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌lead‌ ‌fulfillment‌ ‌method‌ ‌to‌ ‌bring‌ ‌solidarity,‌ ‌social‌ ‌order‌ ‌and‌ ‌stability.‌ ‌\n ‌\nMethodology‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌main‌ ‌method‌ ‌for‌ ‌functionalism‌ ‌is‌ ‌‌fieldwork‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Malinowski‌ ‌is‌ ‌considered‌ ‌the‌ ‌“‌father‌ ‌of‌ ‌fieldwork‌”‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌his‌ ‌in-depth‌ ‌description‌ ‌of‌ ‌how‌ ‌to‌ ‌properly‌ ‌go‌ ‌about‌ ‌participant-observation‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nethnography‌ ‌in‌ ‌‌Argonauts‌‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Western‌ ‌Pacific.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌chapter‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌book,‌ ‌Malinowski‌ ‌rails‌ ‌against‌ ‌earlier‌ ‌accounts‌ ‌of‌ ‌native‌ ‌life‌ ‌for‌ ‌being‌ ‌‌etic‌:‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌outsider's‌ ‌point‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nview‌ ‌or‌ ‌the‌ ‌strictly‌ ‌external‌ ‌perspective.‌ ‌\n○He‌ ‌champions‌ ‌a‌ ‌new‌ ‌method‌ ‌of‌ ‌collecting‌ ‌data‌ ‌in‌ ‌native‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌ultimately‌ ‌‌emic‌:‌ ‌focused‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌indigenous‌ ‌and‌ ‌internal‌ ‌\nperspective‌ ‌of‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\n●Malinowski's‌ ‌systematic‌ ‌approach‌ ‌to‌ ‌field‌ ‌work‌ ‌seeks‌ ‌to‌ ‌bring‌ ‌the‌ ‌method‌ ‌of‌ ‌hard‌ ‌science‌ ‌to‌ ‌ethnography.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌Argonauts,‌ ‌he‌ ‌states‌ ‌the‌ ‌\"principles‌ ‌of‌ ‌[his]‌ ‌method‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌grouped‌ ‌under‌ ‌three‌ ‌main‌ ‌headings:\"‌ ‌\n○First,‌ ‌the‌ ‌anthropologist‌ ‌conducting‌ ‌field‌ ‌work‌ ‌must‌ ‌have‌ ‌scientific‌ ‌goals‌ ‌and‌ ‌values.‌ ‌\n○Secondly,‌ ‌the‌ ‌best‌ ‌and‌ ‌perhaps‌ ‌only‌ ‌way‌ ‌to‌ ‌competently‌ ‌study‌ ‌another‌ ‌culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌to‌ ‌actually‌ ‌live‌ ‌in‌ ‌it.‌ ‌\n○And‌ ‌third,‌ ‌a‌ ‌researcher‌ ‌must‌ ‌\"apply‌ ‌a‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌special‌ ‌methods‌ ‌of‌ ‌collecting,‌ ‌manipulating‌ ‌and‌ ‌fixing‌ ‌his‌ ‌evidence.\"‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Thus,‌ ‌Three‌ ‌steps‌ ‌to‌ ‌Malinowski’s‌ ‌fieldwork.‌ ‌ ‌\n1)‌ ‌describe‌ ‌and‌ ‌detail‌ ‌the‌ ‌structure‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌society‌ ‌(skeleton);‌ ‌ ‌\n2)‌ ‌fill‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌ways‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌this‌ ‌structure‌ ‌is‌ ‌inhabited‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual‌ ‌lives‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌culture‌ ‌(flesh‌ ‌and‌ ‌blood);‌ ‌and‌ ‌ ‌\n3)‌ ‌through‌ ‌exact‌ ‌transcription,‌ ‌give‌ ‌an‌ ‌account‌ ‌of‌ ‌how‌ ‌it‌ ‌feels‌ ‌to‌ ‌live‌ ‌that‌ ‌life‌ ‌(spirit).‌ ‌\n●Prior‌ ‌to‌ ‌Malinowski’s‌ ‌functionalist‌ ‌movement,‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌was‌ ‌done‌ ‌from‌ ‌a‌ ‌distance.‌ ‌‌His‌ ‌theories‌ ‌and‌ ‌methods‌ ‌showed‌ ‌how‌ ‌a‌ ‌true‌ ‌\nresearcher‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌hope‌ ‌to‌ ‌understand‌ ‌a‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌its‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌without‌ ‌learning‌ ‌the‌ ‌language‌ ‌and‌ ‌living‌ ‌the‌ ‌life‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌subjects.‌ ‌ ‌\n●By‌ ‌immersing‌ ‌himself‌ ‌in‌ ‌another‌ ‌culture,‌ ‌Malinowski‌ ‌was‌ ‌able‌ ‌to‌ ‌conceive‌ ‌the‌ ‌interconnectedness‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n●His‌ ‌work‌ ‌showed‌ ‌how‌ ‌“living‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌village‌ ‌with‌ ‌no‌ ‌other‌ ‌business‌ ‌but‌ ‌to‌ ‌follow‌ ‌native‌ ‌life”‌ ‌can‌ ‌lead‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌rich‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌very‌ ‌different‌ ‌\nsociety‌ ‌and‌ ‌its‌ ‌individuals.‌ ‌\n ‌\n662‌ ‌\nDecline‌ ‌of‌ ‌Functionalism‌ ‌\n●Functionalism‌ ‌was‌ ‌at‌ ‌its‌ ‌peak‌ ‌of‌ ‌influence‌ ‌in‌ ‌1940‌ ‌and‌ ‌1950‌ ‌but‌ ‌by‌ ‌1960‌ ‌there‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌rapid‌ ‌decline‌ ‌in‌ ‌its‌ ‌influence.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌place‌ ‌of‌ ‌functionalism‌ ‌was‌ ‌taken‌ ‌up‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌more‌ ‌complete‌ ‌oriented‌ ‌approach‌ ‌that‌ ‌was‌ ‌arising‌ ‌in‌ ‌Europe.‌ ‌\n●Recently‌ ‌the‌ ‌place‌ ‌of‌ ‌functionalism‌ ‌was‌ ‌taken‌ ‌up‌ ‌by‌ ‌structuralism.‌ ‌\n●Although‌ ‌the‌ ‌functionalist‌ ‌theme‌ ‌became‌ ‌Absent‌ ‌from‌ ‌Imperial‌ ‌sociology,‌ ‌certain‌ ‌functionalist‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌could‌ ‌be‌ ‌still‌ ‌seen‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌idea‌ ‌that‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌\na‌ ‌society‌ ‌are‌ ‌interdependent‌ ‌if‌ ‌a‌ ‌path‌ ‌changes‌ ‌and‌
