‌others‌ ‌also‌ ‌change.‌ ‌\n ‌\nCriticism‌ ‌\n●Functionalism‌ ‌can‌ ‌also‌ ‌be‌ ‌critiqued‌ ‌for‌ ‌its‌ ‌overly‌ ‌harmonious‌ ‌view‌ ‌on‌ ‌society;‌ ‌it‌ ‌completely‌ ‌disregards‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌differences‌ ‌within‌ ‌single‌ ‌\nsocieties.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Functionalism‌ ‌considered‌ ‌the‌ ‌function‌ ‌of‌ ‌parts‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌whole‌ ‌to‌ ‌fulfill‌ ‌the‌ ‌needs‌ ‌but‌ ‌it‌ ‌did‌ ‌not‌ ‌look‌ ‌into‌ ‌the‌ ‌matter‌ ‌of‌ ‌why‌ ‌and‌ ‌how‌ ‌they‌ ‌needed‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌emerge.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌was‌ ‌greatly‌ ‌criticized‌ ‌for‌ ‌neglecting‌ ‌historical‌ ‌perspective.‌ ‌\n●Ecological‌ ‌factors‌ ‌were‌ ‌also‌ ‌ignored.‌ ‌\n●Inequalities‌ ‌like‌ ‌race,‌ ‌geder,‌ ‌class‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌main‌ ‌caustic‌ ‌agent‌ ‌of‌ ‌conflict‌ ‌and‌ ‌tension‌ ‌is‌ ‌ignored‌ ‌\nStructural—‌ ‌Functionalism‌ ‌(Radcliffe-Brown)‌ ‌\n ‌\nIntroduction‌ ‌\n●Closely‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌Malinowski's‌ ‌theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌functionalism‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌structural‌ ‌functionalism‌ ‌of‌ ‌Radcliffe‌ ‌Brown.‌ ‌\n●Structural‌ ‌functionalism‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌theoretical‌ ‌school‌ ‌in‌ ‌Great‌ ‌Britain‌ ‌originally‌ ‌formulated‌ ‌to‌ ‌move‌ ‌away‌ ‌from‌ ‌evolutionism‌ ‌and‌ ‌diffusion.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌premier‌ ‌concern‌ ‌with‌ ‌structural‌ ‌functionalism‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌viewpoint‌ ‌of‌ ‌‌Radcliffe-Brown‌ ‌was‌ ‌to‌ ‌focus‌ ‌primarily‌ ‌on‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌rather‌ ‌than‌ ‌\nbiological‌ ‌needs,‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌main‌ ‌concern‌ ‌of‌ ‌Maliowski’s‌ ‌functionalism.‌ ‌\n663‌ ‌\n●Radcliffe-Brown‌ ‌argued‌ ‌that‌ ‌social‌ ‌phenomena‌ ‌had‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌constructed‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌level.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Pointing‌ ‌to‌ ‌his‌ ‌idea‌ ‌that‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌were‌ ‌irrelevant‌ ‌and‌ ‌replaceable,‌ ‌they‌ ‌were‌ ‌occupants‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌roles.‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌differed‌ ‌from‌ ‌Malinowski‌ ‌in‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌latter‌ ‌conceived‌ ‌society‌ ‌as‌ ‌to‌ ‌fulfil‌ ‌the‌ ‌needs‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual,‌ ‌while‌ ‌the‌ ‌former‌ ‌conceived‌ ‌society‌ ‌as‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌maintain‌ ‌its‌ ‌structure.‌ ‌\n●Alfred‌ ‌Reginald‌ ‌Radcliffe‌ ‌Brown‌ ‌showed‌ ‌how‌ ‌functions‌ ‌could‌ ‌be‌ ‌analysed‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌context‌ ‌of‌ ‌structure.‌ ‌Hence‌ ‌he‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌labeled‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nstructural‌ ‌functionalist‌.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nRadcliff‌ ‌Brown:‌ ‌\n ‌\nAbout:‌ ‌Radcliff‌ ‌Brown‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Alfred‌ ‌Reginald‌ ‌Radcliffe-Brown,‌ ‌was‌ ‌an‌ ‌English‌ ‌social‌ ‌anthropologist‌ ‌who‌ ‌developed‌ ‌the‌ ‌theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌structural‌ ‌functionalism‌ ‌and‌ ‌\ncoadaptation.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●The‌ ‌Structural-Functionalist‌ ‌theory‌ ‌was‌ ‌founded‌ ‌by‌ ‌Radcliffe-Brown‌ ‌with‌ ‌E.E.‌ ‌Evans-Pritchard‌ ‌contributed‌ ‌major‌ ‌field‌ ‌work‌ ‌and‌ ‌analysis.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Primarily,‌ ‌this‌ ‌theory‌ ‌is‌ ‌based‌ ‌upon‌ ‌social‌ ‌structures‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌positive/negative‌ ‌effects‌ ‌upon‌ ‌a‌ ‌culture‌ ‌with‌ ‌customs‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌tool‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌\npreserve‌ ‌these‌ ‌social‌ ‌structures.‌ ‌\n●Radcliffe-Brown‌ ‌saw‌ ‌social‌ ‌systems‌ ‌almost‌ ‌like‌ ‌an‌ ‌organism‌ ‌where‌ ‌the‌ ‌different‌ ‌parts‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌living‌ ‌being‌ ‌do‌ ‌their‌ ‌functions‌ ‌in‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌keep‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nwhole‌ ‌working.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌physiological‌ ‌explanation‌ ‌works‌ ‌for‌ ‌structural-functionalist‌ ‌theory‌ ‌because‌ ‌customs,‌ ‌practices,‌ ‌social‌ ‌roles,‌ ‌and‌ ‌behavior‌ ‌are‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nwork‌ ‌together‌ ‌to‌ ‌help‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌systems‌ ‌\n ‌\nE.E.‌ ‌Evans-Pritchard‌ ‌ ‌\n664‌ ‌\n ‌\n●E‌ ‌Evans‌ ‌Pritchard‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌notable‌ ‌British‌ ‌anthropologist,‌ ‌and‌ ‌studied‌ ‌history‌ ‌and‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌at‌ ‌Oxford.‌ ‌He‌ ‌lived‌ ‌from‌ ‌1902‌ ‌to‌ ‌\n1973.‌ ‌Pritchard‌ ‌and‌ ‌Brown‌ ‌focused‌ ‌on‌ ‌kinships,‌ ‌and‌ ‌descent,‌ ‌leading‌ ‌into‌ ‌family‌ ‌organizations,‌ ‌economy,‌ ‌politics,‌ ‌and‌ ‌inter-group‌ ‌\nrelations.‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌believed‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌should‌ ‌analyze‌ ‌societies‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌local‌ ‌communities‌ ‌viewpoints‌ ‌rather‌ ‌than‌ ‌pre‌ ‌existing‌ ‌ideas.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Evans-Pritchard‌ ‌studied‌ ‌primarily‌ ‌in‌ ‌Africa.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌1937‌ ‌he‌ ‌published‌ ‌his‌ ‌first‌ ‌book‌ ‌called‌ ‌Witchcraft,‌ ‌Oracles,‌ ‌and‌ ‌Magic‌ ‌Among‌ ‌the‌ ‌Azande.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌book‌ ‌was‌ ‌an‌ ‌analyzed‌ ‌overview‌ ‌on‌ ‌witchcraft‌ ‌within‌ ‌Azande‌ ‌society‌ ‌in‌ ‌East‌ ‌Africa.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Evans-Pritchard’s‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌proves‌ ‌that‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌culture‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Azande’s‌ ‌witchcraft‌ ‌is‌ ‌rational‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌their‌ ‌personal‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌Cairo‌ ‌Evans-Pritchard‌ ‌became‌ ‌acquainted‌ ‌with‌ ‌Radcliffe-Brown.‌ ‌Evans-Pritchard‌ ‌used‌ ‌Radcliffe-Brown’s‌ ‌theory‌ ‌on‌ ‌structural‌ ‌\nfunctionalism‌ ‌to‌ ‌help‌ ‌him‌ ‌write‌ ‌his‌ ‌trilogy‌ ‌of‌ ‌books‌ ‌called,‌ ‌‌The‌ ‌Nuer,‌ ‌Nuer‌ ‌Religion,‌ ‌and‌ ‌Kinship‌ ‌and‌ ‌Marriage‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌Nuer,‌ ‌\nwhich‌ ‌became‌ ‌a‌ ‌primary‌ ‌source‌ ‌among‌ ‌British‌ ‌social‌ ‌anthropologists.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Evans-Pritchard‌ ‌fundamentally‌ ‌believed‌ ‌that‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌was‌ ‌more‌ ‌about‌ ‌studying‌ ‌the‌ ‌history‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌actual‌ ‌people‌ ‌rather‌ ‌than‌ ‌\nabout‌ ‌natural‌ ‌science.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌believed‌ ‌calling‌ ‌it‌ ‌natural‌ ‌science‌ ‌“dehumanized”‌ ‌the‌ ‌society‌ ‌being‌ ‌studied.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●A‌ ‌R‌ ‌Radcliffe‌ ‌Brown,‌ ‌in‌ ‌his‌ ‌book‌ ‌‌Structure‌ ‌and‌ ‌Function‌ ‌in‌ ‌Primitive‌ ‌Societies‌‌ ‌(1952)‌ ‌elaborates‌ ‌his‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌and‌ ‌its‌ ‌\nfunction.‌ ‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌him,‌ ‌the‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌structure‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌an‌ ‌arrangement‌ ‌of‌ ‌parts‌ ‌or‌ ‌components‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌one‌ ‌another‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌example‌,‌ ‌the‌ ‌structure‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌house‌ ‌reveals‌ ‌the‌ ‌arrangement‌ ‌of‌ ‌walls,‌ ‌roofs,‌ ‌rooms,‌ ‌windows,‌ ‌doors‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Likewise,‌ ‌the‌ ‌structure‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌human‌ ‌body‌ ‌consists‌ ‌of‌ ‌different‌ ‌organs,‌ ‌cells,‌ ‌tissues,‌ ‌bones‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure,‌ ‌the‌ ‌ultimate‌ ‌components‌ ‌are‌ ‌human‌ ‌beings‌ ‌or‌ ‌persons.‌ ‌Social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌consists‌ ‌of‌ ‌arrangement‌ ‌of‌ ‌persons‌ ‌in‌ ‌relation‌ ‌to‌ ‌\neach‌ ‌other.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Within‌ ‌a‌ ‌society,‌ ‌the‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌are‌ ‌grouped‌ ‌into‌ ‌different‌ ‌social‌ ‌units‌ ‌and‌ ‌institutions.‌ ‌Each‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌social‌ ‌units‌ ‌or‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌perform‌ ‌its‌ ‌\nrespective‌ ‌functions.‌ ‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌are‌ ‌interrelated,‌ ‌inter-‌ ‌dependent‌ ‌and‌ ‌form‌ ‌the‌ ‌structure‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌instance,‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌village,‌ ‌we‌ ‌find‌ ‌an‌ ‌arrangement‌ ‌of‌ ‌persons‌ ‌into‌ ‌families.‌ ‌In‌ ‌family,‌ ‌the‌ ‌structure‌ ‌consists‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌relations‌ ‌of‌ ‌father,‌ ‌mother,‌ ‌\nbrother,‌ ‌sister,‌ ‌uncle‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌Thus,‌ ‌the‌ ‌structural‌ ‌feature‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌life‌ ‌consists‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌existence‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌groups‌ ‌and‌ ‌its‌ ‌internal‌ ‌structure.‌ ‌\n●Types‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure:‌ ‌‌We‌ ‌have‌ ‌seen‌ ‌that‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌continuous‌ ‌arrangement‌ ‌of‌ ‌persons‌ ‌controlled‌ ‌by‌ ‌social‌ ‌institutions.‌ ‌In‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nsociety,‌ ‌persons‌ ‌or‌ ‌groups‌ ‌change‌ ‌from‌ ‌time‌ ‌to‌ ‌time‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌marriage,‌ ‌birth‌ ‌and‌ ‌death.‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌affects‌ ‌the‌ ‌structure‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌society.‌ ‌On‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌this,‌ ‌Brown‌ ‌classifies‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌into‌ ‌two:‌ ‌\n1.‌ ‌Actual‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌internal‌ ‌structure‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌society.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌of‌ ‌persons‌ ‌or‌ ‌groups,‌ ‌changes‌ ‌from‌ ‌time‌ ‌to‌ ‌time.‌ ‌ ‌\n●New‌ ‌members‌ ‌come‌ ‌into‌ ‌being‌ ‌by‌ ‌birth‌ ‌or‌ ‌immigration,‌ ‌while‌ ‌some‌ ‌others‌ ‌will‌ ‌go‌ ‌out‌ ‌by‌ ‌death‌ ‌or‌ ‌out-migration.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Besides‌ ‌this,‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌marriages‌ ‌and‌ ‌divorces,‌ ‌whereby‌ ‌members‌ ‌change‌ ‌several‌ ‌times.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Actual‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌may‌ ‌change‌ ‌many‌ ‌times.‌ ‌\n2.‌ ‌General‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌\n665‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌external‌ ‌structure‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n■This‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌is‌ ‌constituted‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌institutions,‌ ‌and‌ ‌it‌ ‌may‌ ‌remain‌ ‌relatively‌ ‌constant.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Even‌ ‌though‌ ‌birth‌ ‌and‌ ‌death‌ ‌take‌ ‌place‌ ‌in‌ ‌society,‌ ‌the‌ ‌general‌ ‌structure‌ ‌of‌ ‌society‌ ‌remains‌ ‌the‌ ‌same.‌ ‌ ‌\n■For‌ ‌example‌,‌ ‌the‌ ‌actual‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌family‌ ‌may‌ ‌change‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌birth‌ ‌or‌ ‌death.‌ ‌\n■But‌ ‌the‌ ‌institution‌ ‌of‌ ‌family‌ ‌remains‌ ‌relatively‌ ‌constant‌ ‌over‌ ‌a‌ ‌period.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Social‌ ‌Structure‌ ‌and‌ ‌Social‌ ‌Organisation:‌ ‌ ‌\n○Radcliffe‌ ‌Brown‌ ‌differentiated‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌from‌ ‌social‌ ‌organization.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌an‌ ‌arrangement‌ ‌of‌ ‌persons,‌ ‌while‌ ‌social‌ ‌organisation‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌arrangement‌ ‌of‌ ‌activities‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌or‌ ‌more‌ ‌\npersons.‌ ‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌example,‌ ‌organisation‌ ‌of‌ ‌factory‌ ‌means,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌arrangement‌ ‌of‌ ‌activities‌ ‌or‌ ‌duties‌ ‌done‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌manager,‌ ‌foreman‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌\nlabourers‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌factory.‌ ‌\n ‌\nMethodology‌ ‌\n●As‌ ‌a‌ ‌school‌ ‌of‌ ‌thought‌ ‌structural‌ ‌functionalism‌ ‌came‌ ‌in‌ ‌response‌ ‌to‌ ‌criticisms‌ ‌leveled‌ ‌against‌ ‌evolutionism.‌ ‌\n●His‌ ‌school‌ ‌wants‌ ‌to‌ ‌make‌ ‌the‌ ‌science‌ ‌objective‌ ‌neutral‌ ‌and‌ ‌free‌ ‌from‌ ‌judgement..‌ ‌\n○To‌ ‌do‌ ‌so‌ ‌they‌ ‌relied‌ ‌on‌ ‌scientific‌ ‌methods‌ ‌of‌ ‌observation.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Scholars‌ ‌compare‌ ‌social‌ ‌life‌ ‌with‌ ‌organic‌ ‌life‌ ‌to‌ ‌explain‌ ‌the‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌function.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌is‌ ‌as‌ ‌real‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual.‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌schools‌ ‌compared‌ ‌to‌ ‌social‌ ‌life,‌ ‌with‌ ‌organic‌ ‌life‌ ‌explaining‌ ‌the‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌function.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌is‌ ‌as‌ ‌real‌ ‌as‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual.‌ ‌\n● ‌The‌ ‌school‌ ‌believes‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌core‌ ‌of‌ ‌society‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌complex‌ ‌phenomenon.‌ ‌\n● ‌This‌ ‌could‌ ‌believe‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌basic‌ ‌essence‌ ‌of‌ ‌societies‌ ‌is‌ ‌stability,‌ ‌harmony‌ ‌and‌ ‌evolution.‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌explain‌ ‌this‌ ‌they‌ ‌developed‌ ‌and‌ ‌studied‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌of‌ ‌society‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌whole.‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌argued‌ ‌that‌ ‌one‌ ‌should‌ ‌study‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌function‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌Institutions‌ ‌and‌ ‌how‌ ‌they‌ ‌function‌ ‌to‌ ‌maintain‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌whole.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌is‌ ‌continuous‌ ‌and‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌diary‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌person.‌ ‌Although‌ ‌it‌ ‌might‌ ‌vary‌ ‌a‌ ‌little.‌ ‌The‌ ‌social‌ ‌life‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌community‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nfunctioning‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure.‌ ‌\n○E.g.‌‌ ‌To‌ ‌study‌ ‌the‌ ‌problem‌ ‌of‌ ‌drug‌ ‌abuse.‌ ‌structural‌ ‌function‌ ‌first‌ ‌study‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌boy.‌ ‌I.e.‌ ‌the‌ ‌friend‌ ‌circle‌ ‌and‌ ‌how‌ ‌\nthey‌ ‌are‌ ‌influenced‌ ‌and‌ ‌why?‌ ‌Then‌ ‌they‌ ‌study‌ ‌the‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌interpretation‌ ‌of‌ ‌how‌ ‌these‌ ‌structures‌ ‌believe‌ ‌about‌ ‌drugs‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌\nconsequences.‌ ‌\n○Finally‌ ‌with‌ ‌this‌ ‌information‌ ‌they‌ ‌try‌ ‌to‌ ‌answer‌ ‌the‌ ‌question‌ ‌how‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌going‌ ‌to‌ ‌affect‌ ‌the‌ ‌stability,‌ ‌harmony‌ ‌and‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌whole.‌ ‌\n○As‌ ‌society‌ ‌through‌ ‌family‌ ‌teachers‌ ‌are‌ ‌newborn‌ ‌to‌ ‌settle‌ ‌in‌ ‌stability‌ ‌harmony‌ ‌and‌ ‌evolve‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\nCriticism‌ ‌\n●Radcliffe‌ ‌Brown‌ ‌did‌ ‌not‌ ‌come‌ ‌up‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌adequate‌ ‌definition‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure.‌ ‌His‌ ‌definition‌ ‌is‌ ‌too‌ ‌wide‌ ‌and‌ ‌very‌ ‌open.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌unable‌ ‌to‌ ‌deal‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌contemporary‌ ‌process‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌change.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌historical‌ ‌reaction‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌historical‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌approach.‌ ‌\n666‌ ‌\n● ‌It‌ ‌has‌ ‌a‌ ‌conservative‌ ‌bias,‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌maintains‌ ‌the‌ ‌status‌ ‌co‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌dominating‌ ‌power‌ ‌Elite‌ ‌class.‌ ‌\n● ‌It‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌adequately‌ ‌deal‌ ‌with‌ ‌conflict.‌ ‌\n●Theories‌ ‌are‌ ‌too‌ ‌grand‌ ‌and‌ ‌ambitious‌ ‌when‌ ‌more‌ ‌historically‌ ‌and‌ ‌situation‌ ‌relevant‌ ‌theories‌ ‌might‌ ‌be‌ ‌more‌ ‌appropriate.‌ ‌\n●There‌ ‌are‌ ‌inadequate‌ ‌methods‌ ‌to‌ ‌research‌ ‌the‌ ‌Quest‌ ‌of‌ ‌interest.‌ ‌\n●Comparative‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌is‌ ‌Virtually‌ ‌impossible.‌ ‌\n ‌\nACCOMPLISHMENTS(for‌ ‌both)‌ ‌\n●By‌ ‌the‌ ‌1970’s‌ ‌functionalism‌ ‌was‌ ‌declining,‌ ‌but‌ ‌its‌ ‌contributions‌ ‌continue‌ ‌to‌ ‌influence‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌today.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Functional‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌gave‌ ‌value‌ ‌to‌ ‌social‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌by‌ ‌considering‌ ‌them‌ ‌not‌ ‌as‌ ‌mere‌ ‌custom‌ ‌(as‌ ‌proposed‌ ‌by‌ ‌early‌ ‌American‌ ‌ethnologists),‌ ‌\nbut‌ ‌as‌ ‌active‌ ‌and‌ ‌integrated‌ ‌parts‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌social‌ ‌system‌ ‌(Langness‌ ‌1987).‌ ‌ ‌\n●Though‌ ‌Malinowski‌ ‌and‌ ‌Radcliffe-Brown‌ ‌differed‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌approaches‌ ‌to‌ ‌functional‌ ‌interpretation,‌ ‌they‌ ‌both‌ ‌contributed‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌push‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌“shift‌ ‌\nin‌ ‌the‌ ‌assumptions‌ ‌of‌ ‌ethnology,‌ ‌from‌ ‌a‌ ‌concern‌ ‌with‌ ‌isolated‌ ‌traits‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌interpretation‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌life”.‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌school‌ ‌of‌ ‌thought‌ ‌has‌ ‌contributed‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌that‌ ‌traditional‌ ‌usages,‌ ‌whatever‌ ‌their‌ ‌origin,‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌shaped‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nrequirement‌ ‌that‌ ‌human‌ ‌beings‌ ‌must‌ ‌live‌ ‌together‌ ‌in‌ ‌harmony.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Therefore‌ ‌the‌ ‌demands‌ ‌of‌ ‌interpersonal‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌are‌ ‌a‌ ‌causative‌ ‌force‌ ‌in‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\n●Despite‌ ‌its‌ ‌theoretical‌ ‌limitations,‌ ‌functionalism‌ ‌has‌ ‌made‌ ‌important‌ ‌methodological‌ ‌contributions.‌ ‌With‌ ‌its‌ ‌emphasis‌ ‌on‌ ‌intensive‌ ‌fieldwork,‌ ‌\nfunctionalism‌ ‌has‌ ‌provided‌ ‌in-depth‌ ‌studies‌ ‌of‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌\n●Additionally,‌ ‌the‌ ‌investigation‌ ‌of‌ ‌functional‌ ‌interrelationships‌ ‌of‌ ‌customs‌ ‌and‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌provides‌ ‌a‌ ‌ready-made‌ ‌framework‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌collection‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌information.‌ ‌\n●Its‌ ‌theoretical‌ ‌difficulties‌ ‌notwithstanding,‌ ‌functionalism‌ ‌can‌ ‌yet‌ ‌be‌ ‌fruitful.‌ ‌Such‌ ‌statements‌ ‌as,‌ ‌“all‌ ‌societies‌ ‌are‌ ‌functionally‌ ‌cohesive,”‌ ‌are‌ ‌\ntoo‌ ‌vague‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌refuted‌ ‌easily.‌ ‌ ‌\n●However,‌ ‌these‌ ‌statements‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌refuted‌ ‌if‌ ‌they‌ ‌suggest‌ ‌that‌ ‌societies‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌change‌ ‌or‌ ‌disintegrate.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Therefore,‌ ‌such‌ ‌theories‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌considered‌ ‌uncontroversial‌ ‌tautologies.‌ ‌It‌ ‌could‌ ‌be‌ ‌said‌ ‌that‌ ‌functionalism‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌integration‌ ‌of‌ ‌false‌ ‌theory‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌trivially‌ ‌true‌ ‌tautology‌ ‌into‌ ‌a‌ ‌blueprint‌ ‌for‌ ‌fieldwork.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Accordingly,‌ ‌such‌ ‌fieldwork‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌thought‌ ‌of‌ ‌as‌ ‌empirical‌ ‌attempts‌ ‌to‌ ‌refute‌ ‌such‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌that‌ ‌savages‌ ‌are‌ ‌simple-minded,‌ ‌that‌ ‌savage‌ ‌\ncustoms‌ ‌are‌ ‌superstitious,‌ ‌and‌ ‌that‌ ‌savage‌ ‌societies‌ ‌are‌ ‌chaotic,‌ ‌in‌ ‌essence,‌ ‌that‌ ‌savage‌ ‌societies‌ ‌are‌ ‌“savage.”‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n667‌ ‌\n(d)‌ ‌Structuralism‌ ‌(L’evi-Strauss‌ ‌and‌ ‌E.‌ ‌Leach)‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nIntroduction‌ ‌\n●Structuralism‌ ‌represents‌ ‌a‌ ‌movement‌ ‌that‌ ‌began‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌1950‌ ‌and‌ ‌1960‌ ‌in‌ ‌France.‌ ‌\n●Emile‌ ‌Durkheim‌,‌ ‌a‌ ‌‌French‌ ‌anthropologist‌,‌ ‌generated‌ ‌the‌ ‌idea‌ ‌that‌ ‌human‌ ‌thought‌ ‌precedes‌ ‌observation‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌and‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌\nphenomena‌ ‌derived‌ ‌from‌ ‌Universal‌ ‌cognition.‌ ‌\n●Claude‌ ‌Levi‌ ‌Strauss‌,‌ ‌considered‌ ‌the‌ ‌founder‌ ‌of‌ ‌structuralism,‌ ‌expanded‌ ‌upon‌ ‌Durkheim‌ ‌basic‌ ‌concepts‌ ‌to‌ ‌generate‌ ‌the‌ ‌main‌ ‌Idea‌ ‌behind‌ ‌\nstructuralism.‌ ‌\n● ‌in‌ ‌his‌ ‌definition‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌three‌ ‌fundamental‌ ‌properties‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌human‌ ‌mind:‌ ‌\n○People‌ ‌follow‌ ‌rules.‌ ‌\n○Reciprocity‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌simplest‌ ‌way‌ ‌to‌ ‌create‌ ‌social‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌gift‌ ‌binds‌ ‌both‌ ‌the‌ ‌giver‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌recipient‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌continuous‌ ‌social‌ ‌relationship.‌ ‌\n●Lévi-Strauss‌ ‌held‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌human‌ ‌brain‌ ‌was‌ ‌wired‌ ‌to‌ ‌organize‌ ‌the‌ ‌world‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌key‌ ‌structures‌ ‌of‌ ‌organization,‌ ‌which‌ ‌enabled‌ ‌people‌ ‌to‌ ‌\norder‌ ‌and‌ ‌interpret‌ ‌experience.‌ ‌Since‌ ‌these‌ ‌structures‌ ‌were‌ ‌universal,‌ ‌all‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌systems‌ ‌were‌ ‌inherently‌ ‌logical.‌ ‌They‌ ‌simply‌ ‌used‌ ‌different‌ ‌\nsystems‌ ‌of‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌to‌ ‌explain‌ ‌the‌ ‌world‌ ‌around‌ ‌them,‌ ‌resulting‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌stunning‌ ‌diversity‌ ‌of‌ ‌myths,‌ ‌beliefs,‌ ‌and‌ ‌practices.‌ ‌The‌ ‌\nanthropologist’s‌ ‌task,‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌Lévi-Strauss,‌ ‌was‌ ‌to‌ ‌explore‌ ‌and‌ ‌explain‌ ‌the‌ ‌logic‌ ‌within‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌system.‌ ‌\n668‌ ‌\n●Social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌Levi‌ ‌Strauss,‌ ‌mirror‌ ‌cognitive‌ ‌structure,‌ ‌the‌ ‌way‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌mankind‌ ‌think‌ ‌and‌ ‌understand‌ ‌structuralism‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌\napproach‌ ‌with‌ ‌seek‌ ‌to‌ ‌isolate‌ ‌and‌ ‌decode‌ ‌deep‌ ‌structure‌ ‌of‌ ‌meaning,‌ ‌organised‌ ‌through‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌science‌ ‌inherent‌ ‌in‌ ‌human‌ ‌\nbehaviour(language,‌ ‌ritual,‌ ‌dress‌ ‌and‌ ‌so‌ ‌on)‌ ‌\n●Structuralism‌ ‌focuses‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌effects‌ ‌of‌ ‌universal‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌in‌ ‌human‌ ‌thought‌ ‌on‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌phenomena.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Although‌ ‌not‌ ‌attempting‌ ‌to‌ ‌explain‌ ‌these‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌patterns,‌ ‌it‌ ‌rather‌ ‌presents‌ ‌them‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌result‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌subconscious,‌ ‌of‌ ‌universal‌ ‌human‌ ‌\nknowledge.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌link‌ ‌between‌ ‌societal‌ ‌norms‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌mind's‌ ‌thought‌ ‌process‌ ‌is‌ ‌ingrained‌ ‌so‌ ‌deeply‌ ‌within‌ ‌individual‌ ‌cultures,‌ ‌it‌ ‌becomes‌ ‌logical‌ ‌thought,‌ ‌\ntaking‌ ‌specific‌ ‌actions,‌ ‌thoughts‌ ‌and‌ ‌activities‌ ‌and‌ ‌conceptualizing‌ ‌them.‌ ‌The‌ ‌process‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌psychic‌ ‌unity,‌ ‌states‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌human‌ ‌\nspecies,‌ ‌despite‌ ‌differences‌ ‌in‌ ‌race‌ ‌and‌ ‌culture,‌ ‌share‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌basic‌ ‌psychological‌ ‌make-up.‌ ‌\n●Even‌ ‌with‌ ‌this‌ ‌universal‌ ‌knowledge,‌ ‌every‌ ‌culture‌ ‌retains‌ ‌its‌ ‌own‌ ‌specific‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌structure.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Much‌ ‌of‌ ‌Levi-Strauss'‌ ‌work‌ ‌comes‌ ‌from‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌Marcel‌ ‌Mauss,‌ ‌who‌ ‌states‌ ‌\"these‌ ‌elementary‌ ‌principles‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌'glue'‌ ‌that‌ ‌unifies‌ ‌different‌ ‌\nsocial‌ ‌institutions.\"‌ ‌\n●From‌ ‌this‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌works‌ ‌of‌ ‌Roman‌ ‌Jakobson,‌ ‌Levi-Strauss‌ ‌presented‌ ‌the‌ ‌idea‌ ‌of‌ ‌‌binary‌ ‌oppositions.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌concept‌ ‌coordinates‌ ‌certain‌ ‌ways‌ ‌of‌ ‌thinking.‌ ‌Examples‌ ‌of‌ ‌binary‌ ‌systems‌ ‌studied‌ ‌could‌ ‌be:‌ ‌\"life‌ ‌vs.‌ ‌death,\"‌ ‌\"culture‌ ‌vs.‌ ‌nature,\"‌ ‌or‌ ‌\"self‌ ‌\nvs.‌ ‌other.\"‌ ‌ ‌\n●Each‌ ‌individual‌ ‌concept‌ ‌has‌ ‌an‌ ‌opposite‌ ‌concept‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌codependent‌ ‌on.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌is‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌unity‌ ‌of‌ ‌opposites;‌ ‌no‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌can‌ ‌exist‌ ‌without‌ ‌the‌ ‌other.‌ ‌Every‌ ‌community‌ ‌takes‌ ‌these‌ ‌concepts‌ ‌and‌ ‌makes‌ ‌\nthem‌ ‌specific‌ ‌to‌ ‌their‌ ‌individual‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Presenting‌ ‌universal‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌and‌ ‌oppositions,‌ ‌and‌ ‌uniting‌ ‌them‌ ‌under‌ ‌a‌ ‌unique,‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌stand-point,‌ ‌eventually‌ ‌forming‌ ‌a‌ ‌structured‌ ‌and‌ ‌\norganized‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌relate‌ ‌to‌ ‌linguistic‌ ‌anthropology,‌ ‌in‌ ‌that‌ ‌all‌ ‌humans‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌common‌ ‌base‌ ‌for‌ ‌which‌ ‌we‌ ‌can‌ ‌create‌ ‌complex‌ ‌sounds‌ ‌and‌ ‌develop‌ ‌\ndifferent‌ ‌languages.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Taking‌ ‌the‌ ‌idea‌ ‌of‌ ‌\"phonemes,\"‌ ‌pairs‌ ‌of‌ ‌sounds‌ ‌that‌ ‌create‌ ‌meaning,‌ ‌and‌ ‌bringing‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌concept‌ ‌into‌ ‌structuralism,‌ ‌that‌ ‌we,‌ ‌as‌ ‌humans,‌ ‌\nall‌ ‌share‌ ‌a‌ ‌common‌ ‌base‌ ‌for‌ ‌thought,‌ ‌leading‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌different‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌that‌ ‌stem‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌unconscious‌ ‌roots.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n669‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nClaude‌ ‌Levi‌ ‌Strauss‌ ‌\n ‌\nAbout:‌ ‌Claude‌ ‌Levi‌ ‌Strauss‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n670‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Claude‌ ‌Lévi-Strauss:‌ ‌(1908‌ ‌–‌ ‌2009)‌ ‌is‌ ‌unquestionably‌ ‌the‌ ‌founding‌ ‌and‌ ‌most‌ ‌important‌ ‌figure‌ ‌in‌ ‌anthropological‌ ‌structuralism.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌was‌ ‌born‌ ‌in‌ ‌Brussels‌ ‌in‌ ‌1908.‌ ‌and‌ ‌obtained‌ ‌a‌ ‌law‌ ‌degree‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌University‌ ‌of‌ ‌Paris.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n●As‌ ‌the‌ ‌founder‌ ‌of‌ ‌Structuralism‌ ‌school‌ ‌of‌ ‌thought,‌ ‌Strauss,‌ ‌believes‌ ‌that‌ ‌certain‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌facts‌ ‌are‌ ‌universal‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌physical‌ ‌or‌ ‌structural‌ ‌\nfactors.‌ ‌\n●Example‌-‌ ‌Human‌ ‌culture‌ ‌tends‌ ‌to‌ ‌divide‌ ‌larger‌ ‌concepts‌ ‌into‌ ‌binary‌ ‌opposition‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌left‌ ‌and‌ ‌right,‌ ‌black‌ ‌and‌ ‌white,‌ ‌hot‌ ‌and‌ ‌cold.‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌left‌ ‌his‌ ‌Legacy‌ ‌to‌ ‌future‌ ‌structuralism‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌Edmond‌ ‌Leach‌ ‌post‌ ‌structuralist‌ ‌philosophers‌ ‌Judith‌ ‌Butler‌ ‌and‌ ‌Jacques‌ ‌\nDerrida.‌ ‌\n●Structuralism‌ ‌focuses‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌effect‌ ‌of‌ ‌Universal‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌in‌ ‌human‌ ‌thought‌ ‌on‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌phenomenon.‌ ‌\n●Although‌ ‌not‌ ‌attempting‌ ‌to‌ ‌explain‌ ‌these‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌patterns,‌ ‌it‌ ‌rather‌ ‌presents‌ ‌them‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌result‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌subconscious‌ ‌of‌ ‌Universal‌ ‌human‌ ‌\nknowledge.‌ ‌\n●Meeting‌ ‌of‌ ‌Myth‌ ‌and‌ ‌Science‌ ‌\n○Strauss‌ ‌discussing‌ ‌the‌ ‌differences‌ ‌between‌ ‌modern‌ ‌science‌ ‌and‌ ‌mythological‌ ‌thought‌ ‌and‌ ‌how‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌connected‌ ‌using‌ ‌\nmathematics‌ ‌as‌ ‌an‌ ‌example‌ ‌he‌ ‌explain‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌human‌ ‌mind‌ ‌is‌ ‌able‌ ‌to‌ ‌create‌ ‌a‌ ‌triangle‌ ‌with‌ ‌perfectly‌ ‌straight‌ ‌lines‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌circle‌ ‌even‌ ‌\nthough‌ ‌those‌ ‌things‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌exist‌ ‌in‌ ‌nature,‌ ‌they‌ ‌were‌ ‌implemented‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌human‌ ‌mind‌ ‌being‌ ‌an‌ ‌example‌ ‌of‌ ‌mind‌ ‌vs‌ ‌experience.‌ ‌\n● ‌‌Primitive‌ ‌thinking‌ ‌and‌ ‌civilized‌ ‌mind‌ ‌\n○He‌ ‌suggested‌ ‌the‌ ‌elimination‌ ‌of‌ ‌Stark‌ ‌contrast‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌and‌ ‌civilized‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n○There‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌similarity‌ ‌of‌ ‌Mind‌ ‌between‌ ‌all‌ ‌kinds‌ ‌of‌ ‌people‌ ‌and‌ ‌that‌ ‌we‌ ‌should‌ ‌treat‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌cosmologies‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌rational,‌ ‌coherent‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nlogical‌.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nE.‌ ‌Leach‌ ‌\n ‌\n671‌ ‌\nAbout:‌ ‌E.‌ ‌Leach‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Sir‌ ‌Edmund‌ ‌Ronald‌ ‌Leach‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌British‌ ‌social‌ ‌anthropologist‌ ‌and‌ ‌academic.‌ ‌He‌ ‌served‌ ‌as‌ ‌Provost‌ ‌of‌ ‌King's‌ ‌College,‌ ‌Cambridge‌ ‌from‌ ‌\n1966‌ ‌to‌ ‌1979.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌was‌ ‌also‌ ‌President‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Royal‌ ‌Anthropological‌ ‌Institute‌ ‌from‌ ‌1971‌ ‌to‌ ‌1975.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●In‌ ‌his‌ ‌book’‌ ‌political‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌Highland‌ ‌Burma’‌ ‌a‌ ‌study‌ ‌in‌ ‌Kachin‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌(1954)‌ ‌for‌ ‌which‌ ‌he‌ ‌is‌ ‌best‌ ‌known.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌book's‌ ‌impact‌ ‌was‌ ‌largely‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌innovative‌ ‌methods‌ ‌of‌ ‌addressing‌ ‌social‌ ‌and‌ ‌political‌ ‌change‌ ‌by‌ ‌studying‌ ‌the‌ ‌last‌ ‌and‌ ‌varied‌ ‌\narea‌ ‌rather‌ ‌than‌ ‌studying‌ ‌a‌ ‌single‌ ‌society‌ ‌or‌ ‌a‌ ‌tribe.‌ ‌\n●Over‌ ‌the‌ ‌course‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌career,‌ ‌Leach‌ ‌attention‌ ‌shifted‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌tribal‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌to‌ ‌structuralism.‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌led‌ ‌to‌ ‌significant‌ ‌discussion‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌methodology‌ ‌of‌ ‌Strauss‌ ‌and‌ ‌Leach‌ ‌structuralist‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Biblical‌ ‌myth.‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌social‌ ‌anthropologist‌ ‌regarded‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌structuralist‌ ‌he‌ ‌is‌ ‌known‌ ‌for‌ ‌his‌ ‌teaching‌ ‌studies‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌field‌ ‌of‌ ‌kinship,‌ ‌marriage,‌ ‌rituals‌ ‌and‌ ‌Myth,‌ ‌\nmoving‌ ‌rapidly‌ ‌from‌ ‌one‌ ‌topic‌ ‌to‌ ‌another.‌ ‌\n●Examine‌ ‌the‌ ‌way‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌humans‌ ‌use‌ ‌categories‌ ‌to‌ ‌distinguish‌ ‌between‌ ‌self‌ ‌and‌ ‌other.‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌criticized‌ ‌radcliffe-brown‌ ‌and‌ ‌his‌ ‌successor‌ ‌who‌ ‌claimed‌ ‌to‌ ‌confirm‌ ‌the‌ ‌typology‌ ‌socially‌ ‌or‌ ‌directly‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌return‌ ‌of‌ ‌graphical‌ ‌data.‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌was‌ ‌perhaps‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌important‌ ‌interpreter‌ ‌of‌ ‌British‌ ‌Structuralism.‌ ‌his‌ ‌version‌ ‌of‌ ‌structuralism‌ ‌criticized‌ ‌the‌ ‌French‌ ‌anthropologist‌ ‌\nanalysis‌ ‌of‌ ‌Burmese‌ ‌Kinship.‌ ‌\n●More‌ ‌importantly,‌ ‌however‌ ‌he‌ ‌insisted‌ ‌on‌ ‌an‌ ‌empirical‌ ‌basis‌ ‌for‌ ‌structuralist‌ ‌generalisation‌ ‌rejecting‌ ‌Levi‌ ‌Strauss‌ ‌emphasis‌ ‌on‌ ‌Universal‌ ‌\nproperties‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌human‌ ‌mind‌ ‌insisting‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌similarities‌ ‌of‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌across‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌understood‌ ‌the‌ ‌ethnographic‌ ‌context‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌\nspecies‌ ‌biology.‌ ‌\n ‌\nCriticism‌ ‌\n672‌ ‌\n●Lack‌ ‌of‌ ‌proof-‌ ‌\n○While‌ ‌Structuralism‌ ‌was‌ ‌very‌ ‌popular‌ ‌during‌ ‌the‌ ‌1960's‌ ‌and‌ ‌70's,‌ ‌it‌ ‌eventually‌ ‌fell‌ ‌to‌ ‌much‌ ‌criticism‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌late‌ ‌1970's‌ ‌and‌ ‌80's,‌ ‌giving‌ ‌\nway‌ ‌to‌ ‌Post-Structuralism‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌anthropological‌ ‌theories.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌largest‌ ‌source‌ ‌of‌ ‌criticism‌ ‌for‌ ‌Structuralism‌ ‌seems‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌the‌ ‌lack‌ ‌of‌ ‌proof.‌ ‌Claude‌ ‌Levi-Strauss‌ ‌did‌ ‌not‌ ‌have‌ ‌proof‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌\nconcepts,‌ ‌but‌ ‌rather‌ ‌he‌ ‌assumed‌ ‌the‌ ‌fundamental‌ ‌structures‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌thought‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌universal.‌ ‌ ‌\n○\"Some,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌materialist‌ ‌Marvin‌ ‌Harris,‌ ‌have‌ ‌derided‌ ‌Structuralism‌ ‌for‌ ‌assuming‌ ‌that‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌structures‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌empirical‌ ‌reality‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nany‌ ‌given‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Validity‌ ‌of‌ ‌structural‌ ‌\n○Explanation‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌challenged‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌ground‌ ‌that‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌imprecise‌ ‌and‌ ‌depend‌ ‌heavily‌ ‌on‌ ‌observers.‌ ‌\n●Ignores‌ ‌Individual‌ ‌Differentiation‌ ‌\n○Another‌ ‌criticism‌ ‌of‌ ‌Levi-Strauss‌ ‌and‌ ‌his‌ ‌structuralist‌ ‌theory‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌assumption‌ ‌that‌ ‌all‌ ‌human‌ ‌minds‌ ‌were‌ ‌identical.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Levi-Strauss'‌ ‌\"synchronic‌ ‌approach,‌ ‌which‌ ‌advocates‌ ‌a‌ ‌“psychic‌ ‌unity”‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌human‌ ‌minds,‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌criticized‌ ‌because‌ ‌it‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌\naccount‌ ‌for‌ ‌individual‌ ‌human‌ ‌action‌ ‌historically.\"‌ ‌\n●Ahistorical‌ ‌\n○Structuralism‌ ‌looks‌ ‌at‌ ‌society‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌present‌ ‌without‌ ‌any‌ ‌regard‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌past,‌ ‌completely‌ ‌ignoring‌ ‌the‌ ‌historical‌ ‌context‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\ndevelopment‌ ‌of‌ ‌ideas.‌ ‌\n○Structuralism,‌ ‌therefore,‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌account‌ ‌for‌ ‌social‌ ‌change‌ ‌which‌ ‌gives‌ ‌a‌ ‌weakness‌ ‌to‌ ‌structuralist‌ ‌claims.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Another‌ ‌reaction‌ ‌to‌ ‌structuralism‌ ‌is‌ ‌grounded‌ ‌in‌ ‌scientific‌ ‌enquiry.‌ ‌structural‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌allow‌ ‌external‌ ‌validation‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Structuralism‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌be‌ ‌subjected‌ ‌to‌ ‌scientific‌ ‌scrutiny.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌Addition‌ ‌\nFunctionalism‌ ‌vs‌ ‌Structuralism‌ ‌\n●Functionalism‌ ‌in‌ ‌addition‌ ‌to‌ ‌being‌ ‌a‌ ‌Theory‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌a‌ ‌method,‌ ‌why‌ ‌is‌ ‌structural‌ ‌functionalism‌ ‌if‌ ‌is‌ ‌more‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌Theory.‌ ‌\n●Functionalism‌ ‌‌is‌ ‌concerned‌ ‌with‌ ‌action‌ ‌among‌ ‌individualism,‌ ‌the‌ ‌constraint‌ ‌proposed‌ ‌by‌ ‌social‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌on‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌and‌ ‌relation‌ ‌\nbetween‌ ‌the‌ ‌needs‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌and‌ ‌satisfaction‌ ‌of‌ ‌those‌ ‌needs‌ ‌to‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌framework.‌ ‌\n●Structural‌ ‌functionalism‌‌ ‌tends‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌concerned‌ ‌less‌ ‌with‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌action‌ ‌for‌ ‌needs‌ ‌and‌ ‌more‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌place‌ ‌of‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌in‌ ‌social‌ ‌\norder‌ ‌and‌ ‌indeed‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌construction‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌order‌ ‌itself.‌ ‌\n●Malinowaski‌ ‌suggested‌ ‌that‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌have‌ ‌biological‌ ‌and‌ ‌psychological‌ ‌needs‌ ‌and‌ ‌that‌ ‌social‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌exist‌ ‌to‌ ‌meet‌ ‌these‌ ‌needs.‌ ‌\n○Radcliffe‌ ‌Brown‌ ‌focuses‌ ‌on‌ ‌social‌ ‌structure‌ ‌rather‌ ‌than‌ ‌biological‌ ‌needs.‌ ‌\n●Functionalism:American‌ ‌thought‌ ‌individual‌ ‌thought‌ ‌\n○Structural‌ ‌functionalism:‌ ‌European--target‌ ‌macro‌ ‌system‌ ‌\n●Structural‌ ‌functionalism:‌ ‌maintain‌ ‌Status‌ ‌quo‌ ‌and‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌promote‌ ‌social‌ ‌change‌ ‌\n●Structural‌ ‌functionalism:‌ ‌was‌ ‌more‌ ‌scientific‌ ‌and‌ ‌its‌ ‌approach‌ ‌than‌ ‌functionalism.‌ ‌\n●Both‌ ‌study‌ ‌society‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌whole.‌ ‌\n673‌ ‌\n●Both‌ ‌use‌ ‌the‌ ‌ethnography‌ ‌method‌ ‌to‌ ‌study‌ ‌society‌ ‌and‌ ‌propose‌ ‌theory.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n6.‌ ‌Anthropological‌ ‌theories‌ ‌:‌ ‌(e)‌ ‌Culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌personality‌ ‌(Benedict,‌ ‌Mead,‌ ‌Linton,‌ ‌Kardiner‌ ‌and‌ ‌Cora-du‌ ‌Bois)‌ ‌(g)‌ ‌Cultural‌ ‌materialism‌ ‌\n(Harris)-Part-IV‌ ‌\n ‌\n674‌ ‌\n(e)‌ ‌Culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌personality‌ ‌(Benedict,‌ ‌Mead,‌ ‌Linton,‌ ‌Kardiner‌ ‌and‌ ‌Cora-du‌ ‌Bois)‌ ‌\n ‌ ‌\n ‌\nIntroduction:‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌Personality‌ ‌movement‌ ‌was‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌core‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌half‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌20th‌ ‌century.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌examined‌ ‌the‌ ‌interaction‌ ‌between‌ ‌psychological‌ ‌and‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌forces‌ ‌at‌ ‌work‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌human‌ ‌experience.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌Personality‌ ‌was‌ ‌too‌ ‌divided‌ ‌to‌ ‌really‌ ‌be‌ ‌considered‌ ‌a‌ ‌“school‌ ‌of‌ ‌thought.”‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌had‌ ‌no‌ ‌orthodox‌ ‌viewpoint,‌ ‌centralized‌ ‌leadership,‌ ‌or‌ ‌coherent‌ ‌training‌ ‌program;‌ ‌however,‌ ‌there‌ ‌were‌ ‌also‌ ‌some‌ ‌basic‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌with‌ ‌\nwhich‌ ‌most‌ ‌practitioners‌ ‌would‌ ‌agree.‌ ‌At‌ ‌a‌ ‌minimum,‌ ‌these‌ ‌would‌ ‌include:‌ ‌\n■Adult‌ ‌behavior‌ ‌is‌ ‌“culturally‌ ‌patterned,”‌ ‌\n■Childhood‌ ‌experiences‌ ‌influence‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual’s‌ ‌personality‌ ‌as‌ ‌an‌ ‌adult,‌ ‌and‌ ‌\n■Adult‌ ‌personality‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌are‌ ‌reflected‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌beliefs‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌institutions,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌religion.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌important‌ ‌study‌ ‌in‌ ‌psychological‌ ‌anthropology,thus‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌personality‌ ‌study‌ ‌also‌ ‌called‌ ‌‌psychological‌ ‌anthropology‌.‌ ‌\n●It's‌ ‌beginnings‌ ‌are‌ ‌associated‌ ‌especially‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌great‌ ‌American‌ ‌linguist‌ ‌and‌ ‌anthropologist‌ ‌Edward‌ ‌sapir.‌ ‌\n●Culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌personality‌ ‌studies‌ ‌applies‌ ‌the‌ ‌method‌ ‌of‌ ‌psychology‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌field‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropology.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌personality‌ ‌was‌ ‌Saphir's‌ ‌solution‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌problem‌ ‌paused‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌way‌ ‌that‌ ‌,in‌ ‌anthropological‌ ‌accounts,‌ ‌\nculture‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌made‌ ‌to‌ ‌assume‌ ‌the‌ ‌appearance‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌closed‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌behaviour.‌ ‌\n ‌\nHistory/Background‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌personality‌ ‌examined‌ ‌how‌ ‌different‌ ‌socialization‌ ‌practices‌ ‌resulted‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌personality‌ ‌types.‌ ‌\n●Like‌ ‌the‌ ‌Functionalist‌ ‌schools‌ ‌of‌ ‌Radcliffe-Brown‌ ‌and‌ ‌Malinowski,‌ ‌Culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌Personality‌ ‌was‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌reactions‌ ‌against‌ ‌19th‌ ‌century‌ ‌\nsocial‌ ‌evolutionism‌ ‌and‌ ‌diffusionism.‌ ‌ ‌\n675‌ ‌\n●Franz‌ ‌Boas‌ ‌and‌ ‌many‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌students‌ ‌(such‌ ‌as‌ ‌Ruth‌ ‌Benedict)‌ ‌argued‌ ‌against‌ ‌the‌ ‌views‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌early‌ ‌evolutionists,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌‌Louis‌ ‌Henry‌ ‌\nMorgan‌ ‌and‌ ‌Edward‌ ‌Tylor,‌ ‌who‌ ‌believe‌ ‌each‌ ‌culture‌ ‌goes‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌hierarchical‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌sequence.‌ ‌\n●There‌ ‌is‌ ‌some‌ ‌debate‌ ‌on‌ ‌exactly‌ ‌how‌ ‌the‌ ‌field‌ ‌of‌ ‌Culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌Personality‌ ‌emerged.‌ ‌Some‌ ‌believe‌ ‌it‌ ‌developed‌ ‌from‌ ‌an‌ ‌interaction‌ ‌between‌ ‌\nanthropology‌ ‌and‌ ‌‌Freud’s‌ ‌psychoanalysis.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nProminent‌ ‌figures‌ ‌\n●American‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌‌Ruth‌ ‌Benedict,‌ ‌Margaret‌ ‌Mead,‌ ‌Ralph‌ ‌Linton,and‌ ‌Abram‌ ‌Kardiner‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌pioneers‌ ‌of‌ ‌Culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nPersonality‌ ‌School‌ ‌of‌ ‌thought‌ ‌or‌ ‌Psychological‌ ‌anthropological‌ ‌theories.‌ ‌ ‌\n●There‌ ‌are‌ ‌three‌ ‌approaches‌ ‌that‌ ‌had‌ ‌emerged‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌contributions‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌scholars‌ ‌to‌ ‌study‌ ‌and‌ ‌examine‌ ‌the‌ ‌inter-relationship‌ ‌between‌ ‌\nculture‌ ‌and‌ ‌personality.‌ ‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌include:‌ ‌\n1.‌ ‌Personality‌ ‌builds‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\n2.‌ ‌Culture‌ ‌determines‌ ‌the‌ ‌formation‌ ‌of‌ ‌personality.‌ ‌\n3.‌ ‌Culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌personality‌ ‌are‌ ‌inseparable‌ ‌and‌ ‌influence‌ ‌each‌ ‌other.‌ ‌\n ‌\nRuth‌ ‌Benedict‌ ‌\n ‌\n676‌ ‌\nAbout:Ruth‌ ‌Benedict‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Ruth‌ ‌Benedict‌ ‌(1887-1948)‌ ‌Ruth‌ ‌Benedict‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌student‌ ‌of‌ ‌Franz‌ ‌Boas‌ ‌at‌ ‌Columbia‌ ‌University.‌ ‌\n●Her‌ ‌well-known‌ ‌contribution‌ ‌was‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌configurationalist‌ ‌approach‌ ‌to‌ ‌Culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌Personality.‌ ‌\n●Like‌ ‌Boas,‌ ‌she‌ ‌believed‌ ‌that‌ ‌culture‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌product‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌choices‌ ‌rather‌ ‌than‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌determinism.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Benedict‌ ‌conducted‌ ‌fieldwork‌ ‌among‌ ‌American‌ ‌Indians,‌ ‌contemporary‌ ‌European‌ ‌and‌ ‌Asian‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Her‌ ‌key‌ ‌works,‌ ‌Patterns‌ ‌of‌ ‌Culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌Chrysanthemum‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌Sword,‌ ‌spread‌ ‌the‌ ‌importance‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌in‌ ‌individual‌ ‌personality‌ ‌\nformation.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Patterns‌ ‌of‌ ‌Culture‌ ‌summarized‌ ‌Benedict’s‌ ‌views‌ ‌on‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌best-selling‌ ‌anthropological‌ ‌books‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌time.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Ruth‌ ‌Benedict,‌ ‌the‌ ‌teacher‌ ‌of‌ ‌Margaret‌ ‌Mead‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌known‌ ‌woman‌ ‌anthropologist‌ ‌of‌ ‌America‌ ‌dealt‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌impact‌ ‌of‌ ‌personality‌ ‌on‌ ‌\nculture.‌ ‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌Ruth‌ ‌Benedict,‌ ‌‌culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌personality.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌self-created‌ ‌but‌ ‌personality‌ ‌builds‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\n●Human‌ ‌beings‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌creators‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌in‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌fulfill‌ ‌their‌ ‌various‌ ‌kinds‌ ‌of‌ ‌needs.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual‌ ‌(personality)‌ ‌who‌ ‌plays‌ ‌a‌ ‌significant‌ ‌\nrole‌ ‌in‌ ‌handling‌ ‌down‌ ‌the‌ ‌culture‌ ‌from‌ ‌one‌ ‌generation‌ ‌to‌ ‌another.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌this‌ ‌sense,‌ ‌Benedict‌ ‌says,‌ ‌culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌gift‌ ‌of‌ ‌personality.‌ ‌‌She‌ ‌studied‌ ‌Kwakiutl,‌ ‌Dobu‌ ‌and‌ ‌Pueblo‌ ‌Zuni.‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌Benedict,‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌two‌ ‌kinds‌ ‌of‌ ‌genius‌ ‌(personality)‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌human‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n1.‌ ‌Apollonian‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌word‌ ‌apollonian‌ ‌is‌ ‌from‌ ‌Greek‌ ‌god‌ ‌Apollo,‌ ‌the‌ ‌peaceful‌ ‌sun‌ ‌deity.‌ ‌\n■Apollo‌ ‌is‌ ‌regarded‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌god‌ ‌of‌ ‌peace,‌ ‌discipline,‌ ‌kindness‌ ‌and‌ ‌humanity‌ ‌by‌ ‌Greek‌ ‌people.‌ ‌\n■Thus,‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌apollonian‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture,‌ ‌‌one‌ ‌finds‌ ‌the‌ ‌existence‌ ‌of‌ ‌peace,‌ ‌kindness‌ ‌and‌ ‌discipline.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Benedict‌ ‌cites‌ ‌the‌ ‌example‌ ‌of‌ ‌Pueblo‌ ‌of‌ ‌New‌ ‌Mexico‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌representative‌ ‌of‌ ‌Apollonian‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\n ‌\n677‌ ‌\n2.‌ ‌Dionysian‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌word‌ ‌Dionysian‌ ‌is‌ ‌derived‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌name‌ ‌of‌ ‌Greek‌ ‌god‌ ‌Dionysius.‌ ‌\n■Dionysius‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌symbol‌ ‌of‌ ‌luxurious‌ ‌life‌ ‌and‌ ‌drinking.‌ ‌In‌ ‌the‌ ‌Dionysian‌ ‌culture,‌ ‌a‌ ‌great‌ ‌deal‌ ‌of‌ ‌storms‌ ‌and‌ ‌changes‌ ‌are‌ ‌\nexperienced.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Benedict‌ ‌cites‌ ‌the‌ ‌example‌ ‌of‌ ‌‌Dobu‌ ‌and‌ ‌Kwakiutl‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌of‌ ‌North‌ ‌West‌ ‌coast‌ ‌of‌ ‌America‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌representatives‌ ‌of‌ ‌Dionysian‌ ‌\ngenius.‌ ‌\n■Dobu‌ ‌of‌ ‌Melanesia‌ ‌is‌ ‌exactly‌ ‌in‌ ‌contrast‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌Pueblo‌ ‌in‌ ‌character‌ ‌and‌ ‌temperament.‌ ‌\n●Among‌ ‌them‌ ‌occured‌ ‌frequently‌ ‌conflict,‌ ‌competition‌ ‌and‌ ‌violence.‌ ‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌usually‌ ‌used‌ ‌magic‌ ‌to‌ ‌harm‌ ‌others.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n■People‌ ‌of‌ ‌Kwakiutl‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌believe‌ ‌in‌ ‌religious‌ ‌practices.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌their‌ ‌culture,‌ ‌wealth‌ ‌determines‌ ‌status‌ ‌and‌ ‌prestige.‌ ‌ ‌\n678‌ ‌\n●Everyone‌ ‌becomes‌ ‌busy‌ ‌in‌ ‌earning‌ ‌money‌ ‌by‌ ‌one‌ ‌way‌ ‌or‌ ‌another.‌ ‌Those‌ ‌with‌ ‌less‌ ‌money‌ ‌feel‌ ‌ashamed‌ ‌on‌ ‌account‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nit.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Benedict’s‌ ‌study‌ ‌clearly‌ ‌reveals‌ ‌the‌ ‌influence‌ ‌of‌ ‌personality‌ ‌on‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌groups‌ ‌differ‌ ‌because‌ ‌their‌ ‌members‌ ‌have‌ ‌different‌ ‌characters‌ ‌and‌ ‌personality.‌ ‌\n●Accordingly‌ ‌they‌ ‌behave‌ ‌in‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌groups.‌ ‌\n679‌ ‌\n ‌\nConcept‌ ‌of‌ ‌Culture‌ ‌Pattern:‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌concept,‌ ‌which‌ ‌was‌ ‌already‌ ‌known‌ ‌among‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌to‌ ‌refer‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌universal‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture,‌ ‌is‌ ‌elaborated‌ ‌in‌ ‌her‌ ‌famous‌ ‌book‌ ‌\nPatterns‌ ‌of‌ ‌Culture‌ ‌(1934‌).‌ ‌ ‌\n●Benedict‌ ‌tries‌ ‌to‌ ‌show‌ ‌the‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌as‌ ‌applicable‌ ‌to‌ ‌individual‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌culture‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌is‌ ‌formed‌ ‌when‌ ‌many‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌traits‌ ‌and‌ ‌culture‌ ‌complexes‌ ‌become‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌each‌ ‌other,‌ ‌and‌ ‌integrated‌ ‌into‌ ‌the‌ ‌functional‌ ‌\nwhole.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌our‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌culture,‌ ‌culture‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌consist‌ ‌of‌ ‌Gandhism,‌ ‌spiritualism,‌ ‌joint‌ ‌family‌ ‌system,‌ ‌caste‌ ‌system,‌ ‌ruralism‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Each‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌culture‌ ‌complexes‌ ‌consists‌ ‌of‌ ‌numerous‌ ‌culture‌ ‌traits.‌ ‌ ‌\n●All‌ ‌these,‌ ‌integrated‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌functional‌ ‌whole,‌ ‌give‌ ‌rise‌ ‌to‌ ‌culture‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌of‌ ‌Indian‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\n ‌\nMargaret‌ ‌Mead‌ ‌\n ‌\nAbout:Margaret‌ ‌Mead‌ ‌\n ‌\n680‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Margaret‌ ‌Mead‌ ‌(1901-1978)‌ ‌Margaret‌ ‌Mead‌ ‌was‌ ‌born‌ ‌in‌ ‌Philadelphia.‌ ‌ ‌\n●She‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌student,‌ ‌a‌ ‌lifelong‌ ‌friend,‌ ‌and‌ ‌collaborator‌ ‌of‌ ‌Ruth‌ ‌Benedict.‌ ‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌both‌ ‌studied‌ ‌the‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌configuration‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture,‌ ‌socialization‌ ‌in‌ ‌each‌ ‌particular‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌individual‌ ‌personality‌ ‌\nformation.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Mead’s‌ ‌works‌ ‌explored‌ ‌human‌ ‌development‌ ‌from‌ ‌a‌ ‌cross-cultural‌ ‌perspective‌ ‌and‌ ‌covered‌ ‌topics‌ ‌on‌ ‌gender‌ ‌roles‌ ‌and‌ ‌childrearing‌ ‌in‌ ‌both‌ ‌\nAmerican‌ ‌and‌ ‌foreign‌ ‌cultures.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Her‌ ‌first‌ ‌work,‌ ‌‌Coming‌ ‌of‌ ‌Age‌ ‌in‌ ‌Samoa‌,‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌best‌ ‌seller‌ ‌and‌ ‌built‌ ‌up‌ ‌Mead‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌leading‌ ‌figure‌ ‌in‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌anthropology.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌book‌ ‌described‌ ‌how‌ ‌individual‌ ‌development‌ ‌was‌ ‌determined‌ ‌by‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌expectations‌ ‌and‌ ‌was‌ ‌not‌ ‌biologically‌ ‌determined.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Margaret‌ ‌Mead,‌ ‌through‌ ‌her‌ ‌study,‌ ‌attempted‌ ‌to‌ ‌show‌ ‌the‌ ‌impact‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌on‌ ‌personality‌ ‌formation.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌her‌ ‌view,‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌adopts‌ ‌not‌ ‌only‌ ‌material‌ ‌aspects‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌i.e.‌ ‌house,‌ ‌tool,‌ ‌furniture‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌but‌ ‌also‌ ‌non-material‌ ‌aspects‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nculture,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌religion,‌ ‌tradition,‌ ‌custom,‌ ‌rituals,‌ ‌beliefs,‌ ‌values‌ ‌and‌ ‌ideals.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌culture‌ ‌which‌ ‌teaches‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌to‌ ‌behave‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌way.‌ ‌ ‌\n●An‌ ‌individual‌ ‌learns‌ ‌a‌ ‌culture‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌process‌ ‌of‌ ‌enculturation‌ ‌and‌ ‌assimilation.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Mead‌ ‌studied‌ ‌the‌ ‌impact‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌on‌ ‌personality‌ ‌through‌ ‌her‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌three‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌societies‌ ‌namely,‌ ‌Mundugumor,‌ ‌Arapesh‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nTschambuli.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Though‌ ‌these‌ ‌people‌ ‌live‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌geographical‌ ‌region,‌ ‌they‌ ‌have‌ ‌different‌ ‌characters‌ ‌and‌ ‌personalities‌ ‌because‌ ‌of‌ ‌differences‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌\ncultures.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌short,‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌Mead,‌ ‌culture‌ ‌influences‌ ‌the‌ ‌personality‌ ‌formation‌ ‌of‌ ‌individuals.‌ ‌\n●Mead‌ ‌published‌ ‌another‌ ‌book‌ ‌entitled‌ ‌‌And‌ ‌Keep‌ ‌Your‌ ‌Powder‌ ‌Dry‌ ‌‌(1942).‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌this‌ ‌book,‌ ‌Mead‌ ‌deals‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌national‌ ‌character‌ ‌of‌ ‌America.‌ ‌ ‌\n●She‌ ‌did‌ ‌not‌ ‌see‌ ‌differences‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌personalities‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌child‌ ‌in‌ ‌America‌ ‌and‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌any‌ ‌other‌ ‌countries‌ ‌like‌ ‌Japan‌ ‌and‌ ‌Russia.‌ ‌ ‌\n681‌ ‌\n●Their‌ ‌early‌ ‌personality‌ ‌was‌ ‌similar.‌ ‌They‌ ‌gradually‌ ‌become‌ ‌different‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌education‌ ‌and‌ ‌school‌ ‌education‌ ‌differ.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌this‌ ‌way,‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌personality‌ ‌developed‌ ‌in‌ ‌them‌ ‌reflect‌ ‌their‌ ‌national‌ ‌characters.‌ ‌\n ‌\nCase‌ ‌Study‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌Mead's‌ ‌fieldwork‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌her‌ ‌book‌ ‌‌Sex‌ ‌and‌ ‌Temperament‌ ‌in‌ ‌Three‌ ‌Primitive‌ ‌Societies‌ ‌(1935)‌,‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌psycho-cultural‌ ‌study,‌ ‌Mead‌ ‌deals‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌impact‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nculture‌ ‌on‌ ‌personality.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Mead‌ ‌had‌ ‌selected‌ ‌three‌ ‌societies‌ ‌of‌ ‌New‌ ‌Guinea‌ ‌namely‌ ‌Arapesh,‌ ‌Mundugumour,‌ ‌Tschambuli,‌ ‌residing‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌geographical‌ ‌region.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Mead‌ ‌was‌ ‌interested‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌as‌ ‌to‌ ‌why‌ ‌societies‌ ‌living‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌area‌ ‌differ‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌character‌ ‌and‌ ‌personality.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Mead’s‌ ‌study‌ ‌reveals‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌differences‌ ‌in‌ ‌personality‌ ‌of‌ ‌male‌ ‌and‌ ‌female‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌society‌ ‌or‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌societies‌ ‌are‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌\ndifferences.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌the‌ ‌personality‌ ‌of‌ ‌Arapesh,‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌conflict,‌ ‌competition‌ ‌and‌ ‌struggle.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○They‌ ‌are‌ ‌co-operative,‌ ‌peace-loving‌ ‌and‌ ‌kind.‌ ‌ ‌\n682‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌character‌ ‌of‌ ‌Mundugumour,‌ ‌another‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌group‌ ‌living‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌area,‌ ‌is‌ ‌in‌ ‌contrast‌ ‌with‌ ‌Arapesh.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n○The‌ ‌Mundugumour‌ ‌are‌ ‌characterised‌ ‌by‌ ‌suspicion,‌ ‌competition,‌ ‌quarrel‌ ‌and‌ ‌jealousy.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Both‌ ‌male‌ ‌and‌ ‌female‌ ‌are‌ ‌aggressive.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Because‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌factors,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Mundugumour‌ ‌society‌ ‌is‌ ‌dominated‌ ‌by‌ ‌aggressiveness‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌formation‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌personality.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌status‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌male‌ ‌is‌ ‌determined‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌wives‌ ‌he‌ ‌has.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌greater‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌wives‌ ‌one‌ ‌has,‌ ‌the‌ ‌higher‌ ‌is‌ ‌his‌ ‌status.‌ ‌The‌ ‌multiple‌ ‌wives‌ ‌disturb‌ ‌the‌ ‌peace‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌atmosphere.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Marriage‌ ‌by‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌prevalent‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Accordingly,‌ ‌a‌ ‌husband‌ ‌is‌ ‌capable‌ ‌of‌ ‌exchanging‌ ‌his‌ ‌own‌ ‌daughter‌ ‌for‌ ‌his‌ ‌new‌ ‌wives.‌ ‌\n○Marriage‌ ‌by‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌brings‌ ‌conflict‌ ‌between‌ ‌father‌ ‌and‌ ‌son.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Father‌ ‌wants‌ ‌to‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌his‌ ‌own‌ ‌daughter‌ ‌for‌ ‌his‌ ‌own‌ ‌marriage,‌ ‌so‌ ‌also‌ ‌the‌ ‌son.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌mother‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌like‌ ‌to‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌her‌ ‌daughter‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌new‌ ‌wife.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Hence‌ ‌Mundugumour‌ ‌culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌characterized‌ ‌by‌ ‌continuous‌ ‌struggle,‌ ‌competition‌ ‌and‌ ‌conflict‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n ‌\nRalph‌ ‌Linton‌ ‌\n ‌\nAbout:‌‌ ‌‌Ralph‌ ‌Linton‌ ‌\n683‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Ralph‌ ‌Linton‌ ‌(1893-1953)‌ ‌Ralph‌ ‌Linton‌ ‌was‌ ‌born‌ ‌in‌ ‌Philadelphia,‌ ‌Pennsylvania.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌was‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌founders‌ ‌of‌ ‌basic‌ ‌personality‌ ‌structure‌ ‌theory.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌worked‌ ‌on‌ ‌ethnographies‌ ‌of‌ ‌Melanesians‌ ‌and‌ ‌American‌ ‌Indians‌ ‌and‌ ‌partnered‌ ‌with‌ ‌Abram‌ ‌Kardiner‌ ‌to‌ ‌develop‌ ‌the‌ ‌personality‌ ‌\nmediation‌ ‌view.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n684‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌developed‌ ‌the‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌status‌ ‌and‌ ‌role‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌classic‌ ‌book‌ ‌‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌man(1936).‌ ‌\n ‌\n●He‌ ‌emphasized‌ ‌also‌ ‌as‌ ‌to‌ ‌how‌ ‌personality‌ ‌influences‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌behaviour.‌ ‌\n●Linton‌ ‌is‌ ‌often‌ ‌identified‌ ‌with‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌personality‌ ‌School,‌ ‌Linton‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌believe‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌between‌ ‌culture‌ ‌exerting‌ ‌its‌ ‌influence‌ ‌\nmore‌ ‌or‌ ‌less‌ ‌uniformly‌ ‌across‌ ‌the‌ ‌personalities‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌shaped.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌the‌ ‌twentieth-century‌ ‌his‌ ‌writing‌ ‌tells‌ ‌about‌ ‌the‌ ‌model‌ ‌skills.‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌argued‌ ‌that‌ ‌while‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌personality‌ ‌were‌ ‌similarly‌ ‌integrated‌ ‌there‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌specific‌ ‌causal‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌between.‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌agreed‌ ‌that‌ ‌primary‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌deal‌ ‌with‌ ‌basic‌ ‌personalities,‌ ‌while‌ ‌second‌ ‌are‌ ‌products‌ ‌of‌ ‌basic‌ ‌personality‌ ‌structure.‌ ‌\n ‌\nAbram‌ ‌Kardiner‌ ‌\n ‌\nAbout‌:‌Abram‌ ‌Kardiner‌ ‌\n685‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Abram‌ ‌Kardiner‌ ‌(1891-1981)‌ ‌Kardiner‌ ‌was‌ ‌born‌ ‌in‌ ‌New‌ ‌York‌ ‌City‌ ‌and‌ ‌was‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌founders‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌New‌ ‌York‌ ‌Psychoanalytic‌ ‌Institute.‌ ‌ ‌\n●His‌ ‌contribution‌ ‌concerned‌ ‌the‌ ‌interplay‌ ‌of‌ ‌individual‌ ‌personality‌ ‌development‌ ‌and‌ ‌situated‌ ‌cultures.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Looking‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌way‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌personality‌ ‌types‌ ‌are‌ ‌present‌ ‌in‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌patterns,‌ ‌Kardiner‌ ‌and‌ ‌his‌ ‌colleagues‌ ‌argue‌ ‌that‌ ‌religion‌ ‌and‌ ‌politics‌ ‌\nare‌ ‌screen‌ ‌onto‌ ‌which‌ ‌the‌ ‌basic‌ ‌personality‌ ‌orientation‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌society‌ ‌is‌ ‌from.‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌introduced‌ ‌the‌ ‌idea‌ ‌of‌ ‌basic‌ ‌personality.‌ ‌\n●After‌ ‌developing‌ ‌the‌ ‌basic‌ ‌personality‌ ‌structure‌ ‌approach,‌ ‌he‌ ‌argued‌ ‌along‌ ‌with‌ ‌Linton‌ ‌that‌ ‌while‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌personality‌ ‌was‌ ‌similarly‌ ‌\nintegrated,‌ ‌specific‌ ‌casual‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌existed‌ ‌between‌ ‌them.‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌developed‌ ‌a‌ ‌psycho-cultural‌ ‌model‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌between‌ ‌child-rearing,‌ ‌housing‌ ‌and‌ ‌decent‌ ‌types‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌different‌ ‌cultures.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌distinguished‌ ‌primary‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌(e.g.‌ ‌child‌ ‌training,‌ ‌toilet‌ ‌behavior‌ ‌and‌ ‌family‌ ‌structure)‌ ‌and‌ ‌secondary‌ ‌institutions‌ ‌(such‌ ‌as‌ ‌religion‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nart).‌ ‌ ‌\n686‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌explained‌ ‌that‌ ‌basic‌ ‌personality‌ ‌structures‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌society‌ ‌influenced‌ ‌the‌ ‌personality‌ ‌types‌ ‌which‌ ‌further‌ ‌influenced‌ ‌the‌ ‌secondary‌ ‌\ninstitutions.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n●He‌ ‌also‌ ‌was‌ ‌noted‌ ‌for‌ ‌studying‌ ‌the‌ ‌object‌ ‌relations‌ ‌and‌ ‌ego‌ ‌psychology‌ ‌in‌ ‌psychoanalysis.‌ ‌ ‌\n●His‌ ‌interpretations‌ ‌were‌ ‌presented‌ ‌principally‌ ‌in‌ ‌‌The‌ ‌Individual‌ ‌and‌ ‌His‌ ‌Society‌ ‌(1939)‌ ‌and‌ ‌Psychological‌ ‌Frontiers‌ ‌of‌ ‌Society‌ ‌(1945).‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n687‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nCora-du‌ ‌Bois‌ ‌\n ‌\nAbout:Cora-du‌ ‌Bois‌ ‌\n688‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Cora‌ ‌Dubois‌ ‌(1903-‌ ‌1991)‌ ‌Cora‌ ‌Dubois‌ ‌was‌ ‌born‌ ‌in‌ ‌New‌ ‌York‌ ‌City.‌ ‌ ‌\n●She‌ ‌earned‌ ‌her‌ ‌M.A.‌ ‌degree‌ ‌in‌ ‌Columbia‌ ‌University‌ ‌and‌ ‌attended‌ ‌the‌ ‌University‌ ‌of‌ ‌Berkeley‌ ‌for‌ ‌her‌ ‌Ph.‌ ‌D‌ ‌degree.‌ ‌ ‌\n●She‌ ‌was‌ ‌influenced‌ ‌by‌ ‌her‌ ‌mentor‌ ‌and‌ ‌collaborator‌ ‌Abram‌ ‌Kardiner‌ ‌in‌ ‌cross-cultural‌ ‌diagnosis‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌psychoanalytic‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌\n ‌\n●She‌ ‌stated‌ ‌that‌ ‌individual‌ ‌variations‌ ‌within‌ ‌a‌ ‌culture‌ ‌exist‌ ‌and‌ ‌each‌ ‌culture‌ ‌shares‌ ‌the‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌type‌ ‌which‌ ‌might‌ ‌not‌ ‌exist‌ ‌\nin‌ ‌its‌ ‌individual.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌1945,‌ ‌Cora‌ ‌Dubois,‌ ‌Abram‌ ‌Kardiner‌ ‌and‌ ‌Ralph‌ ‌Linton‌ ‌co-authored‌ ‌the‌ ‌book,‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Psychological‌ ‌Frontiers‌ ‌of‌ ‌Society‌ ‌which‌ ‌consisted‌ ‌of‌ ‌\ncareful‌ ‌descriptions‌ ‌and‌ ‌interpretations‌ ‌of‌ ‌three‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌‌(the‌ ‌Comanche‌ ‌culture,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Alorese‌ ‌culture,‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌culture‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌American‌ ‌\nrural‌ ‌community).‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌explained‌ ‌the‌ ‌basic‌ ‌personality‌ ‌formed‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌diversity‌ ‌of‌ ‌subject‌ ‌matter‌ ‌in‌ ‌each‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\n●She‌ ‌argues‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌primary‌ ‌Institutions‌ ‌leads‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌formation‌ ‌of‌ ‌basic‌ ‌characteristics‌.‌ ‌\n●Between‌ ‌1937‌ ‌and‌ ‌1939,‌ ‌Dubois‌ ‌investigated‌ ‌the‌ ‌island‌ ‌of‌ ‌‌Alor‌ ‌(now‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌Indonesia)‌ ‌using‌ ‌participant‌ ‌observation,‌ ‌detailed‌ ‌case‌ ‌\nstudies,‌ ‌life-history‌ ‌interviews,‌ ‌and‌ ‌various‌ ‌personality‌ ‌tests.‌ ‌\n●Based‌ ‌on‌ ‌her‌ ‌ethnographic‌ ‌and‌ ‌psychoanalytic‌ ‌study,‌ ‌she‌ ‌wrote‌ ‌the‌ ‌book‌ ‌entitled‌ ‌‌The‌ ‌People‌ ‌of‌ ‌Alor‌ ‌(1944).‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌this‌ ‌social-psychological‌ ‌study,‌ ‌she‌ ‌advanced‌ ‌the‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌modal‌ ‌personality‌ ‌structure.‌ ‌Cora‌ ‌Dubois‌ ‌stated‌ ‌that‌ ‌individual‌ ‌\nvariation‌ ‌within‌ ‌a‌ ‌culture‌ ‌exists,‌ ‌and‌ ‌each‌ ‌culture‌ ‌shares‌ ‌the‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌type‌ ‌which‌ ‌might‌ ‌not‌ ‌exist‌ ‌in‌ ‌its‌ ‌individuals.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nMETHODOLOGIES‌ ‌\n●Clinical‌ ‌Interviews‌ ‌ ‌\n○Through‌ ‌a‌ ‌variety‌ ‌of‌ ‌methods,‌ ‌the‌ ‌professional‌ ‌is‌ ‌able‌ ‌to‌ ‌record‌ ‌and‌ ‌attempt‌ ‌to‌ ‌understand‌ ‌the‌ ‌internal‌ ‌thoughts‌ ‌and‌ ‌motivations‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nan‌ ‌individual‌ ‌within‌ ‌a‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n689‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌interviews‌ ‌are‌ ‌usually‌ ‌conducted‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌specific‌ ‌room‌ ‌or‌ ‌office.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌method‌ ‌used‌ ‌more‌ ‌by‌ ‌psychologists‌ ‌like‌ ‌Freud‌ ‌than‌ ‌other‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Dream‌ ‌Analysis‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌Freud’s‌ ‌psychoanalysis‌ ‌and‌ ‌attempts‌ ‌to‌ ‌seek‌ ‌out‌ ‌the‌ ‌repressed‌ ‌emotions‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌person‌ ‌by‌ ‌peeling‌ ‌back‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nsubconscious.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌is‌ ‌accomplished‌ ‌through‌ ‌discussion‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual’s‌ ‌dreams.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Life‌ ‌Histories‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌documentation‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual’s‌ ‌experiences‌ ‌throughout‌ ‌his‌ ‌life.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌most‌ ‌used‌ ‌by‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Modal‌ ‌Personality‌ ‌Approach‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌ethnographers.‌ ‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌psychoanalysts,‌ ‌this‌ ‌aids‌ ‌in‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌the‌ ‌underlying‌ ‌reasons‌ ‌for‌ ‌actions‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌way‌ ‌that‌ ‌dream‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌would.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Person-centered‌ ‌Ethnography‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌term‌ ‌was‌ ‌first‌ ‌used‌ ‌by‌ ‌Robert‌ ‌I.‌ ‌Levy.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌approach‌ ‌that‌ ‌draws‌ ‌interpretations‌ ‌from‌ ‌psychiatry‌ ‌and‌ ‌psychoanalysis‌ ‌to‌ ‌see‌ ‌how‌ ‌\nindividuals‌ ‌relate‌ ‌and‌ ‌interact‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌socio-cultural‌ ‌context.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Participant‌ ‌Observation‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌popular‌ ‌technique‌ ‌with‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌they‌ ‌spend‌ ‌a‌ ‌prolonged‌ ‌amount‌ ‌of‌ ‌time‌ ‌living‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌culture‌ ‌he‌ ‌is‌ ‌studying.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌involves‌ ‌a‌ ‌balancing‌ ‌act‌ ‌between‌ ‌watching‌ ‌and‌ ‌taking‌ ‌an‌ ‌active‌ ‌role‌ ‌within‌ ‌that‌ ‌community.‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌important‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌ethnographer’s‌ ‌research‌ ‌because‌ ‌it‌ ‌aids‌ ‌in‌ ‌discovering‌ ‌the‌ ‌intricate‌ ‌behaviors‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Participant‌ ‌observation‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌and‌ ‌is‌ ‌still‌ ‌used‌ ‌today‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌wide‌ ‌variety‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropologist.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Projective‌ ‌Tests‌ ‌ ‌\n○These‌ ‌are‌ ‌personality‌ ‌tests‌ ‌which‌ ‌have‌ ‌an‌ ‌ambiguous‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌so‌ ‌that‌ ‌a‌ ‌person’s‌ ‌thoughts‌ ‌or‌ ‌emotions‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌revealed.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌can‌ ‌then‌ ‌be‌ ‌compared‌ ‌to‌ ‌other‌ ‌responses.‌ ‌ ‌\n○One‌ ‌common‌ ‌test‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌Rorschach‌ ‌inkblot‌ ‌test.‌ ‌In‌ ‌this‌ ‌test,‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌must‌ ‌describe‌ ‌what‌ ‌he‌ ‌sees‌ ‌and‌ ‌his‌ ‌perceptions‌ ‌are‌ ‌\ncompared‌ ‌with‌ ‌other‌ ‌results‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n○These‌ ‌tests,‌ ‌however,‌ ‌are‌ ‌very‌ ‌influenced‌ ‌by‌ ‌Western‌ ‌thought‌ ‌which‌ ‌sometimes‌ ‌presents‌ ‌problems‌ ‌when‌ ‌used‌ ‌cross-culturally‌ ‌\nespecially‌ ‌in‌ ‌non-Western‌ ‌cultures.‌ ‌\n ‌\nACCOMPLISHMENTS‌ ‌\n●Culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌personality‌ ‌studies‌ ‌have‌ ‌greatly‌ ‌limited‌ ‌the‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌racist,‌ ‌hierarchical‌ ‌descriptions‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌types‌ ‌that‌ ‌were‌ ‌common‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nearly‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌century.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Through‌ ‌these‌ ‌studies,‌ ‌a‌ ‌new‌ ‌emphasis‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual‌ ‌emerged‌ ‌and‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌links‌ ‌between‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌and‌ ‌psychology‌ ‌was‌ ‌\nmade.‌ ‌ ‌\n690‌ ‌\n●From‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌personality,‌ ‌psychological‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌developed‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌small‌ ‌but‌ ‌still‌ ‌active‌ ‌today.‌ ‌\n ‌\nCRITICISMS‌ ‌\n●Culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌Personality‌ ‌came‌ ‌under‌ ‌the‌ ‌heavy‌ ‌scrutiny‌ ‌of‌ ‌Radcliffe-Brown‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌British‌ ‌social‌ ‌anthropologists.‌ ‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌dismissed‌ ‌this‌ ‌view‌ ‌due‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌‘vague‌ ‌abstraction’.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌was‌ ‌criticized‌ ‌as‌ ‌being‌ ‌unscientific‌ ‌and‌ ‌hard‌ ‌to‌ ‌disprove,‌ ‌and‌ ‌little‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌was‌ ‌given‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌connection‌ ‌between‌ ‌child-rearing‌ ‌practices‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌adulthood‌ ‌personality‌ ‌traits.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Benedict‌ ‌and‌ ‌Mead‌ ‌were‌ ‌critiqued‌ ‌for‌ ‌not‌ ‌considering‌ ‌individual‌ ‌variation‌ ‌within‌ ‌a‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌discussing‌ ‌the‌ ‌society‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌homologous‌ ‌unit.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n(g)‌ ‌Cultural‌ ‌materialism‌ ‌(Harris)‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Cultural‌ ‌materialism‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌anthropological‌ ‌theory‌ ‌espoused‌ ‌by‌ ‌‌Marvin‌ ‌Harris‌ ‌in‌ ‌his‌ ‌book‌ ‌‘‌The‌ ‌rise‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropological‌ ‌theory‌,‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nidea,‌ ‌value‌ ‌and‌ ‌religious‌ ‌belief‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌means‌ ‌of‌ ‌adaptation‌ ‌to‌ ‌environmental‌ ‌conditions.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌was‌ ‌developed‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌reaction‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌structuralism‌ ‌of‌ ‌Claude‌ ‌Levis‌ ‌Strauss‌.‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌tries‌ ‌to‌ ‌technological,‌ ‌economically,‌ ‌and‌ ‌demographic‌ ‌factor‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌societal‌ ‌infrastructure,‌ ‌structure‌ ‌and‌ ‌superstructure.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌believes‌ ‌that‌ ‌all‌ ‌structures‌ ‌are‌ ‌made‌ ‌by‌ ‌society‌ ‌to‌ ‌benefit‌ ‌the‌ ‌production‌ ‌and‌ ‌reproduction‌ ‌capacity‌ ‌of‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n●With‌ ‌changes‌ ‌in‌ ‌material‌ ‌condition‌ ‌the‌ ‌socio-cultural‌ ‌feature‌ ‌also‌ ‌changes.‌ ‌\n●But‌ ‌the‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌materialism‌ ‌suffered‌ ‌from‌ ‌Shortcoming‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌tries‌ ‌to‌ ‌make‌ ‌everything‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌society‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌material‌ ‌condition‌ ‌and‌ ‌follow‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nWestern‌ ‌ethnocentrism‌ ‌because‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌nature‌ ‌of‌ ‌study.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nAbout:Marvin‌ ‌Harris‌ ‌\n ‌\n691‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Marvin‌ ‌Harris‌ ‌was‌ ‌an‌ ‌American‌ ‌anthropologist.‌ ‌He‌ ‌was‌ ‌born‌ ‌in‌ ‌Brooklyn,‌ ‌New‌ ‌York‌ ‌City.‌ ‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌prolific‌ ‌writer,‌ ‌he‌ ‌was‌ ‌highly‌ ‌influential‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌materialism‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nStudy‌ ‌by‌ ‌Harris‌ ‌\n●Marvin‌ ‌Harris‌ ‌and‌ ‌his‌ ‌students‌ ‌have‌ ‌developed‌ ‌this‌ ‌theory‌ ‌After‌ ‌analysing‌ ‌and‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌adaptive‌ ‌s‌tudies‌ ‌specially‌ ‌on‌ ‌some‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌\nsocieties‌ ‌from‌ ‌Africa.‌ ‌\n●Cultural‌ ‌materialism‌ ‌promotes‌ ‌the‌ ‌idea‌ ‌of‌ ‌Infrastructure,‌ ‌consisting‌ ‌of‌ ‌material‌ ‌realities‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌Technologies,‌ ‌economic‌ ‌and‌ ‌reproductive‌ ‌\nfactor‌ ‌that‌ ‌mould‌ ‌and‌ ‌influence‌ ‌other‌ ‌aspect‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\n●Cultural‌ ‌materialism‌ ‌believes‌ ‌that‌ ‌technology‌ ‌and‌ ‌economy‌ ‌play‌ ‌the‌ ‌primary‌ ‌role‌ ‌in‌ ‌shaping‌ ‌the‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n●Harris‌ ‌tried‌ ‌to‌ ‌create‌ ‌a‌ ‌pan‌ ‌human‌ ‌science‌ ‌of‌ ‌society‌ ‌whose‌ ‌finding‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌accepted‌ ‌on‌ ‌logical‌ ‌and‌ ‌if‌ ‌the‌ ‌density‌ ‌crowned‌ ‌by‌ ‌Pan‌ ‌human‌ ‌\nsociety.‌ ‌\n692‌ ‌\n ‌\n693‌ ‌\n ‌\nHarris‌ ‌response‌ ‌to‌ ‌other‌ ‌theories:‌ ‌\n●Harris‌ ‌criticised‌ ‌the‌ ‌idealistic‌ ‌and‌ ‌realistic‌ ‌perspective‌ ‌which‌ ‌claimed‌ ‌that‌ ‌comparisons‌ ‌between‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌are‌ ‌non‌ ‌productive‌ ‌and‌ ‌irrelevant‌ ‌\nbecause‌ ‌each‌ ‌culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌product‌ ‌of‌ ‌its‌ ‌own‌ ‌dynamic.‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌argued‌ ‌that‌ ‌these‌ ‌approaches‌ ‌remove‌ ‌culture‌ ‌from‌ ‌its‌ ‌material‌ ‌page‌ ‌and‌ ‌plays‌ ‌its‌ ‌only‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌mind‌ ‌of‌ ‌its‌ ‌people.‌ ‌\n●With‌ ‌a‌ ‌strictly‌ ‌emic‌ ‌approach,‌ ‌Harry's‌ ‌stated‌ ‌that‌ ‌idealized‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌fail‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌holistic,‌ ‌violating‌ ‌a‌ ‌basic‌ ‌principle‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropological‌ ‌\nresearch.‌ ‌\n●By‌ ‌focusing‌ ‌on‌ ‌observable‌ ‌measurable‌ ‌phenomenon,‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌materialism‌ ‌present‌ ‌etic‌ ‌perspective‌ ‌of‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n ‌\nACCOMPLISHMENTS‌ ‌\n●Cultural‌ ‌materialism‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌credited‌ ‌with‌ ‌challenging‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌to‌ ‌use‌ ‌more‌ ‌scientific‌ ‌research‌ ‌methods.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Rather‌ ‌than‌ ‌rely‌ ‌solely‌ ‌on‌ ‌native‌ ‌explanations‌ ‌of‌ ‌phenomenon,‌ ‌Harris‌ ‌and‌ ‌others‌ ‌urged‌ ‌analysts‌ ‌to‌ ‌use‌ ‌empirical‌ ‌and‌ ‌replicable‌ ‌methods.‌ ‌\n●Cultural‌ ‌materialism‌ ‌also‌ ‌promoted‌ ‌the‌ ‌notion‌ ‌that‌ ‌culture‌ ‌change‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌studied‌ ‌across‌ ‌geographic‌ ‌and‌ ‌temporal‌ ‌boundaries‌ ‌in‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌get‌ ‌\nat‌ ‌so-called‌ ‌universal,‌ ‌nomothetic‌ ‌theories‌.‌ ‌\n●Archaeologists,‌ ‌too,‌ ‌have‌ ‌adopted‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌materialist‌ ‌approaches.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nCRITICISMS‌ ‌\n●Criticisms‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌materialism‌ ‌are‌ ‌plentiful‌ ‌in‌ ‌anthropology.‌ ‌ ‌\n●As‌ ‌with‌ ‌all‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌different‌ ‌paradigms‌ ‌in‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌(e.g.‌ ‌functionalism,‌ ‌structuralism,‌ ‌and‌ ‌Marxism),‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌materialism‌ ‌does‌ ‌have‌ ‌its‌ ‌\nflaws.‌ ‌ ‌\n694‌ ‌\n●Cultural‌ ‌materialism‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌termed‌ ‌“vulgar‌ ‌materialism”‌ ‌by‌ ‌Marxists‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌J.‌ ‌Friedman‌ ‌because‌ ‌opponents‌ ‌believe‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌\nmaterialists'‌ ‌empirical‌ ‌approach‌ ‌to‌ ‌culture‌ ‌change‌ ‌is‌ ‌too‌ ‌simple‌ ‌and‌ ‌straightforward.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Marxists‌ ‌believe‌ ‌that‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌materialists‌ ‌rely‌ ‌too‌ ‌heavily‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌one-directional‌ ‌infrastructure-superstructure‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌to‌ ‌explain‌ ‌culture‌ ‌\nchange,‌ ‌and‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌“base”‌ ‌(a‌ ‌distinct‌ ‌level‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌sociocultural‌ ‌system,‌ ‌underlying‌ ‌the‌ ‌structure,‌ ‌in‌ ‌Marxist‌ ‌\nterminology)‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌superstructure‌ ‌must‌ ‌be‌ ‌dialectically‌ ‌viewed.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Idealists‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌structuralists‌ ‌(e.g.‌ ‌Durkheim‌ ‌and‌ ‌his‌ ‌followers)‌ ‌argue‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌key‌ ‌to‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌culture‌ ‌change‌ ‌lies‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌emic‌ ‌thoughts‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌behaviors‌ ‌of‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌native‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Thus,‌ ‌in‌ ‌contrast‌ ‌to‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌materialists,‌ ‌they‌ ‌argue‌ ‌that‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌need‌ ‌for‌ ‌an‌ ‌etic/emic‌ ‌distinction.‌ ‌\n●To‌ ‌idealists,‌ ‌the‌ ‌etic‌ ‌view‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌irrelevant‌ ‌and‌ ‌full‌ ‌of‌ ‌ethnocentrism;‌ ‌furthermore,‌ ‌they‌ ‌argue‌ ‌that‌ ‌culture‌ ‌itself‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌controlling‌ ‌factor‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nculture‌ ‌change‌ ‌\n●Postmodernists‌ ‌also‌ ‌argue‌ ‌vehemently‌ ‌against‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌materialism‌ ‌because‌ ‌of‌ ‌its‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌strict‌ ‌scientific‌ ‌method.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n695‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n6.‌ ‌Anthropological‌ ‌theories:(h)‌ ‌Symbolic‌ ‌and‌ ‌interpretive‌ ‌theories‌ ‌(Turner,‌ ‌Schneider‌ ‌and‌ ‌Geertz),‌ ‌(i)‌ ‌Cognitive‌ ‌theories‌ ‌(Tyler,‌ ‌Conklin),‌ ‌\n(j)‌ ‌Postmodernism‌ ‌in‌ ‌anthropology-Part-V‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n(h)‌ ‌Symbolic‌ ‌and‌ ‌interpretive‌ ‌theories‌ ‌(Turner,‌ ‌Schneider‌ ‌and‌ ‌Geertz)‌ ‌\n ‌\nIntroduction:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Symbolic‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌studies‌ ‌the‌ ‌way‌ ‌people‌ ‌understand‌ ‌their‌ ‌surroundings,‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌actions‌ ‌and‌ ‌utterances‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌\ntheir‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌interpretations‌ ‌form‌ ‌a‌ ‌shared‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌meaning–i.e.,‌ ‌understandings‌ ‌shared,‌ ‌to‌ ‌varying‌ ‌degrees,‌ ‌among‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nsame‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Symbolic‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌studies‌ ‌symbols‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌processes,such‌ ‌as‌ ‌myth‌ ‌and‌ ‌ritual,‌ ‌by‌ ‌which‌ ‌humans‌ ‌assign‌ ‌meanings‌ ‌to‌ ‌these‌ ‌symbols‌ ‌to‌ ‌\naddress‌ ‌fundamental‌ ‌questions‌ ‌about‌ ‌human‌ ‌social‌ ‌life.‌ ‌\n●Symbolic‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌views‌ ‌culture‌ ‌as‌ ‌an‌ ‌independent‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌deciphered‌ ‌by‌ ‌interpreting‌ ‌key‌ ‌symbols‌ ‌and‌ ‌rituals.‌ ‌ ‌\n●There‌ ‌are‌ ‌two‌ ‌major‌ ‌premises‌ ‌governing‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌anthropology.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌first‌ ‌is‌ ‌that‌ ‌“beliefs,‌ ‌however‌ ‌unintelligible,‌ ‌become‌ ‌comprehensible‌ ‌when‌ ‌understood‌ ‌as‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌meaning”.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌second‌ ‌major‌ ‌premise‌ ‌is‌ ‌that‌ ‌actions‌ ‌are‌ ‌guided‌ ‌by‌ ‌interpretation,‌ ‌allowing‌ ‌symbolism‌ ‌to‌ ‌aid‌ ‌in‌ ‌interpreting‌ ‌conceptual‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌\nmaterial‌ ‌activities.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Traditionally,‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌‌has‌ ‌focused‌ ‌on‌ ‌religion,‌ ‌cosmology,‌ ‌ritual‌ ‌activity,‌ ‌and‌ ‌expressive‌ ‌customs‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌mythology‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nperforming‌ ‌arts.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Symbolic‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌have‌ ‌also‌ ‌studied‌ ‌other‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌organization‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌and‌ ‌political‌ ‌organization.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Studying‌ ‌these‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌forms‌ ‌allows‌ ‌researchers‌ ‌to‌ ‌study‌ ‌the‌ ‌role‌ ‌of‌ ‌symbols‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌everyday‌ ‌life‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌people.‌ ‌\n●Symbolic‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌was‌ ‌also‌ ‌a‌ ‌reaction‌ ‌against‌ ‌materialism‌ ‌and‌ ‌Marxism.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Materialists‌ ‌define‌ ‌culture‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌observable‌ ‌behavior‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌where‌ ‌“techno‌ ‌environmental‌ ‌factors‌ ‌are‌ ‌primary‌ ‌and‌ ‌causal”.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Symbolic‌ ‌anthropologists,‌ ‌instead,‌ ‌view‌ ‌culture‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌symbols‌ ‌and‌ ‌mental‌ ‌constructs.‌ ‌\n○As‌ ‌implied‌ ‌above,‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌divided‌ ‌into‌ ‌two‌ ‌major‌ ‌approaches.‌ ‌ ‌\n■One‌ ‌is‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌‌Clifford‌ ‌Geertz‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌University‌ ‌of‌ ‌Chicago‌ ‌and‌ ‌ ‌\n696‌ ‌\n■the‌ ‌other‌ ‌with‌ ‌Victor‌ ‌W.‌ ‌Turner‌ ‌at‌ ‌Cornell.‌ ‌ ‌\n■David‌ ‌Schneider‌ ‌was‌ ‌also‌ ‌a‌ ‌major‌ ‌figure‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌anthropology,‌ ‌however‌ ‌he‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌fall‌ ‌entirely‌ ‌\nwithin‌ ‌either‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌above‌ ‌schools‌ ‌of‌ ‌thought.‌ ‌\n ‌\n○The‌ ‌major‌ ‌difference‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌two‌ ‌schools‌ ‌lies‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌respective‌ ‌influences.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Geertz‌ ‌was‌ ‌influenced‌ ‌largely‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌sociologist‌ ‌Max‌ ‌Weber,‌ ‌and‌ ‌was‌ ‌concerned‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌operations‌ ‌of‌ ‌“culture”‌ ‌rather‌ ‌than‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌ways‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌symbols‌ ‌influence‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌process.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Geertz‌ ‌focused‌ ‌much‌ ‌more‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌ways‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌symbols‌ ‌relate‌ ‌to‌ ‌one‌ ‌another‌ ‌within‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌how‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌“see,‌ ‌feel,‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌think‌ ‌about‌ ‌the‌ ‌world”‌ ‌ ‌\n■Turner,‌ ‌influenced‌ ‌by‌ ‌Emile‌ ‌Durkheim,‌ ‌was‌ ‌concerned‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌operations‌ ‌of‌ ‌“society”‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌ways‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌symbols‌ ‌function‌ ‌\nwithin‌ ‌it.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Turner,‌ ‌reflecting‌ ‌his‌ ‌English‌ ‌roots,‌ ‌was‌ ‌much‌ ‌more‌ ‌interested‌ ‌in‌ ‌investigating‌ ‌whether‌ ‌symbols‌ ‌actually‌ ‌functioned‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nsocial‌ ‌process‌ ‌the‌ ‌way‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌believed‌ ‌they‌ ‌did.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nVictor‌ ‌Turner‌ ‌\n ‌\nAbout:‌ ‌Victor‌ ‌Turner‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Victor‌ ‌Witter‌ ‌Turner‌ ‌(1920-1983)‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌major‌ ‌figure‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌branch‌ ‌of‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌anthropology.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Born‌ ‌in‌ ‌Scotland,‌ ‌Turner‌ ‌was‌ ‌influenced‌ ‌early‌ ‌on‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌structural-functionalist‌ ‌approach‌ ‌of‌ ‌British‌ ‌social‌ ‌anthropology.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Turner‌ ‌states‌ ‌that‌ ‌symbols‌ ‌are‌ ‌operators‌ ‌of‌ ‌Social‌ ‌process.‌ ‌\n●Symbols‌ ‌“instigate‌ ‌social‌ ‌action”‌ ‌and‌ ‌exert‌ ‌“determinable‌ ‌influences‌ ‌inclining‌ ‌persons‌ ‌and‌ ‌groups‌ ‌to‌ ‌action”‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Turner‌ ‌felt‌ ‌that‌ ‌these‌ ‌“operators,”‌ ‌by‌ ‌their‌ ‌arrangement‌ ‌and‌ ‌context,‌ ‌produce‌ ‌“social‌ ‌transformations”‌ ‌which‌ ‌tie‌ ‌the‌ ‌people‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌society‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nsociety’s‌ ‌norms,‌ ‌resolve‌ ‌conflict,‌ ‌and‌ ‌aid‌ ‌in‌ ‌changing‌ ‌the‌ ‌status‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌actors‌ ‌ ‌\n697‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌studied‌ ‌connectivity‌ ‌called‌ ‌‌Ud‌ ‌‘Ndembu’‌ ‌in‌ ‌Northwest‌ ‌Zambia.‌ ‌he‌ ‌published‌ ‌a‌ ‌book’‌ ‌the‌ ‌forest‌ ‌of‌ ‌symbol‌ ‌1969.‌ ‌he‌ ‌found‌ ‌the‌ ‌symbol‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nin‌ ‌Ndembu‌ ‌serve‌ ‌following‌ ‌purpose:‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌are‌ ‌helpful‌ ‌in‌ ‌classifying‌ ‌the‌ ‌universe.‌ ‌\n○ ‌A‌ ‌set‌ ‌of‌ ‌cognitive‌ ‌classification‌ ‌for‌ ‌ordering‌ ‌the‌ ‌Ndembu‌ ‌universe.‌ ‌\n○ ‌Symbols‌ ‌are‌ ‌a‌ ‌set‌ ‌of‌ ‌evocative‌ ‌process/‌ ‌devices‌ ‌for‌ ‌fear,‌ ‌hatred‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n○ ‌Symbols‌ ‌Orient‌ ‌action.‌ ‌\n●V‌ ‌Turner‌ ‌concluded‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌symbol‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌grouped‌ ‌around‌ ‌a‌ ‌formative‌ ‌structure.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Formative‌ ‌structure------>‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌among‌ ‌symbols.‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌believes‌ ‌that,‌ ‌the‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌expression‌ ‌of‌ ‌shared‌ ‌meaning,‌ ‌not‌ ‌the‌ ‌attraction‌ ‌of‌ ‌material‌ ‌interest,‌ ‌lie‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌centre‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌relationship.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nClifford‌ ‌Geertz‌ ‌\n ‌\nAbout:Clifford‌ ‌Geertz‌ ‌\n ‌\n698‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Clifford‌ ‌Geertz‌ ‌(1926-2006)‌ ‌studied‌ ‌at‌ ‌Harvard‌ ‌University‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌1950s.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌was‌ ‌strongly‌ ‌influenced‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌writings‌ ‌of‌ ‌philosophers‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌Langer,‌ ‌Ryle,‌ ‌Wittgenstein,‌ ‌Heidegger,‌ ‌and‌ ‌Ricouer,‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌by‌ ‌\nWeber,‌ ‌adopting‌ ‌various‌ ‌aspects‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌thinking‌ ‌as‌ ‌key‌ ‌elements‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌construction‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌interpretive‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌\n ‌\n●In‌ ‌1973‌ ‌Geertz‌ ‌in‌ ‌his‌ ‌book’‌ ‌‌The‌ ‌interpretation‌ ‌culture‌’‌ ‌proposed‌ ‌the‌ ‌idea‌ ‌of‌ ‌symbols‌ ‌in‌ ‌relation‌ ‌to‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌systems.‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌him,‌ ‌man‌ ‌is‌ ‌in‌ ‌need‌ ‌of‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌‘‌ ‌sources‌ ‌of‌ ‌illumination’‌ ‌to‌ ‌silent‌ ‌himself‌ ‌wrt‌ ‌the‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌any‌ ‌particular‌ ‌\nculture.‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌believed‌ ‌that‌ ‌an‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌should‌ ‌not‌ ‌be‌ ‌an‌ ‌experimental‌ ‌science‌ ‌insert‌ ‌of‌ ‌law‌ ‌but‌ ‌an‌ ‌interpretative‌ ‌one‌ ‌in‌ ‌search‌ ‌of‌ ‌meaning.‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌him‌ ‌symbol‌ ‌System‌ ‌Of‌ ‌Culture‌ ‌are‌ ‌sources‌ ‌of‌ ‌information‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌template‌ ‌of‌ ‌explaining‌ ‌behaviour.‌ ‌\n●Symbols‌ ‌provide‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌to‌ ‌human‌ ‌behaviour.‌ ‌Culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌expressed‌ ‌by‌ ‌external‌ ‌symbols‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌used‌ ‌rather‌ ‌than‌ ‌being‌ ‌locked‌ ‌inside‌ ‌\npeople's‌ ‌heads.‌ ‌\n●Societies‌ ‌use‌ ‌symbols‌ ‌to‌ ‌express‌ ‌their‌ ‌worldview,‌ ‌value,‌ ‌orientation,‌ ‌ethos‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌aspects‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌.‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌Geertz‌ ‌symbols‌ ‌are‌ ‌“vehicles‌ ‌of‌ ‌‘culture',‌ ‌and‌ ‌he‌ ‌asserts‌ ‌that‌ ‌symbols‌ ‌should‌ ‌not‌ ‌be‌ ‌studied‌ ‌in‌ ‌and‌ ‌of‌ ‌themselves,‌ ‌but‌ ‌for‌ ‌what‌ ‌they‌ ‌can‌ ‌\nreveal‌ ‌about‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Geertz’s‌ ‌main‌ ‌interest‌ ‌was‌ ‌manner‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌symbols‌ ‌shape‌ ‌the‌ ‌ways‌ ‌that‌ ‌social‌ ‌actors‌ ‌see,‌ ‌feel,‌ ‌and‌ ‌think‌ ‌about‌ ‌the‌ ‌world‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌his‌ ‌scheme‌ ‌culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌understood‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌text,‌ ‌as‌ ‌an‌ ‌anthropologist‌ ‌one‌ ‌has‌ ‌to‌ ‌interrupt‌ ‌these‌ ‌texts.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Because‌ ‌these‌ ‌texts‌ ‌contain‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌and‌ ‌encoding‌ ‌meaning.‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌semiotic.‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌defined‌ ‌culture‌ ‌as‌ ‌“an‌ ‌historically‌ ‌transmitted‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌of‌ ‌meanings‌ ‌embodied‌ ‌in‌ ‌symbols,‌ ‌a‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌inherited‌ ‌conceptions‌ ‌expressed‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nsymbolic‌ ‌forms‌ ‌by‌ ‌means‌ ‌of‌ ‌which‌ ‌men‌ ‌communicate,‌ ‌perpetuate,‌ ‌and‌ ‌develop‌ ‌their‌ ‌knowledge‌ ‌about‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌attitudes‌ ‌toward‌ ‌life”‌ ‌\n○Culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌neither‌ ‌organised‌ ‌or‌ ‌organised‌ ‌but‌ ‌a‌ ‌heap‌ ‌of‌ ‌sand.‌ ‌\n○Culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌neither‌ ‌concrete‌ ‌or‌ ‌abstract,‌ ‌neither‌ ‌like‌ ‌dream‌ ‌nor‌ ‌rock.-‌ ‌but‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌things‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌world‌ ‌that‌ ‌have‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌interpreted‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nin‌ ‌their‌ ‌richness.‌ ‌\n ‌\n699‌ ‌\nThick‌ ‌Description‌ ‌–‌ ‌The‌ ‌Interpretation‌ ‌of‌ ‌Cultures‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌The‌ ‌Interpretation‌ ‌of‌ ‌Cultures,‌ ‌Clifford‌ ‌Geertz‌ ‌outlines‌ ‌in‌ ‌broader‌ ‌sense‌ ‌the‌ ‌job‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌ethnographer.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌ethnographer’s‌ ‌role‌ ‌is‌ ‌to‌ ‌observe‌ ‌and‌ ‌analyse‌ ‌a‌ ‌culture‌ ‌by‌ ‌interpreting‌ ‌signs‌ ‌to‌ ‌understand‌ ‌deeper‌ ‌meanings‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌context‌ ‌of‌ ‌that‌ ‌\nculture.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌asserts‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌essentially‌ ‌semiotic‌ ‌nature‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌has‌ ‌implications‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌sciences‌ ‌in‌ ‌general‌ ‌and‌ ‌political‌ ‌science‌ ‌in‌ ‌particular.‌ ‌ ‌\n●His‌ ‌idea‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌taken‌ ‌from‌ ‌Kluckhohn,‌ ‌where‌ ‌he‌ ‌feels‌ ‌culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌\n ‌\n1)‌ ‌“the‌ ‌total‌ ‌way‌ ‌of‌ ‌life‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌people”;‌ ‌\n ‌\n2)‌ ‌“the‌ ‌social‌ ‌legacy‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual‌ ‌acquires‌ ‌from‌ ‌his‌ ‌group”;‌ ‌\n ‌\n3)‌ ‌“a‌ ‌way‌ ‌of‌ ‌thinking,‌ ‌feeling,‌ ‌and‌ ‌believing”;‌ ‌\n ‌\n700‌ ‌\n4)‌ ‌“an‌ ‌abstraction‌ ‌from‌ ‌behaviour”;‌ ‌\n ‌\n5)‌ ‌“a‌ ‌theory‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌anthropologist‌ ‌about‌ ‌the‌ ‌way‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌people‌ ‌in‌ ‌fact‌ ‌behave”;‌ ‌\n ‌\n6)‌ ‌“a‌ ‌storehouse‌ ‌of‌ ‌pooled‌ ‌learning”;‌ ‌\n ‌\n7)‌ ‌“a‌ ‌set‌ ‌of‌ ‌standardized‌ ‌orientations‌ ‌to‌ ‌recurrent‌ ‌problems”;‌ ‌\n ‌\n8)‌ ‌“learned‌ ‌behaviour”;‌ ‌\n ‌\n9)‌ ‌“a‌ ‌mechanism‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌normative‌ ‌regulation‌ ‌of‌ ‌behaviour”;‌ ‌\n ‌\n10)‌ ‌“a‌ ‌set‌ ‌of‌ ‌techniques‌ ‌for‌ ‌adjusting‌ ‌both‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌external‌ ‌environment‌ ‌and‌ ‌to‌ ‌other‌ ‌men”;‌ ‌\n ‌\n11)‌ ‌“a‌ ‌precipitate‌ ‌of‌ ‌history”;‌ ‌\n ‌\n12)‌ ‌a‌ ‌behavioural‌ ‌map,‌ ‌sieve,‌ ‌or‌ ‌matrix.‌ ‌\n ‌\nGeertz‌ ‌prescribes‌ ‌interpreting‌ ‌a‌ ‌culture’s‌ ‌web‌ ‌of‌ ‌symbols‌ ‌by‌ ‌\n ‌\n1.‌ ‌Isolating‌ ‌its‌ ‌elements,‌ ‌\n ‌\n2.‌ ‌Specifying‌ ‌the‌ ‌internal‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌among‌ ‌those‌ ‌elements‌ ‌and,‌ ‌\n ‌\n3.‌ ‌characterize‌ ‌the‌ ‌whole‌ ‌system‌ ‌in‌ ‌some‌ ‌general‌ ‌way—according‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌core‌ ‌symbols‌ ‌around‌ ‌which‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌organized,‌ ‌the‌ ‌underlying‌ ‌structures‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nwhich‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌surface‌ ‌expression,‌ ‌or‌ ‌the‌ ‌ideological‌ ‌principles‌ ‌upon‌ ‌which‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌based.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌Geertz’s,‌ ‌ethnography‌ ‌is‌ ‌by‌ ‌definition‌ ‌“thick‌ ‌description”—“an‌ ‌elaborate‌ ‌venture‌ ‌in.”‌ ‌ ‌\n●By‌ ‌example‌ ‌of‌ ‌“winking,”‌ ‌Geertz‌ ‌observes‌ ‌how—in‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌differentiate‌ ‌the‌ ‌winking‌ ‌from‌ ‌a‌ ‌social‌ ‌gesture,‌ ‌a‌ ‌twitch,‌ ‌etc.—we‌ ‌must‌ ‌carefully‌ ‌\nanalyse‌ ‌the‌ ‌action‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌both‌ ‌the‌ ‌particular‌ ‌social‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌“winking”‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌gesture,‌ ‌the‌ ‌real‌ ‌intention‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌winker,‌ ‌and‌ ‌how‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌the‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌winking‌ ‌action‌ ‌itself‌ ‌is‌ ‌interpreted.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Symbols‌ ‌and‌ ‌interpretation:‌ ‌\n○Examples‌ ‌of‌ ‌tribals‌ ‌of‌ ‌Southeast‌ ‌Asia:‌ ‌representing‌ ‌symbols‌ ‌play‌ ‌an‌ ‌important‌ ‌role‌ ‌in‌ ‌interpreting‌ ‌an‌ ‌actual‌ ‌meaning.‌ ‌\n701‌ ‌\n■Cock‌ ‌fight‌ ‌in‌ ‌Bali:‌ ‌ ‌it‌ ‌conveys‌ ‌the‌ ‌message‌ ‌like,‌ ‌Status,‌ ‌rivalry,‌ ‌obsessive‌ ‌consumption‌ ‌of‌ ‌power‌ ‌and‌ ‌narcissism.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nCock‌ ‌fight‌ ‌in‌ ‌Bali:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●\"Deep‌ ‌Play:‌ ‌Notes‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌Balinese‌ ‌Cockfight\"‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌essay‌ ‌included‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌book‌ ‌The‌ ‌Interpretation‌ ‌of‌ ‌Cultures,‌ ‌written‌ ‌\nby‌ ‌anthropologist‌ ‌Clifford‌ ‌Geertz.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌essay,‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌considered‌ ‌Geertz's‌ ‌most‌ ‌seminal‌ ‌work,‌ ‌addresses‌ ‌the‌ ‌symbolism‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌dynamics‌ ‌of‌ ‌\ncockfighting‌ ‌(sabungan)‌ ‌in‌ ‌Balinese‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌important‌ ‌example‌ ‌of‌ ‌Geertz's‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌\"‌thick‌ ‌description‌\"‌ ‌as‌ ‌an‌ ‌anthropological‌ ‌approach.‌ ‌\n○\"‌Thick‌ ‌description‌\"‌ ‌\n■In‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌sciences‌ ‌and‌ ‌related‌ ‌fields,‌ ‌a‌ ‌thick‌ ‌description‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌description‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌social‌ ‌action‌ ‌\nthat‌ ‌describes‌ ‌not‌ ‌just‌ ‌physical‌ ‌behaviors,‌ ‌but‌ ‌their‌ ‌context‌ ‌as‌ ‌interpreted‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌actors‌ ‌as‌ ‌well,‌ ‌so‌ ‌\nthat‌ ‌it‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌better‌ ‌understood‌ ‌by‌ ‌an‌ ‌outsider.‌ ‌ ‌\n■A‌ ‌thick‌ ‌description‌ ‌typically‌ ‌adds‌ ‌a‌ ‌record‌ ‌of‌ ‌subjective‌ ‌explanations‌ ‌and‌ ‌meanings‌ ‌provided‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌\npeople‌ ‌engaged‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌behaviors,‌ ‌making‌ ‌the‌ ‌collected‌ ‌data‌ ‌of‌ ‌greater‌ ‌value‌ ‌for‌ ‌studies‌ ‌by‌ ‌other‌ ‌\nsocial‌ ‌scientists.‌ ‌\n●Culture‌ ‌of‌ ‌cockfights‌ ‌\n○Example‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌cockfight‌ ‌in‌ ‌Bali‌ ‌circa‌ ‌1958.‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌\"Of‌ ‌Cocks‌ ‌and‌ ‌Men,\"‌ ‌the‌ ‌second‌ ‌section,‌ ‌the‌ ‌essay‌ ‌describes‌ ‌how‌ ‌cocks‌ ‌are‌ ‌taken‌ ‌to‌ ‌stand‌ ‌in‌ ‌for‌ ‌\npowerful‌ ‌men‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌villages.‌ ‌ ‌\n○He‌ ‌notes‌ ‌that‌ ‌even‌ ‌the‌ ‌double-entendre‌ ‌sense‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌word‌ ‌\"cock\"‌ ‌(\"Sabung,\"‌ ‌which‌ ‌also‌ ‌means‌ ‌\"hero,\"‌ ‌\"man‌ ‌\nparts,\"‌ ‌and‌ ‌\"champion\")‌ ‌exists‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Balinese‌ ‌language‌ ‌as‌ ‌much‌ ‌as‌ ‌in‌ ‌English.‌ ‌ ‌\n○He‌ ‌also‌ ‌wrote‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌intimate‌ ‌connection‌ ‌that‌ ‌many‌ ‌Balinese‌ ‌men‌ ‌have‌ ‌with‌ ‌their‌ ‌cocks,‌ ‌which‌ ‌includes‌ ‌\ngrooming‌ ‌them,‌ ‌feeding‌ ‌them,‌ ‌observing‌ ‌them,‌ ‌and‌ ‌discussing‌ ‌them‌ ‌amongst‌ ‌each‌ ‌other.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Geertz‌ ‌wrote,‌ ‌\"cocks‌ ‌are‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌expressions‌ ‌or‌ ‌magnifications‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌owner's‌ ‌self,‌ ‌the‌ ‌narcissistic‌ ‌male‌ ‌\nego,‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌also‌ ‌expressions--and‌ ‌rather‌ ‌more‌ ‌immediate‌ ‌ones--of‌ ‌what‌ ‌the‌ ‌Balinese‌ ‌regard‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌direct‌ ‌\ninversion,‌ ‌aesthetically,‌ ‌morally,‌ ‌and‌ ‌metaphysically,‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌status:‌ ‌animality.\"‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌\"The‌ ‌Fight,\"‌ ‌the‌ ‌third‌ ‌section,‌ ‌the‌ ‌essay‌ ‌describes‌ ‌how‌ ‌cocks‌ ‌are‌ ‌sheltered‌ ‌and‌ ‌fed‌ ‌in‌ ‌preparation‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nmatches,‌ ‌followed‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌description‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌matches‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌rules.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌last‌ ‌half‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌essay‌ ‌describes‌ ‌the‌ ‌rituals‌ ‌of‌ ‌betting‌ ‌(toh).‌ ‌\n○He‌ ‌concludes‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌cockfight‌ ‌serves‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌Balinese‌ ‌commentary‌ ‌on‌ ‌themselves,‌ ‌as‌ ‌it‌ ‌embodies‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nnetwork‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌in‌ ‌kin‌ ‌and‌ ‌village‌ ‌that‌ ‌govern‌ ‌traditional‌ ‌Balinese‌ ‌life.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌title‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌essay‌ ‌is‌ ‌explained‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌British‌ ‌philosopher‌ ‌Jeremy‌ ‌Bentham,‌ ‌who‌ ‌defines‌ ‌\"deep‌ ‌play\"‌ ‌as‌ ‌\na‌ ‌game‌ ‌with‌ ‌stakes‌ ‌so‌ ‌high‌ ‌that‌ ‌no‌ ‌rational‌ ‌person‌ ‌would‌ ‌engage‌ ‌in‌ ‌it.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌amounts‌ ‌of‌ ‌money‌ ‌and‌ ‌status‌ ‌involved‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌very‌ ‌brief‌ ‌cockfights‌ ‌make‌ ‌Balinese‌ ‌cockfighting‌ ‌\"deep‌ ‌play.\"‌ ‌The‌ ‌\nproblem‌ ‌of‌ ‌explaining‌ ‌why‌ ‌the‌ ‌activity‌ ‌prevails‌ ‌is‌ ‌what‌ ‌Geertz‌ ‌sets‌ ‌out‌ ‌to‌ ‌solve‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌essay.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n702‌ ‌\n■Puppet‌ ‌show‌ ‌in‌ ‌Java:‌‌ ‌The‌ ‌society‌ ‌is‌ ‌very‌ ‌tranquil,‌ ‌the‌ ‌puput‌ ‌show‌ ‌conveys‌ ‌this‌ ‌tranquility‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌situation.‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌dramatic‌ ‌stories‌ ‌depict‌ ‌mythologies,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌episodes‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌Hindu‌ ‌epics‌ ‌the‌ ‌Ramayana‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌Mahabharata,‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌\nas‌ ‌local‌ ‌adaptations‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌legends.‌ ‌\n●Geertz‌ ‌gives‌ ‌useful‌ ‌insight‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌Indonesian‌ ‌shadow-puppet‌ ‌play‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌deeply‌ ‌rooted‌ ‌art‌ ‌form‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌religious‌ ‌\nrite.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌makes‌ ‌direct‌ ‌comparison‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌characters‌ ‌of‌ ‌Semar‌ ‌and‌ ‌Falstaff.‌ ‌In‌ ‌his‌ ‌section‌ ‌on‌ ‌“Ritual‌ ‌and‌ ‌Social‌ ‌\nChange:‌ ‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌Javanese‌ ‌Example‌,”‌ ‌Geertz‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌B.‌ ‌Malinowski’s‌ ‌Magic,‌ ‌Science‌ ‌and‌ ‌Religion‌ ‌(1948)‌ ‌on‌ ‌how‌ ‌religion‌ ‌satisfies‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌individual’s‌ ‌demand‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌stable,‌ ‌comprehensible,‌ ‌and‌ ‌coercible‌ ‌world.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌wayang‌ ‌kulit‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌applied‌ ‌to‌ ‌promote‌ ‌stability‌ ‌through‌ ‌education,‌ ‌faith,‌ ‌and‌ ‌government‌ ‌control.‌ ‌\nTurner‌ ‌vs‌ ‌Geertz‌ ‌\n●Geertz‌ ‌Position‌ ‌illustrates‌ ‌the‌ ‌interpretative‌ ‌approach‌ ‌to‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌anthropology,‌ ‌While‌ ‌Turner‌ ‌illustrates‌ ‌the‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌approach.‌ ‌\n●Geertz‌ ‌was‌ ‌influenced‌ ‌largely‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌sociologist‌ ‌Max‌ ‌Weber‌ ‌and‌ ‌concerned‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌operation‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌rather‌ ‌than‌ ‌the‌ ‌way‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌symbol‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌rate‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌process.‌ ‌\n●Turner‌ ‌was‌ ‌influenced‌ ‌by‌ ‌Emile‌ ‌durkheim,‌ ‌Turner‌ ‌was‌ ‌not‌ ‌interested‌ ‌in‌ ‌symbols‌ ‌as‌ ‌vehicles‌ ‌of‌ ‌“culture”,‌ ‌rather‌ ‌he‌ ‌instead‌ ‌investigated‌ ‌\nsymbols‌ ‌as‌ ‌“operators‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌process”‌ ‌\n●Turner,‌ ‌reflecting‌ ‌the‌ ‌English‌ ‌roots,‌ ‌was‌ ‌much‌ ‌more‌ ‌interested‌ ‌in‌ ‌investigating‌ ‌whether‌ ‌symbols‌ ‌actually‌ ‌function‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌process,‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌way‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌believe‌ ‌they‌ ‌did.‌ ‌\n●Geertz‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌way‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌symbols‌ ‌operate‌ ‌within‌ ‌culture‌ ‌like‌ ‌how‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌see,‌ ‌feel‌ ‌and‌ ‌think‌ ‌about‌ ‌the‌ ‌World.‌ ‌\n●Turner‌ ‌was‌ ‌not‌ ‌interested‌ ‌in‌ ‌symbols‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌vehicle‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌as‌ ‌Geertz‌ ‌was‌ ‌but‌ ‌instead‌ ‌investigated‌ ‌symbols‌ ‌as‌ ‌operators‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌\nprocesses‌ ‌believing‌ ‌that‌ ‌symbols'‌ ‌expression‌ ‌of‌ ‌shared‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌lie‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌centre‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌relationship.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nDavid‌ ‌Schneider‌ ‌\n ‌\nAbout:David‌ ‌Schneider‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●David‌ ‌Schneider‌ ‌(1918-1995)‌ ‌was‌ ‌another‌ ‌important‌ ‌figure‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌“Chicago‌ ‌school”‌ ‌of‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌anthropology.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌did‌ ‌not‌ ‌make‌ ‌the‌ ‌complete‌ ‌break‌ ‌from‌ ‌structuralism‌ ‌that‌ ‌had‌ ‌been‌ ‌made‌ ‌by‌ ‌Geertz‌ ‌and‌ ‌Turner,‌ ‌rather‌ ‌he‌ ‌retained‌ ‌and‌ ‌modified‌ ‌\nLevi-Strauss’‌ ‌idea‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌set‌ ‌of‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n●In‌ ‌his‌ ‌book‌ ‌‘‌American‌ ‌kinship-‌ ‌structural‌ ‌account’‌ ‌‌(1968),‌ ‌Schneider‌ ‌argued‌ ‌that‌ ‌for‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌the‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌system,‌ ‌one‌ ‌has‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nunderstand‌ ‌the‌ ‌symbols‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌it.‌ ‌\n●Schneider‌ ‌differed‌ ‌from‌ ‌Geertz‌ ‌by‌ ‌detaching‌ ‌culture‌ ‌from‌ ‌everyday‌ ‌life.‌ ‌He‌ ‌defined‌ ‌a‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌system‌ ‌as‌ ‌“a‌ ‌series‌ ‌of‌ ‌symbols”‌ ‌where‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nsymbol‌ ‌is‌ ‌“something‌ ‌which‌ ‌stands‌ ‌for‌ ‌something‌ ‌else‌ ‌ ‌\n703‌ ‌\n● ‌According‌ ‌to‌ ‌him,‌ ‌culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌defined‌ ‌as‌ ‌shared‌ ‌symbols‌ ‌and‌ ‌meaning.‌ ‌\n● ‌culture‌ ‌comprises‌ ‌domain,‌ ‌every‌ ‌domain‌ ‌has‌ ‌its‌ ‌own‌ ‌symbol.‌ ‌\n● ‌these‌ ‌symbols‌ ‌serve‌ ‌important‌ ‌purpose:‌ ‌\n○Identify‌ ‌the‌ ‌units.‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌defines‌ ‌the‌ ‌unit‌ ‌that‌ ‌makes‌ ‌them‌ ‌meaningful.‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌distinguish‌ ‌them‌ ‌from‌ ‌other‌ ‌domain‌ ‌unit‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌relates‌ ‌one‌ ‌with‌ ‌another.‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌Schneider,‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌aspects‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌as‌ ‌relevant‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌actual‌ ‌aspect‌ ‌of‌ ‌it.‌ ‌\n●Culture‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌studied‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌levels:‌ ‌\n○Empirical‌ ‌level-‌‌ ‌no‌ ‌relevance‌ ‌to‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌analyzed.‌ ‌\n○Normative‌ ‌order-‌‌ ‌deals‌ ‌with‌ ‌rules‌ ‌and‌ ‌norms‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌of‌ ‌individuals.‌ ‌\n○Symbolic‌ ‌order-‌‌ ‌refer‌ ‌to‌ ‌symbols‌ ‌values‌ ‌the‌ ‌cosmological‌ ‌associated.‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌argued‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌lower‌ ‌two‌ ‌orders‌ ‌interact‌ ‌with‌ ‌each‌ ‌other.‌ ‌The‌ ‌normative‌ ‌order‌ ‌is‌ ‌ego‌ ‌focused‌ ‌and‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌order‌ ‌is‌ ‌system‌ ‌centric‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nsymbols‌ ‌provide‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌to‌ ‌normative‌ ‌order.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nMETHODOLOGIES‌ ‌\n●Like‌ ‌many‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌anthropology,‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌is‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌cross-cultural‌ ‌comparison.‌ ‌ ‌\n●One‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌major‌ ‌changes‌ ‌made‌ ‌by‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌movement‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌literary-based‌ ‌rather‌ ‌than‌ ‌a‌ ‌science-based‌ ‌approach.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Symbolic‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌focuses‌ ‌largely‌ ‌on‌ ‌culture‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌whole‌ ‌rather‌ ‌than‌ ‌on‌ ‌specific‌ ‌aspects‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌isolated‌ ‌from‌ ‌one‌ ‌another.‌ ‌\n ‌\nACCOMPLISHMENTS‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌major‌ ‌accomplishment‌ ‌of‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌to‌ ‌turn‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌towards‌ ‌issues‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌interpretation‌ ‌rather‌ ‌than‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌grand‌ ‌theories.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Geertz,‌ ‌through‌ ‌his‌ ‌references‌ ‌to‌ ‌social‌ ‌scientists‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌Ricouer‌ ‌and‌ ‌Wittgenstein,‌ ‌became‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌often‌ ‌cited‌ ‌anthropologist‌ ‌by‌ ‌other‌ ‌\ndisciplines.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌similar‌ ‌citations‌ ‌by‌ ‌Schneider,‌ ‌Turner,‌ ‌and‌ ‌others‌ ‌helped‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌turn‌ ‌to‌ ‌sources‌ ‌outside‌ ‌the‌ ‌bounds‌ ‌of‌ ‌traditional‌ ‌\nanthropology,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌philosophy‌ ‌and‌ ‌sociology.‌ ‌\n●Geertz’s‌ ‌main‌ ‌contribution‌ ‌to‌ ‌anthropological‌ ‌knowledge,‌ ‌however,‌ ‌was‌ ‌in‌ ‌changing‌ ‌the‌ ‌ways‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌American‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌viewed‌ ‌\nculture,‌ ‌shifting‌ ‌the‌ ‌concern‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌operations‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌way‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌symbols‌ ‌act‌ ‌as‌ ‌vehicles‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Another‌ ‌contribution‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌reinforcement‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌importance‌ ‌of‌ ‌studying‌ ‌culture‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌perspective‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌actors‌ ‌who‌ ‌are‌ ‌guided‌ ‌by‌ ‌that‌ ‌\nculture.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Turner’s‌ ‌major‌ ‌contribution‌ ‌to‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌was‌ ‌‌the‌ ‌investigation‌ ‌of‌ ‌how‌ ‌symbols‌ ‌actually‌ ‌do‌ ‌social‌ ‌‘work’,‌ ‌whether‌ ‌or‌ ‌not‌ ‌they‌ ‌function‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nways‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌say‌ ‌they‌ ‌do.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌was‌ ‌an‌ ‌aspect‌ ‌of‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌that‌ ‌Geertz‌ ‌and‌ ‌Schneider‌ ‌never‌ ‌addressed‌ ‌in‌ ‌any‌ ‌great‌ ‌detail.‌ ‌This‌ ‌reflects‌ ‌Turner’s‌ ‌\nembeddedness‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌traditions‌ ‌of‌ ‌British‌ ‌social‌ ‌anthropology.‌ ‌\n704‌ ‌\n ‌\nCRITICISMS‌ ‌\n●Symbolic‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌has‌ ‌come‌ ‌under‌ ‌fire‌ ‌along‌ ‌several‌ ‌fronts,‌ ‌most‌ ‌notably‌ ‌from‌ ‌Marxists.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌an‌ ‌important‌ ‌critique‌ ‌of‌ ‌Geertz’s‌ ‌views‌ ‌on‌ ‌religion,‌ ‌Talal‌ ‌Asad‌ ‌(1983)‌ ‌attacks‌ ‌the‌ ‌dualism‌ ‌evident‌ ‌in‌ ‌Geertz’s‌ ‌arguments.‌ ‌ ‌\n●While‌ ‌acknowledging‌ ‌Geertz’s‌ ‌strengths,‌ ‌Asad‌ ‌argues‌ ‌that‌ ‌Geertz’s‌ ‌weakness‌ ‌lies‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌disjunction‌ ‌between‌ ‌external‌ ‌symbols‌ ‌and‌ ‌internal‌ ‌\ndispositions,‌ ‌corresponding‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌gap‌ ‌between‌ ‌“cultural‌ ‌system”‌ ‌and‌ ‌“social‌ ‌reality”,‌ ‌when‌ ‌attempting‌ ‌to‌ ‌define‌ ‌the‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌religion‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nuniversal‌ ‌terms.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌addition,‌ ‌Marxists‌ ‌charge‌ ‌that‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌anthropology,‌ ‌while‌ ‌describing‌ ‌social‌ ‌conduct‌ ‌and‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌systems,‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌attempt‌ ‌to‌ ‌explain‌ ‌\nthese‌ ‌systems,‌ ‌instead‌ ‌focusing‌ ‌too‌ ‌much‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual‌ ‌symbols‌ ‌themselves.‌ ‌\n●Another‌ ‌attack‌ ‌on‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌came‌ ‌from‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌ecology.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Cultural‌ ‌ecologists‌ ‌considered‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌“fuzzy‌ ‌headed‌ ‌mentalists,‌ ‌involved‌ ‌in‌ ‌unscientific‌ ‌and‌ ‌unverifiable‌ ‌\nflights‌ ‌of‌ ‌subjective‌
