‌interpretation”.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌other‌ ‌words,‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌did‌ ‌not‌ ‌attempt‌ ‌to‌ ‌carry‌ ‌out‌ ‌their‌ ‌research‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌manner‌ ‌so‌ ‌that‌ ‌other‌ ‌researchers‌ ‌could‌ ‌\nreproduce‌ ‌their‌ ‌results.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Mental‌ ‌phenomenon‌ ‌and‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌interpretation,‌ ‌they‌ ‌argued,‌ ‌was‌ ‌scientifically‌ ‌untestable.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Also,‌ ‌since‌ ‌different‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌could‌ ‌view‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌symbol‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌ways,‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌attacked‌ ‌as‌ ‌being‌ ‌too‌ ‌subjective.‌ ‌\n●Symbolic‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌answered‌ ‌the‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌ecologists‌ ‌by‌ ‌asserting‌ ‌that‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌ecology‌ ‌was‌ ‌too‌ ‌scientific.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Cultural‌ ‌ecologists‌ ‌ignored‌ ‌the‌ ‌fact‌ ‌that‌ ‌culture‌ ‌dominates‌ ‌all‌ ‌human‌ ‌behavior,‌ ‌thus‌ ‌they‌ ‌had‌ ‌lost‌ ‌sight‌ ‌of‌ ‌what‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌had‌ ‌established‌ ‌\npreviously.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n(i)‌ ‌Cognitive‌ ‌theories‌ ‌(Tyler,‌ ‌Conklin)‌ ‌\n●Cognitive‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌addresses‌ ‌the‌ ‌ways‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌people‌ ‌conceive‌ ‌of‌ ‌and‌ ‌think‌ ‌about‌ ‌events‌ ‌and‌ ‌objects‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌world.‌ ‌It‌ ‌provides‌ ‌a‌ ‌link‌ ‌\nbetween‌ ‌human‌ ‌thought‌ ‌processes‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌physical‌ ‌and‌ ‌ideational‌ ‌aspects‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌1950‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌US‌ ‌realised‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌manner‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌conducting‌ ‌ethnography‌ ‌was‌ ‌unproductive‌ ‌and‌ ‌futile,‌ ‌\nthere‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌standard‌ ‌way‌ ‌and‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌be‌ ‌compared‌ ‌with‌ ‌others.‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌argue‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌using‌ ‌Western‌ ‌concepts‌ ‌to‌ ‌understand‌ ‌the‌ ‌indigenous‌ ‌people,‌ ‌instead‌ ‌the‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌should‌ ‌pursue‌ ‌culture‌ ‌reality‌ ‌\nas‌ ‌perceived‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌local‌ ‌community‌ ‌to‌ ‌understand‌ ‌the‌ ‌reality.‌ ‌\n●Thus,‌ ‌theories‌ ‌are‌ ‌called‌ ‌ethnoscience,‌ ‌or‌ ‌cognitive‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌and‌ ‌cognitive‌ ‌sociology‌ ‌&‌ ‌ethnosemantics.‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌principle‌ ‌the‌ ‌bargain‌ ‌with‌ ‌local‌ ‌classification‌ ‌popularly‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌folk‌ ‌classification,‌ ‌by‌ ‌studying‌ ‌these‌ ‌they‌ ‌developed‌ ‌theories.‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌them,‌ ‌culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌set‌ ‌of‌ ‌mental‌ ‌models.‌ ‌these‌ ‌mod‌ ‌in‌ ‌and‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌need‌ ‌to‌ ‌understand‌ ‌these‌ ‌cognitive‌ ‌models.‌ ‌\n●Every‌ ‌culture‌ ‌has‌ ‌an‌ ‌invalid‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌logic‌ ‌and‌ ‌therefore‌ ‌every‌ ‌culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌logical‌ ‌mathematical‌ ‌model‌ ‌and‌ ‌discovery‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌\nmodel‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌important‌ ‌task‌ ‌of‌ ‌cognitive‌ ‌anthropologists.‌ ‌\n● ‌One‌ ‌branch‌ ‌of‌ ‌cognitive‌ ‌theory‌ ‌is‌ ‌Neo‌ ‌ethnography.‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌process‌ ‌is‌ ‌to‌ ‌understand‌ ‌new‌ ‌models‌ ‌using‌ ‌local‌ ‌emic‌ ‌categories.‌ ‌\n705‌ ‌\n●Kenneth‌ ‌Pike,‌ ‌studied‌ ‌how‌ ‌phonographic‌ ‌reveals‌ ‌that‌ ‌some‌ ‌words‌ ‌and‌ ‌contrasts‌ ‌with‌ ‌one‌ ‌another‌ ‌with‌ ‌slight‌ ‌differences‌ ‌in‌ ‌sound‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nphonetics‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌contrast.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌new‌ ‌ethnography‌ ‌developed‌ ‌a‌ ‌scientific‌ ‌and‌ ‌rigorous‌ ‌method‌ ‌of‌ ‌Data‌ ‌Collection‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌metaphysics‌ ‌and‌ ‌narratives.‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌also‌ ‌relied‌ ‌on‌ ‌highly‌ ‌structured‌ ‌interviews‌ ‌to‌ ‌find‌ ‌what‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌domains‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌that‌ ‌become‌ ‌their‌ ‌area‌ ‌of‌ ‌analysis.‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌believed‌ ‌this‌ ‌method‌ ‌led‌ ‌to‌ ‌scientific‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌of‌ ‌facts.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌has‌ ‌adopted‌ ‌some‌ ‌theoretical‌ ‌elements‌ ‌and‌ ‌methodological‌ ‌technique‌ ‌from‌ ‌structuralism‌ ‌and‌ ‌linguistics.‌ ‌\n●Not‌ ‌concerned‌ ‌with‌ ‌describing‌ ‌events‌ ‌in‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌explain‌ ‌or‌ ‌Discover‌ ‌the‌ ‌process‌ ‌of‌ ‌change.‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌emphasize‌ ‌rule‌ ‌of‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌not‌ ‌the‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌of‌ ‌rules.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌closely‌ ‌aligned‌ ‌with‌ ‌psychology‌ ‌because‌ ‌both‌ ‌explore‌ ‌the‌ ‌nature‌ ‌of‌ ‌cognitive‌ ‌process.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nCriticism‌ ‌of‌ ‌new‌ ‌Ethnography‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌so-called‌ ‌“new‌ ‌ethnography”‌ ‌was‌ ‌unable‌ ‌to‌ ‌move‌ ‌beyond‌ ‌the‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌of‌ ‌artificially‌ ‌simplified‌ ‌and‌ ‌often‌ ‌trivial‌ ‌semantic‌ ‌domains.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Ethnoscientists‌ ‌tended‌ ‌to‌ ‌study‌ ‌such‌ ‌things‌ ‌as‌ ‌color‌ ‌categories‌ ‌and‌ ‌folk‌ ‌taxonomies,‌ ‌without‌ ‌being‌ ‌able‌ ‌to‌ ‌elucidate‌ ‌their‌ ‌relevance‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nunderstanding‌ ‌culture‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌whole.‌ ‌\n●Critics‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌opinion‌ ‌that‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌nothing‌ ‌new‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌new‌ ‌economy‌ ‌graphy.‌ ‌example‌ ‌in‌ ‌his‌ ‌work‌ ‌has‌ ‌always‌ ‌captured‌ ‌the‌ ‌local‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌\nthrough‌ ‌emic‌ ‌categories.‌ ‌\n●Discovery‌ ‌of‌ ‌such‌ ‌a‌ ‌logico‌ ‌model‌ ‌may‌ ‌not‌ ‌be‌ ‌very‌ ‌useful‌ ‌because‌ ‌it‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌lead‌ ‌anywhere.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌might‌ ‌be‌ ‌loaded‌ ‌with‌ ‌fragmented‌ ‌analysis.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nStephan‌ ‌A‌ ‌Tyler‌ ‌\n●We‌ ‌argue‌ ‌that‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌cognitive‌ ‌universal‌ ‌processes‌ ‌that‌ ‌reflect‌ ‌in‌ ‌inner‌ ‌structure‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌human‌ ‌brain‌ ‌like‌ ‌cognitive‌ ‌structure.‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌cognitive‌ ‌structures‌ ‌are‌ ‌responsible‌ ‌for‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌abstract‌ ‌thinking‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌and‌ ‌symbols.‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌comparative‌ ‌standing‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌processes‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌need‌ ‌of‌ ‌discipline.‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌Tyler,‌ ‌culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌mental‌ ‌model‌ ‌it‌ ‌has‌ ‌ruled‌ ‌by‌ ‌which‌ ‌things‌ ‌are‌ ‌categorised.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌believed‌ ‌that‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌should‌ ‌be‌ ‌more‌ ‌like‌ ‌philosophy‌ ‌for‌ ‌mathematics‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌sense‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌should‌ ‌search‌ ‌for‌ ‌logical‌ ‌models.‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌came‌ ‌up‌ ‌with‌ ‌two‌ ‌concepts‌ ‌\n○Schema-‌ ‌\n■A‌ ‌schema‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌“organizing‌ ‌experience,”‌ ‌implying‌ ‌activation‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌whole.‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌mental‌ ‌prototype,‌ ‌which‌ ‌individual‌ ‌developed‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌priority‌ ‌experience.‌ ‌\n■An‌ ‌example‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌English‌ ‌term‌ ‌writing.‌ ‌When‌ ‌one‌ ‌thinks‌ ‌of‌ ‌writing,‌ ‌several‌ ‌aspects‌ ‌come‌ ‌into‌ ‌play‌ ‌that‌ ‌can‌ ‌denote‌ ‌the‌ ‌action‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌guiding‌ ‌a‌ ‌trace‌ ‌leaving‌ ‌implementation‌ ‌across‌ ‌a‌ ‌surface,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌writer,‌ ‌implement,‌ ‌surface,‌ ‌and‌ ‌so‌ ‌on.‌ ‌ ‌\n■While‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌schemas‌ ‌may‌ ‌differ,‌ ‌cognitive‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌search‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌common‌ ‌notions‌ ‌that‌ ‌can‌ ‌provide‌ ‌keys‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nmental‌ ‌structures‌ ‌behind‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌notions.‌ ‌ ‌\n706‌ ‌\n■These‌ ‌notions‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌necessarily‌ ‌culturally‌ ‌universal.‌ ‌In‌ ‌Japanese,‌ ‌the‌ ‌term‌ ‌kaku‌ ‌is‌ ‌usually‌ ‌translated‌ ‌into‌ ‌English‌ ‌as‌ ‌writing.‌ ‌ ‌\n■However,‌ ‌‌whereas‌ ‌in‌ ‌English,‌ ‌nearly‌ ‌everyone‌ ‌would‌ ‌consider‌ ‌writing‌ ‌to‌ ‌imply‌ ‌that‌ ‌language‌ ‌is‌ ‌being‌ ‌traced‌ ‌onto‌ ‌a‌ ‌surface,‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌term‌ ‌kaku‌ ‌in‌ ‌Japanese‌ ‌can‌ ‌mean‌ ‌language,‌ ‌doodles,‌ ‌pictures,‌ ‌or‌ ‌anything‌ ‌else‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌traced‌ ‌onto‌ ‌a‌ ‌surface.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Therefore,‌ ‌schemas‌ ‌are‌ ‌culturally‌ ‌specific,‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌need‌ ‌for‌ ‌an‌ ‌emic‌ ‌view‌ ‌is‌ ‌still‌ ‌a‌ ‌primary‌ ‌force‌ ‌in‌ ‌any‌ ‌ethnographic‌ ‌research‌ ‌\n○Connectivism‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌is‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌explain‌ ‌not‌ ‌sequentially‌ ‌what‌ ‌process‌ ‌without‌ ‌involving‌ ‌linguistic‌ ‌categories.‌ ‌\n■Connectivism‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌follow‌ ‌and‌ ‌rely‌ ‌on‌ ‌linguistic‌ ‌categories.‌ ‌\n■Information‌ ‌and‌ ‌knowledge‌ ‌need‌ ‌not‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌language.‌ ‌\n■Complex‌ ‌actions‌ ‌are‌ ‌performed‌ ‌rapidly‌ ‌without‌ ‌conscious‌ ‌thought.‌ ‌This‌ ‌is‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌internal‌ ‌cognitive‌ ‌structure.‌ ‌\n■Anthropology‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌discipline‌ ‌should‌ ‌not‌ ‌be‌ ‌an‌ ‌appropriate‌ ‌metalinguistic‌ ‌category.‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌has‌ ‌engaged‌ ‌Institute‌ ‌\nmetalinguistic‌ ‌categories‌ ‌like‌ ‌Kinship,‌ ‌religion‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nHarold‌ ‌Conklin‌ ‌\n ‌\nAbout:Harold‌ ‌Conklin‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Harold‌ ‌Conklin‌ ‌(1926-2016)‌ ‌conducted‌ ‌extensive‌ ‌research‌ ‌in‌ ‌Southeast‌ ‌Asia,‌ ‌producing‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌largest‌ ‌ethnographic‌ ‌collections‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nPhilippines.‌ ‌ ‌\n●His‌ ‌interest‌ ‌in‌ ‌linguistics‌ ‌and‌ ‌ecology‌ ‌and‌ ‌commitment‌ ‌to‌ ‌ethnoscience‌ ‌led‌ ‌to‌ ‌pioneering‌ ‌investigations‌ ‌of‌ ‌indigenous‌ ‌systems‌ ‌of‌ ‌tropical‌ ‌\nforest‌ ‌agriculture.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌also‌ ‌made‌ ‌important‌ ‌contributions‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌terminology‌ ‌including‌ ‌“Lexicographical‌ ‌Treatment‌ ‌of‌ ‌Folk‌ ‌Taxonomies”‌ ‌(1969)‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌“Ethno‌ ‌Genealogical‌ ‌Method”‌ ‌(1969).‌ ‌\n ‌\n707‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌studied‌ ‌‘Hanunoo‌ ‌community's‌ ‌color‌ ‌categories.‌ ‌\n○To‌ ‌find‌ ‌out‌ ‌how‌ ‌particular‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌classify‌ ‌color.‌ ‌\n●Among‌ ‌‌Hanunoo‌ ‌‌colors‌ ‌are‌ ‌found‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌various‌ ‌criteria.‌ ‌\n●Two‌ ‌important‌ ‌are:‌ ‌\n●○General‌ ‌level‌ ‌of‌ ‌classification.‌ ‌\n○Detailed‌ ‌and‌ ‌specific‌ ‌level‌ ‌of‌ ‌Classification‌ ‌\n●●‌ ‌According‌ ‌to‌ ‌Conklin,‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌various‌ ‌factors‌ ‌influencing‌ ‌color‌ ‌classification:‌ ‌\n○Perceived‌ ‌moisture‌ ‌object‌ ‌\n○Texture‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌object‌ ‌\n○‌ ‌the‌ ‌Shine‌ ‌or‌ ‌glow‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌object‌ ‌surface‌ ‌\n ‌\n●He‌ ‌concluded‌ ‌that‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌lot‌ ‌of‌ ‌confusion‌ ‌about‌ ‌colour‌ ‌classification‌ ‌at‌ ‌second‌ ‌level.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌is‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌lack‌ ‌of‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌of‌ ‌criteria‌ ‌which‌ ‌they‌ ‌employed‌ ‌to‌ ‌distinguish‌ ‌the‌ ‌color.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌first‌ ‌level‌ ‌has‌ ‌a‌ ‌cognitive‌ ‌model‌ ‌whereas‌ ‌the‌ ‌later‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌have‌ ‌the‌ ‌model‌ ‌for‌ ‌understanding.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Everybody‌ ‌has‌ ‌their‌ ‌own‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌model‌ ‌of‌ ‌perception.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nACCOMPLISHMENTS‌ ‌\n●One‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌main‌ ‌accomplishments‌ ‌of‌ ‌cognitive‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌is‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌provides‌ ‌detailed‌ ‌and‌ ‌reliable‌ ‌descriptions‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌representations.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Additionally,‌ ‌it‌ ‌has‌ ‌challenged‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌of‌ ‌monolithic‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌has‌ ‌helped‌ ‌to‌ ‌bridge‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌functioning‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌mind.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌personality‌ ‌approach‌ ‌helped‌ ‌demonstrate‌ ‌how‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual’s‌ ‌socialization‌ ‌influenced‌ ‌personality‌ ‌systems‌ ‌that,‌ ‌in‌ ‌turn,‌ ‌\ninfluenced‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌practices‌ ‌and‌ ‌beliefs.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nCRITICISMS‌ ‌\n●Some‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌severe‌ ‌criticisms‌ ‌of‌ ‌cognitive‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌have‌ ‌come‌ ‌from‌ ‌its‌ ‌own‌ ‌practitioners.‌ ‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌Keesing‌ ‌the‌ ‌so-called‌ ‌“new‌ ‌ethnography”‌ ‌was‌ ‌unable‌ ‌to‌ ‌move‌ ‌beyond‌ ‌the‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌of‌ ‌artificially‌ ‌simplified‌ ‌and‌ ‌often‌ ‌trivial‌ ‌\nsemantic‌ ‌domains.‌ ‌ ‌\n●One‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌glaring‌ ‌problems‌ ‌is‌ ‌that‌ ‌almost‌ ‌all‌ ‌investigators‌ ‌do‌ ‌the‌ ‌majority‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌research‌ ‌in‌ ‌English.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌is‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌expected,‌ ‌given‌ ‌the‌ ‌elaborate‌ ‌nature‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌investigative‌ ‌methods‌ ‌now‌ ‌being‌ ‌used,‌ ‌but‌ ‌begs‌ ‌the‌ ‌question‌ ‌of‌ ‌just‌ ‌how‌ ‌\napplicable‌ ‌the‌ ‌results‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌for‌ ‌other‌ ‌cultures.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌addition,‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌multiple‌ ‌factors‌ ‌in‌ ‌operation‌ ‌at‌ ‌any‌ ‌given‌ ‌moment‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌difficult‌ ‌to‌ ‌account‌ ‌for‌ ‌using‌ ‌standard‌ ‌methods‌ ‌of‌ ‌cognitive‌ ‌\nanthropology.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Cognitive‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌deals‌ ‌with‌ ‌abstract‌ ‌theories‌ ‌regarding‌ ‌the‌ ‌nature‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌mind.‌ ‌\n708‌ ‌\n○While‌ ‌there‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌a‌ ‌plethora‌ ‌of‌ ‌methods‌ ‌for‌ ‌accessing‌ ‌culture‌ ‌contained‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌mind,‌ ‌questions‌ ‌remain‌ ‌about‌ ‌whether‌ ‌results‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nfact‌ ‌reflect‌ ‌how‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌organize‌ ‌and‌ ‌perceive‌ ‌society,‌ ‌or‌ ‌whether‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌merely‌ ‌manufactured‌ ‌by‌ ‌investigators,‌ ‌having‌ ‌no‌ ‌\nfoundation‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌subjects’‌ ‌reality.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n(j)‌ ‌Postmodernism‌ ‌in‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Postmodernism‌ ‌is‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌latest‌ ‌theoretical‌ ‌perspectives‌ ‌which‌ ‌challenges‌ ‌the‌ ‌foundation‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌anthropological‌ ‌theories.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌argues‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌claims‌ ‌made‌ ‌by‌ ‌anthropological‌ ‌theory‌ ‌are‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌slippery‌ ‌ground.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌challenge‌ ‌them‌ ‌on:‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌conduct‌ ‌of‌ ‌fieldwork‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌literary‌ ‌techniques‌ ‌used‌ ‌in‌ ‌writing‌ ‌\n○Authors‌ ‌interpretation‌ ‌over‌ ‌alternative‌ ‌interpretation‌ ‌\n●Postmodernists‌ ‌claim‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌impossible‌ ‌for‌ ‌anyone‌ ‌to‌ ‌have‌ ‌objective‌ ‌and‌ ‌neutral‌ ‌knowledge‌ ‌of‌ ‌another‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\n●As‌ ‌a‌ ‌philosophy,‌ ‌postmodernism‌ ‌rejects‌ ‌concepts‌ ‌of‌ ‌rationality,‌ ‌objectivity,‌ ‌and‌ ‌universal‌ ‌truth.‌ ‌Instead,‌ ‌it‌ ‌emphasizes‌ ‌the‌ ‌\ndiversity‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌experience‌ ‌and‌ ‌multiplicity‌ ‌of‌ ‌perspectives.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nHistorical‌ ‌Background‌ ‌ ‌\n●Many‌ ‌assumptions‌ ‌of‌ ‌20th‌ ‌century‌ ‌fieldwork‌ ‌and‌ ‌ethnography‌ ‌became‌ ‌subject‌ ‌of‌ ‌debate‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌1980s‌ ‌onwards.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Anthropologists‌ ‌like‌ ‌‌James‌ ‌Clifford,‌ ‌Stephens,‌ ‌and‌ ‌Michel‌ ‌Foucault‌‌ ‌criticized‌ ‌subjectivity‌ ‌in‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropology.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Foucault‌ ‌argued‌ ‌that‌ ‌those‌ ‌in‌ ‌political‌ ‌power‌ ‌were‌ ‌able‌ ‌to‌ ‌shape‌ ‌the‌ ‌way‌ ‌accepted‌ ‌truth‌ ‌is‌ ‌defined.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nBasic‌ ‌premises‌ ‌\n●Post‌ ‌modernism‌ ‌espouses‌ ‌a‌ ‌systematic‌ ‌skepticism‌ ‌of‌ ‌grounded‌ ‌theoretical‌ ‌perspective.‌ ‌(‌James‌ ‌Clifford,‌ ‌Michel‌ ‌Foucault)‌ ‌\n●Post‌ ‌modernism‌ ‌concentrates‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌tensions‌ ‌of‌ ‌difference‌ ‌and‌ ‌similarity‌ ‌erupting‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌globalization‌ ‌process.‌ ‌\n●Post‌ ‌modernism‌ ‌is‌ ‌suspicious‌ ‌of‌ ‌authoritative‌ ‌definition‌ ‌and‌ ‌singular‌ ‌narratives‌ ‌of‌ ‌any‌ ‌event.‌ ‌\n●Postmodernism‌ ‌is‌ ‌divided‌ ‌into‌ ‌2‌ ‌camps;‌ ‌\n○Skeptics‌ ‌:‌‌ ‌They‌ ‌are‌ ‌extremely‌ ‌critical‌ ‌of‌ ‌modern‌ ‌subjects.‌ ‌They‌ ‌reject‌ ‌theories.‌ ‌No‌ ‌theory‌ ‌considered‌ ‌more‌ ‌correct‌ ‌than‌ ‌others.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Affirmatives‌ ‌:‌ ‌They‌ ‌also‌ ‌reject‌ ‌theory‌ ‌by‌ ‌denying‌ ‌claims‌ ‌of‌ ‌truth.‌ ‌They‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌however‌ ‌feel‌ ‌that‌ ‌theory‌ ‌need‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌abolished‌ ‌but‌ ‌\nmerely‌ ‌transformed.‌ ‌They‌ ‌are‌ ‌less‌ ‌rigid.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Self-reflectivity‌ ‌\n●Postmodernists‌ ‌believe‌ ‌that‌ ‌anthropological‌ ‌texts‌ ‌are‌ ‌influenced‌ ‌by‌ ‌political‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌contexts‌ ‌within‌ ‌which‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌retained.‌ ‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌claim‌ ‌that‌ ‌acceptance‌ ‌of‌ ‌interpretation‌ ‌is‌ ‌ultimately‌ ‌an‌ ‌issue‌ ‌of‌ ‌wealth‌ ‌and‌ ‌power.‌ ‌\n ‌\nMethodology‌ ‌\n709‌ ‌\n●Deconstruction‌ ‌and‌ ‌demystifying‌ ‌text‌ ‌to‌ ‌reveal‌ ‌underlying‌ ‌biases‌ ‌in‌ ‌interpretation‌ ‌(Vincent‌ ‌Crapanzano).‌ ‌\n○Deconstruction‌ ‌emphasizes‌ ‌negative‌ ‌critical‌ ‌capacity.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Deconstruction‌ ‌involves‌ ‌demystifying‌ ‌a‌ ‌text‌ ‌to‌ ‌reveal‌ ‌internal‌ ‌arbitrary‌ ‌hierarchies‌ ‌and‌ ‌presuppositions.‌ ‌ ‌\n○By‌ ‌examining‌ ‌the‌ ‌margins‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌text,‌ ‌the‌ ‌effort‌ ‌of‌ ‌deconstruction‌ ‌examines‌ ‌what‌ ‌it‌ ‌represses,‌ ‌what‌ ‌it‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌say,‌ ‌and‌ ‌its‌ ‌\nincongruities.‌ ‌ ‌\n○I‌t‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌solely‌ ‌unmask‌ ‌error,‌ ‌but‌ ‌redefines‌ ‌the‌ ‌text‌ ‌by‌ ‌undoing‌ ‌and‌ ‌reversing‌ ‌polar‌ ‌opposites.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Deconstruction‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌resolve‌ ‌inconsistencies,‌ ‌but‌ ‌rather‌ ‌exposes‌ ‌hierarchies‌ ‌involved‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌distillation‌ ‌of‌ ‌information‌ ‌\n●Intuitive‌ ‌interpretation.‌ ‌\n●Focus‌ ‌on‌ ‌process‌ ‌of‌ ‌fieldwork‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nACCOMPLISHMENTS‌ ‌\n●Critical‌ ‌Examination‌ ‌of‌ ‌Ethnographic‌ ‌Explanation‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌unrelenting‌ ‌re-examination‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌nature‌ ‌of‌ ‌ethnography‌ ‌inevitably‌ ‌leads‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌questioning‌ ‌of‌ ‌ethnography‌ ‌itself‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌mode‌ ‌of‌ ‌\ncultural‌ ‌analysis.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Postmodernism‌ ‌adamantly‌ ‌insists‌ ‌that‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌must‌ ‌consider‌ ‌the‌ ‌role‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌own‌ ‌culture‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌explanation‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌“other”‌ ‌\ncultures‌ ‌being‌ ‌studied.‌ ‌\n○Postmodernist‌ ‌theory‌ ‌has‌ ‌led‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌heightened‌ ‌sensitivity‌ ‌within‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌collection‌ ‌of‌ ‌data.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Demystification‌ ‌\n○Perhaps‌ ‌the‌ ‌greatest‌ ‌accomplishments‌ ‌of‌ ‌postmodernism‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌focus‌ ‌upon‌ ‌uncovering‌ ‌and‌ ‌criticizing‌ ‌the‌ ‌epistemological‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nideological‌ ‌motivations‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌sciences,‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌increased‌ ‌attention‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌factors‌ ‌contributing‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌production‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nknowledge.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Polyvocality‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌self-reflexive‌ ‌regard‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌ways‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌social‌ ‌knowledge‌ ‌is‌ ‌produced,‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌general‌ ‌skepticism‌ ‌regarding‌ ‌the‌ ‌objectivity‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌authority‌ ‌of‌ ‌scientific‌ ‌knowledge,‌ ‌has‌ ‌led‌ ‌to‌ ‌an‌ ‌increased‌ ‌appreciation‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌voice‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌anthropological‌ ‌Other.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Even‌ ‌if‌ ‌we‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌value‌ ‌all‌ ‌interpretations‌ ‌as‌ ‌equally‌ ‌valid‌ ‌for‌ ‌whatever‌ ‌reason,‌ ‌today‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌generally‌ ‌recognized‌ ‌(although‌ ‌perhaps‌ ‌not‌ ‌\nalways‌ ‌done‌ ‌in‌ ‌practice)‌ ‌that‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌must‌ ‌actively‌ ‌consider‌ ‌the‌ ‌perspectives‌ ‌and‌ ‌wellbeing‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌people‌ ‌being‌ ‌studied.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nCRITICISMS‌ ‌\n●Roy‌ ‌D’Andrade‌ ‌(1931-2016)‌ ‌–‌ ‌In‌ ‌the‌ ‌article‌ ‌“Moral‌ ‌Models‌ ‌in‌ ‌Anthropology,”‌ ‌D’Andrade‌ ‌critiques‌ ‌postmodernism’s‌ ‌definition‌ ‌of‌ ‌objectivity‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌subjectivity‌ ‌by‌ ‌examining‌ ‌the‌ ‌moral‌ ‌nature‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌models.‌ ‌ ‌\n710‌ ‌\n●Patricia‌ ‌M.‌ ‌Greenfield‌ ‌‌–‌ ‌Greenfield‌ ‌believes‌ ‌that‌ ‌postmodernism’s‌ ‌complete‌ ‌lack‌ ‌of‌ ‌objectivity,‌ ‌and‌ ‌its‌ ‌tendency‌ ‌to‌ ‌push‌ ‌political‌ ‌agendas,‌ ‌\nmakes‌ ‌it‌ ‌virtually‌ ‌useless‌ ‌in‌ ‌any‌ ‌scientific‌ ‌investigation‌ ‌ ‌\n●Bob‌ ‌McKinley‌ ‌‌–‌ ‌McKinley‌ ‌believes‌ ‌that‌ ‌postmodernism‌ ‌is‌ ‌more‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌religion‌ ‌than‌ ‌a‌ ‌science.‌ ‌\n○He‌ ‌argues‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌origin‌ ‌of‌ ‌postmodernism‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌Western‌ ‌emphasis‌ ‌on‌ ‌individualism,‌ ‌which‌ ‌makes‌ ‌postmodernists‌ ‌reluctant‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nacknowledge‌ ‌the‌ ‌existence‌ ‌of‌ ‌distinct‌ ‌multi-individual‌ ‌cultures.‌ ‌\n ‌\nConclusion‌ ‌\n●Though‌ ‌one‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌define‌ ‌the‌ ‌term,‌ ‌postmodernism‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌way‌ ‌of‌ ‌looking‌ ‌at‌ ‌things‌ ‌around‌ ‌us.‌ ‌\n●Perspective‌ ‌on‌ ‌board‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌intellectual‌ ‌movement‌ ‌that‌ ‌he's‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌absolute‌ ‌truth‌ ‌as‌ ‌every‌ ‌text‌ ‌has‌ ‌many‌ ‌meanings‌ ‌in‌ ‌it.‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌Postmodernism‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌truth,‌ ‌no‌ ‌fact,‌ ‌no‌ ‌one‌ ‌right‌ ‌way‌ ‌to‌ ‌understand‌ ‌nature‌ ‌or‌ ‌text‌ ‌and‌ ‌ultimately‌ ‌objectivity‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌myth‌ ‌for‌ ‌\npostmodernists.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n711‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n7.‌ ‌Culture,‌ ‌Language‌ ‌and‌ ‌Communication‌ ‌:‌ ‌Nature,‌ ‌origin‌ ‌and‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌language;‌ ‌verbal‌ ‌and‌ ‌non-verbal‌ ‌communication;‌ ‌social‌ ‌\ncontext‌ ‌of‌ ‌language‌ ‌use-Part-I‌ ‌\n ‌\nIntroduction:‌ ‌\n●Meaning‌ ‌and‌ ‌scope‌ ‌of‌ ‌Linguistic‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌term‌ ‌linguistic‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌and‌ ‌its‌ ‌variant‌ ‌anthropological‌ ‌linguistics‌ ‌are‌ ‌currently‌ ‌understood‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌variety‌ ‌of‌ ‌ways.‌ ‌\n○Linguistic‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌focuses‌ ‌on‌ ‌how‌ ‌people‌ ‌use‌ ‌language‌ ‌in‌ ‌particular‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Linguistic‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌often‌ ‌work‌ ‌with‌ ‌people‌ ‌who‌ ‌have‌ ‌unwritten‌ ‌(purely‌ ‌spoken,‌ ‌or‌ ‌oral)‌ ‌languages‌ ‌or‌ ‌with‌ ‌languages‌ ‌that‌ ‌very‌ ‌\nfew‌ ‌people‌ ‌speak‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Linguistic‌ ‌anthropological‌ ‌work‌ ‌may‌ ‌involve‌ ‌developing‌ ‌a‌ ‌way‌ ‌to‌ ‌write‌ ‌a‌ ‌formerly‌ ‌unwritten‌ ‌language.‌ ‌\n○Some‌ ‌linguistic‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌specialise‌ ‌in‌ ‌reconstructing‌ ‌dead‌ ‌languages‌ ‌(languages‌ ‌no‌ ‌longer‌ ‌in‌ ‌use)‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌connections‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nliving‌ ‌languages,‌ ‌a‌ ‌study‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌historical‌ ‌linguistics.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nNature,‌ ‌origin‌ ‌and‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌language‌ ‌\n●Language‌ ‌is‌ ‌called‌ ‌a‌ ‌‌social‌ ‌phenomenon‌,‌ ‌‌because‌ ‌it‌ ‌has‌ ‌relevance‌ ‌only‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌social‌ ‌setting.‌ ‌Language‌ ‌undergoes‌ ‌a‌ ‌continuous,‌ ‌though‌ ‌\nunnoticed,‌ ‌process‌ ‌of‌ ‌growth‌ ‌and‌ ‌change.‌ ‌\n ‌\nMeaning‌ ‌\n●\"Language‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌said‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌any‌ ‌means‌ ‌of‌ ‌expression‌ ‌or‌ ‌mental‌ ‌concepts‌ ‌by‌ ‌any‌ ‌living‌ ‌beings‌ ‌whatsoever‌ ‌and‌ ‌of‌ ‌communicating‌ ‌them‌ ‌to,‌ ‌\nor‌ ‌receiving‌ ‌them‌ ‌from‌ ‌other‌ ‌living‌ ‌beings.\"‌ ‌\n ‌\n712‌ ‌\nDefinition‌ ‌\n●\"Language‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌primarily‌ ‌human‌ ‌and‌ ‌non-instinctive‌ ‌method‌ ‌of‌ ‌communicating‌ ‌ideas,‌ ‌emotions‌ ‌and‌ ‌desires‌ ‌by‌ ‌means‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nvoluntarily‌ ‌produced‌ ‌symbols\"‌ ‌(Sapir).‌ ‌\n●\"Language,‌ ‌in‌ ‌its‌ ‌widest‌ ‌sense,‌ ‌means‌ ‌the‌ ‌sum‌ ‌total‌ ‌of‌ ‌such‌ ‌signs‌ ‌of‌ ‌our‌ ‌thoughts‌ ‌and‌ ‌feelings‌ ‌as‌ ‌are‌ ‌capable‌ ‌of‌ ‌external‌ ‌perception‌ ‌and‌ ‌as‌ ‌\ncould‌ ‌be‌ ‌produced‌ ‌and‌ ‌repeated‌ ‌at‌ ‌will\"‌ ‌(A.H.‌ ‌Gardiner).‌ ‌\n●\"Language‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌defined‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌expression‌ ‌of‌ ‌thought‌ ‌by‌ ‌means‌ ‌of‌ ‌speech-sounds\"‌ ‌(Henry‌ ‌Sweet).‌ ‌\n●\"A‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌communication‌ ‌by‌ ‌sound‌ ‌i.e.,‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌organs‌ ‌of‌ ‌speech‌ ‌and‌ ‌hearing,‌ ‌among‌ ‌human‌ ‌beings‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌certain‌ ‌group‌ ‌or‌ ‌\ncommunity,‌ ‌using‌ ‌vocal‌ ‌symbols‌ ‌possessing‌ ‌arbitrary‌ ‌conventional‌ ‌meanings.\"‌ ‌(Mario‌ ‌A‌ ‌Pei‌ ‌&‌ ‌Frank‌ ‌Gaynor).‌ ‌\n●Language‌ ‌is‌ ‌human..a‌ ‌verbal‌ ‌systematic‌ ‌symbolism..‌ ‌a‌ ‌means‌ ‌of‌ ‌transmitting‌ ‌information...a‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌behaviour...‌ ‌(with‌ ‌a‌ ‌high‌ ‌degree‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌convention\"‌ ‌(.‌ ‌Whatmough).‌ ‌\n●\"A‌ ‌language‌ ‌(is‌ ‌a‌ ‌symbol‌ ‌system...‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌pure‌ ‌or‌ ‌arbitrary‌ ‌Convention...‌ ‌infinitely‌ ‌extendable‌ ‌and‌ ‌modifiable‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌lunging‌ ‌\nneeds‌ ‌and‌ ‌conditions‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌speakers\"‌ ‌(R.‌ ‌H.‌ ‌Robins).‌ ‌\n●\"A‌ ‌language‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌device‌ ‌that‌ ‌establishes‌ ‌sound-meaning‌ ‌correlations,‌ ‌pairing‌ ‌meanings‌ ‌with‌ ‌signals‌ ‌to‌ ‌enable‌ ‌people‌ ‌to‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌\nthrough‌ ‌observable‌ ‌sequences‌ ‌of‌ ‌sound\"‌ ‌(Ronals‌ ‌W.‌ ‌Langacker)‌ ‌\n●\"A‌ ‌language‌ ‌is‌ ‌\"audible,‌ ‌articulate‌ ‌human‌ ‌speech‌ ‌as‌ ‌produced‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌action‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌tongue‌ ‌and‌ ‌adjacent‌ ‌vocal‌ ‌organs.‌ ‌The‌ ‌body‌ ‌of‌ ‌words‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌methods‌ ‌of‌ ‌combining‌ ‌words‌ ‌used‌ ‌and‌ ‌understood‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌considerable‌ ‌community,‌ ‌especially‌ ‌when‌ ‌fixed‌ ‌and‌ ‌elaborated‌ ‌by‌ ‌long‌ ‌usage;‌ ‌a‌ ‌\ntongue\"‌ ‌(Webster).‌ ‌\n ‌\nNature‌ ‌of‌ ‌Language‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌language‌ ‌consists‌ ‌of‌ ‌words,‌ ‌idioms‌ ‌and‌ ‌syntax.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌through‌ ‌language‌ ‌that‌ ‌we‌ ‌think,‌ ‌feel,‌ ‌judge‌ ‌and‌ ‌express.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Hence‌ ‌language‌ ‌is‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌important‌ ‌and‌ ‌characteristic‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌we‌ ‌use‌ ‌words‌ ‌and‌ ‌idioms‌ ‌as‌ ‌tools‌ ‌to‌ ‌perform‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nshare‌ ‌experience‌ ‌among‌ ‌people‌ ‌possible.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Language‌ ‌is‌ ‌speech‌ ‌\n○Language‌ ‌is‌ ‌speech‌ ‌and‌ ‌is‌ ‌distinct‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌signs,‌ ‌gestures‌ ‌and‌ ‌sounds‌ ‌produced‌ ‌by‌ ‌animals‌ ‌or‌ ‌pets‌ ‌to‌ ‌convey‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌\nfeeling‌ ‌or‌ ‌emotion.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌distinct‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌sign‌ ‌language‌ ‌even‌ ‌amongst‌ ‌the‌ ‌humans‌ ‌at‌ ‌any‌ ‌point‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌and‌ ‌biological‌ ‌evolution.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌restricts‌ ‌itself‌ ‌to‌ ‌recognised‌ ‌expression‌ ‌and‌ ‌communication‌ ‌to‌ ‌or‌ ‌from‌ ‌human‌ ‌beings‌ ‌by‌ ‌means‌ ‌of‌ ‌speech‌ ‌and‌ ‌hearing.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌communication,‌ ‌therefore,‌ ‌has‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌from‌ ‌man‌ ‌to‌ ‌man,‌ ‌from‌ ‌a‌ ‌person‌ ‌to‌ ‌another‌ ‌person‌ ‌by‌ ‌means‌ ‌of‌ ‌speech,‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nhearing.‌ ‌Speech,‌ ‌therefore,‌ ‌is‌ ‌language.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Living‌ ‌Language‌ ‌ ‌\n○Language‌ ‌undergoes‌ ‌a‌ ‌continuous‌ ‌and‌ ‌unnoticed‌ ‌change‌ ‌for‌ ‌its‌ ‌refinement‌ ‌and‌ ‌depth.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌responds‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌demands‌ ‌and‌ ‌requirements‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌group‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌represents.‌ ‌ ‌\n713‌ ‌\n○As‌ ‌the‌ ‌human‌ ‌utterances‌ ‌became‌ ‌complex‌ ‌and‌ ‌varied,‌ ‌a‌ ‌language‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌living‌ ‌must‌ ‌move‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌group,‌ ‌must‌ ‌grow‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌\ngroup,‌ ‌should‌ ‌be‌ ‌alive‌ ‌to‌ ‌their‌ ‌needs‌ ‌and‌ ‌aspirations.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌this‌ ‌process‌ ‌of‌ ‌change‌ ‌and‌ ‌growth,‌ ‌language‌ ‌acquires‌ ‌new‌ ‌shape,‌ ‌new‌ ‌approach,‌ ‌new‌ ‌significance‌ ‌and‌ ‌new‌ ‌application.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Language‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌system:‌ ‌ ‌\n■Each‌ ‌language‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌unique‌ ‌system.‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌language‌ ‌consists‌ ‌of‌ ‌sounds,‌ ‌structures‌ ‌and‌ ‌vocabulary.‌ ‌ ‌\n■A‌ ‌person‌ ‌who‌ ‌wants‌ ‌to‌ ‌learn‌ ‌a‌ ‌new‌ ‌language‌ ‌will‌ ‌have‌ ‌to‌ ‌learn‌ ‌new‌ ‌sounds,‌ ‌new‌ ‌structures‌ ‌and‌ ‌new‌ ‌vocabulary.‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌sound‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌language‌ ‌differs‌ ‌from‌ ‌language‌ ‌to‌ ‌language‌ ‌depending‌ ‌upon‌ ‌the‌ ‌culture‌ ‌to‌ ‌which‌ ‌a‌ ‌language‌ ‌belongs.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Each‌ ‌language‌ ‌has‌ ‌its‌ ‌own‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌vocabulary.‌ ‌Thus‌ ‌each‌ ‌language‌ ‌is‌ ‌systematic.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Language‌ ‌and‌ ‌Society‌ ‌\n○\"Language‌ ‌is‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌important‌ ‌and‌ ‌characteristic‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌behaviour\"‌ ‌With‌ ‌widening‌ ‌range‌ ‌and‌ ‌horizon‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nhuman‌ ‌thought‌ ‌and‌ ‌action,‌ ‌the‌ ‌language‌ ‌has‌ ‌to‌ ‌keep‌ ‌in‌ ‌step‌ ‌with‌ ‌its‌ ‌social‌ ‌calling.‌ ‌ ‌\n○As‌ ‌\"language‌ ‌is‌ ‌activity,‌ ‌a‌ ‌purposeful‌ ‌activity\",‌ ‌it‌ ‌must‌ ‌help‌ ‌man‌ ‌to‌ ‌express‌ ‌himself‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌variety‌ ‌of‌ ‌new‌ ‌and‌ ‌different‌ ‌kinds‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nsituations.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌society‌ ‌that,‌ ‌in‌ ‌its‌ ‌turn,‌ ‌bestows‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌towards‌ ‌and‌ ‌idioms‌ ‌by‌ ‌conventionalising‌ ‌them‌ ‌to‌ ‌mean‌ ‌what‌ ‌they‌ ‌mean‌ ‌\ntoday‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌or‌ ‌a‌ ‌community,‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌variety‌ ‌of‌ ‌complex‌ ‌contexts.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Operation‌ ‌of‌ ‌Language‌ ‌\n○As‌ ‌language‌ ‌has‌ ‌relevance‌ ‌only‌ ‌in‌ ‌social‌ ‌context,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌necessary‌ ‌for‌ ‌its‌ ‌operation,‌ ‌that‌ ‌a‌ ‌social‌ ‌necessity‌ ‌or‌ ‌scenario‌ ‌exists.‌ ‌ ‌\n○There‌ ‌should‌ ‌be‌ ‌a‌ ‌corresponding‌ ‌situation‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌language‌ ‌to‌ ‌operate‌ ‌upon.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌conventional‌ ‌arrangement‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nspeaker‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌listener.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Sounds‌ ‌and‌ ‌Signals‌ ‌\n○Sounds‌ ‌produced‌ ‌by‌ ‌human‌ ‌beings‌ ‌differ‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌'signal-Like'‌ ‌sounds‌ ‌and‌ ‌actions‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌animals.‌ ‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌lot‌ ‌of‌ ‌research‌ ‌is‌ ‌going‌ ‌on‌ ‌to‌ ‌establish‌ ‌if‌ ‌the‌ ‌animals‌ ‌also‌ ‌have‌ ‌similar‌ ‌conventionalised‌ ‌arrangement‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌expression.‌ ‌ ‌\n○According‌ ‌to‌‌ ‌Bloomfield‌,‌ ‌\"In‌ ‌human‌ ‌speech,‌ ‌different‌ ‌sounds‌ ‌have‌ ‌different‌ ‌meanings.‌ ‌ ‌\n○To‌ ‌study‌ ‌this‌ ‌coordination‌ ‌of‌ ‌certain‌ ‌sounds‌ ‌with‌ ‌certain‌ ‌meanings‌ ‌is‌ ‌to‌ ‌study‌ ‌language\".‌ ‌In‌ ‌other‌ ‌words,‌ ‌a‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nlanguage‌ ‌consists‌ ‌in‌ ‌giving‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌meaning.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌already‌ ‌exists,‌ ‌we‌ ‌have‌ ‌to‌ ‌give‌ ‌it‌ ‌a‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌intelligible‌ ‌to‌ ‌us‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌language.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nCharacteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌Language:‌ ‌\n●Language‌ ‌is‌ ‌learnt:‌ ‌\n714‌ ‌\n○Learning‌ ‌a‌ ‌language‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌an‌ ‌automatic‌ ‌process.‌ ‌of‌ ‌course‌ ‌this‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌but‌ ‌unlike‌ ‌other‌ ‌diseases‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌walking‌ ‌crawling‌ ‌\nit‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌come‌ ‌naturally.‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌acquired‌ ‌by‌ ‌imitation‌ ‌and‌ ‌practice.Language‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌possible‌ ‌without‌ ‌effort.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Language‌ ‌is‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌culture‌ ‌of‌ ‌society‌ ‌\n○Every‌ ‌language‌ ‌is‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌culture‌ ‌of‌ ‌society‌ ‌to‌ ‌which‌ ‌it‌ ‌belongs.‌ ‌The‌ ‌culture‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌people‌ ‌naturally‌ ‌influences‌ ‌the‌ ‌language.‌ ‌Every‌ ‌\nlanguage‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌product‌ ‌of‌ ‌society.‌ ‌We‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌separate‌ ‌language‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌culture‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌that‌ ‌language‌ ‌exists.‌ ‌It‌ ‌has‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌only‌ ‌\nin‌ ‌relation‌ ‌to‌ ‌that‌ ‌society‌ ‌and‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Governed‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌set‌ ‌of‌ ‌rules:‌ ‌ ‌\n○Each‌ ‌language‌ ‌is‌ ‌governed‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌set‌ ‌or‌ ‌rules.‌ ‌For‌ ‌example‌ ‌English‌ ‌is‌ ‌S.V.O.‌ ‌language.‌ ‌In‌ ‌forming‌ ‌sentence,‌ ‌we‌ ‌put‌ ‌subject,‌ ‌\nthen‌ ‌verb‌ ‌and‌ ‌after‌ ‌verb‌ ‌we‌ ‌put‌ ‌object.‌ ‌\n ‌\nFor‌ ‌example‌ ‌\nHe‌ ‌killed‌ ‌a‌ ‌snake.‌ ‌\nSubject‌ ‌Verb‌ ‌Object‌ ‌\n ‌\nOn‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌hand,‌ ‌Hindi‌ ‌is‌ ‌S.O.V.‌ ‌language.‌ ‌First‌ ‌we‌ ‌put‌ ‌the‌ ‌subject,‌ ‌the‌ ‌object‌ ‌and‌ ‌after‌ ‌the‌ ‌object,‌ ‌we‌ ‌put‌ ‌the‌ ‌verb.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌Usne‌ ‌saap‌ ‌ko‌ ‌maara‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌Subject‌ ‌Object‌ ‌Verb‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Language‌ ‌is‌ ‌species‌ ‌specific‌ ‌\n○ ‌Only‌ ‌human‌ ‌being‌ ‌can‌ ‌communicate‌ ‌using‌ ‌the‌ ‌language.‌ ‌\n○Of‌ ‌course,‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌species‌ ‌do‌ ‌communicate‌ ‌but‌ ‌only‌ ‌human‌ ‌beings‌ ‌can‌ ‌make‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌language.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Language‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌system‌ ‌\n○Each‌ ‌language‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌unique‌ ‌system.‌ ‌The‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌language‌ ‌consists‌ ‌of‌ ‌sounds,‌ ‌structures‌ ‌and‌ ‌vocabulary.‌ ‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌person‌ ‌who‌ ‌wants‌ ‌to‌ ‌learn‌ ‌a‌ ‌new‌ ‌language‌ ‌will‌ ‌have‌ ‌to‌ ‌learn‌ ‌new‌ ‌sounds,‌ ‌new‌ ‌structures‌ ‌and‌ ‌new‌ ‌vocabulary.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌sound‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌language‌ ‌differs‌ ‌from‌ ‌language‌ ‌to‌ ‌language‌ ‌depending‌ ‌upon‌ ‌the‌ ‌culture‌ ‌to‌ ‌which‌ ‌a‌ ‌language‌ ‌belongs.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Each‌ ‌language‌ ‌has‌ ‌its‌ ‌own‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌vocabulary.‌ ‌Thus‌ ‌each‌ ‌language‌ ‌is‌ ‌systematic.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Language‌ ‌is‌ ‌SYMBOLIC‌ ‌\n ‌\nQuestion:‌ ‌How‌ ‌is‌ ‌language‌ ‌symbolic?‌ ‌\nNote:‌ ‌Below‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌a‌ ‌structured‌ ‌answer‌ ‌\n715‌ ‌\n○Language‌ ‌is‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌because‌ ‌it‌ ‌just‌ ‌stands‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌items‌ ‌it‌ ‌represents.‌ ‌This‌ ‌is‌ ‌like‌ ‌how‌ ‌a‌ ‌symbol‌ ‌just‌ ‌stands‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌item‌ ‌it‌ ‌represents‌ ‌\nwithout‌ ‌actually‌ ‌being‌ ‌the‌ ‌item‌ ‌itself.‌ ‌\n○Some‌ ‌languages‌ ‌are‌ ‌more‌ ‌obviously‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌than‌ ‌others.‌ ‌Chinese,‌ ‌for‌ ‌instance,‌ ‌uses‌ ‌ideographs,‌ ‌many‌ ‌of‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌\npictures‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌object‌ ‌or‌ ‌representations‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌concept‌ ‌for‌ ‌which‌ ‌they‌ ‌stand.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n○However,‌ ‌all‌ ‌language‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌refinement‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌principle,‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌only‌ ‌reason‌ ‌why‌ ‌this‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌immediately‌ ‌obvious‌ ‌is‌ ‌because,‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌\ntime‌ ‌people‌ ‌understand‌ ‌the‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌symbolism,‌ ‌language‌ ‌is‌ ‌already‌ ‌deeply‌ ‌familiar‌ ‌to‌ ‌them.‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌example:‌ ‌If‌ ‌you‌ ‌ask‌ ‌a‌ ‌skilled‌ ‌artist‌ ‌to‌ ‌draw‌ ‌a‌ ‌man,‌ ‌they‌ ‌will‌ ‌create‌ ‌something‌ ‌that‌ ‌looks‌ ‌recognizably‌ ‌similar‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌man,‌ ‌though‌ ‌it‌ ‌\nwill‌ ‌probably‌ ‌be‌ ‌small‌ ‌and‌ ‌certainly‌ ‌be‌ ‌flat‌ ‌when‌ ‌compared‌ ‌to‌ ‌an‌ ‌actual‌ ‌man.‌ ‌However,‌ ‌someone‌ ‌who‌ ‌has‌ ‌no‌ ‌artistic‌ ‌training‌ ‌or‌ ‌ability‌ ‌\nwill‌ ‌probably‌ ‌draw‌ ‌a‌ ‌\"stickman.\"‌ ‌This‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌line‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌circle‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌top,‌ ‌with‌ ‌two‌ ‌lines‌ ‌emanating‌ ‌at‌ ‌angles‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌top‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌central‌ ‌\nline,‌ ‌and‌ ‌two‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌bottom.‌ ‌This‌ ‌looks‌ ‌nothing‌ ‌like‌ ‌a‌ ‌man,‌ ‌and‌ ‌someone‌ ‌who‌ ‌had‌ ‌not‌ ‌been‌ ‌taught‌ ‌to‌ ‌recognize‌ ‌it‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌symbol‌ ‌\nwould‌ ‌probably‌ ‌not‌ ‌know‌ ‌what‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌supposed‌ ‌to‌ ‌represent.‌ ‌\n○From‌ ‌this‌ ‌depiction,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌short‌ ‌step‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌word‌ ‌\"man\"‌ ‌(or‌ ‌\"homme\"‌ ‌if‌ ‌you‌ ‌happen‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌French,‌ ‌or‌ ‌\"hombre\"‌ ‌if‌ ‌Spanish).‌ ‌These‌ ‌\nwords‌ ‌look‌ ‌even‌ ‌less‌ ‌like‌ ‌a‌ ‌man‌ ‌than‌ ‌the‌ ‌stick‌ ‌man,‌ ‌but‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌no‌ ‌longer‌ ‌intended‌ ‌as‌ ‌any‌ ‌kind‌ ‌of‌ ‌visual‌ ‌representation.‌ ‌They‌ ‌are‌ ‌a‌ ‌\npure‌ ‌symbol,‌ ‌signaling‌ ‌the‌ ‌concept‌ ‌without‌ ‌depicting‌ ‌it.‌ ‌This‌ ‌separation‌ ‌of‌ ‌depiction‌ ‌and‌ ‌symbol‌ ‌allows‌ ‌language‌ ‌to‌ ‌express‌ ‌very‌ ‌\ncomplex‌ ‌concepts,‌ ‌particularly‌ ‌abstractions.‌ ‌While‌ ‌a‌ ‌talented‌ ‌artist‌ ‌could‌ ‌draw‌ ‌a‌ ‌clear‌ ‌representation‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌man,‌ ‌they‌ ‌could‌ ‌not‌ ‌draw‌ ‌\nlove‌ ‌or‌ ‌tragedy.‌ ‌However,‌ ‌these‌ ‌simple‌ ‌words‌ ‌have‌ ‌the‌ ‌power‌ ‌instantly‌ ‌to‌ ‌symbolize‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌which‌ ‌would‌ ‌take‌ ‌a‌ ‌long‌ ‌time‌ ‌to‌ ‌describe‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌explain.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Symbols‌ ‌of‌ ‌language‌ ‌are‌ ‌Arbitrary:‌ ‌ ‌\n○Here‌ ‌by‌ ‌arbitrary‌ ‌symbols‌ ‌we‌ ‌meant‌ ‌that‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌visual‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌language‌ ‌item‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌object‌ ‌for‌ ‌which‌ ‌it‌ ‌stands.‌ ‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌man‌ ‌is‌ ‌called‌ ‌man‌ ‌traditionally.‌ ‌There‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌visual‌ ‌similarity‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌symbol‌ ‌‘man’‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌actual‌ ‌man.‌ ‌ ‌\n○We‌ ‌have‌ ‌not‌ ‌named‌ ‌it‌ ‌so‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌some‌ ‌logic‌ ‌or‌ ‌scientific‌ ‌principles.‌ ‌In‌ ‌English‌ ‌we‌ ‌say‌ ‌man,‌ ‌in‌ ‌‘Hindi’‌ ‌we‌ ‌say‌ ‌‘manausya’‌ ‌ ‌\n○None‌ ‌of‌ ‌them‌ ‌is‌ ‌better‌ ‌than‌ ‌the‌ ‌other.‌ ‌In‌ ‌fact,‌ ‌we‌ ‌call‌ ‌a‌ ‌man‌ ‌‘man’‌ ‌because‌ ‌people‌ ‌have‌ ‌agreed‌ ‌to‌ ‌use‌ ‌it‌ ‌in‌ ‌that‌ ‌sense.‌ ‌\n ‌\n716‌ ‌\nLanguage‌ ‌functions‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Social‌ ‌Function‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌said‌ ‌time‌ ‌and‌ ‌again‌ ‌that‌ ‌language‌ ‌is‌ ‌social'.‌ ‌\n○I‌t‌ ‌operates‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌social‌ ‌setting‌ ‌it‌ ‌acquires‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌and‌ ‌significance‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌social‌ ‌interaction.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌means‌ ‌of‌ ‌communication‌ ‌between‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌community,‌ ‌or‌ ‌between‌ ‌a‌ ‌community‌ ‌and‌ ‌community.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌capable‌ ‌of‌ ‌handling‌ ‌all‌ ‌references‌ ‌and‌ ‌meanings\"‌ ‌(Sapir)‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌given‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌means‌ ‌of‌ ‌expression.‌ ‌\n●Cultural‌ ‌Function‌ ‌\n○As‌ ‌a‌ ‌\"language‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌culture‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌people‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌chief‌ ‌means‌ ‌by‌ ‌which‌ ‌the‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌society‌ ‌communicate\",‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌\nwedded‌ ‌to‌ ‌culture,‌ ‌is‌ ‌inseparable‌ ‌from‌ ‌it‌ ‌and‌ ‌hence‌ ‌performs‌ ‌a‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌function.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌content‌ ‌of‌ ‌every‌ ‌culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌expressible‌ ‌in‌ ‌its‌ ‌language‌ ‌ ‌\n●Language‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌Individual‌ ‌\n○As‌ ‌a‌ ‌symbolic‌ ‌system,‌ ‌language‌ ‌either‌ ‌reports‌ ‌to,‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌or‌ ‌substitutes‌ ‌for,‌ ‌direct‌ ‌experience.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Whatever‌ ‌the‌ ‌case‌ ‌may‌ ‌be,‌ ‌language‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌\"stand‌ ‌apart‌ ‌from‌ ‌or‌ ‌run‌ ‌parallel‌ ‌to‌ ‌direct‌ ‌experience,‌ ‌but‌ ‌completely‌ ‌interpenetrates‌ ‌\nwith‌ ‌it.\"‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Expressive‌ ‌Function‌ ‌\n○Language‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌great‌ ‌force‌ ‌of‌ ‌socialisation.‌ ‌\"language‌ ‌is‌ ‌primarily‌ ‌a‌ ‌vocal‌ ‌actualisation‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌tendency‌ ‌to‌ ‌see‌ ‌realities‌ ‌symbolically''‌ ‌ ‌\n○There‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌be‌ ‌any‌ ‌meaningful‌ ‌social‌ ‌interaction‌ ‌without‌ ‌language.‌ ‌ ‌\n717‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌language‌ ‌binds‌ ‌the‌ ‌people‌ ‌into‌ ‌one‌ ‌large‌ ‌group‌ ‌called‌ ‌nation.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌national‌ ‌language‌ ‌socialises‌ ‌the‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌whole‌ ‌nation,‌ ‌whereas,‌ ‌the‌ ‌regional‌ ‌languages‌ ‌help‌ ‌integrate‌ ‌regional‌ ‌groups.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Language‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌greatest‌ ‌and‌ ‌most‌ ‌potent‌ ‌force‌ ‌of‌ ‌integration.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Aesthetic‌ ‌Aspect‌ ‌ ‌\n○Language‌ ‌helps‌ ‌store‌ ‌culture‌ ‌experiences‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌literature‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌written‌ ‌records‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌posterity.‌ ‌ ‌\n○These‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌experiences‌ ‌form‌ ‌the‌ ‌nexus‌ ‌of‌ ‌individual‌ ‌realisation.‌ ‌It‌ ‌breathes‌ ‌life‌ ‌into‌ ‌our‌ ‌poets‌ ‌and‌ ‌dramatists.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Short‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌language,‌ ‌such‌ ‌fine‌ ‌arts‌ ‌were‌ ‌not‌ ‌possible.‌ ‌Aesthetic‌ ‌experiences‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌treasure‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌posterity‌ ‌to‌ ‌feel‌ ‌proud‌ ‌of‌ ‌it‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nnational‌ ‌treasure-house.‌ ‌\n ‌\nRoman‌ ‌Jakobson‌ ‌defined‌ ‌six‌ ‌primary‌ ‌functions‌ ‌of‌ ‌language‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌which‌ ‌an‌ ‌effective‌ ‌act‌ ‌of‌ ‌verbal‌ ‌communication‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌\ndescribed.‌ ‌ ‌\nThese‌ ‌functions‌ ‌are:‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌referential‌ ‌function:‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌function‌ ‌is‌ ‌primarily‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌convey‌ ‌information‌ ‌which‌ ‌was‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌primary‌ ‌reasons‌ ‌that‌ ‌language‌ ‌was‌ ‌discovered.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Descriptions‌ ‌of‌ ‌situations,‌ ‌objects‌ ‌and‌ ‌even‌ ‌mental‌ ‌states‌ ‌come‌ ‌under‌ ‌this.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌expressive‌ ‌function:‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌function‌ ‌reports‌ ‌feelings‌ ‌or‌ ‌attitudes‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌speaker‌ ‌or‌ ‌writer‌ ‌and‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌meant‌ ‌to‌ ‌evoke‌ ‌feelings‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌listener‌ ‌or‌ ‌reader.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌communication‌ ‌can‌ ‌also‌ ‌happen‌ ‌when‌ ‌we‌ ‌are‌ ‌alone.‌ ‌For‌ ‌example,‌ ‌if‌ ‌my‌ ‌mobile‌ ‌phone‌ ‌falls‌ ‌into‌ ‌a‌ ‌bucket‌ ‌of‌ ‌water,‌ ‌what‌ ‌\ndo‌ ‌you‌ ‌think‌ ‌I’m‌ ‌likely‌ ‌to‌ ‌say‌ ‌to‌ ‌myself?‌ ‌Probably‌ ‌use‌ ‌a‌ ‌swear‌ ‌word.‌ ‌\n○We‌ ‌can‌ ‌also‌ ‌utter‌ ‌emotive‌ ‌utterances‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌positive‌ ‌nature,‌ ‌especially‌ ‌when‌ ‌we‌ ‌sight‌ ‌something‌ ‌of‌ ‌great‌ ‌beauty‌ ‌“Wow,‌ ‌isn’t‌ ‌that‌ ‌\nbeautiful!”‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌directive‌ ‌function:‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌function‌ ‌engages‌ ‌the‌ ‌addressee‌ ‌directly‌ ‌and‌ ‌is‌ ‌usually‌ ‌used‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌purpose‌ ‌of‌ ‌causing‌ ‌or‌ ‌preventing‌ ‌an‌ ‌action.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌therefore‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌commands‌ ‌and‌ ‌requests‌ ‌and‌ ‌requires‌ ‌the‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌vocatives‌ ‌and‌ ‌imperatives,‌ ‌example,‌ ‌‌“Adit,‌ ‌come‌ ‌here‌ ‌at‌ ‌\nonce”,‌ ‌“Please‌ ‌shut‌ ‌the‌ ‌window.”‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌phatic‌ ‌function:‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌involves‌ ‌language‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌sake‌ ‌of‌ ‌social‌ ‌interaction.‌ ‌This‌ ‌function‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌observed‌ ‌in‌ ‌greetings‌ ‌‌“Hi,‌ ‌how‌ ‌are‌ ‌you”‌ ‌and‌ ‌casual‌ ‌\ndiscussions‌ ‌about‌ ‌the‌ ‌weather,‌ ‌i.e.‌ ‌“It’s‌ ‌so‌ ‌hot‌ ‌these‌ ‌days”.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌poetic‌ ‌function:‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌function‌ ‌focuses‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌message‌ ‌for‌ ‌its‌ ‌own‌ ‌sake,‌ ‌and‌ ‌is‌ ‌used‌ ‌in‌ ‌poetry‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌in‌ ‌slogans.‌ ‌This‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌aesthetic‌ ‌function‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nlanguage.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌metalingual‌ ‌function:‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌function‌ ‌is‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌talk‌ ‌about‌ ‌language‌ ‌itself‌ ‌as‌ ‌we‌ ‌are‌ ‌doing‌ ‌in‌ ‌this‌ ‌unit.‌ ‌\n○However,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌very‌ ‌rare‌ ‌for‌ ‌any‌ ‌piece‌ ‌of‌ ‌discourse‌ ‌to‌ ‌serve‌ ‌only‌ ‌one‌ ‌function,‌ ‌unless‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌very‌ ‌specialized‌ ‌and‌ ‌restrictive‌ ‌piece‌ ‌of‌ ‌\ndiscourse;‌ ‌most‌ ‌ordinary‌ ‌kinds‌ ‌of‌ ‌discourse‌ ‌are‌ ‌mixed‌ ‌\n ‌\n718‌ ‌\nORIGIN‌ ‌OF‌ ‌LANGUAGES‌ ‌\nOne‌ ‌can‌ ‌subdivide‌ ‌approaches‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌origin‌ ‌of‌ ‌language‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌some‌ ‌underlying‌ ‌assumptions:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●\"‌Continuity‌ ‌theories‌\"‌ ‌build‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌idea‌ ‌that‌ ‌language‌ ‌exhibits‌ ‌so‌ ‌much‌ ‌complexity‌ ‌that‌ ‌one‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌imagine‌ ‌it‌ ‌simply‌ ‌appearing‌ ‌from‌ ‌nothing‌ ‌\nin‌ ‌its‌ ‌final‌ ‌form;‌ ‌therefore‌ ‌it‌ ‌must‌ ‌have‌ ‌evolved‌ ‌from‌ ‌earlier‌ ‌pre-linguistic‌ ‌systems‌ ‌among‌ ‌humans'‌ ‌primate‌ ‌ancestors.‌ ‌\n●\"‌Discontinuity‌ ‌theories‌\"‌ ‌take‌ ‌the‌ ‌opposite‌ ‌approach,‌ ‌that‌ ‌language,‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌unique‌ ‌trait‌ ‌which‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌be‌ ‌compared‌ ‌to‌ ‌anything‌ ‌found‌ ‌among‌ ‌\nnon-humans,‌ ‌must‌ ‌have‌ ‌appeared‌ ‌fairly‌ ‌suddenly‌ ‌during‌ ‌the‌ ‌course‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌evolution.‌ ‌\n●Some‌ ‌theories‌ ‌consider‌ ‌language‌ ‌mostly‌ ‌as‌ ‌an‌ ‌innate‌ ‌faculty,‌ ‌largely‌ ‌genetically‌ ‌encoded.‌ ‌\n●Other‌ ‌theories‌ ‌regard‌ ‌language‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌mainly‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌system,‌ ‌learned‌ ‌through‌ ‌social‌ ‌interaction.‌ ‌\nPresently,‌ ‌A‌ ‌majority‌ ‌of‌ ‌linguistic‌ ‌scholars‌ ‌believe‌ ‌‌continuity-based‌ ‌theories‌,‌ ‌but‌ ‌they‌ ‌vary‌ ‌in‌ ‌how‌ ‌they‌ ‌hypothesize‌ ‌language‌ ‌development.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nSome‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌theories/hypothesis‌ ‌concerning‌ ‌the‌ ‌origin‌ ‌of‌ ‌language:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Gestural‌ ‌theory‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌gestural‌ ‌theory‌ ‌states‌ ‌that‌ ‌human‌ ‌language‌ ‌developed‌ ‌from‌ ‌gestures‌ ‌that‌ ‌were‌ ‌used‌ ‌for‌ ‌simple‌ ‌communication.‌ ‌\n○Two‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌support‌ ‌this‌ ‌theory.‌ ‌\n■Gestural‌ ‌language‌ ‌and‌ ‌vocal‌ ‌language‌ ‌depend‌ ‌on‌ ‌similar‌ ‌neural‌ ‌systems.‌ ‌The‌ ‌regions‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌cortex‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌responsible‌ ‌for‌ ‌\nmouth‌ ‌and‌ ‌hand‌ ‌movements‌ ‌border‌ ‌each‌ ‌other.‌ ‌\n■Nonhuman‌ ‌primates‌ ‌can‌ ‌use‌ ‌gestures‌ ‌or‌ ‌symbols‌ ‌for‌ ‌at‌ ‌least‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌communication,‌ ‌and‌ ‌some‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌gestures‌ ‌resemble‌ ‌\nthose‌ ‌of‌ ‌humans,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌\"begging‌ ‌posture\",‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌hands‌ ‌stretched‌ ‌out,‌ ‌which‌ ‌humans‌ ‌share‌ ‌with‌ ‌chimpanzees.‌ ‌\n719‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Divine‌ ‌Creation‌ ‌Hypothesis‌ ‌\n○Many‌ ‌societies‌ ‌throughout‌ ‌history‌ ‌believed‌ ‌that‌ ‌language‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌gift‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌gods‌ ‌to‌ ‌humans.‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌belief‌ ‌predicates‌ ‌that‌ ‌humans‌ ‌were‌ ‌created‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌start‌ ‌with‌ ‌an‌ ‌innate‌ ‌capacity‌ ‌to‌ ‌use‌ ‌language.‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌impossible‌ ‌to‌ ‌prove‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌anatomically‌ ‌modern‌ ‌humans‌ ‌possessed‌ ‌creative‌ ‌language.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌impossible‌ ‌to‌ ‌disprove‌ ‌the‌ ‌hypothesis‌ ‌that‌ ‌primitive‌ ‌languages‌ ‌might‌ ‌have‌ ‌existed‌ ‌at‌ ‌some‌ ‌point‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌distant‌ ‌past‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nHomo‌ ‌sapiens‌ ‌development.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Natural‌ ‌Evolution‌ ‌Hypothesis‌ ‌\n○According‌ ‌to‌ ‌this,‌ ‌at‌ ‌some‌ ‌point‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌development,‌ ‌humans‌ ‌acquired‌ ‌a‌ ‌more‌ ‌\nsophisticated‌ ‌brain‌ ‌which‌ ‌made‌ ‌language‌ ‌invention‌ ‌and‌ ‌learning‌ ‌possible.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌simple‌ ‌vocalizations‌ ‌and‌ ‌gestures‌ ‌inherited‌ ‌from‌ ‌our‌ ‌primate‌ ‌ancestors‌ ‌then‌ ‌gave‌ ‌way‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌creative‌ ‌system‌ ‌of‌ ‌language.‌ ‌\n ‌\nIn‌ ‌1861,‌ ‌historical‌ ‌linguist‌ ‌Max‌ ‌Müller‌ ‌published‌ ‌a‌ ‌list‌ ‌of‌ ‌speculative‌ ‌theories‌ ‌concerning‌ ‌the‌ ‌origins‌ ‌of‌ ‌spoken‌ ‌language‌ ‌\n ‌\nA.‌ ‌IMITATION‌ ‌HYPOTHESIS‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌believes‌ ‌that‌ ‌language‌ ‌began‌ ‌through‌ ‌some‌ ‌sort‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌mimicry‌ ‌of‌ ‌natural‌ ‌occurring‌ ‌sounds‌ ‌or‌ ‌movements.‌ ‌Some‌ ‌of‌ ‌them‌ ‌are:‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌DING-DONG‌ ‌HYPOTHESIS‌ ‌\n720‌ ‌\n■Müller‌ ‌suggested‌ ‌what‌ ‌he‌ ‌called‌ ‌the‌ ‌ding-dong‌ ‌theory,‌ ‌which‌ ‌states‌ ‌that‌ ‌language‌ ‌began‌ ‌when‌ ‌humans‌ ‌started‌ ‌naming‌ ‌\nobjects,‌ ‌actions‌ ‌and‌ ‌phenomena‌ ‌after‌ ‌a‌ ‌recognizable‌ ‌sound‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌it‌ ‌in‌ ‌real‌ ‌life.‌ ‌eg.‌ ‌boom‌ ‌for‌ ‌explosions,‌ ‌crash‌ ‌for‌ ‌\nthunder.‌ ‌\n ‌\n○The‌ ‌POOH-POOH‌ ‌HYPOTHESIS‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌pooh-pooh‌ ‌theory‌ ‌saw‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌words‌ ‌as‌ ‌emotional‌ ‌interjections‌ ‌and‌ ‌exclamations‌ ‌triggered‌ ‌by‌ ‌pain,‌ ‌pleasure,‌ ‌surprise,‌ ‌\netc.‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌holds‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌words‌ ‌came‌ ‌from‌ ‌involuntary‌ ‌exclamations‌ ‌of‌ ‌dislike,‌ ‌hunger,‌ ‌pain‌ ‌or‌ ‌pleasure,‌ ‌eventually‌ ‌leading‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nexpression‌ ‌of‌ ‌more‌ ‌developed‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌and‌ ‌emotions.‌ ‌eg.‌ ‌ha-ha-ha,‌ ‌wa-wa-wa‌ ‌\n ‌\n○The‌ ‌BOW-BOW‌ ‌HYPOTHESIS‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌bow-wow‌ ‌or‌ ‌cuckoo‌ ‌theory,‌ ‌which‌ ‌Müller‌ ‌attributed‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌German‌ ‌philosopher‌ ‌Johann‌ ‌Gottfried‌ ‌Herder,‌ ‌saw‌ ‌early‌ ‌words‌ ‌\nas‌ ‌imitations‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌cries‌ ‌of‌ ‌beasts‌ ‌and‌ ‌birds.‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌holds‌ ‌that‌ ‌vocabulary‌ ‌developed‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌imitations‌ ‌of‌ ‌animal‌ ‌noises‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌Moo,‌ ‌hiss,‌ ‌meow,‌ ‌quack-quack‌ ‌etc‌ ‌\n ‌\n○TA-TA‌ ‌HYPOTHESIS‌ ‌ ‌\n■This‌ ‌did‌ ‌not‌ ‌feature‌ ‌in‌ ‌Max‌ ‌Müller's‌ ‌list,‌ ‌having‌ ‌been‌ ‌proposed‌ ‌in‌ ‌1930‌ ‌by‌ ‌Sir‌ ‌Richard‌ ‌Paget.‌ ‌\n■According‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌ta-ta‌ ‌theory,‌ ‌humans‌ ‌made‌ ‌the‌ ‌earliest‌ ‌words‌ ‌by‌ ‌tongue‌ ‌movements‌ ‌that‌ ‌mimicked‌ ‌manual‌ ‌gestures,‌ ‌\nrendering‌ ‌them‌ ‌audible.‌ ‌i.e.‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌words‌ ‌were‌ ‌lip‌ ‌icons‌ ‌of‌ ‌hand‌ ‌gestures‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nB.‌ ‌The‌ ‌NECESSITY‌ ‌HYPOTHESES‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌believes‌ ‌that‌ ‌language‌ ‌began‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌response‌ ‌to‌ ‌some‌ ‌acute‌ ‌necessity‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌community.‌ ‌Some‌ ‌of‌ ‌them‌ ‌are:‌ ‌\n○WARNING‌ ‌HYPOTHESIS‌ ‌\n■Language‌ ‌may‌ ‌have‌ ‌evolved‌ ‌from‌ ‌warning‌ ‌signals‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌those‌ ‌used‌ ‌by‌ ‌\n■animals.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Such‌ ‌as‌ ‌look‌ ‌out,‌ ‌run,‌ ‌help‌ ‌etc‌ ‌to‌ ‌alert‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌tribe‌ ‌when‌ ‌some‌ ‌beast‌ ‌was‌ ‌approaching.‌ ‌\n■This‌ ‌did‌ ‌not‌ ‌feature‌ ‌in‌ ‌Max‌ ‌Müller's‌ ‌list‌ ‌\n ‌\n○YO-HE-HO‌ ‌HYPOTHESIS‌ ‌\n■Language‌ ‌developed‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌cooperative‌ ‌efforts.‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌earliest‌ ‌language‌ ‌was‌ ‌chanting‌ ‌to‌ ‌simulate‌ ‌collective‌ ‌effort‌ ‌like‌ ‌moving‌ ‌great‌ ‌stones‌ ‌to‌ ‌block‌ ‌off‌ ‌cave‌ ‌entrances,‌ ‌\nrepeating‌ ‌warlike‌ ‌phrases‌ ‌to‌ ‌inflame‌ ‌the‌ ‌fighting‌ ‌spirit‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n ‌\n○THE‌ ‌LYING‌ ‌HYPOTHESIS‌ ‌\n721‌ ‌\n■Since‌ ‌all‌ ‌real‌ ‌intentions‌ ‌or‌ ‌emotions‌ ‌get‌ ‌involuntarily‌ ‌expressed‌ ‌by‌ ‌gesture,‌ ‌look‌ ‌or‌ ‌sound,‌ ‌voluntary‌ ‌communication‌ ‌must‌ ‌\nhave‌ ‌been‌ ‌invented‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌purpose‌ ‌of‌ ‌lying‌ ‌or‌ ‌deceiving.‌ ‌\n■This‌ ‌did‌ ‌not‌ ‌feature‌ ‌in‌ ‌Max‌ ‌Müller's‌ ‌list‌ ‌\n ‌\nRelevance‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌theories:‌ ‌\n●Most‌ ‌scholars‌ ‌today‌ ‌consider‌ ‌all‌ ‌such‌ ‌theories‌ ‌not‌ ‌so‌ ‌much‌ ‌wrong—they‌ ‌occasionally‌ ‌offer‌ ‌peripheral‌ ‌insights—as‌ ‌naïve‌ ‌and‌ ‌irrelevant.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌problem‌ ‌with‌ ‌these‌ ‌theories‌ ‌is‌ ‌that‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌so‌ ‌narrowly‌ ‌mechanistic.‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌assume‌ ‌that‌ ‌once‌ ‌human‌ ‌ancestors‌ ‌had‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌the‌ ‌appropriate‌ ‌ingenious‌ ‌mechanism‌ ‌for‌ ‌linking‌ ‌sounds‌ ‌with‌ ‌meanings,‌ ‌language‌ ‌\nautomatically‌ ‌evolved‌ ‌and‌ ‌changed.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nValue‌ ‌Addition‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nStructural‌ ‌Linguistics‌ ‌\n●Descriptive‌ ‌Linguistics‌ ‌or‌ ‌Structural‌ ‌Linguistics‌ ‌studies‌ ‌about‌ ‌such‌ ‌languages‌ ‌and‌ ‌analyses‌ ‌their‌ ‌\n●features.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌this‌ ‌task,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌important‌ ‌to‌ ‌differentiate‌ ‌a‌ ‌language‌ ‌from‌ ‌another‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌its‌ ‌rules‌ ‌and‌ ‌properties.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌done‌ ‌either‌ ‌by‌ ‌distinguishing‌ ‌the‌ ‌sounds‌ ‌used‌ ‌in‌ ‌them‌ ‌or‌ ‌by‌ ‌analysing‌ ‌the‌ ‌symbols‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌express‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌sound.‌ ‌\nProperties‌ ‌of‌ ‌Language‌ ‌\n●Phonemes‌ ‌\n○Every‌ ‌human‌ ‌language‌ ‌has‌ ‌between‌ ‌12‌ ‌to‌ ‌60‌ ‌sound‌ ‌(phone)‌ ‌units.‌ ‌These‌ ‌sound‌ ‌units‌ ‌are‌ ‌called‌ ‌Phonemes.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌term‌ ‌is‌ ‌derived‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌Greek‌ ‌word‌ ‌‘phone’‌ ‌means‌ ‌sound.‌ ‌Thus,‌ ‌the‌ ‌sound‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌language‌ ‌is‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌its‌ ‌features.‌ ‌\nPhoneme‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌unit‌ ‌of‌ ‌sound‌ ‌that‌ ‌distinguishes‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌language.‌ ‌ ‌\n○‘English’‌ ‌has‌ ‌26‌ ‌letters‌ ‌but‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌40‌ ‌significant‌ ‌sounds,‌ ‌the‌ ‌multiple‌ ‌combinations‌ ‌of‌ ‌which‌ ‌can‌ ‌change‌ ‌the‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌word.‌ ‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌example‌ ‌in‌ ‌English,‌ ‌the‌ ‌difference‌ ‌between‌ ‌‘bit’‌ ‌and‌ ‌‘pit’‌ ‌is‌ ‌distinguished‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌sound‌ ‌difference‌ ‌or‌ ‌phonemic‌ ‌difference‌ ‌\nbetween‌ ‌/b/‌ ‌and‌ ‌/p/,‌ ‌and‌ ‌thereby‌ ‌brings‌ ‌out‌ ‌a‌ ‌change‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌meaning.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌sound‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌in‌ ‌language‌ ‌is‌ ‌done‌ ‌under‌ ‌a‌ ‌branch‌ ‌of‌ ‌study‌ ‌called‌ ‌Phonetics/Phonology.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌systematic‌ ‌identification‌ ‌and‌ ‌description‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌distinctive‌ ‌sounds‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌language.‌ ‌\n●Morpheme‌ ‌\n○Usually,‌ ‌the‌ ‌phonemes‌ ‌are‌ ‌combined‌ ‌with‌ ‌other‌ ‌phonemes‌ ‌to‌ ‌form‌ ‌a‌ ‌meaningful‌ ‌set‌ ‌of‌ ‌sounds.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Often,‌ ‌these‌ ‌meaningful‌ ‌sets‌ ‌of‌ ‌sounds‌ ‌make‌ ‌up‌ ‌what‌ ‌we‌ ‌call‌ ‌words.‌ ‌Words‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌composed‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌smaller‌ ‌meaningful‌ ‌\nunits.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌combination‌ ‌of‌ ‌meaningful‌ ‌sounds‌ ‌is‌ ‌called‌ ‌Morpheme.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Thus,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌arrangement‌ ‌of‌ ‌phonemes‌ ‌that‌ ‌makes‌ ‌a‌ ‌morpheme.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌Morphology‌ ‌that‌ ‌studies‌ ‌the‌ ‌morphemes‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌language.‌ ‌People‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌usually‌ ‌pause‌ ‌between‌ ‌words‌ ‌when‌ ‌they‌ ‌speak.‌ ‌ ‌\n○If‌ ‌we‌ ‌did‌ ‌not‌ ‌know‌ ‌our‌ ‌language,‌ ‌a‌ ‌sentence‌ ‌would‌ ‌seem‌ ‌like‌ ‌a‌ ‌continuous‌ ‌stream‌ ‌of‌ ‌sounds.‌ ‌ ‌\n○We‌ ‌separate‌ ‌one‌ ‌word‌ ‌from‌ ‌another‌ ‌only‌ ‌when‌ ‌we‌ ‌write‌ ‌it.‌ ‌A‌ ‌word‌ ‌is‌ ‌only‌ ‌an‌ ‌arbitrary‌ ‌sequence‌ ‌of‌ ‌sounds‌ ‌that‌ ‌has‌ ‌a‌ ‌meaning.‌ ‌ ‌\n722‌ ‌\n○We‌ ‌would‌ ‌not‌ ‌‘hear’‌ ‌words‌ ‌as‌ ‌separate‌ ‌units,‌ ‌if‌ ‌we‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌know‌ ‌the‌ ‌particular‌ ‌language.‌ ‌\n○Just‌ ‌as‌ ‌phoneme‌ ‌may‌ ‌have‌ ‌one‌ ‌or‌ ‌more‌ ‌phones‌ ‌(sounds),‌ ‌one‌ ‌or‌ ‌more‌ ‌morphs‌ ‌\n○(smallest‌ ‌unit‌ ‌of‌ ‌language‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌meaning)‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌may‌ ‌make‌ ‌up‌ ‌a‌ ‌morpheme.‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌example‌ ‌the‌ ‌prefix‌ ‌‘in’‌ ‌as‌ ‌in‌ ‌‘indefinite’‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌prefix‌ ‌‘un’‌ ‌in‌ ‌‘unclear’‌ ‌are‌ ‌morphs‌ ‌that‌ ‌belong‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌morpheme‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌‘not’.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Although‌ ‌some‌ ‌words‌ ‌are‌ ‌single‌ ‌morphemes,many‌ ‌words‌ ‌are‌ ‌built‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌combination‌ ‌of‌ ‌morphemes.‌ ‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌example‌ ‌‘cow’‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌word‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌single‌ ‌morpheme‌ ‌but‌ ‌the‌ ‌word‌ ‌‘cows’‌ ‌contains‌ ‌two‌ ‌meaningful‌ ‌units.‌ ‌A‌ ‌root‌ ‌–‌ ‌cow‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌suffix‌ ‌\n‘s’‌ ‌pronounced‌ ‌‘z’‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌one.‌ ‌\n●Syntax‌ ‌\n○As‌ ‌language‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌open‌ ‌system,‌ ‌we‌ ‌can‌ ‌make‌ ‌meaningful‌ ‌sounds‌ ‌that‌ ‌we‌ ‌heard‌ ‌earlier.‌ ‌\n○But‌ ‌in‌ ‌every‌ ‌language‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌certain‌ ‌rules‌ ‌for‌ ‌making‌ ‌phrases‌ ‌and‌ ‌sentences.‌ ‌\n○These‌ ‌rules‌ ‌are‌ ‌termed‌ ‌syntax.‌ ‌These‌ ‌rules‌ ‌determine‌ ‌whether‌ ‌a‌ ‌subject‌ ‌is‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌before‌ ‌or‌ ‌after‌ ‌a‌ ‌verb‌ ‌or‌ ‌an‌ ‌object‌ ‌follows‌ ‌a‌ ‌verb‌ ‌\netc.‌ ‌ ‌\n○We‌ ‌generally‌ ‌learn‌ ‌these‌ ‌rules‌ ‌from‌ ‌schools.‌ ‌But‌ ‌children‌ ‌know‌ ‌many‌ ‌of‌ ‌them‌ ‌before‌ ‌going‌ ‌to‌ ‌school.‌ ‌\n●Semantics‌ ‌\n○Semantics‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌meanings‌ ‌of‌ ‌symbols,‌ ‌words,‌ ‌phrases‌ ‌and‌ ‌sentences‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌language.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Linguistic‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌focus‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌of‌ ‌language‌ ‌as‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌beliefs‌ ‌and‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌of‌ ‌thoughts‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Separate‌ ‌area‌ ‌has‌ ‌evolved‌ ‌to‌ ‌study‌ ‌about‌ ‌meanings‌ ‌of‌ ‌concepts‌ ‌and‌ ‌terms,‌ ‌like‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌terms‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌phenomena.‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌special‌ ‌field‌ ‌is‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌Ethno-Semantics.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Ethno-semantics‌ ‌is‌ ‌very‌ ‌much‌ ‌related‌ ‌to,‌ ‌if‌ ‌not‌ ‌similar‌ ‌to‌ ‌Cognitive‌ ‌Anthropology.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n7.‌ ‌Culture,‌ ‌Language‌ ‌and‌ ‌Communication‌ ‌:‌ ‌Nature,‌ ‌origin‌ ‌and‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌language;‌ ‌verbal‌ ‌and‌ ‌non-verbal‌ ‌communication;‌ ‌social‌ ‌\ncontext‌ ‌of‌ ‌language‌ ‌use-Part-II‌ ‌\n ‌\nVerbal‌ ‌and‌ ‌non-verbal‌ ‌communication;‌ ‌\n ‌\nIntroduction‌ ‌\n●Speech‌ ‌&‌ ‌writing‌ ‌are‌ ‌indeed‌ ‌the‌ ‌fundamental‌ ‌faculties‌ ‌of‌ ‌language.‌ ‌\n●But,‌ ‌when‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌speak,‌ ‌they‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌normally‌ ‌confine‌ ‌themselves‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌mere‌ ‌emission‌ ‌of‌ ‌speech‌ ‌sounds.‌ ‌\n723‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌great‌ ‌deal‌ ‌of‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌is‌ ‌expressed‌ ‌through‌ ‌facial‌ ‌expression,‌ ‌tone‌ ‌of‌ ‌voice,‌ ‌movement‌ ‌and‌ ‌postures‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌body‌ ‌etc,‌ ‌collectively‌ ‌called‌ ‌\ngestures‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌contribution‌ ‌of‌ ‌bodily‌ ‌gestures‌ ‌is‌ ‌in‌ ‌part‌ ‌culturally‌ ‌determined‌ ‌and‌ ‌hence‌ ‌vary‌ ‌from‌ ‌society‌ ‌to‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n ‌\nVerbal‌ ‌Communication‌ ‌\n●Verbal‌ ‌communication‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌sharing‌ ‌of‌ ‌information‌ ‌between‌ ‌two‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌using‌ ‌words.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌auditory‌ ‌language‌ ‌to‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌information‌ ‌with‌ ‌other‌ ‌people.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌includes‌ ‌sounds,‌ ‌words,‌ ‌or‌ ‌speaking.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌tone,‌ ‌volume,‌ ‌and‌ ‌pitch‌ ‌of‌ ‌one's‌ ‌voice‌ ‌can‌ ‌all‌ ‌contribute‌ ‌to‌ ‌effective‌ ‌verbal‌ ‌communication.‌ ‌\n ‌\nTypes:‌ ‌\n●Formal‌ ‌versus‌ ‌Informal:‌ ‌ ‌\n○We‌ ‌use‌ ‌spoken‌ ‌communication‌ ‌informally‌ ‌while‌ ‌we‌ ‌use‌ ‌written‌ ‌communication‌ ‌formally.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Synchronous‌ ‌versus‌ ‌Asynchronous:‌ ‌ ‌\n○Synchronous‌ ‌communication‌‌ ‌is‌ ‌communication‌ ‌that‌ ‌takes‌ ‌place‌ ‌in‌ ‌real‌ ‌time,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌conversation‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌friend.‌ ‌ ‌\n724‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌contrast,‌ ‌‌asynchronous‌ ‌communication‌ ‌is‌ ‌communication‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌immediate‌ ‌and‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌over‌ ‌longer‌ ‌periods‌ ‌of‌ ‌time,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌\nletters,‌ ‌email,‌ ‌or‌ ‌even‌ ‌text‌ ‌messages.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Recorded‌ ‌versus‌ ‌Unrecorded:‌ ‌ ‌\n○Written‌ ‌communication‌ ‌is‌ ‌generally‌ ‌archived‌ ‌and‌ ‌recorded‌ ‌for‌ ‌later‌ ‌retrieval‌ ‌while‌ ‌spoken‌ ‌communication‌ ‌is‌ ‌generally‌ ‌not‌ ‌recorded.‌ ‌\n725‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nNonverbal‌ ‌Communication‌ ‌\n●Non-verbal‌ ‌communication‌ ‌is‌ ‌communication‌ ‌between‌ ‌people‌ ‌through‌ ‌non-verbal‌ ‌or‌ ‌visual‌ ‌cues.‌ ‌This‌ ‌includes‌ ‌gestures,‌ ‌facial‌ ‌expressions,‌ ‌\nbody‌ ‌movement,‌ ‌timing,‌ ‌touch,‌ ‌and‌ ‌anything‌ ‌else‌ ‌that‌ ‌communicates‌ ‌without‌ ‌speaking.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n●This‌ ‌includes:‌ ‌\n○Body‌ ‌language‌ ‌(Kinesics),‌ ‌ ‌\n○Distance‌ ‌between‌ ‌people‌ ‌(Proxemics)‌ ‌\n○Voice‌ ‌quality‌ ‌(Paralingual)‌ ‌\n○Touch‌ ‌(Haptics)‌ ‌\n○Time‌ ‌(Chronemics)‌ ‌\n726‌ ‌\n○Clothing‌ ‌&‌ ‌Appearance‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○Body‌ ‌language‌ ‌(Kinesics)‌ ‌\n■Facial‌ ‌expressions.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌human‌ ‌face‌ ‌is‌ ‌extremely‌ ‌expressive,‌ ‌able‌ ‌to‌ ‌convey‌ ‌countless‌ ‌emotions‌ ‌without‌ ‌saying‌ ‌a‌ ‌word.‌ ‌Facial‌ ‌\nexpressions‌ ‌are‌ ‌universal.‌ ‌The‌ ‌facial‌ ‌expressions‌ ‌for‌ ‌happiness,‌ ‌sadness,‌ ‌anger,‌ ‌surprise,‌ ‌fear,‌ ‌and‌ ‌disgust‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nsame‌ ‌across‌ ‌cultures.‌ ‌\n■Body‌ ‌movement‌ ‌and‌ ‌posture.‌ ‌ ‌\n727‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌nonverbal‌ ‌communication‌ ‌includes‌ ‌your‌ ‌posture,‌ ‌bearing,‌ ‌stance,‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌subtle‌ ‌movements‌ ‌you‌ ‌make.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n■Gestures.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Gestures‌ ‌are‌ ‌woven‌ ‌into‌ ‌the‌ ‌fabric‌ ‌of‌ ‌our‌ ‌daily‌ ‌lives.‌ ‌Like‌ ‌wave,‌ ‌point,‌ ‌beckon,‌ ‌or‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌hands.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌of‌ ‌some‌ ‌gestures‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌very‌ ‌different‌ ‌across‌ ‌cultures.‌ ‌ ‌\n●While‌ ‌the‌ ‌OK‌ ‌sign‌ ‌made‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌hand,‌ ‌for‌ ‌example,‌ ‌conveys‌ ‌a‌ ‌positive‌ ‌message‌ ‌in‌ ‌English-speaking‌ ‌countries,‌ ‌it's‌ ‌\nconsidered‌ ‌offensive‌ ‌in‌ ‌countries‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌Germany,‌ ‌Russia,‌ ‌and‌ ‌Brazil.‌ ‌\n■Eye‌ ‌contact.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Since‌ ‌the‌ ‌visual‌ ‌sense‌ ‌is‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌for‌ ‌most‌ ‌people,‌ ‌eye‌ ‌contact‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌especially‌ ‌important‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌nonverbal‌ ‌\ncommunication.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌communicates‌ ‌interest,‌ ‌affection,‌ ‌hostility,‌ ‌or‌ ‌attraction.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Eye‌ ‌contact‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌important‌ ‌in‌ ‌maintaining‌ ‌the‌ ‌flow‌ ‌of‌ ‌conversation‌ ‌and‌ ‌for‌ ‌gauging‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌person's‌ ‌interest‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nresponse.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○Distance‌ ‌between‌ ‌people‌ ‌(proxemics)‌ ‌\n■Space‌ ‌ ‌\n●Physical‌ ‌space‌ ‌is‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌communicate‌ ‌many‌ ‌different‌ ‌nonverbal‌ ‌messages,‌ ‌including‌ ‌signals‌ ‌of‌ ‌intimacy‌ ‌and‌ ‌\naffection,‌ ‌aggression‌ ‌or‌ ‌dominance.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Need‌ ‌for‌ ‌physical‌ ‌space‌ ‌differs‌ ‌depending‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌culture,‌ ‌the‌ ‌situation,‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌closeness‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌relationship.‌ ‌\n728‌ ‌\n●Introduced‌ ‌by‌ ‌anthropologist‌ ‌Edward‌ ‌T.‌ ‌Hall‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌1960s,‌ ‌the‌ ‌theory‌ ‌emerged‌ ‌from‌ ‌studies‌ ‌of‌ ‌animal‌ ‌behavior‌ ‌\nconducted‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌19th‌ ‌and‌ ‌early‌ ‌20th‌ ‌centuries.‌ ‌\n ‌\n■Proximity:‌ ‌ ‌\n●Closeness‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌audience‌ ‌sends‌ ‌a‌ ‌nonverbal‌ ‌message.‌ ‌a‌ ‌very‌ ‌small‌ ‌distance‌ ‌may‌ ‌mean‌ ‌threatening‌ ‌communication.‌ ‌ ‌\n●On‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌hand,‌ ‌too‌ ‌much‌ ‌space‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌awkward‌ ‌nonverbal‌ ‌communication‌ ‌that‌ ‌might‌ ‌confuse‌ ‌the‌ ‌listener.‌ ‌\n ‌\n○Voice‌ ‌quality‌ ‌(paralanguage)‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌includes‌ ‌timing‌ ‌and‌ ‌pace,‌ ‌loudness,‌ ‌tone‌ ‌and‌ ‌inflection,‌ ‌and‌ ‌sounds‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌\"ahh\"‌ ‌and‌ ‌\"uh-huh.\"‌ ‌Tone‌ ‌of‌ ‌voice‌ ‌can‌ ‌indicate‌ ‌\nsarcasm,‌ ‌anger,‌ ‌affection,‌ ‌or‌ ‌confidence.‌ ‌\n ‌\n○Touch‌ ‌(haptics)‌ ‌\n■We‌ ‌communicate‌ ‌a‌ ‌great‌ ‌deal‌ ‌through‌ ‌touch.‌ ‌For‌ ‌example-‌ ‌weak‌ ‌handshake,‌ ‌a‌ ‌warm‌ ‌bear‌ ‌hug,‌ ‌a‌ ‌patronizing‌ ‌pat‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nhead,‌ ‌or‌ ‌a‌ ‌controlling‌ ‌grip‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌arm.‌ ‌\n●Time‌ ‌(Chronemics)‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌way‌ ‌that‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌would‌ ‌perceive‌ ‌and‌ ‌value‌ ‌time,‌ ‌structure‌ ‌our‌ ‌time‌ ‌and‌ ‌react‌ ‌to‌ ‌time‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌powerful‌ ‌communication‌ ‌\ntool,‌ ‌and‌ ‌helps‌ ‌set‌ ‌the‌ ‌stage‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌communication‌ ‌process.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Across‌ ‌cultures,‌ ‌time‌ ‌perception‌ ‌plays‌ ‌a‌ ‌large‌ ‌role‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌nonverbal‌ ‌communication‌ ‌process.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Time‌ ‌perceptions‌ ‌include‌ ‌punctuality,‌ ‌willingness‌ ‌to‌ ‌wait,‌ ‌and‌ ‌interactions.‌ ‌The‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌time‌ ‌can‌ ‌affect‌ ‌lifestyles,‌ ‌daily‌ ‌agendas,‌ ‌\nspeed‌ ‌of‌ ‌speech,‌ ‌movements‌ ‌and‌ ‌how‌ ‌long‌ ‌people‌ ‌are‌ ‌willing‌ ‌to‌ ‌listen.‌ ‌ ‌\n729‌ ‌\n■Time‌ ‌can‌ ‌also‌ ‌be‌ ‌used‌ ‌as‌ ‌an‌ ‌indicator‌ ‌of‌ ‌status.‌ ‌ ‌\n■For‌ ‌example‌,‌ ‌in‌ ‌most‌ ‌companies‌ ‌the‌ ‌boss‌ ‌can‌ ‌interrupt‌ ‌progress‌ ‌to‌ ‌hold‌ ‌an‌ ‌impromptu‌ ‌meeting‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌middle‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌work‌ ‌day,‌ ‌\nyet‌ ‌the‌ ‌average‌ ‌worker‌ ‌would‌ ‌have‌ ‌to‌ ‌make‌ ‌an‌ ‌appointment‌ ‌to‌ ‌see‌ ‌the‌ ‌boss.‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌way‌ ‌different‌ ‌cultures‌ ‌perceive‌ ‌time‌ ‌can‌ ‌influence‌ ‌communication‌ ‌as‌ ‌well.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Cultures‌ ‌are‌ ‌usually‌ ‌put‌ ‌into‌ ‌two‌ ‌time‌ ‌system‌ ‌categories:‌ ‌ ‌\n●Monochronic‌ ‌and‌ ‌ ‌\n●Polychronic.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Clothing‌ ‌&‌ ‌Appearance:‌ ‌ ‌\n○Clothing,‌ ‌hair,‌ ‌and‌ ‌jewelry‌ ‌are‌ ‌also‌ ‌a‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌nonverbal‌ ‌communication.‌ ‌The‌ ‌quality‌ ‌and‌ ‌condition‌ ‌of‌ ‌clothing,‌ ‌hair,‌ ‌and‌ ‌jewelry‌ ‌-all‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nthese‌ ‌things‌ ‌speak‌ ‌nonverbally.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nCharacteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌non-verbal‌ ‌communication‌ ‌\n●Non-verbal‌ ‌communication‌ ‌is‌ ‌any‌ ‌information‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌communicated‌ ‌without‌ ‌using‌ ‌words.‌ ‌The‌ ‌important‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌non-verbal‌ ‌\ncommunication‌ ‌are‌ ‌as‌ ‌follows:‌ ‌\n●No‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌words:‌ ‌ ‌\n●Non-verbal‌ ‌communication‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌communication‌ ‌without‌ ‌words‌ ‌or‌ ‌language‌ ‌like‌ ‌oral‌ ‌or‌ ‌written‌ ‌communication.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌uses‌ ‌gestures,‌ ‌facial‌ ‌expressions,‌ ‌eye‌ ‌contact,‌ ‌physical‌ ‌proximity,‌ ‌touching,‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌for‌ ‌communicating‌ ‌with‌ ‌others.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Culturally‌ ‌determined:‌ ‌ ‌\n●Non-verbal‌ ‌communication‌ ‌is‌ ‌learned‌ ‌in‌ ‌childhood,‌ ‌passed‌ ‌on‌ ‌to‌ ‌you‌ ‌by‌ ‌your‌ ‌parents‌ ‌and‌ ‌others‌ ‌with‌ ‌whom‌ ‌you‌ ‌associate.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Through‌ ‌this‌ ‌process‌ ‌of‌ ‌growing‌ ‌up‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌society,‌ ‌you‌ ‌adopt‌ ‌the‌ ‌taints‌ ‌and‌ ‌mannerisms‌ ‌of‌ ‌your‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌group.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Different‌ ‌meaning:‌ ‌ ‌\n730‌ ‌\n●Non-verbal‌ ‌symbols‌ ‌can‌ ‌have‌ ‌many‌ ‌meanings.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Cross-culture‌ ‌aspects‌ ‌give‌ ‌various‌ ‌meanings‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌expression‌ ‌in‌ ‌respect‌ ‌of‌ ‌non-verbal‌ ‌communication.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Vague‌ ‌and‌ ‌imprecise:‌ ‌ ‌\n●Non-verbal‌ ‌communication‌ ‌is‌ ‌quite‌ ‌vague‌ ‌and‌ ‌imprecise.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Since‌ ‌in‌ ‌this‌ ‌communication,‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌words‌ ‌or‌ ‌language‌ ‌which‌ ‌expresses‌ ‌clear‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌receiver.‌ ‌\n●May‌ ‌conflict‌ ‌with‌ ‌verbal‌ ‌message:‌ ‌ ‌\n●Non-verbal‌ ‌communication‌ ‌is‌ ‌so‌ ‌deeply‌ ‌rooted,‌ ‌so‌ ‌unconscious,‌ ‌that‌ ‌you‌ ‌can‌ ‌express‌ ‌a‌ ‌verbal‌ ‌message‌ ‌and‌ ‌then‌ ‌directly‌ ‌contradict‌ ‌\nit‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌nonverbal‌ ‌message.‌ ‌\n●Largely‌ ‌unconscious:‌ ‌ ‌\n●Non-verbal‌ ‌communication‌ ‌is‌ ‌unconscious‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌sense‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌usually‌ ‌not‌ ‌planned‌ ‌nor‌ ‌rehearsed.‌ ‌It‌ ‌comes‌ ‌almost‌ ‌instantaneously.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Shows‌ ‌feelings‌ ‌and‌ ‌attitudes:‌ ‌ ‌\n●Facial‌ ‌expressions,‌ ‌gestures,‌ ‌body‌ ‌movements,‌ ‌the‌ ‌way‌ ‌you‌ ‌use‌ ‌your‌ ‌eyes‌ ‌-‌ ‌all‌ ‌communicate‌ ‌your‌ ‌feelings‌ ‌and‌ ‌emotions‌ ‌to‌ ‌others.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Informality:‌ ‌ ‌\n●Nonverbal‌ ‌communication‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌follow‌ ‌any‌ ‌rules,‌ ‌formality‌ ‌or‌ ‌structure‌ ‌like‌ ‌other‌ ‌communication.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Most‌ ‌cases‌ ‌people‌ ‌unconsciously‌ ‌and‌ ‌habitually‌ ‌engage‌ ‌in‌ ‌non-verbal‌ ‌communication‌ ‌by‌ ‌moving‌ ‌the‌ ‌various‌ ‌parts‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌body.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nSocial‌ ‌context‌ ‌of‌ ‌language‌ ‌use‌ ‌\nIntroduction:‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌‌Pier‌ ‌Paolo‌ ‌Giglioli‌ ‌in‌ ‌“Language‌ ‌and‌ ‌Social‌ ‌Context,”‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌study‌ ‌the‌ ‌relation‌ ‌between‌ ‌worldviews,‌ ‌grammatical‌ ‌\ncategories‌ ‌and‌ ‌semantic‌ ‌fields,‌ ‌the‌ ‌influence‌ ‌of‌ ‌speech‌ ‌on‌ ‌socialization‌ ‌and‌ ‌personal‌ ‌relationships,‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌interaction‌ ‌of‌ ‌linguistic‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌\ncommunities.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌this‌ ‌case,‌ ‌linguistic‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌closely‌ ‌studies‌ ‌those‌ ‌societies‌ ‌where‌ ‌language‌ ‌defines‌ ‌a‌ ‌culture‌ ‌or‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌example‌,‌ ‌in‌ ‌New‌ ‌Guinea,‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌tribe‌ ‌of‌ ‌indigenous‌ ‌people‌ ‌who‌ ‌speak‌ ‌one‌ ‌language.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌what‌ ‌makes‌ ‌those‌ ‌people‌ ‌unique.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌its‌ ‌\n“index”‌ ‌language.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌tribe‌ ‌may‌ ‌speak‌ ‌other‌ ‌languages‌ ‌from‌ ‌New‌ ‌Guinea,‌ ‌but‌ ‌this‌ ‌unique‌ ‌language‌ ‌gives‌ ‌the‌ ‌tribe‌ ‌its‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌identity.‌ ‌\n●Linguistic‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌may‌ ‌also‌ ‌take‌ ‌an‌ ‌interest‌ ‌in‌ ‌language‌ ‌as‌ ‌it‌ ‌relates‌ ‌to‌ ‌socialization.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌applied‌ ‌to‌ ‌infancy,‌ ‌childhood,‌ ‌or‌ ‌a‌ ‌foreigner‌ ‌being‌ ‌enculturated.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌anthropologist‌ ‌would‌ ‌likely‌ ‌study‌ ‌a‌ ‌society‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌way‌ ‌that‌ ‌language‌ ‌is‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌socialize‌ ‌its‌ ‌young.‌ ‌\n731‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌language’s‌ ‌effect‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌world,‌ ‌the‌ ‌rate‌ ‌of‌ ‌spread‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌language‌ ‌and‌ ‌its‌ ‌influence‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌society‌ ‌or‌ ‌multiple‌ ‌societies‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌\nimportant‌ ‌indicator‌ ‌that‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌will‌ ‌study.‌ ‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌example‌,‌ ‌the‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌English‌ ‌as‌ ‌an‌ ‌international‌ ‌language‌ ‌can‌ ‌have‌ ‌wide-ranging‌ ‌implications‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌world’s‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌compared‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌effects‌ ‌of‌ ‌colonization‌ ‌or‌ ‌imperialism‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌import‌ ‌of‌ ‌language‌ ‌to‌ ‌various‌ ‌countries,‌ ‌islands,‌ ‌and‌ ‌\ncontinents‌ ‌all‌ ‌over‌ ‌the‌ ‌world.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nAnthropological‌ ‌Linguistics‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌closely‌ ‌related‌ ‌field‌ ‌(some‌ ‌say,‌ ‌exactly‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌field),‌ ‌anthropological‌ ‌linguistics,‌ ‌investigates‌ ‌the‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌between‌ ‌language‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nculture‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌linguistics‌ ‌perspective.‌ ‌\n●Anthropological‌ ‌Linguistics‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌subfield‌ ‌of‌ ‌linguistics,‌ ‌while‌ ‌Linguistic‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌subfield‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropology.‌ ‌\n●Anthropological‌ ‌Linguistics‌ ‌and‌ ‌Sociolinguistics‌ ‌are‌ ‌interested‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌aspects‌ ‌of‌ ‌language,‌ ‌but‌ ‌differ‌ ‌mainly‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌\nsignature‌ ‌research‌ ‌methods.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌some,‌ ‌this‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌branch‌ ‌of‌ ‌linguistics.‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌may‌ ‌differ‌ ‌from‌ ‌linguistic‌ ‌anthropology‌ ‌because‌ ‌linguists‌ ‌will‌ ‌focus‌ ‌more‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌way‌ ‌words‌ ‌are‌ ‌formed,‌ ‌for‌ ‌example,‌ ‌the‌ ‌phonology‌ ‌or‌ ‌\nvocalization‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌language‌ ‌to‌ ‌semantics‌ ‌and‌ ‌grammar‌ ‌systems.‌ ‌\n732‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌example,‌ ‌l‌inguists‌ ‌pay‌ ‌close‌ ‌attention‌ ‌to‌ ‌“code-switching,”‌ ‌a‌ ‌phenomenon‌ ‌that‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌when‌ ‌two‌ ‌or‌ ‌more‌ ‌languages‌ ‌are‌ ‌spoken‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nregion‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌speaker‌ ‌borrows‌ ‌or‌ ‌mixes‌ ‌the‌ ‌languages‌ ‌in‌ ‌normal‌ ‌discourse.‌ ‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌example‌,‌ ‌when‌ ‌a‌ ‌person‌ ‌is‌ ‌speaking‌ ‌a‌ ‌sentence‌ ‌in‌ ‌English‌ ‌but‌ ‌completes‌ ‌his‌ ‌or‌ ‌her‌ ‌thought‌ ‌in‌ ‌Spanish‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌listener‌ ‌understands‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌continues‌ ‌the‌ ‌conversation‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌similar‌ ‌way.‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌linguistic‌ ‌anthropologist‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌interested‌ ‌in‌ ‌code-switching‌ ‌as‌ ‌it‌ ‌affects‌ ‌the‌ ‌society‌ ‌and‌ ‌evolving‌ ‌culture,‌ ‌but‌ ‌will‌ ‌not‌ ‌tend‌ ‌to‌ ‌focus‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nstudy‌ ‌of‌ ‌code-switching,‌ ‌which‌ ‌would‌ ‌be‌ ‌more‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌interest‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌linguist.‌ ‌\n ‌\nSociolinguistics‌ ‌\n●Very‌ ‌similarly,‌ ‌sociolinguistics,‌ ‌considered‌ ‌another‌ ‌subset‌ ‌of‌ ‌linguistics,‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌how‌ ‌people‌ ‌use‌ ‌language‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌social‌ ‌situations.‌ ‌\n733‌ ‌\n●Sociolinguistics‌ ‌includes‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌dialects‌ ‌across‌ ‌a‌ ‌given‌ ‌region‌ ‌and‌ ‌an‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌way‌ ‌some‌ ‌people‌ ‌may‌ ‌speak‌ ‌to‌ ‌each‌ ‌other‌ ‌in‌ ‌\ncertain‌ ‌situations,‌ ‌for‌ ‌example,‌ ‌at‌ ‌a‌ ‌formal‌ ‌occasion,‌ ‌slang‌ ‌between‌ ‌friends‌ ‌and‌ ‌family,‌ ‌or‌ ‌the‌ ‌manner‌ ‌of‌ ‌speaking‌ ‌that‌ ‌may‌ ‌change‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌gender‌ ‌roles.‌ ‌\n● ‌Additionally,‌ ‌historical‌ ‌sociolinguists‌ ‌will‌ ‌examine‌ ‌language‌ ‌for‌ ‌shifts‌ ‌and‌ ‌changes‌ ‌that‌ ‌occur‌ ‌over‌ ‌time‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌society.‌ ‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌example‌,‌ ‌in‌ ‌English,‌ ‌a‌ ‌historical‌ ‌sociolinguistic‌ ‌will‌ ‌look‌ ‌at‌ ‌when‌ ‌“thou”‌ ‌shifted‌ ‌and‌ ‌was‌ ‌replaced‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌word‌ ‌“you”‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌language‌ ‌\ntimeline.‌ ‌\n●Like‌ ‌dialects,‌ ‌sociolinguists‌ ‌will‌ ‌examine‌ ‌words‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌unique‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌region‌ ‌like‌ ‌regionalism.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌American‌ ‌regionalisms,‌ ‌a‌ ‌“faucet”‌ ‌is‌ ‌used‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌North,‌ ‌whereas‌ ‌a‌ ‌“spigot”‌ ‌is‌ ‌used‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌South.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Other‌ ‌regionalism‌ ‌includes‌ ‌frying‌ ‌pan/skillet;‌ ‌pail/bucket;‌ ‌and‌ ‌soda/pop/coke.‌ ‌Sociolinguists‌ ‌may‌ ‌also‌ ‌study‌ ‌a‌ ‌region,‌ ‌and‌ ‌look‌ ‌at‌ ‌other‌ ‌\nfactors,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌socio-economic‌ ‌factors‌ ‌that‌ ‌may‌ ‌have‌ ‌played‌ ‌a‌ ‌role‌ ‌as‌ ‌to‌ ‌how‌ ‌language‌ ‌is‌ ‌spoken‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌region.‌ ‌\n●Some‌ ‌fundamental‌ ‌concepts‌ ‌of‌ ‌Sociolinguist‌ ‌are:‌ ‌\n○External‌ ‌vs.‌ ‌Internal‌ ‌Language‌ ‌\n■Sociolinguistics‌ ‌is‌ ‌different‌ ‌from‌ ‌many‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌branches‌ ‌of‌ ‌linguistics‌ ‌in‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌studies‌ ‌external‌ ‌as‌ ‌opposed‌ ‌to‌ ‌internal‌ ‌\nlanguage.‌ ‌Internal‌ ‌language‌ ‌applies‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌language‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌abstract‌ ‌level,‌ ‌or‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌head,‌ ‌put‌ ‌simply.‌ ‌ ‌\n■External‌ ‌language‌ ‌applies‌ ‌to‌ ‌language‌ ‌in‌ ‌social‌ ‌contexts,‌ ‌or‌ ‌outside‌ ‌the‌ ‌head.‌ ‌ ‌\n■This‌ ‌distinction‌ ‌is‌ ‌important,‌ ‌because‌ ‌internal‌ ‌language‌ ‌analyses,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌syntax‌ ‌and‌ ‌semantics,‌ ‌operate‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌assumption‌ ‌\nthat‌ ‌all‌ ‌native‌ ‌speakers‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌language‌ ‌are‌ ‌quite‌ ‌homogeneous‌ ‌in‌ ‌how‌ ‌they‌ ‌process‌ ‌and‌ ‌perceive‌ ‌language.‌ ‌ ‌\n■External‌ ‌language‌ ‌fields,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌sociolinguistics,‌ ‌attempt‌ ‌to‌ ‌explain‌ ‌why‌ ‌this‌ ‌is‌ ‌in‌ ‌fact‌ ‌not‌ ‌the‌ ‌case.‌ ‌ ‌\n■These‌ ‌two‌ ‌approaches,‌ ‌while‌ ‌distinct,‌ ‌complement‌ ‌each‌ ‌other‌ ‌in‌ ‌practice.‌ ‌\n ‌\n○Speech‌ ‌Community‌ ‌\n■Describe‌ ‌more‌ ‌or‌ ‌less‌ ‌a‌ ‌discrete‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌people‌ ‌who‌ ‌use‌ ‌language‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌unique‌ ‌and‌ ‌mutually‌ ‌acceptable‌ ‌way‌ ‌among‌ ‌\nthemselves.‌ ‌\n■ ‌The‌ ‌members‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌professional,‌ ‌student‌ ‌family‌ ‌or‌ ‌friends.‌ ‌\n■ ‌The‌ ‌members‌ ‌will‌ ‌often‌ ‌develop‌ ‌to‌ ‌serve‌ ‌the‌ ‌group's‌ ‌special‌ ‌purpose‌ ‌and‌ ‌priority.‌ ‌\n○ ‌‌Prestige‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌is‌ ‌crucial‌ ‌for‌ ‌sociolinguist‌ ‌analysts‌ ‌certain‌ ‌speech‌ ‌habits‌ ‌are‌ ‌assigned‌ ‌positive‌ ‌or‌ ‌negative‌ ‌and‌ ‌these‌ ‌are‌ ‌automatically‌ ‌\nassigned‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌speaker.‌ ‌\n■ ‌it‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌realised‌ ‌on‌ ‌individual‌ ‌sound‌ ‌or‌ ‌phenomenon‌ ‌level‌ ‌or‌ ‌pronunciation.‌ ‌\n■ ‌fallen‌ ‌macroscale‌ ‌Prestige‌ ‌value‌ ‌extends‌ ‌to‌ ‌language‌ ‌choices.‌ ‌\n○Social‌ ‌network‌ ‌\n■Understanding‌ ‌the‌ ‌language‌ ‌in‌ ‌society‌ ‌means‌ ‌one‌ ‌also‌ ‌have‌ ‌to‌ ‌understand‌ ‌the‌ ‌social‌ ‌network.‌ ‌\n■A‌ ‌social‌ ‌network‌ ‌way‌ ‌of‌ ‌describing‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌community‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌relation‌ ‌between‌ ‌individual‌ ‌members‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌community.‌ ‌\n○Class‌ ‌difference‌ ‌\n■Class‌ ‌and‌ ‌occupation‌ ‌are‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌important‌ ‌linguist‌ ‌markers‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌society.‌ ‌\n■Class‌ ‌and‌ ‌language‌ ‌variety‌ ‌are‌ ‌related.‌ ‌\n734‌ ‌\n■Number‌ ‌of‌ ‌working‌ ‌class‌ ‌people‌ ‌tend‌ ‌to‌ ‌speak‌ ‌less‌ ‌standard‌ ‌language‌ ‌while‌ ‌the‌ ‌lower‌ ‌,‌ ‌middle‌ ‌and‌ ‌upper‌ ‌class‌ ‌will‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌\nbe‌ ‌closer‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌standard‌ ‌language.‌ ‌\n○Class‌ ‌Aspiration‌ ‌\n■Studies,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌those‌ ‌by‌ ‌‌William‌ ‌Labov‌‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌1960s,‌ ‌have‌ ‌shown‌ ‌that‌ ‌social‌ ‌aspirations‌ ‌influence‌ ‌speech‌ ‌patterns.‌ ‌ ‌\n■This‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌true‌ ‌of‌ ‌class‌ ‌aspirations.‌ ‌In‌ ‌the‌ ‌process‌ ‌of‌ ‌wishing‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌certain‌ ‌class‌ ‌(usually‌ ‌the‌ ‌upper‌ ‌class‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌upper‌ ‌middle‌ ‌class)‌ ‌people‌ ‌who‌ ‌are‌ ‌moving‌ ‌in‌ ‌that‌ ‌direction‌ ‌socio-economically‌ ‌will‌ ‌adjust‌ ‌their‌ ‌speech‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌to‌ ‌sound‌ ‌\nlike‌ ‌them.‌ ‌ ‌\n■However,‌ ‌not‌ ‌being‌ ‌native‌ ‌upper‌ ‌class‌ ‌speakers,‌ ‌they‌ ‌hypercorrect,‌ ‌and‌ ‌end‌ ‌up‌ ‌speaking‌ ‌'more'‌ ‌standard‌ ‌than‌ ‌those‌ ‌whom‌ ‌\nthey‌ ‌are‌ ‌trying‌ ‌to‌ ‌imitate.‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌same‌ ‌is‌ ‌true‌ ‌for‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌moving‌ ‌down‌ ‌in‌ ‌socio-economic‌ ‌status.‌ ‌\n○Social‌ ‌language‌ ‌codes‌ ‌\n■Basil‌ ‌Bernstein‌,‌ ‌a‌ ‌well-known‌ ‌British‌ ‌socio-linguist,‌ ‌devised‌ ‌in‌ ‌his‌ ‌book,‌ ‌'Elaborated‌ ‌and‌ ‌restricted‌ ‌codes:‌ ‌their‌ ‌social‌ ‌origins‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌some‌ ‌consequences,'‌ ‌a‌ ‌social‌ ‌code‌ ‌system‌ ‌which‌ ‌he‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌classify‌ ‌the‌ ‌various‌ ‌speech‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌for‌ ‌different‌ ‌social‌ ‌\nclasses.‌ ‌ ‌\n■He‌ ‌claimed‌ ‌that‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌middle‌ ‌class‌ ‌have‌ ‌ways‌ ‌of‌ ‌organising‌ ‌their‌ ‌speech‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌fundamentally‌ ‌very‌ ‌different‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌ways‌ ‌adopted‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌working‌ ‌class.‌ ‌\n●Restricted‌ ‌code:‌‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌example‌ ‌of‌ ‌speech‌ ‌Code‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌working‌ ‌class.‌ ‌\n●Elaborated‌ ‌code:‌ ‌mid‌ ‌and‌ ‌upper‌ ‌middle‌ ‌class‌ ‌use‌ ‌this‌ ‌language‌ ‌to‌ ‌gain‌ ‌access‌ ‌to‌ ‌education‌ ‌and‌ ‌career‌ ‌\nadvancement.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n735‌ ‌\nLanguage‌ ‌and‌ ‌Culture‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌structure‌ ‌and‌ ‌content‌ ‌of‌ ‌language‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌great‌ ‌extent‌ ‌are‌ ‌influenced‌ ‌by‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Linguistic‌ ‌diversity‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌result‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌diversity.‌ ‌ ‌\n●According‌ ‌to‌ ‌‌Overton‌ ‌Brent‌ ‌Berlin‌,‌ ‌a‌ ‌famous‌ ‌American‌ ‌Anthropologist,‌ ‌the‌ ‌increase‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌words‌ ‌indicates‌ ‌the‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌\ncomplexity.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Language‌ ‌reflects‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌situations.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌socialisation‌ ‌process‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌child‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌influenced‌ ‌by‌ ‌language.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌status‌ ‌of‌ ‌people,‌ ‌their‌ ‌living‌ ‌condition,‌ ‌their‌ ‌environment‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌way‌ ‌of‌ ‌subsistence‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌understood‌ ‌through‌ ‌languages.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌between‌ ‌language‌ ‌and‌ ‌culture,‌ ‌and‌ ‌how‌ ‌they‌ ‌mutually‌ ‌influence‌ ‌each‌ ‌other‌ ‌is‌ ‌examined‌ ‌under‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nsub-discipline‌ ‌Ethno-linguistics.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌examines‌ ‌how‌ ‌a‌ ‌language‌ ‌reflects‌ ‌the‌ ‌traditional‌ ‌natural‌ ‌environment.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Ethno-linguists,‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌interaction‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌group‌ ‌under‌ ‌study,‌ ‌learn‌ ‌to‌ ‌understand‌ ‌the‌ ‌prevailing‌ ‌social‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌situation.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Relationship‌ ‌between‌ ‌Culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌language‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌well‌ ‌understood‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌examination‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌following‌ ‌areas:‌ ‌\n ‌\n○Language‌ ‌Influences‌ ‌Human‌ ‌Thought:‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌is‌ ‌important‌ ‌to‌ ‌note‌ ‌that‌ ‌language,‌ ‌to‌ ‌some‌ ‌extent,‌ ‌shapes‌ ‌the‌ ‌way‌ ‌people‌ ‌view‌ ‌and‌ ‌think‌ ‌about‌ ‌the‌ ‌world.‌ ‌ ‌\n736‌ ‌\n■Culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌directly‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌human‌ ‌thought.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n■Some‌ ‌Linguists‌ ‌even‌ ‌say‌ ‌that‌ ‌language‌ ‌actually‌ ‌determines‌ ‌thought.‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌also‌ ‌shapes‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌and‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌concept‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌this‌ ‌outlook‌ ‌is‌ ‌termed‌ ‌as‌ ‌‌Linguistic‌ ‌Determinism.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌is‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌research‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthropologists,‌ ‌‌Edward‌ ‌Sapir‌ ‌(American‌ ‌Linguist‌ ‌and‌ ‌student‌ ‌of‌ ‌Franz‌ ‌\nBoas)‌ ‌and‌ ‌his‌ ‌student‌ ‌and‌ ‌American‌ ‌linguist‌ ‌Benjamin‌ ‌Whorf.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Based‌ ‌on‌ ‌their‌ ‌research,‌ ‌they‌ ‌proposed‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Sapir‌ ‌-‌ ‌Whorf‌ ‌hypothesis‌,‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌they‌ ‌proposed‌ ‌how‌ ‌language‌ ‌\ndetermines‌ ‌human‌ ‌thought.‌ ‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌example‌ ‌if‌ ‌a‌ ‌language‌ ‌has‌ ‌no‌ ‌word‌ ‌to‌ ‌denote‌ ‌‘snow‘‌ ‌as‌ ‌used‌ ‌in‌ ‌English,‌ ‌then‌ ‌a‌ ‌person‌ ‌brought‌ ‌up‌ ‌in‌ ‌that‌ ‌culture‌ ‌\ncannot‌ ‌think‌ ‌of‌ ‌snow‌ ‌as‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌implied‌ ‌in‌ ‌English.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Thus,‌ ‌Linguistic‌ ‌determinism‌ ‌proposes‌ ‌that‌ ‌language,‌ ‌to‌ ‌some‌ ‌extent,‌ ‌determines‌ ‌the‌ ‌way‌ ‌we‌ ‌think‌ ‌about‌ ‌the‌ ‌world‌ ‌\naround.‌ ‌ ‌\n●As‌ ‌the‌ ‌thought‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌changes,‌ ‌the‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌situation‌ ‌of‌ ‌that‌ ‌society‌ ‌also‌ ‌changes‌ ‌accordingly.‌ ‌\n737‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Language‌ ‌indicates‌ ‌Social‌ ‌Roles‌ ‌and‌ ‌Statuses:‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌your‌ ‌local‌ ‌language,‌ ‌there‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌different‌ ‌words‌ ‌to‌ ‌denote‌ ‌‘death’‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌person.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌terms‌ ‌may‌ ‌vary‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌caste,‌ ‌gender,‌ ‌age‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌status.‌ ‌\n○Generally‌ ‌the‌ ‌judges‌ ‌in‌ ‌courts‌ ‌are‌ ‌honorably‌ ‌addressed‌ ‌as‌ ‌‘Your‌ ‌honour’.‌ ‌But‌ ‌if‌ ‌the‌ ‌judges‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌higher‌ ‌title,‌ ‌the‌ ‌position‌ ‌will‌ ‌\nbe‌ ‌respectfully‌ ‌addressed‌ ‌by‌ ‌using‌ ‌the‌ ‌term‌ ‌‘Your‌ ‌Lordship’.‌ ‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌king/queen‌ ‌or‌ ‌emperor/empress‌ ‌is‌ ‌addressed‌ ‌as‌ ‌His/Her‌ ‌Majesty.‌ ‌But‌ ‌the‌ ‌ruler‌ ‌below‌ ‌the‌ ‌rank‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌king/queen‌ ‌is‌ ‌addressed‌ ‌\nas‌ ‌His/Her‌ ‌Highness.‌ ‌\n○Japanese‌ ‌uses‌ ‌different‌ ‌word‌ ‌for‌ ‌water‌ ‌by‌ ‌males‌ ‌and‌ ‌females:‌ ‌\n■Female‌ ‌-Ohiya‌ ‌\n■Male-Mizui‌ ‌\n●Culture‌ ‌Influences‌ ‌Basic‌ ‌Vocabulary‌ ‌of‌ ‌Language:‌ ‌ ‌\n○All‌ ‌languages‌ ‌have‌ ‌many‌ ‌different‌ ‌ways‌ ‌to‌ ‌express‌ ‌colour‌ ‌variations.‌ ‌Most‌ ‌often,‌ ‌certain‌ ‌basic‌ ‌words‌ ‌are‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌denote‌ ‌this.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌English,‌ ‌words‌ ‌representing‌ ‌some‌ ‌basic‌ ‌colors‌ ‌are‌ ‌white,‌ ‌black,‌ ‌red,‌ ‌green,‌ ‌blue,‌ ‌yellow,‌ ‌brown‌ ‌pink,‌ ‌purple‌ ‌and‌ ‌grey.‌ ‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌basic‌ ‌colour‌ ‌words.‌ ‌A‌ ‌basic‌ ‌color‌ ‌word‌ ‌consists‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌single‌ ‌morph.‌ ‌It‌ ‌may‌ ‌not‌ ‌denote‌ ‌the‌ ‌variant‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌\ncolour.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌basic‌ ‌words‌ ‌for‌ ‌colours‌ ‌varies‌ ‌from‌ ‌society‌ ‌to‌ ‌society‌ ‌(language‌ ‌to‌ ‌language).‌ ‌ ‌\n○Berlin‌ ‌and‌ ‌Kay‌ ‌(Basic‌ ‌colour‌ ‌terms‌ ‌1969)‌ ‌suggest‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌basic‌ ‌colour‌ ‌words‌ ‌increases‌ ‌with‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌complexity.‌ ‌ ‌\n○More‌ ‌complex‌ ‌societies‌ ‌may‌ ‌require‌ ‌a‌ ‌large‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌basic‌ ‌colour‌ ‌words‌ ‌because‌ ‌they‌ ‌have‌ ‌more‌ ‌decorated‌ ‌objects‌ ‌that‌ ‌\ncan‌ ‌be‌ ‌effectively‌ ‌distinguished‌ ‌by‌ ‌colour.‌ ‌\n○All‌ ‌languages‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌core‌ ‌vocabulary.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌influenced‌ ‌by‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌environment.‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌example‌ ‌Eskimos‌ ‌can‌ ‌distinguish‌ ‌different‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌snows‌ ‌and‌ ‌winds.‌ ‌So‌ ‌among‌ ‌them‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌different‌ ‌terms‌ ‌to‌ ‌denote‌ ‌\nthese‌ ‌‘snows’‌ ‌and‌ ‌‘winds’.‌ ‌Hence,‌ ‌we‌ ‌can‌ ‌infer‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌basic‌ ‌vocabulary‌ ‌is‌ ‌influenced‌ ‌by‌ ‌culture‌ ‌and‌ ‌environment.‌ ‌The‌ ‌more‌ ‌\ncomplex‌ ‌a‌ ‌society‌ ‌is,‌ ‌the‌ ‌larger‌ ‌the‌ ‌total‌ ‌vocabulary‌ ‌of‌ ‌its‌ ‌language.‌ ‌\n●Language‌ ‌helps‌ ‌to‌ ‌share‌ ‌Cultural‌ ‌Symbols:‌ ‌\n○One‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌features‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture‌ ‌is‌ ‌its‌ ‌nature‌ ‌of‌ ‌shared‌ ‌practice.‌ ‌ ‌\n○To‌ ‌ensure‌ ‌this‌ ‌sharing‌ ‌in‌ ‌society,‌ ‌we‌ ‌require‌ ‌the‌ ‌medium‌ ‌of‌ ‌language.‌ ‌ ‌\n○We‌ ‌learn‌ ‌the‌ ‌beliefs‌ ‌and‌ ‌practices‌ ‌of‌ ‌our‌ ‌culture‌ ‌through‌ ‌language.‌ ‌\n●Language‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌medium‌ ‌of‌ ‌Acculturation‌ ‌and‌ ‌Enculturation:‌ ‌ ‌\n○Language‌ ‌helps‌ ‌us‌ ‌to‌ ‌learn‌ ‌various‌ ‌aspects‌ ‌of‌ ‌our‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌We‌ ‌learn‌ ‌to‌ ‌behave‌ ‌and‌ ‌involve‌ ‌in‌ ‌social‌ ‌interaction‌ ‌by‌ ‌sharing‌ ‌the‌ ‌\ncommon‌ ‌rules‌ ‌and‌ ‌norms‌ ‌of‌ ‌our‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌\n○Language‌ ‌unites‌ ‌people‌ ‌together‌ ‌and‌ ‌helps‌ ‌to‌ ‌formulate‌ ‌common‌ ‌sense‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌given‌ ‌society.‌ ‌We‌ ‌require‌ ‌the‌ ‌medium,‌ ‌language‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌assimilate‌ ‌the‌ ‌traits‌ ‌of‌ ‌other‌ ‌cultures.‌ ‌\n●Language‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌vehicle‌ ‌of‌ ‌Culture:‌ ‌ ‌\n○Language,‌ ‌in‌ ‌short,‌ ‌fulfills‌ ‌the‌ ‌function‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌carrier‌ ‌of‌ ‌culture.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌medium‌ ‌of‌ ‌language‌ ‌that‌ ‌parents‌ ‌and‌ ‌elders‌ ‌\ntransmit‌ ‌their‌ ‌way‌ ‌of‌ ‌life‌ ‌to‌ ‌their‌ ‌children‌ ‌and‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌next‌ ‌generation.‌ ‌ ‌\n738‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌carries‌ ‌culture‌ ‌from‌ ‌one‌ ‌generation‌ ‌to‌ ‌another‌ ‌and‌ ‌from‌ ‌one‌ ‌culture‌ ‌to‌ ‌another.‌ ‌\n○Thus‌ ‌the‌ ‌processes‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌evolution,‌ ‌diffusion‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌are‌ ‌facilitated‌ ‌by‌ ‌language.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n739‌ ‌\n9.1‌ ‌Human‌ ‌Genetics‌ ‌:‌ ‌Methods‌ ‌and‌ ‌Application:‌ ‌Part-I‌ ‌ ‌\na)‌ ‌Methods‌ ‌for‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌principles‌ ‌in‌ ‌man-family‌ ‌study‌ ‌ ‌\ni.‌ ‌Pedigree‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌\nii.Twin‌ ‌study‌ ‌\niii.‌ ‌Foster‌ ‌child‌ ‌\n ‌ ‌\n ‌\ni.‌ ‌Pedigree‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌\n ‌\nDefinition:‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌pedigree‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌visual‌ ‌tool‌ ‌for‌ ‌documenting‌ ‌biological‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌in‌ ‌families‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌presence‌ ‌of‌ ‌diseases.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌inherited‌ ‌traits‌ ‌or‌ ‌disorders‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌phenotypic‌ ‌variability‌ ‌over‌ ‌several‌ ‌generations‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌blood-related‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌by‌ ‌\nway‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌pedigree‌ ‌chart,‌ ‌which‌ ‌depicts‌ ‌that‌ ‌group's‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌history‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌family‌ ‌tree.‌ ‌\n●Simply,‌ ‌‌A‌ ‌pedigree‌ ‌chart‌ ‌displays‌ ‌a‌ ‌family‌ ‌tree,‌ ‌and‌ ‌shows‌ ‌the‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌family‌ ‌who‌ ‌are‌ ‌affected‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌trait.‌ ‌\n●First‌ ‌suggested‌ ‌by‌ ‌‌Francis‌ ‌Galton‌.‌ ‌\n ‌\nSignificance:‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌track‌ ‌and‌ ‌trace‌ ‌‌inheritance‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌character‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌trace‌ ‌the‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌of‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌of‌ ‌traits‌ ‌of‌ ‌abnormality‌ ‌or‌ ‌disease.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌used‌ ‌by‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌counsellors‌ ‌to‌ ‌inform‌ ‌the‌ ‌couples‌ ‌if‌ ‌their‌ ‌child‌ ‌will‌ ‌have‌ ‌any‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌defect‌ ‌or‌ ‌not.‌ ‌\n ‌\nBasics‌ ‌\n●Study‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌trait‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌family‌ ‌usually‌ ‌begins‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌affected‌ ‌person‌ ‌who‌ ‌is‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to‌ ‌as‌ ‌‌proband,‌ ‌or‌ ‌propositus‌ ‌\n(female=proposila)‌ ‌or‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌index‌ ‌case‌.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌following‌ ‌conventions‌ ‌are‌ ‌used‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌construction‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌Pedigree‌ ‌chart:‌ ‌\n○Mens‌ ‌are‌ ‌placed‌ ‌first‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌left,‌ ‌represented‌ ‌by‌ ‌squares.‌ ‌\n○Females‌ ‌are‌ ‌placed‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌right‌ ‌represented‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌circle.‌ ‌\n○Marriage‌ ‌is‌ ‌indicated‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌horizontal‌ ‌line‌ ‌connecting‌ ‌the‌ ‌two.‌ ‌\n○Double‌ ‌marital‌ ‌lines‌ ‌are‌ ‌used‌ ‌in‌ ‌case‌ ‌of‌ ‌consanguinity.‌ ‌\n○Siblings‌ ‌are‌ ‌marked‌ ‌1,2,3‌ ‌in‌ ‌chronological‌ ‌order‌ ‌of‌ ‌birth.If‌ ‌numbers‌ ‌are‌ ‌large‌ ‌its‌ ‌customary‌ ‌to‌ ‌write‌ ‌inside‌ ‌the‌ ‌circle‌ ‌or‌ ‌square.‌ ‌\n ‌\n○Twins‌ ‌indicated‌ ‌by‌ ‌joining‌ ‌the‌ ‌siblings‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌capping‌ ‌line.‌ ‌\n740‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌case‌ ‌of‌ ‌identical‌ ‌twins‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌joined‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌horizontal‌ ‌line‌ ‌also.‌ ‌\n○If‌ ‌zygosity‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌confirmed,‌ ‌a‌ ‌cap‌ ‌is‌ ‌accompanied‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌question‌ ‌mark.‌ ‌\n■Zygosity‌ ‌‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌degree‌ ‌to‌ ‌which‌ ‌both‌ ‌copies‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌or‌ ‌gene‌ ‌have‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌sequence.‌ ‌In‌ ‌other‌ ‌words,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌degree‌ ‌of‌ ‌similarity‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌in‌ ‌an‌ ‌organism.‌ ‌\n○People‌ ‌affected‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌traits‌ ‌understudy‌ ‌are‌ ‌indicated‌ ‌by‌ ‌blackening‌ ‌the‌ ‌square‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌circle.‌ ‌\n○Heterozygous‌ ‌male/female‌ ‌carriers‌ ‌are‌ ‌indicated‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌dot‌ ‌inside‌ ‌the‌ ‌square/circle‌ ‌to‌ ‌indicate‌ ‌the‌ ‌carrier‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌X‌ ‌linked‌ ‌trait.‌ ‌\n ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○Parent‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌person‌ ‌affected‌ ‌by‌‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌traits‌‌ ‌is‌ ‌indicated‌ ‌by‌ ‌half‌ ‌blackening‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌square‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌circle.‌ ‌\n ‌\n○Generation‌ ‌of‌ ‌numbers‌ ‌in‌ ‌Roman‌ ‌numerals,‌ ‌the‌ ‌older‌ ‌one‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌copper‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌Pedigree‌ ‌chart‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌recent‌ ‌one‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌bottom‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌chart.‌ ‌\n741‌ ‌\n ‌\n742‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nTypes‌ ‌of‌ ‌Pedigree:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Pedigree‌ ‌depends‌ ‌upon‌ ‌the‌ ‌nature‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌gene‌ ‌causing‌ ‌the‌ ‌character‌ ‌understudy.‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌gene‌ ‌can‌ ‌be:‌ ‌\n○Autosomal‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌\n○Autosomal‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌\n○X-linked‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌\n○X-linked‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌\n ‌\n●The‌ ‌nature‌ ‌of‌ ‌Inheritance‌ ‌of‌ ‌genes,‌ ‌therefore,‌ ‌varies.‌ ‌\n ‌\nAutosomal‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌\n●Autosomal‌ ‌traits‌ ‌are‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌single‌ ‌gene‌ ‌on‌ ‌an‌ ‌autosome‌ ‌(non-sex‌ ‌chromosome)—they‌ ‌are‌ ‌called‌ ‌\"dominant\"‌ ‌because‌ ‌a‌ ‌single‌ ‌\ncopy—inherited‌ ‌from‌ ‌either‌ ‌parent—is‌ ‌enough‌ ‌to‌ ‌cause‌ ‌this‌ ‌trait‌ ‌to‌ ‌appear.‌ ‌ ‌\n743‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌often‌ ‌means‌ ‌that‌ ‌one‌
