‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌parents‌ ‌must‌ ‌also‌ ‌have‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌trait,‌ ‌unless‌ ‌it‌ ‌has‌ ‌arisen‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌an‌ ‌unlikely‌ ‌new‌ ‌mutation.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Examples‌ ‌of‌ ‌autosomal‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌traits‌ ‌and‌ ‌disorders‌ ‌are:‌ ‌\n○Huntington's‌ ‌disease(progressive‌ ‌degradation‌ ‌of‌ ‌nervous‌ ‌system)‌ ‌\n○Achondroplasia‌ ‌(short‌ ‌limbed‌ ‌dwarfism)‌ ‌\n○Brachydactly‌ ‌(short‌ ‌finger)‌ ‌\n○Porphyria‌ ‌(skin‌ ‌lesion‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌exposure‌ ‌to‌ ‌sunlight)‌ ‌\n○Polydactyly‌ ‌(extra‌ ‌finger)‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n●Such‌ ‌characters‌ ‌are‌ ‌present‌ ‌in‌ ‌all‌ ‌generations‌ ‌i.e.‌ ‌generation‌ ‌skip‌ ‌with‌ ‌equal‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌in‌ ‌male‌ ‌and‌ ‌female.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌character‌ ‌thus‌ ‌shows‌ ‌a‌ ‌vertical‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌of‌ ‌inheritance.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●AD‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌\n○Homozygous‌ ‌parents:‌ ‌children‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌100%‌ ‌probability‌ ‌of‌ ‌inheriting‌ ‌the‌ ‌allele‌ ‌that‌ ‌causes‌ ‌the‌ ‌trait/disorder.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○One‌ ‌heterozygous‌ ‌and‌ ‌one‌ ‌homozygous‌ ‌parent:‌ ‌Children‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌50%‌ ‌probability‌ ‌of‌ ‌inheriting‌ ‌the‌ ‌allele‌ ‌that‌ ‌causes‌ ‌the‌ ‌trait/disorder.‌ ‌\n ‌\n744‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○Heterozygous‌ ‌parents:‌ ‌Children‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌75%‌ ‌probability‌ ‌of‌ ‌inheriting‌ ‌the‌ ‌allele‌ ‌that‌ ‌causes‌ ‌the‌ ‌trait/disorder.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n745‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●In‌ ‌the‌ ‌above‌ ‌diagram,‌ ‌In‌ ‌generation‌ ‌I,‌ ‌mother‌ ‌is‌ ‌affected.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌generation‌ ‌II‌ ‌only‌ ‌2‌ ‌children‌ ‌are‌ ‌unaffected.‌ ‌\n●Affected‌ ‌male‌ ‌3,‌ ‌transit‌ ‌the‌ ‌character‌ ‌to‌ ‌two‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌progeny‌ ‌even‌ ‌if‌ ‌he‌ ‌marry‌ ‌a‌ ‌normal‌ ‌person.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌character‌ ‌appears‌ ‌in‌ ‌both‌ ‌sexes‌ ‌with‌ ‌equal‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌without‌ ‌skipping‌ ‌generation.‌ ‌\n ‌\nAutosomal‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌\n●Autosomal‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌traits‌ ‌is‌ ‌one‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌of‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌trait,‌ ‌disease,‌ ‌or‌ ‌disorder‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌passed‌ ‌on‌ ‌through‌ ‌families.‌ ‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌a‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌trait‌ ‌or‌ ‌disease‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌displayed‌ ‌two‌ ‌copies‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌trait‌ ‌or‌ ‌disorder‌ ‌needs‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌presented.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌trait‌ ‌or‌ ‌gene‌ ‌will‌ ‌be‌ ‌located‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌non-sex‌ ‌chromosome.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Because‌ ‌it‌ ‌takes‌ ‌two‌ ‌copies‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌trait‌ ‌to‌ ‌display‌ ‌a‌ ‌trait,‌ ‌many‌ ‌people‌ ‌can‌ ‌unknowingly‌ ‌be‌ ‌carriers‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌disease.‌ ‌ ‌\n●From‌ ‌an‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌perspective,‌ ‌a‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌disease‌ ‌or‌ ‌trait‌ ‌can‌ ‌remain‌ ‌hidden‌ ‌for‌ ‌several‌ ‌generations‌ ‌before‌ ‌displaying‌ ‌the‌ ‌phenotype.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Examples‌ ‌of‌ ‌autosomal‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌disorders‌ ‌are:‌ ‌\n○Albinism‌ ‌(absence‌ ‌of‌ ‌melanin)‌ ‌\n○Cystic‌ ‌fibrosis‌ ‌(formation‌ ‌of‌ ‌thick‌ ‌mucus‌ ‌in‌ ‌lungs)‌ ‌\n○Sickle‌ ‌cell‌ ‌anemia‌ ‌\n○Thalassemias‌ ‌\n●Such‌ ‌characters,‌ ‌though‌ ‌present‌ ‌in‌ ‌both‌ ‌the‌ ‌sexes‌ ‌with‌ ‌equal‌ ‌frequency,‌ ‌skip‌ ‌generation.‌ ‌ ‌\n746‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌character‌ ‌thus,‌ ‌shows‌ ‌horizontal‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌of‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●AR‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌\n○Homozygous‌ ‌parents:‌ ‌no‌ ‌children‌ ‌will‌ ‌be‌ ‌affected,‌ ‌but‌ ‌all‌ ‌will‌ ‌be‌ ‌carriers‌ ‌\n ‌\n○One‌ ‌heterozygous‌ ‌and‌ ‌one‌ ‌homozygous‌ ‌parent:‌ ‌All‌ ‌children‌ ‌inherit‌ ‌the‌ ‌allele‌ ‌that‌ ‌causes‌ ‌the‌ ‌trait‌ ‌or‌ ‌disorder,‌ ‌but‌ ‌only‌ ‌50%‌ ‌will‌ ‌\nexpress‌ ‌the‌ ‌trait‌ ‌while‌ ‌other‌ ‌50%‌ ‌will‌ ‌be‌ ‌carriers.‌ ‌\n ‌\n○Heterozygous‌ ‌parents:‌ ‌ ‌\n■Half‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌children‌ ‌will‌ ‌be‌ ‌carriers,‌ ‌25%‌ ‌will‌ ‌express‌ ‌the‌ ‌trait,‌ ‌and‌ ‌25%‌ ‌will‌ ‌not‌ ‌express‌ ‌the‌ ‌trait.‌ ‌\n■Healthy‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌with‌ ‌an‌ ‌affected‌ ‌sibling‌ ‌(nn)‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌two-thirds-probability‌ ‌of‌ ‌being‌ ‌a‌ ‌carrier‌ ‌(Nn,‌ ‌Nn,‌ ‌or‌ ‌NN).‌ ‌\n ‌\n747‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●In‌ ‌above‌ ‌diagram,‌ ‌Generation‌ ‌I,‌ ‌both‌ ‌parents‌ ‌are‌ ‌heterozygous,‌ ‌and‌ ‌unaffected‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌generation‌ ‌II,‌ ‌3‌ ‌are‌ ‌affected‌ ‌who‌ ‌marry‌ ‌a‌ ‌normal‌ ‌girl.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌generation‌ ‌III,‌ ‌2,3,4‌ ‌are‌ ‌heterozygous‌ ‌and‌ ‌unaffected..‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌character‌ ‌appeared‌ ‌in‌ ‌generation‌ ‌IV,‌ ‌character‌ ‌skip‌ ‌I‌ ‌and‌ ‌III‌ ‌Generation.‌ ‌\n ‌\nX-Recessive‌ ‌\n●Definition:‌ ‌a‌ ‌mode‌ ‌of‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌that‌ ‌requires‌ ‌two‌ ‌copies‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌allele‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌X‌ ‌chromosome,‌ ‌one‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌mother‌ ‌and‌ ‌one‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌father,‌ ‌\nfor‌ ‌the‌ ‌phenotypic‌ ‌expression‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌trait‌ ‌or‌ ‌disorder‌ ‌in‌ ‌offspring‌ ‌\n748‌ ‌\n●X-linked‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌(XR)‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌leads‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌expression‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌phenotype‌ ‌in‌ ‌all‌ ‌male‌ ‌children‌ ‌who‌ ‌inherit‌ ‌the‌ ‌mutated‌ ‌allele.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Female‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌are‌ ‌more‌ ‌frequently‌ ‌carriers‌ ‌(unaffected)‌ ‌of‌ ‌X-linked‌ ‌inherited‌ ‌disorders‌ ‌than‌ ‌male‌ ‌individuals.‌ ‌\n○Female‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌typically‌ ‌require‌ ‌the‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌of‌ ‌one‌ ‌mutated‌ ‌allele‌ ‌from‌ ‌their‌ ‌father‌ ‌and‌ ‌one‌ ‌allele‌ ‌from‌ ‌their‌ ‌mother‌ ‌(affected‌ ‌\nhomozygous)‌ ‌to‌ ‌phenotypically‌ ‌express‌ ‌XR‌ ‌disorders.‌ ‌\n○Therefore,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌more‌ ‌common‌ ‌for‌ ‌female‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌heterozygous‌ ‌carriers‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌allele‌ ‌\n○However,‌ ‌female‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌may‌ ‌also‌ ‌express‌ ‌XR‌ ‌phenotypes‌ ‌if‌ ‌the‌ ‌non‌ ‌affected‌ ‌X‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌is‌ ‌inactivated‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌majority‌ ‌of‌ ‌cells‌ ‌\n(see‌ ‌“Manifestation‌ ‌of‌ ‌X-linked‌ ‌disorders‌ ‌in‌ ‌female‌ ‌individuals”‌ ‌above).‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Individuals‌ ‌with‌ ‌Turner‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌only‌ ‌have‌ ‌one‌ ‌X‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌and‌ ‌are,‌ ‌therefore,‌ ‌more‌ ‌susceptible‌ ‌to‌ ‌X-linked‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌disorders‌ ‌\nMale-to-male‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌is‌ ‌impossible.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Male‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌tend‌ ‌to‌ ‌develop‌ ‌a‌ ‌more‌ ‌severe‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌XR‌ ‌disease‌ ‌because‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌reasons:‌ ‌\n○Since‌ ‌females‌ ‌have‌ ‌two‌ ‌X‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌hence,‌ ‌for‌ ‌them‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌affected‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌necessary‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌gene‌ ‌is‌ ‌present‌ ‌on‌ ‌both‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nchromosomes‌ ‌(homozygous)‌ ‌whereas‌ ‌males‌ ‌are‌ ‌affected‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌single‌ ‌dose‌ ‌of‌ ‌gene‌ ‌since‌ ‌they‌ ‌have‌ ‌only‌ ‌one‌ ‌X-Chromosome.‌ ‌In‌ ‌\naddition‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌presence‌ ‌of‌ ‌double‌ ‌dose‌ ‌of‌ ‌such‌ ‌gene‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌female‌ ‌zygote‌ ‌is‌ ‌lethal‌ ‌hence,‌ ‌rarely‌ ‌developed.‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌frequently‌ ‌skips‌ ‌generations.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Examples:‌ ‌\n○Color‌ ‌blindness‌ ‌\n○Duchenne‌ ‌muscular‌ ‌dystrophy‌ ‌\n○Fabry‌ ‌disease‌ ‌\n○Hemophilia‌ ‌A‌ ‌\n○Hemophilia‌ ‌B‌ ‌\n○Hunter‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌\n● ‌XR‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌\n●Heterozygous‌ ‌(carrier)‌ ‌mother‌ ‌and‌ ‌hemizygous‌ ‌(unaffected)‌ ‌father‌ ‌ ‌\n■Children‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌50%‌ ‌probability‌ ‌of‌ ‌inheriting‌ ‌the‌ ‌X‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌that‌ ‌causes‌ ‌the‌ ‌trait/disorder.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Sons‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌50%‌ ‌probability‌ ‌of‌ ‌inheriting‌ ‌the‌ ‌trait‌ ‌or‌ ‌disorder.‌ ‌\n749‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Heterozygous‌ ‌(carrier)‌ ‌mother‌ ‌and‌ ‌hemizygous‌ ‌(affected)‌ ‌father‌ ‌\n■Children‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌75%‌ ‌probability‌ ‌of‌ ‌inheriting‌ ‌the‌ ‌X‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌responsible‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌trait/disorder.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Children‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌50%‌ ‌probability‌ ‌of‌ ‌developing‌ ‌the‌ ‌trait/disorder.‌ ‌\n ‌\n○Homozygous‌ ‌(unaffected)‌ ‌mother‌ ‌and‌ ‌hemizygous‌ ‌(affected)‌ ‌father‌ ‌\n■Children‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌50%‌ ‌probability‌ ‌of‌ ‌inheriting‌ ‌the‌ ‌X‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌that‌ ‌causes‌ ‌the‌ ‌trait/disorder.‌ ‌\n■None‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌children‌ ‌will‌ ‌be‌ ‌affected.‌ ‌\n ‌\n○Homozygous‌ ‌(affected)‌ ‌mother‌ ‌and‌ ‌hemizygous‌ ‌(affected)‌ ‌father:‌ ‌ ‌\n■If‌ ‌both‌ ‌parents‌ ‌have‌ ‌the‌ ‌trait/disease‌ ‌then‌ ‌all‌ ‌children‌ ‌will‌ ‌invariably‌ ‌be‌ ‌affected.‌ ‌\n750‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●In‌ ‌the‌ ‌above‌ ‌diagram,‌ ‌In‌ ‌generation‌ ‌I,‌ ‌father‌ ‌is‌ ‌affected.‌ ‌\n●But‌ ‌in‌ ‌generation‌ ‌II,‌ ‌none‌ ‌is‌ ‌affected‌ ‌but‌ ‌females‌ ‌are‌ ‌carriers.‌ ‌\n●Even‌ ‌if‌ ‌they‌ ‌marry‌ ‌a‌ ‌normal‌ ‌male(2)‌ ‌in‌ ‌generation‌ ‌II‌ ‌carrier‌ ‌female‌ ‌(3‌ ‌and‌ ‌affected‌ ‌male‌ ‌(4)‌ ‌are‌ ‌born‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌III‌ ‌generation.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌gene‌ ‌travels‌ ‌from‌ ‌father‌ ‌to‌ ‌daughter‌ ‌to‌ ‌son.‌ ‌This‌ ‌is‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to‌ ‌as‌ ‌Criss‌ ‌cross‌ ‌inheritance.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌character‌ ‌is‌ ‌inherited‌ ‌from‌ ‌maternal‌ ‌grandfather‌ ‌to‌ ‌grandson‌ ‌via‌ ‌mother.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nX-Dominant‌ ‌\n●Definition:‌ ‌a‌ ‌mode‌ ‌of‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌that‌ ‌only‌ ‌requires‌ ‌one‌ ‌copy‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌mutated‌ ‌allele‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌X‌ ‌chromosome,‌ ‌from‌ ‌either‌ ‌the‌ ‌mother‌ ‌or‌ ‌father,‌ ‌for‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌phenotypic‌ ‌expression‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌trait‌ ‌or‌ ‌disorder‌ ‌in‌ ‌offspring‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌X-linked‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌(XD)‌ ‌inheritance,‌ ‌male‌ ‌and‌ ‌female‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌have‌ ‌an‌ ‌equal‌ ‌probability‌ ‌of‌ ‌inheriting‌ ‌the‌ ‌trait‌ ‌or‌ ‌disorder.‌ ‌\n●Because‌ ‌female‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌have‌ ‌two‌ ‌X‌ ‌chromosomes,‌ ‌the‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌X-linked‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌disorder‌ ‌typically‌ ‌manifests‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌less‌ ‌severe‌ ‌\nform‌ ‌than‌ ‌in‌ ‌male‌ ‌individuals.‌ ‌\n751‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌nature‌ ‌of‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌depends‌ ‌upon‌ ‌whether‌ ‌the‌ ‌gene‌ ‌is‌ ‌inherited‌ ‌from‌ ‌father‌ ‌or‌ ‌mother.‌ ‌\n● ‌If‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌father‌ ‌'s‌ ‌side‌ ‌the‌ ‌character‌ ‌will‌ ‌be‌ ‌inherited‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌daughter‌ ‌only‌ ‌because‌ ‌father‌ ‌has‌ ‌one‌ ‌x‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌always‌ ‌given‌ ‌only‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌\ndaughter.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Examples:‌ ‌\n●Alport‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌\n●Fragile‌ ‌X‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌\n●Hypophosphatemic‌ ‌\n●Rickets‌ ‌\n●Rett‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌\n●XD‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌\n●Heterozygous‌ ‌mother‌ ‌and‌ ‌hemizygous‌ ‌(unaffected)‌ ‌father:‌ ‌Children‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌50%‌ ‌probability‌ ‌of‌ ‌inheriting‌ ‌the‌ ‌trait/disease.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Homozygous‌ ‌mother‌ ‌and‌ ‌hemizygous‌ ‌(unaffected)‌ ‌father:‌ ‌All‌ ‌the‌ ‌children‌ ‌will‌ ‌inherit‌ ‌the‌ ‌trait/disease.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n752‌ ‌\n●Heterozygous‌ ‌mother‌ ‌and‌ ‌hemizygous‌ ‌(affected)‌ ‌father:‌ ‌Children‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌75%‌ ‌probability‌ ‌of‌ ‌inheriting‌ ‌the‌ ‌trait/disease.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Homozygous‌ ‌(unaffected)‌ ‌mother‌ ‌and‌ ‌hemizygous‌ ‌(affected)‌ ‌father‌ ‌\n●All‌ ‌daughters‌ ‌will‌ ‌be‌ ‌affected.‌ ‌\n●Sons‌ ‌are‌ ‌invariably‌ ‌unaffected.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n753‌ ‌\n ‌\n●In‌ ‌generation‌ ‌I,‌ ‌father‌ ‌is‌ ‌affected.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌generation‌ ‌II,‌ ‌both‌ ‌daughters‌ ‌1‌ ‌&‌ ‌3‌ ‌are‌ ‌also‌ ‌affected.‌ ‌\n●If‌ ‌the‌ ‌gene‌ ‌is‌ ‌inherited‌ ‌from‌ ‌other‌ ‌side‌ ‌both‌ ‌boy‌ ‌and‌ ‌girl‌ ‌have‌ ‌equal‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌\n ‌\nContemporary‌ ‌Relevance:‌ ‌\n●Genetic‌ ‌Counselors‌ ‌use‌ ‌Pedigree‌ ‌charts‌ ‌for‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌of‌ ‌various‌ ‌trade‌ ‌and‌ ‌diseases‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌family‌ ‌and‌ ‌predict‌ ‌their‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌pattern.‌ ‌\n● ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌useful‌ ‌in‌ ‌preventing‌ ‌haemophilia,‌ ‌sickle‌ ‌anaemia‌ ‌disease‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nii.‌ ‌Twin‌ ‌study‌ ‌\n●Twin‌ ‌method‌ ‌of‌ ‌studying‌ ‌Genetics‌ ‌is‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌comparison‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌monozygotic‌ ‌(MZ)‌ ‌and‌ ‌Dizygotic‌ ‌(DZ)‌ ‌twins,‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌purpose‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nestimating‌ ‌the‌ ‌degree‌ ‌of‌ ‌environmental‌ ‌versus‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌influence‌ ‌operating‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌specific‌ ‌trait.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nMZ‌ ‌\n●Identical‌ ‌twins‌ ‌are‌ ‌also‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌monozygotic‌ ‌twins.‌ ‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌result‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌fertilization‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌single‌ ‌egg‌ ‌that‌ ‌splits‌ ‌in‌ ‌two.‌ ‌Identical‌ ‌twins‌ ‌share‌ ‌all‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌genes‌ ‌and‌ ‌are‌ ‌always‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌\nsex.‌ ‌\nDZ‌ ‌\n●Dizygotic‌ ‌twins‌ ‌occur‌ ‌when‌ ‌two‌ ‌eggs‌ ‌are‌ ‌fertilized‌ ‌by‌ ‌two‌ ‌separate‌ ‌sperm.‌ ‌Dizygotic‌ ‌twins‌ ‌are‌ ‌also‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌fraternal‌ ‌or‌ ‌\nnon-identical‌ ‌twins.‌ ‌ ‌\n754‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌common‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌twins.‌ ‌1﻿‌ ‌Unlike‌ ‌monozygotic‌ ‌twins‌ ‌(also‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌identical‌ ‌twins),‌ ‌dizygotic‌ ‌twins‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌share‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌same‌ ‌genes.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●It‌ ‌was‌ ‌Galton‌ ‌in‌ ‌1870,‌ ‌who‌ ‌first‌ ‌tried‌ ‌to‌ ‌identify‌ ‌the‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌between‌ ‌nature‌ ‌and‌ ‌nurture.‌ ‌\n● ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌20th‌ ‌century‌ ‌the‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌twins‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌assessment‌ ‌of‌ ‌hereditary‌ ‌variation‌ ‌started‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌principle‌ ‌that‌ ‌monozygotic‌ ‌twins‌ ‌(by‌ ‌\nsplit‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌zygote)‌ ‌100%‌ ‌genetically‌ ‌similar‌ ‌but‌ ‌dizygotic‌ ‌twins‌ ‌(from‌ ‌diff‌ ‌zygotes)‌ ‌differ‌ ‌in‌ ‌some‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌composition.‌ ‌\n●Based‌ ‌on‌ ‌it‌ ‌through‌ ‌studies‌ ‌following‌ ‌conclusion‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌made:‌ ‌\n○If‌ ‌a‌ ‌trait‌ ‌is‌ ‌completely‌ ‌dependent‌ ‌on‌ ‌genetics‌ ‌then‌ ‌MZ‌ ‌twins‌ ‌will‌ ‌have‌ ‌complete‌ ‌resemblance.‌ ‌\n○If‌ ‌a‌ ‌trait‌ ‌is‌ ‌completely‌ ‌dependent‌ ‌on‌ ‌environment‌ ‌only‌ ‌then‌ ‌the‌ ‌MZ‌ ‌and‌ ‌dz‌ ‌twin‌ ‌will‌ ‌have‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌resemblance‌ ‌\n755‌ ‌\n○If‌ ‌a‌ ‌trait‌ ‌is‌ ‌dependent‌ ‌on‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌and‌ ‌environment‌ ‌then‌ ‌the‌ ‌MZ‌ ‌twins‌ ‌will‌ ‌have‌ ‌comparatively‌ ‌more‌ ‌resemblance‌ ‌than‌ ‌the‌ ‌DZ.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●How‌ ‌are‌ ‌they‌ ‌able‌ ‌to‌ ‌do‌ ‌this?‌ ‌ ‌\n●Twin‌ ‌studies‌ ‌allow‌ ‌researchers‌ ‌to‌ ‌examine‌ ‌the‌ ‌overall‌ ‌role‌ ‌of‌ ‌genes‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌trait‌ ‌or‌ ‌disorder.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Comparisons‌ ‌between‌ ‌monozygotic‌ ‌(MZ‌ ‌or‌ ‌identical)‌ ‌twins‌ ‌and‌ ‌dizygotic‌ ‌(DZ‌ ‌or‌ ‌fraternal)‌ ‌twins‌ ‌are‌ ‌conducted‌ ‌to‌ ‌evaluate‌ ‌the‌ ‌degree‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌and‌ ‌environmental‌ ‌influence‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌specific‌ ‌trait.‌ ‌ ‌\n●MZ‌ ‌twins‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌sex‌ ‌and‌ ‌share‌ ‌100%‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌genes.‌ ‌DZ‌ ‌twins‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌the‌ ‌same-‌ ‌or‌ ‌opposite-sex‌ ‌and‌ ‌share,‌ ‌on‌ ‌average,‌ ‌50%‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌their‌ ‌genes.‌ ‌\n●If‌ ‌MZ‌ ‌twins‌ ‌show‌ ‌more‌ ‌similarity‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌given‌ ‌trait‌ ‌compared‌ ‌to‌ ‌DZ‌ ‌twins,‌ ‌this‌ ‌provides‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌that‌ ‌genes‌ ‌significantly‌ ‌influence‌ ‌that‌ ‌\ntrait.‌ ‌However,‌ ‌if‌ ‌MZ‌ ‌and‌ ‌DZ‌ ‌twins‌ ‌share‌ ‌a‌ ‌trait‌ ‌to‌ ‌an‌ ‌equal‌ ‌extent,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌likely‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌environment‌ ‌influences‌ ‌the‌ ‌trait‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌\ngenetic‌ ‌factors.‌ ‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌example‌,‌ ‌Figure‌ ‌presents‌ ‌MZ‌ ‌and‌ ‌DZ‌ ‌twin‌ ‌correlations‌ ‌for‌ ‌several‌ ‌physical‌ ‌and‌ ‌psychological‌ ‌characteristics.‌ ‌ ‌\n756‌ ‌\n●As‌ ‌shown‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌figure,‌ ‌MZ‌ ‌twins,‌ ‌on‌ ‌average,‌ ‌are‌ ‌twice‌ ‌as‌ ‌similar‌ ‌as‌ ‌DZ‌ ‌twins‌ ‌for‌ ‌these‌ ‌characteristics,‌ ‌suggesting‌ ‌that‌ ‌genes‌ ‌\ninfluence‌ ‌the‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌traits.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌addition‌ ‌to‌ ‌traditional‌ ‌twin‌ ‌studies,‌ ‌children-of-twins‌ ‌studies‌ ‌are‌ ‌a‌ ‌particularly‌ ‌useful‌ ‌way‌ ‌to‌ ‌examine‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌and‌ ‌environmental‌ ‌\ninfluences‌ ‌on‌ ‌traits‌ ‌and‌ ‌disorders‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌transmission‌ ‌across‌ ‌generations.‌ ‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌example,‌ ‌since‌ ‌MZ‌ ‌(identical)‌ ‌twins‌ ‌share‌ ‌100%‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌genes,‌ ‌the‌ ‌children‌ ‌of‌ ‌MZ‌ ‌twins‌ ‌are‌ ‌as‌ ‌genetically‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌their‌ ‌twin‌ ‌\nparent’s‌ ‌twin‌ ‌sister‌ ‌or‌ ‌twin‌ ‌brother‌ ‌as‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌to‌ ‌their‌ ‌parent.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Given‌ ‌this,‌ ‌their‌ ‌cousins‌ ‌through‌ ‌that‌ ‌aunt‌ ‌or‌ ‌uncle‌ ‌are‌ ‌like‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌half-siblings.‌ ‌As‌ ‌these‌ ‌cousins‌ ‌typically‌ ‌live‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌\nhouseholds,‌ ‌this‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌allows‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌unique‌ ‌perspective‌ ‌into‌ ‌possible‌ ‌interactions‌ ‌between‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌influences‌ ‌and‌ ‌environmental‌ ‌\nfactors.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Results‌ ‌from‌ ‌twin‌ ‌studies‌ ‌may‌ ‌suggest‌ ‌that‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌trait‌ ‌or‌ ‌disorder‌ ‌has‌ ‌a‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌component,‌ ‌but‌ ‌this‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌provide‌ ‌\ninformation‌ ‌about‌ ‌the‌ ‌location‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌gene‌ ‌or‌ ‌genes.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Nevertheless,‌ ‌twin‌ ‌designs‌ ‌and‌ ‌methods‌ ‌are‌ ‌extremely‌ ‌useful‌ ‌for‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌the‌ ‌extent‌ ‌to‌ ‌which‌ ‌psychological‌ ‌and‌ ‌medical‌ ‌\ndisorders,‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌behaviors‌ ‌and‌ ‌traits,‌ ‌are‌ ‌influenced‌ ‌by‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌factors.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌information‌ ‌can‌ ‌then‌ ‌be‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌develop‌ ‌better‌ ‌ways‌ ‌to‌ ‌prevent‌ ‌and‌ ‌treat‌ ‌disorders‌ ‌and‌ ‌maladaptive‌ ‌behaviors.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Indeed,‌ ‌some‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌effective‌ ‌treatments‌ ‌for‌ ‌medical‌ ‌disorders‌ ‌(e.g.,‌ ‌early‌ ‌onset‌ ‌breast‌ ‌cancer)‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌developed‌ ‌partly‌ ‌as‌ ‌\na‌ ‌result‌ ‌of‌ ‌twin‌ ‌study‌ ‌research.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nViability‌ ‌of‌ ‌twin‌ ‌method‌ ‌in‌ ‌heritability‌ ‌estimates‌ ‌\n●Some‌ ‌point‌ ‌some‌ ‌time,‌ ‌the‌ ‌twin‌ ‌method‌ ‌is‌ ‌utilised‌ ‌to‌ ‌analyse‌ ‌the‌ ‌role‌ ‌of‌ ‌heredity‌ ‌and‌ ‌environment‌ ‌in‌ ‌bringing‌ ‌about‌ ‌human‌ ‌variation.‌ ‌\n●Moreover‌ ‌a‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌traits‌ ‌both‌ ‌physical‌ ‌and‌ ‌behavioural‌ ‌were‌ ‌analyzed‌ ‌using‌ ‌this‌ ‌method.‌ ‌\n757‌ ‌\n●However,‌ ‌the‌ ‌viability‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌method‌ ‌is‌ ‌under‌ ‌consideration.‌ ‌This‌ ‌is‌ ‌because‌ ‌of‌ ‌following‌ ‌reasons:‌ ‌ ‌\n○Method‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌actually‌ ‌specify‌ ‌the‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌and‌ ‌environment‌ ‌to‌ ‌composition‌ ‌but‌ ‌rather‌ ‌realise‌ ‌it.‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌recognise‌ ‌the‌ ‌nature,‌ ‌location‌ ‌and‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌of‌ ‌genes‌ ‌nor‌ ‌does‌ ‌it‌ ‌recognise‌ ‌the‌ ‌physical,‌ ‌chemical‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nbiological‌ ‌components‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌environment.‌ ‌\n■Entity‌ ‌and‌ ‌environment‌ ‌are‌ ‌rather‌ ‌treated‌ ‌as‌ ‌aggregate.‌ ‌\n○Heritability‌ ‌estimation‌ ‌of‌ ‌complex‌ ‌character‌ ‌as‌ ‌Intelligence‌ ‌and‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌are‌ ‌resented‌ ‌because‌ ‌they‌ ‌result‌ ‌not‌ ‌independently‌ ‌from‌ ‌\ngenetic‌ ‌or‌ ‌environmental‌ ‌influence‌ ‌alone‌ ‌but‌ ‌an‌ ‌abstract‌ ‌interaction‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌two‌ ‌which‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌be‌ ‌easily‌ ‌quantified.‌ ‌\n○Twin‌ ‌methods‌ ‌assume‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌MZ‌ ‌twins‌ ‌are‌ ‌exactly‌ ‌identical.‌ ‌However,‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌shows‌ ‌that‌ ‌they‌ ‌do‌ ‌differ‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌\ncharacters‌ ‌like‌ ‌size‌ ‌and‌ ‌vigor.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌twin‌ ‌method‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌be‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌estimate‌ ‌the‌ ‌intrauterine‌ ‌environment‌ ‌component‌ ‌and‌ ‌influence.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌difference‌ ‌in‌ ‌such‌ ‌environmental‌ ‌components‌ ‌may‌ ‌result‌ ‌in‌ ‌low‌ ‌concordance‌ ‌among‌ ‌MZ‌ ‌twins.‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌method‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌be‌ ‌applied‌ ‌to‌ ‌analyze‌ ‌traits‌ ‌like‌ ‌congenital‌ ‌misinformation.‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌majority‌ ‌of‌ ‌environmental‌ ‌factors‌ ‌are‌ ‌still‌ ‌being‌ ‌neglected.‌ ‌Hence,‌ ‌the‌ ‌changes‌ ‌brought‌ ‌about‌ ‌by‌ ‌these‌ ‌factors‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌falsely‌ ‌\nassumed‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌genetic.‌ ‌\n○One‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌important‌ ‌drawbacks‌ ‌of‌ ‌twin‌ ‌methods‌ ‌is‌ ‌that‌ ‌twining‌ ‌by‌ ‌nature‌ ‌in‌ ‌itself‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌very‌ ‌rare‌ ‌phenomenon.‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌such‌ ‌a‌ ‌case,‌ ‌this‌ ‌study‌ ‌is‌ ‌questionable‌ ‌in‌ ‌its‌ ‌objectivity.‌ ‌\n ‌\nConclusion‌ ‌\n●Results‌ ‌from‌ ‌twin‌ ‌studies‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌be‌ ‌directly‌ ‌generalized‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌general‌ ‌population,‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌lack‌ ‌of‌ ‌randomization;‌ ‌in‌ ‌addition,‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌\ndifferent‌ ‌with‌ ‌regard‌ ‌to‌ ‌their‌ ‌developmental‌ ‌environment,‌ ‌as‌ ‌two‌ ‌fetuses‌ ‌growing‌ ‌simultaneously.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\niii.‌ ‌Foster‌ ‌child‌ ‌or‌ ‌adoption‌ ‌stuy‌ ‌\n●Adoption‌ ‌studies‌ ‌are‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌classic‌ ‌tools‌ ‌of‌ ‌behavioral‌ ‌genetics.‌ ‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌studies‌ ‌are‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌estimate‌ ‌the‌ ‌degree‌ ‌to‌ ‌which‌ ‌variation‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌trait‌ ‌is‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌environmental‌ ‌and‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌influences.‌ ‌ ‌\n758‌ ‌\n●Adoption‌ ‌studies‌ ‌are‌ ‌typically‌ ‌used‌ ‌together‌ ‌with‌ ‌twin‌ ‌studies‌ ‌when‌ ‌estimating‌ ‌heritability.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●There‌ ‌are‌ ‌two‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌adoption‌ ‌study‌ ‌designs;‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌Adoptee's‌ ‌method‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌Familial‌ ‌method‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌most‌ ‌powerful‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌adoption‌ ‌studies‌ ‌compare‌ ‌pairs‌ ‌of‌ ‌genetically-identical‌ ‌monozygotic‌ ‌identical‌ ‌twins‌ ‌who‌ ‌are‌ ‌adopted‌ ‌into‌ ‌different‌ ‌\nfamilies‌ ‌(MZA);‌ ‌however,‌ ‌historical‌ ‌changes‌ ‌in‌ ‌adoption‌ ‌practices‌ ‌to‌ ‌try‌ ‌to‌ ‌keep‌ ‌twin‌ ‌pairs‌ ‌together‌ ‌make‌ ‌these‌ ‌now‌ ‌the‌ ‌rarest‌ ‌kind‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nadoption‌ ‌studies.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Adoption‌ ‌studies‌ ‌have‌ ‌pinpointed‌ ‌that‌ ‌some‌ ‌traits‌ ‌are‌ ‌linked‌ ‌to‌ ‌genetics,‌ ‌for‌ ‌example,‌ ‌Schizophrenia,‌ ‌IQ‌ ‌and‌ ‌criminality,‌ ‌however‌ ‌other‌ ‌\ncompound‌ ‌factors‌ ‌(such‌ ‌as‌ ‌age‌ ‌and‌ ‌environment)‌ ‌can‌ ‌have‌ ‌an‌ ‌impact‌ ‌too.‌ ‌\nTesting‌ ‌Design‌ ‌\n●Firstly,‌ ‌the‌ ‌adoptee's‌ ‌method‌ ‌investigates‌ ‌similarities‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌adoptee‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌biological‌ ‌and‌ ‌adoptive‌ ‌parents.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Similarity‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌biological‌ ‌parent‌ ‌is‌ ‌expected‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌heritable‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌effect,‌ ‌while‌ ‌similarity‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌adoptive‌ ‌parent‌ ‌is‌ ‌associated‌ ‌\nwith‌ ‌home-environment,‌ ‌called‌ ‌the‌ ‌shared‌ ‌environmental‌ ‌effect.‌ ‌\n●Secondly,‌ ‌the‌ ‌familial‌ ‌method‌ ‌compares‌ ‌non-biological‌ ‌siblings‌ ‌who‌ ‌are‌ ‌reared‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌household.‌ ‌\n○Similarity‌ ‌to‌ ‌non-biological‌ ‌siblings‌ ‌raised‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌household‌ ‌is‌ ‌attributed‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌shared‌ ‌environment‌ ‌effect,‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌siblings‌ ‌are‌ ‌\nbiologically‌ ‌unrelated‌ ‌but‌ ‌share‌ ‌the‌ ‌home‌ ‌environment.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Variation‌ ‌that‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌be‌ ‌accounted‌ ‌for‌ ‌by‌ ‌either‌ ‌genetics‌ ‌or‌ ‌home-environment‌ ‌is‌ ‌typically‌ ‌described‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌non-shared‌ ‌environment.‌ ‌Adoption‌ ‌\nstudies‌ ‌are‌ ‌meant‌ ‌to‌ ‌evaluate‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌and‌ ‌environmental‌ ‌influences‌ ‌on‌ ‌phenotype.‌ ‌\n●Case‌ ‌Studies:Refer‌ ‌Video‌ ‌\n ‌\nConclusion‌ ‌\n ‌\nIf‌ ‌something‌ ‌is‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌:‌ ‌\nIdentical‌ ‌twins‌ ‌raised‌ ‌together‌ ‌=‌ ‌Identical‌ ‌twins‌ ‌raised‌ ‌apart.‌ ‌\n759‌ ‌\nAdopted‌ ‌child‌ ‌=‌ ‌Biological‌ ‌parents‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nIf‌ ‌something‌ ‌is‌ ‌environmental:‌ ‌\nIdentical‌ ‌twins‌ ‌raised‌ ‌together‌ ‌‌≠‌ ‌ ‌Identical‌ ‌twins‌ ‌raised‌ ‌apart.‌ ‌\nAdopted‌ ‌child‌ ‌=‌ ‌Adoptive‌ ‌parents‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n9.1‌ ‌Human‌ ‌Genetics‌ ‌:‌ ‌Methods‌ ‌and‌ ‌Application:‌ ‌-Part-II‌ ‌ ‌\na)‌ ‌Methods‌ ‌for‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌principles‌ ‌in‌ ‌man-family‌ ‌study‌ ‌ ‌\niv.‌ ‌Co-twin‌ ‌method‌ ‌\nv.‌ ‌Cytogenetic‌ ‌method‌ ‌\nvi.‌ ‌Chromosomal‌ ‌and‌ ‌karyo-type‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌\nb)‌ ‌Biochemical‌ ‌methods‌ ‌\nc)‌ ‌Immunological‌ ‌methods‌ ‌\nd)‌ ‌D.N.A.‌ ‌technology‌ ‌&‌ ‌Recombinant‌ ‌technologies‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\niv.‌ ‌Co-twin‌ ‌method‌ ‌\n●Co‌ ‌twin‌ ‌method‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌method‌ ‌to‌ ‌study‌ ‌human‌ ‌genetics‌ ‌and‌ ‌its‌ ‌principles.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌method‌ ‌studies‌ ‌relative‌ ‌influences‌ ‌of‌ ‌heredity‌ ‌and‌ ‌environment‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌expression‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌trait.‌ ‌\n●Such‌ ‌investigation‌ ‌when‌ ‌done‌ ‌under‌ ‌controlled‌ ‌conditions,‌ ‌is‌ ‌called‌ ‌co-twin‌ ‌method.‌ ‌\n●Co-twin‌ ‌Method‌ ‌:‌ ‌ ‌\n○Co‐twin‌ ‌control‌ ‌studies‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌used‌ ‌in‌ ‌both‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌experimental‌ ‌and‌ ‌observational‌ ‌settings.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Various‌ ‌experiments‌ ‌have‌ ‌used‌ ‌monozygotic‌ ‌and‌ ‌dizygotic‌ ‌twins‌ ‌in‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌separate‌ ‌the‌ ‌hereditary‌ ‌and‌ ‌environmental‌ ‌\ncomponents‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌character‌ ‌Co-twin‌ ‌method‌ ‌is‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌them.‌ ‌\n■In‌ ‌co-twin‌ ‌studies‌ ‌the‌ ‌identical‌ ‌twins(MZ)‌ ‌along‌ ‌with‌ ‌its‌ ‌co-twin‌ ‌and‌ ‌ ‌\n■fraternal‌ ‌(DZ)‌ ‌twin‌ ‌along‌ ‌with‌ ‌its‌ ‌co-twin‌ ‌are‌ ‌investigated‌ ‌and‌ ‌compared.‌ ‌\n ‌\n760‌ ‌\nOutcomes:‌ ‌\n●While‌ ‌dealing‌ ‌with‌ ‌twin‌ ‌methods,‌ ‌it‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌stated‌ ‌that‌ ‌if‌ ‌monozygotic‌ ‌twins‌ ‌are‌ ‌reared‌ ‌apart‌ ‌they‌ ‌show‌ ‌differences,‌ ‌then‌ ‌these‌ ‌differences‌ ‌\nare‌ ‌regarded‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌caused‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌environment.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n○Examples‌ ‌:‌ ‌ ‌\n■An‌ ‌experiment‌ ‌was‌ ‌carried‌ ‌out‌ ‌by‌ ‌anthropologists‌ ‌with‌ ‌some‌ ‌monozygotic‌ ‌and‌ ‌dizygotic‌ ‌twins‌ ‌in‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌find‌ ‌out‌ ‌the‌ ‌influence‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌environment‌ ‌(say‌ ‌training)‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌particular‌ ‌trait‌ ‌(say‌ ‌intelligence).‌ ‌ ‌\n■All‌ ‌of‌ ‌them‌ ‌were‌ ‌tested‌ ‌before‌ ‌training.‌ ‌Then,‌ ‌a‌ ‌twin‌ ‌from‌ ‌each‌ ‌pair‌ ‌was‌ ‌given‌ ‌training‌ ‌for‌ ‌sometime.‌ ‌ ‌\n■All‌ ‌were‌ ‌tested‌ ‌again‌ ‌after‌ ‌providing‌ ‌training‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌set‌ ‌of‌ ‌twins‌ ‌described‌ ‌above.‌ ‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌was‌ ‌noted‌ ‌that‌ ‌performance‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌large‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌trained‌ ‌twins‌ ‌improved‌ ‌as‌ ‌compared‌ ‌to‌ ‌their‌ ‌co-twins.‌ ‌\n○Use‌ ‌of‌ ‌co-twin‌ ‌method‌ ‌\n○Separating‌ ‌influence‌ ‌of‌ ‌heredity‌ ‌and‌ ‌environment‌ ‌in‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌trait.‌ ‌\n○Determining‌ ‌effect‌ ‌of‌ ‌environment‌ ‌in‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌trait.‌ ‌\n○Identifying‌ ‌importance‌ ‌of‌ ‌heredity‌ ‌in‌ ‌determination‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌trait.‌ ‌\n○Study‌ ‌of‌ ‌mental‌ ‌traits.‌ ‌\n○Study‌ ‌of‌ ‌Mendelian‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌in‌ ‌man.‌ ‌\nConclusion‌ ‌\n●Co-twin‌ ‌method‌ ‌is‌ ‌one‌ ‌among‌ ‌other‌ ‌methods‌ ‌to‌ ‌study‌ ‌influence‌ ‌of‌ ‌heredity‌ ‌and‌ ‌environment‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌trait.‌ ‌Though,‌ ‌the‌ ‌method‌ ‌has‌ ‌\nlimitations‌ ‌like‌ ‌it‌ ‌falls‌ ‌short‌ ‌of‌ ‌providing‌ ‌any‌ ‌insight‌ ‌to‌ ‌genes‌ ‌involved,‌ ‌their‌ ‌mode‌ ‌of‌ ‌action‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌of‌ ‌transmission.‌ ‌Also,‌ ‌the‌ ‌results‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌twin‌ ‌studies‌ ‌are‌ ‌only‌ ‌applicable‌ ‌to‌ ‌twins,‌ ‌not‌ ‌whole‌ ‌populations.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nv.‌ ‌Cytogenetic‌ ‌method‌ ‌\n●Cytogenetics‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌branch‌ ‌of‌ ‌genetics‌ ‌that‌ ‌studies‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Cytogenetics‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌structure.‌ ‌\n●Chromosomes‌ ‌are‌ ‌complex‌ ‌structures‌ ‌located‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌cell‌ ‌nucleus,‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌composed‌ ‌of‌ ‌DNA,‌ ‌non‌ ‌histone,‌ ‌protein,‌ ‌RNA‌ ‌and‌ ‌\npolysaccharides.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n●The‌ ‌cytogenetic‌ ‌studies‌ ‌the‌ ‌number‌ ‌and‌ ‌morphology‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosomes.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Using‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌banding‌ ‌techniques‌ ‌(classical‌ ‌cytogenetics)‌ ‌or‌ ‌ ‌\n■hybridization‌ ‌fluorescently‌ ‌labeled‌ ‌probes‌ ‌(molecular‌ ‌cytogenetics).‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌number‌ ‌and‌ ‌morphology‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌cell‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌species‌ ‌are‌ ‌always‌ ‌constant,‌ ‌in‌ ‌most‌ ‌cells‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌body‌ ‌(with‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nexception‌ ‌of‌ ‌reproductive‌ ‌cells‌ ‌and‌ ‌others‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌liver).‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌characteristic‌ ‌of‌ ‌each‌ ‌specie,‌ ‌in‌ ‌humans‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌is‌ ‌46.‌ ‌\n ‌\nWhy‌ ‌Analyse‌ ‌Chromosomes‌ ‌and‌ ‌Genes?‌ ‌ ‌\n761‌ ‌\n●Genetic‌ ‌errors‌ ‌arise‌ ‌from‌ ‌deletions‌ ‌or‌ ‌insertions‌ ‌of‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌material,‌ ‌abnormal‌ ‌numbers‌ ‌of‌ ‌whole‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌or‌ ‌genes,‌ ‌and‌ ‌even‌ ‌from‌ ‌\nmisplacement‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌single‌ ‌base‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌DNA‌ ‌sequence.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Genetic‌ ‌abnormalities‌ ‌can‌ ‌range‌ ‌from‌ ‌relatively‌ ‌harmless‌ ‌to‌ ‌severe:‌ ‌from‌ ‌vitamin‌ ‌deficiencies‌ ‌and‌ ‌food‌ ‌allergies‌ ‌to‌ ‌cancer,‌ ‌birth‌ ‌defects‌ ‌and‌ ‌\ninfant‌ ‌mortality.‌ ‌\n ‌\nBasics‌ ‌\n●Deletions‌ ‌and‌ ‌Insertions‌ ‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌deletion‌ ‌removes‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌material‌ ‌\n■Male‌ ‌infertility:‌ ‌Tiny‌ ‌deletions‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌Y‌ ‌ ‌\n○An‌ ‌insertion‌ ‌adds‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌material‌ ‌\n■Gaucher‌ ‌disease:‌ ‌Insertion‌ ‌of‌ ‌one‌ ‌base‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nWhat‌ ‌is‌ ‌cytogenetic‌ ‌testing?‌ ‌\n●Cytogenesis‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌examination‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌to‌ ‌identify‌ ‌structural‌ ‌abnormalities.‌ ‌\n●Cytogenetic‌ ‌testing‌ ‌involves‌ ‌the‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌of‌ ‌cells‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌sample‌ ‌of‌ ‌blood,‌ ‌tissue,‌ ‌amniotic‌ ‌fluid,‌ ‌bone‌ ‌marrow,‌ ‌or‌ ‌cerebrovascular‌ ‌fluid‌ ‌to‌ ‌identify‌ ‌\nany‌ ‌changes‌ ‌in‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual’s‌ ‌chromosomes.‌ ‌\n●There‌ ‌are‌ ‌three‌ ‌major‌ ‌methods‌ ‌of‌ ‌cytogenetic‌ ‌testing:‌ ‌\n○Routine‌ ‌karyotyping‌ ‌\n○Fluorescent‌ ‌in‌ ‌situ‌ ‌hybridisation‌ ‌(FISH)‌ ‌\n○Comparative‌ ‌genomic‌ ‌hybridisation‌ ‌(CGH)‌ ‌and‌ ‌ ‌\n762‌ ‌\n○Array‌ ‌comparative‌ ‌genomic‌ ‌hybridisation‌ ‌(aCGH)‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Methods:‌ ‌\n○Chromosomes‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌dividing‌ ‌human‌ ‌cell‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌analyzed‌ ‌clearly‌ ‌in‌ ‌white‌ ‌blood‌ ‌cells,‌ ‌specifically‌ ‌‌T‌ ‌lymphocytes‌,‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌easily‌ ‌\ncollected‌ ‌from‌ ‌blood.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Cells‌ ‌from‌ ‌other‌ ‌tissues‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌bone‌ ‌marrow,‌ ‌amniotic‌ ‌fluid,‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌tissues‌ ‌can‌ ‌also‌ ‌be‌ ‌cultured‌ ‌for‌ ‌cytogenetic‌ ‌analysis.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Following‌ ‌several‌ ‌days‌ ‌of‌ ‌cell‌ ‌culture,‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌are‌ ‌fixed,‌ ‌spread‌ ‌on‌ ‌microscope‌ ‌slides,‌ ‌and‌ ‌stained.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌staining‌ ‌methods‌ ‌for‌ ‌routine‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌allow‌ ‌each‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌individually‌ ‌identified.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌distinct‌ ‌bands‌ ‌of‌ ‌each‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌revealed‌ ‌by‌ ‌staining‌ ‌allow‌ ‌for‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌chromosomal‌ ‌structure.‌ ‌\n○Fluorescent‌ ‌in‌ ‌situ‌ ‌hybridization‌ ‌(FISH)‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n763‌ ‌\n■FISH‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌molecular‌ ‌technique‌ ‌that‌ ‌uses‌ ‌fluorescent‌ ‌probes‌ ‌that‌ ‌bind‌ ‌to‌ ‌specific‌ ‌parts‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌\ndetect‌ ‌and‌ ‌localize‌ ‌the‌ ‌presence‌ ‌or‌ ‌absence‌ ‌of‌ ‌specific‌ ‌DNA‌ ‌sequences‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌process‌ ‌that‌ ‌vividly‌ ‌paints‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌or‌ ‌portions‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌with‌ ‌fluorescent‌ ‌molecules‌ ‌to‌ ‌identify‌ ‌\nchromosomal‌ ‌abnormalities‌ ‌(e.g.,‌ ‌insertions,‌ ‌deletions,‌ ‌translocations,‌ ‌and‌ ‌amplifications).‌ ‌ ‌\n■FISH‌ ‌was‌ ‌first‌ ‌introduced‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌late‌ ‌1980s‌ ‌and‌ ‌has‌ ‌rapidly‌ ‌become‌ ‌a‌ ‌well-known‌ ‌diagnostic‌ ‌cytogenetic‌ ‌test‌ ‌in‌ ‌both‌ ‌\ncongenital‌ ‌and‌ ‌acquired‌ ‌disease.‌ ‌ ‌\n■FISH‌ ‌has‌ ‌a‌ ‌much‌ ‌higher‌ ‌resolution‌ ‌than‌ ‌routine‌ ‌karyotyping,‌ ‌especially‌ ‌when‌ ‌used‌ ‌on‌ ‌interphase‌ ‌cells‌ ‌(the‌ ‌phase‌ ‌cells‌ ‌\nremain‌ ‌in‌ ‌when‌ ‌not‌ ‌in‌ ‌mitosis).‌ ‌\n■FISH‌ ‌uses‌ ‌fluorescent‌ ‌probes‌ ‌with‌ ‌complementary‌ ‌base‌ ‌sequences‌ ‌to‌ ‌locate‌ ‌the‌ ‌presence‌ ‌or‌ ‌absence‌ ‌of‌ ‌specific‌ ‌portions‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nDNA‌ ‌on‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌[2,6].‌ ‌The‌ ‌probe‌ ‌and‌ ‌target‌ ‌DNA‌ ‌must‌ ‌be‌ ‌denatured‌ ‌with‌ ‌heat‌ ‌or‌ ‌chemicals‌ ‌to‌ ‌break‌ ‌hydrogen‌ ‌bonds‌ ‌\nin‌ ‌the‌ ‌DNA‌ ‌and‌ ‌to‌ ‌allow‌ ‌hybridisation‌ ‌to‌ ‌occur‌ ‌once‌ ‌the‌ ‌two‌ ‌samples‌ ‌are‌ ‌mixed.‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌fluorescent‌ ‌probes‌ ‌form‌ ‌new‌ ‌hydrogen‌ ‌bonds‌ ‌with‌ ‌their‌ ‌complementary‌ ‌base‌ ‌pairs‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌DNA,‌ ‌and‌ ‌these‌ ‌can‌ ‌then‌ ‌be‌ ‌\ndetected‌ ‌via‌ ‌microscopy.‌ ‌\n■FISH‌ ‌is‌ ‌commonly‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌detect‌ ‌specific‌ ‌chromosomal‌ ‌deletions‌ ‌or‌ ‌translocations‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌paediatric‌ ‌conditions‌ ‌or‌ ‌\ncancers.‌ ‌\n■Examples‌‌ ‌include‌ ‌the‌ ‌deletion‌ ‌on‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌22‌ ‌in‌ ‌‌DiGeorge‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌translocation‌ ‌of‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌gene‌ ‌on‌ ‌\nchromosomes‌ ‌22‌ ‌and‌ ‌9‌ ‌in‌ ‌chronic‌ ‌myeloid‌ ‌leukaemia.‌ ‌\n■FISH‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌used‌ ‌for‌ ‌melanocytic‌ ‌lesions‌ ‌to‌ ‌distinguish‌ ‌atypical‌ ‌melanocytic‌ ‌naevi‌ ‌(eg,‌ ‌Spitz‌ ‌naevus)‌ ‌from‌ ‌melanoma.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nApplications‌ ‌in‌ ‌cytogenetics‌ ‌\n○One‌ ‌important‌ ‌area‌ ‌of‌ ‌application‌ ‌for‌ ‌cytogenetic‌ ‌techniques‌ ‌is‌ ‌in‌ ‌cancer‌ ‌management,‌ ‌to‌ ‌detect‌ ‌somatic‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌changes‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nneoplastic‌ ‌cells.‌ ‌In‌ ‌cancer,‌ ‌cytogenetic‌ ‌investigations‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌help‌ ‌with‌ ‌diagnosis,‌ ‌inform‌ ‌prognosis,‌ ‌or‌ ‌help‌ ‌prioritise‌ ‌\ntreatment‌ ‌options.‌ ‌\n○Cytogenetics‌ ‌is‌ ‌poised‌ ‌to‌ ‌have‌ ‌an‌ ‌important‌ ‌role‌ ‌in‌ ‌plant‌ ‌biology‌ ‌into‌ ‌the‌ ‌future.‌ ‌Therefore,‌ ‌informed‌ ‌plant‌ ‌breeding‌ ‌to‌ ‌increase‌ ‌yield‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌quality‌ ‌and‌ ‌to‌ ‌improve‌ ‌farming‌ ‌practice‌ ‌is‌ ‌urgently‌ ‌needed.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Detecting‌ ‌and‌ ‌characterising‌ ‌alien‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌or‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌segments‌ ‌in‌ ‌plant‌ ‌breeding‌ ‌lines‌ ‌with‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌\nsegments‌ ‌of‌ ‌various‌ ‌origins.‌ ‌\n■Developing‌ ‌markers‌ ‌for‌ ‌characters‌ ‌of‌ ‌interest‌ ‌to‌ ‌plant‌ ‌breeders.‌ ‌\n ‌\nDisadvantages‌ ‌of‌ ‌cytogenetic‌ ‌testing‌ ‌\n●Unfortunately,‌ ‌cytogenetic‌ ‌testing‌ ‌is‌ ‌limited‌ ‌by‌ ‌its‌ ‌resolution.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌different‌ ‌methods‌ ‌can‌ ‌identify‌ ‌small‌ ‌gains‌ ‌and‌ ‌losses‌ ‌of‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌material,‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌larger‌ ‌translocations,‌ ‌but‌ ‌they‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌allow‌ ‌testing‌ ‌\nfor‌ ‌single‌ ‌nucleotide‌ ‌variations‌ ‌that‌ ‌could‌ ‌contribute‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌patient’s‌ ‌condition.‌ ‌ ‌\n●There‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌the‌ ‌possibility‌ ‌that‌ ‌cytogenetic‌ ‌testing‌ ‌will‌ ‌identify‌ ‌other‌ ‌chromosomal‌ ‌changes‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌necessarily‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌patient’s‌ ‌\ncondition.‌ ‌\n764‌ ‌\n ‌\nConclusion‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌cytogenetic‌ ‌techniques‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌mapping‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌human‌ ‌genome‌ ‌have‌ ‌provided‌ ‌scientists‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌great‌ ‌deal‌ ‌of‌ ‌insight‌ ‌into‌ ‌the‌ ‌\ncauses‌ ‌of‌ ‌numerous‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌disorders.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Though‌ ‌rooted‌ ‌in‌ ‌early‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌staining‌ ‌and‌ ‌gene‌ ‌mapping‌ ‌techniques,‌ ‌modern‌ ‌FISH,‌ ‌SKY,‌ ‌and‌ ‌CGH‌ ‌methods‌ ‌have‌ ‌far‌ ‌outshone‌ ‌their‌ ‌\npredecessors‌ ‌by‌ ‌providing‌ ‌an‌ ‌unprecedented‌ ‌view‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌chromosomes.‌ ‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌procedures‌ ‌allow‌ ‌for‌ ‌precise‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌labeling‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌identification‌ ‌of‌ ‌missing‌ ‌or‌ ‌translocated‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌or‌ ‌genes,‌ ‌and‌ ‌they‌ ‌\nhave‌ ‌lessened‌ ‌cytogeneticists'‌ ‌reliance‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌light‌ ‌microscope‌ ‌in‌ ‌favor‌ ‌of‌ ‌more‌ ‌high-tech‌ ‌devices.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌the‌ ‌decades‌ ‌to‌ ‌come,‌ ‌cytogenetic‌ ‌technologies‌ ‌will‌ ‌be‌ ‌further‌ ‌refined,‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌future‌ ‌of‌ ‌molecular‌ ‌cytogenetics‌ ‌looks‌ ‌bright.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌field‌ ‌will‌ ‌most‌ ‌certainly‌ ‌continue‌ ‌to‌ ‌uncover‌ ‌new,‌ ‌unexpected‌ ‌insights‌ ‌about‌ ‌both‌ ‌human‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌structure‌ ‌and‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌disease.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nvi.‌ ‌Chromosomal‌ ‌and‌ ‌karyo-type‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌\n ‌\nWhat‌ ‌is‌ ‌Karyotype?‌ ‌\n●Karyotyping‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌process‌ ‌by‌ ‌which‌ ‌photographs‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌are‌ ‌taken‌ ‌in‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌determine‌ ‌the‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌complement‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌\nindividual,‌ ‌including‌ ‌the‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌and‌ ‌any‌ ‌abnormalities.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌term‌ ‌karyotype‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌used‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌complete‌ ‌set‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌species‌ ‌or‌ ‌in‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌organism‌ ‌and‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌test‌ ‌that‌ ‌detects‌ ‌\nthis‌ ‌complement‌ ‌or‌ ‌measures‌ ‌the‌ ‌number.‌ ‌\n●Karyotypes‌ ‌describe‌ ‌the‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌count‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌organism‌ ‌and‌ ‌what‌ ‌these‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌look‌ ‌like‌ ‌under‌ ‌a‌ ‌light‌ ‌microscope.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Attention‌ ‌is‌ ‌paid‌ ‌to‌ ‌their‌ ‌length,‌ ‌the‌ ‌position‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌centromeres,‌ ‌banding‌ ‌pattern,‌ ‌any‌ ‌differences‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌sex‌ ‌chromosomes,‌ ‌and‌ ‌any‌ ‌\nother‌ ‌physical‌ ‌characteristics.‌ ‌The‌ ‌preparation‌ ‌and‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌karyotypes‌ ‌is‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌cytogenetics.‌ ‌\n●Karyotypes‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌used‌ ‌for‌ ‌many‌ ‌purposes;‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌to‌ ‌study‌ ‌chromosomal‌ ‌aberrations,‌ ‌cellular‌ ‌function,‌ ‌taxonomic‌ ‌relationships,‌ ‌medicine‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌to‌ ‌gather‌ ‌information‌ ‌about‌ ‌past‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌events‌ ‌(karyo‌ ‌systematics).‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n765‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Chromosome‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌or‌ ‌karyotyping‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌test‌ ‌that‌ ‌evaluates‌ ‌the‌ ‌number‌ ‌and‌ ‌structure‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌person's‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌in‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌detect‌ ‌\nabnormalities.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Chromosomes‌ ‌are‌ ‌thread-like‌ ‌structures‌ ‌within‌ ‌each‌ ‌cell‌ ‌nucleus‌ ‌and‌ ‌contain‌ ‌the‌ ‌body's‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌blueprint.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Each‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌contains‌ ‌thousands‌ ‌of‌ ‌genes‌ ‌in‌ ‌specific‌ ‌locations.‌ ‌These‌ ‌genes‌ ‌are‌ ‌responsible‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌person’s‌ ‌inherited‌ ‌physical‌ ‌\ncharacteristics‌ ‌and‌ ‌they‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌profound‌ ‌impact‌ ‌on‌ ‌growth,‌ ‌development,‌ ‌and‌ ‌function.‌ ‌\n●Humans‌ ‌have‌ ‌46‌ ‌chromosomes,‌ ‌present‌ ‌as‌ ‌23‌ ‌pairs.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Twenty-two‌ ‌pairs‌ ‌are‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌both‌ ‌sexes‌ ‌(autosomes)‌ ‌and‌ ‌one‌ ‌pair‌ ‌(sex‌ ‌chromosomes)‌ ‌is‌ ‌present‌ ‌as‌ ‌either‌ ‌XY‌ ‌(in‌ ‌males)‌ ‌or‌ ‌XX‌ ‌(in‌ ‌\nfemales).‌ ‌ ‌\n○Normally,‌ ‌all‌ ‌cells‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌body‌ ‌that‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌nucleus‌ ‌will‌ ‌contain‌ ‌a‌ ‌complete‌ ‌set‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌46‌ ‌chromosomes,‌ ‌except‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nreproductive‌ ‌cells‌ ‌(eggs‌ ‌and‌ ‌sperm),‌ ‌which‌ ‌contain‌ ‌a‌ ‌half‌ ‌set‌ ‌of‌ ‌23.‌ ‌ ‌\n766‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌half‌ ‌set‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌contribution‌ ‌that‌ ‌will‌ ‌be‌ ‌passed‌ ‌on‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌child.‌ ‌At‌ ‌conception,‌ ‌half‌ ‌sets‌ ‌from‌ ‌each‌ ‌parent‌ ‌combine‌ ‌to‌ ‌form‌ ‌a‌ ‌new‌ ‌set‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌46‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌developing‌ ‌fetus.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Chromosomal‌ ‌abnormalities‌ ‌include‌ ‌both‌ ‌numerical‌ ‌and‌ ‌structural‌ ‌changes.‌ ‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌numerical‌ ‌changes,‌ ‌anything‌ ‌other‌ ‌than‌ ‌a‌ ‌complete‌ ‌set‌ ‌of‌ ‌46‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌represents‌ ‌a‌ ‌change‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌amount‌ ‌of‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌\nmaterial‌ ‌present‌ ‌and‌ ‌can‌ ‌cause‌ ‌health‌ ‌and‌ ‌development‌ ‌problems.‌ ‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌structural‌ ‌changes,‌ ‌the‌ ‌significance‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌problems‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌severity‌ ‌depends‌ ‌upon‌ ‌the‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌altered.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌type‌ ‌and‌ ‌degree‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌problem‌ ‌may‌ ‌vary‌ ‌from‌ ‌person‌ ‌to‌ ‌person,‌ ‌even‌ ‌when‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌abnormality‌ ‌is‌ ‌present.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●A‌ ‌chromosomal‌ ‌karyotyping‌ ‌examines‌ ‌a‌ ‌person's‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌to‌ ‌determine‌ ‌if‌ ‌the‌ ‌right‌ ‌number‌ ‌is‌ ‌present‌ ‌and‌ ‌to‌ ‌determine‌ ‌if‌ ‌each‌ ‌\nchromosome‌ ‌appears‌ ‌normal.‌ ‌ ‌\n●While‌ ‌theoretically‌ ‌almost‌ ‌any‌ ‌cells‌ ‌could‌ ‌be‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌perform‌ ‌testing,‌ ‌in‌ ‌practice‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌usually‌ ‌performed‌ ‌on‌ ‌amniotic‌ ‌fluid‌ ‌to‌ ‌evaluate‌ ‌a‌ ‌fetus‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌on‌ ‌lymphocytes‌ ‌(a‌ ‌white‌ ‌blood‌ ‌cell)‌ ‌from‌ ‌a‌ ‌blood‌ ‌sample‌ ‌to‌ ‌test‌ ‌all‌ ‌other‌ ‌ages.‌ ‌ ‌\n767‌ ‌\n●Alternately,‌ ‌white‌ ‌blood‌ ‌cells‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌obtained‌ ‌from‌ ‌bone‌ ‌marrow‌ ‌aspirations‌ ‌to‌ ‌look‌ ‌for‌ ‌changes‌ ‌in‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌suspected‌ ‌of‌ ‌having‌ ‌\nhematologic‌ ‌or‌ ‌lymphoid‌ ‌diseases‌ ‌(e.g.,‌ ‌leukemia,‌ ‌lymphoma,‌ ‌myeloma,‌ ‌refractory‌ ‌anemia).‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nHow‌ ‌Karyotype‌ ‌Tests‌ ‌is‌ ‌performed:‌ ‌\n●Taking‌ ‌a‌ ‌sample‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌person's‌ ‌cells,‌ ‌culturing‌ ‌them‌ ‌in‌ ‌nutrient-enriched‌ ‌media‌ ‌to‌ ‌promote‌ ‌cell‌ ‌division‌ ‌in‌ ‌vitro.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌is‌ ‌done‌ ‌in‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌select‌ ‌a‌ ‌specific‌ ‌time‌ ‌during‌ ‌the‌ ‌cells'‌ ‌growth‌ ‌phase‌ ‌when‌ ‌the‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌are‌ ‌easiest‌ ‌to‌ ‌distinguish.‌ ‌\n○During‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌metaphase‌ ‌portion‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌cell‌ ‌cycle,‌ ‌when‌ ‌the‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌are‌ ‌lined‌ ‌along‌ ‌the‌ ‌equator‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌cell‌ ‌prior‌ ‌to‌ ‌separation‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nare‌ ‌most‌ ‌condensed.‌ ‌\n ‌\n768‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Isolating‌ ‌the‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌nucleus‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌cells,‌ ‌placing‌ ‌them‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌slide,‌ ‌and‌ ‌treating‌ ‌them‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌special‌ ‌stain.‌ ‌\n●Taking‌ ‌microphotographs‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌chromosomes.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌jigsaw‌ ‌puzzle‌ ‌fashion,‌ ‌rearranging‌ ‌the‌ ‌pictures‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌to‌ ‌match‌ ‌up‌ ‌pairs‌ ‌and‌ ‌arrange‌ ‌them‌ ‌by‌ ‌size,‌ ‌from‌ ‌largest‌ ‌to‌ ‌smallest,‌ ‌\nnumbers‌ ‌1‌ ‌to‌ ‌22,‌ ‌followed‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌sex‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌23rd‌ ‌pair.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌pictures‌ ‌also‌ ‌allow‌ ‌the‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌vertically‌ ‌oriented.‌ ‌Each‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌looks‌ ‌like‌ ‌a‌ ‌striped‌ ‌straw.‌ ‌It‌ ‌has‌ ‌two‌ ‌arms‌ ‌that‌ ‌differ‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nlength‌ ‌(a‌ ‌short‌ ‌arm‌ ‌(p)‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌long‌ ‌arm‌ ‌(q)),‌ ‌a‌ ‌pinched-in‌ ‌area‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌arms‌ ‌called‌ ‌a‌ ‌centromere,‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌series‌ ‌of‌ ‌light‌ ‌and‌ ‌dark‌ ‌\nhorizontal‌ ‌bands.‌ ‌The‌ ‌length‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌arms‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌location‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌bands‌ ‌help‌ ‌determine‌ ‌top‌ ‌from‌ ‌bottom.‌ ‌\n●Once‌ ‌the‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌photo‌ ‌arrangement‌ ‌is‌ ‌completed,‌ ‌a‌ ‌laboratory‌ ‌specialist‌ ‌evaluates‌ ‌the‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌pairs‌ ‌and‌ ‌identifies‌ ‌any‌ ‌\nabnormalities‌ ‌that‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌present.‌ ‌\n ‌\n○Simply,‌ ‌Karyotype‌ ‌tests‌ ‌take‌ ‌a‌ ‌close‌ ‌look‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌inside‌ ‌your‌ ‌cells‌ ‌to‌ ‌see‌ ‌if‌ ‌anything‌ ‌about‌ ‌them‌ ‌is‌ ‌unusual.‌ ‌ ‌\n769‌ ‌\n○They’re‌ ‌often‌ ‌done‌ ‌during‌ ‌pregnancy‌ ‌to‌ ‌spot‌ ‌problems‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌baby.‌ ‌This‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌procedure‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to‌ ‌as‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌or‌ ‌\nchromosome‌ ‌testing,‌ ‌or‌ ‌cytogenetic‌ ‌analysis.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Some‌ ‌examples‌ ‌of‌ ‌abnormalities‌ ‌that‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌may‌ ‌reveal‌ ‌include:‌ ‌\n○Trisomy‌ ‌\n■This‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌presence‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌extra‌ ‌chromosome,‌ ‌a‌ ‌third‌ ‌instead‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌pair.‌ ‌\n■Diseases‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌trisomies‌ ‌include‌ ‌Down‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌(associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌Trisomy‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌21),‌ ‌Patau‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌\n(Trisomy‌ ‌13),‌ ‌Edward‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌(Trisomy‌ ‌18),‌ ‌and‌ ‌Klinefelter‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌(a‌ ‌male‌ ‌with‌ ‌an‌ ‌extra‌ ‌X‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌–‌ ‌XXY‌ ‌instead‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌XY).‌ ‌\n○Monosomy‌ ‌\n■This‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌absence‌ ‌of‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌chromosomes.‌ ‌ ‌\n■An‌ ‌example‌ ‌of‌ ‌monosomy‌ ‌is‌ ‌Turner‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌(a‌ ‌female‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌single‌ ‌X‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌–‌ ‌X‌ ‌instead‌ ‌of‌ ‌XX).‌ ‌ ‌\n■Most‌ ‌other‌ ‌monosomies‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌compatible‌ ‌with‌ ‌life.‌ ‌\n○Deletions‌ ‌\n■These‌ ‌are‌ ‌missing‌ ‌pieces‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌and/or‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌material.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Some‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌small‌ ‌and‌ ‌difficult‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌detected.‌ ‌\n○Duplications‌ ‌\n■These‌ ‌represent‌ ‌extra‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌material‌ ‌and‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌present‌ ‌on‌ ‌any‌ ‌chromosome,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌presence‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌horizontal‌ ‌\nbands‌ ‌at‌ ‌a‌ ‌specific‌ ‌location‌ ‌instead‌ ‌of‌ ‌one.‌ ‌\n○Translocations‌ ‌\n■With‌ ‌translocations,‌ ‌pieces‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌break‌ ‌off‌ ‌and‌ ‌reattach‌ ‌to‌ ‌another‌ ‌chromosome.‌ ‌ ‌\n■If‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌one-to-one‌ ‌switch‌ ‌and‌ ‌all‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌material‌ ‌is‌ ‌present‌ ‌(but‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌wrong‌ ‌place),‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌said‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌a‌ ‌balanced‌ ‌\ntranslocation.‌ ‌ ‌\n■If‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌not,‌ ‌then‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌called‌ ‌an‌ ‌unbalanced‌ ‌translocation.‌ ‌\n○Genetic‌ ‌Rearrangement‌ ‌\n■With‌ ‌this,‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌material‌ ‌is‌ ‌present‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌but‌ ‌not‌ ‌in‌ ‌its‌ ‌usual‌ ‌location.‌ ‌ ‌\n■A‌ ‌person‌ ‌could‌ ‌have‌ ‌both‌ ‌rearrangement‌ ‌and‌ ‌duplication‌ ‌or‌ ‌deletion.‌ ‌ ‌\n■An‌ ‌almost‌ ‌infinite‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌rearrangements‌ ‌are‌ ‌possible.‌ ‌Interpreting‌ ‌the‌ ‌effects‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌changes‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌challenging.‌ ‌\n ‌\n770‌ ‌\n ‌\nExample:‌ ‌ ‌\n●Turner‌ ‌Syndrome-Turner‌ ‌syndrome,‌ ‌a‌ ‌condition‌ ‌that‌ ‌affects‌ ‌only‌ ‌females,‌ ‌results‌ ‌when‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌X‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌(sex‌ ‌\nchromosomes)‌ ‌is‌ ‌missing‌ ‌or‌ ‌partially‌ ‌missing.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Turner‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌can‌ ‌cause‌ ‌a‌ ‌variety‌ ‌of‌ ‌medical‌ ‌and‌ ‌developmental‌ ‌problems,‌ ‌including‌ ‌short‌ ‌height,‌ ‌failure‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌ovaries‌ ‌to‌ ‌develop‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌heart‌ ‌defects.‌ ‌\n ‌\n771‌ ‌\n ‌\nUses‌ ‌for‌ ‌Karyotype‌ ‌Tests‌ ‌\n●Humans‌ ‌have‌ ‌‌46‌ ‌chromosomes‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Babies‌ ‌inherit‌ ‌23‌ ‌from‌ ‌their‌ ‌mom‌ ‌and‌ ‌23‌ ‌from‌ ‌their‌ ‌dad.‌ ‌\n●Sometimes,‌ ‌babies‌ ‌have‌ ‌an‌ ‌extra‌ ‌chromosome,‌ ‌a‌ ‌missing‌ ‌chromosome,‌ ‌or‌ ‌an‌ ‌abnormal‌ ‌chromosome.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Karyotype‌ ‌tests‌ ‌will‌ ‌see‌ ‌if‌ ‌any‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌have‌ ‌happened‌ ‌with‌ ‌your‌ ‌baby.‌ ‌The‌ ‌most‌ ‌common‌ ‌things‌ ‌doctors‌ ‌look‌ ‌for‌ ‌with‌ ‌karyotype‌ ‌tests‌ ‌\ninclude:‌ ‌\n○Down‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌(trisomy‌ ‌21).‌‌ ‌A‌ ‌baby‌ ‌has‌ ‌an‌ ‌extra,‌ ‌or‌ ‌third,‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌21.‌ ‌This‌ ‌affects‌ ‌how‌ ‌the‌ ‌baby‌ ‌looks‌ ‌and‌ ‌learns.‌ ‌\n○Edwards‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌(trisomy‌ ‌18)‌.‌ ‌A‌ ‌baby‌ ‌has‌ ‌an‌ ‌extra‌ ‌18th‌ ‌chromosome.‌ ‌These‌ ‌babies‌ ‌usually‌ ‌have‌ ‌many‌ ‌problems,‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nmost‌ ‌don’t‌ ‌live‌ ‌longer‌ ‌than‌ ‌a‌ ‌year.‌ ‌\n○Patau‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌(trisomy‌ ‌13).‌‌ ‌A‌ ‌baby‌ ‌has‌ ‌an‌ ‌extra‌ ‌13th‌ ‌chromosome.‌ ‌These‌ ‌babies‌ ‌usually‌ ‌have‌ ‌heart‌ ‌problems‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nsevere‌ ‌mental‌ ‌impairment.‌ ‌Most‌ ‌won’t‌ ‌live‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌a‌ ‌year.‌ ‌\n○Klinefelter‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌.‌‌ ‌A‌ ‌boy‌ ‌baby‌ ‌has‌ ‌an‌ ‌extra‌ ‌X‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌(XXY).‌ ‌They‌ ‌may‌ ‌go‌ ‌through‌ ‌puberty‌ ‌at‌ ‌a‌ ‌slower‌ ‌pace,‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nmay‌ ‌not‌ ‌be‌ ‌able‌ ‌to‌ ‌have‌ ‌children.‌ ‌\n○Turner‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌.‌‌ ‌A‌ ‌girl‌ ‌baby‌ ‌has‌ ‌a‌ ‌missing‌ ‌or‌ ‌damaged‌ ‌X‌ ‌chromosome.‌ ‌It‌ ‌causes‌ ‌heart‌ ‌problems,‌ ‌neck‌ ‌problems,‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nshort‌ ‌height.‌ ‌\n ‌\n772‌ ‌\nKaryotype‌ ‌tests‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌used‌ ‌for‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌finding‌ ‌birth‌ ‌defects‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌can‌ ‌find‌ ‌out‌ ‌if‌ ‌a‌ ‌person‌ ‌has‌ ‌a‌ ‌disorder‌ ‌that‌ ‌could‌ ‌pass‌ ‌down‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌child.‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌can‌ ‌test‌ ‌a‌ ‌stillborn‌ ‌baby‌ ‌to‌ ‌see‌ ‌if‌ ‌there‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌issue.‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌can‌ ‌find‌ ‌the‌ ‌cause‌ ‌of‌ ‌certain‌ ‌physical‌ ‌or‌ ‌developmental‌ ‌problems‌ ‌your‌ ‌baby‌ ‌or‌ ‌young‌ ‌child‌ ‌has.‌ ‌\n●Chromosome‌ ‌tests‌ ‌can‌ ‌show‌ ‌whether‌ ‌a‌ ‌newborn‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌boy‌ ‌or‌ ‌a‌ ‌girl‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌rare‌ ‌cases‌ ‌where‌ ‌it‌ ‌isn’t‌ ‌clear.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Certain‌ ‌kinds‌ ‌of‌ ‌cancer‌ ‌can‌ ‌cause‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌changes.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Karyotype‌ ‌testing‌ ‌can‌ ‌help‌ ‌get‌ ‌you‌ ‌the‌ ‌right‌ ‌treatment.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nb)‌ ‌Biochemical‌ ‌methods‌ ‌\nIntroduction‌ ‌\n●Biochemistry‌ ‌is‌ ‌carried‌ ‌out‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌cellular‌ ‌or‌ ‌subcellular‌ ‌level,‌ ‌generally‌ ‌on‌ ‌cell‌ ‌extracts.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Biochemical‌ ‌methods‌ ‌are‌ ‌applied‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌main‌ ‌chemical‌ ‌compounds‌ ‌of‌ ‌genetics—notably‌ ‌DNA,RNA,‌ ‌and‌ ‌protein.‌ ‌\n●Biochemical‌ ‌techniques‌ ‌are‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌determine‌ ‌the‌ ‌activities‌ ‌of‌ ‌genes‌ ‌within‌ ‌cells‌ ‌and‌ ‌to‌ ‌analyze‌ ‌substrates‌ ‌and‌ ‌products‌ ‌of‌ ‌gene-controlled‌ ‌\nreactions.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌one‌ ‌approach,‌ ‌cells‌ ‌are‌ ‌ground‌ ‌up‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌substituent‌ ‌chemicals‌ ‌are‌ ‌fractionated‌ ‌for‌ ‌further‌ ‌analysis.‌ ‌\n●Special‌ ‌techniques‌ ‌(e.g.‌ ‌chromatography‌ ‌and‌ ‌electrophoresis)‌ ‌‌are‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌separate‌ ‌the‌ ‌components‌ ‌of‌ ‌proteins‌ ‌so‌ ‌that‌ ‌inherited‌ ‌\ndifferences‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌structures‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌revealed.‌ ‌\n●Specialised‌ ‌biochemical‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌departments‌ ‌offer‌ ‌clinical‌ ‌and‌ ‌laboratory‌ ‌services‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌range‌ ‌of‌ ‌inherited‌ ‌metabolic‌ ‌disorders.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Tests‌ ‌are‌ ‌undertaken‌ ‌to‌ ‌identify‌ ‌conditions‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌disorders‌ ‌of‌ ‌amino‌ ‌acids,‌ ‌organic‌ ‌acids‌ ‌and‌ ‌mucopolysaccharides,‌ ‌lysosomal‌ ‌and‌ ‌lipid‌ ‌\nstorage‌ ‌diseases,‌ ‌peroxisomal‌ ‌and‌ ‌mitochondrial‌ ‌disorders.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Tests‌ ‌for‌ ‌other‌ ‌metabolites‌ ‌or‌ ‌enzymes‌ ‌are‌ ‌performed‌ ‌when‌ ‌a‌ ‌diagnosis‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌specific‌ ‌disorder‌ ‌is‌ ‌being‌ ‌considered‌ ‌\n ‌\nHow?‌ ‌\n●Gene‌ ‌controls‌ ‌the‌ ‌appearance‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌phenotypic‌ ‌trait‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌organism‌ ‌exercising‌ ‌control‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌developmental‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌biological‌ ‌activities‌ ‌of‌ ‌its‌ ‌\ncell.‌ ‌ ‌\n●All‌ ‌activities‌ ‌are‌ ‌controlled‌ ‌by‌ ‌enzymes,‌ ‌whose‌ ‌synthesis‌ ‌is‌ ‌directly‌ ‌supervised‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌genes.‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌gene‌ ‌is‌ ‌capable‌ ‌of‌ ‌synthesizing‌ ‌the‌ ‌required‌ ‌enzymes‌ ‌and‌ ‌expresses‌ ‌itself.‌ ‌\n●Biochemical‌ ‌genetics‌ ‌combines‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌and‌ ‌biochemistry‌ ‌to‌ ‌elucidate‌ ‌the‌ ‌nature‌ ‌of‌ ‌metabolic‌ ‌Pathways‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌control.‌ ‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌widely‌ ‌studied‌ ‌in‌ ‌man‌ ‌where‌ ‌any‌ ‌error‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌metabolic‌ ‌pathway‌ ‌is‌ ‌expressed‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌disease.‌ ‌\n●Biochemical‌ ‌Genetics‌ ‌was‌ ‌initiated‌ ‌by‌ ‌English‌ ‌physician‌ ‌‌A.E.‌ ‌Garrod‌‌ ‌when‌ ‌he‌ ‌noticed‌ ‌that‌ ‌some‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌hereditary‌ ‌diseases‌ ‌in‌ ‌man‌ ‌are‌ ‌due‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌the‌ ‌effect‌ ‌of‌ ‌mutant‌ ‌genes‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌metabolic‌ ‌system.‌ ‌\n●5‌ ‌metabolic‌ ‌disorder‌ ‌‌(phenylketonuria,‌ ‌alkaptonuria,‌ ‌tyrosine‌ ‌metabolism,‌ ‌albinism‌ ‌disorder,‌ ‌and‌ ‌goitrous‌ ‌cretinism)‌‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌noticed‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nmen‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌defective‌ ‌metabolism‌ ‌of‌ ‌Phenylalanine,‌ ‌an‌ ‌essential‌ ‌amino‌ ‌acid‌ ‌of‌ ‌dietary‌ ‌protein.‌ ‌\n●Each‌ ‌step‌ ‌of‌ ‌normal‌ ‌metabolism‌ ‌of‌ ‌phenylalanine‌ ‌is‌ ‌controlled‌ ‌by‌ ‌specific‌ ‌enzymes.‌ ‌\n●Various‌ ‌diseases‌ ‌caused‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌mutated‌ ‌gene‌ ‌that‌ ‌block‌ ‌particular‌ ‌steps‌ ‌in‌ ‌biochemical‌ ‌reaction.‌ ‌\n ‌\n773‌ ‌\nMethods‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌procedures‌ ‌for‌ ‌preparation‌ ‌of‌ ‌biochemical‌ ‌substances‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌developed.‌ ‌Most‌ ‌important‌ ‌of‌ ‌them:‌ ‌\n○Protein‌ ‌purification:‌ ‌ ‌\n■Protein‌ ‌purification‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌series‌ ‌of‌ ‌processes‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌isolate‌ ‌a‌ ‌specific‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌protein‌ ‌from‌ ‌a‌ ‌complex‌ ‌mixture.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Protein‌ ‌purification‌ ‌is‌ ‌important‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌characterization‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌function,‌ ‌structure‌ ‌and‌ ‌interactions‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌protein‌ ‌of‌ ‌interest.‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌various‌ ‌steps‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌purification‌ ‌process‌ ‌may‌ ‌include‌ ‌the‌ ‌isolation‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌protein‌ ‌from‌ ‌a‌ ‌matrix,‌ ‌separate‌ ‌the‌ ‌protein‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nnon-protein‌ ‌parts‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌mixture,‌ ‌and‌ ‌finally‌ ‌separate‌ ‌the‌ ‌desired‌ ‌protein‌ ‌from‌ ‌all‌ ‌other‌ ‌proteins.‌ ‌\n■Separation‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌proteins‌ ‌depends‌ ‌on‌ ‌protein‌ ‌size,‌ ‌physio-chemical‌ ‌properties,‌ ‌binding‌ ‌affinity‌ ‌and‌ ‌biological‌ ‌activity.‌ ‌\n■Chromatographic‌ ‌methods‌ ‌ ‌\n●Ion-exchange‌ ‌chromatography‌ ‌ ‌\n■separates‌ ‌proteins‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌charge.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Columns‌ ‌can‌ ‌either‌ ‌be‌ ‌prepared‌ ‌for‌ ‌anion‌ ‌exchange‌ ‌or‌ ‌cation‌ ‌exchange.‌ ‌\n■Elution‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌target‌ ‌proteins‌ ‌is‌ ‌done‌ ‌by‌ ‌changing‌ ‌the‌ ‌pH‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌column,‌ ‌which‌ ‌results‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌change‌ ‌or‌ ‌\nneutralisation‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌charged‌ ‌functional‌ ‌groups‌ ‌of‌ ‌each‌ ‌protein‌ ‌ ‌\n●Size-exclusion‌ ‌chromatography‌ ‌(gel‌ ‌filtration)‌ ‌ ‌\n■separates‌ ‌larger‌ ‌proteins‌ ‌from‌ ‌small‌ ‌ones,‌ ‌since‌ ‌the‌ ‌larger‌ ‌molecules‌ ‌travel‌ ‌faster‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌\ncross-linked‌ ‌polymer‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌chromatography‌ ‌column.‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌large‌ ‌proteins‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌fit‌ ‌into‌ ‌the‌ ‌pores‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌polymer‌ ‌whereas‌ ‌smaller‌ ‌proteins‌ ‌do,‌ ‌and‌ ‌take‌ ‌longer‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌travel‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌chromatography‌ ‌column,‌ ‌via‌ ‌their‌ ‌less‌ ‌direct‌ ‌route.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Affinity‌ ‌chromatography‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌very‌ ‌useful‌ ‌technique‌ ‌for‌ ‌completing‌ ‌the‌ ‌protein‌ ‌purification‌ ‌process.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Beads‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌chromatography‌ ‌column‌ ‌are‌ ‌cross-linked‌ ‌to‌ ‌ligands‌ ‌that‌ ‌bind‌ ‌specifically‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌target‌ ‌protein.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌protein‌ ‌is‌ ‌then‌ ‌removed‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌column‌ ‌by‌ ‌rinsing‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌solution‌ ‌containing‌ ‌free‌ ‌ligands.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌method‌ ‌generally‌ ‌gives‌ ‌the‌ ‌purest‌ ‌results‌ ‌and‌ ‌highest‌ ‌specific‌ ‌activity‌ ‌compared‌ ‌to‌ ‌other‌ ‌techniques‌ ‌\n ‌\n○Electrophoresis‌ ‌\n■Electrophoresis‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌main‌ ‌biochemical‌ ‌technique‌ ‌for‌ ‌molecular‌ ‌separation.‌ ‌Electrophoresis‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌one‌ ‌dimensional‌ ‌or‌ ‌two‌ ‌\ndimensional.‌ ‌ ‌\n■One‌ ‌dimensional‌ ‌electrophoresis‌ ‌is‌ ‌used‌ ‌for‌ ‌most‌ ‌routine‌ ‌protein‌ ‌and‌ ‌nucleic‌ ‌acid‌ ‌separations.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Two‌ ‌dimensional‌ ‌separation‌ ‌of‌ ‌proteins‌ ‌is‌ ‌used‌ ‌for‌ ‌fingerprinting‌ ‌,‌ ‌and‌ ‌when‌ ‌properly‌ ‌constructed‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌extremely‌ ‌accurate‌ ‌\nin‌ ‌resolving‌ ‌all‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌proteins‌ ‌present‌ ‌within‌ ‌a‌ ‌cell‌ ‌(greater‌ ‌than‌ ‌1,500).‌ ‌\n■When‌ ‌the‌ ‌detergent‌ ‌‌SDS‌ ‌‌(sodium‌ ‌dodecyl‌ ‌sulfate)‌ ‌is‌ ‌used‌ ‌with‌ ‌proteins,C‌ ‌all‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌proteins‌ ‌become‌ ‌negatively‌ ‌charged‌ ‌by‌ ‌\ntheir‌ ‌attachment‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌SDS‌ ‌anions.‌ ‌ ‌\n■When‌ ‌separated‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌polyacrylamide‌ ‌gel,‌ ‌the‌ ‌procedure‌ ‌is‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌‌SDS—PAGE‌‌ ‌(Sodium‌ ‌Dodecyl‌ ‌Sulfate-‌ ‌PolyAcrylamide‌ ‌\nGel‌ ‌Electrophoresis).‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌technique‌ ‌has‌ ‌become‌ ‌a‌ ‌standard‌ ‌means‌ ‌for‌ ‌molecular‌ ‌weight‌ ‌determination‌ ‌\n774‌ ‌\n■Electrophoresis‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌laboratory‌ ‌technique‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌separate‌ ‌DNA,‌ ‌RNA,‌ ‌or‌ ‌protein‌ ‌molecules‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌their‌ ‌size‌ ‌and‌ ‌electrical‌ ‌\ncharge.‌ ‌An‌ ‌electric‌ ‌current‌ ‌is‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌move‌ ‌molecules‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌separated‌ ‌through‌ ‌a‌ ‌gel.‌ ‌Pores‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌gel‌ ‌work‌ ‌like‌ ‌a‌ ‌sieve,‌ ‌\nallowing‌ ‌smaller‌ ‌molecules‌ ‌to‌ ‌move‌ ‌faster‌ ‌than‌ ‌larger‌ ‌molecules.‌ ‌\nMost‌ ‌of‌ ‌biochemical‌ ‌methods‌ ‌offer‌ ‌certain‌ ‌advantages‌ ‌over‌ ‌molecular‌ ‌methods:‌ ‌ ‌\n●Less‌ ‌training‌ ‌for‌ ‌lab‌ ‌personnel‌ ‌\n●Lower/isolate‌ ‌cost‌ ‌\n●Potential‌ ‌to‌ ‌perform‌ ‌the‌ ‌methods‌ ‌on‌ ‌hundreds‌ ‌of‌ ‌isolates‌ ‌per‌ ‌week‌ ‌(versus‌ ‌a‌ ‌few‌ ‌dozen‌ ‌isolates‌ ‌per‌ ‌week,‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌typical‌ ‌for‌ ‌molecular‌ ‌\nmethods).‌ ‌\n●Biochemical‌ ‌methods‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌fact‌ ‌that‌ ‌an‌ ‌organism's‌ ‌genes‌ ‌actively‌ ‌produce‌ ‌a‌ ‌biochemical‌ ‌substance.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌biochemical‌ ‌substances‌ ‌produced‌ ‌are‌ ‌what‌ ‌is‌ ‌being‌ ‌measured.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nc)‌ ‌Immunological‌ ‌methods‌ ‌\n●Many‌ ‌substances‌ ‌(e.g.,‌ ‌proteins)‌ ‌are‌ ‌antigenic;‌ ‌i.e.‌ ‌when‌ ‌introduced‌ ‌into‌ ‌a‌ ‌vertebrate‌ ‌body,‌ ‌they‌ ‌stimulate‌ ‌the‌ ‌production‌ ‌of‌ ‌specific‌ ‌proteins‌ ‌\ncalled‌ ‌antibodies.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Various‌ ‌antigens‌ ‌exist‌ ‌in‌ ‌red‌ ‌blood‌ ‌cells,‌ ‌including‌ ‌those‌ ‌that‌ ‌make‌ ‌up‌ ‌the‌ ‌major‌ ‌blood‌ ‌groups‌ ‌of‌ ‌man‌ ‌‌(A,‌ ‌B,‌ ‌AB,‌ ‌O)‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌antigens‌ ‌are‌ ‌genetically‌ ‌determined;‌ ‌their‌ ‌study‌ ‌constitutes‌ ‌immunogenetics.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Blood‌ ‌antigens‌ ‌of‌ ‌man‌ ‌include‌ ‌inherited‌ ‌variations,‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌particular‌ ‌combination‌ ‌of‌ ‌antigens‌ ‌in‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌is‌ ‌almost‌ ‌as‌ ‌unique‌ ‌as‌ ‌\nfingerprints‌ ‌and‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌used‌ ‌in‌ ‌such‌ ‌areas‌ ‌as‌ ‌paternity‌ ‌testing‌ ‌(although‌ ‌this‌ ‌approach‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌largely‌ ‌supplanted‌ ‌by‌ ‌DNA-based‌ ‌\ntechniques).‌ ‌\n●Immunological‌ ‌techniques‌ ‌are‌ ‌used‌ ‌in‌ ‌blood‌ ‌group‌ ‌determinations‌ ‌in‌ ‌blood‌ ‌transfusions,‌ ‌in‌ ‌organ‌ ‌transplants,‌ ‌and‌ ‌in‌ ‌determining‌ ‌‌Rhesus‌ ‌\nincompatibility‌ ‌in‌ ‌childbirth.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Specific‌ ‌antigens‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌human‌ ‌leukocyte‌ ‌antigen‌ ‌(HLA)‌‌ ‌genes‌ ‌are‌ ‌correlated‌ ‌with‌ ‌human‌ ‌diseases‌ ‌and‌ ‌disease‌ ‌predispositions.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌ability‌ ‌of‌ ‌our‌ ‌body‌ ‌cells‌ ‌to‌ ‌invade‌ ‌foreign‌ ‌substances‌ ‌be‌ ‌they‌ ‌cellular,‌ ‌viral‌ ‌chemical‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌subject‌ ‌of‌ ‌interest‌ ‌as‌ ‌far‌ ‌as‌ ‌immunology‌ ‌is‌ ‌\nconcerned.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Example‌ ‌\n○Immunological‌ ‌techniques‌ ‌have‌ ‌become‌ ‌and‌ ‌will‌ ‌remain‌ ‌an‌ ‌important‌ ‌and‌ ‌widespread‌ ‌technology‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌detection‌ ‌and‌ ‌identification‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌filamentous‌ ‌fungi‌ ‌and‌ ‌yeasts‌ ‌in‌ ‌food.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌is‌ ‌particularly‌ ‌possible‌ ‌because‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌availability‌ ‌of‌ ‌monoclonal‌ ‌antibody‌ ‌(MAb)‌ ‌technology,‌ ‌which‌ ‌has‌ ‌revolutionized‌ ‌the‌ ‌\ndevelopment‌ ‌process‌ ‌in‌ ‌detection,‌ ‌and‌ ‌diagnosis‌ ‌of‌ ‌organisms.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Like‌ ‌many‌ ‌other‌ ‌microorganisms,‌ ‌fungi‌ ‌produce‌ ‌a‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌antigens,‌ ‌which‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌used‌ ‌for‌ ‌identification‌ ‌with‌ ‌desired‌ ‌specificity.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Immunological‌ ‌techniques‌‌ ‌are‌ ‌important‌ ‌to‌ ‌detect‌ ‌emerging‌ ‌infectious‌ ‌agents‌ ‌like‌ ‌dengue‌ ‌fever,‌ ‌West‌ ‌Nile‌ ‌fever,‌ ‌and‌ ‌Rift‌ ‌Valley‌ ‌fever‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nbiological‌ ‌weapons‌ ‌like‌ ‌Bacillus‌ ‌anthracis‌ ‌(anthrax)‌ ‌and‌ ‌variola‌ ‌major‌ ‌virus‌ ‌(smallpox),‌ ‌‌Botulinum‌ ‌neurotoxins‌,‌ ‌‌Yersinia‌ ‌pestis‌,‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nFrancisella‌ ‌tularensis‌‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌great‌ ‌threat‌ ‌to‌ ‌public‌ ‌health.‌ ‌ ‌\n775‌ ‌\n●Following‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌immunological‌ ‌methods‌ ‌are‌ ‌based‌ ‌mainly‌ ‌upon‌ ‌antigen‌ ‌antibody‌ ‌reactions.‌ ‌ ‌\n1)‌ ‌Agglutination‌ ‌Tests‌ ‌ ‌\n2)‌ ‌Coomb’s‌ ‌Test‌ ‌(Antiglobulin‌ ‌Test)‌ ‌ ‌\n3)‌ ‌Precipitation‌ ‌tests‌ ‌ ‌\n4)‌ ‌Immunoelectrophoresis‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nd)‌ ‌D.N.A.‌ ‌technology‌ ‌&‌ ‌Recombinant‌ ‌technologies‌ ‌\n●Recombinant‌ ‌DNA,‌ ‌molecules‌ ‌of‌ ‌DNA‌ ‌from‌ ‌two‌ ‌different‌ ‌species‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌inserted‌ ‌into‌ ‌a‌ ‌host‌ ‌organism‌ ‌to‌ ‌produce‌ ‌new‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌combinations‌ ‌\nthat‌ ‌are‌ ‌of‌ ‌value‌ ‌to‌ ‌science,‌ ‌medicine,‌ ‌agriculture,‌ ‌and‌ ‌industry.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌recombinant‌ ‌DNA‌ ‌technology,‌ ‌also‌ ‌called‌ ‌as‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌engineering,‌ ‌involves‌ ‌artificial‌ ‌modification‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌constitution‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌living‌ ‌cell‌ ‌\nby‌ ‌introduction‌ ‌of‌ ‌foreign‌ ‌DNA‌ ‌through‌ ‌experimental‌ ‌techniques.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌tools‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌required‌ ‌in‌ ‌recombinant‌ ‌DNA‌ ‌include‌ ‌vectors,‌ ‌restriction‌ ‌enzymes,‌ ‌ligases‌ ‌and‌ ‌host‌ ‌organisms.‌ ‌\n ‌\nApplications‌ ‌ ‌\n●Pharmaceutical‌ ‌products‌ ‌\n○Gene‌ ‌defects‌ ‌in‌ ‌humans‌ ‌can‌ ‌lead‌ ‌to‌ ‌deficiencies‌ ‌in‌ ‌proteins‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌‌insulin,‌ ‌human‌ ‌growth‌ ‌hormone,‌ ‌and‌ ‌Factor‌ ‌VIII.‌ ‌ ‌\n○These‌ ‌protein‌ ‌deficiencies‌ ‌may‌ ‌lead‌ ‌to‌ ‌problems‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌diabetes,‌ ‌dwarfism,‌ ‌and‌ ‌impaired‌ ‌blood‌ ‌clotting,‌ ‌respectively.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Missing‌ ‌proteins‌ ‌can‌ ‌now‌ ‌be‌ ‌replaced‌ ‌by‌ ‌proteins‌ ‌manufactured‌ ‌through‌ ‌biotechnology.‌ ‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌insulin‌ ‌production,‌ ‌two‌ ‌protein‌ ‌chains‌ ‌are‌ ‌encoded‌ ‌by‌ ‌separate‌ ‌genes‌ ‌in‌ ‌plasmids‌ ‌inserted‌ ‌into‌ ‌bacteria.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌protein‌ ‌chains‌ ‌are‌ ‌then‌ ‌chemically‌ ‌joined‌ ‌to‌ ‌form‌ ‌the‌ ‌final‌ ‌insulin‌ ‌product.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Human‌ ‌growth‌ ‌hormone‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌produced‌ ‌within‌ ‌bacteria,‌ ‌but‌ ‌special‌ ‌techniques‌ ‌are‌ ‌used‌ ‌because‌ ‌the‌ ‌bacteria‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌usually‌ ‌\nproduce‌ ‌human‌ ‌proteins.‌ ‌\n ‌\n○Recombinant‌ ‌human‌ ‌growth‌ ‌hormone‌ ‌(HGH,‌ ‌somatotropin)‌ ‌\n■Administered‌ ‌to‌ ‌patients‌ ‌whose‌ ‌pituitary‌ ‌glands‌ ‌generate‌ ‌insufficient‌ ‌quantities‌ ‌to‌ ‌support‌ ‌normal‌ ‌growth‌ ‌and‌ ‌development.‌ ‌ ‌\n■This‌ ‌hormone‌ ‌stimulates‌ ‌growth‌ ‌and‌ ‌cell‌ ‌reproduction.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌secreted‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌somatotroph‌ ‌cells‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌anterior‌ ‌pituitary‌ ‌gland.‌ ‌ ‌\n■When‌ ‌present‌ ‌in‌ ‌insufficient‌ ‌amount‌ ‌it‌ ‌causes‌ ‌retarded‌ ‌growth,‌ ‌body‌ ‌fat‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌waist‌ ‌and‌ ‌dwarfism.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌made‌ ‌of‌ ‌191‌ ‌amino‌ ‌\nacids.‌ ‌ ‌\n■For‌ ‌the‌ ‌formation‌ ‌of‌ ‌recombinant‌ ‌human‌ ‌growth‌ ‌hormone‌ ‌the‌ ‌gene‌ ‌for‌ ‌HGH‌ ‌is‌ ‌inserted‌ ‌into‌ ‌plasmid‌ ‌and‌ ‌then‌ ‌introduced‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nhost‌ ‌for‌ ‌large‌ ‌production.‌ ‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌also‌ ‌consists‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌26‌ ‌amino‌ ‌acid‌ ‌signal‌ ‌peptides‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌removed‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌HGH‌ ‌molecule‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌help‌ ‌of‌ ‌EcoRI‌ ‌\nrestriction‌ ‌enzyme.‌ ‌\n●Before‌ ‌recombinant‌ ‌HGH‌ ‌became‌ ‌available,‌ ‌HGH‌ ‌for‌ ‌therapeutic‌ ‌use‌ ‌was‌ ‌obtained‌ ‌from‌ ‌pituitary‌ ‌glands‌ ‌of‌ ‌cadavers.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌unsafe‌ ‌practice‌ ‌led‌ ‌to‌ ‌some‌ ‌patients‌ ‌developing‌ ‌Creutzfeldt–Jakob‌ ‌disease.‌ ‌Recombinant‌ ‌HGH‌ ‌eliminated‌ ‌this‌ ‌\nproblem,‌ ‌and‌ ‌is‌ ‌now‌ ‌used‌ ‌therapeutically.‌ ‌\n776‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌has‌ ‌also‌ ‌been‌ ‌misused‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌performance-enhancing‌ ‌drug‌ ‌by‌ ‌athletes‌ ‌and‌ ‌others.‌ ‌\n ‌\n○Insulin:‌ ‌ ‌\n■Insulin‌ ‌is‌ ‌secreted‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌â‌ ‌cells‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌pancreas.‌ ‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌is‌ ‌required‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌cellular‌ ‌uptake‌ ‌of‌ ‌glucose‌ ‌for‌ ‌use‌ ‌in‌ ‌energy‌ ‌metabolism.‌ ‌When‌ ‌produced‌ ‌in‌ ‌insufficient‌ ‌amounts‌ ‌it‌ ‌causes‌ ‌\ndiabetes‌ ‌mellitus.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Almost‌ ‌completely‌ ‌replaced‌ ‌insulin‌ ‌obtained‌ ‌from‌ ‌animal‌ ‌sources‌ ‌(e.g.‌ ‌pigs‌ ‌and‌ ‌cattle)‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌treatment‌ ‌of‌ ‌insulin-dependent‌ ‌\ndiabetes.‌ ‌ ‌\n■A‌ ‌variety‌ ‌of‌ ‌different‌ ‌recombinant‌ ‌insulin‌ ‌preparations‌ ‌are‌ ‌in‌ ‌widespread‌ ‌use.‌ ‌\n■Recombinant‌ ‌insulin‌ ‌is‌ ‌synthesized‌ ‌by‌ ‌inserting‌ ‌the‌ ‌human‌ ‌insulin‌ ‌gene‌ ‌into‌ ‌E.‌ ‌coli,‌ ‌or‌ ‌yeast‌ ‌(Saccharomyces‌ ‌cerevisiae)‌ ‌\nwhich‌ ‌then‌ ‌produces‌ ‌insulin‌ ‌for‌ ‌human‌ ‌use‌ ‌\n ‌\n■Example:‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Gene‌ ‌therapy‌ ‌ ‌\n777‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌modification‌ ‌of‌ ‌defective‌ ‌genotypes‌ ‌by‌ ‌adding‌ ‌functional‌ ‌genes‌ ‌made‌ ‌through‌ ‌recombinant‌ ‌DNA‌ ‌technology.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌these‌ ‌cells‌ ‌are‌ ‌taken‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌patient,‌ ‌altered‌ ‌by‌ ‌adding‌ ‌genes,‌ ‌and‌ ‌replaced‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌patient,‌ ‌where‌ ‌the‌ ‌genes‌ ‌provide‌ ‌the‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌\ncodes‌ ‌for‌ ‌proteins‌ ‌the‌ ‌patient‌ ‌is‌ ‌lacking.‌ ‌\n○Example‌ ‌\n■Recombinant‌ ‌blood‌ ‌clotting‌ ‌factor‌ ‌VIII‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌blood-clotting‌ ‌protein‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌administered‌ ‌to‌ ‌patients‌ ‌with‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌bleeding‌ ‌disorder‌ ‌hemophilia,‌ ‌who‌ ‌are‌ ‌unable‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌produce‌ ‌factor‌ ‌VIII‌ ‌in‌ ‌quantities‌ ‌sufficient‌ ‌to‌ ‌support‌ ‌normal‌ ‌blood‌ ‌coagulation.‌ ‌\n■Before‌ ‌the‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌recombinant‌ ‌factor‌ ‌VIII,‌ ‌the‌ ‌protein‌ ‌was‌ ‌obtained‌ ‌by‌ ‌processing‌ ‌large‌ ‌quantities‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌blood‌ ‌\nfrom‌ ‌multiple‌ ‌donors,‌ ‌which‌ ‌carried‌ ‌a‌ ‌very‌ ‌high‌ ‌risk‌ ‌of‌ ‌transmission‌ ‌of‌ ‌blood‌ ‌borne‌ ‌infectious‌ ‌diseases,‌ ‌for‌ ‌example‌ ‌HIV‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nhepatitis‌ ‌B.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Vaccines‌ ‌ ‌\n○Vaccines‌ ‌represent‌ ‌another‌ ‌application‌ ‌of‌ ‌recombinant‌ ‌DNA‌ ‌technology.‌ ‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌instance,‌ ‌the‌ ‌hepatitis‌ ‌B‌ ‌vaccine‌ ‌now‌ ‌in‌ ‌use‌ ‌is‌ ‌composed‌ ‌of‌ ‌viral‌ ‌protein‌ ‌manufactured‌ ‌by‌ ‌yeast‌ ‌cells,‌ ‌which‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌\nrecombined‌ ‌with‌ ‌viral‌ ‌genes.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌vaccine‌ ‌is‌ ‌safe‌ ‌because‌ ‌it‌ ‌contains‌ ‌no‌ ‌viral‌ ‌particles.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Experimental‌ ‌vaccines‌ ‌against‌ ‌AIDS‌ ‌are‌ ‌being‌ ‌produced‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌way.‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌production‌ ‌of‌ ‌recombinant‌ ‌vaccines:‌‌ ‌The‌ ‌recombinant‌ ‌technology‌ ‌is‌ ‌responsible‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌production‌ ‌of‌ ‌vaccines‌ ‌for‌ ‌various‌ ‌\ndiseases‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌Hepatitis‌ ‌B,‌ ‌AIDS,‌ ‌Influenza,‌ ‌cholera‌ ‌and‌ ‌leishmaniasis.‌ ‌\n○AstraZeneca‌ ‌ChAdOx1-S/nCoV-19‌‌ ‌[recombinant],‌ ‌COVID-19‌ ‌vaccine‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌‌ChAdOx1-S/nCoV-19‌ ‌[recombinant]‌‌ ‌vaccine‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌replication-deficient‌ ‌adenoviral‌ ‌vector‌ ‌vaccine‌ ‌against‌ ‌coronavirus‌ ‌\ndisease‌ ‌2019‌ ‌‌(COVID-19)‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌vaccine‌ ‌expresses‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌SARS-CoV-2‌‌ ‌spike‌ ‌protein‌ ‌gene,‌ ‌which‌ ‌instructs‌ ‌the‌ ‌host‌ ‌cells‌ ‌to‌ ‌produce‌ ‌the‌ ‌protein‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nS-antigen‌ ‌unique‌ ‌to‌ ‌‌SARS-CoV-2‌,‌ ‌allowing‌ ‌the‌ ‌body‌ ‌to‌ ‌generate‌ ‌an‌ ‌immune‌ ‌response‌ ‌and‌ ‌to‌ ‌retain‌ ‌that‌ ‌information‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nmemory‌ ‌immune‌ ‌cells.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n778‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n9.2‌ ‌Mendelian‌ ‌genetics‌ ‌in‌ ‌man-family‌ ‌study,‌ ‌single‌ ‌factor,‌ ‌multifactor,‌ ‌lethal,‌ ‌sub-lethal‌ ‌and‌ ‌polygenic‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌in‌ ‌man-Part-I‌ ‌\n ‌\n779‌ ‌\nMendelian‌ ‌genetics‌ ‌in‌ ‌man-family‌ ‌study‌ ‌\nBackground:‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌thousands‌ ‌of‌ ‌years‌ ‌farmers‌ ‌and‌ ‌herders‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌selectively‌ ‌breeding‌ ‌their‌ ‌plants‌ ‌and‌ ‌animals‌ ‌to‌ ‌produce‌ ‌more‌ ‌useful‌ ‌hybrids.‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌was‌ ‌somewhat‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌hit‌ ‌or‌ ‌miss‌ ‌process‌ ‌since‌ ‌the‌ ‌actual‌ ‌mechanisms‌ ‌governing‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌were‌ ‌unknown.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Knowledge‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌mechanisms‌ ‌finally‌ ‌came‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌result‌ ‌of‌ ‌careful‌ ‌laboratory‌ ‌breeding‌ ‌experiments‌ ‌carried‌ ‌out‌ ‌over‌ ‌the‌ ‌last‌ ‌century‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌a‌ ‌half.‌ ‌\n●By‌ ‌the‌ ‌1890's,‌ ‌the‌ ‌invention‌ ‌of‌ ‌better‌ ‌microscopes‌ ‌allowed‌ ‌biologists‌ ‌to‌ ‌discover‌ ‌the‌ ‌basic‌ ‌facts‌ ‌of‌ ‌cell‌ ‌division‌ ‌and‌ ‌sexual‌ ‌reproduction.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌focus‌ ‌of‌ ‌genetics‌ ‌research‌ ‌then‌ ‌shifted‌ ‌to‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌what‌ ‌really‌ ‌happens‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌transmission‌ ‌of‌ ‌hereditary‌ ‌traits‌ ‌from‌ ‌parents‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nchildren.‌ ‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌hypotheses‌ ‌were‌ ‌suggested‌ ‌to‌ ‌explain‌ ‌heredity,‌ ‌but‌ ‌Gregor‌ ‌Mendel,‌ ‌a‌ ‌little‌ ‌known‌ ‌Central‌ ‌European‌ ‌monk,‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌only‌ ‌one‌ ‌\nwho‌ ‌got‌ ‌it‌ ‌more‌ ‌or‌ ‌less‌ ‌right.‌ ‌ ‌\n●His‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌had‌ ‌been‌ ‌published‌ ‌in‌ ‌1866‌ ‌but‌ ‌largely‌ ‌went‌ ‌unrecognized‌ ‌until‌ ‌1900,‌ ‌which‌ ‌was‌ ‌long‌ ‌after‌ ‌his‌ ‌death.‌ ‌ ‌\n●While‌ ‌Mendel's‌ ‌research‌ ‌was‌ ‌with‌ ‌plants,‌ ‌the‌ ‌basic‌ ‌underlying‌ ‌principles‌ ‌of‌ ‌heredity‌ ‌that‌ ‌he‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌also‌ ‌apply‌ ‌to‌ ‌people‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌\nanimals‌ ‌because‌ ‌the‌ ‌mechanisms‌ ‌of‌ ‌heredity‌ ‌are‌ ‌essentially‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌for‌ ‌all‌ ‌complex‌ ‌life‌ ‌forms.‌ ‌\n●Through‌ ‌the‌ ‌selective‌ ‌cross-breeding‌ ‌of‌ ‌common‌ ‌pea‌ ‌plants‌ ‌‌(Pisum‌ ‌sativum)‌‌ ‌over‌ ‌many‌ ‌generations,‌ ‌Mendel‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌that‌ ‌certain‌ ‌traits‌ ‌\nshow‌ ‌up‌ ‌in‌ ‌offspring‌ ‌without‌ ‌any‌ ‌blending‌ ‌of‌ ‌parent‌ ‌characteristics.‌ ‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌instance,‌ ‌the‌ ‌pea‌ ‌flowers‌ ‌are‌ ‌either‌ ‌purple‌ ‌or‌ ‌white--intermediate‌ ‌colors‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌appear‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌offspring‌ ‌of‌ ‌cross-pollinated‌ ‌pea‌ ‌plants‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Mendel‌ ‌observed‌ ‌seven‌ ‌traits‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌easily‌ ‌recognized‌ ‌and‌ ‌apparently‌ ‌only‌ ‌occur‌ ‌in‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌forms:‌ ‌\n ‌\n1.Seed‌ ‌shape‌ ‌is‌ ‌round‌ ‌or‌ ‌wrinkled‌ ‌\n2.Seed‌ ‌color‌ ‌is‌ ‌yellow‌ ‌or‌ ‌green‌ ‌\n3.Flower‌ ‌color‌ ‌is‌ ‌purple‌ ‌or‌ ‌white‌ ‌\n4.Flower‌ ‌position‌ ‌is‌ ‌axial‌ ‌or‌ ‌terminal‌ ‌ ‌\n5.Stem‌ ‌length‌ ‌is‌ ‌long‌ ‌or‌ ‌short‌ ‌\n6.Pod‌ ‌shape‌ ‌is‌ ‌inflated‌ ‌or‌ ‌constricted‌ ‌\n7.Pod‌ ‌color‌ ‌is‌ ‌yellow‌ ‌or‌ ‌green‌ ‌\n780‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●This‌ ‌observation‌ ‌that‌ ‌these‌ ‌traits‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌show‌ ‌up‌ ‌in‌ ‌offspring‌ ‌plants‌ ‌with‌ ‌intermediate‌ ‌forms‌ ‌was‌ ‌critically‌ ‌important‌ ‌because‌ ‌the‌ ‌leading‌ ‌\ntheory‌ ‌in‌ ‌biology‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌time‌ ‌was‌ ‌that‌ ‌inherited‌ ‌traits‌ ‌blend‌ ‌from‌ ‌generation‌ ‌to‌ ‌generation.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Most‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌leading‌ ‌scientists‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌19th‌ ‌century‌ ‌accepted‌ ‌this‌ ‌\"blending‌ ‌theory.\"‌ ‌ ‌\n●Charles‌ ‌Darwin‌ ‌proposed‌ ‌another‌ ‌equally‌ ‌wrong‌ ‌theory‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌\"pangenesis\".‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌held‌ ‌that‌ ‌hereditary‌ ‌\"particles\"‌ ‌in‌ ‌our‌ ‌bodies‌ ‌are‌ ‌affected‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌things‌ ‌we‌ ‌do‌ ‌during‌ ‌our‌ ‌lifetime.‌ ‌ ‌\n○These‌ ‌modified‌ ‌particles‌ ‌were‌ ‌thought‌ ‌to‌ ‌migrate‌ ‌via‌ ‌blood‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌reproductive‌ ‌cells‌ ‌and‌ ‌subsequently‌ ‌could‌ ‌be‌ ‌inherited‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌next‌ ‌\ngeneration.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌was‌ ‌essentially‌ ‌a‌ ‌variation‌ ‌of‌ ‌Lamarck's‌ ‌incorrect‌ ‌idea‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\"inheritance‌ ‌of‌ ‌acquired‌ ‌characteristics.\"‌ ‌\n ‌\nWhat‌ ‌is‌ ‌Mendelian‌ ‌Genetics?‌ ‌\n●Mendelian‌ ‌Genetics‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌kind‌ ‌of‌ ‌biological‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌that‌ ‌highlights‌ ‌the‌ ‌laws‌ ‌proposed‌ ‌by‌ ‌Gregor‌ ‌Mendel‌ ‌in‌ ‌1866‌ ‌and‌ ‌rediscovered‌ ‌in‌ ‌1900.‌ ‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌laws‌ ‌faced‌ ‌a‌ ‌few‌ ‌controversies‌ ‌initially‌ ‌but‌ ‌when‌ ‌Mendel’s‌ ‌theories‌ ‌got‌ ‌integrated‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌inheritance,‌ ‌they‌ ‌\nsoon‌ ‌became‌ ‌the‌ ‌heart‌ ‌of‌ ‌classical‌ ‌genetics.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Later,‌ ‌Ronald‌ ‌Fisher‌ ‌combined‌ ‌these‌ ‌ideas‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌natural‌ ‌selection‌ ‌and‌ ‌formed‌ ‌a‌ ‌base‌ ‌for‌ ‌population‌ ‌genetics‌ ‌and‌ ‌‌modern‌ ‌\nevolutionary‌ ‌synthesis.‌ ‌\n ‌\nMendel‌ ‌Experiment‌ ‌\n●Mendel‌ ‌laid‌ ‌the‌ ‌foundation‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌science‌ ‌of‌ ‌genetics‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌discovery‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌basic‌ ‌principle‌ ‌of‌ ‌hereditary.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌conducted‌ ‌his‌ ‌experiment‌ ‌with‌ ‌‌pea‌ ‌(pisum‌ ‌sativum)‌ ‌‌for‌ ‌over‌ ‌7‌ ‌years‌ ‌from‌ ‌1856‌ ‌to‌ ‌1864.‌ ‌\n●Mendel‌ ‌conducted‌ ‌2‌ ‌main‌ ‌experiments‌ ‌to‌ ‌determine‌ ‌the‌ ‌laws‌ ‌of‌ ‌inheritance.‌ ‌These‌ ‌experiments‌ ‌were:‌ ‌\n781‌ ‌\n○Monohybrid‌ ‌Cross‌ ‌Experiment‌ ‌\n○Dihybrid‌ ‌Cross‌ ‌Experiment‌ ‌\n●While‌ ‌experimenting,‌ ‌Mendel‌ ‌found‌ ‌that‌ ‌certain‌ ‌factors‌ ‌were‌ ‌always‌ ‌being‌ ‌transferred‌ ‌down‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌offspring‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌stable‌ ‌way.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Those‌ ‌factors‌ ‌are‌ ‌now‌ ‌called‌ ‌genes‌ ‌i.e.‌ ‌genes‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌called‌ ‌the‌ ‌units‌ ‌of‌ ‌inheritance.‌ ‌\n●Mendel‌ ‌picked‌ ‌common‌ ‌garden‌ ‌pea‌ ‌plants‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌focus‌ ‌of‌ ‌his‌ ‌research‌ ‌because‌ ‌they‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌grown‌ ‌easily‌ ‌in‌ ‌large‌ ‌numbers‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌\nreproduction‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌manipulated.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Pea‌ ‌plants‌ ‌have‌ ‌both‌ ‌male‌ ‌and‌ ‌female‌ ‌reproductive‌ ‌organs.‌ ‌ ‌\n○As‌ ‌a‌ ‌result,‌ ‌they‌ ‌can‌ ‌either‌ ‌self-pollinate‌ ‌themselves‌ ‌or‌ ‌cross-pollinate‌ ‌with‌ ‌another‌ ‌plant.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌his‌ ‌experiments,‌ ‌Mendel‌ ‌was‌ ‌able‌ ‌to‌ ‌selectively‌ ‌cross-pollinate‌ ‌purebred‌ ‌plants‌ ‌with‌ ‌particular‌ ‌traits‌ ‌and‌ ‌observe‌ ‌the‌ ‌outcome‌ ‌over‌ ‌many‌ ‌\ngenerations.‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌was‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌for‌ ‌his‌ ‌conclusions‌ ‌about‌ ‌the‌ ‌nature‌ ‌of‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌inheritance.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Monohybrid‌ ‌Cross‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌this‌ ‌experiment,‌ ‌Mendel‌ ‌took‌ ‌two‌ ‌pea‌ ‌plants‌ ‌of‌ ‌opposite‌ ‌traits‌ ‌(one‌ ‌short‌ ‌and‌ ‌one‌ ‌tall)‌ ‌and‌ ‌crossed‌ ‌them.‌ ‌ ‌\n○He‌ ‌found‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌generation‌ ‌offspring‌ ‌were‌ ‌tall‌ ‌and‌ ‌called‌ ‌it‌ ‌F1‌ ‌progeny.‌ ‌Then‌ ‌he‌ ‌crossed‌ ‌F1‌ ‌progeny‌ ‌and‌ ‌obtained‌ ‌both‌ ‌tall‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nshort‌ ‌plants‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌ratio‌ ‌3:1.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Mendel‌ ‌even‌ ‌conducted‌ ‌this‌ ‌experiment‌ ‌with‌ ‌other‌ ‌contrasting‌ ‌traits‌ ‌like‌ ‌green‌ ‌peas‌ ‌vs‌ ‌yellow‌ ‌peas,‌ ‌round‌ ‌vs‌ ‌wrinkled,‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌In‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌\ncases,‌ ‌he‌ ‌found‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌results‌ ‌were‌ ‌similar.‌ ‌From‌ ‌this,‌ ‌he‌ ‌formulated‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌laws‌ ‌of‌ ‌Segregation‌ ‌And‌ ‌Dominance.‌ ‌\n ‌\n782‌ ‌\n ‌\n783‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Dihybrid‌ ‌Cross‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌a‌ ‌dihybrid‌ ‌cross‌ ‌experiment,‌ ‌Mendel‌ ‌considered‌ ‌two‌ ‌traits,‌ ‌each‌ ‌having‌ ‌two‌ ‌alleles.‌ ‌He‌ ‌crossed‌ ‌wrinkled-green‌ ‌seed‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nround-yellow‌ ‌seeds‌ ‌and‌ ‌observed‌ ‌that‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌generation‌ ‌progeny‌ ‌(F1‌ ‌progeny)‌ ‌were‌ ‌round-yellow.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌meant‌ ‌that‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌traits‌ ‌were‌ ‌the‌ ‌round‌ ‌shape‌ ‌and‌ ‌yellow‌ ‌colour.‌ ‌\n○He‌ ‌then‌ ‌self-pollinated‌ ‌the‌ ‌F1‌ ‌progeny‌ ‌and‌ ‌obtained‌ ‌4‌ ‌different‌ ‌traits:‌ ‌wrinkled-yellow,‌ ‌round-yellow,‌ ‌wrinkled-green‌ ‌seeds‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nround-green‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌ratio‌ ‌9:3:3:1.‌ ‌\n784‌ ‌\n○After‌ ‌conducting‌ ‌for‌ ‌other‌ ‌traits,‌ ‌the‌ ‌results‌ ‌were‌ ‌found‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌similar.‌ ‌From‌ ‌this‌ ‌experiment,‌ ‌Mendel‌ ‌formulated‌ ‌his‌ ‌second‌ ‌law‌ ‌of‌ ‌\ninheritance‌ ‌i.e‌ ‌‌law‌ ‌of‌ ‌Independent‌ ‌Assortment.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nThe‌ ‌two‌ ‌experiments‌ ‌lead‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌formulation‌ ‌of‌ ‌Mendel’s‌ ‌laws‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌laws‌ ‌of‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌which‌ ‌are:‌ ‌\n1.Law‌ ‌of‌ ‌Segregation‌ ‌\n2.Law‌ ‌of‌ ‌Independent‌ ‌Assortment‌ ‌\n3.Law‌ ‌of‌ ‌Dominance‌ ‌\n ‌\nNOTE:‌ ‌‌Some‌ ‌biologists‌ ‌refer‌ ‌to‌ ‌Mendel's‌ ‌\"principles\"‌ ‌as‌ ‌\"laws\".‌ ‌\n ‌\n785‌ ‌\nNOTE:‌ ‌ ‌One‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌reasons‌ ‌that‌ ‌Mendel‌ ‌carried‌ ‌out‌ ‌his‌ ‌breeding‌ ‌experiments‌ ‌with‌ ‌pea‌ ‌plants‌ ‌was‌ ‌that‌ ‌he‌ ‌could‌ ‌observe‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌in‌ ‌up‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌two‌ ‌generations‌ ‌a‌ ‌year.‌ ‌Geneticists‌ ‌today‌ ‌usually‌ ‌carry‌ ‌out‌ ‌their‌ ‌breeding‌ ‌experiments‌ ‌with‌ ‌species‌ ‌that‌ ‌reproduce‌ ‌much‌ ‌more‌ ‌rapidly‌ ‌so‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌\namount‌ ‌of‌ ‌time‌ ‌and‌ ‌money‌ ‌required‌ ‌is‌ ‌significantly‌ ‌reduced.‌ ‌Fruit‌ ‌flies‌ ‌and‌ ‌bacteria‌ ‌are‌ ‌commonly‌ ‌used‌ ‌for‌ ‌this‌ ‌purpose‌ ‌now.‌ ‌Fruit‌ ‌flies‌ ‌reproduce‌ ‌\nin‌ ‌about‌ ‌2‌ ‌weeks‌ ‌from‌ ‌birth,‌ ‌while‌ ‌bacteria,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌E.‌ ‌coli‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌our‌ ‌digestive‌ ‌systems,‌ ‌reproduce‌ ‌in‌ ‌only‌ ‌3-5‌ ‌hours.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Law‌ ‌of‌ ‌Segregation‌ ‌or‌ ‌Law‌ ‌of‌ ‌Purity‌ ‌of‌ ‌Gametes‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌two‌ ‌factors‌ ‌(alleles)‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌trait‌ ‌which‌ ‌remain‌ ‌together‌ ‌in‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌get‌ ‌mixed‌ ‌up‌ ‌but‌ ‌keep‌ ‌their‌ ‌identity‌ ‌distinct,‌ ‌separate‌ ‌\nat‌ ‌the‌ ‌time‌ ‌of‌ ‌gametogenesis‌ ‌(i.e.‌ ‌gametes‌ ‌formation)‌ ‌or‌ ‌sporogenesis‌ ‌(i.e.spores‌ ‌formation),‌ ‌get‌ ‌randomly‌ ‌distributed‌ ‌to‌ ‌different‌ ‌\ngametes‌ ‌and‌ ‌then‌ ‌get‌ ‌paired‌ ‌again‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌offspring’s‌ ‌as‌ ‌per‌ ‌the‌ ‌principle‌ ‌of‌ ‌probability.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Since‌ ‌two‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌remain‌ ‌together‌ ‌in‌ ‌pure‌ ‌form‌ ‌without‌ ‌mixing,‌ ‌affecting‌ ‌or‌ ‌blending‌ ‌each‌ ‌other,‌ ‌the‌ ‌law‌ ‌of‌ ‌segregation‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌known‌ ‌\nas‌ ‌“law‌ ‌of‌ ‌purity‌ ‌of‌ ‌gametes”.‌ ‌\n●Main‌ ‌features‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌law‌ ‌are‌ ‌as‌ ‌follows:‌ ‌\n○When‌ ‌a‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌allele‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌gene‌ ‌come‌ ‌together‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌hybrid‌ ‌after‌ ‌crossing‌ ‌between‌ ‌two‌ ‌having‌ ‌contrasting‌ ‌\ncharacters,‌ ‌they‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌mix‌ ‌or‌ ‌blend‌ ‌together.‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌separate‌ ‌into‌ ‌different‌ ‌gametes‌ ‌in‌ ‌equal‌ ‌number.‌ ‌Each‌ ‌gamete‌ ‌has‌ ‌only‌ ‌one‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌allele‌ ‌(say‌ ‌either‌ ‌A‌ ‌or‌ ‌a).‌ ‌\n○Separation‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌gene‌ ‌during‌ ‌gamete‌ ‌formation‌ ‌takes‌ ‌place‌ ‌usually‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌separation‌ ‌of‌ ‌homologous‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌\nduring‌ ‌meiosis‌ ‌(anaphase‌ ‌I),‌ ‌because‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌are‌ ‌located‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌chromosomes.‌ ‌\n○With‌ ‌complete‌ ‌dominance,‌ ‌segregation‌ ‌leads‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌phenotypic‌ ‌ratio‌ ‌of‌ ‌3:‌ ‌1‌ ‌in‌ ‌F2‌ ‌generation‌ ‌for‌ ‌characters‌ ‌governed‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌single‌ ‌gene,‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌9:‌ ‌3:‌ ‌3:‌ ‌1‌ ‌ratio‌ ‌for‌ ‌characters‌ ‌controlled‌ ‌by‌ ‌two‌ ‌genes.‌ ‌ ‌\n○If‌ ‌crossing‌ ‌over‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌take‌ ‌place,‌ ‌segregation‌ ‌of‌ ‌genes‌ ‌takes‌ ‌place‌ ‌during‌ ‌anaphase‌ ‌I.‌ ‌ ‌\n○If‌ ‌crossing‌ ‌over‌ ‌occurs,‌ ‌segregation‌ ‌of‌ ‌genes‌ ‌will‌ ‌take‌ ‌place‌ ‌during‌ ‌anaphase‌ ‌II.‌ ‌\n●Example:‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌principle‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌law‌ ‌of‌ ‌segregation‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌explained‌ ‌by‌ ‌means‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌monohybrid‌ ‌cross.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Law‌ ‌of‌ ‌Independent‌ ‌Assortment‌ ‌ ‌\n○After‌ ‌being‌ ‌satisfied‌ ‌with‌ ‌monohybrid‌ ‌crosses,‌ ‌Mendel‌ ‌took‌ ‌into‌ ‌consideration‌ ‌two‌ ‌pairs‌ ‌of‌ ‌contrasting‌ ‌characters‌ ‌and‌ ‌studied‌ ‌their‌ ‌\ninheritance‌ ‌(i.e.,‌ ‌di-hybrid‌ ‌cross).‌ ‌\n○According‌ ‌to‌ ‌this‌ ‌law‌ ‌“the‌ ‌two‌ ‌factors‌ ‌(genes)‌ ‌of‌ ‌each‌ ‌contrasting‌ ‌character‌ ‌(trait)‌ ‌assort‌ ‌or‌ ‌separate‌ ‌independently‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌factors‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nother‌ ‌characters‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌time‌ ‌of‌ ‌gamete‌ ‌formation‌ ‌and‌ ‌get‌ ‌randomly‌ ‌rearranged‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌offspring”‌ ‌\n●Following‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌main‌ ‌features‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌law:‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌law‌ ‌explains‌ ‌simultaneous‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌plant‌ ‌characters.‌ ‌\n○ ‌In‌ ‌F1‌ ‌when‌ ‌two‌ ‌genes‌ ‌controlling‌ ‌two‌ ‌different‌ ‌characters‌ ‌come‌ ‌together,‌ ‌each‌ ‌gene‌ ‌exhibits‌ ‌independent‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌behaviour‌ ‌\nwithout‌ ‌affecting‌ ‌or‌ ‌modifying‌ ‌the‌ ‌effect‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌gene.‌ ‌\n○These‌ ‌gene‌ ‌pairs‌ ‌segregate‌ ‌during‌ ‌gamete‌ ‌formation‌ ‌independently.‌ ‌\n786‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌of‌ ‌one‌ ‌gene‌ ‌can‌ ‌combine‌ ‌freely‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌of‌ ‌another‌ ‌gene.‌ ‌Thus,‌ ‌each‌ ‌allele‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌gene‌ ‌has‌ ‌an‌ ‌equal‌ ‌chance‌ ‌to‌ ‌\ncombine‌ ‌with‌ ‌each‌ ‌allele‌ ‌of‌ ‌another‌ ‌gene.‌ ‌\n○Each‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌two‌ ‌gene‌ ‌pairs,‌ ‌when‌ ‌considered‌ ‌separately,‌ ‌exhibits‌ ‌typical‌ ‌3:‌ ‌1‌ ‌segregation‌ ‌ratio‌ ‌in‌ ‌F2‌ ‌generation.‌ ‌This‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌typical‌ ‌\ndi-hybrid‌ ‌segregation‌ ‌ratio.‌ ‌\n○Random‌ ‌or‌ ‌free‌ ‌assortment‌ ‌of‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌genes‌ ‌leads‌ ‌to‌ ‌formation‌ ‌of‌ ‌new‌ ‌gene‌ ‌combinations‌ ‌\n●Example:‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌principle‌ ‌or‌ ‌law‌ ‌of‌ ‌independent‌ ‌assortment‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌studied‌ ‌by‌ ‌means‌ ‌of‌ ‌di-hybrid‌ ‌cross.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Law‌ ‌of‌ ‌dominance:‌ ‌\n○When‌ ‌two‌ ‌homozygous‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌with‌ ‌one‌ ‌or‌ ‌more‌ ‌sets‌ ‌of‌ ‌contrasting‌ ‌characters‌ ‌are‌ ‌crossed,‌ ‌the‌ ‌characters‌ ‌which‌ ‌appear‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nhybrids‌ ‌of‌ ‌F1‌ ‌generation‌ ‌are‌ ‌always‌ ‌the‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌characters‌ ‌and‌ ‌those‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌appear‌ ‌in‌ ‌F1‌ ‌offspring‌ ‌are‌ ‌always‌ ‌the‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌\ncharacters”.‌ ‌\n○During‌ ‌the‌ ‌course‌ ‌of‌ ‌investigations‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌principles‌ ‌of‌ ‌inheritance,‌ ‌Mendel‌ ‌crossed‌ ‌plants‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌variety‌ ‌of‌ ‌Pisum‌ ‌sativum‌ ‌six‌ ‌feet‌ ‌tall‌ ‌\nwith‌ ‌plants‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌variety‌ ‌one‌ ‌foot‌ ‌in‌ ‌height‌ ‌on‌ ‌an‌ ‌average,‌ ‌(i.e.,‌ ‌parents‌ ‌or‌ ‌P‌ ‌generation).‌ ‌ ‌\n○When‌ ‌the‌ ‌seeds‌ ‌from‌ ‌this‌ ‌cross‌ ‌were‌ ‌planted‌ ‌they‌ ‌produced‌ ‌plants‌ ‌not‌ ‌intermediate‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌two‌ ‌parents,‌ ‌as‌ ‌might‌ ‌be‌ ‌expected,‌ ‌\nbut‌ ‌all‌ ‌tall,‌ ‌like‌ ‌the‌ ‌six-foot‌ ‌parent.‌ ‌\n ‌\nApplication‌ ‌of‌ ‌Mendelism:‌ ‌\n●Pedigree‌ ‌analysis:‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌Pedigree‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌transmission‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌character‌ ‌is‌ ‌traced‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌earliest‌ ‌parent‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌recent‌ ‌progeny‌ ‌along‌ ‌with‌ ‌all‌ ‌\nblood‌ ‌relatives‌ ‌living‌ ‌or‌ ‌dead‌ ‌including‌ ‌marital‌ ‌ones.‌ ‌\n●Medico‌ ‌legal‌ ‌application:‌ ‌ ‌\n○Mendelism‌ ‌can‌ ‌fairly‌ ‌well‌ ‌serve‌ ‌the‌ ‌judgement‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌cases‌ ‌of‌ ‌paternity‌ ‌dispute.‌ ‌\n●Medical‌ ‌Application:‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌helped‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌kinds‌ ‌of‌ ‌histocompatibility.‌ ‌\n●Genetic‌ ‌counselling:‌ ‌ ‌\n○hundreds‌ ‌of‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌diseases‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌inherited.‌ ‌\n●Hybrid‌ ‌varieties:‌ ‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌large‌ ‌variety‌ ‌of‌ ‌resistant‌ ‌varieties‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌produced.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n9.2‌ ‌Single‌ ‌factor,‌ ‌multifactor,‌ ‌lethal,‌ ‌sub-lethal‌ ‌and‌ ‌polygenic‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌in‌ ‌man‌ ‌Part-II‌ ‌\n ‌\n787‌ ‌\nBackground‌ ‌\n●Mendel’s‌ ‌experiments‌ ‌with‌ ‌pea‌ ‌plants‌ ‌suggested‌ ‌that:‌ ‌ ‌\n1)‌ ‌two‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌“units”‌ ‌or‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌exist‌ ‌for‌ ‌every‌ ‌gene;‌ ‌ ‌\n2)‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌maintain‌ ‌their‌ ‌integrity‌ ‌in‌ ‌each‌ ‌generation‌ ‌(no‌ ‌blending);‌ ‌and‌ ‌ ‌\n3)‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌presence‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌allele,‌ ‌the‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌allele‌ ‌is‌ ‌hidden,‌ ‌with‌ ‌no‌ ‌contribution‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌phenotype.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Therefore,‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌“carried”‌ ‌and‌ ‌not‌ ‌expressed‌ ‌by‌ ‌individuals.‌ ‌Such‌ ‌heterozygous‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌are‌ ‌sometimes‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to‌ ‌as‌ ‌\n“carriers.”‌ ‌Since‌ ‌then,‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌studies‌ ‌in‌ ‌other‌ ‌organisms‌ ‌have‌ ‌shown‌ ‌that‌ ‌much‌ ‌more‌ ‌complexity‌ ‌exists,‌ ‌but‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌fundamental‌ ‌principles‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌Mendelian‌ ‌genetics‌ ‌still‌ ‌hold‌ ‌true.‌ ‌\n ‌\nWhat‌ ‌are‌ ‌Mendelian‌ ‌Traits?‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌earlier‌ ‌studies,‌ ‌some‌ ‌physical‌ ‌attributes‌ ‌of‌ ‌humans‌ ‌were‌ ‌considered‌ ‌Mendelian‌ ‌in‌ ‌nature,‌ ‌but‌ ‌further‌ ‌study‌ ‌suggested‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌in‌ ‌fact‌ ‌not.‌ ‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌traits‌ ‌may‌ ‌involve‌ ‌more‌ ‌complex‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌models‌ ‌that‌ ‌usually‌ ‌include‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌one‌ ‌gene.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Mendelian‌ ‌traits‌ ‌are‌ ‌passed‌ ‌onto‌ ‌the‌ ‌offspring‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌of‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌or‌ ‌through‌ ‌the‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌pattern.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌needs‌ ‌both‌ ‌parents‌ ‌to‌ ‌have‌ ‌the‌ ‌genes,‌ ‌and‌ ‌offspring‌ ‌must‌ ‌inherit‌ ‌a‌ ‌gene‌ ‌from‌ ‌each‌ ‌parent‌ ‌to‌ ‌display‌ ‌the‌ ‌\ntrait.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Through‌ ‌the‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌of‌ ‌inheritance,‌ ‌only‌ ‌one‌ ‌copy‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌gene‌ ‌needs‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌inherited‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌child‌ ‌to‌ ‌display‌ ‌the‌ ‌trait.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌the‌ ‌case‌ ‌of‌ ‌autosomal‌ ‌genes‌ ‌the‌ ‌child‌ ‌can‌ ‌inherit‌ ‌the‌ ‌gene‌ ‌from‌ ‌either‌ ‌parent.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Mendelian‌ ‌Traits‌ ‌are‌ ‌traits‌ ‌which‌ ‌follow‌ ‌Mendel’s‌ ‌rules‌ ‌of‌ ‌only‌ ‌two‌ ‌possible‌ ‌versions‌ ‌(dominant‌ ‌and‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌traits).‌ ‌\n ‌\nNon-Mendelian‌ ‌trait:‌ ‌\n●Mendel‌ ‌explained‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌discrete‌ ‌factors-‌ ‌gene-‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌passed‌ ‌along‌ ‌from‌ ‌generation‌ ‌to‌ ‌generation‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌rules‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌probability.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Mendel’s‌ ‌laws‌ ‌are‌ ‌valid‌ ‌for‌ ‌all‌ ‌sexually‌ ‌reproducing‌ ‌organisms,‌ ‌including‌ ‌garden‌ ‌peas‌ ‌and‌ ‌human‌ ‌beings.‌ ‌However,‌ ‌Mendel’s‌ ‌law‌ ‌stops‌ ‌\nshort‌ ‌of‌ ‌explaining‌ ‌some‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌of‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌inheritance.‌ ‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌most‌ ‌sexually‌ ‌reproducing‌ ‌organisms,‌ ‌cases‌ ‌where‌ ‌Mendel’s‌ ‌laws‌ ‌can‌ ‌strictly‌ ‌account‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌of‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌are‌ ‌relatively‌ ‌rare.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Often‌ ‌the‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌are‌ ‌more‌ ‌complex.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Non-Mendelian‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌is‌ ‌any‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌of‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌traits‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌segregate‌ ‌in‌ ‌accordance‌ ‌with‌ ‌Mendel's‌ ‌laws.‌ ‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌include‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌of‌ ‌multiple‌ ‌allele‌ ‌traits,‌ ‌traits‌ ‌with‌ ‌codominance‌ ‌or‌ ‌incomplete‌ ‌dominance,‌ ‌and‌ ‌polygenic‌ ‌traits,‌ ‌among‌ ‌\nothers‌ ‌\n○These‌ ‌laws‌ ‌describe‌ ‌the‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌of‌ ‌traits‌ ‌linked‌ ‌to‌ ‌single‌ ‌genes‌ ‌on‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌nucleus.‌ ‌In‌ ‌Mendelian‌ ‌inheritance,‌ ‌each‌ ‌\nparent‌ ‌contributes‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌possible‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌trait.‌ ‌\n ‌\nQualitative‌ ‌Inheritance‌ ‌and‌ ‌Quantitative‌ ‌Inheritance‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nQualitative‌ ‌Inheritance‌ ‌\n788‌ ‌\n ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌a‌ ‌single‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌gene‌ ‌influences‌ ‌a‌ ‌complete‌ ‌trait.‌ ‌Presence‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌such‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌genes‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌alter‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌phenotype.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌genes‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌the‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌allele‌ ‌expresses‌ ‌the‌ ‌complete‌ ‌trait‌ ‌are‌ ‌called‌ ‌monogenes,‌ ‌e.g.,‌ ‌TT‌ ‌or‌ ‌Tt‌ ‌for‌ ‌tallness‌ ‌in‌ ‌Pea.‌ ‌Qualitative‌ ‌\ninher­itance‌ ‌produces‌ ‌a‌ ‌sort‌ ‌of‌ ‌discontinuous‌ ‌trait‌ ‌variations‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌progeny,‌ ‌e.g.,‌ ‌either‌ ‌tallness‌ ‌or‌ ‌dwarfness.‌ ‌Intermediate‌ ‌forms‌ ‌or‌ ‌\ncontinuous‌ ‌trait‌ ‌variations‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌produced.‌ ‌\n ‌\nQuantitative‌ ‌Inheritance‌ ‌(Polygenic‌ ‌Inheritance):‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌
