‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌con­trolled‌ ‌by‌ ‌one‌ ‌or‌ ‌more‌ ‌genes‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌the‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌have‌ ‌cumulative‌ ‌effect‌ ‌with‌ ‌each‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌allele‌ ‌\nexpressing‌ ‌a‌ ‌part‌ ‌or‌ ‌unit‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌trait,‌ ‌the‌ ‌full‌ ‌trait‌ ‌being‌ ‌shown‌ ‌only‌ ‌when‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌are‌ ‌present.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌genes‌ ‌involved‌ ‌in‌ ‌quantitative‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌are‌ ‌called‌ ‌polygenes.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Quantitative‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌is,‌ ‌therefore,‌ ‌also‌ ‌called‌ ‌‌polygenic‌ ‌inheritance‌.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌named‌ ‌as‌ ‌‌multiple‌ ‌factor‌ ‌inheritance.‌ ‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌few‌ ‌instances‌ ‌of‌ ‌quantitative‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌are‌ ‌kernel‌ ‌colour‌ ‌in‌ ‌wheat,‌ ‌cob‌ ‌length‌ ‌in‌ ‌Maize,‌ ‌skin‌ ‌colour‌ ‌in‌ ‌human‌ ‌beings,‌ ‌human‌ ‌intelligence,‌ ‌\nmilk‌ ‌and‌ ‌meat‌ ‌yield‌ ‌in‌ ‌animals,‌ ‌height‌ ‌in‌ ‌human‌ ‌beings‌ ‌and‌ ‌several‌ ‌plants,‌ ‌yield‌ ‌of‌ ‌crop‌ ‌plants‌ ‌including‌ ‌size,‌ ‌shape‌ ‌and‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌seeds‌ ‌or‌ ‌\nfruits‌ ‌per‌ ‌plant.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌uses‌ ‌the‌ ‌frequencies‌ ‌of‌ ‌different‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌gene‌ ‌in‌ ‌breeding‌ ‌populations‌ ‌(gamodemes),‌ ‌and‌ ‌combine‌ ‌them‌ ‌with‌ ‌concepts‌ ‌from‌ ‌simple‌ ‌\nMendelian‌ ‌inheritance‌‌ ‌to‌ ‌analyze‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌across‌ ‌generations‌ ‌and‌ ‌descendant‌ ‌lines.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌height‌ ‌and‌ ‌weight‌ ‌in‌ ‌human‌ ‌beings‌ ‌are‌ ‌traits‌ ‌that‌ ‌vary‌ ‌continuously‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌population;‌ ‌distinct‌ ‌classes‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌be‌ ‌identified‌ ‌for‌ ‌such‌ ‌\ntraites‌ ‌making‌ ‌it‌ ‌difficult‌ ‌to‌ ‌analyse‌ ‌by‌ ‌conventional‌ ‌Genetics‌ ‌method.‌ ‌\n●Quantitative‌ ‌Genetics‌ ‌is‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌measurement‌ ‌of‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌within‌ ‌a‌ ‌population‌ ‌of‌ ‌organisation‌ ‌the‌ ‌methods‌ ‌of‌ ‌quantitative‌ ‌gene‌ ‌\nrecognise‌ ‌two‌ ‌important‌ ‌factors.‌ ‌\n○Most‌ ‌quantitative‌ ‌traits‌ ‌involve‌ ‌the‌ ‌contribution‌ ‌of‌ ‌many‌ ‌different‌ ‌genes.‌ ‌Sometimes‌ ‌a‌ ‌single‌ ‌gene‌ ‌may‌ ‌have‌ ‌primary‌ ‌influence‌ ‌but‌ ‌\nusually‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌many‌ ‌equally‌ ‌influential‌ ‌genes.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌existence‌ ‌of‌ ‌many‌ ‌different‌ ‌Alleles‌ ‌at‌ ‌each‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌genes‌ ‌will‌ ‌produce‌ ‌genotypic‌ ‌variation‌ ‌which‌ ‌in‌ ‌twins‌ ‌will‌ ‌produce‌ ‌\nphenotypic‌ ‌variation‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌trait.‌ ‌\n○Qualitative‌ ‌traits‌ ‌are‌ ‌often‌ ‌influenced‌ ‌by‌ ‌environmental‌ ‌factors;‌ ‌the‌ ‌quantitative‌ ‌trait‌ ‌will‌ ‌show‌ ‌phenotypic‌ ‌variation‌ ‌over‌ ‌and‌ ‌above‌ ‌\nthat‌ ‌caused‌ ‌by‌ ‌genotyping‌ ‌differently.‌ ‌\nvalue‌ ‌\nStudy‌ ‌and‌ ‌Experiments‌ ‌\n●Quantitative‌ ‌or‌ ‌polygenic‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌was‌ ‌first‌ ‌studied‌ ‌by‌ ‌‌J.‌ ‌Kolreuter‌ ‌(1760)‌‌ ‌in‌ ‌case‌ ‌of‌ ‌height‌ ‌in‌ ‌tobacco‌ ‌and‌ ‌‌F.‌ ‌Galton‌ ‌(1883)‌‌ ‌in‌ ‌case‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nheight‌ ‌and‌ ‌intelligence‌ ‌in‌ ‌human‌ ‌beings.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Nilsson-Ehle‌ ‌(1908)‌ ‌‌obtained‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌experimental‌ ‌proof‌ ‌of‌ ‌polygenic‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌case‌ ‌of‌ ‌kernel‌ ‌colour‌ ‌in‌ ‌wheat.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Polygenic‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌in‌ ‌case‌ ‌of‌ ‌plant‌ ‌height,‌ ‌crop‌ ‌yield,‌ ‌milk‌ ‌yield,‌ ‌intelligence‌ ‌height‌ ‌and‌ ‌skin‌ ‌colour‌ ‌in‌ ‌humans.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌easily‌ ‌\ninfluenced‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌environment‌ ‌and‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌known‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌of‌ ‌phenotypes.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌monogenic‌ ‌or‌ ‌qualitative‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌the‌ ‌phenotypes‌ ‌are‌ ‌two‌ ‌(3:‌ ‌1)‌ ‌in‌ ‌case‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌single‌ ‌gene‌ ‌pair‌ ‌and‌ ‌4‌ ‌(9:‌ ‌3:‌ ‌3:‌ ‌1)‌ ‌in‌ ‌case‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌pairs‌ ‌of‌ ‌\ngenes.‌ ‌\n789‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌polygenic‌ ‌or‌ ‌quantitative‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌the‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌phenotypes‌ ‌is‌ ‌3‌ ‌(1:‌ ‌2:‌ ‌1)‌ ‌in‌ ‌case‌ ‌of‌ ‌one‌ ‌polygene‌ ‌pair,‌ ‌5‌ ‌(1:‌ ‌4:‌ ‌6:‌ ‌4:‌ ‌1)‌ ‌in‌ ‌case‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌\npolygene‌ ‌pairs‌ ‌and‌ ‌7‌ ‌(1‌ ‌:‌ ‌6:‌ ‌15:‌ ‌20:‌ ‌15:‌ ‌6:‌ ‌1)‌ ‌when‌ ‌three‌ ‌polygene‌ ‌pairs‌ ‌are‌ ‌involved.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Thus‌ ‌we‌ ‌see‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌intermediate‌ ‌types‌ ‌increases‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌increase‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌polygenes‌ ‌but‌ ‌the‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌parental‌ ‌types‌ ‌\nremain‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌(2‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌above‌ ‌cases).‌ ‌The‌ ‌possible‌ ‌origin‌ ‌of‌ ‌polygenes‌ ‌is:‌ ‌\n ‌\n(i)‌ ‌Duplication‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌part‌ ‌\n(ii)‌ ‌Polyploidy‌ ‌or‌ ‌increase‌ ‌in‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌number‌ ‌\n(iii)‌ ‌Mutations‌ ‌producing‌ ‌genes‌ ‌having‌ ‌similar‌ ‌effect.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nMendelian‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌\n ‌\nSingle‌ ‌factor‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌in‌ ‌man‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌determination‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌character‌ ‌by‌ ‌one‌ ‌major‌ ‌gene,‌ ‌although‌ ‌the‌ ‌gene‌ ‌may‌ ‌exist‌ ‌in‌ ‌various‌ ‌allelic‌ ‌forms.‌ ‌‌Mendel's‌ ‌genes‌ ‌are‌ ‌examples‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nsingle-factor‌ ‌inheritance.‌ ‌\n●Within‌ ‌a‌ ‌population,‌ ‌there‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌a‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌given‌ ‌gene.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Individuals‌ ‌that‌ ‌have‌ ‌two‌ ‌copies‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌allele‌ ‌are‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to‌ ‌as‌ ‌homozygous‌ ‌for‌ ‌that‌ ‌allele;‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌that‌ ‌have‌ ‌copies‌ ‌of‌ ‌different‌ ‌\nalleles‌ ‌are‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌heterozygous‌ ‌for‌ ‌that‌ ‌allele.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌observed‌ ‌will‌ ‌depend‌ ‌on‌ ‌whether‌ ‌the‌ ‌allele‌ ‌is‌ ‌found‌ ‌on‌ ‌an‌ ‌autosomal‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌or‌ ‌a‌ ‌sex‌ ‌chromosome,‌ ‌and‌ ‌on‌ ‌\nwhether‌ ‌the‌ ‌allele‌ ‌is‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌or‌ ‌recessive.‌ ‌\n●Autosomal‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌\n○Following‌ ‌Mendel's‌ ‌Law‌ ‌of‌ ‌Dominance‌ ‌and‌ ‌Uniformity,‌ ‌only‌ ‌one‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌allele‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌disease‌ ‌gene‌ ‌is‌ ‌necessary‌ ‌for‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌be‌ ‌affected‌ ‌or‌ ‌show‌ ‌the‌ ‌phenotype.‌ ‌ ‌\n790‌ ‌\n○ ‌Since‌ ‌autosomal‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌disorders‌ ‌involve‌ ‌autosomes‌ ‌or‌ ‌the‌ ‌non-sex‌ ‌chromosomes,‌ ‌the‌ ‌disorders‌ ‌affect‌ ‌males‌ ‌and‌ ‌females‌ ‌\nequally.‌ ‌\n●Autosomal‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌\n○If‌ ‌the‌ ‌phenotype‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌given‌ ‌version‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌gene‌ ‌is‌ ‌observed‌ ‌only‌ ‌when‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌has‌ ‌two‌ ‌copies,‌ ‌the‌ ‌allele‌ ‌is‌ ‌said‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌\nautosomal‌ ‌recessive.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌phenotype‌ ‌will‌ ‌be‌ ‌observed‌ ‌only‌ ‌when‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual‌ ‌is‌ ‌homozygous‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌allele‌ ‌concerned.‌ ‌ ‌\n○An‌ ‌individual‌ ‌with‌ ‌only‌ ‌one‌ ‌copy‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌allele‌ ‌will‌ ‌not‌ ‌show‌ ‌the‌ ‌phenotype,‌ ‌but‌ ‌will‌ ‌be‌ ‌able‌ ‌to‌ ‌pass‌ ‌the‌ ‌allele‌ ‌on‌ ‌to‌ ‌subsequent‌ ‌\ngenerations.‌ ‌ ‌\n○As‌ ‌a‌ ‌result,‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌heterozygous‌ ‌for‌ ‌an‌ ‌autosomal‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌allele‌ ‌is‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌carrier.‌ ‌\n●Sex-linked‌ ‌or‌ ‌X-linked‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌many‌ ‌organisms,‌ ‌the‌ ‌determination‌ ‌of‌ ‌sex‌ ‌involves‌ ‌a‌ ‌pair‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌that‌ ‌differ‌ ‌in‌ ‌length‌ ‌and‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌content‌ ‌-‌ ‌for‌ ‌example,‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌XY‌ ‌system‌ ‌used‌ ‌in‌ ‌human‌ ‌beings‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌mammals.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌X‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌carries‌ ‌hundreds‌ ‌of‌ ‌genes,‌ ‌and‌ ‌many‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌connected‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌determination‌ ‌of‌ ‌sex.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌smaller‌ ‌Y‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌contains‌ ‌a‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌genes‌ ‌responsible‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌initiation‌ ‌and‌ ‌maintenance‌ ‌of‌ ‌maleness,‌ ‌but‌ ‌it‌ ‌lacks‌ ‌\ncopies‌ ‌of‌ ‌most‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌genes‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌found‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌X‌ ‌chromosome.‌ ‌ ‌\n○As‌ ‌a‌ ‌result,‌ ‌the‌ ‌genes‌ ‌located‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌X‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌display‌ ‌a‌ ‌characteristic‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌of‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to‌ ‌as‌ ‌sex-linkage‌ ‌or‌ ‌\nX-linkage.‌ ‌\n○Females‌ ‌(XX)‌ ‌have‌ ‌two‌ ‌copies‌ ‌of‌ ‌each‌ ‌gene‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌X‌ ‌chromosome,‌ ‌so‌ ‌they‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌heterozygous‌ ‌or‌ ‌homozygous‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌given‌ ‌allele.‌ ‌ ‌\n○However,‌ ‌males‌ ‌(XY)‌ ‌will‌ ‌express‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌present‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌single‌ ‌X‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌that‌ ‌they‌ ‌receive‌ ‌from‌ ‌their‌ ‌mother,‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nconcepts‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌'dominant'‌ ‌or‌ ‌'recessive'‌ ‌are‌ ‌irrelevant.‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌medical‌ ‌conditions‌ ‌in‌ ‌humans‌ ‌are‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌genes‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌X‌ ‌chromosome,‌ ‌including‌ ‌haemophilia,‌ ‌muscular‌ ‌\ndystrophy‌ ‌and‌ ‌some‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌colour‌ ‌blindness.‌ ‌\n791‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nExamples‌ ‌of‌ ‌single‌ ‌gene‌ ‌disorders‌ ‌\n●Huntington's‌ ‌disease‌‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌progressive‌ ‌neurodegenerative‌ ‌disorder‌ ‌that‌ ‌exhibits‌ ‌autosomal‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌inheritance.‌ ‌The‌ ‌children‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\naffected‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌50%‌ ‌risk‌ ‌of‌ ‌inheriting‌ ‌the‌ ‌disease,‌ ‌which‌ ‌can‌ ‌manifest‌ ‌with‌ ‌uncontrolled‌ ‌movements,‌ ‌emotional‌ ‌problems‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nloss‌ ‌of‌ ‌thinking‌ ‌ability.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌late‌ ‌onset‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌disorder‌ ‌(35-45‌ ‌years‌ ‌of‌ ‌age)‌ ‌means‌ ‌that‌ ‌many‌ ‌affected‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌have‌ ‌kids‌ ‌before‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌aware‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌\ncondition.‌ ‌Other‌ ‌examples‌ ‌of‌ ‌autosomal‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌diseases‌ ‌include‌ ‌Marfan‌ ‌syndrome,‌ ‌neurofibromatosis,‌ ‌retinoblastoma‌ ‌and‌ ‌\npolydactyly.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Phenylketonuria‌ ‌‌represents‌ ‌a‌ ‌prominent‌ ‌example‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌single‌ ‌gene‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌disorder‌ ‌with‌ ‌an‌ ‌autosomal‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌pattern.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌characterized‌ ‌by‌ ‌an‌ ‌inability‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌body‌ ‌to‌ ‌utilize‌ ‌the‌ ‌essential‌ ‌amino‌ ‌acid‌ ‌phenylalanine‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌phenylalanine‌ ‌\nhydroxylase‌ ‌(PAH)‌ ‌gene.‌ ‌ ‌\n○As‌ ‌a‌ ‌result,‌ ‌the‌ ‌buildup‌ ‌of‌ ‌phenylalanine‌ ‌can‌ ‌eventually‌ ‌cause‌ ‌mental‌ ‌retardation‌ ‌and‌ ‌abnormal‌ ‌behavior.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Other‌ ‌examples‌ ‌of‌ ‌autosomal‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌diseases‌ ‌include‌ ‌cystic‌ ‌fibrosis,‌ ‌sickle‌ ‌cell‌ ‌anemia‌ ‌and‌ ‌Tay-Sachs‌ ‌disease.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Hemophilia‌ ‌A‌‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌disorder‌ ‌where‌ ‌the‌ ‌blood‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌clot‌ ‌properly‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌deficiency‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌clotting‌ ‌factor‌ ‌called‌ ‌Factor‌ ‌VIII.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌exhibits‌ ‌an‌ ‌X‌ ‌chromosome-linked‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌of‌ ‌inheritance,‌ ‌so‌ ‌men‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌mutant‌ ‌copy‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌gene‌ ‌will‌ ‌always‌ ‌have‌ ‌the‌ ‌\ndisease,‌ ‌whereas‌ ‌women‌ ‌are‌ ‌rarely‌ ‌affected‌ ‌by‌ ‌it.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Other‌ ‌examples‌ ‌are‌ ‌Duchenne‌ ‌muscular‌ ‌dystrophy‌ ‌and‌ ‌glucose-6-phosphate‌ ‌dehydrogenase‌ ‌deficiency.‌ ‌\n792‌ ‌\n○X-linked‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌conditions‌ ‌are‌ ‌rare‌ ‌but‌ ‌do‌ ‌exist.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Heterozygous‌ ‌mutations‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌X-linked‌ ‌MECP2‌ ‌gene‌ ‌result‌ ‌in‌ ‌Rett‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌–‌ ‌a‌ ‌severe‌ ‌neurodevelopmental‌ ‌disorder‌ ‌of‌ ‌young‌ ‌\nfemales.‌ ‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌nonobstructive‌ ‌spermatogenic‌ ‌failure‌ ‌that‌ ‌leads‌ ‌to‌ ‌infertility‌ ‌problems‌ ‌in‌ ‌males‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌example‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌Y-linked‌ ‌disorder.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nPolygenic‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌and‌ ‌Multi‌ ‌factor‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌in‌ ‌man‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nNon-Mendelian‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌\nThe‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌polygenic‌ ‌and‌ ‌multifactorial‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌are‌ ‌sometimes‌ ‌used‌ ‌interchangeably.‌ ‌However,‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌strict‌ ‌sense,‌ ‌polygenic‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌sum‌ ‌\ntotal‌ ‌of‌ ‌many‌ ‌genes,‌ ‌whereas‌ ‌multifactorial‌ ‌also‌ ‌includes‌ ‌the‌ ‌interaction‌ ‌of‌ ‌environmental‌ ‌and‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌determinants.‌ ‌\n ‌\nIntroduction‌ ‌\n●Polygenic‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌kind‌ ‌of‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌the‌ ‌trait‌ ‌is‌ ‌produced‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌cumulative‌ ‌effects‌ ‌of‌ ‌many‌ ‌genes‌ ‌in‌ ‌contrast‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nmonogenic‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌the‌ ‌trait‌ ‌results‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌expression‌ ‌of‌ ‌one‌ ‌gene‌ ‌(or‌ ‌one‌ ‌gene‌ ‌pair).‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌monogenic‌ ‌inheritance,‌ ‌the‌ ‌expression‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌predicted‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌phenotypic‌ ‌ratio‌ ‌that‌ ‌follows‌ ‌Mendelian‌ ‌inheritance.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Polygenic‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌‌non-Mendelian‌ ‌form‌ ‌‌since‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌controlled‌ ‌by‌ ‌multiple‌ ‌genes‌ ‌at‌ ‌different‌ ‌loci‌ ‌on‌ ‌different‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌expressed‌ ‌\ntogether‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌trait.‌ ‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌example‌,‌ ‌if‌ ‌one‌ ‌pair‌ ‌of‌ ‌genes‌ ‌controls‌ ‌color,‌ ‌and‌ ‌red‌ ‌is‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌to‌ ‌white,‌ ‌then‌ ‌when‌ ‌you‌ ‌cross‌ ‌two‌ ‌heterozygotes‌ ‌(Aa),‌ ‌red‌ ‌and‌ ‌white‌ ‌\nprogeny‌ ‌will‌ ‌appear‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌ratio‌ ‌of‌ ‌3:1.‌ ‌ ‌\n●However,‌ ‌if‌ ‌two‌ ‌pairs‌ ‌of‌ ‌genes‌ ‌control‌ ‌color‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌allele‌ ‌at‌ ‌both‌ ‌loci‌ ‌must‌ ‌be‌ ‌expressed‌ ‌to‌ ‌get‌ ‌red‌ ‌flowers,‌ ‌then‌ ‌crossing‌ ‌two‌ ‌\nheterozygotes‌ ‌(Aa‌ ‌Bb)‌ ‌will‌ ‌give‌ ‌you‌ ‌red‌ ‌and‌ ‌white‌ ‌flowers‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌ratio‌ ‌of‌ ‌9:7.‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌modification‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌typical‌ ‌dihybrid‌ ‌Mendelian‌ ‌ratio‌ ‌of‌ ‌9:3:3:1,‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌three‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌progeny‌ ‌groups‌ ‌all‌ ‌have‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌phenotype.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nWhat‌ ‌is‌ ‌polygenic‌ ‌inheritance?‌ ‌ ‌\n●Polygenic‌ ‌inheritance,‌ ‌in‌ ‌simple‌ ‌terms,‌ ‌implies‌ ‌a‌ ‌character‌ ‌or‌ ‌phenotypic‌ ‌trait,‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌regulated‌ ‌by‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌one‌ ‌gene.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌biology,‌ ‌it‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌quantitative‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌wherein‌ ‌two‌ ‌or‌ ‌more‌ ‌independent‌ ‌genes‌ ‌additively‌ ‌affect‌ ‌a‌ ‌single‌ ‌phenotypic‌ ‌trait.‌ ‌In‌ ‌a‌ ‌way,‌ ‌\npolygenic‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌multiple‌ ‌factor‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌or‌ ‌multiple‌ ‌gene‌ ‌inheritance,‌ ‌or‌ ‌multifactorial‌ ‌inheritance.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Thus,‌ ‌polygenic‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌phenotypic‌ ‌trait‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌a‌ ‌single‌ ‌gene‌ ‌trait‌ ‌but‌ ‌a‌ ‌cumulative‌ ‌expression‌ ‌of‌ ‌multiple‌ ‌genes.‌ ‌\n ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌important‌ ‌to‌ ‌note‌ ‌that‌ ‌polygenic‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌is‌ ‌different‌ ‌from‌ ‌Mendelian‌ ‌Inheritance‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌and‌ ‌expression.‌ ‌ ‌\n793‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌Mendelian‌ ‌Inheritance,‌ ‌each‌ ‌phenotypic‌ ‌trait‌ ‌is‌ ‌monogenic,‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌the‌ ‌expression‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌trait‌ ‌is‌ ‌either‌ ‌expressed‌ ‌or‌ ‌masked‌ ‌\nbased‌ ‌on‌ ‌it‌ ‌being‌ ‌‘a‌ ‌dominant’‌ ‌or‌ ‌‘a‌ ‌recessive’‌ ‌gene.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌polygenic‌ ‌inheritance,‌ ‌the‌ ‌expression‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌phenotypic‌ ‌trait‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌display‌ ‌complete‌ ‌dominance‌ ‌wherein‌ ‌the‌ ‌phenotypic‌ ‌\nexpression‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌trait‌ ‌in‌ ‌an‌ ‌offspring‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌mixture‌ ‌or‌ ‌additive‌ ‌of‌ ‌traits‌ ‌displayed‌ ‌in‌ ‌parents.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌polygenic‌ ‌inheritance,‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌additive‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌traits‌ ‌present‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌parents.‌ ‌This‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌is‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌\npolygenic‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌pattern.‌ ‌\nWhat‌ ‌are‌ ‌polygenic‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌examples?‌ ‌ ‌\n●Human‌ ‌phenotypes‌ ‌or‌ ‌human‌ ‌physical‌ ‌traits‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌hair‌ ‌color,‌ ‌height,‌ ‌skin‌ ‌color,‌ ‌blood‌ ‌pressure,‌ ‌intelligence,‌ ‌autism,‌ ‌and‌ ‌longevity‌ ‌are‌ ‌\nsome‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌examples‌ ‌of‌ ‌polygenic‌ ‌inheritance.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Accordingly,‌ ‌traits,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌height‌ ‌or‌ ‌skin‌ ‌color,‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌be‌ ‌categorized‌ ‌as‌ ‌‘tall’‌ ‌or‌ ‌‘short’‌ ‌/‌ ‌‘light’‌ ‌or‌ ‌‘dark’.‌ ‌These‌ ‌traits‌ ‌exhibit‌ ‌multiple‌ ‌and‌ ‌\ncontinuous‌ ‌variations‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌phenotype.‌ ‌\n●Polygenic‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌is‌ ‌controlled‌ ‌by‌ ‌two‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌or‌ ‌genes,‌ ‌namely:‌ ‌\n○Contributing‌ ‌alleles:‌ ‌‌Alleles‌ ‌that‌ ‌contribute‌ ‌to‌ ‌continuous‌ ‌variation‌ ‌are‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to‌ ‌as‌ ‌contributing‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌\n○Non-contributing‌ ‌alleles:‌‌ ‌Alleles‌ ‌that‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌contribute‌ ‌to‌ ‌continuous‌ ‌variation‌ ‌are‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to‌ ‌as‌ ‌non-contributing‌ ‌alleles.‌ ‌\n■These‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌are‌ ‌sometimes‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to‌ ‌as‌ ‌effective‌ ‌and‌ ‌non-effective‌ ‌alleles,‌ ‌respectively.‌ ‌\n ‌\nCharacteristics‌ ‌of‌ ‌Polygenic‌ ‌Inheritance‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌gene‌ ‌that‌ ‌employs‌ ‌a‌ ‌minor‌ ‌effect‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌phenotype‌ ‌along‌ ‌with‌ ‌other‌ ‌genes‌ ‌is‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to‌ ‌as‌ ‌polygenes.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌effect‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌gene‌ ‌is‌ ‌too‌ ‌minor‌ ‌and‌ ‌often‌ ‌remains‌ ‌undetected‌ ‌\n●Numerous‌ ‌genes‌ ‌exert‌ ‌an‌ ‌equal‌ ‌effect.‌ ‌\n●Individually,‌ ‌each‌ ‌allele‌ ‌contributes‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌result‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌cumulative‌ ‌or‌ ‌additive‌ ‌manner‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌expression‌ ‌of‌ ‌one‌ ‌gene‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌masked‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌presence‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌genes,‌ ‌i.e.,‌ ‌epistasis‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌involved.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌gene‌ ‌involved‌ ‌in‌ ‌polygenic‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌is‌ ‌either‌ ‌contributing‌ ‌(active‌ ‌allele)‌ ‌or‌ ‌non-contributing‌ ‌(null‌ ‌allele);‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌no‌ ‌genes‌ ‌as‌ ‌\ndominant‌ ‌or‌ ‌masked‌ ‌genes.‌ ‌\n●There‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌continuous‌ ‌variation‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌phenotype‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌trait‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌polygenic‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌polygenic‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌is‌ ‌difficult‌ ‌to‌ ‌predict‌ ‌and‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌highly‌ ‌complex.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌statistical‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌of‌ ‌polygenic‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌can‌ ‌help‌ ‌to‌ ‌provide‌ ‌an‌ ‌estimate‌ ‌of‌ ‌population‌ ‌parameters.‌ ‌Most‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌polygenic‌ ‌\ninheritance‌ ‌follow‌ ‌the‌ ‌normal‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌curve,‌ ‌wherein‌ ‌the‌ ‌majority‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌people‌ ‌fall‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌middle‌ ‌range‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌curve.‌ ‌\n●Polygenic‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌is‌ ‌different‌ ‌from‌ ‌multiple‌ ‌alleles.‌ ‌In‌ ‌multiple‌ ‌alleles,‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌locus,‌ ‌three‌ ‌or‌ ‌more‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌are‌ ‌present‌ ‌in‌ ‌an‌ ‌\norganism,‌ ‌e.g.‌ ‌human‌ ‌blood‌ ‌group‌ ‌system,‌ ‌i.e.,‌ ‌the‌ ‌ABO‌ ‌system,‌ ‌is‌ ‌controlled‌ ‌by‌ ‌three‌ ‌alleles.‌ ‌\n ‌\nPolygenic‌ ‌Inheritance‌ ‌Examples‌ ‌\nLet’s‌ ‌take‌ ‌a‌ ‌look‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌examples‌ ‌of‌ ‌polygenic‌ ‌inheritance.‌ ‌\n ‌\n1.‌ ‌Polygenic‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌in‌ ‌humans‌ ‌\nA.‌ ‌Skin‌ ‌color‌ ‌and‌ ‌pigmentation‌ ‌\n794‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌color‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌skin‌ ‌is‌ ‌polygenic‌ ‌inheritance.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌controlled‌ ‌by‌ ‌around‌ ‌60‌ ‌loci.‌ ‌ ‌\n●To‌ ‌understand‌ ‌the‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌of‌ ‌skin‌ ‌color‌ ‌let‌ ‌us‌ ‌consider‌ ‌an‌ ‌example‌ ‌of‌ ‌pair‌ ‌of‌ ‌three‌ ‌different‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌present‌ ‌at‌ ‌unlinked‌ ‌loci‌ ‌\nrepresented‌ ‌as‌ ‌A‌ ‌and‌ ‌a,‌ ‌B‌ ‌and‌ ‌b,‌ ‌C‌ ‌and‌ ‌c.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌responsible‌ ‌for‌ ‌dark‌ ‌color‌ ‌skin‌ ‌are‌ ‌represented‌ ‌by‌ ‌letters‌ ‌where‌ ‌capital‌ ‌letters‌ ‌represent‌ ‌those‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌incompletely‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌\nalleles.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Accordingly,‌ ‌the‌ ‌greater‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌“capital‌ ‌letters”‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌indicates‌ ‌dark‌ ‌skin‌ ‌color‌ ‌whereas‌ ‌the‌ ‌presence‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌greater‌ ‌number‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌“small‌ ‌letters”‌ ‌represents‌ ‌the‌ ‌lighter‌ ‌color‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌skin.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌progeny‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌parents‌ ‌with‌ ‌genotype‌ ‌AABBCC‌ ‌and‌ ‌aabbcc‌ ‌will‌ ‌have‌ ‌intermediate‌ ‌color‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌F1‌ ‌generation,‌ ‌i.e.‌ ‌genotype‌ ‌would‌ ‌be‌ ‌\nAaBbCc.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Further,‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌F2‌ ‌generation‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌triple‌ ‌heterozygotes‌ ‌parents‌ ‌—‌ ‌AaBbCc‌ ‌x‌ ‌AaBbCc‌ ‌—‌ ‌will‌ ‌produce‌ ‌varying‌ ‌skin‌ ‌colors‌ ‌ranging‌ ‌from‌ ‌very‌ ‌\ndark‌ ‌to‌ ‌very‌ ‌light,‌ ‌the‌ ‌ratio‌ ‌of‌ ‌which‌ ‌would‌ ‌range‌ ‌in‌ ‌1:6:15:20:15:6:1‌ ‌(see‌ ‌Figure‌ ‌1).‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌skin‌ ‌color‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌is‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌presence‌ ‌of‌ ‌melanin‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌skin.‌ ‌A‌ ‌dark‌ ‌skin‌ ‌color‌ ‌(with‌ ‌all‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌alleles,‌ ‌AABBCC)‌ ‌would‌ ‌\nhave‌ ‌the‌ ‌highest‌ ‌amount‌ ‌of‌ ‌melanin‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌skin.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Conversely,‌ ‌a‌ ‌light‌ ‌skin‌ ‌color‌ ‌(aabbcc)‌ ‌would‌ ‌have‌ ‌the‌ ‌least‌ ‌or‌ ‌a‌ ‌negligible‌ ‌amount‌ ‌of‌ ‌melanin‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌skin.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nB.‌ ‌Human‌ ‌height‌ ‌\n●Human‌ ‌height‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌polygenic‌ ‌trait‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌controlled‌ ‌by‌ ‌three‌ ‌genes‌ ‌that‌ ‌have‌ ‌six‌ ‌alleles.‌ ‌ ‌\n●So,‌ ‌a‌ ‌tall‌ ‌person‌ ‌would‌ ‌have‌ ‌all‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌whereas‌ ‌a‌ ‌short‌ ‌person‌ ‌will‌ ‌have‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌alleles.‌ ‌ ‌\n795‌ ‌\n●Like‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌polygenic‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌patterns,‌ ‌human‌ ‌height‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌also‌ ‌follows‌ ‌a‌ ‌normal‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌curve‌ ‌wherein‌ ‌the‌ ‌extreme‌ ‌ends‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\ncurve‌ ‌represent‌ ‌either‌ ‌extremely‌ ‌short‌ ‌or‌ ‌tall‌ ‌people,‌ ‌while‌ ‌the‌ ‌middle‌ ‌portion‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌curve‌ ‌represents‌ ‌the‌ ‌population‌ ‌with‌ ‌average‌ ‌height‌ ‌\n ‌\nC.‌ ‌Polygenic‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌human‌ ‌eye‌ ‌color‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌eye‌ ‌color‌ ‌follows‌ ‌a‌ ‌polygenic‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌pattern.‌ ‌In‌ ‌humans,‌ ‌9‌ ‌eye‌ ‌colors‌ ‌are‌ ‌recognized.‌ ‌Phenotypic‌ ‌expression‌ ‌of‌ ‌eye‌ ‌color‌ ‌is‌ ‌\ncontrolled‌ ‌by‌ ‌two‌ ‌major‌ ‌genes‌ ‌and‌ ‌14‌ ‌additional‌ ‌genes,‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌linked‌ ‌to‌ ‌X‌ ‌chromosomes.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Different‌ ‌combinations‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌result‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌variety‌ ‌of‌ ‌eye‌ ‌colors.‌ ‌The‌ ‌eye‌ ‌color‌ ‌is‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌presence‌ ‌of‌ ‌melanin‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌front‌ ‌\nportion‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌iris.‌ ‌\n●Black‌ ‌and‌ ‌brown‌ ‌eye‌ ‌color‌ ‌has‌ ‌a‌ ‌high‌ ‌amount‌ ‌of‌ ‌melanin‌ ‌in‌ ‌comparison‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌hazel‌ ‌or‌ ‌green‌ ‌eye‌ ‌color‌ ‌while‌ ‌the‌ ‌complete‌ ‌absence‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌the‌ ‌melanin‌ ‌results‌ ‌in‌ ‌blue‌ ‌eye‌ ‌color.‌ ‌ ‌\n●●Dominant‌ ‌allele‌ ‌(AABB)‌ ‌contributes‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌melanin‌ ‌synthesis‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌iris‌ ‌that‌ ‌results‌ ‌in‌ ‌black‌ ‌eye‌ ‌color‌ ‌while‌ ‌the‌ ‌combination‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌\nrecessive‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌(aabb)‌ ‌results‌ ‌in‌ ‌blue‌ ‌eye‌ ‌color.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌rest‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌eye‌ ‌colors‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌combination‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌and‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌alleles.‌ ‌See‌ ‌below:‌ ‌\nThe‌ ‌rest‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌eye‌ ‌colors‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌combination‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌and‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌alleles.‌ ‌See‌ ‌below:‌ ‌\n○○AABB‌ ‌results‌ ‌in‌ ‌Black‌ ‌eyes‌ ‌\n○○AABb‌ ‌or‌ ‌AaBB‌ ‌results‌ ‌in‌ ‌Dark‌ ‌Brown‌ ‌eyes‌ ‌\n○○AaBb‌ ‌or‌ ‌AAaa‌ ‌or‌ ‌aaBB‌ ‌results‌ ‌in‌ ‌Light‌ ‌Brown‌ ‌eyes‌ ‌\n○○Aabb‌ ‌or‌ ‌aaBb‌ ‌results‌ ‌in‌ ‌Green‌ ‌eyes‌ ‌\n○○Aabb‌ ‌results‌ ‌in‌ ‌Blue‌ ‌eyes‌ ‌\n796‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n2.‌ ‌Polygenic‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌in‌ ‌plants‌ ‌\nThe‌ ‌shape‌ ‌and‌ ‌color‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌flower,‌ ‌stem,‌ ‌pollen,‌ ‌size‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌seed,‌ ‌yield,‌ ‌oil‌ ‌content,‌ ‌time‌ ‌to‌ ‌mature‌ ‌or‌ ‌reach‌ ‌flowering,‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌are‌ ‌some‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\npolygenic‌ ‌traits‌ ‌in‌ ‌plants.‌ ‌\n ‌\nA.‌ ‌Kernel‌ ‌color‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌wheat‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌kernel‌ ‌color‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌wheat‌ ‌is‌ ‌controlled‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌expression‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌three‌ ‌independently‌ ‌assorted‌ ‌pairs‌ ‌of‌ ‌alleles.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌dark‌ ‌red‌ ‌wheat‌ ‌kernel‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌expression‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌alleles,‌ ‌i.e.,‌ ‌AABBCC,‌ ‌while‌ ‌the‌ ‌white‌ ‌kernel‌ ‌color‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌expression‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nrecessive‌ ‌allele,‌ ‌i.e.,‌ ‌aabbcc.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Consequently,‌ ‌when‌ ‌the‌ ‌AABBCC‌ ‌wheat‌ ‌is‌ ‌crossed‌ ‌with‌ ‌aabbcc,‌ ‌the‌ ‌F1‌ ‌generation‌ ‌will‌ ‌have‌ ‌an‌ ‌intermediate‌ ‌red‌ ‌color‌ ‌kernel‌ ‌with‌ ‌\nAaBbCc.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Further,‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌F2‌ ‌generation,‌ ‌during‌ ‌crossbreeding,‌ ‌there‌ ‌would‌ ‌be‌ ‌1‌ ‌white‌ ‌kernel‌ ‌plant‌ ‌while‌ ‌63‌ ‌red‌ ‌kernel‌ ‌plants‌ ‌with‌ ‌varying‌ ‌\nshades‌ ‌would‌ ‌be‌ ‌produced.‌ ‌\n797‌ ‌\n ‌\nB.‌ ‌Length‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌corolla‌ ‌in‌ ‌tobacco‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌length‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌corolla‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌tobacco‌ ‌plant‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌expression‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌5‌ ‌genes.‌ ‌The‌ ‌variation‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌length‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌corolla‌ ‌in‌ ‌tobacco‌ ‌is‌ ‌\ndue‌ ‌to‌ ‌polygenic‌ ‌inheritance.‌ ‌\n ‌\nEffect‌ ‌of‌ ‌environment‌ ‌on‌ ‌Polygenic‌ ‌Inheritance‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌expression‌ ‌of‌ ‌polygenes‌ ‌is‌ ‌greatly‌ ‌influenced‌ ‌by‌ ‌environmental‌ ‌conditions.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌genotype‌ ‌sets‌ ‌the‌ ‌range‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌quantitative‌ ‌trait,‌ ‌but‌ ‌the‌ ‌environmental‌ ‌conditions‌ ‌decide‌ ‌the‌ ‌phenotype‌ ‌within‌ ‌its‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌limits.‌ ‌\nGenes‌ ‌function‌ ‌differently‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌environmental‌ ‌conditions.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Environment‌ ‌regulates‌ ‌the‌ ‌activity‌ ‌of‌ ‌certain‌ ‌genes‌ ‌and‌ ‌sets‌ ‌them‌ ‌on‌ ‌or‌ ‌off.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌range‌ ‌of‌ ‌phenotype‌ ‌possible‌ ‌under‌ ‌the‌ ‌different‌ ‌environmental‌ ‌conditions‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌genotype‌ ‌is‌ ‌termed‌ ‌as‌ ‌‘norm‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nreaction’.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌norm‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌reaction‌ ‌is‌ ‌narrow‌ ‌for‌ ‌certain‌ ‌genotypes‌ ‌and‌ ‌broad‌ ‌for‌ ‌some‌ ‌genotypes,‌ ‌e.g.‌ ‌genotypes‌ ‌involved‌ ‌in‌ ‌human‌ ‌height‌ ‌\nhave‌ ‌a‌ ‌very‌ ‌broad‌ ‌norm‌ ‌of‌ ‌reaction.‌ ‌\n●Identical‌ ‌twins‌ ‌raised‌ ‌in‌ ‌two‌ ‌different‌ ‌environments‌ ‌show‌ ‌that‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌may‌ ‌have‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌potential‌ ‌or‌ ‌vulnerability,‌ ‌but‌ ‌\nenvironmental‌ ‌conditions‌ ‌influence‌ ‌the‌ ‌expression‌ ‌of‌ ‌genotype.‌ ‌ ‌\n798‌ ‌\n●Human‌ ‌characters‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌intelligence,‌ ‌depression,‌ ‌height,‌ ‌skin‌ ‌colour,‌ ‌schizophrenia‌ ‌show‌ ‌the‌ ‌effect‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌environment‌ ‌on‌ ‌gene‌ ‌\nexpression.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Phenotypic‌ ‌expression‌ ‌is‌ ‌dependent‌ ‌on‌ ‌both‌ ‌nature‌ ‌and‌ ‌nurture.‌ ‌\n●Examples:‌ ‌\n○Diet‌ ‌and‌ ‌general‌ ‌health‌ ‌greatly‌ ‌influences‌ ‌height‌ ‌\n○Flower,‌ ‌the‌ ‌colour‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌shrub,‌ ‌Hydrangeas,‌ ‌depends‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌level‌ ‌of‌ ‌aluminium‌ ‌present‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌soil‌ ‌\n○Effect‌ ‌of‌ ‌temperature‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌skin‌ ‌of‌ ‌Himalayan‌ ‌rabbits.‌ ‌\n ‌\nWhy‌ ‌is‌ ‌Polygenic‌ ‌Inheritance‌ ‌Important?‌ ‌\n●Polygenes‌ ‌are‌ ‌responsible‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌population‌ ‌variance‌ ‌and‌ ‌have‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌significance.‌ ‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌polygenic‌ ‌variations‌ ‌or‌ ‌changes‌ ‌(polygenesis)‌ ‌are‌ ‌responsible‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌species.‌ ‌‌This‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌\npolygeny‌ ‌for‌ ‌evolution.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌variations‌ ‌are‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌specific‌ ‌requirement‌ ‌and‌ ‌needs‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual‌ ‌or‌ ‌species.‌ ‌These‌ ‌are‌ ‌essentially‌ ‌responsible‌ ‌for‌ ‌\nadaptive‌ ‌changes.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌polygenes‌ ‌are‌ ‌majorly‌ ‌applied‌ ‌or‌ ‌utilized‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌plant‌ ‌breeders.‌ ‌‌The‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌variability‌ ‌is‌ ‌stored‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌polygenic‌ ‌complexes.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Segregation‌ ‌and‌ ‌recombination‌ ‌of‌ ‌polygenic‌ ‌genes‌ ‌after‌ ‌inbreeding‌ ‌results‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌release‌ ‌of‌ ‌hidden‌ ‌variability‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌species.‌ ‌\n ‌\nMultifactorial‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nBackground‌ ‌\n●Some‌ ‌traits‌ ‌or‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌display‌ ‌continuous‌ ‌variation,‌ ‌a‌ ‌range‌ ‌of‌ ‌phenotypes‌ ‌that‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌be‌ ‌easily‌ ‌divided‌ ‌into‌ ‌clear‌ ‌categories.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌many‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌cases,‌ ‌the‌ ‌final‌ ‌phenotype‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌result‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌interaction‌ ‌between‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌factors‌ ‌and‌ ‌environmental‌ ‌influences.‌ ‌\n●An‌ ‌example‌ ‌is‌ ‌human‌ ‌height‌ ‌and‌ ‌weight.‌ ‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌factors‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual‌ ‌may‌ ‌predispose‌ ‌them‌ ‌to‌ ‌fall‌ ‌within‌ ‌a‌ ‌certain‌ ‌height‌ ‌or‌ ‌weight‌ ‌range,‌ ‌but‌ ‌the‌ ‌observed‌ ‌height‌ ‌\nor‌ ‌weight‌ ‌will‌ ‌depend‌ ‌on‌ ‌interactions‌ ‌between‌ ‌genes,‌ ‌and‌ ‌between‌ ‌genes‌ ‌and‌ ‌environmental‌ ‌factors‌ ‌(for‌ ‌example,‌ ‌nutrition).‌ ‌ ‌\n●Traits‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌a‌ ‌range‌ ‌of‌ ‌phenotypes‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌produced‌ ‌by‌ ‌gene‌ ‌interactions‌ ‌and‌ ‌gene-environment‌ ‌interactions‌ ‌are‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌complex‌ ‌or‌ ‌\nmultifactorial.‌ ‌\nWhat‌ ‌Is‌ ‌Multifactorial‌ ‌Inheritance?‌ ‌\n●Multifactorial‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌is‌ ‌when‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌one‌ ‌factor‌ ‌causes‌ ‌a‌ ‌trait‌ ‌or‌ ‌health‌ ‌problem,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌birth‌ ‌defect‌ ‌or‌ ‌chronic‌ ‌illness.‌ ‌The‌ ‌main‌ ‌\nfactor‌ ‌is‌ ‌genes.‌ ‌But‌ ‌the‌ ‌cause‌ ‌includes‌ ‌other‌ ‌factors‌ ‌that‌ ‌aren’t‌ ‌genes,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as:‌ ‌\n○Nutrition‌ ‌\n○Lifestyle‌ ‌\n○Alcohol‌ ‌and‌ ‌tobacco‌ ‌\n○Some‌ ‌medicines‌ ‌\n○An‌ ‌illness‌ ‌\n○Pollution‌ ‌\n799‌ ‌\n●Often‌ ‌one‌ ‌sex—males‌ ‌or‌ ‌females—is‌ ‌affected‌ ‌more‌ ‌often‌ ‌than‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌for‌ ‌certain‌ ‌traits‌ ‌or‌ ‌disorders.‌ ‌\n ‌\nMulti‌ ‌factor‌ ‌Characteristics‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌disease‌ ‌can‌ ‌occur‌ ‌in‌ ‌isolation,‌ ‌with‌ ‌affected‌ ‌children‌ ‌born‌ ‌to‌ ‌unaffected‌ ‌parents.‌ ‌Although‌ ‌familial‌ ‌aggregation‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌common‌ ‌\n(i.e.,‌ ‌there‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌multiple‌ ‌cases‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌family),‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌clear‌ ‌Mendelian‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌of‌ ‌inheritance.‌ ‌\n●Environmental‌ ‌influences‌ ‌can‌ ‌increase‌ ‌or‌ ‌decrease‌ ‌the‌ ‌risk‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌disease.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌disease‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌more‌ ‌frequently‌ ‌in‌ ‌one‌ ‌gender‌ ‌than‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌other,‌ ‌but‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌a‌ ‌sex-limited‌ ‌trait.‌ ‌In‌ ‌addition,‌ ‌first-degree‌ ‌relatives‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nindividuals‌ ‌belonging‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌more‌ ‌rarely‌ ‌affected‌ ‌gender‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌higher‌ ‌risk‌ ‌of‌ ‌bearing‌ ‌the‌ ‌disease.‌ ‌\n●Quantitative‌ ‌traits‌ ‌were‌ ‌not‌ ‌determined‌ ‌by‌ ‌single‌ ‌genes‌ ‌but‌ ‌many‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌each‌ ‌had‌ ‌small‌ ‌and‌ ‌approximately‌ ‌additive‌ ‌effects‌ ‌\nthus‌ ‌a‌ ‌phenotype‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌depends‌ ‌upon‌ ‌its‌ ‌genotype‌ ‌at‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌relevant‌ ‌Loci;‌ ‌with‌ ‌each‌ ‌Allele‌ ‌adding‌ ‌or‌ ‌subtracting‌ ‌a‌ ‌small‌ ‌\namount.‌ ‌\n●Traits‌ ‌that‌ ‌have‌ ‌these‌ ‌features‌ ‌are‌ ‌called‌ ‌polygenic‌ ‌traits.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Many‌ ‌environmental‌ ‌factors‌ ‌influenced‌ ‌the‌ ‌trait‌ ‌by‌ ‌adding‌ ‌or‌ ‌subtracting‌ ‌effect‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌manner‌ ‌similar‌ ‌to‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌loci.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌combination‌ ‌of‌ ‌multiple‌ ‌environmental‌ ‌and‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌factors‌ ‌determined‌ ‌the‌ ‌phenotype‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nTypes‌ ‌Of‌ ‌Multifactorial‌ ‌Traits‌ ‌And‌ ‌Disorders‌ ‌\n●Health‌ ‌problems‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌caused‌ ‌by‌ ‌both‌ ‌genes‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌factors‌ ‌include:‌ ‌\n○Birth‌ ‌defects‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌neural‌ ‌tube‌ ‌defects‌ ‌and‌ ‌cleft‌ ‌palate‌ ‌\n○Cancers‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌breast,‌ ‌ovaries,‌ ‌bowel,‌ ‌prostate,‌ ‌and‌ ‌skin‌ ‌\n○High‌ ‌blood‌ ‌pressure‌ ‌and‌ ‌high‌ ‌cholesterol‌ ‌\n○Diabetes‌ ‌\n○Alzheimer‌ ‌disease‌ ‌\n○Schizophrenia‌ ‌\n○Bipolar‌ ‌disorder‌ ‌\n○Arthritis‌ ‌\n○Osteoporosis‌ ‌\n○Skin‌ ‌conditions‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌psoriasis,‌ ‌moles,‌ ‌and‌ ‌eczema‌ ‌\n800‌ ‌\n○Asthma‌ ‌and‌ ‌allergies‌ ‌\n○Multiple‌ ‌sclerosis‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌autoimmune‌ ‌disorders‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nMultiple‌ ‌factor‌ ‌readily‌ ‌involves‌ ‌three‌ ‌features‌ ‌of‌ ‌quantitative‌ ‌traits:‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌multiplicity‌ ‌of‌ ‌factors‌ ‌contributing‌ ‌to‌ ‌A‌ ‌trait‌ ‌accounted‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌variability‌ ‌among‌ ‌phenotypes;‌ ‌this‌ ‌variability‌ ‌arises‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌large‌ ‌\nnumber‌ ‌of‌ ‌genotypes‌ ‌and‌ ‌environments‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌possible‌ ‌when‌ ‌many‌ ‌factors‌ ‌are‌ ‌involved.‌ ‌\n●If‌ ‌a‌ ‌trait‌ ‌is‌ ‌influenced‌ ‌by‌ ‌two‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌(+)‌ ‌and‌ ‌(-),‌ ‌defined‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌whether‌ ‌they‌ ‌add‌ ‌or‌ ‌subtract‌ ‌an‌ ‌effect,‌ ‌mendelian‌ ‌\nsegregation‌ ‌should‌ ‌lead‌ ‌to‌ ‌many‌ ‌individual‌ ‌carrying‌ ‌a‌ ‌mixture‌ ‌of‌ ‌(+)‌ ‌and‌ ‌(-)‌ ‌does‌ ‌extreme‌ ‌value‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌trait‌ ‌should‌ ‌be‌ ‌rare‌ ‌whereas‌ ‌\nintermediate‌ ‌values‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌close‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌mean‌ ‌should‌ ‌be‌ ‌common.‌ ‌\n●One‌ ‌parent‌ ‌might‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌large‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌(+)‌ ‌Alleles‌ ‌The‌ ‌Other‌ ‌a‌ ‌large‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌(-)‌ ‌Alleles‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌offspring‌ ‌would‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌mixture‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌both‌ ‌types‌ ‌such‌ ‌offspring‌ ‌would‌ ‌therefore‌ ‌be‌ ‌expected‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌phenotypically‌ ‌in‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌parents.‌ ‌\n ‌\nLethal,‌ ‌sub-lethal‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nBackground‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌observed‌ ‌that‌ ‌all‌ ‌genes‌ ‌or‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌factors‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌useful‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌organism.‌ ‌ ‌\n●There‌ ‌are‌ ‌some‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌factors‌ ‌or‌ ‌genes,‌ ‌when‌ ‌present‌ ‌in‌ ‌any‌ ‌organism,‌ ‌cause‌ ‌its‌ ‌death‌ ‌during‌ ‌the‌ ‌early‌ ‌stage‌ ‌of‌ ‌development.‌ ‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌may‌ ‌even‌ ‌cause‌ ‌death‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual‌ ‌either‌ ‌in‌ ‌homozygous‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌or‌ ‌homozygous‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌condition.‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌the‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌that‌ ‌Mendel‌ ‌studied,‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌equally‌ ‌possible‌ ‌to‌ ‌get‌ ‌homozygous‌ ‌dominant,‌ ‌homozygous‌ ‌recessive,‌ ‌and‌ ‌heterozygous‌ ‌\ngenotypes.‌ ‌That‌ ‌is,‌ ‌none‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌genotypes‌ ‌affected‌ ‌the‌ ‌survival‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌pea‌ ‌plants.‌ ‌However,‌ ‌this‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌the‌ ‌case‌ ‌for‌ ‌all‌ ‌genes‌ ‌and‌ ‌all‌ ‌alleles.‌ ‌\n●Many‌ ‌genes‌ ‌in‌ ‌an‌ ‌organism’s‌ ‌genome‌ ‌are‌ ‌needed‌ ‌for‌ ‌survival.‌ ‌If‌ ‌an‌ ‌allele‌ ‌makes‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌genes‌ ‌nonfunctional,‌ ‌or‌ ‌causes‌ ‌it‌ ‌to‌ ‌take‌ ‌on‌ ‌\nan‌ ‌abnormal,‌ ‌harmful‌ ‌activity,‌ ‌it‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌impossible‌ ‌to‌ ‌get‌ ‌a‌ ‌living‌ ‌organism‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌homozygous‌ ‌(or,‌ ‌in‌ ‌some‌ ‌cases,‌ ‌even‌ ‌a‌ ‌heterozygous)‌ ‌\ngenotype.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nIntroduction‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌French‌ ‌geneticist‌ ‌L.‌ ‌Cuenot‌ ‌(1905)‌ ‌reported‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌of‌ ‌mouse‌ ‌body‌ ‌colour.‌ ‌ ‌\n●He‌ ‌found‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌“yellow”‌ ‌body‌ ‌colour‌ ‌was‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌over‌ ‌the‌ ‌normal‌ ‌“brown”‌ ‌colour‌ ‌and‌ ‌was‌ ‌governed‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌single‌ ‌gene‌ ‌“Y”.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌was‌ ‌observed‌ ‌that‌ ‌yellow‌ ‌mice‌ ‌could‌ ‌never‌ ‌be‌ ‌obtained‌ ‌in‌ ‌homozygous‌ ‌condition.‌ ‌\n●When‌ ‌yellow‌ ‌coated‌ ‌mice‌ ‌were‌ ‌crossed‌ ‌with‌ ‌other‌ ‌yellow‌ ‌coated‌ ‌mice,‌ ‌segregation‌ ‌for‌ ‌yellow‌ ‌and‌ ‌brown‌ ‌body‌ ‌colour‌ ‌was‌ ‌obtained‌ ‌in‌ ‌2:‌ ‌1‌ ‌\nratio.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌brown‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌were‌ ‌pure‌ ‌and‌ ‌homozygous‌ ‌whereas‌ ‌yellow‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌were‌ ‌heterozygous.‌ ‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌results‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌explained‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌assumption‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌allele‌ ‌for‌ ‌yellow‌ ‌body‌ ‌colour‌ ‌is‌ ‌lethal‌ ‌in‌ ‌homozygous‌ ‌condition.‌ ‌\n ‌\n801‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n(Inheritance‌ ‌of‌ ‌yellow‌ ‌coated‌ ‌colour‌ ‌in‌ ‌mice.‌ ‌Mice‌ ‌with‌ ‌yellow‌ ‌coated‌ ‌colour‌ ‌are‌ ‌always‌ ‌heterozygous.)‌ ‌\n ‌\n●In‌ ‌1907,‌ ‌Edwin‌ ‌Baur‌ ‌began‌ ‌his‌ ‌work‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌snapdragon‌ ‌plant‌ ‌Antirrhinum‌ ‌and‌ ‌characterized‌ ‌the‌ ‌condition‌ ‌aurea,‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌plants‌ ‌had‌ ‌\ngolden‌ ‌instead‌ ‌of‌ ‌green‌ ‌leaves‌ ‌(Baur,‌ ‌1907;‌ ‌Castle‌ ‌&‌ ‌Little,‌ ‌1910).‌ ‌When‌ ‌two‌ ‌aurea‌ ‌snapdragon‌ ‌plants‌ ‌were‌ ‌crossed,‌ ‌Baur‌ ‌observed‌ ‌a‌ ‌2:1‌ ‌\nratio‌ ‌of‌ ‌green‌ ‌seedlings‌ ‌to‌ ‌yellow‌ ‌seedlings.‌ ‌Homozygous‌ ‌aurea‌ ‌plants‌ ‌lacked‌ ‌normal‌ ‌chlorophyll‌ ‌development‌ ‌and‌ ‌died‌ ‌either‌ ‌during‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nembryonic‌ ‌stage‌ ‌or‌ ‌when‌ ‌the‌ ‌plant‌ ‌seedlings‌ ‌were‌ ‌two‌ ‌to‌ ‌three‌ ‌days‌ ‌old.‌ ‌In‌ ‌other‌ ‌words,‌ ‌like‌ ‌Cuénot's‌ ‌homozygous‌ ‌mice,‌ ‌the‌ ‌homozygous‌ ‌\naurea‌ ‌plants‌ ‌could‌ ‌not‌ ‌fully‌ ‌develop,‌ ‌so‌ ‌an‌ ‌entire‌ ‌class‌ ‌of‌ ‌progeny‌ ‌died‌ ‌(Castle‌ ‌&‌ ‌Little,‌ ‌1910).‌ ‌\n●Cuénot‌ ‌and‌ ‌Baur‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌these‌ ‌first‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌lethal‌ ‌genes‌ ‌because‌ ‌they‌ ‌altered‌ ‌Mendelian‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌ratios.‌ ‌Recessive‌ ‌lethal‌ ‌genes‌ ‌\ncan‌ ‌code‌ ‌for‌ ‌either‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌or‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌traits,‌ ‌but‌ ‌they‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌actually‌ ‌cause‌ ‌death‌ ‌unless‌ ‌an‌ ‌organism‌ ‌carries‌ ‌two‌ ‌copies‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌lethal‌ ‌\nallele.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n802‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nTypes‌ ‌of‌ ‌Lethal‌ ‌Genes:‌ ‌\n●Lethal‌ ‌genes‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌classified‌ ‌in‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌following‌ ‌groups:‌ ‌\n ‌\n1.‌ ‌Recessive‌ ‌lethals‌ ‌\n2.‌ ‌Dominant‌ ‌lethals‌ ‌\n3.‌ ‌Conditional‌ ‌lethals‌ ‌\n4.‌ ‌Balanced‌ ‌lethals‌ ‌\n5.‌ ‌Gametic‌ ‌lethals‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Recessive‌ ‌lethal:‌ ‌\n○Most‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌lethal‌ ‌genes‌ ‌are‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌lethals.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌expressed‌ ‌only‌ ‌when‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌in‌ ‌homozygous‌ ‌condition.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌survival‌ ‌of‌ ‌heterozygotes‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌affected‌ ‌e.g.,‌ ‌coat‌ ‌colour‌ ‌in‌ ‌mice.‌ ‌ ‌\n○According‌ ‌to‌ ‌Cuenot,‌ ‌Castle‌ ‌and‌ ‌Little,‌ ‌the‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌allele‌ ‌Y‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌lethal‌ ‌and‌ ‌it‌ ‌causes‌ ‌death‌ ‌of‌ ‌homozygous‌ ‌YY‌ ‌embryos‌ ‌at‌ ‌\nan‌ ‌early‌ ‌stage‌ ‌of‌ ‌development.‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌example,‌ ‌‌this‌ ‌is‌ ‌true‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌allele‌ ‌that‌ ‌causes‌ ‌achondroplasia,‌ ‌a‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌dwarfism.‌ ‌A‌ ‌person‌ ‌heterozygous‌ ‌for‌ ‌this‌ ‌allele‌ ‌will‌ ‌have‌ ‌\nshortened‌ ‌limbs‌ ‌and‌ ‌short‌ ‌stature‌ ‌(achondroplasia),‌ ‌a‌ ‌condition‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌lethal.‌ ‌\n803‌ ‌\n○However,‌ ‌homozygosity‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌allele‌ ‌causes‌ ‌death‌ ‌during‌ ‌embryonic‌ ‌development‌ ‌or‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌months‌ ‌of‌ ‌life,‌ ‌an‌ ‌example‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nrecessive‌ ‌lethality‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Dominant‌ ‌lethal:‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌lethal‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌is‌ ‌one‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌an‌ ‌allele‌ ‌is‌ ‌lethal‌ ‌both‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌homozygote‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌heterozygote;‌ ‌this‌ ‌allele‌ ‌can‌ ‌\nonly‌ ‌be‌ ‌transmitted‌ ‌if‌ ‌the‌ ‌lethality‌ ‌phenotype‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌after‌ ‌reproductive‌ ‌age.‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌fact,‌ ‌if‌ ‌a‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌lethal‌ ‌allele‌ ‌lets‌ ‌a‌ ‌person‌ ‌survive‌ ‌to‌ ‌reproductive‌ ‌age,‌ ‌it‌ ‌may‌ ‌even‌ ‌be‌ ‌passed‌ ‌on‌ ‌to‌ ‌children.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌case‌ ‌in‌ ‌Huntington’s‌ ‌disease,‌ ‌a‌ ‌fatal‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌disorder‌ ‌affecting‌ ‌the‌ ‌nervous‌ ‌system.‌ ‌ ‌\n○People‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌Huntington‌ ‌allele‌ ‌inevitably‌ ‌develop‌ ‌the‌ ‌disease,‌ ‌but‌ ‌they‌ ‌may‌ ‌not‌ ‌show‌ ‌any‌ ‌symptoms‌ ‌until‌ ‌age‌ ‌40‌ ‌and‌ ‌can‌ ‌\nunknowingly‌ ‌pass‌ ‌the‌ ‌allele‌ ‌on‌ ‌to‌ ‌their‌ ‌children.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Conditional‌ ‌lethal:‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌lethal‌ ‌genes‌ ‌that‌ ‌require‌ ‌a‌ ‌definite‌ ‌or‌ ‌specific‌ ‌condition‌ ‌for‌ ‌their‌ ‌lethal‌ ‌action‌ ‌are‌ ‌said‌ ‌as‌ ‌conditional‌ ‌lethals.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Many‌ ‌mutants‌ ‌of‌ ‌barley,‌ ‌maize,‌ ‌Neurospora,‌ ‌Drosophila‌ ‌and‌ ‌many‌ ‌other‌ ‌organisms‌ ‌are‌ ‌termed‌ ‌as‌ ‌temperature‌ ‌sensitive‌ ‌mutations.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Each‌ ‌of‌ ‌them‌ ‌needs‌ ‌a‌ ‌definite,‌ ‌generally‌ ‌high‌ ‌temperature‌ ‌to‌ ‌express‌ ‌their‌ ‌lethal‌ ‌action.‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌chlorophyll‌ ‌mutant‌ ‌of‌ ‌barley‌ ‌allows‌ ‌normal‌ ‌chlorophyll‌ ‌development‌ ‌at‌ ‌a‌ ‌temperature‌ ‌of‌ ‌19°C‌ ‌or‌ ‌above,‌ ‌but‌ ‌it‌ ‌develops‌ ‌albina‌ ‌or‌ ‌\nabnormal‌ ‌white‌ ‌seedlings‌ ‌at‌ ‌temperature‌ ‌below‌ ‌8°C.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Temperature‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌only‌ ‌responsible‌ ‌for‌ ‌bringing‌ ‌out‌ ‌conditional‌ ‌lethals.‌ ‌Some‌ ‌conditional‌ ‌lethals‌ ‌require‌ ‌light,‌ ‌nutrition‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Balanced‌ ‌Lethals:‌ ‌\n○Two‌ ‌different‌ ‌lethal‌ ‌systems‌ ‌can‌ ‌operate‌ ‌in‌ ‌an‌ ‌organism,‌ ‌and‌ ‌balance‌ ‌each‌ ‌other's‌ ‌effect.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Both‌ ‌genes‌ ‌are‌ ‌tightly‌ ‌linked‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌repulsion‌ ‌phase‌ ‌of‌ ‌linkage‌ ‌where‌ ‌a‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌allele‌ ‌of‌ ‌one‌ ‌gene‌ ‌is‌ ‌linked‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌allele‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nanother‌ ‌gene.‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌such‌ ‌cases,‌ ‌one‌ ‌parent‌ ‌contributes‌ ‌the‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌allele‌ ‌of‌ ‌gene‌ ‌one‌ ‌and‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌allele‌ ‌of‌ ‌gene‌ ‌two,‌ ‌while‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌parent‌ ‌\ncontributes‌ ‌the‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌allele‌ ‌of‌ ‌gene‌ ‌one‌ ‌and‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌allele‌ ‌of‌ ‌gene‌ ‌two.‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌arrangement‌ ‌of‌ ‌lethal‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌maintains‌ ‌a‌ ‌heterozygous‌ ‌combination,‌ ‌and‌ ‌ensures‌ ‌that‌ ‌homozygotes‌ ‌for‌ ‌lethal‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌do‌ ‌\nnot‌ ‌occur.‌ ‌\n○Balanced‌ ‌lethals‌ ‌are‌ ‌seen‌ ‌in‌ ‌mice,‌ ‌Oenothra,‌ ‌Drosophila‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Gametic‌ ‌Lethals:‌ ‌\n○Some‌ ‌genes‌ ‌make‌ ‌the‌ ‌gametes‌ ‌incapable‌ ‌of‌ ‌fertilization.‌ ‌Such‌ ‌genes‌ ‌are‌ ‌said‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌gametic‌ ‌lethals.‌ ‌\n○Sometimes‌ ‌the‌ ‌term‌ ‌‘Meiotic‌ ‌drive’‌ ‌is‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌describe‌ ‌gametic‌ ‌lethals.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Meiotic‌ ‌drive‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌called‌ ‌a‌ ‌mechanism‌ ‌that‌ ‌leads‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌production‌ ‌of‌ ‌unequal‌ ‌numbers‌ ‌of‌ ‌functional‌ ‌gametes‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌heterozygote.‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌certain‌ ‌males‌ ‌of‌ ‌Drosophila‌ ‌pseudoobscura,‌ ‌producing‌ ‌only‌ ‌half‌ ‌the‌ ‌amount‌ ‌of‌ ‌sperm‌ ‌as‌ ‌compared‌ ‌to‌ ‌normal‌ ‌\nmales.‌ ‌ ‌\n○When‌ ‌these‌ ‌males‌ ‌are‌ ‌mated‌ ‌to‌ ‌normal‌ ‌females,‌ ‌most‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌progeny‌ ‌are‌ ‌females.‌ ‌ ‌\n804‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌demonstrates‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌sperm‌ ‌cells‌ ‌produced‌ ‌by‌ ‌these‌ ‌males‌ ‌contain‌ ‌the‌ ‌‘X’‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌only‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌sperms‌ ‌having‌ ‌‘Y’‌ ‌\nchromosome‌ ‌are‌ ‌non-functional.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●It‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌clarified‌ ‌as‌ ‌follows:‌ ‌\n ‌\n●On‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌effect‌ ‌of‌ ‌survivability‌ ‌the‌ ‌genes‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌grouped‌ ‌in‌ ‌to‌ ‌5‌ ‌classes:‌ ‌\n1.‌ ‌Vital‌ ‌genes‌ ‌\n2.‌ ‌Lethal‌ ‌genes‌ ‌\n3.‌ ‌Sub-lethal‌ ‌genes‌ ‌\n4.‌ ‌Sub-vital‌ ‌genes‌ ‌\n5.‌ ‌Super-vital‌ ‌genes‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Vital‌ ‌genes:‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌genes‌ ‌which‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌affect‌ ‌the‌ ‌survival‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌present‌ ‌are‌ ‌said‌ ‌as‌ ‌vital‌ ‌genes.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌mean‌ ‌that‌ ‌these‌ ‌genes‌ ‌are‌ ‌necessary‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌survival‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌concerned‌ ‌individual.‌ ‌Wild‌ ‌type‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌genes‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌\norganism‌ ‌are‌ ‌said‌ ‌as‌ ‌vital‌ ‌genes.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌other‌ ‌words,‌ ‌the‌ ‌survival‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌organism‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌influenced‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌vital‌ ‌genes,‌ ‌whether‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌present‌ ‌in‌ ‌homo‌ ‌or‌ ‌heterozygous‌ ‌\nconditions.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Lethal‌ ‌genes:‌ ‌ ‌\n○Lethals‌ ‌or‌ ‌lethal‌ ‌genes‌ ‌or‌ ‌lethal‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌are‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌causing‌ ‌the‌ ‌end‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌entity‌ ‌which‌ ‌carries‌ ‌it.‌ ‌Typically‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌consequence‌ ‌of‌ ‌\ngene-mutation‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌required‌ ‌to‌ ‌grow‌ ‌and‌ ‌develop‌ ‌\n ‌\n● ‌‌Sub-lethal‌ ‌or‌ ‌semi-lethal‌ ‌genes:‌ ‌\n○Such‌ ‌genes‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌lead‌ ‌the‌ ‌organism‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌death‌ ‌that‌ ‌carry‌ ‌them‌ ‌in‌ ‌appropriate‌ ‌genotype.‌ ‌90%‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌die,‌ ‌however,‌ ‌only‌ ‌\nless‌ ‌than‌ ‌10%‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌survive.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Some‌ ‌Xantha‌ ‌mutants‌ ‌of‌ ‌several‌ ‌plants‌ ‌are‌ ‌sub-lethal‌ ‌or‌ ‌semi-lethal‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌homozygous‌ ‌state.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Sub-vital‌ ‌genes:‌ ‌\n805‌ ‌\n○Most‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌mutant‌ ‌genes‌ ‌reduce‌ ‌the‌ ‌viability‌ ‌of‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌having‌ ‌them‌ ‌in‌ ‌appropriate‌ ‌genotype‌ ‌as‌ ‌compared‌ ‌to‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌normal‌ ‌\nindividuals.‌ ‌Most‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌mutant‌ ‌genes‌ ‌are‌ ‌sub-vital‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌effect‌ ‌and‌ ‌kill‌ ‌less‌ ‌than‌ ‌90%‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌which‌ ‌carry‌ ‌them.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌examples‌ ‌are‌ ‌some‌ ‌virdis‌ ‌mutants‌ ‌of‌ ‌barley,‌ ‌miniature‌ ‌wings‌ ‌in‌ ‌Drosophila.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Super-vital‌ ‌genes:‌ ‌\n○Most‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌mutant‌ ‌genes‌ ‌increase‌ ‌the‌ ‌survival‌ ‌of‌ ‌such‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌which‌ ‌carry‌ ‌them‌ ‌in‌ ‌appropriate‌ ‌genotype‌ ‌as‌ ‌compared‌ ‌to‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nwild‌ ‌type‌ ‌allele.‌ ‌Such‌ ‌genes‌ ‌are‌ ‌called‌ ‌super-vital‌ ‌genes.‌ ‌\n○Super-vital‌ ‌genes‌ ‌protect‌ ‌the‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌carrying‌ ‌them‌ ‌against‌ ‌the‌ ‌various‌ ‌diseases‌ ‌thus‌ ‌increasing‌ ‌the‌ ‌chance‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌survival.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Likewise,‌ ‌the‌ ‌genes‌ ‌provide‌ ‌resistance‌ ‌or‌ ‌tolerance‌ ‌to‌ ‌different‌ ‌environmental‌ ‌pressure‌ ‌or‌ ‌strain‌ ‌like‌ ‌high‌ ‌and‌ ‌low‌ ‌temperature,‌ ‌low‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌high‌ ‌light‌ ‌intensity,‌ ‌drought,‌ ‌salinity,‌ ‌alkanity‌ ‌etc..‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n9.3‌ ‌Concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌polymorphism‌ ‌and‌ ‌selection,‌ ‌Mendelian‌ ‌population,‌ ‌Hardy-Weinberg‌ ‌law;‌ ‌Part-I‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nConcept‌ ‌of‌ ‌Genetic‌ ‌Polymorphism‌ ‌and‌ ‌Selection,‌ ‌\nBackground‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌biology,‌ ‌‌polymorphism‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌occurrence‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌or‌ ‌more‌ ‌clearly‌ ‌different‌ ‌morphs‌ ‌or‌ ‌forms,‌ ‌also‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to‌ ‌as‌ ‌alternative‌ ‌phenotypes‌,‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌\npopulation‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌species.‌ ‌ ‌\n●To‌ ‌be‌ ‌classified‌ ‌as‌ ‌such,‌ ‌morphs‌ ‌must‌ ‌occupy‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌habitat‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌time‌ ‌and‌ ‌belong‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌‌panmictic‌ ‌population‌‌ ‌(one‌ ‌with‌ ‌random‌ ‌\nmating).‌ ‌\n●Put‌ ‌simply,‌ ‌polymorphism‌ ‌is‌ ‌when‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌two‌ ‌or‌ ‌more‌ ‌possibilities‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌trait‌ ‌on‌ ‌a‌ ‌gene.‌ ‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌example‌,‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌one‌ ‌possible‌ ‌trait‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌jaguar's‌ ‌skin‌ ‌colouring;‌ ‌they‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌light‌ ‌morph‌ ‌or‌ ‌dark‌ ‌morph.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Due‌ ‌to‌ ‌having‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌one‌ ‌possible‌ ‌variation‌ ‌for‌ ‌this‌ ‌gene,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌termed‌ ‌'polymorphism'.‌ ‌ ‌\n○However,‌ ‌if‌ ‌the‌ ‌jaguar‌ ‌has‌ ‌only‌ ‌one‌ ‌possible‌ ‌trait‌ ‌for‌ ‌that‌ ‌gene,‌ ‌there‌ ‌was‌ ‌only‌ ‌one‌ ‌possible‌ ‌skin‌ ‌colour‌ ‌that‌ ‌a‌ ‌jaguar‌ ‌could‌ ‌have,‌ ‌it‌ ‌\nwould‌ ‌be‌ ‌termed‌ ‌monomorphic.‌ ‌\n●Another‌ ‌example‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌difference‌ ‌in‌ ‌pigmentation‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌birds.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Birds‌ ‌like‌ ‌Gouldian‌ ‌finch‌ ‌have‌ ‌striking‌ ‌color‌ ‌morphs‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌variant‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌of‌ ‌pigmentation‌ ‌of‌ ‌non-melanic‌ ‌pigments.‌ ‌ ‌\n○There‌ ‌are‌ ‌red‌ ‌and‌ ‌black‌ ‌color‌ ‌variants,‌ ‌and‌ ‌then‌ ‌further‌ ‌inter-morph‌ ‌difference‌ ‌exists‌ ‌because‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌variants‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌two‌ ‌alleles.‌ ‌ ‌\n806‌ ‌\n○Then‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌differences‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌feathers'‌ ‌structure.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●The‌ ‌term‌ ‌polyphenism‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌clarify‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌different‌ ‌forms‌ ‌arise‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌genotype.‌ ‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌polyphenic‌ ‌trait‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌trait‌ ‌for‌ ‌which‌ ‌multiple,‌ ‌discrete‌ ‌phenotypes‌ ‌can‌ ‌arise‌ ‌from‌ ‌a‌ ‌single‌ ‌genotype‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌result‌ ‌of‌ ‌differing‌ ‌\nenvironmental‌ ‌conditions.‌ ‌ ‌\n○There‌ ‌are‌ ‌several‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌polyphenism‌ ‌in‌ ‌animals,‌ ‌from‌ ‌having‌ ‌sex‌ ‌determined‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌environment‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌castes‌ ‌of‌ ‌honey‌ ‌bees‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nother‌ ‌social‌ ‌insects.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Some‌ ‌polyphenisms‌ ‌are‌ ‌seasonal,‌ ‌as‌ ‌in‌ ‌some‌ ‌butterflies‌ ‌which‌ ‌have‌ ‌different‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌during‌ ‌the‌ ‌year,‌ ‌and‌ ‌some‌ ‌Arctic‌ ‌animals‌ ‌like‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌snowshoe‌ ‌hare‌ ‌and‌ ‌Arctic‌ ‌fox,‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌white‌ ‌in‌ ‌winter.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Other‌ ‌animals‌ ‌have‌ ‌predator-induced‌ ‌or‌ ‌resource‌ ‌polyphenisms,‌ ‌allowing‌ ‌them‌ ‌to‌ ‌exploit‌ ‌variations‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌environment.‌ ‌Some‌ ‌\nnematode‌ ‌worms‌ ‌can‌ ‌develop‌ ‌either‌ ‌into‌ ‌adults‌ ‌or‌ ‌into‌ ‌resting‌ ‌dauer‌ ‌larvae‌ ‌according‌ ‌to‌ ‌resource‌ ‌availability.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Genetic‌ ‌polymorphism‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌term‌ ‌used‌ ‌somewhat‌ ‌differently‌ ‌by‌ ‌geneticists‌ ‌and‌ ‌molecular‌ ‌biologists‌ ‌to‌ ‌describe‌ ‌certain‌ ‌mutations‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌\ngenotype,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌‌single‌ ‌nucleotide‌ ‌polymorphisms‌‌ ‌that‌ ‌may‌ ‌not‌ ‌always‌ ‌correspond‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌phenotype,‌ ‌but‌ ‌always‌ ‌correspond‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌branch‌ ‌\nin‌ ‌the‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌tree.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nHow‌ ‌is‌ ‌it‌ ‌different?‌ ‌\n ‌\nDNA‌ ‌sequence‌ ‌variations‌ ‌are‌ ‌sometimes‌ ‌described‌ ‌as‌ ‌mutations‌ ‌and‌ ‌sometimes‌ ‌as‌ ‌polymorphisms.‌ ‌What‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌difference‌ ‌between‌ ‌these‌ ‌terms‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌how‌ ‌are‌ ‌they‌ ‌applied‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌human‌ ‌genome?‌ ‌\n807‌ ‌\n ‌\n●The‌ ‌important‌ ‌property‌ ‌of‌ ‌DNA‌ ‌is‌ ‌its‌ ‌fidelity:‌ ‌most‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌time‌ ‌it‌ ‌accurately‌ ‌passes‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌information‌ ‌from‌ ‌one‌ ‌generation‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌next.‌ ‌\n●However,‌ ‌DNA‌ ‌sequences‌ ‌can‌ ‌also‌ ‌change.‌ ‌Changes‌ ‌in‌ ‌DNA‌ ‌sequences‌ ‌are‌ ‌called‌ ‌‌mutations.‌ ‌ ‌\n●If‌ ‌a‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌changes‌ ‌the‌ ‌phenotype‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual,‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual‌ ‌is‌ ‌said‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌a‌ ‌mutant.‌ ‌‌Naturally‌ ‌occurring,‌ ‌but‌ ‌rare,‌ ‌sequence‌ ‌variants‌ ‌\nthat‌ ‌are‌ ‌clearly‌ ‌different‌ ‌from‌ ‌a‌ ‌normal,‌ ‌wild-type‌ ‌sequence‌ ‌are‌ ‌also‌ ‌called‌ ‌mutations.‌ ‌\n●On‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌hand,‌ ‌many‌ ‌naturally‌ ‌occurring‌ ‌variants‌ ‌exist‌ ‌for‌ ‌traits‌ ‌for‌ ‌which‌ ‌no‌ ‌clearly‌ ‌normal‌ ‌type‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌defined;‌ ‌thus,‌ ‌we‌ ‌use‌ ‌the‌ ‌term‌ ‌\npolymorphism‌ ‌to‌ ‌refer‌ ‌to‌ ‌variants‌ ‌of‌ ‌DNA‌ ‌sequences‌ ‌(and‌ ‌other‌ ‌phenotypes)‌ ‌that‌ ‌co-exist‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌population‌ ‌at‌ ‌relatively‌ ‌high‌ ‌frequencies‌ ‌\n(>1%).‌ ‌\n●To‌ ‌put‌ ‌it‌ ‌simply,‌ ‌The‌ ‌arbitrary‌ ‌cut-off‌ ‌point‌ ‌between‌ ‌a‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌polymorphism‌ ‌is‌ ‌1%.‌ ‌ ‌\n○That‌ ‌is,‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌classed‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌polymorphic‌ ‌trait,‌ ‌a‌ ‌character‌ ‌must‌ ‌be‌ ‌present‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌below‌ ‌this‌ ‌level‌ ‌is‌ ‌supposed‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌arising‌ ‌\ndue‌ ‌to‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌&‌ ‌selection‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌operating‌ ‌on‌ ‌it,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌only‌ ‌above‌ ‌the‌ ‌ratio‌ ‌of‌ ‌1%‌ ‌that‌ ‌we‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌sure‌ ‌to‌ ‌say‌ ‌some‌ ‌selection‌ ‌is‌ ‌\ninvolved‌ ‌in‌ ‌its‌ ‌maintenance‌ ‌and‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌because‌ ‌of‌ ‌recurrent‌ ‌mutation.‌ ‌\n○If‌ ‌the‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌is‌ ‌lower‌ ‌than‌ ‌this,‌ ‌the‌ ‌allele‌ ‌is‌ ‌regarded‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌mutation.‌ ‌\n●Polymorphisms‌ ‌and‌ ‌mutations‌ ‌arise‌ ‌through‌ ‌similar‌ ‌biochemical‌ ‌processes,‌ ‌but‌ ‌the‌ ‌use‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌word‌ ‌“polymorphism”‌ ‌avoids‌ ‌implying‌ ‌that‌ ‌any‌ ‌\nparticular‌ ‌allele‌ ‌is‌ ‌more‌ ‌normal‌ ‌or‌ ‌abnormal.‌ ‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌example‌,‌ ‌a‌ ‌change‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌person’s‌ ‌DNA‌ ‌sequence‌ ‌that‌ ‌leads‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌disease‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌cancer‌ ‌is‌ ‌appropriately‌ ‌called‌ ‌a‌ ‌mutation,‌ ‌but‌ ‌a‌ ‌\ndifference‌ ‌in‌ ‌DNA‌ ‌sequence‌ ‌that‌ ‌explains‌ ‌whether‌ ‌a‌ ‌person‌ ‌has‌ ‌red‌ ‌hair‌ ‌rather‌ ‌than‌ ‌brown‌ ‌or‌ ‌black‌ ‌hair‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌example‌ ‌of‌ ‌polymorphism.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nSummarize:‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌is‌ ‌defined‌ ‌as‌ ‌any‌ ‌change‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌DNA‌ ‌sequence‌ ‌away‌ ‌from‌ ‌normal.‌ ‌This‌ ‌implies‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌normal‌ ‌allele‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌prevalent‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌\npopulation‌ ‌and‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌changes‌ ‌this‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌rare‌ ‌and‌ ‌abnormal‌ ‌variant.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌contrast,‌ ‌polymorphism‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌DNA‌ ‌sequence‌ ‌variation‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌common‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌population.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌this‌ ‌case‌ ‌no‌ ‌single‌ ‌allele‌ ‌is‌ ‌regarded‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌standard‌ ‌sequence.‌ ‌Instead‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌two‌ ‌or‌ ‌more‌ ‌equally‌ ‌acceptable‌ ‌alternatives.‌ ‌ ‌\n808‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n809‌ ‌\nWhat‌ ‌is‌ ‌Genetic‌ ‌Polymorphism?‌ ‌\n●Genetic‌ ‌polymorphisms‌ ‌are‌ ‌defined‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌occurrence‌ ‌of‌ ‌multiple‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌at‌ ‌a‌ ‌locus,‌ ‌where‌ ‌at‌ ‌least‌ ‌two‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌occur‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌\ngreater‌ ‌than‌ ‌1%.‌ ‌\n●Genetic‌ ‌polymorphism‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌simultaneous‌ ‌occurrence‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌locality‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌or‌ ‌more‌ ‌discontinuous‌ ‌forms‌ ‌in‌ ‌such‌ ‌proportions‌ ‌\nthat‌ ‌the‌ ‌rarest‌ ‌of‌ ‌them‌ ‌cannot‌ ‌be‌ ‌maintained‌ ‌just‌ ‌by‌ ‌recurrent‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌or‌ ‌immigration,‌ ‌‌originally‌ ‌defined‌ ‌by‌ ‌Ford‌ ‌(1940).‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌later‌ ‌definition‌ ‌by‌ ‌‌Cavalli-Sforza‌ ‌&‌ ‌Bodmer‌ ‌(1971)‌‌ ‌is‌ ‌currently‌ ‌used:‌ ‌\"Genetic‌ ‌polymorphism‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌occurrence‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌\npopulation‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌or‌ ‌more‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌at‌ ‌one‌ ‌locus,‌ ‌each‌ ‌with‌ ‌appreciable‌ ‌frequency\",‌ ‌where‌ ‌the‌ ‌minimum‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌is‌ ‌typically‌ ‌taken‌ ‌as‌ ‌\n1%.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●The‌ ‌definition‌ ‌has‌ ‌three‌ ‌parts:‌ ‌ ‌\na)‌ ‌sympatry:‌ ‌one‌ ‌interbreeding‌ ‌population;‌ ‌ ‌\nb)‌ ‌discrete‌ ‌forms;‌ ‌and‌ ‌ ‌\nc)‌ ‌not‌ ‌maintained‌ ‌just‌ ‌by‌ ‌mutation.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●In‌ ‌simple‌ ‌words,‌ ‌the‌ ‌term‌ ‌polymorphism‌ ‌was‌ ‌originally‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌describe‌ ‌variations‌ ‌in‌ ‌shape‌ ‌and‌ ‌form‌ ‌that‌ ‌distinguish‌ ‌normal‌ ‌\nindividuals‌ ‌within‌ ‌a‌ ‌species‌ ‌from‌ ‌each‌ ‌other.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Presently,‌ ‌geneticists‌ ‌use‌ ‌the‌ ‌term‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌polymorphism‌ ‌to‌ ‌describe‌ ‌the‌ ‌inter-individual,‌ ‌functionally‌ ‌silent‌ ‌differences‌ ‌in‌ ‌DNA‌ ‌\nsequence‌ ‌that‌ ‌make‌ ‌each‌ ‌human‌ ‌genome‌ ‌unique.‌ ‌\n●Example:‌ ‌ ‌\n●All‌ ‌the‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌blood‌ ‌groups‌ ‌are‌ ‌examples‌ ‌of‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌polymorphism,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌ABO‌ ‌blood‌ ‌group‌ ‌system.‌ ‌We‌ ‌see‌ ‌this‌ ‌system‌ ‌\nhaving‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌two‌ ‌morphs:‌ ‌A,‌ ‌B,‌ ‌AB,‌ ‌and‌ ‌O‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌variants‌ ‌present‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌entire‌ ‌human‌ ‌population,‌ ‌but‌ ‌these‌ ‌groups‌ ‌vary‌ ‌in‌ ‌\n810‌ ‌\nproportion‌ ‌in‌ ‌different‌ ‌parts‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌world.‌ ‌This‌ ‌trait‌ ‌is‌ ‌controlled‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌presence‌ ‌of‌ ‌multiple‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌at‌ ‌one‌ ‌locus.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nWhat‌ ‌Causes‌ ‌Polymorphism?‌ ‌\nThere‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌several‌ ‌causes‌ ‌of‌ ‌polymorphism.‌ ‌Some‌ ‌are‌ ‌listed‌ ‌below.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●One‌ ‌reason‌ ‌for‌ ‌maintaining‌ ‌polymorphism‌ ‌is‌ ‌to‌ ‌create‌ ‌a‌ ‌balance‌ ‌between‌ ‌variations‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌created‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌process‌ ‌of‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌or‌ ‌due‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌natural‌ ‌selection.‌ ‌\n●Frequency-dependent‌ ‌selection‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌a‌ ‌cause‌ ‌of‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌variation‌ ‌or‌ ‌polymorphism.‌ ‌\n●Heterozygous‌ ‌polymorphism‌ ‌works‌ ‌to‌ ‌maintain‌ ‌alleles.‌ ‌\n●Migration‌ ‌of‌ ‌populations‌ ‌of‌ ‌species‌ ‌also‌ ‌results‌ ‌in‌ ‌polymorphism.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Misconceptions:‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌two‌ ‌general‌ ‌misconceptions‌ ‌regarding‌ ‌polymorphism.‌ ‌They‌ ‌are‌ ‌as‌ ‌follows:‌ ‌\n○Continuous‌ ‌variation‌ ‌traits‌ ‌\n■Traits‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌height‌ ‌have‌ ‌continuous‌ ‌variations‌ ‌and‌ ‌they‌ ‌may‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌be‌ ‌inherited‌ ‌but‌ ‌they‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌come‌ ‌under‌ ‌the‌ ‌\ncategory‌ ‌of‌ ‌polymorphism.‌ ‌\n ‌\n○Geographical‌ ‌variants‌ ‌\n■Variants‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌gene‌ ‌differing‌ ‌by‌ ‌geography‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌included‌ ‌in‌ ‌polymorphism‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌term‌ ‌is‌ ‌specific‌ ‌to‌ ‌variants‌ ‌existing‌ ‌\nin‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌habitat‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌time.‌ ‌\n811‌ ‌\n ‌\nWhat‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌Heterozygote‌ ‌advantage?‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Genetic‌ ‌Polymorphism‌ ‌is‌ ‌usually‌ ‌maintained‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌superiority‌ ‌of‌ ‌heterozygotes‌ ‌over‌ ‌both‌ ‌homozygous.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌heterozygote‌ ‌advantage‌ ‌means‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌heterozygous‌ ‌genotype‌ ‌has‌ ‌a‌ ‌rather‌ ‌higher‌ ‌relative-fitness‌ ‌than‌ ‌other‌ ‌possible‌ ‌\ngenotypes.‌ ‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌single‌ ‌locus‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌overdominance‌ ‌is‌ ‌responsible‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌specific‌ ‌case‌ ‌of‌ ‌heterozygous‌ ‌advantage.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Example:‌ ‌Cystic‌ ‌Fibrosis‌ ‌(Cystic‌ ‌fibrosis‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌example‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌disease.‌ ‌That‌ ‌means‌ ‌a‌ ‌person‌ ‌must‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌in‌ ‌both‌ ‌\ncopies‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌CFTR‌ ‌gene‌ ‌to‌ ‌have‌ ‌CF)‌ ‌\nRecently‌ ‌a‌ ‌heterozygote‌ ‌advantage‌ ‌was‌ ‌suggested‌ ‌to‌ ‌explain‌ ‌the‌ ‌high‌ ‌incidence‌ ‌(1:25‌ ‌carrier‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌in‌ ‌Europeans)‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌cystic‌ ‌\nfibrosis‌ ‌gene.‌ ‌This‌ ‌selective‌ ‌advantage‌ ‌was‌ ‌speculated‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌high‌ ‌resistance‌ ‌to‌ ‌chloride-secretion‌ ‌diarrhea,‌ ‌including‌ ‌\ncholera.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n812‌ ‌\n●Another‌ ‌example,‌ ‌heterozygote‌ ‌for‌ ‌sickle‌ ‌cell‌ ‌anemia‌ ‌trait‌ ‌is‌ ‌observed‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌more‌ ‌resistant‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌debilitating‌ ‌effects‌ ‌of‌ ‌malaria‌ ‌than‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌homozygous‌ ‌dominant.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nWhat‌ ‌is‌ ‌Balanced‌ ‌Polymorphism?‌ ‌\n○When‌ ‌Polymorphism‌ ‌is‌ ‌maintained‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌result‌ ‌of‌ ‌heterozygote‌ ‌advantages‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌‌balanced‌ ‌polymorphism.‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌balanced‌ ‌polymorphism,‌ ‌two‌ ‌different‌ ‌genes‌ ‌are‌ ‌maintained‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌population‌ ‌of‌ ‌one‌ ‌species‌ ‌or‌ ‌organism.‌ ‌This‌ ‌happens‌ ‌\nbecause‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌that‌ ‌carry‌ ‌both‌ ‌versions‌ ‌of‌ ‌polymorphic‌ ‌genes‌ ‌are‌ ‌relatively‌ ‌fit‌ ‌or‌ ‌are‌ ‌more‌ ‌able‌ ‌to‌ ‌survive‌ ‌than‌ ‌those‌ ‌\nhaving‌ ‌two‌ ‌copies‌ ‌of‌ ‌either‌ ‌version‌ ‌alone.‌ ‌This‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌process‌ ‌that‌ ‌helps‌ ‌to‌ ‌maintain‌ ‌the‌ ‌two‌ ‌versions‌ ‌over‌ ‌a‌ ‌long‌ ‌time‌ ‌\nis‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to‌ ‌as‌ ‌balanced‌ ‌polymorphism‌ ‌or‌ ‌balancing‌ ‌selection.‌ ‌\n○Example‌ ‌\n■Sickle‌ ‌cell‌ ‌anemia‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌observed‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌tropical‌ ‌populations‌ ‌in‌ ‌Africa‌ ‌and‌ ‌India.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌autosomal‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌\ndisorder.‌ ‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌is‌ ‌responsible‌ ‌for‌ ‌causing‌ ‌anemia,‌ ‌a‌ ‌swollen‌ ‌spleen,‌ ‌joint‌ ‌pain,‌ ‌and‌ ‌some‌ ‌other‌ ‌frequent‌ ‌severe‌ ‌infections.‌ ‌It‌ ‌\nillustrates‌ ‌a‌ ‌balanced‌ ‌polymorphism.‌ ‌In‌ ‌sickle‌ ‌cell‌ ‌anemia,‌ ‌the‌ ‌heterozygous‌ ‌carrier‌ ‌becomes‌ ‌resistant‌ ‌to‌ ‌malaria.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nTypes‌ ‌of‌‌ ‌‌Genetic‌ ‌Polymorphism‌ ‌\nVarious‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌polymorphisms‌ ‌include:‌ ‌\n●Single‌ ‌nucleotide‌ ‌polymorphisms‌ ‌(SNPs),‌ ‌ ‌\n●Tandem‌ ‌repeat‌ ‌polymorphisms‌ ‌(VNTRs)‌ ‌\n●Short‌ ‌tandem‌ ‌repeats‌ ‌(STRs)/Microsatellite‌ ‌\n●Insertion/deletion‌ ‌polymorphisms‌ ‌\n ‌\nSingle‌ ‌nucleotide‌ ‌polymorphisms‌ ‌(SNPs)‌ ‌\n● ‌SNPs‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌observed‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌variations‌ ‌among‌ ‌individuals.‌ ‌A‌ ‌nucleotide‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌DNA‌ ‌building‌ ‌block.‌ ‌Each‌ ‌SNP‌ ‌stands‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌single‌ ‌\nnucleotide‌ ‌variant.‌ ‌The‌ ‌replacement‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌nucleotide,‌ ‌cytosine,‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌nucleotide,‌ ‌thymine,‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌example‌ ‌of‌ ‌single‌ ‌nucleotide‌ ‌\npolymorphism.‌ ‌\n●If‌ ‌a‌ ‌gene‌ ‌has‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌one‌ ‌allele,‌ ‌it‌ ‌means‌ ‌SNP‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌in‌ ‌that‌ ‌gene.‌ ‌SNPs‌ ‌may‌ ‌also‌ ‌be‌ ‌responsible‌ ‌for‌ ‌variations‌ ‌in‌ ‌amino‌ ‌acid‌ ‌\nsequences.‌ ‌ ‌\n●However,‌ ‌along‌ ‌with‌ ‌their‌ ‌association‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌gene,‌ ‌single‌ ‌nucleotide‌ ‌polymorphisms‌ ‌may‌ ‌also‌ ‌occur‌ ‌in‌ ‌non-coding‌ ‌areas‌ ‌of‌ ‌DNA.‌ ‌\n●Around‌ ‌90%‌ ‌of‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌variation‌ ‌in‌ ‌human‌ ‌beings‌ ‌is‌ ‌caused‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌SNPs.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌observed‌ ‌that‌ ‌most‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌variations‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌affect‌ ‌cellular‌ ‌\nfunction‌ ‌in‌ ‌humans.‌ ‌\n●However,‌ ‌some‌ ‌studies‌ ‌have‌ ‌shown‌ ‌that‌ ‌SNPs‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌a‌ ‌reason‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌various‌ ‌diseases‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌cancer.‌ ‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌may‌ ‌also‌ ‌influence‌ ‌physiological‌ ‌responses‌ ‌to‌ ‌drugs.‌ ‌\n ‌\n813‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nTandem‌ ‌repeat‌ ‌polymorphisms‌ ‌(VNTRs)‌ ‌\n●Tandem‌ ‌repeats‌ ‌occur‌ ‌in‌ ‌DNA‌ ‌when‌ ‌a‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌of‌ ‌one‌ ‌or‌ ‌more‌ ‌nucleotides‌ ‌is‌ ‌repeated‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌repetitions‌ ‌are‌ ‌directly‌ ‌adjacent‌ ‌to‌ ‌each‌ ‌other.‌ ‌\n○An‌ ‌example‌ ‌would‌ ‌be:‌ ‌AATTTTCCGGCCCCAAAATTCCAATTTTCCGGCCCCAAAATTCCAATTTTCCGGCCCCAAAATTCC‌ ‌These‌ ‌\ncan‌ ‌be‌ ‌found‌ ‌on‌ ‌many‌ ‌chromosomes,‌ ‌and‌ ‌often‌ ‌show‌ ‌variations‌ ‌in‌ ‌length‌ ‌between‌ ‌individuals.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌elements‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌given‌ ‌region‌ ‌may‌ ‌vary,‌ ‌hence‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌variable‌ ‌number‌ ‌tandem‌ ‌repeats.‌ ‌\n●Each‌ ‌variant‌ ‌acts‌ ‌as‌ ‌an‌ ‌inherited‌ ‌allele,‌ ‌allowing‌ ‌them‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌used‌ ‌for‌ ‌personal‌ ‌or‌ ‌parental‌ ‌identification.‌ ‌\n●Scientists‌ ‌use‌ ‌polymorphic‌ ‌loci‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌known‌ ‌to‌ ‌contain‌ ‌VNTRs/STRs‌ ‌in‌ ‌order‌ ‌to‌ ‌differentiate‌ ‌people‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌their‌ ‌DNA.‌ ‌\n ‌\nShort‌ ‌tandem‌ ‌repeats‌ ‌(STRs)‌ ‌\n●Short‌ ‌tandem‌ ‌repeats‌ ‌(STRs),‌ ‌also‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌microsatellites‌ ‌or‌ ‌simple‌ ‌sequence‌ ‌repeats,‌ ‌are‌ ‌short‌ ‌tandemly‌ ‌repeated‌ ‌DNA‌ ‌sequences‌ ‌that‌ ‌\ninvolve‌ ‌a‌ ‌repetitive‌ ‌unit‌ ‌of‌ ‌1-6‌ ‌bp‌ ‌(1),‌ ‌forming‌ ‌a‌ ‌series‌ ‌with‌ ‌lengths‌ ‌of‌ ‌up‌ ‌to‌ ‌100‌ ‌nucleotides‌ ‌(nt).‌ ‌ ‌\n814‌ ‌\n●STRs‌ ‌are‌ ‌widely‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌prokaryotes‌ ‌and‌ ‌eukaryotes,‌ ‌including‌ ‌humans.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nInsertion/deletion‌ ‌polymorphisms‌ ‌\n●An‌ ‌insertion/deletion‌ ‌polymorphism,‌ ‌commonly‌ ‌abbreviated‌ ‌“indel,”‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌variation‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌a‌ ‌specific‌ ‌nucleotide‌ ‌sequence‌ ‌is‌ ‌\npresent‌ ‌(insertion)‌ ‌or‌ ‌absent‌ ‌(deletion).‌ ‌ ‌\n●While‌ ‌not‌ ‌as‌ ‌common‌ ‌as‌ ‌SNPs,‌ ‌indels‌ ‌are‌ ‌widely‌ ‌spread‌ ‌across‌ ‌the‌ ‌genome.‌ ‌\n ‌\nApplications‌ ‌of‌ ‌DNA‌ ‌Polymorphisms‌ ‌in‌ ‌Anthropology‌ ‌\nIt‌ ‌is‌ ‌impossible‌ ‌to‌ ‌exhaustively‌ ‌list‌ ‌all‌ ‌possible‌ ‌applications.‌ ‌The‌ ‌more‌ ‌important‌ ‌\nones‌ ‌are:‌ ‌\n●Genetic‌ ‌polymorphisms‌ ‌determine‌ ‌the‌ ‌diversity‌ ‌of‌ ‌individuals.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌gene‌ ‌polymorphism‌ ‌has‌ ‌opened‌ ‌a‌ ‌new‌ ‌area‌ ‌for‌ ‌us‌ ‌to‌ ‌explore‌ ‌the‌ ‌pathogenesis‌ ‌and‌ ‌progression‌ ‌of‌ ‌diseases‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌nature‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nphenotypic‌ ‌diversity.‌ ‌\n●Inferring‌ ‌population‌ ‌histories‌ ‌and‌ ‌affinities‌ ‌\n●Reconstructing‌ ‌mutational‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌and‌ ‌dating‌ ‌occurrences‌ ‌of‌ ‌mutations‌ ‌in‌ ‌\npopulations‌ ‌\n ‌\nHow‌ ‌is‌ ‌polymorphism‌ ‌different‌ ‌from‌ ‌inheritance?‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Inheritance‌ ‌is‌ ‌essentially‌ ‌the‌ ‌passing-down‌ ‌of‌ ‌genes‌ ‌from‌ ‌parents‌ ‌to‌ ‌their‌ ‌offsprings.‌ ‌Polymorphism,‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌hand,‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌of‌ ‌\ndifferent‌ ‌forms‌ ‌or‌ ‌variants‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌gene.‌ ‌\n ‌\n815‌ ‌\n ‌\nGenetic‌ ‌polymorphism‌ ‌and‌ ‌selection‌ ‌\n●Natural‌ ‌selection‌ ‌is‌ ‌defined‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌process‌ ‌or‌ ‌a‌ ‌“force”‌ ‌that‌ ‌allows‌ ‌for‌ ‌organisms‌ ‌better‌ ‌adapted‌ ‌to‌ ‌their‌ ‌environment‌ ‌to‌ ‌better‌ ‌survive‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nproduce‌ ‌more‌ ‌offspring.‌ ‌The‌ ‌theory‌ ‌of‌ ‌natural‌ ‌selection‌ ‌was‌ ‌first‌ ‌founded‌ ‌by‌ ‌‌Charles‌ ‌Darwin.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌process‌ ‌of‌ ‌natural‌ ‌selection‌ ‌is‌ ‌important‌ ‌and‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌driving‌ ‌force‌ ‌for‌ ‌evolution.‌ ‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌organisms‌ ‌to‌ ‌evolve,‌ ‌there‌ ‌needs‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌differences‌ ‌in‌ ‌traits‌ ‌between‌ ‌organisms‌ ‌that‌ ‌provide‌ ‌certain‌ ‌advantages‌ ‌or‌ ‌disadvantages,‌ ‌and‌ ‌it‌ ‌\nis‌ ‌these‌ ‌traits‌ ‌that‌ ‌natural‌ ‌selection‌ ‌acts‌ ‌upon.‌ ‌\n●When‌ ‌it‌ ‌comes‌ ‌to‌ ‌natural‌ ‌selection,‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌three‌ ‌different‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌selection‌ ‌that‌ ‌can‌ ‌occur.‌ ‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌types‌ ‌include‌ ‌the‌ ‌following:‌ ‌\n●Stabilizing‌ ‌Selection‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌natural‌ ‌selection‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌when‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌selective‌ ‌pressures‌ ‌working‌ ‌against‌ ‌two‌ ‌extremes‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌trait‌ ‌and‌ ‌therefore‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nintermediate‌ ‌or‌ ‌“middle”‌ ‌trait‌ ‌is‌ ‌selected‌ ‌for.‌ ‌ ‌\n○If‌ ‌we‌ ‌look‌ ‌at‌ ‌a‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌of‌ ‌traits‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌population,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌noticeable‌ ‌that‌ ‌a‌ ‌standard‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌is‌ ‌followed:‌ ‌\n ‌\n○Example:‌ ‌‌For‌ ‌a‌ ‌plant,‌ ‌the‌ ‌plants‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌very‌ ‌tall‌ ‌are‌ ‌exposed‌ ‌to‌ ‌more‌ ‌wind‌ ‌and‌ ‌are‌ ‌at‌ ‌risk‌ ‌of‌ ‌being‌ ‌blown‌ ‌over.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌plants‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌very‌ ‌short‌ ‌fail‌ ‌to‌ ‌get‌ ‌enough‌ ‌sunlight‌ ‌to‌ ‌prosper.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Therefore,‌ ‌the‌ ‌plants‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌a‌ ‌middle‌ ‌height‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌two‌ ‌get‌ ‌both‌ ‌enough‌ ‌sunlight‌ ‌and‌ ‌protection‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌wind.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Directional‌ ‌Selection‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌natural‌ ‌selection‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌when‌ ‌selective‌ ‌pressures‌ ‌are‌ ‌working‌ ‌in‌ ‌favour‌ ‌of‌ ‌one‌ ‌extreme‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌trait.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Therefore‌ ‌when‌ ‌looking‌ ‌at‌ ‌a‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌of‌ ‌traits‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌population,‌ ‌a‌ ‌graph‌ ‌tends‌ ‌to‌ ‌lean‌ ‌more‌ ‌to‌ ‌one‌ ‌side:‌ ‌\n ‌\n○Example:‌ ‌‌Giraffes‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌longest‌ ‌necks‌ ‌are‌ ‌able‌ ‌to‌ ‌reach‌ ‌more‌ ‌leaves‌ ‌to‌ ‌each.‌ ‌Selective‌ ‌pressures‌ ‌will‌ ‌work‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌advantage‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌longer‌ ‌neck‌ ‌giraffes‌ ‌and‌ ‌therefore‌ ‌the‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌trait‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌population‌ ‌will‌ ‌shift‌ ‌towards‌ ‌the‌ ‌longer‌ ‌neck‌ ‌trait.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Disruptive‌ ‌Selection‌ ‌ ‌\n816‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌natural‌ ‌selection‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌when‌ ‌selective‌ ‌pressures‌ ‌are‌ ‌working‌ ‌in‌ ‌favour‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌two‌ ‌extremes‌ ‌and‌ ‌against‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nintermediate‌ ‌trait.‌ ‌This‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌selection‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌as‌ ‌common.‌ ‌ ‌\n○When‌ ‌looking‌ ‌at‌ ‌a‌ ‌trait‌ ‌distribution,‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌two‌ ‌higher‌ ‌peaks‌ ‌on‌ ‌both‌ ‌ends‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌minimum‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌middle‌ ‌as‌ ‌such:‌ ‌\n ‌\n○Example:‌‌ ‌An‌ ‌area‌ ‌that‌ ‌has‌ ‌black,‌ ‌white‌ ‌and‌ ‌grey‌ ‌bunnies‌ ‌contains‌ ‌both‌ ‌black‌ ‌and‌ ‌white‌ ‌rocks.‌ ‌Both‌ ‌the‌ ‌traits‌ ‌for‌ ‌white‌ ‌and‌ ‌black‌ ‌will‌ ‌\nbe‌ ‌favored‌ ‌by‌ ‌natural‌ ‌selection‌ ‌since‌ ‌they‌ ‌both‌ ‌prove‌ ‌useful‌ ‌for‌ ‌camouflage.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌intermediate‌ ‌trait‌ ‌of‌ ‌grey‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌prove‌ ‌as‌ ‌useful‌ ‌and‌ ‌therefore‌ ‌selective‌ ‌pressures‌ ‌act‌ ‌against‌ ‌the‌ ‌trait.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nGenetics‌ ‌Polymorphism‌ ‌&‌ ‌Selection‌ ‌\n●Most‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌inherited‌ ‌differences‌ ‌in‌ ‌human‌ ‌beings‌ ‌represent‌ ‌differences‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌structure‌ ‌of‌ ‌DNA‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌change‌ ‌in‌ ‌its‌ ‌basis,‌ ‌Has‌ ‌been‌ ‌found‌ ‌\nout‌ ‌that‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌differences‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌DNA‌ ‌Menon‌ ‌important‌ ‌for‌ ‌natural‌ ‌selection‌ ‌act,‌ ‌affect‌ ‌Darwinism‌ ‌fitness.‌ ‌\n817‌ ‌\n●However,‌ ‌too‌ ‌much‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌variation‌ ‌of‌ ‌polymorphism‌ ‌might‌ ‌increase‌ ‌the‌ ‌effect‌ ‌of‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌load‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌latter‌ ‌is‌ ‌responsible‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌\npopulation‌ ‌duty‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌excess‌ ‌presence‌ ‌of‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌polymorphism.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌average‌ ‌fitness‌ ‌rate‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌population‌ ‌might‌ ‌get‌ ‌affected.‌ ‌\n●Moreover‌ ‌certain‌ ‌character‌ ‌In‌ ‌the‌ ‌population‌ ‌are‌ ‌more‌ ‌or‌ ‌less‌ ‌permanently‌ ‌polymorphic.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Example:‌ ‌ ‌Sexual‌ ‌dimorphism‌ ‌\n○Stable‌ ‌polymorphic‌ ‌features‌ ‌are‌ ‌maintained‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌population‌ ‌by‌ ‌stabilizing‌ ‌natural‌ ‌selection.‌ ‌this‌ ‌removes‌ ‌those‌ ‌individual‌ ‌fromthe‌ ‌\npopulation‌ ‌that‌ ‌deviates‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌population‌ ‌mean,‌ ‌thus,‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌not‌ ‌perfectly‌ ‌male‌ ‌or‌ ‌female‌ ‌are‌ ‌removed‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌population‌ ‌so‌ ‌\nthat‌ ‌the‌ ‌population‌ ‌so‌ ‌individual‌ ‌with‌ ‌reference‌ ‌to‌ ‌sex-male‌ ‌or‌ ‌female.‌ ‌\n●Polymorphism‌ ‌maybe‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌transitory‌ ‌phase‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌sense‌ ‌that‌ ‌certain‌ ‌population‌ ‌with‌ ‌shifting‌ ‌environment‌ ‌shift‌ ‌their‌ ‌population‌ ‌for‌ ‌some‌ ‌\ncharacter‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌direction‌ ‌of‌ ‌environmental‌ ‌change‌ ‌at‌ ‌a‌ ‌time‌ ‌when‌ ‌one‌ ‌form‌ ‌has‌ ‌not‌ ‌replaced‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌completely,‌ ‌polymorphic‌ ‌population‌ ‌\nmay‌ ‌exist‌ ‌but‌ ‌gradually‌ ‌over‌ ‌time‌ ‌this‌‌ ‌Transient‌ ‌polymorphism‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌replaced‌ ‌by‌ ‌monomorphism‌ ‌by‌ ‌directional‌ ‌natural‌ ‌selection.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Transient‌ ‌polymorphism‌‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌case‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌advantageous‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌that‌ ‌gradually‌ ‌“fixes”‌ ‌itself‌ ‌by‌ ‌eliminating‌ ‌alternative‌ ‌alleles,‌ ‌\nwhich‌ ‌can‌ ‌lead‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌of‌ ‌1.‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌case,‌‌ ‌for‌ ‌example,‌ ‌‌of‌ ‌insecticide‌ ‌resistance‌ ‌genes‌ ‌in‌ ‌mosquitoes,‌ ‌antibiotic‌ ‌resistance‌ ‌in‌ ‌bacteria‌ ‌and‌ ‌antimalarial‌ ‌drug‌ ‌\nresistance‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌malaria‌ ‌parasite:‌ ‌these‌ ‌mutations‌ ‌would‌ ‌probably‌ ‌not‌ ‌have‌ ‌had‌ ‌an‌ ‌advantage‌ ‌under‌ ‌natural‌ ‌conditions,‌ ‌but‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nenvironmental‌ ‌context‌ ‌imposed‌ ‌by‌ ‌medicine,‌ ‌these‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌increase‌ ‌in‌ ‌frequency.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌the‌ ‌case‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌three‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌that‌ ‌regulate‌ ‌the‌ ‌expression‌ ‌of‌ ‌lactase,‌ ‌an‌ ‌enzyme‌ ‌that‌ ‌allows‌ ‌humans‌ ‌to‌ ‌digest‌ ‌milk‌ ‌sugar‌ ‌\n(lactose)‌ ‌not‌ ‌only‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌newborn‌ ‌state,‌ ‌as‌ ‌in‌ ‌other‌ ‌mammals,‌ ‌but‌ ‌also‌ ‌in‌ ‌adults.‌ ‌ ‌\n■These‌ ‌mutations‌ ‌have‌ ‌become‌ ‌beneficial‌ ‌in‌ ‌livestock‌ ‌populations,‌ ‌while‌ ‌our‌ ‌hunter-gatherer‌ ‌ancestors‌ ‌only‌ ‌had‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nopportunity‌ ‌to‌ ‌digest‌ ‌fruit‌ ‌sugar‌ ‌(sucrose)‌ ‌as‌ ‌adults.‌ ‌\n●Genetics‌ ‌is‌ ‌important‌ ‌to‌ ‌our‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌of‌ ‌selection‌ ‌for‌ ‌at‌ ‌least‌ ‌three‌ ‌reasons:‌ ‌ ‌\n○Although‌ ‌the‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌selection‌ ‌seems‌ ‌obvious,‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌not‌ ‌until‌ ‌selection‌ ‌was‌ ‌linked‌ ‌to‌ ‌Mendelian‌ ‌genetics‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌became‌ ‌a‌ ‌viable‌ ‌\nexplanation‌ ‌for‌ ‌evolution;‌ ‌\n○Non-Mendelian‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌and‌ ‌relatedness‌ ‌add‌ ‌more‌ ‌complex‌ ‌dimensions‌ ‌to‌ ‌selection‌ ‌and‌ ‌allow‌ ‌the‌ ‌spread‌ ‌of‌ ‌deleterious‌ ‌alleles;‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌apparent‌ ‌failure‌ ‌of‌ ‌selectionist‌ ‌models‌ ‌to‌ ‌explain‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌observations,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌levels‌ ‌of‌ ‌polymorphism,‌ ‌led‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌development‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌alternative‌ ‌models‌ ‌of‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌and‌ ‌sophisticated‌ ‌statistical‌ ‌methods‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌diagnosis‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌modes‌ ‌of‌ ‌evolution.‌ ‌\n ‌\nMendelian‌ ‌population‌ ‌\nDefinition:‌ ‌\n●An‌ ‌interbreeding‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌organisms‌ ‌that‌ ‌share‌ ‌a‌ ‌common‌ ‌gene‌ ‌pool.‌ ‌\n818‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌named‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌honor‌ ‌of‌ ‌Gregor‌ ‌Mendel,‌ ‌a‌ ‌Moravian‌ ‌Augustinian‌ ‌monk‌ ‌who‌ ‌founded‌ ‌the‌ ‌modern‌ ‌science‌ ‌of‌ ‌genetics.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Ideally‌ ‌the‌ ‌population‌ ‌isolate‌ ‌inhabits‌ ‌an‌ ‌island,‌ ‌a‌ ‌mountain‌ ‌valley,‌ ‌a‌ ‌peninsular‌ ‌region,‌ ‌a‌ ‌forested‌ ‌area,‌ ‌or‌ ‌even‌ ‌a‌ ‌large‌ ‌area‌ ‌covering‌ ‌\nseveral‌ ‌villages,‌ ‌where‌ ‌the‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌alliance‌ ‌is‌ ‌restricted‌ ‌within‌ ‌that‌ ‌endogamous‌ ‌group.‌ ‌\n●Dobzhonsky‌‌ ‌has‌ ‌defined‌ ‌the‌ ‌Mendelian‌ ‌population‌ ‌as‌ ‌\"a‌ ‌reproductive‌ ‌community‌ ‌of‌ ‌sexual‌ ‌and‌ ‌cross‌ ‌fertilizing‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌which‌ ‌share‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌\ncommon‌ ‌gene‌ ‌pool.\"‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌biological‌ ‌population‌ ‌has‌ ‌moving‌ ‌and‌ ‌permeable‌ ‌boundaries‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌intimately‌ ‌linked‌ ‌with‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌factors.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Genetic‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌within‌ ‌and‌ ‌between‌ ‌population‌ ‌like‌ ‌allele‌ ‌frequencies,‌ ‌consanguinity,‌ ‌mating‌ ‌patterns,‌ ‌gene‌ ‌flow‌ ‌Population‌ ‌Genetics,‌ ‌\nnatural‌ ‌selection,‌ ‌etc,‌ ‌define‌ ‌the‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌genetics‌ ‌of‌ ‌populations‌ ‌\n●If‌ ‌the‌ ‌Mendelian‌ ‌population‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌changed‌ ‌by‌ ‌natural‌ ‌selection,‌ ‌nor‌ ‌by‌ ‌mutation,‌ ‌nor‌ ‌by‌ ‌migration,‌ ‌and‌ ‌if‌ ‌the‌ ‌population‌ ‌size‌ ‌is‌ ‌large‌ ‌and‌ ‌if‌ ‌\nindividuals‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌mating‌ ‌assortatively‌ ‌(that‌ ‌is,‌ ‌random‌ ‌choice‌ ‌of‌ ‌partners),‌ ‌then‌ ‌the‌ ‌Mendelian‌ ‌population‌ ‌is‌ ‌said‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌in‌ ‌equilibrium.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌other‌ ‌words,‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌change‌ ‌if‌ ‌\n○No‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌\n○Random‌ ‌mating‌ ‌\n○No‌ ‌biased‌ ‌migration‌ ‌\n○No‌ ‌biased‌ ‌selected‌ ‌mortality‌ ‌(selection)‌ ‌\n○No‌ ‌biased‌ ‌random‌ ‌mortality‌ ‌(drift)‌ ‌\n ‌\nGene‌ ‌Frequency‌ ‌\n819‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Proportion‌ ‌of‌ ‌different‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌gene‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌random‌ ‌mating‌ ‌population‌ ‌is‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to‌ ‌as‌ ‌gene‌ ‌frequency.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Estimation‌ ‌of‌ ‌gene‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌population‌ ‌consists‌ ‌of‌ ‌three‌ ‌important‌ ‌steps:‌ ‌ ‌\n1.‌ ‌Sampling‌ ‌ ‌\n2.‌ ‌Classification‌ ‌ ‌\n3.‌ ‌Calculation‌ ‌of‌ ‌gene‌ ‌frequency.‌ ‌\n●Suppose‌ ‌a‌ ‌random‌ ‌sample‌ ‌of‌ ‌100‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌was‌ ‌drawn‌ ‌from‌ ‌a‌ ‌random‌ ‌mating‌ ‌population‌ ‌of‌ ‌‌Mirabilis‌ ‌Jalapa.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Out‌ ‌of‌ ‌100‌ ‌plants,‌ ‌30‌ ‌were‌ ‌red,‌ ‌40‌ ‌were‌ ‌pink,‌ ‌30‌ ‌were‌ ‌white‌ ‌flowers.‌ ‌So,‌ ‌the‌ ‌allele‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌is‌ ‌worked‌ ‌out‌ ‌as‌ ‌follows:‌ ‌\n○Red‌ ‌colours‌ ‌are‌ ‌homozygous‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌allele‌ ‌(RR).‌ ‌\n○White‌ ‌colours‌ ‌are‌ ‌homozygous‌ ‌for‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌allele‌ ‌(rr).‌ ‌\n○Each‌ ‌heterozygous‌ ‌individual‌ ‌pink‌ ‌colour‌ ‌will‌ ‌have‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌(R)‌ ‌and‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌(r)‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌in‌ ‌equal‌ ‌number.‌ ‌\n○Number‌ ‌of‌ ‌R‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌sample‌ ‌(30‌ ‌individual)‌ ‌=‌ ‌2‌ ‌(No.of‌ ‌red‌ ‌individuals)‌ ‌+‌ ‌No.of‌ ‌pink‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌=(2x‌ ‌30)+‌ ‌40‌ ‌=‌ ‌100‌ ‌\n○Proportion‌ ‌of‌ ‌R‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌sample=‌ ‌No.of‌ ‌RR‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌2(‌ ‌total‌ ‌plants‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌sample)‌ ‌=‌ ‌100/(2x‌ ‌100)‌ ‌=0.50‌ ‌ ‌\n○Similarly,‌ ‌no.of‌ ‌r‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌=‌ ‌(2x30)+‌ ‌40=‌ ‌100‌ ‌Proportion‌ ‌of‌ ‌r‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌=100/(2x100)‌ ‌=0.50‌ ‌ ‌\n○Therefore,‌ ‌the‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌of‌ ‌RR‌ ‌and‌ ‌rr‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌is‌ ‌0.50‌ ‌each.‌ ‌\n●Genotype‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌ ‌\n○Genotypic‌ ‌frequencies‌ ‌at‌ ‌a‌ ‌specific‌ ‌locus‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌calculated‌ ‌by‌ ‌counting‌ ‌the‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌genotype‌ ‌and‌ ‌\ndivide‌ ‌this‌ ‌number‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌total‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌populations.‌ ‌ ‌\n●So,‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌above‌ ‌sample‌ ‌the‌ ‌genotypic‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌of‌ ‌each‌ ‌individual‌ ‌is‌ ‌calculated‌ ‌as‌ ‌follows:‌ ‌\n○Frequency‌ ‌of‌ ‌Red‌ ‌(RR)‌ ‌individuals‌‌ ‌=‌ ‌30/100‌ ‌=‌ ‌0.30‌ ‌\n○Frequency‌ ‌of‌ ‌Pink‌ ‌(Rr)‌ ‌individuals‌‌ ‌=‌ ‌40/100‌ ‌=‌ ‌0.40‌ ‌\n○Frequency‌ ‌of‌ ‌White‌ ‌(rr)‌ ‌individuals‌‌ ‌=‌ ‌30/100‌ ‌=‌ ‌0.30‌ ‌\n ‌\nPopulation‌ ‌Genetics‌ ‌\n●Study‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌of‌ ‌genes‌ ‌and‌ ‌genotypes‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌mendelian‌ ‌population‌ ‌is‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌Population‌ ‌Genetics.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌recognized‌ ‌that‌ ‌although‌ ‌the‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌of‌ ‌individual‌ ‌genes‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌governed‌ ‌by‌ ‌Mendelian‌ ‌principles,‌ ‌the‌ ‌frequencies‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nindividuals‌ ‌carrying‌ ‌these‌ ‌genes‌ ‌may‌ ‌depend‌ ‌on‌ ‌several‌ ‌factors,‌ ‌which‌ ‌include‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌gene,‌ ‌size‌ ‌of‌ ‌population‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌\nfactors.‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌population‌ ‌consists‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌community‌ ‌of‌ ‌sexually‌ ‌or‌ ‌potential‌ ‌inbreeding‌ ‌organisms‌ ‌inhabiting‌ ‌a‌ ‌geographical‌ ‌area.‌ ‌\n●Sewall‌ ‌Wright‌ ‌called‌ ‌these‌ ‌populations‌ ‌‘Mendelian‌ ‌populations’‌ ‌.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nApplication‌ ‌\nMendelian‌ ‌and‌ ‌Population‌ ‌Genetics‌ ‌\nQuestion‌ ‌\n820‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌a‌ ‌certain‌ ‌species‌ ‌of‌ ‌bird,‌ ‌yellow‌ ‌beaks‌ ‌are‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌to‌ ‌orange‌ ‌beaks,‌ ‌and‌ ‌blue‌ ‌feathers‌ ‌are‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌to‌ ‌black‌ ‌feathers.‌ ‌Two‌ ‌\nheterozygous‌ ‌birds‌ ‌are‌ ‌crossed.‌ ‌What‌ ‌fraction‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌offspring‌ ‌would‌ ‌be‌ ‌expected‌ ‌to‌ ‌have‌ ‌yellow‌ ‌beaks‌ ‌and‌ ‌blue‌ ‌feathers?‌ ‌\nSolution‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌question‌ ‌requires‌ ‌us‌ ‌to‌ ‌do‌ ‌a‌ ‌dihybrid‌ ‌cross.‌ ‌We‌ ‌can‌ ‌represent‌ ‌the‌ ‌gene‌ ‌for‌ ‌beak‌ ‌color‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌symbol‌ ‌\"A\"‌ ‌for‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌yellow‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌\"a\"‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌orange.‌ ‌Likewise,‌ ‌for‌ ‌feather‌ ‌color,‌ ‌we‌ ‌can‌ ‌use‌ ‌\"B\"‌ ‌for‌ ‌blue‌ ‌feathers‌ ‌and‌ ‌\"b\"‌ ‌for‌ ‌black.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌problem‌ ‌states‌ ‌that‌ ‌both‌ ‌birds‌ ‌are‌ ‌heterozygous‌ ‌for‌ ‌each‌ ‌trait,‌ ‌implying‌ ‌that‌ ‌our‌ ‌cross‌ ‌is‌ ‌between‌ ‌two‌ ‌birds‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌genotype‌ ‌\nAaBb.‌ ‌\n○Now‌ ‌we‌ ‌look‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌gametes‌ ‌that‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌produced‌ ‌by‌ ‌these‌ ‌parents:‌ ‌AB,‌ ‌Ab,‌ ‌aB,‌ ‌and‌ ‌ab.‌ ‌These‌ ‌gametes‌ ‌can‌ ‌then‌ ‌be‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌make‌ ‌\na‌ ‌punnet‌ ‌square.‌ ‌\n■Offspring:‌ ‌‌1‌ ‌AABB,‌ ‌3‌ ‌Aabb,‌ ‌8‌ ‌AaBa,‌ ‌3‌ ‌aaBb,‌ ‌1‌ ‌aabb‌ ‌\n●There‌ ‌are‌ ‌16‌ ‌total‌ ‌offspring.‌ ‌12‌ ‌of‌ ‌them‌ ‌carry‌ ‌the‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌A‌ ‌allele,‌ ‌giving‌ ‌them‌ ‌the‌ ‌yellow‌ ‌beak‌ ‌phenotype.‌ ‌\n■Yellow‌ ‌beaks:‌ ‌‌1‌ ‌AABB,‌ ‌3Aabb,‌ ‌8‌ ‌AaBb‌ ‌\n●Finally,‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌12,‌ ‌9‌ ‌carry‌ ‌the‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌B‌ ‌allele‌ ‌for‌ ‌blue‌ ‌feathers.‌ ‌\n■Yellow‌ ‌beaks‌ ‌and‌ ‌blue‌ ‌feathers:‌‌ ‌1‌ ‌AABB,‌ ‌8‌ ‌AaBb‌ ‌\n■This‌ ‌gives‌ ‌a‌ ‌total‌ ‌of‌ ‌9‌ ‌out‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌16‌ ‌offspring‌ ‌that‌ ‌will‌ ‌express‌ ‌both‌ ‌the‌ ‌yellow‌ ‌beak‌ ‌and‌ ‌blue‌ ‌feather‌ ‌phenotypes.‌ ‌\n○You‌ ‌should‌ ‌be‌ ‌familiar‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌9:3:3:1‌ ‌phenotypic‌ ‌ratio‌ ‌resulting‌ ‌from‌ ‌dihybrid‌ ‌crosses.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nHardy-‌ ‌Weinberg‌ ‌Law‌ ‌\n ‌\n●In‌ ‌1908,‌ ‌Hardy,‌ ‌an‌ ‌English‌ ‌Mathematician‌ ‌and‌ ‌W.‌ ‌Weinberg,‌ ‌a‌ ‌German‌ ‌Physician‌ ‌independently‌ ‌discovered‌ ‌a‌ ‌principle‌ ‌concerned‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nfrequency‌ ‌of‌ ‌genes(alleles)‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌population.‌ ‌\n●W.E.‌ ‌Castle‌ ‌‌(a‌ ‌geneticist)‌ ‌was‌ ‌first‌ ‌to‌ ‌recognize‌ ‌the‌ ‌relationship‌ ‌between‌ ‌gene‌ ‌and‌ ‌genotypic‌ ‌frequencies.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌law‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌Castle-Hardy-Weinberg‌ ‌law.‌ ‌\n ‌\nThe‌ ‌law‌ ‌states‌ ‌that:‌ ‌ ‌\n●“In‌ ‌a‌ ‌infinitely,‌ ‌random‌ ‌mating‌ ‌population,‌ ‌the‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌of‌ ‌genes‌ ‌and‌ ‌genotypes‌ ‌remains‌ ‌constant‌ ‌generation‌ ‌after‌ ‌generation,This‌ ‌\npresumes‌ ‌the‌ ‌following‌ ‌conditions:‌ ‌\n●the‌ ‌population‌ ‌is‌ ‌large‌ ‌\n●there‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌immigration‌ ‌or‌ ‌emigration‌ ‌of‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌population‌ ‌\n●there‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌\n●there‌ ‌is‌ ‌random‌ ‌mating‌ ‌\n●there‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌natural‌ ‌selection‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Simply,‌ ‌The‌ ‌Hardy-Weinberg‌ ‌equilibrium‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌principle‌ ‌stating‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌variation‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌population‌ ‌will‌ ‌remain‌ ‌constant‌ ‌from‌ ‌one‌ ‌\ngeneration‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌next‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌absence‌ ‌of‌ ‌disturbing‌ ‌factors.‌ ‌ ‌\n821‌ ‌\n●When‌ ‌mating‌ ‌is‌ ‌random‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌large‌ ‌population‌ ‌with‌ ‌no‌ ‌disruptive‌ ‌circumstances,‌ ‌the‌ ‌law‌ ‌predicts‌ ‌that‌ ‌both‌ ‌genotype‌ ‌and‌ ‌allele‌ ‌frequencies‌ ‌\nwill‌ ‌remain‌ ‌constant‌ ‌because‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌in‌ ‌equilibrium.‌ ‌\n ‌\nTo‌ ‌explore‌ ‌the‌ ‌Hardy-Weinberg‌ ‌equation,‌ ‌we‌ ‌can‌ ‌examine‌ ‌a‌ ‌simple‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌locus‌ ‌at‌ ‌which‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌two‌ ‌alleles,‌ ‌A‌ ‌and‌ ‌a.‌ ‌ ‌\nThe‌ ‌Hardy-Weinberg‌ ‌equation‌ ‌is‌ ‌expressed‌ ‌as:‌ ‌p2‌ ‌+‌ ‌2pq‌ ‌+‌ ‌q2‌ ‌=‌ ‌1‌ ‌\n ‌\nwhere‌ ‌p‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\"A\"‌ ‌allele‌ ‌and‌ ‌q‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\"a\"‌ ‌allele‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌population.‌ ‌\n ‌\nIn‌ ‌the‌ ‌equation,‌ ‌p2‌ ‌represents‌ ‌the‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌homozygous‌ ‌genotype‌ ‌AA,‌ ‌ ‌\nq2‌ ‌represents‌ ‌the‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌homozygous‌ ‌genotype‌ ‌aa,‌ ‌and‌ ‌ ‌\n2pq‌ ‌represents‌ ‌the‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌heterozygous‌ ‌genotype‌ ‌Aa.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nIn‌ ‌addition,‌ ‌the‌ ‌sum‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌allele‌ ‌frequencies‌ ‌for‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌locus‌ ‌must‌ ‌be‌ ‌1,‌ ‌so‌ ‌p‌ ‌+‌ ‌q‌ ‌=‌ ‌1.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nIf‌ ‌the‌ ‌p‌ ‌and‌ ‌q‌ ‌allele‌ ‌frequencies‌ ‌are‌ ‌known,‌ ‌then‌ ‌the‌ ‌frequencies‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌three‌ ‌genotypes‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌calculated‌ ‌using‌ ‌the‌ ‌Hardy-Weinberg‌ ‌equation.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nIn‌ ‌population‌ ‌genetics‌ ‌studies,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Hardy-Weinberg‌ ‌equation‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌measure‌ ‌whether‌ ‌the‌ ‌observed‌ ‌genotype‌ ‌frequencies‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌population‌ ‌\ndiffer‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌frequencies‌ ‌predicted‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌equation.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n822‌ ‌\nProblem‌ ‌Solving‌ ‌\nQuestion:‌ ‌\nIn‌ ‌a‌ ‌population‌ ‌of‌ ‌130,000‌ ‌mice,‌ ‌green‌ ‌fur‌ ‌is‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌over‌ ‌orange.‌ ‌If‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌300‌ ‌orange‌ ‌mice‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌population‌ ‌of‌ ‌130,000,‌ ‌find‌ ‌the‌ ‌following‌ ‌\n(assume‌ ‌population‌ ‌is‌ ‌in‌ ‌Hardy-Weinberg‌ ‌equilibrium):‌ ‌\n1.‌ ‌Frequency‌ ‌of‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌(green)‌ ‌allele‌ ‌\n2.‌ ‌Frequency‌ ‌of‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌(orange)‌ ‌allele‌ ‌\n3.‌ ‌Frequency‌ ‌of‌ ‌homozygous‌ ‌dominant,‌ ‌heterozygous‌ ‌and‌ ‌homozygous‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌genotypes‌ ‌\n ‌\nSolution:‌ ‌\nStep‌ ‌1:‌ ‌‌Assign‌ ‌the‌ ‌Alleles‌ ‌\n●By‌ ‌convention,‌ ‌we‌ ‌use‌ ‌the‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌phenotype‌ ‌to‌ ‌name‌ ‌the‌ ‌alleles.‌ ‌In‌ ‌this‌ ‌case,‌ ‌green‌ ‌is‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌over‌ ‌orange,‌ ‌so‌ ‌we'll‌ ‌use‌ ‌'G'‌ ‌for‌ ‌green‌ ‌\nfur‌ ‌and‌ ‌'g'‌ ‌for‌ ‌orange‌ ‌fur.‌ ‌\n●Assign‌ ‌'p'‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌the‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌of‌ ‌G,‌ ‌the‌ ‌green‌ ‌fur‌ ‌allele‌ ‌\n●Assign‌ ‌'q'‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌the‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌of‌ ‌g,‌ ‌the‌ ‌orange‌ ‌fur‌ ‌allele‌ ‌\n ‌\nStep‌ ‌2:‌‌ ‌Calculate‌ ‌q‌ ‌ ‌\n823‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌homozygous‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌is‌ ‌q2‌ ‌,‌ ‌NOT‌ ‌q.‌ ‌To‌ ‌find‌ ‌q,‌ ‌take‌ ‌the‌ ‌square‌ ‌root‌ ‌of‌ ‌q2‌ ‌.‌ ‌\n●Frequency‌ ‌of‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌=‌ ‌Individuals/Total‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌Population‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nStep‌ ‌3:‌‌ ‌Calculate‌ ‌p‌ ‌ ‌\n●Once‌ ‌you‌ ‌have‌ ‌q,‌ ‌finding‌ ‌p‌ ‌is‌ ‌easy!‌ ‌The‌ ‌sum‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌frequencies‌ ‌of‌ ‌both‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌must‌ ‌equal‌ ‌1.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nStep‌ ‌4:‌ ‌‌Use‌ ‌p‌ ‌and‌ ‌q‌ ‌to‌ ‌calculate‌ ‌the‌ ‌remaining‌ ‌genotypes‌ ‌ ‌\n●Calculate‌ ‌q2‌ ‌even‌ ‌though‌ ‌that's‌ ‌what‌ ‌you‌ ‌started‌ ‌with.‌ ‌Realize‌ ‌that‌ ‌rounding‌ ‌will‌ ‌give‌ ‌you‌ ‌slightly‌ ‌different‌ ‌values‌ ‌and‌ ‌all‌ ‌3‌ ‌genotype‌ ‌\nfrequencies‌ ‌may‌ ‌not‌ ‌EXACTLY‌ ‌equal‌ ‌1‌ ‌because‌ ‌of‌ ‌this.‌ ‌Its‌ ‌okay.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nAnswer‌ ‌the‌ ‌questions:‌ ‌ ‌\n1.‌ ‌Frequency‌ ‌of‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌(green)‌ ‌allele‌ ‌=‌ ‌0.96‌ ‌ ‌\n824‌ ‌\n2.‌ ‌Frequency‌ ‌of‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌(orange)‌ ‌allele‌ ‌=‌ ‌0.04‌ ‌ ‌\n3.‌ ‌Frequency‌ ‌of‌ ‌each‌ ‌genotype:‌ ‌ ‌\n●Homozygous‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌=‌ ‌0.92‌ ‌\n●Heterozygous‌ ‌=‌ ‌0.08‌ ‌\n●Homozygous‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌=‌ ‌0.002‌ ‌\n ‌\nIs‌ ‌it‌ ‌applicable‌ ‌in‌ ‌reality?‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Hardy-Weinberg‌ ‌equilibrium‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌disturbed‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌forces,‌ ‌including‌ ‌mutations,‌ ‌natural‌ ‌selection,‌ ‌nonrandom‌ ‌mating,‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌\ndrift,‌ ‌and‌ ‌gene‌ ‌flow.‌ ‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌instance,‌ ‌mutations‌ ‌disrupt‌ ‌the‌ ‌equilibrium‌ ‌of‌ ‌allele‌ ‌frequencies‌ ‌by‌ ‌introducing‌ ‌new‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌into‌ ‌a‌ ‌population.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Similarly,‌ ‌natural‌ ‌selection‌ ‌and‌ ‌nonrandom‌ ‌mating‌ ‌disrupt‌ ‌the‌ ‌Hardy-Weinberg‌ ‌equilibrium‌ ‌because‌ ‌they‌ ‌result‌ ‌in‌ ‌changes‌ ‌in‌ ‌gene‌ ‌\nfrequencies.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌because‌ ‌certain‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌help‌ ‌or‌ ‌harm‌ ‌the‌ ‌reproductive‌ ‌success‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌organisms‌ ‌that‌ ‌carry‌ ‌them.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Another‌ ‌factor‌ ‌that‌ ‌can‌ ‌upset‌ ‌this‌ ‌equilibrium‌ ‌is‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌drift,‌ ‌which‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌when‌ ‌allele‌ ‌frequencies‌ ‌grow‌ ‌higher‌ ‌or‌ ‌lower‌ ‌by‌ ‌chance‌ ‌and‌ ‌\ntypically‌ ‌takes‌ ‌place‌ ‌in‌ ‌small‌ ‌populations.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Gene‌ ‌flow,‌ ‌which‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌when‌ ‌breeding‌ ‌between‌ ‌two‌ ‌populations‌ ‌transfers‌ ‌new‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌into‌ ‌a‌ ‌population,‌ ‌can‌ ‌also‌ ‌alter‌ ‌the‌ ‌Hardy-Weinberg‌ ‌\nequilibrium.‌ ‌\n●Because‌ ‌all‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌disruptive‌ ‌forces‌ ‌commonly‌ ‌occur‌ ‌in‌ ‌nature,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Hardy-Weinberg‌ ‌equilibrium‌ ‌rarely‌ ‌applies‌ ‌in‌ ‌reality.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Therefore,‌ ‌the‌ ‌Hardy-Weinberg‌ ‌equilibrium‌ ‌describes‌ ‌an‌ ‌idealized‌ ‌state,‌ ‌and‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌variations‌ ‌in‌ ‌nature‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌measured‌ ‌as‌ ‌changes‌ ‌from‌ ‌\nthis‌ ‌equilibrium‌ ‌state.‌ ‌\n ‌\nFactors‌ ‌Responsible‌ ‌for‌ ‌Genetic‌ ‌Variation‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌HW‌ ‌principle‌ ‌assumes‌ ‌an‌ ‌ideal‌ ‌equilibrium‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌genotypic‌ ‌and‌ ‌allelic‌ ‌frequencies‌ ‌without‌ ‌mutations,‌ ‌or‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌drift‌ ‌or‌ ‌natural‌ ‌\nselection,‌ ‌or‌ ‌random‌ ‌mating‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌large,‌ ‌freely‌ ‌interbreeding‌ ‌ideal‌ ‌population.‌ ‌ ‌\n●However,‌ ‌over‌ ‌time,‌ ‌to‌ ‌enable‌ ‌population‌ ‌survival,‌ ‌the‌ ‌gene‌ ‌pool‌ ‌can‌ ‌change.‌ ‌This‌ ‌change‌ ‌depends‌ ‌upon‌ ‌several‌ ‌factors,‌ ‌which‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌\nclassified‌ ‌as‌ ‌follows:‌ ‌\n ‌\n1.Genetic‌ ‌factors,‌ ‌e.g.,‌ ‌random‌ ‌mating,‌ ‌mutation,‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌drift,‌ ‌natural‌ ‌selection‌ ‌\n2.Environmental‌ ‌factors,‌ ‌e.g.,‌ ‌diversity‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌environment‌ ‌\n3.Societal‌ ‌factors,‌ ‌e.g.,‌ ‌population‌ ‌size,‌ ‌migration‌ ‌of‌ ‌populations‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n825‌ ‌\n9.3‌ ‌Causes‌ ‌and‌ ‌changes‌ ‌which‌ ‌bring‌ ‌down‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌–‌ ‌mutation,‌ ‌isolation,‌ ‌migration,‌ ‌Selection,‌ ‌inbreeding‌ ‌&‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌drift‌ ‌Part-II‌ ‌\n ‌\nRecap:‌ ‌\nSignificance‌ ‌of‌ ‌Hardy-Weinberg‌
