‌Law:‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌law‌ ‌is‌ ‌important‌ ‌primarily‌ ‌because‌ ‌it‌ ‌describes‌ ‌the‌ ‌situation‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌evolution,‌ ‌and‌ ‌thus‌ ‌it‌ ‌provides‌ ‌a‌ ‌theoretical‌ ‌baseline‌ ‌for‌ ‌\nmeasuring‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌change.‌ ‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌population‌ ‌in‌ ‌Hardy-Weinberg‌ ‌equilibrium‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌show‌ ‌evolution.‌ ‌In‌ ‌other‌ ‌words,‌ ‌for‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌to‌ ‌occur‌ ‌the‌ ‌population‌ ‌should‌ ‌not‌ ‌\nfollow‌ ‌Hardy-Weinberg‌ ‌equilibrium‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌equilibrium‌ ‌tendency‌ ‌serves‌ ‌to‌ ‌conserve‌ ‌gains‌ ‌which‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌made‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌past‌ ‌and‌ ‌also‌ ‌to‌ ‌avoid‌ ‌too‌ ‌rapid‌ ‌changes;‌ ‌in‌ ‌other‌ ‌words,‌ ‌\ngiving‌ ‌a‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌stability‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌population.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌Hardy-Weinberg‌ ‌equation‌ ‌describes‌ ‌conditions‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌natural‌ ‌population.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌function‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Hardy-Weinberg‌ ‌principle,‌ ‌and‌ ‌its‌ ‌equation,‌ ‌is‌ ‌as‌ ‌an‌ ‌experimental‌ ‌control,‌ ‌a‌ ‌prediction‌ ‌of‌ ‌what‌ ‌the‌ ‌allelic‌ ‌and‌ ‌genotypic‌ ‌\nfrequencies‌ ‌should‌ ‌be‌ ‌if‌ ‌nothing‌ ‌acts‌ ‌to‌ ‌alter‌ ‌the‌ ‌gene‌ ‌pool.‌ ‌Thus,‌ ‌if‌ ‌q‌ ‌is‌ ‌known‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌0.40‌ ‌then‌ ‌q2‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌next‌ ‌generation‌ ‌should‌ ‌be‌ ‌0.16.‌ ‌\n○If‌ ‌instead‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌0.02,‌ ‌then‌ ‌we‌ ‌know‌ ‌that‌ ‌a‌ ‌change‌ ‌has‌ ‌occurred‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌gene‌ ‌pool,‌ ‌the‌ ‌magnitude‌ ‌of‌ ‌that‌ ‌change,‌ ‌and‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌caused‌ ‌\nby:‌ ‌mutations,‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌drift,‌ ‌gene‌ ‌flow,‌ ‌assortative‌ ‌mating,‌ ‌or‌ ‌natural‌ ‌selection.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Then‌ ‌design‌ ‌experiments‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌done‌ ‌to‌ ‌test‌ ‌which‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌five‌ ‌agents‌ ‌of‌ ‌change‌ ‌contributed‌ ‌most‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌change‌ ‌in‌ ‌allelic‌ ‌and‌ ‌genotypic‌ ‌\nfrequencies.‌ ‌\n ‌\nIntroduction:‌ ‌\n ‌\nHow‌ ‌Population‌ ‌change?‌ ‌\n ‌\n1.Populations‌ ‌change‌ ‌over‌ ‌time.‌ ‌The‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌population‌ ‌may‌ ‌in­crease‌ ‌or‌ ‌decrease‌ ‌depending‌ ‌on‌ ‌food‌ ‌resources,‌ ‌climate,‌ ‌\nweather‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌availability‌ ‌of‌ ‌breeding‌ ‌areas,‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌ ‌\n2.At‌ ‌the‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌level,‌ ‌a‌ ‌population‌ ‌may‌ ‌change‌ ‌because‌ ‌of:‌ ‌\n○Mutation‌ ‌\n○Migration‌ ‌\n○Selec­tion‌ ‌\n826‌ ‌\n○Random‌ ‌Genetic‌ ‌drift‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n■These‌ ‌natural‌ ‌processes‌ ‌alter‌ ‌allele‌ ‌frequencies,‌ ‌thereby‌ ‌changing‌ ‌the‌ ‌fundamental‌ ‌makeup‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌population.‌ ‌\n■Mutations‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌produce‌ ‌new‌ ‌alleles,‌ ‌though‌ ‌the‌ ‌rate‌ ‌of‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌is‌ ‌too‌ ‌low‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌noticeable.‌ ‌In‌ ‌case‌ ‌of‌ ‌deleterious‌ ‌mutation,‌ ‌\nselection‌ ‌counteracts‌ ‌the‌ ‌effect.‌ ‌\n■Migration‌ ‌ ‌\n●Changes‌ ‌the‌ ‌frequencies‌ ‌because‌ ‌the‌ ‌immigrants‌ ‌from‌ ‌a‌ ‌population‌ ‌have‌ ‌different‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌makeup.‌ ‌ ‌\n●So,‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌population‌ ‌the‌ ‌gene‌ ‌fre­quency‌ ‌changes‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌genotype‌ ‌changes‌ ‌because‌ ‌of‌ ‌differential‌ ‌emigration‌ ‌\nfrom‌ ‌other‌ ‌locality.‌ ‌\n■Selection‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌reduces‌ ‌the‌ ‌fertility‌ ‌or‌ ‌survival‌ ‌of‌ ‌certain‌ ‌genotypes.‌ ‌In‌ ‌many‌ ‌popu­lations‌ ‌survival‌ ‌and‌ ‌reproductive‌ ‌ability‌ ‌are‌ ‌\nvariable‌ ‌traits.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Some‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌may‌ ‌die‌ ‌before‌ ‌they‌ ‌reproduce,‌ ‌whereas‌ ‌others‌ ‌may‌ ‌have‌ ‌many‌ ‌progeny.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌differential‌ ‌contribution‌ ‌of‌ ‌progeny‌ ‌implies‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌superior‌ ‌fitness‌ ‌will‌ ‌increase‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nfrequency‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌population.‌ ‌\n■Random‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌drift‌ ‌‌(chance‌ ‌difference)‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌causes‌ ‌small‌ ‌deviations‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌predicted‌ ‌frequencies,‌ ‌especially‌ ‌in‌ ‌small‌ ‌samples.‌ ‌These‌ ‌deviations‌ ‌however‌ ‌are‌ ‌\nexpected‌ ‌and‌ ‌allowed‌ ‌for‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌basis‌ ‌of‌ ‌statistical‌ ‌tests.‌ ‌\n●Assortative‌ ‌mating‌ ‌of‌ ‌either‌ ‌similar‌ ‌or‌ ‌dissimilar‌ ‌genotypes‌ ‌results‌ ‌in‌ ‌an‌ ‌excess‌ ‌of‌ ‌homozygotes‌ ‌and‌ ‌heterozygotes‌ ‌\nrespectively‌ ‌which‌ ‌changes‌ ‌the‌ ‌gene‌ ‌frequency.‌ ‌\n827‌ ‌\n●Existence‌ ‌of‌ ‌subpopulations‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌locally‌ ‌mating‌ ‌groups‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌large‌ ‌popu­lation‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌some‌ ‌ethnic‌ ‌causes‌ ‌\nor‌ ‌class‌ ‌grouping‌ ‌as‌ ‌in‌ ‌human,‌ ‌or‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌low‌ ‌mobility‌ ‌of‌ ‌some‌ ‌organisms‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌large‌ ‌area.‌ ‌These‌ ‌phenomena‌ ‌increase‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌of‌ ‌homozygotes‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌result‌ ‌of‌ ‌inbreeding.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nCauses‌ ‌and‌ ‌changes‌ ‌which‌ ‌bring‌ ‌down‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌–‌ ‌mutation,‌ ‌isolation,‌ ‌migration,‌ ‌Selection,‌ ‌inbreeding‌ ‌&‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌drift‌ ‌\n ‌\nLet's‌ ‌Consider‌ ‌each‌ ‌in‌ ‌detail:‌ ‌\n ‌\nMutation‌ ‌\n○Features‌ ‌\n■These‌ ‌are‌ ‌sudden,‌ ‌large‌ ‌and‌ ‌inheritable‌ ‌changes‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌material.‌ ‌\n■Mutations‌ ‌are‌ ‌random‌ ‌(indiscriminate)‌ ‌and‌ ‌occur‌ ‌in‌ ‌all‌ ‌directions.‌ ‌\n■Most‌ ‌mutations‌ ‌are‌ ‌harmful‌ ‌or‌ ‌neutral.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌estimated‌ ‌that‌ ‌‌only‌ ‌one‌ ‌out‌ ‌of‌ ‌1,000‌ ‌mutations‌ ‌is‌ ‌useful.‌ ‌\n■Rate‌ ‌of‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌is‌ ‌very‌ ‌low,‌ ‌i.e.‌ ‌one‌ ‌per‌ ‌million‌ ‌or‌ ‌one‌ ‌per‌ ‌several‌ ‌million‌ ‌genie‌ ‌loci.‌ ‌ ‌\n●But‌ ‌the‌ ‌rate‌ ‌of‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌is‌ ‌sufficient‌ ‌to‌ ‌produce‌ ‌considerable‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌variability.‌ ‌\n■Certain‌ ‌mutations‌ ‌are‌ ‌preadaptive‌ ‌and‌ ‌appear‌ ‌even‌ ‌without‌ ‌exposure‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌specific‌ ‌environment.‌ ‌ ‌\n■These‌ ‌express‌ ‌and‌ ‌become‌ ‌advantageous‌ ‌only‌ ‌when‌ ‌after‌ ‌exposure‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌new‌ ‌environment‌ ‌which‌ ‌only‌ ‌selects‌ ‌the‌ ‌preadaptive‌ ‌\nmutations‌ ‌that‌ ‌occurred‌ ‌earlier.‌ ‌\n828‌ ‌\n ‌\nPoint‌ ‌Mutations‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌point‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌change‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌single‌ ‌nucleotide‌ ‌in‌ ‌DNA.‌ ‌This‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌is‌ ‌usually‌ ‌less‌ ‌serious‌ ‌than‌ ‌a‌ ‌chromosomal‌ ‌alteration.‌ ‌ ‌\n●An‌ ‌example‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌point‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌that‌ ‌changes‌ ‌the‌ ‌codon‌ ‌UUU‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌codon‌ ‌UCU.‌ ‌Point‌ ‌mutations‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌silent,‌ ‌missense,‌ ‌or‌ ‌\nnonsense‌ ‌mutations‌ ‌\n ‌\n○What‌ ‌Are‌ ‌the‌ ‌Types‌ ‌of‌ ‌Mutation?‌ ‌\n■A‌ ‌silent‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌happens‌ ‌when‌ ‌the‌ ‌change‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌DNA‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌cause‌ ‌any‌ ‌change‌ ‌in‌ ‌expression.‌ ‌\n■For‌ ‌example‌,‌ ‌if‌ ‌the‌ ‌DNA‌ ‌sequences‌ ‌AAT,‌ ‌AAA,‌ ‌and‌ ‌AAG‌ ‌all‌ ‌result‌ ‌in‌ ‌brown‌ ‌fur,‌ ‌then‌ ‌a‌ ‌DNA‌ ‌sequence‌ ‌mutating‌ ‌from‌ ‌AAT‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nAAG‌ ‌will‌ ‌not‌ ‌cause‌ ‌any‌ ‌changes.‌ ‌\n■A‌ ‌missense‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌happens‌ ‌when‌ ‌the‌ ‌change‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌DNA‌ ‌does‌ ‌cause‌ ‌a‌ ‌change‌ ‌in‌ ‌expression.‌ ‌\n■For‌ ‌example‌,‌ ‌if‌ ‌the‌ ‌DNA‌ ‌sequences‌ ‌CCC‌ ‌and‌ ‌CCG‌ ‌create‌ ‌brown‌ ‌fur‌ ‌while‌ ‌CCA‌ ‌and‌ ‌CCT‌ ‌create‌ ‌red‌ ‌fur,‌ ‌then‌ ‌a‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌\nfrom‌ ‌CCC‌ ‌to‌ ‌CCA‌ ‌will‌ ‌cause‌ ‌red‌ ‌fur‌ ‌to‌ ‌grow‌ ‌instead‌ ‌of‌ ‌brown.‌ ‌\n■A‌ ‌nonsense‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌happens‌ ‌when‌ ‌a‌ ‌DNA‌ ‌sequence‌ ‌stops‌ ‌making‌ ‌a‌ ‌complete‌ ‌protein‌ ‌product‌ ‌because‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌mutation.‌ ‌\n829‌ ‌\n■When‌ ‌a‌ ‌ribosome‌ ‌translates‌ ‌RNA‌ ‌into‌ ‌a‌ ‌protein,‌ ‌signals‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌RNA‌ ‌tell‌ ‌the‌ ‌ribosome‌ ‌to‌ ‌start‌ ‌and‌ ‌stop.‌ ‌If‌ ‌a‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌\naccidentally‌ ‌creates‌ ‌a‌ ‌stop‌ ‌codon,‌ ‌then‌ ‌the‌ ‌ribosome‌ ‌won't‌ ‌translate‌ ‌the‌ ‌entire‌ ‌protein.‌ ‌\n ‌\n○How‌ ‌Do‌ ‌Mutations‌ ‌Impact‌ ‌Natural‌ ‌Selection?‌ ‌\n■Overall,‌ ‌silent‌ ‌mutations‌ ‌will‌ ‌not‌ ‌affect‌ ‌natural‌ ‌selection‌ ‌because‌ ‌they‌ ‌have‌ ‌no‌ ‌effect‌ ‌on‌ ‌allele‌ ‌expression,‌ ‌so‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌effect‌ ‌\non‌ ‌fitness.‌ ‌\n■Missense‌ ‌mutations‌ ‌will‌ ‌affect‌ ‌natural‌ ‌selection‌ ‌because‌ ‌they‌ ‌can‌ ‌change‌ ‌the‌ ‌fitness‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌organism.‌ ‌ ‌\n■These‌ ‌mutations‌ ‌can‌ ‌increase‌ ‌or‌ ‌decrease‌ ‌allele‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌depending‌ ‌on‌ ‌if‌ ‌they‌ ‌help‌ ‌or‌ ‌hurt‌ ‌the‌ ‌organism.‌ ‌\n■Nonsense‌ ‌mutations‌ ‌are‌ ‌almost‌ ‌always‌ ‌harmful‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌organism‌ ‌and‌ ‌will‌ ‌decrease‌ ‌fitness.‌ ‌Mutant‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌caused‌ ‌by‌ ‌nonsense‌ ‌\nmutations‌ ‌are‌ ‌rare.‌ ‌\n ‌\n○Applicability‌ ‌of‌ ‌HardyWeinberg‌ ‌equilibrium‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌validity‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Hardy-Weinberg‌ ‌principle‌ ‌is‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌assumption‌ ‌that‌ ‌no‌ ‌new‌ ‌mutations‌ ‌occur.‌ ‌ ‌\n■If‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌locus‌ ‌shows‌ ‌a‌ ‌high‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌rate‌ ‌then‌ ‌there‌ ‌will‌ ‌be‌ ‌a‌ ‌steady‌ ‌increase‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌proportion‌ ‌of‌ ‌mutant‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌population.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌that‌ ‌case‌ ‌the‌ ‌law‌ ‌will‌ ‌not‌ ‌be‌ ‌applicable.‌ ‌\nThe‌ ‌law‌ ‌states‌ ‌that:‌ ‌ ‌\n●“In‌ ‌a‌ ‌infinitely,‌ ‌random‌ ‌mating‌ ‌population,‌ ‌the‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌of‌ ‌genes‌ ‌and‌ ‌genotypes‌ ‌remains‌ ‌constant‌ ‌generation‌ ‌after‌ ‌\ngeneration,This‌ ‌presumes‌ ‌the‌ ‌following‌ ‌conditions:‌ ‌\n●the‌ ‌population‌ ‌is‌ ‌large‌ ‌\n●there‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌immigration‌ ‌or‌ ‌emigration‌ ‌of‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌population‌ ‌\n●there‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌\n●there‌ ‌is‌ ‌random‌ ‌mating‌ ‌\n●there‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌natural‌ ‌selection‌ ‌\n ‌\nMutation‌ ‌and‌ ‌change‌ ‌in‌ ‌Gene‌ ‌Frequency‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌ultimate‌ ‌source‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌variation‌ ‌is‌ ‌mutation.‌ ‌Both‌ ‌chromosomal‌ ‌rearrangements‌ ‌and‌ ‌point‌ ‌mutations‌ ‌are‌ ‌implied‌ ‌here‌ ‌as‌ ‌they‌ ‌\nfollow‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌rules‌ ‌of‌ ‌population‌ ‌dynamics.‌ ‌ ‌\n●However,‌ ‌mutations‌ ‌occur‌ ‌with‌ ‌an‌ ‌extremely‌ ‌low‌ ‌frequency.‌ ‌In‌ ‌humans‌ ‌where‌ ‌there‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌from‌ ‌30-50‌ ‌successive‌ ‌mitotic‌ ‌divisions‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌\ngerm‌ ‌cells‌ ‌in‌ ‌each‌ ‌generation,‌ ‌‌only‌ ‌one‌ ‌gene‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌million‌ ‌or‌ ‌10‌ ‌million‌ ‌roughly‌ ‌undergoes‌ ‌a‌ ‌mutation.‌ ‌\n○Consider‌ ‌an‌ ‌allele‌ ‌‌A‌‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌homozygous‌ ‌in‌ ‌many‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌population.‌ ‌Assume‌ ‌that‌ ‌in‌ ‌every‌ ‌generation‌ ‌one‌ ‌‌A‌‌ ‌allele‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌million‌ ‌\nmutates‌ ‌to‌ ‌‌a.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌will‌ ‌reduce‌ ‌the‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌of‌ ‌‌A‌‌ ‌allele‌ ‌over‌ ‌many‌ ‌generations,‌ ‌while‌ ‌‌a‌‌ ‌allele‌ ‌will‌ ‌gradually‌ ‌accumulate‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌population.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌change‌ ‌in‌ ‌frequencies‌ ‌of‌ ‌A‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌at‌ ‌an‌ ‌unimaginably‌ ‌slow‌ ‌rate.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌a‌ ‌allele‌ ‌however,‌ ‌‌can‌ ‌also‌ ‌back‌ ‌mutate‌ ‌to‌ ‌A‌;‌ ‌this‌ ‌event‌ ‌will‌ ‌take‌ ‌place‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌of‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌increases.‌ ‌ ‌\n○After‌ ‌a‌ ‌very‌ ‌long‌ ‌time‌ ‌the‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌‌A‌‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌lost‌ ‌by‌ ‌forward‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌would‌ ‌be‌ ‌balanced‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌‌A‌ ‌‌alleles‌ ‌arising‌ ‌from‌ ‌\nback‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌to‌ ‌‌A.‌ ‌\n830‌ ‌\n○When‌ ‌this‌ ‌happens‌ ‌gene‌ ‌frequencies‌ ‌of‌ ‌A‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌are‌ ‌said‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌in‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌equilibrium.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Thereafter,‌ ‌no‌ ‌further‌ ‌change‌ ‌in‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌of‌ ‌A‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌will‌ ‌occur‌ ‌in‌ ‌subsequent‌ ‌generations.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌applies‌ ‌however,‌ ‌only‌ ‌when‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌forces‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌migration,‌ ‌selection‌ ‌and‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌drift‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌operating‌ ‌to‌ ‌\naffect‌ ‌gene‌ ‌frequencies‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌population.‌ ‌\n●Experimental‌ ‌work‌ ‌has‌ ‌shown‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌rate‌ ‌of‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌affected‌ ‌by‌ ‌environmental‌ ‌factors‌ ‌like‌ ‌radiation‌ ‌and‌ ‌chemicals.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌some‌ ‌instances‌ ‌mutations‌ ‌are‌ ‌under‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌control.‌ ‌ ‌\n○There‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌mutator‌ ‌gene‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌second‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌of‌ ‌Drosophila‌ ‌melanogaster.In‌ ‌stocks‌ ‌of‌ ‌flies‌ ‌homozygous‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nmutator‌ ‌gene,‌ ‌sex-linked‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌lethals‌ ‌occur‌ ‌spontaneously‌ ‌with‌ ‌high‌ ‌frequency.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌maize‌ ‌the‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌mutator‌ ‌gene‌ ‌Dt‌ ‌acts‌ ‌on‌ ‌an‌ ‌unlinked‌ ‌locus‌ ‌which‌ ‌controls‌ ‌synthesis‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌purple‌ ‌anthocyanin‌ ‌pigment.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌mutator‌ ‌gene‌ ‌Dt‌ ‌causes‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌of‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌form‌ ‌A‌ ‌which‌ ‌leads‌ ‌to‌ ‌synthesis‌ ‌of‌ ‌anthocyanin‌ ‌appearing‌ ‌\nas‌ ‌purple‌ ‌spots‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌stem,‌ ‌leaves‌ ‌and‌ ‌kernels‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌maize‌ ‌plant.‌ ‌\n○Mutator‌ ‌genes‌ ‌also‌ ‌occur‌ ‌in‌ ‌micro-organisms‌ ‌including‌ ‌E.‌ ‌coli.‌ ‌ ‌\n○As‌ ‌the‌ ‌action‌ ‌of‌ ‌mutator‌ ‌genes‌ ‌is‌ ‌directed‌ ‌at‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌locus,‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌said‌ ‌to‌ ‌produce‌ ‌directed‌ ‌mutations‌ ‌in‌ ‌contrast‌ ‌to‌ ‌random‌ ‌\nmutations‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌specific.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Normally‌ ‌all‌ ‌genes‌ ‌could‌ ‌mutate.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌the‌ ‌case‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌rare‌ ‌allele‌ ‌its‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌to‌ ‌other‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌is‌ ‌difficult‌ ‌to‌ ‌detect‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌low‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌and‌ ‌slow‌ ‌rate‌ ‌of‌ ‌mutation.‌ ‌ ‌\n○But‌ ‌when‌ ‌an‌ ‌allele‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌more‌ ‌frequently‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌population‌ ‌it‌ ‌leads‌ ‌to‌ ‌higher‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌rate‌ ‌and‌ ‌increases‌ ‌the‌ ‌population’s‌ ‌potential‌ ‌\nfor‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌change.‌ ‌ ‌\n831‌ ‌\n○If‌ ‌a‌ ‌rare‌ ‌deleterious‌ ‌allele‌ ‌accumulates‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌population,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌disadvantage‌ ‌and‌ ‌constitutes‌ ‌what‌ ‌is‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌mutational‌ ‌\nload.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Isolation‌ ‌\n○Change‌ ‌in‌ ‌Gene‌ ‌Frequency‌ ‌\n■Isolating‌ ‌mechanisms‌ ‌are‌ ‌things‌ ‌that‌ ‌prevent‌ ‌some‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌population‌ ‌from‌ ‌mating‌ ‌with‌ ‌others‌ ‌i.e.‌ ‌The‌ ‌lack‌ ‌of‌ ‌\ninterbreeding‌ ‌or‌ ‌little‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌mixing‌ ‌between‌ ‌organisms‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌species.‌ ‌\n■Isolation‌ ‌of‌ ‌organisms‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌species‌ ‌into‌ ‌several‌ ‌populations‌ ‌or‌ ‌groups‌ ‌under‌ ‌psychic,‌ ‌physiological‌ ‌or‌ ‌geographical‌ ‌factors‌ ‌is‌ ‌\nsupposed‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌significant‌ ‌factors‌ ‌responsible‌ ‌for‌ ‌evolution.‌ ‌ ‌\n■This‌ ‌could‌ ‌be:‌ ‌\n●Geographical‌ ‌barriers‌ ‌include‌ ‌physical‌ ‌barriers‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌rivers,‌ ‌oceans,‌ ‌high‌ ‌mountains‌ ‌which‌ ‌prevent‌ ‌interbreeding‌ ‌\nbetween‌ ‌related‌ ‌organisms.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Physiologi­cal‌ ‌barriers‌ ‌help‌ ‌in‌ ‌maintaining‌ ‌the‌ ‌individuality‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌species,‌ ‌since‌ ‌the‌ ‌isolations‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌‌reproductive‌ ‌\nisolation‌‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌allow‌ ‌the‌ ‌inbreeding‌ ‌amongst‌ ‌the‌ ‌organisms‌ ‌of‌ ‌different‌ ‌spe­cies.‌ ‌\n832‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌temporal‌ ‌barrier,‌ ‌like‌ ‌a‌ ‌difference‌ ‌in‌ ‌when‌ ‌some‌ ‌organisms‌ ‌look‌ ‌for‌ ‌mates.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n833‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌may‌ ‌lead‌ ‌to‌ ‌‌speciation‌‌ ‌(formation‌ ‌of‌ ‌new‌ ‌species)‌ ‌and‌ ‌endangering‌ ‌species‌ ‌to‌ ‌extinction‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌small‌ ‌gene‌ ‌pool.‌ ‌\n ‌\n○Examples‌‌ ‌of‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌isolation‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌ecological‌ ‌community‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌secluded‌ ‌away‌ ‌from‌ ‌others‌ ‌(such‌ ‌as‌ ‌Tristan‌ ‌da‌ ‌Cunha‌ ‌or‌ ‌\nPitcairn‌ ‌Islands),‌ ‌crossing‌ ‌of‌ ‌plants‌ ‌which‌ ‌produce‌ ‌sterile‌ ‌offspring,‌ ‌and‌ ‌human‌ ‌influence‌ ‌on‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌isolates‌ ‌through‌ ‌restricted‌ ‌\nbreeding‌ ‌of‌ ‌dogs.‌ ‌\n■(Genetic‌ ‌isolation‌ ‌differs‌ ‌from‌ ‌gene‌ ‌isolation,‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌isolation‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌gene‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌rest‌ ‌for‌ ‌use‌ ‌in‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌\nengineering).‌ ‌\n ‌\nMigration‌ ‌\n●Migration‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌when‌ ‌a‌ ‌large‌ ‌influx‌ ‌of‌ ‌people‌ ‌moves‌ ‌into‌ ‌another‌ ‌population‌ ‌and‌ ‌interbreeds‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌latter.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌phenomenon‌ ‌called‌ ‌gene‌ ‌flow‌ ‌takes‌ ‌place‌ ‌if‌ ‌one‌ ‌population‌ ‌contributes‌ ‌an‌ ‌allele‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌population.‌ ‌ ‌\n○ ‌‌\"In‌ ‌an‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌sense,‌ ‌the‌ ‌movement‌ ‌of‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌between‌ ‌populations\".‌ ‌Naturally,‌ ‌the‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌donut‌ ‌move‌ ‌by‌ ‌themselves‌ ‌-‌ ‌they‌ ‌\nmove‌ ‌as‌ ‌organisms‌ ‌disperse‌ ‌from‌ ‌population‌ ‌to‌ ‌population.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Note‌‌ ‌-‌ ‌don't‌ ‌confuse‌ ‌migration‌ ‌in‌ ‌this‌ ‌sense‌ ‌with‌ ‌seasonal‌ ‌migrations,‌ ‌e.g.‌ ‌of‌ ‌birds.‌ ‌\"Gene‌ ‌flow\"‌ ‌and‌ ‌\"migration\"‌ ‌are‌ ‌\nsynonymous.‌ ‌\n○Dispersal‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌by‌ ‌adult‌ ‌animal‌ ‌organisms,‌ ‌seeds‌ ‌and‌ ‌spores‌ ‌of‌ ‌plants,‌ ‌planktonic‌ ‌larvae‌ ‌of‌ ‌intertidal‌ ‌animals,‌ ‌gametes/zygotes‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nalgae,‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n●Effects‌ ‌of‌ ‌migration‌ ‌on‌ ‌allele‌ ‌frequencies:‌ ‌\n■In‌ ‌absence‌ ‌of‌ ‌selection‌ ‌(i.e.‌ ‌if‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌are‌ ‌selectively‌ ‌neutral)‌ ‌migration‌ ‌homogenizes‌ ‌allele‌ ‌frequencies‌ ‌among‌ ‌populations.‌ ‌\n■If‌ ‌selection‌ ‌and‌ ‌migration‌ ‌tend‌ ‌to‌ ‌increase‌ ‌the‌ ‌frequencies‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌alleles,‌ ‌selection‌ ‌can‌ ‌amplify‌ ‌effect‌ ‌of‌ ‌migration.‌ ‌\n■If‌ ‌selection‌ ‌and‌ ‌migration‌ ‌are‌ ‌opposed‌ ‌--‌ ‌\n■If‌ ‌selection‌ ‌is‌ ‌stronger‌ ‌than‌ ‌migration,‌ ‌than‌ ‌differences‌ ‌among‌ ‌populations‌ ‌will‌ ‌be‌ ‌maintained,‌ ‌even‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌face‌ ‌of‌ ‌migration.‌ ‌\n■If‌ ‌migration‌ ‌is‌ ‌stronger‌ ‌than‌ ‌selection,‌ ‌differences‌ ‌among‌ ‌populations‌ ‌will‌ ‌be‌ ‌reduced.‌ ‌\n ‌\nSelection‌ ‌\n●Selection‌ ‌is‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌forces‌ ‌that‌ ‌change‌ ‌gene‌ ‌frequencies‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌population‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌fundamental‌ ‌process‌ ‌of‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌change.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌idea‌ ‌was‌ ‌first‌ ‌conceived‌ ‌by‌ ‌‌Charles‌ ‌Darwin‌ ‌in‌ ‌his‌ ‌Origin‌ ‌of‌ ‌Species‌ ‌published‌ ‌in‌ ‌1859‌ ‌and‌ ‌by‌ ‌Alfred‌ ‌Russel‌ ‌Wallace.‌ ‌\n○Selection‌ ‌is‌ ‌defined‌ ‌as‌ ‌differential‌ ‌survival‌ ‌or‌ ‌fertility‌ ‌of‌ ‌different‌ ‌genotypes.‌ ‌ ‌\n834‌ ‌\n■If‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌carrying‌ ‌gene‌ ‌A‌ ‌are‌ ‌more‌ ‌successful‌ ‌in‌ ‌reproduction‌ ‌than‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌carrying‌ ‌its‌ ‌allele‌ ‌a,‌ ‌then‌ ‌the‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌of‌ ‌\ngene‌ ‌A‌ ‌will‌ ‌tend‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌greater‌ ‌than‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌gene‌ ‌a.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌wide‌ ‌variety‌ ‌of‌ ‌mechanisms‌ ‌responsible‌ ‌for‌ ‌modifying‌ ‌the‌ ‌reproductive‌ ‌success‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌genotype‌ ‌are‌ ‌collectively‌ ‌included‌ ‌under‌ ‌selection.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌process‌ ‌that‌ ‌determines‌ ‌the‌ ‌contribution‌ ‌that‌ ‌people‌ ‌of‌ ‌different‌ ‌genotypes‌ ‌will‌ ‌make‌ ‌as‌ ‌parents‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌next‌ ‌generation.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Selection‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌act‌ ‌on‌ ‌individual‌ ‌genes,‌ ‌but‌ ‌rather‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌organism‌ ‌bearing‌ ‌the‌ ‌genes.‌ ‌\n ‌\nChange‌ ‌in‌ ‌Gene‌ ‌Frequency‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌the‌ ‌‘ideal’‌ ‌population‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌selection‌ ‌for‌ ‌or‌ ‌against‌ ‌any‌ ‌particular‌ ‌genotype.‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌reality‌ ‌for‌ ‌deleterious‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌likely‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌negative‌ ‌selection‌ ‌with‌ ‌affected‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌having‌ ‌reduced‌ ‌reproductive‌ ‌\nfitness‌ ‌in‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌sense,‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌genes‌ ‌would‌ ‌not‌ ‌be‌ ‌transmitted‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌next‌ ‌generation.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌the‌ ‌absence‌ ‌of‌ ‌new‌ ‌mutations‌ ‌this‌ ‌reduction‌ ‌in‌ ‌fitness‌ ‌will‌ ‌lead‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌gradual‌ ‌reduction‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌mutant‌ ‌gene‌ ‌and‌ ‌will‌ ‌\ncause‌ ‌disturbance‌ ‌of‌ ‌Hardy-Weinberg‌ ‌equilibrium.‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌some‌ ‌autosomal‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌disorders‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌that‌ ‌heterozygotes‌ ‌show‌ ‌a‌ ‌slight‌ ‌increase‌ ‌in‌ ‌biological‌ ‌fitness‌ ‌as‌ ‌\ncompared‌ ‌with‌ ‌unaffected‌ ‌homozygotes.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌is‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to‌ ‌as‌ ‌‌heterozygote‌ ‌advantage.‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌best‌ ‌understood‌ ‌example‌ ‌is‌ ‌sickle‌ ‌cell‌ ‌disease‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌affected‌ ‌homozygotes‌ ‌have‌ ‌severe‌ ‌anemia‌ ‌and‌ ‌often‌ ‌show‌ ‌\npersistent‌ ‌ill-health.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌reproductive‌ ‌efficiency‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌genotype‌ ‌is‌ ‌measured‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌average‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌offspring‌ ‌born‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌bearers‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌genotype‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nis‌ ‌called‌ ‌Darwinian‌ ‌fitness‌ ‌or‌ ‌relative‌ ‌fitness.‌ ‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌organism’s‌ ‌adaptive‌ ‌value.‌ ‌The‌ ‌fitness‌ ‌value‌ ‌of‌ ‌1‌ ‌is‌ ‌usually‌ ‌assigned‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌genotype‌ ‌with‌ ‌highest‌ ‌\nreproductive‌ ‌efficiency.‌ ‌\n○When‌ ‌selection‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌in‌ ‌favour‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌heterozygote‌ ‌over‌ ‌both‌ ‌homozygotes‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌called‌ ‌over‌ ‌dominance‌ ‌or‌ ‌heterosis.‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌when‌ ‌the‌ ‌fitness‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌heterozygous‌ ‌genotype‌ ‌is‌ ‌greater‌ ‌than‌ ‌the‌ ‌fitness‌ ‌of‌ ‌both‌ ‌homozygotes.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Assume‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌relative‌ ‌fitness‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌genotypes‌ ‌AA,‌ ‌Aa‌ ‌and‌ ‌aa‌ ‌are‌ ‌0.9,1‌ ‌and‌ ‌0.8‌ ‌respectively.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌greater‌ ‌fitness‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌Aa-‌ ‌genotype‌ ‌will‌ ‌not‌ ‌allow‌ ‌either‌ ‌A‌ ‌or‌ ‌a‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌from‌ ‌homozygotes‌ ‌to‌ ‌become‌ ‌fixed.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Ultimately‌ ‌equilibrium‌ ‌gene‌ ‌frequencies‌ ‌would‌ ‌be‌ ‌attained.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌effect‌ ‌of‌ ‌selection‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌counterbalanced‌ ‌by‌ ‌mutation.‌ ‌ ‌\n■While‌ ‌selection‌ ‌is‌ ‌eliminating‌ ‌some‌ ‌genes‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌population,‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌is‌ ‌creating‌ ‌new‌ ‌ones.‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌two‌ ‌forces‌ ‌selection‌ ‌and‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌operate‌ ‌in‌ ‌opposite‌ ‌directions,‌ ‌and‌ ‌tend‌ ‌to‌ ‌compensate‌ ‌each‌ ‌other.‌ ‌ ‌\n■After‌ ‌a‌ ‌long‌ ‌time,‌ ‌gene‌ ‌frequencies‌ ‌will‌ ‌reach‌ ‌equilibrium.‌ ‌\n●Natural‌ ‌selection‌ ‌can‌ ‌cause‌ ‌microevolution,‌ ‌or‌ ‌a‌ ‌change‌ ‌in‌ ‌allele‌ ‌frequencies‌ ‌over‌ ‌time,‌ ‌with‌ ‌fitness-increasing‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌becoming‌ ‌more‌ ‌\ncommon‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌population‌ ‌over‌ ‌generations.‌ ‌Fitness‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌measure‌ ‌of‌ ‌relative‌ ‌reproductive‌ ‌success.‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌popular‌ ‌example‌ ‌of‌ ‌selection‌ ‌is‌ ‌industrial‌ ‌melanism‌ ‌as‌ ‌exhibited‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌pepper‌ ‌moth‌ ‌Biston‌ ‌betularia.‌ ‌ ‌\n■In‌ ‌the‌ ‌mid‌ ‌19th‌ ‌century‌ ‌the‌ ‌light‌ ‌coloured‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌moth‌ ‌were‌ ‌abundant‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌pale‌ ‌barks‌ ‌of‌ ‌trees‌ ‌growing‌ ‌in‌ ‌unpolluted,‌ ‌\nnon-industrialised‌ ‌regions‌ ‌of‌ ‌England.‌ ‌ ‌\n835‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌dark‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌Biston‌ ‌was‌ ‌extremely‌ ‌rare.‌ ‌As‌ ‌industry‌ ‌developed‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌area,‌ ‌the‌ ‌environment‌ ‌became‌ ‌polluted‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nbarks‌ ‌of‌ ‌trees‌ ‌turned‌ ‌dark‌ ‌grey‌ ‌with‌ ‌smoke‌ ‌and‌ ‌dust.‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌light‌ ‌moths‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌dark‌ ‌coloured‌ ‌bark‌ ‌were‌ ‌easily‌ ‌noticed‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌predators‌ ‌and‌ ‌were‌ ‌preyed‌ ‌upon.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Their‌ ‌number‌ ‌began‌ ‌to‌ ‌decrease.‌ ‌In‌ ‌the‌ ‌following‌ ‌decades,‌ ‌the‌ ‌population‌ ‌of‌ ‌dark‌ ‌moths‌ ‌was‌ ‌observed‌ ‌to‌ ‌gradually‌ ‌increase‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌95%;‌ ‌the‌ ‌light‌ ‌moths‌ ‌were‌ ‌hardly‌ ‌seen.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Industrial‌ ‌melanism‌ ‌is‌ ‌thus‌ ‌a‌ ‌clear‌ ‌cut‌ ‌example‌ ‌of‌ ‌selection‌ ‌disturbing‌ ‌gene‌ ‌frequencies‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌population.‌ ‌\n○Artificial‌ ‌and‌ ‌Natural‌ ‌Selection:‌ ‌\n ‌\n○Selection‌ ‌was‌ ‌being‌ ‌practiced‌ ‌by‌ ‌humans‌ ‌since‌ ‌antiquity.‌ ‌Plant‌ ‌and‌ ‌animal‌ ‌breeders‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌attempting‌ ‌to‌ ‌modify‌ ‌hereditary‌ ‌transmission‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌traits‌ ‌by‌ ‌selecting‌ ‌most‌ ‌desirable‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌to‌ ‌serve‌ ‌as‌ ‌parents‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌next‌ ‌generation.‌ ‌This‌ ‌is‌ ‌called‌ ‌artificial‌ ‌selection.‌ ‌ ‌\n○By‌ ‌contrast,‌ ‌when‌ ‌organisms‌ ‌are‌ ‌selected‌ ‌by‌ ‌natural‌ ‌forces‌ ‌instead‌ ‌of‌ ‌by‌ ‌human‌ ‌choice,‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌said‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌subject‌ ‌to‌ ‌natural‌ ‌selection.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nInbreeding‌ ‌\n●Nonrandom‌ ‌mating‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌phenomenon‌ ‌that‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌choose‌ ‌their‌ ‌mates‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌their‌ ‌genotypes‌ ‌or‌ ‌phenotypes.‌ ‌Examples‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌kind‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nmating‌ ‌occur‌ ‌in‌ ‌species‌ ‌like‌ ‌humans,‌ ‌peacocks,‌ ‌and‌ ‌frogs.‌ ‌Nonrandom‌ ‌mating‌ ‌can‌ ‌happen‌ ‌in‌ ‌many‌ ‌different‌ ‌forms‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n836‌ ‌\n○Inbreeding‌ ‌changes‌ ‌genotype‌ ‌frequencies,‌ ‌not‌ ‌allele‌ ‌frequencies:‌ ‌\n■Homozygotes‌ ‌increase‌ ‌in‌ ‌frequency,‌ ‌heterozygotes‌ ‌decrease‌ ‌in‌ ‌frequency.‌ ‌\n■This‌ ‌is‌ ‌most‌ ‌easily‌ ‌seen‌ ‌in‌ ‌extreme‌ ‌case‌ ‌of‌ ‌inbreeding‌ ‌-‌ ‌selfing.‌ ‌When‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌self-fertilize,‌ ‌all‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌homozygotes‌ ‌\nproduce‌ ‌homozygotes,‌ ‌and‌ ‌half‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌offspring‌ ‌of‌ ‌heterozygotes‌ ‌are‌ ‌homozygotes‌ ‌(only‌ ‌half‌ ‌are‌ ‌heterozygotes).‌ ‌Hence,‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nfrequency‌ ‌of‌ ‌heterozygotes‌ ‌declines‌ ‌by‌ ‌50%‌ ‌each‌ ‌generation.‌ ‌The‌ ‌same‌ ‌argument‌ ‌applies‌ ‌to‌ ‌sibling‌ ‌matings,‌ ‌half-sib‌ ‌\nmatings,‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Genetic‌ ‌drift‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌random‌ ‌change‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌of‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌occurring‌ ‌by‌ ‌chance‌ ‌fluctuations.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌characterized‌ ‌by:‌ ‌\n(i)‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌binomial‌ ‌sampling‌ ‌error‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌gene‌ ‌pool,‌ ‌i.e.‌ ‌that‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌which‌ ‌form‌ ‌the‌ ‌gene‌ ‌pool‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌next‌ ‌generation‌ ‌are‌ ‌a‌ ‌sample‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nalleles‌ ‌of‌ ‌present‌ ‌population.‌ ‌\n(ii)‌ ‌Genetic‌ ‌drift‌ ‌always‌ ‌influences‌ ‌frequencies‌ ‌of‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌and‌ ‌is‌ ‌inversely‌ ‌proportional‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌size‌ ‌of‌ ‌population.‌ ‌So‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌drift‌ ‌is‌ ‌most‌ ‌\nimportant‌ ‌in‌ ‌very‌ ‌small‌ ‌populations‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌increased‌ ‌chances‌ ‌of‌ ‌inbreeding‌ ‌which‌ ‌increases‌ ‌the‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌of‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌\nhomozygous‌ ‌for‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌alleles,‌ ‌many‌ ‌of‌ ‌which‌ ‌maybe‌ ‌deleterious.‌ ‌\n(iii)‌ ‌Genetic‌ ‌drift‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌when‌ ‌a‌ ‌small‌ ‌group‌ ‌separates‌ ‌from‌ ‌a‌ ‌larger‌ ‌population‌ ‌and‌ ‌may‌ ‌not‌ ‌have‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌or‌ ‌may‌ ‌differ‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nparental‌ ‌population‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌frequencies‌ ‌of‌ ‌certain‌ ‌genes.‌ ‌This‌ ‌explains‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌difference‌ ‌between‌ ‌island‌ ‌populations‌ ‌and‌ ‌mainland‌ ‌\npopulation.‌ ‌\n(iv)‌ ‌In‌ ‌a‌ ‌small‌ ‌population,‌ ‌a‌ ‌chance‌ ‌event‌ ‌(e.g.‌ ‌snow‌ ‌storm)‌ ‌may‌ ‌increase‌ ‌the‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌character‌ ‌having‌ ‌little‌ ‌adaptive‌ ‌value.‌ ‌\n(v)‌ ‌Genetic‌ ‌drift‌ ‌can‌ ‌also‌ ‌operate‌ ‌through‌ ‌founder‌ ‌effect.‌ ‌In‌ ‌this,‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌drift‌ ‌can‌ ‌cause‌ ‌dramatic‌ ‌changes‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌allele‌ ‌frequencies‌ ‌in‌ ‌\na‌ ‌population‌ ‌derived‌ ‌from‌ ‌small‌ ‌groups‌ ‌of‌ ‌colonisers,‌ ‌called‌ ‌founders,‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌new‌ ‌habitat.‌ ‌\nThese‌ ‌founders‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌have‌ ‌all‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌source‌ ‌population.‌ ‌These‌ ‌founders‌ ‌become‌ ‌quickly‌ ‌different‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nparental‌ ‌population‌ ‌and‌ ‌may‌ ‌form‌ ‌a‌ ‌new‌ ‌species,‌ ‌e.g.‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌Darwin‌ ‌finches‌ ‌on‌ ‌Galapagos‌ ‌Islands‌ ‌which‌ ‌were‌ ‌probably‌ ‌derived‌ ‌\nfrom‌ ‌a‌ ‌few‌ ‌initial‌ ‌founders.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Change‌ ‌in‌ ‌Gene‌ ‌Frequency‌ ‌\n ‌\n■These‌ ‌are‌ ‌unexpected‌ ‌random‌ ‌changes‌ ‌that‌ ‌occur‌ ‌in‌ ‌gene‌ ‌frequencies‌ ‌from‌ ‌generation‌ ‌to‌ ‌generation‌ ‌in‌ ‌all‌ ‌populations.‌ ‌ ‌\n■They‌ ‌are‌ ‌particularly‌ ‌noticeable‌ ‌as‌ ‌sampling‌ ‌variation‌ ‌in‌ ‌small‌ ‌populations.‌ ‌ ‌\n■In‌ ‌some‌ ‌generations‌ ‌the‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌certain‌ ‌allele‌ ‌will‌ ‌by‌ ‌chance‌ ‌increase,‌ ‌in‌ ‌others‌ ‌it‌ ‌will‌ ‌decrease,‌ ‌in‌ ‌still‌ ‌others‌ ‌it‌ ‌may‌ ‌\nremain‌ ‌the‌ ‌same.‌ ‌These‌ ‌fluctuations‌ ‌in‌ ‌gene‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌occur‌ ‌at‌ ‌random.‌ ‌\n■In‌ ‌small‌ ‌samples‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌greater‌ ‌variation‌ ‌as‌ ‌compared‌ ‌to‌ ‌big‌ ‌samples.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Drift‌ ‌however,‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌depend‌ ‌upon‌ ‌the‌ ‌total‌ ‌size‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌population,‌ ‌rather‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌breeding‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌who‌ ‌would‌ ‌\nproduce‌ ‌the‌ ‌next‌ ‌generation.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌unlikely‌ ‌that‌ ‌random‌ ‌drift‌ ‌alone‌ ‌will‌ ‌affect‌ ‌allele‌ ‌frequencies‌ ‌at‌ ‌a‌ ‌gene‌ ‌locus‌ ‌over‌ ‌long‌ ‌\nperiods‌ ‌of‌ ‌time.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌more‌ ‌likely‌ ‌that‌ ‌selection,‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌or‌ ‌migration‌ ‌would‌ ‌also‌ ‌take‌ ‌place‌ ‌at‌ ‌one‌ ‌time‌ ‌or‌ ‌another.‌ ‌\n ‌\n837‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nEffect‌ ‌of‌ ‌Drift‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Bottleneck‌ ‌effect‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌population‌ ‌bottleneck‌ ‌or‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌bottleneck‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌sharp‌ ‌reduction‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌size‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌population‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌environmental‌ ‌events‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌\nfamines,‌ ‌earthquakes,‌ ‌floods,‌ ‌fires,‌ ‌disease,‌ ‌and‌ ‌droughts‌ ‌or‌ ‌human‌ ‌activities‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌specicide‌ ‌and‌ ‌human‌ ‌population‌ ‌planning.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○Example‌ ‌glycogen‌ ‌storage‌ ‌related‌ ‌disease‌ ‌in‌ ‌Southeast‌ ‌Asia.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Spread‌ ‌of‌ ‌ITD‌ ‌gene‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌US.‌ ‌\n●Inbreeding‌ ‌\n○Inbreeding‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌mating‌ ‌of‌ ‌organisms‌ ‌closely‌ ‌related‌ ‌by‌ ‌ancestry.‌ ‌It‌ ‌goes‌ ‌against‌ ‌the‌ ‌biological‌ ‌aim‌ ‌of‌ ‌mating,‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌shuffling‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌DNA.‌ ‌\n○Examples‌ ‌‌of‌ ‌specific‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌disorders‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌inbreeding‌ ‌include‌ ‌schizophrenia,‌ ‌limb‌ ‌malformation,‌ ‌blindness,‌ ‌congenital‌ ‌\nheart‌ ‌disease,‌ ‌and‌ ‌neonatal‌ ‌diabetes.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Founder‌ ‌effect‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌population‌ ‌genetics,‌ ‌the‌ ‌founder‌ ‌effect‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌loss‌ ‌of‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌variation‌ ‌that‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌when‌ ‌a‌ ‌new‌ ‌population‌ ‌is‌ ‌established‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌very‌ ‌\nsmall‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌from‌ ‌a‌ ‌larger‌ ‌population.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌was‌ ‌first‌ ‌fully‌ ‌outlined‌ ‌by‌ ‌Ernst‌ ‌Mayr‌ ‌in‌ ‌1942,‌ ‌using‌ ‌existing‌ ‌theoretical‌ ‌work‌ ‌by‌ ‌those‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌Sewall‌ ‌Wright.‌ ‌ ‌\n838‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○Example:‌ ‌six‌ ‌finger‌ ‌dwarfism.‌ ‌\n●Bottlenecks‌ ‌occur‌ ‌when‌ ‌a‌ ‌population's‌ ‌size‌ ‌is‌ ‌reduced‌ ‌for‌ ‌at‌ ‌least‌ ‌one‌ ‌generation.‌ ‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌founder‌ ‌effect‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌when‌ ‌a‌ ‌new‌ ‌colony‌ ‌is‌ ‌started‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌few‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌original‌ ‌population.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n9.3‌ ‌Consanguineous‌ ‌and‌ ‌non-consanguineous‌ ‌mating,‌ ‌Genetic‌ ‌load,‌ ‌Genetic‌ ‌effect‌ ‌of‌ ‌consanguineous‌ ‌and‌ ‌cousin‌ ‌mating-‌ ‌Part-III‌ ‌\n ‌\nIntroduction‌ ‌\n●Sexual‌ ‌selection‌ ‌is‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌powerful‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌forces.‌ ‌Its‌ ‌mode‌ ‌of‌ ‌natural‌ ‌selection.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌when‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌one‌ ‌biological‌ ‌sex‌ ‌choose‌ ‌mates‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌sex‌ ‌to‌ ‌mate‌ ‌with,‌ ‌and‌ ‌compete‌ ‌with‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌sex‌ ‌for‌ ‌\naccess‌ ‌to‌ ‌members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌opposite‌ ‌sex.‌ ‌\n839‌ ‌\n○Sexual‌ ‌selection,‌ ‌theory‌ ‌in‌ ‌postulating‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌evolution‌ ‌of‌ ‌certain‌ ‌conspicuous‌ ‌physical‌ ‌traits—such‌ ‌as‌ ‌pronounced‌ ‌coloration,‌ ‌\nincreased‌ ‌size,‌ ‌or‌ ‌striking‌ ‌adornments—in‌ ‌animals‌ ‌may‌ ‌grant‌ ‌the‌ ‌possessors‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌traits‌ ‌greater‌ ‌success‌ ‌in‌ ‌obtaining‌ ‌mates.‌ ‌ ‌\n○From‌ ‌the‌ ‌perspective‌ ‌of‌ ‌natural‌ ‌selection,‌ ‌such‌ ‌increases‌ ‌in‌ ‌mating‌ ‌opportunities‌ ‌outweigh‌ ‌the‌ ‌risks‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌animal’s‌ ‌\nincreased‌ ‌visibility‌ ‌in‌ ‌its‌ ‌environment.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌concept‌ ‌was‌ ‌initially‌ ‌put‌ ‌forth‌ ‌by‌ ‌English‌ ‌naturalist‌ ‌Charles‌ ‌Darwin‌ ‌in‌ ‌The‌ ‌Descent‌ ‌of‌ ‌Man‌ ‌(1871).‌ ‌\n●Analyses‌ ‌of‌ ‌mating‌ ‌systems‌ ‌since‌ ‌Darwin‌ ‌have‌ ‌emphasized‌ ‌either‌ ‌the‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌between‌ ‌male‌ ‌and‌ ‌female‌ ‌mating‌ ‌elements,‌ ‌\nusually‌ ‌among‌ ‌plants,‌ ‌or‌ ‌the‌ ‌numbers‌ ‌of‌ ‌mates‌ ‌males‌ ‌and‌ ‌females‌ ‌may‌ ‌obtain,‌ ‌usually‌ ‌among‌ ‌animals.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Combining‌ ‌these‌ ‌schemes‌ ‌yields‌ ‌a‌ ‌quantitative‌ ‌methodology‌ ‌that‌ ‌emphasizes‌ ‌measurement‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌sex‌ ‌difference‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌variance‌ ‌in‌ ‌relative‌ ‌\nfitness,‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌phenotypic‌ ‌and‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌correlations‌ ‌underlying‌ ‌reproductive‌ ‌traits‌ ‌that‌ ‌may‌ ‌arise‌ ‌among‌ ‌breeding‌ ‌pairs.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Such‌ ‌information‌ ‌predicts‌ ‌the‌ ‌degree‌ ‌and‌ ‌direction‌ ‌of‌ ‌sexual‌ ‌dimorphism‌ ‌within‌ ‌species,‌ ‌it‌ ‌allows‌ ‌the‌ ‌classification‌ ‌of‌ ‌mating‌ ‌systems‌ ‌\nusing‌ ‌existing‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌and‌ ‌life‌ ‌history‌ ‌data,‌ ‌and‌ ‌with‌ ‌information‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌spatial‌ ‌and‌ ‌temporal‌ ‌distributions‌ ‌of‌ ‌fertilizations,‌ ‌it‌ ‌may‌ ‌also‌ ‌\npredict‌ ‌floral‌ ‌morphology‌ ‌in‌ ‌plants.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Because‌ ‌this‌ ‌empirical‌ ‌framework‌ ‌identifies‌ ‌selective‌ ‌forces‌ ‌and‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌architectures‌ ‌responsible‌ ‌for‌ ‌observed‌ ‌male-female‌ ‌differences,‌ ‌it‌ ‌\ncompliments‌ ‌discoveries‌ ‌of‌ ‌nucleotide‌ ‌sequence‌ ‌variation‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌expression‌ ‌of‌ ‌quantitative‌ ‌traits.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Moreover,‌ ‌because‌ ‌this‌ ‌methodology‌ ‌emphasizes‌ ‌the‌ ‌process‌ ‌of‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌change,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌easier‌ ‌to‌ ‌test‌ ‌and‌ ‌interpret‌ ‌than‌ ‌frameworks‌ ‌\nemphasizing‌ ‌parental‌ ‌investment‌ ‌in‌ ‌offspring‌ ‌and‌ ‌its‌ ‌presumed‌ ‌evolutionary‌ ‌outcomes.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌significance‌ ‌of‌ ‌each‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌mating‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌investigated‌ ‌theoretically‌ ‌and‌ ‌its‌ ‌theoretical‌ ‌expectation‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌possible‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌\nchanges‌ ‌over‌ ‌generations‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌worked‌ ‌out‌ ‌or‌ ‌marriages‌ ‌in‌ ‌diverse‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nVarious‌ ‌forms‌ ‌of‌ ‌mating‌ ‌\n ‌\nRandom‌ ‌Mating‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌mating‌ ‌between‌ ‌two‌ ‌organisms‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌influenced‌ ‌by‌ ‌any‌ ‌environmental,‌ ‌hereditary‌ ‌or‌ ‌social‌ ‌interaction.‌ ‌Hence,‌ ‌potential‌ ‌mates‌ ‌have‌ ‌an‌ ‌\nequal‌ ‌chance‌ ‌of‌ ‌being‌ ‌selected.‌ ‌\n●Random‌ ‌mating‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to‌ ‌as‌ ‌‘panmixia’.‌ ‌Panmixia‌ ‌or‌ ‌Random‌ ‌mating‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌situation‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌population‌ ‌where‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌equal‌ ‌\nopportunity‌ ‌for‌ ‌both‌ ‌the‌ ‌sexes‌ ‌to‌ ‌mate‌ ‌and‌ ‌reproduce‌ ‌irrespective‌ ‌of‌ ‌any‌ ‌choice‌ ‌or‌ ‌selection.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It's‌ ‌a‌ ‌situation‌ ‌where‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌absence‌ ‌of‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌rules‌ ‌and‌ ‌regulations‌ ‌that‌ ‌involve‌ ‌preferences‌ ‌or‌ ‌avoidances‌ ‌of‌ ‌choice‌ ‌or‌ ‌selection‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nmarriage‌ ‌partners.‌ ‌ ‌\n●If‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌mates‌ ‌or‌ ‌marries‌ ‌without‌ ‌any‌ ‌criteria‌ ‌of‌ ‌selection‌ ‌or‌ ‌choice‌ ‌whatsoever,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌random‌ ‌mating.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Random‌ ‌mating‌ ‌can‌ ‌also‌ ‌refer‌ ‌to‌ ‌those‌ ‌mating‌ ‌with‌ ‌respect‌ ‌to‌ ‌individual‌ ‌genotype‌ ‌or‌ ‌phenotype,‌ ‌though‌ ‌they‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌marrying‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌\nwithin‌ ‌the‌ ‌community.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Therefore,‌ ‌‌the‌ ‌random‌ ‌mating‌ ‌also‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌characters‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌involved,‌ ‌either‌ ‌directly‌ ‌or‌ ‌indirectly,‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌choice‌ ‌or‌ ‌selection‌ ‌by‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌respective‌ ‌mates‌ ‌or‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌partners.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Random‌ ‌mating‌ ‌is‌ ‌one‌ ‌important‌ ‌criterion‌ ‌in‌ ‌‌Hardy-Weinberg‌ ‌equilibrium‌‌ ‌which‌ ‌ensures,‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌large‌ ‌population,‌ ‌stability‌ ‌of‌ ‌gene‌ ‌\nfrequency‌ ‌over‌ ‌generations.‌ ‌\n840‌ ‌\n○Otherwise‌ ‌deviations‌ ‌from‌ ‌random‌ ‌mating,‌ ‌a‌ ‌common‌ ‌phenomenon‌ ‌among‌ ‌human‌ ‌populations,‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌important‌ ‌factor‌ ‌which‌ ‌changes‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌gene‌ ‌frequency.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nNon‌ ‌Random‌ ‌Mating‌ ‌ ‌\nMating‌ ‌that‌ ‌has‌ ‌not‌ ‌occurred‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌chance,‌ ‌and‌ ‌therefore‌ ‌has‌ ‌had‌ ‌human‌ ‌interference.‌ ‌\nex.‌ ‌People‌ ‌who‌ ‌look‌ ‌alike‌ ‌mate‌ ‌more‌ ‌often‌ ‌than‌ ‌they‌ ‌would‌ ‌under‌ ‌totally‌ ‌random‌ ‌conditions.‌ ‌\n1.‌ ‌arranged‌ ‌marriages‌ ‌\n2.‌ ‌people‌ ‌who‌ ‌look‌ ‌alike‌ ‌mate‌ ‌together‌ ‌\n ‌\nNon-random‌ ‌mating‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌population‌ ‌when‌ ‌similar‌ ‌phenotype‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌mate‌ ‌more‌ ‌frequently‌ ‌with‌ ‌each‌ ‌other‌ ‌than‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌dissimilar‌ ‌\nphenotype‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌is‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌positive‌ ‌(ASSORTATIVE)‌ ‌non-random‌ ‌mating‌ ‌\ndissimilar‌ ‌phenotype‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌mate‌ ‌more‌ ‌frequently‌ ‌with‌ ‌each‌ ‌other‌ ‌than‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌similar‌ ‌phenotype‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌is‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌negative‌ ‌(DISASSORTATIVE)‌ ‌non-random‌ ‌mating‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nAssortative‌ ‌mating‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌all‌ ‌human‌ ‌populations,‌ ‌from‌ ‌simple‌ ‌societies‌ ‌of‌ ‌tribes‌ ‌and‌ ‌to‌ ‌complex‌ ‌societies‌ ‌of‌ ‌urban‌ ‌metropolises,‌ ‌people‌ ‌usually‌ ‌like‌ ‌to‌ ‌select‌ ‌their‌ ‌\nmarriage‌ ‌partners,‌ ‌mates‌ ‌or‌ ‌spouse,‌ ‌i.e.,‌ ‌non-randomly,‌ ‌with‌ ‌desirable‌ ‌characters‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌liking.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌is‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to‌ ‌as‌ ‌‘assortative‌ ‌mating’,‌‌ ‌an‌ ‌important‌ ‌factor‌ ‌of‌ ‌non-random‌ ‌selection‌ ‌of‌ ‌mates‌ ‌that‌ ‌exists‌ ‌in‌ ‌all‌ ‌human‌ ‌societies.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Assortative‌ ‌mating‌ ‌is‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌deviations‌ ‌from‌ ‌random‌ ‌mating‌ ‌assumption‌ ‌of‌ ‌Hardy-Weinberg‌ ‌equilibrium.‌ ‌ ‌\n○According‌ ‌to‌ ‌H‌ ‌W‌ ‌Law‌ ‌the‌ ‌gene‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌population‌ ‌is‌ ‌expected‌ ‌to‌ ‌change‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌result‌ ‌of‌ ‌non-random‌ ‌mating‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌assortative‌ ‌\nmating.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Marriage‌ ‌between‌ ‌close‌ ‌relatives‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌special‌ ‌case‌ ‌of‌ ‌assortative‌ ‌mating.‌ ‌The‌ ‌closer‌ ‌the‌ ‌kinship,‌ ‌the‌ ‌more‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌shared‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌\ngreater‌ ‌the‌ ‌degree‌ ‌of‌ ‌inbreeding.‌ ‌Inbreeding‌ ‌can‌ ‌alter‌ ‌the‌ ‌gene‌ ‌pool.‌ ‌\n○Choice‌ ‌of‌ ‌mate‌ ‌selection‌ ‌is‌ ‌more‌ ‌concerned‌ ‌directly‌ ‌with‌ ‌respect‌ ‌to‌ ‌some‌ ‌specific‌ ‌phenotypic‌ ‌characters‌ ‌(rarely‌ ‌genotypes‌ ‌are‌ ‌\ninvolved)‌ ‌and‌ ‌it‌ ‌might‌ ‌involve,‌ ‌indirectly,‌ ‌other‌ ‌characters‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌associated‌ ‌or‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌selected‌ ‌traits‌ ‌or‌ ‌characters‌ ‌among‌ ‌\nspouses‌ ‌or‌ ‌mates.‌ ‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌example‌,‌ ‌choice‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌partner‌ ‌could‌ ‌be‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌such‌ ‌desired‌ ‌or‌ ‌preferred‌ ‌traits‌ ‌e.g.,‌ ‌skin‌ ‌colour,‌ ‌age‌ ‌preferences,‌ ‌intelligence,‌ ‌\nsocial‌ ‌status‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌case‌ ‌one‌ ‌selects‌ ‌intelligence‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌criterion‌ ‌it‌ ‌might‌ ‌be‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌high‌ ‌social‌ ‌status,‌ ‌which‌ ‌may‌ ‌not‌ ‌be‌ ‌a‌ ‌desired‌ ‌trait.‌ ‌ ‌\n841‌ ‌\n○\n ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nInbreeding‌ ‌\n ‌\n●In‌ ‌many‌ ‌societies‌ ‌marriages‌ ‌take‌ ‌place‌ ‌between‌ ‌relatives.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌general,‌ ‌breeding‌ ‌among‌ ‌close‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌within‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌is‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to‌ ‌as‌ ‌‘inbreeding’,‌ ‌and‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌applicable‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌case‌ ‌of‌ ‌plants‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nanimals.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌extent‌ ‌of‌ ‌inbreeding‌ ‌depends‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌amount‌ ‌of‌ ‌common‌ ‌ancestry‌ ‌shared‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌parents‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌‘inbred’‌ ‌child‌ ‌(the‌ ‌progeny‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nconsanguineous‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌or‌ ‌inbreeding)‌ ‌or‌ ‌in‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌terms‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌proportion‌ ‌of‌ ‌genes‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌parents‌ ‌have‌ ‌in‌ ‌common.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌opposite‌ ‌to‌ ‌outbreeding‌ ‌referring‌ ‌to‌ ‌breeding‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌from‌ ‌outside‌ ‌the‌ ‌group‌ ‌or‌ ‌unrelated‌ ‌individuals.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌human‌ ‌societies‌ ‌the‌ ‌marriages‌ ‌contracted‌ ‌among‌ ‌relatives‌ ‌are‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to‌ ‌as‌ ‌‘consanguineous‌ ‌marriages’‌ ‌or‌ ‌‘inbreeding’.‌ ‌\n●Consanguineous‌ ‌is‌ ‌more‌ ‌with‌ ‌reference‌ ‌to‌ ‌cultural‌ ‌context‌ ‌and‌ ‌inbreeding‌ ‌is‌ ‌more‌ ‌with‌ ‌reference‌ ‌to‌ ‌general‌ ‌breeding‌ ‌that‌ ‌include‌ ‌Man‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nother‌ ‌organisms.‌ ‌\n842‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nConsanguineous‌ ‌Mating‌ ‌\n●Consanguinity,‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌characterized‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌sharing‌ ‌of‌ ‌common‌ ‌ancestors.‌ ‌The‌ ‌word‌ ‌is‌ ‌derived‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌Latin‌ ‌consanguineus,‌ ‌“of‌ ‌common‌ ‌\nblood,”‌ ‌which‌ ‌implied‌ ‌that‌ ‌Roman‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌were‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌father‌ ‌and‌ ‌thus‌ ‌shared‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌right‌ ‌to‌ ‌his‌ ‌inheritance.‌ ‌\n○Kin‌ ‌are‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌basic‌ ‌kinds:‌ ‌ ‌\n■Consanguineous‌‌ ‌(sharing‌ ‌common‌ ‌ancestors)‌ ‌and‌ ‌\n■Affinal‌‌ ‌(related‌ ‌by‌ ‌marriage).‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌some‌ ‌societies‌ ‌other‌ ‌pairs‌ ‌of‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌also‌ ‌treat‌ ‌each‌ ‌other‌ ‌as‌ ‌relatives.‌ ‌\n■For‌ ‌example‌,‌ ‌the‌ ‌wives‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌pair‌ ‌of‌ ‌brothers,‌ ‌relatives‌ ‌by‌ ‌adoption,‌ ‌and‌ ‌godparents‌ ‌who‌ ‌have‌ ‌special‌ ‌kinlike‌ ‌relationships‌ ‌\n(fictive‌ ‌kin).‌ ‌ ‌\n●Consanguineous‌ ‌kinship‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌universal‌ ‌type;‌ ‌it‌ ‌includes‌ ‌those‌ ‌with‌ ‌common‌ ‌ancestors‌ ‌and‌ ‌excludes‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌who‌ ‌\nlack‌ ‌ancestors‌ ‌in‌ ‌common.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●In‌ ‌the‌ ‌modern‌ ‌sense,‌ ‌consanguinity‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌concept.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌terms‌ ‌inbreeding‌ ‌and‌ ‌consanguinity‌ ‌are‌ ‌used‌ ‌interchangeably‌ ‌to‌ ‌describe‌ ‌unions‌ ‌between‌ ‌couples‌ ‌who‌ ‌share‌ ‌at‌ ‌least‌ ‌one‌ ‌common‌ ‌\nancestor.‌ ‌\n○Consanguinity‌ ‌and‌ ‌Inbreeding‌ ‌are‌ ‌often‌ ‌confused.‌ ‌ ‌\n843‌ ‌\n■Because‌ ‌many‌ ‌humans‌ ‌exist‌ ‌and‌ ‌marry‌ ‌in‌ ‌more‌ ‌or‌ ‌less‌ ‌closed,‌ ‌finite‌ ‌populations,‌ ‌any‌ ‌two‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌partners‌ ‌may‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nmore‌ ‌or‌ ‌less‌ ‌distant‌ ‌common‌ ‌ancestor,‌ ‌and‌ ‌are‌ ‌therefore‌ ‌consanguineous‌ ‌distant‌ ‌cousins.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Their‌ ‌offspring‌ ‌would‌ ‌have‌ ‌(in‌ ‌principle)‌ ‌a‌ ‌calculable‌ ‌F.‌ ‌ ‌\n○All‌ ‌populations‌ ‌are‌ ‌to‌ ‌some‌ ‌degree‌ ‌\"inbred,\"‌ ‌as‌ ‌measured‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌average‌ ‌F‌ ‌over‌ ‌all‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌population,‌ ‌and‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌inversely‌ ‌\nproportional‌ ‌to‌ ‌its‌ ‌size‌ ‌N.‌ ‌\"Inbreeding\"‌ ‌becomes‌ ‌of‌ ‌special‌ ‌interest‌ ‌when‌ ‌the‌ ‌rate‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriages‌ ‌between‌ ‌closely-related‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌is‌ ‌\nhigher‌ ‌than‌ ‌expected.‌ ‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌may‌ ‌occur‌ ‌deliberately‌ ‌in‌ ‌societies‌ ‌where‌ ‌sib-sib‌ ‌or‌ ‌first-cousin‌ ‌marriages‌ ‌are‌ ‌encouraged,‌ ‌as‌ ‌sometimes‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌for‌ ‌religious‌ ‌\nreasons,‌ ‌or‌ ‌to‌ ‌keep‌ ‌property‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌family.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Western‌ ‌societies‌ ‌often‌ ‌discourage‌ ‌first-cousin‌ ‌marriages,‌ ‌but‌ ‌attach‌ ‌no‌ ‌onus‌ ‌to‌ ‌marriages‌ ‌between‌ ‌second-‌ ‌or‌ ‌higher-degree‌ ‌\ncousins;‌ ‌most‌ ‌people‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌unaware‌ ‌of‌ ‌fourth-‌ ‌or‌ ‌fifth-degree‌ ‌cousins.‌ ‌\n●From‌ ‌a‌ ‌strictly‌ ‌biological‌ ‌point‌ ‌of‌ ‌view,‌ ‌the‌ ‌term‌ ‌is‌ ‌inappropriate‌ ‌(as‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌terms‌ ‌mixed‌ ‌blood‌ ‌and‌ ‌good‌ ‌blood),‌ ‌because‌ ‌the‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌\ncontributions‌ ‌of‌ ‌ancestors‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌passed‌ ‌on‌ ‌to‌ ‌their‌ ‌descendants‌ ‌as‌ ‌blood‌ ‌but‌ ‌through‌ ‌genes‌ ‌contained‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌chromosomes.‌ ‌\n●From‌ ‌a‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌perspective,‌ ‌consanguinity‌ ‌influences‌ ‌the‌ ‌probabilities‌ ‌of‌ ‌specific‌ ‌combinations‌ ‌of‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌characteristics‌ ‌called‌ ‌genotypes.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Consanguinity‌ ‌results‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌inheritance,‌ ‌from‌ ‌common‌ ‌ancestors‌ ‌of‌ ‌both‌ ‌parents,‌ ‌of‌ ‌transmissible‌ ‌capacities‌ ‌to‌ ‌synthesize‌ ‌and‌ ‌control‌ ‌\nnucleic‌ ‌acids‌ ‌and‌ ‌proteins,‌ ‌the‌ ‌essential‌ ‌substances‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌organisms.‌ ‌\n ‌\nConsanguinity‌ ‌\nDefinition‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌consanguineous‌ ‌marriage/mating‌ ‌is‌ ‌considered‌ ‌as‌ ‌being‌ ‌between‌ ‌two‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌who‌ ‌are‌ ‌1st‌ ‌to‌ ‌4th‌ ‌degree‌ ‌relatives,‌ ‌when‌ ‌considering‌ ‌\n1st‌ ‌degree‌ ‌relatives‌ ‌the‌ ‌term‌ ‌incestuous‌ ‌marriage/mating‌ ‌(or‌ ‌simply‌ ‌incest)‌ ‌is‌ ‌often‌ ‌used.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌degree‌ ‌to‌ ‌which‌ ‌two‌ ‌people‌ ‌are‌ ‌related‌ ‌is‌ ‌usually‌ ‌measured‌ ‌via‌ ‌the‌ ‌Coefficient‌ ‌of‌ ‌Relatedness‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌coefficient‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌consanguinity.‌ ‌ ‌\nNote:Coefficient‌ ‌of‌ ‌Relatedness‌ ‌discussed‌ ‌below‌ ‌\n844‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌value‌ ‌generated‌ ‌represents‌ ‌the‌ ‌proportion‌ ‌of‌ ‌identical‌ ‌by‌ ‌descent‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌that‌ ‌two‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌will‌ ‌share.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nEffect‌ ‌of‌ ‌Consanguinity‌ ‌\n ‌\n845‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nNon-consanguineous‌ ‌mating‌ ‌\nNon‌ ‌Consanguineous‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌is‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌between‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌who‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌closely‌ ‌related.‌ ‌ ‌\n846‌ ‌\n ‌\nGenetic‌ ‌Load‌ ‌\n●Genetic‌ ‌variability‌ ‌pertains‌ ‌to‌ ‌many‌ ‌advantages‌ ‌and‌ ‌disadvantages,‌ ‌many‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌genes‌ ‌maintained‌ ‌by‌ ‌natural‌ ‌selection‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌population‌ ‌are‌ ‌\ndisadvantageous‌ ‌to‌ ‌it‌ ‌if‌ ‌their‌ ‌carriers‌ ‌are‌ ‌in‌ ‌homozygous‌ ‌state.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌concept‌ ‌of‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌load‌ ‌was‌ ‌given‌ ‌by‌ ‌‌Haldane‌ ‌and‌ ‌Muller.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌hovers‌ ‌around‌ ‌an‌ ‌idea‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌genotypes‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌population‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌mixture‌ ‌where‌ ‌one‌ ‌is‌ ‌better‌ ‌than‌ ‌the‌ ‌other.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Genetic‌ ‌load‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌measure‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌disadvantageous‌ ‌genes‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌population‌ ‌or‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌damage‌ ‌done‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌population‌ ‌by‌ ‌certain‌ ‌\ngenetic‌ ‌factors.‌ ‌Disadvantageous‌ ‌genes‌ ‌reduce‌ ‌fitness‌ ‌by‌ ‌mortality,‌ ‌morbidity‌ ‌or‌ ‌sterility‌ ‌in‌ ‌heterozygotes,‌ ‌if‌ ‌the‌ ‌gene‌ ‌is‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌and‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nhomozygotes,‌ ‌if‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌recessive.‌ ‌Thus,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌Darwinian‌ ‌fitness.‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌accompanies‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌loss‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌portion‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌death‌ ‌as‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌probability‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌organism‌ ‌failing‌ ‌to‌ ‌reach‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nreproductive‌ ‌age.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌fact‌ ‌is‌ ‌important‌ ‌to‌ ‌study‌ ‌by‌ ‌scientists‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌population‌ ‌with‌ ‌too‌ ‌high‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌load‌ ‌will‌ ‌be‌ ‌in‌ ‌danger‌ ‌of‌ ‌going‌ ‌extinct‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌organism‌ ‌is‌ ‌\nunable‌ ‌to‌ ‌survive‌ ‌and‌ ‌reproduce‌ ‌viable‌ ‌offspring.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nDefinition‌ ‌of‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌load‌ ‌‌:‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌decrease‌ ‌in‌ ‌fitness‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌average‌ ‌individual‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌population‌ ‌relative‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌fittest‌ ‌genotype‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌presence‌ ‌of‌ ‌deleterious‌ ‌genes‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌gene‌ ‌pool.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌difference‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌average‌ ‌fitness‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌population‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌fitness‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌best‌ ‌genotype(‌(Malthusian)‌ ‌fitness)‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌measures‌ ‌the‌ ‌probability‌ ‌of‌ ‌selective‌ ‌death‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌population.‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌comparative‌ ‌study‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌offspring‌ ‌of‌ ‌consanguineous‌ ‌and‌ ‌non-consanguineous‌ ‌marriages‌ ‌can‌ ‌provide‌ ‌useful‌ ‌information‌ ‌on‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌load‌ ‌\ndue‌ ‌to‌ ‌disadvantageous‌ ‌genes.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌number‌ ‌and‌ ‌proportion‌ ‌of‌ ‌homozygous‌ ‌offspring‌ ‌are‌ ‌relatively‌ ‌high‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌result‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌mating.‌ ‌\n●Genetic‌ ‌load‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌number‌ ‌between‌ ‌0‌ ‌and‌ ‌1‌ ‌and‌ ‌it‌ ‌measures‌ ‌the‌ ‌extent‌ ‌to‌ ‌which‌ ‌the‌ ‌average‌ ‌individual‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌population‌ ‌is‌ ‌inferior‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nbest‌ ‌possible‌ ‌kind‌ ‌of‌ ‌individual.‌ ‌\n● ‌The‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌load‌ ‌equals‌ ‌the‌ ‌relative‌ ‌chance‌ ‌that‌ ‌an‌ ‌average‌ ‌individual‌ ‌will‌ ‌die‌ ‌before‌ ‌reproducing‌ ‌because‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌deleterious‌ ‌genes‌ ‌\nthat‌ ‌it‌ ‌possesses.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Ignoring‌ ‌frequency-dependent‌ ‌selection,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌calculated‌ ‌as‌ ‌follows:‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nExample:‌ ‌\n847‌ ‌\n ‌\nTwo‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌(A‌ ‌and‌ ‌a)‌ ‌with‌ ‌frequencies‌ ‌p‌ ‌=‌ ‌q‌ ‌=‌ ‌0.5:‌ ‌\n ‌\nThe‌ ‌relative‌ ‌fitness‌ ‌values‌ ‌are:‌ ‌\nAA‌ ‌=‌ ‌0.8‌ ‌\nAa‌ ‌=‌ ‌1‌ ‌\naa‌ ‌=‌ ‌0.6‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nThe‌ ‌mean‌ ‌fitness‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌population‌ ‌=‌ ‌0.25(0.8)‌ ‌+‌ ‌0.25*2(1)‌ ‌+‌ ‌0.25(0.6)‌ ‌=‌ ‌0.85‌ ‌\nThe‌ ‌load‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌population‌ ‌(L)‌ ‌=‌ ‌1‌ ‌–‌ ‌0.85‌ ‌=‌ ‌0.15‌ ‌\n[Note‌ ‌that‌ ‌if‌ ‌every‌ ‌member‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌population‌ ‌had‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌genotype‌ ‌the‌ ‌average‌ ‌fitnes‌ ‌would‌ ‌equal‌ ‌1‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌load‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌population‌ ‌would‌ ‌\nbe‌ ‌zero.]‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Selective‌ ‌death‌ ‌(or‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌death):‌ ‌‌the‌ ‌chance‌ ‌that‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌will‌ ‌die‌ ‌without‌ ‌reproducing‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌consequence‌ ‌of‌ ‌natural‌ ‌selection.‌ ‌\n[e.g.,15%‌ ‌of‌ ‌offspring‌ ‌in‌ ‌above]‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nCauses‌ ‌of‌ ‌Genetic‌ ‌Load‌ ‌\n●Mutational‌ ‌load‌ ‌\n848‌ ‌\n○Genetic‌ ‌loads‌ ‌are‌ ‌affected‌ ‌by‌ ‌mutation,‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌negative‌ ‌as‌ ‌more‌ ‌mutations‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌genome‌ ‌are‌ ‌deleterious‌ ‌than‌ ‌advantageous.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Mutational‌ ‌load‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌defined‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌extent‌ ‌to‌ ‌which‌ ‌a‌ ‌population‌ ‌is‌ ‌impaired‌ ‌by‌ ‌recurrent‌ ‌mutation.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Mutational‌ ‌load‌ ‌is‌ ‌larger‌ ‌in‌ ‌big‌ ‌populations‌ ‌with‌ ‌positive‌ ‌selection‌ ‌because‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌more‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌that‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌potential‌ ‌carriers‌ ‌of‌ ‌\ndeleterious‌ ‌genes‌ ‌and‌ ‌can‌ ‌pass‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌over‌ ‌generations.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌positive‌ ‌selection‌ ‌the‌ ‌genome‌ ‌undergoes‌ ‌changes‌ ‌and‌ ‌also‌ ‌restores‌ ‌the‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌beneficial‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌population.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌mutational‌ ‌load‌ ‌has‌ ‌two‌ ‌components:‌ ‌one‌ ‌produced‌ ‌by‌ ‌deleterious‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌produced‌ ‌by‌ ‌beneficial‌ ‌mutations.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Both‌ ‌the‌ ‌components‌ ‌of‌ ‌mutational‌ ‌load‌ ‌arises‌ ‌because‌ ‌an‌ ‌ideal‌ ‌population‌ ‌consist‌ ‌of‌ ‌individual‌ ‌homozygous‌ ‌for‌ ‌both‌ ‌beneficial‌ ‌as‌ ‌\nwell‌ ‌as‌ ‌deleterious‌ ‌gene‌ ‌\n●Segregational‌ ‌Load‌ ‌ ‌\n○Segregation‌ ‌leads‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌formation‌ ‌of‌ ‌different‌ ‌genotypes,‌ ‌of‌ ‌which‌ ‌some‌ ‌are‌ ‌less‌ ‌fit.‌ ‌ ‌\n○There‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌a‌ ‌heterozygous‌ ‌advantage‌ ‌also‌ ‌as‌ ‌in‌ ‌balanced‌ ‌polymorphism.‌ ‌Blood‌ ‌group‌ ‌incompatibility‌ ‌is‌ ‌another‌ ‌component‌ ‌of‌ ‌\ngenetic‌ ‌load.‌ ‌ ‌\n○One‌ ‌should‌ ‌note‌ ‌the‌ ‌differential‌ ‌fitness‌ ‌of‌ ‌some‌ ‌genotypes‌ ‌under‌ ‌different‌ ‌environmental‌ ‌conditions.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌segregational‌ ‌or‌ ‌the‌ ‌balancing‌ ‌load‌ ‌comes‌ ‌into‌ ‌play‌ ‌when‌ ‌a‌ ‌population‌ ‌is‌ ‌segregating‌ ‌less‌ ‌fit‌ ‌homozygotes‌ ‌because‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nheterozygote‌ ‌advantage‌ ‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌a‌ ‌gene‌ ‌with‌ ‌two‌ ‌alleles,‌ ‌segregational‌ ‌load‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌computed.‌ ‌E.g‌ ‌sickle‌ ‌cell‌ ‌anemia‌ ‌\n●Inbreeding‌ ‌ ‌\n○Inbreeding‌ ‌increases‌ ‌the‌ ‌rate‌ ‌of‌ ‌homozygosity,‌ ‌an‌ ‌inbreeding‌ ‌depression‌ ‌will‌ ‌be‌ ‌observed‌ ‌when‌ ‌the‌ ‌offspring‌ ‌receive‌ ‌two‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌deleterious‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌resulting‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌lower‌ ‌fitness.‌ ‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌declining‌ ‌population‌ ‌will‌ ‌experience‌ ‌a‌ ‌high‌ ‌rate‌ ‌of‌ ‌mutation.‌ ‌An‌ ‌increase‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌rate‌ ‌of‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌in‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌will‌ ‌increase‌ ‌the‌ ‌pairing‌ ‌\nfrequency‌ ‌of‌ ‌alleles.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Due‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌decline‌ ‌in‌ ‌population‌ ‌because‌ ‌of‌ ‌higher‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌rate,‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌chance‌ ‌of‌ ‌mating‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌remaining‌ ‌organism‌ ‌to‌ ‌breed‌ ‌\nwith‌ ‌their‌ ‌relatives‌ ‌and‌ ‌it‌ ‌will‌ ‌help‌ ‌in‌ ‌pushing‌ ‌out‌ ‌some‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌harmful‌ ‌mutations‌ ‌ ‌\n●Migration‌ ‌ ‌\n○Migrational‌ ‌load‌ ‌results‌ ‌when‌ ‌an‌ ‌organism‌ ‌non-adaptive‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌environment‌ ‌comes‌ ‌in‌ ‌contact‌ ‌with‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌adapted‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nthat‌ ‌environment.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌offspring‌ ‌produced‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌result‌ ‌of‌ ‌such‌ ‌mating‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌as‌ ‌fit‌ ‌as‌ ‌they‌ ‌would‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌if‌ ‌both‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌parents‌ ‌were‌ ‌adapted‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nsame‌ ‌environment.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌offspring‌ ‌will‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌lower‌ ‌variability‌ ‌rate‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌lower‌ ‌overall‌ ‌fitness‌ ‌and‌ ‌higher‌ ‌will‌ ‌be‌ ‌the‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌load‌ ‌if‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌are‌ ‌\nfrom‌ ‌remarkably‌ ‌different‌ ‌environments.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nGenetic‌ ‌effect‌ ‌of‌ ‌consanguineous‌ ‌and‌ ‌cousin‌ ‌mating‌ ‌\n ‌\nIntroduction‌ ‌\n849‌ ‌\n●Consanguinity‌ ‌is‌ ‌both‌ ‌a‌ ‌social‌ ‌and‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌concept.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌degree‌ ‌of‌ ‌relatedness‌ ‌between‌ ‌two‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌defines‌ ‌the‌ ‌proportion‌ ‌of‌ ‌genes‌ ‌shared‌ ‌between‌ ‌them.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌offspring‌ ‌of‌ ‌consanguineous‌ ‌couples‌ ‌are‌ ‌at‌ ‌increased‌ ‌risk‌ ‌for‌ ‌‌autosomal‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌disorders‌‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌their‌ ‌increased‌ ‌risk‌ ‌for‌ ‌\nhomozygosity‌ ‌by‌ ‌descent.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Consanguinity‌ ‌can‌ ‌complicate‌ ‌pedigree‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌when‌ ‌a‌ ‌provider‌ ‌is‌ ‌unaware‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌presence‌ ‌of‌ ‌consanguinity‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌time‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌\nevaluating‌ ‌the‌ ‌pedigree,‌ ‌and‌ ‌what‌ ‌appears‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌an‌ ‌autosomal‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌is‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌an‌ ‌autosomal‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌\ndisease‌ ‌phenotype.‌ ‌\n ‌\nInherited‌ ‌Diseases‌ ‌\n●Mendel‌ ‌identified‌ ‌two‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌of‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌of‌ ‌traits‌ ‌which‌ ‌he‌ ‌explained‌ ‌as‌ ‌being‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌some‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌being‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌while‌ ‌others‌ ‌are‌ ‌\nrecessive,‌ ‌explained‌ ‌by‌ ‌his‌ ‌Laws‌ ‌of‌ ‌Inheritance.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌of‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌were‌ ‌seen‌ ‌to‌ ‌only‌ ‌be‌ ‌accurate‌ ‌for‌ ‌autosomes‌ ‌and‌ ‌not‌ ‌genes‌ ‌carried‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌sex‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌therefore‌ ‌diseases‌ ‌\ninherited‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌manner‌ ‌true‌ ‌to‌ ‌either‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌are‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to‌ ‌as‌ ‌autosomal‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌or‌ ‌autosomal‌ ‌recessive.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌addition‌ ‌to‌ ‌being‌ ‌inherited‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌Mendelian‌ ‌fashion‌ ‌some‌ ‌diseases‌ ‌display‌ ‌Extrachromosomal‌ ‌and‌ ‌Non-Mendelian‌ ‌Inheritance.‌ ‌\n850‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nDegree‌ ‌of‌ ‌inbreeding‌ ‌\n851‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌normally‌ ‌measured‌ ‌as‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌Coefficient‌ ‌of‌ ‌Inbreeding(f).‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌coefficient‌ ‌of‌ ‌inbreeding‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌probability‌ ‌that‌ ‌two‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌at‌ ‌any‌ ‌locus‌ ‌in‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌are‌ ‌identical‌ ‌by‌ ‌\ndescent‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌common‌ ‌ancestor(s)‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌two‌ ‌parents‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌coefficient‌ ‌is‌ ‌of‌ ‌medical‌ ‌significance‌ ‌when‌ ‌considering‌ ‌autosomal‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌conditions‌ ‌and‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌load.‌ ‌The‌ ‌phenomenon‌ ‌by‌ ‌\nwhich‌ ‌the‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌affected‌ ‌by‌ ‌autosomal‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌disorders‌ ‌increases‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌inbreeding‌ ‌is‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to‌ ‌as‌ ‌inbreeding‌ ‌\ndepression‌ ‌and‌ ‌results‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌reduction‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌overall‌ ‌fitness‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌population.‌ ‌\n●Inbreeding‌ ‌is‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌create‌ ‌inbred‌ ‌strains‌ ‌of‌ ‌rats‌ ‌and‌ ‌mice‌ ‌(normally‌ ‌requires‌ ‌20‌ ‌generations‌ ‌of‌ ‌inbreeding)‌ ‌which‌ ‌are‌ ‌genetically‌ ‌\nidentical.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Members‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌inbred‌ ‌stain‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌genetically‌ ‌altered‌ ‌normally‌ ‌by‌ ‌knocking‌ ‌out‌ ‌or‌ ‌altering‌ ‌a‌ ‌single‌ ‌gene‌ ‌to‌ ‌observe‌ ‌its‌ ‌effect.‌ ‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌have‌ ‌provided‌ ‌a‌ ‌large‌ ‌deal‌ ‌of‌ ‌information‌ ‌about‌ ‌the‌ ‌function‌ ‌of‌ ‌specific‌ ‌genes.‌ ‌\n ‌\nInbreeding‌ ‌and‌ ‌pedigree‌ ‌construction‌ ‌\n●Measurement‌ ‌of‌ ‌inbreeding‌ ‌in‌ ‌terms‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌degree‌ ‌of‌ ‌consanguinity‌ ‌between‌ ‌two‌ ‌parents‌ ‌is‌ ‌another‌ ‌significant‌ ‌application‌ ‌of‌ ‌data‌ ‌on‌ ‌\nconsanguinity.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌‌coefficient‌ ‌of‌ ‌inbreeding‌ ‌(F)‌‌ ‌is‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌define‌ ‌the‌ ‌probability‌ ‌that‌ ‌two‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌will‌ ‌be‌ ‌identical‌ ‌and‌ ‌derived‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌forebear.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌application‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌principle‌ ‌is‌ ‌most‌ ‌easily‌ ‌demonstrated‌ ‌by‌ ‌example.‌ ‌ ‌\n○If‌ ‌a‌ ‌brother‌ ‌and‌ ‌sister‌ ‌married,‌ ‌their‌ ‌offspring‌ ‌would‌ ‌have‌ ‌one‌ ‌chance‌ ‌in‌ ‌four‌ ‌of‌ ‌inheriting‌ ‌a‌ ‌pair‌ ‌of‌ ‌identical‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌\ngrandparent.‌ ‌ ‌\n○With‌ ‌each‌ ‌further‌ ‌degree‌ ‌of‌ ‌consanguinity,‌ ‌the‌ ‌likelihood‌ ‌is‌ ‌halved,‌ ‌so‌ ‌that‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌child‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌mating‌ ‌between‌ ‌aunt‌ ‌and‌ ‌nephew‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nlikelihood‌ ‌of‌ ‌identical‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌would‌ ‌be‌ ‌1‌ ‌in‌ ‌8,‌ ‌and‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌child‌ ‌of‌ ‌first‌ ‌cousins,‌ ‌1‌ ‌in‌ ‌16.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌the‌ ‌construction‌ ‌of‌ ‌pedigrees,‌ ‌horizontal‌ ‌lines‌ ‌are‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌connect‌ ‌symbols‌ ‌of‌ ‌siblings‌ ‌and‌ ‌mates‌ ‌and‌ ‌vertical‌ ‌lines‌ ‌to‌ ‌connect‌ ‌parents‌ ‌with‌ ‌\ntheir‌ ‌offspring,‌ ‌with‌ ‌all‌ ‌inbreeding‌ ‌represented‌ ‌by‌ ‌one‌ ‌or‌ ‌more‌ ‌loops,‌ ‌each‌ ‌of‌ ‌which‌ ‌involves‌ ‌consanguinity.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌‌coefficient‌ ‌of‌ ‌inbreeding‌‌ ‌for‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌sum‌ ‌of‌ ‌that‌ ‌calculated‌ ‌for‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌loops‌ ‌that‌ ‌include‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual’s‌ ‌parents.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌‌ ‌inbreeding‌ ‌coefficient‌ ‌‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌population‌ ‌is‌ ‌calculated‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌average‌ ‌F‌ ‌values‌ ‌of‌ ‌its‌ ‌members.‌ ‌ ‌\n●High‌ ‌values‌ ‌of‌ ‌F‌ ‌are‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌small‌ ‌populations‌ ‌whose‌ ‌members‌ ‌marry‌ ‌one‌ ‌another‌ ‌over‌ ‌many‌ ‌generations.‌ ‌Such‌ ‌groups‌ ‌are‌ ‌called‌ ‌\nisolates.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nCoefficient‌ ‌of‌ ‌relatedness‌ ‌\n ‌\nIt‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌probability‌ ‌that‌ ‌two‌ ‌related‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌have‌ ‌inherited‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌allele‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌single‌ ‌locus‌ ‌/‌ ‌gene‌ ‌from‌ ‌their‌ ‌common‌ ‌\nancestor‌ ‌(such‌ ‌allele‌ ‌is‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to‌ ‌as‌ ‌IBD‌ ‌-‌ ‌identical‌ ‌by‌ ‌descent).‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nThe‌ ‌coefficient‌ ‌is‌ ‌calculated‌ ‌as‌ ‌follows:‌ ‌\n ‌\n852‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nwhere‌ ‌n‌ ‌represents‌ ‌the‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌steps‌ ‌in‌ ‌genealogy.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nCoefficient‌ ‌of‌ ‌inbreeding‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nIt‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌probability‌ ‌that‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌inherited‌ ‌both‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌particular‌ ‌locus‌ ‌/‌ ‌gene‌ ‌from‌ ‌a‌ ‌single‌ ‌ancestor.‌ ‌ ‌\nThe‌ ‌coefficient‌ ‌is‌ ‌calculated‌ ‌as‌ ‌follows:‌ ‌\n ‌\n853‌ ‌\n ‌\nwhere‌ ‌n‌ ‌represents‌ ‌the‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌steps‌ ‌in‌ ‌genealogy.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n854‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nConsequences‌ ‌of‌ ‌Inbreeding‌ ‌ ‌\n●One‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌important‌ ‌aspects‌ ‌of‌ ‌inbreeding‌ ‌is‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌increases‌ ‌the‌ ‌chance‌ ‌of‌ ‌some‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌with‌ ‌deleterious‌ ‌effects‌ ‌to‌ ‌get‌ ‌\nexpressed‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌inbred‌ ‌(the‌ ‌offspring‌ ‌of‌ ‌consanguineous‌ ‌marriages)‌ ‌which‌ ‌get‌ ‌transmitted‌ ‌from‌ ‌one‌ ‌or‌ ‌more‌ ‌common‌ ‌ancestors‌ ‌carrying‌ ‌\n(harbour)‌ ‌the‌ ‌rare‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌alleles.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Theoretically,‌ ‌inbreeding‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌population,‌ ‌in‌ ‌general,‌ ‌increases‌ ‌the‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌homozygotes‌ ‌at‌ ‌any‌ ‌autosomal‌ ‌locus.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌case‌ ‌of‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌Mendelian‌ ‌diseases‌ ‌this‌ ‌can‌ ‌lead‌ ‌to‌ ‌increased‌ ‌risk‌ ‌of‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌diseases‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌inbred‌ ‌children.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌logic,‌ ‌in‌ ‌case‌ ‌the‌ ‌alleles‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌deleterious‌ ‌in‌ ‌nature,‌ ‌but‌ ‌are‌ ‌advantageous,‌ ‌increase‌ ‌of‌ ‌such‌ ‌genes‌ ‌through‌ ‌inbreeding‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌\npopulation‌ ‌is‌ ‌expected‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌beneficial.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌consequence‌ ‌of‌ ‌inbreeding‌ ‌whether‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌deleterious‌ ‌or‌ ‌advantageous‌ ‌depends‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌status‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌allele‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌involved‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nexpression‌ ‌among‌ ‌the‌ ‌inbred‌ ‌and‌ ‌transmission‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌common‌ ‌ancestors.‌ ‌\n●Such‌ ‌cases‌ ‌pose‌ ‌health‌ ‌and‌ ‌survival‌ ‌problems‌ ‌of‌ ‌deleterious‌ ‌or‌ ‌debilitating‌ ‌diseases.‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌health‌ ‌and‌ ‌socio-economic‌ ‌burden‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌society‌ ‌and‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌country.‌ ‌Increase‌ ‌of‌ ‌deleterious‌ ‌characters‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌result‌ ‌of‌ ‌\ninbreeding‌ ‌is‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to‌ ‌as‌ ‌‌‘inbreeding‌ ‌load’.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Inbreeding‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌small‌ ‌population‌ ‌leads‌ ‌to‌ ‌decrease‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌diversity,‌ ‌and‌ ‌it‌ ‌may‌ ‌lead‌ ‌to‌ ‌decreased‌ ‌Darwinian‌ ‌fitness‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌\norganism.‌ ‌ ‌\n855‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌case‌ ‌if‌ ‌this‌ ‌results‌ ‌in‌ ‌less‌ ‌capability‌ ‌to‌ ‌survive‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌changing‌ ‌environment,‌ ‌or‌ ‌eco-niche,‌ ‌with‌ ‌inbreeding‌ ‌such‌ ‌characters‌ ‌will‌ ‌\neventually‌ ‌allow‌ ‌the‌ ‌species‌ ‌to‌ ‌extinction.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Such‌ ‌characters‌ ‌are‌ ‌supposed‌ ‌to‌ ‌have‌ ‌less‌ ‌Darwanian‌ ‌fitness.‌ ‌Such‌ ‌decline‌ ‌in‌ ‌reproductive‌ ‌performance‌ ‌and‌ ‌fitness‌ ‌with‌ ‌inbreeding‌ ‌\nin‌ ‌a‌ ‌population‌ ‌is‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to‌ ‌as‌ ‌‌‘inbreeding‌ ‌depression’.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nCounselling‌ ‌and‌ ‌Consanguineous‌ ‌Mating‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Preconception‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌counseling‌ ‌for‌ ‌consanguinity‌ ‌is‌ ‌considered‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌important‌ ‌pillars‌ ‌amongst‌ ‌the‌ ‌community‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌services‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nhighly‌ ‌consanguineous‌ ‌populations.‌ ‌\n●Premarital‌ ‌counseling‌ ‌is‌ ‌another‌ ‌increasingly‌ ‌demanded‌ ‌service‌ ‌in‌ ‌some‌ ‌countries‌ ‌and‌ ‌communities‌ ‌where‌ ‌consanguinity‌ ‌rates‌ ‌are‌ ‌still‌ ‌high‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌selective‌ ‌abortion‌ ‌of‌ ‌affected‌ ‌fetus‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌feasible‌ ‌and/or‌ ‌not‌ ‌acceptable.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Marriage‌ ‌in‌ ‌many‌ ‌such‌ ‌countries‌ ‌is‌ ‌regarded‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌family‌ ‌decision‌ ‌and‌ ‌not‌ ‌just‌ ‌the‌ ‌couple’s‌ ‌decision,‌ ‌although‌ ‌the‌ ‌frequency‌ ‌of‌ ‌“arranged‌ ‌\nmarriages”‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌declining‌ ‌in‌ ‌recent‌ ‌years‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌increasing‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌females‌ ‌reaching‌ ‌university‌ ‌level‌ ‌education‌ ‌which‌ ‌gives‌ ‌them‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nbroader‌ ‌choice‌ ‌of‌ ‌marriage‌ ‌partner.‌ ‌\n●Many‌ ‌marriages,‌ ‌whether‌ ‌both‌ ‌interfamilial‌ ‌and‌ ‌intrafamilial‌ ‌(consanguineous),‌ ‌are‌ ‌however‌ ‌still‌ ‌considered‌ ‌arranged‌ ‌marriages‌ ‌in‌ ‌some‌ ‌\ncommunities.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌populations‌ ‌with‌ ‌high‌ ‌consanguinity‌ ‌rates‌ ‌and‌ ‌common‌ ‌inherited‌ ‌blood‌ ‌disorders,‌ ‌community‌ ‌programs‌ ‌for‌ ‌premarital‌ ‌screening‌ ‌to‌ ‌detect‌ ‌\ncarriers‌ ‌of‌ ‌hemoglobinopathies‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌‌thalassemia‌‌ ‌and‌ ‌‌sickle‌ ‌cell‌ ‌anemia‌‌ ‌are‌ ‌in‌ ‌progress‌ ‌as‌ ‌for‌ ‌example‌ ‌in‌ ‌Jordan,‌ ‌Saudi‌ ‌Arabia,‌ ‌Iran,‌ ‌\nIraq,‌ ‌Bahrain‌ ‌and‌ ‌Turkey.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Carrier‌ ‌detection‌ ‌and‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌counseling‌ ‌programs‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌very‌ ‌successful‌ ‌in‌ ‌reducing‌ ‌the‌ ‌birth‌ ‌prevalence‌ ‌of‌ ‌inherited‌ ‌disorders‌ ‌in‌ ‌some‌ ‌\npopulations,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌in‌ ‌Iran.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n856‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nConclusion‌ ‌\n●Consanguinity‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌deeply‌ ‌rooted‌ ‌social‌ ‌trend‌ ‌with‌ ‌one‌ ‌billion‌ ‌people‌ ‌currently‌ ‌living‌ ‌in‌ ‌countries‌ ‌where‌ ‌consanguineous‌ ‌marriages‌ ‌are‌ ‌\ncustomary,‌ ‌and‌ ‌among‌ ‌them,‌ ‌one‌ ‌in‌ ‌every‌ ‌three‌ ‌marriages‌ ‌is‌ ‌between‌ ‌cousins.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌rising‌ ‌public‌ ‌awareness‌ ‌on‌ ‌possible‌ ‌preventive‌ ‌measures‌ ‌for‌ ‌congenital‌ ‌disorders‌ ‌has‌ ‌led‌ ‌to‌ ‌an‌ ‌augmentation‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌couples‌ ‌\nseeking‌ ‌preconception‌ ‌and‌ ‌premarital‌ ‌counseling‌ ‌on‌ ‌consanguinity.‌ ‌\n●Consanguineous‌ ‌marriages‌ ‌are‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌an‌ ‌increased‌ ‌risk‌ ‌for‌ ‌congenital‌ ‌malformations‌ ‌and‌ ‌autosomal‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌diseases,‌ ‌with‌ ‌\nsome‌ ‌resultant‌ ‌increased‌ ‌postnatal‌ ‌mortality‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌offspring‌ ‌of‌ ‌first‌ ‌cousin‌ ‌couples,‌ ‌but‌ ‌demographic‌ ‌and‌ ‌socioeconomic‌ ‌confounders‌ ‌need‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌be‌ ‌well‌ ‌controlled.‌ ‌ ‌\n●No‌ ‌major‌ ‌adverse‌ ‌associations‌ ‌with‌ ‌reproductive‌ ‌parameters‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌miscarriages‌ ‌and‌ ‌fertility‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌documented.‌ ‌ ‌\n857‌ ‌\n●Associations‌ ‌with‌ ‌quantitative‌ ‌traits‌ ‌and‌ ‌complex‌ ‌adult-onset‌ ‌diseases‌ ‌are‌ ‌vague‌ ‌and‌ ‌inconsistent,‌ ‌suggesting‌ ‌the‌ ‌importance‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nimplementing‌ ‌future‌ ‌research‌ ‌in‌ ‌this‌ ‌area.‌ ‌\n●To‌ ‌standardize‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌services,‌ ‌guidelines‌ ‌for‌ ‌screening‌ ‌consanguineous‌ ‌couples‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌offspring‌ ‌are‌ ‌needed.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Consideration‌ ‌could‌ ‌be‌ ‌given‌ ‌to‌ ‌screening‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌common‌ ‌autosomal‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌conditions‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌populations‌ ‌and‌ ‌communities.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌both‌ ‌high‌ ‌and‌ ‌low‌ ‌income‌ ‌countries,‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌capacity‌ ‌to‌ ‌provide‌ ‌health‌ ‌education‌ ‌for‌ ‌consanguinity‌ ‌at‌ ‌individual,‌ ‌family‌ ‌and‌ ‌community‌ ‌\nlevels‌ ‌delivered‌ ‌by‌ ‌primary‌ ‌health‌ ‌care‌ ‌personnel‌ ‌with‌ ‌preconception‌ ‌and‌ ‌premarital‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌counseling,‌ ‌and‌ ‌diagnosis.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Rather‌ ‌than‌ ‌discouraging‌ ‌consanguineous‌ ‌marriages‌ ‌in‌ ‌populations‌ ‌with‌ ‌long-held‌ ‌such‌ ‌tradition,‌ ‌ensuring‌ ‌access‌ ‌to‌ ‌preconception‌ ‌and‌ ‌\npremarital‌ ‌counseling‌ ‌services‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌logical‌ ‌way‌ ‌to‌ ‌proceed‌ ‌and‌ ‌more‌ ‌likely‌ ‌both‌ ‌to‌ ‌receive‌ ‌community‌ ‌acceptance‌ ‌and‌ ‌be‌ ‌successful‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nmaintaining‌ ‌and‌ ‌improving‌ ‌health.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Increasing‌ ‌public‌ ‌literacy‌ ‌on‌ ‌consanguinity‌ ‌could‌ ‌be‌ ‌achieved‌ ‌by‌ ‌providing‌ ‌proper‌ ‌education‌ ‌and‌ ‌training‌ ‌to‌ ‌primary‌ ‌health‌ ‌care‌ ‌workers‌ ‌on‌ ‌\nall‌ ‌health‌ ‌and‌ ‌social‌ ‌issues‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌consanguinity.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n9.4‌ ‌Chromosomes‌ ‌and‌ ‌chromosomal‌ ‌aberrations‌ ‌in‌ ‌man‌ ‌methodology-Part‌ ‌I‌ ‌\n(a)‌ ‌Numerical‌ ‌and‌ ‌structural‌ ‌aberrations‌ ‌(disorders).‌ ‌\n(b)‌ ‌Sex‌ ‌chromosomal‌ ‌aberration-‌ ‌Klinefelter‌ ‌(XXY),‌ ‌Turner‌ ‌(XO),‌ ‌Super‌ ‌female‌ ‌(XXX),‌ ‌intersex‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌syndromic‌ ‌disorders.‌ ‌\n ‌\nWhat‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌Genetic‌ ‌Disease?‌ ‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌disease‌ ‌is‌ ‌any‌ ‌disease‌ ‌caused‌ ‌by‌ ‌an‌ ‌abnormality‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌makeup‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌abnormality‌ ‌can‌ ‌range‌ ‌from‌ ‌minuscule‌ ‌to‌ ‌major‌ ‌--‌ ‌from‌ ‌a‌ ‌discrete‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌single‌ ‌base‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌DNA‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌single‌ ‌gene‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌\ngross‌ ‌chromosomal‌ ‌abnormality‌ ‌involving‌ ‌the‌ ‌addition‌ ‌or‌ ‌subtraction‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌entire‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌or‌ ‌set‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosomes.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Some‌ ‌people‌ ‌inherit‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌disorders‌ ‌from‌ ‌their‌ ‌parents,‌ ‌while‌ ‌acquired‌ ‌changes‌ ‌or‌ ‌mutations‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌preexisting‌ ‌gene‌ ‌or‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌genes‌ ‌\ncause‌ ‌other‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌diseases.‌ ‌ ‌\n858‌ ‌\n●Genetic‌ ‌mutations‌ ‌can‌ ‌occur‌ ‌either‌ ‌randomly‌ ‌or‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌some‌ ‌environmental‌ ‌exposure.‌ ‌\n ‌\n859‌ ‌\nDiagram‌ ‌featuring‌ ‌Genetic‌ ‌disorder‌ ‌located‌ ‌on‌ ‌each‌ ‌Chromosome‌ ‌\n ‌\nFOUR‌ ‌TYPES‌ ‌OF‌ ‌GENETIC‌ ‌DISORDERS‌ ‌(INHERITED)‌ ‌\n●There‌ ‌are‌ ‌a‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌different‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌disorders‌ ‌(inherited)‌ ‌and‌ ‌include:‌ ‌\n○Single‌ ‌gene‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌\n○Multifactorial‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌\n○Chromosome‌ ‌abnormalities‌ ‌\n○Mitochondrial‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌\n ‌\nSingle‌ ‌gene‌ ‌inheritance:‌ ‌‌Single-gene‌ ‌disorders‌ ‌have‌ ‌different‌ ‌patterns‌ ‌of‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌inheritance,‌ ‌including:‌ ‌\n●Autosomal‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌inheritance‌,‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌only‌ ‌one‌ ‌copy‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌defective‌ ‌gene‌ ‌(from‌ ‌either‌ ‌parent)‌ ‌is‌ ‌necessary‌ ‌to‌ ‌cause‌ ‌the‌ ‌condition;‌ ‌\n●Autosomal‌ ‌recessive‌ ‌inheritance‌,‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌two‌ ‌copies‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌defective‌ ‌gene‌ ‌(one‌ ‌from‌ ‌each‌ ‌parent)‌ ‌are‌ ‌necessary‌ ‌to‌ ‌cause‌ ‌the‌ ‌condition;‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌\n●X-linked‌ ‌inheritance‌,‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌the‌ ‌defective‌ ‌gene‌ ‌is‌ ‌present‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌female,‌ ‌or‌ ‌X-chromosome.‌ ‌X-linked‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌dominant‌ ‌or‌ ‌\nrecessive.‌ ‌\n●Some‌ ‌examples‌ ‌of‌ ‌single-gene‌ ‌disorders‌ ‌include‌ ‌\n○Cystic‌ ‌fibrosis,‌ ‌\n○Alpha-‌ ‌and‌ ‌beta-thalassemias,‌ ‌\n860‌ ‌\n○Sickle‌ ‌cell‌ ‌anemia‌ ‌(sickle‌ ‌cell‌ ‌disease),‌ ‌\n○Marfan‌ ‌syndrome,‌ ‌\n○Fragile‌ ‌X‌ ‌syndrome,‌ ‌\n○Huntington's‌ ‌disease,‌ ‌and‌ ‌\n○Hemochromatosis.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nMultifactorial‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌\n●Multifactorial‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌called‌ ‌complex‌ ‌or‌ ‌polygenic‌ ‌inheritance.‌ ‌ ‌\n861‌ ‌\n●Multifactorial‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌disorders‌ ‌are‌ ‌caused‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌combination‌ ‌of‌ ‌environmental‌ ‌factors‌ ‌and‌ ‌mutations‌ ‌in‌ ‌multiple‌ ‌genes.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Examples‌ ‌of‌ ‌multifactorial‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌include‌ ‌\n○heart‌ ‌disease,‌ ‌\n○high‌ ‌blood‌ ‌pressure,‌ ‌\n○Alzheimer's‌ ‌disease,‌ ‌\n○arthritis,‌ ‌\n○diabetes,‌ ‌\n○cancer,‌ ‌and‌ ‌\n○obesity.‌ ‌\n ‌\nChromosome‌ ‌abnormalities‌ ‌\n●Chromosomes‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌carriers‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌material,‌ ‌abnormalities‌ ‌in‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌number‌ ‌or‌ ‌structure‌ ‌can‌ ‌result‌ ‌in‌ ‌disease.‌ ‌ ‌\n862‌ ‌\n●Chromosomal‌ ‌abnormalities‌ ‌‌typically‌ ‌occur‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌problem‌ ‌with‌ ‌cell‌ ‌division.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●There‌ ‌are‌ ‌many‌ ‌other‌ ‌chromosomal‌ ‌abnormalities‌ ‌including:‌ ‌\n○Down‌ ‌syndrome‌‌ ‌(sometimes‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to‌ ‌as‌ ‌\"Down's‌ ‌syndrome\")‌ ‌or‌ ‌trisomy‌ ‌21‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌common‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌disorder‌ ‌that‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌when‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nperson‌ ‌has‌ ‌three‌ ‌copies‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌21.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Turner‌ ‌syndrome‌‌ ‌(45,X0),‌ ‌\n○Klinefelter‌ ‌syndrome‌‌ ‌(47,‌ ‌XXY),‌ ‌and‌ ‌\n863‌ ‌\n○Cri‌ ‌du‌ ‌chat‌ ‌syndrome‌,‌ ‌or‌ ‌the‌ ‌\"cry‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌cat\"‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌(46,‌ ‌XX‌ ‌or‌ ‌XY,‌ ‌5p-).‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Diseases‌ ‌may‌ ‌also‌ ‌occur‌ ‌because‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosomal‌ ‌translocation‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌portions‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌are‌ ‌exchanged.‌ ‌\n●How‌ ‌Chromosomes‌ ‌Get‌ ‌Stuck‌ ‌Together‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌consists‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌arms‌ ‌connected‌ ‌by‌ ‌something‌ ‌called‌ ‌a‌ ‌centromere.‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌human‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌13,‌ ‌14,‌ ‌15,‌ ‌21‌ ‌and‌ ‌22,‌ ‌one‌ ‌arm‌ ‌is‌ ‌very‌ ‌short‌ ‌and‌ ‌contains‌ ‌very‌ ‌little‌ ‌useful‌ ‌information.‌ ‌These‌ ‌are‌ ‌called‌ ‌\nacrocentric‌ ‌chromosomes.‌  ‌ ‌\n864‌ ‌\n ‌\n865‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nMitochondrial‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌disorder‌ ‌is‌ ‌caused‌ ‌by‌ ‌mutations‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌non-nuclear‌ ‌DNA‌ ‌of‌ ‌mitochondria.‌ ‌\n○Mitochondria‌ ‌are‌ ‌small‌ ‌round‌ ‌or‌ ‌rod-like‌ ‌organelles‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌involved‌ ‌in‌ ‌cellular‌ ‌respiration‌ ‌and‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌cytoplasm‌ ‌of‌ ‌plant‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nanimal‌ ‌cells.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Each‌ ‌mitochondrion‌ ‌may‌ ‌contain‌ ‌5‌ ‌to‌ ‌10‌ ‌circular‌ ‌pieces‌ ‌of‌ ‌DNA.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Since‌ ‌egg‌ ‌cells,‌ ‌but‌ ‌not‌ ‌sperm‌ ‌cells,‌ ‌keep‌ ‌their‌ ‌mitochondria‌ ‌during‌ ‌fertilization,‌ ‌mitochondrial‌ ‌DNA‌ ‌is‌ ‌mostly‌ ‌inherited‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌female‌ ‌\nparent.‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌common‌ ‌notion‌ ‌that‌ ‌mitochondrial‌ ‌DNA‌ ‌is‌ ‌largely‌ ‌derived‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌ovum.‌ ‌ ‌\n866‌ ‌\n○However,‌ ‌there‌ ‌were‌ ‌recent‌ ‌reports‌ ‌and‌ ‌cases‌ ‌of‌ ‌mitochondrial‌ ‌diseases‌ ‌that‌ ‌indicate‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌of‌ ‌paternal‌ ‌mitochondrial‌ ‌DNA.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nExamples‌ ‌of‌ ‌mitochondrial‌ ‌disease‌ ‌include:‌ ‌\n●Leber's‌ ‌hereditary‌ ‌optic‌ ‌atrophy‌ ‌(LHON)‌,‌ ‌an‌ ‌eye‌ ‌disease;‌ ‌\n●myoclonic‌ ‌epilepsy‌ ‌with‌ ‌ragged‌ ‌red‌ ‌fibers‌ ‌(MERRF);‌‌ ‌and‌ ‌\n●mitochondrial‌ ‌encephalopathy,‌ ‌lactic‌ ‌acidosis,‌ ‌and‌ ‌stroke-like‌ ‌episodes‌ ‌(MELAS),‌ ‌a‌ ‌rare‌ ‌form‌ ‌of‌ ‌dementia.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nVarious‌ ‌Nomenclature‌ ‌\n ‌\nSyndrome‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌collection‌ ‌of‌ ‌recognizable‌ ‌traits‌ ‌or‌ ‌abnormalities‌ ‌that‌ ‌tend‌ ‌to‌ ‌occur‌ ‌together‌ ‌and‌ ‌are‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌specific‌ ‌disease.‌ ‌ ‌\n867‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌is‌ ‌really‌ ‌a‌ ‌collection‌ ‌of‌ ‌traits‌ ‌or‌ ‌distinctive‌ ‌features‌ ‌that‌ ‌run‌ ‌together.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Most‌ ‌syndromes‌ ‌are‌ ‌named‌ ‌after‌ ‌the‌ ‌physician‌ ‌who‌ ‌first‌ ‌noticed‌ ‌them‌ ‌in‌ ‌people.‌ ‌So‌ ‌that,‌ ‌for‌ ‌instance,‌ ‌Down‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌condition‌ ‌that‌ ‌\nwas‌ ‌first‌ ‌noticed‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌‌Dr.‌ ‌Down‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Marfan‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌condition‌ ‌that‌ ‌was‌ ‌first‌ ‌noticed‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌‌Dr.‌ ‌Marfan‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n●There‌ ‌are‌ ‌a‌ ‌whole‌ ‌list‌ ‌of‌ ‌these,‌ ‌or‌ ‌really‌ ‌hundreds‌ ‌and‌ ‌hundreds‌ ‌of‌ ‌syndromes‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌described‌ ‌mostly‌ ‌over‌ ‌the‌ ‌last‌ ‌150‌ ‌years‌ ‌or‌ ‌so‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nmedicine,‌ ‌and‌ ‌often‌ ‌named‌ ‌after‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual‌ ‌who‌ ‌first‌ ‌noted‌ ‌that‌ ‌these‌ ‌traits‌ ‌tended‌ ‌to‌ ‌run‌ ‌together.‌ ‌\n●Medical‌ ‌syndromes‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌caused‌ ‌by‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌mutations‌ ‌or‌ ‌other‌ ‌factors.‌ ‌\n ‌\nDisease‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌disease‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌medical‌ ‌condition‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌body‌ ‌which‌ ‌disrupts‌ ‌the‌ ‌normal‌ ‌functioning‌ ‌and‌ ‌physiological‌ ‌processes.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Each‌ ‌disease‌ ‌has‌ ‌its‌ ‌own‌ ‌signs‌ ‌and‌ ‌symptoms‌ ‌attributed‌ ‌to‌ ‌it.‌ ‌It‌ ‌is‌ ‌generally‌ ‌accepted‌ ‌that‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌four‌ ‌kinds‌ ‌of‌ ‌diseases‌ ‌–‌ ‌pathogenic,‌ ‌\nhereditary,‌ ‌physiological‌ ‌and‌ ‌deficiency.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌basic‌ ‌difference‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌two‌ ‌terms‌ ‌relates‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌symptoms‌ ‌that‌ ‌they‌ ‌produce.‌ ‌\n868‌ ‌\n● ‌A‌ ‌disease‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌defined‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌health‌ ‌condition‌ ‌that‌ ‌has‌ ‌a‌ ‌clearly‌ ‌defined‌ ‌reason‌ ‌behind‌ ‌it.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nSyndrome‌ ‌vs‌ ‌Disease‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌(from‌ ‌the‌ ‌Greek‌ ‌word‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌‘run‌ ‌together’)‌ ‌however,‌ ‌may‌ ‌produce‌ ‌a‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌symptoms‌ ‌without‌ ‌an‌ ‌identifiable‌ ‌cause.‌ ‌A‌ ‌\nsyndrome‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌symptoms,‌ ‌while‌ ‌a‌ ‌disease‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌an‌ ‌established‌ ‌condition.‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌disease‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌condition‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌marked‌ ‌by‌ ‌3‌ ‌basic‌ ‌factors.‌ ‌\n○An‌ ‌established‌ ‌biological‌ ‌cause‌ ‌behind‌ ‌the‌ ‌condition‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌defined‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌symptoms‌ ‌\n○Consistent‌ ‌change‌ ‌in‌ ‌anatomy‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌condition‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌have‌ ‌any‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌features.‌ ‌Even‌ ‌the‌ ‌symptoms‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌present‌ ‌are‌ ‌usually‌ ‌not‌ ‌consistent,‌ ‌and‌ ‌definitely‌ ‌not‌ ‌\ntraceable‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌single‌ ‌cause.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌symptom‌ ‌caused‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌have‌ ‌an‌ ‌established‌ ‌reason‌ ‌behind‌ ‌it.‌ ‌In‌ ‌case‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌disease,‌ ‌the‌ ‌cause‌ ‌is‌ ‌identified.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Treatment‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌is‌ ‌mainly‌ ‌symptomatic.‌ ‌In‌ ‌case‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌disease,‌ ‌the‌ ‌underlying‌ ‌cause‌ ‌is‌ ‌treated.‌ ‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌disease‌ ‌causes‌ ‌changes‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌anatomy;‌ ‌a‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌may‌ ‌not‌ ‌produce‌ ‌any‌ ‌such‌ ‌changes.‌ ‌\n ‌\nDisorder‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌disruption‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌disease‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌normal‌ ‌or‌ ‌regular‌ ‌functions‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌body‌ ‌or‌ ‌a‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌body.‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌example‌,‌ ‌a‌ ‌disorder‌ ‌resulting‌ ‌from‌ ‌cardiovascular‌ ‌disease‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌arrhythmia‌ ‌or‌ ‌irregular‌ ‌heartbeat.‌ ‌\n869‌ ‌\n●An‌ ‌‌arrhythmia‌‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌a‌ ‌disease‌ ‌itself‌ ‌–‌ ‌it’s‌ ‌an‌ ‌abnormal‌ ‌heartbeat‌ ‌that‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌result‌ ‌of‌ ‌having‌ ‌cardiovascular‌ ‌disease.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Disorders‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌classified‌ ‌into‌ ‌the‌ ‌following‌ ‌areas:‌ ‌\n○Mental‌ ‌\n○Physical‌ ‌\n○Genetic‌ ‌\n○Emotional‌ ‌\n○Behavioral‌ ‌\n○Structural‌ ‌\n○Condition‌ ‌\n●An‌ ‌abnormal‌ ‌state‌ ‌of‌ ‌health‌ ‌that‌ ‌interferes‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌usual‌ ‌activities‌ ‌or‌ ‌feeling‌ ‌of‌ ‌wellbeing‌ ‌\n●Sometimes,‌ ‌a‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌caused‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌diseases‌ ‌or‌ ‌it‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌a‌ ‌medical‌ ‌condition‌ ‌itself.‌ ‌ ‌\n●For‌ ‌example,‌ ‌chronic‌ ‌fatigue‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌neurological‌ ‌condition,‌ ‌diagnosed‌ ‌from‌ ‌a‌ ‌collection‌ ‌of‌ ‌symptoms‌ ‌in‌ ‌addition‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌main‌ ‌symptom‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌post-exertional‌ ‌malaise.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nThe‌ ‌Nomenclature‌ ‌of‌ ‌Chromosomes‌ ‌ ‌\n●There‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌standard‌ ‌used‌ ‌among‌ ‌cytogeneticists‌ ‌for‌ ‌ordering‌ ‌and‌ ‌numbering‌ ‌chromosomes,‌ ‌referring‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌bands‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌chromosome,‌ ‌and‌ ‌\ndescribing‌ ‌any‌ ‌chromosomal‌ ‌abnormalities.‌ ‌\n●Humans‌ ‌have‌ ‌23‌ ‌pairs‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosomes.‌ ‌ ‌\n870‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌are‌ ‌divided‌ ‌into‌ ‌the‌ ‌sex‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌(i.e.,‌ ‌the‌ ‌X‌ ‌and‌ ‌Y‌ ‌chromosome)‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌autosomes‌ ‌(i.e.,‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌22‌ ‌pairs).‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n●The‌ ‌term‌ ‌autosomal‌ ‌is‌ ‌frequently‌ ‌encountered‌ ‌in‌ ‌genetics‌ ‌to‌ ‌refer‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌gene‌ ‌or‌ ‌chromosomal‌ ‌anomaly‌ ‌involving‌ ‌an‌ ‌autosome.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌autosomes‌ ‌are‌ ‌ordered‌ ‌by‌ ‌height,‌ ‌position‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌centromere‌ ‌(the‌ ‌region‌ ‌separating‌ ‌the‌ ‌two‌ ‌arms‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌chromosome),‌ ‌and‌ ‌banding‌ ‌\npatterns.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Banding‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌\n871‌ ‌\n○Chromosome‌ ‌banding‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌alternating‌ ‌light‌ ‌and‌ ‌dark‌ ‌regions‌ ‌along‌ ‌the‌ ‌length‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌chromosome,‌ ‌produced‌ ‌after‌ ‌staining‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌\ndye.‌ ‌\n○G-banding‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌benchmark‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌routine‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌of‌ ‌human‌ ‌chromosomes,‌ ‌producing‌ ‌a‌ ‌characteristic‌ ‌light‌ ‌and‌ ‌dark‌ ‌banding‌ ‌\npattern‌ ‌along‌ ‌the‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌\n■Each‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌has‌ ‌a‌ ‌characteristic‌ ‌black‌ ‌and‌ ‌white‌ ‌banding‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌and‌ ‌has‌ ‌a‌ ‌constriction‌ ‌(called‌ ‌a‌ ‌centromere)‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌\ncharacteristic‌ ‌location‌ ‌somewhere‌ ‌along‌ ‌its‌ ‌length.‌ ‌ ‌\n■These‌ ‌two‌ ‌things,‌ ‌the‌ ‌banding‌ ‌pattern‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌centromere,‌ ‌make‌ ‌each‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌recognizable‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌trained‌ ‌eye.‌ ‌\n○As‌ ‌the‌ ‌centromere‌ ‌of‌ ‌each‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌exactly‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌middle‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌chromosome.‌ ‌This‌ ‌makes‌ ‌the‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌appear‌ ‌as‌ ‌if‌ ‌it‌ ‌\nhad‌ ‌two‌ ‌distinct‌ ‌segments‌ ‌of‌ ‌unequal‌ ‌length.‌ ‌These‌ ‌segments‌ ‌are‌ ‌called‌ ‌arms.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌shorter‌ ‌arm‌ ‌(called‌ ‌“p”‌ ‌for‌ ‌petit)‌ ‌is‌ ‌always‌ ‌shown‌ ‌on‌ ‌top.‌ ‌The‌ ‌longer‌ ‌arm‌ ‌is‌ ‌called‌ ‌the‌ ‌“q”‌ ‌arm‌ ‌and‌ ‌is‌ ‌shown‌ ‌below‌ ‌the‌ ‌\np‌ ‌arm.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌bands‌ ‌on‌ ‌each‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌arm‌ ‌divide‌ ‌it‌ ‌up‌ ‌into‌ ‌regions.‌ ‌The‌ ‌regions‌ ‌are‌ ‌numbered‌ ‌starting‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌centromere‌ ‌and‌ ‌progressing‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌the‌ ‌end‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌arm.‌ ‌Below‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌diagram‌ ‌that‌ ‌shows‌ ‌how‌ ‌the‌ ‌bands‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌are‌ ‌labeled.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌bands‌ ‌depends‌ ‌upon‌ ‌the‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌staining‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌particular‌ ‌stage‌ ‌of‌ ‌cell‌ ‌division‌ ‌at‌ ‌which‌ ‌the‌ ‌cells‌ ‌are‌ ‌arrested‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nculture‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○Bands‌ ‌are‌ ‌denoted‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌number,‌ ‌arm,‌ ‌and‌ ‌band‌ ‌number(s).‌ ‌ ‌\n■For‌ ‌example‌,‌ ‌ ‌\n■15q11-13‌ ‌denotes‌ ‌bands‌ ‌11‌ ‌through‌ ‌13‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌long‌ ‌arm‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌\n872‌ ‌\n■Deletions‌ ‌in‌ ‌this‌ ‌region‌ ‌can‌ ‌result‌ ‌in‌ ‌Prader-Willi‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌or‌ ‌Angelman‌ ‌syndrome.‌ ‌\n ‌\n873‌ ‌\n ‌\n874‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nKaryotype‌ ‌&‌ ‌Idiogram‌ ‌\n ‌\n875‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Karyotypes‌ ‌are‌ ‌abbreviated‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌total‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosomes,‌ ‌a‌ ‌comma,‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌sex‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual.‌ ‌ ‌\n○T‌he‌ ‌notation‌ ‌46,XX‌ ‌denotes‌ ‌a‌ ‌normal‌ ‌female‌;‌ ‌ ‌\n○46,XY,‌ ‌a‌ ‌normal‌ ‌male;‌ ‌and‌ ‌ ‌\n○45,X‌ ‌(or‌ ‌sometimes‌ ‌25,XO)‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌who‌ ‌has‌ ‌only‌ ‌one‌ ‌X‌ ‌chromosome,‌ ‌a‌ ‌condition‌ ‌that‌ ‌produces‌ ‌Turner’s‌ ‌syndrome.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Karyotypes‌ ‌followed‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌plus‌ ‌and‌ ‌then‌ ‌a‌ ‌number‌ ‌indicate‌ ‌trisomy,‌ ‌the‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌whole‌ ‌extra‌ ‌chromosome.‌ ‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌example‌,‌ ‌ ‌\n■47,XX,+21‌ ‌denotes‌ ‌a‌ ‌female‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌trisomy‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌21‌ ‌which‌ ‌results‌ ‌in‌ ‌Down‌ ‌syndrome.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Similarly,‌ ‌a‌ ‌minus‌ ‌sign‌ ‌followed‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌number‌ ‌denotes‌ ‌monosomy‌ ‌or‌ ‌the‌ ‌loss‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌entire‌ ‌chromosome.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n876‌ ‌\n ‌Chromosomes‌ ‌and‌ ‌chromosomal‌ ‌aberrations‌ ‌in‌ ‌man‌ ‌methodology.‌ ‌\n ‌\nChromosomal‌ ‌Aberrations‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nWhat‌ ‌is‌ ‌Chromosomal‌ ‌Aberration?‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌chromosomal‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌that‌ ‌involves‌ ‌changes‌ ‌in‌ ‌gross‌ ‌morphology‌ ‌or‌ ‌architecture‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌chromosomal‌ ‌\naberration.‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌structural‌ ‌abnormality‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosomes.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌generally‌ ‌remains‌ ‌unchanged‌ ‌but‌ ‌during‌ ‌certain‌ ‌conditions‌ ‌leading‌ ‌to‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌causes‌ ‌certain‌ ‌changes‌ ‌in‌ ‌structure‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌which‌ ‌may‌ ‌result‌ ‌in‌ ‌loss‌ ‌or‌ ‌gain‌ ‌of‌ ‌genes‌ ‌or‌ ‌rearrangement‌ ‌of‌ ‌position‌ ‌of‌ ‌genes.‌ ‌\n●There‌ ‌are‌ ‌many‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌aberrations.‌ ‌However,‌ ‌they‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌organized‌ ‌into‌ ‌two‌ ‌basic‌ ‌groups:‌ ‌ ‌\n○Numerical‌ ‌aberration‌ ‌and‌ ‌ ‌\n○Structural‌ ‌aberration‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nImpact‌ ‌\n●Because‌ ‌chromosomal‌ ‌anomalies‌ ‌involve‌ ‌inheritance‌ ‌of‌ ‌extra‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌material‌ ‌or‌ ‌the‌ ‌deletion‌ ‌of‌ ‌important‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌material,‌ ‌the‌ ‌vast‌ ‌majority‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌them‌ ‌are‌ ‌lethal‌ ‌and‌ ‌result‌ ‌in‌ ‌spontaneous‌ ‌abortion.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Nevertheless,‌ ‌conceptions‌ ‌that‌ ‌involve‌ ‌chromosomal‌ ‌anomalies‌ ‌are‌ ‌surprisingly‌ ‌common.‌ ‌ ‌\n●About‌ ‌15%‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌recognized‌ ‌pregnancies‌ ‌terminate‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌spontaneous‌ ‌abortion‌ ‌and‌ ‌over‌ ‌half‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌involve‌ ‌identifiable‌ ‌chromosomal‌ ‌\nabnormalities.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌percentage‌ ‌of‌ ‌aberrations‌ ‌in‌ ‌unrecognized‌ ‌pregnancies‌ ‌(i.e.,‌ ‌those‌ ‌involving‌ ‌spontaneous‌ ‌abortion‌ ‌before‌ ‌pregnancy‌ ‌testing)‌ ‌is‌ ‌thought‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌be‌ ‌even‌ ‌higher.‌ ‌ ‌\n877‌ ‌\n●Clearly,‌ ‌chromosomal‌ ‌aberrations‌ ‌encountered‌ ‌at‌ ‌or‌ ‌shortly‌ ‌after‌ ‌birth‌ ‌represent‌ ‌the‌ ‌tip‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌iceberg‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌perspective‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌human‌ ‌\nconceptions.‌ ‌\n ‌\nBackground‌ ‌\n ‌\nHow‌ ‌do‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌abnormalities‌ ‌happen?‌ ‌\n●Disorders‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌number‌ ‌are‌ ‌caused‌ ‌by‌ ‌‌nondisjunction,‌‌ ‌which‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌when‌ ‌pairs‌ ‌of‌ ‌homologous‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌or‌ ‌sister‌ ‌\nchromatids‌ ‌fail‌ ‌to‌ ‌separate‌ ‌during‌ ‌meiosis‌ ‌I‌ ‌or‌ ‌II‌ ‌(or‌ ‌during‌ ‌mitosis).‌ ‌\n●Most‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌abnormalities‌ ‌occur‌ ‌as‌ ‌an‌ ‌accident‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌egg‌ ‌or‌ ‌sperm.‌ ‌In‌ ‌these‌ ‌cases,‌ ‌the‌ ‌abnormality‌ ‌is‌ ‌present‌ ‌in‌ ‌every‌ ‌cell‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nbody.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Some‌ ‌abnormalities,‌ ‌however,‌ ‌happen‌ ‌after‌ ‌conception;‌ ‌then‌ ‌some‌ ‌cells‌ ‌have‌ ‌the‌ ‌abnormality‌ ‌and‌ ‌some‌ ‌do‌ ‌not.‌ ‌\n●Chromosome‌ ‌abnormalities‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌inherited‌ ‌from‌ ‌a‌ ‌parent‌ ‌(such‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌translocation)‌ ‌or‌ ‌be‌ ‌\"de‌ ‌novo\"‌ ‌(new‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌individual).‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌is‌ ‌why,‌ ‌when‌ ‌a‌ ‌child‌ ‌is‌ ‌found‌ ‌to‌ ‌have‌ ‌an‌ ‌abnormality,‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌studies‌ ‌are‌ ‌often‌ ‌performed‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌parents.‌ ‌\n●Chromosome‌ ‌abnormalities‌ ‌usually‌ ‌occur‌ ‌when‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌error‌ ‌in‌ ‌cell‌ ‌division.‌ ‌There‌ ‌are‌ ‌two‌ ‌kinds‌ ‌of‌ ‌cell‌ ‌division,‌ ‌mitosis‌ ‌and‌ ‌meiosis.‌ ‌\n○Mitosis‌ ‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌results‌ ‌in‌ ‌two‌ ‌cells‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌duplicates‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌original‌ ‌cell.‌ ‌ ‌\n■One‌ ‌cell‌ ‌with‌ ‌46‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌divides‌ ‌and‌ ‌becomes‌ ‌two‌ ‌cells‌ ‌with‌ ‌46‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌each.‌ ‌ ‌\n■This‌ ‌kind‌ ‌of‌ ‌cell‌ ‌division‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌throughout‌ ‌the‌ ‌body,‌ ‌except‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌reproductive‌ ‌organs.‌ ‌ ‌\n■This‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌way‌ ‌most‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌cells‌ ‌that‌ ‌make‌ ‌up‌ ‌our‌ ‌body‌ ‌are‌ ‌made‌ ‌and‌ ‌replaced.‌ ‌\n○Meiosis‌ ‌ ‌\n■It‌ ‌results‌ ‌in‌ ‌cells‌ ‌with‌ ‌half‌ ‌the‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosomes,‌ ‌23,‌ ‌instead‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌normal‌ ‌46.‌ ‌\n■This‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌cell‌ ‌division‌ ‌that‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌reproductive‌ ‌organs,‌ ‌resulting‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌eggs‌ ‌and‌ ‌sperm.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌both‌ ‌processes,‌ ‌the‌ ‌correct‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌is‌ ‌supposed‌ ‌to‌ ‌end‌ ‌up‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌resulting‌ ‌cells.‌ ‌ ‌\n●However,‌ ‌errors‌ ‌in‌ ‌cell‌ ‌division‌ ‌can‌ ‌result‌ ‌in‌ ‌cells‌ ‌with‌ ‌too‌ ‌few‌ ‌or‌ ‌too‌ ‌many‌ ‌copies‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌chromosome.‌ ‌Errors‌ ‌can‌ ‌also‌ ‌occur‌ ‌when‌ ‌the‌ ‌\nchromosomes‌ ‌are‌ ‌being‌ ‌duplicated.‌ ‌\n ‌\n878‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n879‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nMeiosis‌ ‌I‌ ‌\n880‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌diagram‌ ‌below‌ ‌shows‌ ‌how‌ ‌nondisjunction‌ ‌can‌ ‌take‌ ‌place‌ ‌during‌ ‌meiosis‌ ‌I‌ ‌if‌ ‌homologous‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌don't‌ ‌separate,‌ ‌and‌ ‌how‌ ‌this‌ ‌can‌ ‌\nlead‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌production‌ ‌of‌ ‌aneuploid‌ ‌gametes‌ ‌(eggs‌ ‌or‌
