‌sperm):‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nMeiosis‌ ‌II.‌‌ ‌Nondisjunction‌ ‌can‌ ‌also‌ ‌happen‌ ‌in‌ ‌meiosis‌ ‌II,‌ ‌with‌ ‌sister‌ ‌chromatids‌ ‌(instead‌ ‌of‌ ‌homologous‌ ‌chromosomes)‌ ‌failing‌ ‌to‌ ‌separate.‌ ‌Again,‌ ‌\nsome‌ ‌gametes‌ ‌contain‌ ‌extra‌ ‌or‌ ‌missing‌ ‌chromosomes:‌ ‌\n881‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nMitosis.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Nondisjunction‌ ‌can‌ ‌also‌ ‌happen‌ ‌during‌ ‌mitosis.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌humans,‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌changes‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌nondisjunction‌ ‌during‌ ‌mitosis‌ ‌in‌ ‌body‌ ‌cells‌ ‌will‌ ‌not‌ ‌be‌ ‌passed‌ ‌on‌ ‌to‌ ‌children‌ ‌(because‌ ‌these‌ ‌cells‌ ‌\ndon't‌ ‌make‌ ‌sperm‌ ‌and‌ ‌eggs).‌ ‌ ‌\n●But‌ ‌mitotic‌ ‌nondisjunction‌ ‌can‌ ‌cause‌ ‌other‌ ‌problems:‌ ‌cancer‌ ‌cells‌ ‌often‌ ‌have‌ ‌abnormal‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌numbers.‌ ‌\n ‌\nFertilization‌ ‌will‌ ‌result‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌zygote‌ ‌with‌ ‌‌Aneuploidy‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n(a)‌ ‌Numerical‌ ‌and‌ ‌structural‌ ‌aberrations‌ ‌(disorders)‌ ‌\n ‌\nNumerical‌ ‌Aberrations:‌ ‌ ‌\nBasics‌ ‌\n●Ploidy-Genomatic‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌chromosomal‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌the‌ ‌numerical‌ ‌changes‌ ‌in‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌or‌ ‌variation‌ ‌in‌ ‌chromosomal‌ ‌\nnumbers‌ ‌occurs,‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌numerical‌ ‌chromosomal‌ ‌aberration.‌ ‌ ‌\n882‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n883‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n○In‌ ‌normal‌ ‌somatic‌ ‌(body)‌ ‌cells,‌ ‌the‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌exist‌ ‌in‌ ‌pairs.‌ ‌The‌ ‌condition‌ ‌is‌ ‌called‌ ‌diploidy.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Each‌ ‌set‌ ‌is‌ ‌designated‌ ‌by‌ ‌n.‌ ‌Accordingly,‌ ‌one‌ ‌set‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosomes,‌ ‌1n,‌ ‌is‌ ‌described‌ ‌as‌ ‌‌monoploid.‌ ‌ ‌\n○During‌ ‌meiosis‌ ‌the‌ ‌cell‌ ‌produces‌ ‌gametes,‌ ‌or‌ ‌germ‌ ‌cells,‌ ‌each‌ ‌containing‌ ‌half‌ ‌the‌ ‌normal‌ ‌or‌ ‌somatic‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosomes.‌ ‌This‌ ‌\ncondition‌ ‌is‌ ‌called‌ ‌‌haploidy.‌ ‌ ‌\n■When‌ ‌two‌ ‌germ‌ ‌cells‌ ‌(e.g.,‌ ‌egg‌ ‌and‌ ‌sperm)‌ ‌unite,‌ ‌the‌ ‌diploid‌ ‌condition‌ ‌is‌ ‌restored.‌ ‌\n■However,‌ ‌the‌ ‌term‌ ‌haploid‌ ‌is‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌describe‌ ‌gametes‌ ‌that‌ ‌contain‌ ‌only‌ ‌half‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌set‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌usual‌ ‌sets‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌somatic‌ ‌cells‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌organism.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌union‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌‌haploid‌‌ ‌gametes,‌ ‌i.e.‌ ‌female‌ ‌and‌ ‌male‌ ‌gametes,‌ ‌gives‌ ‌rise‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌zygote‌ ‌with‌ ‌two‌ ‌sets‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌thereby‌ ‌\npreserving‌ ‌the‌ ‌original‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌number‌ ‌as‌ ‌that‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌parents.‌ ‌ ‌\n884‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌two‌ ‌sets‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌would‌ ‌be‌ ‌homologous‌ ‌chromosomes,‌ ‌i.e.‌ ‌the‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌female‌ ‌gamete‌ ‌would‌ ‌have‌ ‌the‌ ‌\ncorresponding‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌male‌ ‌gamete‌ ‌based‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌likeness‌ ‌of‌ ‌morphology‌ ‌and‌ ‌linear‌ ‌sequence‌ ‌of‌ ‌gene‌ ‌loci.‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌cell‌ ‌or‌ ‌the‌ ‌organism‌ ‌with‌ ‌two‌ ‌sets‌ ‌of‌ ‌homologous‌ ‌chromosomes,‌ ‌2n,‌ ‌is‌ ‌described‌ ‌as‌ ‌‌diploid.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Having‌ ‌multiple‌ ‌sets‌ ‌of‌ ‌paired‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌genome‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌organism‌ ‌is‌ ‌described‌ ‌as‌ ‌‌polyploid.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Three‌ ‌sets‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosomes,‌ ‌3n,‌ ‌is‌ ‌‌triploid‌‌ ‌whereas‌ ‌four‌ ‌sets‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosomes,‌ ‌4n,‌ ‌is‌ ‌tetraploid.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Extremely‌ ‌large‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌sets‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌designated‌ ‌by‌ ‌number‌ ‌(for‌ ‌example‌ ‌15-ploid‌ ‌for‌ ‌fifteen‌ ‌sets.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌organisms‌ ‌with‌ ‌two‌ ‌full‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌sets,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌humans,‌ ‌this‌ ‌number‌ ‌is‌ ‌given‌ ‌the‌ ‌name‌ ‌2n.‌ ‌ ‌\n●When‌ ‌an‌ ‌organism‌ ‌or‌ ‌cell‌ ‌contains‌ ‌2n‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌(or‌ ‌some‌ ‌other‌ ‌multiple‌ ‌of‌ ‌n),‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌said‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌‌euploid,‌‌ ‌meaning‌ ‌that‌ ‌it‌ ‌contains‌ ‌\nchromosomes‌ ‌correctly‌ ‌organized‌ ‌into‌ ‌complete‌ ‌sets‌ ‌(eu-‌ ‌=‌ ‌good).‌ ‌\n●If‌ ‌a‌ ‌cell‌ ‌is‌ ‌missing‌ ‌one‌ ‌or‌ ‌more‌ ‌chromosomes,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌said‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌‌aneuploid‌‌ ‌(an-‌ ‌=‌ ‌not,‌ ‌\"not‌ ‌good\").‌ ‌ ‌\n○For‌ ‌instance,‌ ‌human‌ ‌somatic‌ ‌cells‌ ‌with‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌numbers‌ ‌of‌ ‌‌(2‌n‌−1)=45‌ ‌or‌ ‌(2n‌ ‌+‌ ‌1)‌ ‌=‌ ‌47‌ ‌‌are‌ ‌‌aneuploid.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Similarly,‌ ‌a‌ ‌normal‌ ‌human‌ ‌egg‌ ‌or‌ ‌sperm‌ ‌has‌ ‌just‌ ‌one‌ ‌set‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌(n‌ ‌=‌ ‌23)‌ ‌\n○An‌ ‌egg‌ ‌or‌ ‌sperm‌ ‌with‌ ‌(n-1)‌ ‌=‌ ‌22(n−1)=22‌ ‌or‌ ‌(n+1)‌ ‌=‌ ‌24(n+1)=24‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌is‌ ‌considered‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌‌aneuploid.‌ ‌\n ‌\nAneuploidy‌ ‌\n●Some‌ ‌cells‌ ‌have‌ ‌an‌ ‌abnormal‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌a‌ ‌whole‌ ‌multiple‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌haploid‌ ‌number.‌ ‌ ‌\n■This‌ ‌condition,‌ ‌called‌ ‌aneuploidy,‌ ‌is‌ ‌most‌ ‌often‌ ‌caused‌ ‌by‌ ‌some‌ ‌error‌ ‌resulting‌ ‌in‌ ‌an‌ ‌unequal‌ ‌distribution‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌daughter‌ ‌cells.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Organisms‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌‌aneuploidy‌‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌may‌ ‌deviate‌ ‌noticeably‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌norm‌ ‌in‌ ‌appearance‌ ‌and‌ ‌behaviour.‌ ‌\n ‌\nWhen‌ ‌an‌ ‌aneuploid‌ ‌sperm‌ ‌or‌ ‌egg‌ ‌combines‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌normal‌ ‌sperm‌ ‌or‌ ‌egg‌ ‌in‌ ‌fertilization,‌ ‌it‌ ‌makes‌ ‌a‌ ‌zygote‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌\naneuploid.‌ ‌For‌ ‌instance,‌ ‌if‌ ‌a‌ ‌sperm‌ ‌cell‌ ‌with‌ ‌one‌ ‌extra‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌(‌n‌ ‌+‌ ‌1)‌ ‌‌combines‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌normal‌ ‌egg‌ ‌cell‌ ‌(n),‌ ‌the‌ ‌resulting‌ ‌\n885‌ ‌\nzygote,‌ ‌or‌ ‌one-celled‌ ‌embryo,‌ ‌will‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌(‌2n‌ ‌+1)‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Two‌ ‌common‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌aneuploidy‌ ‌have‌ ‌their‌ ‌own‌ ‌special‌ ‌names:‌ ‌\n○Monosomy‌ ‌‌is‌ ‌when‌ ‌an‌ ‌organism‌ ‌has‌ ‌only‌ ‌one‌ ‌copy‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌that‌ ‌should‌ ‌be‌ ‌present‌ ‌in‌ ‌two‌ ‌copies‌ ‌(2n-1)‌ ‌\n○Trisomy‌ ‌‌is‌ ‌when‌ ‌an‌ ‌organism‌ ‌has‌ ‌a‌ ‌third‌ ‌copy‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌that‌ ‌should‌ ‌be‌ ‌present‌ ‌in‌ ‌two‌ ‌copies‌ ‌(2n+1)‌ ‌\n●When‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌is‌ ‌missing‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌from‌ ‌a‌ ‌pair,‌ ‌the‌ ‌condition‌ ‌is‌ ‌called‌ ‌‌monosomy.‌ ‌ ‌\n886‌ ‌\n○An‌ ‌example‌ ‌of‌ ‌monosomy‌,‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌lacks‌ ‌a‌ ‌chromosome,‌ ‌is‌ ‌Turner‌ ‌syndrome.‌ ‌In‌ ‌Turner‌ ‌syndrome,‌ ‌a‌ ‌female‌ ‌is‌ ‌born‌ ‌\nwith‌ ‌only‌ ‌one‌ ‌sex‌ ‌chromosome,‌ ‌an‌ ‌X,‌ ‌and‌ ‌is‌ ‌usually‌ ‌shorter‌ ‌than‌ ‌average‌ ‌and‌ ‌unable‌ ‌to‌ ‌have‌ ‌children,‌ ‌among‌ ‌other‌ ‌difficulties.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●When‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌has‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌two‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌instead‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌pair,‌ ‌the‌ ‌condition‌ ‌is‌ ‌called‌ ‌‌trisomy.‌ ‌\n○An‌ ‌example‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌condition‌ ‌caused‌ ‌by‌ ‌numerical‌ ‌abnormalities‌ ‌is‌ ‌‌Down‌ ‌syndrome‌,‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌marked‌ ‌by‌ ‌mental‌ ‌retardation,‌ ‌learning‌ ‌\ndifficulties,‌ ‌a‌ ‌characteristic‌ ‌facial‌ ‌appearance‌ ‌and‌ ‌poor‌ ‌muscle‌ ‌tone‌ ‌‌(hypotonia)‌‌ ‌in‌ ‌infancy.‌ ‌ ‌\n○An‌ ‌individual‌ ‌with‌ ‌‌Down‌ ‌syndrome‌‌ ‌has‌ ‌three‌ ‌copies‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌21‌ ‌rather‌ ‌than‌ ‌two;‌ ‌for‌ ‌that‌ ‌reason,‌ ‌the‌ ‌condition‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌known‌ ‌\nas‌ ‌‌Trisomy‌ ‌21‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Aneuploidy‌ ‌also‌ ‌includes‌ ‌cases‌ ‌where‌ ‌a‌ ‌cell‌ ‌has‌ ‌larger‌ ‌numbers‌ ‌of‌ ‌extra‌ ‌or‌ ‌missing‌ ‌chromosomes,‌ ‌as‌ ‌in‌ ‌(2n‌ ‌-‌ ‌2),‌ ‌(2n‌ ‌+‌ ‌2)‌ ‌etc.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Classification‌ ‌of‌ ‌Aneuploidy‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●However,‌ ‌if‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌entire‌ ‌extra‌ ‌or‌ ‌missing‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌set‌ ‌(e.g.,‌ ‌3n),‌ ‌this‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌formally‌ ‌considered‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌aneuploidy,‌ ‌even‌ ‌though‌ ‌it‌ ‌\nmay‌ ‌still‌ ‌be‌ ‌bad‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌cell‌ ‌or‌ ‌organism.‌ ‌‌Organisms‌ ‌with‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌two‌ ‌complete‌ ‌sets‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌are‌ ‌said‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌‌Polyploid.‌ ‌\n887‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nAutopolyploidy‌ ‌vs‌ ‌Allopolyploidy‌ ‌\n●Autopolyploidy‌ ‌and‌ ‌allopolyploidy‌ ‌are‌ ‌two‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌anomaly‌ ‌that‌ ‌lead‌ ‌to‌ ‌polyploidy.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Polyploidy‌‌ ‌often‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌nondisjunction‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌during‌ ‌the‌ ‌cell‌ ‌division.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌nondisjunction‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌improper‌ ‌split‌ ‌of‌ ‌sister‌ ‌chromatids‌ ‌or‌ ‌homologous‌ ‌chromosomes,‌ ‌which‌ ‌may‌ ‌occur‌ ‌during‌ ‌the‌ ‌nuclear‌ ‌division.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌can‌ ‌occur‌ ‌naturally‌ ‌or‌ ‌under‌ ‌the‌ ‌influence‌ ‌of‌ ‌chemicals.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌main‌ ‌difference‌ ‌between‌ ‌autopolyploidy‌ ‌and‌ ‌allopolyploidy‌ ‌is‌ ‌that‌ ‌autopolyploidy‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌containment‌ ‌of‌ ‌multiple‌ ‌sets‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌\nthat‌ ‌are‌ ‌derived‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌species‌ ‌whereas‌ ‌allopolyploidy‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌containment‌ ‌of‌ ‌multiple‌ ‌sets‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌derived‌ ‌from‌ ‌\ndifferent‌ ‌species.‌ ‌\n●Similarities‌ ‌Between‌ ‌Autopolyploidy‌ ‌and‌ ‌Allopolyploidy‌ ‌\n○Autopolyploidy‌ ‌and‌ ‌allopolyploidy‌ ‌are‌ ‌two‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌cell‌ ‌division‌ ‌anomalies.‌ ‌\n○Both‌ ‌autopolyploidy‌ ‌and‌ ‌allopolyploidy‌ ‌occur‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌nondisjunction‌ ‌of‌ ‌sister‌ ‌chromatids‌ ‌or‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌during‌ ‌prophase‌ ‌1‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nprophase‌ ‌2‌ ‌respectively.‌ ‌\n○Both‌ ‌autopolyploidy‌ ‌and‌ ‌allopolyploidy‌ ‌lead‌ ‌to‌ ‌polyploidy‌ ‌where‌ ‌multiple‌ ‌sets‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌occur‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌nucleus.‌ ‌\n○Both‌ ‌autopolyploidy‌ ‌and‌ ‌allopolyploidy‌ ‌mostly‌ ‌occur‌ ‌in‌ ‌plants.‌ ‌\n○Both‌ ‌autopolyploidy‌ ‌and‌ ‌allopolyploidy‌ ‌can‌ ‌occur‌ ‌naturally‌ ‌or‌ ‌under‌ ‌the‌ ‌influence‌ ‌of‌ ‌chemicals‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌‌colchicine‌.‌ ‌\n ‌\n888‌ ‌\n●Difference‌ ‌Between‌ ‌Autopolyploidy‌ ‌and‌ ‌Allopolyploidy‌ ‌\n ‌\nDefinition‌ ‌\n○Autopolyploidy:‌‌ ‌Autopolyploidy‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌polyploidy‌ ‌where‌ ‌the‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌complement‌ ‌consists‌ ‌of‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌two‌ ‌copies‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌homologous‌ ‌chromosomes.‌ ‌\n○Allopolyploidy:‌‌ ‌Allopolyploidy‌ ‌refers‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌polyploidy‌ ‌where‌ ‌the‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌complement‌ ‌consists‌ ‌of‌ ‌more‌ ‌than‌ ‌two‌ ‌copies‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nchromosomes‌ ‌derived‌ ‌from‌ ‌different‌ ‌species.‌ ‌\n ‌\nArise‌ ‌\n○Autopolyploidy:‌ ‌‌Autopolyploidy‌ ‌arises‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌fusion‌ ‌of‌ ‌gametes‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌species.‌ ‌\n○Allopolyploidy:‌‌ ‌Allopolyploidy‌ ‌arises‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌fusion‌ ‌of‌ ‌gametes‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌different‌ ‌species.‌ ‌\n ‌\nConsist‌ ‌of‌ ‌\n○Autopolyploidy:‌ ‌‌An‌ ‌autopolyploid‌ ‌cell‌ ‌contains‌ ‌homologous‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌sets.‌ ‌\n○Allopolyploidy:‌‌ ‌All‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌sets‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌allopolyploid‌ ‌cell‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌homologous.‌ ‌\n ‌\nCause‌ ‌\n○Autopolyploidy:‌ ‌‌Autopolyploidy‌ ‌is‌ ‌mainly‌ ‌caused‌ ‌by‌ ‌nondisjunction‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosomes.‌ ‌\n○Allopolyploidy:‌‌ ‌Allopolyploidy‌ ‌is‌ ‌caused‌ ‌by‌ ‌mating‌ ‌of‌ ‌different‌ ‌species.‌ ‌\n ‌\nMeiosis‌ ‌\n○Autopolyploidy:‌‌ ‌An‌ ‌autopolyploid‌ ‌cell‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌undergo‌ ‌meiosis‌ ‌since‌ ‌it‌ ‌has‌ ‌arisen‌ ‌from‌ ‌one‌ ‌parent.‌ ‌\n○Allopolyploidy:‌‌ ‌An‌ ‌allopolyploid‌ ‌cell‌ ‌can‌ ‌undergo‌ ‌meiosis.‌ ‌\n ‌\nExamples‌ ‌\n○Autopolyploidy:‌ ‌‌Autopolyploidy‌ ‌is‌ ‌seen‌ ‌in‌ ‌crops‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌wheat,‌ ‌oats,‌ ‌sugar-cane,‌ ‌potato,‌ ‌peanut,‌ ‌banana,‌ ‌and‌ ‌coffee.‌ ‌\n○Allopolyploidy:‌‌ ‌Allopolyploidy‌ ‌is‌ ‌seen‌ ‌in‌ ‌crops‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌wheat‌ ‌and‌ ‌animals‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌mules.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Conclusion‌ ‌\n○Autopolyploidy‌ ‌and‌ ‌allopolyploidy‌ ‌are‌ ‌two‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌cell‌ ‌division‌ ‌anomalies,‌ ‌which‌ ‌lead‌ ‌to‌ ‌polyploidy.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Autopolyploidy‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌containment‌ ‌of‌ ‌multiple‌ ‌copies‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌parent.‌ ‌\n○Allopolyploidy‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌containment‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌multiple‌ ‌copies‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌of‌ ‌different‌ ‌species.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Autopolyploidy‌ ‌mainly‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌nondisjunction‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosomes.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Allopolyploidy‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌mating‌ ‌of‌ ‌different‌ ‌species.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌main‌ ‌difference‌ ‌between‌ ‌autopolyploidy‌ ‌and‌ ‌allopolyploidy‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌sets‌ ‌in‌ ‌their‌ ‌nucleus.‌ ‌\n ‌\n889‌ ‌\n ‌\nStructural‌ ‌Aberrations:‌ ‌ ‌\nA‌ ‌chromosome's‌ ‌structure‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌altered‌ ‌in‌ ‌several‌ ‌ways.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Structural‌ ‌abnormalities‌ ‌involves‌ ‌change‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌structure‌ ‌of‌ ‌one‌ ‌or‌ ‌more‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌these‌ ‌are‌ ‌three‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌common‌ ‌types:‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n●Deletions:‌ ‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌portion‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌is‌ ‌missing‌ ‌or‌ ‌deleted.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌effects‌ ‌are‌ ‌typically‌ ‌severe‌ ‌since‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌loss‌ ‌of‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌materials.‌ ‌\n●Duplications:‌ ‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌portion‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌is‌ ‌duplicated,‌ ‌resulting‌ ‌in‌ ‌extra‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌material.‌ ‌\n●Translocations:‌ ‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌portion‌ ‌of‌ ‌one‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌is‌ ‌transferred‌ ‌to‌ ‌another‌ ‌chromosome.‌ ‌ ‌\n○There‌ ‌are‌ ‌two‌ ‌main‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌translocation.‌ ‌ ‌\n■In‌ ‌a‌ ‌‌reciprocal‌ ‌translocation‌,‌ ‌segments‌ ‌from‌ ‌two‌ ‌different‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌exchanged.‌ ‌ ‌\n890‌ ‌\n■In‌ ‌a‌ ‌‌Robertsonian‌ ‌translocation,‌‌ ‌an‌ ‌entire‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌has‌ ‌attached‌ ‌to‌ ‌another‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌centromere.‌ ‌\n ‌\n○The‌ ‌risk‌ ‌of‌ ‌probability‌ ‌to‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌is‌ ‌same‌ ‌as‌ ‌inversion‌ ‌usually‌ ‌none‌ ‌if‌ ‌familial‌ ‌and‌ ‌slightly‌ ‌if‌ ‌denovo‌ ‌(new)‌ ‌\n●Inversions:‌ ‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌portion‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌has‌ ‌broken‌ ‌off,‌ ‌turned‌ ‌upside‌ ‌down,‌ ‌and‌ ‌reattached.‌ ‌ ‌\n○As‌ ‌a‌ ‌result,‌ ‌the‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌material‌ ‌is‌ ‌inverted.‌ ‌\n○There‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌risk‌ ‌for‌ ‌problems‌ ‌to‌ ‌an‌ ‌individual‌ ‌if‌ ‌the‌ ‌inversion‌ ‌is‌ ‌of‌ ‌familial‌ ‌origin‌ ‌(has‌ ‌been‌ ‌inherited‌ ‌from‌ ‌a‌ ‌parent)‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌slightly‌ ‌\nincreased‌ ‌risk‌ ‌if‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌new‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Rings:‌ ‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌portion‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌has‌ ‌broken‌ ‌off‌ ‌and‌ ‌formed‌ ‌a‌ ‌circle‌ ‌or‌ ‌ring.‌ ‌This‌ ‌can‌ ‌happen‌ ‌with‌ ‌or‌ ‌without‌ ‌loss‌ ‌of‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌material.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n891‌ ‌\n●Insertion‌ ‌\n○An‌ ‌interstitial‌ ‌segment‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌is‌ ‌deleted‌ ‌and‌ ‌transferred‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌new‌ ‌position‌ ‌in‌ ‌some‌ ‌other‌ ‌chromosome,‌ ‌or‌ ‌\noccasionally,‌ ‌into‌ ‌its‌ ‌homologue,‌ ‌or‌ ‌even‌ ‌somewhere‌ ‌else‌ ‌within‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌chromosome.‌ ‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌inserted‌ ‌segment‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌positioned‌ ‌with‌ ‌its‌ ‌original‌ ‌orientation‌ ‌(with‌ ‌respect‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌centromere)‌ ‌or‌ ‌inverted.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nBalanced‌ ‌Translocation‌ ‌\nSometimes‌ ‌two‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌break‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌two‌ ‌long‌ ‌arms‌ ‌get‌ ‌stuck‌ ‌together.‌ ‌The‌ ‌two‌ ‌short‌ ‌arms‌ ‌are‌ ‌lost‌ ‌but‌ ‌that’s‌ ‌OK.‌ ‌The‌ ‌person‌ ‌is‌ ‌\nperfectly‌ ‌fine.‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌is‌ ‌because‌ ‌they‌ ‌still‌ ‌have‌ ‌all‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌important‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌information:‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌just‌ ‌packaged‌ ‌differently.‌ ‌ ‌\n●And‌ ‌this‌ ‌kind‌ ‌of‌ ‌‌balanced‌ ‌translocation‌‌ ‌(as‌ ‌scientists‌ ‌call‌ ‌it)‌ ‌is‌ ‌more‌ ‌common.‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌‌balanced‌ ‌or‌ ‌chromosomal‌ ‌translocation‌‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌condition‌ ‌in‌ ‌which‌ ‌part‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌has‌ ‌broken‌ ‌off‌ ‌and‌ ‌reattached‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nanother‌ ‌location.‌ ‌ ‌\n○In‌ ‌other‌ ‌words,‌ ‌it‌ ‌means‌ ‌that‌ ‌sections‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌have‌ ‌switched‌ ‌places.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Around‌ ‌1‌ ‌in‌ ‌1000‌ ‌people‌ ‌have‌ ‌two‌ ‌of‌ ‌their‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌stuck‌ ‌together.‌ ‌They‌ ‌might‌ ‌not‌ ‌even‌ ‌know‌ ‌it‌ ‌until‌ ‌they‌ ‌start‌ ‌trying‌ ‌to‌ ‌have‌ ‌\nkids.‌ ‌\n ‌\nOther‌ ‌factors‌ ‌that‌ ‌can‌ ‌increase‌ ‌the‌ ‌risk‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌abnormalities‌ ‌are:‌ ‌\n●Maternal‌ ‌Age:‌ ‌ ‌\n○Women‌ ‌are‌ ‌born‌ ‌with‌ ‌all‌ ‌the‌ ‌eggs‌ ‌they‌ ‌will‌ ‌ever‌ ‌have.‌ ‌Some‌ ‌researchers‌ ‌believe‌ ‌that‌ ‌errors‌ ‌can‌ ‌crop‌ ‌up‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌eggs'‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌material‌ ‌\nas‌ ‌they‌ ‌age.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Older‌ ‌women‌ ‌are‌ ‌at‌ ‌higher‌ ‌risk‌ ‌of‌ ‌giving‌ ‌birth‌ ‌to‌ ‌babies‌ ‌with‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌abnormalities‌ ‌than‌ ‌younger‌ ‌women.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Because‌ ‌men‌ ‌produce‌ ‌new‌ ‌sperm‌ ‌throughout‌ ‌their‌ ‌lives,‌ ‌paternal‌ ‌age‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌increase‌ ‌risk‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌abnormalities.‌ ‌\n●Environment:‌ ‌ ‌\n892‌ ‌\n○Although‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌no‌ ‌conclusive‌ ‌evidence‌ ‌that‌ ‌specific‌ ‌environmental‌ ‌factors‌ ‌cause‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌abnormalities,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌still‌ ‌possible‌ ‌that‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌environment‌ ‌may‌ ‌play‌ ‌a‌ ‌role‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌occurrence‌ ‌of‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌errors.‌ ‌\n ‌\nTypes‌ ‌of‌ ‌Chromosomal‌ ‌Abnormalities:‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n(b)‌ ‌Sex‌ ‌chromosomal‌ ‌aberration-Klinefelter‌ ‌(XXY),‌ ‌Turner‌ ‌(XO),‌ ‌Super‌ ‌female‌ ‌(XXX),‌ ‌intersex‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌syndromic‌ ‌disorders‌ ‌\n ‌\nKlinefelter‌ ‌(XXY)‌ ‌\nWhat‌ ‌is‌ ‌Klinefelter‌ ‌(XXY)‌ ‌syndrome?‌ ‌\n●Klinefelter‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌condition‌ ‌that‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌in‌ ‌men‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌result‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌extra‌ ‌X‌ ‌chromosome.‌ ‌\n893‌ ‌\n○Most‌ ‌often,‌ ‌Klinefelter‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌result‌ ‌of‌ ‌one‌ ‌extra‌ ‌X‌ ‌(written‌ ‌as‌ ‌XXY).‌ ‌Occasionally,‌ ‌variations‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌XXY‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌count‌ ‌\nmay‌ ‌occur,‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌common‌ ‌being‌ ‌the‌ ‌XY/XXY‌ ‌mosaic.‌ ‌\n ‌\n○The‌ ‌additional‌ ‌sex‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌results‌ ‌from‌ ‌a‌ ‌random‌ ‌error‌ ‌during‌ ‌the‌ ‌formation‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌egg‌ ‌or‌ ‌sperm.‌ ‌ ‌\n○About‌ ‌half‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌time‌ ‌the‌ ‌error‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌formation‌ ‌of‌ ‌sperm,‌ ‌while‌ ‌the‌ ‌remainder‌ ‌are‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌errors‌ ‌in‌ ‌egg‌ ‌development.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Women‌ ‌who‌ ‌have‌ ‌pregnancies‌ ‌after‌ ‌age‌ ‌35‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌slightly‌ ‌increased‌ ‌chance‌ ‌of‌ ‌having‌ ‌a‌ ‌boy‌ ‌with‌ ‌this‌ ‌syndrome.‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌XXY‌ ‌condition‌ ‌(44‌ ‌autosomes‌ ‌+‌ ‌XXY)‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌in‌ ‌about‌ ‌1‌ ‌in‌ ‌1000‌ ‌newborn‌ ‌males.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nWhat‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌symptoms‌ ‌of‌ ‌Klinefelter‌ ‌syndrome?‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌patients‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌have‌ ‌some‌ ‌degree‌ ‌of‌ ‌mental‌ ‌retardation;‌ ‌growth‌ ‌and‌ ‌physical‌ ‌development‌ ‌are‌ ‌quite‌ ‌normal,‌ ‌but‌ ‌‌the‌ ‌affected‌ ‌\nmales‌ ‌are‌ ‌tending‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌tall‌ ‌for‌ ‌their‌ ‌age.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Puberty‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌occur‌ ‌normally‌ ‌and‌ ‌they‌ ‌remain‌ ‌sterile.‌ ‌\n●Other‌ ‌symptoms:‌ ‌ ‌\n○Small,‌ ‌firm‌ ‌testes,‌ ‌ ‌\n○A‌ ‌small‌ ‌penis,‌ ‌ ‌\n○Sparse‌ ‌pubic,‌ ‌armpit‌ ‌and‌ ‌facial‌ ‌hair,‌ ‌ ‌\n○Enlarged‌ ‌breasts‌ ‌(called‌ ‌gynecomastia),‌ ‌ ‌\n894‌ ‌\n○Tall‌ ‌stature,‌ ‌and‌ ‌ ‌\n○Abnormal‌ ‌body‌ ‌proportions‌ ‌(long‌ ‌legs,‌ ‌short‌ ‌trunk).‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nBabies‌ ‌\n●Weak‌ ‌muscles‌ ‌\n●Slow‌ ‌motor‌ ‌development‌ ‌—‌ ‌taking‌ ‌longer‌ ‌than‌ ‌average‌ ‌to‌ ‌sit‌ ‌up,‌ ‌crawl‌ ‌and‌ ‌walk‌ ‌\n●Delay‌ ‌in‌ ‌speaking‌ ‌\n●Problems‌ ‌at‌ ‌birth,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌testicles‌ ‌that‌ ‌haven't‌ ‌descended‌ ‌into‌ ‌the‌ ‌scrotum‌ ‌\n ‌\nBoys‌ ‌and‌ ‌teenagers‌ ‌\n●Taller‌ ‌than‌ ‌average‌ ‌stature‌ ‌\n●Longer‌ ‌legs,‌ ‌shorter‌ ‌torso‌ ‌and‌ ‌broader‌ ‌hips‌ ‌compared‌ ‌with‌ ‌other‌ ‌boys‌ ‌\n●Absent,‌ ‌delayed‌ ‌or‌ ‌incomplete‌ ‌puberty‌ ‌\n●After‌ ‌puberty,‌ ‌less‌ ‌muscle‌ ‌and‌ ‌less‌ ‌facial‌ ‌and‌ ‌body‌ ‌hair‌ ‌compared‌ ‌with‌ ‌other‌ ‌teens‌ ‌\n●Small,‌ ‌firm‌ ‌testicles‌ ‌\n●Small‌ ‌penis‌ ‌\n895‌ ‌\n●Enlarged‌ ‌breast‌ ‌tissue‌ ‌(gynecomastia)‌ ‌\n●Weak‌ ‌bones‌ ‌\n●Low‌ ‌energy‌ ‌levels‌ ‌\n●Tendency‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌shy‌ ‌and‌ ‌sensitive‌ ‌\n●Difficulty‌ ‌expressing‌ ‌thoughts‌ ‌and‌ ‌feelings‌ ‌or‌ ‌socializing‌ ‌\n●Problems‌ ‌with‌ ‌reading,‌ ‌writing,‌ ‌spelling‌ ‌or‌ ‌math‌ ‌\n ‌\nMen‌ ‌\n●Signs‌ ‌and‌ ‌symptoms‌ ‌may‌ ‌include:‌ ‌\n●Low‌ ‌sperm‌ ‌count‌ ‌or‌ ‌no‌ ‌sperm‌ ‌\n●Small‌ ‌testicles‌ ‌and‌ ‌penis‌ ‌\n●Low‌ ‌sex‌ ‌drive‌ ‌\n●Taller‌ ‌than‌ ‌average‌ ‌height‌ ‌\n●Weak‌ ‌bones‌ ‌\n●Decreased‌ ‌facial‌ ‌and‌ ‌body‌ ‌hair‌ ‌\n●Less‌ ‌muscular‌ ‌compared‌ ‌with‌ ‌other‌ ‌men‌ ‌\n●Enlarged‌ ‌breast‌ ‌tissue‌ ‌\n●Increased‌ ‌belly‌ ‌fat‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nRisk:‌ ‌\n●Klinefelter‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌is‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌an‌ ‌‌increased‌ ‌risk‌ ‌for‌ ‌breast‌ ‌cancer,‌ ‌a‌ ‌rare‌ ‌tumor‌ ‌called‌ ‌extragonadal‌ ‌germ‌ ‌cell‌ ‌tumor,‌ ‌lung‌ ‌disease,‌ ‌\nvaricose‌ ‌veins‌ ‌and‌ ‌osteoporosis.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Men‌ ‌who‌ ‌have‌ ‌Klinefelter‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌also‌ ‌have‌ ‌an‌ ‌increased‌ ‌risk‌ ‌for‌ ‌autoimmune‌ ‌disorders‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌lupus,‌ ‌rheumatoid‌ ‌arthritis‌ ‌and‌ ‌Sjogren's‌ ‌\nsyndrome.‌ ‌\n●About‌ ‌10‌ ‌percent‌ ‌of‌ ‌boys‌ ‌and‌ ‌men‌ ‌with‌ ‌Klinefelter‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌have‌ ‌autism‌ ‌spectrum‌ ‌disorder.‌ ‌\n●Nearly‌ ‌half‌ ‌of‌ ‌all‌ ‌men‌ ‌with‌ ‌Klinefelter‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌develop‌ ‌metabolic‌ ‌syndrome,‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌conditions‌ ‌that‌ ‌include‌ ‌type‌ ‌2‌ ‌diabetes,‌ ‌\nhigh‌ ‌blood‌ ‌pressure‌ ‌(hypertension),‌ ‌increased‌ ‌belly‌ ‌fat,‌ ‌high‌ ‌levels‌ ‌of‌ ‌fats‌ ‌(lipids)‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌cholesterol‌ ‌and‌ ‌triglycerides‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌blood.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nHow‌ ‌is‌ ‌Klinefelter‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌diagnosed?‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌chromosomal‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌(karyotype)‌ ‌is‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌confirm‌ ‌the‌ ‌diagnosis.‌ ‌In‌ ‌this‌ ‌procedure,‌ ‌a‌ ‌small‌ ‌blood‌ ‌sample‌ ‌is‌ ‌drawn.‌ ‌ ‌\n○White‌ ‌blood‌ ‌cells‌ ‌are‌ ‌then‌ ‌separated‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌sample,‌ ‌mixed‌ ‌with‌ ‌tissue‌ ‌culture‌ ‌medium,‌ ‌incubated,‌ ‌and‌ ‌checked‌ ‌for‌ ‌\nchromosomal‌ ‌abnormalities,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌an‌ ‌extra‌ ‌X‌ ‌chromosome.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌analysis‌ ‌looks‌ ‌at‌ ‌a‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌cells,‌ ‌usually‌ ‌at‌ ‌least‌ ‌20,‌ ‌which‌ ‌allows‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌diagnosis‌ ‌of‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌conditions‌ ‌\nin‌ ‌both‌ ‌the‌ ‌full‌ ‌and‌ ‌mosaic‌ ‌state.‌ ‌In‌ ‌some‌ ‌cases,‌ ‌low-level‌ ‌mosaicism‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌missed.‌ ‌ ‌\n●School-age‌ ‌children‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌diagnosed‌ ‌if‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌referred‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌doctor‌ ‌to‌ ‌evaluate‌ ‌learning‌ ‌disabilities.‌ ‌ ‌\n896‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌diagnosis‌ ‌may‌ ‌also‌ ‌be‌ ‌considered‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌adolescent‌ ‌male‌ ‌when‌ ‌puberty‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌progressing‌ ‌as‌ ‌expected.‌ ‌Adult‌ ‌males‌ ‌may‌ ‌come‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌the‌ ‌doctor‌ ‌because‌ ‌of‌ ‌infertility.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nHow‌ ‌is‌ ‌Klinefelter‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌treated?‌ ‌\n●Testosterone‌ ‌therapy‌‌ ‌is‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌increase‌ ‌strength,‌ ‌promote‌ ‌muscular‌ ‌development,‌ ‌grow‌ ‌body‌ ‌hair,‌ ‌improve‌ ‌mood‌ ‌and‌ ‌self‌ ‌esteem,‌ ‌\nincrease‌ ‌energy‌ ‌and‌ ‌improve‌ ‌concentration.‌ ‌\n●Most‌ ‌men‌ ‌who‌ ‌have‌ ‌Klinefelter‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌are‌ ‌not‌ ‌able‌ ‌to‌ ‌father‌ ‌children.‌ ‌ ‌\n●However,‌ ‌some‌ ‌men‌ ‌with‌ ‌an‌ ‌extra‌ ‌X‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌have‌ ‌fathered‌ ‌healthy‌ ‌offspring,‌ ‌sometimes‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌help‌ ‌of‌ ‌infertility‌ ‌specialists.‌ ‌\n●Most‌ ‌men‌ ‌who‌ ‌have‌ ‌Klinefelter‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌can‌ ‌expect‌ ‌to‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌normal‌ ‌and‌ ‌productive‌ ‌life.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Early‌ ‌diagnosis,‌ ‌in‌ ‌conjunction‌ ‌with‌ ‌educational‌ ‌interventions,‌ ‌medical‌ ‌management,‌ ‌and‌ ‌strong‌ ‌social‌ ‌support‌ ‌will‌ ‌optimize‌ ‌each‌ ‌individual's‌ ‌\npotential‌ ‌in‌ ‌adulthood.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nTurner‌ ‌(XO)‌ ‌\nWhat‌ ‌is‌ ‌Turner‌ ‌syndrome?‌ ‌\n●Turner‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌chromosomal‌ ‌condition‌ ‌that‌ ‌alters‌ ‌development‌ ‌in‌ ‌females.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌condition‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌in‌ ‌about‌ ‌1‌ ‌in‌ ‌2,500‌ ‌female‌ ‌births‌ ‌worldwide,‌ ‌but‌ ‌is‌ ‌much‌ ‌more‌ ‌common‌ ‌among‌ ‌pregnancies‌ ‌that‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌survive‌ ‌to‌ ‌term‌ ‌\n(miscarriages‌ ‌and‌ ‌stillbirths).‌ ‌\n●Turner‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌chromosomal‌ ‌condition‌ ‌related‌ ‌to‌ ‌the‌ ‌‌X‌ ‌chromosome‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n897‌ ‌\n ‌\nWhat‌ ‌are‌ ‌the‌ ‌symptoms‌ ‌of‌ ‌Turner‌ ‌syndrome?‌ ‌\n●Women‌ ‌with‌ ‌this‌ ‌condition‌ ‌tend‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌shorter‌ ‌than‌ ‌average‌ ‌and‌ ‌are‌ ‌usually‌ ‌unable‌ ‌to‌ ‌conceive‌ ‌a‌ ‌child‌ ‌(infertile)‌ ‌because‌ ‌of‌ ‌an‌ ‌absence‌ ‌of‌ ‌\novarian‌ ‌function.‌ ‌\n●Other‌ ‌features‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌condition‌ ‌that‌ ‌can‌ ‌vary‌ ‌among‌ ‌women‌ ‌who‌ ‌have‌ ‌Turner‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌include:‌ ‌\n○Extra‌ ‌skin‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌neck‌ ‌(webbed‌ ‌neck),‌ ‌\n○Puffiness‌ ‌or‌ ‌swelling‌ ‌(lymphedema)‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌hands‌ ‌and‌ ‌feet,‌ ‌ ‌\n○Skeletal‌ ‌abnormalities,‌ ‌\n○Heart‌ ‌defects‌ ‌and‌ ‌kidney‌ ‌problems.‌ ‌\n898‌ ‌\n ‌\n899‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Researchers‌ ‌have‌ ‌not‌ ‌yet‌ ‌determined‌ ‌which‌ ‌genes‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌X‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌are‌ ‌responsible‌ ‌for‌ ‌most‌ ‌signs‌ ‌and‌ ‌symptoms‌ ‌of‌ ‌Turner‌ ‌\nsyndrome.‌ ‌\n○They‌ ‌have,‌ ‌however,‌ ‌identified‌ ‌one‌ ‌gene‌ ‌called‌ ‌‌SHOX‌‌ ‌that‌ ‌is‌ ‌important‌ ‌for‌ ‌bone‌ ‌development‌ ‌and‌ ‌growth.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Missing‌ ‌one‌ ‌copy‌ ‌of‌ ‌this‌ ‌gene‌ ‌likely‌ ‌causes‌ ‌short‌ ‌stature‌ ‌and‌ ‌skeletal‌ ‌abnormalities‌ ‌in‌ ‌women‌ ‌with‌ ‌Turner‌ ‌syndrome.‌ ‌\n●Girls‌ ‌who‌ ‌have‌ ‌Turner‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌are‌ ‌shorter‌ ‌than‌ ‌average.‌ ‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌often‌ ‌have‌ ‌normal‌ ‌height‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌first‌ ‌three‌ ‌years‌ ‌of‌ ‌life,‌ ‌but‌ ‌then‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌slow‌ ‌growth‌ ‌rate.‌ ‌At‌ ‌puberty‌ ‌they‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌have‌ ‌the‌ ‌usual‌ ‌growth‌ ‌\nspurt.‌ ‌\n●Non-functioning‌ ‌ovaries‌ ‌are‌ ‌another‌ ‌symptom‌ ‌of‌ ‌Turner‌ ‌syndrome.‌ ‌ ‌\n900‌ ‌\n●Normally‌ ‌a‌ ‌girl's‌ ‌ovaries‌ ‌begin‌ ‌to‌ ‌produce‌ ‌sex‌ ‌hormones‌ ‌(estrogen‌ ‌and‌ ‌progesterone)‌ ‌at‌ ‌puberty.‌ ‌This‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌happen‌ ‌in‌ ‌most‌ ‌girls‌ ‌who‌ ‌\nhave‌ ‌Turner‌ ‌syndrome.‌ ‌ ‌\n●They‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌start‌ ‌their‌ ‌periods‌ ‌or‌ ‌develop‌ ‌breasts‌ ‌without‌ ‌hormone‌ ‌treatment‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌age‌ ‌of‌ ‌puberty.‌ ‌\n●Even‌ ‌though‌ ‌many‌ ‌women‌ ‌who‌ ‌have‌ ‌Turner‌ ‌have‌ ‌non-functioning‌ ‌ovaries‌ ‌and‌ ‌are‌ ‌infertile,‌ ‌their‌ ‌vagina‌ ‌and‌ ‌womb‌ ‌are‌ ‌totally‌ ‌normal.‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌early‌ ‌childhood,‌ ‌girls‌ ‌who‌ ‌have‌ ‌Turner‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌may‌ ‌have‌ ‌frequent‌ ‌middle‌ ‌ear‌ ‌infections.‌ ‌Recurrent‌ ‌infections‌ ‌can‌ ‌lead‌ ‌to‌ ‌hearing‌ ‌loss‌ ‌in‌ ‌\nsome‌ ‌cases.‌ ‌\n●Girls‌ ‌with‌ ‌Turner‌ ‌Syndrome‌ ‌are‌ ‌usually‌ ‌of‌ ‌normal‌ ‌intelligence‌ ‌with‌ ‌good‌ ‌verbal‌ ‌skills‌ ‌and‌ ‌reading‌ ‌skills.‌ ‌Some‌ ‌girls,‌ ‌however,‌ ‌have‌ ‌problems‌ ‌\nwith‌ ‌math,‌ ‌memory‌ ‌skills‌ ‌and‌ ‌fine-finger‌ ‌movements.‌ ‌\n ‌\nAdditional‌ ‌symptoms‌ ‌of‌ ‌Turner‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌include‌ ‌the‌ ‌following:‌ ‌\n●An‌ ‌especially‌ ‌wide‌ ‌neck‌ ‌(webbed‌ ‌neck)‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌low‌ ‌or‌ ‌indistinct‌ ‌hairline.‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌broad‌ ‌chest‌ ‌and‌ ‌widely‌ ‌spaced‌ ‌nipples.‌ ‌\n●Arms‌ ‌that‌ ‌turn‌ ‌out‌ ‌slightly‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌elbow.‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌heart‌ ‌murmur,‌ ‌sometimes‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌narrowing‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌aorta‌ ‌(blood‌ ‌vessel‌ ‌exiting‌ ‌the‌ ‌heart).‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌tendency‌ ‌to‌ ‌develop‌ ‌high‌ ‌blood‌ ‌pressure‌ ‌(so‌ ‌this‌ ‌should‌ ‌be‌ ‌checked‌ ‌regularly).‌ ‌\n●Minor‌ ‌eye‌ ‌problems‌ ‌that‌ ‌are‌ ‌corrected‌ ‌by‌ ‌glasses.‌ ‌\n●Scoliosis‌ ‌(deformity‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌spine)‌‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌in‌ ‌10%‌ ‌of‌ ‌adolescent‌ ‌girls‌ ‌who‌ ‌have‌ ‌Turner‌ ‌syndrome.‌ ‌\n○The‌ ‌thyroid‌ ‌gland‌ ‌becomes‌ ‌under-active‌ ‌in‌ ‌about‌ ‌10%‌ ‌of‌ ‌women‌ ‌who‌ ‌have‌ ‌Turner‌ ‌syndrome.‌ ‌Regular‌ ‌blood‌ ‌tests‌ ‌are‌ ‌necessary‌ ‌to‌ ‌\ndetect‌ ‌it‌ ‌early‌ ‌and‌ ‌if‌ ‌necessary‌ ‌treat‌ ‌with‌ ‌thyroid‌ ‌replacement‌ ‌\n●Older‌ ‌or‌ ‌overweight‌ ‌women‌ ‌with‌ ‌Turner‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌are‌ ‌slightly‌ ‌more‌ ‌at‌ ‌risk‌ ‌of‌ ‌developing‌ ‌diabetes.‌ ‌\n●Osteoporosis‌ ‌can‌ ‌develop‌ ‌because‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌lack‌ ‌of‌ ‌estrogen,‌ ‌but‌ ‌this‌ ‌can‌ ‌largely‌ ‌be‌ ‌prevented‌ ‌by‌ ‌taking‌ ‌hormone‌ ‌replacement‌ ‌therapy.‌ ‌\n ‌\nHow‌ ‌is‌ ‌Turner‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌diagnosed?‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌diagnosis‌ ‌of‌ ‌Turner‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌suspected‌ ‌when‌ ‌there‌ ‌are‌ ‌a‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌typical‌ ‌physical‌ ‌features‌ ‌observed‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌webbed‌ ‌neck,‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nbroad‌ ‌chest‌ ‌and‌ ‌widely‌ ‌spaced‌ ‌nipples.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Sometimes‌ ‌diagnosis‌ ‌is‌ ‌made‌ ‌at‌ ‌birth‌ ‌because‌ ‌of‌ ‌heart‌ ‌problems,‌ ‌an‌ ‌unusually‌ ‌wide‌ ‌neck‌ ‌or‌ ‌swelling‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌hands‌ ‌and‌ ‌feet.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌two‌ ‌main‌ ‌clinical‌ ‌features‌ ‌of‌ ‌Turner‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌are‌ ‌short‌ ‌stature‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌lack‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌ovaries.‌ ‌\n●Many‌ ‌girls‌ ‌are‌ ‌diagnosed‌ ‌in‌ ‌early‌ ‌childhood‌ ‌when‌ ‌a‌ ‌slow‌ ‌growth‌ ‌rate‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌features‌ ‌are‌ ‌identified.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Diagnosis‌ ‌sometimes‌ ‌takes‌ ‌place‌ ‌later‌ ‌when‌ ‌puberty‌ ‌does‌ ‌not‌ ‌occur.‌ ‌\n●Turner‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌suspected‌ ‌in‌ ‌pregnancy‌ ‌during‌ ‌an‌ ‌ultrasound‌ ‌test.‌ ‌ ‌\n901‌ ‌\n○This‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌confirmed‌ ‌by‌ ‌prenatal‌ ‌testing‌ ‌-‌ ‌‌chorionic‌ ‌villus‌ ‌sampling‌ ‌or‌ ‌amniocentesis‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n○To‌ ‌obtain‌ ‌cells‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌unborn‌ ‌baby‌ ‌for‌ ‌chromosomal‌ ‌analysis.‌ ‌If‌ ‌a‌ ‌diagnosis‌ ‌is‌ ‌confirmed‌ ‌prenatally,‌ ‌the‌ ‌baby‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌under‌ ‌the‌ ‌\ncare‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌specialist‌ ‌pediatrician‌ ‌immediately‌ ‌after‌ ‌birth.‌ ‌\n●Diagnosis‌ ‌is‌ ‌confirmed‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌blood‌ ‌test,‌ ‌called‌ ‌a‌ ‌karyotype.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\nWhat‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌treatment‌ ‌for‌ ‌Turner‌ ‌syndrome?‌ ‌\n●During‌ ‌childhood‌ ‌and‌ ‌adolescence,‌ ‌girls‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌under‌ ‌the‌ ‌care‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌pediatric‌ ‌endocrinologist,‌ ‌who‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌specialist‌ ‌in‌ ‌childhood‌ ‌conditions‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nhormones‌ ‌and‌ ‌metabolism.‌ ‌\n●Growth‌ ‌hormone‌ ‌injections‌ ‌are‌ ‌beneficial‌ ‌in‌ ‌some‌ ‌individuals‌ ‌with‌ ‌‌Turner‌ ‌syndrome‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Injections‌ ‌often‌ ‌begin‌ ‌in‌ ‌early‌ ‌childhood‌ ‌and‌ ‌may‌ ‌increase‌ ‌final‌ ‌adult‌ ‌height‌ ‌by‌ ‌a‌ ‌few‌ ‌inches.‌ ‌\n●Estrogen‌ ‌replacement‌ ‌therapy‌‌ ‌is‌ ‌usually‌ ‌started‌ ‌at‌ ‌the‌ ‌time‌ ‌of‌ ‌normal‌ ‌puberty,‌ ‌around‌ ‌12‌ ‌years‌ ‌to‌ ‌start‌ ‌breast‌ ‌development.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Estrogen‌ ‌and‌ ‌progesterone‌ ‌are‌ ‌given‌ ‌a‌ ‌little‌ ‌later‌ ‌to‌ ‌begin‌ ‌a‌ ‌monthly‌ ‌'period,'‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌necessary‌ ‌to‌ ‌keep‌ ‌the‌ ‌womb‌ ‌healthy.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Estrogen‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌given‌ ‌to‌ ‌prevent‌ ‌‌osteoporosis‌.‌ ‌\n●Babies‌ ‌born‌ ‌with‌ ‌a‌ ‌heart‌ ‌murmur‌ ‌or‌ ‌narrowing‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌aorta‌ ‌may‌ ‌need‌ ‌surgery‌ ‌to‌ ‌correct‌ ‌the‌ ‌problem.‌ ‌ ‌\n●A‌ ‌heart‌ ‌expert‌ ‌(cardiologist)‌ ‌will‌ ‌assess‌ ‌and‌ ‌follow‌ ‌up‌ ‌any‌ ‌treatment‌ ‌necessary.‌ ‌\n●Girls‌ ‌who‌ ‌have‌ ‌Turner‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌are‌ ‌more‌ ‌likely‌ ‌to‌ ‌get‌ ‌middle‌ ‌ear‌ ‌infections.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Repeated‌ ‌infections‌ ‌may‌ ‌lead‌ ‌to‌ ‌hearing‌ ‌loss‌ ‌and‌ ‌should‌ ‌be‌ ‌evaluated‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌pediatrician.‌ ‌ ‌\n●An‌ ‌ear,‌ ‌nose‌ ‌and‌ ‌throat‌ ‌specialist‌ ‌(ENT)‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌involved‌ ‌in‌ ‌caring‌ ‌for‌ ‌this‌ ‌health‌ ‌issue.‌ ‌\n●High‌ ‌blood‌ ‌pressure‌ ‌is‌ ‌quite‌ ‌common‌ ‌in‌ ‌women‌ ‌who‌ ‌have‌ ‌Turner‌ ‌syndrome.‌ ‌In‌ ‌some‌ ‌cases,‌ ‌the‌ ‌elevated‌ ‌blood‌ ‌pressure‌ ‌is‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌narrowing‌ ‌\nof‌ ‌the‌ ‌aorta‌ ‌or‌ ‌a‌ ‌kidney‌ ‌abnormality.‌ ‌However,‌ ‌most‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌time,‌ ‌no‌ ‌specific‌ ‌cause‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌elevation‌ ‌is‌ ‌identified.‌ ‌ ‌\n902‌ ‌\n●Blood‌ ‌pressure‌ ‌should‌ ‌be‌ ‌checked‌ ‌routinely‌ ‌and,‌ ‌if‌ ‌necessary,‌ ‌treated‌ ‌with‌ ‌medication.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Women‌ ‌who‌ ‌have‌ ‌Turner‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌have‌ ‌a‌ ‌slightly‌ ‌higher‌ ‌risk‌ ‌of‌ ‌having‌ ‌an‌ ‌underactive‌ ‌thyroid‌ ‌or‌ ‌developing‌ ‌diabetes.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌should‌ ‌also‌ ‌be‌ ‌monitored‌ ‌during‌ ‌routine‌ ‌health‌ ‌maintenance‌ ‌visits‌ ‌and‌ ‌treated‌ ‌if‌ ‌necessary.‌ ‌\n●Regular‌ ‌health‌ ‌checks‌ ‌are‌ ‌very‌ ‌important.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Special‌ ‌clinics‌ ‌for‌ ‌the‌ ‌care‌ ‌of‌ ‌girls‌ ‌and‌ ‌women‌ ‌who‌ ‌have‌ ‌Turner‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌are‌ ‌available‌ ‌in‌ ‌some‌ ‌areas,‌ ‌with‌ ‌access‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌variety‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nspecialists.‌ ‌Early‌ ‌preventive‌ ‌care‌ ‌and‌ ‌treatment‌ ‌is‌ ‌very‌ ‌important.‌ ‌\n●Almost‌ ‌all‌ ‌women‌ ‌are‌ ‌infertile,‌ ‌but‌ ‌pregnancy‌ ‌with‌ ‌donor‌ ‌embryos‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌possible.‌ ‌\n●Having‌ ‌appropriate‌ ‌medical‌ ‌treatment‌ ‌and‌ ‌support‌ ‌allows‌ ‌a‌ ‌woman‌ ‌with‌ ‌Turner‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌to‌ ‌lead‌ ‌a‌ ‌normal,‌ ‌healthy‌ ‌and‌ ‌happy‌ ‌life.‌ ‌\n ‌\nIs‌ ‌Turner‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌inherited?‌ ‌\n●Turner‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌usually‌ ‌inherited‌ ‌in‌ ‌families.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Turner‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌when‌ ‌one‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌two‌ ‌X‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌normally‌ ‌found‌ ‌in‌ ‌women‌ ‌is‌ ‌missing‌ ‌or‌ ‌incomplete.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Although‌ ‌the‌ ‌exact‌ ‌cause‌ ‌of‌ ‌Turner‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌known,‌ ‌it‌ ‌appears‌ ‌to‌ ‌occur‌ ‌as‌ ‌a‌ ‌result‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌random‌ ‌error‌ ‌during‌ ‌the‌ ‌formation‌ ‌of‌ ‌either‌ ‌\nthe‌ ‌eggs‌ ‌or‌ ‌sperm.‌ ‌\n●Humans‌ ‌have‌ ‌‌46‌ ‌chromosomes‌,‌ ‌which‌ ‌contain‌ ‌all‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌person's‌ ‌genes‌ ‌and‌ ‌DNA.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Two‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌chromosomes,‌ ‌the‌ ‌sex‌ ‌chromosomes,‌ ‌determine‌ ‌a‌ ‌person's‌ ‌gender.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Both‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌sex‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌in‌ ‌females‌ ‌are‌ ‌called‌ ‌X‌ ‌chromosomes.‌ ‌(This‌ ‌is‌ ‌written‌ ‌as‌ ‌XX)‌ ‌Males‌ ‌have‌ ‌an‌ ‌X‌ ‌and‌ ‌a‌ ‌Y‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌\n(written‌ ‌as‌ ‌XY).‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n903‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nSuper‌ ‌female‌ ‌(XXX)‌ ‌\n ‌\nWhat‌ ‌is‌ ‌Super‌ ‌female‌ ‌(XXX)‌ ‌syndrome?‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Triple‌ ‌X‌ ‌syndrome,‌ ‌also‌ ‌called‌ ‌trisomy‌ ‌X‌ ‌or‌ ‌47,XXX,‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌disorder‌ ‌that‌ ‌affects‌ ‌about‌ ‌1‌ ‌in‌ ‌1,000‌ ‌females.‌ ‌ ‌\n904‌ ‌\n●Females‌ ‌normally‌ ‌have‌ ‌two‌ ‌X‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌in‌ ‌all‌ ‌cells,‌ ‌one‌ ‌X‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌from‌ ‌each‌ ‌parent.‌ ‌In‌ ‌triple‌ ‌X‌ ‌syndrome,‌ ‌a‌ ‌female‌ ‌has‌ ‌three‌ ‌X‌ ‌\nchromosomes.‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Many‌ ‌girls‌ ‌and‌ ‌women‌ ‌with‌ ‌triple‌ ‌X‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌don't‌ ‌experience‌ ‌symptoms‌ ‌or‌ ‌have‌ ‌only‌ ‌mild‌ ‌symptoms.‌ ‌In‌ ‌others,‌ ‌symptoms‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌more‌ ‌\napparent,‌ ‌possibly‌ ‌including‌ ‌developmental‌ ‌delays‌ ‌and‌ ‌learning‌ ‌disabilities.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Seizures‌ ‌and‌ ‌kidney‌ ‌abnormalities‌ ‌occur‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌small‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌girls‌ ‌and‌ ‌women‌ ‌with‌ ‌triple‌ ‌X‌ ‌syndrome.‌ ‌\n●Treatment‌ ‌for‌ ‌triple‌ ‌X‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌depends‌ ‌on‌ ‌which‌ ‌symptoms,‌ ‌if‌ ‌any,‌ ‌are‌ ‌present‌ ‌and‌ ‌their‌ ‌severity.‌ ‌\n ‌\nSymptoms‌ ‌\n●Signs‌ ‌and‌ ‌symptoms‌ ‌can‌ ‌vary‌ ‌greatly‌ ‌among‌ ‌girls‌ ‌and‌ ‌women‌ ‌with‌ ‌triple‌ ‌X‌ ‌syndrome.‌ ‌Many‌ ‌experience‌ ‌no‌ ‌noticeable‌ ‌effects‌ ‌or‌ ‌have‌ ‌only‌ ‌\nmild‌ ‌symptoms.‌ ‌\n●Being‌ ‌taller‌ ‌than‌ ‌average‌ ‌height‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌typical‌ ‌physical‌ ‌feature.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Most‌ ‌females‌ ‌with‌ ‌triple‌ ‌X‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌experience‌ ‌normal‌ ‌sexual‌ ‌development‌ ‌and‌ ‌have‌ ‌the‌ ‌ability‌ ‌to‌ ‌become‌ ‌pregnant.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Some‌ ‌girls‌ ‌and‌ ‌women‌ ‌with‌ ‌triple‌ ‌X‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌have‌ ‌intelligence‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌normal‌ ‌range,‌ ‌but‌ ‌possibly‌ ‌slightly‌ ‌lower‌ ‌when‌ ‌compared‌ ‌with‌ ‌\nsiblings.‌ ‌Others‌ ‌may‌ ‌have‌ ‌intellectual‌ ‌disabilities‌ ‌and‌ ‌sometimes‌ ‌may‌ ‌have‌ ‌behavioral‌ ‌problems.‌ ‌\n●Occasionally‌ ‌significant‌ ‌symptoms‌ ‌may‌ ‌occur.‌ ‌If‌ ‌signs‌ ‌and‌ ‌symptoms‌ ‌are‌ ‌present,‌ ‌they‌ ‌are‌ ‌often‌ ‌variable.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Signs‌ ‌and‌ ‌symptoms‌ ‌in‌ ‌girls‌ ‌and‌ ‌women‌ ‌with‌ ‌triple‌ ‌X‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌may‌ ‌include‌ ‌an‌ ‌increased‌ ‌risk‌ ‌of:‌ ‌\n905‌ ‌\n○Delayed‌ ‌development‌ ‌of‌ ‌speech‌ ‌and‌ ‌language‌ ‌skills,‌ ‌as‌ ‌well‌ ‌as‌ ‌motor‌ ‌skills,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌sitting‌ ‌up‌ ‌and‌ ‌walking‌ ‌\n○Learning‌ ‌disabilities,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌difficulty‌ ‌with‌ ‌reading‌ ‌(dyslexia),‌ ‌understanding‌ ‌or‌ ‌math‌ ‌\n○Behavioral‌ ‌problems,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌attention-deficit/hyperactivity‌ ‌disorder‌ ‌(ADHD)‌ ‌or‌ ‌symptoms‌ ‌of‌ ‌autism‌ ‌spectrum‌ ‌disorder‌ ‌\n○Psychological‌ ‌problems,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌anxiety‌ ‌and‌ ‌depression‌ ‌\n○Problems‌ ‌with‌ ‌fine‌ ‌and‌ ‌gross‌ ‌motor‌ ‌skills,‌ ‌memory,‌ ‌judgment‌ ‌and‌ ‌information‌ ‌processing‌ ‌\n ‌\nSometimes‌ ‌triple‌ ‌X‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌associated‌ ‌with‌ ‌these‌ ‌signs‌ ‌and‌ ‌symptoms:‌ ‌\n●Vertical‌ ‌folds‌ ‌of‌ ‌skin‌ ‌that‌ ‌cover‌ ‌the‌ ‌inner‌ ‌corners‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌eyes‌ ‌(epicanthal‌ ‌folds)‌ ‌\n●Widely‌ ‌spaced‌ ‌eyes‌ ‌\n●Abnormally‌ ‌curved‌ ‌pinky‌ ‌fingers‌ ‌\n●Flat‌ ‌feet‌ ‌\n●Abnormally‌ ‌shaped‌ ‌breastbone‌ ‌\n●Weak‌ ‌muscle‌ ‌tone‌ ‌(hypotonia)‌ ‌\n●Seizures‌ ‌\n●Kidney‌ ‌abnormalities‌ ‌\n●Premature‌ ‌ovarian‌ ‌failure‌ ‌or‌ ‌ovary‌ ‌abnormalities‌ ‌\n●Developmental‌ ‌delays‌ ‌\n ‌\nCauses‌ ‌\n●Although‌ ‌triple‌ ‌X‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌is‌ ‌genetic,‌ ‌it's‌ ‌usually‌ ‌not‌ ‌inherited‌ ‌—‌ ‌it's‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌a‌ ‌random‌ ‌genetic‌ ‌error.‌ ‌\n●Normally,‌ ‌people‌ ‌have‌ ‌46‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌in‌ ‌each‌ ‌cell,‌ ‌organized‌ ‌into‌ ‌23‌ ‌pairs,‌ ‌including‌ ‌two‌ ‌sex‌ ‌chromosomes.‌ ‌ ‌\n●One‌ ‌set‌ ‌of‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌is‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌mother‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌set‌ ‌is‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌father.‌ ‌These‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌contain‌ ‌genes,‌ ‌which‌ ‌carry‌ ‌\ninstructions‌ ‌that‌ ‌determine‌ ‌everything‌ ‌from‌ ‌height‌ ‌to‌ ‌eye‌ ‌color.‌ ‌\n906‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌pair‌ ‌of‌ ‌sex‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌—‌ ‌either‌ ‌XX‌ ‌or‌ ‌XY‌ ‌—‌ ‌determines‌ ‌a‌ ‌child's‌ ‌sex.‌ ‌A‌ ‌mother‌ ‌can‌ ‌give‌ ‌the‌ ‌child‌ ‌only‌ ‌an‌ ‌X‌ ‌chromosome,‌ ‌but‌ ‌a‌ ‌\nfather‌ ‌can‌ ‌pass‌ ‌on‌ ‌an‌ ‌X‌ ‌or‌ ‌a‌ ‌Y‌ ‌chromosome:‌ ‌\n○If‌ ‌the‌ ‌child‌ ‌receives‌ ‌an‌ ‌X‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌father,‌ ‌the‌ ‌XX‌ ‌pair‌ ‌makes‌ ‌the‌ ‌child‌ ‌genetically‌ ‌a‌ ‌female.‌ ‌\n○If‌ ‌the‌ ‌child‌ ‌receives‌ ‌a‌ ‌Y‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌father,‌ ‌the‌ ‌XY‌ ‌pair‌ ‌means‌ ‌the‌ ‌child‌ ‌is‌ ‌genetically‌ ‌a‌ ‌male.‌ ‌\n ‌\nIntersex‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Intersex‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌conditions‌ ‌where‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌discrepancy‌ ‌between‌ ‌the‌ ‌external‌ ‌genitals‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌internal‌ ‌genitals‌ ‌(the‌ ‌testes‌ ‌and‌ ‌\novaries).‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌older‌ ‌term‌ ‌for‌ ‌this‌ ‌condition‌ ‌is‌ ‌‌hermaphroditism‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Although‌ ‌the‌ ‌older‌ ‌terms‌ ‌are‌ ‌still‌ ‌included‌ ‌in‌ ‌this‌ ‌article‌ ‌for‌ ‌reference,‌ ‌they‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌replaced‌ ‌by‌ ‌most‌ ‌experts,‌ ‌patients‌ ‌and‌ ‌families.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Increasingly,‌ ‌this‌ ‌group‌ ‌of‌ ‌conditions‌ ‌is‌ ‌being‌ ‌called‌ ‌disorders‌ ‌of‌ ‌sex‌ ‌development‌ ‌(DSDs).‌ ‌\n ‌\nCauses‌ ‌\n907‌ ‌\nIntersex‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌divided‌ ‌into‌ ‌4‌ ‌categories:‌ ‌\n●46,‌ ‌XX‌ ‌intersex‌ ‌\n●46,‌ ‌XY‌ ‌intersex‌ ‌\n●True‌ ‌gonadal‌ ‌intersex‌ ‌\n●Complex‌ ‌or‌ ‌undetermined‌ ‌intersex‌ ‌\nEach‌ ‌one‌ ‌is‌ ‌discussed‌ ‌in‌ ‌more‌ ‌detail‌ ‌below.‌ ‌\n ‌\nNote:‌‌ ‌In‌ ‌many‌ ‌children,‌ ‌the‌ ‌cause‌ ‌of‌ ‌intersex‌ ‌may‌ ‌remain‌ ‌undetermined,‌ ‌even‌ ‌with‌ ‌modern‌ ‌diagnostic‌ ‌techniques.‌ ‌\n ‌\n46,‌ ‌XX‌ ‌INTERSEX‌ ‌\n ‌\n●The‌ ‌person‌ ‌has‌ ‌the‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌woman,‌ ‌the‌ ‌ovaries‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌woman,‌ ‌but‌ ‌external‌ ‌(outside)‌ ‌genitals‌ ‌that‌ ‌appear‌ ‌male.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌most‌ ‌often‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌result‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌female‌ ‌fetus‌ ‌having‌ ‌been‌ ‌exposed‌ ‌to‌ ‌excess‌ ‌male‌ ‌hormones‌ ‌before‌ ‌birth.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌labia‌ ‌(\"lips\"‌ ‌or‌ ‌folds‌ ‌of‌ ‌skin‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌external‌ ‌female‌ ‌genitals)‌ ‌fuse,‌ ‌and‌ ‌the‌ ‌clitoris‌ ‌enlarges‌ ‌to‌ ‌appear‌ ‌like‌ ‌a‌ ‌penis.‌ ‌In‌ ‌most‌ ‌cases,‌ ‌this‌ ‌\nperson‌ ‌has‌ ‌a‌ ‌normal‌ ‌uterus‌ ‌and‌ ‌fallopian‌ ‌tubes.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌condition‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌called‌ ‌46,‌ ‌XX‌ ‌with‌ ‌virilization.‌ ‌It‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌called‌ ‌female‌ ‌‌pseudohermaphroditism‌.‌ ‌ ‌\n●There‌ ‌are‌ ‌several‌ ‌possible‌ ‌causes:‌ ‌\n○Congenital‌ ‌adrenal‌‌ ‌hyperplasia‌‌ ‌(the‌ ‌most‌ ‌common‌ ‌cause).‌ ‌\n○Male‌ ‌hormones‌ ‌(such‌ ‌as‌ ‌testosterone)‌ ‌taken‌ ‌or‌ ‌encountered‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌mother‌ ‌during‌ ‌pregnancy.‌ ‌\n○Male‌ ‌hormone-producing‌ ‌tumors‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌mother:‌ ‌‌These‌ ‌are‌ ‌most‌ ‌often‌ ‌ovarian‌ ‌tumors.‌ ‌Mothers‌ ‌who‌ ‌have‌ ‌children‌ ‌with‌ ‌46,‌ ‌XX‌ ‌\nintersex‌ ‌should‌ ‌be‌ ‌checked‌ ‌unless‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌another‌ ‌clear‌ ‌cause.‌ ‌\n○Aromatase‌ ‌deficiency:‌‌ ‌This‌ ‌one‌ ‌may‌ ‌not‌ ‌be‌ ‌noticeable‌ ‌until‌ ‌puberty.‌ ‌Aromatase‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌enzyme‌ ‌that‌ ‌normally‌ ‌converts‌ ‌male‌ ‌\nhormones‌ ‌to‌ ‌female‌ ‌hormones.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Too‌ ‌much‌ ‌aromatase‌ ‌activity‌ ‌can‌ ‌lead‌ ‌to‌ ‌excess‌ ‌estrogen‌ ‌(female‌ ‌hormone);‌ ‌too‌ ‌little‌ ‌to‌ ‌46,‌ ‌XX‌ ‌intersex.‌ ‌ ‌\n○At‌ ‌puberty,‌ ‌these‌ ‌XX‌ ‌children,‌ ‌who‌ ‌had‌ ‌been‌ ‌raised‌ ‌as‌ ‌girls,‌ ‌may‌ ‌begin‌ ‌to‌ ‌take‌ ‌on‌ ‌male‌ ‌characteristics.‌ ‌\n ‌\n46,‌ ‌XY‌ ‌INTERSEX‌ ‌\n ‌\n●The‌ ‌person‌ ‌has‌ ‌the‌ ‌chromosomes‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌man,‌ ‌but‌ ‌the‌ ‌external‌ ‌genitals‌ ‌are‌ ‌incompletely‌ ‌formed,‌ ‌ambiguous,‌ ‌or‌ ‌clearly‌ ‌female.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Internally,‌ ‌testes‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌normal,‌ ‌malformed,‌ ‌or‌ ‌absent.‌ ‌This‌ ‌condition‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌called‌ ‌46,‌ ‌XY‌ ‌with‌ ‌‌undervirilization.‌ ‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌called‌ ‌male‌ ‌‌pseudohermaphroditism‌.‌ ‌Formation‌ ‌of‌ ‌normal‌ ‌male‌ ‌external‌ ‌genitals‌ ‌depends‌ ‌on‌ ‌the‌ ‌appropriate‌ ‌balance‌ ‌\nbetween‌ ‌male‌ ‌and‌ ‌female‌ ‌hormones.‌ ‌ ‌\n●Therefore,‌ ‌it‌ ‌requires‌ ‌the‌ ‌adequate‌ ‌production‌ ‌and‌ ‌function‌ ‌of‌ ‌male‌ ‌hormones.‌ ‌46,‌ ‌XY‌ ‌intersex‌ ‌has‌ ‌many‌ ‌possible‌ ‌causes:‌ ‌\n○Problems‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌testes:‌ ‌ ‌\n■The‌ ‌testes‌ ‌normally‌ ‌produce‌ ‌male‌ ‌hormones.‌ ‌ ‌\n■If‌ ‌the‌ ‌testes‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌form‌ ‌properly,‌ ‌it‌ ‌will‌ ‌lead‌ ‌to‌ ‌undervirilization.‌ ‌ ‌\n908‌ ‌\n■There‌ ‌are‌ ‌a‌ ‌number‌ ‌of‌ ‌possible‌ ‌causes‌ ‌for‌ ‌this,‌ ‌including‌ ‌XY‌ ‌pure‌ ‌gonadal‌ ‌dysgenesis.‌ ‌\n○Problems‌ ‌with‌ ‌testosterone‌ ‌formation:‌ ‌ ‌\n■Testosterone‌ ‌is‌ ‌formed‌ ‌through‌ ‌a‌ ‌series‌ ‌of‌ ‌steps.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Each‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌steps‌ ‌requires‌ ‌a‌ ‌different‌ ‌enzyme.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Deficiencies‌ ‌in‌ ‌any‌ ‌of‌ ‌these‌ ‌enzymes‌ ‌can‌ ‌result‌ ‌in‌ ‌inadequate‌ ‌testosterone‌ ‌and‌ ‌produce‌ ‌a‌ ‌different‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌of‌ ‌46,‌ ‌XY‌ ‌\nintersex.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Different‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌congenital‌ ‌adrenal‌ ‌hyperplasia‌ ‌can‌ ‌fall‌ ‌in‌ ‌this‌ ‌category.‌ ‌\n○Problems‌ ‌with‌ ‌using‌ ‌testosterone:‌ ‌ ‌\n■Some‌ ‌people‌ ‌have‌ ‌normal‌ ‌testes‌ ‌and‌ ‌make‌ ‌adequate‌ ‌amounts‌ ‌of‌ ‌testosterone,‌ ‌but‌ ‌still‌ ‌have‌ ‌46,‌ ‌XY‌ ‌intersex‌ ‌due‌ ‌to‌ ‌\nconditions‌ ‌such‌ ‌as‌ ‌5-alpha-reductase‌ ‌deficiency‌ ‌or‌ ‌androgen‌ ‌insensitivity‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌(AIS).‌ ‌\n○People‌ ‌with‌ ‌5-alpha-reductase‌ ‌deficiency‌ ‌lack‌ ‌the‌ ‌enzyme‌ ‌needed‌ ‌to‌ ‌convert‌ ‌testosterone‌ ‌to‌ ‌dihydrotestosterone‌ ‌(DHT).‌ ‌ ‌\n○There‌ ‌are‌ ‌at‌ ‌least‌ ‌5‌ ‌different‌ ‌types‌ ‌of‌ ‌5-alpha-reductase‌ ‌deficiency.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Some‌ ‌of‌ ‌the‌ ‌babies‌ ‌have‌ ‌normal‌ ‌male‌ ‌genitalia,‌ ‌some‌ ‌have‌ ‌normal‌ ‌female‌ ‌genitalia,‌ ‌and‌ ‌many‌ ‌have‌ ‌something‌ ‌in‌ ‌between.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Most‌ ‌change‌ ‌to‌ ‌external‌ ‌male‌ ‌genitalia‌ ‌around‌ ‌the‌ ‌time‌ ‌of‌ ‌puberty.‌ ‌\n○AIS‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌most‌ ‌common‌ ‌cause‌ ‌of‌ ‌46,‌ ‌XY‌ ‌intersex.‌ ‌ ‌\n○It‌ ‌has‌ ‌also‌ ‌been‌ ‌called‌ ‌testicular‌ ‌feminization.‌ ‌ ‌\n○Here,‌ ‌the‌ ‌hormones‌ ‌are‌ ‌all‌ ‌normal,‌ ‌but‌ ‌the‌ ‌receptors‌ ‌to‌ ‌male‌ ‌hormones‌ ‌don't‌ ‌function‌ ‌properly.‌ ‌ ‌\n○There‌ ‌are‌ ‌over‌ ‌150‌ ‌different‌ ‌defects‌ ‌that‌ ‌have‌ ‌been‌ ‌identified‌ ‌so‌ ‌far,‌ ‌and‌ ‌each‌ ‌causes‌ ‌a‌ ‌different‌ ‌type‌ ‌of‌ ‌AIS.‌ ‌\n ‌\nTrue‌ ‌Gonadal‌ ‌Intersex‌ ‌\n ‌\n●The‌ ‌person‌ ‌must‌ ‌have‌ ‌both‌ ‌ovarian‌ ‌and‌ ‌testicular‌ ‌tissue.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌in‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌gonad‌ ‌(an‌ ‌ovotestis),‌ ‌or‌ ‌the‌ ‌person‌ ‌might‌ ‌have‌ ‌1‌ ‌ovary‌ ‌and‌ ‌1‌ ‌testis.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌person‌ ‌may‌ ‌have‌ ‌XX‌ ‌chromosomes,‌ ‌XY‌ ‌chromosomes,‌ ‌or‌ ‌both.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌external‌ ‌genitals‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌ambiguous‌ ‌or‌ ‌may‌ ‌appear‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌female‌ ‌or‌ ‌male.‌ ‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌condition‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌called‌ ‌true‌ ‌hermaphroditism.‌ ‌ ‌\n●In‌ ‌most‌ ‌people‌ ‌with‌ ‌true‌ ‌gonadal‌ ‌intersex,‌ ‌the‌ ‌underlying‌ ‌cause‌ ‌is‌ ‌unknown,‌ ‌although‌ ‌in‌ ‌some‌ ‌animal‌ ‌studies‌ ‌it‌ ‌has‌ ‌been‌ ‌linked‌ ‌to‌ ‌exposure‌ ‌\nto‌ ‌common‌ ‌agricultural‌ ‌pesticides.‌ ‌\n ‌\nComplex‌ ‌or‌ ‌undetermined‌ ‌intersex‌ ‌\n ‌\n●Many‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌configurations‌ ‌other‌ ‌than‌ ‌simple‌ ‌46,‌ ‌XX‌ ‌or‌ ‌46,‌ ‌XY‌ ‌can‌ ‌result‌ ‌in‌ ‌disorders‌ ‌of‌ ‌sex‌ ‌development.‌ ‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌include‌ ‌45,‌ ‌XO‌ ‌(only‌ ‌one‌ ‌X‌ ‌chromosome),‌ ‌and‌ ‌47,‌ ‌XXY,‌ ‌47,‌ ‌XXX‌ ‌-‌ ‌both‌ ‌cases‌ ‌have‌ ‌an‌ ‌extra‌ ‌sex‌ ‌chromosome,‌ ‌either‌ ‌an‌ ‌X‌ ‌or‌ ‌a‌ ‌Y.‌ ‌ ‌\n●These‌ ‌disorders‌ ‌do‌ ‌not‌ ‌result‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌condition‌ ‌where‌ ‌there‌ ‌is‌ ‌discrepancy‌ ‌between‌ ‌internal‌ ‌and‌ ‌external‌ ‌genitalia.‌ ‌ ‌\n●However,‌ ‌there‌ ‌may‌ ‌be‌ ‌problems‌ ‌with‌ ‌sex‌ ‌hormone‌ ‌levels,‌ ‌overall‌ ‌sexual‌ ‌development,‌ ‌and‌ ‌altered‌ ‌numbers‌ ‌of‌ ‌sex‌ ‌chromosomes.‌ ‌\n ‌\n909‌ ‌\nSyndromic‌ ‌disorder‌ ‌\n ‌\n●In‌ ‌general,‌ ‌the‌ ‌definition‌ ‌of‌ ‌a‌ ‌“syndromic‌ ‌disorder”‌ ‌is‌ ‌the‌ ‌presence‌ ‌of‌ ‌at‌ ‌least‌ ‌1‌ ‌major‌ ‌and‌ ‌2‌ ‌minor‌ ‌anomalies.‌ ‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nMosaicism‌ ‌\n●Mosaicism‌‌ ‌describes‌ ‌the‌ ‌presence‌ ‌of‌ ‌two‌ ‌populations‌ ‌of‌ ‌cells‌ ‌with‌ ‌distinct‌ ‌genotypes‌ ‌within‌ ‌a‌ ‌single‌ ‌organism‌ ‌\n●It‌ ‌is‌ ‌caused‌ ‌when‌ ‌either‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌or‌ ‌division‌ ‌error‌ ‌creates‌ ‌two‌ ‌distinct‌ ‌cell‌ ‌types‌ ‌which‌ ‌divide‌ ‌into‌ ‌separate‌ ‌cell‌ ‌lines‌ ‌\n●Mosaicism‌ ‌‌is‌ ‌more‌ ‌pronounced‌ ‌when‌ ‌errors‌ ‌occur‌ ‌in‌ ‌early‌ ‌embryo‌ ‌development‌ ‌and‌ ‌thus‌ ‌affects‌ ‌a‌ ‌greater‌ ‌proportion‌ ‌of‌ ‌cells‌ ‌\n ‌\n910‌ ‌\n●Mosaicism‌ ‌is‌ ‌caused‌ ‌when‌ ‌a‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌arises‌ ‌early‌ ‌in‌ ‌development.‌ ‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌resulting‌ ‌individual‌ ‌will‌ ‌be‌ ‌a‌ ‌mixture‌ ‌of‌ ‌cells,‌ ‌some‌ ‌with‌ ‌the‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌and‌ ‌some‌ ‌without‌ ‌the‌ ‌mutation.‌ ‌ ‌\n●How‌ ‌early‌ ‌in‌ ‌development‌ ‌the‌ ‌mutation‌ ‌occurs‌ ‌will‌ ‌determine‌ ‌what‌ ‌tissue(s)‌ ‌and‌ ‌what‌ ‌percentage‌ ‌of‌ ‌cells‌ ‌will‌ ‌have‌ ‌the‌ ‌mutation.‌ ‌\n●Mosaicism‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌germline‌ ‌(affecting‌ ‌only‌ ‌egg‌ ‌or‌ ‌sperm‌ ‌cells),‌ ‌somatic‌ ‌(affecting‌ ‌cells‌ ‌other‌ ‌than‌ ‌egg‌ ‌or‌ ‌sperm‌ ‌cells),‌ ‌or‌ ‌a‌ ‌combination‌ ‌of‌ ‌\nboth.‌ ‌\n ‌\nMosaicism‌ ‌can‌ ‌be‌ ‌linked‌ ‌to‌ ‌many‌ ‌different‌ ‌kinds‌ ‌of‌ ‌disorders,‌ ‌such‌ ‌as:‌ ‌\n ‌\n○Ichthyosis‌ ‌with‌ ‌confetti.‌ ‌ ‌\n■This‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌disorder‌ ‌that‌ ‌causes‌ ‌red,‌ ‌scaly‌ ‌skin‌ ‌all‌ ‌over‌ ‌the‌ ‌body.‌ ‌\n○Klippel-Trenaunay‌ ‌syndrome.‌ ‌ ‌\n■This‌ ‌disorder‌ ‌causes‌ ‌a‌ ‌red‌ ‌birthmark‌ ‌called‌ ‌a‌ ‌port-wine‌ ‌stain.‌ ‌It‌ ‌also‌ ‌causes‌ ‌excess‌ ‌growth‌ ‌of‌ ‌soft‌ ‌tissues‌ ‌and‌ ‌bones,‌ ‌and‌ ‌\nabnormal‌ ‌veins.‌ ‌\n○Mosaic‌ ‌Down‌ ‌syndrome.‌ ‌ ‌\n■Down‌ ‌syndrome‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌condition‌ ‌that‌ ‌causes‌ ‌intellectual‌ ‌disabilities‌ ‌and‌ ‌delays,‌ ‌weak‌ ‌muscles,‌ ‌and‌ ‌flat‌ ‌facial‌ ‌features.‌ ‌It‌ ‌can‌ ‌\nalso‌ ‌cause‌ ‌a‌ ‌heart‌ ‌defect,‌ ‌digestive‌ ‌problems,‌ ‌thyroid‌ ‌problems,‌ ‌and‌ ‌other‌ ‌health‌ ‌issues.‌ ‌\n○Pallister-Killian‌ ‌syndrome.‌ ‌ ‌\n■This‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌developmental‌ ‌disorder‌ ‌that‌ ‌causes‌ ‌weak‌ ‌muscles,‌ ‌intellectual‌ ‌disability,‌ ‌thin‌ ‌hair,‌ ‌patches‌ ‌of‌ ‌abnormal‌ ‌skin‌ ‌color,‌ ‌\nand‌ ‌other‌ ‌birth‌ ‌defects.‌ ‌\n○Mosaic‌ ‌ring‌ ‌chromosome‌ ‌14‌ ‌syndrome.‌ ‌ ‌\n■This‌ ‌condition‌ ‌causes‌ ‌seizures,‌ ‌intellectual‌ ‌disability,‌ ‌and‌ ‌delayed‌ ‌speech‌ ‌and‌ ‌motor‌ ‌development.‌ ‌\n○SOX2‌ ‌anophthalmia‌ ‌syndrome.‌ ‌ ‌\n■This‌ ‌is‌ ‌a‌ ‌rare‌ ‌disorder‌ ‌that‌ ‌can‌ ‌cause‌ ‌a‌ ‌child‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌born‌ ‌without‌ ‌eyeballs.‌ ‌It‌ ‌can‌ ‌also‌ ‌cause‌ ‌seizures,‌ ‌brain‌ ‌problems,‌ ‌and‌ ‌\ndelayed‌ ‌growth.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nChimera‌ ‌\n911‌ ‌\n●Chimera,‌ ‌in‌ ‌genetics,‌ ‌is‌ ‌an‌ ‌organism‌ ‌or‌ ‌tissue‌ ‌that‌ ‌contains‌ ‌at‌ ‌least‌ ‌two‌ ‌different‌ ‌sets‌ ‌of‌ ‌DNA,‌ ‌most‌ ‌often‌ ‌originating‌ ‌from‌ ‌the‌ ‌fusion‌ ‌of‌ ‌as‌ ‌\nmany‌ ‌different‌ ‌zygotes‌ ‌(fertilized‌ ‌eggs).‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\nOne‌ ‌way‌ ‌that‌ ‌chimeras‌ ‌can‌ ‌happen‌ ‌naturally‌ ‌in‌ ‌humans‌ ‌is‌ ‌that‌ ‌a‌ ‌fetus‌ ‌can‌ ‌absorb‌ ‌its‌ ‌twin.‌ ‌\n●This‌ ‌can‌ ‌occur‌ ‌with‌ ‌fraternal‌ ‌twins,‌ ‌if‌ ‌one‌ ‌embryo‌ ‌dies‌ ‌very‌ ‌early‌ ‌in‌ ‌pregnancy,‌ ‌and‌ ‌some‌ ‌of‌ ‌its‌ ‌cells‌ ‌are‌ ‌\"absorbed\"‌ ‌by‌ ‌the‌ ‌other‌ ‌twin.‌ ‌\n●The‌ ‌remaining‌ ‌fetus‌ ‌will‌ ‌have‌ ‌two‌ ‌sets‌ ‌of‌ ‌cells,‌ ‌its‌ ‌own‌ ‌original‌ ‌set,‌ ‌plus‌ ‌the‌ ‌one‌ ‌from‌ ‌its‌ ‌twin.‌ ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n ‌\n912‌ ‌\nKindly refer to both the Videos and Lecture Notes for exhaustive coverage and making notes. Ethnocentrism vis-a-vis cultural Relativism\nDefinition by various Thinkers:\nCulture is social, not individual heritage of man:\nCulture is idealistic:\nCulture is the total social heritage:\nCulture fulfills some needs:\nCulture is an integrated system:\nLanguage is the chief vehicle of culture:\nCulture evolves into more complex forms\nContra Cultures:\nCivilization\nCulture vs Civilization\n(ii) Civilization is always advancing, but not culture:\n(iii) Civilization is passed on without effort, but not culture:\n(v) Civilization is external and mechanical while culture is internal and organic:\n(vi) Civilization is borrowed without change or loss, but not culture:\nCulture and civilization are interdependent:\nChina:1600 BC\nAmerica: 1200 BC\nEthnocentrism\nThree Levels of ethnocentrism: Positive, Negative and Extreme Negative\nEthnocentrism Stereotype and Prejudice\nConsumer Ethnocentrism\nCultural Relativism\nEthnocentrism vs Cultural Relativism\nDebate\n2.2 The Nature of Society : Concept of Society;
